column2: The first of five performances of the Hollywood Ice Revue, featuring Sonja Henie, figure skating and motion picture star, will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Deposits and total assets of the Bank of Nova Scotia, at the end of 1937, amounted to $242,417,184 and $299,479,702, respectively, the highest year-end figures in the history of the bank, according to the annual statement which is being published today. The rise of deposits in the year was almost $4,000,000 and the gain of assets was $2,520,435.
Chanting lamas In snow-covered lamaseries in the mountain fastnesses of Tibet are conducting mystical rituals to determine the absolute ruler of the mysterious "Forbidden Land."

Alfred Cooper Watson, last surviving charter member of the Germantown Y. M. C. A., died today at the home of his son, Roy, in Eureka. His age was 86. He was a founder of the Workingmen's Club, later merged with the Y. M. C. A. For twentyfive years he was a partner in Watson Robinson Company, a Germantown millwork firm.

Plans for construction of the first Hall of Marine Transportation in exposition history, designed in a striking nautical pattern and featuring a large basin on which fullsized yachts, cruisers and speedboats will ply, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair of 1939.

ARNSTEIN--Hulda, widow of Max, devoted father of Anna Miller, Rose Schwartzman, Harry and Louis. Services Central Funeral Chapel, 109 West 87th St., Tuesday, Jan. 26, at 10 A. M. BASS-Jacob, devoted husband of Minnie L., beloved father of Louise Bass Jacobson and William L. Bass, and brother of Ephraim Bass, Fannie Negbaur and the late Jennie Jackson. Funeral strictly private, at convenience of family.

Homicide charges were lodged against seven Negroes last night and summonses for disorderly conduct were served on five white persons following a mass altercation early yesterday morning during which one man was stabbed to death and seven others were injured at 105th Avenue and 171st Place, Jamaica.

The gospel of the grace of God is particularly suited to an age like our own, which has outlived the optimism of. a generation ago and is confronted by problems too great for our own solution, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday.

Harry Mehre, head coach at the University of Georgia for ten years, was named head coach and athletic director at the University of Mississippi today. Professor T. A. Bickerstaff, chairman of the athletic committee at Ole Miss, announced that Mehre had been given a three-year contract which becomes effective Feb. 1.

Inspection of the so-called omnibus and county bills sent to the Legislature by the La Guardia Administration reveals that the bills would re-establish a very large number of the county government jobs eliminated from the 1938 budget by the Mayor.
Fraeulein Helga Goedl of Innsbruck won the combination downhill slalom event in the Tyrolean ski championships today as the United States women's team had the first competition of its European tour.

A profit of $2,268,596, after provision for contingencies and reserves, was shown in the annual statement of the Bank of Canada for the calendar year 1937. Profit in 1936 was $2,008,124. Dividends at the rate of 41/2 per cent on the bank's $10,100,000 capital stock took $454,500, leaving a balance of $1,814,096.

Cotton prices moved within a narrow range last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net declines for the week of 8 to 10 points.

Four divisions of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers will hold meetings today in conjunction with the current exposition of heating and ventilating equipment in the Grand Central Palace.

A. Van Zo Post of 66 Bedford Street, who was a member of the United States Olympic fencing teams of 1908 and 1912, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness of peritonitis at the age of 72.

Both on the Stock Exchange and in general trade, last week was a period of slack water. That is not unusual for January; the month is apt in any year to produce an interval of pause between year-end "holiday activity" and the beginning of preparation for Spring trade.

The week's stock market here was dull and, except on Thursday, prices declined. Traders in the heavy industrials withheld operations pending the appearance of Krupps annual report, and, although it was regarded as satisfactory, they proceeded to sell steels on its publication.

While the works of man are praised on earth the miracles of Jesus Christ are ignored and doubted, the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York and pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name of Jesus, said in a sermon yesterday morning in his church, at Amsterdam Avenue and Ninetysixth Street.

Mrs. Florence Candler Ashford, daughter of the late Governor and Mrs. Allen D. Candler, died today at her home. Her age was 71. Mrs. Ashford was widely known in social circles in Gainesville and Atlanta. Her father was Governor of Georgia for four years at the turn df the century.

A slight improvement in steel demand, reflected by buying in small lots to fill gaps in stocks rather than for protecting the future, appears insufficient to indicate a marked change in the position of consumers, says the magazine Steel.

THERE are many differences between baseball and boxing and there is some difference in architecture between Connie Mack and Charley Harvey. But Charley Harvey comes close to being the Connie Mack of the fight game. They are pretty much of an age and deans In their respective fields.

Considerable Congressional sentiment in favor of increasing appropriations for the army will greet President Roosevelt's message this week on national defense. The message, its contents still a complete mystery, is believed to deal largely or completely with the navy, and House friends of the army have already expressed considerable concern and some resentment over what they feel is a relative neglect of the land forces.

Two motions, one to set aside the verdict and the other asking for a new trial, were being prepared today by defense attorneys who represented sixteen major oil companies and thirty prominent oil men convicted yesterday in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case.

The drive for funds of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, in which the main event will be the annual ball, to be held Saturday, in honor of President Roosevelt's birthday, will go on the air this week with appeals by radio stars to send a dime to the White House.

In an express train en route from Brussels to Cologne the other day, having occasion to send a telegram to THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris office, the writer handed the message to the sleeping-car conductor to dispatch at Verviers, on the Belgian side of the frontier.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago, secondranking player in the United States, today defeated Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles, rated sixth, in the final of the Dixie tennis tournament. 6-3. 6-0. 7-5.

Long Island Sound was bell clear today and twenty-three sailing dinghies were out in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Frank Campbell, in his Class B craft Felix, and Bill Dodge, in his Class X boat Moth Ball, were the victors.
By a margin of six-hundredths of a second, Ed Wells of the Dartmouth Outing Club won the New Hampshire slalom championship today, defeating his team-mate Ted Hunter.

Mrs. Mary Mitten, Pennsylvania's first woman Sheriff, died yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Paul Banks, in Lansdowne. Her age was 65. Until she became ill several weeks ago, Mrs. Mitten had served as probation officer of Bradford County Her husband, Fred Mitten, was elected Sheriff of that county in 1924, but died after about a year in office.

Three men who gained admission by pretending that they had come to claim an automobile, knocked open a safe in the office of the Glidden Buick Corporation service station at 552 West Fiftysixth Street between 7:15 and 7;45 o'clock last night. They escaped

Stanley E. Young Jr., in 410 E 57th St. from Tishman Realty and Construction Co; Mrs. Bertha Stockwell, broker. Mrs. M. Elliot Blanc, in 114 E 84th St. through Byrne Bowman; Elsie Southwick Clarke, in 145 E 52d St, from Carpenter Realty Corp; William H. Hamilton, in 10?? E 66th St, through Brett Wyckoff; Chace Chace, brokers.

In one of the most furiously paced matches seen on the Haddon Hall courts, Hunter Lott Jr. of Philadelphia came from behind to quell the tempest of an apparently invincible attack and carry off the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship today.

The decline in wholesale prices, which had continued almost uninterruptedly from last April until the first week of the present month, is shown by the Labor Bureau's. compilation to have been checked. Not only did the general average rise fractionally in the second week of January, but, with two exceptions, all of the ten specified groups of commodities either rose or remained unchanged.

High United States and Philippine military authorities announced today that the joint war manoeuvres, concluded yesterday, were considered highly successful and proved the merits of the new Commonwealth Army.

A fifty-page pamphlet entitled "Five Years of Hitler" was published here yesterday under the imprint of the American Council on Public Affairs, 20 Vesey Street. The pamphlet is composed of six studies presented as "significant and authoritative,"
It seems incredible in this age of strife, hate and name-calling that representatives of Ireland and Great Britain could sit down

For the first time in the more than thirty years of New York A. C. trapshooting, two gunners returned perfect scores of 100 at the Travers Island traps of the Winged Foot organization yesterday. Sharing the honors were L. F. Sanman and Roger Fawcett,

6th St, 609 E; Bernard Barth to Howard A. Scholle, 43 5th Ave; mtg $17,000 (50c). 46th St, 515 W; North River Savings Bank to 46 Estates, Inc. 303 W 42d St ($17.50). 73d St, 51 W; Samuel J. Kopetzky to E. W. Waters, 310 W 160th St; mtg $30,000. 115th St, 36 W; Frank Skolnick to Weiskol Realty Co, 176 E 114th St (50c).

The Union Corporation estimated this week that the production of gold throughout the world in 1937, including a preliminary figure of 6,000,000 ounces for Russia, was 35,400,000 fine ounces. This is almost 7 1/2 per cent more than the 32,960,000 ounces mined in 1936 and is a new high record for a year.

In a foolhardy attempt to cross the Passaic River in a leaky rowboat without oars or paddles, Theodore Clar, 14-year-old son of a baker living at 90 Center Street, Nutley, was drowned about 6 o'clock this evening. A companion in the adventure, Richard Redman, 12, of 62 Center Street, was able to swim to the Belleville side of the river after the boat foundered in midstream.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Larkum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newton D. Larkum of Auburn Road, West Hartford, to Arthur Paul Bencks Jr. of Brookline, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Fletcher D.
Robert Grant 3d of New York retained his Canadian racquets singles championship today, defeating J. R. Leonard of New York in the final.

Governor Browning, defending his proposal that the State and the TVA "join hands" to buy out the Tennessee Electrio Power Company, said tonight the "idea that it puts the State into the power business is entirely erroneous."

Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein, who arrived in New York last week, will devote the next two months to lecturing in various parts of the country. Prince Loewenstein recently completed his autobiography, "Conquest of the Past," which Houghton Mifflin will publish early in March.

Fred Zomzely, 31 years old, of 721 Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, a musician who worked his way back from Germany on the President Roosevelt of the United States lines, said yesterday that he had spent four days in a Berlin prison and had to pay for his board and lodging while there.

Lord Gisborough, soldier and politician, died at his home, Gisborough Hall, Yorkshire, today after a long illness. His age was 81. Lord Gisborough served in the Afghan and Boer wars and during the World War was honorary commandant of a volunteer regiment.

The George Washington Hotel team, which rolled the high score of 3,217 a week ago last Saturday, was declared winner of the metropolitan bowling championship as the tournament came to a close on the alleys of the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy last night.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. John Washington Perkins of Wendell of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Hazel Virginia Perkins, to J. Henry Burnett Jr. of Macon, Ga., and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burnett of Macon.

Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade last week was unusually light, daily sales averaging slightly in excess of 21,000,000 bushels, or 14,000,000 less than the average of the preceding week.

People are so immersed in material things they are likely to forget that this is a "God-made world, not man-made," the Rev. John Doyle, a secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near. Willis Avenue.

Norway won its second title in the European speed-skating championships today when Charles Mathisen captured the 1,500-meter event in the ordinary time of 2:27.4. Hans Engenestangen took the 500 meters for Norway yesterday.

The conclusion that women are showing an increasing interest in education was offered yesterday by the Alumnae Committee of Seven Colleges in making public the results of an analysis of men's and women's contributions to all phases of philanthropy in six cities.
Five French Guiana refugees who reached Santiago in a frail craft three days ago were ordered today by national immigration authorities to be deported.

Miss Reata King Kimball, daughter of Mrs. Donald B. Cragin of this city, has chosen the afternoon of Feb. 11 for her wedding to Jerrems Chamberlain Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Hart of New Britain.

The Dunntgan-Killgrew Bill, extending the benefits of unemployment insurance to those getting $8,000 a year or more, will be reported out of committee in the Assembly this coming week, and will be passed by that body next week, according to present plans of the Republican legislative leaders.

In the most artful bit of juggling he has attempted in the last dozen years, Daniel J. Ferris, secretarytreasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, presented his All-America track and field team yesterday in Spalding's Athletic Almanac, which is just off the press.

The courage of missionary families in the war areas of the Far East was praised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans, pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Eighty-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. "These men," he said, "are nearer to perfection than any other group in the world because they possess the highest standards of Christian idealism and spirituality."

Net assets of $8,226,353 at the close of 1937 were reported yesterday by the Railway and Light Securities Company. The total was equal to $205.66 a $100 of bonds, $199.96 a share of preferred stock and $12.95 a common share, compared with $11,494,705, or $287.37 a $100 of debt, $354.59 a share of preferred stock and $32.98 a common share at the close of 1936.

Henry Block, wood engraver and painter, who lived at 200 Third Street, died last night at the Muhlenburg Hospital in Plainfiela of a heart ailment. He was 60 years old. Colored wood engravings done by Mr. Block are on permanent exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, the New York Public Library, and the Library of Congress in Washington.

Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., won the Kingston tennis tournament singles crown Saturday with a 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 victory over Donald Leahong, Jamaica champion. Hendrix had eliminated Ross Wilson of Toronto in one semi-final. Hendrix and Wilson took the doubles title, deeating Leahong and Dayes of Jamaica, 10-8, 6-8, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3.

Mrs. Frank Asbury Mizener of North East, Pa., and Winter Park, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mathilde Mizener, to Charles O. Andrews Jr., son of United States Senator and Mrs. Charles O. Andrews of Orlando, Fla. The wedding will take place in March in Knowles Memorial Chapel, Winter Park.

In a rough-and-tumble overtime encounter, enlivened by several arguments and fist fights, the Hershey Bears slammed their way to a 5-to-4 victory over the New York Rovers in Madison Square Garden yesterday before the season's largest amateur hockey crowd there.

Winter convention, American Institute of Electrical Engineers, will open at 10 A. M. at 33 West Thirty-ninth Street, and continue to Friday. Morning and afternoon sessions. Town Hall, Inc., 123 West Fortythird Street, 11 A. M. "Regional Art," Grant Wood.

A well-dressed woman about 35 years old, apparently an amnesia victim, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday from the corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, where she was found walking around perplexed. The woman said she could not remember anything.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Iselin of 144 East Sixty-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Iselin, to Wadsworth R. Lewis, son of Mrs. Frederic E. Lewis of 23 West Fiftysecond Street and the late Mr. Lewis.

While wheat prices fluctuated in a most erratic manner last week, there was little relative change in the world supply or demand situation, or in the outlook for the new crop in the Southwest. Price changes largely reflected local operations.

Prohibiting certain unfair methods of competition in the sale of a mineral water, the Federal Trade Commission has issued an order against the Capon Water Company, Philadelphia, distributor, and Capon Springs Mineral Water, Inc.,
The peace program adopted in Washington last Friday by the thirteenth annual Conference on the Cause and Cure of War is a successful combination of realism and idealism.

A drive for recognition of the chiropractic profession by this session of the State Legislature was planned yesterday at the twentyseventh annual mid-year conference of the New York State Chiropractic Society in the Hotel Commodore.

State Secretary Ernst Wilhelm Bohle, Foreign Office chief of the National Socialist party's Foreign Organization, issued a statement today that was in part an answer to an article on Nazi racialism in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine last Nov. 21.

Michael F. O'Dea, Los Angeles pioneer and philanthropist, died today at his hotel home after a brief illness. His age was 90. Born in Toronto, Mr. O'Dea was reared in Rochester, N. Y. While E working as a machinist he studied law and in 1876 was admitted to the bar in New York.

Great Britain's imports in December amounted to [Pound]94,327,639, compared with [Pound]83,542,835 for December, 1936. Last year's exports in December were [Pound]48,860,246, against [Pound]46,715,966 in 1936. The increase in imports was the smallest since February and the third lowest of the year and the increase in exports was the smallest of the year.

Reports from Orizaba, where President Lazaro Cardenas has been for the last week making an effort to settle the inter-union conflict that culminated in bloody clashes last Monday, indicate he is also studying the petroleum controversy.

In holiday mood, the entire company of "Between the Devil," the Shubert brothers' musical hit, came to Washington today for a one-night command performance, beginning a week of festivities for the National Infantile Paralysis Foundation on the occasion of President Roosevelt's birthday next Sunday.

When man seeks happiness it eludes him; happiness can only come through an outpouring of love for God and God's children, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector, said in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Isaac Stanley Walker, an authority on water works and municipal sanitation, died today of a heart attack. He was 55 years old. Mr. Walker made a study of the Delaware River basin for the United States Government as an associate water-consultant for the National Resources Committee during the last year.

Failure on the part of ministers to preach the necessity for forgiveness "is emptying the churches," the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, said in his sermon there last night.

A statement emphasizing the unemployment situation in the Middle West and listing what he considers some of the obstacles to employment and business expansion was sent today to the Senate Committee on Unemployment by George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Birger Ruud, world ski champion, virtually made a one-man show out df the Northwest jumping championship at Bush Lake today. The Kongsberg, Norway, rider, twice an Olympic champion, scored 236.9 points for an easy triumph. He made jumps of 194 and 192 feet.

The financial markets here continue their humdrum course, with the tendency of security prices more upward than downward. The French crisis imposed a restriction on financial business, but its removal has not been followed by any fresh activity.
The Rev. Israel Harding Noe's twenty-two day fast, by which he hoped to attain immortality on earth, came to an involuntary end tonight when he was rushed to a hospital for feeding by force.

Harry Brown Sr., for years a labor leader, died in his home in Maybrook on Friday. He was connected with the Central New England branch of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for years and was secretary of the local branLh of the American Federation of Labor.

The executive board of the Farmer-Labor-Progressive Federation by a vote of 27 to 26 today refused membership to the Committee for Industrial Organization as a group. The decision followed a bitter contest in which Henry Ohl Jr., president of the Wisconsin Federation of Labor,

The captured Bishop of Teruel, the Rev. Dr. Anselmo Polanco Fonseco, who is now a prisoner in San Miguel Penitentiary in Valencia and the only Catholic Bishop in government territory, will probably be exchanged for one or more prisoners in Generalissimo Francisco Franco's hands-whose return the government desires.

Members of the New York City mounted police made practically a sweep of the individual military jumping championship today. This was the featured number on a card of seven events of the annual midwinter exhibition given by the West Point Horse Show Association in
Loom activity in the rayon-weaving industry has continued to hold at the previous low levels, according to the report issued today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

A notable feature of the debates in the current session of the Diet is the limitless confidence that members voice in the country's financial power, with a corresponding eagerness to see the government start vast construction projects in Japan and North China.

Canada may look back on 1937 as a year of great industrial and commercial activity and almost uniform progress, according to the current business review issued by the Bank of Montreal. The only important setback, apart from foreign influences exerted late in the year, was the heavy decline in Western wheat production, the bank found.

The Smithsonian Institution wants to know if the great intellectuals of the world are getting big-headed. There's no impudence in the question; the institution is seeking evidence to back up the theory of Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, the institution's curator of physical anthropology, that the human head swells as a person gets older.
The State Department has begun preparation of an announcement of intention to negotiate a new trade agreement with Canada, amplifying the one which went into effect Jan. 1, 1936.
Miss Katherine Rawls, Olympic swimming star who holds many breast-stroke and medley records, lowered the national 220-yard freestyle mark over the twenty-yard Miami Biltmore course today.

With a protracted budget controversy between Mayor Joseph F. Loehr, Democrat, of Yonkers, and Republican members of the Common Council holding up the collection of more than $11,000,000 in 1938 taxes, City Controller James Hushion was unable to say definitely today whether he would be able to meet the next payroll of $350,000 on Feb. 1.

The future of human liberty depends on Britain, France and the United States and on how they work together, in the opinion of David Lloyd George, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, who said in an interview here that these democracies still held the cards and would be able to make a "clean sweep" when the time came.

The United States Department of Agriculture probably will face a test of its powers in volume control of fruit shipments when such regulations become effective this week, as thirty independent shippers of Texas grapefruit and oranges at a meeting here decided to fight proration to the limit.

Reports from Western Suiyuan Province strengthened recent Japanese assertions that troops of the Soviet-inspired republic of Outer Mongolia were menacing the conquest of that corridor between China and Russia.

An adventurous cocker spaniel named Penny today jeopardized not only his own life when he ventured out on thin ice in Manhasset .Bay in pursuit of a sea gull but also those of his 12-year-old mistress, Nancy Whitmore, and her sister Jane, 21, who attempted to rescue him when he broke through.

The New York Historical Society announced yesterday that it had purchased the Elie Nadelman collection of folk and peasant art. Mr. Nadelman, who, with his wife, began collecting in 1926, said the collection, including the building which housed it at Riverdale, had cost $300,000.

Federal and other governmental agencies spent $2,155,417,000 for public relief in the first eleven months of the calendar year 1937, a decline of $251,821,000 from the like period of 1936, the Social Security Board reported today.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, 39 years old, pastor for the last six years of the First Presbyterian Church, Evanston, Ill., has accepted a call to become pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church here. He will assume his new duties Oct. 1.
Elisabeth Schumann, the eminent Viennese soprano, delighted a large and demonstrative audience with her accomplished artistry in the course of her recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children aided 4,613 children in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens in 1937, according to a report made public yesterday. Nurses of the association devoted 4,101 days to care of crippled children, made 21,959 visits and gave 8,500 interviews.

Surveys of twenty-four States by Department of Agriculture officials and State entomologists indicate grasshoppers may be more troublesome to large farming areas in 1938 than they were last year, the department reported today.

A total of 88,109,696 passengers was carried on the Interborough lines during December as compared with 92,127,879 in the corresponding month a year ago, according to a report filed yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

More consideration needs to be given the means instead of the end, because "the means always determine the ends that will be reached," the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Long Island University continued along the comeback trail during a slow week in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles with three successive victories, while Manhattan and Brooklyn College added two triumphs each. The only other local college to see action was St. John's, which won once.

Congress has turned an almost deaf ear to recent proposals made by the President in the interest of Federal economy. The Senate blithely ignored his recommendation that a top limit of a half billion dollars be placed on annual expenditures under the new Farm Bill.

A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Fridolin E. Oberlander will be held today at 11 A. M. in St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, by the Concordia Lutheran Ministers Association. Dr. Oberlander, who died last month, was pastor of St. John's Church.
Mounted on motor cycles, J. A. Antonio Pinto and two companions left yesterday to attend the fourth Olympic Games of Central America and the Caribbean, which will begin on Feb. 5 in Panama.

Yesterday was the big day for West Palm Beach, for it marked the opening of the Fourth Annual Silver Sailfish Derby, which will have a three-week run. This contest, in which several hundred anglers will participate, is sponsored by the West Palm Beach Fishing Club.

The German December foreign trade return, although it appeared too late to affect the security markets, undoubtedly will be well taken, for it brings to light much the highest trade volume since the depression, imports exceeding the total in December, 1936, by 35 per cent, and exports similarly 20 per cent up.

The newspaper Nichi Nichi in a dispatch from Seoul, Korea, today said that it was informed reliably thatSoviet armaments had been strengthened greatly in the Far East, particularly around Vladivostok.

The Fourth International Leica Exhibit, which opened two weeks ago in Rockefeller Center, closed yesterday with the announcement of the prize-winning photographs. Judgments were passed both by judges and the public and the two groups disagreed.

Despite a slow foreign demand for cash corn last week, the price of that grain averaged higher on the Board of Trade, the close yesterday showing net gains of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel, with the May at 60 3/4 to 60 5/8 cents; July at 611/2 cents and September at 61 5/8 cents a bushel.

Calling of cotton by consumers had a steadying influence on prices on the Exchange yesterday and following Saturday's setback, the list improved 5 to 8 points. Cover ing of near-month obligations stiffened March contracts, and spot houses had so little hedging business that buying orders were exe cuted at an advance in quotations

The Italian Ambassador and Donna Matilde de Suvich were members of a distinguished company which turned out today to hear the program given at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's 102d "Musical Morning" by Ezio Pinza, Italian bassbaritone, and Orlando Barera, violinist A luncheon was given afterward by Mr. Townsend. Due to a cold, Mrs. Townsend was unable to be present.

The Rev. Israel Harding Noe grudgingly joined with doctors tonight in their efforts to restore strength to his fast-ravaged body, but only for the purpose of hastening his return to "spiritual" existence.

Italian troops, Fascist officials and Japanese representatives today joined in funeral services for Sandro, Sandri, Italian newspaper man killed when Japanese bombs sank the United States gunboat Panay in China, Dec. 12.

Park Pl, 130, 22.10x82.4xfrreg; George Demetropoulous and ano. to trustees of Princeton University at Princeton. N. J., mtg $22,000 held by grantee ($22). East Broadway, 42, 25x69.7; Feldor Realty Co (Samuel Bronerwein, press) to Clayton Merchandise Co, 270 Broadway, mtg 1 $24,000 (S7.50).
Ralph E. Ladue, vice president of John David, operating nine men's clothing and furnishings stores in Greater New York, was yesterday elected president of the chain. At

On the eve of the biennial convention of the United Mine Workers President John L. Lewis, who is chairman of the C. I. O., told the miners' newest union division that the "new depression" had retarded organization.

The Giornale d'Italia in a two-column article by Professor Luigi Frontana-Russo, Professor of Commercial Policy at the Rome Institute of Economic and Commercial Sciences, foreshadows Italy's opposition to the economic plan of ex-Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium-whatever it may turn out to be.

Distant fields always look greener and out-of-town basketball teams always look far better than metropolitan foes. A serious error has been made-justifiable in the excitement of the moment-in classifying the Minnesota team of 1938 and the Stanford and Notre Dame teams of 1937 as being the greatest ever to play in New York.

For the first time in many years, strike conditions existed in five theatres in the Broadway amusement area yesterday as the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union continued its battle with theatrical producers and the New York Theatrical Press Agents.

The Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, has received as a gift from Mrs. Simon Guggenheim of New York the painting called "The Mirror" by Pablo Picasso, Spanish artist, who was one of the leaders in the modern art movement. The picture was painted in Paris in 1932.

The Amerioan Scenia and Historic Preservation Society announced last night its 1937 awards for eminent services in park work. The announcement was made by the president, Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball, Controller of New York University, at the forty-third annual meeting of the society in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. The awards, a

William Moore Robinson, retired stockbroker, formerly in business in this city, died at the age of 81 yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment at the Hotel Plaza. He was born in Wilmington, Del. Since his retirement, about 1900, Mr. Robinson had passed most of his time in Europe, chiefly at the Chateau de Crevins, his estate in France near the Swiss border. Mr.
To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 25: PATROLMEN Charles W. Herold, from 3d Precinct to 1st Precinct. William H. Bushell, 6th Precinct, assigned to duty as attendant.

Milton R. Weinberger of New York, who testified before the House Ways and Means Committee as the representative of the American Theatre Council, was quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday as joining with other witnesses in charging that the ticket scalper was one of the theatre's greatest menaces.

The American Federation of Hosiery Workers, through its president, Emile Rieve, announced today that it would sponsor a parade of unemployed silk workers in Washington on Friday as a protest against the boycott on silk stockings, which is aimed to bar commercial aid to Japan.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild has arranged for a second junior student matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 14, it was announced yesterday. The demand for the performance scheduled for March 4 has been so great that another presentation was found to be necessary. "Carmen" will be sung at both matinees.

In his address before the State Bar Association the other evening Governor Lehman reminded his hearers that "democracy is under pressure from powerful and selfish reactionaries on the extreme right and from equally powerful and selfish radicals on the extreme left."

A 50 per cent increase in business over 1986 made last year the best in the history of the heating, ventilating and air conditioning industries, Davis S. Boyden, president of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers, announced yesterday.

Taking the initiative to prevent speculative short selling of securities on the Stock Exchanges in a declining market, the Securities and Exchange Commission today ruled that beginning Feb. 8, no person, for his own account or for the account of a customer, shall effect a short sale of any security on the Exchanges at or below the price at which the last sale of the same security was effected.

Despite high winds which kept most of the scores above the 80s Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., defending titleholder, took the medal with a 78 in the qualifying round of the women's championship of champions golf tournament today.

The Senate Committee on Public Lands, which is investigating the qualifications of Ebert K. Burlew to be assistant secretary of the interior, today turned its attention to the purchase of two automobiles for the use of Secretary Ickes in his capacity as Administrator of the Public Works Administration.
French military manoeuvres this year will be on a larger scale than ever before and will take place during August in the eastern part of France, the newspaper Matin announced today.
The movement of freight by truck declined 15.7 per cent in December from the total for December, 1936, according to the American Trucking Associations. The decline in loadings, which started in

On behalf of the Bondholders Representative Committee, an application was made yesterday to the Supreme Court of Ontario in Toronto for leave to appeal from the judgment of Justice McTague dismissing the trustee's motion for the sale of assets of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd.

Passenger revenues of the Alton Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, apparently increased in 1937 by a greater percentage than was true for any other line in the United States, according to a statement by the B. O. yesterday. The B. O. led in the

John Michael Horan, who claims to be the oldest active railroad employe in the United States, embarked on his second century of life today. He cut into a huge birthday cake, topped with 100 candles, yesterday, turned to his 70-year-old son, William, and said:

The steamship Santa Inez of the Grace Line arrived yesterday from Valparaiso on her last voyage as a regular passenger ship. With her sailing next Friday she will be transferred to the status of a freighter with accommodation for twelve persons, it was learned when the vessel docked.
The statistical news of the week in the National Hockey League has been Cecil Dillon's rise to the point where he is the undisputed goalgetting leader of the big circuit.

While you're reading this we're miles and miles from the desk where it was written, and if luck is with us there'll- be one or two less wild turkeys along the wooded shores of the Roanoke River in North Carolina.

A Foreign Office spokesman today denied reports that Japen intends to construct 48,000-ton to 45,000-ton battleships. Inquiries at the Navy Office today showed authorities there still unprepared to amplify the general denials given last May and again on Jan. 20.

With a fairly large contingent of buyers in town and with mail orders substantial, manufacturers and buying offices reported yesterday that demand for Spring merchandise was developing satisfactorily.

Mrs. Waiter Eyre Lambert gave a luncheon for Sir Willmott Lewis yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre before Sir Willmott's lecture on "Vision of World Affairs" at the hotel. Her other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Henry 0. Tallmadge and Mr. and Mrs. William de Forest Manice.

Bob Pastor, 1841/2. pounds, of Inwood, last night knocked out Buck Tracy, 180, of Everett, Mass., before a slim crowd at the St. Nicholas Palace. The finish came after 2 minutes 34 seconds of the second in a scheduled ten-round bout. Tracy was down four times, three times in the second session, before Referee Frank Fullam intervened.

After doing a stretch as Madame Bovary, Constance Cummings is taking a rest cure in "If I Were You," which was somersaulted across the stage of the Mansfield last evening. This little number is by Paul Hervey Fox and Benn W. Levy, and is suggested by an idea in a novel by the late Thorne Smith.

Two large stores in the threestory commercial building which will rise on the site of the old Brick Presbyterian Church at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, now being demolished, have been leased by the General Realty and Utilities Corporation for long terms at an aggregate rental of close to $2,500,000, according to Louis Abrons, president of the corporation.

A rumor spread today in diplomatic circles that the Japanese Government had applied the soft pedal to anti-British utterances of those in official positions because it expected in the near future an approach by London with the object of mediating between Japan and China.

Amendment of the State Unemployment Insurance Law to include workers in religious, charitable and educational organizations has been recommended to Governor Lehman by the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, Herman A. Gray, chairman of the council, announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia and Reuben A. Lazarus, author of the Omnibus and County Bills now before the Legislature, joined yesterday in denying that adoption of the bills would reestablish a large number of the county jobs eliminated from the 1938 budget.

Ordered by the State Supreme Court to adopt a municipal budget by next Monday, members of the City Council at a caucus today approved a 2 per cent sales tax, with exemptions for food and some other necessities, and indicated the tax would be passed this week.

The entire slate of officers for the coming year. was formally elected yesterday at the Crescent Athletic Club. The choices of the nominating committee were unopposed. Frederick I. Bergen was moved into office as president together with all n the other selections.

The Treasury's ninety-one-day bills were sold today at an average price of 0.103 per cent on a discount basis, compared with 0.111 per cent for the issue sold last week and 0.097 per cent the week before, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call for the repayment on Thursday of a part of the funds which it has on deposit with banks here and in other parts of the country. The withdrawal, which equals
A mass meeting of 250 seamen tonight rejected an American Federation of Labor charter and voted to function independently.

Orders have been issued by Metro to rewrite "Wonder Child," with Judy Garland in the title role. The story by Dalton Trumbo and Arthur Sheekman was purchased for Suzanne Larson, but, as it is probable that the child's option will not be exercised, the yarn is being switched to Judy. Bert Kalmar and Harry Ruby are writing the music.

Metropolitan ski-jumping followers will see this country's foremost fliers in action next month, if plans of the Bear Mountain Sports Association materialize. According to Leib Deyo, director of the B. M. S. A., arrangements are being completed to have the outstanding Midwest and Pacific Northwest jumpers, who are to compete in the national championships at Brattleboro, Vt., Feb. 19-20, engage the East's best at the tricky Interstate Park hill on Feb. 12.

The Farm, a roadhouse on the Bronx River Parkway northwest of here, was destroyed by fire this morning. The origin of the blaze was not determined, but Chief Philip McQuillan of the Green. burgh town police said it was under investigation.
Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Milbank will give a dinner on Thursday at their home, 16 East Sixty-seventh Street, and a theatre party for their niece, Miss Ella D. Milband, and her fiance, W. Ward Foshay.

Sales of copper were made yesterday in the export market from 10.20 down to 9.95 cents a pound, c. i. f., the European base ports. This compares with 10.15 to 10.20 cents a pound on Saturday. The domestic

Ithaca College let the St. Francis longrange shooters pop them in from center court in the early moments in a tight basketball game tonight and then tried to catch them the rest of the way, but failed. The final tally was 42-37, and the entire Brooklyn outfit aided in the scoring:

A gale, which in New York reached a velocity of 48 miles an hour at times, last night lashed the northeast coast of the United States endangering fishermen, delaying vessels and causing considerable damage to signs, buildings and piers. In this city many signs were loosened or blown down.

Will Phillip Hooper, painter and illustrator, who retired as head of the Hooper Advertising Service in 1927, died yesterday at his home in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, where he had lived for more than twenty years. Born in Biddeford, Me., he received his art education in Boston and at the Art Students League in this city. His illustrations had ap-

An eagle 3 on the 450-yard seventh hole enabled Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., former Yale star, to win the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Winter golf championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup today.

William J. Larkin, dean of Worcester newspaper men, died of pneumonia at St. Vincent Hospital at 1 A. M. today. His age was 71. He was a correspondent for The Associated Press, feature editor of the Worcester Post, and district correspondent for the Boston Globe.

James (Smilin' Jeems) Mutrie, the first manager of the New York Giants in 1883, died yesterday at Cancer Institute on Welfare Island at the age of 86. With him at his death was his wife, Catherine. He had been in ill health for several years and some months ago left his home at 11 Pauw Street, New Brighton, S. I., for a Staten Island hospital. Later he was transferred
William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard University and a member of the Olympic Games committee, tonight voiced his disapproval of Tokyo as scene of the 1940 Olympics.
The Assembly Rules Committee, meeting tonight after a brief session of the Legislature, reported out for action by the Assembly tomorrow, the MoffatNunan resolution on child labor.

A sharp contraction in trading volume did not halt the downward trend in railroad issues in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover in all bonds dwindled to $5,219,350, compared with $7,149,700 last Friday, but the character of the market generally was little changed.
Larry MacPhail, newly appointed executive vice president of the Dodgers, launched a shopping tour tonight to bolster the club, with his prize pitching ace, Van Lingle Mungo, as his lure.

Improved train service. for Mount Vernon and neighboring communities will be provided, beginning next Sunday, Corporation Counsel Lester D. Stickles said here today after a conference with passenger agents of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

Funeral services for Mme. Therese Blum, wife of the French Socialist leader, were held today. Burial was in Pere-Lachaise Cemetery. The services were private, in accordance with the wishes of the family. About fifty persons, including relatives and a number of officials and her closest friends were present at the burial services. These

Emigration of several, hundred thousand "Eastern Jews" of Russian origin who settled here after the World War was suggested today in the Sejm (Parliament) by a prominent Pilsudski party leader, Deputy Wojchiechowski.
Travel for educational purposes has always been practiced by members of the British ruling class.

Remedies for the business recession will be discussed by George Matthew Verity, chairman of the board of the American Rolling Mill Company; Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, a.C. I. O. union, and Dr. Oliver M. W, Sprague,

Lord Beaverbrook and Lord Forbes, who arrived at the Towers aboard the former's private plane from Nassau, were joined there today by Viscount and Viscountess Wey- E mouth, who came from New York. Viscount Weymouth is a member of Parliament for Frome Division, Somerset, and is the son of the fifth Marquis of Bath. Before their marriage in 1927 the Viscountess was the Hon. Daphne Vivian, eldest daughter of Lord and Lady Vivian.

The sale of the estate owned by Paul A. Dahlgreen, Greenwich real estate broker, at 159 Park Place, Greenwich, to Robert W. Griggs of Intervale Place, advertising manager for Standard Brands, New York, marks the transfer of another old landmark in Greenwich.

The City A. C. combination, playing on its home courts, scored a shutout triumph over the Short Hills team yesterday to maintain its strong grip at the top in the metropolitan Class B squash tennis tourney. It was the tenth victory in eleven engagements for the City unit.

About 10,000 persons may be dropped from the WPA rolls to make room for others in actual need, as a result of an investigation begun yesterday by the Public Welfare Department to determine the status of WPA employes, of whom there are now 130,000 on the payroll.

In a conversation with this correspondent tonight, Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland [formerly the Irish Free State] gave a vigorous outspoken reply to statements made by Viscount Craigavon, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, in an interview in Belfast last Sunday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Miss Diana Fishwick, British women's golf champion in 1930 and winner of the English and French titles in 1932, will compete in a series of Florida tournaments next month and in March, according to a cable received from London yesterday.

The Collegiate School basketball teak defeated the New York Friends School quintet, 33 to 23, on the losers' court yesterday. Collegiate, ahead by 13 to 12 at the half, put the game on ice with a spurt in the closing stages.

Immediately after Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan had rendered a decision yesterday upholding Councilman John Cashmore as Vice Chairman of the City Council, members of Mayor La Guardia's bloc drew a plan under which they hope to use the decision to unseat Mr. Cashmore from his position at today's meeting and replace him with Councilman James A. Burke of Queens.

The fiftieth wedding anniversary of David Lloyd George, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, was celebrated today in glorious weather. With Mrs. Lloyd George he spent the morning in a garden in Cap d'Antibes surrounded by his family.

The one racing fan who ventured to couple Chauvenet and Spanish Witch in the daily double at the Fair Grounds today received $1,804 in return for his $2. Both were outsiders, Chauvenet paying $18.60 and Spanish Witch $67 in the straight mutuels.

Mayor La Guardia and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, joined with representatives of 226 labor unions in protesting last night at a mass meeting in the Manhattan Opera House against the persecution of Jews in Rumanlia.

J. Overton Paine, 69-year-old former president of the Paine Statistical Corporation of Newark, was found guilty of embezzlement by a jury here tonight. He faces a maximum prison term of three years when he appears for sentence

The State Labor Relations Board will not entertain charges made by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, that the Board of Transportation of New York City maintains a labor spy system and otherwise interferes with the organization of its employes by the union, it was announced last night.
Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia were guests last evening at a reception given for them by aviation and business executives at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Bruno, 400 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The text of the rules on short selling promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and that of its statement on the results of its study of the short-selling situation are as follows:
An exposition to publicize New Jersey will be conducted here next month by L. Bamberger Co., Newark department store, it was announced today by officials of the company.

Irwin Rosoff, 6 years old, of 142 Morton Place,,the Bronx, shot and fatally wounded himself yesterday while playing with a .25-caliber automatic pistol he found in a jewelry store at 2,154 Third Avenue. owned by his three uncles.

An age of super-scientific traffic safety miracles twenty-five to fifty years in the future, when automobiles will automatically dry off wet pavements, and photo-electric cells, infra-red rays and short-wave radio will make accidents "impossible," ??

Andrew Weston has obtained the general contract for construction of the new high school in Glen Cove on a bid of $473,900, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. The plans and specifications were drawn by Tooker Marsh, architects. The heating contract went to John E. Curley, for $77,357; plumbing to James McCullagh, for $26,777, and electrical work to Geeco Electrical Company, for $34,880.
The one-story church structure at the northeast corner of Schenectady Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Bethel's People African Methodist Episcopal Tabernacle. The build-

Net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company amounted to $10,168,689 in 1937 after depreciation, interest, expenses, Federal income taxes and other charges. No provision for Federal surtax on undistributed income is included, B. C. Heacock, president, stated, as dividends paid in the last two years are in excess of the net profits for those periods. In 1936 the company earned $9,849,592.

William Pedriok Jr., who rose from telegraph operator to some of the high positions on the Pennsylvania Railroad, died last night at his home at 829 Park Avenue. He was 68 years old, and had been in failing health for many months. He was formerly passenger traffic manager for the Pennsylvania in New York City.

M. Durham Jr., chief executive officer of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, announced today that the road had redeemed $1,282,000 par value of its ten-year secured 3% per cent certificates of indebtedness, under tenders accepted on Saturday.

Most commodity futures declined in fairly active trading on the local Exchanges yesterday. Cocoa, coffee and cottonseed-oil futures, however, were firm. In the cash markets. wheat, corn, rye, cocoa, lard and cotton advanced, but butter, tins, silk, rubber and hides declined, the latter to a new seasonal low.

The stock market drifted loweryesterday in the forenoon although in most instances the declines were limited to small fractions; after the Steel Institute's report at midday showing a pick-up in steel operations, the market worked higher and closed generally firm. The turnover

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 19: Decreases of $63,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $30,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities;

Accused of accepting $5 from a motorist for dropping a speeding charge, Constable John Pino of Hammonton was arrested on a charge of extortion today by the State police. He was held in $500 bail for a hearing on Jan. 31 by Justice of the Peace David Finkenbinder.

Stephen L. Mershon, president and historian of the Symes Foundation of New York, died here today at his home, 33 Oxford Street, at the age of 78. Born in East Hampton, N. Y., he had lived in Evanston, Ill., for many years before coming to Montclair in 1898.

The drive for funds of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will not end with the celebration of President Roosevelt's birthday Saturday night, Basil O'Connor, New York general chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 21: REAR ADMIRAL Le Breton, D. M., Chief of Staff and aide to the Commander in Chief, United States Fleet, to duty as Commander Yangtze Patrol.

Farrar Rinehart announce that first orders for Hervey Allen's "Action at Aquila" indicate the total advance sale of the book will be more than twice that of any book that has appeared under their imprint.
BANNON, SELINA L. (Jan. 15). Estate. $9,000. To Institution of Mercy, 1,075 Madison Ave. Residue of $7,500 for St. Joseph's residence, 47 E. 81st St. Catherine C. McParland, 1,600 Macombs Road,

The theft and recovery of a rare book on checkers, printed in 1815 and said to be the first on the subjest published in this country, was revealed yesterday by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, who said that an arrest would be made soon.

In the interests of the New York Diet Kitchen Association's opera benefit next month an "opera luncheon" will be held today at the Coq Rouge Restaurant for several officers of the beneficiary and committee members working toward the success of the benefit.
United States Commercial Attache Plans for exploitation of petroleum deposits in Guatemala were described in a report made public tonight by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestio Commerce.

By a party vote of 39 to 18, the Republican majority in the Assembly buried in committee tonight a resolution offered by Minority Leader Fred W. De Voe of Middlesex County, directing an investigation of the purchase of voting machines in Essex County.
Teruel, center of a month-long battle, was reported tonight to have been evacuated by Spanish Government forces in the face of unceasing Insurgent artillery fire.

Effectiveness of the dress industry's machinery for settling labor and other disputes was cited in a report covering the twenty-one and a half months ended Dec. 31, 1937, issued yesterday by Harry Uviller, the industry's impartial chairman and administrator.

The Puerto Ricq Farmers Association has asked Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace to fix a fair and reasonable rate to be paid by processors to cane growers as required by law, asserting that the Secretary's delay is causing the growers hardships.

President Roosevelt today requested the American Red Cross to raise a fund for the relief of Chinese civilians made destitute by the Sino-Japanese war. The President said he hoped the response to the appeal would "result in a good-will offering of as much as perhaps $1,000,000."

A charge that the Roosevelt Administration had shifted the burden of taxation from the substantial-income class to the "working groups" was voiced tonight by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, at a dinner and raliy in his honor.

On the eighteenth day of the Senate filibuster against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill, Senator Barkley, the majority leader, started evening sessions, holding the Senate in session from 11 o'clock this morning until 10:12 tonight, but without diminishing the determination of the bill's opponents.

The Census Bureau reported today tha cotton of 1937 growth ginned before Jan. 16 amounted to 17,645, 756 running bales, counting 316,158 round bales as half bales, and ineluding 9,592 bales of AmericanEgyptian.

Dust storm reports from the more Western sections of the Southwestern Winter wheat belt and strength in Winnipeg led to scattered buying of futures on the board of trade here today and closing sales showed net gains of 3/4 cent a bushel compared with Saturday.

Jake Schaefer of Chicago, launching the defense of his world's 28.2 balkline billiard championship against Welker Cochran of San Francisco yesterday at the Strand Academy, captured the first two blocks of their 3,500-point meeting and forged to a 500-382 lead.

James J. Braddock and Tommy Farr will meet again in the ring before the indoor season is over, if present plans materialize. Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. yesterday announced he has practically completed arrangements for a return bout between boxing's "miracle man" and the British Empire heavyweight titleholder, to be waged in Madison Square Garden April 1.
Andrew S. Grey, member of a Boston law firm, died at his home today after a heart attack. His age was 26. Born in Philadelphia, Mr. Grey was a graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School.

The National Orchestral Association, directed by Leon Barzin, gave the first New York performance of a concerto for piano and strings by Anis Fuleihan at its Carnegie Hall concert last night. Mr. Fulei-...

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3842 and 3843-George W. Watts v. Frank H. Praeger. Frank H. Praeger v. George W. Watts.-Opinlon by Judge Garrett. In an interference proceeding involving improvement in furnace, the Board of Appeals awarded priority to Watts as to five counts and to Praeger es tb two counts.

A new system of electric remotecontrol accounting, applicable to department stores and other fields, was described yesterday before the opening sessions of the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, held this week in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.

The proposed Hamburg bridge over the Elbe River, which Chancellor Adolf Hitler recently said would be "on the whole the world's greatest bridge," has been designed by Hitler himself, who also determined the materials to be used.
President Roosevelt's nomination of Solicitor General Reed to be associate justice of the Supreme Court was quickly approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
The long peace on the Soviet's Baltic State borders has been marred by an incident on the Estonian frontier in which two Soviet border guards were killed.
All signs point to a rigorous censorship in Greece during the last twentyfour hours, betokening important political events.

John Henry Seadlund, kicking, snarling and tugging at his chains, was brought into court today accused of kidnapping Charles S. Ross. The prisoner stood mute while a plea of innocent was entered for him. United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker held him without bail.

After refusing medical treatment following a triple taxicab crash at Seventh Avenue and Forty-eighth Street late last night, Philip C. Rider a bond broker of 17 West Fifty-fourth Street, dropped dead as he was about to summon another taxi and continue on his way home.

Representative Andrew May of Kentucky, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, appealed in a letter to twenty-five "open-minded" Senators today to spike a $2,800,000 appropriation for starting construction of the Gilbertsville Dam in the Tennessee Valley to avoid, he said, "the useless expenditure of more than $112,000,000."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Brokaw of East Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Frances Brokaw, to Dr. William Blummer Clough Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. W. B. Clough of New London, N. H.

Calm was restored tonight in the town of Beaufort, from which inhabitants had fled in terror a few hours previously when air raid wardens warned them a dam holding back 200,000,000 cubic feet of water might burst.

Declaring that world peace depends upon international trade, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, yesterday praised the work of the government in "gradually proving to the world the benefits to be derived through proper and fair trade relations between countries."

Representatives of society and the field of sport filled the boxes and arena seats at the opening performance of Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue in Madison Square Garden last night, for the benefit of the Children's Village.

A trade which is expected to strengthen the New York Aniericans hockey team was concluded yesterday. Joe Lamb, who has been right wing for the star-spangled sextet for the last two years, was sent to Detroit in exchange for Johnny (Red) Beattie, former Boston Bruins captain, who joined the Red Wings this season. No cash was involved in the trade, according to the announcement.
The State Department has added seventy items today to the long list of products on which the United States will consider granting concessions when it negotiates a trade agreement with Great Britain.
John T. Creighton, vice president of City Bank Farmers Trust Company, was elected yesterday president of the Corporate Fiduciaries Association of New York at the annual meeting at 140 Broadway. Mr.

The following have been elected to membership in the Manhattan chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards: Ralph B. Brooks, William S. Norton, Gordon Wolkenberg, John A. Steinmetz, Vivian Green, Theodore Badman, J. Alfred D'Onofrio and Max Grenell.

More witnesses today before the Ways and Means Committee added their protests against the proposed new section to the Internal Revenue Law that would provide for a surtax on corporations closely held and earning a net income of more than $50,000, a part of which was undistributed.

W. R. Burwell of Cleveland, former president of Continental Shares, Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the investment trust paid dividends amounting to $325,000 on 10,000 "founders' shares," which cost their owners $1 each.

The war Department released the following orders today, dated Jan 22. McIlroy, Col. . G, Inf., Phlladelphia, Pa., to Omaha, Neb., for duty in connection with National Guard Affairs at Headquarters about March 1.

The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a plan of reorganization filed with it by the Genesee Valley Gas Company, a New York State Corporation, under the Public Utility Holding Company Act. It found, besides other objections, that the plan did not provide for simplification of the corporation's structure and that holders of old common stock whose securities have no equity value should not have been permitted to participate.

More than 75,000 persons are idle as a result of the longshoremen's strike, which entered its fourth week today, according to a statement sent to President Rooaevelt today by business groups, and the number is increasing daily.
" I know the need," Fred B. Snite Jr. told an international radio audience tonight as he made an appeal from his iron lung for support of' the Foundation for Prevention of Infantile Paralysis.
Forty-fourth annual convention of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association will open at Hotel Pennsylvania this morning 10 o'clock and continue tomorrow Thursday.

Mrs. Hona Furedy, 35 years old, wife of Edward S. Furedy, maitre d'hotel at Harvey's Restaurant, famous eating place for diplomats and legislators in Washington, committed suicide by drowning yesterday in a bathtub on the second floor of a rooming house at 150 St. John's Place, Brooklyn.
The Navy Department announced tonight that the President had approved the following recommendations of the selection board for promotion from lieutenant commander to commander:

The administration's plans for an antitrust drive have not been altered by the government's victory in its price-fixing case against sixteen major Midwest oil companies, it appeared from statements made today by Robert H. Jackson, head of the Department of Justice's antitrust division, after talking with President Roosevelt.

Lithuania has just established here a permanent delegation accredited to the League of Nations. That Lithuania should go to this expense now despite the widespread gloom about the League is taken to reflect a sharp increase in the fear of Poland's increasing coolness toward Geneva and her friendliness toward Berlin.

Mr. and Mrs. Baird H. Markham of New York and Oklahoma City have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jewel Marie Markham, to Joseph Farrington Connolly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Connolly of Oklahoma City. The marriage will take place here on the afternoon of Feb. 19 at the Markham home, 40 East Sixtysixth Street.
The Federal Miller-Tydings and State Fair Trade Acts ultimately will establish the cost price as the "floor" below which branded and trade-marked

World shipbuilding ended 1937 nearly back at its 1929 level, according to the League of Nations monthly statistics bulletin, issued today. In Japan the year ended far above the 1929 level with an index figure of 275, based on 100 for 1929.
Deaths in traffic accidents over the last week-end were two more than the number killed during the corresponding week-end of 1937, the weekly tables at Police Headquarters showed yesterday. From the

The body of a woman who was fatally injured Sunday night by an automobile was identified yesterday as that of Mrs. Diana Milder, 55 years old, of 755 Crown Street, Brooklyn. Identification was made by her son, Alexander Milder.

Baseball players dominated the qualifying round of the Miami Biltmore left-handers' golf tournament today, with Paul Waner, Pirates' outfielder, posting a 78 for medal honors. Waner, winner of the event for the last two years and winner of last week's baseball players' tournament at Sarasota, had on outgoing 38 and an incoming 40 over the par 71 course.

Excessive increases in taxes have caused the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to seek higher gas rates, Jackson A. Dyckman, counsel for the company, said yesterday at a hearing on the proposed rate increase before George R. Van Namee, Public Service Commissioner, in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

The city's street barkers, long familiar figures on busy corners in the midtown area, will go under strict regulation today. Under an ordinance passed last August by the Board of Aldermen each solicitor, sightseeing guide and lecturer must be licensed by the Department of Licenses.

Gross income of the Electric Bond and Share Company last year rose 14 per cent over 1936, and the surplus available for common dividends was equivalent to 42 cents a share, against 17 cents in the year before, according to the annual report made public yesterday. Expenses other than taxes fell 10 per cent and taxes rose 23 per cent.

The philanthropic activities of St. Timothy's League, Inc., will benefit from the performance of "Bachelor Born" on Thursday at the Morosco Theatre. The play opens tonight. Miss Nina Riker Van Vechten is a member of a committee of debutantes assisting with the benefit, this group including also the Misses Mary Jameson, Elise van Siclen, Edith Sawin, Sally Neilson and Eve Philips.

Delayed three days by adverse weather and a clogged fuel line, the China Clipper departed for the Orient at 3:25 P. M. [6:25 P. M. Eastern standard time] today with her original load of eight passengers and two new ones.

Further adoption of Roosevelt New Deal policies for the Philippines was indicated in Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon's message at the opening of the third and last session of the first Commonwealth Assembly.

The revival of "Salome," the third opera in the Richard Strauss cycle; the season's first performance of "Coq d'Or," the opening of the matinee Wagner cycle, the first performance in the opera season of Stravinsky's ballet, "Apollon Musagete," and the debut of Maxine Stellman, American soprano, in the main season will mark next week at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Samuel S. Stovin, real estate dealer and insurance agent here for fifty years, died today at Grace Hospital following an operation. He was born in Kiev, Russia, 67 years ago. Surviving are two sons, Dr. Joseph Stovin of New York and Louis S. of this city, and a daughter, Mrs. Edward Goldenberg of Bridgeport.
More than 200 members of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences opened a four-day session yesterday in the Pupin Physics Laboratories at Columbia University, to consider advances in the air.

A highly interesting example of modern architecture's adaptation to natural surroundings (and in this ease one of the most novel and intricate adaptations on record) is furnished by an exhibition that opens to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street. It contains

Dr. Morrix Flshbein rose before the Medical Society of the County of New York last evening to place the recently published national health survey in its proper light and to reveal how the American Medical Association, of whose Journal he is the editor, is meeting'the problem of caring for the medically indigent.

Captain L. Haywood Cook, last of the Georges Banks fishing captains, died late yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Joseph Lawrence Townsend, at Townsend Manor Inn. His age was 82. Captain Cook was born in Huntington, L. I. and went to sea when 14 years old. At the age of 21 he was master

The Kings County Criminal Bar Association unanimously went on record last night in favor of a new single municipal criminal court after listening to an appeal for its support by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Moose Hall, 482 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.

" It might be argued,"says President Conant of Harvard University in his annual report published yesterday, that even if the instruction in the university suffered from the influx of students, with a consequent loss in important qualities through expansion, "the advantages to the community of producing each year a greater number of university men would more than compensate for the disadvantages."

Justices Burlingame, McDonald and Doyle of Special Sessions unanimously acquitted yesterday suspended Patrolman Harry Lichtblau of 1,205 Avenue R, Brooklyn, and Dr. Nathan Silverstein, a dentist, of 250 Grand Street, on an "information"

All officers of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York were re-elected last night at the annual meeting of the board of directors of the association. Those who will succeed themselves are president Richard W. Lawrence;

Warning that those "who have the most to lose should do the most to serve and to preserve," Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, speaking at the annual dinner of the chamber of commerce tonight, rested the fate of American democracy with its business leaders and their shareholders.

J. W. Seligman Co., private bankers, received a one-quarter participation in 275,000 shares of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway common stock held by Speyer Co., also private bankers, just two days before the directors of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway voted to buy two-thirds of this block, according to evidence taken yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente.

The controversy precipitated last week between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the architects and legislators concerned with plans for the State's participation in the New York World's Fair ended yesterday in an agreement to keep the cost within the original $1,600,000 appropriation.

Mayor La Guardia and Colonel Somervell of WPA, have submitted to President Roosevelt a public works program calling for an expenditure of $180,000,000 in this city. This large sum would be used principally to build new schools, to increase hospital facilities and to construct streets, highways, sewers and other designated projects.
Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but

The United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union yesterday sent a demand to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in session at Miami, Fla., that the A. F. of L. take "appropriate measures in defense of American labor threatened by the indiscriminate dumping of Japanese goods."

The ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with "Traviata," sung to a capacity house. Eide Norena was the Violetta in her first appearance of the season, Bruno Tandi was the! Alfredo and Lawrence Tibbett the Germont. Mr. Tibbett stood out in
Conditions in Nanking under Japanese rule remain lawless and scandalous, according to advices reaching Shanghai yesterday, and foreigners, except diplomats, are still barred from the city.

A fifteen-story structure to be known as The Associated Press Building will be erected immediately in the north block of Rockefeller Center. Plans for the new Rockefeller unit were revealed yesterday when The Associated Press, known as the world's largest cooperative news ar.d picture-gathering organization,

Duties amounting to $37,895,092 were collected on imported wines and spirits in the first eleven months of 1937, compared with $35,205,653 in the corresponding period of 1936, James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs, announced today. Of these

Mrs. E. K. Guttman, president of the Hudson County Branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, said here tonight that she and other officers of the organization had tried unsuccessfully to rent a hall in Jersey City for an address by Miss Dorothy Thompson, newspaper commentator on public affairs, who recently has criticized the policies of Mayor Frank Hague.

An Italian squadron led by 20-year-old Bruno Mussolini rested here tonight after a 2,500mile journey from Rome-the first leg of a propaganda and experimental flight across the Atlantic to Rio de Janeiro.

Employes participating in the Pacific Greyhound Lines seven-State election, to be held on or before Feb. 4, mazy choose to be represented for, purposes of collective bargaining either by the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, an affiliate of the A. F.

General Han Fu-chu, 47-year-old former Shantung Governor and commander of the Third Route Army, was executed here by a firing squad this for evening. He had been found guilty by a military tribunal of having disobeyed orders and having abused his power as Governor of his province.

Admiral R. R. Waesche, Coast Guard commandant, urged the House Merchant Marine Committee today to approve Coast Guard training for merchant seamen. The proposal, which the Maritime Commission advanced last year,

Amendments to the bill introduced in Congress by Senator Francis T. Maloney of Connecticut, providing for self-regulation of the over-thecounter securities market, are to be suggested by the Investment Bankers Conference as the result of a meeting of its governing committee and advisory council here yesterday.
The long-expected Cabinet reconstruction occurred today following the acceptance of the resignation of Minister of War General Christo Loukoff and Minister of Interior Krasnovski.
Captain Robert B. Irving, commander of the liner Queen Mary, was appointed commodore of the Cunard-White Star fleet today, succeeding Commodore Reginald V. Peel, who retired in December.

Arguments were begun today before the three-member Federal commission which heard testimony in the Tennessee Valley Authority's condemnation suit against the mineral and marble holdings of Senator George L. Berry and others in the Norris dam reservoir.

Arthur Dunham, one of Chicago's leading organists, died today in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 62. His home was at 5,806 Harper Avenue. It was in the First Methodist Temple that Mr. Dunham achieved much of his recent fame as an organist. When the skyscraper church

Dr. Arthur D. Houghton, former City Councilman and a founder of the American Legion, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 66. He also was a botanist and a politician.

Senna L. Bannon of 47 East Eighty-first Street, who died on Jan. 15, last, named the Institution of Mercy, 1,075 Madison Avenue, as her residuary legatee in her will filed for probate yesterday. The bequest was valued in the petition at about $7,500.

Decision to take up anew the thirtysix-year-old fight for uniform marriage and divorce laws was reached today at the opening session of the executive committee, conference of commissioners on uniform State laws of the American Bar Association.

The election of Elisha Walker as chairman of the board of directors of the Beekman Street Hospital will be ratified at the annual meeting of the board tomorrow at the Bankers Club. He succeeds Marshall Field.

An attack on Mrs. Frances Walla of Islip late last night led to the arrest early today of George Corbett Jr., 24 years old, of Merrick Road, Islip, on a charge of second-degree assault. He waived examination and was held without bail for the grand jury by Justice John T. Kube

Production of mens and youth's suits made wholly or partly of wool during the four weeks ended Nov. 27, 1937, totaled 562,541 garments, compared with 996,212 in the four weeks ended Oct. 30, according to figures just

William J. Graham and James C.
