McKay, Reno, Nev., gamblers, who had twice won jury disagreements, went on trial yesterday for a third time in Federal Court on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy, growing out of the operations of a ring of confidence men that was alleged to have swindled seventy victims of $2,500,000.
Alan R. Sweezey, Harvard economics instructor who received a twoyear "concluding appointment" last Spring, resigned today, effective in September. He an4 Dr. J.

A 13-year-old girl and a 12-yearold boy were announced by the Board of Education as the winners of the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Scholarship prizes, awarded semiannually to two graduating Manhattan elementary school pupils, who have achieved high records in spite of physical handicaps or other serious obstacles.

M. Leonard Wertheimer of Birmingham, Ala., was elected president of the National Burlap Bag Dealers Association at the opening session of its annual meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday. He succeeds Robert Harris of Buffalo.

Peter James McGuinness, Register of Kings County, has instituted legal action to compel Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to approve the payment to him of about $9,000 deducted in pay cuts from his 1936 and 1937 salaries as Sheriff of Kings County.
Captain Adrian Jones, designer and sculptor of some of London's best known equestrian statues, died at his home in Chelsea today after a long illness. His age was 92.

Federal Judge William Clark directed the removal to Sing Sing prison today of Harry Weiss and Martin Schlossman, defendants with Ellis Parker Sr., Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis. Parker Jr., on a Federal indictment charging conspiracy to kidnap Paul H. Wendel.

Friendly talks from time to time in London and Geneva between Mr. de Valera and Mr. Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, led the former to propose the I conference of representatives of the Governments of Eire and Great Brit- t ain. No agenda were prepared for the meeting, as though it would be infor- I mal and not formal.

WORD came that Jim Mutrie had died, and a group soon gathered around Smiling Mickey Welch, who was a star pitcher of the Giants in the days when Jim Mutrie was their manager shouting in the face of friend and enemy his famous slogan: "We Are the People!"

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that farmers received $8,521,000,000 from the sales of their principal products and in government benefit payments last year, as compared with their 1936 cash income of $7,920,000,000.

Eugene Arnett, who reputedly spent two decades and part of a million-dollar insurance fortune seeking a formula for a race of "supermen," died yesterday at the age of 62. Mr. Arnett once termed himself "years ahead of time." "I have no hope that the work I'm doing now will be accepted during my lifetime," he said, "but it will benefit future generations."

State Trooper Benjamin Dean, assigned tonight to cover a highway fatality at Five Points, near here, discovered that the victim was his sisterin-law, Mrs. Mary Dean, 22 years old, of 428 Grape Street, Vineland. She was a passenger in a truck operated by Albert Jiampetti, 23, of Egg Harbor City, when it skidded into a fence. Jiampetti was hurt seriously.

A remark by General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday in again postponing sentence on Charles Falci, middle-aged former Tammany election inspector in the Second Assembly District West under Albert Marinelli,
Resolutions supporting national wage and hour legislation and favoring a provision which would standardize for any given market area the wage and hour provisions of any labor contract which already

" MR. WITT AMONG THE REBELS,"* the fourth of Ramon Sender's books to be published in this country ("Pro Patria," "Counter-Attack in Spain" and "Seven Red Sundays" were the others), is a muted and oddly pitched story of a Victorian Englishman who happens to take part in a Spanish revolution.

Will C. Headley, former Mayor of Irvington, N. J., and one of the oldest practicing lawyers in New Jersey, died today at his home here. Mr. Headley, who was 84, was a lawyer in Newark sixty-one years. He had lived here since 1919.

Memorial services were held by the Rockland County Bar Association in the Supreme Court chambers here today for Arthur S. Tompkins, State Supreme Court Justice for twenty-nine years. More than 400 jurists, lawyers, county officials and court house attendants were present. Mrs. Tompkins, Miss

President Roosevelt was represented today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as being amenable to the latter's suggestion that the membership of the RFC board be reduced from seven to five "in the interests of economy." Mr. Jones disclosed

-Recess appointments to the State Labor Relations Board and the State Board of Mediation were sent by Governor Lehman to the Senate tonight for confirmation. Referred tq the Finance Committee, the names were:

In the opinions of two lower Federal courts last week the government (1) may legally destroy investments in the private power companies in the Tennessee Valley if it so desires; and (2) producers can be sent to prison for making a trade combination on the urgence of one branch of the government if another branch, the Department of Justice, wants to send them there.

Turpentine quiet, 30%c; sales, none; receipts. 63 barrels: shipments, 45 barrels; stock, 28,914 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 433 barrels: receipts, 895 barrels; shipments, 297 barrels; stock, 73.945 barrels.
Mucho Gusto, winner of two longer races at Tropical Park before he ran out of the money in the six-furlong Hialeah Inaugural Handicap, regained his winning stride at Hialeah Park today.

The failure Trad of the Soviet Government to permit American Consular officials here, despite the recognition agreement, to see Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens, now under arrest in a Soviet prison, has given rise to the general belief that such permission may be long delayed.

It is becoming the custom to give series of concerts of music by a single composer. Often such series meet with popular response. Thus a large audience gathered last night when Alexander Brailowsky gave the first of a cycle of six Chopin programs in Town Hall.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended Jan. 20 was 338, the highest since Nov. 9, 1933, and comparing with 265 in the week previous and 163 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Newark, N. J., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $9,201,100 of 8 per cent first and refunding bonds due in 2037 to be used in exchange on a par for par basis for the outstanding capital stock of the South Jersey Gas, Electric and Traction Company, The Essex and Hudson Gas Company and The Hudson County Gas Company.

Willie Hoppe, veteran New York cue expert, who has held practically every major billiard crown at one time or another, will leave for Havana Friday to play for the threecushion championship of Cuba. Companion, the Cuban titleholder, will be Hoppe's opponent in a 150point match there on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday next week.

Pinchot Gaston, who left a fashionable school fifteen years ago for a career on the stage, was found dead at 7:50 A. M. today in the front seat of her car, the engine of which she had started in the closed garage on her rented estate to asphyxiate herself.

The fire that destroyed the Soviet Embassy here on Sunday evening started only a few hours before the new Soviet Ambassador, Ivan Luganets-Orelsky, presented his credentials to President Lin Sen of Chungking.

The National Maritime Union has been selected as bargaining agent for the unlicensed personnel of the thirty-two ships operated by the United Fruit Company, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board. The election was

Delegates from forty national organizations with an aggregate member. ship of more than 2,000,000 women began arriving here today for the thirteenth Conference on National Defense, which will open tomorrow.

The annual report of the State Law Revision Commission, submitted to the Legislature tonight, outlines a program of clarification and condensation of statutes which has been initiated by the commission.

George Denneny of the law department of the United States Steel Corporation died Sunday night in St. Luke's Hospital following an operation. He was 53 years old. Born on May 19, 1885, at Eckley, Pa., Mr. Denneny was graduated from Fordham University in 1910, and from Fordham Law School four years later. He joined the United

Continued price reductions, as stimulants to declining volume in periods of business recession, frequently force down wage levels and create unemployment, Paul Ryan, president of Ryan, Leach Goode, sales counsellors, declared yesterday at the luncheon session of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt. Mr. Ryan

Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. said at his press conference this afternoon that the recent duty increase on United States imports into Mexico would not interfere with the Treas ury's understanding with Mexico regarding purchases of silver.

Declaring that Senator Glass, who was quoted as pleading that he is weary of the world, is an example of the attitude that the conservative element of the United States must abandon if it is to survive.

Consolidated operating income of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and affiliates, for 1937, amounted to $4,055,888, George F. Rand, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

Italy was disclosed today to have sold Venezuela two cruisers in what shipping circles said was part of a projected deal whereby Italy would provide the South American country with naval and mercantile vessels in return for crude oil.

Organized medicine in this country is now actively engaged in mobilizing State and county medical societies to determine medical service needs throughout the country and to use available facilities to meet those needs, Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, de-

Charles Lynch, well-known boxing official, who was one of the two judges at the Braddock-Farr heavyweight fight on Friday night, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while walking with his wife along Broadway between Fortyseventh and Forty-eighth Streets. He was 46 years old and lived at 2,280 Grand Avenue, the Bronx.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Justice Shientag is reported in THE TIMES as recommending an inquiry on enforcement problems in the FeldCrawford Fair Trade Act. He says, "Experience may show the need for amendments to the statute or the necessity for the creation of an administrative agency charged with its enforcements."

Dean Detton, 215, Salt Lake City, was declared the winner over Sammy Stein, 210, New York, last night after 1:09:17 at the New York Hippodrome before a crowd of 2,500 persons when Stein requested Referee George Bothner to halt the contest.

Henry Picard today won the $3,000 Pasadena open golf tournament with a score of 276, eight strokes under par for seventy-two holes. Outshooting Jimmy Hines, Garden City, N. Y., his nearest rival, by two strokes, the Hershey, Pa., star marched through today's final eighteen holes with a 69 for the par-71 course at Brookside Park.

Miss Leonie Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Parmelee Williams Jr. of Waterbury, will be married to John Ogden White, also of this city, on the afternoon of Feb. 11 in the First Congregational Church. The pastor, the Rev. Dr.
A new shell embodying the latest principles of marine design will be added to Manhattan's rowing cu equipment this Spring, Coach Allen Walz disclosed yesterday.

Maximilian Morgenthau Jr. of 136 West Seventy-fifth Street, who had been engaged in the real estate and mortgage business in this city for the last forty years, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of bronchial pneumonia. He was 59 years old.

John Milton, Jersey City lawyer, took the oath as Senator from New Jersey today with no objection raised in the Senate, although labor critics filed protests charging that he was the "alter ego" of Mayor Frank Hague and "unfit" for the office.

While the bill amending the National Housing Act awaits action by the Senate after having been adopted by the House, home builders in all parts of the country are debating the possible effects of passage of the measure.

A parish luncheon, under the auspices of the Junior Guild, in cooperation with the Women's Auxiliary, the Parents' Guild and the Altar Guild, will take place today in the parish house of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.

Union Ave (10-2677), e s, 298 ft n of 161st St, 37x100; also Union Ave, e s, 246 it n of 161st St, 37x100; Anna Hantman to Ethel Morrison, 1,282 Stebbins Ave.

The following members shall be directed to report at the Fire Hazard Inspectors School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 1:15 P. M. on the dates specified: Groups 1 or 10-Elimination System: Jan. 28, Feb. 7, 15, 25; March 7, 17, 28; April 7:

Mrs. Dorothy Cowan of 1,848 West Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday became the first woman to express reluctance to serve on a jury in a criminal case in the Kings County Court. While being questioned as a prospective juror, she said she did not want to serve in any case where she might have to send a person to prison.

The United- States women's table tennis team, defending the world championship and the Corbillon Cup, lost two of its first three matches today but the American men scored three straight victories in defense of their world title.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan 23, unless specified: At Pearl Harbor Yard: Barry, Childs, Gilmer, Hopkins, Williamson. At San Pedro: Grebe, Jan. 22; Tennessee. Charleston Yard to Yorktown, Jan. 24; Hatfield, Kane.

Visual appeal is of primary importance in the success of an advertising message, Heyworth Campbell, art director of Photoplay Magazine, told the class in advertising conducted by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., last night at THE NEW YORK TIMES club room.

Humphrey J. Lynch, former New York Supreme Court justice, died of a heart ailment in a hospital here today at the age of 56. He had been ill three days. His wife, Mrs. Gertrude Lynch, was at his bedside when he died.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Bossert of 50 West Ninth Street have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Natalie Taylor Bossert, to John Gildersleeve Heermans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Heermans of Brooklyn, which took place on Saturday in the manse of the Ocean Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George M. Miller. Mr. and Mrs. Heermans will reside in New York.
The executive council of the American Federation of Labor opened its quarterly meeting here today, with action against the Committee for Industrial Organization uppermost in the minds of its members.
Dr. Jan de Groot, who is attending Crown Princess Jullana, who to expecting the birth of a child, left Soestdijk for a few hours this afternoon.

Deposits in the first 100 banks in the United States in 1937 showed a decline of approximately $2,000,000,000, it is revealed in the annual rollcall of the 300 largest banks in the country published today by the American Banker. A somewhat

A picture of the nation trying to spend ts way to happiness and prosperity but, instead; "blundering" on toward the destruction of representative government was etched by John R. McCarl tonight in an address before members of Ad-Sell League and their guests.

Assets of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia increased $15,670,000 in 1937 to $331,214,000, the highest in the history of the company, M. A. Linton, president, made known to policyholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

The verdict against the oil companies in the Madison case once more sharply emphasizes the inconsistencies and reversals in the Government's trust policies. Sixteen major oil companies and thirty executives have been convicted in Wisconsin by a jury of farmers and small-town business men of criminal conspiracy to raise and fix gasoline prices.

More than 500 civic leaders and settlement-house workers gave a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night for Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, and presented a gold medal to him in token of his many years' active work in the settlement-house field.
Attorney General Cummings said today that the crime situation in the capital "amounts to a national disgrace."

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 32,000, Including 11,000 directs. The market was mostly strong to 10c higher than Friday's average. Top, $8.80; bulk, 150-200 lbs., $8.60-.75: 210-250 lbs., $8.00-.50; 260-350 lbs., 57.35-$8. Packing sows steady to 10c higher; most good 375500 lb. offerings, $6.60-.85; few upward to S7. Shippers, 5,000; estimated holdover ??

Stocks closed firm and mixed in smallest turnover since August and narrowest trading in more than two years; turnover, 537,130 shares. Japanese loans higher, other bonds irregularly lower in second slowest trading of this year; transactions, $5,219,350.

The annual statement of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, sent to stockholders yesterday by James Lee Loomis, president, shows that total assets on Dec. 31, 1937, reached a high record. At $312,233,793, they compared with $291,429,494 reported a year earlier. Total income last year increased 5.4 per cent to $58,618,879 from $55,626,964. Surplus amounted to $11,100,987, against $10,858,887.

Greenwich St, 332, 25x58; Lillian E..Hingslage and Elizabeth A. Ficken to Marine Midland Trust Co of New York, 120 Broadway: equal lien with mtg, $27,000; due on demand 5 per cent; $4,565. 136th St, 243 W. 17x99.11: Dickle F. Caffey to Grace Albright, 78 Rochester Ave, Long Beach, N. Y.; pr mtg; 3 years 6 per cent; $2,500.
A brief truce between railroad operators and shippers began today when . the Interstate Commerce Commission concluded hearings on the proposed 15 per cent increase in railroad freight rates.

Reports from Tokyo that Japan, as the first step toward withdrawal from the International Labor Organization, would not be represented at the next I. L. O. session drew an explanation today from Juitsu Kitaoka, i Japan's permanent I. L. O. delegate here.
Many persons prominent in the social and political life of the city are expected to attend the annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club on Feb. 2 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Hopes for peaceful "world conditions" were expressed in verse by Emperor Hirohito in his contribution to the annual imperial New Year poetry contest, published today. The theme was "Morning in a Shrine Garden," and the Emperor's poem was:

The stock market here was quiet and somewhat weaker today. Gilt-edged issues were firm, while among the foreign bonds German loans did well. Transatlantic stocks reflected the lower prices in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel lost ground.

MANHATTAN BEECHER, ISADORE G. (Sept. 17, 1937). Gross assets, $4,160: net, $2,917. To Lilly Wise, two-thirds of residue; Leo Wise, jewelry and one-third of residue; several specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $2,636. Moses Altman, 20 W 43d St.

Transit unification came to the fore tonight, as another Democratic attempt was made to obtain an investigation of the Seabury-Berle transit plan, and as a Republican supporter of Mayor La Guardia pressed his resolution to abolish the Transit Commission entirely.

A plea for reduction in government expenditures was made on the floor of the House today by Representative Woodrum, chairman of the subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee which drew up the appropriation measures for the present session.

Mayor Robert R. Williams and two other city commissioners, John Du Bose and Dr. Ralph B. Ferguson, and a special rate expert, Thomas E. Grady, were indicted today on charges of soliciting a bribe from the Florida Power and Light Company.

Alvaro M. Garcia of Garcia y Vega has been elected president of the newly organized- Cigar Manufacturers Association of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Other officers elected are Thomas C. Breen, Congress Cigar Company, Inc., treasurer, and Samuel Blum-berg, general counsel of the- association, secretary.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman headed a large group of honorary pallbearers today at the funeral of Henry F. Lutz, State Director of Parks, at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East Eighty-eighth Street. Mr. Lutz died last Friday in Albany.

John Winthrop Auchincloss, member of an old New York family and a former director in many corporations, died yesterday at his home, 1,115 Fifth Avenue. He was 84 years old. A native of New York, Mr. Auchincloss was prominent for many years in the business and social life of this city. He retired

From the road, which has liked it, there comes tonight the comedy called "Bachelor Born," the same being adapted by Ian Hay from his own novel of that name. First known as "The Housemaster," the play employs Frederick Leister, Peggy Simpson, Aubrey Mather, Phoebe Foster, Lester Lonergan 3d and others, with Mr. Leister directing. The Morosco Theatre receives

Bay City Holding Company sold to Public Realty the four-story flat at 44-46 West Thirty-third Street, Bayonne, mortgaged at $76,000, and the two four-story brick flats at 160-162 Avenue C, subject to mortgages totaling $90,000.

Norman T. Whitaker of Washington has filed a $500,000 libel suit in Federal court here against Macfadden Publications, Inc., of Dunellen, it was disclosed today, as a result of a series of articles growing out of the Lindbergh kidnapping case. Summons has been served on Haydock H. Miller, vice president of the company, with answer to the complaint due by Thursday.

The ten-room house at 56 Ellwood Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, was sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to James G. Ranni. It is on a plot 106 by 110 feet. Harry Levy, broker, negotiated the deal.

The State of Massachusetts began yesterday to present testimony before John S. Flannery, special master for the United States Supreme Court, in its attempt to establish that Colonel Edward H. R. Green was a Massachusetts resident and collect $6,000,000 inheritance tax on his $40,000,000 estate.

Japanese bombers made their first attack this morning on Ichang, 165 miles west of Hankowfar in the interior of China. The Chinese airfield and the waterfront area were reported to have been attacked.
The international stock market indices for Jan. 22, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

A nominal easing took place in automobile production last week, but the decline was smaller than seasonal and the adjusted index advanced to 70.0 from 68.3. The figure for the week ended Jan. 23, 1937, was 87.1.

The London Daily Mail today says that Russia's Far Eastern coast facing Japan has been placed on a wartime footing with the construction of new air and naval bases. In addition, the paper asserts, Leningrad is being converted into a gigantic secret naval dockyard and arsenal.

The Census Bureau reported today that flaxseed crushed in the three months ended on Dec. 31 amounted to 217,114 tons, compared with 194,071 in the corresponding period of 1936. Linseed oil produced amounted to 150,431,644 gallons, against 131,898,873.
Pernambuco State officials tonight disclosed that 140 members of a rebellious religious sect, worshipers of the horse-god Trancelim, were killed in a backwoods battle with Brazilian police.

A bridge and tea will be given in the parish house of St. James Church tomorrow afternoon in aid of the new parish house, on which construction will begin within a few weeks. More than 600 persons are expected to attend.

A policy of peaceful cooperation by the United States with other countries rather than one of isolation war recommended to the triennial convention of the National Council of Jewish Women today as the best means of promoting world peace.

MR. WITT AMONG THE REBELS, by Ramon J. Sender. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) A novel about the Spanish revolt of 1873. STRONG MAN OF CHINA, by Robert Berkov. (Houghton Mifflin, $3.) A biography of Chiang Kaishek.
A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,240,000 of refunding bonds of the city of Pittsburgh, Pa., on a
Farm Bill conferees agreed today to make government loans mandatory on corn, wheat and cotton under the ever-normal granary program, whenever prices of these crops drop below fixed levels.

A $5,000,000 check for the New York State unemployment insurance account was received today by Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, from the United States Treasury. It was the first amount to be received from the Federal Government for unemployment insurance purposes.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, national champion, led the field into the quarter-finals of the seventh annual women's New York State squash racquets championship as two rounds were completed on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club today. Thirty-two started in the competition.

The Southern rail carriers petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a reconsideration of its decision of last week which in effect lowers the freight rates on automobiles for export moving through the Port of New York.

As a result of growing demand by automotive dealers to have the annual auto show switched back to January, the Automobile Manufacturers Association is polling its members on their desires and expects to have a tabulated response ready by the second week in February, it was learned here yesterday.

Operations in the steel industry for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 32.7 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents an increase of 2.9 points, or 9.7 per cent, over the rate of 29.8 per cent in the previous week. The current rate is

Miss Margaret Ruth Adams, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Perry of this place and the late Mason Tyler Adams of Waterbury, Conn., will be married here to Dr. William L. Peltz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. L. Peltz of Albany, N. Y., on Saturday afternoon in the Phillips-Exeter Academy chapel.

Coffee, the mainstay of Brazil's prosperity, is due to re-enter the news spotlight. There arrived here today two representatives from El Salvador to be joined later by representatives of other coffee countries. Back of this lies the hope of an arrangement among these nations to place coffee prices where they will insure growers a profit in a market free from price cutting.

Few visiting foreign missionas to Moscow have called forth more interest than that of Sun Fo, president of the Chinese Legislative Council, and his distinguished associates, and few, if any, have been surrounded by such complete mystery.

A. G. Spalding Bros. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 a net loss of $310,866 after depreciation, amortization, interest, taxes and other charges. In the preceding fiscal year the company had a net loss of $912,392.

Mars Joe McCarthy, who, if you should happen to have forgotten the matter since the last world series, is actually the manager of the Yankees and the guiding genius that makes the world champions function so smoothly on a ball field, emerged quietly from his retreat in Buffalo yesterday for his annual mid-Winter visit to New York.

A net profit of $4,340,348 for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was reported yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiaries. The profit includes $2,125,000 non-recurring income received from license and patent settlements and is after deductions for depreciation and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed earnings. After dividend require-

Support for the Vandenberg resolution asking a Congressional investigation to determine the merits of profit-sharing systems was voiced tonight by Majority Leader Ives in the Assembly. He introduced a resolution memoralizing Congress to adopt the Vandenberg idea.

Five Jewish business men were sentenced to long terms of imprisonment and heavy fines today for violation of the foreign exchange laws. They were accused of having organized the transfer of Jewish emigrants' funds through export in violation of the strict control laws and in collaboration with agents of Julius Barmat, who died recently in a Belgian prison.

Outstanding amateurs and professionals, including Kenneth Chantler, Montreal pro, will compete in the first open invitation racquets tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup, starting today at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
The fates that have doomed the largest ship ever to fly the American flag to a Scottish "boneyard" relented yesterday to the extent of guaranteeing her two weeks' grace.

Irene Murray, 29 years old, of 524 West 162d Street, a WPA social service investigator for the Correction Department for the last six months, yesterday was arrested in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office for the alleged "shakedown" of $51 from the mother of a penitentiary prisoner under the pretext she would obtain special privileges for the son, who was ill.

Opposition to further artificial stimulation of business, a plea for postponement of further reforms of business and confidence that, given the right conditions, recovery from the current depression can come quickly were voiced yesterday by speakers before the tenth annual midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association, held in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank, 33 Liberty Street.

Winning its first game in two starts, the Peddie School hockey team defeated Newman School, 9--0, today. Ray Milici was outstanding for the winning team, scoring twice unassisted and having four assists. Woody Goble and Dick Harding of Peddie also scored twice.

J. Phil Berman, New York advertising man, who was cited by the War Department as "one of the world's foremost salesmen" in disposing of surplus government supplies after the World War, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 65.
Greeted by a thunderous ovation, Sonja Henie came back to New York last night as the star of the latest figure-skating show to be presented at Madison Square Garden, the Hollywood Ice Revue.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the authorized $25-par-value stock of the Commonwealth Edison Company. G. W. Goodwin has joined Paine, Webber . Co.

A. A. Berle Jr., former City Chamberlain of New York and a leading member of President Roosevelt's original Brain Trust, was prominently mentioned today as the probable selection for assistant secretary of state to succeed Hugh R. Wilson, recently appointed Ambassador to Germany.
Oliver Stanley, President of the Board of Trade, insisted in a speech at Liverpool today that the pending Anglo-American trade agreement was not political but mainly commercial in motive.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $778,000 to repair equipment.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Deep Rock Oil Company and Beaver Valley Traction Company, in receivership, for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $3,763,976 after all expenses and charges.

Wall Street comment last night on the new regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission for short selling centered upon the fact that, by making the change itself and not through the facilities of the Exchanges, as in the past, the commission has made the general public as responsible as the brokerage community for its enforcement.

Never in the history of the turf has a year's outlook been more promising than that Which we envisage for 1938. Last year closed with a record showing the turf to have attained greater prosperity than ever before. This result was attained by greater attendance, larger gate receipts, greater distribution to horsemen, greater State tax receipts,

President Roosevelt conferred with Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, and Benjamin V. Cohen on the Administration's anti-monopoly policy, discussed with Jesse H. Jones the latter's proposal to limit the membership on the RFC board to five members, and worked on his naval message to Congress.
The Bombay Stock Exchange, which closed abruptly on Saturday because of a swift decline in prices, remained shut today and its directors were understood to favor suspension until the end of February.

As agent for various individual and institutional investors, the Mortgagees Realty Service, the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company of Brooklyn, has just sold seventeen properties in Brooklyn and on Long Island.
The Administration is preparing a bill for the liquidation of bank holding companies, to be introduced by Senator Glass of Virginia.

Colonel Lewis Walker, who rose to wealth as the head of a vast industrial concern which manufactures hookless fasteners, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 82 years old. Colonel Walker developed the hookless fastener, used in articles of wearing apparel from overshoes to lingerie, into a product which has a world-wide market after discovering the invention at the World's Fair in Chicago in 1893.
On the eve of a related hearing in Washington, the government served notice today that it was continuing an investigation of automobile financing methods.

Several residential parcels figured in the Manhattan and Bronx realty transactions announced yesterday. Donbert Estates, Inc., John P. Finneran, president, has bought the nine-story and penthouse apartment at 106-10 East Eighty-fifth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Higgins 2d gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Marguerite Brokaw and Dr. Charles Crocker, who will be married on Thursday. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Reynolds, Mr. and Mrs. William L. Burton 2d, the Misses Elmina Brewster, Virginia Sinclair and Edna Brokaw; Marshall Sewall, Charles Means and Gordon Tevis.

Building construction projects filed with the Department of Buildings yesterday included plans for a six-story apartment building, to rise on a plot 168 by 82 feet on the southwest corner of Cambridge Avenue and 236th Street, in the Bronx, at a cost estimated at $325,000.
A bill making it unlawful for an, employer to discriminate against any prospective employe because of racial or religious ties was introduced tonight by Assemblyman Crews, Brooklyn Republican.

Wall Street gave yesterday a convincing performance of being bored with it all. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was only 540,000 shares, recording the smallest turnover for a full day since Aug. 31, when 503,710 shares changed hands. At the same time, the market was the narrowest since April 1, 1935, when 610 issues were traded, against 626 yesterday. So

Mrs. Benjamin F. Tillson of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Tillson, to Dr. James Alonzo Taylor of Davenport, Iowa, which took place on Jan. 4 at Cumberland, Md.

Miss Doris Lane Laidlaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Laidlaw of 270 Park Avenue, has completed plans for her marriage to William Edward Dillmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dillmeier of Garden City, L. I., which will take place on Feb. 9 in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Police Commissioner Valentine took another step yesterday in his preparation for concerted action to rid New York City of vice and gambling with the assignment of the fifty top-rankng patrolmen in the department for special training at the police academy in Brooklyn.

Government control of the sale of gasoline in Cuba has been recommended to the Cuban Legislature by the country's President. This follows a report by an investigatory body that gasoline companies in Cuba were working in conjunction to effect a virtual monopoly in the sale of refined petroleum products, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Havaena made public today.

A decree increasing the wages of all private employes in this country receiving 500 sucres a month or less was signed today by President Alberto Enriquez. Employes receiving- 300 sucres a month or less get an increase of 15 per cent and those over 300 sucres and up to 500 sucres get a 10 per cent increase.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following prospective graduates of the R. 0. T. C., University of Delaware, Newark, Delaware, is-assigned to Second Coast Artillery District, effective upon acceptance of appointment in-the Officers' Reserve Corps, as second lieutenant, Coast Artillery Corps Reserve:

Edward Holt Gurney, engineer and industrialist of Toronto, was elected president of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers yesterday at the second session of the forty-fourth annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore.

Stanley F. Reed, Solicitor General, was confirmed quickly today by the Senate as associate justice of the Supreme Court to follow Justice Sutherland. As soon as the Senate met, Vice President Garner submitted the nomination, which was immediately ratified without discussion or dissenting vote.

The payrolls of milk companies for December increased 5.3 per cent over the same period in 1936, although employment decreased 1 per cent, according to a report issued yesterday by the Milk Industry Foundation.

Ground was broken today for a new $800,000 high school, a PWA project for which the Federal Government will advance $360,000. The site adjoins the grounds of the present school, an old frame building at Doscris Lane and Forest Avenue.

The International Agricultural Corporation has sold phosphate rock lands in Tennessee to the Tennessee Valley Authority for a net profit of $527,185, John J. Watson, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting here.
The British freighter Pencarrow radioed an appeal for assistance early this morning, reporting that her propeller was damaged and that she was drifting in ballast in...

Four Judges wandered about at the Treasury Procurement Division offices today among tables laden with several hundred plaster casts. They scribbled notes, preparatory to awarding a $46,500 commission for two sculptures for the new Apex Building.

Thomas Moore's melancholy verses-- I feel like one Who treads alone Some banquet hall deserted; Whose lights are fled, Whose garlands dead And all but he departed are nowhere more applicable than to that little band of Englishmen, Scotchmen and Americans who are now taking the old liner Leviathan, once the queen of the Western oceans, on her last crossing.

A New York syndicate organized by,Frank E. Holmes has bought a vacant plot fronting 275 feet on the north side of Ninety-fourth Avenue, east of Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, through Laurence Adikes and Joseph P. Day, co-brokers.

Al Roth, sterling Bronx lightweight, finished the victor over rugged Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., last night at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, where their ring feud was renewed before 14,000 fans.

Employes over forty years of age are happier in their jobs than those under forty, according to the findings of a survey issued yesterday by Charles C. Stech, consumer research and labor relations specialist.
The Supreme Court at Leipzig today interpreted the Nuremberg law forbidding the employment by Jews of non-Jewish women who are under 45 years old to include the following work:
Share prices again drifted lower yesterday and trading was further diminished. Losses ranged from fractions to 2 points, and in a few instances the setbacks were greater.

What was known in London as "Housemaster" becomes "Bachelor Born" at the Morosco, where it opened last evening. But the deplorable romanticism contained in that shifting of interests should not discourage the theatregoer who likes amiable plays.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Helen Boynton Wells of St. Louis, widow of Lloyd P. Wells of that city, to J. Lester Parsons of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., which took place in this city last Saturday.

Mayor La Guardia's supporters in the City Council turned an apparent defeat into victory yesterday when they used the decision of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan in the John Cashmore case as the weapon to unseat Mr. Cashmore as vice chairman and elected Councilman James A. Burke of Queens in his place.

Funeral services for Humphrey J. Lynch, White Plains attorney and former Supreme Court Justice, who died yesterday at Miami Beach, will be held at 10 A. M. Thursday at the Church of St. John the Evangelist here. The Rev. John Lynch of the faculty of Notre Dame University, nephew of Mr. Lynch, and Mgr. Joseph A. Breslin of the Church of St. John will officate.

Herbert Morrison. a leader of the British Labor party. announced today that he would leave March 20 for New York to confer with United States labor leaders and give advice on the building up of the American Labor party in the light of British experience.
Mickey Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers, tonight was named the "most courageous athlete of 1937" by the Philadelphia Sporting Writers Association.

The Santa Fe Railroad has ordered two electric streamlined trains to be completed in April, the General Electric Company announced today. This will bring to forty-four the number of trains of that type.

The National Foreign Trade Council has notified American interests holding blocked funds in Spain that it cannot recommend acceptance of the Loyalist Government's plan for settling the commercial-debt claims of American exporters, it was learned yesterday.

The most brilliant display of an aurora borealis in fifty years held Britons spellbound over a wide area of this country tonight. From 6:30 to 8:30 P. M. the people of London. watched two magnificent arcs rising in the east and west, from which radiated pulsating beams like searchlights in dark red, greenish blue and purple.

Burrell Memorial Hall was dedicated last night at services held in the basement of the Marble Collegiate Church at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. The new hall was named for the Rev. David James Burrell, minister of the church from 1891 to 1923.

The Hotel Astor has received the certificate of honor of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of New York City for "maintaining the cleanest sidewalk in front of any hotel in the city," it was announced yesterday.

Modern women have made the arrangement of flowers in the home a definite art, said Mrs. Constance Spry, one of the foremost flower decorators in England, when she addressed some 500 women yesterday morning on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A vastly expanded national defense program estimated to cost close to $1,000,000,000 and covering the navy, army and aviation forces will be recommended to Congress by President Roosevelt in a special message which he plans to transmit Thursday.

Among the properties sold at auction yesterday in the Bronx salesrooms at 3,208 Third Avenue was the large six-story apartment house at 114-16 West 238th Street on an irregular plot 226.9 by 178.5 feet.
Officers and members of the North Carolina Society of New York and their guests assembled last night at a supper dance in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Stockholders of the Farmers National Grain Corporation ratified today the recommendation of directors to dissolve the organization. The corporation, a government-financed agency for cooperative marketing, ceased functioning as a marketing unit late last year.

Numerous plans were filed with the Department of Buildings in Queens yesterday. They involved scores of small dwellings in scattered sections of the borough, as well as many large apartment buildings and several business and industrial projects. One group of 192 small houses planned for erection in St. Albans is estimated to cost $614,400.

Progress in devising meters for standardizing sound, which are expected to contribute materially to solution of the noise problem, was reported yesterday at the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in the Enginering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The Union League Club Class B squash racquets team, playing on its home courts, last night defeated the Piping Rock Club, 3-2, in the final match of the season for Group I teams in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,506,200 barrels, compared to 3,476,900 in the preceding week, an increase of 29,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 99,400 barrels more than the calculation of 3,406,800 daily by the Bureau of Mines for January. Gains of 16,700 and of 9,900 barrels, respectively, in Texas and Kansas were the important changes.

As one of the last actions of his administration, Rear Admiral David F. Sellers, superintendent of the Naval Academy, has planned to bring about the removal of the historic cannon of various types which surround the chapel and substitute anchors.

A canvassing board report disclosed today that mailers voted 1,995 to 1,762 in a recent national referendum in favor of separating from the International Typographical Union and forming an independent organization.

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, amplified its position on the Gubernatorial situation in a speech tonight at a dinner held to mark the start of an up-State organization drive to be conducted under his personal supervision.

The Italian police are already in a fever of activity to insure Chancellor Adolf Hitler's safety when he arriveS in Italy about three months hence. They are working in close collaboration with the German police.

The thirteen-story office and store building, comprising the whole blockfront in William Street between Liberty Street and Maiden Lane and known as 80-82 William Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms, 18 Vesey Street.

Eduardo Luis Desvernine, Cuban consul in Baltimore for twenty-four years, died yesterday at his home here in his seventy-fifth year. Although he did not enter the Consular Service until he was 50 years old, Senor Desvernine was the dean of the Baltimore consular corps.

Sir Thomas Stanton, government adviser on tropical diseases, died today at the age of 62. Among his many official duties he advised the government on the selection of candidates for the Colonial Medical Service.

Station WEAF, New York outlet t of the National Broadcasting Company's red network, was silenced yesterday at 1:45 P. M. for an hour and 25 minutes because of failure of power at the Long Island Light and Power Company's sub-station in Bellmore, L. I., where the station's transmitter is situated.

Charged by Judge Carl Foster of the Superior Court that "the citizens of the county and State demand such an investigation," an extraordinary grand jury today began an inquiry into the spending of $6,176,000 in State highway funds for rights of way on the thirty-two miles of the Merritt Parkway, connecting Fairfield County with the Hutchinson River Parkway in New York.

A three-alarm fire of unknown origin destroyed seven small stores and a billiard parlor in a row of two-story brick buildings on Brighton Beach Avenue, between Brighton Fifth and Sixth Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday between 6 and 7 A. M.
Another severe spasm of weakness overtook the French franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday, forcing it down within a small fraction of its low record.
The Hackley quintet won its second game of the season on its own court today, coming from behind to beat Lincoln School, 25-19. At half-time the New York City five was ahead, 17-14.
Two Italian planes, with Bruno Mussolini at the controls of one, landed here today ending a nonstop 3,200-mile flight across the South Atlantic from Dakar, French West Africa.

The St. Peter's quintet upset La Salle Academy, 33 to 29, yesterday on the latter's court in the Manhattan-Richmond division of the C. H. S. A. A. The winners started strongly and led at half time, 9 to 8. Warren Jacques, left forward, was the pace-setter for the victors with six field goals and four free throws for 16 points.

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. However, the total was only slightly less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Russell Forbes, Commissioner of Purchase, was served yesterday with a summons and complaint in an action for $54,000 damages started by Jacob A. Kirsch of the firm of J. A. Kirsch, Ltd., 99 Hudson Street, independent produce dealer.

Broadway tonight will be having its first look at Paul Vincent Carroll's play, "Shadow and Substance," which already has been approved by the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, and the pages of Scribner's Magazine.

On the eve of the hundredth session of the Council of the League of Nations, as Geneva once more fills with Foreign Ministers and diplomats, the atmosphere concerning the League itself is a thing that all serious quarters seem most anxious to feel out.

T. Gaillard Thomas 2d of the firm of Thomas Griffith was sus- ti pended yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange for three years, the governing committee having found his firm guilty of pledging customers' securities for its own account and other violations of the rules.

Miss Mary Alice Brown, business secretary of the Professional Women's League for twenty-five years, died yesterday morning of a heart malady in Sanger's Home for Chronic Patients, 22 West Seventyfourth Street, at the age of 85. She had been ill five months.

The five-story apartment house at 1,211-15 Simpson Street, the Bronx, has been sold by a client of Kiralfy Koch to Harry Mlodinoff, subject to $120,000 in mortgages. The building contains fifty-eight suites. Abraham L. Kramer represented the buyer and M. L. Geller and M. A. Cass acted as brokers.

President Roosevelt issued a statement denouncing wage cutting as a step toward price reductions, conferred with members of the House Naval and Military Appropriation subcommittees on national defense and announced he would send to Congress not later than Friday a message dealing with the subject.
The old New York Interscholastic Athletic League, which functioned from 1888 to 1905, held its annual reunion and dinner last night at the New York Athletic Club.

The grocery industry was urged to attack its price Ecutting and other problems by means of a conference committee made up of representatives of all divisions and backed with facts developed by research, in a speech delivered here today by Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation. Mr. Francis,

Another capacity crowd, numbering 17,000 persons, was in Madison Square Garden last night to see Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue. Many took advantage of the opportunity to buy standing room. Such tickets were not sold on the previous evening, when the show made its bow before a brilliant throng.

Terming the Securities and Exchange Commission's new rules for short selling "a sincere effort to deal with this problem," Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, promised yesterday the cooperation of that instiution.

Mrs. George L. de Peyster gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds. Other guests were Mrs. Cruger G. Fowler, Mrs. James Randall Creel, Mrs. Oliver J. Sterling, Mrs. Hazard Gillespie, Mrs. James Todd,

Fighting his way back in the ranks of middleweight title challengers, Ken Overlin, Richmond (Va.) boxer, will make his second appearance in the ring of the Hippodrome tonight when he tackles Walter Woods, I East Sider, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

Sydney awoke today to the booming guns of United States, French, Italian, The Netherlands and New Zealand warships which came here to aid in the celebration in honor of Australia's 150th birthday. Close behind the warships swooped five Royal Air Force flying boats which had been flown from Britain for the fete.

MANHATTAN ARNOLD, PEARL (March 12, 1937). Gross assets, $446,640; net, $407,197. To Madeleine Sylvester Stoermer, daughter, $5,000 personal property, trust accounts of $19,108 and life estate residue; Salvation Army, remainder ine one-half residue; Adam, Frank,

The infant mortality rate continues unusually low for this season, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in issuing the city's vital statistics for the week ended last Saturday. The rate for last week was 39.4 per 1,000 live births.

Twenty firemen either were overcome by smoke or suffered lacerations during a blaze that swept tonight a city block of eight stores in the heart of the business and theatre district here. Damage was estimated at more than $200,000.

Deals in Manhattan realty reported yesterday involved several properties in the central part of the city. The four-story Hotel St. Albans, at 349-51 West Fifty-eighth Street, was sold by the. De Forest Estates Corporation, Graoe B. De Forest, president,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial in THE TIMES this morning in so far as it favors unity of purpose in ending child labor is, of course, entirely sound. I am sure, however, that you will agree that we should not, for the sake of unity, choose a poor and ineffective tool for controlling child labor in interstate commerce when a sound and proven one is available.

The newspaper Stampa of Turin reports the total gold production of Italian East Africa for the first ten months of last year was 14,000 ounces, valued at more than $450,000. Production admittedly is not yet very high but is increasing. The gold comes mostly from Western Ethiopia and Eritrea.
A greater distribution of purchasing power by increasing wages of American labor was urged last night by Mgr. John A. Ryan, noted Catholic economist, as the best means of speeding business recovery.

Turpentine quiet, 303/4c; no sales; receipts 64 barrels; shipments 19 barrels; stock 28,959 barrels. Resin firm; sales 270: receipts 832; shipments 419; stock 74,358. Quote: B, D, $4.50; E, $4.75; F, $5.60; G, $5.70; H, I, K, $5.80; M, $6; N, $6.15; WG, $7.05; WW, X, $7.75.

Rae Crowther, line coach at Harvard University for the past three seasons, was appointed football line coach today at the University of Pennsylvania. Announcement of Crowther's appointment was made by George A.

The Inland Steel Company and subsidiaries showed a net profit for 1937 of $12,665,317 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the preliminary annual statement made public yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Thomas gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club for Lady Lewis and Mr. and Mrs. John T. De Blois, Wack, who have returned to be guests on the Masquerader II. Other hosts there included Mr. and Mrs. John H. Perry, Mr. and Mrs.

Miss Alice Borchard, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Edwin M. Borchard, was introduced to society today at a reception and tea in her parents' home here given by her mother and sister, Mrs. Robert Gregorv Durham.

Miss Margaret Bostwick, ranked fourth, was the lone seeded player to fall by the wayside as play in the seventh annual women's New York State squash racquets singles championship on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club reached the semi-final round today.
A memorial in the form a stained glass window to the R Rev. Herbert ShiDman. late

Edward L. Parke of Norristown, Pa., holder of the national interscholastic 100-yard breast-stroke record of 1:95.8, has been elected to the captaincy of Princeton University's powerful freshman swimming team, it was announced today by Coach Howard W. Stepp.

Solomon Wahnish, 40 years old, of 4 West 101st Street and Jacob Berkley, 33, of 1,455 Jesup Avenue, the Bronx, both taxicab drivers, were held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Capshaw in Homicide Court for a hearing Feb. 1 as a result of a triple taxicab crash Monday night at Seventh Avenue and Forty-eighth Street in which Philip C. Rider, broker, was killed.

The Tennessee Valley Authority' today announced that "in view of recent developments" it had authorized David E. Lilienthal, a director, to negotiate with private utility companies for the sale of their operating properties to municipalities and their public agencies or to the TVA.

From Aug. 1, 1937, to Jan. 1, last, 403,969 bales of cotton were received at Manchester, England, an increase of 17.47 per cent over the corresponding period of the previous year, a report to the Department of Commerce said today.

The four-story apartment house with ninety rooms on a plot 100 by 105 feet at the northwest corner of South First Avenue and East Third Street, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, was purchased by a group of investors through David S. Meister, broker.

Mrs. Cornelius W. Dresselhuys, the former Lorraine Manville, renounced her American citizenship in the Federal Court in Brooklyn last Thursday, and thereby completed the legal formalities necessary for her to assume the nationality of her husband, a Netherlands industrialist.

Carl Hathaway, who recently succeeded Sam Gumpertz as general manager of Ringling Brothers Circus interests, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 58 years old. Mr. Hathaway was stricken at his office at the Winter quarters of the Ringling circus and died nearly two hours later at a hospital.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
President Roosevelt defined the nation's policies at home and abroad

Construction contracts for all types of building in Manhattan awarded during 1937 aggregated more than $124,000,000, it was reported yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which also disclosed that during last December nearly $4,000,000 worth of apartment and hotel contracts were awarded-more than during any other month of the year.

With 1,300 cars traveling a total of 67,957,771 car miles last year, an increase of 17,000,000 car miles over 1936, the trains of the city's Independent Subway System were 99.81 per cent on time, according to a report made yesterday by Philip E. Pfeifer, general superintendent, to the Board of Transportation. This record was threetenths of 1 per cent better than in 1936.

Lord and Lady Stanley, Lord and Lady Leverhulme, Lady Layton, Sir Ernest and Lady Johnson, Sir Frank Nelson and Baron Okura are due to arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
The National Labor Relations Board is a 99 per cent "C. I. 0. organization," Paul Scharrenberg of the International Seamen's Union asserted before the Senate Committee on Commerce this afternoon.

The annual report of the National Bond and Share Corporation, made public yesterday, shows net assets on Dec. 31, 1937, of $8,801,804, taking securities owned at market values and after deducting the twentyfive-cent dividend paid on Jan. 15.

Another large leasing contract for space in the new Associated Press Building, in Rockefeller Center, was announced yesterday. With this second lease, contracts have been signed for more than half of the rentable area of the building, actual construction of which has not yet commenced.
Mrs. William E. Falkinburg of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Louise. Falkinburg, to Clifford Thomas Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Graham of Brooklyn.

The responsibility of the credit department of retail stores in creating and maintaining good-will among the store's customers was stressed by J. Gordon Ross, credit manager of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company and president of the National Retail Credit Association, in an address last night before the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., at the Hotel Taft. Mr.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, yesterday presented medals to seventeen members of the world organization, who have been members of five or more 100 Per Cent Clubs, at the second session of the company's convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Penn State has been coming along in fine fashion this season and may turn out to be the outstanding basketball team in the East. The Nittany Lions opened their schedule by invading Ohio and dropped their first contest to Akron. Since then they have not been beaten and boast an ight-game winning streak.

Governor Earle of Pennsylvania presented to the President today his proposal for the nationalization of the anthracite coal industry, but Mr. Roosevelt withheld judgment on the plan pending an investigation of alleged monopolistic practices.

On the suggestion of Louis-Oscar Frossard, Minister of State for the Coordination of Social Reform, an agreement was reached today in the conflict which caused a general strike on Paris public services in December.

Despite the spread of European political propaganda in South America countries through the radio and newspapers, most of the inhabitants there desire closer cooperation with the United States, which should foster this intercontinental solidarity, William A. Denker, manager of the foreign trade division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.,

The Ranee of Sarawak, wife of Sir Charles Vyner Brooke, ruler of the sultanate of Sarawak in Northern Borneo and the only white Rajah in the world, went down to the West Twentieth Street pier early yesterday to meet her daughter, known in England as Princess Baba, and her new son-in-law, Bob Gregory, a British wrestler. Mr.

Adding considerably to his advantage in total points, Jake Schaefer of Chicago, defending the world's 28.2 balkline billiard championship against Welker Cochran of San Francisco, made it four straight over his California rival by capturing both blocks at the Strand Academy yesterday. They are playing for 3,500 points.

The Philharmonic - Symphony Society announces the engagement of six prominent artists as soloists in its concerts for the month of February. They are Kirsten Flagstad and Rosa Pauly, sopranos, of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Guila Bustabo, young violinist;

Standard building code and zoning agreements, uniform throughout the nation, were held yesterday to be both necessary and inevitable by Bruce Wilson, educational director of the Federal Housing Authority.

Frederick W. Hohmann, secretary to the president of the Union Carbide and Carbon Company and a former catcher for the Cincinnati Reds, died here suddenly of a heart attack last night at his home, 71 Cambridge Road. His age was 53. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Hohmann was graduated from Brown Business College there.

The War De apartment released the following orders to day, dated Jan. 24: COLONELS Olmstead, D., Signal Corps, Washington D. C., to duty as a member of the Signs Corps Board, Ft. Monmouth, N. J., Jun 30. Eastman, C. L., Signal Corps, Ft. Hayes Ohio, to office of the Chief Signal Officer Washington. D. C.. Jan. 30.

William Henry Kehoe, retired assistant corporation counsel here, who was in the city's service for forty-seven years, died on Monday in his home at Central Valley, N. Y. His age was 69. Mr. Kehoe began his service with the city on Jan. 2, 1887, as a messenger in the New York County Clerk's office.

Mrs. Lilian Aldrich Winchester, daughter of Mrs. Charles F. Aldrich of Boston and Fairwood Farms, Dublin, N. H., and the late Mr. Aldrich, was married yesterday afternoon at the Plaza to Vinton Chapin, second assistant secretary of the United States Legation in Prague,

An upturn in foreign markets maintained fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here slightly above the previous day's closing figures during most of yesterday's trading, but scattered selling before the close left the list with a loss of 4 points to a gain of 1 point on the day.

With two tur judges dissenting, the Court of Appeals today upheld the convictions of Milton Speiser, a New York City attorney, on charges of conspiracy to defraud the American Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company.

Miss Dorothy Douglas Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Chadwick of this city and Syosset. L. I., and Randolph Appleton Kidder of Beverly Farms, Mass., whose engagement was announced last September, took out a license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on Feb. 5 in St. Bartholomew's Church.
The Senate Banking Committee reported favorably today the nominations for reappointment of five directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, including Jesse H. Jones of Texas, chairman.

To the credit of Secretary Morgenthau, it must be said that he does not design the silver policy which so often puts him in the headlines-in the latest instance, in connection with the purchase of silver bullion from Mexico.

August Bendel, for sixty-four years a publisher of religious books and periodicals, died here tonight at the age of 89. Born in Schaffhausen, SwitzerIand, he came to America in 1871. With the cooperation of German Lutheran organizations he expanded his field to Europe.

The appeal of the American Red Cross for the relief of civilian sufferers in China, launched on the initiative of President Roosevelt, is urgent. With the spread of the warfare, large Chinese communities have been depopulated and vast areas made almost uninhabitable: millions of individuals,
Century Shares Trust--As of Dec. 31: Liquidating value of each participating share at the close of last year was equivalent to $19.52, after deduction for the dividend payable on Feb. 1, 1938.

Abe Mallett of Regal Garment Corporation was elected president of the Fur Buyers Association of the Cloak Industry at a meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Other new officers are Jules Katz, Zelinka-Mattick Company, vice president; Sam Burzon, Schenker, Michel Weinstock, Chicago, secretary, and Jules Rothlein, Stern, Slegman Prince, Kansas City, treasurer.

Use by the Department of Justice of compulsion, in the form of grand jury information, to obtain "consent decrees" in anti-trust cases was frankly admitted today by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee.

President Roosevelt, "clearly and unequivocally," went on record today in opposition to wage cutting as a way to reduce prices, and indicated a belief that price adjustments were possible in some mass production industries without affecting wage levels.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History, the occasion being another in the series of "natural science evenings" for the ten-year development program of the museum.
Stocks drifted downward and closed lower; trading smallest since August; turnover 535,430 shares. Bonds lower in listless trading; second-grade rails weakest; transactions, $6,335,275.

By a vote of 124 to 17 the Assembly today adopted the Nunan-Moffat resolution on child labor after an hour and a half of debate in which the feeling between organization Democrats and the American Labor party group was conspicuous.

The Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, in the second day of its annual meeting at Columbia University, turned attention yesterday to gyroplanes that can be built to develop a speed of 200 miles an hour. A method by which a gyroplane can rise 200 feet in the air from a "jump take-off" also was described.

The apartment building at 2-24 Hinckley Place, corner of East D Eighth Street, Brooklyn, containing 259 rooms divided into eighty-two suites, has been sold by the Keav Realty Corporation, Samuel Bernstein, president, to Sarah Shriro.
The Court of Appeals held today that the value of a mortgage certificate was dependent on the value of the mortgage only and not on the value of the underlying real estate.

The Soviet Government today informed the Finnish Government of its decision to close the Finnish Consulate at Leningrad-the only Finnish consulate in Russia-within two months. The measure is regarded as a serious infringement of the FinnishRussian peace treaty and Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti intends to negotiate for the continuation of the consulate.

J. Henry Harper, a former partner in the century-old New York publishing house of Harper Brothers, and a grandson of John Harper, one of its founders, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Paris, where he had lived since his retirement in 1913.

A resolution favoring international political unionism and the organization of a continental labor federation was adopted at the final session of the National Labor Union convention at Cali last night.

According to The Daily Mail, Lord McGowan has decided to resign from the post of managing director of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd. He will remain chairman, and as such is expected to preside over the committee of executive directors, each of whom will control a particular branch of the vast business with world-wide ramifications.

Under an interpretation of Regulation T just handed down by. the Federal Reserve Board cash and securities placed with a brokerage house to meet a margin call may be placed in a special miscellaneous account, according to a letter sent yesterday by the New York Stock' Exchange to its members.

A virtual ultimatum to striking longshoremen and ship companies to reach an agreement within fortyeight hours was issued tonight by Governor Blanton Winship. Failing this, he threatened, the government would step in to end the complete twenty-two-day tie-up of cargo-handling throughout the island.

The Assembly Ways and Means Committee held "open house" today on Governor Lehman's $385,000,000 budget, with Republican members of the corn mittee defending it against attacks by witnesses. The attitude of the Republicans came as no surprise, as they have refrained from making any criticism.
It is felt here that reports being circulated of recent outbreaks in Greece have been greatly exaggerated.
Easily outclassing their opponents, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., and Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis moved into the second round of the women's Winter golf tournament today.

Mrs. Claudia Myar Goldenson, wife of the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, died last evening at their home, 135 Central Park West, after a two-day illness due to a pulmonary embolism.

Hunter College will hold mid-year commencement exercises for 558 graduates at 10:30 A. M. today in Carnegie Hall. Dr. Barnum Brown, curator at the American Museum of Natural History, will deliver the baccalaureate address.

Exports of cotton from the Republic of Peru in 1937 are estimated provisionally at 80,730 tons, against 80,741 in 1936, according to a report published today. Because of droughts in the Northern departments causing a loss estimated at more than 20 per cent

Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday of a new issue of $955,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds of the city of Minneapolis, Minn., on a bid of 100.11 for 2.10s. The bonds, to be dated Feb. 1, 1938, and maturing serially from Feb. 1, 1939, to 1948, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.60 to 2.15 per cent, according to maturity.

What the President said at his press conference today in opposition to any reduction in the average annual earning of labor was no offhand discourse. The document was prepared in advance, after a question had been submitted prior to the conference in the best House of Commons style.

Formal motions for a new trial were filed in Federal court late today by counsel for the sixteen major oil companies and the thirty oil officials found guilty here last week of conspiring to fix artificially high prices on gasoline in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

The Senate Commerce Committee asked Secretary Perkins today to furnish complete files of the Labor Department on Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast maritime union leader. Senator Vandenberg told the committee he had written to the Labor Department a week ago in an effort to obtain "precise facts" on
Hudson . Manhattan Railroad Company-Twelve months to Dec. 31: Net loss after taxes and charges, $588,201, comparing with a net loss of $447,757 in 1936. Figures are preliminary and subject to audit.

James G. Corbett, '41. of Bay City, Texas, dominated Princeton University's annual handicap meet in the field events, capturing two of the five contests and placing second in another, according to the meet results released today by the offices of the Intramural Athletic Association.

Mrs. Rosamond Pinchot Gaston, who committed suicide on Monday at her home in Old Brookfield, L. I., will be buried in the family plot at Milford, Pa., today, the tenth anniversary of her unhappy marriage.

Thomas Lamb, proprietor and owner of Lamb's Drug Store, 138 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, one of the borough's oldest pharmacies, died suddenly yesterday in his apartment at 44 Martense Street of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 74.

La Verne R. Craft, civil engineer, who supervised for the Foundation Company construction of the foundations of some of the city's leading buildings, died yesterday of pneumonia at a Queens sanitarium after a short illness. Mr. Craft, whose home was at 2,873 Heathh Avenue, the Bronx, was 49 years old.

Distributing the new 1938 rosters with their artistically designed plush covers, and announcing the receipt of two more signed contracts, Secretary Eddie Brannick put in another pleasurable afternoon at the Giant headquarters yesterday.

An uncommonly attractive program was given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The novelty of the occasion was its least important item, for the music of Igor Stravinsky's latest opus to have been heard in this country, the ballet "Jeu de Cartes," is the least consequential from a creative standpoint.

Operations of Remington Rand, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended on Dec. 31 resulted in a net income of $3,774,066 after all charges, interest, depreciation and taxes but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings, according to a report issued yesterday.
The State Senate today passed a measure to create the Herty Foundation for the promotion of forestry and pulp paper industrial development.

The gross premium income of the Maryland Casualty Company last year was $30,103,666, an increase of $1,823,220 over the previous year, Silliman Evans, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Baltimore. The company had an underwriting profit of $341,636 and income from investments was $999,735.

An application by the Richfield Oil Corporation for permission to withdraw from listing and registration on the San Francisco and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges commonstock purchase-warrants dated March 15, 1937, and void after March 14, 1947, was dismissed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The seventy-first annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will open with a private view this evening (to the public Thursday) in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Severao Salcedo Solar, dean of the Chilean colony in New York, who had lived in this city since 1911, died Sunday morning in the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a short illness. Coming to the United States In 1891 Mr. Salcedo studied dentistry in Philadelphia and then practiced in Santiago de Chile.

Justice W. E. Middleton granted leave today to a bondholders committee sponsoring a reorganizations plan for the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., to appeal a court decision turning down the plan for the $85,000,000 corporation.

Mixing business with pleasure, according to Eddie Collins's phone call from Philadelphia, Jimmy Foxx, Red Sox first baseman, today signed his 1938 contract before attending the Philadelphia baseball writers' dinner.

Warning that organized labor would fight price reductions aimed to stimulate recovery, if they were based upon wage cuts, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, paused in his presidential address before the convention of the United Mine Workers of America today to pay tribute to President Roosevelt.

Charles Woodruff Rogers, retired organist and pianist, died yesterday of pneumonia at the Leroy Sanitarium after a brief illness. Mr. Rogers, whose home was at 14 East Sixty-fifth Street, was 64 years old.

The Bureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 22: COMMANDER Chandler, T. E., Paris, France, to command the Clark, about April 14. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Gilbert, W. C., VF-6, the Yorktown, to Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla.

It was understood in Wall Street last night that the report of the Committee for the Study of the Organization and Administration of the New York Stock Exchange, headed by Carle C. Conway, may be submitted today to the governing committee of the trading body.

Curly headed Jimmy Colton made his debut yesterday as song writer, composer and concert master. After a bit of coaxing, Jimmy led his fifteen playmates, who were helping him celebrate his .third birthday party, in the singing of an original number-"Bow-Wow."

One of the most important collections of rare books to be sold in London in recent years will be disposed of early in the Spring when the valuable library assembled by the late Mortimer L. Schiff of New York will be put on auction at Sothebys.
The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it had signed a wage and working contract with the Sinclair Oil Company, the third it has signed with fuel oil carriers in the last two weeks.

A twelveyear "subsidy contract" for about $1,200,000 annually, under which the operators agree to build ten new cargo ships in the next five years, has been signed by the Maritime Commission with the American Export Lines of New York City.

As part of the campaign against venereal diseases of the Depart-I ment of Health, a poster urging every expectant mother to have her blood tested by a physician in order to "safeguard baby's right to be born healthy" will be displayed on 100 sign-boards throughout this city in a few days. Dr. John L. Rice,

A $250,000 first mortgage loan has been obtained by the Winston Construction Corp, Samuel Bernstein, president, on its apartment building on the south side of Crocheron Ave, between 167th and 168th Sts, Flushing, L. I. The Home Life Insurance Co is the mortgagee and was represented by Tanner, Sillcocks Friend, attorneys. Irving Rosenfeld was the attorney for the mortgagor.

The stock market here was quiet and generally uncertain today. Gilt-edge issues were among the few bright spots, while in the foreign bond section German loans were firm. Transatlantic shares, after an early show of strength, lost ground and closed lower than yesterday.
