Golf caddies on four famed courses of this section are going to improve their English and etiquette, or else. .. Peter Hay, veteran pro at the Del Monte links, announced today organization of a "school" to correct the caddies' language and manners.

An impaired refrigeration system has brought about temporary suspension of ice hockey at the New York Coliseum, the director of the Bronx arena, Captain E. W. Whitwell. announced yesterday. Because of melting ice during recent Eastern Amateur League games the players have been greatly handicapped.

The New York College Teachers Union asked the Board of Higher Education yesterday to "make immediately public" an announcement of the forthcoming vacancy in the president's post at Brooklyn College and to consult with the staff of the college "concerning the qualifications desired for this position."

The Leviathan headed oceanward yesterday on her last voyage. It was the first time she had moved since Sept. 20, 1934. At 4:37 o'clock, while a dismal dusk closed down on the harbor, her vast bulk yielded reluctantly to the stubborn insistence of two tugs roped to her stern.

The sharp drop in production in recent months is not being reflected in advertising budgets, indicating that companies are promoting their products aggressively so as to move stocks from retail shelves, agency executives said here yesterday.

The resumption of construction work on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was announced yesterday by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in an effort to open the full length of the great Gothic structure in time for the World's Fair of 1989.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic A. Gould, a retired Methodist Episcopal minister, who was ordained sixty years ago, died yesterday of heart disease and asthma at the home of his son, Kenneth M. Gould, Scarsdale, N. Y. He was 86 years old.

In settings representing the ballroom in the palace of Emperor Franz Josef I of Austria, the Viennese ball for the benefit of the Judson Health Center will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

The collapse of charges against Duke Joseph Pozzo di Borgo in connection with the Cagoulards [Hooded Ones] affair will shortly lead to his release from jail and his complete exoneration, his wife, the former Valerie Norrie of New York, told the press today.

In line with the current vogue of a marathon series of recitals devoted to one composer, Webster Aitken, pianist, launched one devoted to Schubert last night at the New School for Social Research. The four recitals of the series will present the sonatas, most of which are unknown to the general public.

While favorable conditions continued in the diamond trade during the first nine months of last year, the tendency changed during the last three months of the year, "probably caused by the crisis on the Stock Exchange in the United States,"

Sweeping reforms in the organization of the New York City school system, intended to deal a "death blow" to delinquency and maladjustment, were recommended yesterday by the Board of Education and Board of Superintendents in a joint committee report.

Wertheim Co. and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. have bought 151,447 shares of the capital stock of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company from two banking institutions, it was announced yesterday. No public offering of the stock is contemplated.
The following version of the Apostles Creed, attributed to certain extremist German Christian (National Socialist Protestant) groups, appeared in Berlin today:

Mrs. E. Haughton's veteran gelding Cruising, in the money nineteen times in twenty-six races last year, gained his first victory in four 1938 starts in the sixth event at the Fair Grounds today. Second to Royal Broom the last time out, Cruising this time overtook the Coward Coffey filly going into the stretch and pulled away. Royal Broom,

Great Britain started a two-year, $150,000 campaign today to regain the Westchester Cup from the United States. The Hurlingham Polo Association, which will challenge the United States in September, 1939, announced it already has bought eighteen ponies for the cup matches.

An autograph of Button Gwinnett, signer of the Declaration of Independence from Georgia, one of the rarest of American historical signatures, was withdrawn last night from an auction sale at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

An ever-increasing factor in the international aspect of the strange recent political happenings in Brazil is an aggressive German commercial drive carried on with the direct aid of the Reich and on the ground here by the best economic and diplomatic talent Germany has to offer.

" The wind was so strong we couldn't get anywhere," Captain Fred A. Jones, Eastern Air Lines pilot, who got lost in the air and was sought nearly all of Monday night, said on his return to New York last night to report the circumstances of his harrowing flight to company officials.
Daniel E. Finn, former Sheriff and former County Clerk of New York County, has joined the ranks of county officials who are seeking to recover back pay from the City, it became known today. Mr. Finn,

Plans for eight new apartment houses estimated to cost $1,485,000 were filed yesterday in the Bronx. In Manhattan plans for the Associated Press Building in Rockefeller Center and for changes costing $150,000 to the Empire State Building, were recorded. The list follows:

Reliable sources disclosed today that extraordinary military precautions were being taken on both sides of the Spanish-Portuguese frontier to forestall suspected plans for Communist outbreaks in both countries before the end of the month.

With heather and haggis pudding imported from Scotland and pipes skirting in the corridors of the Hotel Biltmore, the Burns Society gathered last night for the sixtyeighth time at an annual dinner to observe the 179th birthday of the poet "who set Scotland to music."

The two-day box-office strike, which had affected nine Broadway legitimate theatres and threatened to extend further, ended last night when representatives of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, the League of New York Theatres and the New York Theatrical Press Agents signed a mutually satisfactory agreement.

Regarding the new rule of selling for the "short account," promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it should first be observed that "short selling" is not prohibited. That action has been repeatedly demanded, whenever a fall in Stock Exchange prices has foreshadowed business reaction.

Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday the best earnings on its common stock since 1930, despite the recession in business in the final quarter of the year.

The Legislature pushed work today on some important bills. In the Senate, three Murray housing measures to amend the State Constitution as recommended by Governor Lehman in his annual message were reported out of the Judiciary Committee, of which Senator Kleinfeld, Brooklyn Democrat, is chairman.

Relatives of Arthur Fried, 32year-old sand and gravel company executive who disappeared Dec. 4, increased today to $2,500 their offer of a reward for information concerning him. One week ago a reward of $1,000 was offered. Several "ransom letters" have been received but none has been declared authentic, the authorities said.

Clingendaal of the A. C. Compton stables won the La Cresta Handicap at Santa Anita Park today with a spectacular burst of speed, finishing the six furlongs in 1:10 1-5, the second fastest time ever recorded for the distance at this track.
Luigi Lanfranconi, described as one who ridiculed Mussolini and fascism and "got away with it," died today at Gallarate. He was 65 years old.
Generally fair and much colder weather is forecast for today. Tomorrow will be fair and continued cold, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

One of the greatest movements to insure the future of wild life in America is being carried on today by an organization which began by putting aside all utopian plans and adopted a program which had been subjected to a critical, scientific analysis. This organization is the American Wildlife Institute.

Two resolutions-one seeking a national solution of the "overlapping" of other apparel trades to the detriment of the coat and suit industry, and the other calling for the formation of an Advisory Commission of Members of Industrywere adopted at yesterday's sessions of the convention of the Executive Council of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board in the Hotel New Yorker.

A lone Rebel plane flew low over Barcelona this morning and dropped a bomb squarely on Model Prison. In order to reach that powerful, forbidding edifice to the west of the city the plane had to cross the entire city.

New York's onrushing Rangers outplayed the burly Bruins for a 3-2 victory before a record crowd of more than 16,500 tonight to advance within 2 points of the pace-setting Bostonians in the National Hockey League's American division.

In connection with the application filed by the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation with the California State Railroad Commission for authority to issue $15,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, it is understood that negotiations virtually have been completed for the private sale of the bonds to a group of life insurance companies.

Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, trying to travel incognito to Geneva, was amazed today to find Polish Foreign Office representatives, foreign diplomats and many Americans at the railroad station when he arrived here.
The American Federation of Labor's executive council today rejected drastic proposals for a financial and economic embargo against Japan, suggested by the International Federation of Trade Unions.

The Seventy-seventh Division Association will give an informal reception for eight members, recently elected, appointed or re-elected to public office, on Saturday at 2 P. M. at the Seventy-seventh Division Club, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Members of the American Institute of Iranian Art and Archaeology will have their first opportunity tonight at the organization's annual dinner at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria to see some of the 3,000 photographs brought back recently by the eighth expedition sent out by the institute to survey Iran's historic architecture.

The Atlantic Refining Company and subsidiary companies reported a net profit of $9,942,000 for 1937 in its annual statement released today. The profit is after deductions for interest, depreciation and taxes, including $3,200 provision for surtax on undistributed income.

The elimination of Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., former Yale star, featured the first round of the annual Florida Winter golf championship for the Ponce de Leon Cup on the St. Augustine Links today. Ryerson, who has two legs on the valuable trophy and gained medal honors with a sub-par 71 yesterday, yielded to Oscar Evers of Jacksonville by 1 up.

Two bills aimed at a revision of banking practices in this State were introduced today in the Legislature. In the upper house Senator mcCall, Manhattan Democrat. presented a measure amending the State Savings Bank Law to permit a simplification and clarification of the law which has not been revised since 1914.
Two Wall Stret brokers, E. A. Pierce
Bonds followed a downward course in slightly more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest continued to center in the market for railroad issues,

Sir Thomas White, former ship's steward and saloon owner who became one of the most powerful political and business figures in Liverpool, died today. He was 60 years old. At the age of 10 he joined a windjammer as cabin boy and like many successful sailors eventually bought a "pub." Here,

Elsa Zebranska, Latvian mezzo cal flexibility, while, in soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall and was welcomed with genuins enthusiasm by a large house. Both the size and the disposition of the audience were justified, for the gifts.

Three members of the crew of the American freighter Algic were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of "endeavoring to make a revolt" while the ship was in the harbor of Montevideo, Uruguay, on Sept. 10.

In an opinion which he declared set precedent, Municipal Court Judge Matthew M. Levy settled yesterday an involved legal battle between a landlord and his tenant that had so baffled another Municipal Court judge that he was forced to "vacate" his own "judgment."

Owing to an injury sustained while skiing, W. K. Laughlin of New York was compelled to default to Tony Bertolloti, professional at the Racquet and Tennis Club, yesterday in the open racquet tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

W. E. Derwent, vice president of the George D. Roper Corporation, Rockford, III, was elected a director of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers at a meeting of the association's board yesterday at its offices, 60 East Forty-second Street.
In the opening game of the United States three-cushion championship play at McGirr's academy vi last night, Joe Cosgrove defeated Walter Beck, 40 to 31, in 56 innings. Each man had a high run of 4.

Reports of severe dust storms in the Western section of the Winter Wheat Belt offset the effect of relative easiness in foreign markets today and prices on the Board of Trade here held within a range of around 1/2 cent a bushel, closing at the best prices with net gains of 1/8 to 1/4 cent. It was the third straight day
Collapse of two conferences within twentyfour hours has failed to discourage the Chicago Cubs in their efforts to obtain Van Lingle Mungo, speedball pitching ace, from the Brooklyn Dodgers.

Elijah Smith Boteler Jr., proprietor of Decor, E. S. Boteler, Ltd., 123 East Fifty-seventh Street, an antiques importing and interior decorating firm, died yesterday at his home, 1,170 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of three weeks. His age was 39.

The Board of Tax Appeals rebuffed Treasury efforts today to increase the tax liability on the estate of Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury. The board denied motions to reopen the case and also denied the claim of the Treasury for a different interpretation of part of the recent decision in which the board

Ganna Walska, the singer, announced today she was married to Henry Grindell-Matthews last week in London. At her villa in the Paris suburbs, her secretary said the singer returned to France yesterday, that the bridegroom has "gone back to his mountains," and that the couple planned to go next month to some Winter sports resort.

Most commodity futures were steady in moderate activity on the local exchanges yesterday. Crude rubber futures were active and strong in response to the announcement in London that the International Rubber Regulation Committee had set export quotas at 60 per cent for the second quarter of 1938, compared with 70 per cent in the first quarter.

Three committees to study specific angles of selling conditions in the hosiery market were chosen yesterday at the first meeting of the merchandising division of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The division,
Sixteen labor leaders representing the whole labor movement urged Prime

The National Mobilization Bill is now receiving its finishing touches from legislative bureau draftsmen. It is a compendius measure intended to consolidate and supplement existing laws on the same subject.

The Shinto shrine in the Japanese garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden was razed at noon yesterday by fire of undetermined origin. Though police reported nothing suspicious about the fire, Dr. C. Stuart Gager, director of the Botanic Garden, was inclined to be skeptical.

Sixty persons, most of them women, attended the funeral services last night for James Mutrie, organizer and first manager of the New York Giants, which were conducted by the Rev. George T. Wood, pastor of the First Baptist Church of New Brighton, S. I., in the Edmund Schaefer Funeral Chapel at 535 Bay Street, Stapleton, S. I. The Baptist service included a prayer and two hymns, "Abide With Me" and "Face to Face With Jesus."

Henry Ford and his son, Edsel, inspected in a drizzling rain this morning the almost completed 130foot Edison Memorial Tower here, which is to stand as a symbol of the inventive genius of the elder Ford's close friend, the late Thomas A. Edison.

A housing program which would induce the American public to buy more small homes, permitting a larger expenditure for "comfort" items, together with the formation of a National "Chamber of Housing" which would dispense information on how to buy wisely, was urged yesterday by Arthur R. Herske, vice president of the American Radiator Company, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Trade Association Executives in New York City in the Hotel Astor.

The Salvation Army receives an interest valued at $76,266 in the estate of Mrs. Pearl Arnold, who died March 12, 1937, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The Salvation Army is to get one-half of the residuary estate, the income of which now goes to Mrs. Madeleine Sylvester Stoermer of 160 Central Park West, a daughter.
Mrs. George S. Hasbrouck Jr. or Berwun, Pa., entertained for the Misses Patsy Kramer and Polly Kramer of Coral Gables at the Bath Club today.

East Broadway, 273, 18.1x77.11x irreg; Mishkin Construction Corp (Julius Mishkin, pres) to Jefferson Management Corp, 570 7th Ave. 54th St. 11 to 15 W. 62.6x100.5; Alice T. Drexel to Alonitt Realty Corp. 30 Rockefeller Plaza, mtg $150,000 ($75). 89th St, 230 E, 25x100.8; Kitty Zinn to Clare Epstein, 24 W 72d St. mtg $18,000 (50 cents).
Pensioned On his own application (to take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 31): PARTOLMAN--John J. Magner, 18th Division, 15th Detective District, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 5, 1911.

The New York State Athletic Commission announced yesterday that it had reached a working agreement with the boxing authorities of the District of Columbia. The agreement, long in negotiation, was accepted at the meeting of the New York board, becoming operative as of yesterday.

The Sejm [Parliament] today discussed the Jewish problem when the internal situation was reviewed in the budget debate. Premier Felicien Slawoj-Skladkowski, ending the government's arguments, again outlined the Cabinet's attitude.

The Cabinet of Premier Octavian Gogag tonight banned semi-military organizations of political parties from participating in the elections March 2, which will pass on the government's anti-Semitic program.

The appointment of Allen Neil to succeed Sidney Rosenberg as head of the central buying division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation was announced yesterday. Mr. Neil for the last seven years has been with Stewart Co., Baltimore store of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.
Heavy casaulties were reported today in hand-to-hand fighting along the Yangtze River south of Nanking as reinforced Chinese and Japanese armies launched new offensives simultaneoulsy.
The $12,000,000 reduction in water rates voted by the Board of Aldermen a short time before the municipal elections last Fall was declared void yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull directed the United States Embassy in Moscow today to insist on seeing Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens in prison without delay, as a matter of right guaranteed by the recognition agreement of 1933.
Members of the Blue Hill Troupe, a company of amateur Savoyards which for several years has presented Gilbert and Sullivan operettas in behalf of various philanthropic activities,
MANHATTAN BREEN, WILLIAM (Dec. 11). Estate, $1,500. To eight persons and one institution specific bequests. Marie McManus, sister, executrix, 225 W. 109th St.

Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the Ambassador to Great Britain and daughter of former Mayor John F. Fitzgerald, was operated on for appendicitis tonight at Cardinal O'Connell House of St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Brighton.

Roland L. Redmond, lawyer, was re-elected president of the American Geographical Society last night at the annual members' meeting in the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.

An increasing urban population has placed added responsibility on engineers to train technologists and develop refrigeration for efficient preservation and distribution of food products, the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers was told yesterday at its annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Condo Nast, publisher of Vogue magazine, announced yesterday that he had accepted the resignation of Cecil Beaton, British photographer and artist, from the staff of the magazine as the result of a drawing contributed by Mr. Beaton to the Feb. 1 issue of Vogue.

The 105th anniversary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany was celebrated last night with a dramatic presentation of the church history in the auditorium of St. Thomas Chapel, 229 East Fiftyninth Street.

The first New York meeting of the year between Glenn Cunningham and Archie San Romani, Kansas stars, will take place in the Wanamaker Mile, feature event of the Millrose meet, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5. Their entries for the event were accepted yesterday.

A Plan for reorganization of the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company to reduce its capitalization by $76,879,402, which was opposed by a bondholders' protective committee headed by Harry C. Hagerty and Samuel McRoberts, was recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Homer H. Kirby, an examiner.

A marriage of interest here and in London took place in the Church of the Resurrection, this city, yesterday afternoon, when Miss Elizabeth Ayers Tweedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leslie Tweedy of London, was married to Wilbert Thornton Mendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Mendell of Redwood City, Calif.
Albany headquarters of the C. I. O. legislative committee were opened here today, with Martin M. Cooper and Joseph B. English in charge.

The Grace liner Santa Rosa returned yesterday from the company's initial seventeen-day cruise opening its service to Puerto Rico, Nassau, Venezuela, Colombia and the Netherlands West Indies. The vessel carried a capacity list, including several officials of the line who participated in State celebrations at the ports visited.

Supreme Court Justice Peter M. Daly was elected president of the Alumni Association of the College of St. Francis Xavier at the annual dinner in the Hotel Astor last night. Close to 175 men attended the reunion, which was presided over by T. Louis A. Britt, retiring president.

New York City experienced its warmest Jan. 25 on record yesterday. At 10:15 A. M. the thermometer of the Weather Bureau stood at 56 degrees. The previous record for the date was 55, established last year.

Paul Waner, Pittsburgh outfielder, seeking his third straight title in the Miami Biltmore lefthanders' golf tournament, moved into the semi-finals today with a 4-and-3 victory over S. H. Ivison of Clearwater, Fla.

John M. Ryall, for more than half a century a political leader of this city, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 90. Mr. Ryall was a former Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue and a former president of the Richmond Trades and Labor Council.

The rapidly growing list of major league hold-outs yesterday acquired another conspicuous recruit, Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, southpaw ace of the world champion Yankees and No. 1 pitcher of the American League in effectiveness.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company has reorganized its manufacturing facilities at Bloomfield, N. J., to form a special products division, under the management of H. J. Hoffman, it was announced yesterday.

So that fellow never got around to kidnapping Dizzy Dean. Just imagine! Yes, sir, just imagine to wit, viz, i, e, and as follows: Bradenton, Fla.: Jerome Herman (the Great) Dean disappeared from his filling station today under mysterious circumstances. He was delivering gas as usual when last seen. The police have a clue and an arrest is expected momentarily. The town is strangely quiet.

First by four lengths under the feather of 95 pounds, Go Home, from the Maemere Farm, left nothing to be desired at Hialeah Park today. The one-mile Gulf Stream Purse, which Go Home captured, saw the reappearance of such highly regarded horses as Columbiana, No Sir and Corinto, stake winners all.

After spotting its opponents an early lead, the St. Francis quintet of Brooklyn downed the Cortland Teachers tonight, 34 to 25. St. Francis had a six-point margin at the half and, although the visitors made only four field goals to Cortland's six in the second half, their accuracy at the foul line kept them in front.

On a barren stage Thornton Wilder's longawaited first play, "Our Town," had its Boston premiere tonight. To depict the story of life in Grovers Corners, a small New Hampshire town just across the border from Massachusetts, Mr. Wilder, the former Pulitzer Prize novelist, reverted to the play-writing formula of the ancient Greeks employing a narrator-stage manarer. in this case. Frank Craven.

Nat Rogan, Internal Revenue collector, filed income tax liens totaling about $100,000 today against several film writers, actors, directors and technicians in Hollywood. These represent demands for additional taxes in past years.

Southbound travelers on the Seaboard Air Line Railway increased 40 per cent in 1937 compared with 1936, C. E. Bell, passenger traffic manager, said yesterday. The company has begun steamship service between Miami and Havana in conjunction with trains to Florida.
The hangman's black flag was hoisted three times today over Acre fortress prison as a grim token of British determination to stamp out terror in Palestine.

Solly Krieger, 164 1/2, of Williamsburg resumed his winning ways last night at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn before a capacity crowd of about 4,000, knocking out Al Diamond, 163, Paterson, N. J., in 2:10 of the first in the scheduled ten-round feature bout.
The United States lost virtually all chance of retaining either the men's or women's world table tennis championships today as each team suffered one defeat today.
Twelve products developed largely in the past ten years accounted for about 40 per cent of the total sales volume last year of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., according to Lammot du Pont. president.

A formal verdict of suicide in the death of Fred Lester Acer, Columbia graduate student, was given here today by Dr. Amos O. Squire, medical examiner of Westchester County, after seven witnesses had testified at an inquest.

Today's major events: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Artur Schnabel, pianist, Carnegie Hall, evening; Lily Pons, soprano, Town Hall, evening; Mozart Boys' Choir, Town Hall, afternoon.

The Ways and Means Committee today ended its hearings on the revision of the Internal Revenue Act as recommended by its subcommittee on taxation. Chairman Doughton said the committee would recess for two or three days to give members an opportunity to study the testimony adduced at hearings by witnesses who generally opposed the addition of a 20 per cent surtax on undistributed profits in the case of closely held corporations with incomes above $50.000.

Trading continued slow on most classes of fresh meat yesterday. Steer beef sold weak to lower and lamb cuts were mostly weak to lower. Other classes were steady to weak. Early trading in kosher meats was very slow at generally weak prices. In order to stabilize the lamb market, most slaughterers reduced the kill sharply as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The opening gun in a $1,000,000 membership drive in the campaign of Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., the officially approved apparel industry exhibit of the New York .World's Fair of 1939, is the issuance of an illustrated brochure to 7,500 manufacturers, it was announced here yesterday.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, now conducting a drive for "founder members," elected Basil O'Connor yesterday as its president. Mr. O'Connor,
The Hitler regime has finally begun to tax churches. In accord with the National Socialist practice of advancing slowly to accustom the population to new measures, the tax can be expected to spread.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 15 totaled 303,679,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
An accounting of the Jersey Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of Elizabeth has been filed with the State Department of Banking and Insurance, it was announced here today.

Four new law courses for attorneys will be offered at the eleventh session of the Practicing Law Courses, beginning Feb. 7 at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday by Harold P. Seligson, the director.

The National Life Insurance Company had $533,955,109 insurance in force at the close of last year, the increase of $14,174,100 being the largest for any year since 1930, Elbert S. Brigham, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting at Montpelier, Vt., yesterday. in New insurance, he said, last year ter amounted to $47,139,782, an increase of 3.29 per cent over 1936.

A complete statement of the profits and losses of directors of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) through their participation, as individuals, in underwritings undertaken by Speyer Co. and J. W. Seligman Co., investment bankers, was promised yesterday in Supreme Court by attorneys for the two investment houses.

A strongly organized campaign to force manufacturers of woolen products to inform consumers whether products contain virgin wool and shoddy or reclaimed wool was launched here today by wool-growing interests, including sheep raisers from all of the Western States as well as representatives of the National Wool Marketing Corporation.

An unusual story merging phases of the American theatre and political life is being concocted at RKO for Summer production. "The Actor King," dealing with the life of Edwin Booth and which will contain a thread of the tragedy of John Wilkes Booth, his brother, is being written by Bernard Schubert.

A hectic last-minute rush to file construction plans before the city's new Building Code goes into effect has kept the architects and developers busy during the past few weeks, particularly in Queens.

A 5-cent piece bearing the likeness of Thomas Jefferson, the third President, is soon to replace the Buffalo nickel. The law permits a change in design of the coin of any denomination only once in twenty-five years.

Nervous because he said he feared that he might receive a ticket for passing one red traffic light, William Molzner, 42-year-old baker, last night led four policemen in commandeered automobiles for a wild two-mile chase through mid-Manhattan.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that Canada's production of silver in November amounted to 1,615,990 ounces, against 1,676,751 in November, 1936. Output in the first eleven months of 1937 was 21,397,065 ounces, compared with 16,487,179 a year before.

Barker Ave (16-4626), w s, 100 ft n of Juliana St, 170x164; Julia B. Davidson, extrx, to Flora Boeder, 3,420 Duncomb Ave. Southern Blvd (10-2683), n s. 500 ft w of Ave St John, 50x115; 555 Southern Blvd Realty Corp to Esther Chesney, 63-50 Wetherole St, Rego Park, L 1; mtg $53,200.

REX WARNER'S "The Wild Goose Chase"* is a first novel and as such might seem to warrant the special treatment usually reserved for first novels-applause and praise, or a dead silence. The corpse of one or another unsuccessful maiden effort could be displayed in a column like this every day of the week did not the reviewer consciously restrain his ghoulish impulse and operate on a nil nisi bonum basis.

1st Ave. 1,357, 25.6x100: Eleven-Sixty-Five Pugsley Corp (John F. Burns, press ) to John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co, Boston, Mass., 5 years, 41/2%; $18,000. Division St, 139, 25x65; Ida Oser to Helen Guralnick, 793 Crotona Pk N; due, Jan. 3, 1943, 6%; $5,000.

Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District West, who resigned under fire last month as New York County Clerk, was indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on six counts charging him with unlawfully harboring and concealing Charles Falci, one of his election inspectors, while the latter was a fugitive under a Federal indictment for election violence.

Formation of the nonpartisan committee for the defense of Fred E. Beal, former Communist and leader of the textile workers' strike in Gastonia, N. C., in 1929, now being held at Lawrence, Mass., for extradition to North Carolina, was announced here yesterday.

A proposal for the reorganization of the executive and legal personnel of the American Steamship Owners Association will be submitted next month to the directors by a group of members who conferred Monday at a downtown club.
Seventeenth annual meeting of the American Birth Control League will begin at Biltmore Hotel this morning at 10 o'clock and continue tomorrow. Semi-annual commencement exercises of Hunter College.

The International Rubber Regulation Committee, representing producers of 99 per cent of the world's supply, today reduced permissible rubber exports to 60 per cent of basic quotas for the second quarter of 1938. A quota of 70 per cent was allowed for the first quarter.
The current five-cent piece, which honors aboriginal America with an Indian on one side and a buffalo on the other, is to be succeeded by what one might call a stage-coach nickel.

Despite the rigorous censorship that Japan is now trying to impose on messages from the occupied parts of China, the significant fact of continued insubordination of Japanese troops in the Chinese capital was disclosed by an

A goal by Bob Shepard near the close of a ten-minute overtime session last night gave the St. Nicks hockey team an 8-7 triumph over the Brock Hall sextet from New Haven, Connecticut State champion, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The contest went into the extra period with the teams deadlocked at 6-all, Shepard having passed Kammer for the tying marker midway in the third period.

The seventieth anniversary of the birth of William Allen White is approaching. Notice is here given in advance that those who wish to congratulate him may have time in which to prepare their messages. The date is Feb. 10. He is listed in "Who's Who"

Five citations for "the protection of human rights" were presented last night at a meeting of New York Lodge 1, B'nai B'rith, at the B'Nai Brith Club, 36 West Sixtyninth Street. Scrolls attesting to the individuals' efforts to stem racial and religious prejudices were given to the Right Rev. William

The Pacific Coast Conference will see to it that the general public is not excluded from Rose Bowl games in the future. Professor Hugh Willett, secretary, said tonight the representatives of the conference institutions "fully intend to take action at the June meeting to see that a repetition of the ticket situation that marked the last game is made impossible."
Fred T. Heath, head of an insurance firm in Long Island City bearing his name, died on Monday at his home. 1,603 Beverly Road, Brooklyn, at the age of 71.
Josef Raieff, who made his New York debut as a pianist at the Town

The first meeting of a "Know Your City" course given by the Women's City Club will take place today in the clubhouse of the New York Juniot League, 221 East Seventy-first Street. An informal discussion on correlating the various departments of the City Government will be held.

Joe Triner, chairman of the Illinois Boxing Commission, said on his return from New York today that while no definite offer has been made to Promoter Mike Jacobs to bring the impending Joe Louis-Max Schmeling heavyweight championship bout to Chicago, this city "has the inside track."

Many parties were given yesterday in connection with the card party and tea for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop, which was held at the Plaza. Younger members of society headed by Miss Catherine Rogers and Miss Mallory Mixsell assisted at the tea table during the afternoon.

Mrs. Charles Newbold Welsh, Charles Newbold Welsh Jr. and Mrs. Grenville Dodge Montgomery have come from Ardmore, Pa., to the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Orr of Cincinnati are at the WaldorfAstoria.

Johns S. Wurts of Philadelphia was elected president of the World Association of Daily Vacation Bible Schools at the annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Le Marquis. Mr. Wurts, the sole surviving founder of the organization's work in Philadelphia, succeeds the Rev. Dr. Robert G. Boville,

A report filed yesterday by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman and administrator of the $500,000,000 dress industry, the largest in the city, with 100,000 workers, revealed how the collective labor agreements in the industry operate, emphasizing their contribution to the maintenance of peace in the industry.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 2,000 directs. Market mostly 25c-40c higher than Monday's average, with late sales 230-280 pound butchers 10c-15c lower than early.
A bill wi to appropriate $5,000,000 for relief of the destitute and homeless Chinese in the war zones of China was introduced today by Representative Francis D. Culkin of New York.
The Senate filibuster against the anti-lynching bill was brought face-to-face tonight with a proposal for a closure rule, calling for a vote on the rule at 1 P. M. Thursday.

The Literary agent for Edgar Snow, first newspaper correspondent to go into Communist China, has received a letter from him, postmarked Shanghai, in which he says that he has just received a copy of the English edition of his book, "Red Star Over China." He adds that he has heard nothing of the American edition and does not believe it will sell well.

Carroll Willis Ladd of 130 East Fortieth Street, stockbroker and former architect, died on Monday in Gotham Hospital after a short illness. He was in his fifty-fourth year. He was the son of the late William F. Ladd, owner of the Ladd House in Portsmouth, N. H., now a museum, and the late Caroline Willis Ladd of Texas.

Almerindo Portfolio, recently appointed City Treasurer, said yesterday that the city's finances were "on a sounder basis today than ever in the whole city's history." He addressed members and guests of the Italy America Society and the American Society of the Royal Italian Orders at a luncheon in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A law requiring all physicians to become members of the newly created National Medical College in order to practice in Cuba was approved by the Senate this morning. Only those foreign doctors may practice in Cuba whose countries admit Cubans to practice.

Renewed demands for repeal or substantial modification of the undistributed profits and capital gains taxes were heard on both sides of the Capitol today in answer to President Roosevelt's proposal that business recession losses be borne by those getting the profits when business is good, and that employers refrain from cutting wages.

Benjamin Benenson of 262 Central Park West, real estate operator and builder, who was head of the realty company bearing his name at 342 Madison Avenue, dropped dead at 6 o'clock last night of a heart attack as he entered the Childs Restaurant at 570 Lexington Avenue, near Fifty-first Street.

Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing donned the striped garb of his charges yesterday to be initiated into the Dexter Fellows Tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners. The ceremony took place at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore as 200 members of the club, each wearing a paper policeman's cap, looked on and made appropriate noises.

Charging company violation of contract agreements, some 500 employes of the local plant of the Crucible Steel Company of America went on strike at 3:50 this afternoon at the call of a so-called rankand-file committee.

Coolidge Sherman of Loudonville, formerly of Glens Falls, was elected a director of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company and the Commerce Insurance Company at the annual meeting of stockholders of the group today.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, will install newly elected officers of the New York local of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, tonight at the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue. Councilman Michael J.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday an amendment to the constitution of the Exchange which would have the effect of empowering the committee on odd lots and specialists to approve or disapprove of members wishing to act as oddlot dealers or brokers, or as specialists.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell dismissed yesterday a suit for $50,000 brought by Horace Goldin, magician, who alleged that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had damaged him by exposing his illusion of "sawing a woman in half" in advertisements for'Camel cigarettes.

To the growing list of European children's choral groups heard here, the latest addition is the Mozart Boys' Choir, which was introduced yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The group is from the Haydn Basilica in Vienna.

A threat to destroy the Japanese freighter, Keiyo Maru, brought yesterday a special detail of five plainclothesmen from the Bomb and Alien Squad and eighteen private patrolmen to Pier 16 at the foot of Joralemon Street, to guard the 6,500-ton vessel.

Dr. and Mrs. James Douglass Sharpe have returned from their wedding trip in Jamaica and Havana and are at 1,060 Park Avenue. Mrs. Sharpe is the former Miss Josephine C. Benedict, daughter of Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict and the late Dr. Benedict.

The Merritt Parkway grand jury today began delving into land transactions in which the State spent $6,176,000 for rights of way. Richard J. Corkey, Assistant Attorney General, of New London, spent five hours in testimony behind closed doors in the county court house here.

Discussion of possible economic "appeasement" in Europe will be intensified all over the world with the publication in Friday's newspapers of the longawaited report by former Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium.

Dr. Byron E. Eldred, physicist and inventor, announced yesterday a new method of casting metals, through use of latent heat which scientists expect will become of great. importance industrially. He made the announcement when he was elected president of the Engineers Club.
Dr. Charles F. Ash of Bound Brook, N. J., a dentist with an office at 115. Broadway, died of a heart attack early on Tuesday at the Hotel Astor, where he was an overnight guest. His age was 68.

Lingering near Scotland lightship until 3:15 yesterday afternoon, the Leviathan was at sea last night, headed for the Firth of Forth and a Scottish wreckers' yard. She sailed from Pier 4, Hoboken, Tuesday evening and anchored off Pier 8, Staten Island, until about 2 A. M., taking aboard almost 2,000 additional tons of oil.

One of the greatest ice jams in the history of the Niagara River heaved relentlessly all day today against the Falls View International Bridge, a quarter of a mile below Niagara Falls, and tonight it threatened for a time to sweep the structure away.

Mrs. Catharine Potter Watson of this city, widow of Louis Henry Watson, was married to Albert Eugene Heymann of New York yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Marshall Potter, of 260 East Seventy-second Street.

Funeral services were held yesterday for Maximilian Morgenthau Jr., president of the Morgenthau Corporation, in the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. Mr. Morgenthau died on Monday.

Magistrate Vincent J. Sweeney in Felony Court, Brooklyn, ruled yesterday that a toy "watch-fob" pistol was a "dangerous weapon" and held Louis Tannen, 29 years old, of 629 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, in $500 bail for a hearing on a charge of violating the Sullivan law. Tannen furnished bail and was released.

Negotiations for a return bout between James J. Braddock and Tommy Farr were interrupted yesterday with the sudden departure of Promoter Mike Jacobs for Miami. The match probably will be closed when he returns next week. Plans call for the heavyweights to fight in Madison Square Garden April 1 over the twelveround route.

The Great Atlantie and Pacific Tea Company, operating 14,800 retail grocery stores in thirty-eight States, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to cease forthwith from accepting special discounts on purchases equivalent to fees that manufacturers and sellers ordinarily pay to independent brokers.

The construction of three combination passenger and freight ships for the Mediterranean is being considered by the American Export Lines as part of a five-year building program, it was announced yesterday by John E. Slater, operating vice president of the line.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France will make strong declarations of faith in the League of Nations when the Council opens publicly tomorrow its hundredth session, British and French delegates promised tonight.

A usually well-informed authority said today that Justice Cardozo had notified President Roosevelt informally of an intention to retire from the Supreme Court, but that the Chief Executive had urged him to remain.

A resolution offering the cooperation of the coat and suit industry to President Roosevelt in plans for the stabilization of industry was unanimously adopted yesterday at the concluding session of the convention of the executive council of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board in the Hotel New Yorker.
Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee,
Charles: and Jacques Weill, investors, have purchased from the Excelsior Savings Bank for cash th five-story tenement at 49 West Ninety-ninth Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

While expressing his belief in an early business recovery, Alex Dow, president of the Detroit Edison Company, declared in a statement yesterday that his company's expansion plans for the current year were "not an unqualified gamble on a quick end to the current recession." The $18,000,000

Appearing for probably the last time before a committee of Congress in his capacity as chairman of the Maritime Commission, Joseph P. Kennedy declared today that opposition by some organized labor groups to government mediation of maritime labor disputes had in no way changed p his opinion that such mediation was necessary in building up and maintaining an adequate merchant marine.

Sister Dominica Maria of the Roman Catholic order of the Sisters of Charity was transferred yesterday from her position as superintendent of the New York Foundling Hospital, with which she had been associated for forty of her forty-three years in the order, to superintendent of Seton Hospital for Tuberculosis, Spuyten Duyvil Parkway.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were authorized today by the United States District Court to make two overdue interest payments on Harlem River Portchester and Naugatuck Railroad Company bonds. The first was due on Nov. 1, last, and amounted to $300,000.
J. A. Nesensohn, chief of the Acme Newspicture Bureau here, died today after an illness of several months. He was 38 years old. hs. He was 38 years old.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh of the Berkshire has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alma Clayburgh, to James Hooper Grew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sturgis Grew of 254 Marlboro Street, Boston, and nephew of Joseph C. Grew, United States Ambassador to Japan.

The volume of industrial production in December declined to 84 per cent of the 1923-25 averages compared to 89 per cent in November and then showed little change in the first three weeks of January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly summary of general business and financial conditions.

With hundreds of persons thronging the sidewalks opposite the -home of her father, Amos R. E. Pinchot, at 9 East Eighty-first Street, a simple funeral service was held yesterday morning for Mrs. Rosamond Pinchot Gaston, who committed suicide on Monday by inhaling carbon monoxide gas from her car in the garage of her rented estate at Old Brookville, L. I.

Sales last week of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of only 0.8 per cent under the same week last year, while the. decline for the first three weeks of this month was 0.7 per cent, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The Treasury collected $1,029 too much in taxes from "Franklin D. Roosevelt, Washington," and had to give it back.
There were two passengers on the lost Newark plane which staggered about in the dark and storm for half a dozen hours before reach-

Chairman Smith of the Senate Committee on Agriculture said today that conferees had agreed to limit administrative costs of the new farm program to 3 per cent of the sums available and to pay $1,800,000 to members of a 1933 government cotton pool.

The Federal Trade Commission's cease and desist order requiring the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to stop receiving discounts and allowances in lieu of brokerage was the main topic of conversation among delegates attending a score of food association conventions here today.

Power generated by the electric light and power industry in the United States during November, 1937, was 1.5 per cent ahead of the like month in 1936, according to statistics released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

S. D. Moss, formerly with Pease Elliman, Inc., and the Wood, Dolson Company, is with Henry Baker Co., Inc. Roy Moulton, managing director of the Piccadilly Hotel, will be honored tonight at a dinner at the Riverside Plaza Hotel in West Seventy-third Street.

Reports for 1937 issued yesterday by railroads showed general declines in earnings compared with 1936. While some reports carried results down only to net operating income, it was evident that the companies thus reporting would show adverse net income results for the year.

A diversity of entertainment, varying from elaborate balls and pageants to sports events and simple picnic suppers, is planned throughout the country for the celebration of the President's'birthday on Saturday, Keith Morgan, chairman of the national committee, reported yesterday. All the events are for the benefit of the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
John I. Taylor 3d of Dedham, son of the founder of The Boston Globe and a former owner of The Boston American League Baseball Club, died in a hospital tonight after a brief illness.

" Lohengrin" was performed last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, and on that occasion Karin Branzell appeared in the part of Ortrud for the first time this season. She was warmly welcomed. The substance and the characteristic color of the voice fit her well for the part of the dark sorceress.

This little town, in the heart of the peanut country, is known far and wide among the members of the quailshooting fraternity. Such is the quality of the shooting here that those who travel hundreds of miles to enjoy it only whisper the directions for reaching their favorite covers to a few close friends.
Jim Turner, the Bees' sensational 31-yearold freshman pitcher, today was voted the most valuable player on the two 1937 Boston clubs by the Boston baseball writers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The results of the water-rate cases have caused so many inquires respecting the significance. of the court decisions that a brief review of that chapter in our current municipal history is timely:

Margin requirements on speculative trades in corn futues will be reduced to 3 cents a bushel to members of the Clearing House Corporation of the Chicago Board of Trade, effective tonight, the lowest since 1933, it was announced today following the annual meeting of the corporation.
Lauding American's efforts to "understand France" Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, the new French Ambassador to the United States, addressed the American Club's weekly luncheon today.

H. Melville De Ronde, who retired in 1930 as cashier of the Woodhaven branch of the Bank of. Manhattan, with which and its predecessors he had been associated since 1905, died yesterday at his residence, 89-08 Woodhaven Boulevard, Woodhaven, Queens.
Judge Charles H. Moorman, senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth District, died today of a heart attack and nervous exhaustion. He was 61 years old.

A renewal of the discussion of the construction of a Nicaraguan interoceanic canal by the United States is creating the greatest interest in Nicaragua. People here believe that the construction will create better economic conditions.
John J. Oley and Percy Geary, convicted kidnappers who scorned counsel assigned by the court to defend a jail-breaking charge and pleaded their own case, were rebuffed today by both judge and jury.

A campaign to raise $150,000 was launched yesterday by the Beekman Street Hospital at a luncheon at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway. Private hospital service is in jeopardy today, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, told a group of bankers and business men who had attended the meeting.

The Republicans in the Assembly acted today on two of Governor Lehman's program measures to increase the scope of the present Unemployment Insurance Law, and permit savings banks to establish life-insurance departments.

Formation of an independent research group by builders and manufacturers to study means of reducing the cost of housing construction was proposed yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, new Commissioner of Housing and Buildings and head of the New York City Housing Authority, at a luncheon meeting given in his honor by the New York Building Congress.

The eighteenth international cotton congress was opened at the Royal Opera House here this afternoon by King Farouk in the presence of the entire diplomatic corps and delegates representing twenty-two countries.

The championship committee of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club today ruled that playing for money in prize putting competitions was a breach of amateur status and that in the future any one playing under such conditions will forfeit his amateur standing.

The SEC has called a hearing for Feb. 15 on a declaration by Peoples Water and Gas Company under the Public Utility Holding Company Act covering the re-issue of $400,000 of first mortgage 5 per cent gold

Total assets of $303,150,231,000 were reported by major industrial groups on balance sheets presented with the corporation income and excessprofits tax returns for 1935, the Treasury Department reported today in making public further statistics of income for that year.

L. Edmund Zacher, president, reported today a 1937 income of $237,556,169 for the Travelers Insurance Companies at the stockholders' annual meeting. Assets at the end of the year, he reported, were $943,887,000, compared with $889,552,000 on Dec. 31. 1936.

J. Arthur Nelson, president of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company, in his annual report today to stockholders said the company in 1937 earned an underwriting profit of $348,312, compared with $86,715 for 1936.

Two sophomores may break into Manhattan's starting line-up when the Jaspers meet C. C. N. Y. at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night. Ed Carr and Matt O'Rourke, the latter a holdover from last year's freshman team, have been showing such marked improvement that Coach Neil Cohalan may have them on the floor at the opening gun.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., estimates its consolidated earnings for the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 1 at $6,030,000 after all charges, reserves and taxes, including provision for estimated undistributed profits tax, compared with $6,012,000 for the fifty-three weeks ended on Jan. 2, 1937, which included $2,000,000 credits for application of inventory reserve provided on Dec. 28, 1935, according to a statement issued yesterday.

Chinese guerrillas, raiding the extended, lines of the Japanese in North and Central China, were declared yesterday to have stalled the invaders' march. The defenders also claimed increased effectiveness in the air after a squadron of their planes had bombed Nanking. [Page 1.]

H. Drummond Black of London, who is sailing today on the Aquitania, gave a farewell dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among his guests were Commander and Mrs. Edward Spafford, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Hardy, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Enders, Mrs. John W. Masury, Mrs. Arthur Kudner, Mrs. Hall Herrick, Miss Gladys Kitchen, Miss Dorothy White, Sir Standish O'Grady Roche, Captain P. C. Passman, Laurens WM. Hamilton and Arthur Tremaine.

The House sent to conference today a bill introduced by Representative Clarence Lea of California carrying amendments to the Federal Trade Act extending the board's powers and including a prohibition against "misleading" advertising, making it unlawful for a concern to advertise either "unfairly" or in a misleading manner.

Crown Prince Olaf of Norway and the Crown Princess, who was Princess Martha of Sweden, will represent their country at the opening of the 1939 World's Fair. This announcement, giving the first indication of the presence of European royalty at the fair, was made yesterday by Lorentz Vogt, director of the Federation of Norwegian Industries and chairman of Norway's participation commission.

For proceeding to stabilize price conditions in the demoralized crude oil production fields under the powerful pressure of one branch of the Roosevelt administration, thirty oil company managers now stand as convicted criminals, a result of prosecution by another branch.

DEUTSCH, ESTELLE (Dec. 9). Estate $l,200. To Julia Buchanan, executrix, 242 E. 19th St. DITCHETT, SAMUEL H. (Jan. 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Anna A. Ditchett, widow, Middletown State Hospital, Middletown, N. Y., $5,000 and insurance; Sylvia K. Fuller, 70 Perry St., and Charlotte Victoria Held. 419 W. 118th St., daughters, executrices, residue

Favorites again advanced today in the second round of the women's Winter golf tournament. Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis star, found hard going in her match with Mrs. Leo Walper of Washington, D. C., but won, 4 and 2.

The Delaware Valley tercentenary celebrations, in which Finland was invited to participate officially to mark early Finnish settlements in the United States, are regarded here as an event of national significance. The Cabinet has decided to make Finland's contributions as extensive as possible.

It was like old times yesterday, with a new Mae West show opening and a squad of patrolmen marching down the aisles. The joker is that the police weren't after Miss West, but had been called in to restore order when a personal appearance of Benny Goodman and his band threatened to turn the Paramount
Thurman Harshman, night city editor of The City News Bureau for the last twenty-five years, died of a heart ailment in St. Bernard's Hospital tonight. His age was 62.
Efforts of the committee for the study of the organization and administration of the New York Stock Exchange to complete the final draft of its report yesterday fell short of success.

Amendment to Official Action Guide Section 2-8 of the Official Action Guide is amended as follows: Sec. 2-8. The following members of the department now constitute the Fire Appliance Testing Committee: Patrick Walsh (1), Assistant Chief of Department, chairman. Michael Conway (2), Deputy Chief of Department. Albert B. Carlson. Acting Deputy Chief of Department. Herman F. Kuch, Acting Battalion Chief.

Editorial comment in the nation's press, gathered yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMs, showed that there was general disagreement with President Roosevelt's stand that high wages must not be lowered if purchasing power is to be maintained and the business recession checked. Editorial excerpts follow:

Gene Sarazen, accompanied by his wife, came home yesterday from a voyage that took him around the world. Although he played golf in such places as Bali and Japan and saw many interesting sights, there was one thing that bothered him a lot.

Content to let whatever holdout matters may be pending take care of themselves for the moment, Ed Barrow, business manager of the Yankees, announced yesterday the world champions finally had come off their mark in the general scramble to sign contracts.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday that it would hold a hearing on Feb. 10 on the "inadequacy of service" on the subway and elevated lines of the I. R. T. The hearing, which will be conducted by M. Maidwin Fertig, new member of the commission, follows many complaints against the I. R. T. and reports from its own service inspectors.

Lieut. Comdr. Emile Chourre, 43, and Aviation Cadet Michael J. Ola, about 25, navy fliers, were killed here today when their plane struck the top of a 250-foot mooring mast at Scott Field. They were en route from Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, to San Diego, Calif., where Lieut. Comdr.
Immediately after a speech from the throne read at today's opening of the Quebec Legislature, declaring "war" on communism, four raids were conducted here on alleged centers of communism.

To correct erroneous reports about employment in Chrysler Corporation's plants, K. T. Keller, president, stated today that the corporation had about fifty thousand employes on its current payrolls, as against about seventy-six thousand at the peak, late in October.

In pursuit of the proper design of airplanes to fly 400 miles per hour at an altitude of five miles, the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, in the third day of its annual meeting at Columbia University, received a report yesterday demonstrating that these new highspeed, substratosphere planes must be as smoothly polished over all the surface as a jeweler's toy.
Malmaison, James H. R. Cromwell's house on Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury's estate, was the setting today for a party given by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Robert Jr., guests of the Stotesburys.

A report on the investigation by the Riverhead Town Board of the administration of the Riverhead Township Highway Department by Highway Superintendent William H. Clark, Republican, who, retired from office Dec. 31, was submitted at the meeting of the board today and said "no tangible evidence had been found to indicate any criminal liability on the part of the Superintendent of Highways."

A formal answer to the test suit brought in the name of Edmond J. Dixon, an assistant Municipal Court clerk, to determine the validity of the budget recently approved by the City Council and the Board of Estimate was filed yesterday by Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler.

The number of medically supervised birth-control clinics in this country rose to a new high last year, indicating a larger public concern with birth-control problems, it was reported yesterday at the opening of the two-day annual meeting of the American Birth Control League at the Hotel Biltmore. More than 200 delegates from twenty States are attending the conference.

Fearing a State prison term as a repeated offender, Samuel Lightner, 28 years old, broke from a guard who was about to surrender him in General Sessions yesterday as a bail jumper, knocked over a woman in his flight down the front steps of the Criminal Courts Building to Center Street and was fatally injured when he crashed into a passing automobile.

An order permanently restraining Brenna Brothers, Inc., of 37 Wall Street, securities dealers, and Henry P. Volz, president of the corporation, from further dealing in securities in this State was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon.

Eighteen months after the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) bought 183,333 shares of common stock of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway on Jan. 22, 1926, for about $10,250,000, the value of this holding had increased $16,000,000, Edward N.

The Pilgrims of the United States celebrated "Australia Day" at an annual luncheon meeting at the Bankers Club yesterday, hearing their president, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, plead for international amity through an "interpenetration" of English-speaking peoples.

A plea that about 3,000 Filipinos resident in New York and vicinity who were formerly employed on American merchant ships be permitted to resume their employment was made to Senator Copeland as chairman of the Commerce Committee today by Quintin Parades, resident Commissioner of the Philippines.

Army's basketball five added the University of Pennsylvania to its list of victims today, the Cadets winning by 39 to 29 in a wellplayed game. It was Army's seventh straight victory, with no defeats thus far.

Exports of automotive products from the United States last year amounted to $360,168,886, a gain of $109,695,543, or 43.7 per cent over 1936, while exports of aeronautical equipment made a new record at $39,405,473, an increase of 70.9 per cent from the preceding year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

John L. Lewis made the offer today that the American Federation of Labor take over all the 4,000,000 members of the Committee for Industrial Organization on Feb. 1. He proposed as an alternative that on Feb. 1 the the C. I. O. take over the whole membership of the American Federation of Labor.

When the annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association is held at Poughkeepsie in June, the varsity race will be over the same historic four miles that it has been rowed during most of its long career since 1905.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated, Jan. 24: COMMANDERS Ashbrook, A. W., Mare Island, Calif., to command the Erie. Wallace, W. C., the Colorado, to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Navy Dep't, Washington. D. C.

Rollin Home did it again. He stepped up in company, and once more emerged victorious, in the feature race today at Hialeah Park. The score of the 5-year-old High Time gelding that only a few weeks ago could have been claimed for $1,500 was his fourth in five starts during the Florida racing season, which began at Tropical Park.
Harry Williams starred as home club mermen captured three of the six events at the swimming meet in the New York Athletic Club pool last night.

An extensive schedule in newspapers is a feature of the 1938 advertising campaign of the canned salmon industry, details of which were released yesterday. The drive, which has been considerably increased over that of last year, includes, in addition to newspapers, radio and outdoor advertising.

The dollar value of sales of securities on national security exchanges dropped to $1,376,983,646 in December, a decrease of 7.6 per cent from November and 48.5 per cent from December, 1936, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Stock sales,

SINABADA, by Elinor Mordaunt. (Greystone, $2.75.) An autobiography. IN 1937, by A. C. Eurich and E. C. Wilson. (Holt, $2.50.) A resume of the year. OVER THE NORTH POLE, by George Baidukov. (Harcourt, Brace,
A painting of St. Andrew by Sir Anthony Van Dyck was bought for $1,500 by Frank Schnittjer of this city at an auction sale at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, last night.

BECHHOLD, BERTHA (Aug. 29, 1937). Gross assets, $32,405; net, $30,543. To Murray S. Bechhold. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $20,000. Stanley W. Jones, attorney, 11 Park Pl. GOODELL, CHARLES L. (April 27, 1937). Gross assets, $41,139; net, $36,252. To Mary Frances Goodell, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $32,097. Burke Burke, attorneys. 72 Wall St.

By defeating the Yale Club, 3 to 2, yesterday on the Harvard . Club courts, the Princeton Club won the right to meet the Harvard Club next week to decide the Group 1, Class champion in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

The firemen who hastened to the Hoe-Sai-Gai Restaurant at 85 West Randolph Street tonight put out a small blaze in a grease chute. But the noise they made in the alley disrupted the performance of Helen Hayes in "Victoria Regina" at the Erlanger Theatre.

Rare Chinese objects of art are to be shown at the Arden Gallery beginning on Tuesday for the benefit of civilian war victims in strifetorn China. Most of these paintings, sculptured figures, ritual vessels and other material, it is announced, have not been exhibited before and are loans from private collections. C. T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, has consented to make the, formal opening address.

A Government communique said tonight 125 persons were killed and 208 were injured this afternoon when six Insurgent planes raided Valencia. The bombardment was described as one of the heaviest Valencia had suffered since the Insurgents started their daily raids two weeks ago.

Net assets of the Blue Ridge Corporation at the close of 1937, according to a report issued yesterday, amounted to $28,652,267, equal to $69.47 a share on the outstanding preference stock and to 78 cents a share on the common stock outstanding after allowing for the preference stock at $55 a share and accrued dividends. On Dec. 31, 1936,

The heaviest competitive program of the Eastern skiing season is scheduled for this week-end, but unless snow visits most of the popular rendezvous by tomorrow night most of the events will be called off. According to reports from the upper stretches of Pennsylvania, New York State and New England, the recent rainstorm washed away the snow in the Poconos, Catskills, Adirondacks, Berkshires and Green and White Mountains.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 538 West 179th Street was sold by Sanford H. Markham, attorney, to Michael Guzzardi, treasurer of B. M. S. Management, Inc.

A report issued today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation showed that while expenses and losses for the six months ended on Dec. 31 exceeded income and profit from its securities in the period,

What the Japanese describe, as dreary drudgery of mopping up scattered contingents of disorganized Chinese Army forces, bandit gangs and guerrillas, which has occupied them since the captures of Nanking and Hangchow last month, was revealed today in official statistics for the period between Dec. 20 and Jan. 22.

Sammy Baugh, the Washington Redskins' sensational halfback, will help Head Coach Ray Wolf in Spring football practice at the University of North Carolina this year. Wolf, who coached Baugh at Texas Christian,

Former Premier Karl Huszar, chairman of the committee that is preparing for the World Eucharistic Congress here next Summer, announced today that Germany had definitely prohibited the attendance of German Catholics.
Mrs. Ethel G. Dorsey, wife of former Mayor Frank Dorsey, died this morning in her home here. She was 66 years old. A graduate of

In sympathy with weakness in outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined slightly. Execution of closing buying orders by consumers enabled the list to finish with losses of only 1 to 4 points.
Former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany will celebrate his seventy-ninth birthday tomorrow and many members of his family are coming here for the occasion.

The Madison Historical Society unveiled today a bronze tablet in the Madison station of the Lackawanna Railroad to commemorate the arrival, 100 years ago, of the first train in Madison on the Morris Essex Railroad and to express appreciation for the value of the railroad to the community.

Donald R. Richberg, former NRA Administrator, who was present as an "unofficial observer" at President Roosevelt's conference with five major industrial leaders on Jan. 11, outlined last night his program for enabling business to regulate itself, under governmental supervision to prevent abuses.

The prize winners in the annual members' exhibition of the National Art Club were announced last night at a dinner in the clubhouse, 15 Gramercy Park. The Allen Butler Talcott memorial prize for the best landscape went to Frederick W. Hutchinson for "Winter Landscape"; the prize for the best marine to Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy of Design, for "Maine Headland,"

E I. du Pont de Nemours Co. had 73,369 stockholders at the close of 1937, a gain of 9,000 during the year, Lammot du Pont, president, announced yesterday. Individual holdings comprise 56,577 holders of common shares, 13,358 holders of debenture shares and 7,857 holders of preferred shares, but in this total there were 4,423 instances where the same stockholder held more than one class of stock.
Despite Governor Blanton Winship's ultimatum that the shipping strike end in two days, no move was made today to bring a settlement nearer.

Mayor La Guardia will discuss farm problems from the national standpoint tonight when he addresses members of the Illinois Agricultural Association in Springfield, Ill. The speech will mark his first excursion into the field of national affairs since his re-election.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, who has reigned as United States champion the past two years, and Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Apawamis, three times winner of the metropolitan crown, fought their way into the final of the seventh annual women's New York State squash racquets championship on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club this morning.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company today announced promotions of three executives in the industrial sales department. 0. F. Stroman, manager of the department, was appointed assistant to the vice president in charge of sales.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to operate 3.15 miles of track used for industrial purposes, and to extend the spur 6.6 miles with new track, all in Boone County, West Virginia.

Paul Waner, Pittsburgh outfielder, faded from the Miami Biltmore left-handers' golf tournament today before the booming shots of J. L. Matthews, Miami printer, and it was up to Lloyd Brown of Cleveland to keep the cup in the baseball family.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendations of the committee on stock list to list $10,000,000 West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company first mortgage 41/2 per cent bonds due in 1952 and voting trust certificates for 600,000 common shares of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc.

Officials of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., decided yesterday to omit the dividend on the company's common stock. The quarterly dividend, 20 cents a share, ordinarily would be payable on March 15.
The New York Curb Exchange has approved the listing of 655,287 shares of Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation common stock, 50 cents par value, in substitution for an equal number of no-par value shares.

Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, Middletown, Ohio, was elected president of the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday at the initial meeting of the recently elected board of directors at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Robert Miller, 55 years old, who has a police record running back thirty years under four aliases, was held in $10,000 bail by Magistrate McKiniry in the Felony Court yesterday on a grand larceny charge developed the day before when he was being questioned in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Weakness in securities and in foreign markets quickly spread today to grains and prices declined sharply. The closing on the Board of Trade here showed net losses of 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel and at a new low since Jan. 6.

Having been summoned by "command" invitations on the part of "The Court Chamberlain, by the order of His Majesty Franz Josef I, Emperor of Austria and Apostolic King of Hungary," hundreds of members of society thronged the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the Viennese Ball.
Mrs. Gertrude Simmons Bonnin, president of the National Council of American Indians, and- long active in the sponsorship of Indian legislation in Congress, died here today.

A committee including representatives of banks and underwriting firms has been named by the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., at the request of William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to help in a study of inaccurate or misleading titles used to describe securities.

A French protest was made to Tokyo today against bombardment of the island of Hainan. It was based on a promise obtained at the outbreak of the Chinese conflict that this island would remain outside the war zone.

Special to THE NEW YORK TIMS. WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.-The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 25: COLONEL Smith, T., Cav., Charlotte, N. C., about March 5, to home and await retirement.

That the Westminster Kennel Club will stage the greatest exhibition in its sixty-two years on Feb. 10, 11 and 12 at Madison Square Garden is indicated to a great extent by the' total number of entries, but even more so by the unprecedented entry in many of the popular breeds.

For the first time in many years, the number of tax assessment certiorari suits tried or settled by the tax division of the Corporation Counsel's office last year almost matched the number of cases filed by property owners in an effort to get lower valuations.

The business recession in the United States is having a noticeable effect on world trade and conditions in Great Britain, but not enough to justify pessimism, the heads of two of the "big five" British banks told the stockholders at their annual meetings today.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad pays $675 a month to the Pennsylvania Railroad for the use of the Pennsylvania's passenger station in Newark, N. J., according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The tax changes proposed by the Ways and Means subcommittee are for the most part substantial improvements over existing corporation taxes, but this is not true of the so-called "third basket"-the penalty tax on closely held manufacturing corporations.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Allan R. Armstrong, C.A.-Res., Fort Hancock, N. J., is ordered to active duty for six months, effective Jan. 24, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady. N. Y. for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities.
The Roosevelt Administration apparently is still at a loss for a definition for the "small business man," to whom it is paying much attention in taxation and recovery plans.

Lawrenceville's powerfull quintet scored its seventh victory in eight starts by defeating a weak George School team today, 53-26. Ed Tutwiler, Lawrenceville center. was again high scorer for the Red and Blac, with 20 points. Coepaced the losers with 10.

President Roosevelt held an extraordinary press conference today-one that was not scheduled.
