The newspaper reporters who are regularly assigned to the White House were suddenly called to the President's office late this afternoon, and responded in considerable bewilderment, as they are not accustomed to impromptu chats with the President.

James Newmak Andrews 2d of Somerset, Va., a member of the du Pont family, married Mrs. Kathryn Owen Austin of Great Neck, L. I., here today. The ceremony was performed by Probate Judge N. C. Arnett at his home.

Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein appointed. today United States Senator John Milton counsel for trustees of the Prudential Insurance Company in a suit to compel the company to distribute deferred dividends estimated at $5,000,000 to $6,000,000.

The Westchester Rangers dropped their second Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League game to the Sands Point Tigers tonight, losing, 6 to 2. Kasofsky of the Tigers led the scorers with three goals. Guild, also of the Tigers, made two goals and an assist. The Rangers still hold the lead in the league race.
Steel ingot production continues to rise slowly, being estimated this week at 321/2 per cent, but business shows no signs anywhere of substantial improvement, according to The Iron Age,
The Trust Company of New Jersey has sold to the J. S. Building Company, the three-story c building occupying a plot 23 by 92 feet at 311 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City.

The New York Rovers of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tallied goals in the last two periods tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0. The Orioles apparently scored in the third session, but the officials ruled a shoulder-high stick knocked the puck into the net and held it illegal.

A brief opposing any reduction in the present duties on wool products by means of a trade treaty with the United Kingdom or otherwise was submitted yesterday to the Committee on Reciprocity Information on behalf of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers by Arthur Besse, president of the association.

The Welsbach Street Lighting Company of America, which erects and maintains all street lighting in Manhattan and the Bronx and erects all new street lighting in Greater New York, has leased the entire tenth floor in 70 West Fortieth Street through George A. Bowman, Inc., and Pease Elliman, Inc.

This institution is unique: first, in the territory it serves; second, in the type of service required, and third, in its financial needs. As to the first, it is the only hospital below Canal Street that is "professionally and administratively qualified for admission to the United Hospital Fund."

Two Americans, Willis George and Albert Contelo, alias Howard, residents of Havana, the former for several years, were detained by police early this morning on a charge of alleged "pool room" activities. They are lodged in Principe Fortress jail.

The United States women's table tennis team lost the' world championship Corbillon Cup to Czechoslovakia's squad today as the group competition in the international tournament neared its end and the individual matches began.
William Slavens McNutt, one of Hollywood's highest-paid scenarists, died in his suburban home last night of pneumonia and a weakened heart.

The decline of the French franc was carried further yesterday, although other foreign exchanges were firm against the dollar. The French unit fell to 3.251/2 cents and closed at 3.2553/8 cents, off 27/8 points. This made the net loss for the last two days 7 points.
A Masonic funeral service for Richard Gordon Stableford, who died on Monday of pneumonia, will be held at 8 P. M. today in the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twentythird Street.

ATLANTA--Rich's, Inc.; A. S. Leak, men's clothing, men's, boys' furnishings; S. M. Stern, men's clothing, furnishings; 128 W. 31st (Kirby, Block Co.). ATLANTA--J. M. High Co.; Miss P. O'Neill, infants' wear, house dresses, underwear, sweaters; 112 W. 38th (National Dept. Stores).

The presence in Tirana of the Hungarian Countess Geraldine Apponyi, whose mother was an American, today gave currency to reports she would marry Albania's King Zog. The 22-year-old Countess is a daughter of the former Gladys Virginia Stewart of New York, who was married in Geneva, July 29, 1914, to Count Julius Nagy-Apponyi, member of the old Hungarian famlilies of Apponyi and Karolyi.
The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled reported yesterday afternoon that during 1937 it had provided training for 318 men and women, a larger number than in any previous year of its history:

The stock market here was generally dull today and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edged issues suffered a setback and foreign loans were idle except for German bonds. Transatlantic stocks reflected yesterday's weakness in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel declined.

President Roosevelt spent much of today conferring with members of Congress and others. So far as could be learned from White House attaches, he did not work on the expected National Defense message to Congress, and it was thought likely that it would not be sent up tomorrow, as the President tentatively suggested at his press conference yesterday.

Elimination of traffic ticket "fixing" in the city magistrates' courts has saved the taxpayers $715,000 in 1937 and will save them $1,000,000 in the current year, Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. told members of the Federal Grand Jury Association yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
Congress expects soon to receive from the President a message recommending increased expenditures for national defense. Although the budget already allots nearly a billion dollars to this purpose,
Twenty-six high and prep schools have filed entries in New- York University's fifth annual preparatory school fencing championship for the Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Trophy, It was announced yesterday.
Chancellor Hitler, it is learned today, has convoked a special session of the allNazi Reichstag next Sunday morning on the fifth anniversary of his attainment to the Chancellery.

Viscount Leverhulme, British manufacturer and president of the International Committee for Scientific Management, warned fifty leaders of large-scale American business in a speech at a dinner in the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, last night, against "leaving the solution of industrial problems too much to the politician."
More than 6,000 Italians and Askaris have been killed in fighting in Ethiopia during the past two months, the Ethiopian legation asserted in a statement today.
Today's major events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, evening.

Miss Georgia Robertson Nadler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Nadler, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant John B. Stanley, Sixtyfifth Infantry, U. S. A., in the garden of her parents' home near Caguas by the Rev. Theophane P. Mulroy.

The second annual all-day conference of the Metropolitan Association-of Real Estate Boards will be held today in the Hotel Commodore for a discussion of realty problems, including financing, public housing and legislation.

Fourteen men, of whom five were soldiers, were killed this morning in the Paris suburb of Villejuif by the explosion of 3,000 hand grenades which recently had been seized in the depots of Cagoulard plotters.

The Bucharest and Jassy bar associations decided today to suspend the activities of all Jews admitted after 1918 because the decision on their citizenship has not yet been taken by the government. This means that at least 800 Jewish lawyers will be unable to practice during the coming months.

The Rubber Manufacturers Association, through William L. Finger, assistant to its general manager, has submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington a brief asking for a substantial reduction in .the excise taxes now levied on automobile tires and tubes.
A group of four five-story garden Date apartments, known as 40 to 50 Locust Hill Avenue, Yonkers, has been sold by the 40 Locust Hill Avenue Corporation to the Locust Hill Realty Corporation.

Ken Overlin's dream or a chance at the world middleweight title went up in thin smoke last night after some desultory firing on the Sixth Avenue battle front. The husky Richmond, Va., fighter went down to defeat before Walter Woods, East Side star, in a tenround battle that attracted only 1,727 fans, and gross receipts of $4,201 at the Hippodrome.

Meeting last night to consider the proposal that they join the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union as a semi-autonomous unit, the New York Theatrical Press Agents ratified in principle the negotiations leading to such a step.

The address of Donald R. Richberg last night at the annual dinner of the Northeastern Lumbermen's Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania follows: Every great human adventure arrives some day at the end of well-marked roads over which preceding generations have advanced.
The State Banking Commission today ordered H. M. Byllesby Co. of Chicago to show cause at a hearing here on Feb. 15 why their State license as dealers in securities should not be revoked.

The undefeated Yale freshman hockey team conquered Hotchkiss School,-13 to 1, today in the New Haven arena. George Curtis figured in four goals and his team-mates, Scotty McLennon and George Mead, also were in brilliant form. Godley drove Hotchkiss's goal midway in the second period.
Plans for a twenty-eight-story office skyscraper for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, estimated to cost $10,000,000, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

Led by Norbert Setzler, the American open champion, the professionals turned back the amateurs in every test yesterday as play started in the first open invitation racquets tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup at the Racquet and, Tennis Club.

The 250th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg, Swedish theologian and scientist, was celebrated last night with a dinner of 500 persons at the Hotel Delmonico. Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, who is a member of the local Swedenborgian group, presided.

Artur Schnabel, who appeared in the fifth program of the Hurok Carnegie Hall series last night, was in rare form, even by his own exacting standards. There have not been many piano recitals this season that were the peer of this one, nor could there have been. Mr. Schnabel achieved interpretations that the most exigent listener must have found not merely satisfying but illuminating and exalting.

Larry S. MacPhail, newly named executive vice president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and Burleigh Grimes, the team's field general, headed for St. Louis late today, leaving behind them stout denials of any immediate plans to trade Pitcher Van Lingle Mungo.

The Chamber of Deputies Naval Committee, concerned over Italian battleship construction and Japanese activities in the Orient, went on record today in favor of abolishing clauses of the 1936 London naval treaty limiting battleships to 35,000 tons.

William E. Telling, president of the S. M. A. Corporation, makers of prepared milk for infants' food and former president of the Telling Belle-Vernon Company, died today after a brief illness. He was 68 years old.

T. A. Bisson, who has covered the Far East for the Foreign Policy Association for nearly ten years, has returned from a year's visit to Japan, Manchuria and China and has delivered to Macmillan his manuscript "Japan in China," which will be published soon.

Preliminary figures indicate that the world production of tin in December reached a monthly record of approximately 26,000 tons, making the total for 1937 about 206,000 tons, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. Last year's figures exceed the previous record established in 1929 by about 7 per cent and compare with 180,000 tons in 1936.

Plain silks will share style im- th portance with silk prints for late Spring and pre-Easter wear, according to an analysis of trends for the new season, issued yesterday by the International Silk Guild.

Weights for the $5,000 added San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita Park Saturday were released tonight and showed Charles S. Howward's Seabiscuit at 132 pounds. Mr. Howard had said he would not send his handicap champion postward with more weight than the 130 pounds assigned for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap March 5.

Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District West, who resigned under fire last month as New York County Clerk, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on a sixcount indictment charging him with unlawfully harboring a fugitive from justice. He was released in $2,500 bail for trial March 2.

Failure of the attempt of seventeen Senators. to halt the filibuster against the Wagner-Van NuysAnti-Lynching Bill by invoking the closure rule was indicated today when it appeared that their petition could not muster tomorrow the two-thirds vote necessary to limit debate.

District Court Judge Frank H. Eggers of Jersey City, who is a nephew of Mayor Frank Hague, has resigned the court position to become personal secretary to the Mayor next Tuesday. His resignation, effective that date, was sent today to Governor Moore.

President Roosevelt discussed intercoastal shipping legislation now pending, with Senator Clark and later with Senator McAdoo, the bill for Federal licensing of corporations with Senator O'Mahoney and other matters with Frederic Delano, Abel Wolman, Walter M. W. Splawn, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and Basil O'Connor.

Winning from the University of Baltimore today, 56 to 31, the Navy recorded its biggest basketball score of the season. The scoring was well distributed, with the guards, Laney, Mansfield and Ingram, contributing materially to the aggregate.

The directors of an unusually long list of companies yesterday took no action on dividend declarations due at this time. In order to escape the undistributed profits tax, most companies in the last two years have paid out in dividends virtually all their net earnings, with the result that they have no surpluses on which to fall back for dividend payments in a business recession.

A sudden collapse of government-business cooperation in the utilities field occurred unnoticed a week or so ago, on the day when Thomas W. Lamont of J. P. Morgan Co. and John L. Lewis of the C. I. O. went to the White House together to talk with the President.

The Council of the League of Nations opened its one hundredth session yesterday in an atmosphere of uncertainty. Expressive of this feeling was the statement the day before of the French Premier, Camille Chautemps, that the "essential question" to be considered is "the very future of the Covenant."

With a threat of court action hanging over it, the Board of Education voted at its meeting yesterday by a 4-3 margin to approve Mayor La Guardia's proposed "school-garage" site opposite the Yankee Stadium. for a new elementary school. Charges and countercharges were hurled in one of the most spirited meetings in recent months.
The land on Dec. Ely Culbertsons, who formed a busi- tobiography, ness partnership to win fame and quoted as say fortune from contract bridge, were pending divo divorced here today.
Walter Seymour Ballou, for years a leading rubber manufacturer and a director in many concerns, died last night at his home. He was 88 years old.

Andrew Pendleton of 128 'Bradhurst Avenue, the Bronx, who retired last Fall at the age of 73 after having served more than forty years as doorman for P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the board of the International Mercantile Marine, died yesterday noon at his home.

The Black Hawks, in the midst of a rebuilding campaign and a fight to retain their National League hockey playoff chances, announced tonight the purchase of Left Wing Jack Shill from the Americans. Terms were cash, but the price was not disclosed.

A small but smoky fire in the laundry of Bellevue Hospital, 410 East Twenty-ninth Street, occurring at 11:30 o'clock last night within six feet of the point of origin of a similar fire last Friday, caused the fire department and the hospital to announce that an investigation will be undertaken today.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner of New York City, declared here today that the "era of great construction" was not yet over, but predicted that in the next few years emphasis in the field of public improvements would have to be placed on "projects which are self-liquidating, or at least bring in some revenue."

It cost William Molzen of 1,516 York Avenue a $25 fine yesterday because he drove in a panic past ten traffic lights and led four policemen in commandeered automobiles a swift two-mile chase through mid-Manhattan on Tuesday evening. He was described as a dangerous driver.
George Angelo Haase, a retired auditor, died of a heart attack last night at his home, 197 Walnut Street, Montclair. He was 76 years old.
Two icebergs, the first of the year, were reported off the coast of Newfoundland today, drifting southward toward the transatlantic shipping lanes.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Feb. 1: LIEUTENANTS-Martin J. Corley, from 30th Precinct to office of the Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of inspectors of licensed hacks.

Future appeals from decisions of the State Motion-Picture Division on the showing of controversial movies will be reviewed by the State Board of Regents as a whole instead of by Frank P. Graves, Education Commissioner.

The nation breathed easier tonight when it learned over the radio that King George had completed safely in blustery conditions his return flight from Cranwell Air Station in -Lincolnshire to Sandringham, ending a day's inspection of part of Britain's new Air Force.

Bond prices declined swiftly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as liquidation produced the most active session of the year. All sections of the list were subjected to selling, and it was not until near the close of the day's session that any support made its appearance.

A search had failed tonight to disclose any trace of G. Henry Brethauer, City Treasurer, who disappeared yesterday noon after spending the morning in his office in the Municipal Building. Relatives believe that he is suffering from amnesia.

More than 10,000 retailers throughout the country were advised yesterday by the dress returns control bureau that, effective next Tuesday, the bureau will start its drive against discriminatory practices in violation of the fair trade code for the popular-price dress industry which has been approved by the Federal Trade Commission.

The strengthening of the nation's defense forces, as a major public works program was urged in an address before the Women's Conference on National Defense today by Professor James H. Rogers of Yale who advocated such a plan as a means of easing the economic situation in this country and of restoring to peace-loving nations what he held the dominating influence now exercised by the militarists of the totalitarian States.

Gerard B. Lambert, noted yachtsman, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after spending 'six weeks in Switzerland and on the Riviera. He indicated that he probably would not bring out his America's Cup class boat Yankee this year,

Shortly after the three members of the Bronx Planning Board were sworn in yesterday it was learned that the group had begun consideration of four projects which, if completed, would entail the expenditure of more than $50,000,000.

American labor was warned not to participate in economic boycotts against so-called aggressor nations by the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, speaking last night at the closing session of the CatholicConference on Industrial Problems at the Columbus Club, Brooklyn.

The recital given by Lily Pons, the Metropolitan coloratura soprano, at Town Hall last night for the benefit of the hall's endowment fund, demonstrated once again how deeply she is entrenched in the affections of her public.
Stuyvesant Fish, who last year gave up his seat on the New York Stock Exchange and became a limited partner in Callaway, Fish Co., will retire from the firm on Jan. 31.
Fraeulein Christel Cranz, German skiing star, who placed first in the 1936 Olympic combined downhill and slalom races, today won the women's slalom in the international sports week program.

Hostesses for the first dinner dance in the annual series at the Bath Club tomorrow night will include Mrs. George C. Gordon of Rochester, N. Y.; Mrs. Christian R. Lindback and Mrs. John A. Stevenson of Philadelphia and Mrs. George S. Hasbrouck Jr. of Berwyn, Pa.

Amory L. Haskell of Rumson, N. J., a hunts enthusiast as well as a follower of the show ring, was elected president of the National Horse Show Association at the annual meeting of the board of directors at the organization's headquarters at 90 Broad Street yesterday. Mr. Haskell succeeds J.

SOME day the Yale Bowl may be filled with cheering spectators as a couple of collegiate cue-wielders go into the thrilling final round for the intercollegiate billiard championship on a table located approximately on the 50-yard line of that famous football field.

After five successive setbacks, Welker Cochran of San Francisco broke into the winning column in his 3,500-point match with Jake Schaefer of Chicago for the world's 28.2 balkline billiard championship last night at the Strand Academy. He captured the sixth block, 269250, in sixteen innings.
Richard Wagner was elected today president of the Chicago Corporation to succeed Charles F. Glore, who was made chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Wagner,

At the annual meeting of the Nassau County Clearing House Association held at the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, L. I., last evening, William F. Ploch, president of the National City Bank of Long Beach, was re-elected chairman,
James Roosevelt, the President's eldest son and administrative assistant, will serve two weeks with the Marine Corps in joint manoeuvres to be held in February at Culebra Island, off Puerto Rico.

Authorized increases in the price of bituminous coal will add nearly a million dollars a year to the cost of the government of New York City, Mayor La Guardia told the Bituminous Coal Commission in a petition filed today asking for suspension of the minimum prices approved by the commission.

The Workers Alliance, an organization of home and work relief recipients, was accused of being more interested in fostering "unAmerican doctrines" than in bettering the lot of the unemployed in a presentment handed up yesterday by the November Kings County grand jury, which has been' investigating rackets.

Principles held to contribute largely to success in life were outlined to 580 graduates of Hunter College yesterday by Dr. Barnum Brown, curator at the American Museum of Natural History, at the seventythird commencement in Carnegie Hall.

Jane Peterson, woman painter and wife of M. Bernard Philipp, retired lawyer, has been chosen this year's outstanding individual by the American Historical Society. The selection was made on the basis of accomplishment by the painter, a portrait of whom will be used as a frontispiece in a forthcoming volume of the Encyclopedia of American Biography, published by the society.

Priestly Morrison, who staged more than twoscore Broadway plays and returned to acting in 1935 after thirty-four years as a director, died yesterday in his home at 83-09 Talbot Place, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 66 years old.

Arthur Bassett, representative of the British American Tobacco Company in China, will serve as chairman of an American advisory committee there to handle funds being raised in the United States for the relief of civilians in China, the American Red Cross announced today.

The tranquillity that seemed stable after disputed points were ironed out with various factions in the selection of the winners of the academy awards has been dissipated. Leon Schlesinger, producer of cartoon subjects for Warner Brothers, has withdrawn from the competition on the grounds that preferential treatment is being accorded Walt Disney.

Efforts to apply merchandising of unbranded products to branded goods were scored yesterday by William H. Ingersoll of Ingersoll Norvell, who declared that such a misconception partly accounts for attacks on price maintenance.

Sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania are Sir Philip Sassoon, Lady Helen Herbert, Lady Mary Herbert, the Hon. Betty Askew, Captain Philip Astley, Mrs. Daisy Morse, Colonel John Winslow, military attache at the United States Legation in Warsaw, and Mrs. Winslow;

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens County announced yesterday that he would investigate the question whether Councilman Hugh Quinn was legally elected from Queens last year and promised to prosecute those responsible if any crime had been committed.

Members of the Utility Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, made another sortie yesterday morning upon the main offices of the Consolidated Edison Company, at 129 East Fourteenth Street. Thirty men marched into the display room, on the ground floor, seated themselves on benches and raised aloft banners inscribed with protests against the dismissal of workers by the company.
Mrs. Alfred R. Neuwien has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Ann Neuwien, to Thomas J. Griffin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Griffin of Washington, D. C. The wedding

Plans for the improvement of Inwood Hill Park with new recreational facilities and more convenient access to a projected development designed to compensate for- the areas used for parkway connections to the Henry Hudson Bridge were announced yesterday by the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority.

The servant-employing housewives of New York City, if 150 who met yesterday at the Women's City Club in Rockefeller Center are typical, are in favor of pending bills to regulate the hours of domestic service, but many are emphatically opposed to any union telling them how to run their homes.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Lee of 1,112 Park Avenue and Stratford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lee, to James Norvell Banks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Banks of Vandalia, Mo., formerly of St. Louis.

Senator McAdoo proposed new legislative approaches to the intercoastal shipping problem today coincident with the evident development of powerful Administration backing for some form of Federal aid to the carriers.

In addition to the $10,000,000 project for a twenty-eight-story office building filed by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, architects submitted yesterday in four boroughs the details for many large apartment houses as well as other types of construction. Two large groups are planned for Queens, as are several for Bay Ridge, in Brooklyn.

FRAZIER HUNT has had a colorful fiftyodd years of life thus far, and he writes about them colorfully in his autobiography called "One American."* As in nearly all books of its kind, the pigment is largely on the outside, but that fact hardly needs to be stressed. If journalists, were philosophers, they wouldn't be journalists.

Canada should spend more money on research in pulp and paper if that important Canadian industry is to keep abreast of foreign competitors, R. A. McInnis of Quebec told the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association in his presidential address at the annual convention today.
The Naval Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year 1939, reported to the Senate today by its Appropriations Committee, carried $549,227,842, or $32,348 more than the measure as passed by the House.

The board of examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in orchestral music in day secondary schools other than junior high schools be issued, as of Jan. 24, 1938, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

Moving to protect New York's interest in the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, Mayor La Guardia has written to Senator O'Mahoney of the Judiciary Committee, suggesting two safeguarding amendments to the pending Chandler bill which has passed the House and is coming before the Senate committee for consideration.

The wife of a government witness in the Graham-McKay mail fraud case was reported missing yesterday by the United States Attorney's office, after her husband, Noble John Moore, confessed confidence man, asserted that he had committed perjury -at two previous trials of the defendants which ended in jury disagreements.

Maxwell Howard's Sceneshiftac, making his first start since last June and preparing for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, ran an impressive race today to win the $1,200 El Mirador Purse at six furlongs.

A demurrer to a Federal court indictment against twenty-four coal company executives, twenty-two coal companies and twenty-three present or former Harlan County peace officers was overruled today by Judge H. Church Ford.

The Montrose Industrial Bank of Brooklyn sold to a client of Solomon S. Goldwyn, attorney, the twofamily house containing ten rooms at 132 Sumner Avenu , Brooklyn, for cash over a purchase money mortgage. Joseph W. Gottlieb represented the seller.

Daily drawings under the auspices of the National Lottery Department were authorized by the Senate today. These will supplement the weekly drawings. The bill already has the approval of the House of Representatives and now goes to the President for signature.
Entries for the international Star Class yacht racing to start at Havana tomorrow were announced yesterday. There will be five sloops from this country, one from France and two representing Cuba.

Merchandise exports during December, 1937, exceeded imports by $110,893,000, and for the entire year by $262,000,000, compared to a margin of $33,000,000 in 1936, the monthly survey of foreign trade by the Commerce Department said today.

Staging a brilliant rally on the incoming journey, during which he captured four holes of the six played, Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., the defending champion, gained an-easy victory in the second round of the annual Florida Winter golf championship for the Ponce de Leon Cup on St. Augustine Links today.

Responding to persistent demands, Miss Sonja Henie has consented to a matinee performance of her Hollywood Ice Revue in Madison Square Garden Saturday, starting at 2:15 P. M. Tickets will go on sale today. Following this appearance the troupe will appear in Boston and Miami.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Jan. 25 unless specified: At Sydney, Australia: Louisville, Memphis, Milwaukee, Trenton. At Hong Kong Mindanao, Tulsa. Lynnhaven Roads to Yorktown, Jan. 26: Hatfield, Kane.

The annual financial statement for 1937 to be released today by the Atlas Powder Company shows a net income of $1,433,871 after taxes and charges. This is equivalent after preferred dividends to $4.40 a share on 248,145 shares of no par common stock.

William Cusick, 34-year-old chauffeur, of 27 Stewart Avenue, Hempstead, was found guilty today of seconddegree assault in the shooting last Aug. 28 of his wife, Mrs. Harriet Cusick, 32, whose right leg had to be amputated near the hip and whose left leg is crippled as the result of a shotgun blast.
Forrest (Spec) Towns, the University of Georgia's Olympic champion hurdler, left today for the East. The gangling, freckle-faced youth will participate in three Eastern events.

Behind the flight of the three Italian planes that landed here last night, 13 hours and 48 minutes after having left Dakar, lie motives other than merely a good-will visit to the new unitarian regime set up by President Getulio Vargas on Nov. 10. The flight just ended,

Sub-freezing temperatures, which promised to drop even lower in the near future, nipped the noses and raised the fuel bills of thousands of New Yorkers yesterday. But even so, the metropolitan area was an enviable place in comparison with the rest of the nation.
Organization of a Rudyard Kipling Memorial Fund committee in the United States, under the chairmanship of President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University, was announced yesterday.

Indecision stilled many voices among the 2,500 delegates to the convention of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations yesterday at the Hotel Astor, as a majority vote placed the group on record as favoring a referendum on "any war not strictly defensive."

An agreement which would limit operations in jute mills in Calcutta to either 45 or 48 hours is drawing near, but is not likely to be consummated immediately, according to cables to burlap traders here yesterday.

In preparation for the World's Fair of 1939, owners and operators of smaller hotels in the metropolitan area have formed the Independent Hotel Association of New York, Inc., "for the purpose of cooperating, establishing rates and eliminating unfair practices."

The main questions to be asked about the President's statement opposing wage reductions but advocating price reductions are whether the program he suggests could be put into effect and whether it would be likely to bring recovery.

Bill Terry got support in his feud with sports writers today from an unexpected quarter-Dizzy Dean. "I think Terry's article is the finest I've ever read," declared "Old Diz," speaking of the New York manager's piece in a current magazine.

The First Boston Corporation and Brown Harriman Co., Inc., won yesterday anissue of $3,000,000 tax notes of Boston on an interest basis of 1.58 per cent plus a premium of $39. The notes, dated Jan. 28,

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that 1937 was the best year in history for the safety of its plant employes. Working more than 384,000,000 man hours last year, employes met with only 5.15 lost-time accidents for every million hours they were on the job. The severity of accidents was reduced to 0.652 days lost for every thousand hours worked.

A trade treaty between the United States and Great Britain, in the hands of which nations lies "the power of initiative" in leading the world in removal of trade barriers, "would tend to reduce the barriers to trade over a large part of the world," J. A. McLeod, president, said tonight at the 106th annual meeting of the Bank of Nova Scotia.

Long before the scheduled opening hour at 8 A. M. yesterday crowds filled the lobby of the Paramount Theatre, overflowed onto Broadway and down the Forty-third Street side of the theatre to hail the return of Benny Goodman and his swing orchestra and to welcome the new Mae West comedy "Every Day's -a Holiday."

Michael Lantz of New Rochelle, won a $45,600 competition today on his designs for two large sculptures to be placed -at eac. side of the terrace in front of the Federal Trade Commission, or Apex, Building, now nearing completion at the conjunction of Pennsylvania and Constitution Avenues.
Dr. William Allan Nellson, President of Smith College since 1917. told the faculty this afternoon that he had informed the board of trus tees of his intentinn to retire in the Summer of 1939.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that 1937 was the best year in history for the safety of its plant employes. Working more than 384,000,000 man hours last year, employes met with only 5.15 lost-time accidents for every million hours they were on the job. The severity of accidents was reduced to 0.652 days lost for every thousand hours worked.

A trade treaty between the United States and Great Britain, in the hands of which nations lies "the power of initiative" in leading the world in removal of trade barriers, "would tend to reduce the barriers to trade over a large part of the world," J. A. McLeod, president, said tonight at the 106th annual meeting of the Bank of Nova Scotia.

Long before the scheduled opening hour at 8 A. M. yesterday crowds filled the lobby of the Paramount Theatre, overflowed onto Broadway and down the Forty-third Street side of the theatre to hail the return of Benny Goodman and his swing orchestra and to welcome the new Mae West comedy "Every Day's -a Holiday."

Michael Lantz of New Rochelle, won a $45,600 competition today on his designs for two large sculptures to be placed -at eac. side of the terrace in front of the Federal Trade Commission, or Apex, Building, now nearing completion at the conjunction of Pennsylvania and Constitution Avenues.
Dr. William Allan Nellson, President of Smith College since 1917. told the faculty this afternoon that he had informed the board of trus tees of his intentinn to retire in the Summer of 1939.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild will present "The Barber of Seville" instead of "Carmen" for its junior performance matinees at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 4 and April 14, it was announced yesterday.

For the first time in its history the New York Curb Exchange has released data showing the total market value of securities listed on the Exchange. The figures cover the ends of the last two years and are expected to be continued on an annual basis.

Shareholders of the Dominion Bank, at their annual meeting yesterday in the bank's head office in Toronto, Canada, received a report from Robert Rae, general manager, showing that deposits had increased $5,303,900 in 1937 to a total of $117,782,320.

The present business recession was due primarily to the "aggressive labor movement," which, starting in the first quarter of 1936, resulted in the reduction of hours and rises in pay without any regard to increased efficiency in methods of production, Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, asserted yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Bond prices continued to decline over a broad front in fairly active trading yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with almost all classifications participating in the sell-off. The turnover was $9,105,600, compared with $10,274,400 on Wednesday.

State Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, received a scroll from the Yonkers City Manager League tonight as the legislator who had sponsored the "best legislation for the improvement of municipal government during 1937."
Demands by the United States that Japan shall take adequate measures to stop outrages on American citizens and property in China were revealed yesterday by the State Department.

The crew of nineteen of the New York tugboat Plymouth barely escaped with their lives tonight when their craft sank in the Cape Cod Canal after being in collision with the freighter Everett. The men were rescued immediately. One was reported in serious condition from exposure.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday for the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 27 a consolidated net operating profit of $1,685,599 after all charges including amortization, depreciation and normal Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed income.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, New York City Controller, allotted yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of ninety-day revenue bills to twenty-six banks at an interest rate of 0.40 per cent. The bills, dated Jan. 28 and maturing on April 28, will be paid from the installment of real estate taxes due on April 1. The money will be used by the city for general budgetary requirements.

After the second fire yesterday morning within eleven hours in the laundry building of Bellevue Hospital and the fourth blaze on the hospital grounds since last Friday, members of the fire marshal's office, which had already started an investigation on Wednesday night, would give "no opinion" until the inquiry is completed. Employes at the hospital were being questioned yesterday.

Charles H. Dimick, president of the Textile Dyeing and Printing Company of America, announced tonight that within two weeks the company would close its plant at Fair Lawn, near here, indefinitely because of a combination of poor business and high costs under an existing labor contract.

A brilliant little chestnut gelding with a bad heart, Sir Francis Towle's Airgead Sios, today was made one of the favorites to win the Grand National when weights were allotted to the seventy-eight horses entered in the classic Aintree test March 25.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Droste of 595 Second Street, Brooklyn, and Bellport, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elise Droste, to George B. Turrell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Turrell of this city and Bellport.

Subjects of interest to the Uhited States were touched upon in the speechfrom the throne read by Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General, at the formal opening of Parliament. He expressed for one thing the hope that it would be possible to submit a new Canadian-American trade treaty to Parliament during the present session.

Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11 A. M. "England-Going Up or Down?" Mary Agnes Hamilton. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "World-Wide Current Events," Mrs. Henry R. Caraway.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad reported yesterday for 1937 a deficit of $7,713,451 and a deficit of $1,168,451 for December, 1937. This compares with deficits of $3,580,044 and $511,821, respectively, for the corresponding periods in 1936.

The dollar and the franc weakened in foreign exchange yesterday, the former cheapening in terms of all important currencies except the franc, which so far outstripped the dollar as to drop to the lowest quotation since November, 1926.

Following a short funeral service at his home, 2,280 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, Charles W. Lynch, former newspaper man and boxing judge, who died Monday afternoon, was buried yesterday in Woodlawn Cemetery.

Former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany today celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday anniversary by a reunion with his sister, his children and grandchildren. It was the first time since his seventy-fifth birthday that all of his family had been present for the anniversary.

A drive for general pensions for widows and orphans of all World War veterans, regardless of the cause of death of the veteran, was opened today by the American Legion, the Disabled American Veterans and the Jewish War Veterans. The Veterans of Foreign Wars, second only to the American Legion in strength, is expected to voice its approval of the plan tomorrow.

Japanese airmen retaliated swiftly for the Chinese aerial bombing of Nanking Wednesday by raiding Hankow yesterday morning. Seventeen Japanese planes dropped about a hundred small bombs on the airdrome and arsenal. A partly dismantled bombing plane on the field was destroyed and the hangar was hit.

J. L. Matthews, Miami printer, won the Miami Biltmore lefthanders' golf tournament today (R with a 3-and-2 conquest of Lloyd Brown, pitcher for the Cleveland Indians. The ball player won five of the first six holes, but Matthews then found his putting touch and went 2 up by the end of the first eighteen holes.

Representatives of fifty-seven fraternal benefit societies voiced their objections to licensing collectors of society insurance premiums, at a hearing on proposed codification of New York's Insurance Law, before a joint legislative committee here today. Canadian insurance companies also entered an objection to a section of the proposed code.
Dr. George W. Willcox, Hamilton physician known for his work in horticulture, died today at a hospital in Utica. His age was 71.

Members of President Roosevelt's "Cuff Link Club" will be among the twenty guests at his Saturday night birthday party in the White House. The members will be wearing gold cuff links which Mr. Roosevelt gave them to commemorate their experiences in his Vice Presidential and Presidential campaigns, as well as in the days when he was Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
The vote in the Senate today on the proposal to limit debate on the AntiLynching Bill by imposition of the closure rule was as follows:

After three members of the Board of Estimate had balked yesterday at giving retirement pensions to three former Aldermen amounting to three-fourths of their $5,000 salaries, the retirements were laid over until the board's next meeting.

President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman have written letters of congratulation to the officers and members of Madison, House, 226 Madison Street, on the four decades of service of the settlement, according to an announcement yesterday by Leo M. Klein, chairman of the organization's board of trustees.

This week's awards for building construction again have shown a gain over those in the same period of last year, with a total of $50,749,000, a rise of 18 per cent above the 1937 week, when $44,800,000 was reported, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The Burke Senate buried the petition for closure rule by a vote of 51 to 37 today and then heard from Senator Barkley, Majority Leader, a warning that if the Anti-Lynching Bill was not brought to a vote within a reasonable time he would move to displace it in favor of one of the important measures ready for consideration.
During the week ended Jan. 26 member bank reserve balances increased $77,000,000. Additions to member

Keeping countries free of exchange control so that American business may be conducted on a cash basis in as -great a part of the world as possible is a basic element in the foreign policy of the United States, a high administration official close to the President said today.
Sir Abe winner of the and J. B. today were f 133 pounds Handicap, first English flatrace will be 23.

A five-point program for the peaceful settlement of labor disputes was announced yesterday by Franklin E. Parker Jr. of the law firm of Parker, Finley Benjamin in assuming the presidency- of the American Arbitration Association at a luncheon held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Mrs. Marie Porter, 37, mother of four children, and Angelo Ralph Giancola, 22, both of St. Louis, died in the electric chair at Southern Illinois Penitentiary early today for the insurance slaying of the woman's brother, William Kappen, near Belleville last July 3. Mr. Kappen was to have married that day.

Continuing its advertising department studies, the Association of National Advertisers, Inc., yesterday issued Vol. III in its series on "Organization and Operation of the Advertising Department." The new volume comprises studies on Bristol-Myers Company, Jantzen Knitting Mills and Hercules Powder Company.

Richard T. Leonard, welfare director of the United Automobile Workers, said today that the union would hold a mass demonstration in Cadillac Square Feb. 4 to "protest wholesale layoffs of automobile workers."

Strikers, in the opinion of Albert Gore, Labor Commissioner, are not entitled to benefit from Tennessee's unemployment compensation program. Mr. Gore said an application had been received from Robert Looney Smith of Rockdale, employed by the Tennessee Products Company prior to a strike there.

The Gustav Mahler Medal, awarded annually to the conductor who accomplished most to further appreciation of Mahler's compositions in this country during the preceding music season, has been awarded this year to Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh today enjoined the Philadelphia brokerage firm of Julian Harcourt Ferguson, Inc., and the British-American Gold Mining Company, Inc., from making further sales of their stocks until the Securities and Exchange Commission approved any selling statements made to prospective purchasers.
Abraham Samson, 27, was ordered by the Superior Court today to serve a two-year sentence for involuntary manslaughter imposed after seven persons died in the collapse of his rooming house.
The third annual National Sportsmen's Show will be held in Grand Central Palace from Feb. 18 to 26 with the usual and some unusual features to add interest.

An increase of more than $9,500,000 in deposits by chartered banks was shown today in the report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. Deposits of the Dominion Government declined almost $3,600,000.

It is more than a hundred and twenty years since J. J. Harper began their printing business in a grimy little shop in Dover Street. John, the second J., was twenty and just out of apprenticeship. Both they and the younger brothers, Joseph Wesley and Fletcher, worked as compositors on the first book they printed, an edition of Seneca's "Morals."

A suggestion that Miss Martha Byrne, present Register of New York County, be retained in that post under a plan for a consolidated Register's office is made by Walter Fairchild, president of the Torrens Title League, who announced yesterday that he had sent to Mayor La Guardia the draft of a bill contraining the proposed changes.

Charles W. English, retired dealer and former town official, died here today at the home of his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Arthur S. English. Mr. English, whose age was 90, had been in poor health since 1933.

With the appearance of numerous small orders for men's Spring wear and a noticeable broadening in the demand for women's wear fabrics, there was a decided improvement in sentiment in all sections of the wool goods market this week, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

A group of 178 WPA mechanics, protesting a change of their status to laborers, staged a sit-in strike of about five hours yesterday in the labor relations office of the WPA at 39 Dey Street, a wing of the Hudson Terminal Building, until they were evicted at 5:30 P. M. by seventy-five WPA guards.

Fifty-four prominent New Yorkers have reserved boxes for the President's Birthday Ball tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the New York committee for the celebration, and president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

The Reichstag session Sunday, for which all preparations were made, including invitations to the diplomatic corps, was reported tonight on good authority to have been canceled on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's orders. The explanation offered for the report is that Hitler either decided he had nothing to say justifying the summoning of the Reichstag or that he must say more than he believes would be politic at the present moment.

Three appointments to the Harvard faculty were announced here today, effective next September. They are: George de Santillana, lecturer on the history of science for one year; Roger A. B. Mynors, lecturer on Latin literature for one-half year, and Friedrich-Sell, lecturer on German literature for one year.
THE naval expert said that he had been taking soundings and getting no bottom. He was in an angry mood about it. Rigging a seaanchor, he headed into the wind and demanded:

The season's fourth performance of Strauss's "Rosenkavalier" was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before a capacity house. The principal parts were taken by Lotte Lehmann as the Princess, Kerstin Thorborg as Octavian, Emanuel List as Baron Ochs, Friederich Schorr as Faninal and Marita Farell as Sophie. Artur Bolanzky conducted.
Isaac Newton Lewis, who would have been 101 years old on Feb. 26, died at his home, 166-20 Eightyeighth Avenue, Jamaica, late Wednesday night.
The Naval Academy crews will compete with six college eights in four regattas next Spring, Commander Andrew C. McFall, graduate manager of athletics, announced today.

Decisions of the State Education Commissioner were held today by Justice Francis Bergan of the Supreme Court to be final and not subject to review unless it can be judicially proved that they are not "reasonable."

Captained by Don Bradman, the Australian cricket team slated to tour England this Summer was announced today. Seven players who visited the mother country in 1934 are included, while six of those selected are to make their debut in test matches between the two countries.

If the Republican party wins control of the House of Representatives at the November elections, 3,000,000 men will go back to work, Representative Bruce Barton told members of the New York Young Republican Club at their annual meeting last night at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

John T. Harris of Harrisburg, vice president and general manager for the Central Pennsylvania territory of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, was elected today a director and vice president of operations at a meeting of the board. He succeeds the late G. Thomas Cartier.

In the belief that birth control "is on the threshold of acceptance as a public health measure," the American Birth Control League will open next month a nation-wide campaign to raise a large fund to expand its activities, it was announced yesterday at the seventeenth annual luncheon meeting of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore.

World production of zinc in December was 161,606 tons, compared with 157,359 in November and 162,066 in October, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. World production for 1937 was 1,849,367 tons, compared with 1,650,222 in 1936. The zinc output in the United States in December was 51,787 tons, bringing the output in 1937 to 589,032 tons.

Exports of foodstuffs from the United States during 1937 increased 38 per cent over 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today. The exports totaled $279,000,000 in value compared to $202,000,000 for 1936, while imports of foodstuffs increased from $735,000,000 in 1936 to $853,000,000 in 1937, the report said.

Mayor Frank Hague, who recently banned public demonstrations by the C. I. O. because he said "Reds" were associated with its leadership, announced today that the strike of the C. I. O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee, which closed the local plant of the Crucible Steel Company yesterday, would be handled by the police in the same way as in all strikes in this city.
Colin Frederick Campbell, chairman of the National Provincial Bank, is the most optimistic of the four executives of the big five" British banks who thus far have addressed shareholders.

When President Neilson of Smith College retires, as he has told the faculty he plans to do next year, it will be as if a brilliant star of first magnitude in the academic heavens had dropped out of its constellation. There will be deep regret not only among the daughters of Smith but throughout the educational world which he has illumined.

The United States A. A. U. bas- va ketball combination which departs 32 tomorrow on a three-month tour of th South America defeated the Metropolitan A. A. U. All-Stars, 52 to 42, last night on the Union Temple court.
The Philippine Boy Scouts presented a Filipino flag yesterday to Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the islands, in recognition of his work in the organization.

Much interest is being evidenced in the Smorgasbord party in behalf of the West Sixty-third Street Cormunity House tonight at the Pagano Studio, 11 East Fifty-first Street. The entertainment will include general dancing, a program of music and other divertissements by artists.

Business in the Pittsburgh district last week recovered most of the drop reported in the week ended Jan. 15, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The rise in the level of business here last week resulted partly from a larger than seasonal gain in the volume of trade and partly from a substantial increase in production of bituminous coal.
Arthur W. Straus, retired Chicago and New York investment banker, left an estate of $785,156, according to an inheritance tax return filed today.

John D. Ouelletfe, president of the Acme Glove Works here, died today at his home at the age of 71. After an apprenticeship in New Hampshire glove factories he made gloves for the Hudson's Bay Company from 1895 to 1905, then formed his own firm.
The $900,000 mortgage on the Sherman Square Apartments, the fifteen-story structure on the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West Seventy-third Street, has been reorganized.
All reports indicate that Max Schmeling is going into his fight here Sunday with pla Ben Foord in first-class condition, while his opponent still is trying to take off weight.

The Collector of Internal Revenue will receive $50,000 from the estate of Ivar Kreuger, promoter of Swedish match companies as preferred claim in the final accounting by James F. Egan, Public Administrator; as administrator of the estate, submitted to Surrogate James A. Delehanty yesterday for his approval.

With Elissa Landi starred as Catherine the Great, and Glenn Hunter featured in the supporting cast, "The Empress of Destiny" finally is heading for town in a production by Frederick W. Ayer and Dr. Ilia Motyleff.

Ina Claire in "Once Is Enough" tonight returned in the Shubert Theatre to the traditional role of the clever wife whose charm and finesse turned back her infatuated husband from the final step in a love affair.

The Federal Theatre Project anounces that. during the year ending Jan. 2 there were 3,609,984 persons in Greater New York who saw 4,087 professional performances of project shows. In addition, 513,237 attended 1,412 non-professional performances by community and school groups.

Mayor La Guardia of New York came to the heart of the corn belt tonight to tell members of the Illinois Agriculture Association his views on coordinating industry, labor and agriculture. More than 4,000 persons filled the auditorium for the first evening session of the annual convention.

Spurred by what is rapidly developing into some additional rivalry between the two organizations, both the Giants and the Yankees announced yesterday that appreciable headway is being made in the matter of bringing signed ball players into the fold.

One of the beauty spots of the city will be dedicated tomorrow afternoon to the memory of the woman whom many expect will soon be the first New York resident to be made a sain of the Roman Catholic Church.

The Midston House Squash Club players scored their seventh victory in eight matches in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association and tightened their hold on the lead by downing the Crescent Athletic Club, 4 to 1, on the New Mooners' courts in Brooklyn yesterday.

In continuation of the trends of recent weeks, local reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve felt a further shrinkage of their business loans and added to their holdings of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday,

TODAY--ew Englanld: Clear and colder, with zero and subzero temperatures over all of central and northern portions and parts of the south. New York State: Clear and slightly colder, with zero and subzero temperatures over the northern and central portions. Pennsylvania:

Down here in Bertie County they think 8:30 is early enough to start quail shooting, but when you go after wild turkeys they say "you be at the crossroads in front of the store at dawn"-and they mean it.

Many luncheons and teas will be given before and after the benefit matinee today of "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance has been taken over by the New York Vassar Club and will aid the organization's scholarship fund which, at the present time, is assisting seven students from the metropolitan area.

Former Governor Jack Walton announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor in the July primaries. Among his opponents will be William H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray, Governor from 1931 to 1935. Mr. Walton, now a Corporation Commissioner, was elected Governor in 1922 and was impeached and removed the next year.

A dramatic twenty-four-hour conflict of ice against steel reached a climax just after 4 o'clock this afternoon when the Falls View International Bridge collapsed into the ice-jammed gorge of the Niagara River.
Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., polo player, accepted the chairmanship of the annual Salvation Army appeal yesterday at a meeting of a hundred leaders in the drive in the Council Chamber at City Hall.

The preliminary report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries for the year 1937, issued for publication today, shows a net income equivalent to $4.10 a share on the outstanding common stock after estimated provision for Federal taxes and undistributed earnings taxes applicable to operations. This compares with a net equal to $3.88 a common share during 1936.

Charles Abel Corwin, staff artist at the Field Museum of Natural History since 1903, died today in his home at 1,423 Hyde Park Boulevard. He had been ill of heart disease for several months. His age was 81.

Buzzing excitement pervaded the classrooms and halls of Lincoln School, Columbia University, yesterday as forty-seven senior students and eight teachers prepares to leave tonight from Pennsylvania Station for a 1,327-mile journey to the Tennessee Valley and envirors as Part of a study,
Owners of properties in Queens kept pace yesterday with owners of sites in Manhattan and Brooklyn by filing plans for numerous multifamily buildings and small dwellings.

The discontinuance of one train and the addition of another were among the schedule adjustments for morning trains from Westchester announced yesterday by the New York Central Railroad, effective next Monday. The principal changes were listed as follows:

The increasing tax burden on real estate was protested yesterday at the second annual all-day Metropolitan Realty Conference under the auspices of the New York Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards in the Hotel Commodore.

Odd-lot dealers and specialists in stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange reported 13,341 more customers' orders to buy than orders to sell in the week ended on Jan. 22, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Just a hundred years ago this week the first successful experiment was made by S. F. B. Morse in the use of his telegraphic instrument. The scene was in part re-enacted with impressiveness in a hall in the New York University Washington Square building on the very site of the experiment.

The new Minister of the Interior is taking severe measures against propaganda of the extreme Left. Three hundred persons were arrested today throughout the country, all charged with Communist activities, and three secret printing presses, a considerable quantity of propaganda, several bombs and much ammunition were seized.

The Kennebec County Superior Court docket for February today revealed that Mrs. Helen Caldwell of Mount Vernon, Me., had filed suit for divorce from Erskine Caldwell, author of "Tobacco Road" and other books. Charles P. Nelson, attorney for Mrs. Caldwell,

Title to the property bounded by Boylston, Clarendon and Newbury Streets, Boston, Mass., has been taken by the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company for a building costing $2,500.000 to house its home offices. Work will be started some time next year on the building, the plans for which will be drawn by Cram Ferguson, architects, and Perry, Shaw Ferguson, associates.

With representatives from Yale, Rutgers and the University of Virginia among those scheduled to see action, Long Island University will stage the annual Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championships starting this afternoon at Nick's Tennis courts in Manhattan.

A cooperative movement embracing three religious groups in a program here to combat intolerance and to preserve individual liberty was outlined at a luncheon given yesterday by James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, in the Lawyers Club.

The National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that the National Maritime Union had been selected by 922 members of the unlicensed personnel of the thirty-eight tankers operated by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, as against twenty-two for the International Seamen's Union.

CAPTAIN JINKS OF THE HORSE MARINES, a revival of Clyde Fitch's comedy of old New York. Staged by Charles Hopkins; settings and costumes by Ben Edwards; production lighted by A. H. Feder; dances arranged by Helen Wicks Reid; presented by the New York State Federal Theatre Project.

Martin Krompier, reputed chief aide to the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, underworld racketeer, created a furor in a Brooklyn Federal court room yesterday when he gave the lie to a co-defendant who had pleaded guilty and was testifying as a prosecution witness. Krompier and four others are on trial on charges of conspiracy to conceal $100,000 in assets in a bankruptcy proceeding.

The presentation of silver member badges to ten members of the Rotary Club of New York for twenty-five years or more of service in the club was a feature of the club's regular weekly luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. Three prizes for golf championships also were awarded.

Nearly 2,000 young delegates from more than 600 youth organizations in the city and State will attend the three-day session of the New York State Model Legislature of Youth at City College, beginning tonight. Sponsored by the City Council of the American Youth Congress, the legislature will be opened tonight by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Mrs. Evelyn Pollack Kirkover, wife of Harry D. Kirkover, sportsman, died at the Kirkover home here early today. Her age was 65.

Hiarvey Campbell, fire chief of Irvington for about thirteen years, died today at the Irvington General Hospital. He was 59 years old. He had lived here thirty-fiv.e years. joined the Fire Department in 1908 and eight years later was made a captain. In August of 1925 he became chief. Surviving are his widow and three stepchildren.

Japan's fighting forces today prepared a budget estimated as high as $1,800,000,000 to carry on the undeclared war against China for another year. The tentative army and navy estimates now being worked out are expected to amount to between $1,160,000,000 to $1,450,000,000.
Appointment of a new State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance to succeed Carl K. Withers, resigned, may be made when the Legislature convenes on next Monday night, Governor Moore indicated today.

The Federal Government's charge that Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader and former New York County Clerk, unlawfully harbored a fugitive from justice struck a snag yesterday when Charles Falci, the fugitive, refused to answer questions before the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

Election of a paid president with almost dictatorial powers has been recommended by the committee for the study of the organization and administration of the New York Stock Exchange, headed by Carle C. Conway.

Although it already far exceeds the amount of the seasonal increase prior to Christmas, the seasonal retirement of currency goes on apace. The decline of $52,000,000 in circulation reported in this week's Federal Reserve statement brings the total drop since Christmas to $387,000,000, against a rise of $257,000,000 between July and Christmas.

A. G. Vanderbilt's 2- year- old filly Galley Slave set a world record for three furlongs today when she captured the opening race at Santa Anita track in 32 4-5 seconds. The old mark was 33 seconds flat.

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., was unsteady from the tees today and lost her semifinal match of the women's Winter golf championship to Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., on the nineteenth hole.

THE publication of "U. S. A.,"* by John Dos Passos--a three-decker made of his bestknown work-is a literary event of importance in this Republic. In a new way he has told the story of a new time. His use of certain literary devices (the "Newsreel" and the "Camera Eye") is only a part, though it is the most famous part of it.

Harvey Scott Hincks, 44, Professor of Dramatics and English at Western State Teachers College here, was burned gravely early tody when a rubbing solution he had applied to his body became ignited from an open grate.

The United Mine Workers of America voted limited autonomy to eighteen of its thirty districts at its constitutional convention today. The vote came at the end of an all-day debate marked by the ejection of a Negro delegate who admitted that he once had served as a deputy sheriff in the West Virginia coal fields.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor have leased a chateau in Versailles. It is the property of Mme. Paul Dupuy, American wife of the late Senator and owner of Parisian newspapers. The estate, known as Lay Maye, has extensive grounds, tennis courts, a miniature golf course and a swimming pool.
After the Northern Lights display, visible from the Alps to the, English Channel Tuesday night, Paris witnessed today a severe thunderstorm accompanied by snow.

Dr. Augustine C. McGuire, physician and former public official, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 67. He had been health officer of Pelham Manor and North Pelham, school physician of the town of Pelham, Fire Commissioner of North Pelham and police surgeon of Pelham Heights and Pelham Manor.

Basketball's boom is not confined to the United States. The rest of the world also is taking up the sport with greater zeal than ever before. The Olympic tournament at Berlin, which found the American teams several years ahead of the other nations, has been a great spur in the improvement of play of countries all over the globe.

Funeral services for Humphrey J. Lynch, lawyer and former New HIS WORK WIDELY ADMIR York Supreme Court Justice, were held today in St. John's Roman Catholic Church. More than 800 per- Created Realistic Settings sons attended, including many judges of the Ninth Judicial District. Mr. Lynch died Monday at Miami Beach, Fla.

The City of Yonkers faces the discontinuance next Tuesday of all municipal activities, including those of the fire, police and school deapartments, unless a 1938 municipal budget is adopted by city officials within the next few days, Corporation Counsel Leonard G. McAneny of that city declared today in Supreme Court here.
The rush of plans for new buildings in this city continued yesterZ day when architects submitted projects for many large apartment houses in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Terrorists or disgruntled blackmailers gave Shanghai an exciting hour last evening by hurling four bombs--two in the International Settlement and two in the French Concession. Apparently the missiles were thrown without any discernible political intent.

As steps were taken by the Chicago Stock Exchange today to effect a major reorganization, the Chicago Curb Exchange announced that members would vote on Feb. 3 on a proposal to disband their organization. Both Exchanges have been hit hard by the decline in the volume of trading in securities.

The Porto Rico Line steamer Borinquen sailed for New York today without a cargo of perishable vegetables-cucumbers-for which space had been engaged after the crew had threatened to call a sitdown strike in sympathy with striking waterfront workers if farmers were permitted to carry their own shipments aboard.
CALL LOANS OFF IN CANADA

Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Willis of Port Washington Park have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Willis, to William E. Smith of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Smith. The wedding will take place in June.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Benjamin Geringer, Med.-Res., 666 West 162d St., New York, N. Y., unassigned, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective Jan. 28. On that date he will proceed to Baltimore, Md., reporting to the Commanding General, Third Corps Area, for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities.

Cooperative leadership of the United States, Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy toward an international pact of economic collaboration of the widest possible membership is recommended to various European countries by Paul van Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium, in his long-awaited report.

Most of us over here know very little indeed about Bulgarian art. Specialists, of course, have familiarized themselves with ancient Bulgarian frescoes in Byzantine churches and monasteries; with the unearthing of archaeology; with the intricate web of influence that through centuries has been spun at this "crossroads of Greek, Roman, Egyptian and Oriental cultures."

Mary Nolan, 13, of 450 West Forty-seventh Street, and Thomas Simenson, 12, of 815 Amsterdam Avenue, received the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Scholarship prizes from Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in a brief ceremony at his office yesterday morning.
Recent arrivals here from New York are Mrs. Constance Reyburn, who plans to divorce Albert T. Reyburn, and Mrs. Marjorie Prentice, who will seek a divorce from Sartell Prentice Jr.

Immediate fur trade prospects continue clouded by the deadlock on the new labor agreement, which, unless accord is reached between the union and manufacturers at the meeting tomorrow, threatens to develop into a strike, spokesmen in the industry said yesterday.

Apparently determined to disregard the ruling of a New Jersey Court of Chancery which placed him in the custody' of his mother, 12year-old Howard Frankel was found sleeping in an elevated train in the Bronx yesterday morning,

An eleven-man jury convicted Joseph Shelley Decker of peonage today and the planter was sentenced to three years in Federal prison and fined $1,000. Decker was accused of having held James W. Wiggins and his common-law wife, Ethel Lee Davis, Negroes, in servitude because Wiggins owed him $175. The woman, witnesses said,

Mayor La Guardia submitted a formula to the Board of Estimate yesterday by which he expects to wipe out seventeen square miles of city slums and replace them with model low-cost housing for half a million families who are unable to pay more than $30 a month in rent.

After a close race with the clock a team of nine American amateur q hockey players left yesterday on the Cunard-White Star liner Aquitania for the world championships at Prague from Feb. 11 to 20. The t boat was due to sail at noon, and t six minutes before sailing time the plavers' passports had not arrived.

Reorganized real estate bonds are currently selling at prices to yield an average return of 8.85 per cent, according to Eli T. Watson Co., Inc. This figure is reached in computations which are based on 108 issues with an average bid price of 36.5 on Jan. 3. During 1937 they paid interest averaging 3.28 per cent.
John F. Roche Sr., former Albany supervisor and a cigar manufacturer, died today at his home. He was the father of John F. Roche Jr., secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

President Roosevelt's special message requesting Congress to authorize a widely expanded naval construction program as well as some increase in army equipment will be transmitted tomorrow. While in its specific details it will be devoted to the needs of the armed forces, the message promises to be one based broadly on foreign policy.
Skating at top speed for three periods, the Montreal Canadiens poured fortyseven shots at Dave Kerr tonight and achieved a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers.

Organization of the Association of Marine Surveyors of New York by a group engaged in cargo and hull survey activities was announced yesterday. The association is designed to disseminate information and represent the industry whenever necessary.

The strike of ticket sellers at Madison Square Garden was settiled last night at a conference of officials of the Garden Corporation and representatives of the Theatri cal Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, Local 18,032, A. F. of L., at the Daily News Building 220 East Forty-second Street.

The government has definitely taken the initiative north of Teruel in the sectors of Celadas and Singra, but it is admitted the lines remain virtually unchanged. In striking toward Singra and near-by Santa Eulalia the Loyalists are trying to cut the Rebel line of communications down from Calatayud at a point about thirty miles northwest of Teruel and to create a diversion to relieve pressure in the Teruel sector.

Mrs. Archibald D. Russell entertrained at luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Robert Winthrop Kean, Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr., Mrs. J. Griswold Webb, Mrs. Alexander Morgan, Mrs. Taylor Woodward, Mrs. Frazier Murray, Mrs. George Jones of Philadelphia and Miss Eleanor Doolittle.

Trial Decisions The following members of the department having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on Dec. 20, 1937, for violation of rules and regulations, 1937. the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner: Fireman 1st grade William J. Gillen, Engine Co. 281. Charge: Endorsed note for loan. Guilty. Sentence suspended.

New bookings in the furniture industry declined 59 per cent in December as compared with December, 1936, and furniture activity declined to a new low for the last three and a half years, according to the monthly bulletin issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.

Dr. Alfred Michaelis of 171 West Seventy-first Street, a member of the staff at Presbyterian Hospital, 620 West 168th Street, died of a heart attack last night at the hospital, where he was taken after he collapsed on the northbound platform of the Independent Subway at Fifty-ninth Street. His age was 63.

Carnegie Hall was filled to capacity last night when Yehudi Menuhin played two concertos, those of Schumann and Brahms, with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra. But the audience had not only a Menuhin to hear.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation earned $4,253,329, or 76 cents a share on its common stock, in the fourth quarter of 1937, compared with $5,291,492, or $1.08 a share, in the corresponding period of 1936, Eugene G. Grace, president of the company, announced yesterday.

Led by Sam Chernetsky, Montclair State Teachers College defeated East Stroudsburg State Teachers College, 70-63, tonight. Chernetsky scored on fourteen floor shots and added one more point from the foul line for a total of 29.

The sale of the Leviathan to British interests, to be broken up for scrap, may be followed by the sale of three more ships which have outlived their usefulness and which can bring further profit only if turned over to breakers for their steel and other metal values, it was learned yesterday.

Farm and food products again have led commodity prices sharply lower, The Annalist says, and on Wednesday that publication's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was 83.4 of the 1926 base, a drop of six-tenths of a point in a week and 8.3 points lower than a years ago.

Proposals that the Federal Communications Commission limit to newspapers and press associations the use of frequencies set aside for mobile press stations were agreed upon today at an informal conference of newspaper. press association, radio and communications company representatives.
The Nicaraguan Minister to Mexico, Dr. Lorenzo Guerrero, left Mexico City yesterday by airplane for New York and later will go to Washington. He intends to remain in the United Statres several weeks.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 26, unless specified: Acushnet, Dahlgren to Quantico. Jan. 27. Busnhell, at Guantanamo Bay, Jan. 27. Cashin, Boston Yard to sea, Jan. 27. Cuyama, San Diego to San Pedro, Jan. 27. Dahlgren. New York Yard to Rockland, Me., Jan. 27. Dunlap. Key West to Tampa. Jan. 27.
