Former Premier Paul van Zeeland in an interview with this correspondent has described the survey he has just completed for the British and French Governments, the first of its kind ever undertaken, as a search for a practical starting point for economic disarmament.

The three great powers remaining in the League of Nations used the opening of the Council's hundredth session today to reply to the three great powers that have quit it. They answered that they have kept unshaken their faith in the League and are determined to preserve it and continue to use it 'for the purposes for which it is fitted."
Social life of the youthful element in Greenwich Village and Washington Square two generations ago was much simpler than it is today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 25: CAPTAINS Abbott, J. S., Captain of Yard, Navy Yard Charleston S. C., to home, relieved all active duty, June 29. Barleon, J. S., C. O., the Arkansas, to Chief of Staff and aide, commandant First Naval District, Boston, Mass., about March 16.

An early judicial unraveling of New York City's budget snarl was promised yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan. He pointed out that a prompt determination of the amount of the 1938 budget was essential for the city to establish its real estate tax rate by March 1, the date specified in the charter.
Federal immigration authorities at Seattle have recommended that a warrant be issued for the arrest of Harry Bridges,West Coast Maritime Union leader, Secretary Perkins disclosed today.
Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's anti-trust division, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to the position of Solicitor General.

Miss Lidie Lane Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Scott Sloan of 2 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Andrew M. MeBurney Jr., son of Mrs. Andrew M. McBurney of Philadelphia and the late Mr. McBurney, which will take place here on I Feb. 26 in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Dr.

Miss Helen Flint of New York and Hollywood, Calif., daughter of Mrs. Eva M. Flint of Chicago, was married to H. Spencer Auguste of New York this morning. The ceremony was performed by Dr. William Edward Biederwolf, pastor of Poinciana Chapel at his residence.

An indication that President Roosevelt intends to avoid any suspicion of "meddling" in State political situations, particularly when they develop below the Mason-Dixon Line, was given today by Governor Browning of Tennessee as he emerged from the White House after an hour's conference with the President.

Mrs. Kate Steckler, long active in the philanthropic organizations in the uptown section of the city, died last night of a heart ailment at her home, 845 West End Avenue, at the age pf 60. Mrs. Steckler, who was the wife of David Steckler, an attorney, was a member of the Children's Welfare League, the Reba Liebowitz Aid Society and many other groups.

Motimer H. Isarel, formerly vice president of the Prager Company of Worcester, Mass., importer and exporter of wall paper, died yesterday morning at the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled, 321 East Forty-second Street, after several months' illness. His age was 66.

George Lawson Ford, who lived modestly in a four-room apartment at 91 Central Park West and who informed friends that he did not feel able to afford an automobile, had a net estate of $1,198.917, mostly in stocks and bonds, when he died Oct. 27, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

John Winthrop Auchincloss, who died on Monday in New York in his eightyfifth year and whose funeral was held there Wednesday, was buried in the family plot in Island Cemetery, here this afternoon. The committal service was conducted by the Rev. Dr. Stanley C. Hughes, rector of Trinity Church.
Workrelief rolls approached the "satduration point" today. Aubrey Williams, acting WPA administrator, announced a net increase of 160,799 persons since the first of the year.

The 4,111-ton freighter Nordvard docked yesterday at Pier 7 in South Brooklyn under command of Chief Officer Knut Dikestion, after the ship's master had disappeared on a one-day voyage from Baltimore through smooth seas and clear weather. The captain was 42-year-old Lundberg Borch.

The marriage of Miss Frances Miller, daughter of Mrs. Charles Miller and the late Mr. Miller, to William Herrick Merriman Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merriman of Dyersville, Tenn., took place today in the chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Coupland officiated.

Premier Camille Chautemps issued today a summary of the text of the new labor charter that he has submitted to Parliament, gave over the radio an explanation to the country of the aims of the bill and expressed his hopes that it would assure industrial peace.
Domestic fuel oil deliveries in 1936 went to the record volume of 408,409,000 barrels, according to data made public today by the Bureau of Mines.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad (the Frisco Line) bought 25,000 shares of Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad stock from Speyer Co., investment bankers, on Dec. 9, 1930, for about $38 a share, although it was selling in the open market at the time for about $13.87 1/2.

Norway's Minister to the United States, Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, and Rolf Christensen, Norwegian Consul General, were among those attending last night's performance of the Hollywood Ice Revue, in which Miss Sonja Henie is the star.
Newman School triumphed over the Morristown Academy five by 26--13 today. Otto Schwarz accounted for 8 points to top the victors' scoring. Captain Ken McKinley led the Morristown attack.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 24,000, including 7,000 directs. Market unevenly steady to 25c lower than Wednesday's average: largely 10-15c down; top $8.75; bulk 150-200 pounds $8.45-$8.70: 210-260 pounds $7.65-$8.50; 270-325 pounds $7.35-$7.80. Packing sows steady to shade lower, bulk $6.65-$6.90. Shippers 3,000; estimated holdover 3,000.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Lady Astor took first turn over Eleanor Powell, Ihe dancer, at having her picture taken with a group of Senators today. The Senate stopped its deliberations for twenty minutes when the Virginia-born member of the British House of Commons and Miss Powell visited the Canitol.

The cross of the Order of Leopold II has been conferred by King Leopold III of Belgium on Dr. Hugh S. Taylor, chairman of the Princeton University department of chemistry, in appreciation of his services to education while occupant of the Franequi Chair at the University of Louvain n 1937.

Thomas J. Vanstone, whose daring horsemanship made him a star with Buffalo Bill Cody's Wild West show, died Tuesday at the age of 77. Known to rodeo audiences throughout the United States as Texas Jim more than forty years ago, he was born in Kilhampton District, England.
John Leonard (Pepper) Martin, the "Wild Horse of the Osage," signed a one-year contract with the Cardinals today and said he was "rarin' to go."

More than 750 persons attended the funeral service yesterday afternoon in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, for Mrs. Claudia Myar Goldenson, wife of the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of the temple. Mrs. Goldenson died on Tuesday at her home, 135 Central Park West.

Well-informed opinion in Washington is that only about half a dozen Senators are sincere, convinced advocates of the anti-lynching bill. This leaves ninety who are bitterly opposed to it either for political or constitutional reasons, or have no faith in it as a curative of lynching.

After holding around Wednesday's closing levels for several hours yesterday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved lower in the last hour, influenced by the stock market, and closed with losses of 4 to 7 points.

Perhaps what the world needs most is a lot of utterly unintelligible words. Mr. Thompson in his book column day before yesterday said he would make no attempt to tell us just what happened to the people in the new English novel he was commenting upon; and the reason, said our book reviewer, was that he did not himself quite know.

Wholesale prices slumped in the week ended on Jan. 22, losing the gain of the previous week. A sharp decline in prices of raw materials, caused primarily by falling prices of farm products, sent the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics down to 80.8, based on the 1926 average as 100, compared with 81.0 the week ended on Jan. 15. On Jan. 23, 1937, it was 85.3.

Moving ahead in his investigation of the legality of the election of Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens, District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan sent subpoenas yesterday to the city Board of Elections, to the Board of Elections in Islip, L. I., and to the New York State Motor Vehicle Bureau.

Frank Hanson of the Columbia University Club entered the semifinals of the sixteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today. Playing against A. Hunt Marckwald of the local club,

Retail financing of new passenger automobiles, which recently became a matter of interest to President Roosevelt, amounted in 1937 to more than $1,060,000,000, which was about 4 per cent below the 1936 level and 2 per cent below 1929,. the Department of Commerce announced today.

Secretary Morgenthau invited tenders tonight for Treasury bills in the approximate amount of $50,000,000, bids to be opened on Monday. The tenders will be received by Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, Monday.

Although at 25 years of age he was president and general manager of the Texas Midland Railroad, owned by his mother, Hetty Green, Colonel Edward H. R. Green felt he had to beg her for $200 to attend the Chicago World's Fair, according to a letter introduced yesterday at the proceedings at which Florida, Texas, Massachusetts and New York are contending for the inheritance taxes on his S40,000.000 estate.

After three and a half hours deliberation this afternoon an all-male jury acquitted Mrs. Margaret Pearson, 32 years old, of a charge of murdering her policeman-husband, Wilhelm, 38, by shooting him last Oct. 3 on the lawn of their home at 312 Hickory Street, Kearny.

Joseph De Blasia, 46 years old, said to be one of the world's foremost plate-glass experts and patentee of several solutions for silvering and polishing large mirrors, was held in $2,500 bail in Felony Court yesterday for possessing an army pistol he had kept as a souvenir of his service in the Eighty-second Division of the A. E. F.

Five women, standing before an audience of more than 100 persons yesterday afternoon in the headquarters of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 480 Lexington Avenue, intently focused their eyes upon two girls whose lips moved soundlessly.

The Court of Appeals held today that the State must accept liability for damages to persons and vehicles traveling along highways in cases where stones fall from an overhanging cliff or mountainside. The court so ruled in sending back to the Court of Claims for determination of damages the suit brought against the State by Edward C. Doulin of Newburgh.

WASIINGTON. Jan. 27.-The following marine corps changes were announced today, dated Jan. 24: MAJORS Richards, W. P., Guam, to Department of Pacific, San Francisco, Calif. Gilman, F. S., the Idaho, to 15th Battalion, Galveston, Texas. CAPTAINS Gamble, H. W., San Francisco, Calif., on April 1, ordered home, to retire on June 1.

The Kosciuszko Foundation of New York, a living memorial to General Thaddeus Kosciuszko, Polish patriot and a hero of the American Revolution, will give its fifth annual "Night in Poland" ball tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Detective Edward Roos, assigned to special patrol duty with the Bronx Park station was killed early the aic yesterday morning when the police ing pr car he was driving crashed into a the ge: permanent traffic stanchion at Boston and Gun Hill Roads, Roos, who has been a member of the force since 1926, was 34 years old. He was married and lived at 960 East 219th Street. Two children also survive.

Frank T. Warburton, secretarytreasurer of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon given by the board of managers to mark his fifty years of service with the institute. The luncheon was held at 25 South Street.

Ralph Bucklin Bardwell, chairman of the board of the Pittsfield Third National Bank and Trust Company, with which he had been identified continuously for seventy-four years, died here today. He was 94 years old. Mr. and Mrs. Bardwell celebrated their seventy-first wedding anniversary on Oct. 30, last.

The van Zeeland report which is published today is the latest of a long series of efforts undertaken during a turbulent decade to state the problem of economic recovery in international terms. In the Summer of 1929,

The van Zeeland report received its warmest welcome tonight from financiers and economists who long have been clamoring for the revival of international lending and for a start toward economic disarmament. Elsewhere its reception was friendly but by no means enthusiastic.
Several first-round knockouts were recorded last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, when the Trinity Club sponsored a Golden Gloves elimination 135-pound sub-novice tournament.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 26: Miles, Col. S., General Staff Corps; 1 day's leave, Jan. 26. Hedrick, Lt. Col. L. H., Judge Advocate General's Department; 3 months' leave, March 23. Lord, R. H., Infantry, Washington, D. C., to 26th Infantry, Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y.

Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., advanced to the final in defense of his Florida Winter golf championship for the Ponce de Leon Cup on. St. Augustine Links today. He played brilliantly to eliminate Oscar Evers of Jacksonville, 4 and 2,

Secretary Morgenthau said today that a plan for loans to small business men was one of many ideas being considered by the Administration as an aid to business and industry. The Cabinet member said he could not discuss the details.

One unexpected effect of the visit by Premier Benito Mussolini to Germany last September was seen today when, much to everybody's surprise, the goosestep was performed for the first time in the annals of Italian military history by 2,000 Black Shirts reviewed by Mussolini.

There will not be such a wide selection of snow-covered slopes and trails for the Eastern skiing army tomorrow and Sunday as there has been the past few weekends, according to the weather reports from the "Northlands" yesterday.

Harris A. Dunn, who has been a trustee of the North River Savings Bank since 1919 has been elected honorary vice president of that institution, it was announced yesterday. Bromwell Ault, president of the International Printing Ink Corportion has been elected to the board of trustees.
Josiah Byram Millet, inventor of a submarine signaling device and an artist, writer and pioneer in aviation, died today at his home, 50 Fairweather Street, Cambridge, in his eighty-sixth year.

Nick Kenny, who conducts a radio column, invades the variety field this week at Loew's State Theatre, where he and Dolly Dawn, singer, are the co-featured headliners of the new stage show. The bill also includes Herman Hyde, comedian, assisted by Sally Burrill;

Charlie Beetham, Ohio State alumnus and never before considered an iron man, will go after a double in the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz.

Field tests in television, "broad in from New York Ci scope, and embracing the determination of the fundamental standards for television service in the United States," now being carried reviewed yesterday at the closing sessions of the Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by Dr. Ralph R. Beal, research director of the Radio Corporation of America.

Officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that as a result of tests conducted by the Bureau of Air Commerce the restrictions recently imposed upon their Model 14 transport airplane have been removed and the corporation is proceeding with normal deliveries.

Negotiations for the sale of the traffic signal division of the Tokeim Oil Tank and Pump Company to the Automatic Signal Corporation of New York are nearing completion, Charles M. Neizer, president of the Tokeim Company, announced today.

George E. Schilling, principal of Bradford High School for the past eighteen years, died tonight at the age of 66. Mr. Schilling came here from Mrs. Franklin, Pa., in 1920. He attended Bucknell University and was a battery mate of Christy Mathewson on the college baseball team.

In the most active buying of the last few months, hide prices this week have drifted lower for net losses of 1\2 to 1 cent a pound. Sales of leather have run to good quantities, notably in the calfskin division, but shoe manufacturers, despite sufficiently better demand to warrant advances in their production schedules, have continued to buy only their immediate needs.

With a terrific detonation that shook four towns, a column of flame 200 feet high shot up from one of the world's biggest explosives factories at Ardeer, Ayrshire, this afternoon and for some time the gravest fears were felt for 3,000 workers known to be within the grounds.
Mrs. Laura M. Curtis and James F. Curtis, New York attorney and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury from 1909 to 1913, were divorced in United States District Court today.

Strained trade relations which have existed for nearly two years between this country and Australia were restored to normal today, the State Department announced. Australia was restored to the list of countries entitled to receive most-favored-nation treatment and generalization of concessions granted in all reciprocal trade agreements the United States may negotiate.

Two years ago Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, discovered that the city magistrates were suspending sentence in 46.5 per cent of the traffic cases that came before them. This figure represented the average for all the magistrates; one of them, it was found, was suspending sentence in 95 per cent of his traffic cases.

Conditions for ice yachting were reported yesterday as about perfect on all the lakes in this State and New Jersey, and preparations were made for racing this coming weekend. The ice was so hard that it was figured even an unexpected thaw today or tomorrow could not upset plans.

The educational work of the French nuns of the Order of Sainte Ursule de la Sainte Vierge, whose mother house is in Bruges, Belgium, will be aided by the proceeds from the annual Winter dance of the alumnae of the Academy of Notre Dame de Lourdes, this city, tonight in Le Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Wheat and corn futures declined moderately in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today to new low levels on the current downturn. May wheat sold at 93 cents, or 6 1/4 cents under the recent high point, and May corn at 59 3/4 cents showed a recession of 3 1/4 cents from its recent peak.

Returning to the winning column with some splendid play, Jake Schaefer of Chicago handily defeated Welker Cochran of San Francisco at the Strand Academy yesterday in both the seventh and eighth blocks of their 3,500-point match for the world 28.2 balkline billiard championship.
The Workers Alliance made public yesterday a detailed statement of funds collected by it from relief recipients and sympathizers and of the uses to which the money had been put.

A resolution calling for permanent committees to carry out a program for housing projects in 100 American key cities at a cost of $1,000,000,000 was adopted today by the conference of Realty Factors of America, Inc., attended by about ninety realtors from sixty-five cities.

Mr. and Mrs. Woodward Babcock of 158 East Seventieth Street and Mill Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Babcock, to Dr. Robbert S. Millen of Westbury, L. I., son of Mrs. John Millen and the late Mr. Millen of Norfolk, Va.

The marriage of Miss Jane Caryl Anderson, daughter of Mrs. Percy Edward Anderson of Westport, Conn., to Charles Henschel Conland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Holton Conland of Hartford, took place yesterday in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Westport. The Very Rev. Walter H. Gray, Dean of Christ Church Cathedral, Hartford, performed the ceremony.

A letter from Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut urging support of the campaign to raise $400,000 to pay off the debt incurred in the building of the new auditorium and study hall for the Kent School, Kent, Conn., and to provide for the erection of an administratien building was made public yester day by the committee in charge of the drive.

Herr Hitler is to enjoy a Roman holiday some time next Spring. The Eternal City is striving to make itself worthy of the visitor. For some weeks a commission headed by Count Ciano, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has been pondering the program. of ceremonies and selecting the Triumphal Way along which the Aryan conqueror shall ride.

A hearing on the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the certificates of deposit representing ten-year secured 6 1/2 per centsinking fund gold bonds due April 1934, of the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., will be held here by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Feb. 9.

Delivery of 3,187 airplanes and 6,014 airplane engines during 1937 brought the aircraft industry its best year since the World War, Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce, reported to the annual meeting of the chamber here yesterday.

Kreeper the Turtle has a right to be proud. Kreeper was what is known to medical science as "an interesting case" on the 1937 roll of operative patients at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Birds and Beasts. Dr. James R. Kinney,
Stocks weakened to low levels of year in final hour, but rallied slightly at the close; turnover, 1,208,050 shares. All classes of bonds lower; transactions, $9,105,600.

The New York of the Hamburg American Line will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports On board are Major John S. Courtauld, Captain Cecil J. Crocker,Mr. and Mrs. M. B. Herbrick, Erwin Bockelman, Dr. and Mrs. Hugo Hofmann, Gerhard Certel, Dr. Albrecht Schackow, Mrs. I. L. Simonis, Mrs. Hans Schmidt and Mrs. A. Thompson and H. Kluver.

MANHATTAN DIECK, AMELIA (Aug. 4, 1937). Gross assets, $32,093; net, $29,675. To Lulu Donnelly, niece, $1,500; Augustus J., Harry T. and Albert J. Dick, grandnephews, and Margaret M. Campbell, grandniece, one-fourth residue each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and securities, $20,861. Amend Amend, attorneys, 135 William St.

A contract calling for $15,000 for one season's play with the Pittsburgh Pirate eleven was in the mail today, addressed to Byron (Whizzer) White, All-America quarterback at the University of Colorado.
Before there can be any sound and wholesome increase in residential building, the present large volume of repossessed real estate in the hands of lending institutions must be assimilated, George L.

Bankers Securities Corporation-For 1937: Net profit after expenses, Federal and State income taxes and $716,487 adjustment of security values to cost or market, whichever lower, amounted to $127,974. Net profit in 1936 was $1,134,254 after $48,639 deduction for adjustment of security values.

President Roosevelt discussed with Governor Gordon Browning of Tennessee the latter's plan for State purchase of private utilities and indicated that he would remain aloof from the factional political controversy in Tennessee.

The Austrian Government is taking strong measures against the illegal Nazi organization in this city. Its supreme chief, former Captain Josef Leopold, was detained all day at police headquarters and re leased tonight with an indication that the questioning would continue tomorrow. His right-hand man,

The rate increase which the Brooklyn Union Gas Company is seeking of the Public Service Commission would mean about a 7 per cent increase in the average monthly bill, John I. Blanchfield, assistant vice president of the company, testified yesterday before the commission.

A warning that if business does not restrain its "consumer gouging" practices the government will be compelled to curb the monopolistic combinations he said were responsible, was given last night by Senator James P. Pope of Idaho in an address at the annual dinner of the Williston Academy Alumni Association at the Ambassador Hotel.

The Richard Wagner Society will sponsor a concert Sunday evening, Feb. 27, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. An all-Wagner program will enlist the services of Elizabeth Rethberg, Florence Easton, Lauritz Melchior and Ludwig Hofmann, accompanied by the Philadelphia Orchestra under the baton of Fritz Reiner.

An injunction permanently restraining Campagnoli Son, Inc., of 41 Broad Street and the company's three officers from further dealing in securities in this State was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lydon on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.

Small increases in deposits and also in total assets were made in 1937 by the mutual savings banks of the country, which operate in seventeen States and hold about one-fifth of all bank deposits, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

John M. Allison, whose reports to Washington have caused the United States officially to protest against fifteen illegal military entries of the United States Embassy property in Nanking, was slapped in the face by a Japanese sentry Wednesday.

At the annual stockholders' meeting of the Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation yesterday, John J. Watson, president, reported that profits in November and December, the first two months of the company's fiscal year, were slightly larger than those of the same months of 1936, despite some decline in its volume of business.
Dueling is still to be winked at in the Italian Army, according to the new military penal code just elaborated and submitted to Premier Mussolini.

The regular quarterly survey of its membership by the American Mutual Alliance, with eighteen of the twenty-three member casualty companies reporting their final figures, shows total net premiums for 1937 of $145,929,552 compared with $119,164,196 for the previous record year of 1936, a gain of 22.5 per cent.

The test of strength between Julius Streicher, anti-Semitic leader, and moderates in the government on the issue of suppression of his violently antiSemitic newspaper Stuermer, ended with a complete victory for the high priest of anti-Semitism. A special number of the Stuermer demanding the death penalty for Jewish men and Aryan women found guilty of having relations was released late last night and is on sale throughout the Reich today.

Mrs. Evangeline Johnson Stokowski and Prince Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky of Russia were married in Phoenix, Ariz., it was announced here today. The bride, the former Evangeline Brewster Johnson, a member of a New Brunswick, N. J., family, divorced Mr. Stokowski in Las Vegas, Nev., on Dec. 2. She won custody of their two daughters, Gloria Luba and Andrea Sadja.

Although most sections of the stock markets here, reflecting yesterday's declines in Wall Street, suffered a setback today, comparatively little selling took place. Giltedge issues drooped, but among the foreign bonds German loans were strong. Transatlantic shares were in some demand and United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

The Boston Maine fast streamliner, "Flying Yankee," halted its scheduled non-stop run to Portland here today to pay a debt to a 15-year-old boy. While passengers waved from train windows, Engineman Ernest H. Dow of Biddeford leaned from his cab to present a pair of new skiis to Lawrence Nedeau, whose only comment at the moment was "Gosh!"
Senator Burke, testifying before a judiciary subcommittee, assailed the NLRB as a "curse" to labor and as partly to blame for the recession. [Page 1.]
The Rev. Dr. William McNally, a former chaplain of the State Legislature, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Thomas Boose. His age was 85.

Lady Ribblesdale entertained tonight with a dinner at the Everglades Club. Among her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Captain and Mrs. R. Am- PHY cotts Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes, Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr., Mrs. John W. Garrett, Mrs. Benjamin Rogers, Mrs. Wesson Seyburn, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Prince Rospigliosi, Charles A. Munn, Milton W. Holden, Lytle Hull and Prince George of Russia.

Neutrality in foreign affairs and freedom from alliances that might lead this country into war, further effort to collect the war debts of defaulting nations, and the fingerprinting of all persons in the United States, were urged upon Congress today, and the pending Ludlow war referendum was opposed in resolutions adopted at the closing session of the Women's Conference on National at Defense.

Airplane crashes of recent years, of which more than 50 per cent have been attributed to "pilot error," were traced yesterday to "pilot fatigue" in a report made to the transport section of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences at its closing session in Columbia University.

A group of New York financiers b headed by B. R. Armour have a pledged $500,000 and a local committee of thirty members with Lloyd G. Buckingham as chairman, has al raised $100,000, assuring the opening of the Aspinook Mills on March 1.
Frederick Steiwer, one of the few Republican Senators to survive the "Roosevelt landslide". in 1932, resigned today to return to his law practice after next Monday.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued complaints against eight fireworks companies and their trade association for monopolistic practices and against Charles Atlas, Ltd., 115 East Twenty-third Street, New York, for misrepresentative advertising.

Vienna reports that King Zog of Albania is about. to announce his engagement to Countess Geraldine Apponyi of Hungary raise the question whether such a union would be approved by the Vatican. The Countess is a Roman Catholic.

Displaying a high-powered attack which enabled it to gain a 5-to-0 advantage in the first period, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club conquered the Brooklyn Bruins, 15 to 3, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association test at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Mrs. Suzanne Hutchinson Neville of Pinehurst and Philadelphia will be married to Livingston Ludlow Biddle 2d, son of Colonel and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle of Philadelphia, tomorrow morning in Philadelphia. Mrs. Neville is a daughter of Mrs. Andrew S. Burke and the late Rev. Andrew H. Burke.

The six-story elevator apartment house containing 121 rooms and six stores at 442 West 160th Street and 2,013-15 Amsterdam Avenue has been sold by the V. R. Realty Company to F. B. Realties, Inc., represented by Schiff, Dorfman Stein, attorneys.
John P. Broaca, father of John J. Broaca, former New York Yankee pitcher, died tonight at Lawrence General Hospital after an illness of several weeks.

United States crude oil reserves, having gained 584,511,398 barrels in 1937, now stand at 13,489,457,994 barrels, a new record, The Oil and Gas Journal reported today in its annual survey of petroleum reserves.

The Town Hall Club's mid-season luncheon will be held at 1 P.M. today at the Hotel Astor, with William Lyon Phelps, professor emeritus of Yale, as toastmaster and -with representatives of the stage, screen and musical worlds as guests.

The 1,200 families who are eager tenants of the fancy apartments in the low-rent housing project in Williamsburg, uneasy about making a complete break from their recent environment, are wary of the equally fancy stores in the project property and are giving their trade to shopkeepers in neighboring tenement buildings.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $4,896,893,000 for the principal cities throughout the country, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents a decline of 18.4 per cent from the 1937 total of $6,002,580,000 and is the eleventh consecutive week in which the volume was below the previous year.
Fire destroyed the main residence building on the late George F. Baker's horseshoe plantation near this city today. The Tallahassee Democrat said the loss was estimated at $75,000 to $100,000.

The Federal Power Commisssion's proposal for an investigation of the "inside financial set-up" of Pennsylvania subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company was blocked today for the second time by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

Another phase of the dispute between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization came to the fore here today when Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the C. I. O., announced that his union had not paid the special A. F. of L. assessment for organizing action against the C. I. O.

Forty United States Marine planes from Quantico, Va., commanded by Colonel Roy Geiger, flew in this afternoon, ending a flight to Winter manoeuvres that started at the Virginia marine base last Sunday. Today's hop was from Camaguey, Cuba.

The marriage of Miss Jean Underwood North, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry ThQmpson North of Glendon, Harrington Sound, Bermuda, to Edward Coghlin Gibbons, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Miles Gibbons, took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, 430 East Eightysixth Street. The Rev. Thomas J. Delilant performed the ceremony.
A general policy was set forth by the Public Service Commission today allowing municipal power plants to enter territories of private utilities failing to supply adequate service therein.

Louis Eliasberg, president of the Finance Company of America, at the stockholders' annual meeting here today reported net profit $199,753 for 1937 after all operating expenses, interest charges and provision for Federal and State taxes, equal,
Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York, will address the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on Feb. 3 at 65 Liberty

South Dakota asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to exempt essential food products from any freight-rate increases. The State, through Herman L. Bode, Assistant Attorney General, filed a brief in connection with the railroads' pending application for a general increase of 15 per cent in freight rates.

Helen Simpson, author of "Boomerang" and other novels, in several of which she collaborated with Clemence Dane, will arrive from England on the Normandie about Feb. 2 for a brief lecture tour. Miss Simpson's new novel, "Under Capricorn," which Macmillan published last week, is a story of Australia of a century ago.
The Syracuse basketball game rallied in the closing few minutes to take the measure of Niagara, 25-23, tonight.

The split in the ranks of the C. I. O. on the issue of peace with the A. F. of L. was accentuated last night when Michael J. Quill A. L. P. councilman and international president of the Transport Workers Union, challenged the posi tion taken on the issue by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. 'Both the T. W. U. and I.
Fay Murray, president of the Nashville Southern Association Baseball Club announced today the merging of the Volunteers' farm system with that of the Dodgers.

Twelve acres in Rumson, N. J., part of the holdings of L. Suffern Tailer, have been sold by William H. Hintelmann, broker. One of the parcels was a tract of nine acres of unimproved land on Honeysuckle Hill, on the east side of Bellevue Avenue.
The annual election of Mecca Temple, the pioneer temple of the Mystic Shrine of North America and Canada, was held in Mecca's Mosque, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, last night.
The annual election of Mecca Temple, the pioneer temple of the Mystic Shrine of North America and Canada, was held in Mecca's Mosque, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, last night.

Captain Harvey Delano, commanding officer of the battleship Idaho, was ordered to duty by the Navy Department - yesterday as supervisor of New York Harbor one of the few posts in which naval officers serve under jurisdiction of the War Department.

Robert Grant 3d, national amateur racquets champion, and three professionals advanced to the semifinal round of the first invitation open tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

H. M. Tennent, Ltd., the London theatre management corporation, has decided no player engaged in its productions shall concurrently work in films. Hitherto, theatre managers, aware of the publicity value of the screen, have given actors permission to take concurrent film engagements at London studios, but sometimes there have been complaints of actors arriving at theatres late, tired and hungry after an exacting day in the studios.

A health program, introduced experimentally in 149 elementary schools last year, has proved successful in helping the children form better health habits, Dr. I. H. Goldberger, assistant director of health education, disclosed yesterday. He presented his findings at the nineteenth annual Health Education Institute meeting at the Julia Richman High School.

A charge of homicide against Joseph Lamorti of 1,755 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, in connection with the death of Anna Mae Buttler, 6 years old, of 63 East 101st Street, in an automobile accident Jan. 11,
A warning to property owners that Monday is the last day on which frontage water charges may be paid without penalty was issued by Almerindon Portfolio, City Treasurer.

Prominent Smith alumnae expressed today a decided preference for a man as president of the college to succeed Dr. Neilson, who has announced that he will retire next year. Such an appointment would be in the Smith tradition, they hold, for all three presidents of the college have been men.

Alexander Shuford of the Shuford chain of textile mills in and around Hickory, N. C., proposed to the Council, as an initial step in a plan to abolish the old mill village system, that the city of Hickory take over two Highland millvillages, sidewalks, water and sewerage systems that lie within the city limits.

The first of three intersectional matches among the B group teams of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, held yesterday on the Junior League Club courts, saw the Westchester team emerge a winner and New York both as winner and loser.

Three coast-to-coast air lines announced yesterday that for the next month they would carry, as nonpaying guests, wives who accompany their husbands on certain portions of their lines. The plan is to overcome the fears of women who frown on the use of air travel by their husbands.

Representative Edward A. Kenney of New Jersey accidentally plunged to his death early this morning from a sixth floor room of a local hotel a few hours after he had attended as a guest of honor the annual Congressional Dinner of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce.
Amid scenes that approached riot proportions the City Council, harassed by demands for a balanced budget, passed today an ordinance levying a 2 per cent city sales tax.

The United States' chances of retaining the Swaythling Cup, emblematic of the men's table tennis championship of the world, were blasted tonight when the Austrian squad defeated the American team, 5 to 3, in a play-off.

Directors of the Diamond Match Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, as well as two regular semi-annual distributions of 75 cents each on the preferred stock. Last year's cash disbursements included 50 cents on March 1 and 25 cents each on Sept. and Dec. 1.

Only six matches were actually waged in the opening round of the annual M. M. Sterling Trophy squash tennis tourney at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, although fifteen players advanced into the second round and one into the third.

Two quick goals in the third period by Johnny Gottselig gave the Black Hawks an uphill 4-to-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight and enabled the Hawks to brighten their chances of a spot in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs.

Professor Leo Frobenius, German anthropologist and collector of rock paintings, has sent his assistant, Fraeulein Karin Hisslnk, to America with a 20 by 32 foot reproduction of an Altamira (Spain) cave painting for the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

Miss Marguerite Brokaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Crosby Brokaw of this city and The Chimneys, Oyster Bay, L. I., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Crocker of New York and Pebble Beach, Calif., in the home of her parents here, 984 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Philip Jones of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.
Lumbar production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index moved to 55.2 from 53.1. The figure for the week ended Jan. 23, 1937, was 65.1.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Boston Maine Railroad to borrow $2,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on condition that adequate security is posted with the Federal lending agency. Commissioner Charles D. Mahaffie dissented without opinion.

W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the board of the Union Pacific Railroad and chairman of the Business Advisory Council for the Department of Commerce, will address the-Bond Club of New York at its luncheon today in the Bankers Club. His topic will be "A Business Man Looks at Washington." Nevil Ford, president of the Bond Club, will preside.
City Judge Acton M. Hill held today that the State Legislature had no power to put the words "New York World's Fair 1939" on 1938 automobile license plates, and ruled that it was unconstitutional.

D. Blake Bonnett, formerly a member of the old firm of Bonnett, Schenck Co., New York wholesale importers of tea, coffee and spices, died yesterday at the home of his son, Louis B. Bonnett, here. He was 93 years old.

An investigation into the affairs of Thomas Griffith of 120 Broadway, securities brokers, was begun yesterday by John J. Bennett Jr., New York State Attorney General. Three employes of the concern were questioned under oath by Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, chief of the bureau of securities, in his office in the State Building, 80 Centre Street. Other witnesses will be examined today.

Following is the unofficial text of the report made to various European countries by Paul van Zeeland of Belgium as made available to the press by the State Department today. Explanation was made that this was not a United States Government document and accuracy of the text was not guaranteed:

The Pine Grove Bank, a private institution at Pine Grove, Schuylkill County, closed its doors today. It was the first bank in Pennsylvania to fail since November, 1935. It had deposits of about $355,000 and liquid assets of roughly $18.000.

Rear Admiral and Mrs. Wilson Brown have come from the Naval Academy at Annapolis to the Weylin. Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes and Mrs. Theodore Fiske Savage will give a dinner Feb. 14 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center, followed by a theatre party, for Miss Emily Del Mar of Greenwich, Conn., a debutante.

Concordia Prep won a spirited overtime basketball game Iona Prep, 26-25, on the winner's court in Bronxville yesterday. A goal from the foul line provided the point that Concordia needed for the victory in a three-minute extra session after the teams had finished the regulation time tied at 21-all.

John A. Dilliard, former president of the now defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, which failed in 1933 with $69,000,000 in mortgages and mortgage certificates outstanding, was sentenced yesterday to serve eighteen months in Federal prison for conspiracy to use the mails fraudulently in the sale of certificates.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, national squash racquets champion for the last two years, annexed the New York State title today for the second time when she defeated Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr., three-time metropolitan winner, in the final of the seventh annual tournament.

Volume control of the movement of citrus fruit from Texas is expected to become effective Saturday, if final approval is received tomorrow from Secretary of Agriculture Wallace on a proration limit set by the Texas Control Committees last night.
Foes of the Federal Child Labor Amendment today mapped a new plan of action by which they hope to put New York State definitely on record against ratification.
Mutual assistance for Jewish people was urged today by Albert Einstein, the scientist, in a greeting to the National Council for Jewish Women in session here.

Today's major events: "Otello," afternoon, "Lucia di Lammermoor," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Vronsky and Babin, duo pianists, Carnegie Hall, evening; Alton Jones, pianist, Town Hall, evening; New York Civic Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

LLOYD'S: THE GENTLEMEN OF THE COFFEE HOUSE, by Ralph Straus. (Carrick Evans, $3.75.) An account of the institution during three centuries. ETCHED IN WORDS, by Gertrude Ryder Bennett. (Putnam, $2.) A volume of poems.

Scott Sanders, Queens attorney, who recently had been cited on ambulance-chasing charges before the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, was found unconscious yesterday afternoon, under unexplained circumstances, in the kitchen of the High Hat Club, which he owns, at Merrick Road and 108th Avenue, Jamaica South, Queens.

The directors of the Babcock Wilcox Co., voted yesterday to split the company's stock on a three-forone basis and to increase the authorized stock to 1,000,000 no-par shares from 250,000. The company,

Solon Biffle, "grand old man" of the nation's fox hunting fraeternity, died at his home near Newbern yesterday. "Uncle Solie," as he was known to hundreds of fox hunters and fox hound breeders, was a familiar figure at the National Fox Hunters Association field trials.

Treasury procurement officials said today they were preparing to obliterate from a $3,000 mural in the new Postoffice Department building Rockwell Kent's exhortation to the Puerto Ricans to "change chiefs."

Prime Minister Geronimo Ramirez Brown announced today that several commercial establishments would be fined for not providing chairs for employes when they are not busy and for not giving two hours for lunch.

As far as this country is concerned, the report by Paul van Zeeland brings two fundamental questions squarely into the foreground. First, can Germany return to freer economic intercourse with other nations while maintaining a rigid system of control at home? Second, does the government wish to cooperate?
Declines of prices in foreign cotton markets caused more selling pressure yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here and the May delivery fell to 8.38 cents a pound, compared with 8.70 on Jan. 11.

Senator Barkley, the Senate majority leader, after a long conference with President Roosevelt late today, stated that next week the Senate will consider in order the conference reports on the housing and crop control bills.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Col. Henry D. Cushing, Coast Artillery Corps Reserve, 67 West 44th St., New York, N. Y., is relieved from his present assignment to the 539th Coast Artillery (AA). Each of the following prospective graduates of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps, Fordham University, assigned to the Second Coast Artillery District, is attached for training to the organization indicated, effective upon acceptance of appointment in the Officers Reserve Corps::

Liquor and beer licenses for eleven restaurants and three hotels, beer licenses for six groceries and five restaurants, and a restaurant wine license in various parts of the State have been canceled for violations of the beverage law, it was announced yesterday by the State Liquor Authority.

Federal Judge John C. Knox reserved decision yesterday on an application filed by Hyman I. Fischback, attorney for the J. Edward Jones Petroleum Corporation, for dismissal of the company's petition for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

Convinced that a grand jury investigation should settle the question of the legality of Councilman Hugh Quinn's election from Queens last year, Charles P. Sullivan, District Attorney of Queens, said yesterday that he would ask the Queens County grand jury to proceed with the inquiry.

Bernard McCambley, last surviving member of Uzal Dodd Post, G. A. R., of Orange, and a familiar figure at patriotic celebrations in this area, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Roscoe C. W. Jones, after a three-week illness. He was 93 years old.

The ten-room house on a plot 20 by 100 feet at 1,330 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the estate of Mrs. George C. Kirk to Harold Weidner for investment. The Bulkley Horton Company, brokers, negotiated the sale.

Movement of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 27 unless. specified: At Washington Yard, Jan. 28: Acushnet, Semmes. At Boston Yard: Cassin, Mugford. At Philadelphia Yard: Hatfield. Kane. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Kewaydin. Jan. 2R: Veea.

Stewart H. Nickerson, make-up compositor for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died on Thursday night of a heart ailment at his home, 136 Seaman Avenue. Mr. Nickerson had been taken ill on Thursday morning while at work and, after treatment at the Times Annex emergency hospital, had gone home. His age was 38.

Dr. Chauncey Guy Suits of the research laboratories of the General Electric Company, Schenectady, 'N. Y., received last night the award of Eta Kappa Nu, honorary electrical engineering association, after a committee of judges had chosen him as "America's outstanding young electrical engineer for 1937."
Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart, accompanied by Mrs. Stewart's daughter, Miss Nancy Penn Smith, and the Misses Barbara B. Lucas and Ann Mather, have come from Philadelphia to the Waldorf-Astoria.

The fifth annual "Night in Poland" ball took place last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. One of the outstanding events of the season, the ball drew an attendance of several hundred persons of prominence in society, diplomatic and educational circles, including a party of distinguished guests of honor, among whom were Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador; Charles A.
Yale University boxers tonight won eight of the nine bouts in their international boxing contest with Queens University. Two of Yale's victories came when Queens men defaulted.

PATROLMEN To take effect 12 midnight, Jan, 27. John McElllgott, 75th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 2, 1908. To take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 31. John J. Duffy, 110th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 3, 1912.

Dr. C. Stuart Gager, director of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, announced yesterday that he was satisfied no brush fire started by employes of the garden had destroyed the Inari shrine in the Japanese garden Tuesday.

In a letter to stockholders the Symington-Gould Corporation said yesterday that it had received proxies for 62 per cent of the 788,870 common shares, which are entitled to vote, in favor of the acquisition of the McConway Torley Corporation.

A national used car contest will be started next Tuesday by the Nash Motors division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation as the feature of a new national merchandising campaign aimed at the buyers of used automobiles, according to C. H. Bliss, vice president and director of sales.

Municipalities in nineteen States are ineligible to obtain Federal aid 3 under the United States Housing Act because State Legislatures have not provided the enabling legislation needed under the terms of the Federal law, the January issue of Public Housing Progress, published by the National Public Housing Conference, points out.

Editor and Publisher, trade journal of the newspaper industry, published in its weekly issue yesterday a letter by Ferdinand Lundberg, author of "America's 60 Families," replying to charged made by Carr V.

Overnight consideration of the Conway committee's recommendations for reorganization of the administrative set-up of the New York Stock Exchange, which propose, among other changes, a salaried president and a reduction in the number of governors, failed to alter the hearty reception accorded the first appearance of the report.

The paving of the last two miles T of dirt roads in Manhattan and the in replacement of small sewer lines fac laid before the Civil War form part of a project that has been submitted to the Works Progress Administration, Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs announced yesterday.

Patrick H. Lennon, long a leading political figure in the Bronx, died yesterday in Morrisania Hospital at the age of 68. Born in Ireland, he was brought to this country as an infant. He was an organizer of the Highbridge Democratic Club and its president for several terms.
The New York City District of the National Semi-pro Baseball Congress will hold a meeting today at 2 o'clock at the Commodore Hotel to formulate plans for the city tournament.

Under the Federal housing program, as Mayor La Guardia points out, New York City cannot hope to receive more than about $30,000,000 as its allocation. This would accommodate about 5,000 families. But the Mayor estimates that there are 500,000 families in this city who cannot afford to pay $30 a month for an apartment, and the problem is to take care of as many of these as possible.

A settlement of $145,000 has been agreed upon, subject to court approval, in the $756,000 suit entered by the General Investment Corporation against nine former officers or directors, two other individuals and four corporations, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.

Miss Peggy Flockhart, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert Seaton Flockhart, was introduced to society today at a reception in her home here. Miss Flockhart wore a white velvet frock with a corsage of camellias and Mrs. Flockhart was gowned in sapphire blue uncut velvet.

President Lazaro Cardenas will not insist that Mexico's two big labor unions merge, he revealed in a speech at Orizaba, Veracruz, before members of the Confederacion Regional de Obrera Mexicana [Regional Confederation of Mexican Workers].

The need for sound research, creation of a strong promotion department and building up of a sales force are stressed in "The Road Ahead for Newspapers," a presentation now being prepared by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, under the direction of the bureau's expansion committee.
Nearly every one who viewed the scene of the Niagara bridge collapse today exclaimed: "I wonder what will happen when the ice bridge goes out and carries that mass of steel downstream?"

A two-piano recital before a large Carnegie Hall audience need occasion no surprise when the quality of the performance is such as Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin proffered last night. For this Russian item, heard here for the first time last season, has all but metamorphosed a long neglected musical medium to the rank of the solo piano.

Miss Gloria Ruth Haydock, daughter of Mrs. Vivian Haydock of this city and of Roy Haydock, and Guy Standing Jr., also of New York, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. They will be married on Wednesday at the home of Mr. Standing's sister, Miss Katherine B. Standing, 170 West Seventythird Street, by the Rev. Dr. Charles Francis McCoy of Oyster Bay, L. I.

Six national champions have entered the two-mile run at the Millrose A. A. indoor games at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight, it was announced yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz. They are Tommy Deckard, indoor steeplechase;

LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR-Opera in Italian in three acts and four scenes. Music by Gaetano Donizettt; book by Salvatore Cammarano. Conductor, Gennaro Papo; stage director, Desire Defrere. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Clifford W. Kissinger, for thirteen years president of the National Philatelic Society of America, died tonight at his home here after a - cerebral stroke suffered shortly after Christmas. His age was 64.

Francis D. Weaver, president of the New Jersey State Board of Tax Appeals, died of pneumonia today in Cooper Hospital here. His age was 70. He had suffered from angina pectoris and pneumonia developed. He was taken to the hospital on Dec. 24.
Bernd Rosemeyer, famous German racing driver and 1937 winner of the Vanderbilt Cup in the United States, was killed today in an automobile race on the Frankfort on the MainDarmstadt road.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Beatrice F. Kunhardt, daughter of Mrs. L. Stuart Wing of 116 East Sixty-eighth Street, and of H. Rudolph Kunhardt of this city, to Samuel A. Culbertson 2d, son of Mrs. Wallace F. Kirk of Chicago and of Craig Culbertson of New York. The wedding will take place here on June 16.

Hope of Administration backing for legislation to put interstate corporations under a Federal licensing system grew among supporters of the measure today after Senator Borah had discussed it with the President.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Scoring in double figures for five of the nine innings required, Jake Schaefer, world 28.2 balkline champion, last night defeated his challenger, Welker Cochran, 250 to 96, in the tenth block of their fourteenblock match at the Strand Billiard Academy.

Jake Lvovsky, named with Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, fugitive racketeer, and Samuel Gross as organizers of a ring of smugglers who imported $10,000,000 worth of morphine and heroin from China in six shipments, received a prison sentence of seven years yesterday after pleading guilty to ten indictments charging violation of the narcotic law.

We arrived late last night at the plantation of George B. Kearse which is located about five miles out of town, a bit off the county road. His hunting land embraces some 6,000 acres just about equally divided between fields, pine woods, swamps and meadows.

The Invitation list for Secretary Roper's conference of "small business men" next Wednesday soared over the 500 mark today. Additional invitations were sent to many business men who have, written either Mr. Roper or President Roosevelt in the last few days asking permission to attend or offering suggestions to aid business.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,127,000 bales, against 1,141,000 a week ago, 1,106,000 two weeks ago, 1,108,000 three weeks ago and 972,000 a year ago, of which American 722,000 bales, against 726,000 a week ago, 681,000 two weeks ago, 671,000 three weeks ago and 398,000 a year ago.

Nearly 200 railroads filed late today a petition in the Circuit Court of Appeals here, asking annulment of orders recently issued by the National Bituminous Coal Commission prescribing minimum prices for locomotive fuel which the carriers said would increase their fuel bill by $21,000,000.

Lord and Lady Mountbatten arrived today at the Miami Biltmore. Tonight they were guests of Viscount and Viscountess Weymouth, Lord Beaverbrook and Lord Forbes. Lord and Lady Mountbatten will leave tomorrow for Jamaica.

Congress was called upon by President Roosevelt today to authorize a huge increase in the national defense program of the country. His longawaited message, designed to provide armaments which he considers essential for national security and to inform the world as well, that the United States intends to be-pepared to defend herself against any aggression, was read in both houses at noon.

The New York Branch of the English-Speaking Union was the beneficiary of a concert of selections from the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas given last night at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, new headquarters of the branch, by the Blue Hill Troupe, a company of amateur Savoyards.

DAYTON, CHARLES W. (Jan. 4, 1936). Gross assets, $69,294; net, $64,970. To Frances Wanek Dayton, widow. Chief assets, transfers, $64,902. Abberley Bryde, attorneys, 42 Broadway. FAUR, PIERCE (May 5, 1937). Gross assets, $17,914; net, $15,116. To Anna Faur, widow, life estate in residue.

Both the smelting and producing interests reduced yesterday the price of refined copper to 10 cents a pound in the domestic market. Around noon, the American Smelting and Refining Company lowered its price for the metal from 10.25 to 10 cents and almost immediately the Kennecott Copper Corporation cut its price from 10.5 to 10 cents.

Putnam A. Bates Sr., consulting electrical engineer for the City of New York and chief of the New York Bureau of Fire Alarm Telegraph through the years of the World War, died yesterday at his home here.
One of Europe's most formidable intercollegiate skiing units, the German Universities contingent, arrived in New York last night aboard the S. S. New York of the Hamburg-American Line.
The training camp of the Giants in 1939 will be pitched in Honolulu, hard by famous Waikiki Beach, if plans are carried out.
A semi-official announcement today said permission to Catholic laity to attend the World Eucharistio Congress in Budapest next Summer has been refused primarily for "political reasons.
The six-story apartment house at 30 Crary Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Plaza Properties, Inc., Loomis J. Grossman, president.

John H. Cocks, retired sculptor and illustrator, died today at his home, 1,048 Arlington Avenue, Plainfield. He was 88 years old. He was born in New York and for many years lived in Brooklyn. He once was employed as an Illustrator by I both Harper's and Scribner's Magazines.

Barklie Henry, president of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, 105 East Twenty-second Street, announced yesterday that Mrs. Langbourne Williams and Dr. George Baehr had been elected to the association's board of managers.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in a preliminary statement reported today consolidated net earnings of $88,031,943 for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1937. The company received $36,672,635 from its investment in General Motors Corporation common stock.

Decentralization of industrial management by companies that would be "better off" with their headquarters outside of New York to give local centers of production a greater "stake" in industry was urged yesterday by W. Averill Harriman, chairman of the board of the Union Pacific Railroad and head of the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce.

John Grant, a stationary engineer for THE NEW YORK TIMES employed in The Times Building, 'Times Square, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 2,320 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, after a brief illness. Mr. Grant, who had been with THE TIMES since 1920, was 79 years old.

A throng of nearly 600 persons attended the annual Blue Ridge Ball last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. As in past years, the event was given in behalf of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Virginia, an institution providing an education in agriculture and domestic science for 200 boys and girls from isolated. mountain districts.

THE merry milers are about set for another brisk season on the indoor tracks. The real start will be made in Boston tonight, but, after that, attention will be concentrated on Madison Square Garden, where Glenn Cunningham, Archie San Romani and possibly Don Lash will hook up in such events as the Wanamaker Mile, the Baxter Mile and the Columbian Mile.

The net operating income of all the Class 1 railroads in 1937 was about 12.1 per cent below the total for 1936, according to preliminary estimates. The following table shows how estimated earnings for December and 1937 compare with preceding periods, the percentage of differences being shown but the last three figures being omitted:

Magistrate Anna M. Kross dismissed disorderly conduct charges against thirty Chinese yesterday, after chiding police for invading the place where they were alleged to have been gambling, and suggested that the police inspect the Union League Club.

Gordon Comstock Thorne, son of the late William C. Thorne, former president of Montgomery Ward Co., died today in Miami Beach, Fla., at the age of 44. He lived at 3,400 Lake Shore Drive. Surviving are his widow, Marion Bolin Thorne; a son, Montgomery Ward Thorne, 4, and a sister, Mrs. Helen Thorne Norcott.

Architects kept up yesterday the heavy filing of plans before the city's new Building Code goes into effect. Projects submitted in Manhattan included a public school for East Fourth Street to cost $369,000 and a flat costing $150,000 for a site in East Thirty-second Street. Numerous alterations also were filed.

This prosperous midland city was this morning "blacked out." Over its twenty-seven and one-half square miles, with 270,000 population, scarcely a light showed and certainly no light that would betray its position to hostile aircraft.

Officials of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) frequently had discussed the possibility of a consolidation of their road with the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway between 1924 and 1930, Clarence Michel, a former vice president of the Frisco, testified yesterday in Supreme Court.

The Japanese War Minister, General Gen Sugiyama, told Parliament today Japan must prepare to fight an unnamed third power because of the undeclared war against China. General Sugiyama assured Parliament that Japan's military strategists were "mapping plans carefully to meet all contingencies."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Soviet government announced today it had accepted assurances by Poland that it would take measures to prevent attacks on Russian trains, such as that reported at Dobunovo, Polish frontier town, last November.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in subdued activity on the local exchanges. In the cash markets, rye, cocoa, butter and lard advanced, but wheat, corn, oats, copper, tins, cotton, silk and rubber declined.
The Hofstra College women's basketball team defeated Brooklyn College, 20 to 14, at the Brooklyn gymnasium last night. The Hempstead, L. I., outfit held a 13-8 advantage at the end of the first half.

Grand Concourse, 2,545 (11-3167): Becker Concourse Corp to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtgs to Oct. 1, 1942, at 41/2 per cent; $133,662. 166th St, 429 E (9-2388); Anthony Cobucei to East River Savings Bank; extends mtg to Dec 1, 1942, at 41/2 per cent; $21,340.

The promotion of manners and serenity in youth was described last night as a great contribution which the small college could make to the public welfare by William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, speaking at the annual dinner of New York Alumni of Knox College at the Hotel Lafayette. Dr.

In a unanimous ruling, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reduced yesterday by almost $1,200,000 the aggregate assessments which the State Banking Department can levy against stockholders of the defunct Globe Bank and Trust Company.

The portions of the cabled report of John M. Allison, Third Secretary in charge of the United States Embassy at Nanking, on the faceslapping incident there Wednesday which the State Department made public today follow:

Governor Moore, at his office here, said today he would not call a special election to fill the vacancy caused in New Jersey's Congressional delegation by the death of Representative Edward A. Kenney. Mr. Kenney was killed in a fall from a window of his hotel in Washington early yesterday.

To the Congress of the United States: The Congress knows that for many years this government has sought in many capitals with the leaders of many governments to find a way to limit and reduce armaments and to establish at least the probability of world peace.

MANEHATTAN BACOI, FLORA (Nov. 26). Estate, more than $20,000. To Isaac Grenthal, brother, executor, 29 Morningside Ave., $5,000, specific Jewelry and life estate in residue; Gerald Bach, son, 92 Morningside Ave., one-half decedent's securities in trust and succeeding estate in one-half residue; Estelle Keller, daughter, executrix, 265 Ocean Ave., East Rockaway, one-half decedent's securities and succeeding estate in one-half residue; three specific bequests.

The Rev. Arthur P. S. Hyde, for the last twelve years rector of Holyrood Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue and West 179th Street, has been elected the fiftyfirst president of the New York Churchmen's Association. Dr. Hyde is a retired chaplain of the United States Army, with the rank of colonel.

Premier Camille Chautemps went before the Labor Commission of the Chamber of Deputies today to present his modernized labor charter and press for rapid action on this measure, on the success of which he is staking his new Cabinet.
President Eooseveit was 6 among those who sent congratulations today as the Yale Daily News, "the oldest college daily" in the Unit. d States, observed its sixtieth anniversary.

The first big guns in the major indoor track campaign will be fired in the Boston Garden tomorrow night when the Massachusetts Chapter of the Knights of Columbus stages its annual indoor games before what is expected to be a capacity crowd.

Twenty-four hours before the President's message on armaments was sent to Congress the State Department released for publication the text of its latest note protesting against new Japanese "acts of depredation" which have violated American rights in China.

With the expiration of the fortyeight-hour period that Governor Blanton Winship gave steamship companies and longshoremen to settle their wage differences, both parties today submitted statements on the Governor's order to explain why a settlement had not been reached.

Some signs of support were discernible in certain sections of the bond market yesterday, especially among the higher grade loans. Despite these moderate recovery movementx, scattered liquidation persisted in a sufficient number of pivotal issues to force the combined price average of domestic corporation obligations on the New York Stock Exchange down 0.08 point on the day to a new low level for 1937-38.
A contra-seasonal decline in cotton-mill activity last week caused the index to fall to 85.2 from 88.2, the revised figure for the previous week. It stood at 136.9 for the week ended Jan. 23, 1937.

Addition of 10,000 workers to the WPA rolls in this city, bringing the total on construction and white collar projects to 140,000, was authorized yesterday by the heads of the Works Progress Administration in Washington. Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local administrator, announced that 5,000 new WPA workers would be taken from the city home relief lists on Tuesday and 5,000 more requisitioned, effective Feb. 14.

Retail trade made a somewhat less favorable showing this week than last and department store sales, depending on the volume today, is likely to run under last year by 2 per cent or more, It was estimated yesterday.

Progress was reported today after a meeting of the Interdepartmental Banking Committee at which proposed legislation for the liquidation of bank holding companies was discussed. The meetings will continue next week.

Diplomatic action was undertaken by the United States yesterday in the case of John M. Allison, our representative at Nanking, who was slapped by a Japanese soldier. After a twohour conference at the White House Ambassador Grew was ordered to make "appropriate representations" at Tokyo today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Feb. 7 on an application by the Middle West Corporation, Chicago, for approval of the acquisition of securities of the Central and Southwest Utilities

The five-story tenement on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 164 Attorney Street, between Houston and Stanton Streets, has been bought by Samuel Kilpatrick through E. H. Ludlow Co. It is assessed at $12,000 and is in a block largely occupied by concerns in the wholesale fruit business.
B. Wasserstrom has been appointed an assistant trust officer of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company in the Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue Office.

Robert H. Jackson, assistant attorney general and President Roosevelt's nominee for Solicitor General, warned in a speech here tonight that "in view of an accelerating concentration of control that has occurred in the last five years, the dangers from abandoning our anti-trust laws are probably greater today than they would have been five years ago."

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Comany of Baltimore for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income of 6,516,403 after all expenses and charges. This is equal, after preerred dividend requirements, to 4.63 a share on the outstanding Common stock, and compares with a let of $6,394,688, or $4.52 a common hare, in 1936.

Five dance companies and two independent soloists combined forces last night for a huge benefit performance at the Hippodrome to assist the relief work of the Medical Bureau and the North American Committee to aid Spanish Democracy.

Mrs. Jean L. Shepard, who is responsible for the selection and training of store executives at Lord Taylor's, is publishing through Harper on Feb. 2 her book, "Human Nature at Work." It deals with the problem of relations between employers and employes.

Colonel Laurin L. Lawson, Field Artillery, died here today while on leave from his station with the Organized Reserves at Fort Bragg, N. C. He was in his sixty-second year. Colonel Lawson had been stationed at Fort Bragg since Sept. 15, 1937. He was born in St. Peter.
A "miraculous gas" used for tractor fuel by farmers in Southeastern Alberta and Western Saskatchewan was described to the Federal Tariff Board here by E. D. Arnold of Calgary.
Hamilton College's colorful Winter carnival opened tonight with a Buff and Blue victory over the Middlebury sextet. Hamilton won the hockey game with the Vermont skaters by a score of 3 to 1.

A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc., Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company and Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $412,500 bonds of Union Free School District 3 of Huntington, L. I., on a bid of 100.61 for 2.90s. The bonds will be dated Feb. 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Feb. 1, 1941 to 1968.
An anonymous gift of $54,000 toward building and endowing a new chemistry laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania was announced today.

Charles Falci, 45 years old, the former election inspector whose indictment by the local Federal grand jury in 1936 led to the recent indictment of Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District West, by the Brooklyn Federal grand jury, on a charge of harboring him as a fugitive, received a six - month penitentiary term yesterday from General Sessions Judge Freschi.

Paul van Zeeland's world economic report is being received in Germany with considerable cordiality and even with acclaim for some of its suggestions, and while there is great skepticism as to its ultimate realization, nevertheless, the Voelkischer Beobachter goes so far as to declare that it represents "a basis for discussion that will be welcomed by all."

Charles W. Anderson, who had been considered one of the country's most active Negro politicians and who held the position of Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District, New York, under seven Presidents, died yesterday of pneumonia after a three-year illness in his home, 156 West 132d Street. He was 71 years old.

Contracts for aircraft engine fuel for the last six months of the 1938 fiscal year, which ends next June 30, involving a total of $1,818,786.37, were awarded today by the War Department. Among the larger awards were the following:

In substance, the highly interesting proposal for reconstructing the administrative machinery of the Stock Exchange is a logical further step in the process of evolution through which Stock Exchange methods have been gradually moving during many years.

President Roosevelt sent his national defense message to. Congress, recommending a 20 per cent increase in naval construction authorizations and increased appropriations for army equipment; and late in the day conferred at length with Senator Barkley, the Senate majority leader, over next week's legislative program.

The United States gained $1,492,164 in gold during the week ended on Jan. 21, exports amounting to $21,060 and imports to $1,513,224, the Department of Commerce announced today. In the previous week there were no exports and imports were $957,206.

James Cagney's schedule for his first year under his re-enlistment was completed today at Warners. He will be co-starred in a musical with Ginger Rogers, who is going to the Warners on loan in exchange for Paul Muni's appearance in RKO's "The Woman I Love" last year.

James E. Mattimore, -brother of Richard Arlen, motion picture actor, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the -age of 44. Mr. Mattimore was Western manager for the Phoenix Insurance Company of London. He had lived in Chicago for fifteen years.

How a family of three lived in a classroom for three months while pupils were attending classes in other parts of the same building was described yesterday at the Board of Education hearing of charges preferred against George E. Parsons, custodian engineer of Seward Park High School Annex.

James P. (Jimmy) Henigan, marathon runner of Medford and father of seven children, has been missing since 10:30 last night, his wife, Mrs. Florence Henigan, told the police today. She is in a state of collapse.

Pompoon, Jerome H. Louchheim's crack 4-year-old, installed himself as an outstanding candidate for the coming $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap when he romped to victory today in the seven furlong Spring Fashion Purse at Santa Anita Park.

The French franc recovered yesterday in the foreign exchange market, but the dollar continued to decline. Most important foreign exchanges other than the franc advanced to their highest prices in several weeks and The Netherlands guilder reached its best quotation since its devaluation in September, 1936.

The Council of the League of Nations definitely approved today the plan for a League participation in the New York World's Fair in 1939. It decided that the secretariat should submit a detailed estimate of the cost at the May session.

The season's fifth and last performance of Strauss's "Rosenkavalier" will be given next Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, the cast including Lotte Lehmann, Kerstin Thorborg, Emanuel List and Friedrich Schorr.

The British Government brought stronger pressure to bear on Foreign Minister Istrate Micescu of Rumania today t in an effort to get his government to alter its attitude toward the Jews. The results will depend on how Bucharest is taking the suggestions tonight.
