The Hollywood Ice Revue, in which Miss Sonja Henie is the star, is scheduled to close with a matinee performance at Madison Square Garden today. However, because of the flood of requests for tickets, Garden officials last night were considering the possibility of staging another performance Monday evening.

Liquor price cutting received a setback yesterday when the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled that retail liquor dealers abiding by the price levels established under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act are entitled to injunctive relief against retailers who cut prices on standard brands.

A political row has developed between Senator Clark of Missouri and Tom J. Pendergast, the Kansas City Democratic boss. The Senator yesterday recommended the reappointment as District Attorney of Maurice M. Milligan, who obtained the conviction of thirty-five of Pendergast's workers for election frauds.
Ira A. Schulman, attorney for the Lakewood Chamber of Commerce, was freed tonight of a charge of conspiracy to cause the arrest without justification of three Lakewood bakery pickets Dec. 31.

Housing is one thing which cannot be used to prove that practice makes perfect. Men have been building radios for perhaps fifteen years, and automobiles for fifty years, and telegraph lines and railroads for not much more than 100 years; and in all these fields they have achieved wonders.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Venice in the Eighteenth Century," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Furniture: The Victorian Era in Europe and America," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "Roman Glass and Pottery," Stuart M. Shaw. 2 P. M.; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Delacrois as a Thinker," Walter Pach, 4 P. M.

Despite a moderate rally in the late trading, the stock market closed irregularly lower yesterday and extended the decline to seven consecutive sessions. Losses ranged from fractions to 2 points, and in a few instances the setbacks were greater.

Fidgety, The Netherlands' souvenir manufacturers today kept one eye on the calendar and the other on Soestdijk Palace, where there were no signs of the imminence of the birth of Crown Princess Juliana's baby.

Annual Youth Sunday will be observed tomorrow in many of the churches and today in some of the synagogues. Clergymen will preach on the responsibility of parents to train their children in religion. In some instances young people will assist in conducting the worship.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $13,610,757, to be represented by three States and forty-one municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $23,325,525 for this week.

Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, requested at a hearing of the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday the addition of four exempt positions to the staff of the Department of Finance created by the new charter.

Jim Finan's field goal in the last few seconds gave Power Memorial Academy's five a 24-23 victory over St. Ann's Academy in a Manhattan-Richmond C. H. S. A. A. clash on the winner's court yesterday. The triumph was the fourth in five tourney starts for Power, which gained a firmer hold on first place, and marked its twelfth success in sixteen games this season.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The threat of the proposed British trade treaty, supplemented by the President's pronouncement on wages this week and the easier tone in the foreign markets, naturally have further unsettled this market, and prices are a bit easier again.

Stockholders of the Ohio State Life Insurance Company, at their annual meeting in Columbus, Ohio, on Thursday, elected the following directors: Allen C. Aigler of Bellevue, Ohio; Walter P. Eberle, Cincinnati, and Edward A. Sauer, Dayton. Harry C. Fetsch was elected vice President and actuary.

Harry J. Van Syckel, 38 years old, president of the Van Syckel Realty Corporation at 366 Madison Avenue, was arrested in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office yesterday, after he was alleged to have admitted thefts aggregating $13,000 from the Cumbrae Realty

Don Budge, American tennis champion, defeated Jack Bromwich, young Australian star, 6-4, 6-2, 6-1, to win the Australian singles title today. In yesterday's doubles the German team of Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel entered the men's final by defeating the Australian duo of Jack Crawford and Vivian McGrath, 6-1, 6-3, 4--6. 7--5.

A police sergeant with thirty years of service was slain yesterday and a radio policeman who rushed to his aid was wounded when, with drawn pistols, they burst into a Bronx pawn shop and engaged five thugs in a battle during which one of the bandits was seriously wounded.

World Bank quarters today declined to comment on the van Zeeland report, explaining that the Bank for International Settlements could not make a statement because it was involved in the report and probably would be approached officially for its attitude.
Arthur E. (Turkey) Gehrke, dubbed the human groundhog, decided today that he would remain between the blankets Feb. 2 and leave the job of weather forecasting to the furry variety of groundhog.

While the City Council, disregarding popular protests, was completing its tax program today to balance the 1938 budget, the State Supreime Court issued an order ending payless paydays for the 19,000 city employes.

Twenty-two of Brooklyn's outstanding scholastic football players of the 1937 season will be the guests of Abraham Straus at the twelfth annual football luncheon, to be held at the Brooklyn department store today.

New York motorists used 145,535,342 gallons of motor fuel during November, an Increase of 5,240,195 gallons over the same month of 1930, the State Tax Department reported today. Taxable sales totaled 136,075,918 as compared with 132,499,571 in November, 1936.

Representatives of 350 power laundries and 3,000 hand laundries in the metropolitan area voted yesterday to create the Metropolitan Laundryowners Commission, to serve as a chamber of commerce of the industry in metropolitan New York.
Five railway chiefs, including heads of three of the nation's largest roads, surveyed the business front today and concurred in the opinion that the country was pulling out of the recession.

Britain was quick tonight to catch the significance of President Roosevelt's call for the vast expansion of the United States Navy. Flaring headlines proclaimed the news to thousands hurrying to catch their trains for home.
Carr System, Inc., has appointed Hi Carr to direct its newly established resident buying office for misses' and women's fashion apparel, furs, accessories and children's wear, effective Feb. 1.
Fire today razed the forty-year-old Bellevue Hotel, known to vacationists from all parts of the nation. Sixty guests here for Winter sports were driven out.

The Association of American Railroads reports that 2,896 freight cars were on order with private builders at the end of 1937. The railroads had 5,008 cars under construction in their shops at that time.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt opened the New York State Model Legislature of Youth, sponsored by the City Council of the American Youth Congress, at City College last night with a speech against isolation and in behalf of world peace. She asked also for closer cooperation of the United States and other nations.

Samuel Deutscher, president of the Williamsburg Project Merchants Association, composed of owners of stores in the low-rent housing project, challenged yesterday the statement by Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the City Housing Authority, that its members were charging higher prices than competitors in neighboring old buildings. Mr.

Miss Susan Margaret Stackpole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stackpole, was married at the home of her parents here this afternoon to Franklin B. Lord Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Lord Syosset, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. R. Diedmann of Harriman. Mr. Lord had his father as his best man.

The first official British statement on the van Zeeland report came from Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a speech to the Leeds Chamber of Commerce today. Sir John was friendly, but carefully noncommittal.

Leases of store and office space in the midtown and downtown sections formed the bulk of new quarters taken by concerns yesterday. A lease from the plans was made in the building to be erected by the Hotels Statler Company at 234-236 West Thirty-fourth Street.

The Appalachian Electric Power Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $57,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series, due in 1963, and $10,000,000 of sinking-fund debentures, series, due in 1948, setting the interest rate on the debentures at 41/2, per cent and naming fifty underwriters.

Opponents of the "third basket" provision of the proposed new Tax Bill, aimed specifically at breaking up by excessive taxation closely held corporation ownership, believed today they had at least an even chance of defeating this Administration proposal after the Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee broke up in deadlock for the third successive day.

December sales of reporting wholesale firms averaged 18.2 per cent under the same month of 1936, the largest decrease from the preceding year since March, 1933, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Miss Rose Hayes in THE TIMES of the 21st criticizes the captains and the deck and engine officers of the American merchant marine and the United States inspectors of hulls and boilers.

Wheat fluctuated today within a range of around 1 cent a bushel, a small advance early being followed by a recession as the result of easiness in securities and a forecast for rain or snow in the Southwest.

Today's major events: "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie - Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Philharmonic - Symphony Youth Concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Nathan Milstein, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.; Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Town Hall, evening; Peter Paul Loyanich, pianist, Town Hall, afternoon; "Aida," Hippodrome Opera Company, evening.
Major Gen. Edward Croft, former Chief of Infantry, died at his home in Greenville, S. C., this morning, the War Department was advised today. He would have been 63 years old on July 11.
George H. Condit, president of the Condit Motor Sales Company of Newton, N. J., was seriously injured twenty miles south of here this morning when his automobile hit a truck parked on a highway.
Ward's Automotive Reports showed today that the output of automobile plants for the current week would be 59,365 units, against 65,418 last week and 76,620 this week a year ago.

The tenth annual dinner of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League will be held tonight in the Hotel Astor. Henry Winters, executive secretary, will be toastmaster. Among those scheduled to speak are Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Representative Edward W. Curley, State Senator Lazarus Joseph and B. J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission.

Reports from Athens today indicate that Premier John Metaxas's regime now calls itself "a severe dictatorship." It was learned several days ago that leaders of the former Opposition had issued a manifesto severely criticizing General Metaxas's economic and financial measures and condemning the Government's entire policy.

Charles Hartkopf, member of the Old Irvington Town Council from 1913 to 1915, died last night at his home here of a heart attack at the age of 70. While in office Mr. Hartkopf was a member of the police committee.

The St. Francis Prep quintet suffered its first reversal in seven Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. contests this season when it bowed to St. Augustine's High, defending city titleholder, 21 to 18, on the losers' floor last night.

The United States naval program announced in Washington yesterday is estimated to involve actually some 200,000 tons of steel, but it is evident that the boon to industry cannot be gauged by deadweight alone.

To Sport Editor of The Note York Times: As a constant reader of THE TIMES and a part owner of the Washington Redskins, I would like to answer the recent letter of Morton Alpren concerning our schedule:
A new approach to the problem of attracting more private capital to make sound investments in housing was projected yesterday in Chicago at a meeting of realty brokers from all parts of the nation.
A new bridge was being planned here today for the site of the 40year-old Falls View span which lay in ruins crumpled on the ice jamming the Niagara Gorge.

New bond financing this week was restricted to tax-exempt loans, reverting to the situation that prevailed during the final months of last year. Sizable issues in the State and municipal category were placed on the market. Seven loans in all, totaling $14,874,625, were sold.

A bedsheet wrapped about her neck and thrown over a door, Miss Catherine McKenna, 67 years old, who had been living in retirement for several years, was found dead yesterday morning in her room at the Martha Washington Hotel, 29 East Twenty-ninth Street, where she had been a guest for several years.

Miss Elizabeth Leighton Lee, one of the first women landscape architects in the country, died at her home here on Wednesday. Her age was 73. Born on Staten Island, she studied landscaping at Briarcliff Junior College and at Harvard.

Net income of the petroleum Corporation of America, an investment trust, was $2,538,520 last year, exclusive of profits from transactions in securities, but after all expenses, provision for normal Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to a statement issued yesterday.

The President's Birthday Ball to be held at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria tonight promises to be one of the largest and most colorful of more than 15,000 birthday parties to be given throughout the nation to aid the new national Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Franklin Simon, who founded and managed the department store bearing his name, left a net estate of $1,890,240 when he died Oct. 4, 1934, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Among his assets were 6,294 shares of preferred stock in Franklin Simon Co., valued at $462,677, and 114,630 shares of common, valued at $737,322.

Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said yesterday that applications for 1938 license plates had been coming in at the bureau's offices at 55 Worth Street at a satisfactory rate and also at Albany.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 27: LIEUTENANT 'COLONEL Corlett, C. H. (Inf.), relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corpse Washington, D. C., May 3, and ordered to Governors Island, N. Y., for temporary duty, and about May 26 will sail for duty in the Hawaiian Department.

A field of seventeen, the largest to be named for a stake at Hialeah Park this season, is scheduled to go to the post tomorrow for the $5,000 added Miami Beach Handicap, the mile feature of an eight-race program.

While more cities moved ahead of their retail sales totals of a year ago, deepened declines in the industrial areas restricted the gain this week for the country as a whole to 2 to 5 per cent over the same week of 1937, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

After getting off to a slow start, the St. Thomas College basketball team went forward with a rush tonight and defeated Seton Hall, 49 to 40, The victory kept the Tommies' home slate clean, not a defeat being chalked against them here this season.

Albert C. Bacon, treasurer of the J. Nelson Manning Shoe Company, Inc., was struck on the head with a pistol today by one of three men and robbed of $4,000 in cash. The robbers fled in an automobile. Mr. Bacon was taken to City Hospital.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad tomorrow will take direct control of the Erie and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroads through purchase of capital stock from the Alleghany Corportion, top holding company of m the eight Van Sweringen railroads, and the Virginia Transportation Corporation, a subsidiary of the C. O.

A $34,442,240 contract award to the Interior Construction Company of Oakland for completion of Grand Coulee Dam has been approved by Secretary Ickes. This is the largest construction contract awarded by the Federal Government since 1931, when Boulder Dam was begun.

A new furniture merchandising policy has been adopted by John Wanamaker, Philadelphia, promising savings of 20 per cent in prices to the consumer, it was announced yesterday. John Knox, general merchandise manager of the Wanamaker store here, said the savings reflect both closer cooperation between the store and furniture manufacturers and the results of studies and research whereby internal readjustments have been made eliminating certain costs in handling furniture.
Sensational shooting by George Duzminski, Long Island sophomore, enabled Villanova to defeat Temple University at Convention Hall tonight, 36 to 28.

The exacting of a pledge from every candidate for County Executive of Westchester that he would administer non-politically the county Welfare and Health Departments was recommended here today at the midwinter conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women.
At the annual meeting of the Bank of France this afternoon it was announced that in 1937 gross profits were 713,000,000 francs, which was a decrease of 139,750,000 francs from the preceding year.

The Naval Council met today in Valparaiso, with Admiral Olegario del Rio presiding, to complete plans for naval purchases in accordance with a law recently passed when the navy's urgent requirements were pointed out.

J. Kenneth Bradley said today that he had given up his official posts in the National Young Republican movement to devote his time to law practice and "to the active work of the Republican party in Connecticut and my own county."

Ten well-matched, well-mannered beagles, owned by the Vernon Somerset Beagles of Peapack, N. J., of which Richard V. N. Gambrill is master, carried off the pack championship at the annual New York Hound Show yesterday in Squadron A Armory.

Storm sails of about fifty square feet are to be part of the equipment of Class X sailing dinghies, it was announced yesterday. The class committee drew up a plan of a smaller sheet of canvas than the ordinary one of seventy-two square feet in use, which, it was figured, would reduce the heeling force of one of the craft 35 per cent.

Four bandits carrying a machine gun and revolvers took a $24,000 cash payroll from four unarmed employes of the International Mercantile Marine Company on Pier 62, tra North River, shortly after noon yesterday, and made a clean getaway in a stolen car without firing a shot.
The executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America registered yesterday its disapproval of President Roosevelt's armament program.
At the annual meeting of the Bank of France this afternoon, it was announced that in 1937 gross profits were 713,000,000 francs, which was a decrease of 139,750,000 francs from the preceding year.

Representatives of the hat industry appealed to a Senate Finance Subcommittee today for protection from a "Japanese invasion" of lowcost hats which they said threatened a part of the American industry. J. W. Farley of Amesbury, Mass., a manufacturer, said imports from Japan were "growing tremendously."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 26: CAPTAINS Culp, R. S., Submarine Squadron 4, to duty as recruiting inspector, Western Division, San Francisco, Calif., in June. Hersey, M. L. Jr., Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to command the Raleigh in June. Rogers, F. F., the Texas, to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I.

The Waterman Steamship Company, operator of thirty vessels from Gulf of Mexico ports, is held to have discriminated against the unlicensed personnel of its ships who showed a preference for the National Maritime Union as their labor agent, in a National Labor Relations Board report submitted after hearings, it was announced yesterday.

The number of unemployed workers in this country rose by 1,289,000 last month, bringing the national total to 8,998,000, according to estimates made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Twenty thousand more Japanese troops are being brought to the Peiping area, to be quartered on the campus of TsinghauUniversity, reliable informants said today. The $6,000,000 school was built with American Boxer indemnity funds.

Best cocker spaniel at the silver anniversary show of the Maryland Kennel Club, which opened this morning in the Fifth Regiment Armory, was the noted winner Champion My Black Model, owned by William Gass and Mrs. J. N. Levine of Philadelphia, and handled by Nate Levine.

Detailed plans have been completed for the removal of the Soviet Union's north polar party from its ice floe, it was announced tonight by Professor Otto J. Schmidt, head of the Great Northern Sea Route Administration.

More charges against the National Labor Relations Board, involving alleged intimidation of local public officials, employers, workmen and witnesses, alleged efforts to curb the freedom of the press and the alleged canceling of valid contracts between employers and employes, were made today before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Judiciary by Senator Burke of Nebraska.

Many distinguished persons attended the colorful 112th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York last night in the Hotel Commodore. Some 1,000 men, representing sixty-six military organizations of the thirteen original States, recalled 'every American war since the French and Indian wars as they marched in the grand parade at midnight.

The hunts racing season will get under way March 19 with the Sandhills meeting at Pinehurst, N. C., and close Nov. 12 at Middleburg, Va., embracing thirty-five racing days, four more than were scheduled last year.

John Hilton Land, who was treasurer for-years of the Cuban American Sugar Company, with officers in New York, and a former resident of Yonkers, died at his home in Hopewell, N. J., Thursday night of pneumonia. His age was 64.
Lord Atholstan, proprietor of The Montreal Star and one of Canada's most noted publishers, died here today in his ninetieth year. He had been ill for several weeks.

The entry of Ulen Co. into the domestic heavy construction field and general consulting engineering, with the selection of James H. Manning, until recently president of Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, as president, are the major proposals in a plan which is to be submitted to stockholders at a special meeting on Feb. 17.
Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman gave a dinner tonight at Playa Riente for Mrs. Gilbert Lee and her guests, Mrs. Russell A. Alger and Mrs. Benjamin S. Warren of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

More than 500 members of the Women's University Club were welcomed yesterday by their president, Miss Martha Dodson, and the board of managers at a housewarming tea in the new headquarters of the organization in the Hotel Biltmore.

Japanese spokesmen said yesterday that for the time being army and navy fliers would continue to adhere to their policy of directing aerial bombings only against military objectives, but that a change in policy was possible in the case of Hankow, where it was charged antiaircraft guns and machine-guns were recently mounted in former foreign concessions and densely populated areas.

Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, said today that unless Pennsylvania tax laws were curtailed the company would have to move on to one of several States "very anxious to have us." Among them, he added, were Delaware and New Jersey.

It is expected here that the ownership of The Montreal Star will now pass to J. W. McConnell, a Montreal sugar broker. Some five or more years ago he acquired a majority interest in the newspaper property,
Capturing five of the nine first places, the Brooklyn College swimming team dedicated its new pool by triumphing over Manhattan College, 40 to 35, last night.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court dismissed yesterday a stockholder's suit entered by Mandelson Bros. Factors, Inc., against Arthur Sachs and nine other partners in Goldman, Sachs Co. and the estates of two deceased partners.

CharlesG. Dawes, who was Vice President of the United States under President Coolidge and subsequently Ambassador to the Court of St. James, and Gano Dunn. scientist, engineer and president of the J. G. White Engineering Corporation, were elected directors of the Radio Corporation of America at the regular meeting of the board yesterday, according to an announcement by David Sarnoff, president of R. C. A.

The former $1,815,000 first mortgage on the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment house at 983 Park Avenue has been reduced to $1,320,000 by adjustment and payment and extended for five years at an average rate of 4 1/2 per cent. The property is assessed for $1,660;000. The Tishman Realty Construction Co, Inc, was the broker.

The completion of a tremendous engineering feat-the construction of the founnation of the Palace of the Soviets, which will be the highest and largest structure in the world and which, standing on the bank of the Moscow River, will tower the whole Red capital-was announced today.

Cardinal Hayes has sent out a pastoral letter to his clergy reminding them that February has been permanently and officially designated by the Catholic Bishops of the United States as "the period during which each recurring year intensive efforts shall be made to strengthen and propagate the Catholic press."

Miss Marta Abba, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pompeo Abba of Milan, was married here today to Severance Millikin of this city at the home of Mr. Millikin's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hadden of Cleveland Heights.

WITH THE INSURGENTS, on the Teruel Front, Spain (by courier to Saint-Jean-de-Luz, France), Jan. 28.-After two days of futile and extremely costly attacks toward Singra from Palomera Peak, at the northern tip of the Sierra Palomera, the only position on this mountain range remaining in their hands, Government forces tonight appeared ready to abandon their efforts to make any headway in this sector.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold its thirty-seventh annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 26, it was announced yesterday by J. Stanley Brown, personnel director of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, who is president of the chapter.

Premier T. D. Pattullo of British Columbia will arrive in Ottawa soon ostensibly to consult Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King about Japanese and Chinese immigration. It is understood his real object is to do something to allay fears of Japanese penetration and to guard defense secrets from Japanese.
Motor Cycle Patrolman Michael Darienzo, whose machine angered Magistrate Overton Harris in Washington Heights Court a year ago, was injured yesterday while escorting an emergency medical case.
Cuba today celebrated the eighty-fifth anniversary of the birth of Jose Marti, her most beloved patriot. Commerce 15 and industry were suspended and government offices were closed.

Papers discovered by Loyalists on prisoners and deserters on the Teruel front in the last few days are said to indicate a wide split between the Phalangists, often called the Spanish Fascists, and Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
Brazil is trying to build her own government out of the sum of her own experience and free of every "ism"-fascism, nazism and parliamentarism-and the ideological influences of the outside world.

Hugh A. Allan, member of the family which controlled the old Allan Steamship Line and a brother of Lady Meredith, died today. He was 81 years old. Mr. Allan, grandson of Captain Alexander Allan, who founded the first regular mail and passenger service between Canada and the United Kingdom, was a former president of the line, which was absorbed by the Canadian Pacific Railway steamship service during the war.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 22 amounted to 570,333 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,267 cars, or 1.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 95,013 cars, or 14.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 14,358 cars, or 2.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Ten Socialist and Catholic Deputies of the last eighteen of the Democratic opposition in the Diet have applied for "guest membership" in the Nazi Parliamentary group, Nazi party headquarters will announce next week.

A large audience last night heard the debut recital of Joseph Kahan, 7-yearold pianist, who has won the praise, in private performances, of Josef Hofmann, Jose Iturbi and Mischa Elman. The boy, son of Saloman Kahan. Mexican music critic, is preparing to be a conductor.

Praising Roosevelt's request to Congress today to authorize millions of dollars for national defense, Daniel J. Doherty, national commander of the American Legion, said that "it is the obligation of the United States to go ahead with the President's proposal."

Morris Idelevitz, 48 years old, former gardener on the estate of Herbert L. Pratt at Glen Cove, L. I., won yesterday a $15,000 judgment against his former emplayer and two others by a ju composed of ten men and one woman in Supreme Court.

Miss Jean Swinton Lefebre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Lefebre of 340 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, was married here today to Richard Howell of New York at the home of the bride's cousins, Mr. and Mrs. George Such Pearse.

Without opinion, the Appellate Division unanimously affirmed yesterday the convictions of six men for second-degree manslaughter growing out of the collapse of a building under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, June 19, 1936. Eighteen men were killed in the collapse of the building, a seven-story apartment.

AMERICAN FOXHOUNDS Single, Dog, Hounds (Unentered, Bred by Exhibitor)-First, Essex Foxhounds' Helmet; second, Millbrook Hunt's Jove; third, Millbrook Hunt's Jester. Coupled, Dog, Hounds (Unentered, Bred by Exhibitor)-First, Millbrook Hunt's Jester and Swagger; second, Essex Foxhounds' Talbot and Tackler; third, Essex Foxhounds' Bounder and Boisterous.

At a meeting of the governing committee of the Cruising Club of America the date and place of the start of the Bermuda race next Summer were decided upon and the race committee to handle it appointed, it was announced yesterday.

Retailers will cooperate in the enforcement of the Federal Trade Commission of the rules requiring the identification of rayon merchandise, as they are not afraid of these rules and are willing to call their rayon goods by their proper description, Lew Hahn,

A strong delegation of members of the European Steel Cartel will sail today from Havre and Southampton on the Normandie to seek agreements with manufacturers in this country that they will not undersell European steel makers in the principal foreign markets and, if possible, to obtain their participation in the cartel.

A drive to obtain $10,000 for the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York was announced yesterday in a speech by Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., president of the federation, before a conference of the Brooklyn Girl Scout Council in the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway.

A three-second knockout featured a Golden Gloves amateur boxing program held before a crowd of 4,000 at the Broadway. Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Harry Shillanti floored Sol Golden with the first punch of their battle.

The naval rearmament program advocated by President Roosevelt as a measure of "public defense" is a deliberate step toward an AngloAmerican alliance which will lead us into an aggressive war, Norman Thomas, national chairman of the Socialist party, declared last night in an address before the Friday night forum of the Socialist party of the Sixth Assembly District headquarters, 167 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn.

Indoor polo faces another attractive schedule of play tonight with a benefit for the Warm Springs Foundation being set for the Essex Troop Armory in Newark. The receipts will go to the infantile paralysis work of Warm Springs as a part of the President's birthday celebrations, and the affair has the sponsorship of Governor A. Harry Moore.

Secretary Ickes swooped down today on the office of Charles H. West, Under-Secretary of the Interior and "Presidential contact man," and virtually liquidated its personnel. The coup, which was a climax to Mr. Ickes's long-standing antagonism toward the under-secretaryship, was carried out in Mr. West's absence.

Frederick B. Craven of Winchester, Mass., a graduate of the Naval Academy and a former lieutenant commander in the navy, was elected yesterday Commander General of the Naval Order of the United States at the fifteenth triennial congress of the organization in the Union Club. He replaces Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, who has held office since 1931.
Nearly 3,500 C. I. 0. longshoremen tied up shipping for five hours here today as a "sample" of what they might do if control of the local hiring hall is wrested from them by court order.

Mrs. Adeline A. Taylor, one of Flushing's oldest residents, died yesterday at her home, 147-41 Fortyfirst Avenue, Flushing, at the age of 92. Her husband, Timothy M. Taylor, died forty-one years ago yesterday.

Play in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship tournament started on the courts of the Fifteenth Regiment Armory yesterday with six of, the eight seeded players advancing to the quarterfinal round.

On the hitherto quiescent Rumanian front the forces of international fascism are developing a vigorous offensive to secure control forItaly and Germany of Rumania's inexhaustible supplies of oil and other mineral wealth and the enormous grain and general agricultural produce of the great Rumanian plains.

Senator La Follette and Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General-designate, will be the speakers and Thurman Arnold of Yale University will serve as toastmaster at the dinner to be given here Feb. 20 by the National Lawyers Guild during its annual convention.

ONE of the most famous observations about the English is that they always play the game for the game's sake. It's a noble and commendable trait. But be that as it may, you have probably noticed-that though they play for the sport of it, they never, never forget to keep score. Well, hardly ever.

To avoid wholesale lay-offs of salaried employes due to current slack business, the United States Steel Corporation of New Jersey and all its subsidiaries have adopted a sharethe-work plan which will go into effect Feb. 1, it was announced at the corporation's offices here tonight.

Forty bales of silk, said by the police to be worth $30,000 were stolen from a Railway Express truck in the lower East -Side of Manhattan last night after one of two armed men forced the driver, George Hemond of 747 East 168th Street, to board another machine where he was held prisoner for an hour and a half.

Continued Federal patronage of the arts, especially the theatre, was urged yesterday by Burgess Meredith, acting president of Actors Equity Association, at the Town Hall's midseason music- dramascreen luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

The strong Czechoslovak team of Mile. V. Depetrisova and Mile. V. Votruecova retained the women's world table tennis doubles championship today as United States players met with a series of reverses that erased all but a few from the international competition.

George Bowley of 32-61 38th Street, Long Island City, a brother of Frederick W. Bowley, the first Borough President of Queens County, died yesterday at Borough Hall in Long Island City, as he was reporting for work.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company has notified holders of its 5% per cent convertible investment certificates, due on Nov. 15, 1938, that the amount to be met, $3,250,000, is too great to be retired in a single year out of cash on hand without interfering unduly with the company's ability to meet requirements for construcfrtion.

In an effort to reduce operating expenses in view of the decrease in income "due to the conditions in the securities markets," the finance committee of the New York Curb Exchange voted yesterday to reduce all salaries an average of 121/2 per cent and to eliminate fees paid to members of the board of governors for attendance at the meetings of the board and at the meetings of the committees of the Exchange.

Authorization of the use of State credit for a State-wide program of low-cost housing and slum clearance is sought in a bill introduced today by Assemblyman Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

Mrs. Anna Doherty, wife of Philip A. Doherty, an official of the Eugene Doherty Rubber Works, Inc., and long active in Catholic charities in Brooklyn, died on Thursday in the Midwood Hospital after a brief illness. Her home was at 1,172 Union Street.

One of seven skaters who were thrown into Brady's Pond near Clova Avenue, Grassmere, S. I., at 9:40 o'clock last night when the ice broke and who were rescued by firemen, died at 1 o'clock this morning at Staten Island Hospital of shock, submersion and exposure.

No. 13 was no jinx to pretty, blonde, blue-eyed Phyllis Stankiewicz in the fourth annual "Little Sister" beauty contest yesterday afternoon at the Boys Club of New York, on Avenue A and East Tenth Street. She accepted the traditionally unlucky number without a murmur and came out queen of the contest.

As a result of many years of study and preparation, the National Lutheran Council will establish a national welfare center in New York City which will coordinate all intermission activities of the eight Lutheran bodies in the United States.

The International Air Show opened at the International Amphitheatre here tonight with eighty-five aircraft organizations exhibiting forty airplanes and several hundred products used in manufacturing and operating aircraft.

By defeating the Crecent Athletic Club yesterday, the Harvard Club team broke the tie that had existed between it and the Brooklyn club for honors among Class teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

The 250th anniversary today of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg, Swedish theologian and scientist, is being celebrated throughout the world. Tomorrow the New (Swedenborgian) Church, 118 East Thirtyfifth Street, will hold a special memorial service at 11 A. M., with a sermon by the minister, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Wilde.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday: also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, in her best form, won the women's golf championship of champions with a crushing 10-and-8 victory over Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., today.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 20,000, Including 10,000 directs. Market moderately active; strong to mostly 10 cents higher than Thursday's average; bulk good and choice 150-210 pounds, $8.55$8.75 ton. $8.80 220-260 pounds,

Mrs. Ida F. Craven, 49 years old, and C. Vincent Riccardi, 50, were found guilty of grand larceny by a jury composed of seven women and five men in General Sessions last night. Mrs. Marie Right Dodd of 400 East Fifty-ninth Street alleged they defrauded her of $2,851 in the sale of stock of the Holmes-Western Consolidated Mines, Inc., which formerly had an office at 730 Fifth Avenue.
The newspaper Ultimas Noticias reports today that not a single box car has crossed the frontier at Laredo, Texas, since Dec. 21 as a "result of the Mexican tariffs."

William (Still Bill) Hill, pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds at the turn of the century, died today of injuries suffered Monday when he was struck by an automobile. His age was 63. After leaving professional baseball in 1902 he joined the Cincinnati Police Department and was promoted to a dateotive's rank in 1908.

Proceeds from the sale of $2,300,000 of first refunding mortgage bonds which the Long Island Lighting Company has asked the Public Service Commission to authorize would be used to repay bank loans of an equal amount, Thomas P. Booth, general auditor for the company, said yesterday at a hearing before the commission.

Commenting on President Roosevelt's proposal for a large defense program, William Greeh, president of the American Federation of Labor, said: "I feel that at this period, when we take into account what is happening internationally, we must have confidence in the judgment of the Chief Executive. He must have information on the world situation which we do not possess.

A new reciprocal trade agreement is to be negotiated with Canada, according to a formal announcement by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today, to replace and broaden the arrangement which has been in effect for the past two years.

Twenty-one acres of land fronting on the west side of Cedar Street, north of Northfield Road, Livingston, N. J., near the West Orange line, have been bought by McGovern Brothers, East Orange builders, for immediate development with small homes in the $6,000 price range.

The Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Inc., yesterday inaugurated what it hopes will be the final campaign for the balance of the funds necessary for completion of the major portions of the music shed at Tanglewood, between Stockbridge and Lenox, Mass., in time for the six Summer concerts by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

In connection with the celebrations of the 150th anniversary of Byron's birth, Professor Socrates Kugheas has informed the Academy of Athens that the original draft of the first stanza of the first canto of "Childe Harold" has been found in- the manuscript section of the National Library.

Two men accused under Britain's Secrets Act were refused bail and remanded for six days to the Bow Street jail today amid unusual secrecy. The charge, described by the prosecutor as "serious," involves the alleged act of obtaining four official blueprints which might "be useful to the enemy."

" Art in the Air," an exhibition showing the influence of aviation upon art, will. open at the Decorators Club Gallery Feb. 7. Among the artists to be included are Clayton Knight and William Heaslip. Well-known designers such as Howard Ketchum, Henry Dreyfull and Raymond Loewy will show colored renderings of the latest airplane interiors.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, acting yesterday on a petition filed by the Carter Coal Company, temporarily enjoined the National Bituminous Coal Commission from enforcing orders under which prices of "smokeless" coal shipped from West Virginia were to have been increased next Monday.

Lord Wardington, chairman of Lloyds Bank, sharply rebuked municipal and local authorities for too much borrowing, in his speech at the annual meeting of the bank's stockholders today. This was the last of the annnual meetings this year of the "big five" British banks.

Jackson St, 18-20; 5-story tenement an stores, 39.3x100; Central Savings Bank o New York against Julius J. Ruff; due $16,174; taxes, etc, $353; to plaintiff fo $16,000. By WILLIAM KENNELLY 107th St, 82 E; 5-story tenement, 25x76.11 Hattie F. Bass against Hedwig Burczyk due, $658; to plaintiff for $12,275.

Pawnee Bill is in town on his first visit in twelve years and spent the day "attending to things." His real name is Major Gordon mov W. Lillie, he lives in Pawnee, Okla., and he is very likely the last of the frontiersmen of the days of Buffalo Bill Cody and Wild Bill. Hickok. He is 78 years old.
Nine more players advanced into the second round of the M. M. Sterling Trophy squash tennis tournament in progress at the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Three of them were seeded players.

Robert Grant 3d, national amateur champion, yesterday staged one of the most thrilling uphill fights seen in a racquets court to gain the final round of the invitation open tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup with Norbert Setzler, the American open titleholder.

The National Wool Growers Association this afternoon adopted unanimously the resolution of its wool marketing committee, urging the enactment of national legislation which will require manufacturers to inform the consumers as to the exact amount of reworked wool contained in wool products.

Althdugh occupied with the affairs of the meeting here of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, William Green, president of the federation, said today that he might be able to arrange to appear at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America in Washington next week and face charges of "treason" to his own union by welcoming the Progressive Miners of America into the federation.

C. Herbert Wheeler Jr. of Merchantville, N. J., a graduate student in the School of Architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was awarded today the Boston Society of Architects prize of $100 for a plan for a "concourse at an airport at the New York World's Fair."

Since Ernst Toller's "No, More Peace" is an anti-war play, a Federal Theatre group is naturally attracted to it. Charles Hopkins's visiting players from Roslyn, L. I., put it on with sufficient imagination at Maxine Elliott's last evening.
There is a great buzz of speculation and conjecture about the calling off of the Reichstag session, which had been scheduled for Sunday, but there is no official explanation.

The Associated Actors and Artistes of America, governing all actor unions, suffered one of the most serious internal conflicts in its history late yesterday on the question of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, embracing most of the mechanical employes in the entertainment industry, asking for jurisdiction over all performers.

Dana Wallace, former District Attorney of Queens County and a member of the bar for thirty-seven years, was suspended from the practice of law for one year by order of the Brooklyn Appellate Division yesterday in a unanimous decision based on an official referee's report that Mr. Wallace had solicited negligence cases.

The recent American Legion convention here was largely credited with the increase of 2,203 in membership in the New York County organization, Joseph J. Burkard, county commander, announced last night.

The latest addition to Bermuda's racing fleet, Eldon and Kenneth Trimingham's 6-meter yacht Solenta, arrived from England today. Designed by Charles E. Nicholson of Endeavour fame and built by Camper and Nicholson at Gosport, England, Solenta has created considerable interest internationally.

The French Line flagship Normandie improved its speed and increased its passenger totals last year, according to a report published yesterday by the line. The ship's average speed for 1937 was 28.87 knots, against an average of 28.29 in 1936, the report said.

There are four shows going away after this evening's performances, none of them to tour, all of them having set up runs on the side of brevity. They are "Time and the Conways," J. B. Priestley's play which failed at the Ritz to meet the success it found in London and is closing after but thirty-two performances;

Van Lingle Mungo, speed-ball pitcher of the Brooklyn Dodgers, who has been reported on his way to the Polo Grounds, Chicago, St. Louis and other points, is almost a certainty to do his pitching at Ebbets Field again this year, and, what is more, he already is a member in good standing with the Flatbush Flock, with his contract for 1938 duly approved and signed.

The State Banking Department has approved the change in name of the American Cooperative Savings and Loan Association, 437 Fourth Avenue, New York City, to American Savings and Loan Association, according to the department's weekly bulletin today.

Paddy's Market, a colorful outdoor bazaar consisting of pushcarts and stores along Ninth Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Fortysecond Streets, was rescued yesterday from extinction by the Appellate Division, which handed down a unanimous ruling voiding eviction orders given to the pushcart ped??lers last November by Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr.

White House mail clerks were deluged yesterday with "a march of dimes" and President Roosevelt's secretarial staff had a late luncheon after sifting through more than 30,000 pieces of mail, containing ten-cent coins given to aid the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
Jimmy Hines, his clubs beating a par-shattering answer to a difficult golfing test, posted a 67 to lead the field today in the opening round of the $5,000 Oakland seventy-two-hole open tournament.

Stocks closed lower for seventh successive day, losses ranging from fractions to 2 points; turnover, 1,189,830 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, other groups mixed in trend; transactions, $7.258.550.

The group of institutional investors in , the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul pacific Railroad Company that filed a plan of reorganization of the railroad on Jan. 10, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission minor modifications of the plan.

The rumors of King Zog's forthcoming engagement to Countess Geraldine Apponyi were confirmed today in Tirana dispatches, which were passed by the censor. The 22-year-old Countess is said to have arrived at the Albanian capital Dec. 30, accompanied by a general and a lady of the Hungarian aristocracy, on King Zog's invitation.

The Davidson Chemical Corporation's common stock has been admitted to the list by the New York Stock Exchange. The Lone Star Cement Corporation has notified the Exchange that contracts have been entered into by the corporation and its subsidiaries with nineteen officers, pursuant to which options have been given them to buy an aggregate of 16,400 shares of the common stock of the corporation at $34 a share through Jan. 10, 1941.

Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange represented 17.20 per cent of the total volume in the week ended on Jan. 1, compared with 18.14 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

" Taken From Life," a play in three acts and fifteen scenes, written in Tombs Prison by Arthur H. Chalmers, a mounted patrolman who is under indictment in connection with the fatal shooting of a woman, was given its premiere last night before a small audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Oliver St, 45, 25x100; Gerald F. Finley to 130 Attorney Street Corp, 320 Broadway, care Kantrowltz Solins; consideration $500, foreclosure. Henry St, 191, 25x87.6: Benjamin Cohen to Joseph L. Buttenwieser, 885 Park Ave; mtg $13,850 held by grantee.

Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., successfully defended his Florida Winter golf championship for the Ponce de Leon Cup on St. Augustine Links today by crushing Emmet J. Rogers of Oklahoma City, Okla., 6 and 5, in the thirtysix-hole final.

Unless the League of Nations reverses its earlier decision, the great work organized by the Norwegian explorer and humanitarian, Dr. Fridtjof Nansen, will end at the close of this year. Though the need during the last decade has increased rather than diminished, there are no indications in Geneva that the Nansen International Office will be given a new lease of life.

Anthony Eden, Yvon Delbos and Maxim Litvinoff, the British, French and Soviet Foreign Ministers, after a day devoted mostly to a meeting with V. K. Wellington Koo and Quo Tai-chi, Chinese delegates, agreed tentatively on the terms of a resolution to be submitted to the League of Nations Council on the Sino-Japanese war.
The police have arrested a gang of twenty-five who allegedly specialized in the counterfeit passport traffic. Most of those persons arrested are Poles, Hungarians and Chinese.
Promoter Mique Malloy promised Chicago today it would get its first glimpse of Featherweight Champion Henry Armstrong in action on Feb. 25.
Following is the text of the Vinson bill, introduced in the House today to carry out President Roosevelt's naval recommendations:

An order was entered yesterday in the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., continuing the Mountain States Power Company in possession of its property while in reorganization proceedings under Section 77b, it was announced yesterday by Z. E. Merrill, president of the company.

Priscilla Love, 19 years old, an inmate of Wayside Home, an institution for wayward girls at Valley Stream, L. I., and a patient at Bellevue Hospital for the last six months, was critically injured yesterday afternoon when she jumped two floors from the eye ward. Her spine and pelvis were fractured and she was Injured internally.

The United Mine Workers by resolution endorsed the President's "social and humanitarian" program and cheered references to a third term "if it becomes necessary" for him to run again to "complete the job." [Page 1.]

The Manhattan Badminton Club was shut out by the Central Badminton Club second team and the New York Badminton Club in Metropolitan Badminton Association men's Class A matches played this week. The tournaments in all divisions are in the final stages and play-offs comprise a considerable part of the remaining schedule.

William Esau Heard, for twentyfive years consular agent for the United States and believed to be the oldest ship broker in the world, died today at 103. He joined the ship brokerage firm of Jones, afterward Jones, Heard Co., at the age of 14, and attended business regularly until the age of 97.

Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, told the House Pensions Committee today that pensions proposed for widows and orphans of World War veterans would cost the government $84,000,000 a year.

A young man on crutches, soliciting alms on Flatbush Avenue near State Street, gave Patrolman Edward Bender a surprise yesterday when he threw down his crutches and ran down the street at sight of the patrolman.

Dominick Di Lellia, 30 years old, of 3,808 Avenue P, Brooklyn, a civilian painter employed at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, fell twenty-five feet to his death at 4 P. M. yesterday from a scaffold on the army dredge Goethals, in drydock at the yard. Lieut.
Mayor La Guardia today termed "silly" re- Mr. ports that he was thinking of becoming a Presidential candidate. He was too busy being Mayor of New York, he said, to put his mind on another job.
Sam Breadon, president of the Cardinals, said tonight he would make every effort to obtain Van Lingle Mungo, the Dodgers' right-handed fire-ball pitcher.
The Council of the League of Nations today appointed Miss Dorothy Kenyon of New York on a fact-finding committee of eight to report on the legal status of women in various countries.
Sam Breadon, president of the Cardinals, said tonight he would make every effort to obtain Van Lingle Mungo, the Dodgers' right-handed fire-ball pitcher.
The Council of the League of Nations today appointed Miss Dorothy Kenyon of New York on a fact-finding committee of eight to report on the legal status of women in various countries.

A restaurant is not responsible for the pie it sells, according to Judge Fred H. Witt of the Superior Court. "The position of the restaurant as a service organization has changed since the horse and buggy days," he said. "Now it merely sells prepared foods." Judge Witt ruled that W.

Cooperative Distributors, a consumers' cooperative, with headquarters at 116 East Sixteenth Street, has signed a closed-shop contract with the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1,250, C. I. O., it was announced yesterday.

Contributions of $1,158.20 have been received by New York Chapter, American Red Cross, in response to President Rooseyelt's appeal for the suffering civilians of China. Prior to the President's plea the chapter had received and transmitted $3,410 donated for relief in China.
A directed verdict of acquittal freed William Crum, 31, of Leonia, N. J., today of murder charges in connection with a $17 hold-up, after nearly three years spent behind bars.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burling Dodge of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Dodge, to Edgar Hayes Betts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Betts of Troy. N. Y.

The Rev. P. F. Pindar, rector of St. Luke's Catholic Church for thirtytwo years, died today of a heart attack at the age of: 65. Although his parish was located in a small community, Father Pindar was one of the best known of Bergen County's priests.

The Senate adopted a conference report today approving an appropriation of $39,750,000 to finance benefit payments to domestic sugar cane and beet growers on 1937 crops under the new sugar quota legislation. The report now goes back to the House.
Mount Eden Ave, 31-41, 2-story stores and History garage, 100x126.8 irreg: Mortgage Commission of New York against Leo Silver Co; due, $163,927; taxes, etc, $22,125; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Magistrate Theodore Wilfrid Fry, after a tenth hearing, today decided to commit for trial three officials of Heilbut Symons Company who were charged with business loan frauds.

Mischa Elman, the violinist, ha leased a large apartment In 75 Cer tral Park West through Albert P .shforth, Inc. Leases of other suites follow.: Mrs. Marle H. Pagano, in 2 Beekman Anne K. Barbour, in 400 E 50th St; Davi S. Johnston, in 440 W. 34th St.; Albert E Ashforth, Inc, broker.

Panzer College scored its tenth victory in defeating Arnold tonight, 52-37. The teams were even at the intermission, but led by Knupple, who dropped in ten floor goals, Panzer pulled away in the second half. Knupple's 20 points gave him scoring honors.
Retirement of Dr. Otto Jeidels, managing partner and director of the Berliner Handels-Gesellschaft was announced today. Reports have it that he asked to be relieved of his post.

Mrs. Suzanne H. Neville of the Barclay and Pinehurst, N. C., daughter of Mrs. Andrew S. Burke of Pine Knoll, Pinehurst, and the late Rev. Andrew S. Burke, former rector of All Saints Church, Wynnewood, was married this morning to Livingston Ludlow Biddle 2d, son of Colonel and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle of New York.

Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, passed the seventy-seventh anniversary of his birth last Wednesday on his farm near Oregon, Ill. He was born son of a blacksmith in Minnesota, but when he was a small boy his father moved down into Iowa "to avoid the Sioux Indian massacre."

Prices of memberships on the two local stock exchanges slumped yesterday with prices of stocks. A seat on the New York Stock Exchange went at $65,000, off $10,000 from the last previous transaction, and the lowest since Oct. 19, 1937, when a seat was transferred at $61,000 following a similar sale the previous day, which was the lowest price since 1919.

The assorted noises of boxers in training at Stillman's Gymnasium yesterday were interrupted when Jack Dempsey, James J. Braddock and Joe DiMaggio, Yankee baseball star, suddenly burst on the scene to see Bob Tow and Red Burman work out.

Prices of memberships on the two local stock exchanges slumped yesterday with prices of stocks. A seat on the New York Stock Exchange went at $65,000, off $10,000 from the last previous transaction, and the lowest since Oct. 19, 1937, when a seat was transferred at $61,000 following a similar sale the previous day, which was the lowest price since 1919.

The assorted noises of boxers in training at Stillman's Gymnasium yesterday were interrupted when Jack Dempsey, James J. Braddock and Joe DiMaggio, Yankee baseball star, suddenly burst on the scene to see Bob Tow and Red Burman work out.
THE autobiography of T. Arthur Rickard, mining engineer and editor. is naturally of interest primarily to mining men. But it makes a valid claim to the attention of the general public as well.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, chairman of the executive committee of China Emergency Civilian Relief, announces that local committees of the organization throughout the country have been advised to suspend all projected activities for raising funds for the present.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

The Boston Providence Railroad Company and the protective committee for shareholders of the Old Colony Railroad Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission exceptions to a recent examiner's report proposing a method for segregation of the earnings and expenses of the New. York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

" Rip Van Winkle," the play made famous by Joseph Jefferson in the nineteenth century, will be revived by the Manhattan College Players, it was announced yesterday by Professor Donald J. Carty, faculty director of dramatics. The revival will be presented in April as part of the celebration of Manhattan's diamond jubilee.

The undefeated Choate hockey team kept its slate clean today, defeating the Lawrencevill School sextet, 3-2, in a hard-fought game in Baker Rink. Lawrenceville, unbeaten in four starts, drew first blood in 6:30 of the first period when Greely Summers, defense man, scored on a pass from Doug Bournique.
After an investigation of Nazi activities in the Union of South Africa, The Johannesburg Star states that a large number of Germans are members of organizations similar to those in Germany.

IT will be just a year next week since President Roosevelt made his proposal to remodel the Supreme Court, a proposal that was beaten after one of the most rancorous controversies in the nation's history. Yet today his essential objective of last February has been achieved.

THOUOGH official record has it that Karin Branzell made her season's first appearance with the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night as Ortrud, the truth is that she had already sung and acted on the Metropolitan stage unnoticed by the public or by the omniscient gentlemen of the press.

Hundreds of visitors at the Franklin Institute today tested the amount of energy they expended in bicycle riding in terms of slices of bread. They climbed on a device known as the bread-o-meter and started pedaling.

The opening bouts in the twelfth amateur boxing championships of South America were held tonight in an outdoor arena. Argentine, Brazil, Chile, Peru and Uruguay are represented. The competition will be held nightly through Feb. 7.

William H. Davis, chairman of the New York State Mediation Board, will open a new series of fifteen forums for adults on public labor policies under the auspices of the New York University Division of General Education with an address on "The Philosophy of Labor Relations as Expressed in the State Mediation Act,"

Champion Herman Rinkton, a dark red dachslund dog, owned and handled in the ring by Richard S. Heller of Elmira, N. Y., tonight was awarded the title of best in show of the twenty-fifth annual exhibition of the Maryland Kennel Club.

An improvement in general economic conditions was seen this week with the announcement by Under-Sheriff William Darroch that there were 260 fewer mortgage foreclosures during 1937 than in the preceding year. Mr. Darroch conducts the weekly auction of distressed property at the court house here.

A "THERMOS - BOTTLE" auto windshield, said to be frostless and fogless, is described in a patent (No. 2,106,251) just awarded here to Frank G. Ludwig of Lockport, Ill. The windshield is made of two panes of glass set apart. Edges of the panes are fused together and air in the space is evacuated.

With another of his superlatively competent performances, Glenn Cunningham, a master workman always, scored a smashing twelve-yard victory over Archie San Romani in the mile run that featured the Prout Memorial Games of the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus before a capacity gathering of 14,000 in the Boston Garden tonight.

Dr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander 2d have come from Boston to the Commodore. Mrs. John Henry Dwight of Washington is expected today at the Carlyle. Mrs. Thomas L. Leeming of Mayfair House leaves tomorrow for Palm Beach.
Although Stamford has been through comparatively a lean year in real estate, local dealers are expecting a decided pick-up in the Spring.

NO other phenomenon so accurately gauges the spread of interest in the better type of music in this country as the large number of symphony orchestras each which have been formed of late in smaller communities throughout the land.

All records for registration of thoroughbred dogs in the United States were smashed during 1937 it was announced yesterday by the American Kennel Club. During the year the names of 84,525 individuals were entered in the stud book of the governing body of the sport in this country.
PAHANG is the largest State of the Malay Peninsula and the author of this book tells us, probably the most primitive. "Pahang that's a god-forsaken place!" experienced planters
War Admiral worked a mile in 1:401-5 at Hialeah Park this morning, his most impressive trial since he began training for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup here March 5.
Talk of the desirability of peace between the C. I. O. and the A. F. of L. is heard everywhere at the thirtyfourth constitutional convention of the United Mine Workers of America being held here.
AT first glance, a person picking up this book might take it to be a technical treatise on one limited phase of astronomy. Such an opinion, however, would be very erroneous.

Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, received tonight.the Mahler medal of honor in recognition of his work in creating in this country interest and appreciation for the compositions of Gustav Mahler.

THE Grieg concerto, in A minor, Opus 16, was the subject of one of the more ambitious earlier recordings. Quite fifteen years ago, with pardonable trumpetings, H. M. V. made a series of several piano concertos, each cut to fit two records, with Arthur de Greef as soloist and Landon Ronald conducting.

TO determine how much time Children devote to radio listen ing after school hours and on Saturday and Sunday, the Department of Public Instruction of Delaware recently conducted a surveys which also sought information on favorite programs.
Three policemen in a squad car tonight captured two youths they found hiding in the shrubbery on the grounds of the home of Mrs. S. E. Stoskopf, at 11 Wensley Drive, Russell Gardens, here.

RADIO engineers who instituted television field tests in New York in July, 1936, expect to complete their observations within the next six months, according to a representative of the Radio Corporation of America.
A circulating musical library with branches in each borough will be opened here next September, according to Dr. John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent of Schools.

Sitting in six panels, 1,500 youth delegates from all parts of the State adopted resolutions last night urging increased government aid to youth, condemning fascism and persecution of racial minorities and endorsing President Roosevelt's suggestion "to quarantine aggressor nations."
More than [pound]3,000,000 worth of treasure from Chinese in the war zone, mainly silver coins and articles, reached England today aboard the liner Ranpura.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, Z. G. Simmons took high scratch honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. In the handicap shooting, C. W. Phellis scored in Class A, J. A. Martin in Class B.
Squadron A's polo team came through in one of the hardest fought polo games of the season at its armory last night to turn back the First Division, 11 to 10, in a Metropolitan League contest.

INTEREST at the Metropolitan this week centers about the revival of "Salome," the third opera of the Richard Strauss cycle, which will be presented Friday night after an absence of three Years from the repertoire.

Starting slowly, St. John's basketball team hit its stride midway through the first half and went on to crush Brooklyn College, 61 to 35, at the Kingsmen's gymnasium last night. It was the seventh victory in succession for the Redmen and their tenth in eleven starts.

An artists' advisory board for the examination of the talents of applicants for scholarships has been announced by the Scholarship Fund Committee of the Munleipal Opera Association, Mrs. Clarence H. Mapkay, honorary chairman.

The varied factors working for and against a revival of the real estate market, now somewhat retarded in activity, were outlined yesterday in statements by New York brokers with their fingers on the pulse of trading in the metropolitan district.
THE transformation of Los Angeles from the "Queen of the Cow Counties" to one of the largest industrial centers of the nation came almost overnight.

Three crowded days of club activities will reach a climax for women of the metropolitan district on Friday when the 105th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs opens at the Hotel Astor.

The Student Tutoring Association, one of Princeton University's unusual undergraduate organizations, finds itself once more in the campus i spotlight as athletics and other extra-curricular activities yield for a fortnight to the current mid-year examinations.

United States importers last year paid 1.17 cents a pound more than in 1936 for green coffee bought, and imported 42,091,000 pounds less, according to statistics released yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

AFTER all the kicking around that she's taken-some twenty-three years of hard usage--one might reasonably expect that Louise Fazenda would have cauliflower ears, a busted nose and that occupational disease which is known as the slap-happy Jitters.

NEXT to Don Quixote tilting at windmill, the world's strangest sight would be a windmill tilting at Don Quixote. That, gentle reader, is the vision on today's horizon as one Benny Goodman, windmill extraordinary, couches a swing musician's baton (all right, he doesn't use a baton) against the great, the good, the colossally quixotic motion picture industry. Mr. Goodman,
Surprises were in store for those who attended the recital of little Peter Paul Loyanich, 10-year-old pianist, who made his local debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

The immediate need for privately owned and State-supervised mortgage banks, as provided for in bills introduced in the Legislature, was stressed yesterday in a statement issued by Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York.

Miss Dorothy Douglas Robinson, a grandniece of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and a cousin of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, has completed the plans for her marriage to Randolph Appleton Kidder of Beverly Farms, Mass., which will take place next Saturday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Captain S. Bartley Pearce, retired boat builder and designer and a leading speedboat helmsman, died here this morning after a long illness at the age of 74. He was prominent for half a century in Democratic politics in Monmouth County and pioneered in advocating and working for improvement of the Manasquan River, for pleasure and commercial purposes.

RADIO'S short waves will raise the spelling bee from a national pastime to an international contest when eight students of Oxford University match accents and skill with six Harvard men and two Radcliffe girls today in what is believed to be the first transatlantic spelling bee on record.
Absent from their home haunts for ten days, the New York Americans will return to Madison Square Garden tonight to oppose the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game.

THE arrival of enough snow to cover the ground with white recently set the stage for a perennial favorite among camera subjects: Central Park at night, with the snow gleaming and the lighted buildings twinkling. While many other parks throughout the city afford as alluring pictorial opportunities, the enclosing skyscrapers at the southern end of Central Park crop up far more often both at photographic exhibits and in publications.

A 2-year-old girl, whose face and body was covered with welts and cuts, was taken to North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken late this afternoon after police, summoned by neighbors, had found her in an apartment on the sixth floor of 696 Jackson Street here.

WITH such material as Major John Andre, Miss Peggy Shippen, General Benedict Arnold and Colonel Aaron Burr for leading characters, and Washington with the rebels and Clinton with the British Army for background, this historical novel could not fail to be interesting.

Ascribing the impending suspension of business by their employer to general business recession and unfair competition, more than 800 employes of the Textile Dyeing and Printing Company of America, Inc., of Fairlawn met today and named a committee to go to Washington in an effort to nave a national wage and hour act passed for the textile industry.

New apartments, stores and other structures erected in the old Chelsea neighborhood during the past year have contributed materially to the business and real estate progress in' that section of the city, points out Charles G. Keller.

JAMES HARPOLE is the nom de plume of a surgeon very evidently a middle-aged Britisher of the high-class Harley Street type-who served with Allenby during the World War. The title of the book would lead one to expect a collection of professional reminiscences similar to Dr. John B. Wheeler's "Memoirs of a Small-Town Surgeon."

Two traditions long observed in music and education in this country are due to be disrupted following the arrival here on Tuesday of Mile. Nadia Boulanger, visiting lecturer in music from the Ecole Normal in Paris.

The Public Service Commission announced today it had refused to approve a $14,000,000 refinancing plan proposed by the Northern States Power Company of Eau Claire. The company operates in West Central Wisconsin.

Industrial employment in Canada fell in December, statements from 10,437 employers showing 1,081,471 on payrolls on Jan. 1, as compared with 1,159,759 on Dec. 1, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
The Boston Bruins snapped in two late third-period goals tonight to gain a 2-2 draw with the Montreal Maroons in a bristling National Hockey League encounter before more than 7,000 fans.

Plans have been completed by Miss Mary Theresa Moughty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Moughty of Old Greenwich, for her marriage to James Edward Grout, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Grout of Greenwich, to take place next Saturday in St. Catherine's Church here. The Rev. Joseph A. Ganley,

One of the finest estates in Bernardsvilie, N. J., the tract of 230 acres owned by the late Frederick P. Olcott, banker and director in many financial organizations, is about to be subdivided into small acreage plots for improvement with homes ranging in price from $8,000 and upward.
Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in Monte Carlo of Montaigu La Montage, a former resident of New York, who has been living abroad. He was 57 years old.

The van Zeeland report is drafted by a man who has been both an academic economist and the head of a nation. It combines, therefore, very unusual merits: soundness of principle, grasp of detailed facts, shrewdness in selecting the arguments that might be politically effective, and a pretty realistic view of what is actually likely to be done or to remain undone.

More than 14,000 men and women have received free guidance service in the WPA adult education division of the Board of Education in the last two years, Gustav A. Stumpf, project administrator, reported yesterday.
The marriage of Miss Marjorie Stevenson Le Boutillier, younger daughter of Mrs. Thomas Le Boutillier 2d of this place, to Stewart Birrell Iglehart will take place on Friday at tha home of her mother.

The Seventy-seventh Division Association honored yesterday eight of its members who in recent months have been appointed, elected or re-elected to city or State offices. The veterans honored were Henry H. Curran, Deputy Mayor;

The city's prohibition of parking in the new crosstown express streets was denounced yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, as the forerunner of an encroachment on the right of women shoppers to drive their automobiles downtown.

SILAN CHEN, modern dancer, will make her American debut tonight at the Windsor Theatre, with Anna Sokolow as guest artist, in a benefit recital sponsored by the American Friends of the Chinese People for the administration of medical relief in China.
Fordham and Tulane will meet in a home-and-home football series in 1939 and 1940, it was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics at Fordham.

The question of lower prices was brought strongly to the fore again last week when President Roosevelt called for such adjustments in mass-production industries, but maintained they should not be made at the expense of cutting wages.

Twenty-five per cent of the criminal cases brought in Moscow are without foundation, Andrei Vishinsky, Attorney General, told a meeting of higher prosecutors last night in a speech condemning the tendency to mass accusations. His estimate,

AFTER a routine inaugural came the first novelty of the Scala season: "Margherita da Cortona," styled a legend, in a prologue and three acts, music by Mgr. Licinio Refice, book by Emidio Mucci, the librettist of this composer's previous sacred opera, "Cecilia," successful in the theatres of Europe and South America.

THE authoritative authors of this handbook on indoor gardening have covered their field admirably. One of the most readable chapters is that on miniature gardens, living-plant arrangements, terrariums and underwater gardens.

Expansion of the WPA to provide 3,000,000 Federal relief jobs, in place of the present total of 1,800,000, is recommended to the Senate Committee on Unemployment and Relief in a statement made public by twenty-one officers of social work organizations, editors of social work publications and educators in the social work field.

Sir Thomas Dunlop, well-known shipowner, grain merchant and yachtsman, died today. He was 83 years old. Sir Thomas, who was created a Baronet in 1916, was senior partner in Thomas Dunlop Sons of Glasgow, shipowners and grain merchants, and consul for Paraguay in Glasgow. His father,

In quiet foreign exchange trading here today, continued offering of dollars, caused, it is believed, by the sale of the currency by the exchange equalization authorities in support of the French franc, again forced the rate down to $5.00 11/16 to the pound.

As the month closes, men's wear stores and departments reported yesterday that the volume of business realized on January clearance sales was much better than had been anticipated. Instead of a 10 or 15 per cent loss under a year ago, sales in most instances came close to those of January, 1937, it was said, while a number of stores passed figures for that month.

A "bunch of the boys" who once tossed so many bricks into windows around Eighth Street and Avenue A that Edward H. Harriman founded the Boys' Club of New York to "take them off the street" held a reunion dinner-dance last night at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.
