Through the efforts of a group of young Swarthmore College alumni of the classes of 1930-37, two new regional alumni scholarships of the value of $1,000 yearly each, for four years, will be offered to men entering Swarthmore in the Fall.

A benefit concert will be given next Sunday at Carnegie Hall by Arturo Toscanini and a symphony orchestra under the auspices of the Italian Welfare League. Proceeds will be used to further the work of the league in aiding Italians living in Greater New York.
Cornell strengthened its hold on second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating the Pennsylvania basketball team at the Palestra tonight, 36-30, before 5,000 persons.

The Union League Club, founded in 1863 to help preserve the Union. whose first activity was the enlistment of two Negro regiments to fight in the Union Army during the, Civil War, will celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary on Feb. 6 and 7.

Mrs. Julia van Dernoot, secretary of the committee on legislation of the Board of Higher Education, has been elected chairman of the Hunter College Retirement Board, the first woman to direct its retirement system.

Approaching the final two blocks of their 3,500-point meeting for the 28.2 balkline billiard championship of the world, Jake Schaefer of Chicago and Welker Cochran of San Francisco divided the eleventh and twelfth games at the Strand Academy yesterday. Schaefer,

What gave him most hope and encouragement during his efforts to find means of renovating international commercial exchange, Paul van Zeeland told the writer this week as we sat in his study, was that no single person or representative of any government ever made the slightest allusion to the doctrine of the necessity of war.

Alec Shellogg, captain-elect of the 1938 Notre Dame football team, has withdrawn from the university and resigned the captaincy, it was dearned today. Shellogg gave no reason for withdrawing from school, and university officials pointed out that the tradition of the university in such

WASHINGTON.-There is a way by which the American housewife can do her bit in helping Uncle Sam keep the nation's granary normal. It was suggested by Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, wife of the Secretary of Agriculture,

No dragon-like green lions will dance tomorrow in the two-car wide streets of Chinatown. More than 7,000 Chinese in this section have agreed to suspend, because of "the trouble in China," celebration and ritualistic displays that would normally attend the beginning of the lunar New Year, numbered either 4,642 or 4,662 in Chinese historical records.

Business men-have been "greatly disconcerted over the suggestion from the White House that prices should be reduced at the same time wages are maintained or increased," the Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared today in its Washington Review.

The first complete report of refugee relief work of the Salvation Army in China to reach this country was made public here yesterday by the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army at 57 William Street.

To meet the needs of dramatic groups specializing in play production, and of students in home economics, art, psychology, music and speech, two new courses will be introduced by the Physics Department of the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina.

NORTH CREEK, N. Y.-Winter port crowds in 1936 heaped great blessings on this Central Adirondack village at the foot of Gore Mountain, but the fine skiing season last year was as nothing compared to the promise of the present.

A brisk rally in railroad issues yesterday featured the slowest trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in almost four months. Interest centered mainly on the carrier group, in which leading brisk demand with gains of fractions to more than 2 points, .so, with a decidedly better tone in many of the more speculative issues, the railroad price average rose 0.64 point on the day.

The annual meeting-luncheon of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York will take place on Wednesday in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador. Mrs. Francis Rogers, founder and a vice president of the club, is chairman of the arrangements committee, other members of which are Mrs. Frank R. McCoy, Mrs. Charles D. Dickey and William M. Chadbourne, presiden of the organization.

With the annual nominating conventions of the Westchester political parties less than five months away, discussions of potential candidates for the office of County Executive were becoming widespread today. The $20,000-a-year position was created by the new county charter, and the first man to fill it will be elected in November.

Miss Molly Lane heads a group of members of the Mprymount College Alumnae and the Marymount Academy Alumnae that has arranged a supper dance for next Saturday at Sherry's in behalf of the new library building fund of the college at Tarrytown, N. Y.

Miss Ethel B. Dietrich, Professor of Economics at Mount Holyoke College, will address the Middle Atlantic Division of the Association of Bank Women on "Does America Gain by Bargaining?" at a meeting on Friday at the Bowery Savings Bank, 100 East Forty-second Street.

Although reports as to retail trade volume last week were spotty, there was in general an upturn in the South, declines in most industrial areas and increases over a year ago in the districts which in 1937 suffered from the floods in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys.
No unanimous feminine vote ever was polled on the franchise as an unmixed blessing. Similarly, jury service-whether civic privilege or just plain nuisance-remains a moot point today.
Excluding additions under group policies amounting to $635,902,687, new life insurance business of the Aetna Life Insurance Company last year was $325,777,396.

The Senate will soon be plunged into debate over the government reorganization plan by which President Roosevelt hopes to "streamline" the executive branches into a set-up more efficient than the far-flung, overlapping machinery that now governs 130,000,000 people.

Columbia's basketball, swimming and wrestling teams will resume competition this week as the fencers open their season. Meanwhile, the Lion trackmen, I. C. A. A. A. A. indoor champions, will continue intensive training for their opening triangular meet with Princeton and Penn Feb. 26.

Miss Anna Catherine Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Murray of this place, was married here this morning in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church to Herbert T. Creedon, also of Pelham, son of Mrs. Jeremiah F. Creedon of Brockton, Mass., and the late Mr.
To all of us black coffee is strong coffee. Hence the vogue of the demi-tasse. But why does milk impede the effect of the caffein? Rarely is enough added to dilute an ordinary cup of coffee markedly.

Yard Dash-Won by Ben Johnson, Columbia; second, Ken Clapp, Brown; third, Martin Glickman, Syracuse; fourth, Easton Burlingame. Yale: fifth. Edward O'Sullivan, New York Curb Exchange; sixth, Lawrence Scanlon, Holy Cross.' Time :05.4.

Many dinners were given tonight in homes and at the various clubs here. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury gave a farewell dinner at their villa for Mrs. Dodge Sloane, who will leave soon for a South American cruise.

Among the many differences between the Jewish question here and in Germany the most important is that while Germany's 500,000 Jews played a comparatively minor role in the economic system of a highly developed industrialized population of 66,000,000, here the commercial and industrial machine of a very backward peasant country of 19,000,000 has been built up by 750,000 Jews.
Waters Roar Beneath -- Cantilevered over a mountain stream, which provides a swimming pool under one end of the living room and emerges at the other side as a waterfall,

Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Garfield Lamont of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Zella Weldon Lamont, to Robert Edwin Skippon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Skippon of Brooklyn.

Britain, France and Russia at Geneva yesterday halted plans for aid to China pending a response from the United States on the proposed resolution to be adopted by the Council of the League of Nations. Poland refused to make action unanimous and the draft was modified.

FIVE million cubio feet of workFing space has been added to the Boeing Aircraft Company's plant in Seattle, Wash., to make room for construction and assembly of its four-engined bombers, land planes and transocean transports.

Business booked by the structural steel industry in December amounted to 99,070 tons, compared with 132,835 in November; 62,267 in October, the lowest level for 1937, and with 166,542 tons booked in December. 1936, the second best month for 1936.

Guests of the Belgian Ambassador, Baron E. de Cartier de Marchienne, at a dinner party given at the Belgian Embassy included the Earl of Dudley, the Dowager Viscountess Harcourt, Sir Henry and Lady Chilton, Mrs. Arthur James, John and Lady Catherine Ramsden and Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Koch Degooreynd.
BEFORE dawn one morning in December, 1936, the Chinese generalissimo, Chiang Kai-shek, was interrupted in the midst of his morning exercises by the sound of firing.

Check clearings through the Westchester County Clearing House Association for the week ended on Friday amounted to $3,303,773, compared with $3,584,335 for the preceding week and $2,534,944 for the corresponding week last year.

Kentaro Arai, Vice President of the Privy council, died today at Kamakura, seaside resort near Yokohama, at the lge of 74. Born at Niigata Ken, Kentaro Arai was graduated from the Law School of the Tokyo Imperial University in 1892.

Grace and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church here was the setting this afternoon ,for the marriage of Dr. Katherine Chamberlayne Harvie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Beverly Harvie of this city, to Dr. Victor Spencer Huggins of Evansville, Ind., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Huggins of Halifax, N. S. The Rev. Beverly Mumford Boyd, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Facilities of the speech "clinic" of the College of New Rochelle are to be extended to students of three junior high schools here with the opening of the Spring Lerm next week, it was announced today. The schools are Trinity, Jefferson and Isaac Young.
Winds that at times reached' ninety miles an hour-hurricane force-raked the British Isles today, spreading property damage, disrupting sea travel and taking at least one life.

The highest honors in the 1937 State-wide accident prevention campaign, promoted by the Associated Industries of New York State, were won by the International Business Machines Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Albert J. Passage, the New York City representative of the Associated Industries.

The decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission this week in rejecting a plan of reorganization for the Genesee Valley Gas Company, Inc., an intermediate holding company, is believed by some Administration attorneys to point the way to a process for the breaking up of holding company systems where one link in the structure proves too weak to remain out of court.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Stone of Plainfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Alberta Stone, to Charles Edward Armstrong of Stapleton, S. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. O. B. Armstrong of Adelphi, Ohio.

The cooperation of a group of prominent women has been enlisted in the interests of a benefit theatrical performance next month to advance the pioneer nursing and health program conducted by the Frontier Nursing Service in the Kentucky mountains.

Better mounted and more accurate in its hitting, the Boulder Brook indoor polo team galloped to a 16-9 triumph over the formidable New York A. C. trio in a senior division Metropolitan League match at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

THE Grosvenor, stanch East Indiaman, a vessel of some 750 tons, flying the flag of the East India Company, London bound, sailed from Trincomalee in June, 1782. She carried a rich cargo under hatches; officers, passengers and crew numbered close to 150 persons all told.

ANIUMBER of band leaders, who through the years have built their reputations as maestros of Tin Pan Alley's tunes, are turning from the ladder of melody, upon which they have climbed in public favor, to become comedians and masters of ceremonies.

Alexander E. Frontera, who was the last candidate counted out in the Queens returns of the City Council election by proportional representation, announced yesterday that he was preparing to obtain an order directing the Board of Elections to show cause why he should not be declared elected in place of Councilman Hugh Quinn.

IN Spain and China an occupation legendary in its romance and daring has had a brilliant revival. The men who are shot at without shooting back, in order that the world may know how the war is going, have come into their own again.
Taking advantage of a penalty on Hershey, the New York Rovers banged in two goals within eleven seconds to defeat the Bears, 4 to 2, in an Eastern Amateur League Hockey game tonight.

Former Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey will be a speaker tomorrow at the annual legislative luncheon meeting of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Stacy Trent in Trenton. His subject is "Problems Solved and Unsolved."

AFEW days ago the Westchester County Board of Supervisors was reported to be consider the installation of toll gates on the Sawmill River and Hutchinson River Parkways, in retaliation for New York City bridge tolls and the sales tax.

Continued absorption of both business and residential space is helping to put the real estate market on a better footing in most communities, The National Association of Real Estate Boards reported yesterday in an analysis of confidential reports on the market received from 260 cities in all parts of the country.

J. Kingsley Powell, real estate conservator of the New Jersey State Department of Banking and Insurance, has resigned, effective Feb. 1, to return to private business as realty consultant for Every Real Estate Service, at 744 Broad Street, Newark.

French eighteenth century furniture from the Irving Brokaw residence at 985 Fifth Avenue and from other owners, English silver consigned by a Boston private collector, fifteenth and sixteenth century needle-painted velvet ecclesiastical vestments, Lille and Brussels tapestries, Aubusson and Oriental rugs will be sold at auction at the Parke Bernet Galleries on Saturday afternoon.

With music in the afternoon and fireworks at dusk, the Edgemont Association held its twelfth annual neighborhood ice carnival today at Crane Lake near here. Cheyenne Patrol of the Edgemont Boy Scout Troop won a stretcherrace on skates.

Kiliaen Van Renssaelaer, who were here for a short visit, have gone to Florence to occupy a villa which they have taken for two months. Mrs. Van Rensselaer's daughter, Miss Lorraine Graves, is with them.

Announcement has been made of the marriage on Friday of Mrs. Elizabeth Marshall Mann Knapp of 50 East Seventy-second Street to Walter Russell Herrick of this city. The ceremony took place at the home of the bride's sister, Miss Jessie Mann of 400 Park Avenue.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates consisted principally of public utility issues, with several entire loans of those companies being scheduled for retirement. Other than those, announcements last week were few and involved mostly small lots of foreign and municipal issues.

There can be no doubt that Professor Joseph B. Rhine, who has been under fire for months because of his publications on telepathy and clairvoyance-extra-sensory perception or ESP-has won the first clash with those who have attacked him on mathematical grounds.

At the 133d annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, which opened here with a private view this evening, eight winners of medals and prizes were announced. Four of these awards honored New York artists:

One more addition has been made to the growing list of unashamed dictatorships. General John Metaxas, virtual dictator of Greece since the Summer of 1936, now announces "a period of severity without any pity." The role of King George II, if any, in the transition is not disclosed.
Budgets of the County Center here will be balanced within the next two or three years, Dana Caulkins, ...

Eligibility for art teachers' certification by the State may now be obtained at City College, according to an announcement by Professor George William Eggers, chairman of the Department of Art and sponsor of the plan.

The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and subsidiaries reported yesterday that their net assets were equivalent to $2,705.20 for each $1,000 of debentures, to $647.26 for each Class A preferred share and to $11.19 for each Class B common share at the close of 1937.

Richard P. Limburg, nephew of Governor Lehman, prepared yesterday to resume his seat on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors as a result of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department.

The number of patents for inventions granted throughout the world amounted to 168,960 during 1936, the latest year for which statistics are available, reports the International Bureau for the Protection of Industrial Property in the current issue of its official publication La Pronriete Industrielle.
IN his preface to this beautiful little book of wisdom Yeats tells how he happened to collaborate with Shree Purohit Swami, poet and scholar in Sanscrit, to translate these ten Upanishads.

Chairman Vinson invited high navy officials today to outline their most immediate needs to the House Naval Committee Monday at the start of hearings on the administration's $800,000,000 naval expansion bill.

Miss Alice Wolcott Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. S Brown of this city, was married to Frederic Warren Rees, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rees of Meriden, in the South Congregational Church here this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Wofford C. Timmons.

NEW YORK has a new show that has the standing-room sign out every day it is open: it is unlike anything else ever produced in the city. There is no admission charge, although most of the spectators contribute to the support of the performance. The show is the new City Council in action, and so far it has provided amusement and drama.

After firming up in the first half hour of trading yesterday, the stock market eased slightly and closed irregular. The turnover of 434,170 shares on the Stock Exchange for the two-hour trading period was smaller on an hourly basis than in the two preceding sessions.

WITH the interrupted hockey warfare about to be resumed in this area, it might be pertinent to report that there has been a further investigation into the matter of the New Haven goalie who caught fire in the heat of a hockey scrimmage.

Miss Sophie M. Roskey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Lesko of this city, was married to Emery T. Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. E. Thomas of Clark Township, in St. Mary's Catholic Church here today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Cornelius J. Kane. Miss Philomene Pepe was maid of honor.

HERE is the story of' the early years of a poet. It is told by a poet with a crystal clarity of style and a vividness that make it an outstanding volume among biographies for young people. Out of her sympathy and imaginative understanding Miss Benet has presented in convincing fashion the complicated, passionate, generous character that was the young Percy Bysshe Shelley during the years from 9 to 18.

The play- production course at Union College has woven its program into the curriculum's fabric in a manner which makes it an auxiliary of the liberal arts courses while maintaining its independent work.
The Liberal government of Prime Minister Mackenzie King this week faced its third Parliament and the first real test of its cohesiveness and power of statesmanship.

The need for more graduate instruction in medicine and the present method of certification and control of specialization were discussed last night by leaders of the profession at the fifty-sixth annual dinner of the Faculty Association of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital at the Hotel Biltmore.

The departure of the liner Leviathan for her final berth in a shipbreaker's yard in Scotland resulted in a flood of comment from persons in all parts of the country who had traveled on her as peacetime passengers, as soldiers bound for France or members of her crew.

Credit for the city's new low-cost housing program was assigned yesterday to the American Labor party members of the City Council, rather than to Mayor La Guardia by B. Charney Vladeck, City Councilman, in an address at the opening session of the convention of the Social Democratic Federation, New York local, at the Rand School Auditorium, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
An undamaged specimen of a Mauritius onepenny Orange postage stamp issued in 1847-one of the rarest stamps known to collectors-was discovered in Nykirk among junk bought by a local butcher.

There was an upset in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship tournament at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday when Charles Gilbert of Columbia, nonseeded player, triumphed over Howard Stephens Jr. of Yale, rated third, in the quarter-final round.

Permanent rules for the City Council, which will be presented at the meeting Tuesday by the Mayor's bloc, will, if passed, strengthen the election of Councilman James A. Burke as vice chairman, restore the power of Newbold Morris as President, give the majority leader a $2,500 increase in salary and considerable power, and otherwise solidify the administration's control of the Council.

The new reading of the verse in the Psalms ("Who passing through the Valley of Baca make it a well") becomes even more appropriate for this day when the nation celebrates what he who was born fifty-six years ago has done to bring healing and strengthening waters to thousands who have suffered from infantile paralysis:

A feature of the "Carnival Capers" to be held on Tuesday evening and Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, for the benefit of Colony House will be a pageant designating the spiritual elements which went into the founding of the beneficiary.

Harry G. Kipke, former football mentor at the University of Michigan, tonight announced his retirement from the coaching profession. Ripke, dismissed recently after nine years as Michigan coach, revealed that he had accepted a position as a salesman with the C. J. Edwards Company, Detroit concern that represents manufacturers of watches, tools, hardware and rubber goods.

ALL is not tranquil within the ranks of the Academy of MoAtion Picture Arts and Sciences, which has promised to make its annual awards on March 4. The Warners' Leon Schlesinger, producer of cartoon subjects, has withdrawn his entry on the ground that preferential treatment is being accorded Walt Disney.

Many members of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Club and their friends entertained parties last night at the club's dinner dance, held in the Silver Room of the Ambassador. Net proceeds of the dance will be applied to the hospital fund established by the club to aid former air service men.

The Chamber of Commerce of Vincennes, Ind., urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve the railroad's application for a general increase of 15 per cent in freight rates. It also urged that the case be expedited.

that the camera and notebook of the tourist will head for higher latitudes this season. If there are some travelers not quite persuaded, an evening with "Ships in the Sky" will do one of two things: make it unnecessary for them to go or else send them headlong to book passage to this dark and heady land of poets, farmers and fishermen.
Foreign circles heard reports today that the Soviet Union was transporting thousands of inhabitants from along its frontiers, presumably as a precaution against subversive foreign influences.

Two violent explosions of munitions in a factory near Segni, a small town thirty miles from Rome, killed at least fifteen men, injured about 200 and wrecked one wing of the building. The damage was estimated at several hundred thousand dollars.

NEEARLY every airplane pilot who has flown farther than gliding distance from his home port has been lost at one time or another. But few have gotten the notice received by Captain Fred A. Jones of Eastern Air Lines, who kept his home folks and all airway Officialdom in suspense most of one night last week until he found himself safely on the ground at Hartford, Conn.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Each day we read of happenings which force us to realize that we have on our hands a railroad problem that no longer may be pushed to one side.
Builders in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island are preparing for an active season in new apartment house construction and medium priced homes.

Canadian mining companies will pay out more than $1,000,000 in dividends in February. Dividends declared to date for the month amount to $814,894, but to this will be added Hollinger's regular dividend, bringing the total to $1,060,394, while, if an extra of 5 cents a share is paid, the total will be $1,306,394.

MAN does not live by bread alone but he certainly keeps the bakers busy. Last year almost ten billion loaves of bread were sold in the United States. approximately eighty pounds of breadstuff for every man. woman and child in the country.

The eleven-story loft and store building comprising the blockfront on the east side of University Place, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, excepting forty-nine feet south of Twelfth Street, will be sold at auction Tuesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

SIX concerts having been broadcast in the series of ten under the baton of Arturo Toscanini, the broadcasters are beginning to learn what listeners from coast to coast think about the symphonic waves that overspread the continent on Saturday nights from the aerials of 140 stations.

Dr. Glenn Frank told the nation's Republicans tonight that their party "must be more faithfully expressive of the American spirit than the fascist program of the New Deal," which, he declared, "threatens to Hitlerize what was once democratic self-government."

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Ruth Meyers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Meyers of this city, to Dr. Irving Feuer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Feuer of Brooklyn, which took place on Thursday in the study of the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman in Temple Rodeph Sholom, who performed the ceremony. Dr. and Mrs.

Miss Imelda Jane Heery, daughter of Philip Edward Heery of this city, was married to Francis George Donnelly, son of Mrs. Anna Donnelly, this morning in the chapel of Seton Hall College, South Orange, of which the bridegroom is an alumnus. The Rev. John O'Brien officiated.
The Bronxville Women's Club will sponsor a "Night of Arts" on Feb. 10 at the clubhouse for the benefit of the MacDowell Club at Peterborough, N. H. Mrs. Karl Larsson heads the committee in charge.

That leadership in extra-curricular activities and high scholarship often :go hand in hand is demonstrated by Radcliffe College seniors. Of the thirty-seven in this year's graduating class who hold scholarships, more than half are leaders in the student life of the college,

H. ReevesSmith, English-born actor, who for more than forty years was a favorite of the American stage as well as that of this country, died today in Ewell, Surrey, at the age of 75. He returned from the United States last year as an invalid, suffering from heart disease.
MINNEAPOLIS closed the year 1937 with a new safety record which at once reveals that motorists can be more careful and that traffic accidents and resultant fatalities can Se greatly decreased.

Arthur Bogas, 16 years old, of Plainfield drowned today, despite the efforts of spectators to rescue him, when the ice of a pond at an abandoned fresh air camp on Leland Avenue gave way while he was skating. Three companions, skating with him, were rescued.
United States naval officers here denied today reports that the gunboat Luzon, stationed at Hankow, had been struck either by a Japanese aerial bomb or by a Chinese shell.

The first of two supper dances arranged for the Winter for debutantes of former seasons and younger marired couples took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event, known as an After Dinner Dance, was limited to subscribers by invitation each young woman being allowed to bring two escorts.

Japan's aggression in China is an undeclared war for national aggrandizement and world expansion, Dr. Cheng T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, dedared in an address tonight before 300 members and guests of the Nassau County Bar Association.

Ben Foord, South African opponent of Max Schnmeling in their bout tomorrow, was fifteen pounds heavier than the German when they weighed in today. Schmeling scaled 192 1/2 pounds and Foord 207 1/2. They will meet at the twelve-round route.

WHAT to do with a hundred or so little pitchers in the house would baffle most people, but not those who collect such vessels as a hobby. The return of the oldfashioned "whatnots" and of corner cabinets is partly accounted for by the need of having places to put bric-a-brac of this sort.
Colonel Marvin Edward Singleton, business man of the Middle West, died early yesterday in Harkness Pavilion after a lingering illness. He was 66 years old.

In a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMEs from Pittsburgh Jan. 26, Dr Herman Hailperin, rabbi of the Tree of Life Synagogue in that city, was erroneously quoted as saying he had a predilection for radicalism.

FOR the first time since the World War a selected number of commercially trained airplane pilots are now being given extended active duty as reserve officers with Air Corps tactical units to meet the shortage of military fliers.

David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced last night that contributions to the United Hospital Campaign totaled $2,100,989 and other gifts were still being received. The total is almost 10 per cent more than was received last year.

THE Regiment of Midshipmen-2,200 strong-will welcome a new superintendent this week. Rear Admiral Wilson Brown Jr., naval aide to three Presidents, wartime commander of a destroyer and more recently commander of the training detachment of the United States fleet, will take charge of the "young gentlemen" of the regiment on

John H. Carpenter, builder and real estate operator, who had engaged in important operations in the Park Avenue and upper Fifth Avenue sections of the city, died yesterday, after a brief illness, at his residence, 550 Park Avenue. He was 68 years old.

PHOTOGRAPHIC parties, where the entrance requirement is a set of pictures, are growing in popularity among camera enthusiasts. Invitations are mailed approximately a week in advance, telling the when and where of the party and listing from four to six types of pictures that must be presented at the door before the party-goer will be admitted.

Women guests in gowns of silver fabric and wearing silver ornaments featured tonight's Silver Ball, first in the series of gala dinner dances of this season at the Surf Club, where the event was in a harmonizing setting of decorations done in silver and black.

Rio de Janeiro is likely to become a horseless and muleless city if a new municipal ruling is obeyed. The horse and buggy was pushed out by the automobile, leaving only the mule and cart, used primarily for the hauling of coffee from the warehouse to the steamer.

Barring an atrocious misarrangement for harp and vibratile instrument of small piano pieces of Debussy, cheerfully and inexcusably dispensed during the intermission by the same stations which broadcast the concert given last night by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra to the publics of America and overseas, it can be said that the occasion had memorable features.

ONE of the many signs that music is at last becoming a democratic thing in America, and the common and treasured possession of all ranks and kinds of the people, is this entertaining, shrewdly philosophic. colloquial booklet of Gerald W. Johnson. "A Little Night Music."

A report advocating the enlistment of foreign capital and the maintenance of the open door in the sections of China cow occupied by Japanese troops will be made to Premier Fumimaro Konoye shortly by Baron Kishachiro Okura, leading Japanese industrialist and member of that nation's "good will mission" to the United States and Europe.
THIS volume. in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the publication of Robert Frost's first book of poetry, is a collection of critical essays and personal reminiscences
THE major-domos of the Bear Mountain-Harriman section of Palisades Interstate Park assert that 2,000,000 people may get up here for Winter sports this season, given snow.

Residential construction activity has been making steady gains in Brooklyn since 1933, and the outlook is bright for the acceleration of this type of work during 1938, according to Frank M. McCurdy, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

A FIVE-CENT piece bearing the likeness of Thomas Jefferson on one side and Monticello, his home in Virginia, on the other will be put in circulation this year to replace the buffalo coin, it was announced recently by the United States Treasury.

A program of carillon chimes broadcast from the spot where the first phonograph was conceived sixty years ago will be a feature of the dedication on Friday, Feb. 11, of the 130-foot Edison Memorial Tower here, it was announced today.

IT took me more than 60,000 miles of foreign travel to discover that the legitimate thea tre is fighting against an unnatural death in more places than the United States and Europe. Concentrating my study of the drama in the Far East and South Seas, I found that out there factors other than the films figure materially in the theatre's decline. The irritating part of it is that these other factors could be rectified.

ART critics whose function it is to interpret visual imagery have neglected the most important graphic exhibition of our time, namely: "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs." Cinema critics have distinguished themselves by blessing it with everything from "* * * *" to "the ten best pictures of the year," which it certainly justifies when related to factual photography.

Gerard Cote of St. Hyacinthe, Que., claimed a new world record for the ten-mile snowshoe marathon today as he won the feature race of the opening day's program held in connection with the international snowsheers' convention.

A public hearing before the Senate Committee on Taxation arid Retrenchment and the Assembly Committee on Taxation on the proposal in Governor Lehman's budget to re-enact two 1-cent emergency gasoline taxes, due to expire on June 30, will be held in Albany Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The so-called business recession in the past few months has created an anomalous situation in the metropolitan realty field, according to Willard K. Denton, special deputy superintendent in charge of the real estate bureau of the New York State Banking Department.
The proposed combination school and garage, opposite the Yankee Stadium, is opposed by Howard W. Nudd, director of the Public.Education Association, as a "preposterous proposal."

Determination what constitute "strategic raw materials" has become the' purpose of the work of Senator Elmer Thomas, head of a subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, which is now investigating exports of scrap iron and steel.

Governor Lehman's recent recommendation that the State continue even in the business recession to spend money for centralizing rural schools and for farm courses in high schools, was based on the vastly increased demand for these facilities in the past year.

Still another "nursery" -London's suburban repertory houses-will open Monday. At the King's Theatre in Hammersmith, Jevon Brandon Thomas will begin a season with "Gaily To Set Out," a new play by Sheila Donisthorpe, the author of "Children to Bless Us." In the cast will be Olga Lindo, Betty Jardine and Wilson Barrett.

The National Socialist powers that be have called off another revolution-the revolution, namely, which decreed that German women must go back to the ex-Kaiser's famous three K's, "kueche, kinder, kirche" (meaning kitchen, children, church), which,

Members of debating teams at the University of Pennsylvania are engaged this year in the most extensive program in the history of the university's debate council, partly as a result of additional financial aid extended by the institution.

Twenty-two of Brooklyn's leading high and prep school players of 1937 season were honored at the twelfth annual football luncheon tendered by Abraham Straus in the executive dining room of the Brooklyn department store yesterday.

Tommy Smith of Utica today won the Northville senior men's skating championship. The Eastern States and Capital District titleholder led a field of forty Northern New York skaters in the ,team championship with 170 points.

The stock-market bear, a picturesque but never popular denizen of Wall Street, seems destined to go the way of the buffalo and the vanfishing Indian. In recent years he has been subjected to an accumulating burden of restrictions.

THERE is, of course, no such thing as a murder without motive. As Asaph Clume so forcibly points out, the motive may not be apparent, but the killer always has some reason, real or imaginary, for his act.

The largest gallery to witness a racquets match in this country in years saw Robert Grant 3d add another notable conquest to his long string yesterday to advance his candidacy as a challenger for the world title.

Giuseppe Toeplitz, former co-director of the Banca Commerciale Italiana, died last night after a long illness. He was 72 years old. Financial circles considered him the virtual creator of the bank, which he built into international proportions.

An actual strike, in which mediation so far has failed, will present a case study for the League of Women Voters of the Twenty-third Assembly District, which will conduct a forum on "The Consumer's Stake in a Strike" tomorrow evening at the Paramount Mansions, 183d Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

THE announcement in London that Max Gate House, which Thomas Hardy built for him self on a hill overlooking Dorchester (the Casterbridge of his novels), is to be sold at auction, recalls the Wessex of ancient England and the country covered by his writings.

Forty-five Colgate University students have been enrolled in the course on dictatorships which will start on Monday. So many wanted to take the course that it was necessary to close it to any more students, Dr. Rodney L. Mott, director of the School of Social Sciences, which is giving the course, said tonight.

Citing heavy losses sustained annually by material men. supplying material and labor on New York City public works, the New York Credit Men's Association yesterday urged adoption of a payment bond on all contracts.
Summing up present and future conditions in the real estate field on Long Island, John H. Morris, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board, points out that the market is gradually improving.

Taking a lead early in the game which it never relinquished, the Blair Academy basketball team defeated Peddie School today, 33-24, and assumed first place in the Eastern Private Schools League. Bert Witte was high scorer for the winners, tallying 12 points, while Captain Conrad of Blair was second with 11.

A New Rochelle skipper, George B. Alley, has been chosen commander of the Stamford Power Squadron for 1938 as the result of the recent election. James A. Danver of Glenbrook, Conn., is the new lieutenant commander, Allison Albee of Rye, the secretary, and Carl Paight of Stamford, the treasurer.

Italian industrial development, especially along lines essential to the program of economlo self-sufficiency, made considerable progress last year, according to official data made public here yesterday by Luigi Podesta, delegate of the Italian National Institute of Exchange and operator of the Italian Government's exchange control here.

THIS is the book of a happy scholar who has absorbed much in lecture room and library yet has never quite accustomed himself to academic discipline. There are charm and sincerity in his historical seditions, his literary subversions.

A total of forty-seven properties and mortgages were offered for sale at prices aggregating $223,950 in lists mailed yesterday from the offices of the liquidation bureau of the New York State Insurance DePrtment.

MR. FRISCHAUER, a young Austrian historian and biographer, has chosen Poland during the Third Partition as the scene of his first novel. Against the grim background of a land torn by inward dissension and hacked by outward aggression he parades a diverse group of characters.
Under the supervision of the General State Authority, Pennsylvania plans to begin construction soon of; an "Alcatraz" near Mount Gretna to house its 600 most troublesome prisoners.

The Yale varsity polo team, smarting from a defeat at the hands of Army this afternoon, staged a rousing five-goal rally in the final chukker tonight to defeat the Lawrenceville School, national interscholastic champion, 11-9, at Essex Troop Armory in the main contest of a program celebrating President Roosevelt's birthday.

A New York group of forty-eight pupils and twelve teachers of Lincoln High School, Teachers College, Columbia University, headed by G. D. Baker, principal, arrived here tonight for a study of regional planning as carried out by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Indictments charging Miami's Mayor, Robert R. Williams, and four other city officials with soliciting bribe money have caused embarrassment among the civic-minded in the resort area because of the presence of many Winter visitors, but Floridians, generally, are inclined to reserve judgment until the matter has been aired in court.

AMERICAN MARCO POLOS New York has been host during the past week to three trail blazers the aga of whose journeyings deserves to rank with that of pioneers of unnechanized centuries long dead. They ire Leonidas Borges de Oliveira, comnander; Francisco Lopez da Cruz,
Representative Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana in an interview here today said Germany was supplying arms and ammunition to fascist bands in Mexico, and predicted a Nazi uprising in two months.

The City College School of Business Evening Session will offer during the February term a special course in modern retailing. The course will start Feb. 10 at the downtown branch, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. Registration is Feb. 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7.

Dwellings and apartment houses for families of modest income will constitute the bulk of the building activity in the metropolitan area and in many other parts of the country for the next twelve months, and perhaps for several years to come.

Exactly two years after it had ordered the Committee for Industrial Organization to dissolve, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor opened its quarterly session here this week to make a moment tous decision.

The Southern Council on International Relations has been formed by a group representing social, civic, religious, economic, educational and business activity in the South. Keener C. Frazer is the council secretary.
Marking the fifth anniversary of Hitler's rise to power, the International Relief Association, 20 Vesey Street, has issued a study of youth in Germany under the title, "Youth Betrayed."

The French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street, will give an entertainment under the patronage of the French Embassy Friday evening for Jules Henry, Charge d'Affaires. Proceeds of the event will augment the French Institute Library Fund.

It took Frank Kovacs of Oakland four sets today to turn back his fellow Californian, Wilmer Hines of Hollywood, in the semi-final round of the Florida State tennis tournament. Kovacs won by 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6--3 and will meet Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., in the title round tomorrow.

The house in Stamford, Conn., formerly owned by the late Evan Owen, has been purchased by William W. Fitzhugh Jr. of Brooklyn, through G. B. Glave Co., brokers. The new owner will alter and occupy it.
Dr. John L. Tildsley, former associate superintendent of schools, asserted yesterday that high school students cannot be educated properly "under present conditions."

Dufaycolor, Inc., which has the rights in the United States to manufacture film for colored photography developed from a French invention, plans to build a plant here to cost $1,000,000, Pierpont N. Hamilton, president, said yesterday.
Buck Freeman, head coach of St. Thomas College's basketball team and former coach at St. John's University in New York, was in a hospital tonight, his left ankle fractured.

From housewife to business man, New Yorkers are showing an increased interest in learning to write, if the rapid growth of the Washington Square Writing Center of New York University during the Many of the 506 men and women enrolled are desirous of becoming professional writers and have completed thirteen evening noncredit courses,

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange; Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange, and Dr. Carl E. Parry, chief of the securities loan division of the Federal Reserve System, were among the guests at the first annual dinner of the senior margin clerks' section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms in the Hotel Astor last night.

DURING 1937 the British reader of fiction had thirty-six new novels each week from which to choose. This is one of the facts revealed by the census which the Publishers' Circular has taken of the books published in the British Isles during the year.

Alfred Duff Cooper, First Lord of the Admiralty, tonight praised President Roosevelt's recommendations for increasing the naval strength of the United States. Speaking at the annual banquet of the Birmingham Jewelers and Silversmiths Association, he said:

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Bags and shoes to match in early Spring leathers and fabrics are introduced now to fill in between seasons. These accessories give a touch of newness to a street costume. They are practical purchases; they can be worn now and through the warmer weather to come.
Dean Carl Venth, composer, died in a hospital here today at the age of 78. He underwent a major operation several days ago.
The violinist Nathan Milstein gave what was announced as his only local recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall before a nearcapacity house.
Cyrus S. Eaton of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary A. Eaton, to Dr. Fay A. LeFevre, son of Dr. Walter I. LeFevre, also of Cleveland.

In the nearly eighteen years since the war-to-end-war there have been seventeen wars, large and small. Two of these, the civil war in Spain and the undeclared war in the Far East, involve today one-fourth of the world's population.

Some of those with whom President Roosevelt has discussed the monopoly question recently have gained the impression that he would correct certain business "abuses" by specific legislation defining the practices rather than by vesting in the government discretionary authority to accomplish the objective.

The British Foreign Office today stopped Jacob Epstein's latest work before the New York-born sculptor even started on it. With a group of five writers and artists, Mr. Epstein had accepted an invitation to visit Spanish Government-held territory, where he intended to make a bust of Premier Juan Negrin.

The government has approved plans for the construction of an asphalt highway from Ancon to Pativilca, through the ports of Chancay, Huacho, Supe and Barranca. The distance is about 100 miles and the cost is estimated at about $500,000.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Elizabeth Harriman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, are aiding in the plans for the entertainment to be known as the "Gay Twenties" dinner dance, which will take place next Saturday in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York.

Fourteen government agencies were awarded ninety-eight supply contracts valued at $5,037,932 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act during the week ended on Thursday, the Department of Labor announced today. Of the total,

A specially appointed committee for the defense of national industries asked President Arturo Alessandri in an open letter today to give Chilean enterprise more ample protection in the face of the growing volume of low-priced foreign merchandise "dumped" on local markets.

Homes featuring concrete construction throughout the country increased more than 61 per cent during 1937 as compared with 1936, reports E. M. Fleming, Eastern manager of the Portland Cement Association, who adds that all classes of residences having concrete first floors showed a rise of 38 per cent last year over 1936.
Pleas to Czechoslovakia for help against growing German-Italian influence in Central and Eastern Europe were carried today by three of Vienna's leading newspapers.

The report of the New Jersey Zinc Company for 1937, made public yesterday, showed a net income of $7,871,914 after Federal taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges. This was equivalent to $4.01 a share on 1,963,264 shares of capital stock.
Eight players and Manager-Coach Louis J. Rinaldi of the national A. A. U. basketball squad sailed yesterday on the Southern Cross of the Munson Line for a three-month tour of South America.
Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will attend the conference here next week of more than 500 small business men, the Commerce Department announced today.

Miss Kay Bowe gave a buffet luncheon yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bowe, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Rosina Roche, whose engagement to J. Fabian Rendich of Brooklyn was announced recently.

To take effect 8 A. M. Feb. 1: LIEUTENANT-William M. Carroll. from 19th Division, office of the chief inspector, to 2d Division. Assigned to duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform. SERGEANT-Peter M. O'Brien, from 15th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad Manhattan, designated as acting lieutenant and assigned to duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform.

Despite the decision of the majority leadership to consider the housing conference report next week, the band of Southern Senators who have filibustered against the Wagner-Van Nuys anti-lynching bill for more than three weeks decided today to "sleep on their arms" until that measure was definitely sidetracked.

The United States naval program, coupled with rumors that France is preparing 42,000-ton battleships, is shaking the confidence of the Japanese press that the Japanese Navy can maintain the strict secrecy regarding its plans without provoking a naval race.

From Washington goes out the tocsin call that the United States should have a navy "second to none." There is something strangely familiar about that. It sounds like an old song that was sung back in 1921 and 1922, in the ensuing eight years and then again at the sea-power conference in London in 1930. It is an echo of the policy of naval parity with Great Britain.
An innovation is being introduced this year at Elmira College during the mid-year examination period which began yesterday.

TIRED: In Baltimore's Court House Square has stood for 115 years a Statue of Victory, one arm extended and holding a wreath. The figure was set up to commemorate an American success in the War of 1812. Last week Victory became tired. She dropped her wrist and the wreath.

Attacks on modern education from the right, center and extreme left have intimidated neither the trustees and faculty, nor the student body of Vassar College, President Henry Noble MacCracken told 300 alumnae yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Vassar Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PINEHURST, N. C.--Golf will be the outstanding attraction at this midsouth resort during February. Eleven formal tournaments are scheduled during the month, five Tin Whistles Club LAID events, four Silver Foils Club tourneys and three Pinehurst Country Club golfing contests.

The annual report of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $7,838,737 after all expenses and charges. This is equal to $5.88 a share on the outstanding capital stock.

In addition to the Arab terrorism operating in Palestine there is a strong undercurrent of political manoeuvring, all directed from Damascus and the small town of Junieh in Lebanon, where Haj Amin el Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem, is living as a political exile.
WE are no longer surprised when a foreign correspondent writes a book. We never should have been, for Xenophon, Herodotus, Sir John Mandeville and others set the fashion long ago.

The United States Bureau of Fisheries is tagging herring. The purpose is to find out what areas in Alaskan waters are frequented by herring and how many different races of herring are caught and sold. As they are unloaded from the boats the herring are searched for tags at the rate of 100 a minute.
Fordham University and the New. York Athletic Club shared honors in the matter of individual performances in the A. A. U. track and field meet at the 102d Engineers: Armory last night.

Future automobiles may be outfitted with "radio horns" whose warnings would be silent to everybody but other near-by auto drivers, it is revealed in a patent just granted here to Wilhelm Runge of Berlin, Germany.

With the December cotton harvest over and field, work in other crops reduced to a minimum, alarming reports of hunger, privation and actual starvation among migratory farm workers come from the San Joaquin Valley and other agricultural districts in California.
AFTER a plodding start to 1938, with the usual things done in the conventional way-and not too many of them, either the theatre here has caught its second wind and is making a belated January spurt.

A round-up of known criminals, started simultaneously in various parts of the city by detectives, brought some 600 prisoners into police station houses last night. Although no announcement was made by officials of the department, it was reported at police headquarters that the drive was an answer to two recent major crimes, the murder of a Bronx police sergeant and the machine-gun hold-up of a pier paymaster on Friday.

The John Marshall College of Law basketball team turned back the Geneva College quintet of Beaver Falls, Pa., 28 to 24, at the Thomas Edison High School gymnasium tonight. It was the sixth straight triumph for the charges of Matty Begovich, who have won ten of their thirteen starts.

The Argentine Department of Finance issued yesterday a decree reducing from 20 per cent to 10 per cent- the exchange surcharge on payment of goods imported without prior permits, according to an announcement made here by the Argentine Information Bureau.

COLONIAL powder horns were more than an important article of equipment for the trapper and soldier. In the course of making and use they became an expression of decorative folk art, as fifty examples or so on display in the Recent Accessions Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum attest.

The resolutions recently adopted at Indianapolis, Ind., by the American Association for the Advancement of Science "may have profound effects not only upon the future of science but upon social history," Sir Richard Gregory, editor of the internationally famous scientific journal Nature, wrote in last week's issue.
Five Canadians joined a trio of field stars from two sister dominions today in a record-smashing prelude to the British Empire Games just a week away.

Speakers with a variety of achievements and backgrounds will appear on programs scheduled for club meetings of the week in Westchester. At the Bronxville Women's Club on Wednesday, 10:30 A. M., the guest will be Gordon B. Enders,
Sun Egret and Clingendaal, both flying the green and white silks of A. C. Compton, ran one, two today to dominate the fourth running of the $5,000 added San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita Park.

The ever-appealing indoor games of the Millrose A. A. will be staged in Madison Square Garden Saturday night with all their traditional panoply. Star-studded fields jam the program to the bursting point, an item that the track fans seem to appreciate because the early ticket sales indicate a capacity gathering of 16,000.
The 1937 death rate of 17,700,000 industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was the lowest ever recorded by statisticians of the company.

It is unfortunate that the Treasury cannot afford to recommend the abandonment of the tax on capital gains. If transactions in capital assets were ignored for income-tax purposes, the greatest single step toward the'simplification of the income-tax system would have been taken.

An edition of "progressive education" notebooks for school children in France has been introduced through the Ministry of Education for the purpose of "arousing international peace-mindedness among French children through understanding and knowledge of other cultures and nations."

Under a light volume of business yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range to end unchanged to 3 points lower. An improvement in Bombay tended to counteract the sentimental influence of lower outside markets, while active mill price-fixing in the March position left that month around previous closing levels.

Johnny Goodman, national amateur. golf titleholder, is going after the British amateur championship. He believes the U. S. Golf Association may make arrangements for the Walker Cup team, of which he is a member, to be in England in time for the British amateur, scheduled two weeks before the cup matches.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 26, aggregated $7,452,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 19 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Introduced as a member of the cast of the "greatest show in the city," Councilman Charles Keegan of the Bronx urged members of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night to "get on the job and watch the- city officials and you will be watching your own pocketbooks."

THE current exhibition of paintings -- numbered twentyTive in the series of shows by groups of New York artists at the Municipal Art Galleries-is one of the best and most diversified in the two years of the galleries' existence.
Syracuse flashed aggressive basketball tonight to defeat Georgetown, 43 to 26, with Mark Haller, new center sensation, netting 20 points for the winners before about 2,900 fans.
Diplomatic circles here disclosed today that Edmond Ciuntu, Rumanian Ambassador to Russia, had been recalled to Bucharest.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers yesterday announced that John C. Parker, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., had been selected as nominee for president. Independent nominees may be proposed at a later date. The election will be held in the Spring.

Asserting that the civil service architects employed by the Board of Education have saved the city money and at the same time designed good school buildings, the Society of Architects and Engineers has taken issue with the findings of the Architectural Commission's report.

The powerful St. Paul's School basketball team today vanquished Hackley, 66-27, to remain undefeated this season in nine contests. The St. Paul's five, which boasts an average scoring record of 53 points per game, tallied 28 points in the third period and enjoyed a 60-27 lead at the start of the final session. Hackley suffered its first reverse in three starts.

From the six to eight million tons of cottonseed produced annually in this country at least 40,000 and possibly 80,000 tons of gossypol could be obtained-a deadly poison. Here, it seemed, was one way of controlling the insects that worry farmers.

Miss Lucy Dunlap Smith, daughter of Professor Elliott Dunlap Smith of Yale and Mrs. Smith, was today presented to society at a reception and tea in the home of her parents, the Master's House of Saybrook College, Yale University.

More than a third of the students at Colby College are participating this year in the work of one or another of the religious organizations on the campus, according to a survey made by Professor Herbert Lee Newman, director of religious activities, and Mrs. Mary Finch, student counselor.

Appointment of Alfred Evan Reames, veteran member of the Oregon bar and Democratic party leader, to the seat in the United States Senate which will be vacated Monday by Frederick Steiwer, Republican, was announced today by Governor, Charles H. Martin.

One of the loveliest flowers we can grow in our gardens and one that is too seldom seen is the tuberous rooted begonia. Growing and blooming in the shade, it is the perfect answer to the seeker for plants to bloom on the north side of buildings and under. trees or shrubbery.

The prohibition of parking in ten midtown streets will be continued for at least thirty days more, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. Reduced congestion and a marked saving of time in traveling by using these streets were the chief reasons advanced for continuing the restriction.

Dr. Robert Gordis, rabbi of Temple Beth-El, Rockaway Park, will be the principal speaker at the conference Tuesday morning of Leaders of Sisterhoods and Women's Organizations, to be held at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street.

ATLAS-WOLFF-Mrs. Herman T. Wolff of 43 St. 'Andrew's Place, Yonkers, announces the marriage of her daughter, Hazel, to Mr. Alexander S. Atlas of Mannattan, on Sunday. Jan. 23. BRICKEN - WISE - Mrs. Nathan Wise, Mount Vernon, N. Y., announces marriage of her daughter, Lillian, to Mr. Robert Bricken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Bricken of New Rochelle, N. Y., taking place Jan. 30, 1938.

Miss Eleanor Hoge, a provisional member of the Elizabeth Junior League and a debutante of this season, will play the title role in the forthcoming production of Frances Homer's "Cinderella," which will be presented by the children's theatre executive committee of the league on Feb. 19 at the
Larry MacPhail, new executive vice president of the Dodgers, finally settled in New York

President coupled with the American and British comment that it is intended to "serve the world of democracy" and implies the virtual coordination of American and British forces, commanded keen if uncomfortable interest in Germany today.

Members of the Barat Auxiliary will hold their annual dinner dance on Feb. 19 at Sherry's for the benefit of the various philanthropic activities of the settlement. The beneficiary maintains at its headquarters at 221 Chrystie Street an extensive educational and recreational program for the underprivileged.

Robert James Kaempfer, who lives in a $3-a-week furnished room at 15 West 126th Street and who was an early settler in relief work, was still thinking last night of accepting the self-solicited invitation he received recently from Secretary of Commerce Daniel Roper to attend a forthcoming conference of small business men at Washington.

Estonia's young chess champion, Paul Keres, who has earned the plaudits of the chess-playing world by his showing in important European tournaments during the past year, was again in fine fettle in the recent international tournament at Hastings, where he finished only half a point behind Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, winner of the first prize.

One-eighth of the men on the eligible list of the State Department and of those added to the foreign service this year are graduates of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, the only one of its kind in America.

Two and a half million persons visited the National Zoological Park last year, Dr. William A. Mann, its director, recently told the House Appropriations Committee.Though not the largest, the Washington zoo is today rated one of the world's finest.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Anthony of South Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Anthony, to Linton M. Solomon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon of Macon, Ga.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, denying that he had been a traitor to his union, the United Mine Workers of America, by assisting a rival, the Progressive Miners of America, to obtain an A. F. of L. charter, made today another bitter attack against John L. Lewis.
The world's economic salvation, as envisaged by Paul van Zeeland in his report made public to the world yesterday, is a subject of profound concern here, and has been for the past five years.
Britain's Swedenborgians, who, according to the last census, number 15,000, celebrated tonight the 250th anniversary of the Swedish scientist with a grand festival meeting in Queen's Hall.

Among out-of-town guests attending the Piccadilly supper dance held tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford for the benefit of the social service department of the Orthopedic Hospital were Miss Elise Grace of Syosset, L. I.; Mrs. M. S. C. Robinson of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Mr. and Mrs. Duncan D. Sutphen Jr. of Dobbs Ferry. N. Y.

TORONTO.-The largest and most northern constituency in Canada's House of Commons is represented by Mrs. Martha Louise Black, who, as a young mother, took the Yukon Trail and climbed the long Chilcoot Pass in 1898 with her husband, brother and cousin, along with thousands of others who hoped to make their fortunes in the Yukon gold rush.

The body of Mrs. Clara Ford Phillips, 75, a bullet wound in the breast, was found today in her home here by County Investigator William J. Green. A revolver, fully loaded except for one empty chamber, was beside the body.

With only the whim of the weather to determine whether the snows on the New England river watersheds will turn into a flood this year as disastrous as that of 1936, the lower valleys two months hence face the freshet season without any of the flood control works for which they were led to hope a year ago.

BUILT almost entirely of wood, a new twin-engined transport which can be converted overnight into a highly potent light bomber has made its debut in a secluded valley airport near here. The craft has been designed for marketing in the lucrative foreign governmental field.

A special investigating committee of the Confederacion Trabaja Mexicana, after a detailed inquiry of conditions at the government's key community far min the La Laguna cotton region, reported that President Lazaro Cardenas's project was bound to be a success in the long run, but recommended certain changes in operations.

At an age when most women would be consent to sit by the fire and think of the past, Mrs. Sarah Brodsky, 97 years old, mother of Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky, has taken up the crocheting of a bedspread, extremely difficult in pattern, and hopes to realize an ambition to see her handiwork exhibited in the New York World's Fair of 1939.
Six Wellesley professors and the dean of freshmen, taking sabbatical leave during the next six months, will spend the time in independent study at home and abroad.
THE official anniversary of public television came on Nov. 2, 1937, but in the eyes of the staff of 265 at the Alexandra Palace the significant date is Feb. 5 of this year.

A final report meeting will be held tomorrow at the home of Jules S. Bache, 814 Fifth Avenue, marking the end of the $1,000,000 campaign of the combined women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish, Charities, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Richard Percy Limburg, campaign chairman.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of Grand Central Terminal, a railroad station that is virtually a self-contained city through which more people go every day than live in Newark or Cincinnati, will be observed Wednesday.

The draft of a uniform mortgage foreclosure law for all States has been prepared by the Central Housing Committee and copies have been sent to attorneys and officials of savings and loan associations throughout the country for their comments
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The annual Winter party of the Charity League, an outstanding event of the season for the local social set, will be held in the Hotel Chelsea next Friday night.

Two new courses in "City Gardening" and "Suburban Gardening," designed to meet the needs of the urban garden enthusiast interested in city trees, window boxes, penthouses and back-yard gardens, will be conducted at New York University's Washington Square Center of Adult Education for fifteen Tuesday evenings commencing Feb. 8. Dr. -Forman T.

SHANGHAI.-If the United States were to suffer a disaster involving the destruction of $500,000,000 in any one State the effect would be a terrible shock to American economto life. Recovery would be fairly rapid, because of the country's great resources and the high average income per capital.

The season's third Youth Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony was given yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Rudolph Gahz. The program was devoted largely to the brass instruments.

An anonymous gift of $50,000 has brought the amount raised to date in the building fund campaign of the White Plains Hospital to $817,000, it was announced today. Success of the drive has encouraged officials of the hospital to proceed with plans under which ground will be broken for the new structure within the next six months.

TWENTY years ago-on Jan. 28, 1918, to be exact-there died in Wimereux Military Hospital, on the Channel coast of France, the man who was privileged to write "the greatest poem in English occasioned by the World War." He was Colonel John McCrae,

After a day of traveling between here and Newark, where it began its inquiry into Hudson County election practices this morning, the Assembly's committee recessed for the day without having obtained the poll books, without which it could not proceed.

The Board of Education has notified Governor Lehman and the Legislature that it disapproves of fourteen of the eighteen school bills introduced in the present legislative session, James Marshall, vice president of the board and chairman of its law committee, announced yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation-released the following orders today, dated Jan. 27: CAPTAINS Haines, G. W., Newport, R. I., to duty as recruiting inspector, Southern Division, New Orleans, La., in May. Soule, C. C. Jr., to additional duty as commanding officer, Receiving Station, Boston, Mass.

IN the memories of most of the few people of today who ever give i thought to Brazil's white-bearded imperial patriarch of the nineteenth century he lives principally as the perpetrator of a famous little jokeduly quoted. by the way. in this most recent book about him.

The Tribune said tonight that Merry Fahrney, heiress to a patent medicine fortune, fled from a Los Angeles hotel in a trunk last September to avoid being served with a summons in a $150,000 damage suit filed by her estranged husband, Baron Arturo Berlingieri.

LITTLE that is new has appeared since the beginning of the year, and the most important theatrical event is the announcement that "Mourning Becomes Electra" has proved so successful in one of the specialized theatres, the Westminster, that it is to be transferred to the New Theatre under the auspices of the Albery-Wyndham management.

Four new neighborhood theatres are planned or are under construction by the WPA in branches of the New York Public Library, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, announced yesterday. Eleven such theatres have been installed.

TO those of us in this country who have become accustomed to the inferior quality of nearly all English books on various phases of Hispanic America the present volume will come as a delightful surprise.

To the Screen Editor: In reference to "Music on the Screen" by Herman Weinberg, appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Jan. 16, no mention was made of Jerome Kern, whose music has pleased those of the stage for many years and has in recent years written for the films.

With the New York World's Fair as its inspiration, a course in international expositions will be offered, starting Feb. 10, by the Hunter College evening and extension division. The course, to consist of weekly lectures on the history and influence of such expositions by officials of the World's Fair,
Carrying on with a surprising show of power in the last furlong when many thought he would falter, Wise Prince today captured the $7,000 Miami Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park,

OFFICERS of the Air Corps Tactical School at Maxwell Field, Ala., will transfer classes to Barksdale Field here on Feb. 4' for a two-day "field laboratory" in which units from all three wings of the General Headquarters Air Force will demonstrate the United States Army's newest aerial combat tactics.

John D. Rockefeller's home on Euclid Avenue will soon pass as one of the city's landmarks. T. J. Bartok leased the grounds today at a rental of $20,000 for five years, and announced that the homestead would be razed for a parking lot and filling station.

Jimmy McClure of Indianapolis and Sol Schiff of New York won the world men's doubles table tennis championship today, defeating the crack Hungarian pair of G. Barna and L. Bellak, 21-18, 15-21, 19-21, 21-14, 21-19.

Last week the local hook-and-lad der brigade was called out to pu out a non-existent blaze in Windso Castle, England. All London, too was puzzled by a vivid glow. It was the aurora borealis giving an exhibit tion of beauty and mystery quite in accordance with the predictions of the physicists.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney, announced yesterday eighteen additional appointments to his staff, one assistant district attorney, thirteen deputy assistant district attorneys and four law assistants.

We went on a real old fashioned Carolina dove shoot today, and if it's action you want, and plenty of shooting, we can recommend this form of hunting. The dove shoots here, however, are not private affairs. They are community gatherings, and several women took part.
APITIFUL figure shuffled in to the London postoffice near Charing Cross in 1888, his coat collar turned up and pinned together, his shoes showing chapped and reddened flesh through their cracks.

FORTUNATELY the Federal Theatre still has the Living Newspaper to publish from time to time. It is the most dramatic spokesman on the Federal Theatre's forum and it is one of the most powerful mediums of expression in the country. And,
This week's council session indicates that it is League reform instead of the League itself which the secessionist triangle-Germany, Italy and Japan has killed.

The United States Army and Navy Bandsmen's Asociation, which opened its national convention at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, prepared to act today on resolutions urging Congressional enactment of bills giving the status of commissioned officers to ranking army and National Guard band leaders.
Adoption of a seven-point highway safety program for States is the objective of twelve national civic, educational and business organizations which will start a campaign this week.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair Athletic Club reached the final of the sixteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship today at the Short Hills Club. Only Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club stands between Wolf and his eighth New Jersey title.

That workers are prepared to take over the United States and British petroleum companies in Mexico in case the companies execute their threat to leave Mexico is announced by the executive committee of the Union of Petroleum Workers, an affiliate of the Confederation of Mexican Workers.

" LE GRAND CONDE," by Henri Malo, conservator of the Chantilly Museum (Albin Michel, 512 pp. 8 vo., illustrated, 25 fr.), is not only a memoir of the renowned general, administrator of provinces, scholar and man of the world,

Dr. Arthur Ruark, head of the Physics Department at the University of North Carolina, and his assistant, Creighton Jones, announced that they have made experiments and calculations which disprove the theory of the electron recently advanced by Dr. G. M. Jauncey of Washington University, St. Louis.

Miss Nancy Browning Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Tarrytown, was married in St. Barnabas Church here this afternoon to Robert H. Leith of Rye, son of Mrs. Therese B. Holmes of Rye and William G. F. Leith of Pleasantville. The Rev. C. Kenneth Ackerman, rector of Christ Church, Tarrytown, performed the ceremony. Because of illness in the bride's family there was no reception.

HAROLD LLOYD, last of the silent-era comedians, is well into his first picture in two years, "Professor Beware." While the same prediction is freely made during the shooting of any epic, there is reason to believe that the current Lloyd opus will equal, if not excel, the thrillers that brought him fame two decades ago.

The most significant change in our national defense policies in sixteen years, as well as in the foreign policies which our army and navy implement, was announced Friday by President Roosevelt in his special national defense message to Congress.
West Side brokers are looking forward hopefully to a satisfactory realty year for 1938, but their optimism is on a more conservative basis than was the case at the opening of 1937.

The Giants are going to win the National League pennant this year with the same club that topped the National League last season. The race will be even closer among the first division clubs. Furthermore, with the exception of five regulars, every one of New York's squad of thirty-one players is trading material.

Despite the unfavorable effect of the recession the real estate market has maintained a strong undertone and trading has been marked by a consistent steadiness, in the opinion of Henry G. Waltemade, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.
United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew today made representations to the Japanese Government against the slapping of John M. Allison, ranking American diplomat at Nanking, by a Japanese soldier.

The Junior League Glee Club will give its sixteenth annual concert on Friday night in the Great Hall of the league's clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. The concert each year receives a large subscription from members of the organization and their friends.

Mr. and Mrs. Rowley W. Phillips of Waterbury, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriette Wheeler Phillips, to Thomas Rawdon Fisher Jr. of Scarsdale, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mr. Thomas R. Fisher of Southbury, Conn.
