BOY SCOUT Week, eommemorating the twenty-eighth anniversary of scouting in Amerlca, will begin next Sunday. For 1,129,827 Scouts, Cubs and leaders the celebration will be featured by something new in their experiencethe "live expos" or living exposition of scouting.
Midterm promotion of twenty-one cadets to higher military rank was announced today by Dean Harold Morrison Smith of Bordentown Military Institute.

Benefits to the cinema industry through new application of two scientific developments-a "voice mirror," based on the principle of instantly variable electro-magnetic recording, and a process of producing imperishable metal printswere described to the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, in conference here recently, by S. K. Wolf, president of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers.

SKIPPER: The Cunard White Star fleet last week took aboard a new commodore, 60-year-old Robert B. Irving, captain of the Queen Mary. A Scotsman, Commodore Irving went to sea as a boy, first on a training ship,

The Herald stated today that Mrs. F. Haven Clark, mother of Anne Lindsay Clark, fiance of John Roosevelt, said that her daughter and the President's youngest son would be married in Nahant on June 18.

The American Federation of Musicians will control the output of "canned music" in nearly 589 radio stations in the country under a new contract signed between the musicians on the one hand and the principal recording companies, the chain broadcasting companies and the independent affiliates on the other.
CRYSTALLIZATION of dealer opinion in favor of holding the New York automobile show in January rather than in the Fall as at present is revealed in a poll being conducted by Automotive Daily News.

The marriage of Mrs. Winifred Wood Clark, youngest daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Carter Wood of this city and Bible Hill, Claremont, N.. H., to Edward Riley of Lumberville, Bucks County, Pa., son of Mrs. Edward Smith Riley of Andover, Mass., and the late Mr. Riley, took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,200 Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, volunteered yesterday to appear before the Senate Commerce Committee to refute testimony given against her last Tuesday by Paul Scharrenberg of the International Seamen's Union.

Village trustees will conduct a public hearing at their chambers Monday evening for discussion of a new charter which would transform Peekskill into a city, the fifth in Westchester County, officials announced.
Five candidates today were nominated for the Scottish Universities seat in the House of Commons vacated by the death of J. Ramsay MacDonald.
New York bankers were urged tonight by Senator Wagner to "discharge their responsibility to the nation" by helping to finance residential construction.

THE Roosevelt administration shows signs, the newspapers note, of turning to the recovery ideas of Dr. Oliver M. W. Sprague. The President, the other day, quoted an economist as having said, "Recovery depends far more on business pricing policies than on anything that may or may not be done at Washington," and it was Dr. Sprague who said it.

Representatives from eight foreign countries including China and Japan are among the lay and staff members preparing for the annual conference of the foreign division of the national board of the Y. W. C. A. in New Haven, Conn., on Thursday.
E. L. Davis, president of the Hupmobile Illinois Company of Chicago, has been elected a director of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation. The resignation of Arthur S. Dewing has been accepted.

THIS novel, first issued by the Jewish Publication Society for its members, was chosen for the Edwin Wolf Award as the best novel of Jewish interest. Its appearance here in a trade edition affords ample evidence that its interest is by no means exclusively Jewish.
Morris R. Cohen, retiring Professor of Philosophy at City College, said last night that because the proportion of non-Jews at the college was becoming negligible the college was in real danger.

Although it is not offered as yet as standard or optional equipment, the sliding top roof, here pictured, may be obtained by the individual owner. The Sunair Auto Top Company, operating under the patents of the Metropolitan Sliding Roof Company of London, has made installation here on many makes of cars. The smooth,

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City cannot "for a moment" defend himself from the "barrage of protest against his tyrannical acts, and the protagonists of the right of free assemblage will soon get a victory," Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the organization at 147 West Forty-third Street.

Columbia University will open its Spring session on Wednesday with an enrollment of more than 17,500 students, it was announced yesterday. Edward J. Grant, registrar of the university, disclosed that the total number for the academic year 1937-38, including the last Summer session, would be approximately 32.24 students.
The New York City Association of Teachers of English will hold its annual all-day meeting and luncheon next Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Four section meetings are to be held in the morning.

Army made a clean sweep of five varsity athletic contests here today, the poloists setting the pace with a 10-to-5 conquest of Yale. The Cadet swimmers overwhelmed Colgate, 54 to 31, the boxers shut out Virginia Poly. 9 to 0,

This is a tale of Governor Frank Murphy's shirt. It was the Governor's best full dress shirt that he was to have worn to the President's birthday ball here this evening. Early this week the shirt was sent to the Crawford Laundry, on East Jefferson Avenue, with instructions that it be nicely laundered and delivered not later than Friday-that it was going to the big party Saturday evening.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the Bronx Tigers, 6-1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight and gained 2 points on the league-leading Hershey Bears. Carl Gamble was the leading scorer for Atlantic City with a pair of goals.

THE great majority of authors of recent books on photography do not know how to write simple. correct English. Only a few of them know exactly the ground they want to cover and stick to that territory.
The Sagamore hotel, which has been valued at $4,000,000 was sold today in foreclosure for $50,000, ending a five-year effort for financial reorganization of the property.

Convinced that educational horizons still are untouched by radio, the New York City school system is planning to embark upon an extensive program of classroom broadcasting. Starting March 1, daily broadcasts will take place.

Pennsylvania's varsity track team opened its season today by gaining an easy victory over the Collegiate Track and Field Club of Swarthmore on the Franklin Field boards. Only first places counted, the Red and Blue taking eight of the nine.

The unification of railroads into what the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen had hoped would be a new Eastern trunk line was completed yesterday, although in circumstances which the two brothers could not have anticipated in their, lifetime.

Apprentice training, in which the Women's Bond Club did pioneer service, continues to engage the interest of women's organizations, especially those working to classify vocational and avocational opportunities for women.

Warned that "something might happen," Boston police posted a strong guard around two Japanese ships arriving here today and squelched an attempt by Chinese seamen to fight Japanese sailors without weapons on a wharf.

-Nearly 100 children, many of them in wheel chairs, crowded around a banquet table tonight and lustily sang "Happy Birthday" in the village where President Roosevelt started many years ago his organized fight to aid victims of infantile paralysis.

Appointment by the American Bar Association of a committee on Pacific Settlement of International Disputes and Current Development of International Law was announced yesterday with the issuance of the American Bar Association Directory. The new committees in the section of International Law.

AGAIN public attention is being directed to the hazard on the highways of "old crocks" and "ancient jolopies"-vehicles of remote vintage which have outlived their period of safe operation and have earned retirement. Current campaigns to "junk the junlkers" emphasize the menace of these machines not only to their occupants but to other users of the roed.
Yale won its first basketball game of the season after six defeats tonight by upsetting a previously unbeaten Army five, 31-25. The Cadets came here with a record of seven straight victories.

EPPINGER-HECHT--Mrs. Joseph Hecht announces engagement of her daughter, Josephine. to Mr. Eugene Eppinger, son of Mrs. Max Eppinger. GOLDSMITH-FRIEDMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Moses Friedman, Arverne, L. I.. announce the engagement of their daughter, Rosa Lillian, to Herman Goldsmith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Goldsmith, Ozone Park.
The charitable and civic work carried on by the Ladies of Charity will be aided by a supper and bridge party to be held on Feb. 10 at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Miss Barbara Beard, daughter of Mrs. Walter Kozak of Flushing, Queens, and of E. Leonard Beard Jr. of New York and Palm Beach, was married here yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Therit Rankin Towles 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Therit Rankin Towles 2d of Forest Hills, Queens.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward McBrien of 63-50 Eighty-third Place, Elmhurst, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor McBrien, to William Kollman, son of-Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kollman of Richmond Hill, Queens.

Fourteen Unionist Members of Parliament and all but one Cabinet officer won unopposed nominations today for the Feb. 9 election, called to obtain an expression from the electorate on the government's stand against union with Ireland [the former Irish Free State.

The Census Bureau reported today that factory production of fats and oils, exclusive of refined oils and derivatives, during the quarter ended on Dec. 31, totaled 1,752,134,953 pounds, compared with 1,066,278,286 pounds for the quarter ended on Sept. 30.

IN celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of John Singleton Copley, America's foremost painter of the Colonial period, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts will open on Tuesday an exhibition of oils, pastels, drawings and miniatures by the Boston artist.

Harvey S. Hincks, 47, head of the Speech and Dramatics Department of Western State Teachers College, died today of burns suffered Thursday when flames from an open grate ignited a rubbing solution which he had applied to his body.

ALTHOUGH it was officially announced months ago that the New York World's Fair of 1939 would not include a fine arts building, American artists have displayed an increasingly acute unwillingness to accept the verdict.

A campaign to take 14,000 ablebodied veterans from the public relief rolls and find jobs for them in private industry was started yesterday by the Veterans Employment Regional Board, of which Municipal Court Justice John M. Lewis is chairman.

IT was a happy thought of Helen Simpson's to stage her fictional Irish comedy in New South Wales; or, alternately, to choose that period in Australian history when New South Wales had a genial Irishman for Governor.

The National Arts Club will sponsor a series of open houses this season at the studios of some of its artist life members. The first will be held next Sunday afternoon when a group will visit the studios of Alpheus P. Cole, George J. Lober and Bessie Potter Vonnoh at 33 West Sixty-seventh Street.

President F. H. Arosemena dedicated today the newly completed stadium in which will be held the Olympic Games for Central America and Caribbean countries, which open Feb. 5. The stadium has seats for 22,000 spectators. There is a field for baseball and other field events.

An elderly Chicagoan told a jury before Justice William Van Devanter in Federal Court yesterday how he was swindled of $150,000 and a Portland, Ore., architect told of being cheated of $12,000. They pointed accusing fingers at two of the five defendants in the GrahamMcKay Reno mail fraud trial.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. John Loring Robbins of Great Barrington, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Robbins, to John Anthony Remick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Anthony Remick Jr. of Weston, Mass.

IT may be a good many years before some of the predictions for an automotive age made safe by unseen electrical controls, given over the air last week by Dr. Miller McClintock, director of the Harvard Bureau of Street Traffic Research,

Announcement was made yesterday that 293 diplomas or medals named in honor of Frank A. Rexford, former director of civics in the city school system, would be awarded during high school commencement exercises this week to as many young men and women students who have shown themselves "willing and responsible citizens in their school communities."

Lady Astor expressed herself today as "heartily in favor" of President Roosevelt's proposals to strengthen this nation's defenses, adding that "that is the only road to peace." Here for a visit with friends, Lady Astor said in an interview:

King Carol gave assurance today that Rumania is "clinging to her old friends although the country is trying to make new ones." In addition the King declared that Jews need have no fears of violence in Rumania.

Designed to give industry greater trade-mark protection and to eliminate the numerous proposals for mandatory State registration of marks, the new bill introduced in the House of Representatives by Representative Fritz G. Lanham of Texas last week drew approval from a number of national advertisers and is expected to receive labor's support.

Don Budge, world's No. 1 amateur tennis star, proved conclusively today that his exhibition match defeats were no sign of a slump when he routed Jack Bromwich, 19-yearold Australian Davis Cupper, 6-4, 6-2, 6-1, to add the Australian lawn tennis title to his American and Wimbledon crowns.

ABRAMS-Isaac, dearly beloved husband of Henriettta Jacobson, brother of Rebecca Goldberg, Ray Freeman. the late Charles Abrams and Carric Meyer. Services Monday, 2 P. M., 187 South Oxford St., Brooklyn. ALEXANDER-At East Orange, N. J.. on Saturday, Jan. 29, 1938, Howard T., husband of Clara Armstrong Alexander. Funeral services at the convenience of the family.

Miss Margaret Ruth Adams, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Perry of Exeter and the late Mason Tyler Adams of Waterbury, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Dr. William L. Peltz of Albany, N. Y., in the PhillipsExeter Academy Chapel.
The incalculably vast damage done to Shanghai's industries by the war is being systematically increased every day.

THERE is, undeniably, a reasonably wide school which worships ballroom dancers above all other baskers in the night club sun. Ordinarily this department may not be included in the category because of the standardization and irksome traits which bespoil the efforts of too many of such duos. In more than a word:

WHILE the trade average for the country last week may have eased slightly in the aggregate, sales volume on the whole continued highly encouraging. Retailers had expected rather sharp losses once the holiday season was turned and, instead, they have managed to keep fairly even with last year. The South sent in the best reports, but figures for the Ohio Valley showed up well because of comparison with the flood period a year ago.

Reports from Athens by circuitous routes indicate that tension still prevails in Greece despite all official denials. Proof is found in the fact that the Athens police forbade the family of the late Premier George Kondylis to gather in the cemetery on the second anniversary of his death.
Emmitt T. Lee, Saratoga County bus line operator, manufacturer and real estate dealer, died in an Albany hospital Thursday night after a throat operation. His age was 65.

Professor Floyd Fiske Decker of Syracuse University and Mrs. Decker have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Carol Decker, to Burton Benjamin Corwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Corwin of Brooklyn and Aquebogue, L. I.

Senator Wagner said today he was willing to consider changes in the National Labor Relations Act, which he sponsored. At the same time he defended the Labor Board, which Senator Burke of Nebraska has suggested should be investigated for alleged biased administration.
Girl store workers are about to get their owr New Deal, when minimum wage rates go into effect in Utah, Feb. 1, and in the District of Columbia, Feb. 14, the Labor Department said today.

Fordham resumed its basketball schedule with an impressive 52-31 victory over Cathedral College in the Rose Hill Gymnasium last night. With Bobby Hassmiller, Jack Welch and Ed Kamen showing the way, the Rams ran up a 31-19 lead at half-time,

Without having obtained any assurances from Bucharest, Joseph F. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, today urged Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary and Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, not to grant urgent treatment to petitions from the World Jewish Congress and three other Jewish organizations against Rumania for her anti-Semitic program.

Wearing the gown, slightly remodeled, which had been made for Martha Washington for the first Inaugural Ball, Miss Florence Day Whiting was married here this afternoon to Lieutenant John J. Hyland, U. S. N., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Butler Whiting.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 28 unless specified: At Kingston: Fanning. Philadelphia. At San Diego: Kalmia, Jan. 29; Hovey, Richmond. Acushnet, Washington Yard to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, via. Quantico, Helm. at Hampton Roads.

IT is easy to see that the emphasis in Spring dresses is still on the figure-revealing silhouette. The best of the New York designers mold their lines to the waist. Sometimes they still insist on the deep corselet or the high-low waist, if you will;

Within the Arctic Circle lies Kirovsk, named after S. M. Kirov, who first thought of creating it. And he created it because of apatite, a beautiful, vari-colored phosphate of lime from which phosphate fertilizer and industrial phosphoric acid can be obtained.

Militaery display supplanted society pageantry of previous years at the President's Birthday Ball held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The ball was perhaps the largest and most brilliant of more than 15,000 birthday gatherings held throughout the nation, to enlist public support for the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Mrs. Helen Wing Graves of 275 Clinton Avenue, wife of Arthur H. Graves, curator of public instruction of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, after an operation for appendicitis.

The sun is a celestial machine-gun which sprays it s surroundings with electron-bullets. When spots appear on the solar surface-each spot a cyclone so huge that the earth could be hypothetically dropped within it without' touching the sides-the hail of electrons is more furious.

The magnificent flight of Italian military planes to South America this week was the most recent and most spectacular chapter in an intensive campaign of intelligent, well-managed propaganda which in recent months has greatly enhanced Italy's prestige throughout Latin America.

WE hear so much in these troubled times of the weakness or even the supposed non-existence of international law that it may be well to take stock. Most laymen expect either too much or too little of international law and when they see the world in discord become discouraged or cynical.

Governmental assistance, either Federal or State, to stimulate the mortgage market and encourage building is suggested by Robert H Armstrong, president of the Manhattan Chapter of the National ssociation of Real Estate Boards.

Meats continue to drop in price. Although weekly reductions have amounted to only a penny or two on various cuts, meat cost since the first of the year shows a considerable total decrease. The reductions have come about since the muchheralded sharp price drop in November and December.

COSTUME Jewelry has once again come into its own. The great popularity of the simple dark frock, with its high round neckline or little band collar, has a lot to do with this renewed vogue. Plain black,
Senate and House conferees on the farm bill said today that they had agreed to limit large benefit payments and to increase the size of checks to small farmers.

A movement for reduction in the number of college freshman admissions at Yale is expected in the near future, although no formal action has been reported in that direction. Some faculty members have expressed themselves as strongly in favor of the move.
Thomas F. Meehan, Catholic historian and editor, was the recipient of a medal last night, though poor health prevented him from attending the dinner at which the award was made.

The engagement of Miss Linda Marion Wyckoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rapelye Wyckoff of this place, to Houston Hutchinson Wasson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Washington Wasson of Nashville, Tenn., has been announced by her parents.

Resident representatives of American steamship companies serving Puerto Rico have no authority to accept Governor Blanton Winship's proposal to submit to arbitration the waterfront controversy, they advised him this afternoon.

A card party for the benefit of the Morningside Center of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will take place Tuesday afternoon at the headquarters of the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street.

The Dearborn Pioneers Club, composed of sixty-five business and professional men in the suburb where the Ford Motor Company is situated, announced today that it planned a country-wide circulation of petitions to President Roosevelt protesting what it termed "unwarranted and unrestrained attacks" on Henry Ford.

The Japanese economic picture, which in the face of a costly undeclared war against China, the financing of huge military and naval programs in the home land and other handicaps incident to war, was, all things considered,

The food store, the first cooperative unit opened at the Greenbelt, Md. project of the Resettlement Administration by the Consumer Distribution Corporation, is having weekly sales of about $1,500, it was reported yesterday by Herbert E. Evans, vice president of the corporation.

The state of public security in Palestine daily becomes more aggravated. Neither the military courts nor British experts from India have yet succeeded in improving the situation. Shooting, bomb-throwing, ambushing and terrorism in all forms continue throughout the country.

Eight airplane engine manufacturing companies were showing their wares with airplane makers at the International Air Show here today. Types ranged from a small fiftyhorsepower Menasco engine recently introduced for the light plane trade,

Spurred by President Roosevelt's message urging increased national defenses and legislation to equalize the burdens during war time, proponents of the Connally bill began a drive today for the measure to take war profits through high individual and corporation surtaxes, and thereby furnish revenue for a "pay as you fight" program.
The intense interest in the United States naval program shown here in the past week underlines British worry over the state of the world and her own defenses.

Three competitions featured the closing 'day's activities of the Hamilton College Winter carnival today as Chi Psi and Delta Upsilon fraternities and George E. Bonney of Watertown were declared winners.
King Zog will inform the Albanian Parliament at a special session Monday that he plans to give his country a Queen of American blood by taking Countess Geraldine Apponyi as his wife.

VARIOUS letters have accumutated in the past week. Special interest is manifested in the Coffee bill for a Bureau of Fine Arts, the subject of unfavorable comment in these columns last Sunday. Roy Harris,
Insurgent headquarters today announced that hundreds of Government soldiers had been mowed down in machine-gun fire that met them in two assaults on Celadas, in the mountains north of Teruel.

Mrs. Constance Spry, called England's leading flower decorator, who is now in this country giving a series of lectures on how the English are developing flower art, held some 600 flower-arrangement amateurs entranced while she told them in a lecture last week what their distant cousins are- doing in this comparatively new field.

The New College girls' basketball team defeated Rider, 42-21, for its third victory in as many starts in Thompson Gymnasium yesterday. With Miss Hildegarde Gross turning in 23 points, New led all the way and had a 25-15 edge at the half.

The Livingston-Piper bill authorizing the establishment of life insurance departments in savings banks and three proposed constitutional amendments for a State slum-clearance and low-cost housing program were approved in a statement issued yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union.

Contending that happy, robust teachers tend to develop cheerful, healthy pupils, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional and affairs committee, yesterday pleaded for increased social and recreational facilities for teachers in the city school system.

A brisk demand for homes due to an influx of several large industrial concerns, with a consequent increase in population, is being experienced in Linden, N. J., reports Benjamin Friedman, realty builder and broker of that town.
IT is common knowledge that philosophers disagree, but this fact has always annoyed others more than it has troubled the philosophers themselves.

The Bermuda Biological Station's motor yacht Culver, which is to supplement the work of the Wood's Hole Oceanographic Institute's yacht Atlantis in measuring the Gulf Stream to enable more accurate forecasts of United States Midwest droughts and variations in the European fisheries, has been delayed in England.
A dollar a mouse, 40,000 of them, was the Rockefeller Foundation's latest contribution today toward man's fight against cancer.

The marriage of Miss Isabel Christine Conwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Conwell of this place and Milton, Del., to George Byrd Harrison, son of Mrs. Emma Shelton Harrison of Brandon, on the James River, and the late Burleigh Carter Harrison, took place here today in the First Presbyterian Church.

STRONG MAN OF CHINA. By Robert Berkov. 12mo. Boston, Mass.: Houghton Mifflin Company. $3. A biography of Chiang Kai-shek. THE CHALLENGE OF BURMA. By Alice Towne Eveleth. 12mo. New York: Fleming H. Revell Company. $2.
WASHINGTON. - Japan's exports grew remarkably last yearespecially when one considers that much of the nation's productive plant was given over to the equipment of her army for the war in China.

Small business needs to join in an organized frontal attack on the problem of finding adequate lending agencies for financing the capital requirements of small-scale enterprise, Charles E. Kuhn, business consultant, with offices at 40 Exchange Place, asserted yesterday.

With an attack on the Earle Administration as "wasteful and bureaucratic," Judge Arthur H. James of the Pennsylvania Superior Court today formally announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Three of the fifteen competitors in the women's championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club were tied for first place with scores of 3-0 each after the conclusion of the third round yesterday.
Miss Ethel Clayton Huntof this city, only daughter of Mrs. Henry Jackson Hunt and the late Colonel Henry Jackson Hunt, U.S.A., was married today to Oskar Held at St. Peter's Pro-Cathedral.

The Pennsylvania estate of Mrs. Henry M. Justi at Ardmore has been sold through McMuIIin MoMullin, Philadelphia brokers, according to Previews, Inc. The name of the buyer was not revealed. The English Colonial stone house contains eighteen rooms.

The Long Island University basketball team came from behind to defeat St. Francis College in its first intra-city contest of the season last night, 44 to 34, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

COURTNEY JOHNSON, general sales manager, Nash Motors, Detroit, announced last week the promotion of R. H. Israel, head of the New York organization, to Eastern sales manager of the parent company. In addition to his enlarged responsibilities as Eastern sales manager, Mr. Israel will continue as president and director of Nash Motors Company of New York, Inc.

The color preferences of insects will be used in the future to keep those great enemies of man under control. That was the prediction this week by J. K. Ellsworth, a University of California scientist.

Russell Hardy, special assistant to Attorney General Cummings, was shot in the hip tonight by a man who had asked him for money. He was taken to the Alexandria Hospital, where attendants said his condition was good.
TWO completely independent influences have contributed to the developing importance of stage direction in the opera house today. One has made for dramatic truth and the other for a visual truth.
Mrs. shley T. Cole heads the executive committee for the annual Mi-Careme luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit seminaries, which will take place March 14 at the Ambassador.

Germain G. Glidden of the Harvard Club, national champion, was successful yesterday in reaching the semi-final round of the invitation squash racquets tournament at the Union Club, but not until he had been hard pressed by both his opponents.
Gus Mancuso, catcher for the New York Giants, said tonight he was a holdout and would "hold the fort" against the pay cut in a 1938 contract which he returned to the Giant offices, unsigned.
IN THE TIMES of Jan. 2, Antoinette Perry's article, "Talent in the Wings," discussed the most exciting activity now taking place, the movement to find new talent in the theatre and to keep it there.
The opening guns of the Spring collections were fired by Luceber, who showed a straight silhouette, short skirts, many two-piece frocks with jumpertype tops and often capes of the same length.

Lyolene has designed a charming collection for girls. High waists and fitted hips discreetly emphasize the modern athletic figure with its young curves. Demure decolletes with frilly lace and ribbon trimmings in tender blues accented with white or red outmode the daring lines or colors.

The jinx that has pursued Donna Fox on Garmisch's famous bob-sled run put the American four-man team out of the world title competition today and the New York leader and one of his team-mates in the hospital with injuries.

After twenty-two days of starvation the Very Rev. Israel Harding Noe, aged 47, yielded last week to high moral pressure and reluctantly drank the juice and ate the pulp of six oranges, then swallowed several ounces of water.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the Souvenir Issue Association, comprising philatelists interested in souvenir and miniature sheets, that every government which is a member of the Universal Postal Union is to be sent a "specification" which the association is hopeful will be accepted by all the governments as a guide, representative of the desires of followers of the hobby, in the preparation of such sheets in the future.
Colonel William Henry Clay Broughton, New York lawyer and Summer resident of Becket, died last night at House of Mercy Hospital here. He was 77 years old.

The American boat Ace, skippered by Adrian Iselin 2d and representing the Western Long Island Sound fleet, this afternoon took the first race of the twelfth international Star Class series for the Bacardi Cup with a time of 1 hour 9 minutes 50 seconds. Lawrence Bainbridge sailed as Iselin's crew.

T. J. Pendergast, head of the Kansas City Democratic organization, said today he still would endorse for re-election Senator Bennett Champ Clark, who favors the reappointment of Maurice M. Milligan as United States District Attorney for Western Missouri.
Japanese reports reaching Peiping declare that Chinese forces along the Tientsin-Pukow Railway front are actively preparing for an attack against the Japanese in this sector.
The Hatter rapped briskly on the table. "We are fortunate in having a full attendance today," he said.

Passage of the Nunan-Moffat resolution by the Assembly last week left the majority of women's groups, keyed up to a new campaign to press ratification of the Child Labor Amendment, in a somewhat dispirited mood for today's observance of Child Labor Day.

The relative part that the president, faculty and trustees of a college should have in the selection, promotion and dismissal of teachers will be discussed by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, at the sixth annual midwinter alumni reunion at Williams College Feb. 12-13.

Optimism concerning the prospects for European peace was expressed yesterday by Oskar Morgenstern, Professor of Political Economy at the University of Vienna and director of the Austrian Institute for Trade Cycle Research, in a statement made public by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The School Art League announced yesterday the winners of its semiannual scholarships and medals. The awards will be made tomorrow afternoon at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

FOR many years Mr. Parents has been assembling the greatest collection of books and other material relating to tobacco that has ever been brought together. It occurred to him that he could serve readers, librarians, collectors and research scholars by analyzing his information, organizing it, and then putting it into a form that could be available everywhere. Few who read about this publication will ever handle copies of it.

Assemblyman Phelps Phelps sent yesterday a telgram to Speaker Oswald D. Heck, calling upon him as chairman of the Rules Committee to report out his resolution urging Congress to pass the Vandenberg child labor amendment.

A GENTLEMAN of parts, and system on the whole rather mernorable ones, is Alan Mowbray who might sum himself up, if he was the type who takes page ads in "Variety"-as the man you remember in movies you would just as soon forget.

William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Germany, received the $100 cash award for the outstanding work of the year by a Southern author on a Southern subject at the annual authors' luncheon of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization held yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, disapproved today of the idea of a pact for international economic collaboration put forward on Thursday by Paul van Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium, in his report of findings in an economic survey.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the dismissal of five more patrolmen, bringing to 206 the number of patrolmen-discharged from the department since Mr. Valentine assumed office on Sent. 25. 1934.
PARIS.-Automobile exhausts are continuing their work of destruction to Paris trees, and it will cost the city park department 1,720,000 francs for replacement of dead or dying trees during 1938.

It is doubtful where any war game staged in peace time has attracted such worldwide interest as that which is to be held at Singapore early next month as a prelude to the official inauguration of the new naval base on Feb. 14.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, denied a report yesterday that he had "promoted" Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, from confidential inspector to the position of assistant to the president at an increase in salary.
Political stirring are being felt in all States of the Union, for this is a year in which 34 Senators, all 435 members of the House and 34 Governdrs are to be elected.

A shortage of students within the next decade threatens the academia position of many colleges and universities, Frank H. Bowles, director of Columbia University Admissions, declared in his annual report to Dr. Nichols Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

The right of James H. Tyson of Chicago to give his native village of Versailles $480,000 in new buildings was upheld yesterday by Circuit Judge Sam A. Donnelly. Mr. Tyson, co-founder of a drug company, set up a trust fund eight years ago to give the village a new school,

MEXICO, D. F.-Women of the South American lands are gradually moving ahead from a past of medieval romanticism toward the goal already achieved elsewhere. And two North American institutions-the cinema and the Y. W. C. A.-are playing a conspicuous part in this feminist development.

Preparation of a "Bibliography of Wholesaling," which would provide a centralized .index of all material available in support of the wholesaler and in refutation of propaganda based on the "elimination of the middleman" is planned by the Council of National Wholesale Associations, it was learned yesterday.

A Valentine Bermuda tea dance will be given Saturday in the Trianon Room and Lounge of the Ambassador under the auspices of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, which will receive the net proceeds. A committee of debutantes will appear as manikins in a showing of Bermuda fashions.

Eugene H. Paul, who was for forty-eight years connected with Kuhn, Loeb Co., died yesterday afternoon at the Methodist Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn of heart disease. He had been ill since last September. His age was 67.
Justice Department colleagues of Stanley Reed completed his silver service today at a farewell luncheon.

Facing the current business recession as a fact, but optimistic that the Spring season will see an upturn in consumer buying, more than 5,000 retailers from all sections of the country will attend the twenty-seventh annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which begins at the Motel Pennsylvania tomorrow night.

William Mooney Jr., 8 years old, walked leisurely into his home at 5,025 Broadway at 10:45 o'clock yesterday morning--completely unaware that detectives, a police emergency squad and platoons of patrolmen had been searching upper Manhattan for him all Friday afternoon and night and through the early morning hours.

The fastskating University of Montreal squad had too much experience for Yale today and chalked up its first victory of the season in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League to move out of the league cellar. The French collegians handed the visitors a 5-3 setback before a crowd of not more than 200 fans.

Blond Jimmy Hines, struggling with an unruly putter that cost him three strokes, charged home with another. 67 today for a total of 134 to lead' the field at the halfway mark in the $5,000 Oakland seventytwo-hole open golf tournament.

A Palestine exhibit at the New York World's Fair of 1939, for which, it is hoped, a fund of $250,000 will be raised among American Jews, has been under discussion by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair, and many men and women prominent in Jewish affairs in New York.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today the-appointment of William F. Penniman, assistant general manager of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation, as deputy governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System. He will assume his new duties on Feb. 1.
The Department of Printing at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, the only such division of collegiate rank in America, will celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding Feb. 11 and 12.

A nation-wide educational campaign designed to win the support of consumers to the side of independent retail grocers will be launched shortly by the National Retail Grocers Association and its affiliated State groups in all parts of the country, according to an announcement yesterday by association executives.

Two college presidents are to be inaugurated in Nashville this week at institutions which have pointed the direction of Southern educational progress for more than sixty years. On Friday Dr. Sidney Clarence Garrison will be installed as head of Peabody College and on Saturday Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael will become chancellor of Vanderbuilt University.

George Ghesquiere, taking Bob Gillette's place at right forward after twelve minutes of a basketball game between the Navy and Washington and Jefferson today, pulled the Annapolis team out of danger and contributed the lion's share to its victory by 40 to 34.

A new course in public health education, having for its primary purpose the training of professional workers in its technique, scope and methods, as well as its relation to the general problem, will be started at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology next week with the opening of the second semester.
Mrs. W. H. Harkness Jr., with a baby panda caught near the Tibetan border, sailed for Seattle today on the Empress of Russia. The rare, bear-like animal is destined for the Chicago Zoo.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Brundred Mitchell of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Lida Mitchell, to Ralph Eversz McKinnie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Renwick McKinnie of Evanston, Ill.

MAILAMM, the American Palestine Association, will give two concerts by contemporary Jewish composers, Feb. 19 and March 12, at Town Hall. The proceeds will be devoted to the organization's activities here and abroad.

A plane believed to have been carrying Gerard Vultee, aircraft designer, and his wife, was reported by watching ranchers to have crashed in flames in isolated Oak Creek Canyon country south of here today.

WITH many of the principal steamship lines resuming service to Shanghai, tourists once again are stopping off here for a visit before their ship continues on to European ports or to the Dutch East Indies.
EVOLUTIONS and uprisings are no new thing in Spain. For over a century government in Spain has been in hot water. And Spaniards have a tradition of civil strife-and industrial strife-of their own.

Miss Helene Loew, daughter of Mrs. Osmond L. Loew of this city, and the late Mr. Loew, was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, to Theodore Roosevelt Whitson, also of New York, and Johnson City, Tenn., son of Mrs. Seville Whitson and the late Mr. Whitson. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Geoffrey McComb.

The same united effort, on a national scale, which has practically conquered tuberculosis, smallpox, diphtheria and such dread diseases must now be directed against infantile paralysis and cancer, President Roosevelt said tonight in a radio broadcast commemorating his fiftysixth birthday, which falls tomorrow.
Hard work ahead, unselfish devotion to duty and a navy second to none were the first words given to the United States Fleet today by its new Commander in Chief, Admiral Claude C. Bloch.

Rear Admiral David F. Sellers, U.S.N., whose term as superintendent of the Naval Academy will end on Tuesday, and Mrs. Sellers were guests of honor at a tea dance given by the midshipmen in Memorial Hall this afternoon and at the ball in Dahlgren Hall this evening.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that two more oil transportation companies had signed contracts with the union, affecting 900 unlicensed seamen on ships of the Tidewater Oil Company and the Pennsylvania Shipping Company of Philadelphia.

When Justice Reed, formerly Solicitor General, takes his place on the bench of the Supreme Court of the United States on Monday that event may be considered to mark the end of an important epoch in the history of the highest tribunal and the beginning of a new period.
A business building in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn has been bought by the Consolidated Taxpayers Mutual Insurance Company for its ,home office.
National Socialism's conquest of Germany five years ago was foredoomed to affect the Reich's foreign policy no less profoundly than it did the internal structure.

The Stony Brook School quintet extended its winning streak to eleven yesterday when it downed Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn, 32 to 17, on the winners' court at Stony Brook, L. I. Stony Brook had a commanding advantage at the intermission, 15-5.

The first unemployment insurance checks in the State's history are due to go out this week, probably on Tuesday, it was indicated yesterday in Albany. More than 585,000 applications for payments have been received here and throughout the State.

After winning the Clarence Pell Cup open tournament, Robert Grant 3d, national amateur champion, returned to the court to aid New York in earning a 4-4 tie with Philadelphia yesterday in the annual intercity doubles racquets matches at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

The United Mine Workers of America, it is now expected, will try William Green, president of the A. F. of L., on charges of "treason" against the union on the last day of its current biennal convention nere, probably next Thursday-or Friday, unless Mr. Green should ask for an earlier hearing.

Sir Charles Batho, former Lord Mayor of London, who used to say he was inspired by passing Dick Whittington's milestone at Highgate daily on his way to school, died today at the age of 65. During his term of office in 1927 he entertained the King and, Queen of Afghanistan.

Two thousand persons gathered yesterday on the little plaza that marks the entrance to Fort Tryon Park from Fort Washington and Northern Avenues, to pay tribute to the late Mother Frances Xavier 'Cabrini, in whose honor the place has just been named Cabrini Circle.

THREE days before Christmas the Staatsoper after much travail brought forth a brand new "Carmen" designed to replace that ancient receptacle of moths and mildews which has done service in Vienna for decades and looked as if it came out of Noah's Ark.

A new relief crisis is ahead as a result of the growing unemployment which followed the recent decline in business activity. Possibly 3,000,000 persons who had jobs last August in private employment are now out of work.

Mayor La Guardia informed Pierce H. Power, vice president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce, in a letter made public yesterday that the city was trying to systematize the flow of Federal surplus foodstuffs distributed to relief recipients here.
J. A. Willey,. American consular agent at Matagalpa, has requested the Nicaragua Congress to conduct an investigation to prove that he did not insult the Nicaraguan flag at Matagalpa on July 4, 1912.

President Roosevelt's birthday was celebrated in various ways by Americans sojourning in overseas Territorial possessions, and funds were raised for the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. Appropriate parties were staged in many foreign countries as well by American residents.

Premier Benito Mussolini attended the marriage of another member of his family in the parish church of San Giuseppe today. The bride was his niece, 21-yearold Rosa Mussolini, daughter of the Premier's brother, Arnaldo, who died several years ago.

The Skating Club of New York's figure skating championship, with fourteen contenders in the singles competition, got under way at the club rink yesterday. The initial phase of the program was devoted entirely to school figures. The championship will close today with the free skating, second part of the test.

The 1937 American Daffodil Year Book of the American Horticultural Society, Washington, D. C., reports the popularity of largescale naturalized narcissus plantings. At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and at the New York Botanical Garden each Spring the public may view sheets of yellow and white bloom composed of as many as 10,000 bulbs of -a special variety.
Detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street station arrested five men yesterday, two of whom, seized during a hold-up at 611 Ninth Avenue, admitted they had planned a payroll robbery Tuesday.

Miss Elizabeth Gorham was married here this afternoon in Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church to Donald G. Austin of Cleveland. Bishop Cameron J. Davis and the Rev. William Thomas Heath officiated.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Harry West of Greenway, Guilford, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Wynne West, to Harold Braff, son of Mrs. A. Louis Braff of Montreal, Canada, and the late Mr. Braff.

Those who don't know when to shout "View halloo," or "Gone away," or when not to ride in front of the master or fox hounds, or whether to ride among the hounds, are likely candidates for a school here to instruct young hunters in the traditional manners of fox hunting.

Holding a 23-12 advantage at the intermission, the Savage quintet downed the Princeton Theological Seminary, 46 to 21, on the Savage court yesterday. John Cerrone led the attack for Savage with fourteen points. In a preliminary game,

Howard Townsend Alexander, son of the late James Alexander, one of the founders and vice president of the original Standard Oil Company, died today at Homeopathic Hospital here after a four-day illness. Mr. Alexander, who resided at 131 Harrison Street, was 70 years old.

The marriage of Miss Lillian May Herlin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adam Herlin of Floral Park, L. I., to James M. Campbell, son of Mrs. Madeline Campbell of Richmond Hill, Queens, took place yesterday morning in the rectory of the Catholic Church of St. Mary Gate of Heaven, Richmond Hill.

The Council of the League of Nations today appointed W. W. Riesler of Princeton University to a committee of seven experts to study measures for the prevention and mitigation of economic repressions. The other members include Sir Frederick Phillips of the British Treasury and M. J. Rueff of the French Finance Ministry.
Moscow is watching the present session of the League of Nations Council with what might be called hopeful skepticism.

IT is impossible to discuss the future of China without knowing what we mean by our designation of that vast racial and national entity. And the task is made difficult by the fact that China is swiftly changing,

Five years ago Charles W. Bryan, then Governor of Nebraska, was thought to be on his deathbed. Four years ago, in a contest for the Senatorial nomination, he suffered at the hands of his own party such a defeat that he was believed to have been retired permanently from State politics.

Mrs. Grace Linsley Quaintance, formerly of New York, died suddenly here today of a stroke at her residence, the Holmwood Inn. She was 70 years old. Mrs. Quaintance, who was the widow of William B. Quaintance of New York, had a Summer home in New London.

The nine members of the Minimum Wage Board for the Laundry Industry will be honored at a luncheon on Friday by the Women's Trade Union League. Miss Frieda Miller, director of the Division of Women in Industry of the State Department of Labor,
The Continental Grain Company is negotiating for the Farmers National Grain Corporation's lease of the Rock Island elevator it was learned today.

As negotiations for a British-Irish trade pact drag on and election- speeches in North Ireland revive the old animosities once more, the impression one gains in authoritative quarters in Dublin is that the prospects are not hopeful for an early economic agreement with the government at London.

Three seeded players were successful in second-round matches in the M. M. Sterling squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday. They were L. A. Strasser of the City Athletic Cl- b who is seeded No. 3; J. Larocque Jr. of the Harvard Club, No. I and A. H. Marckwald Jr., Shor Hills, No. 2.
A literary week-end for the appraisal of the importance of literature in contemporary life will be held at BucknellUniversity Feb. 10-13, with prominent figures in the literary world as speakers.

ADELOGE OF foreign countries' new postage stamps, a few of them unannounced in advance, reached New York during the past week. One of the unexpected arrivals is Guatemala's 1-centavo olive green "obligatory" stamp of 1927, now overprinted "CL Aniversario de la Constitucion EE. UU." and the dates 1787-1789 and 1937-1939, thus converting the original into a United States Sesquicentennial Constitution commemorative which supplements Guatemala's Constitution miniature sheet described in these columns on Jan. 16.

The Mercer County Teachers Union, Local 437, said by school authorities to embrace in its membership less than one-fifth of Trenton's 642 teachers, has adopted a resolution putting itself on record as, opposed to the "un-American anti-labor machinations of Mayor Frank Hague" of Jersey City and calling on Louis Marciante of Trenton, president of the New Jersey Federation of Labor, "to withdraw his support from, and repudiate the activity of, Mayor Hague."

The response of more than 5,000 men and women, ranging from teachers to electricians, who in the last year have traveled hundreds of miles for a few days of study and residence at the University of Minnesota's Continuation Center,

IT'S hard to believe that Philip Dunning has had no wares in the Broadway bazaar since "Remember the Day" in 1935-36, but that is how it is, and now he proposes to do something about it. The something is called "Schoolhouse on the Lot," by Joseph A. Fields and Jerry Chodorov,

ARMSTRONG, MARTHA T. (Dec. 20). Estate, less than $10.000. To Myra Armstrong, sister, executrix, 583 Riverside Dr.. residue. BASTERI, STEFANO (Nov. 2). Estate, less than $5,000. To Anna Basteri, widow, executrix 313 E. 60th St.

THE representatives of the legitimate theatre, believing that a more specific legal definition of the spoken drama may place it upon the preferred status as a cultural. institution, have come to the fountainhead of Federal tax legislation for aid to make their path a little smoother in the years to come.

William J. O'Shea Jr. of New York City was named chairman today of the New York State Bar Association's Committee on State legislation. Other committee chairmanships were announced by Joseph Rosch, newly elected association president, as follows: Morton G. Bogue,

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise during 1937, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those in 1936 and 1935. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported. Imports cover only those for consumption in this country. All comparative figures are in thousands of dollars.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of Centra Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, in his sermon yesterday envisioned "the possibility of each national group in America making a proclamation of its faith in democracy," "as a fairly complete formula for peaceful living despite the heritage of past hatreds."

The proposal to require that labor unions be incorporated was advocated and attacked yesterday at the National Republican Club in a debate between Samuel P. Gillman, on the side of industry, and Louis Waldman on the side of labor. Their speeches were broadcast on a nation-wide radio hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company.

Miss Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue closed yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden after scoring one of the most sensational hits on record at the famous arena. Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia witnessed the last performance, which again attracted 17,000 spectators.

Predicting that a striking increase in the volume of home building is inevitable this year, Patrick J. Callan, president of Callan Brothers, Great Neck (L. I.) builders, points out that 'the business recession existing at the close of last year home buyers in that it temporarily put a check on the rapid. rise of building costs experienced last Summer.

S. S. Miller, board chairman of the Mohawk Rubber Company, died today, just a week before a celebration which was to have marked his eighty-second birthday and the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Mohawk Company, which he helped to found.
Approval of Head Coach Dick Harlow's appointment of Lyal W. Clark of Baltimore as Harvard football line coach was announced tonight by William J. Bingham, athletic director.
Encouraged by the fact that more than half of last year's new construction funds in Westchester County went into housing, builders there are preparing to meet a growing demand for low-priced homes.
The stock market last week had its widest decline since the week ended on Nov. 20. THE NEW YORK TIMS index of fifty stocks was down 7.04 points on the week.
Nathan ,Straus, United. States Housing Administrator, will address a luncheon meeting of the Architectural League of New York on Thursday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

Dr. John H. Finley, speaking over station WEAF last night, praised the services of those who keep alive the memories of great men. He referred to New York University's Hall of Fame as "our Westminster Abbey";
EAVESDROPPING on the world at the Antipodes, S. C. Rosier, a listener at Perth, Australia, reports on reception of American stations as follows:
The unexplained radio silence of ships in the North Pacific "storm cradle" left a big blank space on the weather map today apd put forecasters in a quandary.
Jiu-jitsu, which in Japanese is called "shoodoo," tonight permitted Yotaro Sugimura, 53-year-old Japanese Ambassador to France, to throw a much younger and stronger opponent about at will.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Andrew Lauer of this place have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Vivien Frances Lauer, to Cadet George William Rhyne of Pass Christian, Miss., son of Mrs. Josephine Brandt Moore and the late William Clifton Rhyne.

KOTOR, Yugoslavia, is celebrating its Festival of St. Triphonius next Wednesday. Sponsored by possibly the world's oldest seamen's guild, the Bokeljska Mornarica, this annual fete honors the patron saint of Dalmatian sailors.
The appointment of Professor Emil Brunner of Zurich University, Switzerland, to the Charles Hodge Chair of Systematic Theology at Princeton Theological Seminary was announced here today.

BORN 1900, on outskirts of Dundalk, County Louth, Ireland. Father, a country schoolmaster who taught me until I was 14. At 14 I ceased to raise my skull cap to the local grocers and their wives and the other illiterate leaders of rural "society"
James R. Savery, Western Massachusetts industrialist, bank and insurance company director, died here today at the age of 71.

The grain markets here continued on the downgrade today, with wheat and corn selling at new low prices on the current movement. A forecast for rain or snow over the greater part of the Winter Wheat Belt, coupled with selling of futures

A record percentage of twin births was set by mothers in New York City during 1937, the Health Department announced yesterday with something pretty close to pride. Thomas J. Duffield, registrar. of records for the department, showed that. 992 sets of twins were included in the 101,988 live births recorded during the year.

The United Fruit liner Veragua today radioed she had rescued the captain and twenty-one members of the crew of the Norwegian freighter Newsome, aground off Courtown Keys, 225 miles northwest of Panama.

An exhibition opened today in the Sterling Library of Yale University in recognition of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg, Swedish theologian and mystic. Manuscrips and books evidence his wide range of interests and progressive scientific research.

The dollar continued to weaken yesterday in terms of foreign exchange and closed the week with substantial losses against all other important currency units except the French. The franc yesterday rose % point to 3.27 1/4 cents, but showed for the week a net loss of 4 3/4 points.

In a battle that went to the ninth and final bout for a decision the Stuyvesant H. S. swordsmen defeated Barringer H. S. from Newark, 5 to 4, last night to win the fifth annual New York university, high and preparatory school fencing tourney. The event, sponsored by Washington Square College, was held in the School of Education auditorium.
Troy Kinney, artist and author, died today in a hospital here after an emergency operation for an abdominal ailment. He was 66 years old.

Beset by excursions in policy and alarms in speech, the anxious business men of America-large and small-who must raise the national income to the President's $90,000,000,000 minimum, if it is to be raised, may comfort themselves by noting two events of the week just ended. These were the beginning of the actual drafting of the revised tax bill, and the revival of conferences looking to a fixed utility program.

More than fifty students from the departments of economics, psychology, literature, art and dramatics at Sarah Lawrence College are undertaking a joint study of housing in and about New York City and will report some of their findings to the Federal Housing Administration.

The text of President Roosevelt's birthday address tonight-was as follows: My Friends: My hear goes out in gratitude to the whole American people tonight, for we have found common cause in presenting a solid front against an insidious but deadly enemy, the scourge of infantile paralysis..

Retail sales records for the year to date have been favorable enough to encourage retailers to place com-mitments for Spring merchandise with greater confidence, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

IN the Eighteen-Eighties Henry W. Grady was eloquently hailing the New South and point ing the index finger of oratory toward the rosy picture of a future in which a multitude of good yeomen on small farms would create a new prosperity on the ruins of the Old South of slavery. But the New South did not arrive punctually at the command of the prophets.
Installation of a new radio beacon by the Lighthouse Service at Manana Island fog signal station, pear Monhegan Island, off the coast of Maine, was announced today by the Department of Commerce.

British scientists were shocked at the German Government's ban on Nature, internationally famous scientific weekly edited by Sir Richard Gregory. Sir Richard said today that he expected the ban would continue indefinitely.

AGAIN today occurs the anniversary of Nazi domination of Germany. Five years out of the thousland which Hitler has set as the minimum period of his party's supremacy have rolled away. Years replete with incident and sensation they have been-and swift.
A silver cup in which posset was served in England during the seventeenth century was sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries for $775.

Facetious persons refer to the new Illinois Legislative Council as the State Legislature's "own brain trust." The bill creating it was drafted and sponsored by Dr. T. V. Smith, Professor of Philosophy at the-University of Chicago and a State Senator.
Taking as their general theme, "Know Your College," about 100 alumnae will gather on the Mount Holyoke College campus March 4, 5 and 6 for the annual sessions of the Alumnae Council.

The number of automobile licensed in New York City for 1938 will exceed the total for last year by 40,000, it was estimated yesterday the by Charles A. Harnett, Commission- He er of Motor Vehicles. About 500,000 with cars were licensed in this city by Feb. 1 last year.
BRITAIN has long been trying to do away with slums ashore; now she is attacking the seagoing slums. In other words, the traditional fo'c'sle is destined to be swept into limbo.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today denounced Labor's Non-Partisan League as "nothing more than a C. I. O. agency, a ventriloquist's dummy for C. I. O. leaders." He recommended to the executive council that it order all federation affiliates to withdraw from the league,

Anti Semitism is being offered as a cureall for political and economic ills in many countries, but when put into effect it merely intensifies these and causes additional suffering among the general population, David J. Schweitzer, European vice chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, dedared here today.

Conditions in the money market here are now reverting more to normal after the disturbing influences of the yearend heavy currency demand and the increase in the fiduciary note issue which preceded it.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.1, which compared with 83.4 a week ago, 83.9 two weeks ago, 83.2 three weeks ago and 83.1 four weeks ago.

Miss Virginia Caroline Pearson, granddaughter of Mrs. Edgar Pearson of Plainfield, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to Herbert Daniel Ryan, son of Mrs. Daniel F. Ryan of Boston and the late Mr. Ryan, which will take place Feb. 12 in St. Alphonsus

The City continues to flounder hopelessly in attempts to assess the value of President Roosevelt's attitude toward business interests in the United States. It is, indeed, abandoning the task in despair.

Although the markets just before the close of the fifth year of the Hitler administration remained inert and weak?sh, confidence undoubtedly prevails in business circles that the production boom will continue unabated throughout the Nazis' sixth year. To the continuation of this boom the Nazi government,

Master Sergeant Otto P. Mayr, who served as a major during the World War with the Ninth Infantry, Second Division, will retire from the army today after nearly thirty years of service. He holds the Croix de Guerre for heroio conduct in the Meuse-Argonne.

A play-off became necessary in the New Jersey Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association when the Montclair A. C., defending champion, conquered the Englewood F. C. by 4--1 today. Montclair and Englewood are tied with four victories and one defeat each.

Senator Logan, Democrat of Kentucky, said tonight that he was not a candidate for appointment to the Sixth United States Circuit Court bench. There has been speculation in Congressional circles that a Senatorial primary contest between Majority Leader Barkley and Governor Chandler might be avoided if President Roosevelt were to name Mr. Logan to the Circuit Court vacancy.
Tire prices listed in the Spring and Summer catalogue of Sears, Roebuck Co. are about the same as those given in the Fall and Winter book, or are a little higher, it was disclosed today.

The Central No. 1 team scored a 5-to-0 triumph over the New York Badminton Club in a men's Class A contest that featured the matches staged by the Metropolitan Badminton Association over the weekend. Paul Vansco and Frank Hinds both won in singles and doubles.

Former Governor Alf. M. Landon of Kansas will be one of the speakers at the United Methodist Council to be held Thursday, Friday and Saturday in Chicago, it was announced yesterday at the Methodist Book Concern building, 150 Fifth Avenue.

A four-State convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, a Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate, today advocated early settlement of differences between the American Federation of Labor and the C. I. O.

Just so there will be no mistake about it in years to come, SpanishAmerican War veterans want Roosevelt Plaza here renamed. In a petition to the Common Council, the Joint Buffalo City Board of the United Spanish War Veterans has asked that it be redesignated "Theodore Roosevelt Plaza."

Industrial activity in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve District declined further in December and continued in early January "at the lowest level since 1935," according to the monthly business review of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank.

Dr. Edward Hill Baldwin, former member of the State Board of Medical Examiners, died at his residence, 25 Osborne Terrace, this morning C of a heart ailment following a brief illness. He was 66 years old. Dr. Baldwin, whose offices were at 83 Lincoln Park, was an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist in this city for forty years.

Memorial services for Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, who died Christmas Day, were held tonight at Severance Hall. Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick of New York, who, during the war, was chairman of the Commission on Training Camps for the War Department and a daily companion of Mr. Baker, in his address called him "a great lawyer,
Mrs. C. Alan Hudson Jr. of New York was among the luncheon guests of Miss Barbara Clute of Watkins Glen, N. Y., who entertained at the Bath Club.

Little interest is being shown in the oats, rye and soy bean markets, and prices declined last week in sympathy with other grains. Oats futures closed here yesterday at net losses of 3/4 to 7/8 cent for the week, with the May position at 31 1/8cents a bushel, the July at 29 1/8 and the September at 29.

Two of Bill Terry's ball players-Gus Mancuso and Joe Moore-said today the New York Giants' front office sadly underestimated their baseball abilities when they were mailed 1938 contracts. Mancuso, catcher, said flatly he would hold out before he would accept the cut in salary offered, and Outfielder Moore said he was offered the same figure as in 1937, which was extremely distasteful.

The outlook for European industry is considered doubtful, and comments here on the situation in the United States are frankly unfavorable. A bad impression was created by the complaint of the Dutch-German A. K. U. Corporation of a decline in demand.

Pushing over a goal in the last five minutes, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the league-leading Hershey Bears, 3 to 2, tonight in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game that had approximately 3,000 fans on edge.

A message of greeting and sympathy to the members of the Spanish Cortes, which will meet at Barcelona Tuesday, signed by twenty-six United States Senators and thirtyfour - Representatives, was made public today by the Spanish Embassy.

Fire, following an explosion, swept one of Martha Vineyard's largest department stores tonight and threatened this village's business district before it was brought under control. Merchants estimated the damage might reach $50,000. State Trooper George Baker discovered the fire after hearing the explosion. Another blast was heard as firemen fought the blaze. The business district of the Summer resort was rebuilt after a fire fifty years ago.
Three years ago, when he vetoed the Soldiers Bonus Bill-only to have it adopted over his veto a year laterPresident Roosevelt made this prediction:

HERE, at long last, is a book with the air of authentic greatness-Gunnar Gunnarsson's "Ships in the Sky."* It is a difficult book to describe in cold print, because nearly anything that may be written about it is likely to make it appear painfully sentimental. The book itself is not in the least sentimental.

Maison Jeurelle-Seventeen, Inc., International Building, Rockefeller Center, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop certain advertising representations concerning its products which the commission held to be false or misleading, the commission announced today. In general,

Fascism and communism, and a particularly Chancellor Adolf Hitler's National Socialist regime in Germany, were attacked last night at a mass meeting at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the non-sectarian anti-Nazi League. The meeting was called in "protest against five years of Hitler terror."

How the WPA has aided New Yorkers of all ages in their quest for recreation was indicated in a report made public yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator. Recreation projects conducted by the WPA in cooperation with city departments and social agencies have enlisted more than 10,000,000 participants in the last six months, the report showed.

Weary of "the modern canon of personal convenience, which ultimately leads to chaos and personal despair," discouraged by the wars, tyrannies and revolutions that are tearing the world to pieces, the human race today is acknowledging a growing conviction that world unity can be achieved only in God, and is, therefore, slowly beginning to recognize the primacy of the spiritual, the Rev. Edward M.

Mrs. Hilda Drexel Laird, wife of Dr. Donald A. Laird of Colgate University and his "silent partner" for twenty-one years in psychological studies, died last night at her home here. She was in her fortythird year.

The prevailing opinion of business men seems to be that the recession will pass through its low point in the first quarter of 1938, and possibly already is doing so, the National City Bank of New York comments in its monthly bulletin, to be published today.

Sigrid Onegin, the eminent contralto, gave a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon at which she was welcomed with the intense enthusiasm invariably accorded her whenever she brings her artistry to attention on the local concert stage.

Gus Phillips, locomotive engineer, called up his friend, King Boris of Bulgaria, today, extended birthday greetings and gladly paid a $31 toll charge for a conversation interrupted occasionally by 5-yearold Princess Maria Louisa chiming in with "hellos."

A letter telling of the blessing of the first Catholic church built on the Island of Bali, which has 10,000 temples for pagan worship, was received a few days ago by Mgr. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, with headquarters at 109 East Thirty-eighth Street.

" Christianity cannot cease to trouble the conscience of the world as long as war, conditions of poverty and repressed labor continue to exist," declared Donald Herd in an address yesterday at a youth service in the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street 'near Central Park West. Mr. Herd,

Ten employers in the building trades will be taken in custody in Brooklyn today on charges of violating the Workmen's Compensation Law, it was announced last night by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan.

There is need today of a spiritual rebirth and rejuvenation, the Rev. Dr. Edgar De Witt Jones, pastor of the Central Woodward Christian Church, Detroit, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Central Church of the Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street. Dr.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair Athletic Club, national champion, won the New Jersey squash tennis championship for the eighth time at the Short Hills Club today. He defeated Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club, third seeded player, in the final, 15-3, 17-14, 18-13.

Centre St, 114, 23.9x75: trustees of wills of Daniel and Newbold Edgar to City of New York; consideration $29,000. Franklin St. n w cor of Baxter St. 70.2x25: Central Savings Bank to City of New York; consideration $27,500. Rivington St, s w cor of Mangin St, 24.1x 75; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Abraham, Paul and Murray M. Bisgaler, 6 Columbia St ($2).

As noted in an article in yesterday's TIMES, the conditions of farm life in this State are being rapidly improved through the centralization of rural schools. There were a few consolidated districts twenty years or more ago, but great advance has been made under an amendment to the education law of twelve years ago.

The Washington Redskins scoredtwo touchdowns in the first period and coasted to a 17-to-10 victory today over a group of college and pro all-star football players. Some 4,500 tans saw Cliff Battles, behind perfect blocking, race 74 yards returning a punt for one touchdown and watched Sammy Baugh flip a 30-yard pass to Riley Smith, advancing the ball to the 1-yard line.
Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday preliminary plans for a new six-lane transverse road through Central Park at Ninetysixth Street.

Manufacturers of American aircraft can turn out more than twice the volume of their present record peace-time production of planes, engines and accessories without expanding existing plant facilities, Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., announced yesterday. At the same time, Mr.

The error of a narrator translating Hebrew poetic passages into prose for the Old Testament is responsible for the story of the stopping of the sun in the heavens as told in the Book of Joshua, the Rev. Lucius A. Edelblute said
Nine miners were killed today by an underground fire in Dumbreck Colliery, two miles from Kilsyth, while their wives prayed for their safety at the pithead.

John Raimone, 28 years old, of 364 East 123d Street, a helper, was crushed to death about 3 o'clock yesterday morning when he was pinned under a truck overturned in a collision at Eighty-first Street and Lexington Avenue with an automobile, driven by Arthur Bancroft of 1,867 New York Avenue.

The prospect of legislation for a cheap form of savings bank life insurance is recognized in an excerpt from the annual report by Louis m H. Pink, State Superintendent of or Insurance, which will be received m by the Legislature today.

If the steamship companies agree to abide by the final decision of an arbitration board proposed by Governor Blanton Winship to end the longshore strike, labor leaders today decided unanimously to accept it also and so will notify Governor Winship officially tomorrow.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday the formation of eleven committees to launch a concerted attack on the problems of delinquency and maladjustment. These committees were appointed as a result of the suggestions in the recent maladjustment report submitted by the Board of Education and Board of Superintendents.

Ralph Pratt Hinchman of Litchfield, Conn., who retired in 1931 as senior member of Hinchman, Vezin Co., this city, representatives of hosiery manufacturers, died here yesterday, in the Post-Graduate Hospital after a brief illness following a major operation.

Last week's stock market lost ground further; at Friday's lowest, the averages had fallen 8 points from the previous week's closing and were below the final figure of December, though not lowest of the reaction.

The cost of stocks on hand at the end of December for 735 reporting wholesalers was $142,434,000, or 6 per cent higher than at the end of 1936, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today in its first monthly statistical report to include inventory estimates.

Rehabilitation of old tenements for families in the low-income group rather than the use of the city's credit for new housing as suggested a few days ago by Mayor L Guardia was urged yesterday by Frank M. McCurdy, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

Mrs. Martina Peterson, widow of the Rev. Dr. Daniel W. Peterson, who was pastor emeritus of Trinity Lutheran Church, Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, Queens, died at her home, 187-44 Eightyninth Avenue, Hollis, Queens, Saturday night. Her age was 81.

Although occasionally skidding off the base lines in the manner of ardent Dodgers bent upon doing something extraordinary, the baseball writers of New York successfully brought the 1938 "indoor" season to a close on a ringing high note last night at their fifteenth annual dinner and frolic.

Dividend Shares, Inc., an investment trust, of Jersey City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 16,505,041 shares of 25cent par capital stock to be sold at the market price for an aggregate sum of $20,478,651, the commission announced today.
