John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President, and Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, Boston and Nahant debutante, will be married on June 18.

Members of the Hospitals Committee of the New York Junior League and of the Women's Committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association will give a luncheon on Feb. 10 at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, in the interest of social hygiene.

Calling upon President Roosevelt to withdraw his recommendation for executive reorganization, Amos Pinchot charged in a letter made public yesterday that less than a year ago the President sought to set himself up as a dictator by this, very means.

Notice was served today by Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce now investigating railroad financing, that he is looking for "drastic and large-scale legislation" to cure the-ills of the nation's railroads.

Volume control of the movement of citrus fruit from the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas will become effective tomorrow as planned, it was announced here this afternoon following receipt of notice from Secretary of Agriculture Wallace that he had approved the proration order.

Although the round-up by 2,000 fast-moving detectives and patrolmen Saturday night apparently failed to bring in any prisoners connected with the recent crimes that provoked the raids, the police continued last night and early this morning to make wholesale arrests on corners, in poolrooms and in neighborhood "clubs."
Gathering and selling old iron is becoming a very profitable business in Nicaragua, especially in seaports, where piles of old iron are daily increasing, waiting shipment to Japan.
Lancias, Fords and their European models did well in the Monte Carlo overland automobile race, results announced today reveal.

A fall on the ice near his home at Wilton, Conn., late yesterday afternoon prevented Lawrence Tibbett from appearing in a concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Mr. Tibbett struck his forehead on a sharp stone when he fell, and the wound required seven stitches, according to his wife, who informed the management at the Opera House that Mr. Tibbett would be unable to appear.
Arthur E. Littman, Inc., 101 West Thirty-seventh Street, has been appointed to the local office of the women's ready-to-wear division of N. Snellenburg Company, Inc., Philadelphia.

Young couples who go from the marriage license bureau to the county welfare headquarters hereafter will get a cold eye and little more from the relief department. So will those who own automobiles and live on relief. The Wisconsin law makes the only qualification for relief the need of it.

The marriage of Princess Grucha Troubetzkoy, daughter of Prince and Princess Wiadimir Troubetzkoy of Paris, to Boris Tatischeff of this city took place yesterday afternoon in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Savior, 121st Street and Madison Avenue.

Count Anton Sigray, official leader of the Hungarian Legitimists, made this afternoon what purported to be sensational revelations of Nazi Putsch plans, including a march on Budapest. He said in a speech that the organization and agitation of Hungarian Nazis had made tremendous progress in recent weeks.

Retail trade sales in December were 8.3 per cent higher than in December, 1936, the increase comparing with 7.1 for November over November, 1936, and 4.4 similarly for October. The average was 7.7 per cent higher in the eleven months over 1936.

Miss Jean Petrie Fennell, daughter of Edward H. Fennell of this city and the late Mrs. Fennell, has completed plans for her marriage to Hugh Kendall Boice Jr., son of Mr. Boice of New York and Mrs. Dorothy Hay, on Feb. 9 at the home of her father here.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,070,968,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Judson Lawson of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Lawson, to John Leigh Westney, son of Mrs. William E. Westney of Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Mr. Westney.

Forrest A. Heath, one of three inventors of the silent automatic oil burner in 1924, died of a heart attack last night while driving his automobile in Upper Montclair. The car traveled about 200 yards off the road after he was stricken. A neighbor summoned Dr. Barton Kenny of Little Falls, who pronounced the driver dead. Mr. Heath was 63 years old.

The Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company has announced the creation of the office of treasurer, which for the present will be combined with that of senior vice president, now held by J. A. Bogardus. Walter J. Thompson has been made secretary, to succeed F. D. Denton upon his retirement on July 1, 1938.

One of the most remarkable performances in the annals of Eastern skiing was recorded today by stocky Dave Bradley, Dartmouth captain, as he triumphed in a formidable cross-country field in the Eastern Slope Ski Club's invitation meet.

The American yacht Gale, sailed by Harry G. Nye with Leeds Mitchell Jr. as crew, captured the Bacardi Cup today in the twelfth international Star Class regatta. Nye, representing the Southern Lake Michigan fleet,

A. Willing Patterson of the Philadelphia Racquet Club won the Union Club's second annual invitation squash racquets tournament for the Centennial Trophy by defeating Alvah W. Sulloway, Harvard University captain, 15-7, 1215, 15-7, 17-16 in the final yesterday.

The Senator from Texas, or wherever it may be, has the floor. He has had it for several hours. He will hold it as long as his wind lasts. He has it practically to himself, for only five or six of his colleagues are present. Vice President Garner has put on a large, light gray hat and gone home.

The latest relapse in Wall Street has inevitably cast its shadow over the financial markets here. As a result, British securities, lacking stimulating factors, are unable completely to shake themselves free of American influences. The upshot this week was sagging security and commodity prices.

Resolutions suspending the work of Bard College, men's residential unit of Columbia University here, formerly known as St. Stephen's College, have been adopted by the trustees of the institution, effective June 30, because of lack of funds, Acting Dean Harold Mestre announced tonight.

St. John's easy victory over Brooklyn College on Saturday night gained for the Redmen a place at the top of the list. in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles. The triumph was the tenth in eleven starts for St. John's, the same record as that boasted by N. Y. U.,

More than $400,000 will be spent this year in Chicago's war on venereal disease, the Board of Health said today. A recent survey established a minimum potential prevalence of 45,000 syphilis cases in Chicago, or one out of every seventy-five Chicagoans.
The bass fishing here at this time of the year is good. You will not be bothered by other anglers; neither will you have to worry about getting bass off your hook.
Mrs. Alonzo Jersey of West Hartford announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Madeline Jersey, to Robert Carmichael of San Diego, Calif., at a tea given yesterday afternoon at her home.

Delivering the Founders Day address at Hampton Institute today, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, said that Christianity seemed to be a failure in the world today because men were putting too little into Christian performance.

Speculative interest in the wheat market has fallen off to such a degree of late that some operators regard it at almost an irreducible minimum. There is no disposition shown to take a decided stand on either side until such time as there is a change in the character of the news from Washington.

Jose R. de Capriles, former New York University star, now representing the Salle Santelli, defeated Dr. John R. Huffman of the New York A. C., 5 to 2, in a fence-off for the metropolitan open individual foil crown at the Fencers Club yesterday.

Wide revision of the system of county jails and penitentiaries, based upon the underlying principle that the county prisons should be made a part of the State system, is urged in the annual legislative report of the Prison Association of New York, made public yesterday.

Washington Ave. 1,384 (11-2910); Audica Properties. Inc, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mortgage to Jan 1, 1943. at 4 per cent; $11,000. Grant Ave. 1,006 (9-2447); Rose Haimowitz to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mortgages to June 23, 1942, at 4 to 5 per cent $24.000.

Aubrey (Bucky) Wells loaded his four-man bobsled with 850 pounds of crew today and flashed down the Mount Van Hoevenberg run in near-record time to win the Governor Lehman Perpetual Challenge Trophy ..

A collection of rare almanacs and calendars will feature an exhibition entitled "The History of Time," which will be held during February at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday.

A. L. Burns, a Class A gunner, was the winner of the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He scored in a field of twenty-three by breaking 97 in the 100-target event.

Work on the new $186,000 parish house that will rise next to St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, is under way, it was announced in a letter sent by the Rev. H. W. B. Donegan, rector, and read before the sermon yesterday morning.
Financial circles here believe that the declaration of President Roosevelt concerning the maintenance of payrolls leaves little hope of collaboration between him and the industrial leaders to

The Rev. George Grenville Merrill, a retired Protestant Episcopal clergyman who was for-I merly rector of St. Mary's Church at Tuxedo Park, N. Y., died here at 2 A. M. today at the age of 71. He suffered a shock several weeks ago.
Don Lash today settled the problem as to whether he would run the mile or the two miles at the Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden next Saturday. He will run both.
The Fascist editor, Virginio Gayda, chided President Roosevelt today for the United States' rearmament program which he described as "colossal."

John Haight Tyson, one of the last two surviving veterans .of the Civil War in Flushing, died there yesterday at his home, 154-10 Northern Boulevard, from the effects of age. He was born in Manhattan ninety-three years ago.

The Committee for Industrial Organization announced today that it had formed a Utility Workers Organizing Committee, to organize workers in the electric light and power industry. The announcement came at the close of a conference of utility workers' representatives here.

The week's stock market was dull, even the more usually active securities being at times unquoted. Moderate selling or buying for the emigrant or the blocked-mark account was 'sufficient to depress or raise prices.

Advertising expenditures on Palm Beach suits for the coming Spring and Summer may be increased as much as 50 per cent over last year's budget of $500,000, according to L. S. Goldsmith, advertising counsel to the Goodall Company.

If a horse ever is stolen, the eleven surviving members of the Schuylkill Perseverance Company for the Detection of Horse Thieves and Stolen Property are still on the job. They held their seventy-seventh annual meeting last night. W.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M., "Mexico's New Deal," Roger Wellington. Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11 A. M., "Mexico, the Lady Next Door," Bertita Harding.

A banking group comprising Blyth Co., Inc., Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, Buffalo, and Roosevelt Weigold, Inc. will offer today a new issue of $412,500 of Board of Education of Union Free School District No. 3, 2.90 per cent bonds of the town of Huntington, L. I. The bonds,

The thirty oil officials and sixteen oil companies recently convicted at Madison, Wis., for violating the anti-trust laws, also were "convicted for misplacing their confidence in high public officials at Washington," says Warren C.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the adoption of the new charter, the reorganization of the city government and the consolidation of the various civic agencies governing building, it was hoped that the ultimate goal of economy and efficiency for taxpayer and public 'alike was to be conserved.

" Dishonesty is the cancer that is eating at the vitals of our nation," said the Rev. Dr. George Pickett Mayo, Superintendent of the Blue Ridge Industrial School of Virginia, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

' Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" will be the first picture ever to run more than three weeks at the Radio City Music Hall. It was announced yesterday that the attraction will be held over for a fourth week, beginning Thursday, with business each week of its run to date exceeding that of the week before.

Fairly general liquidation developed in the lard market last week, with the January delivery selling within 10 cents of the lowest level reached by any delivery so far this season. The selling movement found support relatively slow until cash interests furnished it.

Catholic clergy read in their pulpits today a letter from the Bishop of Berlin, Count Konrad von Preysing, complaining that government educational authorities were putting pressure on Catholic parents to send their children to Nazi schools.

Art for the New York World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park next year will be required to come off Olympus and take its place in the "very warp and woof" of avenues and buildings, Grover A. Whalen, president of the corporation, announced yesterday in reply to criticism that the fair planned no conventional display of classic paintings and sculpture.

Representatives of many lines of business, including railroad presidents and bankers, will meet in the Palmer House here on Tuesday for a conference called by the Institute of American Meat Packers as a part of a nation-wide campaign to improve the market for meat products and help the livestock industry, which has been hit hard by recent price declines.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 33 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the Jan. 23 report and 14 points from the recent low week, that ended on Jan. 1.

Twenty-five thousand torch - bearing Storm Troopers marching twelve abreast in well-ordered battalions streamed past the Chancellery tonight as the climax of today's celebration of the fifth anniversary of the Nazi attainment of power.

The Chicago Bears, champions of the western section of the National Professional Football League, defeated a team designated as the Southern All-Stars, 41 to 20, in a charity game today. Net proceeds went to the President's Birthday Fund for the Nationai Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

The National Civil Service Reform League in a statement today, characterized the McKellar amendment to the pending Independent Offices- Appropriation Bill as "the most brazer attempt that has yet been made to extend the spoils system in the Federal Government."

A sharp upward' turn in the number and variety of exhibitions -on the calendar is evident as February comes to the art galleries. More than thirty new attractions make up the roster of the current week, with group and one-man shows, ancient Chinese art and the work of modernists vying for attention.

A proposal to have Great Britain, France and Italy construct ships for the United States in payment of their war debts was suggested to the Maritime Commission today by Dr. Clayton D. Carus, foreign trade expert of the University of Southern California.

Rear Admiral Julius C. Townsend, commander of the four United States cruisers now visiting Australia, today placed a wreath in honor of the Australian war dead at the base of the Cenotaph in Martin Place.

Internal enslavement and impoverishment, accompanied by Germany's isolation from the family of nations and ever-growing danger of a new war in which Germany would face defeat and ruin, are the "achievements" of the Hitler regime, Albert Grzesinski,

The fact that, measured by dollar value, our foreign trade in merchandise during 1937, as reported last week by the Commerce Department, should have surpassed all annual records since 1930 was not surprising. The course of prices has been such that, notwithstanding the decline since midsummer, the average for 1937 has been much the highest in six years.

The New York State Council of the Knights of Columbus, with offices at 840 Eighth Avenue, made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia protesting against the "promotion" of Simon W. Gerson, "an avowed Communist" who is an aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, to the position of "assistant to the Borough President."

Mayor John Boyd Thacher 2d of Albany will be the guest of honor and he and Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speakers at the annual dinner of the Albany Society of New York at the Hotel Biltmore on Saturday evening.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reports total assets as of Dec. 31, 1937, of $1,349,057,256, an increase of $40,778,437 in the year. New insurance in 1937 amounted to $269,154,537, lifting total insurance in force at the year-end to $3,758,762,033. Payments to policy holders and their beneficiaries amounted $134,212,373.

Establishment of the State Board of Mediation "has undoubtedly filled the need for a governmental agency to assist management and labor to a better understanding of their mutual problems," the board said yesterday in a review of its first six months of activity.

Ferdinand Brunot, honorary dean of the faculty of letters of the University of Paris and an eminent grammarian, died here today at the age of 78. He had published numerous books and articles on French grammar and language. A few years ago he came before the public when he attacked the grammar used by the French Academy. Following his criticisms the grammar was considerably revised.

The erring person who means well is more acceptable in God's sight than the "goody-goody" persons, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared yesterday in his sermon.

The same Max Schmeling who knocked out Joe Louis could get nothing better than a victory on points today over the oft-defeated South African, Ben Foord. It was only last Autumn that Max Baer forced Foord to give up in the ninth round.

The New York Americans, defending champions of the United States Football Association's national challenge cup, defeated the Hungarian S. C. of Bethlehem, Pa., champions of the Lehigh Valley circuit, 4-1, before 7,000 farts at Starlight Park yesterday in the second round of the Dewar trophy competition.
The first race of the national championship series of the American Skate Sailing Association was won today by C. W. Capes of New York, a member f the metropolitan division.

Playing his ninth game in the annual championship tournament at Toronto the Marshall Chess Club, Frank J. Marshall, titleholder, defeated J. Battell in 27 moves and regained the lead with a total score of 8-1 yesterday.
Mrs. Henry Arthur Huntington of Windsor has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Margaret Huntington, to R. Dunham Braman, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Royce Braman of West Hartford.

Instructions were given by Premier Camille Chautemps today to the Minister of Justice to start proceedings against the Rightist newspaper Echo de Paris for "publishing false news harmful to the confidence of the nation in the currency."

Two skaters who fell through thawing ice on Allentown Lake and struggled in the water for fortyfive minutes were in a critical conedition in a hospital here today after their rescue by members of the Volunteer Fire Department.

Kurt Korff, former editor-in-chief of the Berliner Illustrirte Zeitung and an ex-director in the Ullstein concern of Berlin, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a sixweek illness at the age of 61. Mr. Korff was known widely in German journalism through the skillful methods he applied in the editing of pictures and the use he made of them in the illustration of daily events for outstanding German illustrated periodicals.

The price of corn futures on the Board of Trade here has held within a range of around 34 cents a bushel in the last month and, despite large export sales following the turn of the new year, it has been found impossible to maintain advances.

Jake Schaefer of Chicago retained the world 28.2 balkline billiard championship, conquering Welker Cochran of San Francisco by 824 points in their fourteen-block match concluded last night at the Strand Academy. The final score was 3,500 to 2,676.

Preoccupation with thoughts of the past is a greater deterrent to human progress and happiness than fear of the future, the Rev. Dr. Harold C. Phillips said in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church. Dr. Phillips, in the pulpit as guest pastor, is pastor of the First Baptist Church of Cleveland.

A pagan chapel, equipped with a speaking tube for an oracle, has been discovered in ruins of 2300 B. C., in Northern Syria. The chapel is a discovery of a joint expedition of the British Museum and the British School of Archaeology at the mound called Tall Brak.

The Japanese spokesman who said last week that the slapping of John M. Allison, Third Secretary of the United States Embassy at Nanking, grew out of the "insolent attitude adopted by Allison," tonight amended the statement as "erroneous."

Georges Enesco conducted what was to have been his last appearance of the season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. His departure, fortunately, has been postponed and his engagement will extend through a fifth week.

Niagara's losing streak was extended to ten straight today as the Canisius quintet wiped out an eightpoint deficit at half-time and scored a 42-41 victory in the closing minutes. Jack Digiovanna, Niagara forward, fouled as the final whistle blew, missed the point that would have deadlocked the game.

Dr. Jan de Groot, gynecologist attending Crown Princess Juliana, and Nurse Romkje Vermeer were urgently summoned tonight to Soestdyk Palace, where the heiress to The Netherlands' throne is expecting the birth of a child soon.

The Connecticut Shipbuilding Company has been incorporated in this State, according to papers filed yesterday at the town clerk's office, Groton. The organizers are reported to be negotiating with the government on the construction of merchant vessels, with an eye to the former Groton Iron Works property as a location for the shipyard.

Favored players scored in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor championship tennis tournament at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday, Joseph Fishbach, sophomore at St. John's, and Chauncey D. Steele Jr. of Columbia, seeded first and second respectively, recording straightset victories to gain the final round.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, today made public a letter he has sent to all C. I. O. affiliates in which he said that unemployment was reaching serious proportions and urged that the Works Progress Administration immediately put 3,000,000 unemployed to work.

The declaration by General Peng Teh-huai, vice commander of the Eighth Route Army, that the people of the Northwest are rising against Japan and will bring about an eventual Chinese victory over the Japanese is prominently published today in the Red Army's official organ, Red Star.

Floods which occur on the average only once in a hundred years are being studied by the use of a flood control model of the Chenango River at Binghamton, N. Y., which has been set up at Cornell University.

Despite the deadlock on the adoption of the city budget, Yonkers will meet its $350,000 payroll tomorrow afternoon, Controller James Hushion announced today. He said the city also would be ready to redeem $800,000 in city bonds.

In the February Atlantic Mr. Alexander Woollcott tells an anecdote. Professor Harold Laski is his first authority. The late Justice Holmes used to take flowers to Arlington every Sept. 13, anniversary of the birthday of Major Gen. Sedgwick, commander of the division in which Holmes's, regiment, the Twentieth Massachusetts, served.
The second day of abnormally warm January weather in a week sent the temperature fractionally above 56 at 3:30 P. M. yesterday, making the average for the day fourteen degrees above the normal of 30.

Dean Detton, former heavyweight wrestling champion of the world, will tackle the Irish Giant, John Sullivan, in the feature grappling exhibition at the New York Hippodrome tonight. Detton is favored to defeat Sullivan and earn a match with Bronko Nagurski, who now claims the title. Jesse James,

Despite continuing reports that looting, raping and disorders are not yet checked in Nanking, the Japanese here say conditions are distinctly improving. Responsible Japanese authorities do not make attempts to gloss over the facts,

The government's recent steps toward complete suppression of the Opposition have included one arrest that has attracted particular attention-that of Themistocles Sophoulis, elderly former Premier and perhaps the best-known person in party politics since Eleutherios Venzelos's death.
Representative Fred M. Vinson, chairman of the House subcommittee on taxation, said tonight that the proposed special tax on closely held corporations would yield $50,000,000 revenue.
The manuscript for Phyllis Bentley's new novel, "Sleep in Peace," has been received from England by Macmillan and will probably be published in March.

Efforts to "make the world safe for little children" are described in the reports for 1937 filed with the World's Sunday School Association, and made public yesterday at its headquarters, 51 Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Robert M. Hopkins, the general secretary. These.

Miss Innes Drury and George Boltres, performing in the women's and men's Class A singles events, turned in splendid exhibitions yesterday to capture the titles in their divisions as the Skating Club of New York concluded its annual figure skating championships at the Iceland rink.

Mrs. Constance Morrow Morgan, sister of Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, a sponsor of the Brattleboro Players of Brattleboro, Vt., who are appearing this season in a Winter repertoire of St. Felix Street Little Theatre, near Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, explained coming plays at a tea for members of the cast yesterday afternoon. John Becker, a co-sponsor, also spoke.

Declaring that industry's pathway is blanketed by a fog of uncertainties more retarding than any burden, Lammot du Pont, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., says that "by land and sea the universal practice under conditions of fog is to slacken speed."

Resolutions endorsing pending Congressional legislation to raise the rank of army and National Guard band leaders from warrant officers to commissioned officers, and to provide for a chief band officer in Washington with the rank of major, were approved by the United States Army and Navy Bandsmen's Association in convention at the Hotel Roosevelt here yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday morning in his sermon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, that we are "making a fetish of force and are going mad in our race for armaments."

Mrs. E. Ungrich Gregory gave a reception and tea yesterday at her home, 575 Park Avenue, at which she announced the engagement of her only daughter, Miss Margaret Ungrich Gregory, to Richard Cukor, son of Bela Cukor, also of this city and Budapest, Hungary, and the late Mrs. Cukor.

Miss Rosanne Lawrence Wigham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald E. Wigham, of 131 East Sixty-fifth Street, has chosen March 12 as the date for her marriage to Nicholas Cooke Jenks, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Jenks of Morristown, N. J., and Philadelphia.

Patrolman Walter P. McCloskey of Traffic D, who for the last three months has handled the assignment of ridding the midtown area of panhandlers, car-watchers and taxicab door-openers, was congratulated by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke in Night Court Saturday for his twenty-sixth arrest in two weeks.

The French markets were all deeply perturbed this week by the weakness of the franc and, as the prospects for the currency were considered uncertain, transactions were few both on the Stock Exchange and in the commercial markets.

Wil liam E. Dodd Jr., son of the former Ambassador to Germany, replied to objections to the boycott system here today at a meeting of 250 persons called by the Newark Committee to Boycott Japanese Goods.

Residents of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens were threatened with a water shortage at 1 P. M. yesterday when a turbine in the Millburn pumping station, Baldwin, L. I.. broke down. Within thirty minutes the pump had been repaired and it was back in operation.
Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale splashed over a 25-yard course to better the 200-yard national free-style mark today. Her time was 2 minutes 19.7 seconds. Mrs.

Speculation concerning the coming Gubernatorial campaign, rather than any bitter fight over State issues, continues to dominate the current session of the Legislature, which enters its second month this week.

Financial rehabilitation of the railroads has become a necessary condition of business recovery and a point has been reached where only decisive public action can meet the need, the Guaranty Trust Company declares in a discussion of the railway problem in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey.

The appointment of Sister Agnita Miriam as superintendent of the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Mother Vincentia, mother general of the Sisters of Charity, which conduct the institution.

Miss Frances J. Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Burns of this town, was married here to Edmund Robertson Nalle, son of Mrs. Gladys Sutton of McCook, Neb., yesterday afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. Howard F. Dunn.
The French wholesale price index on Jan. 22 stood at 611, compared with 615 and 608 in the two previous weeks. Native products were 653, 655 and 653, respectively; imported products,

The "weakened state of Jewishness and Judaism" in Poland and Russia is made evident by the fact that not a single Jew of that sector of the world comes to mind in the Inventory of leadership, Rabbi Israel Goldstein declared yesterday in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eightyeighth Street, west of Broadway.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has declined hundreds of invitations to speak at dinners and other gatherings, it was learned yesterday. These invitations have been received from organizations in New York City, up-State and throughout the entire country.

Plans have been completed by Miss Edna Helen Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude L. Johnston of South Orange, for her marriage to Richard E. Bishop Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bishop of New York and South Orange.
Fire of undetermined origin swept through the two-story Williams Building on Main Street here early today, causing damage estimated at $65,000 to $75,000.
A survey of agricultural conditions by the Corn Belt farm dailies shows that the farmer is in better shape than anybody else. The papers which participated are The Daily Drovers Journal, Chicago;

Lieut. Col. James B. Ord was injured fatally today when a Philippine Army training plane crashed into a tree at Baguio. Colonel Ord was one of the bestknown members of the United States military mission which has been guiding the progress of the young Philippine Army.

John W. White, chief South American correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, located in Buenos Aires, was interviewed by radio yesterday for the blue network of the National Broadcasting Company by Linton Wells.

The Young Committee, authorized by the New Jersey Assembly to investigate the Nov. 2 Gubernatorial election in Hudson County, is expected to take drastic steps today to obtain the election records in the custody of Charles F. Stoebling, Hudson's Commissioner of Registration.

National commissioners of the Union Printers International Baseball League have set Aug. 7-13 as dates for, the annual tournament to be held in St. Louis. The commissioners voted to hold next year's tournament at Baltimore.
The return of the Bank of France for Jan. 20, published this week, shows a fresh increase in business discounts of more than 1,100,000,000 francs to 11,924,000,000.

Lord Marley, Labor peer and Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, said tonight that in his opinion the United States, if necessary, would protect Canada from invasion by Japan on the West Coast. Lord Marley has returned from a North American tour.

Si-lan Chen, whose reputation as a popular dancer in the Soviet Union had preceded her to this country, made her local debut last night at the Windsor Theatre in a benefit recital for the American Friends of the Chinese People.

The New York State "Model Legislature" of the American Youth Congress was divided into two camps yesterday at its final session in the Great Hall of City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue. After a filibuster of more than an hour, a handful of delegates from the Young People's Socialist League and the Young Circle League failed to block the endorsement of President Roosevelt's policy of collective

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that "career men" in his office would be trained for promotion within the department by a course of study to be started by him on Feb. 24 with the cooperation of City College.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's last-minute decision against convoking the Reichstag for a speech celebrating five years of National Socialist government is characteristic of the man himself and the position he occupies.

A plea for restoration of the control of life to God was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Y. Beatie, preaching in the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx.
Miss Ethel Haspel of the Park Central A. A. won the junior metropolitan low board diving crown yesterday in the Park Central Hotel pool. The event was part of an A. A. U. program.

Mrs. Marion Moore Cross of this city and John T. Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Adams of Lawrence, L. I., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dana Draper of 9 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that Edward M. M. Warburg, son of the late Felix M. Warburg, had been named chairman of the committee's 1938 fund-raising campaign here. Proceeds of the drive will be used for the rehabilitation and relief of needy Jews abroad.

A campaign to raise $20,000 for Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I., was begun yesterday by the Alumnae Association. Miss Helen M. Robinson of .901 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, is general chairman. Appeals are being sent to 3,000 former students of the college.

Dr. Wellington Koo, Chinese delegate, is understood to have told the other delegations today that he would ask that the meeting of the League of Nations Council on China's appeal be deferred until Tuesday.

Isaac Abrams, florist in Brooklyn for the last quarter of a century, died at his home, 123% Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, on Friday evening. His age was 59. The building served both as his home and as his place of business. He was born in Brook- F lyn and was brought up in an atmosphere of flowers, for his father was a florist, too.

The National Steel Corporation reports for 1937 preliminary net earnings of $19,516,893 after all charges, including interest, taxes, depreciation and depletion, but before provision for the undistributedprofits tax.

Bernard Campanelle of Providence, R. I., won the 200-mile national championship motor-cycle race today. He sent his machine around the sixty-three laps in 2 hours 42 minutes-10 seconds. Lester Hillbish of Reading, Pa., finished second, following Campanelle by one minute.

More than 40 per cent of all the men's, women's and children's apparel and accessories made in the United States is produced in this city, according to the analysis just completed by the industrial bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, of the United States census of manufactures.

Changes in the Federal tax laws now proposed would not help to check the recession, according to a report made public last night by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The chamber demanded, instead, outright repeal of the undistributed-profits levy and a low flat-rate modification of the capital-gains tax. Such changes, it asserted, were necessary to restore business confidence.

A tea will be given on Feb. 10 at 99 Park Avenue in honor of Miss Katharine Cornell to aid the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service. Each guest has been asked to bring used articles suitable for resale at the Bargain Box, thrift shop at 1,175 Third Avenue, which helps to support the beneficiary.

Jacob Brickman, a certified public accountant with offices at 521 Fifth Avenue, reported to the police of the West Sixty-eighth Street station early yesterday morning that he and his wife, Hermina, had been kidnapped and robbed by four men who boarded their car in Eighty-fifth Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

Eddie Miller, sailing Allan Clark's Penguin, topped Class D, and Bud Moxham and Tommy Haire tied for first place in the Class B one-design races held by the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association today. Eighteen boats participated.
Representatives of five American Federation of Labor unions joined, today with delegates of seventy-six C. I. O. unions to back a Labor's Non-Partisan League program in Michigan.
Harry Cooper, living up to his reputation as one of the toughest competitors in golf, turned in a par-smashing finish today to win the $5,000 Oakland tournament with a 72-hole total of 275.

Marking Child Labor Sunday, yesterday, the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches issued a statement urging that the Child Labor Amendment be ratified by at least eight more States.

Cotton prices followed a moderate downward course last week, and, at the close, registered about the same size net declines as in the previous week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, quotations on active future deliveries showed net declines of 5 to 10 points for the week.

The German wholesale price index on Jan. 19 stood at 105.5, unchanged from the preceding week. For the full year 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Mrs. Elizabeth Adams Berger of Stamford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss E. Carolyn Berger, to Brude Morrison of Hartsdale, N. Y., and Stamford, son of James Morrison of Gulfport, Fla., and the late Mrs. Morrison.
The government's National Commission of Foreign Commerce has decided to ask the cooperation of private groups in promoting increased exports of Mexican products, it was announced today.

Joseph McConnell Parker, general manager of the Oakland Chamber of Commerce for the last ten years and active in business, civic and fraternal affairs in many Western cities for more than thirty-five years, died today in an Oakland hospital.

The mass revival meetings formerly conducted by such evangelists as Aimee Semple McPherson and Billy Sunday'are repugnant to the true ideals of the revival movement, the Rev. Thomas E. Thompson, pastor of the Gospel Tabernacle, Eighth Avenue and Fortyfourth Street, said in a sermon yesterday.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Muhlenberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Heister Henry Muhlenberg of Wyomissing, was married to Jackson Kemper 3d, of Clingan, Pa., this afternoon in the Lutheran Church of the Atonement at Wyomissing.

Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, set average rents of $4.55 a room today for the fifty-one apartments in Highland Homes, a slumclearance project in Wayne, Pa. The building stands on the site of a dilapidated stable which was once the home of forty persons.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Appleby will give a dinner tomorrow night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Mrs. Prescott Stade and her daughter, Mrs. Henry D. Babcock, have gone to Havana to remain until March 10.

Abraham Frumker, president of the Noxall Coat, Apron and Towel Supply Company of Hackensack and well known in Hackensack business and civic affairs, was killed here this morning in a fall from a horse not far from the Radburn Riding Academy.

The Dominion wireless station at Bull Harbor, reported that the fiveman crew of a United States Navy plane was rescued near Goose Island this morning by Canadian vessels after heavy seas forced the fliers to abandon their nearly submerged ship and take to a rubber emergency boat.

Miss Jesse Mary Finklea, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Walker Finklea, was married this morning at her parents' plantation home near here to Robert Pace Schofield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schofield of Florence, S. C.

Six firemen were overcome by smoke and illuminating gas yesterday while fighting a fire in a bar and grill and tailor shop at 2,201 Seventh Avenue, at 130th Street. The firemen, all of whom were attended by Dr. Harry Archer, deapartment surgeon, and taken to Bellevue Hospital, were Lieutenant Phillip Silverman and Firemen Joseph W. Brochu, Benjamin Goeren, Michael Linnane and William Callapy, all of Engine 69, and Fireman Thomas Saxton of Engine 36.

Councilman Howard H. Spellman of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would introduce in the City Council a bill providing mandatory pensions for dependents of members of the Police Department at killed in the performance of duty.

The American Brigade of volunteers fighting with the Loyalists has not been destroyed, as reported by the Insurgents. Officers and men to whom I have talked say that the brigade had only a few casualties and that none was taken prisoner.
The Canadiens of Montreal had things their own way with the New York Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The engagement of Miss Catherine Turk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Turk of this city, to Kenneth C. Ballantyne, son of Mrs. Henry Ballantyne of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Ballantyne, has been announced by her parents.

The chairmen of Britain's five leading banks have in the last week delivered their annual addresses to the banks' shareholders. They have followed the invariable practice of rigidly avoiding politics, either domestic or international, but all five of them emphasized the importance to the world in general of developments in the situation in the United States.

French Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden have promised Dr. Giuseppe Motta, President of the Swiss Confederation, it is reported here, that they will support a proposal to have the League of Nations

Aircraft accessory manufacturers drew a substantial share of public interest in the exhibits at the Internal Air Show here today. More than 10,000 spectators crowded the wings of the International Amphitheatre to watch a robot fly a model airplane and to see the hundreds of gadgets used in the manufacture and operation of airplanes.

An exhibition of Japanese priest robes and a collection of rare a brocades will be held by the fine arts group of the Friends of Barnard on Thursday afternoon in the college parlor, Barnard Hall, on the campus of Barnard College.
Niagara's wrecked "honeymoon" bridge settled deeper into the rain-softened ice in the Niagara River gorge today while experts debated the possibility of salvaging the span.
The weekly survey of loom activity on rayon fabrics, issued today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc., evidences a slightly better demand in the primary market.

The Rev. John Baumeister, who was ordained fifty years ago today at the First Reformed Church of Newtown, Corona Avenue and Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens, preached there yesterday morning in commemoration of the anniversary.

Charges that 3,000 Church of England clergymen are offering prayers to obtain unity of the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England under the domination of the Pope, are to be discussed when the Church Assembly meets Feb. 7.

Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., won the Florida State tennis championship singles title today by defeating Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., 8-6, 6-4, 6-0. Miss Marta Bennett of Miami took the women's singles crown from Mrs. Lila G. Porter of Mobile, Ala., 6-0, 6-4, 6-4.

Charles H. Freeman, president of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 121 West 105th Street, announced at the institution's annual meeting yesterday that a total of 125,359 days' care was provided for 407 men and women at the home during 1937. He said three-fourths of the residents were more than 70 years -old.

On exhibition at the Newark Public Library is a collection of more than one hundred autographed pictures presented to Morris S. Schlesinger when he was manager of the Orpheum, Broad Street and Shubert Theatres in Newark.

Dick Werner of Haledon, N. J., representing the New York Curb Exchange A. A., and Miss Helen Bahil of Elmhurst, L. I., New York State champion, representing the Brooklyn Ice Palace, won the New Jersey speed skating championships in a field of 125 competitors on

People who believe that the worshipping of Jesus Christ can be done at home by means of the radio may discover that when they continue to worship from afar God will soon cease to come to them, the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren declared yesterday morning.

JOURNEYMAN, a play in three acts, by Alfred Hayes and Leon Alexander, dramatized from the Erskine Caldwell novel of the same name; staged by Mr. Caldwell and J. Edward Shugrue: settings by Nat Karson; produced by Sam Byrd. At the Fulton Theatre.

Michael J. Quill, Councilman of New York City, today urged 600 members and supporters of the City Employes Union, who face ouster through a change in the Rochester Administration, to "solidify the ranks of the working people as the way out of the spoils system."

Organized labor worked today to mobilize at least 50,000 workers for a march upon City Council to protest against the recently enacted 2 per cent retail sales tax. Executive councils of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor called meetings Monday and Tuesday to vote a special labor holiday for the demonstration on the day Mayor S. Davis Wilson is expected to veto the levy.

Hickman Whittington, 68 years old, an Illinois farmer and coal miner and, so far as known, no relation to the more famous Dick Whittington, has inserted the following advertisement in a Belleville, Ill., paper:

Give a store plenty of light, place the cash register in easy view from the outside and keep Al the window display low enough to make the interior perfectly visible from the street. That was the prescription against hold-ups given to shopkeepers yesterday by the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education.

The four-story apartment house at 140 East Twenty-second Street, in the Gramercy Park section, has been purchased by J. C. Mayer through Oliver Goldsmith, broker. It is between Lexington and Third Avenues and diagonally opposite the site for the new Children's Court.

The Fall River Cotton Manufacturers Association tonight announced a 12 1/2 per cent wage cut for mill workers, effective tomorrow. Notice of the cut was served at a conference with Committee for Industrial Organization delegates, who yesterday voted not to accept the reduction.

A surprise booking will bring Jed Harris's production of "Our Town" to Henry Miller's Theatre next Friday night-a surprise because (a) it had been listed for Broadway the week of Feb. 7 and (b) Gilbert Miller's offering, "Once Is Enough," has been slated for the same house on Feb. 15.
A 10-year-old boy, now a pupil in the Upper Nyack public school, may some day own one of the finest law libraries in the State if he fulfills his ambition to become a lawyer.

The government's plan to remove all military barracks outside the city is understood to be for the benefit of the people, as, in past uprisings, innocent bystanders have been killed or injured and private property destroyed or damaged as the result of revolutionary attacks on barracks.

St. Paul was the "most successful Apostle in carrying out the tasks set by Christ," the Very Rev. John B. Harney, Superior General of the Paulist Fathers, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Sixteen Princeton teams, competing in six branches of sport, compiled during the first half of the Winter season a percentage of .570 in a total of eighty contests, according to statistics announced today by the University Athletic Association.

A movement to create a national organization of independent retail merchants was started here yesterday by 366 delegates, representing six national, seven State and 122 city organizations of retailers in various fields. The delegates met at a conference at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

More than 44,400 employers in this State held policies in the New York State Insurance Fund on Dec. 31, last, according to Charles Gordon Smith, manager, who said the number of employers electing to insure their workmen's compensation liability in the State fund had more than doubled in the last five years.

George Lauder's Apparition was the winner today in the weekly series of dinghy races off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Edward Maxwell's craft was second. There were eleven races, four in the morning and seven in the afternoon. Lauder had five firsts, three seconds, one third-and two fourths.

Most fires in this city occur in homes and most start between 4:30 and 6 P. M., when housewives T "take the matches out" to prepare dinner, George L. McKenna, assistant chief of the New York Fire Deapartment, remarked yesterday.

The virtual elimination of rum-running from the high seas, institution of a Federal drive to rid the nation of marijuana, and the reorganization of the Intelligence Unit were highlights of the Treasury law enforcement activities for the calendar year 1937, as set forth today in a report by Secretary Morgenthau.

The Penn A. C. basketball team A met defeat in an Eastern Athletic Club League contest for the first time in three years yesterday, bowing to the Crescent A. C., 42-33. The New Mooners paced the play throughout in the game at their N home court.

Auxiliary workers, to be paid not less than $15 a week for a forty-hour week, on either a time or piecework basis, may be employed in the men's cap and hat industry on contracts subject to the Public Contracts Act, Secretary Perkins held today in approving recommendations of the Public Contracts Board.

Two .32 caliber pistols were discovered yesterday in a hollow concreate block in a vacant lot at Concord Avenue and St. Mary Street, the Bronx. Rudy Krober of 720 St. Mary Street found the weapons when he shattered the block with a hammer blow as he was attempting to remove a rusty bolt from an automobile license plate. The pistols were taken to the Alexander Avenue police station.

The new return for quarterly reports of taxes and taxable wages under Title VIII of the Social Security Act will be available on Tuesday, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today. He cautioned that tomorrow night was the deadline for the filing of December returns on the last of the monthly forms.
Sixty-nine scholarships totaling $10,437 have been awarded for the Spring session by the Columbia University School of Medicine, it was announced yesterday by Dean Willard C. Rappleye.

The St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn defeated Baltimore, 7 to 1, and eliminated the Maryland soccer team from the annual challenge cup competition of the United States Football Association at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday. The Celtics led by 3-0 at half-time.

A shower of enlightening messages from ships in the North Pacific today broke the seventy-two-hour radio silence which stymied the San Francisco Weather Bureau and emphasized the desire of wireless operators to be paid for getting up at 4 A. M.

Willie Hoppe, scheduled to make a flying trip to Havana to oppose the Cuban champion, Raimundo Campanioni, in a 200-point threecushion match starting tomorrow night, has been forced to postpone the contest because of illness, it was announced last night.

The Goldberg Bill barring the use of detective agencies as strike-breaking or employment agencies is scheduled to be reported out of committee in the Assembly this week, and is slated for early passage through that chamber.
Westchester C. C. gunners participated in a time. regular shoot at sixteen-yard targets, a doubles event and a skeet test today, E. De Cordova taking two of the trophies.

THE fact that some of the Giant ball players didn't meet the postman at the gate and sign their contracts on the spot doesn't seem to be worrying Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, secretary of the club. He didn't think it was worth mentioning. J. fact, he was quite eager to take up other topics.

The heavy industries in Germany are more active, as outdoor work is favored by the mild weather. The total number of hours that was being worked in industry at the end of the year was 14 per cent higher than a year before.

The Far North pitted its limited selentific resources against Arctic cold, primitive ignorance and great distance today in an effort to halt the march of death at Nunochuk, native village forty miles from here, where epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis already has caused four deaths.

James J. Braddock, whose rise to the world's heavyweight boxing championship provided one of the most dramatic chapters in the history of boxing, announced his retirement as a fighter yesterday. The New Jersey longshoreman made his decision known after a lengthy consultation with his wife, Mrs. Mae Fox Braddock, and his manager, Joe Gould.

This is a time when the Jew, his personal conduct, should consider himself not only an individual but a representative of a people, I. Edwin Goldwasser said yesterday at a meeting of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations, of which he is president. The meeting,

The sale departments of the Commonwealth Edison Company of this city will, for the first time, aggressively promote the sale of electric ranges and water heaters and participate in cooperative advertising with the General Electric Company, J. F. McBride, ad manager of the new electric range and water heater section of the appliance department of General Electric, said following the conclusion of the showing here of the "Coast to Coast Conclave" of the company.

The second concert of the allBrahms symphonic series sponsored by the Federal Music Project was given last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. As at the preceding event in the series, the house was sold out and the audience warmly responsive.

Americans vanquished the British today in their first transatlantic orthographic battle. The final score was 28 to 24. Eight selected word-constructors of Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges "met" eight champions of Oxford University in a forty-five minute international spelling bee over an intricate two-way radio hook-up arranged by the National Broadcasting Company between Boston and London.

With the opening of the Spring term tomorrow the New York City schools will continue to show a decrease in the elementary division, but an increase in the junior and senior high school enrollment, it was announced yesterday. All transfers for high school students were completed last week.

Seven-year-old Alvin Eames of 164-33 108th Drive, Jamaica, Queens, was killed yesterday afternoon when he climbed upon a discarded upright piano in the backyard of 1,768 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, causing it to topple over and pin him beneath it.

Trailing at the conclusion of the second period, 3 to 2, the New York Athletic Club hockey team tallied three times in the final chapter and defeated the Long Island Falcons, 5 to 3, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association test at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

An exhibition of "subway art" depicting the possibility of using murals and sculpture in stations for the edification of the more esthetic-minded subway travelers will be opened to the public Feb. 8 at the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Early reports from the 15,000 celebrations held in honor of President Roosevelt's birthday indicate that all records were shattered in this year's "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, according to Keith Morgan, national chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday.

The Watersiders Federation, replying to the Ministry's request, reported today it was willing to load wood, wheat and general cargo for Japan, but on conscientious and humanitarian grounds it could not load war material because of the shooting of the British Ambassador to China,

Uncorking a strong attack in the final period to score twice and erase a 1-all deadlock, the New York Rovers subdued the Atlantic City Sea Gulls. 3 to 1, in the star attraction of the amateur hockey program at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

It was New Year's Eve tonight in China and Chinese patriots found in it an augury of tiger-like resistance of the Japanese invasion. Tomorrow will be the first day of Wuying-the year of the tiger-and today was the last of Tingehou, the year of the ox.

The twenty-six principal public utilities in Wisconsin have set up $17,500,000 for construction, improvements and maintenance this year, exceeding the 1937 budget by $2,000,000. Arthur F. Herwig, executive secretary of the Utilities Association, said the budget would be increased if the utilities received Federal Government encouragement and decreased if Federal threats continued.

Canon Christopher Wordsworth, former chancellor of Salisbury Cathedral and one of the leading scholars of the Anglican Church, died today at Salisbury at the age of 89. Canon Wordsworth, a grandnephew of the poet and a brother of the late Bishop of Salisbury, was a son of the late Bishop of Lincoln.
The second annual credit conference of the paper industries will be held on March 25 at the Hotel La Salle, H. L. Brunner, conference chairman, has announced.
The United States fleet was made ready tonight for a week of hard work under the dictum of its new Commander in Chief that its "only justification for being is to be ready to fight."

If the church were united throughout the world, Christians never could be used as an instrument for propaganda, the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared here today.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, will notify today holders of 14 West Seventy-second Street Corporation (Oliver Cromwell Hotel) first mortgage fee 6 per cent serial gold bond certificates that funds from the sale of the mortgaged premises and other deposits with the trustee are available for distribution to those holders who did not assent to the plan of reorganization.

Great Britain warned the Rumanian Foreign Minister, Istrate Micescu, tonight that she would demand an extraordinary session of the League of Nations Council if Premier Octavian Goga enforced anti-Jewish measures promulgated by his government.

The anti-lynching measure which for nearly four weeks has occupied the time of the Senate to the exclusion of other matters will be laid aside tomorrow. In its place the Senate will take up the conference report on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, which the House passed more than a week ago.

Dr. Graeme M. Hammond, president emeritus of the American Olympic Committee, will be tendered a testimonial dinner in honor of his eightieth birthday by the Caduceus Post, No. 818, of the American Legion at the New York Athletic Club on Saturday evening.

Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, commanding the training detachment of the United States Fleet based at Culebra Island, east of Puerto Rico, this afternoon flew back to his flagship, the U. S. S. New York, from which he is directing landing practice operations.

The steamship Gerolstein of the Arnold Bernstein Line arrived yesterday at pier 3, Hoboken, twentyfour hours late because of a stormy passage all the way across the North Atlantic. Among her 75 passengers were 35 Jewish refugees who made their way from Germany to Antwerp, Belgium, where they boarded the ship.

New Yorkers due to arrive today from the West Coast via Colon and Cuba on the Panama Pacific liner California include Mr. and Mrs. B. C. Boyce, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew de Martini, Dr. and Mrs. E. C. Fassett, Mr. and Mrs. D. M. Frank, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Haines and Dr. John M. Picard.

Encouraging sales volume this month has led a number of stores to augment commitments for Spring merchandise. Buyers in the market last week placed sizable orders for sports coats, toppers, two-piece suits in mannish or dressmaker versions, and three-piece suits.

The value of new residential building permits issued in 1,498 principal cities for new homes in December, 1937 showed a gain of 47.9 per cent over November, according to a survey by the Labor Department.

General Francisco Franco gave his answer today to Defense Minister Indalecio Prieto's proposals that if the Rebels ceased bombing rear guard towns the Loyalists would end their reprisals against the Insurgents' cities.

The gratitude of German nationals to Adolf Hitler on the fifth anniversary of his accession to power was expressed here last night In an address at the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, by Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General.

The season's first performance of "Das Rheingold" and the debut of Jan Kiepura, Polish tenor, who has appeared in opera throughout Europe as well as in the movies, will mark next week at the Metropolitan Opera, the eleventh of the season.

Chunky little Mush March banged home a goal in the last half of the overtime session tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-2 tie with the fastskating New York Rangers in a well-played National Hockey League battle before 12,000 spectators.

Police said today that they expected to clear up soon/ the shooting of Russell Hardy, 44 years old, Justice Department attorney, but could not make public now the progress of their investigation. Mr. Hardy, a special assistant to Attorney General Cummings, was wounded in the hip by a shot fired by an unidentified man on a street here last night.

A "shipwreck party" was given by Eric T. Bradley at his home in Milbrook last evening. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Ilgner, Mr. and Mrs. David Woodcock, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Moody, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Laemmel, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm McMaster, Mr.

Thousands of Chinese in harrying bands that struck at the Japanese rear have been killed, according to reports received by the invaders at Shanghai. In the north the Japanese arranged an accord reuniting Hopeh Province and autonomous East Hopeh under the new Peiping Government.
The first comprehensive investigation in the history of the United States of methods employed by the Department of Justice is contemplated by the House Judiciary Committee.

Diving into seas that made up in the harbor here under a southsouthwest breeze, twenty-three sailing dinghies took part today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There were twelve Class B boats and eleven X craft.

The annual interclub series among the gunners of the Rockaway H. C., Piping Rock C. C. and Nassau C. C. opened today. The home club led, with 437 out of 500 targets. Then came Piping Rock, with 389. Nassau had 385. N. L. Herrick of the winning team was high gun with 95.

Congressional conferees reported today they had agreed-to postpone until 1939 a $10,000 limitation on Federal benefit payments under the new farm program. They previously had agreed to such a limit on the amount any corporation could receive for compliance with the program,

Japanese smokers from today will pay 10 per cent more on their cigarettes, cigars and pipe tobacco to help meet the cost of the war in China. The increase, which is the second in fifteen months, is expected to yield 10,000,000 yen more yearly to the government tobacco monopoly.

Bishop Manning, who occupied the pulpit in the cadet chapel here at the United States Military Academy this morning, selected his text from Epistles; Timothy, "God Hath Not Given Us the Spirit of Fear, but of Power and of Love and of a Sound Mind."

Thomas H. Madigan, assistant counsel to the Maritime Commission, died today at Emergency Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 65 years old. Born in Westfield, Mass., Mr. Madigan became prominent in Democratic politics in New Hampshire, where he was Democratic State chairman.

Arthur F. Douglas, secretary and treasurer of the Hotels Statler Co., Inc., has been elected to the board of directors of the company, according to announcement by Mrs. E. M. Statler, chairman of the board. Mr. Douglas,

Boston's Bruins, leaders of the National Hockey League's American division, came from behind tonight to gain a 2-2 deadlock with the Detroit Red Wings. The Bruins tied the Montreal Maroons last night.

Governor Lehman's proposal to include earners of more than $3,000 annually among beneficiaries of the State's Unemployment Insurance Law was headed tonight toward an immediate vote in both branches of the Legislature.
Advantages in height, reach and weight paid dividends for Phil Furr, I Washington welterweight, last night in his eight-round battle with Frnkie Cavanna of the East Side at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Asking and answering the question as to the source of the $379,000,000 in taxes paid from the start of 1928 to the end of 1936 by the United States Steel Corporation, the U. S. Steel News asserts that "taxes can be paid -only out of the sum left over for division between those who own the property and those who work with it."

One of the largest and most effective shows put on by the New York Society of Women Artists is current until Feb. 15 at the Grant Studios, 175 Macdougal Street. It is the thirteenth annual exhibition by the society, whose exhibitions in recent years have been held in the Squibb Building Galleries.

An order directing the Board of Estimate to provide an additional $18,689 for the operation of the County Court in Queens was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin. The funds will be used to increase the salaries of attaches of the court and to provide for the employment of two additional probation officers at $2,000 salaries.

A number of builders engaged in operations in and around Bronx County have formed an organization known as the Bronx Builders Protective Association, Inc., with headquarters at 1,457 Boscobel Avenue, Bronx. Patrick J. Dwyer is president; Louis Weissman, vice president; Amadeo Giordano, treasurer, and Gerson T. Margolish, secretary.

Two Democratic district leaders were appointed yesterday as secretaries to recently elected Supreme Court Justices in the Second Judicial District. Justice Charles W. Froessel of Queens appointed James F. Pasta, leader of the third zone of the Sixth (Queens) Assembly District. Justice Algeron I. Nova of Brooklyn named Joseph P. Marcelle, leader of the Nineteenth (Brooklyn) Assembly District.

Purchase by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway of 183,333 shares of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway stock was approved on Jan. 26, 1926, by the Missouri Public Service Commission, and on Dec. 9, 1929, a merger of the two roads was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, although the consolidation never took place.

The members of the department band shall report to Captain Julius A. Unrath. at the Hotel Astor, at 10 A. M. and 7 P. M., Thursday, Feb. 3. Trials Marine Stoker Joseph Hansard, Engine Co. 66. Charge: Handling of oil burning equipment In a careless and incompetent manner. Guilty. Fined ten days' pay.
Co-Sport, Flamingo Stakes candidate of Birt Friend, scored his first victory in three starts at Hialeah Park when he led a half dozen other 3-year-olds in the Bartow Handicap today.

Harry Jeffra, Baltimore bantamweight, is assured of having red meat to eat during the training period for his fifteen-round match on Feb. 19 against the Puerto Rican challenger, Sixto Escobar, from whom he won the crown.

Directors of Loew's, Inc., a holding company controlling 175 subsidiaries engaged in the production, distribution and exhibition of motion pictures, were accused of wasting and dissipating the company's
Eugene R. Carichoff, retired General Electric Company engineer and winner of the Charles Coffin Foundation award for outstanding engineering work, died here today. His age was 77.

The index of employment in Canada on Dec. 1 reached a higher level than in the corresponding month of any previous year, according to the current monthly letter of the Royal Bank of Canada, issued yesterday.

The State Mediation Board intervened yesterday in an effort to avert a strike of 1,500 members of the Photoengravers Union, scheduled to begin in more than fifty commercial establishments this morning as a result of a deadlock between the union and the Photoengravers Board of Trade on the union's demand for a shortening of hours.

The Navy Department announced today that the headquarters of the Second Brigade of marines and the Fourth Regiment of marines, now in Shanghai, will soon be withdrawn, but will be sent to the Pearl Harbor navy base near Honolulu instead of returning to the marine base at San Diego, Calif.

Justice Black urged today that the Supreme Court abandon a fifty-twoyear-old interpretation of the Constitution giving corporations the protection . of the Fourteenth Amendment. The amendment provides that no State may "deprive any person of life, liberty or property without due process of law."

Brown Brothers Harriman Co., fiscal agents for Danish Consolidated Municipal Loan thirty-year 51/2 per cent bonds, due in 1955, announced yesterday that $91,000 of the bonds had been drawn by lot for redemption on May 1, 1938, through the sinking fund. Payment of the drawn bonds will be made at par on that date.

The list of the steamship Gerolstein of the Arnold Bernstein Line, leaving today for Rotterdam and Antwerp, includes Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Blomme, Herbert Dowdy, Werner Loeb, Mrs. Florence True, Carl Nelson, Harold Watt and Milton Snow.

After forty-eight years of service in the Postoffice Department, Robert F. Lahey, superintendent of the West Forty-third Street Postoffice, at 25 West Forty-third Street, retired yesterday, having reached the statutory retiring age of 70 for postal officials on Jan. 13.

Professor Harold J. Lockwood, formerly chief engineer in charge of WPA projects in Maine, Vermont and New -Hampshire, has been appointed head of the Department of Electrical Engineering at Manhattan. College, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, the president. The appointment be comes effective today at the opening of the Spring term.

Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of naval operations, told the House Committee on Naval Affairs today that "the political conditions in the world at this moment both in Europe and in the Far East, are far more threatening than at any time since 1918 and no improvement is in sight."
OBSERVATIONS IN RUSSIA, by Sidney I. Luck. (Macmillan, $2.50.) The diary of a member of the British eclipse expedition of 1936.

The gold medal of the American Society of Miniature Artists was awarded to Miss Rosina Cox Boardman of New York yesterday for her miniature called "Composite" in the thirty-ninth annual exhibition of the society, opening today at the Grand Central Art Gallerles, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

Russell Page, sales director for the "Easy-to-Own" Homes Organization, reports that a total of 159 houses were sold during 1937, with a sales value of $1,130,967. Notwithstanding the disturbing factors in the home sales market during the last six months of the year, Mr. Page points out that the record for the year compares favorably with 1936, when 175 houses were sold, with a total sales value of $1,175,887.

A vigorous appeal for a united Christian- church to combat "the rising perils" of Fascism, Communism and paganism was made last night by three speakers at the annual dinner-meeting of the Greater New York Federation of Churches at the Hotel Commodore.

Federal Judge John P. Nields of the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., authorized yesterday. the reorganization manager of the Peoples Light. and Power Company to proceed with reorganization under the plan approved a year ago.

The concentration of retail store interest on annual inventory taking was held responsible by both exhibitors and management for the poor attendance reported yesterday at the National Fashion Accessories Show which opened at the Hotel New Yorker.

More than forty centuries ago some childless woman, some girl waiting tremulously for her first-lover, some shepherd whose flocks were dying of a mysterious illness, some trader about to set forth on a journey, some belted warrior, came to a pagan temple in what is now Northern Syria to ask advice at an altar of one of the gods. A mysterious whispering filled the air.
The State of New Jersey as an industrial and historical unit of the

Max Lerner, editor of The Nation, was quoted in a Philadelphia dispatch printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 31 as having warned members of the American Historical Association that "not only must minorities be protected from majorities but majorities must even be protected from themselves."

The St. John's junior varsity quintet turned back the Brooklyn College jayvees, 57-32, at the Brooklyn gymnasium yesterday for its eighth victory in nine starts. The count was 17-17 at the intermission.

The Southern Maryland Agricultural Association announced today increase in the value of two stake races for Bowie's Spring meeting April 1-14. The Bowie Kindergarten, opening feature for 2-yearolds, was increased from $1,500 to $2,000.

The China Clipper, delayed at Honolulu several days on its trip to Manila, was ordered to return here today, leaving its fourteen passengers to be picked up by the Hawaii Clipper. The Hawaii Clipper is scheduled to leave Alameda, Calif., today with two passengers.

Jacob Tworkowitz, 60 years old, proprietor of a children's apparel shop at 1,582 First Avenue, leaped or fell to his death yesterday morning from the roof of the five-story brick building in which he lived at 336 East Eighty-third Street.
Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, has received from the Ball Foundation a proxy for the annual meeting of the corporation in May, it was announced yesterday.
Bonds called for redemption before maturity for payment in January were in the smallest volume for that month since 1934, although in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding two months.

In a brief and simple ceremony Stanley Forman Reed of Kentucky became in Associate Justice of the Supreme Court today while Robert H. Yackson, slated as his successor as Solicitor General, looked on from a counsel table in the court chamber.

Frankie Parker, American Davis Cup team member, is not expected to defend the Bermuda title in the annual tournament in March. It is almost certain that Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, twice Bermuda M champion, Bobby Riggs and Wayne Sabin, other United States players, will compete, according to an announcement of the Lawn Tennis Club today.

Monte Pearson of Fresno, righthanded pitcher of the Yankees, today signed his contract for 1938. Pearson rejected the Yanks' first offer, but signed the latest contract proffered because it contained a bonus clause that provides for additional pay if he has a good season. He took a slight salary cut.

Structural failure while in flight is blamed by the Bureau of Air Commerce for the crash of the Northwest Air Lines passenger and mail plane near Bozeman, Mont., on Jan. 10. Ten persons, including Pilot Nick Mamer and Co-pilot F. W. West Jr., were killed.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, in its seventy-eighth annual statement released T yesterday, shows an increase of $9,033,230 in assets to a total of $124,770,586, the largest on record.

Methods of the judicial authorities were again severely criticized today in what has come to be an annual attack in the Diet upon the administration of justice. In those attacks the police and procurators are accused of violating "human rights," that is to say, obtaining confessions by means of the third degree.

Post master General Farley and Representative McCormack of Massachusetts replied today to the speech Saturday night by Dr. Glenn Frank, Chairman of the Republican Program Committee, which charged that President Roosevelt was trying to Hitlerize the country.

The annual report of the J. I. Case Company covering the ten months ended on Oct. 31, made public today, shows a net income of $4,275,574 after bad-debt losses, depreciation, interest and provision for Federal and State income taxes, including surtax on undistributed earnings.

Regis High and Fordham Prep advanced to the semi-finals of the fourth annual metropolitan Jesuit School basketball tournament at Collins Memorial Gymnasium today by defeating Loyola High and Xavier Military Academy, respectively,. in the opening round.

Richard Pattee, Assistant Professor of Social Sciences in the University of Puerto Rico, has accepted an invitation of the Department of State to join its division of American republics. He has been asked to inaugurate a program of cultural interchanges between the United States and Central and South American universities.

The German national broadcasting station in the Charlottenburg district of Berlin will broadcast widely all-LatinAmerican programs in February. Daily programs will include two news and one economic broadcast, in addition to the feature "Echoes from Germany" and numbers by several Latin-Amer ican musicians.

Teams from twenty-five nations will compete for the Davis Cup, international tennis trophy, this year. The lists closed yesterday at the United States Lawn Tennis Association, and last year's quota of participants was increased by one, Canada having returned to the competition.

The German universities skiing team of Munich, which arrived last Friday, was feted at a dinner last night at the New York Turn Hall. More than 200 guests and members of the German Ski Club of New York, the host organization, attended.

A first mortgage loan of $120,000 for ten years at 5% on the recently completed store building on the n e cor of Hillside Ave and 169th St, Jamaica, L. I., has been arranged for Sol Atlas, owner of the structure, by J. Halperin Co, Inc, broker. The first mortgage loan of $70,000 on the apartment house at 2,419 Davidson Ave, Bronx, has been extended for five years at 5%. Nehring Brothers. Inc,
