Winning Chance, a non-winner since 1936, from the Millsdale Stable, scored an easy victory over a sloppy track at the Fair Grounds today. Ridden by H. West, Winning Chance assumed command at the start and triumphed going away to pay 17.80 for $2.

Dividend declarations by 936 companies in January aggregated $281,714,493, compared with $266,699,645 dividends voted by 958 companies in the same month of 1937, and with $453,869,081 voted by 1,900 corporations in December.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, physician in chief to the Dionne quintuplets, announced today that the five little girls had been ill with common colds for three or four days and would be kept in bed for the rest of the week.

Ralph E. Ladue, president of John David, Inc., has been named chairman of a sports committee which will be in charge of a program of sports activities to be staged at the New York World's Fair by the Men's Apparel Quality Guild.

The larger cities of the country generally find themselves in a far different position in respect to their supply of homes and apartment space than is the case with regard to office and commercial quarters.

General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, announced yesterday that new contributions totaling $1,094 had been received in response to President Roosevelt's appeal for distressed civilians in China.

The counselor of the Polish Embassy and Mme. Wankowicz announced M today the marriage of their daughter, Irene, to Stanislaw Popiel at the Cathedral of Oliva, near Danzig. The ceremony was performed by the Bishop of Oliva,

John J. Harris, advertising and public relations director of Fenner Beane, was yesterday elected president of the New York Financial Advertisers Association for this year, succeeding Harvey Weeks of Central Hanover Bank Trust Company, at the annual meeting of the association at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

Mrs. Clark P. Read gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Mrs. E. Wadsworth Hotchkiss, Mrs. Charles King Morrison, Mrs. John J. Semple, Mrs. lorenzo M. de Picabia, Mrs. Arthur R. Manice, Mrs. du Pignac Thompson,

The security and commodity markets made small recoveries yesterday, but trading was comparatively light. In the stock market it was the first advance in more than a week, and the turnover on the Stock Exchange of 757,000 shares was the smallest for a full day since last Tuesday.

Firecracker shooting is taboo at Chinese celebrations these days. The government needs all available gunpowder for war purposes. Even China's New Year's Day, celebrated today, passed without the traditional firecracker barrages.
BALSAM--Jacob, beloved husband of Emma, dear father of Blanche Popper and May Frances Balsam. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, Seventy-ninth St., Columbus Ave., Wednesday, Feb. 2, 11 A. M.

President Roosevelt discussed Kentucky politics in separate conferences with Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler, and with John Y. Brown and Thomas S. Rhea, the latter stating on leaving the White House that Mr. Roosevelt left no doubt of his preference of Senator Barkley as against Governor Chandler in the coming Senatorial race.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that the city had received $66,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for the support of research on chronic diseases. The studies are being conducted on Welfare Island.

The convention of the United Mine Workers of America, entering its second week, today heard a guest speaker plead for peace between the Committee for Industrial Organization and- the American Federation of Labor, and later almost unanimously approved "unlimited" financial support to continue the C.. I. O.'s organizing efforts.
Jack Singer, 47 years old, a chiropodist who lived at the Hotel Greystone, 2,450 Broadway, and had an office at 2,345 Broadway,

It is pleasant to turn from wars and revolutions, from filibusters and taxes, from politics and automobile accidents, from recessions and blizzards, and to take a look at a small fraction of humanity born on Monday near Amsterdam. The new arrival is a titled lady and can have herself announced as Princess of The Netherlands, Princess of Orange-Nassau, Duchess of Mecklenburg, and Princess of Lippe-Biesterfeld.

The busiest day in the history of downtown Traffic Court was recorded yesterday; with 1,771 cases disposed of and $2,805 collected in fines. Twenty men went to jail for one or two days in default of fines.

How does an American locomotive engineer named Gus Phillips in Omaha happen to pay $31 for a telephone taok with King Boriss III of Bulgaria on the latter's birthday? The first guess would be that Phillips, like a good many other American engineers and technicians, has been in foreign lands.
The volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the lowest of any month since last August, and sales were the smallest for a January since 1935.

A general meeting of the membership of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York has been called for Feb. 17 at 10 A. M. at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday in the association's weekly news bulletin.

The Supreme Court set aside today an order formulated by Carl K. Withers, as State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, directing the Columbian National Life Insurance Company of Massachusetts to alter its policy-loan plan in New Jersey.

Appointment of John L. Wood as backfield coach at Harvard University was announced tonight, along with the rest of the personnel of the football staff for next season. Wood, assistant to Head Coach Dick Harlow last season, vill succeed Howard Odell, who resigned to become backfield mentor at the University of Pennsylvania.

Isaac N. Sullivan, who as first chief justice of Idaho's Supreme Court admitted Senator William E. Borah to the bar in 1891, died here today at the age of 89. He retired from the Idaho Supreme Court bench in 1917.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn has asked the Board of Estimate for a $25,000 appropriation to aid his investigation of alleged delinquencies in Kings County sales tax payments. The application is scheduled to appear on the board's calendar next Thursday.
The foreign colony, which moved to the beach at El Perello as a precaution against bombardments here, is going underground for further security.

Thomas Tracy Bouve, a former city editor of The Boston Herald, who had been writing fiction for the last fifteen years, died yesterday at his home, 535 East Eightysecond Street, of a heart attack after a fortnight's illness.

Bondsmen for Benjamin W. Sangor and Anthony M. Then, former Toms River bankers, surrendered them to Sheriff Walter H. Applegate today as a result of last week's decision by-the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals upholding their conviction two years ago on charges of embezzling $68,000 worth of securities from the estate of James D. Halton and substituting worthless stock in Sangor's hotel enterprise.

Taking full advantage of the fans' leisure hours, the American Association will open its 154-game schedule on a Saturday and close on a Sunday. April 16 is the opening date, with Toledo, Louisville, Columbus and Indianapolis drawing the curtain raisers.
Mrs. William Thomson Sherron of Germantown has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Alberta Sherron Cooper, to Bruce Lochman Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bruce Lewis of Lafngdon Manor.

The possibility of prolonging human life far beyond its present expectancy arose for speculation as scientists at Brown University announced today completion of experiments which nearly doubled the life span of certain animals.

The Norwegian steamer Belmoira sailed today with twenty Americanmade locomotives for delivery in China. Ten of the locomotives were made in the Baldwin Locomotive Company's plant at Eddystone and the others by the American Locomotive Company at Schenectady, N. Y.

Formation of the Greater New York Bureau of Dental Information was announced last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania attended by leaders in the dental profession and representatives of the fields of education and public health.

In an effort to defeat the Republican county leadership and policy, City Councilman Hugh Quinn and Albert Marinelli, former New York County Clerk, have served in Suffolk County during the last year "as emissaries of Tammany Hall," W. Kingsland Macy, Republican county leader, declared here tonight.

Somehow Mr. Whalen's glowing statement, to the effect that visitors to the New York World's Fair "will find art all around them-to the right, to the left and even under foot," does not entirely reassure those who have suddenly wakened to the realization that American art, as such, is not scheduled to have any formal recognition at the Fair.

The Junior League of the Walter Graham Scott Free Industrial School for Villa Sie Crippled Children and of the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children held its annual benefit card party yesterday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Con tracts for large quantities of textile supplies for the Civilian Conservation Corps were awarded at the local Quartermaster Depot today, as follows:

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation reports combined net earnings of $21,501,296 for 1937, including $2,111,444 representing net underwriting profit and investment income of National Surety Corporation, a wholly owned but non-consolidated subsidiary, compared to $21,181,020 combined net earnings in 1936.
State Auditor Walter R. Darby reported today that, as of Dec. 31, New Jersey's municipalities had collected $172,406,284 of a total 1937 tax levy of $241,098,262, or 71.51 iper cent.

Funeral services with full military honors were held today in Arlington National Cemetery for Major Gen. Edward Croft, former Chief of Infantry, United States Army. Chaplain Ora J. Cohee of Fort Myer, Va., officiated.

Charging milk distributors with s increasing the retail price of milk out of proportion to the distribution service, six City Councilmen will introduce a resolution at today's Council meeting calling for the creation of an investigating commission of five members to develop an adequate supply of milk at reasonable prices.

Yale University's hockey team put up a gallant fight tonight before bowing to.McGill's Redmen, 6-3, in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game. The Reds took over the league leadership from Toronto as a result of the victory.

Marine insurance companies and Lloyd's Underwriters today announced an agreement limiting war risk coverage on ship cargoes to fifteen days after arrival at their ports of destination, whether unloaded or not.

Mrs. Ruth Callahan, 37-year-old widow, was found dead in a driveway near her home in the Dyker Heights section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning, after having shot herself with the service revolver of her brother-in-law,

Bergen Ave. 536-38, 2-story office and store building, 50x100: Seamen's Bank for Savings in City of New York against the Debb Corp; due $71,121; to plaintiff for $50,000. By DANIEL GREENWALD Boston Rd, 3,374-82, 107.9x98.7; Standard National Corp against B. W. M. Construction Co; due $18,450; to Mawels Realty Corp, Fred L. Weisler, pres, for $18,572.
The text of the testimony given by Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, before the House Naval Affairs Committee today follows: Before discussing the specific items of the bill,

More than 25,000 applicants for State unemployment insurance benefits got positions after they had filed notices of unemployment, according to an announcement yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

Indictment charging John Henry Seadlund, alias Peter Anders, with "kidnapping and inflicting bodily harm" on Charles S. Ross was returned by a grand jury today before Federal Judge Philip Sullivan. The trial was immediately assigned to Federal District Judge John P. Barnes.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and Midvale Steel Company all received a share of a 13,700-ton armor-plate order distributed by the Navy Department, which has asked for bids on Friday for 4,500 tons of plates, sheets and strip.

The Committee of Twenty-eight on League of Nations reform was informed today by the delegates of Switzerland, Sweden and The Netherlands that their governments held the opinion that Article XVI, the coercive provision of the League Covenant, had become optional for each member.

Fresh support entered the bond market yesterday, with interest centered mainly in the medium and better-grade railroad issues. Although trading was at an unusually slow pace, the market generally displayed a decidedly better undertone, with the carrier loans,

A proposed legislative bill calling on the State to appropriate $875,000 for improvement of the cross-country parkway in Yonkers and Mount Vernon was endorsed today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. The measure has the approval of several State officials and is the spearhead of a new drive to obtain Westchester parkway funds in Albany. supervisors declared.

The American boat Delilah, sailed by Sampson Smith, with Whitney Stueck crewing, won the first race in the series for the Cup of Cuba today. The international Star Class yacht from Otsego Lake, N. Y., covered the course in 1:42:10.

The George Putnam Fund of Boston has been organized for the purpost of "combining the advantages of the 'Boston-type' investment trust and the benefits obtained through individual trust funds under the supervision of private trustees in Massachusetts," according to the announcement.

The Securities and Exchange Commission denied applications today by several corporations for confidential treatment of data, including in some instances, salaries filed with the commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Data made available included the following:

Manhattan Alterations 50th St, 415 E; to 3-story private residence; John S. Lamont, premises, owner; C. P. Brookfield, architect; cost $10,000. 97th St, 103 E; to 5-story tenement: 103 E 97th St Corp, premises, owner; Boak Paris, Inc, architect; cost $4,800. Broadway, 2,248-58; to 4-story theatre; Fulton Building Co, Inc, 152 W 42d St, owner; Otto H. Spin, architect; cost $3,400.

Agreement on the text of a resolution on the Far Eastern war which is to be submitted to the League of Nations N Council tomorrow was reached tonight by Viscount Cranborne, British Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs; Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs; Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, and Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, Chinese delegate to the League.

More than $1,000 in unsolicited gifts arrived at Bard College here today as friends, students and faculty members of the institution pledged themselves to work to keep the residential unit of Columbia University in operation. A decision to suspend the work of Bard College because of lack of funds was announced by the trustees last night.

The movement of gold through the Port of New York came to a virtual standstill last month. Imports amounted to $776,500, consisting of $705,500 from India and $71,000 from Australia, which was the smallest monthly total since February, 1936.
The seriousness and the sincerity a of a great musician, evident in everything that Rudolf Serkin does, was shown in the program he played last night in Carnegie Hall, and his manner of playing it.

Nathan Frank and his wife sold to the 202 8th Ave Corp, of which he is president, the 5-story fiats with store at 202 8th Ave, for a consideration shown as $15,000, the corporation giving a purchase money mortgage to Matthew Fishman for $10,000, payable five years hence at 6 per cent.

Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Leon E. Nixon, Aug. 16, 1938. 1st Lt. Anthony La Russo, Med.-Res., Aug. 18. 1938. Capt. Samuel E. Abel, Med.-Res., Aug. 19. 1938.
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today four railroads to make joint use of a stretch of tracks in Denver to simplify freight movements.

A United States Treasury Department decision requiring all imported handkerchiefs to be individually marked to indicate the country of origin has been modified to exempt handkerchiefs made of material so delicate that it might be injured by the marking, it was announced yesterday.

A uniform returns credit system will be put into force today in the popular-priced dress industry by the Dress Returns Control Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, chairman of the bureau.

The silk dragons, colorful banners and popping fusillades of firecrackers were banished from New York's Chinatown yesterday as heavy-hearted Chinese, in sorrow for their war-torn homeland, foreswore all traditional gayety in observance of their New Year.

A definite policy on the anti-trust laws, one that is announced, pursued and clearly stated, was called for by Dr. Leverett S. Lyon, executive vice president of the Brookings Institution, in an address before a luncheon at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday, sponsored jointly by the Association of Buying Offices, Inc.,

C. C. Patterson's Brookline (Mass.) Country Club four I moved easily into the third round for the annual Quebec Bonspiel's Holt Renfrew Granite Cup by turning aside two strong Quebec Curling Club quartets today.

Included among the month-end firm changes announced for today were the formation of brokerage houses and the admission of general partners. With the admission to general partnership in Carl M. Loeb Co. of Everett Ware Cady, W. Palmer Dixon, James Averell Clark, Henry Parish 2d and A. Raymond McKernana, all formerly partners of Rhoades Co.,

Charles T. Kountze, former chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Omaha and partner in the former Kountze Brothers banking firm of New York, died today in Honolulu, where he had lived for several years. He was 6 years old.

While crossing the street, accompanied by members of his family, Sylvester Rosenthal, 63 years old, retired builder, of 85-43 169th Street, Jamaica, Queens, was killed last night when hit by a truck at Fiftyfifth Street and First Avenue.

Eager but orderly crowds thronged the offices of the Motor I Vehicle Bureau at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, all day yesterday. It was the last day of grace for motorists still using 1937 license plates.
About 200 persons attended a testimonial dinner to Harry Mendel, Newark bicycling and boxing promoter, last night in Jack Dempsey's Restaurant.

A survey of facilities available in Nassau County for the dissemination of radio education programs through the cooperation of students and teachers in the county's high schools and colleges will be conducted in the next month under the auspices of the Nassau County Radio Education Committee, headed by Dr. S. E. Frost, chairman of the Department of Education of Adelphi College here.

What is believed to have been an attempt at a Gold Shirt, or "Dorado," uprising resulted in outbreaks of violence in Northern Mexico today. Four were known dead from three clashes,. while fragmentary reports of a fourth, at Ramirez, told of a pitched battle with eighteen killed, and a large number wounded.
Violet Wells Norton, middle-aged housewife who asserted that Clark Gable, film actor, was the father of her daughter, will be deported to Canada Wednesday, her lawyer, Morris Lavine, announced today.

The problems confronting the nation's department stores in the coming twelve months were dramatically presented by a dozen leading retail executives last night at the opening of the twenty-seventh annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, has acquired from the Findlay Galleries, Inc., 8 East Fifty-seventh Street, a marble sculpture, "Mother and Child," by Jacob Epstein, whose highly individualistic work has aroused much controversy.
Steel operations are scheduled at 30.5 per cent of capacity this week, a decline of 2.2 points, or 6.7 per cent, from last week, and the first set-back after four consecutive weeks of gain.

The Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., which aids indigent and aged musicians and their dependents, was the beneficiary of a concert given yesterday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

The Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis singles championship was won by Joseph Fishbach, St. John's University sophomore, when he defeated Chauncey Depew Steele Jr. of Columbia, 6-2, 6-3, 9-7, on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.

The National Aviation Corporation and subsidiaries' report for 1937 shows net assets of $12.70 a share on 477,274 capital shares at the year end, compared to $16.07 a share on 477,352 shares a year before.

Julien H. Harvey, executive vice president of the Greater New York Safety Council, has been named managing director of the National Conservation Bureau, according to an announcement yesterday by Claude W. Fairchild, general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives.

The Class A singles championships of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association opened at the University Club yesterday with the only two seeded men to see action coming through to straight-game victories.

Stephen Seguine Johnson, amateur geologist and archaeologist and former municipal official here, died-yesterday at his home after a long illness. His age was 68. In the real estate and insurance business at 1,265 Broadway,
Melville W. Brown, pioneer motion picture scenarist, director and playwright, died at his home here today of a heart attack. He had recently returned from film work in England. His age was 50.

Norman (Baby) Yack of Toronto won a split decision tonight over Indian Quintana Panama in a ten-round bout. There were no knockdowns in the battle, which was a thriller. Each boxer weighed 118'A pounds.

The sixtyfifth birthday of Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, will be celebrated tomorrow with considerable ceremony. German newspapers are full of tributes to his career since he became a Minister under Chancellor Franz von Papen in 1932.

Clifford B. Reeves, since 1933 service director of Doremus Co., advertising agents, has been elected a vice president and director of the company. Before joining Doremus, Mr. Reeves was research manager and a director of the investment banking firm of J. G. White Co., and was a member of the publicity department of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Andre Antoine, famous French actor-manager and founder of the "Theatre Libre," will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow. It was in 1887 that he founded this theatre in Paris to realize his ideas on the proper development of dramatic art.

Three members of the Panaman steamer Alba's crew of twenty-four were missing tonight after the vessel ran aground off the stormlashed Cornwall coast and sank. Three others were injured. Twentyone were taken to shore on a breeches buoy by Coast Guardsmen, using automobile headlights to light the scene.

With the aid of Governor Moore, a Democrat, Senator Winant Van Winkle of Bergen County, a Republican, succeeded tonight in his year-long fight to have Thomas L. Zimmerman Jr. of Ridgewood renamed as judge of the Bergen County Juvenile Court.

The fast-skating New York Rovers gained their fourth straight triumph and their third in as many ' days by downing the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night.

BURGOS, Spain (By Courier to Saint-Jean-de-Luz, France), Jan. 31.--Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain learned with the appearance of today's official bulletin that it now has a permanent Cabinet to replace the temporary technical junta that has functioned here since Oct. 1, 1936.

The Chicago Board of Education approved today the sale of $31,000,000 in 1938 taxanticipation warrants to five Chicago banks and a security brokerage firm at 2 1/4 per cent, one of the lowest rates in the history of the public schools.

That the New York Stock Exchange is eager to effect its proposed reorganization with all haste is indicated by the action of the governors in empowering the president, Charles R. Gay, to name a committee of three to draft the necessary amendments to the constitution that would embody the recommendations contained in the Conway committee's report.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that Canadian imports in December were worth $53,125,000, against $52,996,000 in December, 1936. The United States led all countries sending goods to Canada with a value of $34,831,980, against $32,617,906, with the United Kingdom next with $8,666,223, compared with $8,506,228.

The annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for 1937, issued for publication today, shows net earnings of $4,585,684, after all expenses and fixed charges but before depreciation, compared with $3,98.7,893 in 1936.

Harvard metallurgists announced today the development of a new electron furnace which opens the possibility of more effective study of the basic physical properties and industrial uses of most of the forty metals as yet little understood or exploited.

The Rev. Charles Albert William Brocklebank, for the last four years rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Easton, Md., today will become rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-theBouwerie, Tenth Street West of Second Avenue.

H. C. Wainwright Co. bought yesterday an issue of $3,000,000 of temporary loan notes of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts at par, plus a premium of $26 for 0.26 per cent notes. The issue will be dated Feb. 8 and will be payable on Feb. 2, 1939. There will be no reoffering of the notes.

Dean Detton, 215 pounds, Salt Lake City, threw John Sullivan, 275, Ireland, in 22:11 of the feature wrestling bout at the Hippodrome last night before 2,000 persons. The winner used a flying tackle and body press.
Franklin D. Roosevelt gave a practical reason today for keeping her hair long. She needs a knot, she explained, to anchor her hat when she rides with the President in open cars.

Declaring itself faced with a necessity of reducing an operating deficit of more than $2,500,000 annually, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad filed today with the Massachusetts Public Utilities Department a comprehensive plan for reduction of train service on the Old Colony Railroad, serving South Shore points.

Miss Alice Turnbull, a sister of Arthur Turnbull, president of the Union Club, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at her home, 156 East Sixty-second Street, after several months of failing health.

Representatives of Haiti and the Dominican Republic signed an agreement late today settling a four-month-old controversy between the two nations on the West Indian island of Hispaniola. Haitian officials had charged that their nationals in the Dominican Republic were the victims of "wholesale masacre."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will broadcast on Wednesday an appeal for the China relief fund which the Red Cross is raising to aid Chinese civilians made destitute by the war. She will speak at 6:30 P. M. over a Columbia network.

Mayor La Guardia told his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday that the city would not be able to keep up its share of relief financing for the remainder of this year unless it regained $12,000,000 from its utility tax revenues which had been diverted to State revenues.

Charles Firestone, 65 years old, lawyer and real estate operator, was exonerated yesterday by Special Sessions Justices Voorhees, Walling and Perlman on a simple assault charge made by Mathilda Lindenberger, 17, of 1.225 Ninetyninth Street, Brooklyn.

Another move in the long effort to eliminate abuses in ticket distribution in the legitimate theatre here began yesterday when the League of New York Theatres proposed a plan embodying most of the reforms attempted under the NRA theatre code.

The Little Gardens Club, a Greenwhich Village organization, with the cooperation of New York University, has formed a garden center to disseminate gardening information and encourage community improvement, it was announced last night at a meeting of seventy persons at 10 West Thirteenth Street.

8th Ave. 202, 20x75; Nathan Frank and wife to 202 8th Ave Corp, 202 8th Ave ($15). 38th St, 257-61 W, 54.9x98.9: Cabin Holding Corp to Morton Kulick, 1,491 Vyse Ave, Bronx. 44th St, 504 W, 25x100.5; Armand H. Bousson and wife to Clara H. Van Riper, 22 St. Luke's P1, Montclair, N. J. 92d St, 133 W, 20x100.81/2; Vera M. and Dorothy M. Scully to Mary E. Scully, 133 W 92d St; mtg $13,000.

Towboat operators have felt the effects of the general business recession in the loss of about 40 per cent of their business during the last three months, according to James G. Conway, president of the New York Towboat Exchange.

Heavy fighting along the Tientsin-Pukow railroad fronts was reported yesterday at Shanghai. Both sides claimed successes. The Chinese said they had inflicted serious losses on the enemy. They also told of harassment of the Japanese between Shanghai and Nanking.

Frank Nichols of Athens, N. Y., son of the late Samuel Hamilton and Cornelia Coffin Nichols, died at the Greene County Memorial Hospital here yesterday. His age was 85. His brother, Edwin, died Friday.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Paul Karlsruhr of this city today announced that Mrs. Karlsruhr's sister, Miss Miriam Miona Greil, was married yesterday to Daniel Pouzzner of this city in Elkton, Md.

T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, who refused.to sign a contract with the C. I. O. when a strike occurred in his company's plants last Summer, outlined a program calling for industrial peace, in an address tonight. at the University of North Carolina.
Rinkdom's rhyming rivals-Drillon and Dillon|are still showing the National Hockey Leaguers that they possess more than a couple of names that might fit into a couplet of verse.

The Green Mountain distillery, Inc., Burlington, Vt., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 coverning 100,000 shares of $1-par value common stock to be offered at $2.50 a share. Proceeds will be used for debt retirement, gin, still and working capital.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 29: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Boettcher, A., Inf., Troy, N. Y., to New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn, N. Y., about March 1.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey became incensed yesterday when he learned that somebody connected with his office had made public a confidential order dictated by him that none of his subordinates excepting the legal staff was to give information to newspaper reporters, photographers or others in quest of news.
The Rev. B. Frank Tobey, "marrying parson" of Tompkins County, is dead in near-by Danby after serving for more than forty-three years the Congregational Church there. He was in his ninety-third year.

The relations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization were further strained today when President William Green of the A. F. of L. rejected the peace proposal made before the United Mine Workers convention by Father Francis J. Haas,

Mrs. Elisabeth Connor Buchanan, a law clerk at the Justice Department, identified herself today as. the woman who accompanied Russell Hardy on an automobile ride before the special assistant attorney general was shot Saturday night.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 31: Barber, Capt. R., Dental Corps, orders to Brooklyn, N. Y., revoked; to continue duty at Washington. D. C. Casey, Comdr. J. T., Chaplain Corps, Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa., to treatment at the Naval Hospital, Philadelphia; orders of Jan. 4 revoked.

Members of the Democratic Junior League of New York have completed plans for their annual supper dance in behalf of the Social Service Bureau of the organization, which will take place Feb. 19 at the Biltmore.

Herbert Morrison, British union leader, today stressed the fact that his coming e visit to the United States would be purely that of a guest and that he had no intention of shaping or di- o reacting an American labor party.

It was back to school today for thirty-three members of the New York State police. The troopers, their number augmented by six officers from other police agencies, compose the "student body" at the nineteenth State police school, which will continue here until Feb. 25.

Declaring that more than 2,000,000 boys and girls are now engaged in child labor to the detriment of themselves and of the nation, Mrs. Charles S. Whitman, member of the State Committee on Child Labor of the New York League of Women Voters, yesterday urged public support for the Federal Child Labor Amendment.

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and the city magistrates are commended "for their efforts to enforce the law against illegal picketing" in a report by the committee of public'service of the State Chamber of Commerce, made public yesterday.

The new European run on the dollar, which began late last week, went ahead briskly yesterday with all important foreign exchanges appreciating in terms of the United States currency unit. The pound sterling rose to $5.01%, its best price since Nov. 8, when the last European flight from the dollar was in full career, and closed at $5.011/2, up 13-16 cent from Saturday's closing price.
Vernon Hughes scored 13 points as the Birch Wathen School five defeated the New York Friends combination, 28-24, on the latter's court yesterday. Birch Wathen led at half-time. 12-10.

Mixed views as to the effects of State fair-trade laws on prices were presented before the Association of Retail Secretaries at the first session of its convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday. VictorL. Keys of the Ohio State Pharmaceutical Association held that the laws have tended to level off prices.

Senator Copeland announced today that Mrs. Elinore Herrick, National Labor Relations Board official in New York, would appear before the Senate Commerce Committee Wednesday to reply to charges that she had favored certain maritime unions.

Average daily sales of chain drug stores in December were 2 per cent lower than in December, 1936, according to preliminary estimates made publio today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestio Commerce. The December sales were 29 per cent higher than in November, no adjustment being made for seasonal factors.

Acceptance of Japan's expression of "profound regret" over the slapping of John M. Allison, third secretary of the United States Embassy in China, by a Japanese soldier at Nanking was announced by the State Department today.
Eleven Arabs were killed and two soliders of the Royal Ulster Regiment were wounded, one of them seriously, today in an engagement between an Arab band and British troops.

The board of directors of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association announced yesterday that it had adopted a resolution endorsing the activities of the association's officers and staff in connection with the proposed reciprocal trade treaty with Czechoslovakia and approving the presentation of the group's opposition to the treaty at the public hearing in Washington.

William H. Coverdale, consulting engineer of 120 Wall Street, New York, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to hold the position of director of the Tennessee, Alabama Georgia Railway Company and officer or director of certain other corporations.

Speaking for the National Catholic Welfare Conference, of which he is general secretary, the Right Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Ready tonight criticized the action yesterday of sixty members of the Senate and House of Representatives in sending a message of greeting and sympathy to the Spanish Cortes which was to have met in Barcelona tomorrow.

Solution of the casting problems of two pictures on two lots was sought today through an exchange of stars. With the leading role in Dr. A. J. Cronin's "Hatter's Castle" suited to the talents of Bette Davis.

The weekly figures of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department, made public yesterday by Deputy Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary, showed improvements for last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods last year. The figures covering the entire week were:

Committee consideration of a bill which Congressional leaders see as opening up discussion of JapaneseAmerican commercial rivalry will begin before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. Xavier M. Audibert of 63 East Eighty-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Audibert, to W. Stephen Sturgill Jr., son of Colonel Walter S. Sturgill, U. S. A., chief of staff of the Seventy-eighth Division, and of Mrs. Sturgill, who are now residing at 31 West Twelfth Street.

Permission to enter Canada was granted yesterday by the Commissioner of Immigration in Ottawa to Gina Cigna, Metropolitan Opera singer, who was taken off a train at Windsor, Ont., last Saturday and returned to New York after two hours' examination by the Canadian authorities.

Ninety-eight warships and 260 fighting planes were deployed tonight in defense of the Los Angeles Harbor area. This first concentration here of the United States fleet, in condition of battle readiness and under sealed orders, was the beginning of five days of intensive war games off Southern California.

A variety of events are lined up for Broadway inspection tonight, to wit: "Sunup to Sundown," by Francis Edwards Faragoh, at the Hudson, in a production by D. A. Doran. It is the child labor play that just won the I. L. G. W. U. contest,

Geneva College scored a thrilling 46-43 triumph over an aggressive Rider College quintet tonight. Geneva, though losing three of its players- on personal fouls in the last twenty minutes, managed to maintain its first-half advantage and cut short a belated Rider rally.

The Supreme Court dismissed today an application by the Pamrapau Corporation for a writ to review a fifty-year lease of underwater rights granted by Bayonne to Central District, Inc., for construction of a $5,000,000 ship-to-rail terminal.

Wives who wish to travel with their air-minded husbands may do so without cost on the Canadian Colonial Airways between New York and Montreal, it was announced yesterday. The invitation also includes the snow plane which connects in Montreal with trains to the Laurentian Mountains.

The total reserves of all member banks rose to successive new high levels in January and on Jan. 26 were close to $7,300,000,000, or more than three times the average volume in the years 1927 to 1929, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, issued yesterday.

Four seeded players advanced handily today as play opened in the Silrf Club's annual tennis tournament, but Bobby Riggs of Chicago, and Bitsy Grant of Atlanta, topranked in opposite brackets, delayed the start of their campaigns until tomorrow.

Sir James Crichton-Browne, brain specialist, who began to practice more than seventy years ago and who became one of the most famous specialists on mental and nervous disorders, died at his home in Dumfries, Scotland, today at the age of 97.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken space in apartment buildings throughout the city was George Baker St. George, vice president of the Empire Trust Company, who signed a contract for a suite in the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Reorts for 1937 from insured savings nd loan associations in New York, ixty-four of them Federal instituions and twenty-five State-charared associations, show that direct mortgage loans made by these intitutions rose in the year from 73,990,455 to $93,482,621, an inrease of $19,492,166, Nugent Falon general manager of the Federal savingss and Loan Insurance Cor??oration, announced today.

A taxi driver who turned amateur detective after being deprived of his license. for carrying a pistol, which he-insisted had been left on the seat of his cab, made good yesterday by helping to arrest the man he said had been the cause of his troubled..

A dozen gray-haired, blue-clad veterans, who, as youngsters, fought with the Union forces in the Civil War, met Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning at City, Hall and later were guests of honor at a reception given by the New York County G. A. R. and Women's Auxiliaries of the G. A. R. in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

John F. Downey, 51 years old, chief clerk in the Kings County Court, received a possibly fractured skull late last night when he fell against the radiator in the living room of his home at 7,932 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended Jan. 27 was 321, compared with 338 for the week preceding and 178 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Miss Barbara Sturtevant of New York will be maid of honor at the marriage of her sister, Miss Hope Sturtevant, daughter of Mrs. F. Raymond Sturtevant and the late Dr. Sturtevant, to Dr. Richard Nelson Tillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Henry Tillman of Riderwood, near Baltimore.
The Australian team of Adrian Quist and Jack Bromwich won the Australian men's tennis doubles championship today by defeating Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel of Germany, 7-5, 6-4, 6-0.

Sir Henry and Lady Lyons have left the Waldorf-Astoria to pass several weeks at The Breakers in Palm Beach. Mr. and Mrs. John Sloan will give a dinner tonight at Sherry's for their daughter, Mrs. Robert Carmichael, in celebration of her birthday.

Expressing regret at the necessity for discontinuing broadcasting following a disturbance during Representative Hamilton Fish's address at an anti-Hitler meeting on Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, Donald Flamm, president of WMCA, asserted yesterday that the station "exercises no censorship" except in the matter of good taste.

A contra-seasonal lag in automobile production last week caused the adjusted index to ease to 63.3 from 70.0. The figure for the week ended Jan. 30, 1937, was 79.0. Ward's Automotive Reports estimated the week's output at 59,365 cars, compared with 65,418 for the previous week and 76,620 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Because of the growth of business in the last few years the Church Life Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that new offices had been created. Bishop Cameron J. Davis of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Western New York and Frank L. Polk were elected vice presidents of the corporation.
There is an exposition in Paris to commemorate Adolf Hitler's five-year reign-but it is not a show that Propaganda tic Minister Joseph Goebbels would sponsor.
Joseph D. Daly, vice president and general counsel of the Catholic Church Extension Society, died yesterday at his home in Wilmette at the age of 57.

Grand juries are centuries old. The Department of Justice is highly modern. Not till 1861 did the Attorney General get the power to superintend and direct United States attorneys and marshals, who since 1789 had been absolutely independent in the management of their offices.
Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, chief of army engineers. was named by Mayor La Guardia last night as Commissioner of Public Works, a post listed at $10,000 a year in the city budget.

The American Labor bloc in the Assembly tonight joined hands with the Democrats in opposing two Republican bills which will extend for another year the time in which up-State communities must install voting machines.

The long filibuster in the Senate over the Anti-Lynching Bill was interrupted yesterday when Mr. Wagner brought in a conference report on the new Housing Bill which bears his name. Disagreement on one principal point has been delaying action on it.

The Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation's new common stock of 50 cents par value has been admitted to listing on the New York Curb Exchange in lieu of the old common stock of no par value, which has been suspended from dealings.

Members of the "rank and file" of small business men invited to confer with President Roosevelt in Washington tomorrow, many of whom expressed disapproval of Sunday's meeting of retailers, met yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker to discuss their problems and form their own organization.

Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d entertrained at luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton yesterday for Mrs. Lee Delafield, Mrs. Sidney Dillon Ripley and Mrs. Philip W. Lennen. Mrs. Reginald D. Lanier also was a luncheon hostess in the Oval Room.

The Treasury sold today its issue of ninety-one-day bills at an average interest rate of 0.084 per cent, compared with 0.103 per cent for the issue sold last week and 0.111 per cent for the issue before that, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

A deft putting touch on the first nine holes enabled Frederick C. Painton of Westport, Conn., to win medal honors today in the eleventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Club. Painton carded 36, 40-76.

3d Ave. 953-55, 5-story structure, 50x90; City Bank Farmers Trust Co. trustee, against estate of Bradish Johnson; due, $369,197; to plaintiff for $300,000. By GEORGE P. SINNOTT 17th St, 510 E, 5-story tenement, 25.9x92; Matthew M. Green against Julia A. Green; due, partition: sub to mtg, $5,700; to plaintiff for $7,700.

On their own applications: To take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 31. PATROLMEN Thomas O'Connor, 20th Precinct, at $1,500 per year. Appointed June 15, 1909. Louis FitzGerald, 32d Precinct, at $1,500 per year. Appointed Nov. 5. 1910. John Healy, Traffic Precinct C, at $1,500 per year. Appointed April 11, 1905.
The School Art League yesterday awarded scholarships and medals to students in the city schools for excellence in art. The - exercises were held at the Whitney Museum of American Art,

Samuel Zemurray was elected president of the United Fruit Company yesterday at a meeting of directors in Boston. He succeeds the late Francis R. Hart. T. Jefferson Coolidge, a director, was named to the new post of chairman of the board of directors.

The International Bobsleigh Union today awarded the 1993 championships to Switzerland and Italy, postponing until 1942 the decision to hold the title matches in the United States. Because of the long trip to Tokyo for ,the 1940 O1lympics,

A new draft of the bill providing for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a national self-regulatory association or associations of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market, intended to meet objections raised by some of the investment bankers to the bill in its original form has been proposed by Senator Maloney of Connecticut and will be ready when hearings begin tomorrow before a Senate committee.

As the Yankees are the world champions ofbaseball, the Detroit Red Wings are the world champions of hockey. A couple of weeks ago the Red Wings, with their plumes somewhat bedraggled, fluttered through this territory, and their manager, stout Jack Adams, was heard muttering that the Toronto Maple Leafs had the strongest outfit on skates.

The Rev. Dr. A. J. MacKenzie of the Brewster-Pilgrim Congregational Church, Detroit, has accepted a call to be-pastor of Union Congregational 'Church, 115th Street near Jamaica Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, it was announced yesterday. He will assume his duties March 15, succeeding the State of Rev. Dr. Edward Weeks Cross, who left last June to become pastor of the First Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass. courses.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color Facts," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; print galleries (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Elements of Design," Grace Cornell. 3 P. M.; "China: Back of the Great Wall," Mabel Harrison Duncan.

A ten-acre tract of land in Washington Valley, near Morristown, N. J., was sold by Lyman D. Oberlin to Charles B. Drew of East Orange. The property is partly wooded and contains a swimming pool and tennis court. Eugene V. Welsh, broker, negotiated the sale.

The activities heretofore carried on by Edwin Farnham Greene, Inc., and McCord, Inc., have been consolidated and will be continued under the name of Edwin Farnham Greene-McCord Corporation, with Edwin Farnham Greene as chairman of the board and treasurer and H. M. McCord as president, it was announced yesterday.

A program of color fastness identification for textiles was announced by the Better Fabrics Testing Bureau of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in a joint statement issued yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the N. R. D. G. A.
Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury's understandings with Mexico and Canada on silver purchases had been extended to February, but that no purchase arrangements had yet been made.

Welker Cochran of San Francisco tonight held a commanding lead, 600 to 261, over Jake Schaefer of Chicago, the defending champion, at the end of the second block of their 3,600-point ??18.2 balkline billiard match for the world title.

A number of stockholders of Tudor City Seventh Unit, Inc., the corporation which owns the thirtytwo story Woodstock Tower apartment building, have formed a stockholders protective committee, it was revealed yesterday.

The second for this season of the Yorkville Dinner Dances will take place tonight at the RitzCarlton. Mrs. Grosvenor Farwell is chairman of the dances, which have been given for many years to raise funds for the social center

John Woodruff of Pitt, the Olympic 800-meter champion, yesterday was added to the field for the special half mile at the Millrose A. A. indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. That brought the number of entrants in the race to six.
Railroad men, appearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission today, asked for the right to increase freight and passenger rates.
Col. Gen. Her- turned to mann Goering in his capacity as Minister of Economics created today a Military Economy Council, which may be regarded as Germany's new economic general staff.

Departing again from his practice of keeping out of State political situations, President Roosevelt gave further indication today of his desire to see Senator Barkley of Kentucky returned to the Senate, of which he is the majority leader.

The requirements of consumers and employes must be satisfied before stockholders are considered William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries (ballbearing), told the National Management Council last night at the Hotel Astor.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Fred H. Rees, Charles J. W. Meisel and Harold Sacher, New York, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: Mr. Stanley Reed of Kentucky took the oath of office as associate justice of the Supreme Court.

Mrs. Roger W. Straus will give a breakfast this morning at her home, 6 East Ninety-third Street, for ninety women interested in planning the extension of interfaith amity, under the auspices of the Women's Committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

Through the cooperation of Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, the Metropolitan Opera Guild will offer a second dress-rehearsal to its members on Monday morning, Feb. 28. The opera will be "Amelia Goes to the Ball," by Gian-Carlo Menotti, young Italian-American composer.
Leo Freisinger of Chicago won a, speed skating meet here yester,, capturing two of the races to Urnpile a total of 195.227 points.

The Rev. William J. Wright, former president of Phillips University, Enid, Okla., died here today. His age was 73. He once served as national secretary of the Missionary Alliance of the Christian Church.

State Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the administration and enforcement of the law, announced yesterday it would hold hearings beginning Thursday on the city's system of lunacy commissions.
Open-market money rates continued unchanged in January, with Stock Exchange call loans at 1 per cent and Curb Exchange call loans at 1 1/2 per cent, where both have been since May, 1936.

E. J. Lever, field director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said tonight that the strikers at the local plant of the Crucible Steel Company of America had voted tonight to approve a settlement he made with the company but refused to return to work until twelve "strikebreakers" were discharged.

Business on the stock market here was restricted today, reflecting recent influences from Wall Street, but its tendency was hopeful. Gilt-edge issues were weaker, while among the foreign loans Japanese bonds lost ground. Transatlantic stocks improved after early weakness and United States Steel and International Nickel recovered.

Tenure rights of a public school teacher cannot be circumvented by employing her on a per diemn basis, the Supreme Court held here today in directing Jersey City to reinstate Miss Margaret M. Wall with payment of salary to which she is entitled from Feb. 1, 1936.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/2c; sales, 37 barrels; receipts, 105 barrels; shipments, 157 barrels; stock, 28,123 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 223; receipts, 1,625; shipments, 550; stock, 74,694. Quote: B, D, E, $4.60; F, $5.60: G, $5.65: H, I, K, $5.75: M, $5.90; N, $6.00; WG $7.05; WW, X, $7.75.

Returning to home ice following a road stand which saw them win, lose and draw in three contests, Lester Patrick's New York Rangers will tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BENEDICT, MARGARET (Jan.. 6). Estate, about $1,100. To Elizabeth G. Lambert. executrix, 655 W. 190th St. BERGMAN, LEIB (Jan. 7). Estate, $7,000. To Zipre Bergman, Widow. 199 E. 7th St., Sam Bergman, 610 W. 150th St., Firma Weiner, 230 W. 76th St., children, and Leiser W. Bergman, son and executor, 1,569 E. 8th St., Brooklyn, residue equally. Wolf Albin, 1 Pike St., executor.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 31, unless specified: At Naval Operatnig Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, Jan. 29; Owl, Jan. 30: Henderson. San Diego to San Pedro: Bobolink, Partridge. Bagley, Rockland, Me., to Norfolk Yard, Jan. 30.

A joint legislative committee submitted tonight, with bipartisan support, a program which would extend until 1940, with minor modifications, the present moratorium on real estate foreclosures and deficiency judgments.

Domestid manufacturers of iron and steel products had one of their biggest foreign trade years in 1937 according to preliminary statistics made public today by the Department of Commerce. Japan was the leading market.
Several parties are to be given for Miss Marjorie Bywater, daughter of Selwyn Bywater of Belle Haven, who will be wed to James Benjamin Adams Jr. of New York on Feb. 17.

Since its original unemployment insurance law was passed, New York State has extended the coverage of the law more than once. At the beginning it applied only to "manual" workers earning $50 a week or less.

President Roosevelt signed today a bill to increase the authorized number of medical officers in the army by 100 and the number of dental officers by 50. The increases will bring the total of doctors up to almost 1,200 and the dental officers total to about 260.

Diamond-mounted badges were presented last night to three members of the Fingerprint Bureau of the City Magistrates Courts by their associates, in recognition of the completion of twenty-five years with -the bureau.

Sales and advertising conferences held since the start of the year have placed chief emphasis on the fact that business this year "will be harder to get" and accordingly, selling strategy has been mapped with this viewpoint dominant, sales executives remarked yesterday. They pointed out, however, that they have encountered some difficulty in getting top executives and boards of directors to approve increased advertising promotional effort on this basis.

BRENNER, JOSEPH G. (Jan. 1, 1937). Gross assets, $68,297; net, $57,566. To Walter H. Leonard, Jean Leonard, Edward Stern, Alfred Stern, nephews and niece, Ross Galligan and William B. Martin, $5,000 each; Hebrew Orphan Asylum, Trudeau Sanitarium, New Rochelle Hospital.

Lucie Bigelow Rosen continues to serve as a high priestess of the electrical instrument that Theremin developed and that bears his name. She appeared in recital last night and disclosed a growing mastery of the technical and interpretative problems posed by the Theremin.
Royal T. Hodgkins, connected with the automobile industry since 1914, died today at his home in the Wychwood Apartments here after an illness of four months. He was 59 years old.

Mayor La Guardia and Correction Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick joined in paying tribute last night to Miss Mary A. Frasca, appointed recently by the Mayor to the City Parole Commission, at a dinner given in her honor by the Women's City Club at its headquarters, 20 West Fifty-first Street.

The estate containing an eighteen-room house and three acres of land formerly owned by Mrs. Deborah L. Kimball at New London, Conn., has been purchased by the Interstate Investment Corporation of Massachusetts.

The sudden announcement of Jim Braddock's retirement from boxing complicated plans In several directions yesterday for Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. Of course, the proposal to have Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight chainpion,

Uneasiness over the progress of the British rearmament program will cast a shadow over Parliament when the two houses re-assemble tomorrow after a six weeks' recess. Dissatisfaction is not likely to come into the open, however, until the first of the defense estimates is debated at the end of February.

Inspired by new civil air regulations requiring all planes flying in bad weather to be equipped with radio transmitters and receivers, the leading manufacturers of radio equipment were showing new transmitters and receivers especially designed for private airplane owners at the International Air Show here today.

There are several reasons why the President, with his astute perception of public relations values, might well decide not to impose on his forthcoming conference with representatives of "small" business the rule he applied to his meetings with the Lamont-Young-Lewis, etc., group and the Business Advisory Council.

The number of New York State. employers electing to insure their workmen's compensation liability in the State Insurance Fund has more than doubled in the last five years, Charles Gordon Smith, manager, announced yesterday.

An alleged city-wide workmen's compensation insurance fraud said to have cost the State Insurance Fund and private insurance companies about $1,000,000 annually was revealed yesterday as seven Brooklyn lathing contractors pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to charges of falsely certifying their payrolls in order to reduce insurance premiums.

Fifteen men, one of whom displayed a membership card in the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. 0. affiliate, with offices at 45 Astor Place, invaded the plant of the Eastern Yarn Mills, Inc., at 205 West Nineteenth Street,

Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis entertained today with cocktails at the Breakers, for the Finnish minister, Eero Jarnefelt, and Mme. Jarnefelt. Among the other guests were Mrs. Thomas Richard Coweli, J Miss Alexandra Harvie-Aitken,

A supper dance will be given on Feb. 25 at Sherry's under the auspices of the Junior Committee of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association. Plans for the event will be discussed at a meeting to be held today at the home of Mrs. George H. Dayton, 11 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn.

Richard Strauss's "Elektra" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the third time this season, as the tenth week began, and again it attracted a special audience of eager, knowing listeners.

Mrs. Jane Coffin Childs, in whose memory a cancer research fund reported at $10,000,000 was given to Yale University, left a net estate of $4,783,181 when she died Oct. 31, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Her husband, Starling W. Childs, donor of the fund, three sons and a daughter are the principal beneficiaries.

The Navy Ministry disclosed today that France's 1938 naval building program was being enlarged as a result of the world armament race. William Bertrand, Minister of the Navy, said he would place the new program before the Cabinet at the earliest opportunity and recommend its approval.

After sidetracking the filibuster on the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill, the Senate today took up the Wagner Housing Bill conference report, only to precipitate a four-hour debate which continued until Senator Barkley, majority leader, moved a recess until noon tomorrow.

The nineteenth annual convention crease of the New York Province' of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs will be held for three days, beginning Friday, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and St. Patrick's Cathedral. Three thousand young men and women, members of twentyseven Newman Clubs in nineteen secular colleges in the metropolitan area, will attend.

New York's alcoholic beverage tax receipts in 1987 were the highest for any year since repeal, Mark Graves, Tax Commissioner, announced today. A total of $26,258,107.02 was received. While beer and other fermented malt beverages topped all others in gallonage, liquor of more than 24 per cent alcohol brought the greatest amount of revenue to the State.

A compilation of construction costs in thirty representative American cities based upon 100 for the year 1913, shows a figure of 184 for December of last year, according to the construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company.

Controller Joseph D. MCGoldrick announced yesterday that all employes on the payroll of the City Clerk, with the exception of Robert L. Tudor and Councilman John Cashmore, will be paid on schedule for the second half of January.

The texts of the opinions of the Supreme Court in the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation and the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company cases involving the right of the Federal courts to enjoin proceedings of the National Loabor Relations Board are as follows:

Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk who resigned from that office under fire and was later indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn for harboring a fugitive from justice, testified yesterday for the second time before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan which is investigating the so-called RubensRobinson fake passport ring.

Contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday included one for offices on the seventeenth floor of the International Building in Rockefeller Center taken by the Government of Puerto Rico for its Institute of Tourism.

The executive P committee of the National Council of Methodist Youth asserted today it would not support the government in a Far Eastern war. "It will not be our war," the committee said in a letter to President Roosevelt. "We cannot fight in it."

Macmillan expects soon to receive from England, for publication here, a reference book, "Proverbs of All Nations," edited by Guerney Champion. The book contains approximately 25,000 proverbs from thirty geographical and linguistic sources: Albanian, Basque, British, Corsican, French, German, Icelandic, Latin, Livonian, Maltese, Russian, etc. The publishers say the book has been in preparation twenty years. It will probably be ready early in March.

Thousands of out-of-town retail buyers began to fill Chicago hotels today, the first day of the thirty-second semiannual Interstate Merchants Council convention, at which 2,000 Chicago wholesalers and manufacturers of dry goods, clothing and general merchandise, and 800 outof-town firms are exhibiting their wares this week.

Several thousand persons including Governor A. Harry Moore and the entire New Jersey Congressional delegation paid a final tribute this morning to Representative Edward A. Kenney of the Ninth district, who died last Friday in Washington.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 26: a decrease of $43,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, and an increase-of $33,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations;

Crown Princess Juliana gave birth to a daughter this morning. The Netherlands generally would have hailed a son most enthusiastically, but this country has been ruled so satisfactorily by Queen Wilhelmina that there is really no disappointment, as is shown by the nation-wide rejoicing.

Two opinions sustaining some important challenged powers of the National Labor Relations Board were handed down by the Supreme Court today. Read by Justice Brandeis, they held that Federal District Courts could not enjoin hearings by the Labor Board because Congress had given exclusive power to the board and appellate courts to enforce the Wagner act.

Playing in defense of the laurels she has won for the past two years, Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis finished in a triple tie or the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf tournament today.

The British steamship Endymion has been sunk by a torpedo off the eastern Spanish coast. Eleven persons were lost, including two of the vessel's officers and a Swedish non-intervention control officer. Spanish craft rescued others. [Page 1.]
Iona Prep gained a 36-to-30 basketball victory over St. Joseph's School for the Deaf yesterday on the St. Joseph's floor. At the half the quintets were tied, 16--all.

Argentina's foreign trade in 1937 amounted to 3,865,979,000 pesos, approximately $1,288,000,000, an increase of 39.4 per cent over that of 1936, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. The favorable trade balance for the year was 750,610,000 pesos, about $250,000,000, as compared with 539,000,000 pesos, about $146,000,000, in 1936.
A creditors' committee of the defunct banking firm of Clarke Brothers, which closed its doors in 1929 with a loss of $5,000,000 to its depositors, purchased all the bank's assets yesterday for $1.

John Henry Lewis, world light-heavyweight champion, easily defeated Emil Scholz, German heavyweight, tonight in their ten-round fight. Lewis weighed 185 and his rival 193 pounds. Scholz was far too slow for his opponent.

President Roosevelt told a visiting group of more than 200 Protestant ministers today that America "owes a duty to the rest of the world." He declared that the nation, according to reports from all creeds, had made "definite and distinct progress toward a spiritual reawakening" in the past four years, adding:

Pilgram Ave (15-4162), w s, 211 ft a of Buhre Ave, 138x128; Benjamin Zimmerman to Adams Management Corp, 292 Madison Ave. Morris Ave (11-2806), n e cor of 177th St, 100x80; also 177th St, n s, 85 ft e of Morris Ave, 30x100; 105 Realty Corp to 177 Realty Corp, 1,457 Boscobel Ave.

New securities offered to the public here in January were in the smallest volume since last November and sharply below the total of January last year. Offerings of bonds last month were the smallest for that period since 1934, while stock offerings were the smallest since 1935.

Van Lingle Mungo, fireball pitcher of the Dodgers, positively will remain in Brooklyn this year, Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the club, announced last night, putting an end to reports of trades involving the big right-hander and rumors that persisted despite the announcement of Mungo's signing last week.

Heim's style collection is as gay as the Fourth of July with red, white and blue gone frivolous in the eighteenth century manner. The silhouette emphasizes both bosom and hips, the former with drapery and the latter with jutting basques or small crinolines. Louis XVI influences-are many.

Senator Johnson today asked that the Senate request the President to give it a definition of administration foreign policy. "No man should have the right to decide in secrecy the foreign policies of the nation," he said.

The first move looking toward the reorganization of the administrative set-up of the New York Stock Exchange along the lines proposed by the committee headed by C. C. Conway was taken late yesterday when Charles R. Gay, president, appointed a committee of three members to draw up amendments to the constitution giving effect to the recommendations contained in the report.

President Butler was saying two or three years ago that we may well be on the point of witnessing a movement toward the federation of higher education and that in different parts of our country outstanding universities will become each the center and inspiration of a group of near-by colleges, "all of which, while retaining their separate individuality, gain new strength and multiplied opportunity."

The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company applied today to the Interstate, Commerce Commission for authority to issue short-term unsecured notes in the amount of $250,000, at the rate of interest not to exceed 6 per cent.

A plan of recapitalization for the Birmingham Gas Company, which has been approved by the Alabama Public Service Commission, is to be sent today to holders of notes and preferred shares of the company and to holders of debentures of the American Gas and Power Company. the parent company.
Having exhausted all the invectives in their respective languages, the Bolsheviki and the National Socialists are now taking to doggerel in order to express what they think of one another.

A combination of domestic mill and foreign buying stiffened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and gains of 9 to 13 points were registered. In one hour's trading, the list retraced more than 50 per cent of the ground lost last week.

After a month of government exchange control, with the uncertainties and headaches it has caused among importers because of the exchange embargo put on import bills, the Brazilian exchange outlook was brighter today.
Clarke G. Dailey, president of the New York Real Estate Board, yesterday endorsed Mayor La Guardia's proposal on slum clearance.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell of Flushing, City Superintendent of Schools, and Miss Mildred I. Freygang of Manhattan were married yesterday afternoon in the parsonage of the First Reformed Church of Flushing, by the minister, the Rev. Dr. Thomas Hannah Mackenzie.

Wheat prices were on the up-grade today, due largely to buying induced by the failure of predicted moisture to materialize in the Southwest over the week-end. New crop months led the advance. reversing their action of Saturday.

The police round-up that netted 1,147 prisoners Saturday and Sunday abated last night with Commissioner Valentine's men still apparently unable to locate a key figure in either of the recent major crimes that preceded the raids.

Fewer borrowers from savings, building and loan associations were behind with their payments on mortgages during 1937 than in any previous year since 1930, reports the United States Building and Loan League.

For improvement with a six-story apartment building to house sixtysix families, a vacant plot comprising 17,500 square feet on Gown Street in Forest Hills, L. I., has been purchased by Henry M. Weitzner of New York.
Tonight's major events: Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin, sonata recital, Metropolitan Opera House; Dessoff Choirs, Town Hall; Helsinki University Chorus, Carnegie Hall.

Unless all Hudson County-poll books and registry lists of the first ten districts of Jersey City are produced at the Essex County Court House in Newark by 10 o'clock tomorrow morning, the sergeant-atarms of the Assembly is under instructions to take State troopers to the office of Hudson County Registration Commissioner Charles F. Stoebling forthwith and obtain them.

Hyman Schorenstein, whose position as Kings County Commissioner of Records was one of the sixty-five abolished in Mayor La Guardia's 1938 budget, announced yesterday that he was retiring from that office today.
Dr. Harry Vanderbilt Wurdemann, authority on diseases of the eye, died yesterday after a two weeks' illness. His age was 72.

While the mundane folk worry about recessions and wars, the guardians of the Hayden Planetarium, more concerned with celestial affairs, acquired a worry of their own yesterday with the realization that there would be no new moon this month.

Parcel post is not Expected to break the longshoremen's strike, but today's mail arriving from New York was the largest ever received-more than 4,000 bags-much of it containing food and other small parceled supplies.

Secretary Morgenthau placed himself squarely behind the move to help small business men today, but voiced doubt of what form the aid should take, pointing out that three Federal agencies already are in a position to make loans to small business organizations.

Miss Mary S. Du Bois of Hartford, Conn., a retired New England school teacher, died of pneumonia here today at the home of her sister at the age of 70. Miss Du Bois was born in Randolph, Vt., a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Du Bois.

Most commodities advanced yesterday in moderate trading on the local markets. In the cash markets, wheat, cotton, rye, eggs, rubber and tin advanced, while corn, wool tops and quicksilver sold at new low prices, and oats, cocoa, lard and silk declined.

This has been a busy week, and disproves the theory that most of you seem to have regarding the easy and pleasant life led by the rod and gun writers. Several days we were in the field from dawn to dusk and then drove most of the night in order to reach another place where we could hunt from sun-up to sundown.

The law that requires that no marriage ceremony can be performed until seventy-two hours after the license has been issued was blamed yesterday by attaches of the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building for the sharp drop in the number of applications for licenses in the month of January.

Neither retail nor wholesale dress business last week showed any real improvement over the previous week and both fell below sales volume for the same week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the research department, Joint Board of the Dress and Waistmakers Union.

The realty transactions reported yesterday involved properties in many sections of the city. Several business parcels were among those changing hands. Carey Garage Corporation, which at present operates a large garage running through from Forty-seventh to Fory-eighth Street, bought the two buildings at 334-36 East Forty eighth Street.

The City Athletic Club team, playing at the Princeton Club, captured its eleventh victory in twelve engagements to strengthen its hold on first place in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis race yesterday. The league leaders triumphed easily, 4 'to 1.

By its decision in the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company case last week the Federal Trade Commission has cleared away doubts respecting the effectiveness of the Robinson-Patman act in curbing unfair brokerage allowances and inside discounts, J. K. Javits, counsel for the National Paper Trade Association of the United States, Inc., said here yesterday.
Arthur Theodore Gardner, for more than twenty years a teacher in the New York City school system, died at his home, 85-61 111th Street, Richmond Hill, on Sunday evening. He was 52 years old.

Commander W. R. Mason Field, U. S. N., retired, died here yesterday at the age of 75. A native of Virginia and son of General Charles W. Field of the Civil War, Commander Field was graduated from Annapolis in 1881.

The three-story apartment building with stores at 100-106 South Main Street, Port Chester, Westchester County, has been sold by the trustees of mortgage Series 47,419, to a client of Abraham Abel, broker, reports the Realty Mortgage Servicing Corporation.

A Polish engineer has invented a new type of oxygen tank and gas mask, claimed to be superior to the present devices, which a Polish manufacturer has undertaken to produce, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Warsaw made public today.

With the moving yesterday of the Adolescent Court in Brooklyn from its quarters in the Bay Ridge Court to the building formerly occupied by the Homicide Court at 31 Snyder Avenue, a new system of handling cases involving felonies was put into effect.
The Wickwire-Spencer Steel Company, for which final reorganization proceedings were ordered in Buffalo last Sept. 27, within thirty days or ten years after

Stockholders of the Cord Corporation will be asked at their annual meeting in Chicago on Feb. 11 to change the name of their company for a new title to be disclosed at the meeting, and to approve a reduction in authorized capital from $50,000,000 to $3,000,000, or from 10,000,000 shares of $5 par stock to 3,000,000 shares of $1 per stock.

A defeated even-money favorite in her previous start, Aces Wild brought about the defeat of an odds-on choice in the Kissimmee Purse at Hialeah Park today when she led from end to end to return $10.60 for $2 in the totalisator.

Bonbright Co., Inc., head a nation-wide underwriting group of fifty investment houses which will offer today $67,000,000 of securities of the Appalachian Electric Power Company-the largest single block of securities to be placed on the market in more than seven months.

Patrolman George A. Heidt, who had appeared as a defense witness at the vice trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and later was dismissed from the Police Department for failure to explain satisfactorily bank deposits of $74,500 in eight years, was reinstated yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against TUSCANY RESTAURANT CORP., 124 W. 48th St., by Dorato Cerutti, Inc., for $780; A. Tingaud Sons, $175; Wexler Bros., $535. Petitions Filed-By ABRAHAM M. DITCHIK, surgeon dentist, 284 Stanton St.-Liabilities, $1,540; no assets except insurance.
Laura Ben6t, author of "The Boy Shelley," has a new book entitled "The Hidden Valley" on the Dodd, Mead Spring list. The hidden valley is the Yosemite, and the story is laid there in 1800.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,357,650 barrels, compared with 3,506,200 in the preceding week, a drop of 148,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

A demand by Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the WPA Federal Theatre project, that project workers consider "new forms of staging," involving the elimination of painted scenery and costumes, brought a protest yesterday from the United Scenic Artists of America, Local 829, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
Frederick Schrader, a trombone player who had been a member of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Sousa's Band and other organizations, died today at his home here. Mr.

Efforts of twenty independent motion picture exhibitors to attack the system of "block booking" used by leading film distributors met defeat today when Federal Judge Leon Yankwich sustained a demurrer filed by Paramount Pictures Corporation.
