Recent sales of West Side properties appear to be bearing but realty forecasts that the area within' the zone of influence of the Lincoln Tunnel would take on new life as a result of the opening of this new link between midtown Manhattan and New Jersey.

The British Government tonight announced that King George had appointed Admiral Sir Roger Backhouse to be Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty and Chief of the Naval Staff. The appointment carries with it the post of First Sea Lord, the Admiralty explained.

The sinking of the British freighter Endymion with a loss of eleven lives, including three Britishers and the Swedish observer for the Non-Intervention Committee, is in itself only one more "incident" in the unsavory record of "non-intervention" in the peninsular war.
Responding to higher foreign prices and an advance in the basis on higher grades of cotton in the South, quotations on the Cotton Exchange improved for a time yesterday.

Tailors of the nation cast a practiced eye today over some of America's celebrities and measured up ten men including President Roosevelt, for sartorial honors. The President took top ranking among wearers of double-breasted dinner jackets.

The one-story showroom building, covering an area of approximately 30,000 square feet on Madison and Park Avenues, Paterson, N. J., has been purchased by the Coca Cola Bottling Company of New York. The building formerly was used as the Brogan-Cadillac showroom.

The Cortes [Parliament] held its semi-annual session today as the Constitution demands but under such conditions of secrecy and in such picturesque surroundings as to make it unique in Spanish history.

James Kemper of Kansas City has been elected to succeed his father, the late W. T. Kemper, on the boards of the Missouri Pacific, the New Orleans, Texas Mexico and the Texas Pacific Railroads, it was announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Downs of 50 Clinton Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret MacWinnie Downs, to Frank Thomas Jones, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Frank R. Jones of New York.

Lester A. Strasser of the City A. C.; seeded third, reached the fourth round of the Monte Sterling invitation squash tennis tournament at the New York A. C. courts yesterday. Forced-to an extra game by F. H. Merrill of the Princeton Club, Strasser rallied in the third chapter and carried off the match, 15-9, 3-15, 15-8.

A total of 2,690,000 tons of merchant ships was launched throughout the world last year, representing an increase of 573,000 tons, or more than 25 per cent in excess of the previous year's tonage, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday.
Supreme Court Justice Ellsworth C. Lawrence has issued a temporary injunction restraining the city of Plattsburg from issuing $360,000 in bonds to --finance a municipal power plant.

The desirab'lity of additional financing at this time by the sale of Treasury discount bills for cash in an amount in excess of that required to pay off weekly maturing issues of bills will be discussed on Thursday at a meeting of the executive committee of the open market committee of the Federal Reserve Board with Secretary Morgenthau.

Mrs. Ethel Folger White Remsen, the widow of Cornelius Wagstaff Remsen, a broker, died yesterday in her apartment at the Great Northern Hotel, 118 West Fiftyseventh Street, after a short illness. Mrs. Remsen was a member of several old New England families.

Representatives of the Photoengravers Board of Trade and the Photoengravers Union, Local 1, conferred yesterday at the office of the State Mediation Board, 366 Broadway, in an effort to settle the strike of 850 members of the union employed in commercial establishments.

The grand jury today served Thomas N. Cooke, Greenwich real estate man, with a new subpoena to appear with all his business and personal books and papers to testify Tuesday in the inquiry into the cost of Merritt Parkway. The first subpoena had not called for production of his records.

The Bank of Mexico in its monthly statement, published today, asserts the purchasing power of the Mexican people has been reduced 50 per cent in the past year, and it lays this to the circumstance that incomes have remained stationary whereas living costs have increased tremendously.

William Gillespie of Scarborough School, seeded No. 1, reached the fourth round ahead of the field in the De Witt Clinton interscholastic indoor tennis championship as play was resumed on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.

The Naval Academy, set to start baseball practice, is without a coach for that sport. Marty Karow, who joined the coaching staff of the Navy in :1936 as head baseball coach and. assistant with football and basketball, has resigned to accept a position at Texas A. and M.

The Midston House clinched first place in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association race yesterday by winning from. the New York A. C., by 3 to 2. The Winged Foot players still have undisputed possession of second place, but are being closely pressed by Jackson Heights and the City A. C., in a tie for third place.

The calling of a strike by employes does not absolve an employer from bargaining with the strikers collectively and making a bona fide effort to reach a compromise agreement with the strikers, the State Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday.

President Roosevelt saw his wife compete in a charity horse show at Fort Myer tonight. Mrs. Roosevelt was one of ninetysix contestants in the park or roadhack class. She failed to win a ribbon, but was among the ten riders from which four winners were selected.

Turpentine firm, 27c; sales 11 barrels; receipts 19 barrels; shipments 80 barrels; stock 28,062 barrels. Resin firm; sales 183; receipts 1,135; shipments 120; stock 75,709. Quote: B, D, $4.60; E. $4.65; F. $5.65; G, $5.70; H. I. K, $5.80; M, $5.95; N. $6.05; WG, $7.10; WW. X. $7.80. 10; WW. X. $7.80.

A protest against a bill introduced in Albany by Assemblyman Robert J. Crews has been made by the directors of the Westchester County Realty Board to the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County, on the ground that the bill provides for a merger of the parkway authorities in New York city and has the effect of pooling their bonds.

Frustration that came in bewildering forms on every side left an investigating committee of New Jersey legislators virtually exhausted as to legal resources last night in its attempt to get possession of Hudson County poll books, which still rest in the sealed vault of the Board of Elections office in Jersey City.
Projected new naval construction, including two 35,000-ton battleships, is expected to increase France's 1938 navy budget 50 per cent.

The Chorus Equity Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, has been ordered to answer charges of failing to organize the chorus girls of night clubs, it was disclosed' yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bascom of Monroe Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Marie Bascom, to Robert William Cowles Bascom, son of Judge and Mrs. Wyman S. Bascom of Fort Edward. N. Y.

A sharp, most unusual rebuke was administered to a British colonial government today when a commission that was appointed to investigate last June's riots in Trinidad blamed the Governor, Sir A. G. Murchison Fletcher, and his aides for improperly treating with the oil strikers and too lenient handling of the mob.
President Roosevelt announced he would call a conference to consider the plight of the railroads and remedial legislation;
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 29: CAPTAINS Clement, S. A., the Detroit, to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I., July 1.

Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York--Assets as of Dec. 31, totaled $1,349,057,256, an increase of $40,778,437 over the previous year. New insurance for the year amounted to $269,154,537, bringing the total insurance in force at the close of 1937 to $3,758,762,033.

The Helsinki University Chorus of Finland, Martti Turunen, conductor, gave its American farewell concert last night at Carnegie Hall. It was the end of its first American tour, undertaken under the auspices of the Intercollegiate Musical Cocil, and the honorary sponsorship of Jean Sibelius.

Five members of the Studio Club of the Y. W. C. A., 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, won first prizes yesterday in the annual art exhibitton, which win continue on view to the public for the remainder of the month.

A repetition of his demand that the Stock Exchanges reform and a suggestion that the financing of enterprises be transferred from New York to the communities in which they are located were the high spots of a talk tonight by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Because many fail to distinguish between the legally and medically indigent the problem of caring for the needy in sickness is not clearly understood. The legally indigent are the paupers who must be supported in good or bad health;

Dr. Charles Frederick D'Arcy, Protestant Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of Ireland, died today in his Armagh home at the age of 79. Archbishop D'Arcy had been Primate of the Church of Ireland since 1920.
Japanese forces northwest of Nanking moved forward today toward Suchow, strategic rail junation, after having been held at a standstill for nearly a month by Chinese resistance.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Feb.-2: SERGEANT-Henry Krantz Jr., from 50th Precinct to 40th Precinct. PATROLMEN-John F. Callahan, from 79th Precinct to 18th Division, designated as third grade detective.
Shuddering, clutching at his throat, covering and uncovering his face with his hands, Paul A. Wright told a jury today of the killing in his home of his wife, Evelyn, and his friend, John Kimmel.
The Senate Judiciary Committee delayed final action today on the nomination of Robert H. Jackson to be Solicitor General, pending completion of hearings by a subcommittee Monday.

The German civil service's official organ, in an article by Government Councilor Globke, has announced that probably in the near future an edict will be issued prohibiting giving German first names to Jewish children.

In an elaborate setting of blue, cerise and silver designed especially for the occasion, the first in a series of three performances of the new "Carnival Capers" for the benefit of Colony House was held last night in the ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The Rev. Dr. Levi Brimmer Salmans, Methodist Episcopal medical missionary, who founded the Good Samaritan Hospital at Guanajuato, Mexico, in 1891, and remained as its superintendent until his retirement in 1927, died Saturday in the Huntington Memorial Hospital, Pasadena, Calif.

About an hour after he had returned from his first day at school, Joseph Judeson, 6 years old, of 1,252 West Farms Road, the Bronx, was killed yesterday when he was struck by a truck driven along Home Avenue, about 50 feet east of Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx.
The Ad- in ministration housing bill received final congressional approval today When the Senate adopted by the tic close vote of 42 to 40 a conference report already approved by the House.

Among the seven Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms were two twelve-story apartment houses on West End Avenue. Both were bought in by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, for $350,000 each.

The old custom of expecting groundhogs to forecast an early or a late Spring on Feb. 2 is nearing its end. The Bronx Zoo, stronghold of the annual experiments, has tired of the practice and did not bother to let one of the animals hibernate outside this Winter. Dr. Raymond L.
Many reservations have been made for the luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Chi Kappa Club of Stony Wold, a unit of the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop, today at the Park Lane.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson tonight vetoed the 2 per cent. city sales tax ordinance while more than 2,500 indignant citizens at a town meeting at the Academy of Music were cheering denunciations of the tax.

A joint committee for improvement of relations between manufacturers and wholesalers will be set up in the next few weeks by the groups which prepared the program for the recent convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, it was learned yesterday.

David H. McAlpin Pyle was reelected president of the United Hospital Fund for the fourth successive term at a meeting of the trustees yesterday afternoon in the fund's headquarters at 370 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Pyle, an attorney, first became president of the organization Oct. 1, 1934.

The Attorney General's office collected $409,432 during 1937 for injured workers whose employers carried no compensation or where the insurance carrier was insolvent, according to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who made public the annual report of his labor bureau yesterday.

Governor Clarence S. Ridley, Governor of the Canal Zone, as president of the Panama Railroad Company today reestablished its real estate section, of which A. F. Morris was appointed chief in charge of all the real estate operations of the company.
The police of Jersey City today ended the attempts of C. I. O. organizers to distribute circulars by confiscating the papers and telling the distributors to "scram." They made no arrests.

As Rear Admiral David F. Sellers relinquished the superintendency of the Naval Academy to Rear Admiral Wilson Brown today he stated as his conviction that the regiment of midshipmen was the finest group of young men in the country.

The French liner Normandie, due here tomorrow night from Havre, will sail at 9 P. M., Saturday, for a South American cruise as far as Rio de Janeiro with more than 1,000 passengers, which will establish a record for numbers on a long cruise.

Fiske Warren, Boston paper manufacturer, internationally known for his advocacy of the single tax and his activities in behalf of independence for the Philippines, died here tonight at the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 75.

The suggestions which will be offered at President Roosevelt's conference of "smaller" business men today in Washington by the representatives of the Twenty-third Street Association stress the need for restoring the confidence of larger business organizations if the recession is to be halted.
A total of 49,215 persons moved to Queens last year, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.

Leon Barritt of 244 Adams Street, Brooklyn, publisher of The Evening Sky Map, an astronomical magazine, and inventor of the BarrittServiss star and planet finder, died yesterday in Brooklyn after a long illness. He was 86 years old.
Germain G. Glidden of the Harvard Club, national amateur squash racquets champion, began the defense of his metropolitan title last night at the University Club.
That unofficial watchdog of the city treasury, the Citizens Budget Commission, has just issued its annual report of things accomplished and its annual statement of objectives sought.

Elimination of the "hate psychology" between employer and employe and the further development of mutual policies based on confidence and friendliness are vitally needed now to foster better labor relations, speakers said yesterday at the labor relations session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, being held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Payrolls of the steel industry in the United States in 1937 set a new high record at $976,000,000, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday, or 16 per cent more than the $841,000,000 reported for 1929, although production of steel ingots last year was 9 per cent less than 1929, which was the peak year.

A $10,000 mortgage on 1,695 Lexington Ave., held by the East River Savings Bank from the Ell-Mor Operating Corp., Phil Cohen, president, was extended to Nov. 1, 1942, 4 per cent for the first three years, 41/2 for the last two.

A 15 per cent reduction in automobile insurance rates under the "Safe Driver Reward Plan" went into effect yesterday in twentyseven States and the District of Columbia, William Leslie, general manager of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, announced.

Voluntary cooperation on the part of manufacturers and retailers to give the consumer the information necessary for an intelligent selection of goods is the only way in which legislative action on the subject of factual labeling can be averted, Irving C. Fox, counsel to the National Retail Dry Goods Association, told the association yesterday.

Commercial and industrial failures for the week ended Jan. 27 were higher in four trade groups as compared with the same period last year, according to the weekly compilation issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The New York Curb Exchange has ruled that until further notice New York, Pennsylvania Ohio Railroad Company prior lien 4 per cent bonds due in 1950, with extension agreement attached, shall be dealt in flat and, to be a delivery, must carry March 1, 1938, and subsequent coupons.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint today against the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here on the basis of charges. filed by a C. I. O. affiliate that more than 1,400 of its members were ousted because of union activities.
J. J. Shaw, noted Birmingham seismologist, announced tonight that his instrument had recorded a "very severe but very distant" earthquake, probably in the bed of the Pacific Ocean.

Clarence Michel, a former vice president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, testified yesterday in the Supreme Court here that James M. Kurn, former president of the road, knew of a proposed purchase of 183,333 shares of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway stock in 1926 before the proposal was submitted to the executive committee.

Thirty scholarships are available for women interested in attending the women's law class at New York University during the Spring term, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the university division of General Education.

In naming Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, chief of army engineers, to be Commissioner of Public Works Mayor La Guardia has lived up to the excellent principle of picking the best available man for appointive public office.
William H. Himmelman, retired Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad drill master, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at his home here in his seventy-sixth year. A native of Germany, Mr.

Assertions that Alaska's salmon fishing Industry, producing $46,000,000 annually, is seriously threatened, the jobs of thousands of workers are endangered and private warefare in Bering Sea is possible .unless immediate action is taken to stop the Japanese from operating floating canneries in Bristol Bay, Alaska, were made before the House Fisheries and Merchant Marine Committee today.

Action by the League of Nations Council on the Sino-Japanese war was delayed another day when the delegates of Ecuador and Peru, at a private meeting today, asked for time to get instructions from their governments.

The entry of Italy into the Scandinavian Gold Cup yachting picture for next season was announced yesterday, thereby. making the sixmeter situation in this country more international in scope than ever.

The Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York will start a drive next month to raise $118,000 during the year, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Manhattan Council of Girl Scouts, 670 Lexington Avenue.

Two of the three metropolitan high school quintets which engaged college yearling teams yesterday came through with victories. At New Utrecht the home squad conquered the Long Island University freshman outfit, 26-24. The schoolboys won in the last minute when Rubin Golitsky caged a goal.
Defending World Champion Jake Schaefer of Chicago tonight led Welker Cochran of San Francisco, 1,200 to 1,021, at the end of the fourth block of their 3,600 point 18.2 balklinee match.
Throngs gathered today in every town and village of The Netherlands on the invitation of hundreds of "Orange committees" to celebrate the birth of a princess.
Jeremiah. T. Mahoney, defeated Democratic candidate for Mayor at the last election, will resume the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District.,

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in commenting on the recently issued $30,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York 3 1/2 per cent debentures, declared in a statement made public yesterday but dated Jan. 17,

Sidney M. Gottesman of Brooklyn was appointed yesterday as an assistant district attorney on the staff of William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney. He succeeds Ralph K. Jacobs, who recently resigned as head of the rackets bureau.
Not to be outdone by pins, needles and cradle-rockers, the commercial theatre is peeking into the welfare of laboring youngsters in "Sunup to Sundown," which was played at the Hudson last evening.

Dr. Clifford Walcott Kellogg, physician here for twenty years and for many years a New Haven practitioner, died at the Middlesex County Hospital last night of pneumonia. Born in Amherst, Mass., seventyseven years ago, he was a graduate of Yale and the Yale Medical School.
The list of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's new Nationalist [Insurgent] Cabinet, which he has decided to head himself as President, is published in today's official bulletin.

More than 300 persons attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon at the undertaking establishment of J. Wesley Lane, 112 West 133d Street, for Charles W. Anderson, a former collector of internal revenue for the Third District, New York, who died here on Friday at the age of 71.

Not a single artist survived the first round of match play for the eleventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. This situation exists for the first time in the history of the tourney.

Forest Rutherford, consulting engineer in mining and metallurgy, with offices at 50 Broad Street, died yesterday at the New York Hospital after a brief illness. His home was at 33 Fifth Avenue. He was 66 years old.
An attacking fleet steamed across the South China Sea tonight in a simulated assault on Great Britain's Far Eastern stronghold here.

The stock market here was quiet and generally firm today. Gilt-edge issues improved, while among the foreign loans Brazilian bonds advanced. Transatlantic stocks reacted to yesterday's upturn in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel were in good demand.
Judge William Morley Cain, Associate Professor of Law at Notre Dame University, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. He was 66 years old.

The value of the collateral behind the three bond issues of the Alleghany Corporation declined since Dec. 2, according to an appraisal as of Jan. 31 made public yesterday by the Guaranty Trust Company.

James B. Finger, in 1,212 5th Ave; Mrs. Lillian G. Walker, in 277 Park Ave; John L. Montgomery, in 157 E 72d St: Mrs. Elizabeth Runnell, in 32 E 65th St; Pease Elliman, Inc, broker. George K. Livermore, in .950 Park Ave; W. Dixon Kramer, in 19 W 55th St;

After an acrimonious three-hour session yesterday in which personalities flew thick and fast, the City Council adopted a resolution naming a committee of five Councilmen to investigate the validity of the election of Councilman Hugh Quinn from Queens last Fall.
The White Sewing Machine Corporation's directors today authorized the officers to submit to shareholders a plan for readjusting the company's capital structure.

As both houses of the Legislature worked on the calendars and advanced several bills toward enactment, legislative leaders today remained confident that they would be able to wind up the work of the current session about March 15.

The 1937 toll in this country was 106,000 dead, 375,000 permanently injured and 9,400,000 temporarily injured, according to figures issued today by the National Safety Council, which estimated the cost of "this gruesome jamboree of carelessness" at $3,700,000,000.

Dr. John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent of Schools, died early yesterday morning in his home, 340 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. A member of the New York school system for forty-two years, he had been assigned to the junior and senior high school division. His age was 61.

Two ironworkers were killed instantly and a third was fatally injured at 3:40 P. M. yesterday when they fell forty-five feet from the main deck to the bottom hold of the steamship Yucatan, berthed at Pier 14, East River, at the foot of Pine Street.
A conflict apparently has arisen between permanent officials of the Finance Ministry's Alcohol Department and the Goga Cabinet regarding withdrawal of licenses of Jewish innkeepers.

The Maritime Commission today opened bids on the largest individual peacetime merchant ship order ever placed in this country. An unofficial estimate of the bids was that they set construction prices of $275 to $325 a ton, which impressed some of the commission aides as prohibitive.

The form of arbitration stipulated by the New York shipping heads, that temporarily elated local agents as offering a means of sure solution of the waterfront blockade, today became the cause of new entanglements with the strikers, leaving the controversy more hopelessly involved than ever.

The $800,000,000 naval building program proposed by President Roosevelt contemplates a navy adequate to protect the nation on only one ocean, Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, testified before the House Committee on Naval Affairs today.

Despite the recession in business toward the end of the year and increased operating expenses, the F. W. Woolworth Company had in 1937 larger earnings than in the previous year, C. S. Woolworth, chairman, and C. W. Deyo, president, said in a joint statement accompanying the annual report, issued yesterday.

Deaths Announced Retired Captain Benjamin C. Curren, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 27, residing at 619 28th Ave., San Francisco, Calif., died Jan. 31. Retired Fireman Herman Link, formerly a member of Engine Co, 207, residing at 47-13 Smart St., Flushing, died Jan. 30.
Labor leaders urged today immediate passage of the National Textile Bill to establish a forty-hour maximum week and a $15 minimum weekly wage for 1,250,000 employes.
George A. Munger, head football coach of the University of Pennsylvania, today virtually completed his coaching staff by naming four moreassistants.

In carefully weighed words Paul Marchandeau, the new French Minister of Finance, in a speech broadcast from Chalonssur-Marne last evening warned his countrymen that, while it was the intention of the government to continue the effort to keep the franc free from exchange control and within the tripartite agreement, more than a simple declaration of intention was needed.

The 136th semester of Hunter College will begin this week with the registration of 7,000 students. Juniors and seniors will register today in the buildings at 2 Park Avenue and Lexington Avenue and Sixtyeighth Street, and sophomores and upper freshmen will meet at the same time in the Bronx division of the college at Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard.

House of Representatives passed and sent to Governor E. D. livers today a local option bill repealing Georgia's twenty-year-old dry law. The vote was 105 to 85, the majority being two more than the constitutional requirement of 103 votes.

Mrs. Bertha Newby, wife of Briga- Ir dier Henry Newby of the Salvation D Army, died on Sunday at their home, 2,227 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn. A native of Cleveland, Mrs. Newby was long active in the Salvation Army, which she entered in 1911. Her age was 45.
Two different attacks on depression psychology were launched yesterday by two large companies in the appliance and refrigeration field.

A net increase of more than 10,000 licenses in New York City, as compared with the same day of last year, was reported yesterday by the office of Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, after a check-up of figures for Monday, the final day of application.
Mr. and Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick will give a dinner on Saturday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their niece, Miss Eileen Herrick, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Herrick.

Utility Equities Corporation-As of Dec. 31: Based on market prices on Dec. 31, net assets amounted to $6,737,536, equal to $74.86 a share of priority stock. This compared with net assets of $11,874,761 or $129.07 a share of priority stock the year before.

British airplanes today bombarded a desperate band of Arabs surrqunded on a heavily wooded hill near Haifa. It was believed that at least fifteen of the 100 Arabs estimated to be in the band were killed or wounded.

A victim or du Ran almost incredible series of misfortunes, Oxford University paid today [Pound]70,000 to a group of persons or claiming over ten times that tor amount as the "dupes" of the university's first Director of Research in Agricultural Engineering.

The belief that the Communists and the Kuomintang [Chinese National party] could cooperate harmoniously under Kuomintang leadership, not only against the Japanese but also in internal political and economic matters, unless "the Communists returned to the policy of class struggle in achieving their aims," was expressed today by Dr. Wang Chingwei, chairman of Kuomintang Central Political Council.

In one of the most thrilling games seen in the Fordham gymnasium in years, Fordham defeated Georgetown last night in a five-minute overtime period, 38-36. Baskets by Dutch Weil and Jack Welch won for the Rams.

Daniel J. Doherty of Woburn, Mass., came back to New York City yesterday for his first visit since his election as national commander of the American Legion at the convention here in September. He was greeted officially by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall and by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll at Brooklyn Borough Hall.
The preliminary report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after expenses and charges, of $15,124,835.
The spokesmen of "little business" who are. to meet with the President today are necessarily a more varied group than the spokesmen of "big business" who preceded them.

Shipments of 1,642,019 household washers and 178,858 ironers in 1937, a total of 1,820,877 home laundering appliances, were reported by J. R. Bohnen, secretary of the American Washing Machine Manufacturers Association.
France has taken the initiative to get the powers to use their influence to obtain a suspension of air bombardments of the civilian population of Spain.

A bill calling for pensions of widows and orphans of World War veterans was reported favorably to the House today by its, Pensions Committee, The report was. unanimous, although several- members were absent and did not vote.

A two-year peace in the millinery industry of this city was assured yesterday with the announcement of the signing of an agreement between the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union and its affiliates in the millinery trade and the Eastern Women's Headwear Association.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Comstock, daughter of Mrs. Eliot M. Comstock of this place and the late Mr. Comstock, to Francis W. Cole Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Cole of Hartford, will take place on Feb. 12 at the home of the brideelect's mother.

Davey Kerr's masterful exhibition of goal tending for the Rangers last night seemed just about tc produce a shut-out triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

John L. Lewis, at a conference with Democratic leaders of Pennsylvania here last night, insisted on his demand that Thomas Kennedy, Lieutenant Governor, and secretarytreasurer of the United Mine Workers, be designated for Governor this Fall.

ITS nothing new to find a couple of baseball managers in more or less warm conference at the plate, but this time there were four such characters in the gathering. Mr..Casey Stengel of Boston, however, was the one in the dangerous position It was his plate and it was pretty well stocked with victuals.

President Roosevelt was urged today by the United Automobile Workers of America to sponsor 'legislation to take control of the nation's basic industries out of the hands of their present managers, to limit profits and reduce prices, prohibit the restriction of production and provide complete re-employment by raising rates of pay and shortening hours of labor.

The United States Steel Corporation has borrowed $50,000,000 from banks in New York, Chicago and Pittsburgh on notes maturing in one, two and three years respec tively, in anticipation of substantial cash outlays for construction nnw in- progress.

Marie Dainton, well known stage mimic, died today after a short illness at the age of fifty-six. Although she had made a fortune on the stock exchange in addition to that made in her stage successes, she had been longing to return to the theatre and was actually discussing a proposed engagement at the Comedy when stricken.

Philip A. Johnson, president of the Aspinook Company, announced today confirmation of a contract disposing of the longclosed finishing plant here to B. R. Armour of New York, head of a group that recently pledged $500,000 to bring about reopening of the factory by March 1.

Representative Byron N. Scott of California introduced a resolution today calling upon President Roosevelt to place an immediate embargo on shipment of war materials to Italy and Germany for as long as the Spanish civil war continues.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 2, Special Orders 276, dated Nov. 29, 1937, as continues First Lieutenant Everell W. Diller, Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until June 17, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 13.

Miss Margaret Van Doren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Van Doren of this city, will be married on Saturday to Tom Torre Bevans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Bevans, also of New York, at the prospective bride's home, 123 West Eleventh Street.

Reports of the death of a man and two women, all Americans, and of a Frenchman at the hands of Japanese soldiers at Yangchuan in Shansi in December were conveyed to the United States Embassy here Tuesday in a message from Captain Evans Carlson, a United States Marine Corps intelligence officer, who is traveling in Shansi.

As both Brandywine Shares and Trustee Standard Utility Shares, fixed investment trusts, have been terminated, they have been stricken from the list of such trusts which the New York Stock Exchange finds unobjectionable as to membership association.
The deportation of Carl Ohm; 30-year-old German-born anti-Nazi, has been stayed by an order of the Commissioner of Immigration in Washington, pending an appeal, it was learned yesterday.

Abolition of the present system of lunacy commissions and the establishment of a five-man State lunacy authority which would determine all cases of insanity was advocated in a bill submitted in the Senate today by John J. McNaboe, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the administration and enforcement of the law.

Al Reid, 127, Bronx, defeated Johnny Defoe, 1261/2, West Side, in the main eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night. In the second round Reid caught Defoe, with a hard right to the jaw which floored him for a count of nine.

The controversy between the Transport Workers Union and the Board of Transportation over collective bargaining had its echo in the Legislature today when two Democrats intro- gra duced bills that would put the employes of the city's Independent subway system under the jurisdiction of the State Labor Relations Board.

Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, whose voice is familiar to thousands of metropolitan housewives . (and tradesmen) who listen to the Department of Markets food broadcast on weekday mornings, opened the department's Brooklyn Cooking School yesterday at Glenwood Road and Bedford Avenue with the first of a series of semi-weekly afternoon classes.

Tilford Dudley, trial examiner National Labor Relations Board, recommended today that' the Union Drawn Steel Company of Beaver Falls, Pa., "cease" its support of an independent union, reinstate five discharged employes and dismiss an employee.

Henry Armstrong, world's featherWeight champion, scored a technical knockout in the third round of a ten-round bout tonight over Chalky Wright, Los Angeles Negro, before an overflow crowd of 10,400 at the Olympic Auditorium. Armstrong weighed 1301/2. Wright 1281/4.

The Citizens Budget Commission, presenting its report for 1937, lists seven items that cause needless spending of city funds and offer opportunities for economies, and declares it will continue its efforts to reduce unnecessary costs in these fields.
The Grace liner Santa Paula arrived from the Caribbean and South American ports yesterday with 155 passengers and three stowaways who sneaked on the ship at San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Charles F. Scott, editor and publisher of The Iola Daily Register, said today that Herbert Hoover told him recently he never had taken for his personal use any of the salary paid him while he was President, Secretary of Commerce, Food Administrator or director of the Belgian relief program.

Today's major events: Adolf Busch, violinist, and Rudolf Serkin, pianist, last Beethoven sonata recital, Town Hall, evening; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Dayton Ten-Piano Symphony, Carnegie Hall, evening;
The appointment of Dr. John H. Mulholland as assistant dean of New York University's College of Medicine was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

Despite the unfavorable financial conditions in the latter part of last year, the 1937 contributions for missions in- the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York totaled $326,497, or $7,190 more than the missionary gifts for 1936, Bishop William T. Manning announced last night at the fifty-first annual dinner of the Church Club of New York, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The government's policy of "not enlightening the people but demanding their blind confidence" was attacked today at a meeting of the Diet's budget committee.

Shipments of pneumatic tire casings in December amounted to 3,153,402 units, compared td 3,770,616 in November and 5,015,872 in December, 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Shipments for 1937 were 55,446,668, compared to 55,362,739 in 1936. Casings in the hands of manufacturers on Dec. 31 were 10,775,702, against 11,114,399 a year earlier.

Manhattan Alterations Bowery, 163; to 2-story offices and store; Louis Fish, 329 Broome St, owner; Philip Bardes, architect; cost, $8,000. Pleasant Ave, 409; to 4-story tenement; Angelo de Louise, premises, owner; Frank Straub, architect; cost, $4,000.

The Cargill Grain Company of Illinois and its three principal officers were charged with willful manipulation of the corn market in and prior to September, last, in a report made public today by a special investigating committee of the Chicago Board of Trade.

Premier Camille Chautemps asked the Labor Commission of the Chamber of Deputies today for swift action on his labor code proposals. Unless the arbitration provisions in particular are voted before the month-end, he said, the government may be faced with labor disputes without an instrument for dealing with them.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 31, unless specified: At San Pedro: Brooks, Bobolink, Fox, Goff, Reuben James, Lexington, Partridge, Richmond, Saratoga. Sydney, Australia, to Singapore, Feb. 1: Memphis, Milwaukee, Trenton, Jan. 31.

Dr. William H. Hobbs, geologist, of Ann Arbor, Mich., told a gathering of scientists today that the United States, rather than England, should be credited with the discovery of Graham Land in the Antarctic in 1821.

Gold and silver mines in the United States and its Territories turned out $220,964,529 of the monetary metals in 1937, according to the Bureau of Mines. Gold production was 4,752,801 fine ounces, valued at $166,348,035, and silver, 70,838,514 fine ounces, valued at $54,616,494.

Although the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week, the total was slightly above the corresponding week a year ago for the first time this year, according to the listing in THE TIMES:
" If I Were King," sturdy fixture of the romantic school, will be brought to the screen by Frank Lloyd with Ronald Colman as the star. Basil Rathbone will be cast as Louis XI.

Scholarships with a total value of $1,850 have been awarded for the Spring session to fourteen men and two women students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, it was announced yesterdav by Dean Carl W. Ackerman.

Asserting that the matter of war and peace is of "vital concern" to all, the peace committee of the High School Teachers Association advocated yesterday that peace education be made a mandatory part of the school curriculum throughout the State.

J. B. Kincer, the nation's official weather recorder, agreed today with millions of other Americans that this Winter is unusual. "Some people say it might be due to sunspots," said Mr. Kincer, "but I don't see how sunspots and the radiations they produce would produce the queer weather effects we've had."
Delegates from sixty-two countries and hundreds of organizations attended this morning the inauguration by King Farouk of the International Convention of Telecommunications in the Royal Opera House.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 31: Kennedy, J. T., F. A., Ft. Bragg, N. C., to staff and faculty, the Field Artillery school. Ft. Sill. Okla, about Aug. 15. Kirtland, R. C. (Air Corps), Inspector General's Dep't, Washington, D. C., to retirement.

An appeal to the State Department to use its influence with the Colombian Government to prevent enactment of materially higher import duties on cotton textiles there, was sent to Washington yesterday by the Textile Export Asspciation of the United States.

The budget that Mayor La Guardia vetoed just before the end of last year is the city's valid, legal budget for 1938 and the first six months of 1939, while the substitute budget, approved by the new Board of Estimate and City Council this year, is void, Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan ruled yesterday in a test suit.

As the "little business men's" conference convenes in Washington today to discuss economic and legislative problems, political observers seek an answer to the question: How do small business men throughout the country feel politically toward Roosevelt?

The dollar had a moderate and uneven recovery in the foreign exchange market yesterday following its weakness of Monday. The pound sterling fell back 1/2 cent to $5.01, the guilder dropped 31 points to 55.89% cents and the Swiss franc declined 3/4 point to 23.183 cents.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club before the weekly backgammon tournament. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Phil H. Sawyer, Mr. and Mrs. Luther A. Wait, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Sibley Dow,

ANOTHER OPHELIA, by Edwin Lanham. (Longmans, Green, $2.) Anovel by the author, of "Banner at Daybreak." ROBBERY BY MAUL, by Karl Baarslag. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) The story of the United States Postal Inspectors.

Miss Bernice Wall, medalist, won her first-round match in the Belleair women's championship by defeating Mrs. F. B. Dangler, 6 and 4, today. Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, runner up to Miss Wall, unnerup to Miss Wall, defeated Mrs. E. J. Janes, 7 and 5.

Declaring that artificial price and wage controls are primarily responsible for the current depression, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, asserted that similar efforts to tax the chain stores out of existence "will create a monopoly more far reaching in its effects than any this country has ever seen."

The Assembly, at brief session, passed the Killgrew bill extending benefits of unemployment insurance to persons earning more than $3,000 a year and a bill permitting retirement of State police at the age of 50, after twenty years of service, and advanced New York City Parkway Authority Bill and Omnibus Codification Bill.

Two of the largest gold-mining companies in the United States and Canada have taken up options on many mines in the eastern part of Nicaragua. Large installations of machinery will be made immediately and large-scale production should begin this year.

Works Progress Administration fiscal authorities decided today to spend more on Winter employment and trust that Spring would bring a business spurt to absorb the thousands who will have to be cut off their rolls then.

Unity House, 67 Church Street, was damaged to the extent of $10,000 by fire here tonight while about 200 men and women in evening clothes, who had come to hear a piano concert in the building stood by and watched the city's entire Fire Denartment battle the blaze.

Judge Peter J. Brancato in County Court, Brooklyn, told Vincent Pavone, 29 years old, of 662 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday that if he would admit the $7,165 payroll robbery of two employee of the Fannie Farmer Candy Company on Dec. 17,

Sales representatives of thirty major aircraft companies met here today in connection with the International Air Show to discuss standardization of trading used planes for new ones and other merchandising methods.

Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Adventures Around the World and On the Air," Lowell Thomas. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Current Propaganda Against Freedom," Mrs. George A. Wyeth.

Plans for a nation-wide intercollegiate invitation tournament to be held in this city in March were discussed at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association luncheon at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.

Mrs. Walter H. Sykes of 30 East Sixtieth Street announced last night the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marguerite Sykes, to Walter P. Chrysler Jr. of 856 Fifth Avenue and King's Point, Great Neck, L. I., elder son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Chrysler.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs was severely criticized last night by the Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, for failing to remove Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, from his executive staff.
The Montreal Star carries the following announcement on its front page today: "Mr. J. W. McConnell, in taking over the presidency of the Montreal Star Company, Ltd.,
Tomorrow night the St. Albans Golf Club will meet to consider an offer made by a group headed by Henry Mandel to purchase the 126acre club golf course.

A six-story apartment house and two dwellings on the West Side and a six-story multi-family house on the East Side were among the residential properties in Manhattan which figured in the sales lists of brokers yesterday.

Representatives of the Philippine-American advisory committee group sponsored by the National Foreign Trade Council will go to Washington tomorrow to confer with officials regarding the coming independence for the islands.

The Beauvais and Gobelin tapestries, eighteenth century French furniture, Chinese porcelains and other works of art contained in the Fifth Avenue residence of the late Ogden Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury under President Coolidge and Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, are to be sold at auction.
Maxie Berger, Bronx ring favorite, carried off the decision over Tommy Rawson of Boston in the eight-round feature bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night.
A terrific Arctic hurricane has smashed the ice floe on which four Soviet scientists have been voluntarily marooned for the last eight months.

The Board of Education has abandoned its plan to build a new elementary school to replace Publie School 33 in Chelsea Park, Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the board's buildings and sites committee, announced yesterday.

AUCHINCLOSS, JOHN WINTHROP (Jan. 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To John W. Auchincloss, Locust Valley, L. I., and Dorothea Sutherland, 1,115 5th Ave., grandchildren, $1,000 each; Margaret F. Giles, 1,115 5th Ave., $800 annuity; Joanna R. Auchincloss, daughter, 180 Fort Washington Ave.,
Shareholders of the United Corporation at their annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., elected Roy K. Ferguson, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, as a director of the corporation.
The recent slump in business can in part be accounted for by the rapid rise in costs, says the First National Bank of Boston in its current news letter.

Yielding at last to the demands of bankers, economists and international traders, the British Government today took its first sizable step in several years toward the revival of international lending.

In a game that was virtually no contest, the St. Nicks Hockey Club last night swamped the Columbia Lions, 15-0, on the Brooklyn Ice Palace rink. It was a New York AmateurHockey Association affair. Kammer, with six goals, and McLernon, with five, were chiefly responsible for the high scoring.

Today is the twenty-fifth birthday anniversary of the present Grand Central Terminal. There will be no formal ceremonies, but the station will be bedecked with flags. The terminal, which serves the New York Central and New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads, was formally opened on Feb. 2, 1913.
John Barbirolli, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, is returning tonight on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria after a month's vacation in England.
Tommy Farr's refusal yesterday to consider either Max Baer or Jimmy Adamick shattered plans of Promoter Mike Jacobs for another indoor bout here for the British Empire heavyweight champion.
An exhibition of ancient Chinese art, arranged as. a benefit for civilian sufferers in China, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Madeline Brill, daughter' of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max D. Brill of this city, to Eli H. Bronstein took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's brother, D. Dudley Brill, at 755 Park Avenue.

The phantom "revolt" in North Mexico near Brownsville, Texas, yesterday has been characterized by Governor Marte R. Gomez as a "publicity stunt" by the waning Gold Shirts, and Mexico City was amazed today to learn that what was actually a sporadic clash had been termed a revolt and had been taken seriously in the United States.
Herman Lange Jr., 32 years old, of 66 Caryl. Avenue, Yonkers, was found dead this morning in his automobile parked in a wooded section east of the Irvington Reservoir.

Yehudi Menuhin and his sister, Hepzibah, appeared together last night in a program of violin and piano music in the Metropolitan Opera House. The great theatre was packed and the stage filled with listeners, save for the space about the piano.
Tying the all-time record at Santa Anita Park, Johnny Adams, America's leading rider in 1937, booted four horses into the winners' circle today, including the featured $1,500 Elmwood Purse.

Bill Terry spent all of yesterday trying to engineer some trades that would benefit his Giants and the club's Jersey City team, but never reached a point in the negotiations where he could make a definite announcement of a change, notwithstanding he came out in the open and offered Gus Mancuso, veteran catcher, and Wally Berger, his utility outfielder, as bait.
Beverley R. Robinson was elected president of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the corporation of the museum.

Holland Ave (16-4570), e s, 380 ft Burke Ave, 35x100; also Holland Ave, e s, 415 ft s of Burke Ave, 35x100; 3,010 Holland Ave Corp to Rossam Land Corp, 540 E Fordham Rd. Overing St (15-4000), w s, 229 ft n of St. Raymond Ave, 37x6l; Katherine A. Stein to Helen E Toman, 1,626 Mayflower Ave.
Wheat prices advanced more than 1 cent a bushel today on scattered buying induced by further unfavorable crop reports from the Southwest, firm cables from Liverpool and relative strength in Winnipeg.

The American boat Chuckle III, skippered by Harold Halsted, with Reeve Bowden as crew, won the second race in the Cup of Cuba series for International Star Class Yachts today. The craft from Moriches Bay covered the 10-mile leeward and windward course in 1:44:13.

The pacesetting Boston Bruins tonight held their three-point lead over the New York Rangers in the American Division of the National Hockey League by turning back the lowly Detroit Red Wings in an easy 2-0 victory before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

Company D of the Sixty-fifth Infantry, stationed in Puerto Rico., was designated today 1937 winner of the Edwin Howard -Clark Trophy for the army machine gun unit making the highest average score in tests which include elementary training, marksmanship, marching and making of camp. Its score was 942.2.

The split between John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Laborbecame wider today when the United Mine Workers of America, cornerstone of the C. I. O., in the only constitutional amendment adopted at their convention voted unanimously to strike from its constitution all references to the A. F. of L.

The five-story and basement building at the northwest corner of Willow Avenue and East 135th Street, the Bronx, containing about 30,000 square feet of space, has been leased for a long term from E. C. Ramsey by the T. J. Ronan Company, Inc., who will occupy it for the manufacture of paints and for the firm's general offices. J. P.

The birth rate in New York City for the week ended last Saturday dropped below that for the previous week and continued under the rate of the corresponding period of last year, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The three stars who shared medal honors encountered little trouble in winning their first-round matches in the annual Miami-Biltmore women's golf championship today, the trio being Miss Patty Berg, 19-yearold Minneapolis sensation;
Germany has reached a crossroads, it was indicated yesterday by authoritative reports that the Cabinet was being reorganized.
E. I. du Pont de. Nemours ' Co. and controlled companies paid $107,500,000 in wages and salaries in 1937, or 26 per cent more than in 1936, according to Lammot du Pont, president of the company.
Distribution of unemployment insurance checks in the State and city, under the unemployment insurance provisions of the State Unemployment Law, began yesterday.

Troops totaling 68 officers and 1,200 men; described by army officials as "routine replacements," sailed for Honolulu aboard the transport Republic today coincident with'departure of the submarine Nautilus for the same midpacific base.

Nobody could be found yesterday who could remember arresting Ramon Morales in the week-end police round-up. Yet there he stood before Magistrate Anthony Burke in Yorkville Court, a prisoner. There was no doubt that he had spent Sunday night in jail and that he was at that moment under $100 bail.

The consumption of copper abroad in the last three months for which figures are available averaged 114,473 tons, compared with a monthly average of 96,183 tons in 1936, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.
The Interstate Commerce Commission listened today to arguments for and against a general increase of 15 per cent in railroad freight rates.

Long Island University's basketball team will meet Washington and Lee, Southern Conference champion for the past two seasons, in 'the opening game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

George Y. Allen, president of James Doux, Inc., died last night of a heart attack in a curling match at the Utica Curling Club. Last week he won the Allen Point Medal. He was the son of the late Joseph Y. Allen, who operated the British-American Dyeing Company, and he studied at Bishop's College, Montreal, and Leeds (England) University.

The liner Queen Mary, sailing for New York tomorrow after her first real overhaul, may reach new high speeds. For the first time the preservative paint applied to the ship's bottom when she was built was removed and experts say friction should be reduced.

Prices of commodity futures generally were lower in -moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. World sugar futures, on the heaviest turnover in more than three months, broke into new low ground with losses of 3 1/2 to 5 points. In the cash market all the grains, flour, lard, tins and silk advanced, but cocoa, raw sugar, cotton and rubber declined.

The British Olympic committee met tonight to discuss the apparent failure of Japanese athletic officials to issue invitations for the 1940 Olympics at Tokyo and to decide whether Great Britain was prepared to accept an invitation if it gets one.

Represenitative Rayburn, the House majority leader, stated today that the Hill bill to "take the profits out of war" would be considered by the House next week, in line with President Roosevelt's recent special message recommending legislation to equalize war-time burdens.

Present indications are that the New York Theatrical Press Agents will retain their own identity as a chapter in the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers, according to the substance of a discussion between representatives of the two unions Monday night.
Average daily sales in chain men's wear stores were 10.7 per cent lower in December, 1937, than the corresponding month the previous year, the Commerce Department announced today.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Bitsy Grant of Atlanta moved today toward a renewal of their Winter tennis rivalry as they advanced in separate brackets of the Surf Club tournament.
An attractive set of intercollegiate one-mile relay races will be among the many features of the thirty-first annual indoor Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

President Roosevelt today presented a gold cup to Herbert A. Mendelson of the Detroit Yacht Club for capturing the eleventh annual President's Cup speedboat regatta here last September. Mendelson won with Notre Dame, the same boat he used to annex the trophy in 1935.

Chief Justice William R. Bayes of Special Sessions made public yesterday his annual report on the work of the sixteen justices of his court in the five boroughs in 1937, through which the trial calendars were cut down by more than 5,000 cases from the 7,569 at the beginning of that year and more than $232,000 in fines -collected, or in excess of 50 per cent of the cost of maintaining the court.

The moderate recovery in share prices on Monday was extended yesterday, although the volume of trading contracted. Gains ranged from fractions to about 2 points, and the turnover on the Stock Exchange was 691,000 shares, compared with 757,000 the day before.

Stockholders of the Parker-Wolverine Company approved yesterday in Detroit the plan for acquiring the assets of the Modern Stamping and Manufacturing Company, which is 57 per cent owned by Parker-Wolverine.
For a dreary succession of days and weeks it has been difficult even for an optimistic observer to make a cheering report from Washington.
Theodore C. Hovey, vice president of the New York Trust Company, has sold eighteen acres on Taunton Hill, in Newtown, Conn., improved with an old colonial homestead and farm buildings.

The hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application of Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., a Canadian corporation, for permission to withdraw its common stock for listing on the New York Curb Exchange, scheduled for tomorrow, has been postDoned until March 8.
The First Baptist Church of Pittsfield, as residuary legatee under the will of Nelson J. Lawton, head of the firm of M. P. Lawton Son, coal dealers, will receive $380,000 from his estate.

The presence in retail stores of cosmetic demonstrators, either so specified or "hidden" in cosmetic departments, was the chief complaint expressed by consumers against the toilet industry at a forum meeting held under the auspices of the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., last night at the Town Hall Club.

The Rev. C. A. W. Brocklebank assumed his new duties yesterday as rector of St. Mark's-in-theBouwerie Episcopal Church, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue. "I am starting right in to get acquainted with my people," the 33-year-old rector said.
The marriage of Miss Jean Casilear Cobb, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Greene of this city, to Harry William Norris of Pinehurst, N. C., will take place tomorrow at the home of her uncle and aunt.
An extensive program for the competitive skier has been arranged for the coming week-end, with the Eastern downhill and New York State jumping championships topping the schedule.
The marriage of Miss Jean Casilear Cobb, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Greene of this city, to Harry William Norris of Pinehurst, N. C., will take place tomorrow at the home of her uncle and aunt.
An extensive program for the competitive skier has been arranged for the coming week-end, with the Eastern downhill and New York State jumping championships topping the schedule.

The first broadcast ever attempted directly from the ancient pyramids on the edge of the Sahara Desert will be heard Sunday at 4 P. M. over WEAF's network, when Egyptologists will discuss their latest discoveries.

A banking group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and including Gregory Son, Inc.; Eastman, Dillon Co. and Francis I. du Pont Co., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,031,000 of certificates of indebtedness of the State of Maryland.

3d St, 54-56 E, 43x75; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co to Doglor Realty Corp, 11 W 42d St ($25). 5th St, 340 E, 25x96.2 1/; Paula Chonin to Emigrant Bank, bank mtg, $14,200. 17th St, n s, 280 w of 5th Ave, 53x92; Bowery Savings Bank to Hanid Corp, 32 Liberty St, care Wm. A. Kirk ($133).

The House Military Affairs Committee heard protests today from the War Department against a bill which would allow Brig. Gen Manus McCloskey, commanding officer at Fort Bragg, N. C., to retire with the rank of major general in April, when he reaches the retirement age.
Britain, aroused by the sinking in the Mediterranean of the British steamer Endymion, dispatched eight destroyers yesterday to hunt down and destroy the pirate submarine responsible.

Space has been leased by the WPA in 35-43 West Sixty-Fifth- Street, where the Research and Clerical Department of the Women's. and Professional Project will be housed. The Cross Browm Company was the broker.

Stealing away from her household duties at Chapel Hill, Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, women's national golf champion, motored here today, fired the best score in the St. Valentine's tournament and then hastened home to prepare supper for her husband, Julius.

Mr. Justice Black seems about to establish a record as a dissenter, but his first dissents may puzzle laymen as much as they do lawyers. Let us take, for example, his lone dissent from the opinion of seven of his colleagues that California may not tax premiums received by the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company from other insurance companies doing business in California.

A thirty-day sentence for contempt was imposed on Charles Falci in Brooklyn Federal court yesterday for refusing to answer questions before the Federal grand jury concerning -his relations with Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader and former New York County Clerk, who has been indicted on a charge of unlawfully harboring Falci from justice.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Mortimer Riemer of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 321-Charles G. Johnson, as Treasurer of the State of California, et al., applts., v.

The Power Memorial basketball team continued to set the pace in the Manhattan-Richmond Division of the C. H. S. A. A. race when it defeated the De La Salle Academy five,. 28-14, yesterday on the winners' court.

Cooperation with the livestock industry in its program to increase consumer demand for meat products was pledged today by leaders in manufacturing, retailing, railroading, agriculture, publishing and other industries at a meeting of friends of the livestock industry in the Palmer House.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn M. Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Miller of this place, to L. Kingsley Smith, son of Mrs. Lewis J. Smith and the late Supreme Court Justice Lewis J. Smith, took place this afternoon in the Garden City Hotel.

Stocks extended gains moderately and closed higher in less active trading; turnover, 691,590 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, other issues steadier and generally higher; transactions, $7,655,725.

About 100 New Yorkers who came here last evening at the invitation of Secretary Roper wrangled past midnight on problems of organization, and seemed certain to go into the conference of "small business" today without a program on how to tackle the problem of business recovery.

A building at 1,315-1,317 St. George Avenue, comprising 15,000 square feet, has been leased by Burkam Brothers a,large trucking concern with New York offices at Pier 44, Lehigh Valley Railroad, through M. W. Boyle Sons, from the Y. T Trucking Company, Inc.

A three-year collective agreement granting a closed shop and seniority rights to 2,000 employes of the Hearn Department Stores in Manhattan and the Bronx was signed yesterday between representatives of the stores and the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1,250, C. I. 0. affiliate, at the offices of Ben Golden, labor consultant, at the Hotel Edison.
The directors of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation yesterday elected Walter H. Sammis a vice president of the corporation, succeeding the late T. A. Kenney.

Objections to the licensing of practical nurses, on the ground that, with licenses, they would rapidly replace qualified registered nurses, were expressed at a conference here today by Miss Luciel McGorkey, representing the nurses' locals of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. 0. group.
A larger increase than anticipated seasonally took place in steel ingot output last week and the adjusted index has advanced to 49.4 from 45.9. The figure for the week ended Jan. 30, 1937, was 112.5.

Romans witnessed today the first mass exhibition of the goose step, which the Fascisti call the "Roman step," when thousands of militiamen filed past Premier Benito Mussolini in a parade climaxing the fifteenth anniversary celebration of the foundation of the fascist militia.
Frank F. Shulock, who has been connected with the textile industry for the last twenty years, has been appointed export sales manager of J. Rosenholz, Inc., rayon and silk distributors.

We decided to stop off today, on our way to Palm Beach, and look over the progress of the world's greatest aquariums at Marineland. Ivy Lee had been telling us what a marvelous place this was, and would be, but we were surprised when we arrived and saw the immensity of the undertaking.

SAMUEL BUTLER (the "Hudibras" Butler) left behind this couplet: "Doubtless the pleasure is as great, Of being cheated, as to cheat." To make rhyme out of that you have to pronounce "cheat" in the old-fashioned wayas the old Irishwoman still pronounces the name of her favorite drink-but to make reason of it you need only look around. Or, better still, look at Karl Baarslag's "Robbery by Mail."*
The United States Army transport Chauteau Thierry sailed at noon yesterday carrying replacements for garrisons in Puerto Rico and the Canal Zone.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as' reported by the United Stafes Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 28,000, including 5,000 directs; mostly 25c lower than yesterday's average. Late sales weights downward from 210 pounds 35c off; top $8.75;

Colleges affiliated with the Presbyterian Board of Christian Education have raised $1,255,000 toward the 150th anniversary campaign goal, $10,000,000, it was announced today by the Rev. Dr. Harold McAfee Robinson, the board's general secretary, at an executive committee meeting.

Thorndike, general passenger agent for the New Haven Railroad, announced today that after March 27 Newport, Summer society resort, would be without railroad passenger connections with the rest of the United States.

Alfred Dudley Andrus, Montclair insurance broker and former New York cotton broker, died last night in Mountainside Hospital. Born in Brooklyn, where he attended Polytechnic Institute, he was a member of Royal Arcanum and the Commonwealth Club.

With conversations between the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the managements of steel companies, including the United States Steel Corporation, scheduled to begin on Monday, the fate of the contract between the companies and the unions that will expire on Feb. 28 will be a matter of much concern.

President Roosevelt's foreign policy precipitated a heated though short debate in the Senate today, with Senator Borah, ranking Republican member of the Foreign Relations Committee, warning that this country was risking war by letting the world believe it was in a "tacit alliance" with Great Britain for building up their navies.

E. Frank Vernon, once a wellknown circus and vaudeville performer, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 65 years old. Born at Wheeling, W. Va., Jan. 2, 1873, Mr. Vernon became a professional roller skater at the age of 11, and in January, 1887, won the two and three mile speed skating crowns at Cleveland.

APPLE - Murray (Major), dearly beloved brother of Cecelia Aronson and Clara A. Wolff, darling uncle of Belle Wilson and Olga E. Mayer. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Thursday, Feb. 3, at 11 A. M. St. Louis, Nashville and Philadelphia papers please copy.
The committee on League of Nations reform ended today a far-reaching and often dramatic debate with an agreement merely to refer the whole problem without recommendation to the September Assembly.

Financial methods of holding companies were compared by the government today with the operations of Charles Ponzi, the statement being made in a brief submitted to the Supreme Court preparatory to argument next Monday on the Electric Bond and Share case.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Loyalist Parliament that claims to be the constituent government of Spain is soon to convene in regular session at Barcelona, this being the fifth time it has been able to meet since the civil war began in July, 1936.

Dr. Waldermar Schutz, German educator, sailed for home yesterday from Hoboken on the liner Gerolstein after officials of the company had held the ship while he hurried back to New York to retrieve his wallet from a telephone booth.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Appleby gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Earl K. Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Bertschmann, Mr. and Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, Mr. and Mrs. John Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Hutchins, Mr. and Mrs. Francis S. Appleby, Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lewis, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Martin, Mrs. Hurd Pierce and Samuel H. Reynolds.
Subscribers to the Yorkville Dinner Dances and many of their friends assembled in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the second dance of this season's series.

Another peppery ne chapter was written today into the exchanges between President William Green of the American Federation and Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typpgraphical Union and secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization,
The Treasury approved today a design for a memorial to the fourteen men who died in the crash of the navy dirigible Shenandoah near Ava, Ohio, on Sept. 3, 1925.
The Paramount Theatre was filled to capacity tonight for the concert by the University of Miami Symphony Orchestra, of which Dr. Arnold Volpe is conductor.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, a moneyhungry product of an up-State village and a graduate of the Columbia Law School, was arrested yesterday in Philadelphia on an indictment obtained by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey while he was special prosecutor of rackets.

Industry, labor and academic impartiality were represented last night at a symposium on the business recession, its cause and cure, at a dinner of the Economic Club in the Hotel Astor, attended by 1.500 bankers and business men.
Most motorists put plenty of money into their gasoline tanks, but Pete Sherlock Jr. of Atlanta takes it out as well. He recently turned in his 1936 model automobile on a new car. Before driving away

Hundreds of residents and children living near Beirdsley School were questioned by police today in a hunt for an incendiarist believed responsible for a three-alarm fire that swept the school last night, less than three weeks after a similar fire wreaked historic Barnum School.

Sales of copper were made late yesterday in the export market at 10 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. Earlier trading was done at 9.90 to 9.95 cents a pound. On Tuesday the range was between 9.85 and 9.95 cents a pound. The domestic price was unchanged at 10 cents a pound.

Mrs. Henry F. Misselwitz, wife of a former United Press White House correspondent, obtained a divorce here today on cruelty grounds, and a license to marry H. E. (Bud) Ekins, United Press war correspondent.

Working on the thesis that the small speculator is almost always wrong, the Securities and Exchange Commission is compiling statistics in Wall Street, with the idea of proving its point and then, possibly, doing something about it.

A new storm of employee unrest broke around the WPA Federal Arts Projects yesterday when it became known that 300 workers on the theatre, music, art and writers' projects would be transferred to laboring and white-collar projects.

Jay Lewis, president of Jay Lewis Associates, Inc., 211 East Fortyfifth Street, pleaded not guilty before Magistrate Myles A. Paige in downtown Traffic Court yesterday to a parking charge and said that if convicted he would carry his case to the higher courts.

Class A, Mile-and-a-Half (Handicap)-Won by Joe Dille, Continental S. C. (scratch); Cliff Spelman, Grand St. Boys (scratch) second; Gene McCann, Brooklyn Ice Palace (scratch), third. Time--4:41. Class B, One Mile (Handicap)--Won by George Morales, Niagara S. C. (35 yards); John Haugen, Cornell S. C. (40 yards) second; Frank Ramage, unattached yards) third. Time--3:07.

The State Department is continuing its efforts to assist the evacuation of American nationals from danger zones in China. Paul R. Josselyn, United States Consul General at Hankow, cabled the State Department today that the following Americans had left Hankow for Canton in two special coaches attached to a regular through train:

The Interstate Commerce Commission has issued an order permitting the filing of modified rates by motor carriers for transporting glassware, canned goods and fresh fish, including shell fish, between points in Long Island and Southern New Jersey and places as far south as Washington and Baltimore.

The Works Progress Administration, on instructions from Washington, is considering a- two-monthlayoff in July and August of 6,000 workers on education projects in this city, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, disclosed yesterday.
Fairfax Harrison, former president of the Southern Railway, died at a hospital here tonight of heart disease. His age was 69.
For the first time this season, the Montclair A. C. Class A squash tennis team went down to defeat in the metropolitan interclub series, bowing to the Princeton Club last night, 3 to 2.

Regional Conference on Social Hygiene at the Hotel Astor begins at 10 A. M. and continues all day. Luncheon session at 12:30 P. M., at which speakers will be Dr. W. Bayard Long, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Dr. Louise Pearce, Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff. Annual dinner

The Ways and Means Committee which, within its subcommittee, has been toiling for three months on a program for tax revision may soon bring in a measure to codify the internal revenue laws preliminary to the revision.

Senators Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan and Clyde L. Herring of Iowa announced today that they wished their names to be stricken from the list of twenty-six United States Senators and thirty-four Representatives who signed a message of greeting and sympathy to the Spanish Loyalist Government last Sunday.

A bus carrying twenty-two school children of Walnut Valley, a rural district near here, overturned this afternoon after being in collision with an automobile. Twelve of the youngsters, were injured, none seriously apparently.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to listing 26,050 additional shares of Inland Steel Company capital stock, for issue to officers and employes. The stock will not necessarily be immediately admitted to dealings.

As a correspondent heard accounts of the survivors of the sunken British steamer Endymion that tended to show the ship had been sent down by a torpedo rather than a mine [Page 3], British Foreign Secretary Eden suggested to the French and Italian Ambassadors that Mediterranean patrol ships be instructed to sink submarines on sight.

General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, Spanish Insurgent, announced over the radio today that he had decided to discontinue his nightly broadcasts from Seville following the formation of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Nationalist [Rebel] Cabinet.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of Atlantic Coast seamen, demanded yesterday of the Sailors Union of-the Pacific Coast that it desist from its practice of barring Atlantic Coast seamen from West Coast ships, or suffer retaliatory measures.

Alien residents of New York City, including refugees from European countries, will not-be permitted -to matriculate as free students seeking baccalaureate degrees in any city colleges, under a ruling of the Board of Higher Education, which became public yesterday.

One hundred cash gifts and bequests totaling $189,776 have been made to New York University, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor, announced yesterday. The money will be applied chiefly to scholarships and research in science and medicine.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt heads the patronesses for the card party and dance in behalf of Madonna House which will be held tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A Senate-House committee agreed late today on details of the "EverNormal Granary" bill, providing a system for controlling production and marketing of cotton, wheat, corn, tobacco and rice in an effort to stabilize prices.
Two interpretations of Regulation T of the Federal Reserve Board have been issued by the board and distributed to members by the New York Stock Exchange. The first declared that,
Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., United States Minister to Poland; Lefevre d'Ormesson, French Ambassador to Brazil; William Cameron Forbes, former United States Ambassador to Japan; Baron de

William H. Tubbs, 37-year-old housepainter, was convicted last night of second-degree murder by a jury in the Queens County Court.
