Tubbs had strangled his 6-year-old son, William Guerin Tubbs, in his former home in Flushing in 1933. Tubbs faces a term of twenty years to life. He was remanded for sentencing on Feb. 11.
Total admitted assets of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company on Dec. 31 were $1,178,428,637, a high record and a gain of $48,574,941 over the previous year-end, according to the annual

Represensations of Claude G. Bowers, American Ambassador to Spain, have obtained the promise of release of the tanker Nantucket Chief, its captain and its crew, the State Department announced today. The vessel was taken into custody on Jan. 17 by warships belonging to the Insurgent forces.

The artists of all forty-eight of the United States, its possessions and its territories are to be invited today by Mayor La Guardia and the Municipal Art Committee to participate in the third annual National Exhibition of American Art.
The Crowell Publishing Company will erect a $1,000,000 addition to its plant here this year, Thomas A. Beck, president, announced today.

This week there occurred the fourth anniversary of the formal devaluation of the dollar. Through raising arbitrarily by something over 69 per cent the statutory dollar price of gold, the American dollar's international value was proportionately reduced.

Frederick C. Painton of Westport, Conn., played scintillating golf on the second half to score an easy victory in the second round of match play in the eleventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

From a little tin chapel, which was the first place of worship, to its present imposing yellow brick edifice with a tall Dutch tower at Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, the history of the West End Presbyterian Church was traced last evening at the opening service in celebration of the golden jubilee of the parish.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee for an issue of $3,393,250 first mortgage 5 per cent income and sinking fund bonds due Feb. 1, 1953, of the Hotel Drake Corporation, and also transfer agent for voting trust certificates for 13,573 shares of the corporation's common stock.

George P. Johnson, an official in the former township of Linden and a supervisor in the plant accounting department of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company for thirty-three years, died this morning at the Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, following an operation.

The New York Americans, striving to snap a losing streak, will engage the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Star-Spangled skaters are only four points ahead of the last-place Montreal Maroons, and hope to widen the gap with a victory.

Herbert M. Kopf, recently appointed director of athletics and head coach of football at Manhattan College, was guest of honor at a rally held yesterday in Smith Auditorium under the sponsorship of the student governing associations.

The government will start next week to pour out millions of dollars on its long-delayed municipal power program. The PWA administrator, secretary Ickes, announced today that the first $1,000,000 of PWA grants would

Total sales of hotels in December, 1937, declined 2 per cent from December, 1936, the first such decrease for any month in more than four years, according to the monthly bulletin issued yesterday by Horwath Horwath, accountants.

Here are some sidelights on President Roosevelt's conference of small business men: Miss Julia M. Ring, who runs an agency furnishing watchmen for ships at Philadelphia, suggested that the government pay a little more attention to the plight of the middle class and a little less to that of the underprivileged.
Army's basketball team, back on its home court, regained its winning stride at the expense of Georgetown today, 50 to 30.

Out of a secret conference of Republican legislators at the Carteret Club here today came a reported decision to finance New Jersey's share of unemployment relief largely from the revenue produced by imposition of a $10 fee for the compulsory annual registration of trade-marks.

Forsyth St. 184. 25x100; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Louis Akst and wife, 15 Elliott PI, Bronx ($16). 78th St. 315-17 E, 50x102.2; Maurice P. De Vries et al to Rimsovo Corp, 60 Wall St, care B. Franklin; mtges $20,000 ($4). 131st St, 50-52 E, 55x100; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Renee Stewart, 313 Lenox Ave ($36).
Two army reserve fliers were killed today when their observation plane crashed into dense undergrowth on Virginia Key and burned.
Four officers and five petty officers have been detailed to the Peruvian Navy in an advisory capacity, the Navy Department announced today.

Alexandre Moret, noted Egyptologist, died of a heart attack at his Paris residence, Rue Vaneau, today. His age was 70. Mr. Moret was a former director of the Guimet Museum, which specializes in Oriental art.
The dedication of Cabrini Circle at the entrance to Fort Tryon Park inspired a short letter on this page day

The Princeton Club won the championship in Group 1 of the New York Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C tournament yesterday by defeating the Harvard Club, 3-2, in the last of the play-offs at the Union League Club.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago ran into unexpected opposition in the third round of the Surf Club tennis tournament today and had to use his entire bag of tricks to subdue Carroll Turner of Miami, 8-6, 7-5.

THEY tell a story (apocryphal?) about Talleyrand during the Congress of Vienna. He was carving a joint of beef for his dinner guests one evening. Turning to the first he said politely: "Mon Prince, may I have the honor of giving you some beef?" The next down the table

Brown defeated Northeastern, 77 to 52, tonight as Harry Platt, Brooklyn sophomore, set an alltime Brown scoring record with 48 points. Platt fired from all parts of the court and tallied 21 field goals. Brown led, 36 to 24, at half time.

The present trend of events in Rumania represents merely "passing phenomena" that will not leave a permanent mark on the history of the country, Charles A. Davila, who has just retired as Rumanian Minister to the United States, told a group of Rumanians of New York last night at the Hotel St. Moritz.
Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, director of the second regional office in New York of the National Labor Relations Board, today declared untrue charges made by the American Federation of Labor that she had
Joseph Shaw, 34 years old, owner of the La Hiff Tavern at 158 West Forty-eighth Street, and Raymond Delgado, 27, a concessionaire at the restaurant, were arrested yesterday on charges of gambling.

The annual report for 1937 of the American Woolen Company, Inc., and subsidiaries, excluding the Textile Realty Company, shows a net loss of $1,854,902 after expenses, interest, $129,410 loss on capital assets sold or scrapped, $2,122,541 provision for depreciation, Federal income taxes including $23,947 surtax, and $4,022,989 inventory losses.

Seedings were made yesterday for the selected sixteen-man fields in both the 60-yard sprint and the 60yard high hurdles for the Millrose A. A. games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Four preliminary heats have been arranged for each, with the first two in each first-round test moving into the semi-finals.

The dollar recovered further in the. foreign exchange market yesterday following its recent weakness. The pound sterling went down 1/4 cent to $5.00 3/4, the franc fell 3/4 point to 3.27 1/2 cents, the guilder lost 4 1/2 points to 55.85 cents,
A delegation of New Jersey textile workers carried their demands for relief and enactment of the wageshours and textile bills to the White House today.

AMENDT-Anna Louise, Feb. 1, 1938, at Smithville Flats, New York, beloved aunt of Mrs. A. K. Wightman. Funeral and interment private. APPLE -Murray (Major), dearly beloved brother of Cecelia Aronson and Clara A. Wolff, darling uncle of Belle Wilson and Olga E. Mayer. Services Park West

Formation of the Philadelphia Acceptance Corporation under Delaware laws to finance deals in spivits was announced yesterday. C. J. Koller and Charles W. Collom, both formerly of E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., will be president and secretary-treasurer, respectively, of the corporation.
The British freighter Endymion, according to the stories the survivors told your correspondent in Cartagena today, was undoubtedly sunk by a torpedo and not by a floating mine.

Mrs. Bertha A. Dempsey Curtis, wife of Robert W. Curtis, an assistant to the sports editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a week's illness. Her home was at 252-02 Leith Road, Little Neck, Queens. Mrs. Curtis was 65 years old.

Having apparently lain on the tracks for 'at least twelve hours, the body of Patrolman Thomas McGuire, 44 years old, of the Harbor Precinct, who had been assigned to duty at Metropolitan Hospital, Welfare Island, was found at 3:50 P. M. yesterday 500 feet north of the I. R. T. Subway station at Ninety-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The cost of lunacy commissions in New York, Bronx and Kings Counties in the last three years has exceeded the budget allowances in each county, it was disclosed in a table of figures made public by the Mayor's office yesterday.

The Japanese entrance upon Alaskan salmon fisheries was assailed before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee today by H. B. Friele, Alaskan salmon packer, who declared that the Japanese "wield a two-edged sword over us."

An anonymous $100,000 gift toward the restoration of University Hall at Brown University, the original "College Edifice" of 1770, was announced tonight by President Henry M. Wriston on the eve of the first anniversary of his installation as president.
Natica, Lady Lister Kaye of London, who has been at the Ambassador since November, will leave today for Washington. Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Ira Nelson Morris of Chicago are at the RitzCarlton.

The suspicion voiced here by persons in official life that an understanding of some sort existed between the United States and Great Britain to pool naval resources in the event of war involving either of them was declared to be entirely unfounded today by Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations.

Utility and Railroad Commissioners of Northwestern and other States, opposing the proposed 15 per cent increase in railroad freight rates, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the increase would harm producers in their territories without benefiting the railroads.
The report that there is possibility that the Nicaraguan interoceanic canal may be constructed by the United States has sent prices of land along the proposed canal route up by 500 per cent.
Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight champion, yesterday was promised a return bout with Joe Louis, world champion, if he would agree to box Max Baer in Madison Square Garden March 11.

A movement among the private secretaries of Senators and Representatives to obtain 10 cents a mile for traveling expenses between their homes .and Washington has reached the Accounts Committee of the House. It was estimated that if a- mileage resolution for secretaries were adopted, it would cost about $275,000 a year.
What is a small business man? An unofficial definition by Administration spokesmen termed him a man doing a gross business of less than $1,000,000 a year and having fewer than 500 employes.

" The appointment of the present Nationalist anti-Semitic regime has checked the gradual economic improvement of the two last years. The situation is growing worse each week of its existence. If it lasts six months Rumania will be completely ruined."

The Philharmonic - Symphony League, dedicated to the stimulation of interest in symphonic music, was founded yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis at a luncheon attended by some 200 persons-members of various women's committees, directors and guests of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society.

Though fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday held within the narrowest limits in several weeks, active progress was made in liquidating March obligations. It was estimated that transactions in the near month exceeded 30,000 bales, resulting in the heaviest reduction in open interest so far.
Plans for a new apartment house in the Bronx were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the northeast corner of 181st Street and Ryer Avenue by an estate to Marcus Blaser, builders.

Imminence of a Congressional hearing next week at Washington on the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution was sufficient to precipitate the topic yesterday into the crowded program of the Midwinter board meeting of the State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

Miss Muriel Bache Richards, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Beckman of 791 Park Avenue and of Frederick Lloyd Richards, also of this city, has chosen the afternoon of April 22 as the date for her mar-. riage to Francis Warren Pershing, only son of General John J. Pershing, Commander-in-Chief of the A. E. F. during the World War.

Once more comes a reminder that February is underprivileged. Mr. Moon, as the Germans and other races who have never studied.Endymion's grammar put it, turned up at 8:30 P. M., Jan. 31. If February had had the too

Miss Mary Adams Maverick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Maverick Jr. of San Antonio, Texas, and niece of Representative Maury Maverick of Texas, was married here today to John F. Lambie of Detroit in St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Warner, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Gresham Marmion.
Dexter P. Cooper, noted engineer who dreamed of harnessing the mighty tides of the Bay of Fundy and eventually conceived the Passamaquoddy tidal project, died today of a heart attack. His age was 57.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad's management told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the road's modified plan of reorganization "will not vest any power of control whatever" in the Alleghany Corporation.
Our Carolyne, owned and trained by H. S. Swift, moved into the lead in the stretch and won the $1,200 Paso Robles Handicap at Santa Anita Park today.

Miss Madia Boulanger, French pianist and orchestra leader, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to lecture and give concerts here. On Feb. 18 and 19 she will conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the first woman, it is said, ever to lead that group.

The four Soviet scientists on a polar ice floe reported by wireless today: "Our ice floe has now broken down to 150 by 210 feet. We are living in a sink tent, but have saved all our instruments and records and we have food for three months.

The undefeated New York Aggies of Farmingdale, L. I., rolled to their sixth successive basketball triumph last night, trouncing Wagner College 38 to 13, at the Wagner gymnasium atop Grymes Hill, S. I.

Plans for a cooperative program of the New York City school system and the local colleges in the employment of school teachers to carry on research projects and field studies were announced by the Board of Education yesterday.
Elmer E. Payne, retired newspaper man and former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, died today after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

Construction of $155,000,000 worth of industrial plants and factory buildings is being held up by 275 companies throughout the United States, according to the H. K. Ferguson Company of New York and Cleveland, which has conducted a six-month survey.

The Republican Committee on Program, authorized by the national committee to write a declaration of party principles, as completed and announced today, consists of 217 members, representing all activities and only a sprinkling of "practical politicians."

Turpentine firm, 28c; sales, 13 barrels; receipts, 22 barrels; shipments, 35 barrels; stock, 28,049 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 213; receipts, 347; shipments, 75; stock; 75,981. Quote: B, D, E, $4.65; F. $5.65; G, $5.75; H, I, K, $5.85; M, 5.95; N $6.05; WG, $7.10; WW, X, $7.80.

Guy Standing Jr., son of the late Sir Guy Standing, British actor, married yesterday afternoon Miss Gloria Ruth Haydock, daughter of Mrs. Vivian Haydock of this city and Roy Haydock, also of New York; The ceremony, which took
Captain Mario Stoppani, noted Italian flier, was injured, and the four members of his crew were killed today When the transatlantic seaplane he was piloting fell into the sea and burned.

The Cleveland Indians announced tonight the outright release of Lloyd Brown, veteran left-handed pitcher. Brown is a ten-year man and cannot be sold to a minor league club, but may make his own deals as a free agent.

Edwin Grasse, blind violinist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, assisted at the piano by Ada Zeller. Mr. Grasse presented a program that included several compositions not frequently heard, such as Joseph Joachim's variations in E minor.
Ten lowcost pre-fabricated houses are to be built by a private contractor in Greenbelt, the government-owned housing development near here, the Farm Security Administration announced today.

Suggesttons that ships required for the expanded merchant marine program recommended by the Maritime Commission might be built to some extent by railroads and by private capital in foreign yards were made by Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the commission, at an executive hearing of the Joint Commerceand Labor Committees of the Senate, the record of which was made public today .

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the following from New York City had filed applications in January in connection with registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-countermarket:

The Guaranty Trust Company has invited tenders until 11 A. M. on Feb. 11, of Lehigh Valley Transit Company first mortgage thirty-year 4 per cent bonds, Series A, and 5 per cent, Series B, due Dec. 1, 1935, extended to Dec. 1, 1945, to exhaust the sum of $347,208 now on deposit.

With more than 200 buyers registering at the accessory show at the New Yorker yesterday, business showed some improvement over Tuesday, and exhibitors generally expressed satisfaction with both the size and number of orders booked.
Paul Osborn's adaptation of the Lawrence Edward Watkin novel, "On Borrowed Time," will be opening this evening at the Longacre Theatre. In the cast are Dudley

The continuance of the office of Controller of the Currency as an independent agency of the government is advocated almost unanimously by officers of national banks throughout the country, according to Russell G. Smith, president of the national bank division of the American Bankers Association.
Great Britain's huge new superliner now known only as "552" will be named the "Queen Elizabeth" and will be launched on Sept. 27 by Her Majesty, it was officially announced today.

Voices rose, fists shook, and after the only lull of the day, the "small business" conference suddenly flared into a disruptive climax here this evening over the old issue of New York vs. The Rest of the Nation.
An event of political as well as artistic implications occurred today at SelznickInternational, where Paulette Goddard was placed under term contract. The act gave substance

Ralph G. Macy, a mechanical engineer, was injured seriously yesterday morning when a bit of stone, weighing about a pound, fell 200 feet from a window of the Pine Street side of the Equitable Building and struck him on the head.
The government maid officially tonight that troops, having closed the frontier near Brownsville, Texas, had bottled up and were pursuing a small band of disturbers through the hills.

In one of the most surprising reversals the season has furnished, G. Huntington Hartford of the Harvard Club warn eliminated from the metropolitan squash racquets championship last night at the University Club.
Caution among steel buyers has been intensified by President Roosevelt's recent statement on the subject of wages and prices, The Iron Age says this week.

A luncheon was given yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza by Mrs. Park Mason Woolley for Mrs. Fenton B. Turck, Mrs. Alanson P. Lathrop, Mrs. Gordon Murdock, Mrs. Reginald Burbank, Mrs. J. Addison Woolley, Mrs. George Steel, Mrs. Charles C. Griswold, Mrs. Herman Metz, Mrs. Walter Botts, Mrs. George Large, Mrs. Ira Hubbell, Mrs. Charles Wimpfheimer and Miss Nelly Hatfield.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation denied today reports originating in Pittsburgh that it planned to permanently abandon five plants and transfer operations to the new $60,000,000 Irvin Works at Clairton, Pa.

Go Home, Rob ert L. and First Entry were the respective winners in the Grade A, E and C Handicaps which featured the racing at Hialeah Park today. Winning favorites were hard to find, but Go Home, the choice, prevailed in the main event in decisive style Sam Willians had the leg up on the 5-year-old son of Grandace.

Mrs. Robert C. Ream, president of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, gave a dinner last night in the restaurant of the exchange, 541 Madison Avenue, for members of the board of directors and of the staff of the exchange.

Opponents of the fourth cent emergency gasoline tax marshaled their forces before a joint meeting of the Assembly and Senate Taxation Committees today and for two hours presented arguments that the tax was excessive, discriminatory and must be reduced if bus operators, taxi drivers, truckmen and motorists in general were to be saved from an oppressive burden.

American Capital Corporation-Net assets as of Dec. 31, with securities owned adjusted to market prices on that date, amounted to $5,069,100, equal to $200.61 a share on the $5.50 prior preferred stock.

As the committee of five Councilmen named to investigate the election of Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens prepared to hold its first session this morning, Mr. Quinn announced last night that he had retained Richard J. Barry, Queens attorney, to defend him.

A decline of 10.2 per cent in the sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended Jan. 29 was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday, and it was the sharpest drop in a month which has shown consistent declines.

Senator Wagner, target of many oratorical shafts during the long Senate filibuster against the AntiLynching Bill, stated today that he would speak soon, possibly tomorrow, in defense of the measure as regards constitutional aspects.

Three new members were added to the bondholders committee for the Republic of Colombia at a meeting on Jan. 19 last, it was announced yesterday by the committee. The new members are United States Senator Marvel Mills Logan of Kentucky, Frederick E. Hasler,

The Tennessee Valley Authority has received eight applications since the TVA Act was held constitutional in a recent Federal court decision. Mayor Walter W. Mynatt of Knoxville said today that construction of the first unit of a municipal system to distribute TVA power would be started before Feb. 15.

Yale began its climb from the cellar of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by extricating itself from a trailing role against Columbia midway through the second half, to triumph by 49 to 38. It was the Eli's first league victory in six starts.

Welker Cochran of San Francisco, a former world champion, had a lead of 7 points over Jake Schaefer of Chicago, the present titleholder, at the conclusion tonight of the first half of their 3,600-point, 18.2 balkline billiard match.
Marketings of wheat in the Canadian Prairie Provinces for the week ended on Jan. 28
The annual meeting and luncheon in the interest of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York took place yesterday afternoon in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador. Mrs.

Advancing over three routes, Japanese forces yesterday drove Chinese troops from a large important triangle in Northern Anhwei, finally capturing Pengpu, important railway town on the Tientsin-Pukow line.

An announcement by the Army Information Service that there was a shortage of candidates for aviation training was accompanied yesterday by another which said that the qualifications would be reduced to fill the Spring class now forming.
The Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiaries were ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board to "cease and desist" from interference with self-organization by their employes.

Bonds moved irregularly in quieter trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The widespread buoyancy that characterized dealings on Tuesday, particularly in the railroad list, subsided as the market generally held within a relatively narrow price range.
Flurries of goals early in the game enabled the Navy five to win from Maryland, 37-34, today, despite strong rallies by the visitors late in each period.
Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan found yesterday a typographical error in his opinion on the New York City budget case in The New York Law Journal.

Representative McReynolds, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee and a member of the New York World's Fair Commission, will go to New York Saturday for a commission meeting intent upon urging the Fair management to require of concessionaires a contract guaranteeing compliance with all labor and wage laws, and maintenance of clean shops in conformity with the act extending Federal aid to the Fair.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Dorothy Kenyon, Inzer B. Wyatt Jr., William V. Holohand, all of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 346-Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petr., v. Nellie B. Bowers, admrx., etc. Argument continued for respondent and concluded for petr.

Irwin Vogelstein, a minor figure in the restaurant racket, and brother of Harry Vogelstein, a lawyer who, with six others was convicted last March in that case by Thomas E. Dewey, then Special Prosecutor, was arrested yesterday, according to an announcement by District Attorney Dewey.

The Peddie School five bowed to Irving School, 41-39, today in a thrilling contest. Sherry, visiting star, led the attack with 18 points. Bill Bleicher, Peddie's fast forward, rang up seven field goals and five fouls to total 19 points for the losers.

President Roosevelt discussed investment banking problems with Sidney Weinberg of New York and the demands of the United Automobile Workers of America for direct relief grants to unemployed automobile workers in Michigan with Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progress Administrator.

Stocks closed lower in third slowest trading since August; steel, motor, farm equipment and communication shares off 1 to 3 points; turnover, 583,910 shares. United States Government and other bonds steadier and mixed in quiet dealings; transactions, $6,485,600.

A retirement program has been adopted by the Boy Scouts of America for the benefit of more than 1,500 men and women employes of its national council here and 530 local councils throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by Walter W. Head, president of the organization, and James E. West, chief scout executive.

The Treasury procurement division today invited bids on 1,951,000 yards of cotton textiles for use by the WPA. The specifications will not be available for the trade until Feb. 8; the bids will be opened Feb. 15, and delivery is set for March 15. The items follow:

The ?? hockey team ended Choate School's winning streak today at six games with a 6-1 victory. Tied at 1-all after the first period, the freshmen scored twice in the second and three times in the final.
Harry Sternberg, New York artist, has completed a mural painting which is to be installed moon in the lobby of the Lakeview Postoffice, Chicago.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Feb. 1: COLONELS Lecocq, F. (C. A. C.), Inspector General's Department, detailed as a member of Court of Inquiry to meet at Headquarters, Third Corps Area, Baltimore, Md., Vice Col. A. F. Commiskey, Cav., relived.

Maple T. Harl of Denver, National Commander of the Disabled American-Veterans, said today that his organization had not endorsed the bill reported yesterday by the House Pensions Committee, granting pensions to widows and orphans of World War veterans.

Folks just went through the motions of work, study and play here today-John Tarleton College's basketball team had been defeated. Nothing like it had happened for more than four years. Eighty-six consecutive games the Plowboys had wonuntil last night. San Angelo Junior College, the last team to beat them back in December, 1933, did it again, 27 to 26. It was by that same one-point margin that San Angelo won from them back in '33.
Horace G. Wolfe, former secretarytreasurer of the Morris County Savings Bank, Morristown, N. J., died at his home in Shickshinny, near here, last night. He was 77 years old.

Formation of a national committee of retail traffic managers to seek reduction in tare weight of shipping containers used by manufacturers and to continue the favorable attitude of retailers toward an emergency increase in freight rates has been decided upon

David H. Wiener, associate counsel to the committee of the New Jersey Assembly investigating the Moore-Clee Gubernatorial election of last November, served subpoenas yesterday upon thirteen election officials, clerks and policemen in the committee's attempt to get the Hudson County poll books.

A fine of ten days' pay was imposed yesterday on Patrolman Robert Lewis of the Highbridge Ad station for failure to prevent the distribution of handbills last August during a strike at 1,557 Broadway. The severe penalty,

Prompt police action halted a near-riot in the Grand Central Station of the I. R. T. subway just before noon yesterday when a huge throng of passengers from a northbound train attempted to seize a Negro who allegedly had stabbed a white youth during an altercation.

The Arundel Corporation of Brooklyn, which submitted a figure of $377,044, was announced as the low bidder on a project to deepen and widen the channel along the east side of -Flushing Bay from the main East River channel at College Point to the City. Boat Basin being constructed near the World's Fair site.

The utility industry as a potential major force working for the recovery of the nation is being stymied by a small group within the industry intent on preserving intangible interests regardless of the cost, William O.

For four hours today Albert Sarraut, Minister of the Interior and director of French North African Affairs, appeared before the Senate Foreign Affairs Commission and described in detail the situation with regard to the African colonies.

When the Metropolitan Savings Bank sold to Louis Akst and his wife the house at 184 Forsyth St for $16,000 they gave back a p. m. mortgage for $15,000, payable seven years hence at 3 per cent, paying off $50 quarterly.

Events continue to illustrate the folly of attempting to legislate an automatic foreign policy applicable to all possible emergencies, regardless of when and where they may arise and what their impact on our own affairs may be. When reports came from Japan

Salaries of employes of the Chicago Board of Trade who receive in excess of $150 a month will be reduced 10 per cent as a matter of economy, it was announced today. It is expected an annual saving of $25,000 will result.

The marriage of Mrs. Sally Joost Chace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman B. Joost of 1,185 Park Avenue and Quogue, L. I., to Ludlow Van Deventer of Plainfield, N. J., will take place here on Saturday at the home of her parents in the presence of the two families.
James F. Galligan, superintendent of the eastern district of the Connecticut State Highway Department, died at his home in Middletown this afternoon after a long illness. He was born in New York,

The "small business man" descended on this bewildered city a thousand strong today and in the course of a tumultuous day-long session in the Commerce Department's auditorium gave his individual views on what is wrong in the nation.
Funeral services for Dr. John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent of Schools, who died Tuesday, will be held at 10 A. M. tomorrow at the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension on West 107th Street.

In a rough-and-tumble basketball encounter, where finesse played a minor part, City College outlasted Manhattan to win, 33 to 30, before a wildly excited gathering of 11,000 in Madison Square Garden last night. They didn't have to dust off the court after that battle. The players had done it with their uniforms.

Senate investigators contended today that balance sheets of the Pennroad Corporation, a railroad holding company, presented a "ridiculously artificial picture" because they showed a capital surplus of $126,000,000.

FIRST RACE--Purse $800; maiden 2-year-old fillies; Nursery Course; three furlongs (straightaway). Start good; won driving; place same. Went to post 2:01, off 2:07. Winner, ro. f., by Gino--Sun Fritters. Trainer, G. C. Winfrey. Time--0:34 4/5.

Convinced that extension of residential districts on the upper East Side is necessary to protect the orderly growth of that neighborhood, property owners there are studying plans to provide zoning protection to many more blocks above the Queensborough Bridge.

Australia today named Jack Bromwich, Adrian Quist, L. A. Schwartz and Harry C. Hopman as its representatives in 1938 Davis Cup competition. Vivian McGrath and Jack Crawford, veterans of last year's squad, and Pen Turnbull, doubles star, announced they would not be available.
The Rev. Dr. Charles Stoddard Lane, professor emeritus of the Hartford Seminary Foundation, Hartford, Conn., died at his Winter home here today. His age was 78.

Despite a strike that tied up production in the middle of the year and the severe decline in business in the fourth quarter, the Republic Steel Corporation reported today for 1937 a net income of $9,044,147, including surtax on undistributed profits.

Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today that a claim of $985,982.73 for back personal income taxes had been filed by the State against the estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Hetty Green, the woman financier.

Deep in the basement of the old gymnasium behind the famous statue of Alma Mater, Columbia's oarsmen furnished their campus with a sign of approaching Spring when members of this year's crew squad reported yesterday to Hubert Glendon, head coach,

With his jaw pierced by a bullet fired at close range, the body of George D. Callahan, 38 years old, a liquor salesman of Woodbury, N. J., was found in his parked automobile on the Harding Highway near here at 4:30 o'clock this morning.
Seven Boston players today were named for the United States fifteen-man squash racquet team that will attempt to regain the Lapham Cup from a Canadian squad here Saturday at the Harvard Club.

The Department of Justice, successful In recent anti-trust prosecution of sixteen major oil companies at Madison, Wis., announced today it would press charges next Fall against twenty-four oil companies and forty-six individuals.

The artistic trials and talents of sixteen members of Columbia University's staff and seven faculty wives were revealed yesterday afternoon at the opening of the second annual faculty art exhibition in the Columbia art gallery, University Hall. Comprising seventy-seven oils,

The Rev. Edmund A. O'Connor, pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church at Little Falls, N. Y., and formerly assistant pastor of St. Joseph's Church in Albany, died Sunday night in Peter's Hospital, Albany, after an illness of six weeks. He was born at Waterford,

Grain markets turned downward today on liquidation by scattered longs. The pressure in wheat was mainly on the May delivery, which was effected largely by the continued lack of aggressive foreign demand.

Charles Q. Eldredge, nationally known for his museum of rare articles collected in his world travels, died at his home here at 12:45 A. M. today at the age of 92. He had been in ill health for a year and was stricken with his final illness a week ago. He suffered a shock last Summer when his second wife died.
There is little possibility that a new Queens criminal courts building will be constructed in the near future, Mayor La Guardia yesterday told county officials and members of the December grand jury.

Queens University's hockey team topped the University of Toronto, 4 to 3, tonight to climb into a tie with McGill for the lead in the International Collegiate Hockey League. The Queens skaters did all their scoring in the first two periods, paced by Johnny Munro, who counted two unassisted goals and then stopped Toronto's thirdperiod surge just short of tying.
Mrs. Henry Alvah Strong of Rochester, N. Y., widely known for her benefactions, is the donor of the George Washington University Hall of Government.
Edwin J. Lukas, an attorney of this city, bought from James S. Wolf a ten-room dwelling and six acres in Rosedale Avenue, White Plains, N. Y., through Howard L. Auerbach. Inc.. broker.

The preliminary report of the United Gas Improvement Company for 1937, to be issued today, shows that net income after expenses and taxes was $28,150,549. This compares with $27,953,755 earned in 1936. Total income rose $188,216

The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Watkins, Moderator of the Westchester County Presbytery and pastor of the White Plains Presbyterian Church for the last twelve years, died here early today in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 47 years old.

Winning seven of nine events, Yale defeated the hitherto unconquered Rutgers swimmers, 48 to 27, in the Rutgers gymnasium pool tonight before 1,500 persons. Pete Brueckel of the Blue was the only double winner, beating Frank Paret of the Scarlet in the 150-yard backstroke in 1:43.3, and returning to capture the 440-yard free style from his teammate, Spendelow, in the good time of 5:08.6.

Finance Independence Founders, Inc., New York, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 4,500 periodic-deposit trust certificates with insurance, to be offered at $1,200 each; 3,500 periodic-deposit

The League of Nations session closed today with the Council's adoption of a resolutior reaffirming the Geneva position in favor of China and with the indefinite adjournment of the committee on League reform after the adoption of a brief noncommittal report to the September Assembly.

Homer Stanley, a Milwaukec carpenter, staked his veracity yesterday against the verdict of a lie detector and the gamble cost him $118.50. Judge J. M. Braude set the fine for drunken driving at $25 and then suggested that if the lie detector at Northwestern University showed he was telling the truth when he said he had had one beer Stanley would pay the $25 fine and Judge Braude would pay $10 for the test.

William R. Hoepfner of 299 East Fifth Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 66, after an illness of three weeks. He was a member of Farrington, Gould Hoagland, monument and mausoleum manufacturers, 258 Broadway, and president of Memorial Associates, Inc., an organization of monument manufacturers.

A proposal for France to lay down six 35,000ton battleships within the next three years will be presented to. the Cabinet tomorrow by Naval Minister William Bertrand, a member of his staff said today.

Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia is vacationing incognito in the Semmering district, and it is expected he will- confer with Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, as he always does when he visits Austria.

Four of the country's outstanding women golfers scored double victories in the annual Miami Biltmore championship today. The second and third rounds of match play were contested and the survivors were Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old Minneapolis sensation;

Estate, more than $10,000. To Frances Benenson, widow, executrix, 262 Central Park West, household, personal effects and life estate in residue; Raymond Benenson, Lawrence Benenson and Charles Benenson, executor, sons, all of 262 Central Park West, succeeding estate in residue, with parts of principal at different age and balance of principal at 35;
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Dorothea Antel, former actress, whose stage career was cut short eighteen years ago by a spine and leg injury and who had been bedridden ever since, died Tuesday night at her home, 316 West Seventy-second Street, of pneumonia.
Turkey is likely to be the first country to benefit from relaxation of the British Government's ban on foreign lending.
Transactions on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange in January totaled 546,303 shares with a market value of $5,000,374, the lowest January turnover since 1934.

Longfellow Ave (11-3001), w s. 200 ft n of 172d St, 150x100: Marion Molander to 1,547 Longfellow Realty Corp, 1,450 Bway; mtg $185,800. Loring Pl (11-3225). e s, 95 ft s of Fordham Rd, 75x129; Edison Estates, Inc. to Frances Schoenfeld, 2.914 Cruger Ave; mtg $42.380.

Private industry must find the means of making jobs for men and women who have reached or passed the age of 40, Edward C. Rybicki, chairman of the board of directors of the State League on Economics, -asserted todaybefore the joint legislative committee investigating discrimination against the middle-aged.

Persons prominent in political affairs of the city and State were present last night at the annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club in the WaldorfAstoria. The attendance was more than 1,000.

If the Red Trade Union International is admitted into the International Federation of Trade Unions the American Federation of Labor "will feel compelled to withdraw" from the I. F. T. U., President William Green said today.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Receipts 19,000, including 9,000 directs: opened steady to 10c higher, closed steady to 10c lower than yesterday's average. Top, $8.75; bulk good and choice 140-220 pounds, $8.40-70; 230-270 pound butchers, $7.75-$8.40;

Federal legislation to outlaw direct sales to consumers by wholesalers or producers who also sell through regular retail channels is urged by the National Association of Retail Grocers, as one means of combatting the current recession.

With installment credit sales representing about 12.5 per cent of the country's retail trade, steps to control the quantity and timing of the use of this form of credit are now vital to stabilize production and to safeguard against potential overexpansion dangers,

Octavian Goga, Premier of Rumania, said in a written statement:today that anti-Semitism and nationalism were enduring features of Rumanian policy. He asserted' anti-Semitism would continue even if he were removed from the Premiership.

A Chicago couple whose ages total 165 years are celebrating their sixtieth wedding anniversary in New York. after a trip here by air. When a United Airlines plane set them down at Newark on Tuesday, it was not only the first flight either had made, but also their first visit to New York since they landed from Holland more than sixty-five years ago.

Two points scored just as the whistle sounded brought victory for McBurney School over Brooklyn Prep, 27-26, in a basketball game on the McBurney court yesterday. Before that deciding field goal Brooklyn Prep was ahead, 26-25.

A leading West Side sale yesterday was that of the four-story building at 243-245 West Sixtieth Street. The structure occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and was sold by the Franklin Savings Bank to the United Van Service, which recently acquired two buildings in Jersey City for its expanding storage business.

Jack Dempsey and James J. Braddock, two former heavyweight champions, had proteges fighting last night in the Hippodrome, but each did his second's chores by remote control. Braddock did not even see Bob Tow, Washington heavyweight, in action, and Dempsey sat several rows distant from Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore.

Royal Mail, H. Lloyd Thomas's black son of My Prince, today became the favorite to repeat his 1937 victory in the one hundredth running of the Grand National at Aintree on March 25 as the field was reduced from seventy-nine to fifty-seven.

Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the board of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway entertained a proposal to sell the Choctaw Division of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway several months after control of the Rock Island had been obtained by the Frisco in 1926, it was testified yesterday in Supreme Court here. Earlier Mr.

Morris Ave. 2,001 (11-2829); Paulyne Zerner to General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of New York City, 20 W 44th St; extends mtgs to Dec. 15, 1942, at 4 per cent; $144,000. 179th St, 774 E (11-3106); Loyal Holding Corp to Harlem Savings Bank; due as per bond: $18,000.

The storm precipitated in the highest government circles by the marriage of Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, the War Minister, to one of his secretaries, which simultaneously brought to a climax many other latent issues long postponed, drew ever-widening circles today and began to rock the delicately adjusted balance of power between the army and the National Socialist party on which rests the stability of the Third Reich.

The de Basil Ballet Russe, now on the Pacific Coast on its fifth annual American tour, is to be reorganized at the conclusion of its present season, according to an announcement last night by Prince Serge Obolensky. A new company,

C. J. Gignoux, president of the French Employers Association, protested today before the Chamber of Deputies Labor Commission against parts of Premier Camille Chautemps's proposed labor charter as tending to undermine employers' authority.

An order to discontinue various practices alleged to restrict price competition and keep prices at an artificial level has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission against fourteen companies representing practically the entire source of supply in the country of chalk and wax crayons,
Zinka Milanov, the young Yugoslav soprano who made her debut as Leonore in "II Trovatore" some weeks ago, assumed her second role at the Metropolitan Opera House last night-the name part of "Aida."

The massing of United States and foreign troops, probably about 50,000 in all, will be a feature of the opening of the World's Fair, but as a gesture of peace, Grover A. Whalen, president of that organization, informed directors and patrons of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, Inc., yesterday.
A dance will be held Friday at the Gotham as one of a series known as the Southern Reunion Dances. Many dinner parties will precede the event.

In what was described as "the greatest public health demonstration the country has ever seen," the second National Social Hygiene Day was observed throughout the country yesterday with more than 3,000 meetings, conferences and radio broadcasts emphasizing the need for a nation-wide war against social diseases.

Payment of monthly checks by the Cleveland Baseball Club of the American League to the mother of Louis Boudreau, captain of the University of Illinois basketball team, ended Boudreau's intercollegiate athletic career today.

To the confusion. of newspaper editors at a critical hour tonight the luncheon announcement by Viscount Bledisloe, president of the National Council of Social Service, that Queen Mary would shortly visit parts of the distressed area in South Wales, was officially denied.

The city of St. Paul, Minn., awarded yesterday several issues of various purpose bonds, aggregating $824,000, to three banking groups. The largest block, consisting of $359,000 of sewer and sewage disposal bonds, maturing Feb. 1, 1941

Justice in the so-called inferior criminal courts in New York City is being impeded by an obsolete and cumbersome system which causes trouble and expense for accused persons and witnesses, and which our magistrates themselves deplore.

John M. Tienken, retired salesman of the National Biscuit Company and a leader in the Methodist Episcopal Church, died yesterday at his home, 323 East Eighteenth Street, after a long illness. He was born here 76 years ago.

MURPHY 2d Ave. 551, 4-story tenement, 19.8x77; East River Savings Bank against William Kahn: due, $7,517; taxes, etc, $31; to plaintiff for $5,000.

The Rev. Endicott Peabody, headmaster of Groton School, who has been named to officiate at the wedding of John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President, and Miss Anne Lindsay Clark of Boston on June 18, is ill at the Massachusetts General Hospital. Physicians today reported him "doing very well."

Mrs. George William Tucker of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Fuller Tucker, to James Morrow McIlvaine, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Linton McIlvaine of Tenafly, N. J.

As the committee of five Councilmen named to investigate the election of Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens prepared to hold its first session this morning, Mr. Quinn announced last night that he had retained Richard J. Barry, Queens attorney, to defend him.

That trading in securities, on a when-issued basis, on a registered securities exchange will be impossible under the new short-selling rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will take effect on next Tuesday, was the conclusion reached yesterday by experts in Wall Street from a study of the effects of the new rules.
Dr. William H. Crocker, director of the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research, will receive tonight the gold medal of the American Institute at the institute's dinner at the Hotel Ambassador.

A general lockout in the fur industry, effective a week from Friday, was voted without a dissenting voice last night by more than 1,200 members of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Association at a meeting at the Hotel Penneylvania.

The goal of the Philharmonic-Symphony League, as announced yesterday, is a membership of 10,000-as large a number of members as there were men taking part in the famous anabasis concerning which Xenophon left a lasting story. But it is an army of peace
Count Johannes von Welczeck, the German Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos today. to protest the anti-Nazi exhibition being held in Paris. The exhibition,
More than 400 employes of the Crucible Steel Compay, who ended a strike last night after a compromise on disputed working conditions, returned to work this morning at the company's plant here.

John Cavanaugh, executive of the Hat Corporation of America and member of the Merritt Parkway Commission, testified today before the special grand jury on the sale of fourteen acres in Norwalk by his wife to the State for the parkway right-of-way for $57,000.

New financing yesterday included loans on housing and business property in the Bronx and Manhattan. The 831 Gerard Avenue Building Corporation, Gustave Halpern, president, obtained a loan of $335,000 for ten years on the eight-story apartment house completed recently at the northwest corner of 158th Street and Gerard Avenue, the Bronx. Clarence Tracy Hutchins, 57-yearold executive of the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Corporation, was taken to Roosevelt Hospital yesterday morning in a serious condition after he had been knocked down by a taxicab at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.
Associate Justice McReynolds, senior member of the Supreme Court in point of continuous service, was 76 years old today. He has served since Oct. 12, 1914.

Maryland's State Racing Commission put into effect today a rule that all horses must be examined by a veterinarian before going to the post. Trainers may, under the rule, refuse to permit the examination, but must then assume all responsibility for the' horse's condition and its ability to run. If, subsequently,
Evidence of a decided countrywide awakening in real estate circles such as was noted yesterday in New York City is given in dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES as follows:
A consignment of Italian military airplanes has been delivered to the Afghanistan air force at Kabul by road through Khyber Pass.

Last year established a new low rate of 8.22 deaths per 1,000 among the 17,700,000 industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, a decline of 2.1 per cent from the figure registered for 1936, according to a report by the company's statisticians made public yesterday.

The basis for an agreement on controversial features of the Maloney bill for the registration of a national association of over-the-counter brokers and dealers with the Securities and Exchange Commission was sought today at a conference between
The House Appropriations Committee recommended a $27,638,524 deficiency. appropriation today to finance various governmental activities for the remainder of the fiscal year.

Martin Krompier, reputed chief aide to the late Arthur (Dutch Shultz) Flegenheimer, underworld racketeer, was acquitted last night by a jury of four women and ten men in Brooklyn Federal Court on a three-count indictment charging him with conspiracy to conceal assets, concealing assets and transferring assets of $100,000 in a bankruptcy proceeding.

The most extensive manoeuvres ever held in these waters began today when Air Vice Marshal A. W. Teddea sent two flying boat squadrons racing over the China Sea to find the approaching "Blueland" fleet before it comes nearer this most important of British outposts in the Far East.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson commented on the "lengthy and oppressively expensive" method of administering justice today at a hearing on claims for services in the reorganization of the Baldwin Locomotive Works. Claims for $890,000 were filed by attorneys, banking interests and various stockholders' committees.

A client of Farrell Brothers, brokers, has bought the three-story building at 37-62 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, from the estate of Ida Aaronberg. The house contains one store and four apartments. Walter Samuels were cobrokers.

A force yet to be measured but certainly to be considered in current Brazilian affairs is the tide of international propaganda running this way in increasing volume in the last few years, particularly from Germany, Italy and Japan.

The preferred stockholders' protective committee for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation 7 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock has been disbanded, according to an announcement yesterday by Joseph P. Ripley, chairman of the committee.

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers for January made a remarkably good showing, practically equaling the figures for the corresponding month of last year, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The total for last month
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days.
Colgate won its fourth straight tonight, beating the Middlebury basketball team, 45-23, with Ray Dieffenbach of the Maroon scoring 11 points. At half-time Colgate led, 25 to 9.
Mrs. Cordelia Howard MacDonald, who as Little Eva in "Uncle Tom's Cabin" won the applause of Abraham Lincoln, today began her ninety-first year of life.
Robert Piguet's collections of fashions is based on the plumper silhouette fitted to the hips and abandoning-belts. Every possible modification of this idea is featured for all hours.

The largest crowd ever to witness a ski tournament in the United States is expected to be present at Soldier Field, Chicago, on Sunday when the Central Ski Association's annual jumping championship is held on what is believed to be the world's biggest artificial tower.

An intensive campaign to sell certificates of membership in the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be continued for at least two weeks by the trade and industry committee of the fund-raising drive, it was announced yesterday.

Amendment to Rules and Regulations Section 233 shall be amended by placing "a period" instead of "a comma" after the word absence on the eighth line, and striking out the words: "and the addresses of places to be visited."

Almost endless possibilities in the creation and harnessing of tiny wave that travel inside of metal tubes, or through cylinders of rubber, which may open communication channels more vast than all the radio waves now in use, were predicted here last night at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

Miss Anna Louise Amendt, reputed at one time to be the highest salaried woman in the country and for forty-seven years private secretary to the late Gage E. Tarbell, vice president of The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died on Tuesday at her home at Tarbell Farms, Smithville Flats, N. Y. Her age was 71.

The hearing this afternoon of the. Finance Committees of the Senate and Assembly on Governor Lehman's tax program was interrupted when only half way through by what at first appeared to be a leak in the roof of the Capitol.

Ecuador's campaign against foreign corporations continues unabated, according to newspapers received here. The action of President Alberto Enriquez seems to have the support of the public generally, the army and the press.

An apartment in the cooperative building at 1,165 Fifth Avenue has been bought by Kathleen N. Coxhead through Pease Elliman, Inc. Louis C. Mand, with Pease Elliman since 1915, has been elected a director and vice president of the company.

Two seniors from the Scarborough School reached the quarter-final round ahead of the rest of the field in the twelfth annual De Witt Clinton interscholastic indoor tennis championship yesterday. William Gillespie, seeded No.
An East Side property that had been held in one ownership since 1865 passed to new control in the sale yesterday of 850 Second Avenue, between Forty-fifth and Fortysixth Streets. The buyer intends
Miss Bernice Wall and Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, favorites in the Belleair women's golf championship, won their second round matches today to advance to the final.

The stock market here was generally quiet today but its cheerful tendency was well maintained. Gilt-edge issues went ahead, influenced by relaxation of the restriction on foreign lending. Among the foreign bonds,
Long-hitting Jimmy Thomson, winner of the Los Angeles open last month, remained far in front today as leading money winner of the California Winter golf tournament season.

The Egyptian Chamber of Deputies inaugurated on May 23, 1936, was dissolved today by royal decree. According to the Constitution, new elections must take place within two months. Article II of today's decree provides that the new chamber must meet on April 12.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed today a District Court decree denying to three power companies an injunction against the $37,500,000 SanteeCooper power and navigation project in South Carolina.

The Police Athletic League will introduce at 5 P. M. on Saturday a series of weekly amateur broadcasts with talent from the ranks of its own members. The broadcast will be over Station WBNX (1,350 Kc.).

A worker in the Prospect Park Zoo lost his right arm yesterday as the result of a sudden and ferocious attack by a Bengal tiger. The screams of the victim and the growls of the tiger sent visitors to the lion house scurrying away and roused the animals in the house to a frenzy which necessitated closing that part of the zoo for four hours.

Collective bargaining with organized labor can be conducted better by groups of employers or trade associations than by individual firms, C. Oliver Wellington of the management consultant firm of McKinsey, Wellington Co. said

The Metropolitan Opera Artists' Club of California, to advise and encourage young and talented singers, was organized here today. Dr. Richard Hageman was elected president; Grace Moore, first vice president, and Mario Chamlee, second vice president.

The Commercial Credit Company in its consolidated annual report for the year ended Dec. 31, 1937, reports net income from operations, after deductions for minority interest and provision for taxes, including undistributed profits surtax, amounted to $13,593,119, compared to $12,005,779 for 1936.

Harry Bridges virtually served notice on the Superior Court here today that if there was any interference with the present monopoly of his C. I. O. International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union over longshoring at Los Angeles, harbor maritime unions would paralyze Pacific Coast shipping.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions BELL RADIO, INC., 168 Greenwich St.Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $13,913 and assets of $19,441. NEON RADIO CORP., 174 Greenwich St.Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptey Law listing liabilities of $44,423 and assets of $49,884.

The Northern New England Power Company, Augusta, Me., a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company, a registered holding company, has registered under the Holding Company Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

As the current depression continues, there become apparent a great many superficial similarities to the earlier stages of the Great Depression. To the list of these must be added the apparently very general belief among the small business men now convening in Washington that what is needed is "more credit," for little business.
Boston University's football team will play only one New England opponent next Fall, Boston College, according to the schedule, announced today.

Additional contributions totaling $1,716 were received yesterday by the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, in response to President Roosevelt's appeal for aid to the distressed civilians of China. The total raised up to last night by the chanter was $7.378.

Edouard E. H. Armand, in 17 W. 54th St., through Douglas Gibbons Co.; Dr. William Cliff, in 123 E. 61st St.; George B. Plush. Prentice B. Bassett, in 160 E. 48th St.; Joy Wolfson, in 124 E. 60th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.

Paul Blanshard, former Commissioner of Accountants, was one of the 118 attorneys who were sworn in as members of the bar yesterday in the court room of the Appellate Division, Second Department, in the Borough Hall, Brooklyn.

Professor Kenneth S. M. Davidson of Stevens Institute, Hoboken, N. J., whose experimental work in the institution's towing tank received prominence because of the success of the America's Cup defender Ranger last Summer, yesterday issued a printed report in which some of his aims for the future were outlined.
Deadlocked on the Teruel front in Eastern Spain and north of Cordoba in the South, Spanish Government and Insurgent Armies today searched for openings in their enemy's lines.

In a letter to holders of Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., first mortgage 5 per cent bonds, mailed yesterday, Joseph P. Ripley, chairman of the bondholders' representative committee, said the committee was "not willing to abandon its efforts to effect some

Capt. Frederic W. Hodge, FA-Res., 60 East 42d St., New York, N. Y., 61st Cavalry Division, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective Feb. 2, at Newcomb, N. Y., reporting upon arrival to the Commanding Officer, CCC Co. 1297, Camp $129 (Railhead: North Creek, N. Y.), for CCC duty.

Henry Pringle, who has been working for a number of years on an authorized "Life and Letters of William Howard Taft," has virtually finished the manuscript and Farrar Rinehart announce that this two-volume biography by the Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer will be published this Autumn.

B. D. Barnett, general manager of the metropolitan division of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was appointed yesterday assistant vice president of the commercial department in direct charge of the commercial field administration of the company, according to an announcement by J. C. Willever, vice president of Western Union.

The Senate passed today, without opposition or debate, the bills to abolish "blueribbon" juries in New York, Kings, the Bronx, Queens and Westchester Counties, the only places where they are now used. The bills,

Elliott Clemence of Clemco, Inc., of Newark, N. J., has purchased from Harry Colen and associates the former estate of Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Company, on Western Drive, Short Hills, N. J.

The "Aryan" paragraph recently introduced in the by-laws of several sporting associations here excluding Jewish clubs from membership in national organizations was held illegal today by the government's Physical Education Bureau,

Unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization took issue yesterday with the position of the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., on the question of barring Communists from membership.

Leo L. Fenbert, a 32-year-old lawyer, received a prison sentence of two years yesterday after pleading guilty to having misappropriated $27,031 while serving as co-trustee in the bankruptcy proceedings of Ray Long and Richard R. Smith, Inc., publishers.

The Huron River Silica Company, Detroit, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 375,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

The winds blew, the sun went behind dark clouds, occasionally a rainbow arched over a score of boats, and we sat in a fishing chair in the cockpit of Captain Ed Dowling's boat trying for the sailfish that make this place a haunt of the salt-water anglers. We not only tried, we hooked two of them, but we didn't get them into the boat.
