Leases of store, office and showroom space reported yesterday included several contracts for entire floors. The latest rentals follow: Edwin M. Stroock, store displays, floor in 113 W. 31st St.; Ben Kirschenbaum, buttons and novelties, additional floor in 149 W. 36th St.; Stuart-Nelson, Ltd.,

Weston B. Grimes, attorney for Cargill, Inc., said today that the charge of market manipulation against the firm's subsidiary, the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois, and its officers was an attempt by the Chicago Board of Trade to bolster its prestige.

The University of Newark scored its eighth victory of the season tonight by defeating the Rutgers College of Pharmacy five, 67 to 44. The Newark play was centered around the passing of Nick Halulakos and the defensive work of Irwin Kaplus.
At petition time in the House of Commons this afternoon twenty-two attendants carried the Speaker a petition bearing 804,000 signatures in forty-one bundles.

Hundreds of builders in the metropolitan district were busy yesterday making final plans to start immediately a new era of home-building activity as a result of the passage by Congress of FHA amendments offering to prospective dwelling owners the easiest financing terms ever available to the public generally in the nation's history.

Gross assets. $5,874: net, $5,004. To husband, Solomon Baar, $3,500 mortgage and $500; niece, Miriam Kalter, and nephews, Karl Kalter and Herbert and Mitchell Katz $251 each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $5,874. S. F. and J. F. Katz, attorneys, 25 W. 43d St., Manhattan.

Chancing, 7-year-old son of Chance Play, owned by D. J. Sullivan 3d, refused to give up after being headed at the top of the stretch today, coming back to win the six-furlong feature for players at the Fair Grounds.

Bill De Correvont, touchdown hero of America's prep gridirons, will enter Northwestern University next Fall. There, along with four of his high school team-mates, he plans to continue his amazing football career.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The sucker bait put out by the Administration will probably do what Mr. Krock says it will do-make the small business men forget what they came for-and in the first place the Administration probably took good care not to pick any one who does not hurrah for the Administration.

64th St. 27-29-31 W: 75x84; for 6-story tenement; Mattson Holding Corp, 511 5th Ave, owner; Horace Ginsbern, architect; cost, $150,000. Alterations 17th St, 409 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Bank for Savings in the City of New York. 280 4th Ave., owner; L. E. Ordwein. architect; cost, $3,500.

Landowners in the Saugatuck Valley below the southern end of the proposed Saugatuck reservoir, filed suit today asking $250,000 damages and a permanent injunction restraining the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company from interfering with the natural flow of the river by construction of a dam.

Myles A. Cunningham, assistant superintendent of mails in charge of the registry section of the Brooklyn Postoffice, who had been in the postal service for the last thirty-six years, died yesterday at his home, 599 Macon Street, Brooklyn.

While Britain is seeking by broadcasts in Arabic to counteract Mussolini's persistent anti-British propagenda in the same language, and to bring about peace in Palestine between Arab and Jew, Sir Oswald Mosley, the English Fascist leader, is credited with attempting to embroil still further the racial factions in the Holy Land.
Mrs. Carrie Stix Weiss, widow of Samuel W. Weiss, lawyer, died yesterday afternoon at her residence, 25 West Eighty-first Street, after a lingering illness.

Pursuant to order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Judicial Department, County and State of New York, dated Dec. 17, 1937, and Certificate No. S-140 of the Director of the Budget, dated Jan. 18, 1938, the following reinstatement is- ordered:
His work as a two-gun hero of the movies finished, Lou Gehrig is leaving Hollywood and heading East for a salary conference with Ed Barrow, business manager of the Yankees.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson commented on the "lengthy and oppressively expensive" method of administering justice today at a hearing on claims for services in the reorganization of the Baldwin Locomotive Works.
" What is the foreign policy of the United States?'" asked Senator Johnson of California, three times, in the course of a ragged, running debate his inquiry has started in the Senate.

The New York Rovers scored three times in the last period to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 4 to 2, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight. The victory enabled the Rovers to break a tie with Atlantic City for second place and put them only one point behind leagueleading Hershey.
Reds rearranged portions of the newly announced National League schedule today to provide for their program of seven night games. All clubs except New York will appear in the series.

Robert T. (Bobby) Jones of international golfing fame will head the newly-organized American Golf Institute with headquarters here, it was announced yesterday. The institute will serve as a clearinghouse of information concerning golf and will seek- to develop and advance the sport throughout the country.

The convention of the United Mine Workers of America voted today that the International Executive Board should try William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on charges of treason to the union in fostering the "dual" Progressive Mine Workers and expel him from the U. M. W. if found guilty.

Another lease in the Port of New York Authority Building at 111 Eighth Avenue was announced yesterday with the closing of a contract for 14,000 square feet by the Seggerman Nixon Corporation, importers and distributors of wines and liquors.

Walter Beck defeated Milton Kaye, 40 to 33, in fifty-four frames last night in a three-cushion tourney match at McGirr's Academy. The winner's high run was 4 to 3 for his opponent. In another engagement Joe Toomey beat Leo Lewis, 40 to 34, in fifty-six innings, each having a cluster of 4.

Henry J. McCarthy, 44 years old, of 293 .Brighton Avenue,' Long Branch, former president of the Long Branch Democratic Club, was injured fatally and a woman companion was hurt early today when they were struck by an automobile as they crossed Main Street, near Asburv Avenue. here.

Nathaniel Weltchek, former president of the Board of Public Works of Elizabeth, N. J., and Samuel Elkin and Harold Miller, proprietors of the Lion Varnish Works, of 400 Withers Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to a charge of conspiracy and were sentenced by Judge Franklin Taylor to serve indeterminate terms in the New York County penitentiary.

Continuing her brilliant playing, Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old Minneapolis star, scored another easy victory in defense of her laurels in the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today. She defeated Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, Ga., 18-year-old Southern champion. 4 and 3.
The New York University women's fencing team opened its season by defeating the Waverly F. C., 5 to 4, last night on the strips of the East Building at Washington Square.
Michael B. Donovan, 58-year-old guard and investigator for the Consolidated Edison Company, was killed yesterday when. a bullet from the pistol of a comrade accidentally struCk him in the neck.

Lieut. Gov. Frank J. Hayes of Colorado started a Presidential boom for John L. Lewis here today at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America, and the 2,019 delegates whooped it up for their president.

Thornton Wilder's first original full-length play for the Broadway stage comes tonight to Henry Miller's Theatre, bearing the name "Our Town" and telling the story of thirteen years in the life of a New England village.

The government dealt a blow to its own "Tory-Socialist" program last night when it retreated before a determined lobby of coal mine owners and fewer than 100 Right Wing Conservative members on the- floor of the House of Commons.

Approval of the New York World's Fair in 1939 as an instrument for the creation of better world understanding and the advancement of the cause of peace has been expressed by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State.

In a jammed Bronx County courtroom a legal precedent was set for the county yesterday when three women, one of whom will act as foreman, were selected to serve as jurors in the murder trial of George De Renna.

R. H. Israel, president and director of Nash Motors Company of New York, Inc., has been named Eastern sales manager of the Nash Motors parent company, Detroit, in addition to his present duties. E. B. Shumate has been appointed vice president and general manager of the New York company.

Flushed with its success in the recent criminal anti-trust proceedings against the oil industry at Madison, Wis., the Department of Justice gives notice of an intention to press other criminal indictments in the gasoline jobbers case.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Eichhold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Charles Eichhold of 565 Park Avenue, to Clifford M. Ellinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Ellinger of this city and Nantucket, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride.

Reorders on bedspreads in the last week to ten days have run to substantially larger quantities than were reordered a year ago, selling agents reported yesterday. They said jobbers had taken the lines on the road just after Jan. 1, and the response was sufficient to cause heavy repeat orders from the jobbers.
Viscountess Astor, member of the British Parliament and an outspoken enemy of communism, sailed for home yesterday with a warning for the United States against the subtleties of that political creed.

A six-point program for the guidance of retail stores in meeting their current problems was adopted yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which is holding its twenty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. Andrew J. Noe, Elaine Denton, George S. Messersmith, Mrs. Rebecca Hourwich Reyher, Mrs. Hanna Sheehy Skeffington.
Seven seniors at Columbia College, the top-ranking 2 per cent of their class,--were inducted yesterday into Phi Beta Kappa by Professor James Gutman, president of the Columbia section of the Delta
Five bills, sponsored by the State Flood Control Commission and designed to further the Federal flood control program in the State, were offered in the Legislature today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Mayor's message to the Board of Estimate on Jan. 27 has evoked various and, on the whole, favorable comment not only in New York City but throughout the United States.
In the luncheon party of Miss M. Thayer Gibbons at the Stork Club were the Misses Lisa Mabon, Renee Schank, Dorothy Gerster, Margaret Mabon and Frances Clucas.

Dissolution of the New York Anti-Vivisection Society, with distribution of its funds among six other societies of similar, purpose in various sections of the country, was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary after objections to the dissolution were withdrawn by C. Helen King, a member of the society, which voted to dissolve about a year ago.
Nearly tra all major lines of business in the Pittsburgh district report moderately large gains last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

S. H. Ogden, vice president of the Pennroad Corporation, testified today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee that the Pennsylvania Railroad dictated some of the corporation's investments in order to make a profit for itself.

For what is believed to be the first time in history the French Chamber of Deputies was presided over today by a Negro when Gratien Candace, Deputy from Guadeloupe, took the chair as Vice President of the Chamber.

The plan proposed by the French interests for the reorganization of the capital set-up of Tudor City Seventh Unit, Inc., owner of the thirty-two-story Woodstock Tower Building, was rejected at a lively meeting of the stockholders yesterday.

Mississippi Broomhill Jake, a big brown and white pointer owned and handled by B. C. Goss of Cleveland, became No. 1 dog of the southern amateur field trials today by ranging to victory in the all-age stakes.

Old and modern paintings were sold at auction last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $18,905. The sale comprised property of the late Adele E. Schmidt, Robert Hosea and Camilo Aldao of this city, J. A. Hoagland of Scarsdale, N. Y., and other owners.

After two days of what was described as the bitterest kind of a fight,- a group of Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee. of the House believed tonight that they had won their fight for exclusion from the new tax bill of the so-called "third basket'' provision -which proposes a punitive tax upon closely held corporations.

The first United Council of American Methodism opened its three-day convention here today with the reading of a message from President Roosevelt in which he stressed the "need for a return to religion as exemplified in the Sermon on the mount.

Members of the vast metropolitan skiing army, who from week-end to week-end during the cold months look forward for suitable trail and open slope running in the "Northlands," will have to flee far from the city tomorrow and Sunday to get snow under their steel edges.

A fair amount of business on wool goods was written this week, but it was largely confined to comparatively few mills so that the market continued to have a spotty appearance, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
Associate Justice James Clark McReynolds celebrated his seventy-sixth birthday anniversary today by stickink to his Supreme Court duties.

Reports of an early conference agreement on the proposed farm bill served to counteract yesterday the influence of a weak stock market and lower foreign quotations on prices on the Cotton Exchange. The market not only displayed steadiness but improved 1 to 3 points. Liquidation of March obligations continued a feature of the trading along with purchases by commission houses of the later months.

Further action in regard to changes in the bill by Senator Maloney for control of trading over the counter through registration of a national association of brokers and dealers with the SEC will await the resumption of hearings before the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday when officials of the Investment Bankers Association will appear.
All reports from the Teruel front dur-ing the past four days tell of complete quiet with no evidence that a further great counter-offensive is being prepared.
Thus far the "Blueland's" attacking force in the manoeuvres appears to have had the worst of a preliminary encounter with the defenders of the Singapore base.

Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, steadfastly rebuffed before the House Naval Affairs Committee today all suggestions that the $800,000,000 Naval Construction Bill, drafted to carry out President Roosevelt's naval expansion program, was a measure of aggression rather than national defense.

Lady Eaton, who returned on the Berengaria, is at the Ambassador before going to her home in Toronto, Ont. Mrs. Wilson Hunt Blackwell will give a luncheon today at Sherry's for Miss Florence E. Emerson of Boston.

The Montreal Maroons crashed through with three third-period goals tonight to gain a 4-to-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks and climb within two points of the third-place New York Americans in the National Hockey League's International Group race.

The America Newspaper Publishers Association told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that a 15 per cent increase in railroad freight rates on newsprint would cost the railroads $410,342 a year instead of increasing their revenues.

Responding to petitions filed by the Attorney General of New York State and by the Consumers' Counsel in behalf of Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., regarding minimum coal prices fixed for bituminous coal mined in Districts 1 to 13,

The Utica Knitting Company has increased operations, giving 1,200 persons employment on a three-day week, according to Oscar W. Gridley, president and treasurer.
The number of life insurance companies which are members of the Federal Home Loan Bank system increased from three to twenty-eight in 1937, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

Mrs. Pauline Doyle, the former Miss Pauline Munn of Philadelphia and Paris, filed suit for divorce in Circuit Court here today from Milton Dorland Doyle, New York broker. Two similar suits were filed in previous years and dismissed.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it ended 1937 with the greatest number of policies and the largest amount of insurance ever in force for any company in the world.

Tonight's major events: "Saloma," Metropolitan Opera House; Povla Frijsh, soprano, Town Hall; Margaret Matzenauer, contralto, Carnegie Hall; Federal Opera Chorus and Greenwich Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre.

The six-story tenement at 305 E 114th St was sold by the Emigrant Bank to the Alitha Realty and Construction Corp, Carlos L. Henriques Jr., president, at a price shown as $18,000, the bank taking back a purchase money mortgage for $17,606, and also lending the new owner $14,700 under a building loan agreement.

Four hundred or more- representatives of Jewish organizations met at the Hotel Astor last night to pledge their support to the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee campaign for $5,100,000 for the relief and rehabilitation of Jews abroad.

The committee of five City Councilmen appointed last Tuesday to investigate the qualifications of Hugh Quinn as a member of the Council, held its first session yesterday at City Hall behind closed doors.
Captain John J. Strain, retired United States Army officer and a Rough Rider and scout under Theodore Roosevelt during the Spanish-American War, died here today.

A new plan was announce yesterday by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey through which, is is hoped, witnesses in trials in Special Sessions will be spared repeated appearances in the court rooms before cases finally are reached on the calendars.
United States Consul James Loder Park has been asked to identify electric light bulbs labeled "Made in the U. S. A." in a letter from Alfred, Chan, representing Chinese merchants here.

I find the detailed report of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters offering a 15 per cent refund on insurance premiums after a year of safe driving, with the statement that seven out of ten drivers will benefit.

The dollar showed further small losses yesterday in the foreign exchange market. The pound sterling rose 1/8 cent to $5.00 7/8, the franc gained 3/8 point to 3.27% cents, the guilder was up a point to 55.86 cents and the Swiss franc rose 2 points to 23.19 1/4 cents.

Creation of a "high school of science," to train prospective physicians, dentists, engineers and laboratory workers, was recommended by the Board of Superintendents yesterday. Emphasis would be placed on courses in mathematics, physics and other sciences.
William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday that the department had fined twenty-five brewers for selling short measures of beer in barrels and half barrels.

At the close of their fourth day of play, Welker Cochran of San Francisco tonight held a slight lead over the world champion, Jake Schaefer of Chicago, in their 3,600-point 18.2 balkline billiard title match.

" If Admiral Leahy said that the Japanese fleet would have fourteen battleships when its present construction program is completed, he must be building them in his imagination," said Rear Admiral Kiyoshi Noda, chief of the Naval Affairs Propagation Department, today.
Enough money is now available to take care of the government's work relief obligations through the fiscal year, Secretary Morgenthau. said today at his press conference.
A parliamentary committee today moved closer to final passage the bill designed to continue the present drastic restrictions on British imports of American movies.

Some observers who had expressed themselves as fearful that the more liberal rules for FHA mortgage assurance, just adopted by Congress, might result in a wave of unsound building or lead to wholesale foreclosures because of the low down payment required on the smaller homes have been reassured somewhat by a careful reading of the bill.

On this page today we publish an impressive letter from Mr. Vladeck, the majority leader of the City Council, setting forth in some detail what is involved in the housing program recently announced by the Mayor.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb.3.--The Porto Rico liner Coamo, sailing for New York this afternoon, carried more than 1,100 bags of parcel post, mostly dresses, silk underwear and children's clothes, diverted from express, owing to the stevedore's strike.

A client of the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., has purchased the two-story dwelling at 1,144 Fiftythird Street, Brooklyn, from the Bowery Savings Bank for occupancy. This house contains eleven rooms and stands on a plot 24.6 by 100 feet. S. Tessitore was cobroker.

The Commission of Correction reported today that the detention pens of the Domestic Relations Court, family branch, in Brooklyn were a fire trap. The report said the pens were unsatisfactory because of lack of ventilation and supervision.
Reiterating his first greetings when he was appointed a year ago-"Peace be with you"-Archbishop Luis M. Martinez made today in his first pastoral letter an urgent appeal for spiritual peace.

Colonel Thomas Spalding Wylly, wholesale lumber merchant, died on Wednesday in his apartment at 155 East Fifty-second Street, after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and maintained a Summer home at Tenafly, N. J.

A law which virtually places members of the medical: profession in Cuba under- government control through obligatory membership in the new National Medical College, was approved by the House of Representatives early this morning after an all night session. The bill was passed by the Senate on Jan. 26.

Acceptance of the Protestant cochairmanship of the National Conference of Jews and Christians by Dr. Arthur H. Compton, 1937 Nobel Prize winner and Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago, was announced yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, conference director. Dr. Compton succeeds the late Newton D. Baker.

Fellow-workers in the Jones Laughlin Steel Company works here disclosed today that Blaine Fairless, son of the president of the United States Steel Corporation, nad been an inspector at the mill for several weeks.
Creation of an authority empowered to issue bonds up to $200,000,000 for construction of a super-highway between New York and Albany was proposed today in the State Legislature.

The American boat Chuckle III, sailed by Harold Halsted with Reeve Bowden as crew-man, won the Cuba Cup in the twelfth international Star Class regatta when she crossed the finishing line second in the last race this morning, accumulating a total of 17 points. Chuckle III,
President Roosevelt canceled all engagements and remained in the White House to catch up on a large accumulation of mail and official business.

John C. Zulauf, a retired Indiana banker and writer on economic subjects, died yesterday at his home at 111 East Eightieth Street of a heart ailment after a brief illness. Mr. Zulauf was 73 years old.
With the city practically deserted by major league managers, interest in baseball activities swung yesterday from the trading mart to the contract-signing curb.

A rise of more than $8,000,000 in Dominion Government deposits was shown today in the Bank of Canada's report for the week ended yesterday, while other major item: on the statement remained practically unchanged.

Staging a brilliant rally on the incoming nine, Frederick C. Painton of Westport, Conn., the medalist, won his semi-final' match in the eleventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.
Trevanion B. Dallas, president of the American Bricquet Company, T sportsman and a member of a distinguished family, died in his apartment at the Belgravia here today. His age was 68.

The debtor's modified plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, now before the Interstate Commerce Commission, was denounced today ina brief by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as perpetuating control of the railroad by the Alleghany Corporation.

Ten government pursuit planes from Tampico and Monterrey today cruised over this area and troops were moved up to reinforce the garrison in Northeastern Mexico to assure the government's authority in view of the widespread unrest.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis moved swiftly yesterday -in an effort to regain his freedom or, second best, a reduction of his $300,000 bail in Philadelphia, while Assistant District Attorney Charles P. Grimes worked here on extradition papers which were expected to go to Governor Lehman today.

Taking heart from its two recent victories in byeelections against French National- Ja ist candidates who opposed spending money on armaments, the Canadian Government tonight announced another big defense appropriation which will be used principally for the protection of Canada's coasts.
The French Senate, virtually without discussion today, passed the Chamber's bill raisring the salaries of members of Parliament to 82,500 francs annually.

Fairfax Harrison was one of the railway presidents who greatly advanced efficiency of operation, after the depression following 1907. and who had an important hand in cooperating with the Government's operation of the railways after 1917. Harrison had headed.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran demurred yesterday at approval by the Board of Estimate of a $25,000 appropriation requested by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn to investigate sales tax administration in that borough, and his objection blocked authorization of the fund.
Bert Erdman of Mutual Rosenbloom Company was re-elected president of the Far Western Travelers Association, Inc., at the organization's annual meeting last night at the Hotel Victoria.

Led by the sharpshooting Eddie Wares, who scored two goals and received credit for an assist, the revitalized Detroit Red Wings decisively subdued the fast-sinking New York Americans, 6 to 1, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, told the Bond Club today that the railroads would spend at least $1,000,000,000 annually for several years in increased maintainance, equipment, etc., if the Interstate Commerce Commission approved their application for a 15 per cent. increase in freight rates.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club recorded its seventh victory in as many starts in the New York Amateur Hockey Association and tightened its hold on first place by beating the New York Athletic Club, 10 to 3, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Purchases of securities in odd lots exceeded sales by 323,719 shares on the New York Stock Exchange in the falling market in the week ended on Jan. 29, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Mrs. Mabel Mayo-Smith, widow of Professor Richmond Mayo-Smith of Columbia University, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a three weeks' illness. She was 74 years old.
The orange gardens of the Everglades Club was the setting today for a large cocktail party which Mr. and Mrs. Messmore Kendall gave for the Artists and Writers.

Benno Falk, in the Hotel Boliver; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, broker. Edward H. Hartwig, through Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, in 345 E 57th St; Paul J. Morrissey, in 355 E 86th St; Miss Sybla Ramus, in 905 Madison Ave; Duff Conger, Inc, broker.

A plan that would have the ultimate effect of reducing the tax on payrolls for social security and lowering the reserve requirements from the present figure of $47,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 or $10,000,000,000 was put before retail merchants yesterday by Jay Iglauer,

The second "Intimate Evening Dinner Dance" of the season took place last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. More than 200 reservations were made for the dinner and many subscribers came in later for supper and dancing.

Arthur Herring, who before his retirement twenty-seven years ago was manager of Taylor Co., 45 Art Wall Street, importers and exporters of iron and steel, died yesterday morning at his home, 593 Fifth Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness at the age of 87.

The trustees of the United States Trust Company at a meeting yesterday advanced William M. Kingsley from the position of president of the institution to that of chairman of the board, elected Williamson Pell, formerly first vice president, to the presidency and made Benjamin - Strong, formerly vice president, first vice president.

The FHA amendments enacted by Congress will accelerate the construction of moderately priced homes in New Jersey, according to Howard W. Van Ness, chairman of the subdividers' and homebuilders' committee of the New Jersey Associtation of Real Estate Boards. Mr.

Howard Goula, for forty years identified with the American stage, died this morning at his home, 20 Underhill Street, Winthrop, at the age of 74. His death removed one of the last if not actually the last surviving member of the famous theatrical company of the Old Boston Museum.

Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the board of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway, was questioned yesterday in the Supreme Court about financing undertaken in 1927 and 1930 by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway. The 'Frisco acquired stock control of the Rock Island for $10,506,090 on Jan. 22, 1926, and thereafter Mr. Brown became chairman of the Rock Island executive committee.

Emil Ericksen, a former president and secretary of the Norwegian Hospital in Brooklyn, who in 1923 received the Order of the Cross of St. Olaf, First Class, for his social service work among Norwegians in that borough, died on Tuesday at his home, 7,502 Fourth Avenue, at the age of 81.

A survey by the traffic division of the Police Department covering the first month's operations on the ten express crosstown streets on which parking was banned on Jan. 3 showed a substantial time saving in runs between Third and Ninth Avenues, it was announced yesterday.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, yesterday urged revision of the Federal laws governing the merchant marine so that capital may be attracted for use in the upbuilding of the merchant marine. He gave his views at the annual meeting of the bureau, in the afternoon. at 24 Old Slip.

THE rise of Jim Braddock from the Dismal Swamp of pugilism to the heavyweight championship of the world was romance in the rough. But in the bizarre business of boxing almost every successful fighter has a tale to unfold of the rags-to-riches type.

A heavy, shifting fog, which attained at times a visibility of zero and at others gave way to intermittent rain, shrouded New York and the Eastern seaboard most of yesterday, delaying several ships, causing a ferryboat to go aground and halting inbound airplane service for hours.

New Yorkers who attended the conference of small business men left for home this afternoon, believing that by the simple stratagem of literally pulling a name out of a hat they had averted the misfortune of being unrepresented on the group to be received by President Roosevelt.

Charles Waterman Stone, consuiting engineer of the General Electric Company, died at his home here today after a long illness at the age of 63. Born in Providence, R. I., he had been associated with the General Electric Company since 1900, when he took a position in the drafting department.

Miss Helen Eleanor Yaffe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Yaffe of 895 Park Avenue, was married to Lawrence Covitz of Flint, Mich., last evening in the Pierre by Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu El. Only relatives and a few friends witnessed the ceremony.

The budget for 1938 is at least $4,471,604 out of balance, the amount by which Mayor La Guardia overestimated the unneeded remainder which there would be in the general fund at the close of 1937 to be applied to the 1938 fund.

Public apathy toward social diseases, with their attendant toll in human and economic welfare, is rapidly disappearing and is being replaced by a vigorous nation-wide campaign, which, if maintained, will reduce the social diseases to a relatively negligible factor in public health within ten years.

A general strike in the fur industry was threatened yesterday by the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union in the event the Association of Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers carried out its threat of a general lockout in the industry, set by the association for next Friday.

The 80-year-old King of Sweden arrived here from Stockholm this morning and spent his first day in Paris playing several strenuous sets of tennis and this evening attending a "girlie" show at the Chatelet Theatre.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, beaten by Mayor La Guardia in last year's campaign, was admitted to practice before the Supreme Court today. Sponsored by Samuel M. Gold, connected with the Department of Justice in New York,

William Green hit back today at his critics in the United Mine Workers convention, defended himself from the charge of cowardice, asserted that the whole trial procedure was "ridiculous" and made public a report by the American Federation of Labor's peace committee, which reiterated its charges that John L. Lewis had caused the collapse of the negotiations to end the civil war in organized labor.
A woman secretary disclosed today how she had turned spy and foiled an alleged plot to smuggle British arms secrets to a foreign power.

Major Biff Jones's newest lieutenant at the University of Nebraska is Glenn Presnell, former all-America quarterback of the Cornhuskers. Jones, football head, announced today that Presnell would coach the backfield here next season.
T. H. Cabot, member of the Boston family, died yesterday at his Winter home in Florence, Italy, it was learned here today. He was in his seventy-fifth year.

Three burglars cracked two safes tic early yesterday morning in the offices of Kliegl Brothers, theatrical and lighting concern at 321 West Fiftieth Street. They spent three and one-half hours at the job and for.. their. pains obtained $60 and two costly cameras. Disappointed.
Foreign Minister, Istrate Micescu told the Cobinet council today that he had scored a great success over the Jews in Geneva.

France, following Britain's lead, gave orders to her navy yesterday to destroy submarines operating in her patrol area off the Spanish coast. The Spanish Government agreed that civilian populations should not be bombed during negotiations to outlaw such raids.
The Federal Trade Commission today charged nine companies manufacturning liquid chlorine with engaging in a combination and conspiracy to fix and maintain uniform enhanced prices.

The seven-story business building at 697-699 Madison Avenue, formerly the home of Fortnum Mason, London importers, has been purchased by the 699 Corporation from the 697-99 Madison Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Potter, Hamilton Co., brokers. The latter reported at the same time that they had leased the three upper floors to H. Leo Gould, importer of oriental works of art.

During the week ended Feb. 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $47,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $29,000,000 in money in circulation, $26,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $6,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold, offset in part by a decrease of $11,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and an increase of $3,000,000 in Treasury currency.

The Metropolitan's afternoon Wagner cycle was inaugurated yesterday with a performance of "Tannhaeuser," given before a sold-out house. The season to date has seen few changes in announced casts at the Opera House, but one was necessitated on this occasion.

It is a pity that the value of Georges Enesco as a conductor has not been earlier and more fully appreciated in this city. His concert last night with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was the performance of a magnificent musician and a leader who struck fire with his orchestra and his audience.

Dexter P. Cooper, who died this week a in Boston, had a wide-windowed office in his home on an island opposite Eastport, Me. There he watched the mighty coming and going of the tides of the Bay of Fundy,

The constitutionality of the Anti-Lynching Bill was asserted today by Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, co-author of the measure, in a speech which represented the first formal defense of it made in the Senate chamber since the filibuster of Southern opponents began Jan. 6.
Making its first appearance on the basketball floor of the University of Maryland in twenty-seven years, the New York University court squad administered a 42-27 beating to the Terrapins tonight.

The wedding of Miss Sara Jayne Smith, daughter of Alan Wood Smith of Seven Maples, New Wilmington, Pa., to Edwin Hascall Brown, son of Dr. and Richard J. Brown of South Orange, took place this afternoon in the home of the bridegroom's parents,

The worst airplane disaster in the history of the United States Navy took a toll of eleven lives when two giant navy bombers met in midair last night during manoeuvres seventy miles at sea, south of San Clemente Island, and plunged into the ocean.
Rimsky - Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and once again its blend of satire and fantasy wove its enchantment.

Opposition to anything in the nature of a war veterans' bonus was reaffirmed by the convention of the Canadian Legion when the delegates concentrated their attention on the many resolutions placed before them by Colonel B. W. Rosco of Kentville, N. S., chairman of the resolutions committee.

Coast guardsmen in a Dreecnes buoy today- brought to shore a man marooned since midnight on a jagged rock in the Merrimack River basin below Pawtucket Falls. He was identified as Edward Giblin, 33, of Lowell. His father, John J. Giblin, director of the Lowell High School band and prominent in musical circles, said his son had gone for a walk last evening.

The art of brewing was well developed as early as 4200 B. C. in Babylon, sometimes called the cradle of civilization. About 600 A. D. large copper caldrons were used for making beer in the Caucasus Mountains, reports the Copper and Brass Research Association.

Mrs. Marion M. MacMillin gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Countess de Marenches, who will sail for Paris tomorrow on the Conte Di Savoia. Other guests were Mrs. Edward Dimon Bird, Mrs. Walter H. Sykes, Mrs. Charles X. Cordier, Miss Lynn Curtis and Miss Marguerite Waters.

The rate of general business activity in New England during December was 78 per cent of normal, a decline of 27.5 per cent from December, 1936, but a fractional increase over November, according to the New England Council's index of business. The rise from November was the first monthly gain since August.

Men were lowered by ropes down the 60-degree incline of the Niagara River Gorge today to start the hazardous task of cutting the Falls View Bridge into four parts. The bridge, which fell last Thursday, started breaking up before the workmen started their descent.
Automobile fatalities in this State last year increased 11 per cent over 1936, year Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, stated today in his annual report.

Talked About from the Calumet farm of Warren Wright in Chicago captured today's feature at Hialeah, but there was much more talk about Eddie Arcaro's triple. This lad now has a commanding lead among the riders in action at the meeting, and in all probability will keep his ranking.
The Engineers Public Service Company reported a net income of $3,768,777 for 1937, after all deductions, against $2,946,392 in 1936. Gross in the year was $52,456,909, against $48,123,557.
Paul Seglie, for years a leader or Hudson County Republicans, died today at Christ Hospital, Jersey City, where he recently underwent a thyroid operation. He was 63 years old.

The Metropolitan Milk Producers Cooperative Bargaining Agency regarded the milk price situation "with alarm" today and asked the Federal Government for a marketing agreement aimed at ending the price difficulties resulting from surplus production.
A strike is news. The bigger it is, the more bitterness it stirs up, the more attention it gets. On the other hand, a strike that is settled before it happens is rarely noticed.

Organization of a consumers tax committee dedicated to resistance against new taxes and efforts to repeal or revise present overlapping ones was announced yesterday by Mrs. William Dick Sporborg. Women from every section of the State have been enrolled, she said, and will participate in an intensive drive of ten weeks, under-auspices of the approaching Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries.

The Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to sell $117,000 of convertible consolidated refunding mortgage 4' per cent bonds at 106, instead of at 110, as directed by the commission on Jan. 22.

Beginning on Feb. 28, there will be an additional weekly Treasury bill offering of about $50,000,000 until $200,000,000 to $300,000,000 of the new series has been sold, Secretary Morgenthau announced this afternoon after a meeting of the executive committee of the Federal Reserve Board's open market committee.

Appointment of Max Bishop, former second baseman of the Philadelphia Athletics, as baseball coach at the Naval Academy was announced today by Commander Andrew C. McFall, graduate manager of athletics.

Revision of the State Banking Law by an amend ment of the article relating to savings and loan associations is advccated in a bill introduced in the Senate today by John T. McCall. Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.

Something blissful has come to town. Paul Osborn's "On Borrowed Time" has arrived at the Longacre, where it opened last evening. If that item of theatrical news did not seem especially important a day or two ago, it seems uncommonly joyous now. For Mr. Osborn,

George X. McLanahan entertained at dinner at Larue for Miss Sally Clark of Boston, who will be maid of .honor at the marriage of her sister, Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, to John Roosevelt on June 18 in Nahant,' Mass.

King Zog of Albania and his partAmerican fiancee, Countess Geraldine Apponyi, who had been expected here this week-end, have now altered their arrangements. The Apponyi family lawyer says that various difficulties have arisen making the visit impossible at this juncture.

Awards for engineering construction during January, totaling $190,186,000, were 10 per cent above the figures for the same period of last year, when $173,077,000 was recorded, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The feeling of comparative security that has characterized the attitude of the people of Hankow and Chinese Government officials here has been abruptly shattered by the dramatic Japanese advances northward toward Suchow along the TientsinPukow Railway and by renewed Japanese threats of intensified aerial bombardments in the zones of hostilities and further inland.

Well, we wanted wind, but we didn't want quite so much of it. We were routed out of bed bright and early this morning, intending to put in a full day after the sailfish, but during the night the wind swung from northwest to east, and it would have taken a bigger boat than Captain Dowling's to get through the inlet with any safety.

SINCLAIR LEWIS'S 'The Prodigal Parents" knocks the stuffing out of a pair of strawstuffed-brats. Josephine Lawrence's new novel, "Bow Down to Wood and Stone,"* on the other" hand, tackles---in the course of larger issues-a truer confrontation between one parent and a credible lot of children who are staging a rather varied rebellion of their own.
Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 29 were reported yesterday as $572,874,101, or 8.9 per cent more than the $526,292,136 reported in the previous fiscal year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the letter relative to Washington's desk in the City Hall. In my childhood I used to see the desk at which Thomas Jefferson wrote the Declaration of Independence much respected in my grandfather's house in Boston.

The Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls, Inc., of 440 East Fiftyseventh Street will be aided by a song recital by Earl Spicer, baritone, and a lecture on Mary Queen of Scots by Mark Haight on Tuesday evening at the Woman's National Republican Club.

Dr. Robert Ley, head of the Labor Front, announced plans last night for further construction of great buildings in Munich and Berlin. The structures will serve as headquarters for various branches of his organization.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, former women's golf champion, regained her form today to defeat Miss Bernice Wall, medalist, by 3 and 2, in the final of the Belleair golf championship on the No. 2 course. The long-distance driving of the winner was a feature.

Promoter Harry Mendel today reoffered Joe Louis $100,000 to defend his heavyweight title against Tony Galento of Orange in the Atlantic City Auditorium some time during April, and Julian Black, comanager of the champion, promised a definite answer by next Tuesday.

Announcement has been made here by Dr. and Mrs. Dennis Frank Reeder of Balboa Heights, Panama, of the marriage on Jan. 25 of their daughter, Miss Louis Reeder, to Dr. John Paul Gens of ew Haven, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul William Gens of Hollis, Queens.
Grand Duchess Kira of the Romanoffs and Prince Louis Ferdinand of the Hohenzollerns planned today to go honeymooning to America--after their marriage May 5 at Doorn, The Netherlands.

Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, told a Senate subcommittee today that the charges against the board by Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, appeared to be based upon a "supply of misinformation, half-truths and trivialities."

Dropping $6,000 from the previous transaction, the price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange hit the lowest level in Exchange yesterday hit the lowest level in twenty years at $59,000. In 1918 a membership sold for $45,000.
Gram markets turned upward today due to a moderate revival in the European demand for wheat, corn and rye and on the strength in wheat futures in Liverpool.
Senator Wagner expressed strong opposition today to proposed changes in the National Bankruptcy Act, which, he contended, might jeopardize the 5-cent fare in New York City.

Following tryouts at the Junior League courts yesterday, Mrs. A. W. Paine, president of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, chose the teams that will represent New York in the intercity matches at Boston next week against Philadelphia and Boston players.

The Senate Commerce and Labor Committees, which are jointly considering changes in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to carry out recommendations of the Maritime Commission for an expanded merchant marine,

Augusta Arms, a six-story apartment house containing 272 rooms at 2,070 Grand Concourse, southeast corner of 180th Street, the Bronx, has been bought by the Wel-Managed Realty Corporation through Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers.

Hobert b Grant 3d and C. C. Pell Jr. of New t York today began defense of their national racquets doubles championship by gaining a straight-game victory over Daniel A. Newhall and William Lingelbach, Philadelphia team, at the Racquets Club.

Comprehensive plans for the development of the waterfront area of the upper East Side of Manhattan were announced yesterday in the annual report of L. Gordon Hamersley, president of the First Avenue Association.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of J. Dudley Peterson has been transferred to Milton Steinhardt of Harrison Co.

The Port of New York Authority will report net income for 1937 of $5,500,000, an increase of 24 per cent over 1936, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the board of the authority, disclosed yesterday in an address before the Municipal Bond Club of New York, meeting at the Bankers Club.
Jeremiah D. Maguire, president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, has been elected a director of the Pierce Governor Company. James D. Cleland is in the trading department of R. H. Johnson Co.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Labor conscription began in Austria today on order of the War Ministry. The period of service is one year, the same as in the military service. Conscripts for labor service include those who for political reasons do not serve in the army.

Assailing the activities of Communists in labor unions as destructive and declaring Communist propaganda to be as dangerous as that of Nazism and fascism, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, second largest C. I. O. affiliate,...

While conferences continue between Dr. Karl Ritter, the German Ambassador to Brazil, and Brazilian officials in an effort to arrange a new German-Brazilian trade agreement in blocked currency or compensated marks, large imports from Germany continue to arrive here protected by the old agreement.

The Leviathan, once proud queen of the seas, dropped anchor in the Firth of Forth today to end her last transatlantic voyage. She was nine days out of New York. After remaining here about ten days the liner will be taken to scrap yards at Rosyth to be dismantled to supply steel for Britain's rearmament program.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, was guest of honor as the new president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York at a dinner held- privately last night in the Racquet and Tennis Club by de Lancey.Kountze, chairman of Devoe Raynolds Company.

Secretary of State Hull dipped his fingers into the famous Davis Cup today and pulled out the playing schedules of the countries which will try to take the tennis trophy from the United States this year.

David E. McElroy, architect and structural engineer, died yesterday at his home, 39-48 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of three months. He was 43 years old. Born in Monroe, N. Y., Mr. McEIroy came from one of the oldest families in Orange County.

The pamphlet report of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. shows net sales and other operating revenues amounting to $286,043,075 for 1937, compared to $260,333,330 for 1936, a gain of about $25,700,000, or 10 per cent.

Veterans of the 107th United States Infantry (old Seventh) will hold their annual dinner dance tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street. Harry P. Cook heads the arrangements committee.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius B. Kouwenhoven of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Marie Kouwenhoven, to William Potts Gillespie of New York, son of Mrs. Bessie Killian Gillespie of Miami, Fla., and the late William Potts Gillespie.

Superior Judge Charles S. Burnell ended Miss Constance Bennett's suit for breach of contract against British-Gaumont Pictures today by announcing, in the middle of closing arguments: "You can argue all day but you can't change my mind."

Bobby Jones, who is suing the government for the return of $53,000 in income tax payments, played golf today with the judge who heard the case, the special prosecutor who appeared against him and a Macon man.

Dodd, Mead call attention to the closing of a $2,000 prize competition on March 1. The competition is open to staff members of American newspapers and magazines, and books of fiction and non-fiction between 70,000 and 150,000 words are eligible.

The gift made by Mrs. Henry Alvah Strong to the George Washington University crowns a long list of benefactions by Mrs. Strong. The name "Hall of Government" in an institution that bears the name "George Washington," and located in the capital of the United States, has a singular appropriateness.

Senator Truman of Missouri, after conferring with Thomas. J. Pendergast, Democratic leader of Kanaas City, said today that he had reversed his position on the confirmation of Maurice Milligan to be District Attorney in the Kansas City area.

Protests will be lodged with the New Jersey Legislature by various advertising associations against enactment of the proposed mandatory trade-mark bill, which calls for a $10 registration fee for each trademark.

With the independent shipper members of the Citrus Control Committee resigning in a body, four independents reported closing their houses and the volume limit for shipments next week increased by 33 per cent, the Texas citrus situation presented a rapidly changing picture today with the final outcome still uncertain.
Dilmore C. Barton, owner of the largest retail hardware store in Morris County, died at the Morristown Memorial Hospital today at 79.

Another production officer of the WPA Federal Theatre Project resigned yesterday, charging that "the ideals of the present administrative leadership seem to be those of the dreariest level of show business.
Members of the Chicago Curb Exchange voted today to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for cancellation of. their license as a national security exchange.

The total of loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $34,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to their condition statement issued yesterday.

The five-story factory building, formerly owned and occupied by the Hanan Shoe Company, at 54-70 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Solvic Realty Corportion, a subsidiary of the Pronto File Corporation, manufacturer of storage files, who will occupy a major portion of the structure. The Bank for Savings in the City of New York was the seller.

The nine-story building containing fifty-one apartments at 345 West Eighty-eighth Street, adjoining the corner of Riverside Drive, has been purchased by Bud A. Lipman and associates from Crown Equities, Inc., represented by Irving Kimmelman, broker.
Sharply better buying of women's shoes in the last few weeks has resulted in a complete reversal of the position of manufacturers, it was reported in the market here yesterday.

Whole sale prices dropped again during the week ended on Jan. 29, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Raw materials, largely influenced by farm products, accounted for most of the decline.
Favorites continued to win their matches in the Eastern interscholastic indoor tennis championship, sponsored by De Witt Clinton High School, yesterday on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory.

Germain G. Glidden, the national amateur squash racquets champion from the Harvard Club, Samuel Cochran Jr. of the University Club and Donald Frame and R. W. Gilder of the Harvard Club gained the semi-final round of the metropolitan championship last night on the University Club courts.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $373,536,212 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price share of all listed stocks on Feb. 1 was $27.59, compared with $27.53 at the beginning of January.

Reserve officers plan to establish antiaircraft defenses in unprotected Western New York. Major W. Earl Smith of the Reserve Corps, revealed plans to seek authorization for such defenses here and at Buffalo and Lackawanna.
Tokyo has apologized for the Japanese sentry who slapped one of our embassy officials at Nanking, and the United States has thus

Gene Reynolds, youthful extra who was elevated to a feature role in "Of Human Hearts," has been placed under a term contract by Metro and has been assigned to "Boys Town," the story of Father Flanagan's juvenile experiment near Omaha.

Mrs. James J. Walker, wife of former Mayor Walker, opened her new flower shop at 437A Madison Avenue -yesterday afternoon. Her ownership is shown in the name over the large show window: Bettyy compton walker inc."
The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen and channel ports. Passengers are Sir Walrond Sinclair, chairman and managing director of the British Tyre and Rubber Company;

The Reds announced tonight the outright release of Wild Bill Hallahan, pitcher for the club since. mid-season of 1936. Hallahan was formerly with the Cards. He started with Syracuse of the International League in 1924. He is 34 and is said to be one of the wealthiest men in baseball.

New railway operating income in 1937 totaled $590,180,565, compared with $667,174,165 in 1936, but twenty-three Class I railroads of the country failed to earn expenses and taxes last year, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Lester A. Strasser of the City A. C. and J. A. Schwarz of the Crescent A. C. yesterday gained the semi-final round of the Monte Sterling invitation squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club. Both players are one step ahead of the field.

The four-story apartment building at 240-242 Central Avenue, Union City, N. J., was sold by the Provident Institution for Savings to the Janis Corporation, which will hold the property for investment. The structure is on a plot 50 by 100 feet, contains twelve apartments and produces a reported annual rental of approximately $6,500. J. I. Kislak, Ihc., negotiated the deal.

TODAY-New England: Cloudy, with occasional snow and rising temperatures to near the thawing point over the north; cloudy, probably occasional snow, sleet and rain, with rising temperatures to above the freezing point over the central and southern portions. New York State: Cloudy,

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of this place, to William Drought Cox of New York will take place at the home of her parents on the afternoon of Feb. 19.

Mainbocher has an extremely varied collection based on four silhouettes. One, trim and straight, enhancing boyish lines, continues his sweatertop line; slim matching tunics and boleros with contrasting skirts are notable.

Miss Cecile Haupt, daughter of Ira Haupt, was married to Joseph M. Kaufman of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Major Kaufman of Pittson, Pa., yesterday afternoon in the apartment of the bride's father in the Towers of the WaldorfAstoria.

The marriage of Dr. Mary Stewart Hooke, daughter of Mrs. Walter G. Hooke of this city and the late Mr. Hooke, to Dr. T. Campbell Goodwin of Baltimore, son of Mrs. Robert Archer Goodwin of Richmond, Va., and the late Rev. Mr. Goodwin, which took place Tuesday afternoon, has been announced by her mother.

Operations of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company and its subsidiaries in 1937 resulted in a net income of $3,410,798 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and $16,000 provision for surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annual report submitted yesterday by William B. Given Jr., president.

Although William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, announced yesterday the resignation of William E. McCarthy, one of his assistants, Mr. McCarthy insisted later in the day that he had not quit and had no intention of quitting.

Responding to a report that Harold Gillam, Fairbanks aviator, forced down on a flight to Barrow, is safe without gasoline somewhere on the tundra between the Endicott Range and Barrow, we will start early Saturday to search for him.
Somewhere between "Viva Villa" and "The Old Soak"-a genial cinema cross-road where cut-throat and fond father meet-stands "The Bad Man of Brimstone," which the Capitol brought in yesterday.

Fred Apostoli, the San Francisco middleweight who has come to be regarded as the uncrowned champion of his division, will oppose Glen Lee, durable warrior from Edison, Neb., in the feature bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Splashing over a wet track, Count Atlas annexed the featured Avalon pur of $1,500 today at Santa Anita Park.
Wilfred Van Fleet, 15 years old, lies in Memorial Hospital here with an Eagle Scout badge pinned on his hospital garment, a symbol that he may not long enjoy.

The plan to rebuild the strength of the Republican party through the formulation of a platform by representative citizens for its guidance, has grown beyond the conception of former President Hoover, who was the first to suggest it.

A banking group composed of Phelps, Fenn Co., the Marine Trust Company, Kean, Taylor Co., and Safford, Biddulph Co. received yesterday the award of a new issue of $800,000 of home-relief and relief-project bonds of the city of Buffalo, N. Y.
A contra-seasonal increase in lumber output last week sent the adjusted index forward to 56.9 from 55.2. The figure for the week ended Jan. 30, 1937, was 68.6.
Stocks closed With losses of 1 to 5 points; A. T. and T., at new low, depreciated more than $154,000,000 in market value; turnover, 1.088.350 shares.

Some drastic changes in the State Insurance Law to be provided in a proposed recodification of that statute to be presented to the Senate and Assembly at the 1938 session are foreshadowed in a statement made public yesterday by the New York Legislative Service.
Senator William H. Smathers of New Jersey will marry Miss Mary James Foley of Winterhaven, Fla., early in the Spring, it was announced informally on behalf of the Senator today.

Bank clearings for the week end ed on Wednesday, as reported by the twenty-two principal cities throughout the country, amounted to $5,035,156,000, compared with $6,850,935,000 for the corresponding week of 1937, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

According to assertions in authoritative quarters, the secret Cabinet crisis precipitated by Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg's unusual marriage and the army generals' consequent demarche against the War Minister is approaching a solution by virtue of a decision that Chancellor Hitler rendered today.
Eugene A. Widmann, president of Widmann Co., investment brokers, with offices at 70 Pine Street, died suddenly last night at his home, .190 Hick Street, Brooklyn. He was 61 years old.

Wise, Whitney Canfield, counsel for the Crayon, Water-Color and Craft Institute, called attention yesterday to the fact that the order issued by the Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday does not forbid members from reporting their prices to the association.

Mayor Joseph Loehr and the Yonkers Board of Estimate agreed today to a settlement of $17,000 for about $250,000 in tax claims on part of the former plant of the Spreckles Sugar Corporation of Yonkers, thus enabling the present owner of the abandoned refinery to sell that part to Refined Syrups, Inc., of 120 Wall Street, New York.

Trading was fair to slow. Lamb, cow and bull sold weak to lower and other classes of traefa meats were mostly unchanged. Thursday being an off kosher day, business of this nature was confined largely to lamb at weak prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agricultur+..
The Official Gazette has published a decree containing various fiscal exemptions for new foreign capital seeking investment in Italy, conforming with the Cabinet's decision last Oct. 19.

British sources were the largest buyers of United States goods in 1937. and the most important origin of American imports, the Department of Commerce announced today in an analysis of 1937 foreign trade.
Seismic experts here said today a great earthquake occurred in Western New Guinea Tuesday and Wednesday.
The Maple Leafs put on one of their few tight defensive displays of the season tonight and blanked the Canadiens, 3 to 0, in a National Hockey League contest before 11,000 fans.

Fearing a merger between the Western Union and Postal Telegraph and Cable companies, more than 300 persons last night at a combined meeting of the New York locals of the American Radio Telegraphists Association adopted a resolution petitioning a "Congressional committee to investigate the communications industry with a view to protecting the interest of the publie and the employes in the industry."

President Roosevelt has granted a full pardon to Thomas Scarpone, a WPA worker in New York, to avert his deportation. In 1909, when Scarpone was 22 years old, he was convicted in connection with a counterfeiting charge and served six months in prison at Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

The "small business men" called to Washington by President Roosevelt to help him work out a recovery formula became a collective boomerang today and, in resolutions passed without discussion at a final stormy session in the Commerce Department auditorium, demanded repeal or modification of many New Deal measures already enacted and the rejection of others under consideration..

James P. Doig, with the Thomas A. Edison Company, Inc., of West Orange for the last twenty years as assistant secretary of the Edison Cement Company and secretarytreasurer of the E-K Gas Company died of a heart attack last night on a Lackawanna train while he and his wife were returning from New York to their home here.

" Committee of 100" has a traditional, patriotic and civic sound. That may have been in Mr. Hoover's mind when he proposed a committee of that number to make a national Republican platform to be adopted by an amateur national convention in time to get the benefit of it in the Congressional elections of this year.
Assignment of Bishop Herbert Welch of New York to the Boston area was announced today by Bishop Hughes of Washington, Senior Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Two-story houses for two or four families each, on large sites in new outlying areas where land is comparatively cheap, probably will be the "backbone" of the public housing program in the major cities of the nation, Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, said yesterday.

Champions in court tennis, squash tennis and lawn tennis will gather with ranking squash racquets players at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn today for the start of the first annual open doubles squash racquets tournament staged by the Casino.

With the markets for many leading stocks admittedly very thin, the application of increased selling pressure yesterday weakened prices easily. The principal issues were down 1 to 5 points; American Telephone and Telegraph, which was under pressure from the start, lost 7 1/8 points on the day.

It is easy enough to smile at some of the antics of the President's conference for small business men, and to agree with the- manufacturer of toy balloons that he is entitled to claim some distinction because he alone seems to have brought with him from Ohio the slogan, "I am not advocating anything."
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices on Wednesday was 83.2, a drop of onetenth of a point in the week and the lowest point reached since July 16, 1936.
Stocks of lead in the United States on Dec. 31 amounted to 208, 803 tons, compared to 194,836 on Nov. 30 and 246,311 on Dec. 31, 1936, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

The outstanding question in Egyptian political circles is whether Mustafa Nahas Pasha will boycott the elections if King Farouk refuses his request to dismiss the present Cabinet and appoint a neutral one.

Because Congress enacted the RobinsonPatman act to prevent "the great chain-store organizations from destroying the individual retail dealers" and "a vast number of wholesalers whose existence depended on the business which they had from the retailers,"

Nashville called herself the educational center of the country tonight as several college and university presidents, deans by the score and about 400 delegates from educational institutions and learned societies assembled here.

Nicolai Petrovich, secretary - to Dr. Ivan Solonevich, editor of the anti-Soviet Russian emigre newspaper Russki. Glas, and Dr. Solonevich's wife, Tamara, were killed today by an infernal machine. A parcel containing the bomb was left in the Solonevich home by an unidentified person.
Mrs. Ida M. Starr, writer and art critic, who converted her 500-acre estate into an arboretum as a memorial to her lumberman husband, William J. Starr, died today of pneumonia. She was 79 years old.
Dr. Harry W. Tyler, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics and former secretary of the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died yesterday in Washington. His age was 75.

The Associated Press reports that it was in error in identifying the two photographs printed on the obituary page of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. The photograph identified as that of the late Dexter Cooper was in reality that of Lieut. Col. Philip B. Fleming, U. S. A., now stationed at St. Paul, Minn., as head of the army engineers there.

The 641,000 shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company probably had a fine case of the jitters yesterday as the stock tumbled to a low of 129 1/2 on heavy liquidation, supposedly from institutional sources. At the low price,

The marriage of Miss Jessie Wachenheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Wachenheim of New Rochelle, N. Y., to Dr. Philip I.I Burack of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Burack of Hartford, Conn., will take place on Thursday afternoon at the Society for Ethical Culture.
The gains made early this week were more than relinquished yesterday as the result of a severe sinking spell in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading picked up on the decline.

Bow DOWN TO WOOD AND STONN, by Josephine Lawrence (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "If I Had Four Apples." THE WALL OF MEN, by William Rollins Jr. (Modern Age, 25 cents.) A novel of adventure.
Forty-seven New York City high school students pounced upon a dilapidated North Georgia farm today and took a blister-raising lesson in practical :agriculture.

Led by John Carroll and Jerry Dorich, who made 28 points between them, the Newtown High tossers continued their unbeaten streak in the Queens P. S. A. L. race by downing John Adams High, 46 to 26, on the losers' floor yesterday.
Frank Kovacs, an up-and-coming youngster from Oakland, Calif., knocked Bitsy Grant out of the Surf Clubs tennis tournament today, apparently paving the way for another easy victory by Bobby Riggs.

Dr. William H. Crocker, director of the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research, received last night the Gold Medal of the American Institute "for his contributions to the knowledge of the life processes in plants and for his unique leadership in the organization of diverse sciences and techniques in plant research."
Whoever started it, none can tell- Calling the place a wishing well! Maybe a witch or a sighing swain, Or a lovelorn maid with a moon-touched brain. For it isn't a well but an innocent spring
The Prussian Superior Court ruled today that persons opposed to the National Socialist party may be deprived of their drivers' licenses.

All of the Soviet Union heaved a high of relief today when at 6 P. M. the radio announced that Ivan Papanin and his three companion scientists had reported all well on their small ice floe in the Arctic Ocean, that the wind had abated, the temperature was 4 degrees above zero Fahrenheit and the icefield was freezing in around them to the horizon.

A Supreme Court trial room was transformed into a motion-picture studio yesterday as a joint legislative committee investigating law enforcement began public hearings on the efficiency of the city's system of lunacy commissions.
Armando Palacio Valdes, ranked among Spain's greatest novelists, died yesterday in the Santa Alicia sanatorium. His age was 84. Senor Palacio Valdes, born in Asturias Province in 1853,

An era in shipping ended today as the captain of the Edna Hoyt, last American five-masted schooner remaining in commission, announced that she would become a floating coal storage in the harbor of Lisbon, Portugal.

A recapitulation for 1937 by the Securities and Exchange Commission today showed that the dollar value of transactions on all national securities exchanges was $23,708,915,211, compared with $27,282,741,291 in 1936, a decrease of 13.1 per cent.

Igor Stravinsky has won a 3-cent symbolic damage verdict in the Seine tribunal in his suit against Warner Brothers over a film entitled "The Fire Bird," which, the composer charges, was named after his ballet of the same name.
Mrs. Ruth Rodgers Schoonover, art teacher in the schools here since 1930, died yesterday in the White Plains Hospital at the age of 37. She was the wife of Romaine H. Schoonover.
With receipt of several additional entries yesterday, the program for the Millrose games went to press, carrying one of the most notable lists of stars in the meet's long history.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who recently went vacationing in Florida in the midst of the investigation of the Moore-Clee Gubernatorial election of last November in Hudson, his home county, by the Young committee of the New Jersey Asseinbly, was accused yesterday by the legislative committee's counsel of "running out" on the inquiry.

Expenditures of American steel companies for new equipment and construction will total at least $165,000,000 during 1938, according to reports received by the American Iron and Steel Institute from 120 companies comprising more than 90 per cent of the industry's productive capacity.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York recorded unanimous opposition yesterday to reorganization of the executive branch of the Federal Government as proposed in the Byrnes bill.

The round-robin greeting of sixty United States Senators and Representatives, a few of whom have since repudiated their action, to the Spanish Parliament was attacked here yesterday by the National Catholic Alumni Federation.
Charity will receive most of the estate of Mrs. Sophie Marsh Gondran, widow of Adolph L. Gondran, according to the terms of her will filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Investment Bankers Conference, an outgrowth of the Investment Bankers Association Code Committee under the NRA, will begin on Tuesday to supply quotations on over-the-counter securities, it became known yesterday.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the boards of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority-to be a director of or to hold any other position with the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad.

Stocks recovered moderately and closed generally higher; turnover, 806,290 shares. United States Government bonds steady and dull at slightly lower levels; other bonds irregular; transactions, $6,044,725.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 3, unless specified: Claxton. Marsellles to Vlllefranche. Feb. 4. Fanning, Kingston to Guantanamo Bay, Feb. 4. John D. Ford. Shanghai to Yokohama. Gannet, Panama Bay to Coco Solo Feb. 4.

Several hundred shoppers on the ground floor of the central building of the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn left quietly shortly before 4 P. M. yesterday while firemen extinguished a small blaze in the ceiling of the entrance lobby on Fulton Street, a few hundred feet west of Hoyt Street.

Claims of the Old Colony Railroad against the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in the latter's reorganization proceedings, totaling $22,450,326 and arising out of the New Haven's rejection of its lease of the Old Colony, were allowed by the United States District Court in a decision handed down today by Judge Carroll C. Hincks.
Sit-down strikes were in progress last night in four district offices of the Department of Welfare. Three of the demonstrations began on Thursday and one started yesterday.

Advising that a new name be selected for Continental Shares, Inc., Judge Edwin T. Dickerson of the Supreme Court, in a decision made public here today, approved a reorganization plan of the large investment trust as outlined and sponsored by the Cyrus S. Eaton interests.
The principal foreign exchanges continued yesterday to advance against the dollar in response to the withdrawal of European

The Universal Insurance Company and the Universal Indemnity Insurance Company petitioned the Court of Errors and Appeals today for cancellation of personal property assessments totaling $836,624 levied by the city of Newark.

Climaxing a week of sub-par golf, Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old Minfneapolis player, won the Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today for the third year in succession. She defeated Mrs. Jane Cothran Jameson of West Palm Beach, 4 and 3, in the thirty-six hole final.

After having tramped over highways and through jungles for 103 days, Marcello Castro and Armando Gonzalez arrived here: last night from El Salvador to attend the fourth Central American Olympics, which will begin here tomorrow.
Edwin King Lumpkin, 85-year-old dean of the Athens bar and member of one of Georgia's oldest families, died at his home today after a brief illness.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier, younger daughter of Mrs. Thomas Le Boutillier and the late Mr. Le Boutillier, to Stewart Birrell Iglehart, son of D. Stewart Iglehart, also of Westbury, and the late Mrs. Iglehart, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother here.
111th St, 3 W. 30x101; Rose Rothenberg. to Marjorie Johnson; consideration $4,000 over 1st mtg of $36,372; same property, Marjorie Johnson to 3 West 111th St Corp. 441 Lexington Ave ($5).
James H. Cruikshank, operator, bought from Minnie Frowenfeld the four-story dwelling at 50 West Seventy-first Street in the first sale of the property in more than fifty years.

The Pennroad Corporation's three voting trustees heard Senator Wheeler of Montana assert today as chairman of a Senate committee that they constituted a "dictatorship over 136,000 stockholders" which prevented the "real owners"

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 3. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Clarkson, H. S., F.A., Ft. Sill, Okla., to Ft. Lewis, Wash., July 1. Jone, L. E., F.A., Ft. Sill, Okla., to 6th F.A., Ft. Hoyle, Md.
Coming from behind with a late scoring drive, the Cincinnati Cavalry polo team defeated the Yale University horsemen, 17 to 16, tonight at the Armory.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday that Andrew Mills Jr., president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution and president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, had been appointed chairman of a committee of bankers to arrange the program and other details of the annual Spring savings conference of the American Bankers Association, which is to be held in the Hotel Roosevelt on March 3 and 4.

Published first some years ago, Donald A. Lowrie's "Masaryk of Czechoslovakia" has been revised, and now contains a new chapter carrying Masaryk's story to his death, and two additional Illustrations. The Oxford University Press will publish the new edition on Feb. 17.
