Retail trade here improved somewhat this week in comparison with last, but volume continued under last year's figures for the corresponding period. Department store.

The Hudson Manhattan Railway Company, operator of the Hudson Tubes between New York and New Jersey, is not subject to provisions of the Railway Labor Act as amended on June 21, 1934, Federal Judge John M. Woolsey ruled yesterday, reversing a finding of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The two top-seeded players, William Gillespie of the Scarborough School and Bernard Jacoby of Evander Childs, successfully fought their way into the final of the Eastern interscholastic indoor tennis championship being sponsored by De Witt Clinton High School, on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.
The estate of Commodore E. C. Benedict at Indian Harbor has been sold to Andrew A. Fraser of Greenwich. The price was said to be about $200,000. The property was assessed at $446,720.
Two New York teams, including the defending titleholders, Robert Grant 3d and C. C. Pell Jr., reached the final round of the national racquets doubles championship at the Racquet Club today.

Overcoming flooded fairways, slow greens and intermittent rain, stocky Earl Fry of Alameda, Calif., shot one of the four below-par rounds played today, to lead the field in the first round of the $3,000 Sacramento open golf tournament.

The opening ceremonies of the New York World's Fair of 1939 will have all the pomp and grandeur of the coronation of King George VI if plans outlined yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, are realized.

A. reiteration of two of the charges of inaccurate information on newspapers in Ferdinand Lundberg's "America's 60 Families" was made yesterday by Carr V. Van Anda, former managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a letter to Editor and Publisher, weekly trade journal of the newspaper industry.

Issuance of a license to Aaron J. Funk, enabling him to operate as a licensed lender and doing business as the Preferred Personal Loan Company at 15 East Fortieth Street, New York City, was announced today in the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department.

The taxrevision problem continued to disturb the House today, with Ways and Means Committee Democrats seeking privately to devise a satisfactory modification of the "third basket" penalty tax on closely held or family corporations which fail to distribute a "proper" share of their profits,

A new demand from the Senate Commerce Committee for information about Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast C. I. O. leader, led Secretary Perkins tonight to ask the Labor Department's West Coast offices for all files dealing with him.

Severe fighting raged all day yesterday in the Granja de Torrehermosa ector, on the border of the provences of Cordoba and Badajoz, as he Loyalists tried to regain ground ??st in recent operations that reulted in their loss of the Santa barbara lead mines.

Mrs. Percy V. Pennybacker, former president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, died at her home here today at the age of 76. Mrs. Pennybacker took a prominent part in the suffrage movement and at her death was president of the Chautauqua Women's

The Bowery Savings Bank extended these mortgages: $23,000 on 509 Amsterdam Ave, William H. McDaniels, owner, to Aug. 1, 1942, 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent; $11,000 on 1,384 2d Ave. Clara Pfifferling, owner, to Feb. 1, 1943, interest reduced from 5 to 3 to 4 per cent; $35,150 on 5 E 81st St, Lorenzo D.

Mrs. Lucie D. Schelling, wife of Ernest Schelling, conductor of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, who is on leave of absence because of eye trouble, died last night at their Summer home at Lausanne, Switzerland, according to a cable received here.

Standardization of sizes, together with more effective promotion of children's wear, were discussed by speakers yesterday at the concluding sessions of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
The Federal Court of Appeals, after a hearing, deferred decision today on a petition by the Association of American Railroads for an order to suspend government - fixed minimum soft coal prices.

The Mozart Boys Choir of Vienna, all seventeen singers, hurried to the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon for a little sightseeing in the few hours before the Europa left its dock early this morning, taking them home. With their director, Dr. Georg Gruber, and their nurse, Miss Henrietta Dworzak, they had been touring since Nov. 14 in New England and Eastern Canada,

MANHATTAN BALLANTINE, EVELYN (Jan. 7. 1936). Gross assets, $79,376; net $73.551. To Elizabeth Florence Ballantine, life estate In one-fourth residue; the following institutions have remainders in above trust:

The Daily Telegraph publishes the following from its well-informed diplomatic correspondent: "I have received from a source which I regard as entirely trustworthy the following account of the German crisis.
Mrs. William Larimer Mellon Jr. was married today to John Evans Rose of suburban Sewickley and Washington, D. C. Her marriage to Mr. Mellon was terminated by divorce.

Now that early adoption of the plan for selection of a paid president for the New York Stock Exchange seems assured, interested persons, in both governmental and financial circles, are making their nominations.

BLANK, ANNA E. (Nov. 1). Estate, less than $5,000. To Rosa Jacob, daughter, executrix, 80 Pine St., Bogota, N. J., specific bequests and residue; five specific bequests. DRISCOLL, LORETTA A. (Jan. 15). Estate, about $18,000. To Mrs. James Slevin. 78 Linden St., Brooklyn, $2,000;

A deficit of more than $1,300,000 for operating expenses was reported for the twenty-three Catholic hospitals in the Archdiocese of New York last year, in a preliminary summary made public yesterday by Mgr. John F. Brady, director of the division of health of the New York Catholic Charities.

The Rose Range Corporation, manufacturers of gas ranges and appliances, leased from the Jay T. Holding Corporation the second and third floors in 57 Pearl Street, through to Jay Street, an area of about 30,000 square feet.

The new commanders of the German Army forces, Col. Gen. Walther von Brauchitsch, and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's chief of staff, General of Artillery Wilhelm Keitel, are officers of the prewar regime who stayed with the army after the war and rose slowly by seniority.

An urgent appeal for assistance by the American people for the people of China, suffering "one of the-greatest catastrophes of world history," was made by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, in a radio address last night.

A marked improvement in business conditions during the next six months is expected by an overwhelming majority of voters throughout the nation, according to the American Institute of Public Opinion's latest index of national business confidence.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick is negotiating with representatives of labor and contractors for a reduced scale of wages for two new contracts for about $10,000,000 each to be let for construction of part of the Delaware water supply project it was learned yesterday.
Tom W. Balfe, general sales manager for the National Distillers Products Corporation, has been elected a vice president of the company, it was announced yesterday.

Columbia's fencing team opened its campaign by defeating Hamilton, 19 to 8, on the Columbia strips last night. The Lion bladesmen were superior in all three weapons, winning the saber bouts 8-1, the foil events 6-8, and the epee contests 5--4.
Governor Rivers signed early today a County Option Liquor Bill that repealed Georgia's Prohibition Law of two decades. The measure was passed Tuesday by the Legislature in special sessionn,

The "law and policy" of the American Federation of Labor exclude Communists from membership in central labor bodies and unions directly accountable to the federation, William Collins, regional representative of the A. F. of L., said yesterday.
If Margaret Matzenauer has no been heard here for several seasons she has not for that reason beer forgotten by the many who remember with gratitude the pleasure her artistry afforded in past years.

Comfortably settled, after its routin migration, in Park Avenue, the Union League Club keeps today the seventyfifth anniversary of its birthday. Founded by a committee of the United States Sanitary Commission, its name recalls the Northern fears of disaffection in the War between the States.

Robert C. Alston, former president of the Georgia Bar Association, died today at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 64 years old. The son of Judge Augustus H. Alston, Mr. Alston was a native of Barbour County, Ala.

Dr. Carter N. Colbert, assistant director of the Psychiatric Division, Bellevue Hospital, recalled as a witness yesterday afternoon before the joint legislative committee investigating the city's system of lunacy commissions, brought an armful of records to support his charge of Thursday that political pressure was used in behalf of patients before Dr. S. S. Goldwater became Commissioner of Hospitals.
Repeal of the Miller-Tydings Resale Price Maintenance Act was proposed today in a bill introduced in both houses of Congress concurrently by Seator King and Representative Celler of New York.

The State Department announced today that it had decided to reduce the number of the American armed forces in North China by withdrawing the Fifteenth Infantry, now stationed at Tientsin, and transferring to Tientsin two companies of the United States Marine Guard stationed at Peiping.

A trial examiner's findings that the Ford Motor Company "interfered with, restrained and coerced its employes" at the Somerville plant last year were reported today by A. Howard Myers, regional director for the National Labor Relations Board.

Detroit automobile workers at a mass meeting 100,000 strong protested layoffs, demanded "adequate relief," a debt moratorium and reductions in rent, and heard Homer Martin, head of the C. I. O automobile union, declare that "the workers are not going to starve." [Page 1.]

" Sunup to Sundown," the Francis Edwards Faragoh play which won the recent award of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, will close its Broadway career after this evening's performance at the Hudson.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,146,000 bales, against 1,127,000 a week ago, 1,141,000 two weeks ago, 1,106,000 three weeks ago and 906,000 a year ago; of which American, 739,000 bales,

SECOND MILITARY AREA So much of Paragraph 5, Special Orders 12, dated Jan. 21, 1938, as reads; "2d Lt. Milton Malbert. Engr.-Res.," is amended to read: "2d Lt. Milton Lambert, Engr.Res." Each of the following Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated:
The State Council of Parks held its monthly meeting yesterday morning in the Administration Building at the World's Fair grounds in Flushing, with Robert Moses, chairman, presiding.

Poor weather and curtailed employment and payrolls held retail sales this week about even with the previous week and cut the gain over the corresponding period last year to 1 to 3 per cent, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Abraham Lindner, 65-year-old theatrical ticket seller, known for many years along Broadway, was held up, robbed and severely beaten last night by two men in the automatic elevator of the apartment building in which he lives at 628 West 161st Street.
Mayor Frank Hague, on leave from service in the Jersey City trenches, was basking in the sun on Miami Beach.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company will increase tomorrow the monthly gas rates of 800,000 domestic consumers, adding, it is estimated, about $3,000,000 annually to its revenue. The rise will be reflected in the bills in about thirty days.
The shifting fog that disrupted harbor schedules Thursday night and delayed incoming transatlantic liners had cleared by dawn yesterday, and all ships reached their docks at an early hour.

Great Britain's golf rulers today invited sixteen players to compete for places on the British Walker Cup team which will face the United States at St. Andrews June 3-4. The squad, which may be enlarged later, was asked to report at St.

The plenipotentiary committee of the European Steel Cartel, which has come to the United States to seek an end of "unfair competition" by smaller American steel companies in the world market, arrived on the Normandie yesterday morning and plunged into a series of meetings that lasted virtually all day.
The Administration will probably take action in line with the suggestions embodied in the resolutions adopted at the small business men's conference in Washington this week,
Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, and Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, played tonight before an audience of 2,500 at the County Center here.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Noel Edge of 1,200 Fifth Avenue and Parsonage Point, Rye, N. Y., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Du Bois Edge, to Eric Nightingale of this city, formerly of Montreal, which took place in Croton, N. Y., on Dec. 21. The ceremony was performed by a justice of the peace.

John H. Feeley, retired New York City police sergeant and crack pistol shot, died at his home, 250-12 Cross Island Boulevard, Rosedale, Thursday night. Retiring from the Far Rockaway precinct last May after thirty-four years in the department, he said to fellow-policemen:

The methods and probabilities of a rescue of the four Soviet Arctic scientists on an ice floe east of Greenland were summed up in an article in today's Izvestia by Professor Nikolai Zuboff, head of the meteorological service of the Great Northern Sea Route.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Seldom have I read a sports article with such genuine satisfaction as I received from Bill Terry's recent story in The Saturday Evening Post. For years I have been reading vindictive articles by sports writers whose main idea seems not the advancement of sport but to sour the fans on the arrogant Terry.
Vassily Molokoff, Polar flier, was named chief of all Soviet civil aviation today, succeeding Ivan Feodorovich Tkacheff.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.
An upward revision of the city's constitutional debt-incurring power to $130,065,249 was announced yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Chinese forces on the southern Tientsin-Pukow Railway front, from positions on the north bank of the Hwai River, taken up following the fall of Pengpu, battled the Japanese yesterday. Intensive Japanese aerial activity along the railway behind the Chinese lines was reported.
Rome accepted the new antipiracy proposals for the Mediterranean, the announcement becoming known in London a few hours after receipt of the account of the sinking of another British ship,

William B. Vernam, friend of Henry George, himself long a leader in the Single Tax Movement here and abroad, and for twenty-eight years with the Kings County Register's office, died Thursday in his home, 1,717 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 81.

The number of telephones in service in the Bell System reached a new high record in January, when the principal subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had a net gain of 31,500 instruments.

The marriage of Miss Therese de la Tour Ligon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Daniel Ligon Jr. of Canterbury Hall, Baltimore, to William Franklin Mills, son of Mrs. John Alby Mills and the late Mr. Mills of Manchester, Mass., took place this evening in St. David's Protestant Episcopal Church, Roland Park.

The ever-glamorous Millrose athletic carnival, more appealing now than at its inception thirty-one years ago, will be staged in Madion Square Garden tonight before a crowd that will provide a proper setting for so magnificent a show.
St. Ann's Ave. 773, 4-story brick tenement, 25x100; Elsye P. Hegner, admx, against Joseph Miedoszewski; due, $15,742; taxes, etc, $2,213; to plaintiff for $2,000.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow "There is more wool being sold. Usually holders insist on a clean basis of 65 cents for good French combing topmaking wools, although some wool has been sold for 2 to 3 cents less.
New Utrecht High, defending champion, bowed to the Jamaica High skaters, 1 to 0, as the city Public Schools Athletic League ice hockey championship race began at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The marketing of $67,000,000 of bonds and debentures of the Appalachian Electric Power Company lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $70,257,262, the largest weekly volume since the period ended on Oct. 8 last year, when $113,224,300 in new bonds were placed on the market.

A nine-game winning streak for the New York State Teachers was broken last night when they inv were defeated, 37 to 35. Monty Levin, Pratt guard, who was the high scorer, netted the winning field goal late in the game when the visitors were leading, 35-34.

A men's jury and a mixed jury were able to agree on a verdict, buth an all-woman jury reported itself hopelessly deadlocked after consideration tonight of a case presented at a mock trial arranged by the Larchmont League of Woman Voters.

Too little is known about the Department of State. Though commonly spoken of as the country's "first line of defense," the public seems to regard it as a relatively unimportant accessory, and Congress consequently inclines to treat it as such.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4.--Frederick C. Painton, writer, of Westport, Conn., won the eleventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. The medalist defeated Rex Beach, noted author, by 3 and 2, in the eighteen-hole final.

A recommendation for liquidation of the Cuban Public Works obligations that have been in default since 1933 was contained in a message by President Federico Laredo Bru to Congress, made public this afternoon.

James Monroe High'js quintet suffered its first setback in five starts in the. Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division: of the P. S. A. L. tournament yesterday when it bowed to George Washington High, 26 to 23, on the Monroe court.

Harry Gumbert, right-handed pitcher, returned his signed contract to the Giants yesterday and gladdened Secretary Eddie Brannick for more reasons than one. Principally, Brannick exulted because he still is 5 up on the Yankees in players signed.

An increase in the Jersey City tax rate of about $3 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation is indicated for 1938 in the tentative budget introduced at today's meeting 'of the City Commission by Arthur Potterton, Commissioner of.Revenue and Finance.
Forty CCC enrollees quit Oregon today for the gayer life of their native New York and New Jersey homes.

Bachelors between the ages of 45 and 60 possessing capital of 1,500 cordobas or more must pay an impost of two cordobas monthly to the municipality of Jinotepe, Department of Carazo. Newspapers commenting assert that under forty-five there is always the possibility of a man

Joseph At Dempsey, 60 years old, died yesterday in Columbus Hospital half an hour after he had shot himself-in the-head with a pistol. The shooting occurred about 3:30 P. M. while Mr. Dempsey was alone in a part of his office on the tenth floor of 225 Fourth Avenue.

The St. Francis College swimming team came from behind last night to defeat New York University, 39 to 36, at the Park Central pool. It was the third victory in four meets for the Terriers, and for N. Y. U. it was the second setback in as many starts.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, emerged unscathed today after his name had been bandied about at a session of the Senate Public Lands Committee investigating the qualifications of E. K. Burlew, his administrative secretary, nominated early last month for Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

Formation of the partnership of Diefendorf, Sanders Ward is to be considered by the New York Stock Exchange's committee on quotations and commissions on Feb. 17. The firm, which will be at 14 Wall Street, is proposed to comprise Robert R. Diefendorf James W. Sanders and Kenneth Ward.

William Wyamar Vaughan, brilliant educationalist and headmaster successively of the three great British public schools of Giggleswick, Wellington and Rugby, died today at the age of 72. He fell and broke a thigh while visiting Taj Mahal last December with wife and delegates to the Indian Science Congress. Subsequently his leg was amputated.

Former Senator Thomas P. Gore of Oklahoma and his wife were injured today in a collision of their automobile with a city refuse truck. Police said witnesses reported that Mrs. Gore drove through an intersection against traffic lights.

Stockholders of the Cord Corporation will be asked at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on Feb. 11 to aprpove a proposed purchase of 58,000 shares of Cord stock from L. B. Manning, president of the company, at $2 a share.
The American Minister, Frank P. Corrigan, was the guest of honor at a cocktail party at the Union Club last night given by the American Society.

Big business and little business see eye to eye on many problems affecting the national economy. But in some instances they differ on the methods the government should employ to solve them. Highlights of their views, from the report presented by Secretary Roper's conference of "little business men" and from the Business Advisory Council's statement of Jan. 19 follow:

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Fuguet McClure, daughter of Mrs. Yvonne Fuguet Keefe McClure of this place, and of Major Linwood Dunham McClure, to John Shaw Lafean, son of Mrs. Wilbur Leroy Lafean of Wynnewood and of the late Mr. Lafean, formerly of Chicago.

Public curiosity as to why Germany has not yet followed Italy's example in recognizing Manchukuo found expression in the Diet today when Mr Sunaga, a Social Mass party member, reminded Foreign Minister Koki Hirota that he had said

Unannounced, the old dispute be tween proponents and opponents of the "Lucretia Mott," or Equal Rights, Amendment to the Constitution flared again briefly yesterday on the program of the convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

Political activity brought unusual reward yesterday to two students in New College, Columbia Univer- sity, who received scholarships because they had demonstrated to the satisfaction of the student council that their social consciousness was the most highly developed in the r school.

With a series of conferences scheduled to overcome the impasse in which its inquiry into the Moore-Clee Gubernatorial election in Hudson County is mired, the New Jersey Assembly investigating committee indicated today that it intended to subpoena Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City to appear before it when the city executive returns from his Florida vacation.

The tax bill paid by the oil industry and its customers, as such, last year reached a high record of $1,312,935,361, an increase of more than 10 per cent from the $1,180,876,256 collected in 1936 by the Federal, State and local governments, according to preliminary estimates made by the American Petroleum Industries Committee.

The Public Health Council of the State Health Department announced today that it was considering an addition to the Sanitary Code to prohibit breeding, importing, selling and giving of birds of the parrot family in up-State New York.
Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, toured yesterday the prospective sites for slum clearance and low-rent housing projects in the city.

The Chorus Equity Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was exonerated yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent of all acter unions, of charges of failing to organize the chorus girls of night clubs.

A Samurai of distinguished mien called at the British Embassy at Tokyo the other day and presented the Ambassador, Sir Robert Craigie, with an inscribed dagger, which he said had been in the possession of his family for centuries, according to the Tokyo correspondent of The Times of London, who adds:

Cotton-mill activity showed a small increase last week, running counter to the seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 86.7 from 85.2. The figure for the week ended Jan. 30, 1937, was 139.4.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa futures rallied sharply and hide and cottonseed oil futures were higher, but rubber, coffee and domestic sugar contracts ended lower.

Lawrin's chance to establish himself as a confirmed pre-race favorite for the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes will come tomorrow at Hialeah Park when he goes to the post for the $5,000 added Bahamas Handicap under top weight of 126 pounds.

Members of the Stamford Bar Association asked the Superior Court today for a writ of mandamus to compel the County Commissioners to establish a county court house in Stamford through the issuance of $95,000 in bonds, authorized last Summer.

Louis Avalone, 36 years old, of 2,301 First Avenue, described as the "key" figure in a daring daylight subway hold-up last April by three gunmen who got away with $16,000 in diamond rings from a jewelry salesman, was convicted in General Sessions yesterday at his second trial for criminally receiving $6,000 of the loot.

STEFAN ZWEIG'S streamlined story of Magellan, "Conqueror of the Seas,"* is written in a tone of astonished wonder. It is as though he had just discovered the enormous importance of the first circumnavigation of the world-Magellan's part in it ended in the Spring of 1521 on a bloodswept Philippine beach-and the discovery had struck him like a bolt from the blue.

THEY may grow taller corn in Iowa, but the men come faster from Kansas. The reference in particular is to Archie San Romani and Glenn the Galloping Cunningham, Kansans both, though denizens of the New York area now as post-graduate students at N. Y. U.

Business men and others interested in the coming reciprocal trade negotiations with the United Kingdom, Canada and Turkey were urged by the Committee for Reciprocity today to submit their requests for hearing in ample time.

Firing as he ran from bed to bed today in the crowded wards of the Tewksbury State Infirmary, John Mack, 79, who stands 6 feet 3 inches, killed four fellow-patients and critically wounded another with a mail-order pistol.

The activities over which each of the five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission will have general supervision have been deternined, and a memorandum has been sent to the various division leads concerning the assignments, t became known today.

Hope that, despite the dismal outlook for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, some way might be found to resume peace negotiations was expressed here today by President William Green of the A. F. of L.

We should no doubt be able much more fully to appreciate the revolution that has taken place of late years in the art of Bali were the ancient Balinese art forms better known to us. On the other hand, it is not necessary to gain access to a great deal of the old culture of the island before beginning.
Hsu Shihying, the Chinese Ambassador to Japan, arrived in Wuchang today by airplane from Hong Kong accompanied by Shao Yu-lin, the Consul General at Yokohama, and two members of the Embassy staff.

The powerful fists of Fred Apostoli, the Pacific Coast's candidate for the middleweight title, claimed stout-hearted Glen Lee of Edison, Neb., as a victim last night in twelve rounds of savage fighting, but quite a few in the gathering of the 11,000 present left Madison Square Garden unconvinced of the superiority of the victor.
The stock markets here again were dull today with the exception of gilt-edge securities, which forged ahead on a continued investment demand. Little change occurred in the foreign bonds.

Lillian Smith, a 16-year-old girl from Newark, N. J., who admitted, Police Inspector Schifley said, that she fired upon a pursuer from a speeding automobile, was held today on armed robbery charges with a companion, William Engler, 19, also of Newark.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Crete of the Hundred Cities," Stuart M. Shaw, 11 A. M.; "Gothic Furniture in Europe," Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Earliest Egypt," William C. Hayes, 4 P. M. Cornell Women's Club of New York. annual luncheon, Essex House, 160 Central Park South, 12:30 P. M. Address by Dr. Edmund Ezra Day.

Captain Clarence L. Dalrymple, captain of the White House Police since July, 1930, and a member of the organization since 1898, died of a heart attack tonight while walking at Eighth and D Streets Southeast. He was 68 years old.
Andrew Fletcher Wilson of 87 Elm Road, Caldwell, N. J., a trustee of the Bushwick Savings Bank of Brooklyn, died here tonight in Mountainside Hospital following a short illness. He was 77 years old.
Scoring a 4-to-1 victory on its home courts in its match with the Yale Club, the Harvard Club's Class C squash tennis team. last night retained the lead in the Metropolitan League competition.

Opposition to a bill introduced in the New Jersey Legislature providing for compulsory registration of trade marks was expressed in a statement sent yesterday to Governor Moore, to Senator Foran, who introduced the bill, and to majority leaders of both parties, by L. E. Daniels, secretary of the United States Trade Mark Association.

After demanding the removal of Simon W. Gerson as assistant to Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, in an interview with Mayor La Guardia yesterday, Jeremiah F. Cross, State commander of the American Legion, said the legion would hold a demonstration at City Hall unless the demand was met.

The National Socialist Cabinet crisis that has been smoldering for a week behind walls of silence came to an end tonight when with a Napoleonio gesture Chancellor Adolf Hitler assumed personal charge both of the armed forces and the Third Reich's foreign policy.

Albert H. Marckwald Jr. of Short Hills and Franklin V. Brodil, Columbia University Club, won their matches yesterday to complete the semi-final bracket in the third annual Monte M. Sterling squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York County announced his opposition today to bills which would eliminate provision for "blue-ribbon" juries, and at his request a hearing has been called by Chairman Harry A. Reoux- of the Assembly Judiciary Committee to consider the measures.

President Roosevelt opened-the way today for what is expected to be the biggest small homes building movement in the history of the country when the White House announced that he had signed the new Housing Bill.
Another builder of Manhattan apartment houses has turned to the suburbs, and another of the dwindling number of large undeveloped tracts in Queens will be turned into a residential center.

A summary covering transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in December, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that Pierre S. du Pont, a director, had sold 80,737 shares of General Motors common stock, the value of which at the average market price was approximately $2,500,000.
All the crew of the navy bombing plane 11-P-4, which collided with a sister ship during manoeuvres last Wednesday night, bringing death to eleven men, escaped from the ship's hull before it sank.

Controversial questions that have impeded the organization of the City Council were laid before a committee of six Councilmen at City Hall yesterday so that they could agree on a statement of facts for submission to the Appellate Division.

One of the committees at the President's conference for small business men wound up its report with the suggestion that "if American leaders, as represented by the Federal Government, would light some place and maintain a constant perch, rather than flit about like a canary, American business would find encouragement."
The Federal Intermediate Credit Banks sold yesterday, through Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent, an issue of $30,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent consolidated debentures, maturing in five and nine months.

The regular season of entertaining for debutantes was climaxed last night with the third and last of the Junior Assemblies for this Winter at the Ritz-Carlton. The assembly as usual followed several long-established traditions.

Although Thornton Wilder is celebrated chiefly for his fiction, it will be necessary now to reckon with him as a dramatist. His "Our Town," which opened at Henry Miller's last evening, is a beautifully evocative play.

Isidore Lazarus and Nathan Borock, two members of the American Labor party, were sworn in yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. as assistant attorneys general at the State office building, 80 Center Street.

A requiem mass was celebrated yesterday for Dr. John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent of Schools, at the Catholic Church of the Ascension, on West 107th Street. The Right Rev. Joseph P. Donahue was the celebrant.

Raoul Grenade, commercial counselor of the Belgian Embassy, and Mrs. Grenade gave a reception yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis for Baron Herve de Gruben, newly appointed counselor of the Belgian Embassy, and Baroness de Gruben, who- arrived on the Normandie.
The thrill of catching his first sailfish-a fighter more than seven feet long-proved fatal to the Hon. Michael Simon Scott, grandson of a British peer, in the Gulf Stream off Palm Beach today.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an annual statement released yesterday, that, as of Sept. 30 last, it had reserved 150,000 shares of common stock for sale to officers and employes and 115,000 shares for exercise of options granted to officers and employes, at $3 a share.

Harold Gillam, the Fairbanks aviator who, with a mechanic, was forced down on a flight to Barrow, reported to Barrow last night by radiophone that he was well and needed only gasoline. Dog teams dispatched from Barrow had not yet reached him.

Surpassing in contributions and number of donors last year's campaign, the three-week financial drive of the Y. M. C. A. for funds to meet current expenses ended yesterday with a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore at which 300 solicitors reported donations totaling 62,297 from 6,513 persons.
Boy Scout Sunday will be celebrated tomorrow in many churches, marking the opening of Boy Scout Week in commemoration of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the organization of the movement in America.

John. Connor, 30 years old, husky unemployed laborer who said he had no home, was in jail last night after Beatrice Cooke, slight, short and 20, had made him a prisoner by holding his wrists with her small hands.
The National Maritime Union submitted proposals yesterday to the American Steamship Owners' Association, to be included in a wage contract effective with all American steamship lines.

John Michael Horan, whose ambition to live 100 years was reached Jan. 22, died this morning. He had worked eighty-three consecutive years for the Milwaukee Railroad, where, as "Soda Ash Johnny" Horan, he was the personal friend of road officials and workers from the president down to the newest employee of the shops here.
The Board of Education at Westhampton Beach, L. I., has awarded to the John J. Dixon Company the contract for general construction of its new Junior High School on a bid of $293,435.

A banking group comprising the Mercantile - Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, Wheelock Cummins, Inc., and Callender, Burke MacDonald, has obtained a new issue of $655,000 of water plant bonds of Bartlesville, Okia.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Paul Van Anda of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 435 - New York Rapid Transit Corp., applt., v. the City of New York, and 436 - Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corp., applt., v. the City of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Feb. 4.--The Very Rev. Francis W. Walsh, V. F., pastor of the Church of the Assumption, Peekskill, has been appointed president of the College of New Rochelle, one of the largest Catholic women's colleges in the country, it was announced today by Mother M. Ignatius, dean of the institution.

The first plank in the platform submitted by the little business men to the President called for action by the government to "enable the American banking system to make insured loans for all necessary purposes."
A deluge of applications for Federal Housing Act loans under the terms by the- act just signed by President Roosevelt swamped lending agencies today.

Vincent Sheehan. in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave 58th St. Sylvia Streetor, in 50 Commerce St; W. Greene, George R. Ford, in 37 Washington Sq W; Charles P. Warwick, in 33 W 10th St; Clifford L. McMillen, in 320 E 53d St; Jerrold Krimsky, in 39 E 61st St; Raymond Ashman, Donald E. Curran, in 1 W 67th St; Carl Lincoln, in 130 E 40th St: Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

Ike Conrad's long field goal in the last fifty seconds enabled Blair Academy to turn back Horace Mann, 19 to 18, in an Eastern Private Schools League basketball game on the Horace, Mann court last night.
Robert R. McKee, who was formerly with the Irving Trust Company and Samuel Kronsky Co., has joined the mortgage and sales division of Hy D. Agar, Inc., 140 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

Republican leaders, in preliminary conferences on the set-up of the coming Constitutional Convention, are discussing only one name, that of Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, for presiding officer.

Philadelphia will be the scene of the next Lutheran World Convention. Announcement of the decision was made yesterday at the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirtyfifth Street. It will be the first time the convention has taken place in America.

Edward Bayard Halsted, retired stock broker, of 440 Park Avenue, died on Thursday at the Foster Memorial Hospital, Ventura, Calif., following an emergency operation for appendicitis, according to word received here. He was 76 years old.

Thomas J. Watson, president and director of the International Business Machines Corporation, has ac cepted the chairmanship of the 19 Men's Committee of the Citizens' Appeal for the Salvation Army, according to an announcement yesterday by Chalmers Wood, member of the Army's advisory board. Mr.

ALBANY, Feb.4.--The perfunctory five-minute session of the Assembly today brought two younger members of that body into positions of prominence, similar to those once held by their respective fathers.

United States export trade with reciprocal trade-agreement countries increased 41 per cent in 1937, compared with 34 per cent for non-agreement countries, while, because of special conditions described "as abnormal," our imports from the agreement countries increased only 18

When this age of the world becomes historic, as the periods of the American Civil War, the American Revolution, the Napoleonic wars, the French Revolution, Louis XIV and Richard the Lionhearted have done, the romance writers will have rich pickings.

The Packard Motor Car Company announced here and in Detroit yesterday a reduction of $100 in the prices of all body types of its sixcylinder models. This is the first reduction in the automotive industry in current prices.
Challenger Welker Cochran of San Francisco tonight extended his lead to 95 points in the tenth block of a 3,600point match with the reigning 18.2 balkline billiard king, Jake Schaefer of Chicago.

Henry Morgenthau, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, and Mrs. Morgenthau of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Ruth Morgenthau Naumburg, to John Knight of New York, which took place here yesterday noon at the New York County Court House in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, who officiated.

Led by Herman Knupple, who made 25 points, the Panzer quintet turned back Brooklyn College, 54 to 48, at the losers' gymnasium last night. Jim Coward starred for the Kingsmen with 19 markers. In a preliminary, the Brooklyn jayvees topped Boys High School, 34-19.
Jacob Schultz's Navarre Estates has purchased the two four-story apartment houses known as 15-21 Crary Avenue and 20-26 Park Avenue, Mount Vernon, from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Deaths Announced Lieutenant Edward J. Byrnes of H. L. Co. 33 died Feb. 4. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 153 Seaman Ave., Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, Feb. 7. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. The following funeral honors are ordered:
Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan renewed today his demand for an explanation of the government's foreign policy.

The Rio Grande Oil Company has been dissolved as a corporate entity having completed the transfer of its assets to the Richfield Oil Corporation in accordance with the merger-reorganization plan effected in March, 1937, it was announced yesterday.

The silence of Democratic leaders in the Senate concerning the Nunan-Moffat resolution, petitioning Congress to pass the Wheeler-Johnson bill on child labor, gave rise today to reports that the resolution, passed with Democratic votes in the Assembly, may be killed or amended in the upper house.

The long-expected break in the AntiLynching Bill debate and filibuster came today when the Senate voted to continue consideration of the measure, but under circumstances pointing to the probability that,
Governor Frank Murphy's dress shirt has come home from the laundry. Miss Lydia White, laundry employee, got a $2 prize for finding it. The Governor sent the shirt to the Crawford laundry last week.
President Roosevelt discussed the small-business proposals with a delegation from the business conference and announced that the National Housing Act had been signed.
A bill to require certification of new medicines by the Secretary of Agriculture before they can be put on the market was introduced today by Representative Chapman, Democrat, of Kentucky.

New York stood third among the States in 1937 in producing liquor taxes for the Federal Government, according to figures made public today by the Bureau of Internal Revenue on distribution of these taxes, totaling $587,305,610 for the year.

Mrs. Ethel Rounds, who is a grandmother at 37, was held without bail for the grand jury here today on a charge of murdering Edward at Rooney, 40, in her tavern near here last night. Rooney, who lived at the tavern with Mrs. Rounds and her husband, was shot through the heart.

Wheat prices continued to advance today on vague rumors that something constructive was to come out of Washington, and war talk. There was nothing in the day's developments which appeared to justify the former,

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 4.--Two bank robber suspects were killed and three detectives and two other persons were wounded in a fierce twenty-minute gun battle as police raided a gang hide-out here today in search of bandits.

Business volume in January, as measured by the turnover of checks at the leading clearing houses of the country, dropped to $24,299,213,026, a loss of 15 per cent from the turnover in December and one of 18.8 per cent, compared with January a year ago. It was the smallest volume since August, 1936.

The Interstate Commerce Commission heard a plea today that it give immediate consideration to the possibility of merging the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific and the Chicago North Western Railroad.
SALOME--Music-drama in one act (in German) after Oscar Wilde's poem; music by Richard Strauss; conductor, Ettore Panizza; stage director, Herbert Graf; presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Lady Ribblesdale gave a luncheon today at the Alibi and her guests included Colonel and Mme. Louis Jacques Balsan, Mr. and Mrs. Myron C. Taylor, Mr. and- Mrs. John W. Garrett and Mrs. Benjamin Rogers.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $42,968,452, three States and 117 municipalities being represented. This compares with the revised total of $15,865,757 for this week, with the weekly average of new offerings for the year to date standing at $21,077,947.

A plot of land 67.6 by 100 feet on the east side of East Thirty-first Street, forty feet north of Avenue H and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Realty Purchasing Corporation, of which Walter McMeekan is president, from the Forbro Realty Corporation.
Southern Blvd, 431 to 437 (10-2576); Joseph Reitman to Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance; extends mtg to May 31, 1941, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $21,000.

Miss Elizabeth Ann Mullison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Olin Mullison of Kingston, was married today to Burt Bryant Lauderbaugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dayton S. Lauderbaugh, also of Kingston, in the Central Methodist Church here.

The Garden City Casino men's Class B team entered the final of the Metropolitan Badminton Association's championship by defeating the Huguenot Badminton Society, 4 to 1, in their semi-final encounter.

Charles Bowser and Dr. Ralph Daugherty, the two chief assistants to Jock Sutherland on Pittsburgh's football coaching staff, resigned today and a pair of 1937 Panther stars were named to succeed them. Without designating a chief assistant, Sutherland said John Micheloson and Donald Hensley, a pair of seniors, would fill the vacancies.

Basing his decision on a recent Court of Appeals opinion against secondary picketing, Magistrate Mark Rudich in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, found two former strikers of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle guilty yesterday of disorderly conduct despite the fact that he did not believe their actions had been disorderly. He suspended sentence.
Four vacationers from the New York area were killed today in a sedan and truck collision on a cut-off opened several years ago to eliminate a dangerous bridge. The dead were:
The Earl of Athlone left today for the first visit by a member of the royal family to King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia.
More than 500 attended the Pennywise Cruise Ball for the benefit of "Flowers for the Flowerless" fund tonight in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom There was a two-hour

The Eastern downhill skiing championship, the most important race' to be held thus far this season in this part of the country, will take place tomorrow afternoon on the exacting Thunderbolt Trail at Adams,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your recent editorial "The Silver Fantasy" you ask a series of questions, the answers to which lead to your conclusion that the Silver Purchase Act of 1934 served no purpose except to provide a subsidy for silver-producing States.
The complete reorganization of the Ministry of Economics into the executive organ of Field Marshal Hermann Goering's Four-Year Plan was announced today.

Domestic corporation bonds were weak yesterday in the early trading, but met sufficient support in the afternoon to close at slightly higher levels. Trading proceeded at a much reduced pace, and it was not until after many issues had dipped to new lows for the movement that the rally developed, and even then with only little enthusiasm.
A well-balanced City College swimming team left Manhattan College's mermen far behind last night as the Beavers gained their second victory. in three starts by a 52-to-23 score.
This correspondent has just witnessed a pocket drama which illuminates and reduces to the human scale the national conflict dividing and subdividing all of the succession States of Central Europe.

Following is the text of the confer ence report on the National Housing Act amendments as adopted by Congress and signed by the President: That this Act may be cited as the "National Housing Act Amendments of 1938."

One of the most important questions in the minds of some of the government officials who will confer shortly with President Roosevelt on solving the acute economic problem of the nation's railroads is how far the public is now willing to go in the matter of eliminating railroad competition, it was learned today.

The transmission of color in a television program was effected for the first time by radio tonight when an experimental demonstration of Professor John L. Baird's system was given at the Dominion Theatre.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 29 totaled 553,176 cars the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Changing the custom of having Monday as "wash-day" or "laundry-day" is needed to make the recent recommendations of the Laundry Minimum Wage Board effective, Walter Frank, chairman of that body, declared yesterday, in urging members of the Women's Trade Union League to support such a step.

A sense of foreboding ran through the first astounded comments in London today on the sensational "bloodless purge" in Germany. The British Government has long dreaded the weakening of what it regarded as the "moderate" influence of the army on German foreign policy.
A large entry is expected for Bloomingdale's seventh annual pet dog show, scheduled from Feb. 23 to 26. It will be held on the sixth floor of the building at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Commonwealth Trust Co sold to the Foxco Realty Co, Emily Fox, president, the two-story garage on a plot 99x89 ft at 4.171-75 Boulevard, n w cor of Shippen St, Union City. It took back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $31,000 due April 1, 1943, at 4 per cent. The Centreville Building Loan Asso sold the three-story flat, 721 Boulevard, n w cor of 28th St, Bayonne, to Mary F. Toye.

The preliminary report of the Market Street Railway Company and the South San Francisco Railroad and Power Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $178,257, after interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and other charges.

Bernard Strauss, who before his retirement twenty years ago was a partner in Berliner, Strauss Meyer of New York, manufacturers of neckwear, died on Thursday at his home, 222 West Seventyseventh Street, at the age of 75.
BERLIN, Feb. 4.--New income tax regulations issued here today provide no reduction will be granted for Jewish children. The German law provides a reduction in income tax for each child in the family.

With its temper cooled, the "conservative manifesto" by which the small business men brought their two-day conference to a rip-roaring finale yesterday was formally presented today to President Roosevelt by the twelve conference chairmen in the presence of Secretary of Commerce Roper and Assistant Secretary Draper.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 4.--Recent consultations by Captain Royal E. Ingersoll, chief of the navy's War Plans Division, with British officials in London went unexplained today when Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations,...

Betting odds at Santa Anita Park were smashed and one of the highest prices in recent years of turf history was chalked up today when a 5-year-old mare, Playmay, captured the first race and paid off at the rate of $673.40 to win, $141.60 to place and $104.60 to show on $2 mutuel tickets.

Senator Wagner moved today to extend the collective bargaining requirements of the National Labor Relations Act to all companies and individuals which benefit by government contracts. loans or grants.

Mrs. Bridget J. Walsh, mother of the Very Rev. Francis W. Walsh, pastor of the Church of the Assumption at Peekskill and recently appointed dean of Westchester County and president of New Rochelle College, died here today. Another son, the Rev. Joseph M. Walsh, pastor of the Church of St. Charles Borromeo in New York, survives.

Having just launched its advertising campaign to promote a 15 per cent rebate on automobile liability insurance to safe drivers in newspapers of twenty-seven States and the District of Columbia, member companies of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters may use eventually 900

Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 24.17 per cent of total volume in the week ended on Jan. 8, compared with 17.20 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Earth tremors, believed due to mine disturbances, damaged three Hughestown school buildings today and resulted in the suspension of classes for the town's 700 students. Three distinct shocks were reported-the first at 7:50 A. M., the second at 7:55 and the third at 8:05.

John Hay Whitney, member of the New York State Racing Commission and the Jockey Club, yesterday denied recent reports that he might become interested in Narragansett Park. In a statement issued in his behalf by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the racing commission, he said:

The net profit of the United Fruit Company in 1937 amounted to $11,817,128, equal to $4.04 a share, compared with $14,176,996, or $4.84 a share, in 1936, the concern reported yesterday. Dividends declared to?? $11,610,388, against $12,350,484 in 1936.

Purchase was announced today at Warners of the recently published "We Are Not Alone" by James Hilton. Bette Davis will be featured. The picture probably will be filmed in June after Miss Davis completes "Comet Over Broadway."

The French liner Normandie will sail today on a cruise to South America, the largest vessel ever to cross the equator. Sailing under the auspices. of the travel firm, Raymond-Whitcomb, the liner will have nearly 1,000 passengers.

The marriage of Miss Mary Tapp Bird, daughter of Mrs. Nathaniel F. Glidden of Tenafly, N. J., and of Samuel Bird of New York and London, to Gerard Piel, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Piel of this city and Salisbury, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in the Louis XVI Suite of the St. Regis.

Traffic in the Hudson Tubes was tied up for nearly thirty minutes yesterday during the morning rushhour period because of a short circuit on a train approaching the Hudson Terminal station at Cortlandt Street.
Horace Lincoln Day, founder of Valumet Chocolate Company of Elmsford, N. Y., died at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Albert C. Edgar, 421 Field Point Road, Greenwhich, last night. He was 71 years old.

The Rev. Paul J. Slavik will be installed tomorrow at 11 A. M. as pastor in the Slovak Lutheran Church of St. Paul, 1,410 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. Slavik came to the metropolitan district last May from Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Utica, N. Y.
Realty activity in the Bronx was featured yesterday by additional purchases by buyers who have been active in the borough during the last year.

Certificates of deposit for Standard Gas and Electric Company twenty-year 6 per cent notes due on Oct. 1, 1935, which certificates were issued under the plan of reorganization dated Nov. 1, 1937, will be admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange today.

The wedding of Miss Jane McQuiggan of this city to Henry Driggs Burrall, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Burrall of Waterbury, took place this afternoon in St. Ann's Church, Hamden. The Rev. John J. Reilly officiated.
Miss Annette Hall McIntire, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A Reed McIntire of Ardmore, was married this afternoon to Harold Beckler Pough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Pough of St. Louis.

Japanese airplane bombers and warships increased their activity near Canton yesterday, while the officials of the Kwangtung Province port were crushing a revolt believed to have been inspired by Tokyo.

Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, and Donald Frame, both former pupils of Harry Cowles at Harvard, gained the final round of the metropolitan squash racquets championship yesterday at the University Club.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

With less than an hour's debate the House today passed the $27,638,000 First Deficiency Bill with only one change in the Appropriations Committee recommendations, thus adding another log to the legislative jam dammed up in the filibusterbound Senate.

Captain Arthur W. Brandt, State Superintendent of Highways, today termed "excessive" the proposed construction of a $200,000,000 super-highway between New York City and Albany, as recommended in a bill before the Legislature.

After a brief flurry of opposition, the Democratic County Committee of the Fifteenth Assembly District last night unanimously accepted the resignation of Maurice B. Blumenthal as leader and elected Jeremiah T. Mahoney to succeed him. Mr. Mahoney relinquished the leadership last Fall when he became the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

Walter C. Teagle, board chairman of Standard Oil of New Jersey, testified at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on investment trusts today that he did not know who controlled the American I. G. Chemical Corporation, in which he has been a director since 1929.

E. N. Brown, former chairman of the board of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, is to testify on next Tuesday before the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington on a plan for reorganization of the road.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Wilson of this city have announced the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Josephine L. Wilson, to John Levering Hammer Jr. of the St. Anthony Club, Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hammer of Brightwaters, N. Y., formerly of Wilmington, N. C.

Isaac Jocelyn Wild, a Yale graduate of 1867, died at his home here today at the age of 95. Only two other members of his class survive. He was born in Stockport, N. Y., and upon graduation joined the United Tea Company in New York.
The New York Infirmary for Women and Children will be the beneficiary of a Bermuda Valentine tea dance this afternoon in the Trianon Room and Lounge of the Ambassador.
Fordham Prep eliminated Brooklyn Prep, defending champion, in the semi-final round of the fourth annual metropolitan Jesuit school basketball tournament today, 35 to 28.

To bring about better adjustment between the schools and the pupils, an extensive guidance program will be introduced experimentally in fifteen New York City schools next week, Dr. Charles M. Smith, director of guidance and placement, announced yesterday.

The team-work of Stanley Galowin, N. Y. U. senior, and his partner, Joseph Wiener of the 42 Broadway gymnasium, furnished the highlight of the initial round of the first annual Heights Casino open squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday.

James Alexander Turnbull, who for many years was an official here of Turnbull Co., a carriage-manufacturing concern founded by his grandfather, the late James Turnbull; died here today in the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of eight weeks. He was 71 years old and lived at 390 Mount Prospect Avenue.

Hyman Lederman, who is accused of having represented himself to be an heir of the late Theodore N. Vail, former head of the Bell Telephone Company, and to have solicited funds pending a determination of "his share" of the Vail estate, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on twenty-nine counts alleging mail fraud.

Joseph Molloy, also known as Durkin, 35 years old, who was described by the police as a bookmaker and bootlegger operating in Northern New Jersey, was found dead with a bullet in his head in an abandoned automobile in front of 332 West Eighteenth Street, yesterday morning.

David Hill, an 87-year-old farmer, critically ill with pneumonia, received the treatment prescribed by his physician today because five construction crews made a mile-long electrio power line extension in eight hours.

Miss Mary Ann Travers, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Travers of 23 East Eighty-third Street, entertained with a dinner last night at the home of her parents for Miss Jean Harrington, who celebrated her birthday, and later took her guests to the Stork Club for supper and dancing.

Fordham snapped Villanova's winning streak by driving to a 40-37 victory at the Arena tonight in the second part of a double-header before 7,983 fans. It was the first meeting between teams of the two colleges since 1921.

Following the fourth disappearance within a fortnight of Howard Frankel, 12 years old, from the home of his mother, Mrs. Rose Frankel, to whom a court awarded his custody, Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Children's Court in Brooklyn appointed yesterday a guardian for the boy.

Under the influence of the most active trading in several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved up 10 points yesterday to close with net gains of 5 to 9 points. An advance in the dollar value of the pound sterling and a further

The systematic and purposeful propaganda of Germany and Italy in Brazil is a growing challenge to the trade and influence of the United States in that country. In his dispatch Thursday from Rio de Janeiro our correspondent, Turner Catledge, reported the results of a careful study of these efforts of nonAmerican States to advance their commercial and political interests in the largest of the South American republics.

The Securities and Exchange Commiscurities under the name of the John Fry of Philadelphia, dealing in securities under the name the John W. Fry Company, has been enjoined permanently from selling securities.
This morning dawned fair and somewhat gusty, but we decided to take a chance anyway, despite the fact that we were warned that it was going to be "a trifle rough" outside.

China's foreign merchandise trade balance in 1937 showed a slight gain ,over the previous year, the adverse balance having been $34,530,000 compared with $70,740,000 in 1936, said a radio report to the Department of Commerce made public today.
Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Austria, said tonight that his recall to Berlin came as a complete surprise to him and that he did not know the reason.

Trading was generally only fair in the wholesale markets. The lamb market continued weak and some cuts were sharply lower. Cows were weak. Other classes were mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to lower; other classes steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. Charles Brennig, who recently sold her five-acre estate in Manhasset, has purchased a Colonial dwelling on the west side of Knolls Lane, in the village of Flower Hill, L. I., which has just been completed by George F. Scudder, builder.
Lord and Lady Sackville of London are expected Monday on the Queen Mary and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.

The principal manufacturers of steel office furniture and equipment, their dealers and the trade associations for the dealers and manufacturers were charged with pricefixing and maintaining a combination with monopolistic tendencies in a complaint filed today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Broadway strollers groped their way through smoke for more than twenty minutes a little after noon yesterday when grease in the kitchen flue of Diamond Jim's Grill at 1,481 Broadway, the Rialto Theatre building, north of Fortysecond Street, became, ignited.

A special grand jury investigating the city administration reported today without additional indictments, but with criticism of a bond refunding deal and of police activity against horse race bookmakers.

The powerfully appealing statement by Colonel Henry L. Stimson, former United States Secretary of State, in behalf of Chinese relief, should reach every home in this country and be repeated to the other side of the globe.

Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN--Francis H. Hunt. from 4th Precinct to 18th Division, for 10 days, from 8 A. M., Feb. 5. William A. Gibbons. from 7th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office. N. Y. County, for 1 day, from 12:01 A. M., Feb. 2.
In response to your invitation, extended through the Secretary of Commerce, the Hon. Daniel C. Roper, approximately one thousand representatives of smaller business units,
The appointment of A. Simon, divisional sales manager, as general sales manager of the metropolitan division of the Western Union Telegraph Company was announced yesterday.

On his first leave of absence since he took over the post at Warsaw last June, Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., United States Minister to Poland returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie to visit at his home in Philadelphia and to report to Secretary Hull.

Judge William Clark of the United States District Court of New Jersey, sitting in Newark yesterday, signed an order directing the Benjamin Franklin Foundation, Inc., of Philadelphia to show cause on Feb. 14 why it should not be restrained,

Dr. Winfred G. Leutner, president of Western Reserve University, said last night that American colleges should not plan to curtail their enrollments in general arts and science courses, although he admitted that professional graduates were too numerous and forecast a falling off in the number of youths of college age in 1943.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, the erstwhile "kid mouthpiece" for high pressure crime as it was organized by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, lost today his first legal skirmish to stay out of reach of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Judge William Clark of the United States District Court of New Jersey, sitting in Newark yesterday, signed an order directing the Benjamin Franklin Foundation, Inc., of Philadelphia to show cause on Feb. 14 why it should not be restrained,

Dr. Winfred G. Leutner, president of Western Reserve University, said last night that American colleges should not plan to curtail their enrollments in general arts and science courses, although he admitted that professional graduates were too numerous and forecast a falling off in the number of youths of college age in 1943.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, the erstwhile "kid mouthpiece" for high pressure crime as it was organized by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, lost today his first legal skirmish to stay out of reach of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.
DOUGLAS R. BROWN, clerk, 2,964 Perry Ave.--Labilities, $1,948; no assets except insurance. HENRY FRIEDBERG, as Princely Sales Co., hats, 42 Prince St. - Liabilities. $2,367; assets, $910.

An upset price of $5,250,000 has been fixed as a basis upon which the office skyscraper known as the Canadian Pacific Building, at 342 Madison Avenue will be sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms on Feb. 23.

Mrs. Abigail Persis Worthley, who claimed to be the oldest mother in the United States, died yesterday at the home of a daughter at the age of 106. A native of Goffstown, N. H., she would have been 107 Sept. 29.

In a series of letters in the Physical Review, the latest of which is published today, Professor G. M. Jauncey of George Washington University, St. Louis, Mo., describes experiments which, in his opinion, make it necessary to abandon some cherished theories about the constitution of matter.

Publication of the first photographs of Princess Beatrix, baby daughter of Princess Juliana, today before the date for their release caused considerable criticism of some members of the royal entourage.

Tuesday's communique by the Ministry of Finance in which permanent officials were revealed to be in open conflict with the government has given a startled public an indication of the constant friction behind the scenes in the Goga Cabinet.

THE program to be given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, at Carnegie Hall, Feb. 15, will feature Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde," with Charles Kullmann, tenor, and Enid Szantho, contralto, as soloists. Mozart's "Haffner" symphony in D will complete the schedule of this sixth event in the organization's current New York season.

The following Foreign Service changes since Jan. 21 were announced by the State Department today: Hugh Corby Fox of New York, Department of State, designated third secretary of embassy at Mexico City, Mexic.

A recent visitor to Paris, according to a wireless dispatch to THE TIMES, spent the day "playing several strenuous sets of tennis," and in the evening went to a show. So far there is nothing unusual in the occurrence, except the tennis.

With the Federal Housing Administration preparing to send out new rules immediately and put into operation within a week the amended FHA program as adopted by Congress last week, builders in suburban areas reported a quick response to the easier financing terms in the form of a flood on. inquiries and even in sales.

J. P. Doycheff, Bulgarian Consul in New York, has announced an agreement between Bulgaria and the United States under which the former agrees to waive all requirements for legalization or authentication of certificates of origin, relating to merchandise, which have been issued by the Merchants Association of New York or Chambers of Commerce in important centers of this country.

Another new building will be added to the group on the campus of Hofstra College, the branch of the New York University here, according to Dr. J. T. P. Calkins, chairman of the board of trustees of the college.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Feb. 5.--Richard N. Gruendyke, owner of the Musconetcong Publishing Company, which publishes The Hackettstown Courier-Post, has announced that P. Grier Hart Jr. of Summit has purchased a half interest in the concern. Mr. Hart has assumed his duties as business manager.
Sixteen of seventeen men arrested "in a knitting school," today were ordered by Judge Ralph Reeve to "drop a few stitches" into the court coffers.

The "little man" who had two busy days here this week and retreated after laying down the greatest oratorical barrage in the recent history of the capital had a multiple personality and a multi-multiple point of view.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla.--Serving a triple purpose, the first annual Luna Fiesta of this resort will be held on Feb. 14 at the Roney Plaza Cabana,Sun Club on Miami Beach.

A supper dance under the auspices of the Giuditta Guild of the Cencale of St. Regis will take place Feb. 26 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The organization, which will mark its fifteenth anniversary this year, is composed of 350 young women and girls devoted to furthering charitable enterprises.
Prices were' moderately higher in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange,

Holding its opponents to five field goals and dominating the play throughout, Notre Dame tonight overwhelmed Pittsburgh, 51-17, for its sixteenth consecutive basketball victory at home and its thirteenth of the season.

With business failures spurting almost 63 per cent in January over the like month of 1937, a definite movement on the part of credit men to tighten up on their restrictions and to ban Spring shipments to very slow accounts was revealed yesterday.

Vitamin D can be artificially generated in much the same manner used by atom smashers to induce artificial radioactivity in such common substances as table salt, according to a patent just granted here to Charles C. Whittier of Chicago.

A dinner and dance were given last night at the Plaza under the auspices of the American-Hungarian Medical Association to augment its relief fund for needy Hungarian families in the metropolitan area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The exact provisions of the proposals now before Congress for the reorganization of the Federal system of audit and accounting control are not widely known and their purport has been the subject of considerable misconception.
Young men who some day may stand within the bar rails of the highest tribunals of the country are arguing their first cases in the "Supreme Court of the State of Ames."

Movements vessels follow. All dates are Feb. 4 unless specified. At San Pedro: Indianapolis. Kanawha. Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Guantanamo Bay: Semmes, S-20, Ralph Talbot (Feb. 5). Acushnet. Naval Operating Base. Norfolk, to Yorktown, Feb. 5. Brooklyn, Guantanamo Bay to Galveston. Chaumont, at Manila, Feb. 5.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, has sent 745 boys and girls, 15 to 17 years of age, to Palestine, according to a report by Mrs. David B. Greenberg, chairman of the Youth Aliyah (immigration) committee.

The retirement of Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg as German War Minister, following his marriage with a carpenter's daughter, evidenced the caste system in German army life, Rabbi B. A. Tintner of Mount Zion Congregation, 257 West Ninety-third Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Mrs. Sally Joost Chace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman B. Joost, of 1,185 Park Avenue and Quogue, L. I., was married here yesterday noon at the home of her parents to Ludlow Van Deventer of Plainfield, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob H. Van Deventer. The Rev.

ONE of the nation's tiniest railroads will become one of the busiest also when the tenth annual show of the New York Society of Model Engineers gets under way next Saturday at the club's headquarters, 152 West Forty-second Street.

THIS is not one of those profound labors of the scholar, coming out of years of brooding and study. A year before completing the book Mr. Zweig made a journey to Brazil, was bored by the monotony of the voyage,

ALTHOUGH the scene of his new novel is laid in New port during a single social season, and his principal characters are three women of the Summer colony, Mr. Neville indulges in no diatribes against the idle rich. For which restraint the reader is duly grateful.' Instead.

MOTORISTS journeying to New Orleans for a first visit usually find a curious if not always understanding pleasure in the foreign-sounding cries of her native salespeople and at the sight of the wares offered.
The Bureau of Air Commerce announced today the suspension of all passenger service on the Northwest Airlines routes west of Chicago until the line meets department regulations.

Intervention of President Roosevelt in what spokesmen for the railroads call their crisis is expected to revive plans for moves toward consolidation long held in abeyance, according to views in informed circles.

For several years the question has been asked almost daily in capitals of other countries, "What is the influence of the German Army and its General Staff? Does Hitler really control the army or does he have to compromise with it?" The reason for this question has been the common impression in the Chancelleries of other powers that the army did not approve of many of the acts of the Nazi Government.

Walter Rysam Jones, president of the Badminton Club and Recorder General of the Naval Order of the United States, died yesterday at his home, 256 East Sixty-eighth Street, after an illness of three weeks.

Peace in organized labor's civil war is still a willo'-the-wisp, desirable but distant. The last fortnight has witnessed hostile exchanges between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization. Bitter personal attacks,

Final assessed valuation of taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City was announced yesterday as $16,650,297,794 by the Tax Commission, which under the new charter succeeded the Board of Taxes and Assessments.

With air raids of almost nightly occurrence, seven women nurses in the original unit sent to Spain a year ago by the American Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy, were speedily inured to the hardships of war, according to one of them-Miss Fredericka Martin.

Company B, Twenty-eighth Infantry, stationed at Fort Niagara, N. Y., won the annual trophy of the New York Society of Military and Naval Officers of the World War for being the most efficient among all infantry rifle companies of the First Division, according to an announcement yesterday at head quarters of the First Division, Fort Hamilton.

Communion Mass of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs of New York Province (Newman Clubs), St. Patrick's Cathedral, 9 A. M. to be followed by breakfast at the WaldorfAstoria at 10:30 A. M. at which speakers will be: Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Francis J. Sheed, Rev. John P. Monaghan.

More than 130 American colleges and universities are this year giving courses in public administration. Sixty of them profess to offer comprehensive programs of educational preparation for public administration.

Four hundred and nineteen delegates, representing organizations with a total membership of more than 600,000 persons, voted yesterday afternoon to support a boycott of Japanese goods as a gesture of protest against the "Japanese military group."

Enactment of the Clark-Connery AntiChild Labor Bill, which the Senate passed in modified form at the special session as a rider on the Wages and Hours Bill, was urged today by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the 1938 budget is "properly and sufficiently balanced" and again denounced as "infamous" the budget passed by the Board of Aldermen that Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan has held to be the valid budget.

Charles F. Stoebling, Hudson county's Registration Commissioner, whose refusal, because of illness, to surrender election records has balked the Young committee's investigation, was examined by three physicians this afternoon at his home, 50 Glenwood Avenue, Jersey City.
More than 500,000 children in this city are growing up in families dependent on public relief for the essentials of life, a survey of welfare rolls showed yesterday.

The "profoundly beneficial" effect that participation of sixty-four nations in the New York World's Fair r of 1939 will have in fostering international understanding was acclaimed by Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace, speaking at a luncheon yesterday for members of the United States New York World's Fair Commission, as a hopeful sign for future peace.

It must often have been realized that the difference between an attractive and an unattractive home lies not in the number, size, shape or richness of the buildings but rather in the environs of the buildings-the setting. A garden-or lack of one-makes or mars a home.

A blue-ribbon panel of 125 talesmen has been directed to appear in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Erskine C. Rogers tomorrow to qualify as jurors for the perjury trial of William W. Kleinman, former Assistant District Attorney of Brooklyn.

The military and political changes in Germany are considered here a triumph of the Rome-Berlin axis and the RomeBerlin-Tokyo triangle. Now that the German armed forces are unifled under Chancellor Adolf Hitler's leadership as Italian forces unified under Premier Benito

ANNOUNCEMENT that April 20 has been set as the date for the 1938 World Bridge Olympic brings to mind the recurrent argument, of five years' standing, between the sponsors of this contract bridge tournament and the International Olympic Committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock discussed recently the verdict against certain oil companies and officials for having restrained trade through the operation of a gasoline purchasing "program."
Residents of this city have for some years been familiar with exhibitions here of backyard gardens and landscaped penthouse terraces, held in the Spring, Summer or Autumn.

Testimony that standards of workmanship at the St. Louis assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company declined sharply after organization of a local of the United Automobile Workers of America was given today at a National Labor Relations Board hearing.
