INSTEAD of presenting a few new canvases by Leonid, as in other years, Julien Levy this time is holding something like a definitive exhibition of work by one of the most distinctive of the younger modern French painters (till Feb. 19).

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5.--Dr. Samuel C. Shellabarger, author and a former member of the Princeton University faculty, has been named headmaster of the Columbus School for Girls, Columbus, Ohio, it became known here today.

THE birth, last Monday, of a princess who may some day be Queen of The Netherlands is of interest to philatelists--first because the baby's mother is in te hobby's gallery, and second because a likeness of this royal child is expected to appear on Netherlands postal paper in due time, in keeping with familiar practice in countries of Continental Europe.

SEVEN dignified men sit hunched over a low round table in a big room where the north light is good. They look like bank presidents. Their clothes are faultless and conservative. They are working hard and earnestly for the government and the tea-drinking public of the United States.
FEW persons have ever heard of the Jeannette or of her commander, George Washington De Long, United States naval officer, who died as heroically as he lived.

Two veteran right-handers, Guy Bush and Ray Benge, were added to the pitching staff of the Cardinals today. Vice President Branch Rickey announced the purchase of Bush from the Boston Bees and the signing of Benge, a free agent, "to take care of our reserve pitching until we see how things shape up."

MOSCOW, Feb. 5.--A representative of the United States Embassy will visit Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens Monday, it was disclosed today, in the hope of solving the mystery of her trip to Russia and subsequent arrest.

The Loomis basketball team defeated Berkshire, 43 to 22, today after leading at half time, 13 to 9. O'Malley, Loomis forward, starred with 15 points, while the Berkshire scoring honors were divided between Sadler and Knickerbocker.

The Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women, founded and maintained by the Daughters of the British Empire, will be aided by a performance of "England's Hourglass" the night of Feb. 27 at the Lyceum Theatre.

IN "The African Farm," Karen Blixen tells a vivid story of her many years on the large possessions she held in Kenya, partly a coffee plantation and partly primeval forest, at the foot of the Ngong Hills not far from Nairobi.

TODAY is "Scout Sunday" and the beginning of "Boy Scout Week,' which marks the twenty-eighth anniversary of the movement in America. Scout programs during the week will emphasize scouting's advance since 1910 into every city and town and virtually every village and hamlet of the nation.

The working class and the poor must be provided with the necessities of life, announced President Anastasio Somoza today as he initiated a project to establish government commissaries throughout the republic.

Dave Clark, Detroit, was credited with a knockout over Bruno Sala, Poughkeepsie, in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Rockland Palace last night. Sala suffered a bad cut under his left eye and was unable to respond to the bell to start the fifth.

TO some women Spring and a new tweed suit are synonymous-not only tweed but English tweed. Those who share this fondness for tweed can now gratify their liking, for several New York shops are carrying suits imported from Jaeger House of London.

Hard-riding Clarence (Buddy) Combs played in his usual sparkling style to lead unbeaten Evergreen Farms to an 11-to-8 triumph over Boulder Brook in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League senior division match at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ernst Ruprecht of Englewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emmy-Lou Ruprecht, to Bernard J. Salembier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Salembier, also of Englewood.

Completion of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, linking Ferry Point In the Bronx and Whitestone in Queens, will lead to a period of expansion and development in Bronx Borough, predicts Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade- and a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

LONDON.--More than fifty British towns are maintaining contact in various ways with more than 600 of their namesake towns in the United States. Usually the contacts take the form of Christmas and other anniversary gifts, but in some cases they have been more substantial.

Although Wall Street has accepted without important objection, the Securities and Exchange Commission's restriction on short selling which will become effective on Tuesday, there is a well-defiied feeling in financial circles that the problem of short sales is by no means solved.

With the opening of the Spring term last week, the enrollment figures portrayed in graphic form the changes taking place in the New York City school system. While the elementary schools lost ground again, the junior high schools continued their steady upward march. This division now has 133,400 boys and girls.

The origin of life on earth and the forces that gave rise to it are among the most fascinating of mysteries, a subject of pure speculation for the poet as well as the scientist. Until recently it looked ery much as if the mysteries would remain forever unsolved.

Miss Beulah Washburn of Worcester, Mass., was married to Charles B. Swartwood Jr. of Corning in the Church of the Transfiguration, New York, yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine, curate of the parish.

Members of the Alumnae Association of Marymount College gave a supper dance last night at Sherry's for the benefit of the library building fund of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N. Y. Miss Molly Lane headed the dance committee.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, and Mrs. Fosdick of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinor Whitney Fosdick, to Dr. Roger Sherman Downs, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherman Downs of Saratoga, N. Y.
Annual inventory in New York's retail stores, which stops the normal flow of new merchandise about as effectively as Norris Dam holds back the Tennessee River, is just over.

Miss Elizabeth Van Cleaf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Van Cleaf of Maplewood, will be married to Walter C. Bachm??n, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. E. Ba??chman of Nazareth, Pa. The wedding will take place the evening of March 25 in the Maplewood Country club.

Guerrilla warfare against the Japanese invaders of China is not only the fight 'of armed civilian groups against the Japanese Army; it is also a fight of these Chinese groups against those among their own nationals who serve and enter into friendly relations with the Japanese.
RADIO drama is a medium of make-believe. It is an art of two distinct classifications; one characterized by illustrative sound effects, the other depending solely upon words dramatically spoken.

With two foreign entries received yesterday for the yacht race from Newport to Bermuda, which will be started on June 20, the event was turned into an international one. They were for an English sloop, or cutter, named the Latifa, and the German yawl Roland von Bremen.
THE Summer months will mark the opening of two important highway projects in Connecticut, which have been urgently needed to accommodate an ever-increasing flow of traffic.

Miss Alice Schroder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Schroder of East Orange, was married this evening to Alexander John Geiges Jr., son of Mr. Geiges, also of this city. The ceremony was performed in Bethel Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Alexander Macaulay.

Britain's action in cooperating with the United States and France in demanding that Japan reveal her naval program "or else" is the final move in a long series of efforts to pierce the mystery with which Japan has surrounded her naval program ever since she walked out of the London Naval Conference of 1936.
Unbeaten in league play since Dec. 4, the Wolverhampton Wanderers are making a great drive to win the English football championship for the first time in the club's long history.

BEFORE the men and women in this story embark on their eventful voyage up the Nile we are told something about the background of the most important of them and are given some insight into their characters.

ATHENS.--As Princess Frederica of Hanover becomes more firmly established in her new role as the presumable future Queen of Greece it is evident that she has captured the fancy and conquered the hearts of many who were perhaps indifferently disposed before her recent marriage to Prince Paul, heir to the Greek throne.
Greenwich real estate sales showed an increase in 1937 over 1936 and leading real estate brokers are looking for an even larger demand for residences and properties during the coming months.

John Boyd Thacher 2d, now serving his fourth consecutive term as Mayor of Albany, in an address at the annual dinner of the Albany Society of New York at the Hotel Biltmore last night, pleaded for a partnership of capital and laborin a well-considered endeavor to rebuild prosperity, shattered by the recession.

Secure in the confidence born of twenty-seven years in which the weather has never failed them, officials of the Dartmouth Outing Club are ready to put the finishing touches on preparations for their twenty-eighth annual Winter carnival, which will open next Friday at Hanover.

The plan to integrate the functions and activities of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., and the New York Security Dealers Association by having the former take over the matter of quotations and uniform practice rulings of the New York organization, effective on Tuesday, was announced formally today.

More than six hundred thousand visits to the homes of sick persons in this city were made in 1937 by the nursing staff of the City Health Department, according to an article in Our Nurses, the departmental publication, the February issue of which was published yesterday.

The dollar registered a slight recovery yesterday in terms of the principal foreign exchanges in the local market, but declines in the overseas currencies were not sufficiently wide to nullify their gains for the week.

Governor Dummer Academy bowed to the Exeter Academy quintet tonight, 45-30. Exeter led by only 2 points at the half but rapidly pulled away. from the Governors thereafter. Stewart and Bowersox were high scorers for Exeter while Lawler starred for the Governors.

Welker Cochran of San Francisco regained the 18.2 balkline billiard championship of the world tonight, staving off a spirited last-block rally by Jake Schaefer of Chicago and winning with a total score of 3,600 to 3,476.

The current anti-Semitic campaign in Rumania was described as "just a passing phase" by Charles A. Davila, former Rumanian Minister to the United States, as he sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Mr. Davila resigned recently, after serving for eight years.
The annual luncheon of the New York Wellesley Club will be held on Feb. 26 in the grand ballroom of the Biltmore.
LITTLE WOMEN" is the most popular book for girls that has ever been published in America. In England. too, it has been widely read and loved.
WASHINGTON.--Although 18 is considered the normal age for entering college, more students enroll after that year than do before.

Brooklyn Woman's Club--Education and civics department meeting. R. E. Vetterli of United States Department of Justice, speaker. college Women's Club of Montclair (N. J.)-Meeting, auspices literature group, First Congregational Church, 2:30 P. M. Mrs. Arne Fisher, speaker.

The French reaction to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's government shakeup has been largely confined to somewhat fruitless discussion as to how France is to find political unity to offset the more complete Nazi domination of the Reich.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of history and civics in junior high schools, as of Feb. 3, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Once again the imposing facade of the Third Reich has cracked and through that crack the outside world sees exposed once more the deep inner conflicts behind the supposedly solid front of German unity. Force can discourage Hitler's foes.

Scholarship awards to twelve German exiles are announced by the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom through the chairman of the executive committee, Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research.

Three ski trails and a shack, a new rink and organization of hockey as a university sport, are the developments of little more than a year since six men students furnished the impetus for the St. Lawrence University Outing Club, which now has a membership of 200, or about one-third of the student body.

Representatives of veterans and religious organizations opposing the appointment by Manhattan Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, as assistant to the President, will carry their protest to a hearing to be held Tuesday at 3 P. M.

The New York City school system and the American Institute of the City of New York will cooperate with New York University in conducting a fifteen-week course in "Laboratory Technique for Science Club Sponsors" beginning next Wednesday evening, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the university's Division of General Education.

FIGURATIVELY America has taken her rusty skates out of the attic and headed for the ice. The long-neglected sport of skating-a sport never completely forgotten by the youngsters-has returned to high favor. It may be that the lure of Winter sports in general, which have had a steady revival in the last ten years or so. has been partly responsible.

Immediate adjournment of Congress after passing the appropriation bills, without any further attempt to regulate business, was declared yesterday by Max D. Steuer to be the one true solution for the difficulties of industry.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago reached the final round of the Surf Club tennis tournament today with a 6-2, 6-3, 4-6, 7-5 victory over Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore.

The Union College basketball team proved a stubborn foe for City College in their game at the C. C. N. Y. gym last night, but the Lavender put on the pressure in the second half to conquer the Garnet, 37-19.
The War and Navy Departments, responding to pressure from press, commercial and amateur

Miss Sarah Pemberton Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Taylor of Hartford, was married to Dr. Edgar Buell Butler of West Hartford this afternoon in Trinity Church by the rector, the Rev. Raymond Cunningham, assisted by the Rev. Charles L. Taylor of Cambridge, Mass., a brother of the bride.

Motorists will be able to drive from New Jersey to New England without encountering traffic hindrances if a highway plan promulgated by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors and the State Council of Parks is financed by the State Legislature, parkway engineers said here today.

Dr. Graeme M. Hammond, former president of the New York Athletic Club and for fifteen years a champion fencer, was honored on his eightieth birthday last night at a dinner given by the Caduceus Post, 818, American Legion, at the New York Athletic Club.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, Roger Fawcett annexed the highover-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. In the competition for the handicap prizes, the winner In Class A was 0. Agathon. In Class B, the trophy was taken by J. H. Dessing.

Further tightening rather than liberalization of New York's marriage laws is gaining favor among certain legislators. This was disclosed tonight as supporters of the year-old law requiring a seventy-two-hour lapse between issuance of a marriage certificate and the ceremony prepared for a "finish fight" in the Assembly Monday night against a proposal designed to make the statute nonapplicable when one or both of the contracting parties are out-of-State residents.

Although the one-hundredth session of the Council of the League of Nations lasted for more than a week, its results are at best meager. In answer to the appeal of China the Council adopted unanimously an involved but halting resolution which is a step backward from the not very advanced stand of the Assembly last October.

Baron Wardington, chairman of the board of Lloyds Bank, is in a serious condition at Banbury Hospital following a hunting' accident. One report states he fractured his neck. Formerly J. W. Beaumont Pease, he has a notable record as a sportsman as well as a banker.

The eyes of the world are focused on an ice floe measuring 150 by 210 square feet drifting off the northeast coast of Greenland. Four Soviet scientists and a dog cling to the floe for their lives. An occasional laconic radio message describes their plight.

THE Roth String Quartet, assisted by Johana Harris, piano, will give three concerts, under the auspices of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, this Thursday and Friday nights and Saturday afternoon at the Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. At these events the entire "Art of the Fugue" by Bach arranged for string quartet by Roy Harris and M. D. Herter Norton will be presented.
Mrs. Rowena Randall, a descendant of Thomas Burnet, who founded the village of Southampton in Suffolk County, died at her home here on Thursday at the age of 92. Mrs.

A phrase that has been ringing through Spain this week is "Terror for terror." Defense Minister Indalecio Prieto used it in a note he issued Jan. 28, offering to refrain from bombing open towns in reprisal if Generalissimo Francisco Franco also would cease bombing such towns.
The Patent Office granted 567 patents this week, among which the following attract attention for their unusual slant.

C. C. Slapnicka, vice president of the Cleveland Baseball Club, said today he had authorized release of any claims of the club on the services of Louis Boudreau, University of Illinois athlete, if that will bring about Boudreau's reinstatement in college athletics.

Cooperation by all organized religions to combat their common enemies was urged yesterday at a forum in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria which was part of the nineteenth annual convention of the New York Province of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs.

Pilot Harold Gillam, stranded in the desolate country south of Barrow since Monday, when he was forced down by fuel shortage on a flight from Fairbanks, arrived here today after a dog team brought him gasoline.

ENGLAND'S QUEENS: Next September a new British superliner is scheduled to slide down the ways at Clydebank, four years exactly after the Queen Mary was launched at the same place and christened by Queen Mary herself.

Students, of the Cooperative School for Teachers, at 69 Bank Street, believing that teachers as citizens should take an active part in the life of the community, have been gathering data on neighborhood rental and food costs to be presented to a conference of community groups on Friday and Saturday as a basis for proposed legislation in Albany and for municipal action.
Scores of prospective home owners called at the FHA offices here today seeking information on terms of the new Housing Act. After interviewing applicants local housing authorities were optimistic.

In the Rutgers University bookstore, where hundreds of faculty members and undergraduates pass daily on business, and sometimes stop to chat, The Targum, undergraduate newspaper, this week asked the question:

The New York Retail Tobacco Council, Inc., has taken a stand against the "policy of certain manufacturers who are endeavoring to initiate fair-trade contracts including minimum price schedules substantially at variance with the schedules that organized retailers deem fair and equitable," it was announced yesterday by William Goldstein, secretary.

The Blair Academy quintet recorded its fourth straight Eastern Private Schools League success and its second in as many days yesterday when it downed Trinity School, 32 to 21, on the losers' floor. By winning Blair tightened its grip on the league leadership.

Six debates have been scheduled this month for the Manhattan College debating team, according to an announcement by James A. Kane, manager. Villanova, Georgetown and Randolph-Macon will be met on successive nights beginning Wednesday,

The major oil companies and their chief executives are to be subjected to further criminal proceedings by the Department of Justice for alleged violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, according to Attorney General Cummings, who stated last week in Washington that the department planned to proceed next Fall with their trial in Madison, Wis.

The second children's concert sponsored by the Greenwich Unit of the New York Junior League was given here this morning at the Pickwick Theatre. Quinto Maganini and his Chamber Symphony Orchestra played.

China wilt be defeated if it is deprived of munitions shipped by other nations and the defeat will be "effected not by Japan but, in reality, by America and Great Britain," Mme. Chiang-Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, asserted in a letter sent to W. Reginald Wheeler of the Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China, and. made public here yesterday.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's varsity swimming team triumphed over Fordham University, 51-24, today in the first meet between these two colleges.

Two more policemen have been dismissed for infractions of rules, bringing to 208 the total of those dropped from the department in disciplinary proceedings since Lewis Valentine became Police Commissioner in 1934, it was announced yesterday.
The team race between four American and four Cuban boats, the final event of the twelfth International Star Class yacht regatta, was won by the visitors today with a score of 25 points to 12.

Women leaders in welfare and education head the speakers' lists this week of women's clubs in Westchester County. On Tuesday at 3 P. M., Dr. Mary Woolley, former president of Mount Holyoke College, will speak to the Manor Club of Pelham Manor.

Gerry Seeders's only field goal, with less than thirty seconds to play, gave Pennsylvania a sensational victory over Dartmouth at basketball in the Palestra tonight in the second extra period before 6,000 howling fans. The score was 40-38.
The first Summer fashions run the style gamut from the mannish garconne to the glamorous seductress type. Myriad influences and silhouettes offer a chance for the expression of every personality.

The New York University fencing team, last year's intercollegiate three-weapon champion, rang up its second victory in as many starts this seas on by defeating Yale, 14 to 13 yesterday at the N. Y. U. Washington Square center.
UPCOUNTRY as maple syrup -and as unfamiliar to most urbanites-the wintry sport of ice fishing has started its four-and-a-half-month season in northern States from Maine to Oregon.

A crashing eight-point second-half drive gave Scotland an 8-6 victory over Wales in an international rugby match played before 60,000 persons at Murrayfield today. The Scots trailed 6-0 at the interval.
Lady Ali Khan, mother of the Aga Khan, who is spiritual leader of the Ismaili Mohammedans, died here today at the age of 79. She was known to millions as Queen Mother.

Composers, like other mortals, have stomachs, and the Soviet government amply recognizes that fact, Serge Prokofieff said yesterday afternoon in an interview. The eminent Russian composer arrived on Thursday for a three-week concert tour of this country as pianist and conductor.

The St. Nicks of New York staged a winning drive in the closing minutes of their exciting contest with the Harvard sextet to triumph, 4 to 2, at the Boston Arena tonight. The game was exciting all the way, with the count deadlocked twice.
Billy Thompson's goal in an overtime period tonight gave Syracuse a 47to-45 basketball victory over Colgate before a crowd of 3,000.
Word that the Senate Judiciary Committee will hold a public hearing on the equal rights amendment tomorrow in the Capitol rang out like a tocsin last week to women's organizations.

INCREASING demand for space on the high-speed extra-fare streamliners to California will be met this month by the inauguration of additional trains. On Feb. 22 the Santa Fe will place in service a second Super Chief, thus providing twice-a-week departures from Chicago and Los Angeles.
A gift of $500 to the library of the Pingry School here from Mr. and Mrs. Aage Gusmer of Rahway in memory of their son, Aage Jr., was announced today by E. Laurence Springer, head master.

Two synthetic emeralds on exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History. The one at top was made about a year ago and weighs about 20 carats. It was not perfect enough to cut emerald stones of any value from it.

Expansion of the America Spanish Relief Fund to become a national movement among the 20,000,000 American Catholics, was announced here yesterday by Father Francis X. Talbot, chairman of the fund, which aids needy, sick and injured non-combatant victims of the civil war in Spain on non-sectarian, nonpartisan lines.

George H. Bradley, pioneer oil man in this part of the State, executive of several oil and natural gas firms and former bank official, died in his home here today. He was 73 years old. Mr. Bradley was born in Springboro, Pa., Oct. 9, 1864.

Warren Henry Manning, landscape architect and designer of park systems and college campuses in forty States, died today at the age of 78. He had been at work in his Cambridge office a few hours before his death.

Some of It 1766 B. C.--Rare Chinese art from private collections assembled at the Arden Gallery, where it may be seen until Feb. 26. Bronzes (many of them from the mist-shrouded Shang-yin period, which extends from 1766 to 1122 B. C.), jade animals and birds from the Chou (1122-221 B. C.), little stone figures-and some marvelous scroll paintings.

ALMOST any one should enjoy this story. It is so smoothly written. The people talk like real people, the characters are sharply defined: no one is entirely pure or utterly black, and the mystery and adventure are quick and credible.

A series of Saturday afternoon "amateur" broadcasts for underprivileged children of New York, with the children supplying the entertainment as readers, singers and instrumentalists, began yesterday over station WBNX under the auspices of the Police Athletic League.

Utilization of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway's right of way. in Westchester and the Bronx to establish express toll highways for .trucks and bus traffic from Connecticut and Upper New York State into New York City was visualized here today by Commissioner Robert Moses of the New York City Department of Parks after an inspection of the proposed routes.

UNDERGOING acceptance trials at Cape May, N. J., is the largest flying boat ever built for the Coast Guard, the first of seven identical planes designed chiefly for life-saving and emergency transportation work and capable of covering 2,000 miles without refueling.

NEW YORK CITY'S central government-legislative and executiverevamped by a brand new charter and taking care of 8,000,000 people, is carried on today in an art museum just recently freed from the hands of renovators.

The student board of Columbia College yesterday named an undergraduate committee of nine to cooperate with the university appointments office and the school of business in arranging a series of nine occupational conferences with business men for the next three months.
The sailing of the Dollar liner President Coolidge tonight at midnight for the Orient brings to a close a bitterly disputed chapter in the history of the American merchant marine.

Although the dust bowl of the high plains country is entering its seventh year of drought, with dust storms beginning to appear a month earlier than usual, Roy I. Kimmel, government coordinator for the region, believes that the bowl Is in better condition from a wind erosion point of view than it has been since the Spring of 1935.

Swift passage of Governor Lehman's $385,000,000 budget through the Legislature the week after next has apparently been assured, as the result of conferences between Republican legislative leaders and the Governor, it became known today.

The extensive realty holdings of the defunct North Jersey Title Insurance Company of Hackensack, N. J., will soon be placed on the market, it was announced yesterday by William J. Morrison of Morrison, Lloyd Morrison, attorneys for the North Jersey Liquidating Trust, which will attempt to dispose of the properties.

Held scoreless in the first period, the Dartmouth hockey team struck forcibly to hand Yale's sextet a decisive setback tonight. The Indians from the hills of New Hampshire fired two goals into the nets in the second session, and came through for three more in the third to fashion a 5-to-1 triumph over the hardfighting Eli skaters.

DAVID O. SELZNICK'S signing of Paulette Goddard to a term contract the other day tends to substantiate reports of long standing that the actress is being considered for the role of Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone With the Wind." The producer had nothing definite to say, however, merely commenting that her first assignment would be announced within two weeks.

A new course on "the principles for which Lincoln stood-liberty, equality and justice," is to be introduced at Lincoln Memorial University in Tennessee. It will be given by Professor R. Gerald McMurtry, former librarian of the Lincoln Life Foundation of Fort Wayne, who was recently appointed to the John Wingate Weeks Chair of Citizenship.
Prehistoric man, in his trade of making stone implements, was responsible for the first industrial hazard, according to Miss Sara J. Davenport of the Bureau of Mines at Washington.

Miniature museums of science and industry have been installed in typical elementary schools, one in each borough, as forerunners of an elaborate plan of objective education to be spread through the city's entire system.

In the hope of teaching Americans to spend more intelligently, national center for research and education in consumers' problems is being established at Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., through the cooperation of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc.

The Household Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net profit of $6,382,155. This was after interest charges, normal Federal and Dominion income taxer, a deduction of $463,000 for the surtax on undistributed profits, minority interest and other charges, and was equal to $7.65 each on 717,025 common shares outstanding after dividend requirements on the 5 per cent preferred stock.
BEFORE he became Sir John, J. C; Squire was one of the most important men in literary London, especially in the heyday of the Georgian poets.

Check clearings through the Northern New Jersey Clearing House Association amounted to $24,757,890 in the week ended on Feb. 4, compared with $25,226,169 in the previous week and $39,982,188 in the week ended on Feb. 4, 1937.
Mrs. Margaret Painter Duhring, an illustrator of children's books, died at Presbyterian Hospital yesterday after an illness of six weeks.

After a withdrawal of all air services from Northern China when hostilities first started in that area, putting a summary end to the national air system, a new network of "national" air routes has been set up by Pan American Airways. It links Southern China with the new temporary capital of the Chinese National Government, now located at Chungking, 1,000 miles up the Yangtze River from Shanghai.

Search for an unidentified airplane, which crashed and sunk earlier in about seventy feet of water in the ice-filled Hudson River near Constitution Island, was begun early this. morning by rescue crews of the United States Military Academy and by State police.

VARIED are the methods by which the States allot the sought-for No. 1 license plate, according to a study which has been made by the American Automobile Association and the Oregon State Motor Association.
FIESTAL--LEVY--Mr. and Mrx. Hugo Levy announce the marriage of their daughter, Clarice Ruth, to Mr. Henry H. Fiestal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fiestal, on Sunday, Jan. 30. 1938.

Three thousand and ninety-three dogs of ninety-four breeds will be benched in Madison Square Garden this week for the sixty-second annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opens at nine o'clock Thursday morning to continue through Saturday evening.

Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes and Mrs. Theodore Fiske Savage gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Miss Emily Del Mar, debutante daughter of William A. Del Mar of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Del Mar. Later they took their guests to a theatrical performance.
Hospitals participating in the three-cents-a-day plan will get a total of more than $5,000,000 from it next year, according to David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund.

Led by George Ghesquiere, who for the fourth successive game entered late and became high scorer with 16 points, Navy reached the high mark of its basketball season to date by winning from Columbia today, 38 to 29.

Sweeping seven of the eight events, three of them by falls, the Columbia wrestling team defeated Rutgers, 27 to 3, before 500 persons today. Chubby Edwards defeated Floyd Snavely by a referee's decision in the unlimited class to score the only victory for the Scarlet.

THE vast reservoir of classic theatre literature will be tapped by radio to trace the development of drama from the productions at sunrise in the Theatre Dionysus in ancient Athens down to the stage of present-day Broadway in a WEAF series of fullhour weekly dramatizations beginning Feb. 26 at 5 P. M.

Michael Karsmarsky, 50 years old, of 307 Springfield Avenue, was hungrily examining a large piece of bologna when two policemen found him d raiding an ice box in the basement apartment of Frederick Rumsey at 624 High Street early today.

Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell University, in an address yesterday before the Cornell Women's Club of New York, deplored the fact that not more than one in twenty parents examined the edunational qualifications of the college they chose for their children.

Some 500 persons, gathered in Columbus Circle yesterday afternoon in a demonstration under the auspices of the New York State Committee, Communist Party, shouted approval of a resolution protesting, among other things, "the Fascist wave of terror aimed at 900,000 Jews of Rumania."
Manikins for the second annual "Fashion Show Your Own" will be selected on Tuesday at a tea to be given by Mrs. James Weiskopf at her home, 1,185 Park Avenue.

A former showgirl, her husband and a man accused as a "big shot" in the smuggling of narcotics on Atlantic liners for the Broadway underworld, were held for the Federal grand jury yesterday following the seizure Friday night. of 400 Y ounces of heroin valued at $200,000 in the hideout of the reputed ringleader.

Part one of the art property ot the late Mrs. Thomas Fortune Ryan, which was auctioned on Thursday, Friday and yesterday at the Plaza Art Galleries, realized $36,023. The rest of the collection will be sold at the same galleries next week.

A partial study of the final realty valuations upon which owners will be required to pay taxes during the present year and for the first half of 1939 reveals, points out Bela Darwin Eisler, an attorney who has specialized in tax litigation, that the tax assessors have made considerable progress toward narrowing the gap between actual valuations and tax valuations.

FOR twelve years now Poland has not seen the genius who found her independence in America. For four years America has not seen the lion-maned musician who was the idol of a whole generation. Paderewski his triumphs in music and in statesmanship behind him, is nearing his eighties here on Lake Geneva-at Morges, in his chalet of Riond-Bosson,

Two important specialty events will serve as curtain-raisers for the Westminster dog show, which will get under way Thursday. Wednesday, terrier fanciers from far and near will gather in Commerce Hall of the Port of New York Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, for the annual specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs, made up of ten national organizations.
Several dinner parties were given tonight in the Palm Beach colony. Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick entertained at Casa Alexado for their house guests, Mrs. Carey Reed and Charles G. West of New York.

AS he approaches the end of his fifth year in the White House President Roosevelt, facing the possibility of another general depression, is feeling his way toward the accomplishment of two apparently contradictory objectivesthe completion of his program of economic reform and the conciliation of business.
The School of Education at City College, under the direction of Dr. Samuel B. Heckman, has organized a special curriculum of courses that is known as the "Afternoon Division."

Funeral services tor the Rev. Thomas F. Watkins, D. D., for twelve years pastor of the White Plains Presbyterian Church, who died of a heart attack Wednesday, were held at 2 P. M. today at the church. He was 47 years old and was Moderator of the Westchester Presbytery.
Snow carnival visitors today saw a "snowman' made of Texas snow obtained from a refrigerator car as a warm, bright sun forced can cellation of most of the annual Winter celebration.

While the Mediterranean situation again became acute owing to the sinking of the Endymion last Monday followed by the sinking of the Alcita yesterday, Virginio Gayda, editor of Giornale d-Italia yesterday printed a long article giving the details of the help in men and supplies that the Spanish Loyalist Government has allegedly received from France.

A tea was given yesterday by Mrs. Robert Weeks Kelley at her home, 510 Park Avenue, for Miss Beatrice Barclay Chard and her fiance, George B. Carpenter. Miss Chard is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Chard of this city and Thornfield.

Yesterday's changes in the German Government were not unexpected by Moscow, especially after the failure of Viscount Halifax's mission to Berlin last November, which among other things was an attempt to strengthen the hand of the German "moderates."
Moving to meet changing social and economic conditions and incorporate advances in education, Syracuse University has added several new courses to the curriculum for the second semester.

A new attack on the coalition forces that control the City Council by a slim margin was started yesterday when five Democratic Councilmen petitioned Mayor La Guardia to call a special meeting of the Council "at once for the purpose of considering the qualifications of Michael J. Quill, Joseph Clark Baldwin 3rd, and any others to be members of the said Council."

The "MilliMan incident" may prove to be an importantt event in Missouri politcal history. Some believe that because of it a shink in "Boss" Pendergast's rmor has been found, and with his entering wedge they may see in eventual unhorsing of the Demcratic leader, who for years has been a dictator of party politics in the State.

In what promises to be the most widely interesting Kentucky Senatorial race since 1900, this State may be a scene of action of artillery of New Deal and anti-New Deal camps, with budget balancing as an issue, and Governor Albert B. Chandler challenging Alben W. Barkley, the Senate majority leader, who is said to be favored by President Roosevelt.

Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania is likely to be the Democratic nominee for Governor this year, it was learned today. Governor Earle, who under the law cannot succeed himself, is expected to be the party nominee for the Senate to succeed James J. Davis, Republican.

An earthquake throughout Colombia at 9:20 last night was felt in Bogota. It caused some alarm but no damage or casualties. The Bogota Observatory seismograph recorded tremors lasting fourteen seconds.

TAKING its cue from the Metropolitan Opera Guild, the Philharmonic - Symphony Society launched its Philharmonic-Symphony League last week. As the Guild's avowed purpose is to stimulate interest in opera, so the league's purpose is to stimulate interest in symphonic music. Professedly, neither is immediately concerned with the solicitation of funds or the sale of tickets; only membership.

Calling attention to the fact that in Canada a royal commission on Dominion-Provincial Relations is investigating real estate tax conditions with a view to ameliorating the overlapping tax situation, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, cites the fact that a resolution somewhat similar in character is now before Congress.

LOURDES. ONE of the undoubted miracles of Lourdes, which even the skeptic must recognize, is historical fact that a simple peasant girl has transformed a sleepy, humdrum Pyrenean town into a modern metropolis with a million visitors per year, while she herself has become sainted.

The Associate Alumnae of Hunter College will celebrate the sixtyeighth birthday of their alma mater at the annual breakfast next Saturday at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. John C. Keddie, 82 years old, of the class of '74, who is the oldest living graduate of the college, will represent the first graduating class of Hunter.

Foreign traders faced the prospect of revising their shipping practices in the Far East and other sections of the globe as a result of the refusal of maritime underwriters to assume war risk responsibility on merchandise before it is loaded or after it is discharged from a vessel.

RHYS DAVIES has never gained the appreciation in this country that he receives in England. It is likely that his work is accepted there for its accurate portrayal of life among the Welsh coal miners, while to us, less immediately concerned with the factual material, the conflicting and disruptive forces at work in Mr. Davies's mind are more apparent.

Girls from the Posse School of Physical Education of Boston repeated their victory of last yea; over the Penn Hall Junior College and Preparatory School of Chambersburg, Pa., 37-20, in a swimming meet at London Terrace yesterday.

Continuing its annual allegiance to cycles of the instrumental literature, the National Orchestral Association under Leon Barzin began its series of four concerts devoted to the 'cello repertoire yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with the collaboration of the eminent Viennese artist, Emanuel Feuermann.
For the second time since Adolf Hitler came to power the National Socialist Fuehrer State was thrown this week into what in any other country would be called a Cabinet crisis.

Austria is deeply interested in current German events. Not only are offiicialdom and the press discussing the possible repercussions, but the man in the street senses that they may have a bearing on his own future.
Zevson, top-weighted at 116 pounds, took down another purse at the Fair Grounds today when he won the $2,000 added Pontchartrain Handicap in easy fashion.
SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY MORGEN THAU was quoted in the newspapers a few weeks ago to the effect that the nation's three-point monetary policy is working "extermely well."
THAT the automotive industry enjoyed the second best year in its history in 1937 is revealed as final new passenger and commercial car registration figures are released.

THE dramatic critic insisted upon this. He wanted another review of the great James J. Braddock romance. But everybody knew that story. Plain James hung up his gloves a week ago. The whirling Toronto Maple-Leafs were advancing on the town to tackle the rampant Rangers in a boisterous battle on ice Joe DiMaggio was still unsigned.

Public opinion, or a segment of it, became vocal in Philadelphia this week and City Councilmen who had decided to impose a 2 per cent sales tax to help balance the 1938 budget were announced as agreeing that the tax would be "nullified."
The search for a new style in art is the central theme in a new course in modern art at the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of Buffalo the coming semester.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., announced yesterday that the three winners of the airline's first annual newspaper aviation trophy for newspaper men who "consistently develop the best-informed writing" on air transportation will receive their awards in Washington next Thursday.
BABSHAY--BROENBAUM--Mr. and Mrs. B. Rosenbaum of 171 West 79th St. announce the engagement of their daughter. Selma, to Sam Barshay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Barsnay of Summerville, S. C.

Deep-soil cultivation is the foundation of all good gardening; The majority of plants will thrive in any garden providing the soil is well tilled before they are planted, while no amount of subsequent care will compensate for slipshod soil preparation.

The marriage of Miss Mary Virginia Geisier, daughter of Mrs. Theodore J. Geisier of 1,160 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Cincinnati, and the late Mr. Geisler, to Augustin d'Entremont Bourneuf, also of New York, son of Mrs. Volusien Bourneuf of Boston, and the late Mr. Bourneuf, took place here yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. Coleman Nevils.

Miss Ellen Alford Walton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Janney Walton of Baltimore, and Richmond Manning of 'New York, son of Mrs. Walter W. Manning and the late Mr. Manning of that city, were married tonight in Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas Guthrie Speers.

The study of the problem of discrimination against employing elderly workers, recently begun by the United States Department of Labor, will be extended on a world scale by the International Labor Organization, its governing body has decided on a motion of the United States workers' delegate, Robert Watt.

The Anchor Line announced yesterday plans for the installation of new propellers to speed up the liners Caledonia, Transylvania and Cameronia and extensive renovation of their third-class quarters that will increase the space per passenger by about 10 per cent.

In addition to being a notable sporting competition, Westminster Kennel Club officials always have considered their annual exhibition an educational institution. Like similar events it is intended to show to the public the highest types of the many breeds of dogs-individuals that approach nearest to the ideals established through many years of selective breeding and competition.

Newspapers with Rightist tendencies generally rest content with recording the fact that Berlin events concentrate all power in the hand of Chancellor Adolf Hitler. More democratic sheets express anxiety lest the new German Foreign Minister intensify the "Drang nach Osten" policy and cause trouble in the Danubian basin.

LONDON.--After years of bickering between the national government and London municipal authorities, the controversy over Waterloo Bridge has been settled and construction of a new link between the West End and South London will begin in a few months.

The. fifth week of the longshoremen's strike ended today, with Governor Blanton Winship conferring all day against his doctor's orders while ill in bed, attempting to devise a settlement. Associate Justice Martin Travieso was drawn in in an attempt to define arbitration to the workers with the hope that a settlement might be arranged by a roundtable discussion.

With Joe Weber accounting for 20 points, the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy quintet downed Cathedral College, 57-42, on the Pharmacy court last night. The victors were ahead at half time, 27-23. The line-up:

John Wicklun, New York Athletic Club star, captured the New York State A. A. U. 150-yard, back-stroke championship for the third straight year at the swimming meet conducted by the Central Swimming Club in the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. pool last night.

John Loaring of Windsor, Ont., paced a dazzling display of recordbreaking today at the opening of the British Empire Games, setting a mark of 52.9 seconds in the 440yard hurdles to post one of Canada's two victories in track and field.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Congreve Jackson in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Sibyl Jackson of Baltimore, whose engagement to Dorsey Brown, also of Baltimore, was recently announced. Later she took her guests to the opera.

Assailing what it called "unfair practice leading to chaos," the Textile Workers Organizing Committee today accepted "under protest" a 121/2 per cent weekly wage cut declared by mill owners this week.

A concert devoted to the varied works of Jacob Weinberg was given last night at Town Hall. These comprised a sonata for two pianos, heard for the first time; three songs for baritone; excerpts from the drama "Jacob's Dream," played by a chamber ensemble;

Mrs. W. E. Quillin of Forest Hills, Queens, gave a reception at her home last night at which she. announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Louise Quilin, to. Joseph Theodore Clauss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clauss of Forest Hills.
With the pledge to meet his task with "courage and determination," Dr. Oliver Cromwell Carmichael today formally took his chair as the third chancellor of Vanderbilt University.

Appeals to increase the $14 weekly minimum wage for women laundry workers in this State and to abolish a temporary differential in fa-vor of districts outside the metropolitan area 'were made yesterday by laundry workers and union leaders at a public hearing before Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews in the State Office Building.
Plans for a comprehensive twoyear college training course for youths seeking to become firemen, policemen or members of the Deapartment of Sanitation were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.
The 124th Field Artillery polo team of Don Rice, Romeo Mura and Russell Rasmussen defeated Yale, 16 to 8, before an overflow crowd tonight at the victors' armory.

Tom Iannicelli, holder of the world's open squash tennis title, once more proved himself adept at another court game yesterday. Paired with Johnny Smith, Rockaway Hunting Club pro, he gained the semi-final round of the first squash racquets open doubles tournament held at the Heights Casino.

Results "as revolutionary as those which followed the invention of the printing press" are prophesied by John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, from the allocation last week by the Federal -Communications Commission of twenty-five channels in the ultrahigh frequency band for non-profit educational broadcasting.

Leo Freisinger of the United States broke the world record for 500 meters as the world ice skating championships opened today but was beaten for first place by the Norwegian titleholder, Hans Engnestangen, whose winning time was 41.8 seconds.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. A. Pyott Spence of this place, formerly of Kahdina, Morristown, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doris Spence, to Norman Low Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Norman Kennedy of Short Hills.

The committee on legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the DunniganKillgrew bill to amend the State Unemployment Insurance Law to make it apply to employes earning more than $3,000' a year.

THOUGH reticence has never been trumpeted as an attribute of the film industry, there are times and circumstances when a hush-hush policy is purposely adopted. This is particularly true during the production of a picture.

The secret of the famous "mystery clock," the glass dial of which seems to operate without any mechanism, is revealed in the current issue of Sky, bulletin of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

In a race that was hand-tailored for him, Glenn Cunningham won the Wanamaker Mile before a capacity gathering of 16,000 at the thrill-packed Millrose A. A. carnival at Madison Square Garden last night with another of his highly efficient jobs.

ALYERS--Mr. and Mrs. William C., announce birth of a son, Jan. 29, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. BERNSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Bernstein (nee Martha Duff) announce birth of a baby boy, Alan Duff, Jan. 31, LyingIn Hospital.
Several leaders in the printing industry will take part in a program observing the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Department of Printing at the Carnegie Institute of Technology Friday and Saturday.
Dr. Henry L. Sanford, Cleveland surgeon and past president of both the Academy of Medicine of Cleveland and the Cleveland Medical Library, died today after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America will hold its second Annual Conference on Jewish affairs on the general subject of "The Future of Judaism in America" today at 2:30 P. M. in the seminary at Broadway and 122d Street, according to an announcement yesterday.
THE theatre in Vienna has always been widely separated from that of Germany. Vienna is a city of music, airiness, romance, and its playwrights have imbibed this spirit.

Alumni, faculty and students of Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, will observe the 147th anniversary of the birth of Peter Cooper, the founder, on Saturday, Lincoln's Birthday. The Civil War President made his first Eastern speech in the great hall of the institute in February, 1860.
The Society of Virginia Women in New York will celebrate the birthday of George Washington on Friday at 3 P. M. at the WaldorfAstoria.

Yale University's basketball team, which has suddenly found itself after an exceptionally poor start, scored its third straight triumph tonight by whipping Williams, 38 to 21, on the Westchester County Center floor before a crowd of 1,200 persons. The Blue, through aggressiveness and an airtight defense, jumped into the lead at the beginning and Williams came close only once during the contest.

Dr. William Smith, new debating coach at the College of New Rochelle, announced today that the Spring program of the college's council of debate would be featured by intercollegiate debates, forum discussions and symposiums on current problems.

The Mexican Government has hired Japanese fishing experts to make an investigation of fishing off the Mexican east coast near the Texas border. One of these experts, Yoshiichi Matsui, has just completed an investigation in these waters with Captain Manuel Camiro, chief of the Mexican Bureau of Fisheries.
Five cruise ships left the North River yesterday for the West Indies, Bahamas and South America with 2,887 passengers. The French liner Normandie led in numbers with 1,000.

NASSAU, Bahamas.--The first Monday meet of the season will be held at Montagu Park tomorrow when the Normandie Handicap will be the feature event in honor of the first visit to the island of the Normandie, which will be in port with cruise visitors.

The confidence with which diplomats have been "forgetting" about the Spanish civil war was rudely shattered this week when a "pirate" submarine and two Insurgent bombers sent two small British steamers to the bottom of the Mediterranean.

The $100,000 legal fight of four States for the right to levy millions in taxes on the $40,000,000 estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green ended in Massachusetts tonight. Florida is the next stop of the "touring court."

The second annual scholarship ball of the Art Students League will be held on Friday at the Hotel Roosevelt. Proceeds of the dance, which is under the sponsorship of the instructors of the league, will provide scholarships for one year's tuition to aid worthy students.

Wanamaker Mile-Won by Glenn Cunningham. New York Curb Exchange A. A.; Archie San Romani, New York Curb Exchange A. A., second; Charles Fenske, University of Wisconsin, third; Gene Venzke. New York A. C.. fourth. Time4:11. (Equals meet record made by Cunningham in 1935 and equaled by Joseph R. Mangan in 1936).

Today, Boy Scout Sunday, will usher in Boy Scout Week, marking the twenty-eighth anniversary of the movement in the United States. More than one million Scouts in the United States and its possessions will take part in the week's observance.

A conclusion that after succeeding depressions, relief costs never return to pre-depression levels is recorded in a report on relief trends for the twenty-five-year period of 1910-35 issued by the Works Progress Administration today.

After trying for three years, William Gillespie of Atlanta, Ga., a student at the Scarborough School, finally won the Eastern interscholastic indoor tennis championship in the tournament sponsored by the De Witt Clinton High School when he defeated Bernard Jacoby of New York, star player of the Evander Childs team, 6-3, 6-2, 6-3, on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.
Dr. Norman Philip Geis, gynecologist, died yesterday at the Harkness avilion of the Medical Center after a short illness. He was 64 years old.
The complete program for the traditional alumnae day, to be held on Saturday at Barnard College, was announced by the Associate Alumnae Office at the college yesterday.

Emma Suelke Shaw a concert singer, died last night at the home of her granddaughter, Mrs. Louis C. Jarrett, in Wynnewood at the age of 78. Born in this city, Mme. Suelke, as she was known to Eastern Pennsylvania music lovers for nearly a half century, received her training under Signor Barrilli.

PHILATELY'S major interest at the moment centers in the regulations which the Treasury Department at Washington is preparing as a result of the law which Congress has passed to permit black-and-white illustrating of United States postage stamps.
Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, and Kolomon de Kanya, Hungarian Minister of Foreign Affairs, arrived today for a state visit.

The special matinee performance of "Rigoletto" on Feb. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over as the annual benefit for the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. In the leading roles will be Lily Pons, Jan Kiepura and Lawrence Tibbett. Ettore Panizza will conduct.

The first Members' Tea of the season of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association will be held on Feb. 16 at Roosevelt House, the birthplace of Theodore Roosevelt, at 28 East Twentieth Street. Miss Dorothy Thompson will be the guest of honor.
The New York State Milk Committee, which says it represents nearly 20,000 dairymen, has announced a conference here Tuesday to consider problems of the industry.

An informal inventory taken in the Natural History Museum at Amherst College since the sudden death of its director, Professor Frederic B. Loomis, shows that the collection to which he had devoted a large part of his adult life have a cash value exceeding half a million dollars.
British film censors have decided that children under 16 cannot see Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" unless they are accompanied by adults.

IT seems that each new poet from England has to be in troduced from Oxford, that nest of singing birds, though they have left their nest and they don't precisely sing. Rex Warner is the latest to appear in, an American edition, simultaneously with the publication of his novel.
Wagner College of Staten Island gained its third basketball triumph in twelve starts last night by coming from behind to defeat Arnold College of New Haven, Conn., 28 to 22, at the Wagner gymnasium.

CORRESPONDENT IN SPAIN. By Edward H. Knoblaugh. 233 pp. New York: Sheed Ward. $2.50. COUNTER-ATTACK IN SPAIN. By Ramon Sender. Translated from the Spanish by Sir Peter Chalmers Mitchell. 288 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $3.

THE first performance this season of "Das Rheingold" and the debut of the Polish tenor, Jan Kiepura, in "La Boheme" Thursday evening, are features of the eleventh week of the Metropolitan Opera season. Complete opera and concert programs for the current week follow:

VAUGHAN WILLIAMS'S new opera, "Riders to the Sea," based on Synge's play, recently received its first performance by students of the Royal College of Music under Malcolm Sargent's baton, at the Parry Opera Theatre in London, England. According to Richard Capell, critic of The London Daily Mail and Morning Post, the "short and reticent score is, indeed, worthy of study.

More than 400 Princeton University alumni are expected to return to the campus on Washington's birthday, Feb. 22, for the annual midwinter gathering of the National Alumni Association, Bevis Longstreth, '15, chairman of the alumni day committee, announced today in making public the program for the meeting.

Professor George W. Dawson, professor of freehand drawing and water-color in the School of Fine Arts at the University of Pennsylvania, died suddenly tonight a short while after he arrived at the Sherborn home of his brother, James, to attend the funeral of another brother, Henry S. Dawson of Holliston, who died Thursday.
Classifying corpora Lions for tax purposes according to amounts of their net income is, in effect, an extension of the print ple of applying progressive rates.

MANY Turks have neglected so far to adopt family surnames, as the law orders them to do and their dilatoriness is said to make them liable to heavy fines. It is hardly likely that their family names, when they get around to making their choice, will prove very diverting to foreigners By far the most diverting exercises in nomenclature are to be found in places like West Africa.

The Census Bureau said today that automobile fatalities in 134 leading cities in the first four weeks of the year, totaling 715, were 163 less than in the similar period of 1937a decline of 181/2 per cent.

Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, using notes which he asserted he prepared while acting as chairman of the peace committee of the C. I. O., in the absence of Philip Murray, the official chairman, declared today that the version set forth by a committee of the A. F. of L. of the collapse of the recent peace parleys was "inaccurate and utterly false in some of its statements."
AT 75 Emil Sauer remains not only one of the most conspicuous and decorative features of Viennese musical life but also one of the lustiest juveniles of the keyboard.

VERITABLE engraved murals were the early nineteenth century scenic wallpapers. Their designs were furnished by the best artists of the day and painstakingly transferred by hand through the medium of innumerable wood blocks.

A fleet and air force twice the size of Japan's is the United States' only hope for security in the Pacific, Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., U. S. N., retired, declared yesterday at the bimonthly luncheon meeting of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.

Stocks continued to improve moderately and closed higher in quiet trading; turnover, 445,690 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds irregular; corporate issues higher; trading slowest since Sept. 4, 1937; transactions, $2,647,000.

Dedicated to those New York business and professional people in whom still lingers an unsatisfied longing for knowledge and study, a series of late afternoon "custommade" courses in philosophy, modern literature, science and current affairs as they relate to contemporary living will be offered by Town Hall.

For the second time in three years a washwoman is the Philippine women's open golf champion. Husky Dominga Capati, who washes clothes for a living at a Calambra sugar estate, captured the title today from a strong field of American and other women players.

MissAnita Duerr, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. John Duerr of this place,. was married this. evening to Robert A. Parr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Parr, by the Rev. Robert C. Falconer in St. Paul's Congregational Church here.

To the surprise of a great many at Hialeah Park, Lavengro led from start to finish of today's $6,120 Bahamas Handicap, a prep for the $20,000 Flamingo, and established himself as a much more formidable candidate than the highly touted Lawrin.

Mr. and Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 10 East Sixty-second Street, for their house guest, Lady Decies, who arrived here on Friday on the Normandie.

The varied program of philanthropic work carried on by the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El will be aided by a card party to be held tomorrow afternoon at the Plaza. Mrs. Edward B. Schulkind is chairman of the committee on arrangements.
SPECULATOR, N. Y.--A brand new rope tow has started dragging skiers up the brand new slope on Scribner's Hill and a brand new Winter enthusiasm grips this old Summer resort.
IT appears that Josephine Lawrence has taken over and adapted to her own permaeent use a literary form now generally out of favor.
Strike leaders ordered employes of four wholesale gasoline distributing centers back to work today, averting a threatened fuel' shortage.
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. Election of a secretary to succeed Joseph Miller is scheduled at this time.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Resolved Williams of 43 East Eightieth Street, this city, and Lawrence, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalie Neilson Williams, to Edward Everett Post, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Otis Post of Morristown, N. J.

An arrangement has been completed by which the Controllers Institute of America will cooperate in the preparation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of standard accounting practice, Arthur R. Tucker, managing director of the institute, said yesterday.

The consumer, generally most neglected of all contributors to our economic order, is winning new attention. A sign of the trend was the recent launching of Consumers Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization, national in scope and backed by prominent educators, economists, women's leaders and clergymen.

Plans to raise an annual fund of $50,000 to promote men's and boys' cloth caps, beginning with the Fall season, were approved yesterday at a meeting held yesterday by the Cap Textile Credit Association, Inc., and five committees were formed to formulate collection plans.

Lending institutions throughout the United States were notified today by Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, that they might resume making insured loans for modernization and repair under Title One of the recently amended National Housing Act.

Mrs. Elsie Gottheil Jaretzki died at her home, 128 East Seventyfourth Street, yesterday after a long illness. She was the wife of Alfred Jaretzki Jr., a member of the firm of Sullivan Cromwell, lawyers, and the mother of Hugh and Paul Cullman, Mrs.

Members of the Olivet College Art Department, under the direction of Professor George Rickey, will paint a mural in one of the college buildings. The students will attempt to portray significant phases of American life, the material for which will be drawn from their own experience.

Amid recriminations and charges of poor sportsmanship made by church leaders, Georgia's thirty-year-old experiment in prohibition ended this week. The General Assembly passed a bill authorizing county option on the sale and manufacture of alcoholic beverages.
Members of the Winter colony donned overalls and ginghams for tonight's "Down on the Farm" gala dinner dance at the Surf Club, in a barnyard setting to which- lire animals added realism.

The steady expansion of air conditioning has attracted into the field a number of manufacturers from related industries and has brought about their use of yearround promotional programs, supplanting previous seasonal campaigns of six months or so, executives in the industry pointed out yesterday.

The Jewish Agency for Palestine in Jerusalem spent $2,343,460 in the last year for agricultural colonization, German-Jewish settlement, housing, immigration, education and trade and industry, according to a report made public yesterday by Louis Lipsky, national co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal

The girls' basketball team of Manhattanville College again proved its invincibility yesterday by scoring a 29-to-14 triumph over the visiting Carroll Club sextet, thus running its victory streak to fifty games over a five-year period. The game was played on the winners' court.

Paced by 'their All-America football end, Handy Andy Bershak, who accounted for 16 points, the University of North Carolina basketball team administered to New York University tonight the worst drubbing the Violets have suffered this season. The score was 57 to 89.

Fearing that the reorganization of Westchester County's central government under the new charter will jeopardize the special privileges and home rule powers of villages, Ossining and Peekskill are considering the adoption of city charters to protect their entity, members of charter commissions in those communities declared today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 3: CAPTAINS Newton. J. H., orders of Jan. 19 revoked; to continue duty as chief of staff and aide to commander of destroyers, battle force. Shafroth, J. F. Jr., the Reina Mercedes,to headquarters 12th Naval District, San Francisco, Calif.,in uly.

A photograph taken by Mrs. Francis Krasnow Thau of her daughter won the grand prize last week in the final judging of the photographic contest sponsored by the Undergraduate Land and Building Fund of Barnard College. Mrs. Thau was a member of the class of '17 at the college, and her entry was also first-prize winner in the faculty and alumnae section of the portrait studies.

An event of many years' standing, the Aviators Ball under the auspices of Aviators Post, 743, of the American Legion, will take place on Feb. 18 at the Roosevelt. The ball, since its inception in 1919, has provided funds for the Aviators Welfare and Relief Fund.

The annual parents' day celebration of Uncle Robert, announcer of children's radio programs and promother of a plan to convert Mothers Day into a celebration for both parents, will be held this year on May 8 on the Mall in Central Park, it was announced last night by the sponsor.

Further improvement of the East Main Street business section was indicated today in an announcement of the purchase of the Krause Building, 70 East Main Street, by the Amicum Realty Corporation of Patchogue. It was bought from the People's National Bank of Patchogue.

The benefit performance on Friday afternoon of "The Barber of Seville" at the Metropolitan Opera House will be preceded by many luncheons to be given by subscribers to the event. The matinee has been taken over by the Smith College Club of New York to augment its scholarship fund.

Holding company bankers, confronted with the proposal of Senator Carter Glass of Virginia to introduce legislation providing for abolition of bank holding companies over a five-year period. appear to have adopted the strategy of "lying low and saying nothing.'

La Salle College of Philadelphia scored a 28-26 victory over the St. Francis College basketball team on the Franciscan court last night. The victors got away to a 17-6 lead in the first half on accurate shooting by Ed Krupa and John Brnich, but St. Francis came back strong and slowly cut down the visitors' advantage.

MORE than a century and a decade have passed since there occurred in St. Petersburg, on the first day of the reign of Nicholas I (brother and successor on the throne of Alexander I, the victorious opponent of Napoleon),

The results of the 1938 Winter furniture markets held throughout the various furniture centers show conclusively that the downward trend in the industry, which started early in 1937, has not yet been halted, according to the report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, public accountants.

Competent reports reaching here through a cloud of conflicting statements and propaganda indicate that though Benito Mussolini's conquering legions are still in possession of the capitals and the government of Ethiopia, the country is not only not quiet politically but is still far from being an economic asset to Italy.

The Westinghouse C. I. O. union, numbering several thousand members, set up today a $500 nucleus of a fund for assistance of unemployed members and then took measures to augment this fund and named a committee to administer it.

The Metropolitan's sumptuous production of Verdi's "Otello" was staged again last night with two important changes of cast To Arthur Carron befell the exactions of the name part. Irene Jessner was the Desdemona.

IN Edwin Lanham's last novel. "Banner at Daybreak," the story of post-war expatriates, the leading character returns to America convinced that a man must find his own place in his country's society and give

The large system of fortifications which the Soviet is building at the easternmost part of the Gulf of Finland. as a base for its Baltic navy recently has been extended to include the coast district between Estonia and Krasnaya Gorka, the writer has learned in reliable quarters.

Water pressure was reduced for nearly two hours in ten communities in the north shore section of Queens yesterday morning after a break in a 30-inch main under Queens Boulevard at Sixty-third Drive, Rego Park.
Andover's alumni played a decisive part in the Yale freshmen's 37-29 victory over the academy swimming team and in the 34-31 triumph of the Eli yearlings over the academy's basketball team today.
REVIVING sharply old memories of "Mother India," "Root in the Rock" is a story of three generations of Brahmins whose lives spanned a period of significant social change.

The Federal Reserve Board published today, in the midst of an Administration drive to abolish. bank holding companies, figures showing that these companies had shrunk of their own accord in the last five years.

Figures on the medical staff of the Department of Hospitals were made public yesterday, with an accompanying statement that the staff now includes "approximately one out of every twenty-five physicians practicing in the United States."

Bishop Cecil Hook; who held many important offices during a long ecclesiastical career, died in Chichester today at the age of 93. While vicar of All Saints Church, Leamington, he aroused heated controversy by holding that the national anthem was inappropriate for singing during Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee.
Vassar College is including this year for the first time a course in comparative Slavonic literature taught by Nikander Strelsky, instructor in Russian.
Neither unfavorable political reports from Europe nor talk of dry weather in the southwestern fart of the Winter wheat belt had any material effect on the market today.

THE new British naval base at Singapore will be formally opened on Feb. 11. The formal opening will be accompanied by naval and aerial manoeuvres participated in by British units from all over the Far East Secrecy will surround certain details, but the whole world will be boldly informed that the naval base, one of the world's largest. is now ready for use.

Demands on Simmons College for preparation in public nursing have increased so far beyond the available facilities for field training in Boston that, beginning this term, students will be assigned to distant organizations for this phase of their work, according to Miss Helen Wood, director of the Simmons School of Nursing.

An educational conference on the subject of venereal disease control is planned for Wednesday evening by the Bergen County League of Women Voters, of which Mrs. Howard Abeel is president. The meeting will be held at the Woman's Club of Hackensack, N. J., 359 Union Street, at 8:30 P. M.

SOUTHERN PINES; N. C.--The Sand Hills Steeplechase and Racing Association announces that the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association has set the fourth annual races, to be held at the Barber estate course, midway between Southern Pines and Pinehurst, for Saturday, March 19.

Robert Grant 3d and Clarence C. Pell Jr. of New York retained the national racquets doubles championship by defeating the 1935 champions, J. Richard Leonard and Malcolm Kirkbride, also of New York, in the final round at the Racquet Club today. The scores were 2-15, 15-10, 15-6, 15-17, 15-2.

William A. Larney of 160 West Fifty-sixth Street, a city appraiser who was formerly secretary of the Fire Department, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Bronx, following an operation. He was 63 years old.

A constitutional issue long considered to have been settled was raised by Justice Black in one of the three lone dissenting opinions which he read in the Supreme Court of the United States last Monday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Organized medicine has consistently held that the peculiar personal relationship between patient and physician precludes the possibility of any system of medical care which prevents free choice of the physician.

The annual junior promenade of the Newark College of Engineering is scheduled to be held on Feb. 18 at the Essex House here. More than 150 couples are expected to attend. Proceeds will be used for the yearbook fund of the class of 1939.
The Hun School basketball team halted the Newark Academy's string of victories at seven today in the Hun gymnasium, defeating the Newark five, 32-26, in a hard-fought contest
ONLY a half block from the major radio stations, near the market of San Juan, barefooted and sandaled Indians and peons talk and live the language and heritage of the Aztecs and Mayas.
Heavy purchasing of war equipment by Latin-American countries is aggravating an already difficult exchange situation in those markets, exporters complained here last week.

A moderate gain, a sharp decline and an irregular recovery marked he uncertain course of the stock market last week. At the week's lo w level. THE NEW YORK TIMES inde x of fifty stocks at 82.76 was within 0.69 point of the 1937-38 low, tou ched on Nov. 24. At the closing leve yesterday of 86.40 the index showeed a net gain of 1.35 pooints on the Week.
Dr. George Walter Dawson was well known here as an artist. He had been associated with the university Rirncf 1893. succeeding Charles Dana.

IN their thirteenth annual exhibition, the members of the New York Society of Women Artists follow the precedent established in their previous shows, assembling work rather more frankly modern in sympathies than the bulk of the examples shown by the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, which recently held its annual.

The recent raid of Secretary Ickes upon the office force of his Under-Secretary, Charles West, may result in Mr. West being transferred to the higher-salaried post of Controller of the Currency, it was indicated today.

The marriage of Miss Mary Keith Shaw, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry L. K. Shaw of Albany and Guilderland to Burton Francis Bossi of New York, son of Mrs. Arnaldo Luigi Bossi and the late Dr. Bossi of New York and Milan, took place today at the Guilderland home of the bride's parents.

Brooklyn Poly staged a secondhalf spurt to vanquish New York State Teachers College, 35-31, in a basketball game at the 101st Signal Battalion Armory, Brooklyn, last night. Poly trailed at the intermission, 17-14. Captain Don Pitman and Hank Johnson made 11 points apiece for scoring honors.

The New York Southern Society's annual Dixie dinner dance will take place on Feb. 18 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Before dinner, which will be served at 8 o'clock, officers of the society and committee members for the party will give a reception in the east foyer of the ballroom.
