GINA CIGNA'S set-to with the Canadian customs officers last week proves that there are limits to the awe which daily meet the eyes and nourish the sensitive spirits of prima donnas. Miss Cigna was firmly informed by a brass-buttoned guard that she had better not attempt entrance into Canada, because exit might be rather difficult.

ABELSON--Annie, 272 Livonfa Ave., Brooklyn, on Feb. 5. Funeral today. ABRABIOWITZ--Zise. Temple Israel of Long Beach extends its heartfeld sympathy to Mrs. Adolph Metrowitz, dear wife of our esteemed member and benefactor, on the demise of her beloved father.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Frances Hull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Kingsley Hull of this place, to John Harrison Hammett of New York, son of Mrs. Charles H. Hammett of Washington, D. C., and the late Mr. Hammett, has been announced by her parents.

Over German radios last Friday night at 10 o'clock came the order: Stand by for an important announcement. Listeners waited. The order gave substance to rumors current for several days that something was afoot. At midnight came the announcementcomplete reorganization of the army, the air force, the diplomatic corps and the Cabinet.

Wanamaker's second annual Flower Show, to be held at the New York store Feb. 14 through 18, will include daily competitive exhibitions in flower arrangements, professional exhibitions of table arrangements, and lectures to which the public is invited.

In 1937 some 60,000 changes occurred in the directorates of corporations, an increase of about 36 per cent over the previous year, a comparison of the 1937 and 1938 editions of Poor's Register of Directors of the United States

Alexander Brailowsky, Russian pianist, gave the third recital of his Chopin cycle yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, where his performances again were enthusiastically received. The list of offerings comprised no less than thirty numbers.

Western Pacific naval forces are to be strengthened by the transfer of fifteen naval flying boats to Guam "before June," an 'unusually reliable source said today. Fliers of Squadron VP-18, stationed at the Pearl Harbor fleet air base, were said to be expecting orders directing them to proceed to Guam for a one-year tour of duty.

THE plan announced last week by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs for a six-lane transverse road through Central Park at Ninety-sixth Street is the latest of many recent proposals for cracking down on that bugbear of New York motorists, cross-town traffic.

Paced by left-handed Germain Glidden of New York, the national champion, a fifteen-man United States squash racquets team today routed Canada, 13 to 2, in their seventeenth annual series for the Henry G. Lapham Trophy.

Yale defeated the United States Coast Guard Academy boxing team of New London today in a series of evenly contested bouts, 5-3. Dick Goehring of the visitors and Pierson Jones of Yale scored technical knockouts in the 125 and 145 pound classes.
A FEATURE of the program of Gregor Piatigorsky's 'cello recital, Feb. 13, will be an "Inter??" by Claude Debussy, which the artist unearthed last Summer while seeking rare musical material

Amicable discussions in which representatives of employers and workers will sit down together and calmly attempt to work out the problems of industry and of labor provide the ultimate solution to the nation's industrial strife, the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board,. said yesterday. He spoke at the first of a series of forum luncheons of the Progressive party in the Town Hall Club.

Miss Margaret Van Doren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Van Doren of 123 West Eleventh Street, was married to Tom Torre Bevans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bevans, also of this city, yesterday afternoon in the home of her parents by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.
A picketer of pickets appeared here this afternoon in the person of Ray A. Pettit, 50 years old, formerly editor of the defunct Lakewood Free Press and now an employee of a Toms River newspaper.

Italian representatives have opened negotiations with the government for the sale of Italian planes to the army. The government has been invited to send two representatives to Italy to visit airplane factories and study production methods.

ALTHOUGH the date is eighteen months distant, Strasbourg is already making plans to celebrate the 500th anniversary of an Important event in its historynamely, the completion of the tower of fits famous cathedral, which is 469 feet high, and in 1439 was the highest in Christendom.

Representatives of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the United States Steel Corporation will begin conferences on Monday looking to renewal of wage and hour contracts between the union and 463 steel manufacturers and fabricators.
BACHELOR KING: The Albanian Parliament last week approved the engagement of 42-year-old Zog I to 22-year-old Countess Geraldine Apponyi,
Lou Salica, 118 pounds, New York outpointed Ernie Weiss, 117, Austria, in the star bout at eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night before 3,400 fans.

The basis upon which Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, will adjudicate the claims of holders of mortgage certificates and guaranteed mortgages of all the mortgage companies that the State has in liquidation was explained by him yesterday.

In an odd case in which the government was represented on both sides, Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard ruled yesterday that William Gebers, a German alien, must be deported on the ground that he had fraudulently married here merely to obtain a preference quota visa.

France's ultimate decision "in favor or against the totalitarian conception of the State will incline the balance of the world on one or the other side perhaps for many years," Dr. Jose Castillejo, Professor of Law at the University of Madrid declared in a statement yesterday.

In the plight of the Soviet scientists on an icefloe in the Arctic, the first thought of Ivan Papanin, the leader, was to save the instruments and specimens, leaving the rest of the equipment, except indispensable food, to the mercy of the ocean.

ONE of the salient reasons for the increase of Hollywood's budgets is the yearning of the customers for laughter. Having totaled the cost of "Fools for Scandal" the Warners have attributed $300,000 of the bill to the fact that the picture was designed to amuse. Had it been a dramatic offering it is improbable that the budget would have exceeded $600,000 and it could have been much less. As it is, the picture cost $900.000.
A 27.4 per cent rise in Canadian imports in the nine months ended on Dec. 31 was reported today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
It was Sun Egret again today, winning his third straight major engagement at Santa Anita Park- and establishing himself as the candidate to beat in the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby on Feb. 22.

Taxes and public welfare programs will be discussed next Tuesday at the second annual luncheon of the White Plains branch of the Westchester County Children's Association. The luncheon will be at the Contemporary Club here.

Georgetown University's basketball team dropped a 34-33 decision to Penn State tonight in an overtime battle after the Nittany Lions had deadlocked the count at 30-all at the end of the regulation game.

THIS brilliant and moving book is a success. It reveals life-not merely the life of a Prime Minister whose place in history is assured. He and his great office are no more than incidentals in a larger theme. We are shown the life of a characteristic clan. An Asquith invites us to meet the Asquiths.
Mr. Price has, in his own words, written for "the instruction of the lads of the country whose goal is the camera staff of a newspaper" rather than for the general public.

In recent years Mrs. George Carleton Beal has been an honored guest at leading functions here in celebration of Lincoln's birthday, for she knew Abraham Lincoln when she was a little girl in Springfield, Ill., and enjoyed what he called "hossy" rides on his knee.

The naval expansion program and the tense situation in the Far East are attracting attention of authorities to the project of a Nicaraguan canal. Testimony of navy officials before the House Naval Affairs Committee and the statement of Admiral Leahy that the United States Fleet is not capable of defending both the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts have increased interest in the proposal.

" CookingMister Boulestin Will Tell You How to Do It," will be the subject of a lecture and demonstration in the Speaker's kitchen in the Palace of Westminster on Thursday, Feb. 17. This unique idea is being sponsored by the Speaker's wife, the Hon. Mrs. Edward Fitzroy, in aid of the Westminster Hospital Nurses Home and Linen Guild.

Members of the New York State Chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will hold their annual supper dance in aid of their educational and charitable enterprises Friday in the main ballroom of the Biltmore.

Jan. 30, 1933--Hitler made Chancellor with a coalition Cabinet which limited his power. March 5, 1933--National election which gave the Nazi party complete control of the Reichstag. March 5, 1933--Enabling act passed by which absolute power was conferred on Chancellor Hitler and his Cabinet. Oct. 21, 1933--Germany resigns from the League of Nations.

A 20year-old robber was near death tonight in the Paterson General Hospital and his 27-year-old brother and partner in crime was suffering from a badly lacerated scalp as a result of a battle early this mornihg with policemen.
BROADCAST showmen often wonder what there is in radio that may make a listener favor a symphonic concert one night and a speech or jazz band the next week or day, when he brushes the classics away.

Patient-visits to the New York Osteopathic Clinic, 205 East Twentieth Street, rose from 7,725 to 9,528, an increase of 24 per cent, during 1937, Hamilton Fish Benjamin, president of the clinic, reported last week at the annual meeting of its board of directors.
President Florencio Arosemena welcomed 1,100 athletes today as the fourth Olympic games of the Central American and Caribbean countries opened before a crowd of 25,000.

The engagement of Miss Miriam Rafferty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rafferty of Bellevue Avenue, Westchester Country Club, this place, to Earl Edward McEvoy of New Rochelle and Culver City, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. McEvoy of New Rochelle, has been announced by her parents.

Uneasiness persists in London today as the European implications of the German shake-up are studied. Would the new balance of power in Berlin tend toward peace or war in Europe? Did it mean that all brakes were off and that Germany might soon plunge into an "adventure" in Austria, Spain or elsewhere?
The women's squash racquets season will close officially this week with the playing of the national championship at Boston starting tomorrow and lasting through Friday.

The New, York State Teachers Retirement System, represented by Pease Elliman, has sold to M. Moskowitz, representing a syndicate, the three five-story apartment houses at 27 to 31 West Sixtyfourth Street.

Copies of two English publications "Votes for Women" and "The Suffragette" which span the dramatic struggle for enfranchisement of women between the years 1909 and 1913 have been added to the World Center for Women's Archives, Mrs. Mary Beard has reported to her associates.

Diego Rivera still finds the germ of inspiration in the market place and in the fields, and laughs to scorn Mexico's pet slogan: "Mexico for the Mexicans." Not since the time he helped Leon Trotsky find a home in exile has Rivera played a sensational role in the scheme of things.

Suffield Academy defeated Deerfield Academy at basketball tonight, 3728, thus running its record to eight straight victories this season. Suffield gained a 10-to-5 lead in the first quarter but Deerfield, opened an attack which brought the score to 17 to 16 at half time in Suffield's favor.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 2, aggregated $8,141,000,000, or 9 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 24 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Exeter's hockey team blanked Worcester Academy, 8 to 0, today. The Worcester players were on the defense throughout and got only three shots at the Exeter net. Wood, Stuckey and Dreher each scored twice. E. Brown and J. Sloane caged the other goals.

IN July. 1822. the bright star that was Percy Bysshe Shelley was quenched in the waters off Leghorn, and the controversies which immediately arose over his life have scarcely even now been settled. This biography of Mary Shelley the poet's widow,

If the investigating committee of the New Jersey Assembly succeeds in its efforts to get possession of the Hudson County poll books, Senator Lester H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor in last November's election, expects to show that 55,000 votes were illegally cast in the county ruled by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

More than 500 persons from the theatre, radio and other fields attended a funeral service yesterday morning for Dorothea Antel, former actress whose stage career ended abruptly eighteen years ago because of injuries sustained when she stumbled and fell while hurrying from her dressing room to the stae in a Hartford theatre.
FANTASIO and UN CAPRICE--Tomorrow evening at the Barbizon-Plasa Theatre. As its eighth and final bill of the season the Theatre des Quatre Saisons is giving two plays by Alfred de Musset.

Resolutions calling for an extension of the mortgage moratorium which expires July 1 this year and an amendment to the city's ordiordinances which would allow the storage of fuel oil in all types of dwellings without the necessity of obtaining a permit from the Fire Department have been adopted by the Jackson Heights Community Council.

Only a few gains were reported in retail trade last week, and these were in the South, where increases have been consistent for many months, and where this week's upturn over a year ago was smaller than that for several weeks.

While thousands of Columbia University graduates in local clubs throughout the nation and in foreign countries join next Saturday in the annual celebration of alumni day, 3,000 alumni in the metropolitan area will take over Morningside Heights to observe the occasion in a program dedicated to the School of Architecture.

A survey of the occupations of the fathers of about 500 freshmen at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute shows only 8 per cent listed as engineers. Dr. Ray Palmer Baker, assistant director, remarked however:
James Nelson Mandeville of 124 Pelhamdale Avenue, a retired investment broker, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a long illness. His age was 59.

Those who are interested in adyanced socialization programs and who have been looking to Sweden as a model country the past few years, will find its traditional scope of social questions or "social reforms" considerably widened in the future.

The Freeport (L. I.) Board of Education is urging the purchase of a plot of approximately five acres at Brookside and Lena Avenues, in the Freeport Acres development, as a site for a new public school in the northwest part of the village.

THE race Into the Cherokee Strip has 'been used before now by novelists and motion-picture scenarists as a source of frontier color. By the Summer of 1893 the scramble for free land was almost over, but this was one of its last and most dramatic episodes.

The fact that the United States, under President Roosevelt's leadership, is definitely preparing itself against the contingency of war, near or remote, is now a major topic of public interest and inquiry. This week it stirred debates in the Senate, which sought primarily to stimulate the President or his spokesmen to a declaration of foreign policy.

Miss Edith Doughett Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Harding Lewis of this city, was married here tonight in Christ and St. Luke's Church to William Ward Moss Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moss of Swarthmore, Pa.

Mrs. Winifred Westlake O'Hara of Washington widow of Colonel James J. O'?? United States Cavalry, was married to Colonel William H. Cowles, United States Army, retired, yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn.

Miss Marjorie Loomis Aitken of Orange, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George A. Aitken of East Orange, was married to Howard Morgan Stone, son of George R. Stone of East Orange and the late Mrs. Stone, this afternoon in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, East Orange. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Lloyd Ellis Foster, officiated.

FOR a person who has coached hundreds of telephone operators, Mrs. Genevieve Hofstedt, senior voice instructor in the training division of the New York Telephone Company in the Manhattan area, is surprised that radio has been so slow in developing women announcers.
J. Edgar Hoover said today that Alvin Karpis, one-time "Public Enemy No. 1," plotted a mass murder of Federal Agents prior to his capture in 1936.

ROBERT ARDREY'S first produced play, "Star Span gled," had been impregnated with grace notes, asides caprices and prejudices inspired by Jed Harris, Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur and George Abbott be fore Mr. Ardrey had ever so much as set foot upon a stage, ever so much as sat in on a rehearsal.
We arrived at Miami Beach early this morning and found that weather conditions were not what might be termed favorable. The wind was blowing from the northeast and it kicked up quite a heavy sea.
Mr. and Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their niece, Miss Eleanor E. Herrick, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Herrick.
The Labor Relations Board announced today that it had asked the Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia to deny a petition of the Regal Shirt Company of Philadelphia,

Three vandals early yesterday morning invaded a five-story unoccupied tenement building at 735 East 152d Street, the Bronx, which is being remodeled, and smeared forty of the forty-six newly painted rooms of the building with red paint.

Old man par, floored four,times in the opening round, scored an easy decision over the field in the second eighteen holes of the $3,000 Sacramento open golf tournament today. Not one of the nearly ninety starters could equal standard figures.

City Magistrate and Mrs. Louis B. Brodsky of 12 West Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Gertrude Brodsky, to Dr. Edward David Sherman of Sydney, Nova Scotia.

Kansas City has only 178,000 registered voters, in sharp contrast to the 256,000 ballots counted in this city of 415,000 population in the November, 1936, general election. Some political observers attributed the sharp decline in registration partly to a purge of the ghosts who stalked Kansas City's election booths in the 1936 election.
To the Drama Editor: One might wish you would refer to the Elizabethan revival, "The Shoemakers' Holiday," with the apostrophe in the. right place.

Even experienced concertgoers, if they tuned in a few minutes late for the concert given last night by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, may have asked themselves, or each other, the name of the composer of the riant and sparkling pieces that opened the program. Mr.

With the aid of a new local anesthetic, called monocaine, "there is no op eration in dentistry which cannot be performed without actual pain," members of the Philadelphia County Dental Society were told Thursday by Dr. Fred R. Adams, past president of the Second District Dental Society of the -State of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--A threat of the greatest naval building race in the world's history was presented to Japan today in the form of practically identical notes from the governments of Great Britain, France and the United States.

The Albert C. Bowman collection of early American pewter, comprising more than 400 marked pieces, now the property of Mrs. Albert C. Bowman of Springfield, Vt., will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., next Friday and Saturday afternoons. At the same time early American furniture and decorations, the property of Mrs. Bowman and other owners, will be offered.

IN many sections of America this Sunday dogs, great and small, are undergoing with patience or with heightened nervous tension, according to their several temperaments, those final preparations which lead to the acid test of the show ring.

Your article today on Continental Shares, Inc., reorganization from Baltimore was absolutely false in stating that the reorganization plan approved by Judge Dickerson of the Circuit Court of Baltimore was outlined and sponsored by Cyrus Eaton interests.

FOLLOVWING are a few notes jotted down on a passenger flight last week from Newark to Chicago on United Air Lines, leaving Newark at 12:30 P. M.: Clear and cold weather expedited the take-off and we were in the air with a comparatively short run.

WRITING in Time and Tide, John Brophy assails the vogue of best sellers as a menace to the well-being of the profession of letters. He points out that the amount of money spent on new books does not vary much from one year to another.

MR. HINTON does not offer much encouragement to Americans who hope that this country may be able to keep out of war. A meticulous critic, indeed, might even question the appropriateness of his book's title,
Manhattan College defeated Canisius College, conqueror of Marquette, in a basketball game, 49-40, tonight at the State Armory before a crowd of 1,800.

WHEN the authors of this book sat down to put it together they had in mind something other than the conventional one-volume American history.

The United States Steel Corporation of New Jersey and a subsidiary, the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company, were declared today by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake to have infringed on a patent of the Cold Metal Process'Company of Youngstown, Ohio. The two companies were upheld, however, on the use of four other contested patents.

The Pittsburgh Glass Institute announces that its second national glass competition will be held this year, with Nov. 1 as the closing date. The contest is open to architects, decorators, designers, home owners and builders.

The New York Athletic Club polo team, winner of the championship last year, came back from a losing streak which had gripped them through the past two weeks to pull out their metropolitan league game against the first division, 18 to 13, at the Squadron A Armory last night.

The fifteen city Councilmen who passed a 2 per cent sales tax ordinance last week, only to have it vetoed by Mayor S. Davis Wilson, decided in a caucus today to pass it and other tax measures over the Mayor's veto Tuesday, "unless a completely new and feasible plan" to raise money was presented.

TO those who have heard tales of Toscanini's phobia for recording and accepted the veiled hints that the New York Philharmonic-Symphony series marked his positively last work in this direction, it must come as a distinct surprise to learn that while in London last Fall the maestro made yet another set.

The Madison Square branch of the Public National Bank and Trust Company will open new offices at the northwest corner of Broadway and Twenty-fourth Street tomorrow, after occupying quarters at Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street for twenty-five years.

THIS fascinating volume has been written after years of extensive research in the style magazines of the world published in the last 178 years. It is the author's belief that fashions repeat themselves in fixed cycles which may be as definitely charted as Dow-Jones averages.

The passing of many large estate holdings on the North Shore of Long Island is noted in a review of sales there for the past year by Henry A. Rogers of Henry A. Rogers and Kenneth Ives Co., affiliated brokers.

As three New England Intercollegiate Association swimming records were broken, Springfield College beat Rider of Trenton, N. J., today, 39 to 36. The meet was not settled until the final event, the 400-yard free-style relay, which the Maroon natators took in the record time of 3:44.4, to better. a previous mark set by Brown.

WITHOUT question "Golden Boy" is the biggest winner the Group Theatre has ever had, confounding pedants who said it would fail because the dressing-room scene didn't show the taping of the fighter-hero's hands.

In one of the last public addresses of Mrs. Pennypacker, formerly president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, she said that no great body of women can work together without showing some tolerance and that women's clubs have been teaching women "how to differ in opinion without letting personal heat get in"though men have' not entirely learned the lesson through ages' of practice.

Mrs. Roger Wisner heads a group of women in charge of the plans for a Spring luncheon and fashion revue in aid of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery which will be held March 1 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. The fashion revue will include a showing of the latest Spring costumes for all occasions.
Twelve players, including Ralph Greenleaf, present holder of the title, are slated to participate in the world pocket billiard championship tourney at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

Interpretations of the new shortselling rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission were sent yesterday by the New York. Stock Exchange to its members, accompanied by a letter which revealed that they had been amended and approved by experts of the commission.

Students of St. Mary's Hall, this city, will be guests Thursday night of the Right Rev. Wallace J. Gardner, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey. The occasion will be the Bishop's Feast, a traditional ceremony, the outgrowth of the old Twelfthnight Feasts given by Bishop George

MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP).--Sparked by Russ McConnell, right winger, who counted five goals, McGill University's Redmen swamped Queens University, 10 to 1, in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game today.

The arrest of J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, disbarred lawyer who was reputed heir of the crime machine of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, has turned the interest of a special investigation of crime and politics under way here to evidence indicating a strong affiliation between gang bosses of New York and this city.

Early action of Premier Mussolini's long-postponed plan to supplant the Chamber of Deputies with a "Chamber of Fascios and Guilds" was indicated today with an announcement the Grand Council would consider the matter on March 3.

Reconstruction of the tower of the Baptist Meeting House of this historic village has been completed. The tower was dedicated in August as a memorial to George Jones, a native of East Poultney, who, with Henry T. Raymond, founded THE NEW YORK TIMES in 1851.

Lester A. Strasser of the City Athletic Club and Albert H. Marckwald Jr. of Short Hills yesterday gained the final round in the third annual Monte M. Sterling squash tennis tournament on the courts of the New York Athletic Club.

Education and control of both automobile driver and pedestrian must play the major roles if we are to reduce the highway accident toll, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, told members of the commercial vehicle section of the Greater New York Safety Council last week.

ARCHAIC" is the adjective used by the Maritirhe Commission to describe the system under which American merchant seamen are continually hired and fired as voyages begin and end. The commission proposes that sailormen should have continuous employment, as do men who work for corporations ashore.

Chancellor Adolf Hitier's reorganization of his Cabinet and the army high command, involving the retirement of fifteen generals and the shifting of other important officials, represents "just a change of a few personalities and no change of policy," Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, declared here today.

Household marketers find it difficult now to say that a vegetable or fruit is high enough in price to make it worth while to shop around for very long. Nor are there many fresh-food products that are not of excellent quality.

A large number of persons in the United States borrowed money from savings, building and loan associations, constructed more new houses and bought more existing homes with the financial aid of those institutions during 1937- than in any previous year since 1930, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday.
Athletic officials of the University of Michigan said tonight announcement of a football coach to succeed Harry G. Kipke may be expected next week, probably Friday when the board of regents meets.

Two projects on the campus of the New Jersey College for Women have been made possible by WPA funds and workers. The government has allotted $6,564 for a project concerned with the making of campus maps and $10,581 for physical development and improvements.

After a mutual knockout on "parrakeet" (also spelled "parakeet," "parroket" and "paroket") in the fourth round of a heated spelling match between picked spellers from city rooms of New York and Boston newspapers, the New York team, though groggy on its feet from misspelling "parapegm,"

COINCIDENTAL with the departure last Thursday of Leonide Massine for Monte Carlo to take up his work as artistic director of the new ballet company which has been built around the nucleus of Rene Blum's Ballets de Monte Carlo, there appeared the first official announcement of a reorganization of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo,

Mayor La Guardia has accepted chairmanship of a committee to raise $1,000,000 to complete the sanctuary and choir, making it possible to open the great interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine before the opening of the New York World's Fair in 1939, it was announced yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.

Individual announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were greater in number than in any week in the last two months. Few of the prepayments, however, were for large amounts of bonds, most of the calls being for small lots to satisfy sinking fund requirements.
Mrs. M. R. King, the former Phyllis Mudford, who played for England in the Wightman Cup matches at Forest Hills in 1935,

The second lecture of the course on flower arrangement, now being conducted by the Junior League, will be given Tuesday morning at the League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, when Miss Alice Carson will speak on "Arrangements in the Modern Manner."

The two chief contenders for the metropolitan intercollegiate basketball championship, St. John's and New York University, will stage their long awaited encounter at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday to supply the feature of a very busy week on the courts.
It is the sesquicentennial of the Constitution, and a person might obviously do much worse than spend a couple of

Although scientists have not yet figured out the exact relationship between the intensity of the sun's rays and the activity of insects, there is no doubt in the minds of those who have grown house plants that, with the longer and brighter days of approaching Spring, house plant pests begin to take a new interest in life.

Teachers who warn children against reading the comics or "awful" magazines, and then go home and read them themselves were criticized as being "dishonest" yesterday at the midyear conference of English teachers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON.--In two out of sixteen major professional occupations women not only outnumber men but they have gained in comparison with men in the last twenty years, the Department of Labor disclosed in a recent survey of the trend of occupations of women.
The Republican National Committee has arranged for many speeches at dinners and meetings to be held on Lincoln's birthday with about fifty members of Congress participating.

100-Yard Dash--Cyril Holmes, England. Three-Mile Run-C. H. Matthews, New Zealand. 440-Yard Hurdles--John Loaring, Canada. High Jump--Edwin Thacker, South Africa. Javelin Throw--Jim Courtright, Canada. Women's 100-Yard Dash--Decima Norman, Australia.

Descendants of distinguished Virgirians dating from Colonial times will be guests of honor at a large reception to be given by the Society of Virginia Women on Friday afternoon in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Governor James H. Price of Virginia has been invited to attend as the principal honor guest.
IT seems that Wilkie Collins had a superstition about rewriting a story once he had it down on paper. There were no second drafts.

The four Soviet Arctic campers riding the ice from the North Pole tonight reported that their floe had drifted twenty miles farther from Greenland's east coast in twenty-four hours while the temperature continued to drop.

Committees on labeling, store program, local groups and research of the Consumer Retailer Relations Council have been organized and are now functioning, according to a summary of activities issued by the council.
PICTURE a Shogun of other days, but uniformed in modern khaki and using the modern telephone in laying down the law. Place him, not in Tokyo but in the colonial capital, Seoul.

The first meeting of the recently organized Caritas Guild, a new philanthropic project of the Alumnae of the Academy of Mount St. Vincenton-Hudson, will take place tomorrow night at the headquarters of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, 131 East Twentyninth Street.
A flower and fashion show will be held on May 20 on board the Nieuw Amsterdam for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt heads the benefit committee.

John Lewis, manager, and William O'Connor, a clerk, in the Thom McAn Shoe Store at 232 Willis Avenue, near 138th Street, the Bronx, were felled by blows from the butts of pistols of three hold-up men who escaped with $30 from the cash register about 9 o'clock last night, when they attempted to resist.

TWO of the season's out-of-town group shows, important "regulars" both, are now current: The 133d annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy in Philadelphia and the third American Painting of Today biennial at the Worcester Museum.

Miss Marjorie Stearns, daughter of Mrs. William Taylor Stearns of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Church to Frederic William Loeser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Loeser of New Haven, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie.

The Newark branch of Seton Hall College here has enrolled 350 students for its Spring term, more than double the number a year ago, when the branch was established, according to an announcement made today by college officials.

The two seaplane bombers that sank the British freighter Alcira yesterday twenty-two miles off Barcelona were definitely identified today as Spanish Rebel craft by the ship's master, Captain Hugh McCracken.

Champion Flornell Spicypiece of Halleston, the imported wire-haired fox terrier that was best in show at last year's Westminster exhibition, will contend again for the highest honors this week as one of the representatives of the Halleston Kennels of Stanley J. Halle of Chappaqua, N. Y.

Representatives of several patriotic societies interested in the education of young men and women in the mountains of the South have arranged a concert for the benefit of Lincoln Memorial University at Harrogate, Tenn., which will take place Friday night at the Town Hall. The artists will be Miss Emily Roosevelt, coloratura soprano, and Harold Henry, composer-pianist.

The Crucible Steel Company of America paid H. S. Wilkinson, chairman of its board, a salary of $150,000 in both 1935 and 1936 and $145.000 in 1934, according to confidential reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission which the commission declined to accept as confidential. These and other reports were made public today.

The Hebrew Sunday School Society of Philadelphia will celebrate its centenary tomorrow night with addresses by educators, pageantry and music centering upon a tribute to the memory of its founder, Rebecca Gratz, said to have been the prototype of Sir Walter Scott's Rebecca in "Ivanhoe."

The feature of the foreign exchange market here today was weakness in German marks. Holders were disturbed by political developments in Germany and, while offerings were comparatively small, takers were not readily found, and the rate rose sharply to 12.44 1/4 to the pound sterling, against 12.41.
Members of the New York Chapter, United Daughters of the Confederacy, will give their annual card party to augment their philanthropic fund on Feb. 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S recent use of a quotation from Shakespeare to show his impatience with the battle waging between leaders of industry and leaders of labor might with good purpose be applied to the split in the ranks of labor itself.

The cooperation of President Roosevelt in the solution of the "problem of the new leisure", has been sought as the result of a nation-wide conference on recreation at the University of Minnesota, and he has been asked to call a conference in Washington to consider the "vast social implications involved."

Charles H. Winslow, husband of former Alderman Ebba M. Winslow, now Republican State Committeewoman for the Fourth Assembly District, died yesterday in his home at 43-15 Hook Creek Boulevard, Rosedale, Queens. Mr. Winslow, who was 83 years old, had retired from the practice of law four years ago and had been in ill health for some time.

Gates. W. McGarrah, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank in the New York district and former president of the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, Switzerland, received a medal for "distinguished service" last night at the annual dinner of the Orange County Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
William F. Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, announced yesterday the launching of a drive by his department to cut the price of bread to 9 cents a loaf. A typical retail price is 11 cents.
A member of the Communications Commission urged tonight that a free radio be added to free speech and a free press as "pillars of democracy."

TRADE volume sagged last week for various reasons, which included increased unemployment, lower livestock prices and adverse weather conditions. But, from all accounts, January business held up surprisingly well, due to sales in the earlier part of the month.

The unbeaten New College girls' basketball team defeated Beaver College, 34-19, in Thompson Gymnasium yesterday. The victors led at the half, 16-12. Miss Hildegarde Gross scored 17 points to lead the attack.

Students at the University of Vermont are making "loan boxes" for the State's backward children in rural schools this year. Containing directions for weaving, basketry, metal and wood work, complete with drawings, patterns and samples, the boxes are prepared as a National Youth Administration project.

Yellow and white predominated in the floral decorations at St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Dorothy Douglas Robinson and Randolph Appleton Kidder. Tall seven-branched candelabra illuminated the chancel, where the ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.

Army won from Duke today in a loosely played basketball game, doubling the Blue Devils' count in a 40-to-20 triumph. The Southerners played hard throughout, but missed easy shots and handled the ball clumsily at critical times.

The German public was stunned yesterday by the sweeping reorganization of the government through which Chancellor Hitler concentrated control over all military, political and economic policies in his own hands.

FIVE acres of rocky hillside land constitute the unusual site chosen for a modern fifteenroom house which is being erected in Mount Pleasant, N. Y., for Edwin M. Stern of Stern Stern, textile merchants.

THE Broadwayites have finally become alarmed over the slander done their street and are out to prove to the outof-towners that it can still hold its own with Piccadilly Circus, Kurfurstendamm and Main Street.

One of the old estates in Central Valley, Orange County; N. Y., containing two acres of land with a large residence and a bungalow, has been sold by the executors of the J. V. Sutherland estate, to Colonel Alfred J. L'Heureux of Central Valley and Hackensack, N. J. The property has frontages on Clove Valley and Pine Hall Roads.

On the day that Larry MacPhail took over the task of directing the Brooklyn Dodgers' destinies for the next three years, one of the first of several things that drew his disapproving frowns was the Spring training trip schedule of exhibition games that already, had been arranged.
The world and United States interscholastic record for the 180-yard medley relay in a sixty-foot pool was broken today by a Blair Academy swimming team.

Thomas P. Keeley of Green, Ellis Anderson was elected president of the Cashiers Association of Wall Street, Inc., at the eleventh annual meeting and banquet of the association held last night in the Cafe Savarin, 120 Broadway.

From time immemorial snow has been considered the friend of the horticulturist. An old farmers' saying is that "a good fall of snow is equivalent to a top dressing of manure"-a statement due more probably to the beneficial protection to plants afforded by the snow than to any nutritive value provided.

The former estate here of Elsie Janis, the actress, is being considered as a site for a new Junior and senior high school, according to the Rev. Ernest E. Edmond, president of the North Tarrytown Board of Education.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following calendar for Monday, Feb. 7, was an nounced: CALL OF THE FEBRUARY CALENDAR Calendar for the day. Law calendar. 43748-Olds Whipple. Inc.

10:00--Ring 1, bull terriers. Judge, William L. Kendrick. Stewards, Mrs. Walter N. Stake, W. Freeland Kendrick. 10.00--Ring 2, chow chows. Judge, Mrs. Grace G. Neyhzart. Stewards, William H. Schwinger, Miss Ella D. Milbank. 12.00--Ring 2, Chihauhuas. Judge, Mrs. Charies H. Willits. Stewards, William J. Ryan, Miss Caroline Saltus.
Calvin Pardee 3d, Hazleton, Pa., coal mine operator, won the A. A. U. bobsled race for novice drivers on Mount Van Hoevenberg today with an.elapsed time for four heats of 2 minutes 54.79 seconds.
The annual campaign for funds to maintain the work of the Brooklyn and Queens Young Men's Christian Association will close next Friday, it was announced yesterday by William F. Hirsch, director.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Auchincloss Truslow, daughter of Mrs. Henry Adams Truslow of Little Lindum, Summit, and the late Mr. Truslow, to William Morris Greenwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Greenwood of Kings Highway Farm, Middletown, took place here this afternoon in Christ Church.
A bill providing for the liquidation of the public works obligations, in default since 1933, through a new bond issue was approved "in totality" by the Senate tonight.

PRINTING has always had a strong fascination for some people. They take keen pleasure in handling the small but potent slugs of lead that, placed in the proper sequence. can make countless millions laugh or cry, bring on wars or peace, change the habits or political opinions of nations and project into time the word and sDirit of dead geniuses.
Prosecutor Ralph Bartlett is preparing to ask a grand jury to indict two gangsters for the slaying of Detective Robert Cline in what police described as one of Columbus's fiercest gun battles.
BASIL MATHEWS hadstudied India for twenty-five years before he made the journey in which he allowed India to "reveal herself," and which forms the foundation for this book.

The business recession during the latter part of 1937 had an adverse effect on loan investmets in Manhattan real estate as gauged by the flow of new mortgage money, according to the yearly report of the Real Estate Board of New York, citing figures for each of the four quarterly periods last year as compared with 1936.

A REPORTER covering a disaster works against long odds. Consider, for example, what the Chicago correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES had to contend with when he covered the great fire which, sixty-six years later, forms the 30-odd minute climactic scenes of the motion picture "In Old Chicago," and which was then the biggest story of the time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--The demands made of Japan by the United States, Great Britain and France for information concerning her naval building program, it was indicated today, will precipitate increased demands in Congress for an explanation of President Roosevelt's foreign policy objectives.
Effective tomorrow, liquor wholesalers in the New York area will quote on domestic and imported liquors the prices stipulated by the owners of the brands, it was learned yesterday.

Francisco Campos, Minister of Justice and the Interior, is preparing to submit a solution soon regarding the fate of thousands of immigrants who entered Brazil on tourist visas and have remained illegally after the expiration of the stipulated six-month period.
The Scarsdale unit of the New York Junior League sponsored a children's play this afternoon at the Edgemont School auditorium for the benefit of the Westchester Speedwell Unit.

An average of one to one and one-half planes daily are being manufactured in Loyalist Spain, official circles say. Since "'consumption" at the front is distinctly less it means that the government air force is increasing steadily, not counting any machines which may be imported.

Many changes In the real estate field are likely in New York this year, points out Joseph H. Nassoit, president of the Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation, who cites the extension of transit facilities, the plans for new housing and the demolition of extensive areas of outmoded buildings as among the factors which will help the Market.

While admitting that as yet they lacked details about the bill introduced last week in the New York State Assembly to repeal the FeldCrawford price-maintenance law, proponents of the fair-trade acts said they were not concerned over the possibility of its passage.

A new television principle, which is expected to reduce greatly the cost of the ultimate home television receiver and simplify vastly its inner construction, was demonstrated yesterday in Upper Montclair, N. J., by Allen B. DuMont, inventor and cathode-ray tube expert.

More than 40,000 tons of surplus foodstuffs were distributed to needy families here and up-State last year by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration and the State Department of Social Welfare, which absorbed the TERA on July 1.

HIGH in the New England hills, midwinter finds the short-wave listener cut off from the busy world when antenna and forest-fir swing to the tune of sub-zero winds above deepening snow. Yet the observer is not alone.
Fifty women before her had failed, but Mrs. Georgiana Brown Harbeson had the knack and the grit to step in and develop a new industry and a different art.

THE motorist has dreamed for years of a transcontinental two-lane highway with north and south connections, and the current emphasis on armaments, curiously, has revived in Congress the talk of a Federal defense road system which would be of incaloulable benefit in peacetime.

Backwoods Night will be observed at La Salle Tropicale of Le Coq Rouge Restaurant on Feb. 24 when a Wild West Dinner Dance will be given as a benefit for the Madison Square Boys Club, an organization which, since its establishment in 1884, has conducted an extensive program for the educational, cultural and moral guidance of underprivileged boys.

The stock market extended its recover in quiet trading yesterday. The armament shares, so-called, led the rise, reflecting the reintroductionr of .the armament topic by reason of the inquiry directed by the United States to Japan concerning the latter's naval building plans.

THERE have been for some time considerable expectations of a piece called "The Melody That Got Lost," which was tried out last year at the Embassy Theatre and now, after considerable changes, has been reproduced in state at the Phoenix.

The Soviet Government sent a protest to Rome today against the seizure of Russian funds in a Milan branch of the Bank of Italy to satisfy the claim of Italian builders of a Russian warship. The embassy in Rome was ordered to protest against a Milan court decision under which the funds were seized Jan. 20.

Former President Herbert Hoover arrived yesterday from California and will leave Wednesday on the steamship Washington for a visit to Belgium. Mr. Hoover's visit is on invitation of his former associates in Belgian relief and of educational institutions in that country which have benefited from American cooperation.

VIRTUALLY all of the new foreign stamps arriving in New York last week are British colonials with the likeness of King George VI. Indications are that such issues will be much in philately's limelight during the next few months,

Not only has the birth of Princess Beatrix assured the continuance of the House of Orange on the throne of The Netherlands but the resulting celebrations should dispose of the myth that we Dutch are a hopelessly solemn and phlegmatic race.

Students of the Gardner School and members of the Gardner School Alumnae Association have arranged a card party to be held the night of Feb., 19 at the school, 154 East Seventieth Street, in behalf of the Louise Eltinge Memorial Fund and the school publication. Milestones.
In sympathy with a further advance in Liverpool and an improvement in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange here gained ground again yesterday and ended 2 to 5 points higher than Friday.

The Duke of Windsor has telephoned Windsor Castle requesting that most of his furniture, formerly at Fort Belvedere, be sent to the Chateau de la Maye, near Versailles. This was taken as an indication that the Duke plans a long residence there.
Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Landau of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Celia Landau, to Frederick M. Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison of Kingston, Pa.
WASHINGTON. -- The Treasury has launched a drive through its Secret Service division to make the American public, particularly retailers and storekeepers, more counterfeit-minded.

Smith College is now offering twenty-five competitive tuition scholarships to new students of distinction, in addition to the Dwight Morrow, William Allan Neilson and Sophia Smith scholarships, which are awarded for highest standing to students of the three upper classes.

Undergraduate editors of the various publications on the University Heights campus of New York University were announced yesterday. Twenty-five students in the Schools of Engineering and Arts and Pure Science were selected to serve on the staffs of five publications. The following were named:
M. T. Zarotschenzeff, Russian-born refrigeration expert who recently returned from a world tour, advocates development of "a universal meat" to improve international relations.

Japanese troops stabbed at both sides of China's double-edged central front today, but on the south, Chinese reported, they were held back by Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's artillery. In the frozen bottomlands of the Hwai River, about ninety miles south of Suchow, the keystone of the Chinese defense, the embattled forces faced each other with the Japanese halted by artillery fire, according to Chinese advices.
Mr. arid Mrs. Charles Abes of Butler, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Abes, to Robert Lincoln London,. son of Mrs. Frrances London of this city.
Miss Henrietta M. Bradshaw, an organist and music patron, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 95. Daughter of Mrs.

Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, sailed unexpectedly yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, which left at noon for Mediterranean ports. Arriving at the West Fiftysecond Street pier only two minutes before the departure, he preented a ticket issued to A. R. Allen, the name under which it was purchased ten days ago.

On the assumption that attractive window displays and neatly arranged counters can entice more customers and help beat back the recession, the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education has started courses in store operation and promotion for the small business man of this city.

Chile's attitude toward the League of Nations has again been brought to the fore,' it is conceded in well-informed quarters, in view of the general lack of support at this weeks session for Chile's proposals for substantial revision of the League covenant.

EVERY seat was occupied in the low-hung, torpedo-shaped cars of the "autorail" from Paris to Brussels. These light motor-driven trains speed on nonstop trips between the principal cities of most Continental countries and they are always crowded. Everywhere people travel more than they used to, travel faster and more comfortably.

EVERY government in Europe is just now watching France, with anxiety in the case of her friends, with scarcely concealed anticipation of evil in the case of those who regard her empire with envious eyes. How is she going to evolve?

A year ago today President Roosevelt proposed his Court Reorganization Bill and precipitated a momentous Congressional battle. Political effects of the long struggle which left his party ranks in Congress badly split are still in almost daily evidence on Capitol Hill. The breach has not healed.

SOME of the outstanding masterpieces of European art will be exhibited to visitors at the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition. This became certain with the latest report of Dr. Walter Heil, who for months has been arranging for the exhibition to include works by many old masters, some of which have never before been shown in this country.

The Travelers Aid Society has written a letter of sympathy to the monks of St. Bernard's Hospice, damaged recently by an avalanche in the Swiss Alps. At the same time the letter, signed by Miss Virginia M. Murray, executive secretary of the Travelers Aid Society, expresses gratification that the monks and the famous St. Bernard dogs escaped unharmed.

The annual Valentine Tea Dance under the auspices of the Long Distance Club of the College of New Rochelle will be held in the Sports Building on the campus next Saturday afternoon. Miss June Tague is chairman of the arrangements committee.

Miss Adele Edge, daughter of Nelson J. Edge 2d of this place and the late Mrs. Grace Neill Edge, was married here this afternoon in the Carteret Club to J. Randolph Jones of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chesnut E. Jones of Richmond, Va.

Miss Adele Edge, daughter of Nelson J. Edge 2d of this place and the late Mrs. Grace Neill Edge, was married here this afternoon in the Carteret Club to J. Randolph Jones of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chesnut E. Jones of Richmond, Va.

Because of the increasing interest in war and peace problems, the National Board of the Y. W. C. A. has undertaken a national survey of their units to discover methods by which they may be a more effective force for peace than they have in the past.

A large two-story industrial building is being erected in the Ridgefield Industrial Terminal at Grand and Slocum Avenues, Ridgefield, N. J., for the American Gas Machine Company of Albert Lea, Minn., which will occupy the premises on a long-term lease.
THIS modern era of beautiful glass is shown in its exquisite, skilled and imaginative beauty in the ninety-seven photographs which illustrate Leloise Davis Skelley's sumptuous quarto book.

SIR HENRY CURTIS-BENNETT took part in more murder trials than any other lawyer in English court history. When, in 1922; his career reached its apex in his appearance for the defense in three long-to-becelebrated murder cases, he had already been of counsel in fortyeight murder trials, and there were plenty more to come.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--Four of the first ten tennis stars of the country are expected as entrants in the second annual Palm Beach invitational tournament to be held on the clay courts of the Everglades Club from tomorrow through Saturday.

In the most exciting game played here this season, the Rutgers basketball team remained undefeated by subduing a fighting Springfield five, 48 to 46, before 2,500 persons in the university gymnasium tonight. The victory was the seventh of the season for the Scarlet.

The project for the creation of a unified political party of Fascist complexion has died of inanition and is being quietly shunted into a siding. The process is disguised by describing it as the conversion into a purely spiritual movement to promote great Japanism, but this has only to be compared with the original aim to reveal the extent of the change.

BERLIN.--The appearance tomorrow of Martin Niemoeller, leader of the Protestant resistance to the totalitarian regime, before the judges who are to try him for sedition promises to be one of those turning points in the history of a people where the immediate issues cannot be compared with the underlying significance of the event.

The announced plan of Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, to make new small housing on cheap, outlying land the backb one" of his program, was declared last night by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, to be in direct conflict with the spirit of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act.

COPENHAGEN.--The name of Sweden brings to mind, whenever you mention it, many pleasant connotations--of unruffled peace for the last 123 years and a brilliant record in every sphere of human progress.
In one of the most exciting Eastern Intercollegiate League meets staged in New York, Yale's swimming team defeated Columbia, 48 to 27, in the Columbia pool last night.

In reviewing real estate activity in Larchmont, Westchester County, during 1937, Thomas B. Sutton, president of the Real Estate Exchange of Larchmont, reveals that 152 homes were sold in that area for $2,932,850 during the year. This compares with ninety-two homes sold for $2,134,850 in 1936. He adds that 1937 was the best year since 1931.

Two days spent in this essentially Russian town, the capital of Bessarabia, barely an hour's journey from the Soviet frontier and in Jassy, the home town of Professor Alexander C. Cuza, Minister Without Portfolio, have given this correspondent two distinct pictures of the situation in the Rumanian provinces, each differing from the picture seen in Bucha- est.

LAKELAND, Fla. LOATH to return to their firesides in the North, Florida's Winter visitors plan to linger from three to six weeks longer this season, and communities all over the peninsula have hastily added entertainment programs to meet the extension of the season.

The body of a woman about 45 years of age, believed to be Martha Zeddies, a nurse, of 89-11 Thirtyfourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, was found in a few inches of water at the foot of Pacific Boulevard here today.
ASCHOLASTIC salon of photography, open only to highschool students, has been an nounced by the American Institute of the City of New York, so East Forty-second Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Leigh J. Sessions of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, gave a dinner last night at the Montauk Club, Park Slope, Brooklyn, for their niece, Miss Margaret Augusta Seavers. Later the guests went to Miss Elsie Hepburn's Assembly at the Apollo Club, Brooklyn.

The New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs will clash in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. With both teams stressing the wideopen, free-scoring type of play, the game promises to be an exciting one and should attract a crowd of more than 14,000.

Matthias McCormick, senior member of the retail grocery firm of McCormick Joyce, died here yesterday of pneurronia at the age of 78. He was born in Cheshire, Mass.; came to Pittsfield in 1886,
Former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas impressed upon his fellow-Methodists today that "Christianity has a great stake in the preservation of democracy."

The Silver Brook trio of Red Bank captured the lead in the newly formed New Jersey Polo League by setting back Ridgewood, national junior titleholder, 14 to 10, in the final contest of a polo triple-header at Essex Troop Armory tonight.

A trend toward solid-color dresses, instead of the prints which were so popular last year at this time, is one of the outstanding facts revealed in a fashion report based on actual January sales records at Lord Taylor, New York department store.

ONE of the earliest signs of Spring, just as dependable as the first robin or blue bird and preceding these fliers by some weeks, is making itself evident in the mail of members of Congress , the Navy Department and Naval District Communications offices from Maine to Florida and the Atlantic to the Pacific.
Gustav Killian and Heinz Vopel, dashing young riders from Germany, won their tenth straight six-day bicycle race tonight to set a new world record for consecutive victories.

The Triborough Bridge Authority has adopted a resolution urging prompt acquisition by the city of the land needed for the easterly approaches to the bridge, according to Roderick Stephens, member of the Authority and president of the Bronx Board of Trade.

Extra-curricula studies of world affairs and the leading movements of the day at home have won an important place on the Bryn Mawr College campus this year, as a result of programs drafted by a group of allied student organizations.

NEW finds in ancient lands and interest to Mediterranean tours. One of the latest, according to a recent dipatch, is a pagan chapel in Northern Syria, a land where archaeologists have been for some time uncovering ancient civilizations.
Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., will speak on "A Chinese Holiday Under Fire;' Wednesday at the annual Founders Day luncheon of the Woman's Club of Orange.
Commodore Emile Jacoby and other bigwigs of the New Jersey Outboard Association last week found to their elation that they had another and brand-new regatta for their racing schedule.

The Triborough Bridge Authority has adopted a resolution urging prompt acquisition by the city of the land needed for the easterly approaches to the bridge, according to Roderick Stephens, member of the Authority and president of the Bronx Board of Trade.
Three thousand former students of Adelphi College at Garden City, L. I., will participate in a drive to raise $20,000 within the next two weeks.

Dr. and Mrs. G. Herbert Carter of Huntington, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Carter, to Dr. John Cannon, son of Mrs. Charles Madison Cannon of New York and the late Mr. Cannon.

Moscow is moving fast nowadays, perhaps faster than the rest of Europe. The superficial changes in the Soviet capital in the past three months are obvious and striking, but perhaps, too, there are underlying changes no less important if less evident.

The Stevens Tech quintet bowed before a last-minute Lehigh rally, 50-46, in a rapid-fire game tonight. Groome and Feucht shared highscoring honors with 15 points each. Goldrich followed with 14 points.
The Transit Commission, in a statement issued yesterday, announced that it would continue its fight against the Chandler bill, introduced in Congress to amend the National Bankruptcy Act.

WITHOUT overpraising Paul Vincent Carroll as a Writer, it is plain that his "Shadow and Substance" belongs In that tradition. He is a schoolmaster, aged 38, who has had a dream of an impossibly noble life for Ireland, and it has plunged him into a beautiful and bitter reverie.

A double engagement in the family of Julius Strauss of 865 West End Avenue has been announced. His daughter, Miss Helen Straus, is betrothed to Lester Joseph Milich, and his son, Harold Leon Strauss, will marry Miss Jane Kohler.

IT is one of the ironies of our history that the powers of the Presidency were stretched to their utmost limit by a man who not only believed with mystic fervor in "government of the people, by the people and for the people" but who was also as stanch a defender as the American Constitution ever had.

Cornell will have another engineering school when the academic year begins next Fall. To the already existing units of mechanical, electrical and civil engineering the university will add a chemical engineering division in the College of Engineering, it was decided at a recent meeting of the board of trustees.

Active participation by retailers throughout the country in a national housing drive will be one of several major objectives of his policy as president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association during the coming year, Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company, and newly elected head of the retailers' organization, said yesterday.

ACCORDING to F. J. Harmon, branch manager of the Inter national Harvester Company, Forty-second Street, at Eleventh Avenue, this week, Feb. 7 to 12 inclusive has been designated as a special truck show week.

With gains in four of its components offset by losses in three, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Jan. 29 remained unchanged at the previous week's level of 82.3. The index stood at 101.7 for the comparable week a year ago.

Evidences of an unusually active Spring market in all of the popular residential sections in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island are being forcibly presented in the large building operations under way in many localities and the purchase of many plots for early improvement with homes and apartment structures.

Mrs. G. Hector Petri of Brookline has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellanor Pet?, to Elliott Warren Robbins, sona of Mrs. Elliott B. Robbins, also of Brookline, and the late Mr. Robbirs.

The possibility of keeping the United States out of any general war that may develop was discussed last night by speakers at the third annual "jamboree" of the magazine Common Sense. The dinner was held at the Aldme Club, and was attended by about 500 persons.
THIS is a magnificent study of the devastating effect of a deep and desperate love upon the career and character of a brilliant phvsician.
IN form and material, classification and workmanship this is the most comprehensive and attractive little volume on the subject that has come to hand.

Led by the National Hockey League's leading point-getter, the Maple Leafs tonight beat the Bruins, 3-1, for the first time in five starts this season. Gordon Drillon made two goals and assisted in the other.
In 1915 Conway Robinson, an engineer at that time engagedd in research at the General Electric Laboratories in Schenectady, had a conversation with his famous coworker, Dr. Charles Steinmetz.

The marriage of Miss Mary Louise Peelle, daughter of Mrs. Charles White Peelle of Douglas Manor, Queens, and the late Mr. Peelle, to Henry Lawrence Sparks Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Lawrence Sparks of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Sparks, took place last night in the Douglaston Community Church, Douglaston, Queens.
Dividing a pair of overtime goals, the New York Americans and the Montreal Canadiens battled to a 3-3 National Hockey League draw tonight.

Led by the National Hockey League's leading point-getter, the Maple Leafs tonight beat the Bruins, 3-1, for the first time in five starts this season. Gordon Drillon made two goals and assisted in the other.
In 1915 Conway Robinson, an engineer at that time engagedd in research at the General Electric Laboratories in Schenectady, had a conversation with his famous coworker, Dr. Charles Steinmetz.

The marriage of Miss Mary Louise Peelle, daughter of Mrs. Charles White Peelle of Douglas Manor, Queens, and the late Mr. Peelle, to Henry Lawrence Sparks Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Lawrence Sparks of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Sparks, took place last night in the Douglaston Community Church, Douglaston, Queens.
Dividing a pair of overtime goals, the New York Americans and the Montreal Canadiens battled to a 3-3 National Hockey League draw tonight.
The International Cycling Union today postponed for a year an American application for affiliation "in order to look thoroughly into the problem."

The seven-week strike of employes in the fifty-seven metropolitan stores of the Whelan Drug Company was settled yesterday with the aid of the State Mediation Board. The 200 strikers will be reinstated, although some will have to wait one to three months before getting their jobs back, but the terms of settlement provide for no change in wages and hours and no closed or preferential shop.

Even before the receipt of the American, British and French notes, the Japanese Navy had foreseen that a showdown would be demanded on the matter of naval construction. But yesterday's notes make that demand in a more peremptory manner than Japan has been accustomed to recently.

There is much interest here in the Tokyo announcement that the Japanese-owned South Manchuria Railway Company "will be entrusted by the provisional government of the Republic of China with the operation of the Peiping-Mukden, Peiping-Hankow and Tientsin-Pukow railways as well as bus lines, harbor construction and coal mining in the interior of North China."

Whatever the reaction in the United States, Japan and China to the withdrawal of the Fifteenth American Infantry from North China, some one is going to be" sore, good and sore-the doughboy of the Fifteenth.

Pamphlets calling upon Roman Catholics to unite and demand the ousting of Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, were distributed yesterday in more than a score of Roman Catholic Churches in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

Fordham's victories over Georgetown and Villanova were outstanding in a busy week in intercollegiate basketball circles, which saw every leading team in the metropolitan district in action at least once.

While wheat prices averaged higher last week, there was no snap to the buying, and the upturn, to a considerable extent, was regarded by traders as due more to short covering than to any material change in the world situation.

While Frank J. Marshall and David S. Polland, leaders in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, adjourned their games in the semifinal round yesterday, A. E. Santasiere, former club champion, strengthened his hold on third place by defeating A. C. Cass. Santasiere thereby completed his schedule with a total score of 7-4.

Mrs. Ferdinand Thieriot of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Yvonne Thieriot, to Ferdinand Stent of San Francisco. The announcement was made at a large tea given by Mrs. Thieriot this afternoon at the Burlingame Country Club to celebrate the birthday of her niece, Mrs. Sheldon Cooper.
Mrs. Robert Mills McClintock, wife of the third secretary of the United States Legation in the Dominican Republic, and Miss Betty Jane McClintock will arrive today and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.

In the background of the recent political upheaval in the Reich was a monarchist plot, it is related in a dispatch from a special correspondent in Basle, Switzerland, published here today by the Temps and repeated in many other papers.

The twenty-second annual report of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., for 1937 shows total sales of $23,277,441, compared with sales of $20,762,708 in 1936, an increase of 12.11 per cent. The number of operating units was increased by fifteen routes and nine stores,

Herman Van Dien Terhune, a descendant of one of the oldest families of Northern New Jersey, died here last night at the age of 78 after a brief illness. The last survivor of the ten children of Richard and Ann Maria Brinkerhoff Terhune,
Gladness in doing something pleasing to God should be the motive behind going to church, Dean Milo H. Gates of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Lard futures averaged somewhat higher last week, strength in cottonseed oil having considerable effect and more than offsetting the effect of a steady accumulation in supplies at leading packing centers.

Holland now takes a gloomier view of the situation in the United States than at the year-end, and leading financial circles which only a month ago still expressed moderate optimism regarding an early recovery prefer now to adopt a non-committal attitude.

In an Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League encounter, which required two extra five-minute periods before a decision was reached, the New York A. C. quintet defeated the Crescent A. C., 50-47, yesterday on the losing team's court in Brooklyn.

A bullet from the dark killed Dr. Charles H. Lee, 71-year-old rector of historic Christ Church, as he sat preparing a sermon in his rectory last night. The text ??on the paper found clutched in his hand read, "What so ever ye do in word or deed, do all in the name Lord, Jesus."

The Rev. Charles Edward Souter,. for the last decade pastor of the Peoples Church, Long Beach, L. I., was called yesterday to the pastorate of the Presbyterian Church of the Good Shepherd, 152 West Sixtysixth Street.

Annual meeting Metropolitan Certified Milk Producers with Certified Milk Producers Association of America, Hotel Roosevelt, 9 A. M. to 5 P. 6. Midwinter conference National Electrical Manufacturers Association, begins at Hotel Waldorf-Astoria this morning at 9:30 and continues to Friday.
The Missouri Pacific's fast passenger train, "The Texan," rammed an unoccupied automobile at a rural grade crossing near here today, killing three trainmen and three Negro passengers.

Charity treatments provided in 1937 by the Israel Zion Hospital in Brooklyn totaled $160,993, against $127,726 in 1936, according to a report by Hyman Meyerson, hospital vice president, made public yesterday.
Coming from behind in the last two periods, the Brooklyn Bruins defeated the Columbia Lions, 4 to 1, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association contest at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday.

Over the weekend there has been a revival of Nazi activity which may or may not be connected with events in Germany. On Friday there was an orgy of window smashing directed against Jewish-owned premises, and a largescale scattering of pro-Hitler leaflets.

In a splendidly played final to the first squash racquets open doubles tournament, Frank Ward of the City A. C. and George Cummings of the University Club defeated Thomas Iannicelli of Short Hills and John J. Smith of the Rockaway Hunting Club. at the Heights Casino yesterday.

The ferryboat Manadnock, with 100 passengers and twenty-one automobiles aboard, was marooned nearly four hours in the ice-filled Hudson River tonight about half a mile from here ona trip from Nyack to Tarrytown.

The French wholesale price index on Jan. 29 was 612, compared to 611 the week before and 615 two weeks before. The rise was chiefly accounted for by the textiles. The gold index for raw materials was 43.9, compared to 44.3 the week before and 45.3 two weeks before.

Before people can do anything as Christians, they must become Christians by practicing the Christian virtues, the Rev. Otto George Gerbich said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 437 East 140th Street, Bronx.

Miss Sophie Mack, daughter of Mrs. John Mack of Greenwich and the late Mr. Mack, was married to Vincent Valena of this place, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Valena, in the Sacred Heart Church at East Portchester this afternoon, by the rector, the Rev. Alexander C. Wollschlager.
Returning once more to his charge against the legal short cut "and/or," which he denounces as a "monster,"

In December the Commissioner of Accounts issued a report on lunacy commissions in criminal cases in this city. They were shown to be valueless, highly expensive, a fat bit of political spoils. The professional criminal killed recently in a fight with the police had successfully shammed insanity before one of these boards.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 82.6, which compared with 83.1 a week ago, 83.4 two weeks ago, 83.9 three weeks ago and 83.2 four weeks ago.

After playing the same consistent brand of golf that has earned him an international reputation, Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., won the $3,000 Sacramento open tournament today with a 72hole total of 290.

Donald Wakula, 16 years old, was shot through the heart and killed about 10 A. M. yesterday in the parlor of his home at 243 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, when an automatic pistol was accidentally discharged while his brother, John, 26, was reloading it.

The newly founded National Federation of Catholic College Students : yesterday adopted a constitution at ' a meeting of delegates of ten colleges of the New York region, held at Manhattanville College, 133d Street -and Convent Avenue.

The United States offers all nations, through its reciprocal trade agreement policy, an opportunity to participate in a program for peaceful attainment of "economic appeasement and security," but will never cease to exert whatever moral influence it can to bring about universal acceptance of basic principles for cooperative settlement of the world's economic ills, Secretary of State Cordell Hull asserted tonight.

A trade in talent whereby RKO will receive the services of Frank Capra for one picture in exchange for those of Ginger Rogers and Katharine Hepburn in Columbia's remake of "Holiday," now known as "Vacation Bound," is being negotiated.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. William B. Lusk of this place of the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Joan P. Lusk, to Charles H. Tenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gleason Tenney of 630 Park Avenue, New York.
The fifteen-story Port Authority Commerce Building, one of the largest structures of its type in the country, is 100 per cent occupied for the first time since it was opened nearly five years ago.

The Bruins maintained their three-point advantage over the Rangers in the American division of the National Hockey League tonight and pushed the Black Hawks within a point of last place by going on a scoring spurt in the last period to beat Chicago, 7 to 2. A crowd of 12,000 saw the game.

Light weather limited the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet to two championship races today and the usual leaders finished at the top of the standing. Bud Moxham, sailing Stingaree, beat his brother Jimmy, skipper of Stormy Petrel, by two points for first place in Class B one-design series, and Leonard Romagna had a similar margin over Dick Bertram for the honors in Class D.

Miss Eugenie Louise Requa, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Eugene Requa of this city, was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to Harry Doughlas Hough Jr., son of Mrs. H. D. Hough of Trenton and the late Mr. Hough.

Mrs. Caroline Downer Buhrer, widow of John Stephen Buhrer, died yesterday morning at the home of a son, John Downer Buhrer, 1,220 Park Avenue, at the age of 87. Her husband, who died thirty years ago, was an iron founder. She made her home since with her son. Another son, Stephen, of Chicago, also survives.
