THE BRIDAL CROWN, a play in three acts by August Strindberg, based on the translation by Edwin Bjorkman. Directed by Andrius Jilinsky; scenery by Eugene Dunkel; music composed by Michael Zadora; presented by the Experimental Theatre in behalf of the New York Players. At the Vanderbilt Theatre.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrives this morning from England after a six-week lieup and overhaul at Southampton, again flying the commodore flag at her mainmasthead, the red burgee with a golden lion in the center.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 76.2 on Feb. 2, compared with 77.2 a fortnight before, 77.8 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

A man believed to be George A. Carmody, 46-year-old cashier in the general postoffice at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, was reported missing to the police yesterday after the Eastern Steamship liner St. John tied up at Warren Street and the Hudson River from Boston.

The marriage of Dr. Margaret Bevans, daughter of Mrs. Martin J. Bevans of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Bevans, to Dr. David Lyall, son of Mrs. William L. Lyall of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Lyall, has been announced by her mother. It took place here on Friday.

Heywood Broun's announcement that he probably would drop in on the American Federation of Labor us, press conference tomorrow brought the rejoinder from Philip Pearl, A. F. L. publicity director, that he would not be admitted.

Riding along the crest of a victory wave, the New York Rovers extended their winning streak to six in a row yesterday afternoon by downing the Bronx Tigers, 4 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden.

The Marchioness of Normanby and her son, the Marquis of Normanby, Lord and Lady Sackville, Sir Louis and Lady Sterling, Lady Yule, Lady Fisher, and Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Indianapolis Union No. 1, oldest unit of the International Typographical Union, cast its lot with the American Federation of Labor in preference to the Committee for Industrial Organization today in the first endorsement by a large local of candidates for international offices.

Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Supreme Court, who has been ill since Dec. 10, is recovering. A bulletin issued today by his physicians said that "the justice is now gaining strength and they are much encouraged with his present condition."
Miss Megan Taylor of England won the world women's figure skating championship today, edging out her favored countrywoman, Miss Cecilia College, by 6.9 points, before a crowd of nearly 20,000.

Miss Mary R. Smith, water-color artist and member of a family of well-known artists, died today. She was a daughter of the late Xanthus Smith, marine artist, and a granddaughter of the late Russell Smith, early Philadelphia landscape painter.

Three little children and a man who tried to rescue them crashed through soft ice and were drowned today in Social Pond, in the center of the city. Another man who went to their aid also went through the ice, but was pulled out by companions.

Ralph G. Steinhardt of the Steinhardt Leather Company bought from the Fraternal Building and Loan Association the dwelling 205 McWhorter Street, northwest corner of Oliver Street, Newark N. J., which will be razed in the Spring and replaced with a onestory warehouse.

The long-awaited concert by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, who performed Beethoven's First and Ninth symphonies for the benefit of the Italian Welfare League, Inc., of this city, took place last night in Carnegie Hall.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 6. (AP).--Colonel Avery C. Sickels of Canton, Pa., at one time a figure in Pennsylvania Republican affairs and a friend of former President Theodore Roosevelt, died last night in a hospital here. He had been in Syracuse since October establishing manufacturing business.
More United States savings bonds (Baby Bonds) -were bought in January than in any month since March, 1935, when the bonds first were offered, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The presence of ample reserves and the slow rise in commercial demand for loans have caused the banks of this country in recent years to turn to installment and personal loans, as well as other methods of increasing their earnings, according to an analysis of bank earnings published in the February issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin.

Irs. Charles Edward Herrmann ave a small reception at her home ere today at which she announced ie engagement of her daughter, liss Jane Elizabeth Herrmann, to Villiam Edwin Hill, son of Mrs. Villiam Edwin Hill of Orienta point , Mamaroneck, and the late Er. Hill.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Provence Mullins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Walker Mullins of 460 Riverside Drive, this city, and Woodstock, Vt., to E. Morton Holland of New York and Santa Barbara, Calif., son of Mrs. R. McClelland Brady of Santa Barbara, and the late E. Morton Holland of Detroit, has been announced by her parents.

Pastor Martin Niemoeller's trial, scheduled to be held in Germany today, was c d yesterday by the Rev. C. Lawson Willard Jr. as a modern type of persecution to be expected by genuine Christians in any 2 i-Christian situation. Mr. Willard preached at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Corona Avenue and Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens.

Long columns of khaki-clad youngsters marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where they took part in the fourth annual observance of Scout Sunday and the twenty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America.

The Citizens Budget Commission recommended yesterday an eightpoint program of salary adjustments and changes in pension systems and working conditions in the Police and Fire Departments. The proposals were submitted to Mayor La Guardia and to all members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

The average young Christian today knows more of the life, history and accomplishments of his favorite motion picture star than he does of the significance, purpose and teachings of God, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert told a confirmation class yesterday morning.

High-speed passenger bus lines and express trucking on toll highways along the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway's rightof-way in Westchester and the Bronx might solve commuting and freight transportation problems created by the railroad's recent closing, Westchester County officials conceded today.

Bill Farnsworth, who is handling the Harry Jeffra-Sixto Escobar fight on Feb. 19 for Promoter Mike Jacobs, flew to Miami today, hoping to get Jim Braddock to act as referee. Farnsworth cabled to Braddock for an appointment before his departure.

What is happening in Germany focuses much more clearly here than in Berlin. Vienna is a magnifying glass. If it makes events a little larger than they are, it also makes them a shade more legible, and the range of its lens / is wider than that of the capitals of Western Europe.

The Spanish Insurgents reported yesterday they had driven back the Loyalists on a long front to the north of Teruel, thereby relieving pressure on Rebel supply lines. The Loyalists, admitting the loss of one town, asserted, however, that they retained the upper hand in the Teruel sector and were continuing their attack on Singra, on the Rebels' vital communications line to Calatayud. [Page 1.]
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent capacity, down 3 points in a week, but unchanged for the fortnight.

Buying activity was maintained in the wholesale market last week, and mail orders increased somewhat. Although retail dress sales were reported sluggish in most parts of the country, steady reorder activity was noted on such "bestselling" items as sports and casual tailored dresses in novelty fabrics. New sheers introduced on better lines met with favor.

Members of the junior committee of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery have planned a luncheon and fashion show in behalf of that organization for Thursday at the Continental. Younger members of society will act as manikins in this fashion display under the direction of Mrs. Eliphalet N. Potter.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two news items recently printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES have attracted my attention because, in a sense, they contradict one. another and show very strikingly the dilemma in which city employes have been placed.

Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, announced today that rules and regulations were being formulated to expedite multi-family and group housing programs under the amended National Housing Act which the President signed last week.

The Rev. Charles Albert William Brocklebank was installed as the eighth rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie, Tenth Street near Second Avenue, yesterday morning at services conducted by Bishop William T. Manning.

Frank H. Hutton, an architect who had practiced in New York since 1900, died yesterday morning in the Brooklyn Hospital after a three weeks' illness which included a major operation. He was about years old and resided at the Hotel Margaret, 97 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

The Bourse was unsettled at the beginning of the week. Uncertainty over the political and social situation at home and menacing incidents in the conflict in the Mediterranean contributed. to the reduction of the volume of trading.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Dempsey Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stuart Chase of Las Terassas, Hope Ranch Park, Santa Barbara, Calif., to George Mercer Nairne of Meikleour House. Perthshire, Scotland, will take place on March 18 in the Church of All Saints by the Sea, Santa Barbara, and will be followed by a reception at the Chase home.

A balanced sophomore team gained Princeton University's interclass gymnastic title by outscoring the juniors, 20-18, in the annual Winter meet, according to the results released today by the Intramural Athletic Association. The freshmen were third with 10 and the seniors fourth with 6.

Six hundred representatives of the independent retail food trade in New York City were asked yesterday to cooperate with William F. Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, in his campaign to cut the retail price of bread from 11 to 9 cents for a standardized one-pound loaf.

Records and testimony to show that J. Richard (Dixie) Davis was the heir to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's $50,000,000 policy racket were made ready today in preparation for a hearing tomorrow in which Davis will seek a reduction of his $300,000 bail.

An answer to the question of what America's colleges and universities pay their presidents, deans, professors and other faculty members is given by the Office of Education of the Department of the Interior In a bulletin entitled "College Salaries1936."

ABRAMOWITZ--Zise. Temple Israel of Long Beach extends its heartfeld sympathy to Mrs. Adolph Meirowitz, dear wife of our esteemed member and benefactor, on the demise of her beloved father. CHARLES A. SILVER, President, IRVING J. SHARLOT, Secretary.

Hope that provision will be made for women as well as men in the farms for narcotic addicts established by the United States Public Health Service is expressed by Miss Rachel Hopper Powell, first director of the Women's Prison Association of New York and the Isaac T. Hopper Home, 110 Second Avenue, in the organization's ninetythird annual report made public yesterday.

Walter A. Simon, Federal Farm Security Administration representative at Jersey Homesteads, denied reports today that the government intended to move relief families into the unoccupied homes at the cooperative industrial and agricultural colony near here. Ninety-six of the 200 homes are unoccupied.

To live, a church must have the spirit of evangelism, be loyal to the truth and have a stable membership, the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, said yesterday in his sermon during special services held in honor of the church's fiftieth anniversary.

The future of Judaism in America was the general subject at the conferance on Jewish affairs at the afternoon and evening sessions yesterday at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street. More than 300 representatives attended.

The Kingston Colonials set back the Brooklyn Visitations, 29 to 27, while the New York Jewels overwhelmed Kate Smith's Celtics, 47 to 33, in an American Basketball League double-header before a crowd of 5,000 at the Hippodrome last night.

Differences of opinion should be accepted by the church, the Rev. Dr. Granville Mercer Williams, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

The Chicago Flexible Shaft Company and its subsidiaries reported that combined net earnings in 1937 increased to $1,120,947 from $1,107,179 in 1936, despite the rise in labor and material costs. The 1937 earnings were equal to $6.23 a share, compared with $6.15 in 1936.
The First Provisional Brigade of the First Division from New York and the First Brigade of the fleet Marine force are prepared to go aboard naval vessels tomorrow to engage in Winter manoeuvres.

Today's most urgent bulletin would say that the first week of February brought two shows that started promisingly. In order of opening, they were "On Borrowed Time" and "Our Town," which arrived last Thursday and Friday, respectively.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Japanese drives from the north and south toward Suchow, the heart of the Chinese defenses on the Lung-Hai Railway front, were said last night to have gained momentum after southern columns battled their way across the River, about ninety miles from their goal.

The use of concrete instead of granite-block surfacing for the new section of the West Side elevated express highway from Canal Street to. Duane Street will save the city about $43,000, Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan announced yesterday.

THE chances are that unless you saw Russell Owen's review in yesterday's paper you have never heard the story of the Jeannette expedition. If you read "Hell.on Ice,"* you will never forget the story of the Jeannette expedition Commander Edward Ellsberg's new book, though a ghostwriting job, is that impressive.

Dr. Guy F. Cleghorn, a former president of the Medical Society of Nassau G County and for many years physician at the Nassau County jail and health officer of this village, died today at his home here of heart trouble. His age was 59.

Irving Swan Brown, a retired merchant who-had realty interests in New York and London, died yesterday at his residence, 137 East Fortieth Street, after a brief illness. He was born in Brooklyn sixty-seven years ago,
National Challenge Cup St. Louis South Sides 1, East St. Louis (III.) Burkes 0. National Amateur Cup Passaic Sport Friends 3, Sharkey Kellys 2. Brooklyn First Germans 1, German Hungarlans ??.

Fifteen-year-old Wilfred H. Van Fleet Jr., a member of Boy Scout Troop 47 here, who received the Eagle award, the highest in scouting, after an emergency operation for an intestinal complication on Wednesday lost his fight against death today.

Britain's revolutionary "Pickabackk" plane took off in mid-air for the first time today. The test-in which a plane was launched from the back of a larger one that had helped carry it into the air-was made from the water near Rochester.

Senator Copeland, chairman of the Commerce Committee, said today that Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime union leader, was a "menace to our welfare and should be deported." He told reporters that the further his committee investigated the activity of maritime labor, "the more we find evidence of communistic leadership."

If the whole modern world were Catholic, there would be no unsolvable moral and social problems, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, said in a sermon there yesterday morning.

With a net profit of $518,281, equal to 9.7 cents a share for the 5,362,699 shares outstanding, and a bullion production of $1,249,725 in 1937, the Kirkland Lake Gold Mining Company has ended the most successful year in its history. It treated 84,886 tons of ore for an average recovery of S14.72 a ton.
The British Government hopes to arrange an international patrol to guard Mediterranean shipping against attacks from the air like that operating against "pirate" submarines, it was learned tonight.

George Charette, retired United States Navy lieutenant and one of van the heroes of the sinking of the U. S. S. Merrimac at the entrance dor to Santiago Harbor, Cuba, in 1898, died early today at his home. His age was 70.

The fierce competition among colleges for tuition-playing students, as well as their exploitation of students, was sharply condemned by Dr. Walter A. Jessup, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, in the foundation's thirty-second annual report, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--Should President Roosevelt decide to spur recovery by some form of "pumppriming," as some of his close advisers are urging, he may support legislation for the construction of a transcontinental system of selfliquidating super-highways.

Larger than the United States in territorial area but with a population of only 45,000,000, Brazil considering lifting immigration barriers imposed by the constitutional amendment of 1934. This restricted immigration to 2 per cent of the foreigners who have settled here the past fifty years.

Into the drab pattern of the security markets is being woven one bright spot, the buoyancy of gilt-edge issues. The market for new gilt-edge offerings opened with spectacular success in the heavy oversubscription of the British Corporation ??2,000,000 loan, for which subscriptions amounted to [Pound]58,000,000.

The Harlingen Valley Morning Star moved tonight to publish tomorrow morning as about fifteen members of the striking Typographical Union picketed its building. The Valley Publishing Company's combined Sunday morning edition was printed here in skeletonized form last night.

Mrs. Frances Perrine Dix of 405 West Twenty-third Street, wife of Dr. Lester Dix, Professor of Education and principal of Lincoln School, Teachers College, Colum-bia, died yesterday morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia r Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs.

Unchallenged at any stage of the race, Miss Helene Rains, little 13year-old star of the Women's Swimming Association of New York, triumphed easily in the women's metropolitan junior 500-yard freestyle championship race in the Hotel Shelton pool yesterday.

Charles L. Richardson, connected with the United States Department of Labor, was killed and Major W. C. Goldsborough, an army flier of Langley Field, Va., was slightly injured when they bailed out of a Florida-bound plane nine miles from here today.

Nominations for the title "The American Mother of 1938" will be received by the Mothers Day committee of the Golden Rule Foundation, 60 East Forty-second Street, until midnight, March 31, it was announced yesterday.
Barton MacLane, who has been in so many Warner Class B's that he's begun to buzz when he talks, has found a solid role at last.

A few years ago Professor Enrico Fermi enriched the vocabulary of physics with the word "neutrino." Like the ether of yesteryear, the neutrino was a desperate necessity. Fermi, its creator, saw to it for scientific reasons that the neutrino could never possibly be discovered.

A fairly full attendance of legislators at, this week's sessions, despite an agreement to shelve all controversial legislation for the time being, was assured today when Speaker Heck sent telegrams to all Republican members of the Assembly requesting them to be in their seats tomorrow night, Tuesday and Wednesday.

If man does not make up his mind whether he will have a world of war or a world of peace, nature will step in and make up his mind for him, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in the morning sermon at Riverside Church.

On Feb. 14 the Foreign Policy Association will publish "War in China," by Varian Fry. Illustrated with twelve historical maps and four charts, the book tells the story of China from the fourteenth century to the present. The author, formerly editor of The Living Age, is now with Headline Books, a series of books on current political and economic problems published by the Foreign Policy Association.

After a week of increasing anxiety and tension the markets closed today in normal condition, although irregular and weak in.tone. The official embargo on publicity concerning the crisis in the government at first achieved its customary success and it was not until yesterday, and then owing mainly to foreign selling, that the Boerse experienced a bearish attack.

THE hold-out season in baseball has everybody guessing, including thousands of innocent bystanders. Only the income tax collectors go prying into the salaries or personal profits of citizens in other professions or industries, but in baseball the fans crave the crass details down to the last dollar.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago faltered momentarily but regained his stride and defeated Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in1 the Surf Club tennis final today. Kovacs, 18-year-old youngster, astonished spectators time and again by slashing back at Riggs and staging spectacular shots that held the national No. 2 player at a standstill.

The South American Development Company has removed all families, particularly Americans, from its mines, which the government has threatened to seize unless the company meets the increased production tax and pays it in advance.

Members of the alumnae association -of the Nightingale-Bamford School will give a concert the evening of Feb. 18 at the school, 20 East Ninety-second Street, to augment their scholarship fund. On the program will be Countess Margaret Seherr-Thoss, singer, and Henri Deering, pianist.
The Railroad Retirement Board, in its annual report today, offered advice from its own experience to guide the setting up of other public agencies to operate social insurance systems.

Preliminary estimates show that the Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production for January will be about the same as for December, when the index stood at 84 per cent of the 1923-25 average, according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin for February, made public today.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

The drug and toilet goods industries, which spend some $60,000,000 to $70,000,000 a year in newspapers, magazines and radio, have planned to increase their ad budgets this year, despite the current recession, according to an analysis of schedules of twenty large companies recently published.

The established precedent of having the welfare of the people on the conscience of the government will not be repealed whether a Republican, a conservative Bourbon Democrat or a New Dealer succeeds President Roosevelt, or whether President Roosevelt succeeds himself in 1940, Dr. Stanley High, former close adviser of President Roosevelt, said yesterday in an address at the Community Church meeting in Town Hall.

Except on Tuesday, when a slight recovery developed, the stock market here moved lower all week. The opening on Monday was irregular, with interest confined to building companies and Berlin real estate securities.
Germany's national soccer team disappointed a crowd of 80,000 fans who jammed the city stadium today by gaining only a 1-1 tie with Switzerland in an international match.

The Case National Bank has announced that North Boston Lighting Properties definitive secured notes, 3 1/2 per cent series due in 1947, are available for delivery in exchange for the temporary notes, at its corporate trust department, 11 Broad Street,
Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor department store, announced yesterday that the store had established four awards of $1,000 each for excellence in the field of goods designing.

The Comet Gallery, 10 East Fiftysecond Street, which began its career earlier in the season, continues to present to the New York public work by contemporary Italian painters. The present display embraces two one-man shows, made up respectively of oils by Carlo Carr. and Filippo de Pisis.

Recruits filled the places of arrested pickets in front of the White House and New Kriegel Hotels here today as rapidly as Toms River and Lakehurst constables, armed with John Doe warrants, arrested those participating in the picketing.

German industry in general is more quiet, but building and allied lines are making extensive preparations for the Reich's new construction programs. Bankruptcies numbered 179 in January, against 226 in the same month last year.

The Apawamis Club defeated the Ardsley County Club, 7 to 0, in a Metropolitan League, Westchester Division, squash racquets team match played on the losers' courts yesterday. In the No. 1 encounter J. Depew of Ardsley turned back F. M. Haines, 12-15, 17-18, 18-17, 18-17, 15-12.

The foreign exchange market was quieter this week and quotations were steadier. The franc was supported at the beginning of the week and fluctuated only slightly. On Wednesday and Thursday the tendency was again temporarily weak, but a moderate intervention was sufficient to arrest the decline and at the end of the period the franc showed resistance.

Andres Segovia, Spanish guitarist, who has developed a large following in this country because of his mastery of the instrument and his discriminating musicianship, gave his first recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
A son was born yesterday at Wesson Maternity Hospital, Springfield, to Mr. and Mrs. Churchill Francis of Westfield. The child was named Robert Talcott Francis 2d for his great-uncle in New York.

Nominations for the annual awards for distinguished service to the screen were announced today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Ten productions regarded as Hollywood's outstanding accomplishments of 1937 were named together with stars, supporting players, directors and their assistants, writers and song writers.

Legislation which may outrank in importance anything to be undertaken in Congress during the present session will be considered this week when both chambers take up the conference report on the "ever-normal granary" farm bill.

The role of medical science in any attempt to evolve a more exact criminal justice is much more limited than early promises made on its behalf have led many to expect, according to Professor George H. Dession of the Yale Law School.

A model of the mechanical plant of The Buffalo Evening News, reproducing every detail of the original on a scale of threeeights of an- inch to the foot, has been placed on view at the New York Museum of. Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,055,102,900. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

A few minutes after witnessing a demonstration project in forest fire fighting, fifty-five school boys and girls from New York City responded to an emergency call and helped quell a stubborn blaze near here.

William H. Alderson, bridge and structural engineer, died here last night. Mr. Alderson had been connected with engineering concerns in Chicago, New York and St. Paul. His widow, two sons and a daughter survive.

The working man today is "morally bound to organize" to maintain his individuality and obtain the fundamental necessities that God meant he should have because "only through organization" can he get those things, the Rev. John P. Monaghan, one of the founders of the labor college at Fordham University, declared yesterday.

The outlook for the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, who goes on trial before an emergency court here tomorrow charged with sedition, is very bad. The political events of the last three days have notably weakened his position as an opponent of the totalitarian regime.

Income was higher last year than in 1936 in every one of the geographical divisions of the United States, and in all the States save four and the District of Columbia, according to a detailed study made by the National Industrial Conference Board, which puts last year's figure for the country as a whole at $67,534,000,000, against $63,984,000,000 in 1936, a gain of 5.5 per cent.

Finance and industry are at present merely marking time. January's early improvement was considerable; but it started from a very low level at the year-end and, in the past week or two, recovery ceased.
Offering of a new issue of $475,000 City of Bartlesville, Okla., water plant bonds will be made today by the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, Wheelock Cummins, Inc., Des Moines, Iowa,

John Carson, consumers' counsel with the Bituminous Coal Commission, has reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission that bituminous coal consumers are paying "shocking and unconscionable" charges to the railroads.

The personal philosophy credited to Queen Victoria, "to do something worth doing," should be followed by us in making the world anew, the Right Rev. Joseph Wellington Hunkin, Lord Bishop of Truro, England, declared in a sermon yesterday at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

The turn of the month has brought out the customary abundance of cash. The day-loan rate declined to 2 3/4 to 3 per cent on Friday. Fundamentally, the market underwent a strain from the Reich loan flotation.

Supply contracts amounting to $8,502,489 were awarded by. fourteen Federal agencies in the week ended on Feb. 3, the Department of Labor has announced. The 107 awards were made under the Public Contracts Act.

Thousands of Catholics took part In the farewell demonstration this afternoon on the departure of the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, on the liner Northland for Miami.
Early this morning we had an opportunity to take a flight across the Gulf Stream to Bimini and Cat Cay, and we couldn't tear ourselves away.

Only five members of the St. Louis Browns have signed their 1938 contracts, the club disclosed tonight The latest two are Rookie Pitchers George Hennessey and Emil Bildilli. The others are Pitchers Buck Newsom and Jim Weaver and recruit Catcher Sam Harshany.
The body of Frederick W. Burgess, 21, of Cincinnati, a Harvard law student, was recovered today from the Charles River by the crew of a boat engaged in breaking ice. He disappeared in November.
The Federal Reserve Banks showed net earnings for 1937 of $10,801,247, compared with $8,513,000 in 1936, according to the Federal Reserve bulletin for February.

Insurance companies throughout the- State have shown a decided increase in business in the last year with the result that a "record high point of insurance" is expected to be reached by the end of 1938, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, declared in his annual report, made public here today.

Trading in oats futures was at a minimum last week, and the July and September deliveries were largely nominal. Closing trades were unchanged to 1/8 cent lower for the week, with May quoted yesterday at 31. 1/8 cents, July 29 cents and September 28 7/8 cents.

William Macy Joy, an electrical engineer associated with the Electric Bond and Share Company, New York, died here yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 305 Grove Street, at the age of 60. After graduating from Tufts in 1901, Mr. Joy entered the service of the Boston Elevated Railway Company, later working inTrinidad, B. W. I., and Puerto Rico, His widow, Violet Smith Joy, survives.

Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, criticized William Stanley Miller, president of the Tax Commission, yesterday for his contention, expressed in making public the 1938 assessment rolls, that "newspaper articles" indicate a revived spirit of optimism in the real estate market.

The ashes of Dexter P. Cooper, internationally famous engineer, were consigned to a sodden earth today in a little Anglican churchyard on a hillside overlooking Passamaquoddy Bay, which he had hoped to harness to man's use.

Four Russian scientists reported they were in extreme peril tonight as they frantically strove to prevent the tiny floe bearing their North Pole weather observation camp-from being crushed in an ice jam.

The celebration of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg was continued yesterday with special services and a discussion of Swedenborg's teachings at the New Swedenborgian Church, Thirty-fifth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

David Bauer of 3,072 Thirty-fourth Street, Long Island city, chief clerk of the mail order department of R. H. Macy Co., died Saturday of heart disease in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, after an illness of two months. He was a member of the Macy Twenty-five Year Club.

The Association of Veterans of the Philippine Revolution today approved a proposed trip by their leader, General Emilio Aguinaldo, to the United States later this year to ask the Washington government for immediate and complete independence.
Frank H. Ginn, corporation lawyer and bank and railroad director, died today at Lakeside Hospital, where he was taken three weeks ago for a rest. His age was 70.

Herman Van Putten of Paterson, N. J., representing the Continental Skating Club of Greenwood Lake, and Miss Helen Bahil of Elmhurst, L. I., Brooklyn Ice Palace representative, won the Southern New York speed skating championships in a field of 140 competitors today.

The New York Americans and Brooklyn Hispanos played to a 4-4 tie in a thrilling soccer game at Starlight Parc yesterday before a crowd of 6,000. In the preliminary contest Local No. 24 and Local No. 22 of the I.

Having completed his "second revolution," which firmly consolidated all the Third Reich's political and military power in his own hands, Adolf Hitler left Berlin today for his mountain retreat at Berchtesgaden.

The Union League Club at 38 East Thirty-seventh Street began a two-day celebration of its seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday afternoon with a reception for club members and their wives. Many women took advantage of the "open house" to inspect the sanctuary of male Republicanism.
Thrown and crushed beneath her horse in jumping a fence, Mrs. Julia P. Morris, wife of Effingham B. Morris Jr. of Plymouth Meeting, was killed today on Skippack Pike in Whitemarsh Valley.

The American note to Japan is a straightforward request for information which is of legitimate and urgent interest to this country. It can in no sense of the word be described as an "ultimatum." On the contrary,

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will move into their new home, the Chateau de la Maye at Versailles, tomorrow. A dozen servants in addition to four cooks are already installed. Inspectors from Scotland Yard have arrived and have conferred with the French police concerning measures to be taken to guard the chateau.

Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dillmeier gave a buffet supper at their home here tonight for their son, William E. Dillmeier; and Miss Doris Lane Laidlaw of New York, who will be married on Wednesday in Saint Patrick's Cathedral, New York.

Five men, four of whom described themselves as agents of the National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, were being held today by the Hudson County police in $3,000 bail on a charge of carrying a concealed and dangerous weapon.
The principal source of expansion in income for labor as well as other classes is technological progress and growth in productivity, Maurice Leven asserted in a book,

THE CAISSONS ROLL, by Hanson W. Baldwin. (Knopf, $2.50.) A military survey of Europe. HELL ON ICE, by Commander Edward Ellsberg. (Dodd, Mead, $2.75.) The story of an ill-fated Arctic expedition undertaken in 1879.

A fairly good export business was put through in domestic corn last week, sales in all positions exceedings 2,000,000 bushels, but the only market effect was to cause a rally of around 2 cents a bushel from the inside figures,

Warm weather continued to take the sting out of Winter yesterday as the temperature rose to the highest point since last Fall and to within 3 degrees of a record. Colder and cloudy weather is expected today.
Denying that the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes had made any request for jurisdiction over the Screen Actors Guild, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor,

The National League of Women Voters wants to amend the Constitution so as to make it easier to amend the Constitution. This is the first plank in a platform of nine objectives in Federal legislation which the league made public today, as a program for 19381940, in preparation for its biennial convention in St. Louis, April 25 to 29.
The Essex Club of Newark won New Jersey Class C division honors of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association in a play-off with the Englewood Field Club at the Montclair Athletic Club today, 3-2.

1st St, 52, 24.2x101; Cesare Interligi to Giuseppina Di Falco, 947 57th St, Brooklyn. 3d Ave, 100 26x100; Anson Realty Holding Corp to Grant William Anson, Inc, 100: 3d Ave, with theater equipment and fixtures included. 27th St. 418-20 W. 50x98.9; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, as trustee, to Isidore Edelstein, 138 E 36th St, as trustee for certificate holders.

In the opinion of the National Association of Manufacturers, the pending Borah-O'Mahoney bill providing for the Federal licensing of businesses, both corporate and non-corporate, initiates an unsound and unwise policy in further extending government control over private initiative.
Arthur Johnston, esilversmith, who was noted for his work in completing some of Paul Revere's unfinished work, died tonight at his home here after a brief illness. His age was 90.

Numerous celebrities of the English stage, elderly persons who remembered him and hundreds of others who know only his fame, joined today in celebrating the centenary of the birth of Sir Henry Irving. One of the most outstanding actors of the Victorian era, he was the first member of his profession to be knighted and is now buried in Westminster Abbey.

The marriage of Miss Helen Clafter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Clafter of Brooklyn, to Aaron Horovitz, Mayor of Cornwall, Ont., took place here last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ceremony was performed in the presence of the immediate families by the Rev. Dr. Samuel J. Levinson of Beth Emeth Temple in Brooklyn.

The beautiful Molyneux collection features slim, straight, very short daytime ensembles with new semi-fitted jackets, giving the effect of a bolero in front but sloping to the hipline in back. Other brief fitted Basque jackets have slight back flares.

David Altman, a former company manager for A. H. Woods, who had been associated recently with the Federal Theatre Project, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, of pneumonia, at the age of 68. He lived at 43-30 Fortysixth Street, Long Island City. As a young man, before entering the theatrical business,

The annual report of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, to be submitted- to the Legislature tomorrow, shows 877 first admissions of alcoholic cases to State hospitals, an increase of 51 per cent over the previous year.

Senator King, Utah Democrat, said today he would seek to include --in the tax-revision program broad provisions designed to encourage the investment of $10,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 of private capital. He declared that such a "potential business expansion" could be realized "if we will give business a chance."

The National Broadcasting Company yesterday brought to the United States a program originating at the base and inside the great pyramid of Cheops, believed to have been built about 4700 B. C., near Cairo, Egypt.

Mac Colville's neatly executed back-hand shot flew Into the cage in the closing minutes to give the New York Rangers a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A capacity crowd of more than 16,000 is expected to turn out at Madison Square Garden tonight for the annual Silver Skates derby, which will be presented under the direction of the News Welfare Association and the Middle Atlantic Skating Association.

The business building, containing nine stores, on a plot 123 by 106 feet, at Webster and Sickles Avenues, New Rochelle, N. Y., has been sold by Samuel J. Wood to an investor. It was held at $150,000 and was sold through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.
The Panama sprinter, Blacket, turned in the best performance of the Central American Olympics today when he equaled the world record of 0:10.3 to win his semi-final heat in the 100-meter dash.

Freeman St (11-3006), s s, 434 ft w of Westchester Ave, 100x1O0: 'Raimondo Ragazzi to Antonio Arcaro, 997 Jennings St; mtg $24,000. White Plains Rd (15-3923), w s, 347 ft n of Archer St, 40x90; Douglas Newman, referee, to Cornelia Vogel, 2,257' University Ave.

Mrs. Margaretta Fryer Wood, wife of Rear Admiral Samuel S. Wood, w U. S. N., retired, died tonight after ten days' illness from heart disease. Mrs. Wood, born in Albany, N. Y., had been a resident of of Washington for about thirty years. She formerly lived in Rhode Island and once was president of the Jamestown (R. I.) Garden Club.

A combination of an increasing birth rate and a decline in deaths made New York's health record for 1937 "outstandingly favorable," Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Division of Statistics of the State Health Department, announced today.

Attorney General Bennett will appear before the National Bituminous Coal Commission on Tuesday and urge immediate steps to correct prices which "now penalize New York consumers and place them at a disadvantage with competitors in near-by States," Governor Lehman announced today.

Home-relief allowances In this city, though higher than those prevailing in any other of the nation's ten largest cities, are 40 per cent below a maintenance standard of living and from 15 to 25 per cent below an emergency standard, the board of survey appointed by Mayor La Guardia last May to evaluate current relief policies and to point the way for a permanent welfare program says in a tentative draft of its final report.

Plans of the Standard Oil Company of California to pioneer a new oil field in the Coal Bay district of Southwestern Alaska are indicated in the assembly of a 500-ton cargo of drilling materials at San Pedro and San Francisco.

The Metropolitan Opera will present a Saturday evening cycle of Wagner's four works of "The Ring." The performances will take place as follows: Feb. 26, "Das Rheingold"; March 5, "Die Walkuere"; March 12, "Siegfried," and March 19, "Goetterdaemmerung." Artur Bodanzky will conduct all four works.

A petition signed by 477 persons prominent in religious, artistic and educational circles, urging President Roosevelt to protest against "the brutality of widespread Rebel bombings Of civilians in Spain," was made public yesterday by the Right Rev. Robert L. Paddock, Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, retired, who is chairman of the American Friends of Spaniah Democracy.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6.--James Roosevelt expressed "sincere hope" today that Senator Pepper of Florida would be returned to the Senate at the coming election. Mr. Pepper will be opposed by two candidates looked upon in political circles as formidable contenders-Representative J. Mark Wilcox and former Governor Dave Sholtz.

A German boxer dog, valued at $3,800, brought here by its owner, Mrs. Hosteter Young of Milwaukee, for the Westminster Dog Show that will open in Madison Square Garden Thursday, was reported missing to police last night by its trainer, Jack MacVeagh of 865 First Avenue.

Declaring "Mayor Hague of Jersey City could be sent to jail for life if the people will exert pressure on Trenton and Washington for an investigation of conditions in Jersey," William J. Carney, regional director of the New Jersey C. 0. O.

Trading in the cotton market here was narrow last week. The salient feature was watchful waiting for details of the Farm Control Bill. Despite the weakness in stocks and the unsatisfactory state of general market conditions,

If Wall Street continues in its present mood of disillusionment, equity securities here will remain depressed and investment funds will concentrate on gilt-edge securities as the only market with little risk of capital depreciation and reasonable prospects for appreciation.

New Yorkers won all five championships in the district open badminton competition today. Bill Markham captured the men's singles by defeating Wayne Sykes, 15-5, 15-7, and Mrs. Roy Bergman took the women's singles title by eliminating Miss Helen Gibson, 8-11. 11-4. 11-7.

The first bespectacled beauty contest on record was staged yesterday by the Community Opticians Association in an effort to prove that girls who wear glasses can be pretty lasses, and Mrs. Vera Georgia Parks, 23-year-old wife of an airline pilot, was adjudged the spectacle queen of the sweepstakes.

Disapproval of Senator Desmond's bill to create a Legislative Council of six Senators and six Assemblymen was expressed yesterday by the Committee on Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, of which William J. O'Shea Jr. is chairman.

The Hershey Bears went on a scoring spurt in the last period tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 6 to 2, and maintain their one-point lead over the New. York Rovers in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.

American sprinters always have been the fastest in the world and sprint records have been hammered down so far by constant pounding that only a superman can break one of them these days-tie them, yes, but break them, never. Never? Well, hardly ever.

Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Lawrence Ryan of Lawrence Park, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Ryan, to Norman Reginald Mac Evilla Prouty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Reginald Prouty, also of Bronxville, formerly of Scarsdale.
The wholesale price index on Jan. 25 was 105.5, unchanged from the week before. The living-cost index for January was 124.9, against 124.8 for December.

Mortimer R. Miller, insurance executive, clubman and prominent Republican, died tonight at his home after a three weeks' illness following a heart attack suffered in Miami. His age was 68. Mr. Miller, a close friend of the late George W. Aldridge, Monroe County Republican chief, was a leader in the first city manager campaign.

Special prayers of thanksgiving were offered for the new little royal Princess in Holland at the services yesterday morning in the French Church of the Holy Spirit, 229 East Sixty-first Street. The Rev. Dr. John. A. F. Maynard, rector, said the French Huguenots had a very warm place in their hearts for the royal family of The Netherlands.

Ivar Ballangrud, crack Norwegian skater, shattered the world record for 10,000 meters today to clinch the individual world ice-skating championship. His time of 17 minutes 14.4 seconds in the final event was 3 seconds under the previous mark, set by another Norwegian,

The money market was narrow at the start of the week because of end-of-the-month expansion of demand. Call money reached 3 per cent on Jan. 31, later returning to 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent, against 2 to 2 1/2 per cent at the beginning of January.

Paced by Billy Foales, who scored twelve goals, the 112th Field Artillery indoor polo team of Red Bank defeated the Essex Troop trio at the local armory today, 17 to 10. In a second match the Red Bank Polo Club triumphed over the Rangers, 15 to 12.

A New, mortgage for $72,500 was given by the Nemeloc Securities Corp., Stanley R. Jacobs, vice president, to the Savings Banks Trust Co. on the seven-story apartments on the southeast corner of Broadway and 102d St, and this has been consolidated with prior mortgages to form one lien for $272,500 thereon, the new mortgage being a building loan, due as per bond.
Racing down the serpentine Thunderbolt Trail on the northeast slope of Mount Greylock, Fritz Dehmel of the German Universities ski team captured the Eastern amateur downhill championship today.

A new biography ofAbraham Lincoln, based on letters and papers collected by his law partner, William H. Herndon, and purporting to reveal many new facts about the Civil War President's parentage, health, courtship, early life,
The St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn and Philadelphia Germans, paired in the third round of the National Cup series, clashed yesterday in an American Soccer League fixture at Celtic Park, Brooklyn.
The Chicago Bears, underdogs in several contests with the world-champion Redskins, finally beat the Washington team, 16 to 10, today in a professional football game enlivened by several fist fights.

Babies whose diets prescribe certified milk are being supplied by 151 certified milk farms in the United States, Edwin P. Brown, field representative and inspector, reported yesterday at the fourmonthly meeting of the Metropolitan Milk Producers, Inc., in session at the Hotel Roosevelt.

By his apparent decision against submitting his new made-to-order Constitution to a plebiscite in the near future and other steps in which he has offended practically every element hitherto important in the country's internal politics, President Getulio Vargas has placed a new emphasis on the army and navy in his extended regime in Brazil.

National Zionist leaders paid tribNational Zionist leaders paid tribute last night to Mordecai Konowitz, president of the Long Island Zionist Region, at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore. More than 600 persons attended the function, which was the first annual dinner of the Long Island unit.

The new chancellor of Vanderbilt University, in putting on his administrative armor last week, paid highest homage to hint whom he succeeded in command-Dr. James H. Kirkland, seven years a Professor of Latin and forty-four years its chancellor.

The declarations of policy made by Finance Minister Marchandeau at the beginning of the week made a good impression in financial circles. It is now known that the government does not propose to change its monetary policy nor that concerning control of exchange.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 6.--Crews from two Coast Guard cutters, working with grappling irons and floodlights in the fog-bound Hudson River, were attempting tonight to solve the mystery of the submerged airplane that plunged into the ice-clogged water last night. It is believed that a pilot was the only one aboard.
The Irish-Americans gained a 2-to-O victory over the Baltimore F. C. in an American Soccer League match at Clark's Field today. The line-up:

A move to get the City Council to memorialize the Legislature to enact the pending bills to place the 4,500 employes of the city's Independent Subway System under the collective bargaining provisions of the State Labor Relations Law has been started by Councilman Michael J. Quill.

Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade last week averaged less than 19,000,000 bushels a day, or about half the volume in the same period in 1937. For January sales averaged 27,700,000 bushels a day, compared with 28,056,000 in December and with 42,500,000 in January, 1937.

A panoramic display of the latest developments of radio art and industry has been added to the list of proposed exhibits for the 1939 World's Fair, according to a joint announcement yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of Amrerica, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Study of the dinner conversations of Jesus to get a new grasp on life was urged yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
A new regulation relating to importation of whisky, brandy and rum will become effective April 1, it was disclosed today in an order in council published in The Canada Gazette.

Preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Mines indicate that smelter production of copper from domestic ores in 1937 was 843,500 short tons; production of refined lead, 435,500 tons, and the output of metallic zinc, 550,200 tons.

The advance in cotton last week put prices at approximately the highest levels since the recovery from their extreme lows in October. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances last week of 21 to 27 points.
British Consul General in New York from 1919 until Jan. 17, 1931, died of pneumonia this morning at the home of his son, Captain Thaddeus G. Armstrong, at 3 Longview Road here. He was 77 years old.

Subway art, American Colonial portraits and work by contemporary Mexican artists are among the attractions on the roster of the current week's exhibitions. Openings today include an exhibition of Colonial portraits at the Milch Galleries:

The necessity of giving more aid to victims of past infantile paralysis epidemics who are striving to overcome their handicaps is stressed by Robert E. Blum in a report made public yesterday on the work of the Bureau Mailing Service, maintained by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities and manned by crippled workers.

The marriage of Miss Pamela Crawford, daughter of Professor Jack Crandall Crawford of Yale University and Mrs. Crawford, to Richard Vincent Holahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Holahan of Darien, will take place on March 4 in the Church of Our Lady of Pompeii.
The Chain Belt Company operated at a profit of $743,834 in 1937, compared with $630,899 in 1936, the annual report, issued today, discloses.

Twenty-five sailing dingies had a race in blind navigation today at the, regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. After three class events had been held, a fog spread over Long Island Sound. The 12-foot craft do not carry sextants, or even compasses.

A meeting of Japanese naval officials yesterday was reported by the press to have decided to keep Japan's construction plans secret. One account, however, said they might make the disclosure in an "independent" way to allay suspicion abroad.
The Federal Trade Commission has announced that Sears, Roebuck Co. of Chicago have stipulated to desist from certain "misleading uses" of the words "Hudson seal."
Luis J. Francke, retired Havana sugar merchant, died at his home, Ferncote, this morning, of a heart ailment, following a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

Federal Trade Commission hearings scheduled at 45 Broadway, New York, this week have been announced as follows: Monday-Dermay Perfumers, Inc., alleged misrepresentations of products; Lynx Knitting Company, alleged unfair methods of competition.

From his sickbed Governor Blanton Winship tonight sent word that negotiations looking to an end of the stevedore strike, now at the conclusion of its fifth week, were being continued and that he had not lost hope of a successful outcome.

Mrs. George Platt Brett of Fairfield, Conn., and New York, who is passing the season at Journey's End, her Coconut Grove estate, was among the luncheon guests of Mrs. Andre Richmers at the Surf Club today.

Vincent J. Buzzard, 20 years old, of 80 West Grand Street, and Stephen Cotellis, 17, of 673 Locust Street, both of this city, -were killed instantly early this morning when Buzzard's roadster mounted a curb and turned over three times at North Seventh Avenue and Putnam Street here.

William Leader, president of Branch Number 1 of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, resigned today as president of the Philadelphia C. I. O. council. The surprise move was viewed in labor circles as putting an end, temporarily at least, to a split in C. I. O. ranks, due to differences between Mr. Leader,

An ex-convict and a young woman, each the parent of two children, were found murdered shortly after 11 A. M. yesterday in the rear of a sedan parked outside a fashionable six-story apartment house at 9,269 Shore Road, Brooklyn.
The slowing down of trade activity in Great Britain continues at a moderate rate, but in this it is not an isolated instance in the world. International trade, after expanding early in 1936,
Pablo Casals, world-famous 'cellist and conductor, has returned to his Barcelona home from a concert tour. He denies Insurgent reports that he fled Barcelona with his family.

J. J. Van Gonsic broke 99 out of 100 targets for high gun honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. E. J. Zeiner defeated F. A. Cauchois Jr. for the Class A handicap trophy. In Class B, W. Black, G. F. Terpenning and M. J. Cushman finished on even terms.

Shall subsidized low-cost housing be built in large units on reclaimed Slum land near the center of town or in small units on cheaper land on the edge of town? This question was raised last week by United States Housing Administrator Nathan Straus.

Jose R. de Capriles, national outdoor epee champion, representing the Salle Santelli, gave every indication that he is off on another successful campaign when he proved best of a star field yesterday to carry off the metropolitan open individual epee title on the strips of the Fencers Club.
The Panzer College jayvee women's basketball team defeated the Morris County Junior College girls tonight, 59--. Miss Helen Mattey was high scorer with 18 points.

Two vacant chairs on the Supreme Court bench today, showed that the Electric Bond and Share challenge of the registration provisions of the 1935 Public Utility Holding Company Act would be tried and decided by seven justices instead of the usual nine

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial on Justice Black's dissent apropos corporations and the Fourteenth Amendment missed his point. His attack was not, as you stated, on the legal concept that corporations are judicial persons but on the Supreme Court's interpretation that the word "person" as there used includes corporations.

Lady Violet Mary Astor of London and her son, George Mercer Nairne, left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for Santa Barbara, where Mr. Mercer Nairne will marry Miss Barbara Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stuart Chase; on March 18.

Tubercular patients at Seton Hospital will be aided by the proceeds of a luncheon and bridge to be given by members of the Edwina Club on Feb. 26 at the Franklin Towers, 333 West Eighty-sixth Street. Miss Elizabeth Alexander is president of the club.

Shipments of steel office furniture in December, 1937, totaled $2,125,222, compared with $2,112,972 in December, 1936, according to figures just issued by the Bureau of the Census. Shipments for 1937 amounted to $26,973,332, against $19,245,935.

Four women were injured and several others shaken up when the Central Railroad of New Jersey ferryboat Red Bank, inbound from New York, crashed into its slip at the foot of Johnston Avenue here early today.
Following last week's improve- 3 ment, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to losses of 2 to 7 points as a result of lower quotations abroad and a dedine in the stock market.

MOSCOW, Feb.7.--The first official comment on the German reorganization published in, today's Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, takes the somewhat facile view that the changes "indicate grave internal contradictions in the Nazi regime" and ends on a note that doubtless will be gratifying to Pravda's readers:

Georgetown conquered West Virginia, an an overtime Eastern Conference basketball game tonight, 40 to 36. Goals by Ed Kurtyka and John Frank decided. Petroskey, Georgetown center, was high scorer with 13 points.

Miss Virginia Randolph of Greenwich, Conn., and Herman Henry Ridder of St. Paul, Minn., who will be married on Friday, were guests of honor last night at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Riddeir and Oscar B. Huffman in the Rowman Boom of the Biltomore.

Frank Brossart, 59 years old, an unemployed veteran of the SpanishAmerican War now on a pension of $50 a month, was held at the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital last night when, after shouting that he intended to end his life, he pulled a loaded revolver from his pocket in the hospital and fired two shots.

Henry Clay Lippincott, an insurance expert, died at his home in Woodstown, N. J., today at the age of 93. Mr. Lippincott wrote a book on insurance, "The How and the Why," which was used widely as a college textbook and of which more than 1,000,000 copies were sold, and he served forty-eight years with the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company.

Mayor La Guardia, speaking last night before a group of "honor men," drivers for the North Shore Bus Company, who received citations for safe driving throughout the year, disclosed that Manhattan soon would have ten more "express" streets to supplement-the ten midtown streets on which daytime parking is now prohibited.

President Roosevelt was represented by participants in a White House conference of thirty-one left-wing members of the House today as anxious to work out a permanent spending program in which the test applied to construction projects would be their self-liquidating character.
DANSVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP).--Dr. Benjamin P. Andrews, once personal physician to Miss Clara Barton, founder of the American Red Cross, died here today at the age of 81.
DRY GUILLOTINE, by Rene Belbenoit. (Dutton, $3.) The story of a man who lived through fifteen years on Devil's Island. GREAT BRITAIN AND PALESTINE, by Herbert Sidebotham. (Macmillan, $4.) A survey.

Construction of a new city prison in Brooklyn on the same block as the Central Courts Building, Smith and Schermerhorn Streets, was recommended to the February Kings County grand jury yesterday by Judge Franklin Taylor as he administered the oath of office.
The annual report of the United States Tobacco Company for 1937, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $3,462,687 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and $303,235 flood loss.
Senator Copeland proposed tonight a broad investigation into "subversive activities at sea," to be conducted by a special Senate committee financed with $25,000.

Two retired Presbyterian missionaries died here within the last two days. They were Mrs. Alice Holstein May Castle Fenn, wife of the Rev. Dr. Courtenay Hughes Fenn, former secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions; and the Rev. Frederick S. Curtis.

Henry St, 26: to 5-story tenement: Sylvia Weintrub, 508 4th Ave. Brooklyn, owner; J. J. Gloster, architect: cost, $4,800. 50th St, 442 W: to 5-story tenement: 442 W 50th St Corp, 129 W 65th St, owner; same architect; cost, $4,000.
Mail orders for Spring merchandise received in the local markets yesterday were numerous but individual requests were limited, in size, manufacturers and resident offices reported.

Honored Palmer Jr., 28-year-old son of Honore Palmer, and grandson of the late Potter Palmer of Chicago, died here yesterday at noon, after a brief illness, at his residence, 244 East Fifty-first Street.

Frederic Ernst, newly elected Associate Superintendent of Schools, has been assigned to head the high school division, succeeding the late Associate Superintendent John S. Roberts, it was announced yesterday.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3883-Ex part Clyde L. Chamberlin. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The decision of the Board of Appeals affirmed. 3871-Ex part Louis J. Eppinger. Opinion by Judge Bland. The decision of the Board of Appeals affirmed.
Thirteen persons died in a crash of the Russian dirigible V-6, preparing for a flight to the rescue of four Russian scientists adrift on an ice floe in the Greenland Sea, it became known today.

A million dollar damage suit brought by Jackson Bell Company, Ltd., radio manufacturers, accusing two companies of entering an agreement to monopolize the loud speaker business, was reinstated today by the Federal Court of Appeals.
The Treasury's ninety-one-day bills were sold today at an average price of 0.080 per cent, compared with 0.084 last week and 0.103 per cent the week before, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.
Counsel for Alphonse Capone appealed to the Supreme Court today in an effort to bring the Chicago gangster out of his involuntary retirement next Jan. 19.

The plan of reorganization for the Chicago North Western Railway Company proposed by the mutual savings bank and life insurance groups and the data substantiating that plan, establish that the equity of the stockholders of the railroad has no value, according to a memorandum filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Bank of New York and Trust Company, as trustee of the Milwaukee, Sparta North Western Railway mortgage.

Long Sing Sing sentences were imposed yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions on four robbers, who in a period of seven weeks perpetrated about forty hold-ups of business establishments in Harlem and the Bronx.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a decision handed down yesterday, indicated that there was serious doubt in the minds of its members as to whether wiretapping of any nature, either in interstate or Intrastate communications, was admissible as evidence in a Federal court, under the recent ruling of the Supreme Court in the Nardone case.

Creation of a State board that would guide and control local government finance in New Jersey is proposed in a bill prepared by the Princeton Local Government Survey for introduction in the Legislature on Wednesday.

The 1,378 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,910,357,663 par valife as of Feb. 1, had a total market value of $42,486,316,399, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Jan. 1, there were 1,37' issues, with a total market value of $47,694,471,418.

Several dinners were given 'this evening in the Palm Beach colony. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton of New York were hosts to a large party at the Everglades Club, where the Earl of Dalhousie and Captain A. D. Crabbe of Scotland and Paul Hyde Bonner of Rye, N. Y. arrived today.

Frederick W. Walker, a former member of the Roselle Borough Council and for more than fifteen years a mnember of the Union County Republican Committee, died today at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth.

Morris Trichon Company today was awarded the army contract for 500,000 pairs of cotton drawers for the Civilian Conservation Corps. Their bid was on five 100,000 lots at the following prices: 19.5, 19.75, 20, 20.5 and 21 cents per pair, less one-tenth of 1 per cent 20 days.

Louis Palermo, a henchman of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, racketeer who is serving a two-year term in prison for violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in the fresh water fish industry, failed yesterday in an attempt to change a plea of guilty he entered two years ago.

The Fifth Avenue Association sent a letter yesterday to the merchants and property owners on Fifty-seventh' Street requesting that they assist in correcting conditions which the association declares threaten to destroy the street's character as a "high-class shopping thoroughfare."
The dollar continued weak against the principal foreign currencies in the local market yesterday, although the volume of business dropped considerably over the daily average registered last week.

A couple of years after Broadway saw his last play, Robert Ardrey steps forth tonight with "How to Get Tough About It," the first of two Ardrey dramas to be unveiled this month. ("Casey Jones" is the other.) This evening's events,

Norfolk House, last of the ducal mansions in St. James's Square-once the hub of fashionable London-echoed to the sound of the auctioneer's hammer today as Christies began a threeday sale of its furnishings.

The Queens unit of the Petroleum Dealers Chamber of Commerce and affiliated organizations representing independent gasoline filling station owners of the borough, meeting last night at the New Yorker ballroom, 149-01 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, subscribed to a resolution under which they will join in a "gasless holiday" on Feb. 15.

The Eureka Mining and Milling Company, Seattle, Wash., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 109,112 shares of $1-par value common stock to be offered at a minimum of $1 a share.
The international stock market indices for Feb. 5, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927;

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Feb. 3 was 256, against 321 in the week previous and 184 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

A mysterious theft of jewelry valued at $150,000 from Mrs. Philip Hill, wife of a British financier, at Palm Beach, Fla., was made known here yesterday as detectives were asked to join in a widespread hunt for the perpetrators.

Establishing a new course record for the revamped layout, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., who last year captured the Ormond Beach and St. Augustine classics, led a select field in the qualifying round for the Palm Beach women's golf championship today with a card of 36, 37-73, two under women's par.
The District of Columbia Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction last March of Dr. Francis E. Townsend on a charge of contempt of the House. contempt of the House.
Two army airplanes collided at an altitude of 5,000 feet near here today. One pilot parachuted to safety and the other landed his plane undamaged.

As a member of the American Legion, Mayor La Guardia was appointed a committee of one yesterday by Jeremiah F. Cross, State commander of the Legion, to demand the removal of Simon W. Gerson, Communist writer, who is assistant to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan.
Oswald Dirmoser, university professor and engineer who constructed the "Big Bertha" cannon of World War fame, died today. He was 63 years old.

Tildord E. Dudley, trial examiner in the National Labor Relations Board's hearing on charges of unfair labor practices brought against the Ford Motor Company, modified today his recent ruling limiting defense testimony.

Richard Woodmansie Jones, retired civil engineer and former chief of the Topographical Division, Bureau of Highways, Borough of Brooklyn, died on Sunday in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn, afta brief illness. Mr. Jones lived at 51 Van Siclen Avenue, Brooklyn.

Allen B. Underhill has been elected president of the J. E. Mergott Company, manufacturers of handbag frames, succeeding William E. Howell, who has resigned. Mr. Underhill was formerly New York sales manager, a post which has been taken over by William L. Allen.

Miss Margaret Waller, 35 years old, a nurse of Beth Moses Hospital in Brooklyn, was arrested last night charged with beating and seriously injuring another nurse of the hospital, Miss Sylvia Barbre, also 35, after an argument.

A tea will be given by members of the New York branch of St. Margaret's Alumnae Association of St. Margaret's School, Waterbury, Conn., on Feb. 19 at the Barclay. Miss Alberta C. Edell, principal of the school, will address the alumnae nn the school's scholarship fund.

Dr. Francis G. Pease, pioneer Mount Wilson astronomer and the first man to measure the diameter of a star, died today at St. Luke's Hospital, Pasadena, after a week's illness. His age was 57. He underwent an intestinal operation on Feb. 1.
The United Mine Workers' executive board has ordered that in addition to regular dues a one-dollar special assessment be collected this month and another in March from all members.

As a means of quieting the unrest and averting possible revolutionary uprisings among dissatisfied nationals in Northeastern Mexico, President Lazaro Cardenas has issued an order that all work on public projects be offered to all unemployed in the State of Tamaulipas.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for December, 1937, issued yesterday, shows net operating income of $1,018,127, compared with $4,058,212 in December, 1936, a drop of $3,040,085, or approximately 75 per cent.

Word has been received from Rome that John J. Morris of 314 West Eighteenth Street has been knighted for his work among youth in the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre by Pope Pius XI. In 1931 he was decorated with the Grand Cross "pro ecclesia et Pontifice."

The ice-jammed Mohawk River, swollen by recent rains and thawing temperatures, poured over its banks today, flooding farm lands and cities for miles along its turbulent course and leaving this city of 34,000 without gas service.

Patrolman Royal W. Pollitt, who was wounded Jan. 28 when he and Sergeant David Kilpatrick engaged five bandits in a pistol battle during which the latter was killed, was promoted yesterday to the rank of third-grade detective, it was announced by Second Deputy Commissioner John A. Lyons.

Fifty candidates for Manhattan's varsity crew reported for the first indoor practice yesterday at the new rowing-room in the basement of George Smith Auditorium. Coach Allen Walz found his squad one of the lightest in the short history of the crew at Manhattan, many of the men having been members of the 150-pound boats last season.
Diligent research 'fails to disclose who won the foursome in which Bobby Jones played at Macon, Ga., on the afternoon of Feb. 3.

The stock market here was generally quiet today, with business somewhat restricted by the political news from the European Continent. Transatlantic stocks opened better following the week-end improvement in Wall Street and they maintained their strength well during the day. Goltedge issues, after early firmness, became dull, while among the foreign bonds German loans sagged.

A temporary exchange of young advertising writers between the United States and Great Britain in the same manner in which scholars and students are now exchanged was proposed yesterday by Sir Charles F. Higham, British adver- c timsing executive and publicist.

The City A. C. clinched the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis championship yesterday and succeeded as titleholder the unbeaten Princeton Club combination of a year ago. The City players turned back the Columbia Club, 4 to 1, to gain the crown.
Bob Pastor of New York won a tenround decision over Al Ettore of Philadelphia tonight before a crowd of 8,000. Pastor weighed 183 pounds and Ettore 194.
Announcement of plans for two conferencetours to foreign countries this year was made today by the committee on the church and cooperatives of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Jan Kiepura, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, Fifth Ave and 58th St. Patrick Hennessy, John J. Bergen, Charles C. Wright, M. Paul Leroy-Beaulieu, Sheldon Coons, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agent.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dymond Gregory of Oakville, Ont., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Lovell Gregory, to William Dunn Richmond, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Walker of Dongan Hills, S. I., and the late Stacy Courtis Richmond of this city.

Money in circulation, at the end of January amounted to $6,320,187,303 compared to $6,550,274,478 at the end of December and $6,348,671,241 at the end of January a year ago, the Treasury announced today in preliminary figures.

Precisely at 7:45 o'clock on almost every opera night a heavy set man in late middle life steps past the ticket taker at the Fortieth Street entrance to the Metropolitan, walks toward the opposite wall of the foyer, touches it with his hand and counts off twelve paces to his left. This brings him to Exit 76.

President Roosevelt, in a message of congratulation to the Boy Scouts of America, broadcast over the networks of the National Broadcasting Company, Columbia Broadcasting System and the Mutual System, said tonight that the greatest assurance of maintaining our democratic institutions

Mrs. Kate Wasserscheid of Bedford, former county recreation executive, became the first woman juror and jury foreman today in the Supreme Court of Westchester County when she was chosen to hear a $10,000 suit involving a headon crash of two automobiles.

UN CAPRICE and FANTASIO. Comedies of one and two acts respectively by Alfred de Musset Produced by Le Theatre des Quatre Saisons under the auspices of the French Theatre of New York and directed by MM. Daste and Barsacq. At the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre.

The American Labor party is considering introduction in the Legislature of an amendment to the Rogers-Allen Act to give the farmers the right to set up bargaining agencies to negotiate milk prices with the distributing companies, Alex Rose, State executive secretary, announced yesterday.

In the event of war in the Pacific, or in any other part of the world, the United 'States. Navy has no understanding involving "assistance to be given or received," and has no thought of obtaining assistance from any other nation, in the event of war with any nation in the world, Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

Work by fifteen contemporary Mexican artists was placed on view yesterday at the Valentine- Gallery and will continue to be shown until Feb. 19. While such well-known painters as Orozco and Rivera and Covarrubias are included, it is interesting to find so many quite unfamiliar Mexicans.
James F. Gilday, former assistant chief accountant of the WaldorfAstoria, has been appointed assistant manager to replace William Gaudenzi, who recently resigned.

Art as well as a subway ride for the five-cent fare may be the ultimate outcome of an exhibition of "Subway Art," which will be opened to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Fortyninth Street.

Puerto Rico spent $90,043,856 last year for goods produced in the Continental United States, according to the Puerto Rican Trade Council. This represented a gain of 4.3 per cent above the 1936 total and 18.5 per cent more than that in 1929.

With what was described as good prospect for an accord, officials of the United States Steel Corporation and a committee representing the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, met yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore to negotiate a new agreement.
Governor Lehman submitted to the Legislature tonight his supplemental budget, totaling $284,156.01, the smallest in recent years.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, seeking her third straight crown, made an impressive start today as. play in the eleventh annual national squash racquets championship tourney beganon the Harvard Club courts.
It was Learned today that within a few days Governor Moore will replace 11 five members of the State Milk Control Board. Members of the board serve at the pleasure of the Executive.

The steel industry produced 260,000 gross tons more steel in January than in December, while the automobile industry produced 123,786 fewer cars and trucks, indicating a gain of 17.7 per cent for steel and a decline of 36 per cent for automobiles.
