Tommy doesn't know it yet, but another Tommy has claimed the title of the nation's oldest cat, almost on the eve of his twenty-third birthday.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 2; decreases of $44,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities and $11,000,000 in holdings of United States direct obligations,

While Chancellor Adolf Hitler is pondering at appear as his Berchtesgaden mountain home the outlines of the speech he will deliver before the Reichstag on Feb. 20, the government in Berlin issued today a semi-official communique refuting some of the rumors circulating in foreign capitals in connection with the recent upheaval.
Trading in city realty reported yesterday by brokers dealt principally with residential properties in three boroughs.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 5: COLONELS Smith, 9. D., Cav., Hot Springs National Park, Ark., to Walter Reed General Hospital, Washington, D. C., for further observation and treatment.

Taxaction for revenue only, and not punitive taxation, was urged as one of the fundamental principles in any solution of present economic difficulties by Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., in an address here today.

The blue-ribbon jurors were chosen yesterday at the perjury trial of William W. Kleinman, former assistant district attorney of Brooklyn. The trial will be resumed today in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Erskine C. Rogers.

Miss Mary Lannon of 75 Park Terrace, West, Manhattan, aunt of the Rev. Michael A. McGuire, chaplain of St. Joseph's in Peekskill, N. Y., died last night in the Brunswick Hospital, Amityville, L. I., of a stroke suffered eight days ago. She was 70 years old. Among other

In a radio address discussing the sixteen trade treaties which he has negotiated, Secretary Hull argues again that there is "no greater fallacy" than the belief that a nation can prosper in a self-contained economy, behind a prohibitive tariff wall.

Bids which more than twenty companies submitted today to supply the goVernment's tire and tube requirements for the six-month period ended on Sept. 30 varied widely, whereas almost identical bids had been quoted at the last bid-taking on Sept. 20.

Once more pressure has developed for a great Federal spending program "to pull us out of the depression." The pressure comes from various sources, but these may be divided broadly into two main groups, who may be labeled respectively the naive spenders and the sophisticated spenders.

A scheduled interview with Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens of New York by Loy W. Henderson, charge d'affaires of the United States Embassy, was postponed today while Soviet authorities completed arrangements as to the time and place.
We have not yet seen the end of the conflict between the German Army and the National Socialist party, and startling developments are perhaps in store for us in the near future.

An appeal by six limestone quarryoperators from an order by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews to use "only approved dust control equipment and methods" in drilling silica bearing rock will be heard Thursday by the State Board of Standards and Appeals in Albany.

A wealthy woman who "won't be inconvenienced" by going to her safe-deposit box more than once in five years has failed to clip bond coupons entitling her to $46,000 interest from New Rochelle, Director of Finance Walter J. Brennan said today.

The sixteenth annual exhibition of the Fifty Books of the Year, selected by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, was opened last night at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The show will be open to the public today and continue through March 7.

Mrs. Amy Johnson Mollison received today a decree nisi of divorce from James A. Mollison. The Australian airman entered no defense in the suit which was based on Mrs. Mollison's allegation of adultery. She testified she discovered her husband's infidelity "after his return from America."

With the operating rate for this week virtually unchanged at 30.7 per cent of ingot capacity, compared to 30.5 per cent last week, the steel industry was reportedyesterday to have produced 1,732,266 gross tons of steel in January, against 1;472,241 tons in December, a gain of 260,000 tons, and compared to 4,724,894 tons produced in January, 1937, a decline of nearly 3,000,000 tons.

An unprecedented admission of serious indiscipline in certain contingents of the Japanese Army operating in the Yangtze Valley was contained in a formal address delivered to his own commanders by General Iwane Matsui. Commander in Chief,

Japanese officials disclaimed responsibility today for the report that the navy must on occasion voluntarily furnish information on its building plans. All that a navy official had to say was that the Japanese policy had been clearly stated to London and that no reason had been shown to change it.

If the United States is to avoid communism, the Jews in this country must be driven from their high posts in government, finance and education, as they have been in certain European countries, Fritz Kuhn of New York, national leader of the German-American Bund, declared here tonight.

The engagement of Miss Suzanne Cort, daughter of Mrs. Harry Lindsley Cort of 102 East Twenty-second Street and the late Mr. Cort, to John Walter Wood, son of Mrs. J. Walter Wood, also of this city, and the late Mr. Wood, has been announced by her mother.
Discovery II, the British research ship that rescued Lincoln Ellsworth, American explorer, in the Antarctic in, 1936, sailed today for a voyage around the South Pole.
Under a rule approved today by the Rules Committee the crop control conference report will go to the House tomorrow to be "voted up or down" in about five hours.

Mr. and Mrs. John Jay McKelvey of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise McKelvey, to John Livingston Holsapple of New York, son of Frank B. Holsapple of Hudson, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Louise Livingston HolsanDle.
Gordie Drillon's place at the head of the National Hockey League marksmen remained unchallenged tonight after another week of sharpshooting that added three points to his margin.

Quimby Ave (14-3687), a w cor of Castle-Hill Ave, 80x37; William J. Seifert to Castle Hill Quimby Avenue Realty Corp. 110 E 42d St; mtg $27,000. Allerton Ave (16-4518). n s, 25 e of Paulding Ave. 75x100; James C. Healy, referee, to Bronx Savings Bank, 429 E Tremont Ave.

The National Maritime Union published - yesterday the report of a special committee that has studied the disciplinary action taken by American crews against their own members on ships operating from the Atlantic Coast, in an effort to maintain efficiency at sea.

Sixteen trim sailing craft rode at anchor tonight, everything shipshape for the start tomorrow of the fifth annual Miami-Nassau yacht race. Conjecture centered on who would skipper Stormy Weather, last year's winner, owned by Robert W. Johnson of New York.

Answering a protest yesterday on the "appointment of Matthew M. Wild as a city magistrate" Mayor La Guardia said he had not made any such appointment and cited the protest as an example of how protesters acted without rhyme or reason.

As the Senate filibuster against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill became a month old today, Senate leaders received assurance that the filibuster sponsors would give way to permit consideration of the Farm Bill conference report later this week.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit at Chicago had-affirmed a lower court decree enjoining R. J. Koeppe Co. and Robert J. Koeppe from manipulating the prices of stocks of the Paducah Cooperage Company, Inc., and the Wahl Company on the Chicago Stock and Curb Exchanges.

Most Italian newspapers, particularly the Tribuna, today carry extremely optimistic London dispatches reporting a complete change in the tone toward Italy on the part of the British press and expressing the hope that the long-delayed Italo-British negotiations may at last be begun.
Max Baer bounced into town yesterday a different man from the fighter on whom were showered so many play-boy titles, and bounced right out again.

Once again Madison Square Gardent was transformed into a Winter sports arena for the fourteenth annual Silver Skates carnival last night. A crowd -of 14,894 persons was delighted by the scenic beauty produced by artificial igloos and papier-mache icicles under powerful floodlights.
The annual report of Central States Electric Corporation for 1937 shows total assets of $46,720,225, compared with $47,482,722 at the end of 1936.

Former Governor Harold G. Hoffman bf New Jersey was the guest of honor last night at a birthday party tendered by some 1,800 members of the "H. G. A. Birthday Club," an organization which came into existence seven years ago and has given an annual dinner in honor of the New _Jersey leader each year since.

THIS is to lodge a loud complaint against the general conduct of this hockey campaign. It's too one-sided. Mr. Conn Smythe is having all the fun. He's been having most of the fun for years, too. It's lucky for him that he is a Canadian or somebody in the Attorney General's office in Washington, D. C., would prosecute him as a monopoly.

William J. Graham, gambler of Reno, Nev., testified yesterday in his trial for mail fraud and conspiracy, before Justice Willis Van Devanter and a jury in Federal Court, that he had never helped confidence men swindle victims,
Settlement of the long-defaulted public works obligations was approved this morning by the House of Representatives, following an all-night session, with a vote of 137 to 13.

The Bees today received the signed. contract of Vince DiMaggio, center fielder, and brother of holdout Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees. In a letter announced by John.Quinn, Bees' secretary, Vince said he had not been holding. out himself and added he was "satisfied with the contract and wish you a good season."

Jim McMillen, 225, Chicago, pinned Sammy. Stein, 220, New York, in 37:59 of the feature bout to a finish last night at the New York Hippodronie before a crowd of 2,000. The winner triumphed with a body press, following a head-on collision.
" Miss X" of the British counter-espionage service today finished her story of springing the trap on four men accaused as arms plans thieves during a lightning appearance in Bow Street Police Court.

John M. Johnnidis, as president of European Restaurant, Inc., has leased the two three-story buildings at 149-51 East Fifty-seventh Street, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., from the Riker Estate and the Inch Corporation.
The Senate, by a vote of 44 to 4, tonight adopted resolutions proposing three amendments to the State Constitution, which are part of Governor Lehman's slum clearance and housing program.

THE time is fifty years hence, and Hanson Baldwin's new book called, "The Caissons Roll"* has become a faded volume on a dusty shelf. One day, out of curiosity, young Johnny Jones, some one's as-yet-unborn grandson, pulls it down to look it over.

Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC. is, with his consent, continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. Lauren C. Skiff, Aug. 25; 1st Lt. Louis Zimmerman, Med.-Res., Aug. 28. Each officer will be returned to his home not later than midnight of the date mentioned, at which time he will revert to an inactive status.

Alix shows carpenter's apron halter blouses with open apron skirts and also an 1880 basque halter blouse with a shorts apron for the beach and adds a reversed bolero brasslere with long slacks having a skirt back for beach evenings.
Dr. Carl Thomas Humphrey, dean of the Engineering School at Villanova College, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home here. His age was 65.

Hachisaburo Hirao, eminent business leader and former Education Minister, is on his way to North China to examine economio conditions. He has been invited to become economic adviser to the special section of the Japanese Army in North China which deals with economic and political questions.

The nucleus a British department of propaganda has been established to "spread a better understanding of this country and the British people abroad," Prime Minister Neville s Chamberlain announced in the d House of Commons today.

Cause of an explosion that wrecked the Modern Cement Company's plant at 134 East Hawthorne Avenue here early this morning was undetermined tonight after investigations by the Bureau of Combustibles of the Nassau County Police Department and the village Department of Publia Works.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates Feb. 5 unless specifled: At San Diego, Feb. 6, Brant. JarviS At Coco Solo, Gannet, Feb. 4; Thrush. At San Pedro, Vestal, Feb. 6; Neches. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Avocet, Tutuila, to Pearl Harbor. Chester, Long Beach to Mare Island Yard, Feb. 7.

Five winners in a nationwide competition for composers of choral works, all but one residents of New York State, were announced today by Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant Administrator of the Works Progress Administration. The-contest was sponsored by the WPA Music Project in cooperation with Carl Fischer, Inc., the Columbia Phonograph Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

In spite of the fact that traffic deaths reached an all-time record of 39,700 in the past year, according to the National Safety Council, Major Charles Spencer Hart, Grand Exalted Ruler of the Elks, predicted yesterday that the toll of automobile fatalities for 1938 would show a substantial drop.

Propo sales to freeze old-age taxes collected under the Social Security Act at current levels and to arrange for what amounts to a public audit of accumulated collections every five years were contained in amendments to that act introduced today by Senator Vandenberg.
Drawing ahead early in the second half, the Seton Hall five defeated the St. Thomas team at the Orange Armory tonight, 37--27. Ed Sadowski paced the scoring with 15 points.

Notice of swift retaliation for attacks on her shipping by submarines and airplanes was served by Britain yesterday on the Spanish Rebels. Foreign Secretary Eden told the House of Commons she was tired of making protests and hereafter would act.

Revision of the system of rating teachers in the public schools, to provide "intellectual emancipation" for New York City's vast teaching corps, was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to the Board of Superintendents by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee.

At the fortieth annual meeting yesterday of the stockholders of the Lawrence Portland Cement Company in Northampton, Pa., William T. Minsch, president of Minsch, Monell Co., Inc. was elected a director.

Following a series of unannounced visits by city sales tax investigators to wholesale women's clothing establishments that occasionally sell at retail, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that assessments totaling nearly $1,000,000 had been made against manufacturers who sold at retail without paying the proper city sales tax.
A 4 per cent increase in the college student population of New York State was attributed, in part, today to the demands of modern business.

Artists, writers, actors and their representatives expressed approval today Before the House Patents Committee of proposals embodied in two bills for establishment of a Federal bureau or department to subsidize creative art.

A 16-year-old youth faced a possible sentence of ten to twenty years in prison yesterday following his conviction in Queens County Court of a burglary in which he got 54 cents. The jury, sitting before Judge Charles S. Colden, included three women.

Bonds moved within a narrow price range yesterday in the slowest trading on the New York Stock Exchange in more than five months. There was virtually no speculative interest, even among the more sensitive railroad issues, with the result that values fluctuated

William Z. Foster, leader of the Communist party in this country, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday from trips to France and the Soviet Union, with a feeling that a war might start soon.
Mrs. Anna Marie Hahn, convicted poison slayer, lost her fight in the Ohio Court of Appeals today to escape a sentence of death in the electric chair. Three Judges of the court

After their return here on Thursday to their Fisher Island estate, Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt and her daughter, Miss Rosemary Warburton, who departed yesterday in the Vanderbilt plane for a brief stay in New York, will leave on a Caribbean cruise of several weeks aboard the Vanderbilt yacht Alva. Marine specimens for Commodore Vandelrhilt's museum will be taken.

Charging that Juliet Stuart Poyntz, for many years a Communist leader, was "lured or kidnapped" to Soviet Russia because she broke with her associates and "knew too much," Carlo Tresca, veteran New York radical and leader of the Italian anti-Fascists in this country, announced yesterday that he would appear before Lester C. Dunigan, Assistant United States Attorney, this morning and give him "important information" bearing on the charge.
Republican leaders agreed tonight on the selection of Gordon Knox Bell of New York City as -a member of the Board of Regents, to succeed James Byrne, who resigned last year.

The Mexican Supreme Court ruled today that cabaret girls cannot work after- 10 P. M. in any part of Mexico. Cabaret workers invoked Article 4 of the Constitution, which guarantees liberty of work, after Federal District police arrested them for working after 10 o'clock in a cafe.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson and Councilman Louis Hollander conferred yesterday on relief problems confronting the city with a prospect that remedial legislation would be introduced in the City Council by Mr. Hollander.
March 1 has been set as the opening date for the new Federal Reserve Bank of China, which is expected to control banking in North China and the Shanghai area.

Safe aboard the tanker Harry F. Sinclair Jr. the six members of the crew of the Halifax schooner Leona, which burned last night off Nantucket Lightship, were- reported today to be in satisfactory condition.

Alex Pisciotta and Francis J. Bloustein, assistant corporation counsels, will appear today before the National Bituminous Coal Commission in Washington to urge that the new schedule of soft coal prices be amended and reduced.

Unfreezing of billions 'of dollars Of idle capital with the resultant opening of million of jobs for the unemployed was predicted tonight by Charles R. Hook, president of the National Association of Manufacturers and president of the American Rolling Mill Company, once the "extraordinary handicaps that have been loaded on business incentive" are removed.

Mrs. E. Jefferson Browder will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 12 Clark Street, Brooklyn, for members of the junior committee of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association of Brooklyn, which is arranging its annual benefit dance for the night of Feb. 25 at Sherry's. Mrs. Browder is chairman of the junior committee and Mrs. Albert Bonynge heads the executiva committee for the dance.

About forty men, women and children were routed from their apartments on the four upper floors of the five-story tenement at 308 West Forty-second Street when a fire that started in the kitchen of the Milan Restaurant on the street Floor swept through the building shortly before 8 A. M. yesterday.

Twenty-two youths, found guilty of operating "hand" or "box" trucks on the sidewalks of the garment district were offered the alternative of $5 fines or two days in jail by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Jefferson Market Court yesterday.
President Roosevelt conferred with a group of liberal members of the House of Representatives who presented a ten-point legislative program calculated to offset recent conservative business demands.

All-India won the fourth unofficial cricket test match with Lord Tennyson's touring eleven by an innings and six runs today. The rivals are now on even terms, with two victories each, and an extra test has been arranged at Bombay Saturday.

Whether Premier Octavian Goga will be able to "make" the elections on March 2 so as to win 40 per cent of the votes, which automatically would give him as a bonus 50 per cent of the seats in the Chamber, is a question on which politicians here differ, although most of them believe he will fail.

John Wakula, 26 years old, of 243 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday on a charge of homicide before Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in felony court, Brooklyn, and held without bail for further hearing next Wednesday.

There were many arrivals on tne Monarch today to attend the wedding tomorrow of Miss Celia Randolph Robinson, daughter of Mrs. J. Randolph Robinson of New York and the late Mr. Robinson, to Julian Peabody of New York.
House approval sent to the White House today a bill to forbid unlicensed picketing of foreign embassies and legations here.

Four undergraduate committees have been named for the third annual Columbia College Rapier Club ball and exhibition, to be held on the evening of alumni day next Saturday. The dance will be in John Jay Hall, according to the announcement of the event yesterday by Forest R. Lombaer of Freeport, L. I., president of the club, who will be master of ceremonies. William V. Beal, a senior, is general chairman.
More than 500 persons attended a dinner last night at the Hotel Astor celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the West End Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Lou Gehrlg is going into a salary huddle today at l0:30 A. M. with Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, at the Colonel's-brewery on Third Avenue. There are optimists who expect a speedy, agreement on Battering Lou's salary for 1938.

The future of agriculture and the welfare of the country as a whole depend upon the preservation of the family-sized farm, in the opinion of Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, who spoke yesterday at a round table of the Women's National Republican Club.

Carlo Nunziato, who lost a leg in the city's service in 1915, will be on the city payroll again, and what was termed yesterday by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan as "a 23year-old wrong" will be righted.
Police Judge Martin J. McHugh upheld here today a clause in the local liquor ordinance banning women from drinking at bars. His ruling is believed to be the first on the issue in New Jersey.

A complete program of songs by Jean Sibelius, an experiment never before made in this city, was given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Theodate Johnson, a young soprano who was sent last Summer to Finland by the American Sibelius Society, there to consult the composer about the interpretation of his works.

Harvey S. Firestone, a farm boy who built one of the largest rubber businesses in the world, died of a coronary thrombosis as he slept early today in the great mansion of Harbel Villa, an ocean-front estate he acquired in 1924. He was 69 years old.

The International Typographical Union began a vote this week that may indicate whether the union, one of America's oldest, will remain in the fold of the American Federation of Labor or swing over to john L. Lewis's rival Com--littee for Industrial Organization.

Rejecting an offer by one to plead guilty, the State of New Jersey insisted today on the death penalty for two Newark girls who went on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer here for the murder of William Barhorst, a bus driver, in a hold-up that netted the girls $2.10 in booty.

A small fire of undetermined origin spread through a linen room on the seventh floor of the eightstory Cadillac Hotel, 165 West Forty-third Street, at the northeast corner of Broadway, at 9:45 o'clock last night, causing a number of guests to abandon their rooms for a short time.

Coroner J. D. Baldwin or Glynn County announced tonight that he would investigate thoroughly a theory that the Rev. Dr. Charles Lee's outspoken views against vice might provide the motive for the slaying of the clergyman at his home here Saturday night.

A card party was held yesterday afternoon at the Plaza to aid the philanthropic work of the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-EI. Mrs. Edward B. Schulkind was chairman of the committee on arrangements.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 10: PATROLMAN George A. Smith, Traffic Precinct D, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 8, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Feb. 8:
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 4: CAPTAIN Read, A. C., Washington, D. C., in June. to command the Saratoga.

The Queens University sextet climbed back into a first-place tie with the McGill Redmen in, the International Intercollegiate Hockey League tonight with a 5-2 victory over the University of Montreal team.

This morning we cruised the "ten thousand islands" to see whether we couldn't hook one of the silver tarpon that make this section famous. We spent the night at the Everglades Rod and Gun Club, which, although it is right in the heart of the tarpon waters, has all the comforts of home, a thing not true of all the hunting and fishing camps we've stopped at recently.

After leaving a note under the door of a friend, proclaiming his intention, Otto Battenschlag, 53 years old, a retired knit goods importer, went to the beach front and shot himself simultaneously with two pistols.

Three hundred and fifty members of the Union League Club, including former President Hoover, attended a dinner last night at the club in celebration of its seventyfifth anniversary. Charles C. Paulding, president, presided.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a list which showed that of the nearly 7,000 over-the-counter brokers and dealers registered with it under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 a total of 936,
The Consolidated Steel Corporation, Ltd., in 1937 completed the largest volume of business and showed the highest earnings for any year since 1929.
The right of the National Labor Relations Board to subpoena for examination books of the Eastern Footwear Corporation of Dolgeville, N. Y., was denied today by Federal Judge Frank Cooper.

Edward I. Crawford, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., will discuss office buildings tomorrow evening in the realty appraisal course sponsored by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and New York University, at 100 Washington Square East.
Coast Guardsmen went hunting with a cannon today for a whale which has frightened operators of small boats in San Francisco Bay.

George Daley, sports editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died at 12:28 o'clock this morning in the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eighty-third Street, where he had been ill with pneumonia, at the age of 68. His home was at the Castleton Apartments, St. George, S. I.

Poor master Harry L. Barck of this city, a septuagenarian whose methods as relief dispenser have been under fire for several weeks, broke a mirror this afternoon. It was unintentional, he says, but he is wondering whether he faces the proverbial seven years of bad luck. en years of bad luck.

The Consumers Tax Committee of the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, through its chairman, Mrs. William Dick Sporborg, issued a blanket request yesterday to all men's organizations to aid in the nonpartisan drive against proposed new taxes.

Lester F. Scott, national executive of Camp Fire Girls, announced yesterday that twelve members of the organization had been selected as winners in the group's third national poetry contest. Each' winner will receive an autographed volume of poetry from one of the twelve poets who served on the committee of judges.

The influence that gave members of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gang "virtual immunity" from the law will be made "painfully evident" when J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and others are placed on trial in New York, Charles P. Grimes, assistant to Thomas E. Dewey, testified here today.

The fourth annual report of the Tennessee Valley Authority, unlike the previous ones, was not signed by the directors. 'There is accordingly a rumor in informed circles that this is because of the wellknown disagreement among the directors and because Chairman Arthur E. Morgan intends soon to file a separate and most dissentient report.

The longawaited report of the audit of the books of fourteen milk companies operating in Metropolitan New York was sent to the Legislature tonight by Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture, and, was immediately assailed by Assemblyman Whitney, Rensselaer County Republican, as inadequate and lacking the confidence of State officials.
Reuben Fine returned to New York yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a sojourn of nineteen months in Europe. Fine acted as second for

Extremely dull trading characterized the security and commodity markets yesterday, and prices moved irregularly lower. Stocks closed with net declines of fractions to about 2 points, with the turnover on the Stock Exchange of 513,000 shares the smallest for a full day since Aug. 31.

2d Ave, 549, 19.8x77; Adrian P. Burke to East River Sav. Bank; consid, $5,000, fel. Lexington Ave, n e cor 92d St, 100.8 1/2x94.6; John T. Javasile to Derby Realty Corp. 119 W 40th St. care C. G. Bernheimer; mtg, $595,500.

Factorytrained Pauline Newman of New York, blunt and articulate, took the stand this afternoon before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee at its hearing on the Equal Rights Amendment, and with barbed sentences and unpretty phrases exploded temporarily the serene atmosphere of soft-voiced courtesy and tea-table mannerisms dominating the gathering.

The New York Americans and the Montreal Maroons will meet tonight at. Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League encounter, the result of which will figure in the battle of the teams for third place in the International group and a position in the Stanley Cup play-offs.

Introducing Harry Platt of Brown. This sophomore may break the great Hank Luisetti's scoring record before he finishes his collegiate career. What makes his feats the more startling is that he has been popping in points at an incredible rate without fanfare or publicity.

The Barnard School for Boys quintet assured itself of at least 'a tie for the-Northern Division honors in the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools race by beating Franklin School, 39 to 21, on the Barnard court yesterday.

James Roosevelt's'assertion yesterday that he hoped Florida would re-elect Senator Pepper drew an angry protest today from Representative Wilcox of Florida, one of Mr. Pepper's Democratic opponents for the nomination.

A dog owned and handled by Dr. Wallace F. Vail of Greenwich, Conn., and two owned and guided by Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga., worked impressively in the opening heats of the national amateur quail championship contest today.

De Witt Millhauser, a partner in Speyer Co., was questioned yesterday in Supreme Court about profits made by his firm in connection with the sale to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway in 1926 of 183,333 shares of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway stock.

If there seems to be another optical illusion at the Seventh Regiment track meet at the armory on Friday, it will not be anything of the kind. Instead, it will be the famous footracing-twins from North Texas Teachers in action once again.
A survey of building permits issued in New York City last month shows that work estimated to cost $84,008,896 was projected in the five boroughs.

Fourteen former directors of the defunct General Surety Company and the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, both affiliates of the National American Company, Inc., were ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter to pay a total of about $500,000 to Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, now liquidating both companies.

There was a decrease of fifty-one in the number of accidents and a decrease of six in the number killed in automobile accidents in the last week in comparison with the corresponding week of last year, according to figures compiled yesterday by the Safety Bureau at police headquarters.

The National Bituminous Coal Commission granted today to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and the Koppers Company of New Jersey a temporary modification of the purchase price of low volatile coal used in the manufacture of gas and its by-products.

Pressing on in the third day of their surprise offensive north of Teruel, Insurgent troops extended their gains today over an area of about 400 square miles, including the Palomera Mountain Range and the towns of Alfambra and Perales.
Joseph Leopold died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventysixth Street and Park Avenue, of bronchial pneumonia. He was 69 years old and lived at Essex House.

The General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on March 12 to stock of record of Feb. 17, compared with 25 cents paid a year ago, $1 each paid on June 12 and Sept. 13 and $1.50 paid on Dec. 13, 1937.

The story of how the American Government's only woman cryptanalyst, through deciphering twenty-seven Chinese code cablegrams, has just enabled Canada to break up what officials called the biggest opium smuggling ring on the Pacific Coast, was brought here today.

William Diehl Jr., veteran airplane pilot, successfully demonstrated a new airplane engine muffler yesterday afternoon at Bendix Airport, Teterboro, N. J. Observers said that it completely silenced the engine, but left a whirr of propeller noise.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Fire Commissioner John J. vicElligott expressed general agreement yesterday with the recommendations of the Citizens Budget Commission for reform of the departmental pension system. He disagreed, however, with other suggestions of the commission.

Alex Dow, president of the Detroit Edison Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that he was confident the present annual dividend of $6 a share would be maintained this year.

The value of the Roman Catholic press to the United States and its people was stressed by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, speaking last night at the formal opening of the Centre Club's Catholic press exhibit at the club, 120 Central Park South. The exhibit, which will continue all week, was opened by Mgr. Lavelle in the name of Cardinal Hayes.
Billy Beauhuld, Jersey City's promising lightweight, gained a well-earned victory over Maxie Berger of the Bronx last night in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Brig. Gen. Walter C. Short, commanding the Second Brigade of the First Infantry Division, arrived here today aboard the transport ChateauThierry en route to Culebra Island, where he will report to Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, commanding the Winter training manoeuvres in the Caribbean.

BERLIN, Feb. 7.--The emergency court trying the Rev. Martin Niemoeller on charges of sedition made it clear at the opening of the trial today that it did not intend to permit the Protestant leader's defense to become known to the world.
Edwin P. Root, former president of the New Haven Clock Company and chairman of the board of directors, died tonight at New Haven Hospital at the age of 76. He was operated upon last week.

George Roeser, 50 years old, owner of a hardware store at 2,148 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and William Hopkins, 25, of 10 Sackman Street, Brooklyn, a salesman in Roeser's store, were arraigned in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, BrookIyn.

United States SENIOR SCIENTIFIC AID (PREPARATOR IN PATHOLOGY), $2,000 a year, Army Medical Museum, War Department. Applications must be on file not later than March 10. if received from Arizona. California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than March 7 from all other States.

The Harris. Trust and Saving Bank has received the award of new issue of $435,000 of public welfare bonds of Ramsey County Minn., on a bid of 100.589 for 2 1/4s The bonds will be dated Feb. 1 1938, and mature serially on Feb. 1 1939 to 1948.

Demands for modification of the undistributed profits tax and some policies of the Works Progress Administration's construction program are expected to be made at the nineteenth annual convention of the Associated General Contractors of America which will open tomorrow.

In the supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 730-Nathan Cosman, petr., v. the United States. On petition for writ of cert. to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals. Motion for leave to proceed in forma paupers granted. Petition for writ of cert. is also granted, and the judgment is reversed.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Susan Corbett Steele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon C. Steele of Fredonia, N. Y., to Robert Utting Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wright Brown of Yonkers, N. Y.
Soviet Legation attaches asked the police today to investigate the whereabouts of Russian Minister Mikhail S. Otrowsky and the legation counselor, Jodor Budenko.

MIAMI, Feb. 7.--Another chapter in organized labor's civil war was written today when William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, announced that at Friday's session the executive council had revoked the charters of the United Mine Workers of America, the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers and the Federation of Flat Glass Workers.

Stocks drifted narrowly and closed slightly. lower in smallest trading since August; turnover, 513,251 shares. All groups of bonds slightly lower in dullest trading since August; transactions, $4,887,375.

Apparently unimpressed by other budget-balancing suggestions, fifteen members of the City Council went ahead today with their plan to pass the 2 per cent sales tax over Mayor Wilson's veto at a special session tomorrow.
The Rettner Construction Corp gave a second mortgage to the Tunams Real Estate Improvement and Holding Corp for $6,500, payable ten years hence, on 1,690 Park Ave, subject to a first for $3,500.

Following the death of two members of the Iron Guard (Fascists) and the wounding of several others in clashes yesterday with Premier Octavian Goga's lance bearers and police, a breach has developed between the government and Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the Iron Guard.

ALPER--Dr. Jacob J. The directors and staff of East New York Dispensary note with deep sorrow death of Dr. J. J. Alper, chief of the Dental Clinic. His acts of charity will long be remembered. SIMON H. KUGEL, President. THOMAS A. SHAPIRO, Secretary.
John Randel Weeks, retired lawyer who was active in religious, politi-| cal and fraternal life in the State, died yesterday at his home here of pneumonia. He was 99 years old.

A jury was about to be chosen in General Sessions yesterday for the trial of Jack Dorf, 39 years old, of 505 West 124th Street on a felony indictment accusing him of defrauding a man of $100 in 1934 under promise to have him appointed to the police force, when Dorf tried to bargain with Assistant District Attorney Milton Schilback.

The California sportsman, Norman W. Church, scored his second feature victory in two racing days when Sir Oracle, fleet-footed son of Bull Dog, literally ran away and hid from four other sprinters in the Royal Palm Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Hearings conducted here since last week by an Assembly investigating committee in an effort to obtain Hudson County election records closed this afternoon with an announcement that the committee would confer tomorrow to arrange for the presentation to the Assembly on Wednesday of testimony taken from Hudson County officials.

New York City is the worst index of American beliefs and principles, : Dr. Livingston Farrand, former president of Cornell University, declared last night at the forty-third annual dinner of the Steuben County Society of New York at the Hotel i Commodore.

Before a jury in the United States District Court here today trial was begun of the $200,000 libel suit of Robert H. Lucas of Louisville, Ky., against the A. S. Abell Publishing Company and Frank R. Kent, political commentator of The Baltimore Sun.

August Hoffman of 71 West 102d Street, a Civil War veteran of the Seventh New York Student Rifles, died yesterday in Veterans Hospital, 81, Bronx, following a stroke suffered twelve days ago. He was 89 years old.
Sink or Swim, 3-year-old fill owned by Conny Smythe of Toronto, made it three straight, two of them at the Fair Grounds, in the mile and seventy-yard feature today.

Wendell F. Bowers, 20, a former inmate of Huntingdon Reformatory, unexpectedly pleaded guilty to the murder of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter as he went to trial here today in the Montgomery County Court of Oyer and Terminer.
Hilda Burke, soprano, and John Charles Thomas, baritone, were received I with applause today at the last concert in the series given this season at the Mayflower by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend.

The League of Nations International Conference, called to conclude the convention definitely settling the status of refugees from Germany, opened today with three main--problems before the dozen countries represented.

The National Labor Relations Board an nounced today filing of a petition in the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, New York, to enforce a cease and desist order issued Dec. 10 against the Federal

Trading was fair to slow. Steer beef sold strong to higher, lamb stronger, other st classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to strong, veal and calf steady, lamb sharply higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Lack of export demand offset the effect of dry weather and dust storm reports as a market influence in wheat today, and the market on the Board of Trade here drifted within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel with speculative operations at a minimum. Closing trades were unchanged to 1/5 cent lower.

So heartily and sympathetically did Sir Harry as consul general enter into the life of this country and especially of New York that his home government was urged to extend his term of service--which was twice done.
Oscar William Smith, president of Parke, Davis Co., died today at a Palm Beach hotel. He had been in failing health for three months; but became critically ill only a week ago. His age was 70.
Prices on its Fall line of all-wool blankets were announced yesterday by American Woolen Company, with reductions ranging from 12.3 to 13.6 per cent from last year's openings on standard numbers.

Arguments upon the tax imposed on two New York City transit corporations in order to raise funds for unemployment relief were heard today by the Supreme Court, which took the case under advisement and will, it is expected, deliver a decision within a few weeks.

The Florida Municipal Bondholders' Protective Committee has approved and adopted plans for the readjustment and refunding of bonds and obligations of the cities of Avon Park, Cocoa and Vero Trust Beach, Fla., John S. Harris, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

The list of the President Pierce of the Dollar Line, due today from the Far East via California, includes S. B. Baldwin, Mrs. M. E. Faulkner, Mrs. W. S. Kimball, Richard Felton, Mrs. F. S. Tyson, Ambrose Johnson and Miss Virsrinia Miller.
Internal revenue collections in the calendar year, 1937 amounted to $5,617,088,564, a gain of $1,829,752,503 over the previous year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

Among three Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms was the fifteen-story apartment house at 419-29 East Fifty-seventh Street. It was bought in by Welz Zerwick, represented by B. H. Roth, for $700,000-the upset price.

John H. Parker, president of the Union Insulating Company, of this city, is one of six men who will be honored here on Thursday night by the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association, for "fifty years of continuous service in the electrical industry."
While six Empire records were shattered, two by the pace-setting Australian team, Canada's track and field athletes today kept a firm grip on second place in the British Empire games.

As Mayor La Guardia's supporters in the City Council produced testimony yesterday challenging the legality of Councilman Hugh Quinn's election from Queens last year, the Mayor called a special meeting of the Council for 10 o'clock Thursday morning, at which the Democratic counter-attack on the qualifications of Councilmen Joseph Clark Baldwin and Michael J. Quill will be considered.

Milton Solomon, former city deputy controller, has resumed the general practice of law in association with Abraham J. Halprin at 170 Broadway. Mr. Solomon was in charge of the administration and enforcement of the emergency revenue laws, consisting of sales tax, utility tax, excise tax and personal property tax, from their inception.

The signing of the National Housing Act by President Roosevelt last week has stimulated real estate companies, building supply and appliance companies o make elaborate advertising and promotional plans, a survey here yesterday revealed.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., which operates oceangoing ferries for freight cars between Hoboken and the Gulf of Mexico, today won a victory over the railroads when the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered the railroads to establish and maintain through routes and joint rates over its lines.

The St. John's University freshman basketball team downed the St. Francis Prep five, 26 to 14, at the St. Francis gymnasium yesterday. The Redmen yearlings enjoyed a 14-8 advantage at the halfway mark.
The University of Rochester basketball team routed the University of Buffalo five tonight, 65 to 30. Bob Ulreck led the scoring with 19 points. Bud Spies and Roy Roberts contributed 17 each.

A further industrial downturn occurred in Canada in January, although it was not quite so pronounced as in December, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. "While the economic depressants of recent months spread to some industries formerly unaffected, including a few mining operations,

Lawrence Quinn, 29 years old, of 1,641 Edison Avenue, the Bronx, received fatal injuries this morning when an automobile left Pelham Road near the entrance of the New York Athletic Club and struck a pole. He died four hours later in New Rochelle Hospital.
Clarence Tracy Hutchins, 57-yearold executive of the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Corporation, died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital from injuries suffered
The National Labor Relations Board announced today certification of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate, on two steamship lines operating vessels out of Atlantic and Gulf ports.

The large collection of American Indian art formed by Miss Amelia Elizabeth - White of New York, Santa Fe, N. M., and Miami, Fla., has been distributed among several American museums and other institutions by donations, it was announced yesterday.
In an apparent suicide pact because of poverty, Grace Roemer, 28 years old, and Bruce Lindo, 33, ended their lives by gas yesterday morning in their furnished room at 358 West 120th Street.

The store space in the building at 285 Madison Avenue, formerly occupied by the Leeds Resturant, has been leased to B. U., Inc., and will be reopened as the Park-Madison Restaurant, it was announced yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman reserved decision in Brooklyn yesterday on the applications of the International Brotherhood of Building Trades Unions of America and the Renault Construction Corporation to restrain six affiliates of the American Federation of Labor from picketing an apartment house under construction at 665 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, and from continuing efforts to organize employes on the job.

Mrs. Sadie Concheado, 28 years old, of 243 West Fifteenth Street, was in the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital last night after she had collapsed in a subway station following three days of aimless wandering in subways with her 10-year-old son, Joseph Jr.

Twenty-one members of the Culinary Alliance, an A. F. of L. affiliate, who were arrested yesterday for picketing the White House and New Kriegel Hotels here, were released in their own recognizance today for a hearing on Feb. 17 before Justice of the Peace Benjamin Novins.

British unemployment jumped back toward the 2,000,000 mark, with publication of official returns tonight showing a rise of 162,000 between December 13 and January 17. The total now stands at 1,827,000, representing an increase of 500,000, or about 38 per cent, since -the peak of prosperity last Summer.

Major events today: Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin, sonatas, Carnegie Hall tonight; Marie Beutner, soprano, Town Hall, in the afternoon; Samuel Carmell, violinist, Town Hall, evening; Webster Aitken, Schubert piano sonatas, New School for Social Research, evening.

William H. Stapleton, chief clerk of the Bridge Plaza Magistrate's Court in Brooklyn and from 1926 to 1936 chief clerk of the Traffic Court in Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday in the bathroom of his home at 1,280 Pacific Street, a bullet wound in his head.
Automobile output last week declined more than seasonally and the adjusted index dropped to 57.5 from 63.3. The figure for the week ended Feb. 6. 1937, was 80.8.

A Colonial-style home on a large wooded plot in the village of Flower Hill, L. I., has been purchased by Harry A. Trautman, a vice president of the Central Hanover Bank of New York. L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. were the brokers in the deal.

On March 1, Random House will publish "Out of Africa," by Isak Dineson. It is a choice of the Bookof-the-Month Club for March, and is the author's second book. Her first, "Seven Gothic Tales," was also a Book-of-the-Month Club selection.

Oblique attacks on the Communist party in China were made in the official Kuomintang [Nationalist party] daily, Wuhan Jih Pao, and the official organ of the younger army officers, Sao Tang Pao, this morning in the course of comments on the German Government shake-up.

Much has been written about rugged individualists in this trying period of social readjustment. Harvey S. Firestone was one of them. "I believe in one-man control," he said in his autobiography. "No business is large enough to survive divided authority."

Another postponement, this one until April 18, was granted by Judge Wallace in General Sessions yesterday of the trial of Robert Edward Edmondson, elderly pamphleteer, on the indictment alleging he criminally libeled Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins,

Two seeded and two nonseeded players advanced yesterday as competition opened in the invitation squash tennis tournament- at the Whitehall Club. W. K. Rice of the Harvard Club, No. 2, and Frank A. Sieverman Jr. of the New York A. C., No. 8, moved up to the second round. Rice defeated N. F.
One hundred and fifty high school students struck today, defying a plea of the Board of Education to arbitrate the public utility demands of the students.

President Roosevelt expressed interest in a pending crude oil tax bill today in a memorandum to Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee and Representative Boland, majority whip and author of the bill.

The one-story industrial building at 224-234 Twenty-first Street, Paterson, N. J., was leased by the National Transformer Company of Jersey City, B. H. H. Noble, president. The property comprises 21,000

In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: ANNOUNCEMENTS 4259 and 42904--American Woolen Co. Former action of court in overruling motions for new trial sustained. Opinion by Judge Green.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

" Sing Sing," by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of the New York prison has been placed on the schedule at Warners. It will be the third to be produced from a Lawes story, "Twenty Thousand Years in Sing Sing" and "Over the Wall" having preceded it.

While striking stevedores met in various ports today to consider arbitration proposals, J. L. Bernard, conciliation commissioner of the United the States Department of Labor, here as an adviser to Governor Blanton Winship, conferred with the Governor, Associate Justice Travieso,
Death of Harvey S. Firestone today left Henry Ford as the only survivor of a quartet of famous men, all nature lovers, who enjoyed vacations together for years.
This session of Congress has been devoted during the first week to a general discussion of labor legislation as the result of proposals made by Socialist and Communist delegates.

James Caras and .Andrew Ponzi broke even yesterday in their exhibition pocket billiard engagement at the Strand Academy. In the afternoon Caras won, 125 to 111, in ten innings. Caras had a high run of 42 to 38 for his opponent.

In observance of the 126th anniversary of the birth of Charles Dickens, about 200 persons attended a dinner at the Hotel Brevoort, Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street, last night under the auspices of the Dickens Fellowship of New York.

A big three-bladed propeller from a large flying boat broke into three pieces and dropped on Melbourne today in the course of a squadron flight of visiting Royal Air Force planes from London, but no one was injured.

Seventeen questions in a bill of particulars asked by counsel for Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials in an injunction suit to restrain them from interfering with the activities of the C. I. O., American Civil Liberties Union, affiliated organizations and certain individuals were consolidated into one question here today by Federal Judge William Clark.

The Federal Theatre Project's local office denied yesterday that "One-Third of a Nation," its show about housing, contained any deliberate satire on United States Senators Byrd, Andrews and Tydings. Dispatches from Washington

Bennett M. Brigman, dean and organizer of the Speed Scientific School of the University of Louisville, died tonight in a hospital which he entered Jan. 10 for treatment of a heart ailment. He was 56 years old..

Former Vice Chancellor Merritt Lane submitted his resignation today to the Hudson County Bar Association rather than account to the association for his recent court statement that "lawyers create nothing," and the public would be better off if it could get along without them.

Acting Detective Captain Joseph Cocozza of the Essex County Prosecutor's staff testified in the Court of Oyer and Terminer here today that Mrs. Ethel S. Sohl, who with her friend, Miss Genevieve Owens,
Italian owners of the process for production of artificial wool known as "lanital," have organized a company to manufacture that product in France, the Department of Commerce has been advised.
Charles W. Bell, one of Canada's leading criminal lawyers, author and playwright and for a decade an outstanding figure in the House of Commons, died at his home here today. He was 61 years old.

Miss Georgia Inez Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kauffman of this place, will be married on Feb. 19 to Dr. Frederick E. Mowry of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Mowry of Johnstown, Pa.
Alphonse Capone, once the most powerful gang leader in Chicago, is ill and under observation in the hospital of Alcateaz prison.
William Tuttle, auditor- of The Evening Bulletin, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday afternoon at his home in Bala. He was 70 years old.

Two ex-convicts, declared by the police to be among the city's most dangerous gunmen, were sentenced to State prison with terms of thirty to sixty years each by Judge Collins in General Sessions yesterday.

Several hundred men and women, protesting against the planned discontinuance of clothing allowances and demanding increased food allowances for persons on relief, began sit-down demonstrations yesterday afternoon at three stations of the Home Relief Bureau.

After a lull of several days, Arab terrorist activities in Palestine were resumed today. A British sergeant and an Arab bus passenger were killed. When a detachment of the Royal Ulster Rifles was searching the village of Attil a sergeant was separated from his comrades.
Blocked in a direct advance on Suchow by stiff resistance, the Japanese apparently shifted their strategy yesterday and were moving in on the western flank of the 400,000 Chinese defenders. [Page 1.]

Funeral services were held here tonight for William Sylvester Budworth, artist and former head of W. S. Budworth Son of New York, packers and shippers of art objects. He died Sunday at his home at the age of 76. Burial will be in Woodlawn Cemetery tomorrow.
C. Putnam's Somali, non-winner in the past two. years, won the mile and a sixteenth feature race today for four-year-olds and up at the Fair Grounds.

Miss Virginia Randolph of Greenwich, Conn., and Herman Henry Ridder of New York and St. Paul, whose marriage will take place here Friday afternoon, were guests of honor at a dinner given last night by his mother, Mrs. Hilda M. Ridder, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Victor F. Ridder, 81 East Seventyninth Street.
The Senate and House Banking Committees approved today bills to authorize the Treasury to cancel about $2,600,000,000 of obligations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Several young theatre people who are on -the way up join forces in "How to Get Tough About It," which opened at Mr. Beck's showshop last evening.

Mrs. Margaretta Fryer Wood, wife of Rear Admiral Spencer Shepard Wood, U. S. N., retired, who died on Sunday after a brief illness, was buried today in the National Cemetery at Arlington. Services were held in Christ Episcopal Church, Georgetown.

Mounting crime waves and increasing juvenile delinquency find their causes in the "rampant paganism" of 20,000,000 youth of America, Dr. Roy G. Ross, executive secretary of the International Council on Religious Education, told the convention of that body here today.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered bondholders to file by April 22 a combined reorganization plan for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company.

AN attorney appeared for the defense. It was the zone defense that he was representing. It was a basketball argument, of which there have been plenty this Winter under a roof and rather bitter ones considering what a mild Winter it has been out of doors.

The deadlock of Democrats in the Ways and Means Committee over the proposal to put into the Tax Revision Bill a special surtax on the undistributed profits of closely held, or family, corporations may be broken by a compromise.

The Cathedral College basketball team turned back Hofstra, 44 to 37, last night at the Holy Spirit gymnasium in the Bronx. Jerry Nolan, left forward, led Cathedral with nine field goals for 18 points. The visitors led at half time, 22 to 15.

A University of Kentucky student's advertised slogan contest and race horse "tips" landed him in jail today on two Federal charges of using the mails to defraud. The student, Raymond Schlachter of Mount Pulaski, Ill., junior in the Arts and Science College, was arrested while attending classes. The warrant,

The Senate Joint Committee on Commerce and Labor investigating labor conditions on the Pacific Coast, and especially the activities of Harry Bridges, radical labor leader, was officially informed today that Raphael P. Bonham, director of the Seattle division of the Immigration Service, had recommended the deportation of Bridges.
Sales of A. G. Spalding Bros. for the quarter ended on Jan. 31 were about 7 per cent above the same period a year ago, Charles F. Robbins, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

Food and drug manufacturers, associations and advertising agencies are organizing strong opposition to a bill now in the New York State Assembly Committee on Public Health which would establish a consumer bureau in the State Department of Health to regulate the manufacture and sale of foods, drugs and cosmetics, it was learned here yesterday.
The annual exhibition in New York of the Alumni Association of the Fontainebleau School of Fine Arts opened last evening with a reception at the' National Arts Club.

The, governinent's case against eleven nationalists at Ponce now being retried for the murder of Policeman Ceferino Loyola last Palm Sunday will probably be completed tomorrow. Judge Robert H. Todd Jr. has insisted on the elimination of repetitious material which dragged out the first trial three months.

Victory, after a long absence, paid a visit to the camp of the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's skaters registered their first triumph in the National Hockey League since Jan. 2 by beating the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 1.
St. John's University School of Law will confer ninety-eight degrees tonight at the semi-annual graduation exercises in the gymnasium at 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.

Consular representatives of European countries, British war veterans and leaders of industry in this country joined yesterday in final tribute to Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York for more than ten years before his retirement in 1931.

A new residential community planned to comprise eventually about twenty-five dwellings in English, Colonial and French provincial style will be developed at Lawrence, L. I., as the result of the purchase of seven acres of landscaped land running from Lawrence Avenue through to Herrick Drive, between Broadway and Central Avenue.

Elaborate plans for the beautification and development of Ottawa as a great and picturesque capital were disclosed today by Jacques Greber, French architect and adviser to the Dominion government. The work may take twenty-five to fifty years to complete and involves almost complete transformation of the center of the city.
Resuming our intermittent sessions in English rhetoric and composition, we take up Secretary Hull's letter to Senator Pittman

" It is unwise for Japan to conceal her naval-building program. Japan's chief concern is with Russia. Japan should not be considered a Fascist State." Those comments were made here today by Jiuji G. Kasai, Japanese, whose is returning to Tokyo from Europe.

Because of the success of "The Irish in Us," which Warners made some seasons ago as a minor venture, the studio will follow it with "Three Cheers for the Irish," for which Earl Baldwin is preparing the script. Pat O'Brien and Mary Maguire have been assigned the leading roles.

Floodwaters surged tonight over a wide front in Illinois and Wisconsin, inundating city streets and thousands of acres of farm lands. The menace that seemed to have abated last night was revived as thawing weather sent swollen rivers out of their banks in many communities.

Miss Louisa Mead, descendant of one of the oldest families here, is observing her ninety-sixth birthday today. Born before the Mexican War, she is the last of the women who sewed the flags displayed here during the Civil War.

The Greater New York Chapter of the Society of Residential Appraisers will meet tomorrow evening at the Hotel Lexington, Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, to discuss the new building code. Speakers will be Edwin H. Thatcher, former Commissioner of Buildings; William Wilson, former technical director of the State Housing Board, and M. H. Sugarman, architect.

Mrs. Annie Bateman Ewart, a daughter of the late Dr. Newton Bateman, former president of Knox College and close friend of Abraham Lincoln, died on Monday in her home at Colorado Springs, Col., at the age of 76.
Wallis Warfield, who spent her girlhood at 212 East Biddle Street herd, married the ex-King of England. A group bought 212 East Biddle, turned it into a museum. The initial entrance price was $1.
Yehudi Menuhin is one of the most popular artists in the recital field today, but his appearances in sonata programs with his younger sister, Hephzibah, have even greater drawing powers.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, closing its midwinter meeting here today, called upon Congress to repeal or modify the undivided profits and capital gains taxes as a step toward the restoration of public confidence.

For the first time in many years the Soviet Union has found it necessary to lower the daily production norms, or quotas, in such important branches of heavy industry-as steel, iron, coal, motor trucks and freight-car loadings.
Francis F. Rosenbaum was elected president of the Jewish Agricultural Society at the annual meeting yesterday at headquarters, 301 East Fourteenth Street.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, conferred with President Roosevelt today. Mr. Young was here for a meeting of the Advisory Council to the National Youth Administration which will call on the President tomorrow.
Germain G. Glidden, national amateur squash racquets champion, retained his metropolitan title last night.

Soviet Russla's growing military strength was emphasized by the War Minister, General Gen Suglyama, today as he outlined before the Diet's Budget Committee conditions that necessitate expansion of Japan's armament.
Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club was the victim of an upset in the opening round of the Whitehall Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday.

Formation by 123 persons of the Citizens Committee for Planned Parenthood to aid the American Birth Control League in its "campaign to provide scientific birth control information to America's 27,000,000 married couples" was announced yesterday.

Dizzy Dean said tonight he would sign a contract to pitch for the Cardinals this year for $20,000. It was the first time Dean, who said he had drawn $25,500 last year, named publicly the sum he is asking.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A, Coll of 50 Summit Road of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Jeanne Coll, to Lieutenant William J. Cain Jr., U. S. A., son of former Judge and Mrs. Willaim J. Cain of Bayonne.

Awards which, with interest, will exceed $1,000,000 were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin to the Manhattan Railway Company for its light, air and access rights along the East Thirty-fourth Street elevated spur and along the spur in Sixth Avenue from Fifty-third to Fiffty-ninth Streets. Both spurs have been removed by the city.
Jewelry firms accounted for several of the leases of business space reported by brokers yesterday. The Merrin Jewelry Company, Ino., dealers in precious stones and silverware,

Announcement was made today by L. W. Sutherland, president of the Sutherland Paper Company, of the purchase by his company of the equipment and good-will of the Champion No Leak Dish Company of Toledo, Ohio.

Robert C. Townsend said today that he planned an appeal of the District of Columbia Appellate Court ruling which affirmed the conviction of his father, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, pension plan advocate, of contempt of the House of Representatives.

Rumors published in various foreign newspapers of measures taken recently in Italy against the intellectual activity of Jews caused the Minister for Popular Culture to issue an official statement today that such reports "find no confirmation in official circles."

J. Clarence Smith, an artist who had produced paintings and decorations for New York and Brooklyn churches, died suddenly here last night of a heart attack at his home .on Araca Road, ten minutes after collapsing while walking near by.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,316,450 barrels, compared with 3,357,650 in the preceding week, a decline of 41,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Prime Minister Viscount Craigavon issued an election eve manifesto today calling upon Northern Ireland voters to repulse "the impudent challenge" of Eamon de Valera for fusion with Ireland.

Rapid progress toward an accord in the negotiations for a new agreement between officials of the United States Steel Corporation and representatives of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee was reported yesterday after another conference between the two parties.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Feb. 9: PATROLMEN-Joseph A. Frieder, from 66th Precinct to 12th Division, assigned to duty in plain clothes. From precincts indicated to 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector, for duty in Bureau of Equipment: Henry J. Coleman, 19th Precinct. Saul W. Bock, Traf. J.
The Exchange has suspended from dealings Lehigh Valley Coal Company five-year secured 6 per cent gold notes due on Jan. 1, 1938, because of the small amount outstanding;

Standard Brands, Inc., has' arranged with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for including hospitalization benefits in its employe group insurance program, according to Thomas L. Smith, president of Standard Brands.

The letter published on this page today from Thomas Craven, as well as those published in our art pages on sunday from Elmer Rice, George Soule, Edith Halpert and others, may, let us hope, have some effect in inducing the managers of the World's Fair to reconsider their decision not to provide for an art exhibit.

Undeterred by the crash of the semirigid V 6 on a test flight while preparing to aid their stranded scientists from the air, the Soviet Government pushed forward with plans for airplane relief if icebreakers cannot reach their four observers imperiled on a drifting ice floe.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 5: CAPTAIN Hoover, J. H., Norfolk, Va., to command the Lexington, in May or June. COMMANDERS Gasser, R. R., Med. Corps, Navy Dept. Dispensary, to-Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C.
The New York A. C. defeated the Columbia Lions, 7-6, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association encounter at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night, staving off a closing bid by the losing sextet.

The winning streak of the St. John's basketball team which has carried through the past eight games will be put to a stern test when the Redmen meet N. Y. U. tonight in the second game of a double-header at Madison Square

The mysterious disappearance of a 700-pound bell from the top of the old Court Street school, opposite the Westchester County Court House here, sent city and county officials today on a search of basements, attics and warehouses.
An ordinance providing for a 2 per cent city sales tax, subject of a bitter controversy here for. two weeks, was passed by the City Council today over the veto of Mayor Wilson. The vote was 15 to 7,
The last words of Prince Nicolas, who died today at the age of 66, were: "I am happy to die in my beloved country."

Autopsies completed yesterday on the bodies of Nino Columbo, 42 years old, of 2,305 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, and Mrs. Christina Oliveri, '24, of 1,745 Seventyfourth Street, who were found murdered in a parked car on Oliver Street, near Ninety-second Street and Shore Road, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on Sunday, revealed that they had been dead for nine days when discovered, Police Inspector Michael F. McDermott said.
The House of Representatives was given four hours yesterday in which to consider one of the most complicated and far-reaching measures which has ever been brought before it.

Completion of the liquidation of twentyone receiverships of national banks in January was reported today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, making a total of 979 finally closed or restored to solvency since the banking holiday in March, 1933.

Sir Josiah Court, authority on miners' diseases, died at Staveley, Derbyshire, today at the age of 97. He discovered the cause of miners' nystagmus and his further investigations resulted in a great reduction in cases of partial and total blindness.

A huge modern transport plane suspended in an exhibition hall and arranged so that a person may sit in the pilot's seat and manoeuvre the mechanical devices that operate such a plane in flight will be a feature of the aviation exhibit of the New York World's Fair of 1939, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, disclosed yesterday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has set for Feb. 28 hearings before Examiners Molster and Eddy on various applications in connection with the merger plans of the New York Central Railroad and its subsidiaries.

The annual report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $6,516,403 after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.63 a common share after preferred dividend requirements. It compares with $6,394,688, or $4.52 a common share, earned in 1936.

Governor Lehman made known today that he was "unalterably .opposed" to the Parsons bill now pending in Congress, which would legalize an annual average diversion of 5,000 cubic feet a second of Lake Michigan water into the Mississippi.
Dr. Warren Arthur Fitzgerald of 1,041 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, a member of the house staff and a former interne of St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the hospital at the age of 28.

A better undertone prevailed in most sections of the bond market yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Improvement was fairly general throughout the list of domestic corporate bonds, with speculative interest again focused on the railroad issues.
Arthur B. Wood, president of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, said at the annual meeting of the company in Montreal yesterday that "the whole business situation,

Infantry from the Millsdale Stable gained stature for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup when he decisively won the Key West Purse at Hialeah Park today. This is the horse many think will give War Admiral his sternest battle, but previously his tests had been what racegoers call "easy" races.

John McL. Simpson, a director, was elected yesterday vice president of A. M. Castle Co. at a meeting of directors in Chicago to succeed George R. Boyce, who resigned because of illness but will continue with the company.

Miss Dorothy Grimmelman, a former captain of the New York University fencing team, now representing Salle Santelli, won the national junior fencing championship on the strips of the Fencers Club last night when she defeated Miss Marie Cerra of the Salle d'Armes Vince, 5-4; Miss Barbara Cochrane

More than 600 terriers of ten breeds will be benched today in Commerce Hall of the Port of New York Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, in the annual combined specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs.
Representative John J. O'Connor, chairman of the House Rules Committee, said in a statement today that he was not a candidate for leader of Tammany Hall.

While the Insurgents were consolidating their forces in the slice of territory north of Teruel gained in three days of fighting, the Loyalists reported yesterday they were prosecuting an offensive near Granada, in the south of Spain.

A contra-seasonal decline in steel ingot output last week caused the adjusted index to drop to 42.6 from 48.0, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Feb. 6, 1937, the index stood at 113.3.
A flying trip back from the Everglades and here we are surrounded by a couple of weeks' accumulated mail and trying to separate the wheat from the tares.

Rosario Marshiano, 24 years old, of 211 Warren Street, Brooklyn, who was convicted of first-degree murder on Jan. 26 in the shooting of Edwin Esposito, a B. M. T. collector, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Peter J. Brancato of Kings County Court to serve a life term in Sing Sing prison.
The Dartmouth Outing Club said today the twenty-eighth annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival would not be canceled, even if there should be no snow in Hanover this week-end.

The appointments of Bernard J. Gillroy as Borough Superintendent of Manhattan and John P. Riley as Borough Superintendent of Queens were announced by Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.

Court attendants attached to the Appellate Division and the Supreme Court in New York and Bronx Counties received from Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin yesterday an order directing the city to pay them a total of $70,671 in back salary.
Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, former women's New York State golf champion, and Mrs. Eldon Trimingham of Bermuda reached the final of the inaugural Princess Hotel invitation tournament today.

Ida Tarbell, Burton Rascoe, Clyde Beals, Beatrice Blackmer and Stanley Walker have been selected as the judges of the annual prize story contest of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, according to an announcement yesterday by Miss Ruth Reynolds, chairman of the contest committee.
The cost of living for families of wageearners and lower-salaried workers In large cities dropped 0.6 per cent during the three months ended Dec. 15, the Labor Department announced today.

The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, will open to the public today a special exhibition of "New York's Children's Books" of before 1900. Most of the books have been lent by private collectors.

For the second year in, succession Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr. of Camden, Me., spread-eagled the field to win the qualifying medal in the annual Ormond Beach championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.
Rumors circulated here tonight and were cabled abroad that twenty army officers had fled from Germany into Austria.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order revoking the registration as an over-the-counter broker or dealer of Trustees Collateral Corporation, 110 East Fortysecond Street, New York City.

Leo Diamond, 45-year-old stockbroker, of 1,185 Park Avenue, died early yesterday morning in Flower Hospital of a self-inflicted wound. Mr. Diamond, who had been ill recently, shot himself in his apartment at 7 P. M. Monday night.
The National Youth party in a telegram and letter signed by Jules P. Sommer of 513 East Eightyfourth Street, its president, yesterday urged Governor Lehman to run for re-election.

A plan to set up financial headquarters of the State Republican party at Hamilton and establish a county quota syntem for the collection of funds was approved here tonight by the leaders of the party.

A beer truck, abandoned while in motion a short time after it was stolen, last night ran down and seriously injured a woman and. a man in East Sixteenth Street, smashed two store fronts and damaged a parked automobile.
Prince Nicolas, uncle of King George II, died of a stroke after a ten-day illness at the Grande Bretagne Hotel here this morning.

Nelson M. Stevens, former supervising electrician for New York contractors, who had designed the electrical installations for many hotels and apartments, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 64.
