Mrs. Clara Biddle Davis, widow of Seymour Davis, architect, died at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital last night, after a short illness. Active in philanthropic and church work she was in charge of the Holy Trinity Bazaar last week.

The Senate and Assembly balloted separately today, in advance of a joint session tomorrow, on the selection of two members of the Board of Regents, and the totals clearly indicated the election tomorrow of Gordon K. Bell of New York City, for the one place on which there is a contest.

The directors of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., have accepted an offer by members of the Bronfman family, who are majority common stockholders, to buy $500,000 of 5 per cent preferred stock with warrants attached,

The National Munitions Export Board granted permission during January for the export to Argentina of $2,462,003.40 worth of ammunition and implements of war, principally military airplanes. Other principal purchasers of war materials from the United States were:

Dr. Jerome D. Green, secretary of the corporation of Harvard University, was the principal speaker yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century, held at the hotel Biltmore in commemoration of the founding of Harvard College . in 1636.

Whether the longshore blockade that has stopped all cargo to and from Puerto Rico since Jan. 3 is to be terminated rests on the decision of the New York steamship owners to accept or reject the arbitration worked out by Governor Blanton Winship and accepted-today unanimously by the striking laborers in all ports, according to Labor Commissioner Prudencio Rivera Martinez.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Monday. For the best names ....1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Peak for Buyers' Arrivals Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday established a new peak in the present buying season.

Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," George Earl Raiguel. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Stoneware," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; collection of Greek art (general tour), 2 P. M.; "Gothic Architecture: Germanic Development of Italian Romanesque Forms" (Mathews lecture), C. Grand LaFarge, 4 P. M.

A bonus of $500 will be paid to Army Air Corps cadets after three years' service with tactical units, the Second Corps Area Headquarters on Governors Island announced yesterday in pointing out that about 100 vacancies still remain open in the class to be enrolled at Randolph Field, Texas, on March 1.

An application seeking the dissolution of the Lake Erie Power and Light Company, the Sandusky Railway and the Ohio Utilities Finance Company, all controlled by the Toledo Edison Company, has been filed with the Ohio Publio Utilities Commission.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada in January, together with shipments overseas, totaled 94,267, as compared to 103,668 in January a year ago and to sales of 160,444 in December. In January 1936, sales were 158,572 cars.

In an address yesterday at the opening of the assembly of the Spring term at Barnard College, Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared that he felt the reawakening of the Orient marked a turning point in history.

Listing of 20,000 shares of Abbott Laboratories 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock and 40,000 additional shares of the company's common stock was authorized yesterday by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Jan. 31 showed that the ratio -of gold reserve to notes in circulation was 121.08 per cent, against 123.84 per cent on Jan. 15.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, ruling that the National Bituminous Coal Commission had acted irregularly in fixing a new schedule of higher prices for coal, continued a temporary stay yesterday.

The secret trial of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller continued today with the small committee of Confessional pastors and twenty-eight representatives of the government permitted to attend sworn to secrecy.
The New York Newspaper Guild made public yesterday two resolutions adopted by its representative assembly Monday night.

A rally in the security markets and mild inflation talk- furnished the incentive for fairly aggressive short covering in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today in the last forty-five minutes of trading and carried prices up 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, with the close at the top.

The decision of the House of Representatives yesterday to limit debates on the Farm Bill was accepted on the Cotton Exchange here as foreshadowing the passage of farm legislation, and a wave of buying swept prices into the highest ground reached since last September.

Jacob C. Klinck, Grand Master of the Masons of the State of New York, was the guest of honor at a reception and dinner last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of his connection with banking.
" Public Enemies" Hugh Gant and Alva Hunt were convicted today of bank robbery and sentenced to twenty-five years each in Federal Prison.
Investment bankers asked a Congressional committee today to give them a chance at "real self-regulation" rather than supervision by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Consumptionn of cotton, wool, rayon, silk and linen in the United States in 1937 totaled 4,374,900,000 pounds, the largest total for any post-war year, according to figures issued yesterday by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The total compares with consumption of 4,270,300,000 pounds in 1936.

Tuesday, Feb. 8, 1938. NG-Not given. SL-Slight. ND-No damage. TF-Trifling. CS-Considerable. TL-Total loss. MANHATTAN A. M. Location. Occupant. Damage. 12:57-102 Delancey St.; not given ......ND 1:00-81 E. 113 St.; not given ...........TF 1:37-Bayard and Elizabeth Sts.; auto;
Representative Barton today announced the designation of Crawford D. Winner of 15 West Sixtieth Street, New York City, for appointment to the Naval Academy.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the American Bar Association, and Mrs. Vanderbilt, the Earl of Castle Stewart, the Earl of Dudley, Sir William Cope and Baron and Baroness Amory de la Grange are among the passengers booked to sail today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, Assistant WPA Administrator in charge of Federal art projects, told the House Patents Committee today that her division employed about 325,000 needy men and women.

A demand that the Electric Bond and Share Company register with the Securities and Exchange Commission or stop using the channels of interstate commerce for its business was made in the Supreme Court today by Robert H. Jackson,

Two men were arrested yesterday in an investigation by detectives of the reported disappearance of optical supplies valued at more than $40,000 from the plant of the American Optical Company at 70 West Fortieth Street in the last six months.

A class of seventy-six nurses received diplomas last night at the fifty-fifth annual commencement of the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing, held in the Blumenthal Auditorium on Ninety-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue. Mayor La Guardia addressed the graduating class.
In a letter to Oliver E. Sweet, director of the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Denver Salt Lake Railway Company,

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson will give a luncheon for Lady Decies tomorrow in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Henry A. Berwind and Mrs. George R. Atterbury have come from Radnor, Pa., to the Plaza.
Mrs. Helen Derby Elwell, widow of Joseph B. Elwell, bridge expert, whose murder on June 11, 1920, has never been solved, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after an operation.

Because Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova owes nearly $381,000, two trustees of the Prudence Company, Inc., now going through reorganization proceedings, have asked Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston to compromise a claim of $255,207 against the Brooklyn justice for $5,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

Cotton prices have displayed a rising tendency in the last few days on the belief that the conference report on the Farm Bill would be passed by both houses of the Congress. Under that report, production of cotton this year would be limited to about 10,700,000 bales and

After sitting all day with a cordon of police watching its Bucharest headquarters, the Senate of the Rumanian Fascist Iron Guard announced tonight that in view of last Sunday's incidents, when two Guardists were killed, the organization would take no further part in electoral propaganda.
" Roosty," the Martin Berkeley play which was scheduled to open tomorrow evening at the Lyceum, has been postponed until next Monday. Same place. Simply more time needed for polishing.

Callahan Consolidated Mines, Inc., Wallace, Idaho, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 2,166,300 shares of 10 cent par value common stock,

James Roosevelt and his party, who arrived in Havana by private plane yesterday, for what was described as a recreation trip, flew to Varadero Beach on the north coast of Matanzas Province this afternoon.

With the declaration that no reasonable person can justly assume that the United States is leading "a worldwide naval building race" or that "our country is becoming a militaristic nation," Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, ended today his testimony before the House Committee on Naval Affairs in support of the administration's $800,000,000 naval construction program.

With her head badly lacerated, Mrs. Harriet Brown Nielson; 35 years old, of 161 West Seventy-sixth Street, who was described by Bernard H. Sandler, her former attorney, as a member of a well-to-do California family, a writer. a linguist and a former Olympic swimmer, was found dead yesterday morning in her two-room furnished apartment.

Did Mr. President contemplate another "breathing spell" for business? That question, put to Mr. Roosevelt at his press conference today, when a correspondent asked him to comment on reports from New York, caused a roar of laughter from his colleagues, and the President joined in.
Percy Hutton Fearon, political cartoonist, announced his retirement today after drawing 10,000 cartoons in thirtyfour years. Born in Shanghai,

The groundwork for the coming Anglo-Italian negotiations was partly laid today in a long talk between Count Dino Grandi, the Italian Ambassador, and the Earl of Plymouth, chairman of the Non-Intervention Committee, over the old question of withdrawing "volunteers" from Spain.

Protests against Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, holding office as assistant to the Borough President of Manhattan, and threats of taxpayers' suits to stop his salary and of complaints to Governor Lehman against Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, were flung at the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday by representatives of veterans' organizations, Catholic societies and taxpayers' groups and individuals.

Declaring that the coming November elections will force Washington to "behave" for the next nine months, Kenneth M. Goode of Ryan, Leach Goode, marketing consultants, yesterday predicted that the "long-delayed boom, which might go anywhere on our now thin stock market," should start within a year.

Attired in gray prison denim, which fitted somewhat less perfectly than the $165 suits to which he has been accustomed, J. Richard (Dixie) Davis sat in a cell in Moyamensing Prison today awaiting extradition proceedings to take him back to New York and criminal prosecution.
President Roosevelt discussed relief problems with the Mayors of Chicago, Cleveland, St. Louis and Detroit, and later with Secretary Morgenthau and other government officials,

A $175,000 permanent loan for ten years on the six-story apartment house recently completed on the n W cor Of E Tremont Ave and E 176th St, the Bronx, has been placed for the Tremont Towers, Inc. owners. Jacob Emil Leltner, Inc, were the brokers.

Senator Johnson did not for a moment expect a statement from Secretary Hull in response to his resolution that the United States has an alliance or agreement of a military nature with any other nation.

Perhaps it may be that New York City, with its 1,250,000 pupils and the "world's largest school system," is growing up. At any rate, the weather-worn one-room little red schoolhouse of song and fable is on its way out here.

On the premises at 12-14 W 46th st 44 feet of frontage. Exchange Estates. Inc., Isadore B. Geller, president, gave a mortgage to John Vernou Bouvier for $100,000, payable April 1, 1953, at 2 per cent for the first three years, 2 1/2, 3, 3 1/2 and 4 per cent for the four following three-year periods. It is agreed that the mortgagor will

Morris Ploscowe, 34-year-old graduate of the Harvard Law School and a research student in criminal law, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as a deputy commissioner of investigation at $6,000 a year, under Commissioner William H. Herlands.

ABELES--Jacob, in his sixty-seventh year. beloved husband of Stina, father of Alexander William. Funeral and services from the Stolzenberger Chapel, 450 East 162d St., Thursday, Feb. 10, at 2 P. M. Interment Beechwood Cemetery.

Victor R. Willoughby, general mechanical engineer of the American Car and Foundry Company since 1924, has been elected vice president in charge of engineering, a new office, Charles J. Hardy, president, announced yesterday.

Finance Minister Paul Marchandeau said today that tax changes were being planned to relieve French industry of a part of the burden it now bears. He also announced that the equalization fund for the defense of the franc would be reinforced.

Casks of pickles, cans of tomato soup and cases of Scotch whisky lay yesterday on the splintered loading platform at 530 West Forty-first Street, where for twenty-three years was dumped everything that went into hundreds of Broadway shows except the actors.
Elmore C. Green, hotel man here for twentytwo years, died today in his apartment in the Hotel Statler of heart disease. Mr. Green, who was 67 years old, had been ill since last Friday.

The directors of the Amalgamated Leather Company took no action yesterday on the quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the preferred stock. It was stated that the dividend probably would be considered on March 8.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kisch of East Orange, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hermine Adelaide Kisch, to Herbert Apfelbaum, son of Murray Apfelbaum of Newark, N. J.

Photographs of lightning strokes which travel at the speed of 10,000 miles per second have revealed the existence of "lightning guides" which leap up from the earth and guide the bolt from the clouds to its earthly landing, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers was told tonight.
The District of Columbia Minimum Wage Board has set $13.25 as the smallest weekly wage for Washington waitresses. Any tips the girls receive will be in addition.

Henry Young Jr., chairman of the Assembly committee appointed to investigate the last Gubernatorial election in Hudson County, announced here today the committee would seek the aid of Governor Moore in its thus far futile attempt to get the election records out of a vault in Jersey City.

Fire flared in an oxygen tent over a bed in a ward in Bellevue Hospital at 7 o'clock last night, severely burning a patient receiving treatments and arousing sixty-two other bed patients in the crowded ward to near panic.

State legislation for the registration of trade-marks and the imposition of fees for such registrations is "both unnecessary and undesirable," the Merchants' Association of New York declared yesterday in a letter sent to State Senator Arthur Foran of New Jersey, who,
Two hundred dogs of doubtful pedigree yapped their applause last night when a fox terrier, Whiskers, stole the Sixteenth Annual Pet Show of the Madison Square Boys Club, 312 East Thirtieth Street.

John U. Troy of 108 North Oraton Parkway, Fast Orange, N. J., vice president of the Hump Hair Pin Manufacturing Company of Chicago and head of its New York office, died of a heart attack yesterday in his office in the Woolworth Building. His age was 63.
Mrs. Marguerite Tobey Goring, wife of Howard A. Goring and daughter of the late Colonel Bennett H. Tobey, died here last night at her home after a long illness.

Given any sort of break by the weather man, whose actions during the last two Winters have been anything but what Eastern skiers had hoped for, there will be no dearth of activity for both the recreative and competitive skier this coming holiday weekend.

Charges against the custodians and some of the cleaners in thirteen city buildings were preferred yesterday by Edward J. McGrew Jr., Acting Commissioner of Public Works, following an inspection tour make by David A. Thompson, assistant commissioner.

The New York State Association of Life Underwriters voted yesterday at a meeting is Albany to endorse the opposition of Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, to the present wording of bills before the State Legislature providing for savings bank life insurance.

Doubts in Congressional circles concerning the Administration's foreign policy were largely, if not completely, removed today by a frank letter from Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.
Despite the sensational efforts of Al Curtis in the visitors' cage, the Dartmouth hockey team defeated Brown tonight, 4 to 1, caging three goals in the final session.
Oscar Zinn, former Property Clerk in the New York County District Attorney's office, who retired Jan. 1, died yesterday in his home, 56 Bay Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 65.

The Austrian Government has announced that a number of Yugoslav residents will be expelled immediately in retaliation for the expulsion in December of the Austrian head of the Fatherland Front in Maribor and six others.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision yesterday removed the four executors of the, estate of David Israel, real estate operator, who died on March 27, 1927, on charges of misconduct, bad faith, gross negligence and various acts asserted to have been in breach of trust as executors and trustees.

Endicott Johnson Corporation, shoe manufacturers, announced a 10 per cent pay reduction today affecting about 19,000 employes. The cut, effective next Monday, follows a 20 per cent pay slash for 200 salaried employes.

Carlo Tresca, veteran radical and member of the Prof. John Dewey commission that investigated the Moscow trials and pronounced them "frame-ups," appeared yesterday before Francis A. Mahony, acting chief of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office, to support his charge that Juliet Stuart Poyntz, former Communist leader, missing since last June, had been "lured or kidnapped" to Soviet Russia because she "knew too much" about the Communist movement.

Sources close to the White House said today that President Roosevelt would send a special message to Congress before the end of the week asking that more funds be made available immediately with which to take care of the mounting burden of relief.

Reviewing twenty-five years of income tax history last night at a meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury and Professor of Law at Columbia University, said that income tax collections, which in 1913 provided a little less than 10 per cent of Federal revenues, now account for more than 40 per cent.

The Legislature completed action today on two of Governor Lehman's program bills and forwarded them to him for certain signature. The DunniganKillgrew measure which extends the benefits of unemployment insurance to persons earning more than $3,000 a year was passed by the Senate.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow; HOGS Receipts, 19,000, including 2,500 directs. Market unevenly 15c to 25c. Lower than yesterday's average; bulk good and choice

THE book called "Dry Guillotine"* is said to tell the unvarnished truth about convicts in French Guiana-of the inhuman conditions under which they live, the perversion rampant among them, the brutality, the heat, the disease, the suffering. "Here," the publishers assert,

President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained ninety guests at dinner tonight in honor of Speaker and Mrs. William B. Bankhead. More than 200 additional guests joined the party afterward to hear a musical program given in the East Room.

This city of 6,000 population tossed its red ink out of the window today; it was out of debt. Citizens celebrating the announcement heard City Clerk John Read list local assets as including streets, concrete sidewalks,
Columbia's basketball team ended a three-game losing streak by defeating Union College, 38 to 31, in a non-league encounter in the Lion gymnasium last night.

The five-man American Labor party group in the Legislature Joined today with upState Republicans in criticism of the report of the audit of fourteen milk companies operating in metropolitan New York, which was submitted last night to both houses by Holton V. Noyes; Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

The waiting room of Pennsylvania Station last night echoed the laughter and singing of forty-seven senior students - from Lincoln School, model school at Teachers College, who returned home from a ten-day journey through the South as part of their study, "Living in Contemporary America."
Miss Miriam Stansfield Draper, for twenty-five years-librarian at the Children's Museum, Brooklyn, N. Y., until her retirement ten years ago, died today at the Milton Hospital.

Jacob E. Weissman, in 65 E 96th St; Dora Constance Smart, in 333 Central Park W; Anna Shinderman, Barney Ripps, in 205 W 54th St; Charles J. Harris, James R. Naseef, Margaret Deal, in 55 W 11th St; Juliet Harris. in 10 Park Ave; Edward G. Robison, in 140 E 46th St; Byrne Bowman, Inc, broker.

The fifteen-acre farm, formerly owned by George Letts, on Stadley Rough Road, in the Great Plain section of Danbury, Conn., has been purchased for Summer occupancy by Dr. Clifford W. Hendrickson of New Rochelle.

Thomas C. Wolfe, the novelist, was successful in a suit in Chancery Court here today against James M. Dooher of Rutherford, N. J., author's agent, for the return of three of Mr. Wolfe's original manuscripts which had been entrusted to Mr. Dooher to sell, and also for the accounting of other manuscripts of Mr. Wolfe's which Mr. Dooher sold after February, 1936.

Miss Mary Loretta Snite, daughter of Mrs. Fred B. Snite of River Forest, Ill., and Miami Beach, and Terrence Dillon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Dillon of Hudson, Mich., were married here in St. Patrick's Catholic Church this morning.
The fourteen-story loft and store building at 231-239 West Twentyninth Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms, 18 Vesey Street.

Following reports that the Conservative party was in financial straits, unable to fight an immediate election should an emergency arise, it was announced the party's honorary treasurer, Viscount Greenwood, has resigned.

Federal courts are behind in their work to the extent of 50,000 cases and have no prospect of catching up unless more judges are appointed, Attorney General Cummings told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today in approving the Ashurst-Hatch bill.

The Vatican news service said today that Pope Pius had granted permission for a radio mass to be broadcast every Sunday from Salamanca, headquarters city of Insurgent Spain, for Catholics in Government Spain.

With women's wear manufacturers buying wool fabrics somewhat more freely, and with stocks of both men's wear and women's wear numbers in the hands of buyers substantially liquidated after a long period of slow buying,- trading in wool goods generally has turned upward and better volume may be expected from this point forward, Louis Surut,

The Alexander Hamilton five, led by Joe SydlandAky, who scored 11 points, maintained its grip on first place in the P. S. A. L. Brooklyn Group 1 race yesterday by defeating Boys High, 35-29, on the losercourt.

Modification of the transaction tax, surtax and other forms of added taxes imposed by Turkey on imported merchandise was asked last night by the National Foreign Trade Council in a brief sent to the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington on behalf of

The Maritime Commission thinks that the bids submitted by shipbuilding companies for twelve fast cargo vessels intended for naval auxiliaries are so "excessive" as to make it impracticable to award contracts.

Annoyed at complaints of discourtesies by private guards dressed like policemen, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday a ban, effective March 15 against the wearing of blue uniforms, similar to those of the police, by private policemen, watchmen and guards, except in banks.

James R. Keiser, an instructor in accounting at the University of Pennsylvania, died in the University Hospital today. He was 41. A member of the class of 1918 at Pennsylvania, Mr. Keiser had been on the faculty for sixteen years.
Howard Gillespy, blank-book manufacturer, died yesterday at his home in Saugerties. He was one of the oldest alumni of Rutgers College, which gave him an A. B. degree in 1875 and an A. M. in 1878.

A charge that Lawrence Sullivan, 23 years old, on trial for murder, had been subjected to third-degree methods after his arrest to induce him to confess, was advanced by counsel yesterday in General Sessions.
The Gibson Girl stepped into the foreground of the fashion -picture last night at a special style show at the Hotel Astor, featuring newSpring hats designed by leading French and American- creators.

In the widespread discussion created by the FHA amendments designed to make home buying easier, perhaps too little attention has been paid to the fact that the revised regulations, now in effect, also will promote the erection of homes for rent.

Expansion of public education to include many of the former responsibilities of the home and community was recommended yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's committee on instructional affairs.

Symons Galleries, Inc., prominent art dealer, has leased the six-story building at 12 East Fiftythird Street for its exclusive occupancy upon completion of extensive alterations. This will be the first move of the firm in fourteen years.

Lying in bed in St. Francis Hospital, his arm in a cast, Patrolman Royal W. Pollitt, who was promoted Monday for his part in a pistol battle with five thugs in a Bronx pawnshop, received yesterday his detective's shield from Police Commissioner Valentine while Mayor La Guardia looked on.
The death of George Herbert Daley, sports editor of The Herald Tribune, removes from the newspaper profession and the realm of sport an able and admirable character.

Faced with a $1,000,000 deficit in city funds, Mayor Thomas L. Holling suggested today adoption of the Federal Government's idea of "baby bonds" to meet the crisis. He proposed borrowing $1,000,000 through sale of $10 and $20. bonds, which could be redeemed after the July 1 tax collections.

Before 9,000 boxing fans last night at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx, Johnny Bellus, 134 1/4 pounds, of New Haven, outpointed George Zengaras, 134, of the East Side, in eight rounds. Bellus's early advantage won a hotly waged battle, despite a rally by Zengaras in the last two rounds.

Governor Lehman, in a letter to the chairman of the House Committee on Rivers and Harbors, announced his opposition to the Parsons bill, which would permit diversion of Lake Michigan water into Mississippi River Valley.

The letter of Secretary Hull. which was read on the floor of the Senate yesterday, is a categorical denial of the reports which have been making the rounds, to the effect that the United States has some secret alliance with Great Britain.
J. Ellwood Calhoun, principal of Simon Grata High School here, died in the Graduate Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania last night in his fifty-fourth year.

Nova Scotia's oldest physician, Dr. J. N. Mack, died suddenly last night. He was 93 years old. Born at Mill Village, Queens County, N. S., Dr. Mack studied at Harvard University and was graduated from Bellevue Medical College, New York, in 1875.

Prices of lead and zinc were reduced yesterday by 15 and 25 points, respectively. The new price for lead was 4.75 cents a pound at New York, while prime Western zinc was quoted at 4.75 cents a pound at St. Louis.
The Interstate Commerce Commission up held today the refusal of railroads to absorb switching charges and terminal costs in joint ocean rail shipments between North Atlantic and Southwestern ports.

After a conference today.. between. Governor Moore and Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former superintendent of the State Police Department, the Governor said the subject discussed was the eligibility of the Colonel for a pension.

The Navy Department announced today the light cruiser Omaha, being overhauled at the Norfolk (Va.) Navy Yard, would replace the light cruiser Raleigh in April as flagship of Squadron 40, operating temporarily in Mediterranean waters.

The Police Department, which has been emphasizing a campaign against illegal parking, has become a victim of its own diligence, it was revealed yesterday when two detectives appeared before Magistrate Ford to answer a parking summons.
John Graham Brooks, widely known authority on social and economic problems and a former Unitarian preacher, died today at his home, 8 Francis Avenue, Cambridge.
Miss Eleonora Sears, State champion, and Mrs. C. Crawford "Madeira of Philadelphia led the field into the quarter-finals of the women's national squash racquets tournament today at the Harvard Club.

The election of Joseph Curran as first president of the National Maritime Union was assured yesterday with the announcement that he had been nominated without opposition for the office in a general election of the membership.

Harry A. Arthur, president of American International Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that about 70 per cent of its assets are invested in the general market. Cash now amounts to $4,000,000, against $3,319,286 at the end of 1937, he said.

Senator Borah's comment that proponents of the Equal Rights Amendment appeared intent on creating an equality between the sexes which the Almighty neglected to provide, lent a fillip to today's progress of the hearing on that fourteen-yearold proposal before the Senate Judiciary subcommittee.
Police said they virtually were without clues tonight in their investigation of the theft of jewelry from Mrs. Philip D. Hill, golfer and wife of a British financier.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Leave of absence for ten days, effective on or about Feb. 7, with permission to leave the continental limits of the United States, is granted Capt. Solomon J. Zoller Inf.-Res. 1st Lt. Joseph R. Mascaro, Med.-Res., 525 Bleecker St., Utica, N. Y., 2d Evacuation

Unless they put a bit of drapery on some of the statuary submitted for the 1938 Golden Gate International Exposition, Harris Connick, general manager, is afraid "we'll have the purity leagues down on us."

The two-family dwelling at 1,009 Hudson Avenue, North Bergen, N. J,. was sold by the Courtlandt Building and Loan Association to William Habicht, who will occupy one of the apartments upon completion of alterations. J. I. Kistak, Inc., broker, negotiated the deal.

In the old days Chinese mandarins let their fingernails grow and Chinese women bound their feet. The object in each case was to show that the possessors of the fingernails or feet did no useful work, and this was thought to be a credit to them.

Word was received here today of the death in Washington, D. C., this morning of F. Carleton Hammond of this town, former banker and NRA official. Born here forty-three years ago, the son of the late Mayor Frank Hammond,

A proposal today by private Canadian broadcasting companies that the publiclyowned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation be displaced by an independent nation-wide radio network, with license fees reduced from $2.50 to $1 a year,
Supreme Court Justice Thomas Noonan was requested yesterday by the Bank of Yorktown to decide whether the State Labor Relations Act applied to employes of financial institutions.

Headquarters of the International Typographical Union here an- t nounced today that unofficial returns from 142 of the 860 locals' showed endorsements running four to one against Charles P. Howard for re-election as president.
Mrs. Mary Winston of 105-56 132d Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, got an award of $5,000 damages in her suit against the City of New York yesterday from a jury in Queens Supreme Court.

The net profit of the Ward Baking Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1937, according to the annual report released yesterday, amounted to $1,140,926 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and $29,661 surtax on undistributed income.

The Standard Milling Company, third largest flour milling firm in the country, will move its general offices from New York to Chicago about April 1 and at that time will consolidate the management of its flour milling division in the Chicago office; it was announced today by J. A. Sim, president.
Your editorial on the exclusion of the fine arts in the forthcoming World's Fair was gratefully recognized by artists in the light of condolence in a great bereavement.

Trial of a suit brought by the trustees of the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers to recover $25,000 from his son, Henry H. Rogers Jr., opened yesterday in Supreme Court. The action is based on a promissory note the younger Mr.. Rogers gave his father during the latter's life.

Fresh developments, it was learned from authoritative sources yesterday, have revived the prospect that Herbert Orrin (Frits) Crisler will leave Princeton to become head football coach at the University of Michigan.

Vigorous denunciation from both sides of the House of the rule limiting debate on the crop control conference report to four hours marked the opening of today's session but the rule was adopted by a standing vote of 186 to 99.
Howard Oxenberg of the Park Central A. A. captured the 220-yard senior metropolitan free-style championship last night in the pool of the Downtown A. C. on an A. A. U. sanctioned program.

To Report to H. F. Guerin The following members shall be excused for one day, from 8 A. M. or 9 A. M., on Feb. 10 and 12, and shall be directed to report to Fireman Harry F. Guerin, as follows: Thursday, Feb. 10, at 10 A. M., at the 14th Regiment Armory, 8th Ave. and 14th St., Brooklyn.

Should Latin be pronounced with the English sound of its vowels and consonants or in the weenie-weekie fashion? Personally we don't care a pin. None the less we can't help admiring the fervor which the question has stirred in the letter columns of The Times of London.

The Englewood Field Club- triumphed over the Montclair Athletic Club at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday by 3 to 2 to win the title in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B tournament.
The favorites, paced by top-seeded Bobby Riggs of Chicago, moved en masse today into the second round of the Everglades tennis tournament.
The Hershey Bears strengthened their grip on first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by deeating the last-place Bronx Tigers, 6 to 0, tonight.

The dollar yesterday reversed its recent downward trend and gained slightly in terms of the principal foreign exchanges. The pound sterling lost 1-16 cent and closed at $5.013-16, slightly under its best quotation of the day.

The use of listening devices by detectives to obtain evidence was held today to be an unlawful violation of private rights - by Superior Judge Frank C. Collier in declaring five persons in contempt of court.

Motion-picture dramas have become so alluring to children, many of whom sit through more than one show and miss their dinners, that decisive steps should be taken to remove boys and girls from the theatres at the end of each performance, parents here declared in answering questionnaires distributed by the Bronxville Motion Picture Council, according to a tabulation of replies made public today.

Thirty-three United States Army planes under the command of Lieut. Col. Benjamin G. Wier left here today for Guatemala. Brig. Gen. George H. Brett, commanding the entire group of sixty-two planes that will meet in the city of Guatemala, preceded the squadron early yesterday.
Miss Harriet Forbes of New York has announced the engagement of her adopted daughter, Miss Polly, Forbles-Johnson, to Charles Moorfield Storey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Moorfield Storey of

Professor Lowry Nelson of the University of Minnesota, who is a member of the permanent agricultural commission of the International Labor Organization at Geneva, urged in today's general discussion that the commission give precedence to the problem caused by farm machinery's displacing of workers.

Directors of the Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company today declared 1938 dividends of $1.20 a share, payable 30 cents each quarter. T. H. Banfield, president of the company, announced that net profits for 1937 were $711,460, equal to $1.98 each on the 359,260 shares outstanding.

The personal estate of Charles S. Ross, slain kidnapping victim, was valued at $79,372.45 today when the widow, Mrs. May Ross, filed a petition for letters of administration. She was appointed executrix.

Today the Public Works Administration will begin pouring out nearly a hundred million dollars in a municipal program which, according to PWA estimates, will create more than 500,000,000 man-hours of work and will, in effect, help to prime the business pump.

The seven-room house of Colonial design at 154 Davis Avenue, White Plains, Westchester County, was purchased for occupancy by William C. Ranscht, recently elected to the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County.

There is more danger of a war at present than in the days preceding the World War, said Ambassador Troyanovsky of Russia, who spoke at the University of North Carolina tonight on "World Affairs and the Soviet Union."

In circumstances recalling in some ways the famous visit of King Edward VII in 1903, which paved the way for the Entente Cordiale, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth are to make the first state visit of their reign to Paris on June 28.

In the presence of many relatives and friends who arrived here recently by ship and plane for the occasion, Miss Celia Randolph Robinson was married to Julian Peabody at noon today at Mount Pleasant, the home here of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Ferdinand W. Roebling.
Gus J. Waibel, a traveling salesman for Aronow Brothers, 500 Seventh Avenue, cloak and suit manufacturers, died yesterday morning at his residence, 10 Cooper Street, after a short illness.
The three-story building at 1,970 Flatbush Avenue, near Kings Highway, Brooklyn, has been purchased from the Realty Freehold Corporaion, Walter McMeekan, president, by Dr. Irving Solot. The building,

The Polish delegate to the League of Nations Conference negotiating a convention for refugees from Germany' gave a warning today that he would not sign the proposed treaty. The Netherlands delegate also is understood to have made difficulties, urging that the whole emigration question should first be settled.
Lieutenant Benjamin S. Kelsey, Waterbury, Conn., now stationed at Wright Field, -Dayton, received today the Distinguished Flying Cross for heroism shown on a night flight Dec. 24, 1936.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 7, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Feb. 8: Acushnet, Henderson, Herbert. At San Diego, Feb. 4: Aylwin, Broome, Balch, Borie, Case, Chandler, Cuyama, Cummings, Conyngham, Clark. Cushine.

Mr. Powell was the son of Colonel Walker Powell, former adjutant general of the militia of Canada. As a mechanical engineer, he was with the. Grand Trunk Railway shops of Montreal and served as master mechanic with the Callfornia Southern Railway, now the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe.

Special Master Harold Harper recommended today that a depositors claim for $882,000 against J. C. Penney, former chairman of the board of the closed City National Bank of Miami, be ended with a judgment for Mr. Penney.
Henry Shattuck Ludlow, newspaper owner, philanthropist and civic leader, died at midnight last night at his home in Saratoga Springs after a long illness. He was in his sixtyeighth year.
That Brazil is slowly worming its way out of the exchange embargo which was decreed on Dec. 23 was indicated here today by the new distribution of exchange coverage which started yesterday.

The preliminary annual report of the Radio Corporation of America for 1937, to be issued today, shows an estimated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $9,000,000. This is equal, after full preferred dividend allowances, to 41 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net income of $6,155,900, or 21 cents a common share, in 1936.

The Queensboro Farm Products, Inc., of 35-15 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, was found guilty yesterday of violating the Sanitary Code by Magistrate Alexander Brough in the Municipal Term, 52 Chambers Street.
Charges of incendiarism were added today to the long account of labor terrorism which has plagued Northwestern Oregon for months with bombings, beatings and vandalism.
4th st, 217 E, 24.9x96.2; 1/2 interest, Meshel Zwerdling to Sarah Zwerdling, 193 E 4th St.
Reversing the trend it has followed since the beginning of the year, the city's birth rate turned sharply upward last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.
After being suddenly served with a subpoena yesterday to appear before the Kings County grand jury this morning on its investigation of relief tax evasion in Brooklyn,
Broadway, 686; to 2-story factory and offices; 686 Broadway Corp. 20 Exchange Pl, owner; K B Norton, architect; cost $5,000.

Tapestries, oriental -rugs, paintings, furniture and objects of art of the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller are -to be sold at auction. Mr. Rockefeller, one of the country's leading industrialists and financiers and a nephew of the late John D. Rockefeller Sr., died in September, 1935. His widow,
Sharp criticism of the salaries paid to highranking officers of the National Guard was voiced today at a meeting of the. Assembly Ways and Means Committee, which discussed the Governor's budget.

Ward Willard Claflin of 64 South Arlington Avenue, architect and engineer of the New York State Building and Housing Commission of Brooklyn for twenty-nine years, died yesterday of pneumonia in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old.

The orders of General Iwane Matsui, Japanese commander in the Yangtze Valley, for better discipline at Nanking are being carried out. Unprejudiced observers arriving from Nanking report a great improvement.

The Commission for Relief in Belgium Educational Foundation, Inc., which also is known as the BelgianAmericanE ucationa, Foundation, announced yesterday its annual awards of fellowships for study in Belgium.

Senate filibusterers against the Anti-Lynching Bill yielded the floor long enough today to permit Senator Guffey to make a speech in support of the measure, but then indicated they would hold- it until the Senate is ready to take up the Farm Bill conference report, now before the House.

A three-hour meeting of the American Steamship Owners Association, held yesterday at 11 Broadway to elect new officers, ended with the announcement that appointment of a committee of nine members to draft a plan of reorganization had been authorized.

President Roosevelt indicated during his press conference today that proposals on the renewed underwriting of securities by national banks would be scrutinized with an eye to safeguarding against evils formerly associated with that practice.

A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co. and associates purchased yesterday $33,688,000 of first series, non-callable highway bonds of the State of Mississippi. They paid par for $23,788,000, maturing on Aug. 1, 1938 to 1949, as 3 1/4s, and $9,900,000, due on Aug. 1, 1949,

Dr. Frank B. Cross, secretary of the faculty of the College of Medicine, University of Cincinnati, and for thirty-five years medical director of the Columbia Life Insurance Company, died of heart disease at his home here today. He was 66 years old.

William J. Stephan, 32 years old, of Berlin, N. J., who was convicted of a first degree murder charge in Camden County for the fatal shooting of Curtis W.. Dobbins, 28, in Haddonfield, on Aug. 11, 1936, was put to death in the electric chair at the State prison here tonight.

Reported enrollment of 8,174 for the Spring session in twelve divisions of Columbia University indicates that total university registration will reach 18,000, Edward J. Grant, registrar, announced yesterday, Figures for six Columbia branches are not yet available, and late registration for all schools will continue to the end of the week.
A new printing of Margaret Mitchell's novel, "Gone with the Wind" (Macmillan), has been ordered, making a total of 1,424,348 copies printed to date.

The Board of Higher Education, at a special meeting next week, will consider Mayor La Guardia's plans for a comprehensive two-year college training, course for youths seeking to. become firemen, policemen or members of the Department of Sanitation, Mark Eisner, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

A recommendation that the right to form chapters be denied the American Student Union in any New York City high schools was made yesterday in a report sub-mitted by the committee on teacher growth and student welfare of the High School Principals Association.
For improvement with a home, a plot on Wright Street, Stapleton, S. I., has been purchased by Jacob Toder from the estate of Elizabeth Mahoney.
Manhattan College will be reprerented by a team of thirty-five athletes in the Seventh Regiment course. games on Friday night, it was announced yesterday. Howard Borck,

The Xavier quintet turned back Manhattan Prep, 26-24, in an exciting game yesterday on the winnear's court. Manhattan Prep led at the half, 16-10. The count was tied at 28-all in the last few minutes, when Dan Patrissy scored a goal and a foul to decide the issue.
REVOLT U. S. A., by Lamar Middleton. (Stackpole, $3.) Ten American rebellions analyzed and related to modern politics. SAINT PETER, by Francis Underhill.

Justice and Mrs. Townsend Scudder have been ordered by H. Allen Barton, town counsel, to appear in the Town Court Thursday to answer eleven "pertinent" questions in connection with the keeping of a dog kennel on their property at Round Hill, the legality of which is to be tested before the Superior Court.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today Maurice LaCellis and Nathaniel L. Leek of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
The Boston Bruins tightened their grip on top place in the American Division of the National Hockey League tonight, beating the Chicago Black Hawks, 3-1, before 12,000 fans at the Boston Garden.

Trading was fair in most classes of locally dressed meats. Steer beef was strong to higher and other classes of non-kosher meats were mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Miss Laddie Irwin of Montclair, N. J., 18-year-old former junior metropolitan titleholder, scored a notable victory in the first round of match play for the Palm Beach women's golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

Asserting that "socialization of the con struction industry Is actually in progress," William A. Klinger of Sioux City, Iowa, president of the Associated General Contractors of America, called upon the nation's contractors today to rally the support of industry and business to resist the activities of the Works Progress Administration in the construction field.

A few days ago an Italian publication, Corriere Diplomatico e Consolare--presumably not without official approval-boasted. that "seven LatinAmerican countries are proceeding decisively toward stabilization upon the principles laid down by Premier Benito Mussolini's fascism.

Bob Pirie of Toronto won the 110-yard free-style final in today's British Empire Games swimming program His time was 59.6 seconds, an Empires mark for the new distance. Formerly the short swim was 100 yards.
Their sails billowing in a brisk wind, thirteen trim yachts boiled toward the Bahaman capital tonight in the fifth annual Miami Nassau race with Stormy Weather, last year's winner, setting the pace.
Kenneth C. Gifford has been appointed general sales manager of the Toastmaster Products division of McGraw Electric Company, it was announced yesterday.

The Rumanian police searched in vain today for the Soviet Charge d'Affaires, Feodor Budenko, who has mysteriously vanished. At 8 o'clock Sunday night after a long day's work at the legation he told his colleagues he was tired and was going home to rest.

The marriage of Miss Lucille Phillips Carmer, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs Frederick Phillips Carmer of New York, to William Lawrence Wilson, also of this city took place yesterday afternoon at the home of City Magistrate Overton Harris, a close friend of the bride's family, at 75 East Fifty-fifth Street.
Calvin L. Vincent, State commander of the Grand Army of the Republic in 1931 and 1932, died today at the home of a son. He was 91 years old.

Columbia's fencing team scored its second straight victory by deeating St. John's, 15-12, on the Lion strips last night. Losing the opening foils bouts, 5 to 4, the Light Blue bladesmen returned to win with the epee, 6-3, and with the saber 5-4.

Lou Gehrig yesterday sought an increase in pay from Colonel Jake Ruppert in the latter's brewery, and departed from a one-hour discussion feeling that maybe he had made a mistake in even mentioning the matter to the owner of the Yankees.

General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, here aboard their yacht Winchester, were luncheon guests, today of'Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Purchase of New York. Mr. and Mrs. S. A. Lynch of New York entertained Mr. and Mrs. August Rust Oppenheim, Mrs. Eugene Byrnes, Mrs. Frank Comerford and Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Ball at the Surf Club.

Their sails billowing in a brisk wind, thirteen trim yachts boiled toward the Bahaman capital tonight in the fifth annual Miami Nassau race with Stormy Weather, last year's winner, setting the pace.

Calvin L. Vincent, State commander of the Grand Army of the Republic in 1931 and 1932, died today at the home of a son. He was 91 years old.

Columbia's fencing team scored its second straight victory by deeating St. John's, 15-12, on the Lion strips last night. Losing the opening foils bouts, 5 to 4, the Light Blue bladesmen returned to win with the epee, 6-3, and with the saber 5-4.

Lou Gehrig yesterday sought an increase in pay from Colonel Jake Ruppert in the latter's brewery, and departed from a one-hour discussion feeling that maybe he had made a mistake in even mentioning the matter to the owner of the Yankees.

Lynch of New York entertained Mr. and Mrs. August Rust Oppenheim, Mrs. Eugene Byrnes, Mrs. Frank Comerford and Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Ball at the Surf Club.

Counsel for Wendell F. Bowers, confessed slayer of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, blamed the court and the prosecutor today for the youth's predicament and asked for mercy for his client on the ground that he was a social misfit.

Price Nicolas was born in Athens Jan. 22. 1872, the third son of King George I of Greece, who had been Prince Wilhelm of Denmark before he ascended the Greek throne in 1863. In his memoirs Prince Nicolas related a few years ago that in his boyhood the royal palace in Athens was "neither sanitary nor habitable, according to our modern standards."
Mrs. James H. Kennedy entertained today with a large reception for her niece, Mrs. George Rich, and Mr. Rich, her guests at Kenlewihai. Mrs.

The marriage of Miss Doris. Lane Laidlaw of this city to William Edward. Dillmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dillmeier of Garden City, L. I., which had been planned for today in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral, has been postponed indefinitely,

Having Previously clinched the title, Midston House added another victory in the closing team matches in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tournament yesterday by defeating Bayside 3-2. The champions finished with nine victories and one defeat.

The Seamen's Bank-- for Savings, which was established. in 1829, issued a passbook for its one-millionth account yesterday to Giles Chester Stedman, captain of the-.Washington of the United States Lines, who placed it in trust for his infant nephew, Giles Stedman Brown.

Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff and Princess Vladimir Koudacheff entertained with a luncheon and bridge yesterday at Sherry's. Among the guests were Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin, Mrs. James H. Caldwell, Mrs. Skinker Matthews, Mrs. Edward Fales Coward, Mrs. Woodin Miner, Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, Miss Sara Lippincott Richards, Mrs. Noah MacDowell,
According to radio messages received yesterday, the Cunard White Star liner Samaria will not arrive until tomorrow afternoon, by which time the passengers will have been on board for twelve days.

Defense Minister Edouard Daladier, who will appear tomorrow before the Army, Navy and Air Commissions jointly assembled, is expected to make a plea for increased defense appropriations. It is probable that he will ask especially that credits for the navy and air force be increased.

The Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn shortly will take estimates for additions and alterations to their bank and office building at 525-45 Broadway, Brooklyn, according to Brown's Letters, Inc., construction reports.
The patient sky bends down to hold The hill, the moon, the winding road Whereon climbs, heavy with his load Of agitated rule, that old King of the world and lord of plan, A solitary man.

There is no place like home. At least, there is no place like Councilman Quinn's home on Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Borough of Queens. Mr. Quinn's home has no bathtub, but it has his name in large letters on the plate-glass windows in front. It has no stove, but it has a chair. It has no bed, but it has a desk.

A reorganization of the Medill School of Journalism of Northwestern University to put it on a professional basis was approved today by the board of trustees of the university. Establishment of the institution as a separate school was approved.

Mr. and Mrs. Waldron Kintling Post of 290 Park Avenue and Bayport, L. I., have received word from their daughter, Mary, Viscountess Lymington of London, that she will be married to John Boothby How, also of London, in that city on Saturday.

Hierbert Orrin (Fritz) Crisler resigned tonight as head football coach at Princeton. He will assume the same post at Michigan and in the near future fill the chair of Fielding H. (Hurry Up) Yost as director of athletics.
Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Robbins of Boston have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Celina Fobbins, to Edmund H. Kellogg of this city and Morristown, N. J.

Preliminary tests of a radio facsimile system over WOR's 710-kilocycle channel were carried out early I today between the New York studio, 1,440 Broadway, and a receiver set up in the L. Bamberger Co. department store in Newark, N. J.

A campaign to raise $250,000 for the Swedish Hospital in Brooklyn will open at 12:30 P. M., today with a parade of about thirty automobiles from the hospital, at Bedford Avenue and Dean Street, to the Swedish, Engineers Club, 27 West Fifty-first Street.
Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N. Y., former New York State women's golf champion, on the Princess Hotel invitation women's. tournament today by defeating Mrs. Eldon Trimingham of Bermuda, 3 and 2.

World s Fair advertising apparently will appear again on the 1939 auto license plates in New York State, despite all the furor this year when the legend, "New York World's Fair," first made its appearance.

Authority to abandon part of a line extending from Hopkinton to Ashland, Mass., and partial approval for abandonment of a branch from Milfore to Hopkinton was granted today to the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An investing client of Louis M. Rogovin bought from the Bocar Realty Corporation the recently completed six-story apartment house at 20 Crooke Avenue, Brooklyn. The building is on a plot 90 by 142 feet and is said to have been held at $300,000. Joseph Aranow was attorney for the seller and H. Paul Shanik for the buyer.
Slow in making its start, a revamped Navy team played some fast basket ball in the latter stages of today's game to defeat William and Mary by 61-20, the biggest score of the season for the Middies.

After these many years, during which much good white paper was blackened and hundreds of discussions held, a group of "fresh water anglers" have organized a unit with an ambitious program and an active membership.

Liberia enjoys a balanced budget and the healthiest financial condition of its history, President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull heard today from Lester A. Walton, American Minister to Monrovia. Mr. Walton is in the United States on a leave of absence from his post.

Charges that Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers has built a "Chinese wall" around the metropolitan area and effectively barred products in intrastate as well as In interstate commerce,-were made by Walter Gordon Merritt, special counsel for fourteen electrical manufacturers, before the policies division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria yesterday.
Governor Lehman signed the DunniganKillgrew bill extending the benefits of unemployment insurance to persons earning more than $3,000 a year.

The question whether Chancellor Adolf Hitler is stronger than his discontented generals. seemed to have been answered in the affirmative by last week's army and Cabinet shake-up, but it was raised again in diplomatic quarters today by reports that three generals had offered their resignations in protest against nazification of the army.
Warners, Universal, Paramount, Walter Wanger, Metro and Fox disclosed today plans for placing in production new or recently purchased stories.

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., former New Jersey State titleholder, advanced to the semi-finals of the annual Palm Beach women's championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. She scored over youthful Miss Laddie Irwin of Montclair, N. J., winner of the metropolitan junior crown in 1935 and 1935, by 7 and 5.
A test suit to determine whether members of the old Board of Aldermen can now collect from the city the pay cuts taken from their salaries in 1933, 1934 and 1935 was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

The Association for Germanism Abroad in a poster here attacks the Italian Government for the "persecution of the German minority in South Tyrol." The poster urges Germans to join the association in order to take part in the struggle against Italian persecution. The poster also states:
THE HOUSE THAT HITLER BUILT, by Stephen H. Roberts. (Harper, $3.) An account of the Nazi regime in Germany.

The stock market here today reflected yesterday's stronger tendency in Wall Street and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while among the foreign bonds German loans continued firm. Transatlantic shares were well supported; among them,

Dr. Alexander Grant Ruthven, president of the University of Michigan, issued a statement tonight confirming the selection of Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, Princeton football coach, as head coach and also an administrator in the Wolverine athletic department.

Professor Gilbert Murray, chairman of the League of Nations Union, astonished an audience at the National Liberal Club today with the statement that he had "reason to believe that we Great Britain] had given the American Government an assurance that we are ready at once to support them in any action' they may take in facing any risk."

The Chicago Mail Order Company has re-elected the following officers: E. M. Schnadig, president; E. L. Schnadig, executive vice president; C. A. Bethge, M. C. Goldman, M. L. Kahn and S. Hexter, vice presidents, and R. L. Arhnheim, secretary-treasurer.

Sharp denials that a group of powerful insiders of the NewYork Stock Exchange, with or without the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had picked 0. Max Gardner of North Carolina to be the Exchange's first paid president were placed on record

The Tydings-Miller amendment to the Sherman Anti-Trust Act has resulted in an average price increase of 13.8 per cent to the consumer on pricefixed brands in the New York metropolitan area, Q. Forrest Walker, economist, of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., told the Cincinnati Advertising Club at a luncheon meeting today.

The Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States and Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway, will share the residuary estate of Miss Lucy D. Akerly, daughter of the late Rev.

Maritime unions affiliated with the C. I. O. scored four victories and the American Federation of Labor scored one in elections conducted on American-flag ship lines by the National Labor Relations Board, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board.
The Canal Company, manufacturers of men's neckwear here, closed its factory today when its employes refused a demand of the three owners that they join a C. I. O. union. The plant,

Robert Irwin, under first-degree murder indictments in the slaying of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and Frank Byrnes, a boarder in their East Fiftieth Street home, last Easter, again refused yesterday_ in: his-cell in the Tombs to answer questions put by the lunacy commission named to examine him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is one subject that the little business man's committee did not discuss with the President-the effect, if any, that foreign affairs are having on business, and what, if anything, this government can do about it.

Simon Goldberg, Polish violinist, whose studies were conducted largely with Carl Flesch in Germany, was heard here for the first time last night at Carnegie Hall. Although Mr. Goldberg is yet in his late twenties, he has for four years been concert master of the Dresden Philharmonic Orchestra under Erich Kleiber and Fritz

Four bills drafted by the Princeton Local Government Survey, with the object of saving New Jersey taxpayers millions of dollars through broadening of State regulatory and supervisory powers over local spending-units, were introduced at tonight's meeting of the Assembly.

" Short-term" thinking and quarterly budgets. by advertisers were cited yesterday as major causes of dissatisfaction with the current advertising situation by Leo E. McGivena, president of Briggs Varley, at the monthly luncheon of the New York Newspaper Promotion Group at the Advertising Club.

With Eddie Sadowski leading the attack with. fifteen points, the Seton Hall College basketball team swept to an impressive 44-to-33 triumph over St.. Francis College in the latter's gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.
A special Supreme Court jury tonight convicted Councilman George R. Reilly of fraudulently obtaining city pay under an assumed name.

Fred M. Wilkes, who peddled ideologies and panaceas to the masses in the chief soap-box forums of the world, died yesterday afternoon of a pulmonary disease in Bellevue Hospital. In his seventyseventh year, he had yet to find a personal millennium, for his friends were trying last night to save him from a pauper's grave.

Mrs. Abbie Church Rickard, national treasurer of the Girl Scouts, Inc., and the wife of Edgar Rickard, mining engineer and president of the Pejepscot Paper Company, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital after a two-month illness.

Passage of the Governor's budget at the earliest date in years was made possible today, as legislative leaders of both parties agreed on several cuts, and additional appropriations as well, which raises the total to $386,364, 615.
Three gangland executioners, dressed as hunters, mortally -wounded one man in Chicago Heights today and shot down three others in a manner reminiscent of the St. Valentine's Day massacre of 1929.

A fourteen-point outburst in; the opening minutes gave the- New York University quintet a running start on favored St. John's before 16,507 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night and the Violet profited by this advantage to upset the Redmen, 40 to 33.
In a seven-minute court proceeding, Wendell F. Bowers was sentenced today to die in the electric chair for the murder of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter on Dec. .13.

Sir Truby King, an authority on mother and child health, died today at the age of 79. More than thirty years ago he founded the Royal New Zealand Society for the health of women and children, later named the Plun ket Society.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, seeking her third successive women's national squash racquets singles title, advanced to the semi-final round of the championship tournament at the Harvard Club today by vanquishing Miss Anne Strobhar and Mrs. C. Crawford Madeira, both of Philadelphia.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 12,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was strong to 10 cents higher than Tuesday's average, lightweights showing the most advance. Top, $8.90;

John H. Kimball, 52 years old, whose address was given as Manor Inn, Larchmont, N. Y., and who told the police he was a banker, was arrested last night at the East 104th Street police station on charges of leaving the scene of two accidents.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Stifel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Stifel of Pleasant Valley, a to H. Dewey Quarrier of Wheeling, took place this afternoon at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. A. Bomberger, rector of St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church, this city.

A card party and supper under the auspices of the Ladies of Charity will be held tonight at Schrafft's in West Fifty-seventh Street for the benefit of the various philanthropic enterprises furthered by the organization.

Any amendment of the Wagner Act, specifically a change designed to make labor unions responsible for acts of their members, was opposed last night by J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor -Relations Board, in an address before a forum of the division of general education of New York University.
A general meeting of shareholders of Allgemeine Elektricitas-Gesellschaft (General Electric Company of Germany) will be held in Berlin on Feb. 24, it was announced yesterday.

Several independent steel companies acted late on Tuesday to reduce the price of cold reduced and oiled sheets by $4 a ton on the eve of the signing of a new agreement between subsidiaries of United States Steel Corporation and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

Returning to Montclair after an absence of seven years, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conducting, gave a concert tonight before more than 1,200 persons, a capacity audience, in the Montclair High School auditorium.

Governor Moore angrily refused today to aid an Assembly committee in its effort to obtain Hudsdn County election books and registry lists for use in its investigation of the plurality of 129,000 he received there in last November's election.
The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendations of

Although Yale easily defeated Brown by 47 to 29 in their annual swimming meet tonight, Mat Soltysiak's breast-stroke speed gave the visitors the victory in the medley relay event and enabled Brown to slash -nearly seven seconds off the New England intercollegiate record. He also swam anchor on the winning 400-yard relay team.

A bill to carry out his plan for the construction of ten transcontinental selfliquidating super-highways, at a cost of from $6,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000, was introduced today by Senator Bulkley of Ohio, who said that President Roosevelt looked with favor on the proposal..

Syracuse defeated Army at basketball today, 36 to 31, in one of the fastest and hardest played games staged on the West Point court this season. Army's hockey team won this afternoon's match from Hamilton College, 1-0. The only score of the game was the result of Rich Curtin's try from in front of the net on a pass from Sussman in 3:44 of the second period.

Agreement on a thesis that the interests of Negroes and whites were identical was reached by speakers at the annual meeting yesterday of the National Urban League for Social Service Among Negroes at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East- Twenty-second Street.

Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, announced today the granting of certificates of voluntary dissolution to the City-Center Building and Loan Association of Jersey City and the Fortune Building and Loan Association of Paterson, following applications made by their directors and shareholders.

The Soviet Union generally and the Communist party in particular is now in the process of a great "post-purge" reorganization. This does not mean that the purge is entirely ended in the sense that efforts to unmask and punish "hyphenated enemies" will be abandoned.

The marriage of Miss A. Geraldine Shepard, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Bishop Shepard of 212 East Fortyeighth Street and the late Mr. Shepard, to William Sutcliffe Sagar of Greenwich, bonn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Sagar of Methuen, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon at 3 East Seventyseventh Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Otis Rice.

Liquor package stores and the bars and grills of the city purchase 80 per cent of their month's liquor requirements in the first two weeks of the month and pay 70 per cent of their bills in that period since the State Liquor Authority issued its ruling Dec. 1 that all liquor bills

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a buffet dinner last night in her apartment at the Waldorf-Astoria and afterward took her guests to a skating party at the Rockefeller Plaza rink. The hostess took over the skating area for the fete, which was marked by special entertainment and decorative effects.

With registrations totaling 800 for the first three days of their annual trade exhibition, sponsors of the notion show being held this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania reported a gain of 25 per cent in the numbers of buyers attending the event this year compared with the corresponding period a year ago.

Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today he had been informed that radio stations in the north-central area "had leased time to certain persons to engage in the wrongful activity of seeking
Compulsory fingerprinting of all children entering the public school system was disapproved yesterday by the Board of Education in a 4to-2 vote opposing the measure now before the State Legislature.

The largest turnover in peacetime history among general officers of the army will take place during 1938, no fewer than twenty-six brigadier and major generals having already been slated for retirement and others may be "elected" for physical reasons over which only the examining doctors have control.

James M. Kurn, former president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, testified yesterday in Supreme Court that he had feared loss of his $50,000-a-year position with the road if he opposed in 1926 its purchase of 183,333 shares of stock in the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway. As a trustee of the road,

A mortgage for $17,500 on 200 Bleecker St, held by the Mortgage Commission as trustee from Stephen Guardino, was extended to Jan. 13, 1941, 31/2 to 41/2 per cent. The Union Dime Savings Bank extended to Feb. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent, with quarterly amortization of $625, a mortgage for $245,625 on 36 Gramercy Park held from the Gramercy Park Club, Eran C. Dresser, President.

As the guest of the Belgian people and the Belgian Government, Herbert Hoover sailed yesterday to revisit for the first time in twenty years the scenes of his work at the head of the Relief Commission during war days.

Efforts by steel producers and consumers to appraise the effect on business of this week's negotiation of a wage contract by the United States Steel Corporation and the S. W. O. C. have not been fruitful, according to The Iron Age.

The Federal Power Commission today allocated to the first power development at Bonneville on the Columbia River in Oregon and Washington $11,682,400 of the estimated total cost of $53,188,800 to June 30, 1938, of the entire project. The project will be ready for commercial operation on or about June 30, the commission said.

Anticipating further municipal improvements on the West Side of Manhattan during the months just ahead, civic, business and realty leaders, as represented by the West of Central Park Association, are laying plans to promote an improved appearance for their neighborhood, to make it even more attractive to prospective residents.
J. F. T. O'Connor, retiring Controller of the Currency, urged Congress today to give bank executives another year to repay to their institutions debts incurred before 1933.

Cleveland Amory of Milton tonight was elected president of The Harvard Crimson. Other officers. elected were: Managing- editor, Caleb Foote, Belmont; business manager, J. Francis Dammann Jr., Winnetka, III.; editorial. chairman, Wildworth S. Rant, West Hartford, Conn.; executive editor,

Margery Sharp, author of "The Nutmeg Tree," will arrive on the Bremen this afternoon. This is her first trip to America as an author, though she visited this country several years ago as a member of the British universities women's debating team. On the Bremen also come corrected proofs of Phyllis Bottome's new novel, "The Mortal Storm," which Little, Brown will bring out in April.
Stocks eased and closed irregular after extending gains moderately; turnover, 747,770 shares. United States Government bonds irregular, rail and foreign issues higher; transactions, $5,928,000.

Up-State is virtuous. Down-State is wicked. Wall Street is the capital of the forces of evil. These things have been said so many times that believers in them are a multitude. Still, it is rather curious to find the Republican State Executive Committee setting up a central agency for the collection of campaign funds in rural Madison County and Hamilton town.

The nomination of Adolf A. Berle Jr. to be Assistant Secretary of State was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt. The vacancy he would fill was created by the appointment of Hugh R. Wilson as Ambassador to Germany.

Professor Gildersleeve made even errataa" (in the footnotes) as readable as the text. One remembers his contempt for the vowel that had failed to emulate the example of its virtuous neighbor and had taken on an accent that did not belong to it; and the other vowel that had crept under the shelter

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1, 1937, of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company of Cleveland.
Miss Lida Cooper Woodring, sister of Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, died today after a long illness in a hospital here.
Nicholas Longworth Fry, president of the Fry Brothers Company, manufacturers of commercial laundry supplies, died at his home today of a heart attack. His age was 66.
Three bandits held up the Arena Bar on Biscayne Boulevard this morning, rifled a bank of private safe deposit boxes, and escaped with cash and jewelry unofficially estimated at $50,000 to $100,000.

Lloyd's announced tonight that the United States liner Manhattan was refloated with the aid of a tug after she had run aground in a fog soon after having left Hamburg, Germany, for New York. She continued her voyage.
Mrs. Harriet Manning Trenchard, wife of Supreme..Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard, died today at her home, 816 Riverside Avenue, after an illness of four weeks.

A grand little veteran of an era fast fading, Aurel Joliat, whose placid features camouflage the power and courage jammed within his 135-pound frame, goes into battle tomorrow night with the Montreal Canadiens against Chicago for his 700th National Hockey League engagement.

Japan's replies to the requests of the United States, Britain and France for assurances regarding her naval construction were reported to be virtually ready yesterday. If Tokyo press reports are accurate, the assurances will be refused. [Page 1.]

An increase of $2,632,251 in the 1938 budget for Hudson County was indicated tonight in the tentative schedule prepared for submission to the board of freeholders Friday. The total for almost fifty- items is $16,007,333, compared with $13,375,081 for 1937.

George W. Alger, arbitrator, denied yesterday demands of the Greater New York Council of the Building Service Employes International Union for a 15 per cent wage increase and a reduction of working hours from 48 to 40 a week in contracts with the Midtown Realty Owners, Inc., Association and the Penn Zone Association, Inc.

A legislative purge of the City Council, which yesterday passed a 2 per cent city sales tax over the Mayor's veto, was demanded tonight by Mayor Wilson, addressing more than 3,000 protesting citizens at a mass meeting.
The Cornell Club, winner of the title in Group II, downed the Princeton Club, Group I victor, in the play-off at the Squash Club yesterday in Class ?? of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, on trial here in Common Pleas Court with Genevieve Owens on a charge of slaying William Barhorst, a bus driver, in a Bellville hold-up, is a victim of "marihuana madness," her counsel said today.

Accused of having started a fire in which three persons were fatally injured last Jan. 1, John Wade, 26 years old, a former WPA watchman, who said he had no home, was questioned by Brooklyn detectives last night and subsequently booked on charges of homicide and arson.

The news spread rapidly through Protestant Berlin today that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller had abandoned his defense before the emergency court that is trying him secretly for sedition and had dismissed his three attorneys.

The Conservation Department announced today that eight hunters lost their hunting and fishing rights for one to ten years as a result of 1937 hunting accidents, bringing to forty-three the total number disciplined under a 1937 law.
