The British Government has hurried ahead eagerly to clear the ground for a reconciliation with Italy. Yesterday one obstacle was disagreement over what would constitute "a substantial withdrawal" of foreign troops from Spain.

The Montclair A. C. squash tennis team gained a firm grip on first place in the metropolitan Class A interclub series last night by defeating the Columbia University Club, thus smashing the tie that had existed with the Columbians for league leadership.

A sale of china, glassware and silver, the first in a series of similar sales, will take place next Monday at the Bargain Box, Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, for the benefit of charitable organizations aided by the shop. Later sales in the series will be held on March 7 and March 21.

The Canadian Pacific Railway advanced $4;235,707 to its controlled Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Saint Marie (Soo) Railway in 1936, bringing advances to this company to $21,234,170, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission which was made public yesterday.

The versatility of cotton as a textile fiber was one of the ideas stressed most strongly at Cotton Futures 1938, the fourth annual fashion show of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, in the ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.
Red-haired Hope Dare, Broadway show girl, was told today she was not wanted here, as a charge that she was a suspicious character was dismissed.

The United States Steel Corporation, acting for four of its subsidiaries, employing 240,000 men, renewed "indefinitely" yesterday its contract of March, 1937, with the Committee for Industrial Organization. The contract, which was to have expired on Feb. 28, will be continued as of March 1.

General Chou En-lai, noted Communist party leader, has been appointed vice minister of the mass training department under the military affairs commission. The department, which has the status of a ministry, is headed by General Chen Cheng, former vice minister of war.
The stockholders of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company, meeting in St. Louis, ratified yes- of terday a proposal to increase the be authorized- common shares from no 350,000 to 500,000.

Bob Pirie, lanky Canadian Olympic swimmer, gained major honors today in the swimming competition of the 1938 British Empire games. Pirie, 6-foot-4 Toronto athlete, cracked Empire records in the 110-yard and 440-yard free style events.
The House approved the conference report on the Crop Control Bill today by a vote of 263 to 135, and sent it to the Senate, where it will be taken up tomorrow.

Construction of the rail transportation building that is to house the $3,000,000 railroad exhibit at the World's Fair was started yesterday with the breaking of ground at formal ceremonies on the fair site. J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad,

Milk is in politics. Consequently it is unlikely that even the State audit of the books of fourteen of the largest milk distributing companies in this city will settle anything or will quiet the suspicious. The audit shows that the fourteen companies had an average profit of 11.06 per cent on net tangible assets and of .464 cent per quart in 1936. That, however, was a year under State milk control.

Nation-wide department store sales in January showed a drop of 4 per cent under the figures for the same month a year ago, according to the report issued today by the Federal Reserve Board. The survey covered the sales of 536 stores located in 260 cities.
The Guaranty Trust Company will receive until noon on Feb. 14 written proposals for sale to it of Bedford Pulp and Paper Company, Inc., first mortgage 6 1/2s, due Dec.

Solly Krieger, Brooklyn middleweight title threat, knocked out Johnny Rossi of Worcester, Mass., in the fourth round of their scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Hippodrome, last night. Rossi visited the canvas eight times. One minute 59 seconds of the fourth had elapsed when he was counted out.

Dr. Curtis B. Haley, official statis- news office stitistician of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, reported today that the denomination's membership had increased by 35,261 in 1937, to a total of 2,885,239. The number received on profession of faith during the year was 95,823.

The American Institute of Steel Construction announced yesterday the appointment of a jury of nationally known engineers and architects to select the prize-winning designs in its tenth annual bridge design competition for engineering and architectural students.

The shooting of four Estonian frontier guards last night by Soviet guards, who alleged that the Estonians had transgressed the border line, has aroused deep resentment all over Estonia. It is held that the Russians cold-bloodedly retaliated for the recent shooting of two Soviet soldiers who were said to have entered Estonian territory.
By a system of coordination which as nearly approaches totalitarian methods as possible under a parliamentary regime, France is preparing to meet the darkening international situation.

A public showing of the Sidney Janis collection of modern painting will be held at the Janis residence, 1 West Eighty-fifth Street, on Sun day afternoon from 1 to 6 o'clock. This event has' been arranged for the benefit of the child welfare work of the Women's Division to Aid the Children of Spanish Democracy.

Policy holders and beneficiaries of the New York Life Insurance Company were paid more than $191,000,000 last year, Thomas A. Buckner, chairman, told directors of the company at their meeting yesterday. He said this brought payments by the company to more than $2,000,000,000 in ten years.

At the conclusion of a five-day hunting visit Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent of Hungary, made a spectacular entry into Warsaw this afternoon on his way home from Bialowieza Forest, where he shot eight boars and a lynx, the latter a great rarity there nowadays.

Proposed amendments to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, which have been submitted to Congress and which would result in Federal regulation of interstate traffic moving on the Erie Canal and in American ships operating on the Great Lakes, were condemned by the Shippers Conference of Greater New York at its monthly meeting yesterday in the assembly room of the Merchants Association.

Announcement has been made by Mr. fro and Mrs. S. Pierre Field of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Barlow Field, to Norborne Pescud Gatling Jr. of New York and Brewster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gatling of Brewster, formerly of Lynchburg, Va.

The meeting of the State Executive Committee of the Republican party, which ended early this morning, appeared today to have left ruffled feelings among the-members. The friction which developed at the meeting was not serious, it was said, because it came up over minor matters.

Trustees of the $27,600,000 Series F-1 mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company reported yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler that the assets securing the issue had been placed on a stable administrative basis and that they expected to have available during the current year for distribution to certificate holders and compenstation of the trustees about $1,295,000.
Chancellor John G. Bowman announced tonight a sweeping change in control of athletics at the University of Pittsburgh, shifting it from the old athletic council to an all-faculty committee.

Former President Herbert C. Hoover sailed on the United States liner Washington yesterday for Belgium, where, as a guest of the Fondation Universitaire, Belgian branch of the Commission for Relief in Belgium Educational Foundation,

Yesterday in this space, preceding an account of an imaginary dialogue between a statesman abroad and his representative here, the following appeared: "Every once in awhile * * * it must be that a Foreign Minister, reading of the activities of M,. Johnson and Mr. Borah, and questions addressed to Admiral Leahy, picks up his transoceanic telephone and gets through to his Ambassador in Washington." Today this communication was received:

The Workers Alliance, which spends much of its time generating "pressure" against the relief policies of the Department of Welfare, had a full measure of "pressure" directed against it yesterday by the city department;

The corporation counsels of several cities, after a visit yesterday to Governor Lehman, disclosed today that they are seeking immediate relief, through legislation, from a tax assessment problem which threatens their cities' debt limit, and thus the constitutionality of their outstanding obligations.

Francis Peabody, Boston lawyer and one of the leaders in the social and financial life of New England, died today at his Highfield estate after several months of illness. He was 83 years old. Funeral services will be in Grace Church, Salem, at noon Friday.

EVERY few minutes the long, lanky and disconsolate visitor would peer out the window. He had a woolen skating cap on his head and was wearing skis under his arms, where they didn't seem to fit. He said he was getting ready to mush int the north for the Dartmouth Winter Carnival at Hanover, N. H., and the outlook was desolate. No snow in sight.

Mrs. Elsa Cover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stewart Cover of this city and Copenhagen, Denmark, will be married on Monday to Gerard B. Lambert Jr. of Princeton, N. J., in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Rockwell S. Brank. The couple took out a license yesterday at the Municipal Building, but no previous announcement had been made of their engagement.

Mrs. Jean Cochran Atwell gave a dinner tonight at the Alibi. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hill, Sir George and Lady Prescott, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Mario Pansa, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Legendre, Lord and Lady Stanley, Mr. and Mrs. John Gaston, Mr. and Mrs. T. Dennie Boardman 2d.

Warning of the possibility of government control over business, the New York Board of Trade registered its unanimous opposition yesterday to the pending Borah-O'Mahoney bill providing for Federal licensing of industry.
The government's preparations against an enemy once more, as in 1915, threatening to cut off imports of food on which Britain's population must live,

With the addition yesterday of Charlie Beetham of the Curb Exchange the finest 600-yard field that yet has been assembled -this season was completed - for the special invitation 600 at the Seventh Regiment games at the armory tomorrow night.

Thomas J. Conway, an executive of-the Dainty Maid Shoe Company and prior to that Eastern representative of the Holland Shoe Company, died yesterday at his home, 210-05 Hollis Avenue, Belleaire, Queens, at the age of 54.

Mrs. Theresa Proops, who saw much of Harlem grow from farm land to a bustling business and residential community, sold yesterday a realty holding that had been in her possession for forty years. She disposed of the three buildings containing twenty-five apartments and six stores at 582, 584 and 586 Lenox Avenue to the Beret Realty Corportion, represented by Lester E. Tomback, attorney.

Repeal of the sale Rogers-Allen law, which permits the establishment of producers' and distributors' bargaining agencies for marketing and price-fixing of a large percentage of milk sold in the State, was advocated in a bill presented to the Assembly today by Daniel Flynn, Manhattan Democrat.

The commission of lawyers that is drafting a law for the election of delegates to the proposed constitutional convention will also prepare for the government a draft of a new constitution, according to the local press.

After he had been rescued by a patrolman from a. threatening crowd in front of a tenement at 93 Second .Avenue, where a fire had been discovered in a baby carriage in a first-floor hallway, a man describedd by the police as William Sinchichen, 55, of 338 East Twentythird Street, was taken to the Fifth Street station last night and booked on a charge of attempted arson.
Indicating that in the future it may adopt as a general rule the practice of striking from its list securities which have become "worthless,"

An appalling picture of mass misery is given in figures released here today by the Central Emergency Relief Commission, the official organization for coordination of war relief work. The commission estimates that 10,000,000 fled from their homes in areas occupied by the Japanese and made their way into interior provinces, where 5,000,000 are destitute and near starvation.
The Earl of Cawdor, the Countess de la Falaise, Ely Culbertson and Colonel William Davis are among the passengers due today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from Europe.
A sudden northward drive today carried Spanish Government troops through foothills southwest of Teruel toward the Insurgent stronghold of Albarracin [about eighteen miles to the west].

William King Loftus, 45 years old, of 108 West Fiftieth Street, a WPA saxophone player, was held without bail on suspicion of homicide yesterday in the death of Mrs. Harriet Brown Neilson, whose body was found Tuesday in her furnished room at 161 West Seventy-sixth Street.

National income paid out in 1937 was approximately $67,500,000,000, compared with $62,400,000,000 in 1936, an increase of 8 per cent, and $45,000,000,000 in 1933 at the lowest point of the depression, according to monthly income estimates made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Meewa, five-month-old lioness and Hollywood performer, arrived at the Central Park Zoo yesterday from the West Coast. Captain Ronaid Cheney-Stout, director of the zoo, said he thought she was "stage-frightened," but predicted she would be all right after resting from her tiresome trip in a crate.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., in its report for 1937 issued yesterday, shows net earnings, after deductions, taxes and preferred dividends, amounting to $8,721,025, equal to $3.06 each on 2,853,971 shares of common stock, compared with $9,038,787, or $3.17 a common share for 1936.

A hurricane hit the California coast today, climaxing two weeks of stormy weather, and caused two deaths and widespread damage. The $35,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge, largest single suspension span in the world, bent twelve and one-half feet out of line under the force of the wind, which reached seventy-six miles an hour in some places. The bridge,
Manhattan 12th Ave, 784-86, 52.4x39.3; for 2-story superintendent's office; Department of Public Works, City of New York, owner; F. B. McDuffee, architect; cost $40,000. Alterations

Dr. Lauge Koch, Danish Arctic explorer, tonight said that he had received a reply from the Danish settlement at Scoresby Sound, Greenland, reporting that everything was ready for the execution of his plan for the rescue of the floating RussiaN polar scientists.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx announced yesterday the award of two contracts totaling $759,472 for work on the westerly approach to the Triborough Bridge. Both contracts had been approved by the regional director of the PWA.

Walter E. O'Hara, head of the Narragansett Race Track, today severed all connections with the $3,000,000- establishment, resigning as president, managing director, and member of the board of directors.

Grand Concourse (11-3156), s e cor of 180th St, 191x100; University Heights Holdings Corp to Well-Managed Realty Corp, 918 Brook Ave. Morris Ave (12-3317), w s, 350 ft s of 196th St, 73x130; University Heights Holdings Corp to 1,320-28 Grant Ave Corp: mtge. $87,000.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago reached the quarter finals of the Everglades Club tennis tournament today with a 5-7, 6-3, 6-0 decision over Vernon Marcum of Lakeland, Fla.
Colgate defeated Cornell's basketball team tonight, 54-48, despite the gallant efforts of Tom Rich, visiting forward, who scored five baskets in the last seven minutes.
The New York A. C. defeated the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A., 47-31, in an Eastern Athletic Clubs League basketball game on the Winged Foot court last night.

Arturo Toscanini, whose ten appearances as conductor of the NBC symphony orchestra were to close with the broadcast of Feb. 26, has been engaged to conduct one more symphonic program on March 5 over the combined networks of stations WEAF and WJZ, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. It will consist entirely of the works of Richard Wagner.

The State Department received notification today that Charge d'Affaires Loy Henderson at Moscow would be permitted to see Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens, American citizen, in the Butyraskaya prison there tomorrow afternoon. Mrs. Rubens is in the prison on suspicion of spying.

Eight persons, five of whom were passengers, were killed instantly this morning when the regular Air France Marseille-Tunis passenger flying boat, on taking off, failed to clear the breakwater and crashed to the bottom in the shallow Marignane seaplane harbor.

King George VI today planted another foot in his father's footsteps. by exhibiting a. dog for. the first, time in a public show. His Labrador retriever, Sandringham Stream, a- 3 1/2year-old female, was entered in four classes in. the annual Crufts Dog a Show.

Four executives of Bonwit, Teller Co. will be taken on a trip tomorrow to inspect the Marcus Hook (Pa.) plant of the American Viscose Corporation as part of the educational and consumer work of the corporation to broaden knowledge of rayon and its production.

Mayor La Guardia and Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, received many letters s yesterday protesting and supporting t the appointment by Mr. Isaacs of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, as c his assistant.

The Rev. and Mrs. Lefferd M. A. Haughwout of Staten Island and Williamsburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Bruce Bucktrout Haughwout, to Charles Johnson Rodarmor of Brooklyn and Erie, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cleveland Rodarmor of Brooklyn.
Heavy wind, rain and spongy turf today made a joke of the scoring efforts of the field in the first round of the $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

Eastern States Corporation (Maryland)-For 1937: Net loss after expenses, taxes and other charges, $2,034, against $1,318 loss in 1936, exclusive of $6,150 profit on sales of securities credited to earned surplus account.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., nominated yesterday by President Roosevelt to be Assistant Secretary of State, will bring to the department exceptional talents, great energy and a fine sense of civic duty.

Miss Laila Schou Nilsen of Norway won the 500-meter event of the women's world speed skating championships today, beating Miss Madeline (Maddy) Horn of Beaver Dam, Wis., by five-tenths of a second. Miss Glou Donker of the Netherlands was third.

Arguing that cooperation offers to the "little man" his only means of survival in an industrial system, Donald R. Richberg, former NRA Administrator, advocated today before the Washington Trade Association Executives the establishment of voluntary cooperative efforts to develop industrial planning and self-discipline in competition.

Tourists and others who go to Havana and other cigar-producing centers will have the number of cigars they may bring into this country, free of duty for personal use, cut to fifty, instead of $100 worth for each individual, if an amendment to the tariff act of 1936 is enacted.
The Surete National announced tonight that three personsohad been arrested after the discovery of tubes of "poisonous bacilli" Said to have been brought from Insurgent Spain into'France.

The Crescent A. C. scored its fourteenth triumph in seventeen starts last night by defeating the Wagner College quintet, 54 to 38, on the Crescent court. The winners held a 25-19 lead at the half and maintained an advantage throughout.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week. in thousands of marks:

The League of Nations conference adopted today the text of a convention governing the status of refugees from Germany and marking a small step forward from the viewpoint of liberality since the 1933 Nansen convention covering Russian and Armenian refugees.

J. V. Lyon, port manager of the Munson Steamship Company, was elected chairman of the New York Shipping Association yesterday at the association's annual meeting at 80 Broad Street. He succeeds A. J. McCarthy, vice president of the United States Lines Company, who asked to be relieved of the office after several years of activity to devote more time to the affairs of his own company.

Security registrations becoming. effective under the Securities act of 1933 tapered off rapidly in the last quarter of 1937 and for the entire year aggregated $3,379,300,000, as compared with $5,064,700,000 in 1936, a decrease of $1,685,400,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Five men. connected with Carlos, Ames Co., Inc., of 400 Madison Avenue, a securities concern whose business was ended by court order last December, were enjoined permanently yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck from any further dealings in securities in this State.

Some more definite clue as to the future course of the one-man regime in Brazil should be forthcoming within the next few days in a decision by President Getulio Vargas as to the political disposition of Oswaldo Aranha, until recently his faithful Ambassador to Washington.
One thing should be said in fairness to the members of the National Woman's Party sponsoring the Equal Rights Amendment at Washington.

Cheering crowds carried General Jose Felix Estigarribia through the streets on their shoulders today when he returned from two years in exile. Colonel Rafael Franco, deposed dictator of Paraguay, had banished General Estigarribia, commander-in-chief of the Paraguayan forces in the Chaco war with Bolivia, after he gained power in a coup in 1936. Colonel Franco was ousted last year.

The towering Owls of Temple University retained their leadership in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference race tonight by brushing aside the challenge of Pitt's Panthers, last year's champions, 43 to 41.
The Suffolk County Democratic executive committee went on record last night unanimously for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. as the Democratic candidate for Governor this Fall.

Miss Marguerite Le Hand, personal secretary of President ,Roosevelt, today was again in possession of a ring set with two diamonds and two pearls, the Christmas gift of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, which was stolen here Dec. 27.

Now in Florida, Sam H. Harris should soon be receiving the script of "Queeny," Sinclair Lewis's new play, on which the producer has taken a thirty-day "reading option." He took it when Mr. Lewis's agent told him the story over the telephone-a tale of a woman of the world in a small village and how they react to each other. Mr.

Mrs. Elisha C. Tower gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Lady Decies, who arrived recently from Paris and is visiting Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh. The other guests included Mrs. Kavanaugh, Mrs. Lenora Warner and Earl C. Tower.

The use of recently developed ultra-fast films for taking X-ray motion pictures of internal organs, three times as fast as any hitherto available, was demonstrated last night before the Science Forum of the New York Electrical Society by Dr. William H. Stewart,

According -to The Iron- Age the January daily average of iron production in the United States was 4.1 per cent under December. January's total production was 1,429,085 gross tons, compared with 1,490,324 tons in December.

Under the captaincy of a seasoned campaigner, Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller of Pennsylvania, endorsers of the Equal Rights Amendment rushed today to defense of the measure, which is scheduled to go to a vote before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday.

A first mortgage of $200,000, carrying interest of 4 per cent has been arrange for ten years by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc, on the sixteen-story business building on the northeast corner of Madison Ave and 28th St for the 79 Realty Corp.

The Agricultural Export Commission decided today to offer financial support and trade privileges to the Chilean Navigation Company, which will soon commence operation between Pacific ports and Europe through the Panama Canal. The steamer Copiapo, constructed in Denmark, is ready for service.

Tremendous satisfaction and enthusiasm have been shown in the French press and among the public generally over the announcement that King George and Queen Elizabeth will visit Paris during the coming Summer.

Morris S. Novik, secretary to the New York County Committee of the American Labor party, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as director of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, at-a salary of $7,500 a year.

Words once spoken in Congress by Abraham Lincoln threw the House into turmoil today. During the babble which followed passage of the revised Farm Bill, Representative Wolcott of Michigan arose to read an excerpt from Carl Sandburg's biography of Lincoln.

An amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange, changing the voting procedure to be followed in considering the new constitution now being prepared by a committee of three, was presented yesterday by that committee to the governing committee.

Three new contracts for work on the Delaware water supply project will be advertised soon with a scale of wages for- skilled and unskilled labor substantially below the scale in the last three contracts let, it was announced yesterday.

A group of eleven musicians receiving compensation above the minimum union scales applied yesterday to the Supreme Court for an order vacating a resolution recently adopted by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians which, they contend, would materially reduce their earnings. All the applicants are members of the local.

Mrs. Jay Tschudy of this city and New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jeannette MacKelvie, to George Lutley Sclater-Booth, only son of the late Hon. Charles Lutley Sclater-Booth and the present Mrs. Sclater-Booth of The Priory, Odiham, Winchfield, England.

A series of lectures for public school teachers was started yesterday afternoon at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, under the joint- auspices of the academy and the Board of Education.
H. Otto Vogt, a former director, was elected today to the presidency of the Gray Telephone Pay Station Company, succeeding George A. Long.

When Freddie Steele, world's middleweight champion, knocked out Bob Turner in a single round in Rochester on Tuesday night the titleholder jeopardized the Feb. 19 bout in which he is scheduled to defend his crown in Cleveland against Carmen Barth.

Senator William H. Smathers of New Jersey married Miss Mary James Foley of Winter Haven, Fla., in the court house at Fairfax, Va., this morning. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. Carl Maxwell, pastor of the Old Fairfax Methodist Church.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, in response to a subpoena and also an invitation, spent an hour yesterday before the Kings County grand jury investigating sales-tax evasion in- Brooklyn. Afterward Mr. Curran said that he was not permitted to reveal the nature of the conference, but he had found the grand jurors "very pleasant gentlemen."

Lawrenceville's basketball team rode to its ninth victory in ten starts today by trouncing a fastbreaking Rutgers Prep five, 55-35. Outclassing the visitors in accurate passing and shooting, the Laurentians were paced by Captain Bartlett's 16 points, while Kluey dropped in the same number for Rutgers.

Miss Jean Petrie Fennell, daughter of Edward H. Fennell of this city and the late Mrs. Fennell, was married this afternoon to Hugh Kendall Boice Jr., son of Mr. Boice of New York and Mrs. Dorothy Hay, at the home of her father here.

Division St. 224-226, 48x67.101/2, trustee will of Ida Egbert to Ames Realty Developing Co, Inc, 233 Broadway, care M. Boxer, consideration $2.500. 26th St, a s. 215 ft ?? of 8th Ave, 84.9x98.9, Railway Express Agency Inc, to 250 West 26th St Corp, 8 W 40th St, care L. B. Boudin ($150).

Mrs. Anna Goepel von Briesen, widow of Arthur von Briesen, for many years president of the Legal Aid Society, died yesterday at her home, 950 Park Avenue. Born in Stuttgart, Germany, on April 20, 1851, she came to this country a girl, and in 1873 married Mr. von Briesen.

Nothing more reassuring has appeared in a long time than the statement of the American Federationr of Labor urging that Congress repeal or modify the undivided profits and capital gains taxes. It is a clear recognition that so far as the volume of production is concerned labor and capital are in the same boat.

Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The Times of London, will be chief speaker at the annual dinner of the Trust Division of the American Bankers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 17.

With a declaration that the "quarantine" policy suggested in a speech at Chicago in October by President Roosevelt is one that calls for "big battleships to be used in aggressive warfare in the Far Pacific or the Far Atlantic," Dr. Charles Austin Beard, historian, former Professor of Politics in Columbia University

Arguments were completed late today before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the application of railroads for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates. Arguments also were completed on an application by Eastern railroads for an increase from 2 to 2.5 cents a mile for passenger coach fares.

The cut of $4 a ton made yesterday in certain grades of cold rolled steel sheets means that other sheets are "high" in relation to the reduced levels, and also that the prices of other products will be as vulnerable to demands for concessions as were the cold rolled sheets.

PEARL BUCK'S new novel,* her first upon an American theme, seems to me a singularly fictitious piece of fiction. Not that there-is rio truth in it, but simply that the net result is artifice. It has been so planned and so executed as to produce little of the sense of life-the stuff that makes good novels, and most great ones.

President Roosevelt will ask Congress to appropriate an additional $250,000,000 for unemployment relief, Congressional leaders said today. The President is expected to request passage immediately of a deficiency appropriation, either in a message to Congress or a letter to Speaker Bankhead tomorrow or Friday, and at the same time to revise upward the billion-dollar estimate for relief contained in the budget for the 1939 fiscal year.

The challenge by the Electric Bond and Share Company of the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Law was taken under consideration by the Supreme Court today as six hours of argument closed.

President Roosevelt conferred on relief legislation with Senators Barkley and Glass, Representatives Rayburn and Taylor, Secretary Morgenthau and Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progress Administrator, and is expected to ask of Congress a deficiency appriopriation of $250,000,000 for relief purposes.
On the fourth anniversary of the coldest day ever recorded by the local Weather Bureau, New York had abnormally mild weather yesterday.

District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators, an A. F. of L. organization, called upon District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday to investigate charges that "an incredible number of employers" in the painting. industry were violating the State laws 'on unemployment insurance and workmen's compensation.

Conflicting reports of success came from the North China battle zone. The Japanese said eight armies were steadily closing in on the Lung-Hai railway. The Japanese reports were disputed by the Chinese, who declared their troops had prevented the Japanese from advancing along the 100-mile Hwai River front and were successfully resisting the armies pushing toward the Lung-Hai railway and the strategic junction city of Suchow from the north.

The Trust Company of New Jersey mold to David L. Marcus the three-story brick building containing a store and two apartments at 106 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City. It took back a purchase-money mortgage for $7,900 due Feb. 1, 1943, at 5 per cent.

Bobby Pearce, world's professional sculling champion since 1933, has accepted terms for defense of his title against Evans Paddon, Australian champion, as a feature event of this year's Canadian national exhibition at Toronto, Jim Rice, Pearce's coach,

The white people of the South art becoming more interested in the problems of church work among Negroes, the Right Rev. Frederick B. Bartlett reported yesterday at a meeting of the National Council of the Episcopal Church at 281 Fourth Avenue.

Sporadic disorders broke out tonight near the conclusion of Northern Ireland's general election called by Prime Minister Viscount Craigavon to back his stand against union with Eire [Ireland]. Five persons were injured in Belfast when police dispersed a large crowd outside a polling place.

The prosecution called its first witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of ten men, two women and ten corporations on indictments alleging frauds totaling $2,000,000 upon 1,500 purchasers of lots in Slovak Manor, near Deer Park, L. I., in 1930.

Wheat fluctuated erratically within a range of 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here today. It advanced early in sympathy with securities and on local buying, only to ease later when stocks reacted and closed within a fraction of the bottom with net gains of 1/2 to 1/4 cent.

The word "scout" meant originally one who listened. But it has in its use the world around come to suggest one who having listened is very active in doing. The Boy Scouts are essentially doers. They are not only doing daily good turns to others. They are keeping themselves fit by daily discipline and especially by keeping in touch with the sources of strength in nature beyond the "pavement's end."

A unique record of the rehearsals and performances of Richard Wagner's "Parsifal" in 1882, the year of its world premiere, was presented yesterday to Arturo Toscanini in his apartment at the Hotel Astor by Kurt Lehmann, musical amateur of this city. Mr. Lehmann made the gift "as a token of my admiration to the man who is, I feel, the greatest living interpreter of music."

Merck Sheldon, in 180 E 78th St; B. Sherman Fowler, in 140 E 81st St; Alexander Gordon, in 55 E 72d St; Thomas F. Coffey, In 305 Lexington Ave; Gabrielle France, in 19 W 55th St; Douglas Gibbons Co, Inc, broker. Frederick Lonsdale, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza. Samuel M. Unger, in 898 West End Ave; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.

The Amherst College basketball team defeated Colby, 43-28, tonight to open the major half of the Winter schedule. The Jeffs rallied to score 10 points in the first three minutes of the second half and never allowed Colby to threaten again.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club scored its eighth straight victory in the New York Amateur Hockey Association and remained unbeaten in league competition by conquering the Long Island Falcons, 7-4, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Counting non-league encounters, the St. Nicks have had a fourteen-game winning streak.

NEW YORK Miss Emily Custis Lewis Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Basil M. Stevens, has joined Miss Betty Jane Buell of Tulsa, Okla., at the Ambassador. Miss Buell and her father, J. Garfield Buell, will sail for Europe tomorrow on the Saturnia.

The National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries announced yesterday its aim to bring about a popular vote on the lottery question in New York through the submission -of a proposal to amend the State Constitution at the State Constitutional Convention in April.
Utica, the Caledonian Club of New York and Schenectady rinks were victorious today in the Allen Medal grand national curling competition.

Addressing representatives of the foreign press, Leon Jbuhaux, president of the Confederation Generale de -Travail [General Labor Federation] today defined French labor's stand with regard to capital and to politics. Labor, he said, is patriotic and willing to do anything for France and to meet capital halfway on any question, provided it is the outcome of fair discussion;

The tumult and rejoicing over young King Farouk's wedding has hardly subsided when Egypt is again en fete for the birthday of the monarch. On Friday Farouk will be 18. With no less enthusiasm the country is again displaying its loyalty to the King.
Charles T. Dazey, playwright whose "In Old Kentucky" brought him-fame, died in a hospital here tonight. His age was 84.

Stockholders of the Mitten Bank Securities Corporation, at a stormy meeting today, accused the directors of "exploiting" employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, who own a substantial part of its securities.
The uproarious meeting last week of "little business men,' who clamored first of all for easier loans with which to expand their enterprises, got results today.

This correspondent's assertion that the royal decree of Jan. 22 whereby the citizenship of Rumania's 750,000 Jews was called into question was a violation of the Constitution's equality clause, the agreement of the Congress of Berlin in 1878 and the 1918 Paris minority agreement received startling official confirmation today.

The Rev. Robert A. Jardine, the former vicar of St. Paul's Church in Darlington, England, who performed the marriage ceremony for the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, arrived from London yesterday with Mrs. Jardine on the American Farmer of the United States Lines.

Champion Flornell Spicypiece of Halleston, imported wire-haired foxterrier bitch owned by the Halleston Kennels of Stanley J. Halle of Chappequa, N. Y., won the highest honors in the specialty show of the American Foxterrier Club, which had the largest entry of 127 dogs in the annual exhibition of the Associated Terrier Clubs held yesterday in Commerce Hall at the Port of New York Authority Building.

The Metropolitan Opera House was packed yesterday afternoon when "Das Rheingold" was given as the first of the matinee performances of "The Ring." It was an eloquent and atmospheric performance-one which served the composer's purpose right well, and which responded to the growing public appreciation of this opera.

The budget of news bearing on the stock market was unexpectedly large yesterday and many traders preferred to take to the sidelines in order to study the latest developments. The net result was that after a moderate advance in the early trading, prices moved down again and closed irregular.

Transit Commissioners Reuben L. Haskell and M. Maldwin Fertig will appear before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington next Tuesday to present an amendment to the pending Chandler bill, in an effort to prevent the privately operated rapid transit lines from using the bankruptcy courts to escape their obligations under their five-cent fare contracts with the city.
The election of three new trustees of the New York Public Library was announced yesterday. They are Morris Hadley, Dr. Henry James and Elihu Root Jr.
The Commerce Department said today that passenger air service would be started between Paris and South America this Summer.

Filing of an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission tc strike from its list the common stock. 50-cent par value, of the. Cusi Mexicana Company was. authorized yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange.
Rutgers kept its season record intact tonight by defeating Lafayette in a keenly fought basketball game before a large crowdy. 29 to 27.

Manhattan College came from behind tonight to beat St. Thomas of Scranton, 44 to 37, in the feature game of a triple-header at the Hershey Sports Arena before a crowd of 3,000. In the first game Hershey Industrial High upset William Penn of Harrisburg, while Lebanon Valley peat Albright in the second game.
Great Britain is speeding preparations for broadcasts soon to South America to combat Italian and German propaganda in that field, which it is feared is hurting British prestige and trade.

The erstwhile stake horse No Sir- gave his best today at Hialeah, but it was only good enough to get him a second place in the Class C handicap which featured the program. Terpsichore, a 5-year-old mare carrying the Fanfare Farm colors, beat No Sir, who is owned and trained by Miss Mary Hirsch.

A Federal court jury awarded to Robert H. Lucas, former executive director of the Republican National Committee, 1 cent damages tonight in his $200,000 libel suit against Frank R. Kent, columnist, and the A. S. A bell Company, publishers of The Baltimore Sun papers.

The South American Development Company, a United States gold-mining concern, paid a fine of 50,000 sucres yesterday for alleged violation of the monetary laws, the newspaper Telegrafo reported today. The fine was imposed because the company had issued scrip in onesucre units when national money in small units was unobtainable.

The State Department telegraphed today to the American Consul in Barcelona asking him to inquire as to the welfare of Cliff Haley of Tacoma, Washington. The department said it acted after being told that Mr. Haley was under arrest by Spanish Loyalists for trying to leave Spain.

A plea that the State Department avoid any duty reductions on floor coverings in negotiating a reciprocal trade treaty with Turkey was made by the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., in a brief filed in Washington yesterday.

What might be called "the mystery of-the missing envoy" was the subject of a Soviet communique tonight. Last Sunday evening Feodor Butenko, Soviet Charge d'Affaires at Bucharest, Rumania, left his chancellery for his own apartment and disappeared from sight. On Monday it was thought he might have been away on business or something like it.
Elkanah Mead, member of an old Greenwich family, died this morning at his home on Milbank Avenue, here. He was 86 years old. He built in 1881 the house in which he died.

Sergio Osmena Jr., son of the vice president of the Commonwealth of the Philippines, has opened a business for the export and import of Philippine and American products, and has taken quarters in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

The buying movement in progress on the Cotton Exchange here received additional stimulus yesterday from the passage of the Farm Bill by the House of Representatives, so prices rose 5 to 13 points in the most active trading in some time.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of a noted Maryland stable, advocated today a change in American racing rules to prevent pari-mutuel betting on horses entered in a race simply for training.
John J. Dwyer, former riding academy and hotel owner at Lakewood, N. J., died on Tuesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Catherine M. O'Neill, 3,102 Kings [bridge Avenue, the Bronx.
Axel Paulsen, outstanding skater of the last century and winner of the world's speed-skating title in the United States in 1884, died today. He was 82 years old.
Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, officiated yesterday morning at his first commissioning ceremony here, that of the 1,850-ton destroyer leader Warrington.

The Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, headed by Harry F. Guggenheim and with offices at 50 Lafayette Street, in a report issued yesterday on its activities in 1937, told of asdistance given to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey while he was special prosecutor of rackets.

For his first best-in-show triumph of a brief career, Radiant Tiny Tim III, owned by Miss Ruth E. Slade of Providence, topped a classy field in the American Pomeranian Club's twenty-seventh specialty competition held yesterday in the Salle Moderne of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Stormy Weather, the yawl owned by Robert W. Johnson of New York, was first of the thirteen yachts entered in the 184-mile ocean race from Miami to Nassau to finish, according to a report by Tropical Radio early this morning. Stormy Weather,

Said by detectives to have admitted breaking into seventy-five homes recently, Theodore Kowaski 21 years old, of 132-15 Eighty-fifth Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, was booked on a charge of burglary last night at Richmond Hili police station.

In Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock this morning the Westminster Kennel Club-will open its sixtysecond annual all-breed'dog show, with 3,093 on. the benches representing ninety-four breeds. The exhibition will continue through Saturday evening, with judging sessions morning, afternoon and evening.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today the following additional applications for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter market from New York City (symbols: S. sole proprietor: P. partnership):
Frederick K. Rupprecht, president of the Consolidated Textile Corporation, has resigned from that position Henry B. Stimson, secretary-treasurer, also has resigned.

The St. Paul's School basketball team remained unbeaten in twelve games when it defeated Stony Brook, 47-21, at Garden City yesterday. It was the first setback in nine starts for Stony Brook. The winners set a fast opening pace and led at the half, 20-9.

James H. R. Cromwell, husband of the former Doris Duke, tobacco heiress, suggested today to the House Banking Committee a new economic theory of synchronizing the flow of dollars with the flow of finished consumer goods.

Mrs. Jessie Dove Bowen, wife of the Rev. Arthur J. Bowen, secretary of the South Africa General Mission and formerly a missionary in the Belgian Congo, died on Tuesday at her home, 563 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, -at the age of 69.

Stocks of all oil products held by the principal marketing companies in California, except those at sales and service stations, at the end of December were 128,040,247 barrels, an increase of 3,750,929 over the total of 124,289,318 at the close of November, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Claude M. Baker of San Francisco, a supporter of the American Federation of Labor, continued tonight to run well ahead of Charles P. Howard of Chicago, secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, in the number of endorsements received from local unions for president of the International Typographical Union. Mr. Howard now is president of the I. T. U.

A flight of army bombers will be sent to Buenos Aires as a good-will gesture in connection with the celebrations surrounding the inauguration of Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz ae President of Argentina on Feb. 20, the State Department announced today. Ambassador Alexander W. Weddell will represent President Roosevelt at the inauguration, it was stated.
The Senate Banking Committee is expected to vote next week on the Maloney bill, which provides for Securities and Exchange Commission regulation of over-the-counter dealings in unlisted securities.

The six-acre estate known as the Genevieve Tuttle property, on the north side of Hoaglands Lane, in Old Brookville, near Glen Head, L. I., has been purchased by Margaret Grout Streibert for her own use.
The Merchants and Miners Transportation Company announced today the suspension of sailings from Baltimore to Boston and Providence, and from Baltimore to South Atlantic ports.

Construction of super-highways to meet developing needs of the people was recommended as a major public works program in an address delivered today by E. C. Lawton, assistant commissioner of the highways division of the New York Department of Public Works, before the annual convention of Associated General Contractors.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death on Sunday in Rio de Janeiro, of Eugene P. Erckenback, for several years representative of Pan American Airways in the West Indies and South America. His death,

Members of the New York Theatrical Press Agents last evening formally ratified the agreement whereby they will be taken into the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, keeping within the union a New York Chapter of Legitimate Press Agents, which is to make all its own rules regarding membership, sharing the work, and so forth.

The five county commanders of the American Legion in the city and Jeremiah F. Cross, State commander, decided yesterday that the next move in the drive to force the ousting of Simon W. Gerson, assistant to the Borough President of Manhattan, should be for the Legion to file removal charges with Governor Lehman against Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, who appointed him.

ANSBACHER, REBECCA (Feb. 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Julia Ansbacher, sister, 801 West End Ave., residue. Harry A. Gordon, 21 E. 87th St., executor. BROWN, ROSE (Oct. 31). Estate, $7.923. To Elsie Brown, daughter, 1,235 Park Ave., $1,633; Daniel Brown, son, 1,235 Park Ave., $1,593: John Brown, son, 49 E. 96th St., $1,190;

The survey conducted by the Pennsylvania Game Commission to determine the amount of game killed during 1937 indicates that the hunters of that State had a much better season than in 1936. The report is very interesting and is given in a form that makes it easy to understand, unlike many such reports that require a slide rule and a mathematical mind.
Because the King does not want to impose "any additional burden" on the Indian taxpayer, the coronation durbar was postponed a second time tonight.

Rumors of double-decker trading posts and other striking changes in the physical equipment of the New York Stock Exchange are going about the financial district, causing considerable concern among the members of that institution.

The Women's Division of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy has arranged for the opportunity to view the Janis collection of modern paintings at the Sidney Janis residence, 1 West Eighty-fifth Street, between 1 P. M. and 6 P. M. on Sunday, Feb. 20.
Congress was called upon by resolution adopted by the Associated General Contractors of America today to repeal the undistributed profits tax and hereafter to enact no other such law.

President Federico Laredo Bru tonight vetoed the bill providing for the settlement of public works obligations in default since 1933. His veto was due exclusively to his opposition to a portion of the bill ordering the payment of debts owed to the railroads by the government and the establishment of a highway tax, according to his statement to the press.

Frank Sieverman 3d of the New York A. C. gained the quarter-final round of the Whitehall Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday by defeating Ed Kilroe of the Columbia University Club. Sieverman rallied to win in the third game, 12-15, 15-6 and 15-2.
Only debutantes and married women who have already been presented at court may attend the four royal courts this year, it was announced tonight by the Lord.Chamberlain.
John C. Hart, former assistant secretary of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, has become associated with Philip H. Goodman, at 110 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

A bondholders' protective committee proposed today a reorganization plan for the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville (Monon) Railway Company under which the Louisville Nashville Railroad and the Southern Railway would lose control of the line.

Kirsten Flagstad was soloist last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall and John Barbirolli returned to conduct that body for the remainder of the season, following the guest appearances in the same capacity of Georges Enesco.

John Barrymore's and Elaine Barrie's names are now formally on a contract to appear next season under the management of Brock Pemberton in "My Dear Children," the Catherine Turney-Jerry Horwin comedy, this being the outcome of negotiations noted in these columns on Jan. 9.

Model steel derricks rigged to pump watery oil, mysterious maps that flashed a bluish-green light when one guessed the correct location of a city, a hot-air heating system that traced the course of air currents and a host of other mechanical contrivances intended to supplement the textbook and dramatize teaching in the classroom were displayed yesterday by the Board of Education.

Rivers swollen by fifteen consecutive days of rain and snow reached or neared the danger level in the Sacramento Valley tonight, while Central California counted six dead and surveyed widespread property damage from yesterday's winds of hurricane force.

Gramercy Arms, a ten-story apartment house at 102 East Twenty-second Street, in the Gramercy Park section, has been bought by Reuben Horowitz, operator, from the Supreme Holding Corporation, Clement E. Merowit, president.

In able and honest leaders and more education can the people find the remedies for the obstacles to social peace and individual happiness "stalemated by false leaders or demagogues and the pressure of ignorant, misguided masses," Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, asserted yesterday.

Edward N. Hartstein, real estate operator, who specialized in building construction, died early yesterday morning at his home, 480 Park Avenue, at the age of 51. Born and educated in New York, Mr. Hartstein entered the aress manufacturing business as a young man with the firm of I. A. Hartstein Co., 477 Seventh Avenue.

Mrs. Susan B. Wissler, known as the first woman Mayor in the United States, died here yesterday at the age of 84. She was elected Mayor of Dayton, Wyo., a cowtown of 400 persons, in 1911 and served two years.

Straight - shooting, long - hitting Charles Congdon played a rainsoaked course for a 73 today to post a thirty-six-hole total of 148 and lead the qualifying field for match play in the $5,000 San Francisco open golf tournament.

Judges were named yesterday for the boy-and-girl violinist audition of the National Federation of Music Clubs. They will assemble here next week to hear through recordings the individual performances of young musicians, all under 16, of twenty-three key cities.

The Treasury procurement division today invited bids on the following lots of textiles, bids to be opened Feb. 18 for shipment by March 20: 630-T Munney crepe 69x68, 15,500 yards; novelty suiting 70x62, 12,000 yards; plisse crepe 73x48, 3,000 yards.

Discussing the proposal to have the Reconstruction Finance Corporation make loans to small industries, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the R. F. C., expressed the opinion today that the corporation already had sufficient authority to act, where a loan appeared to be a justifiable risk.
A larger decline than anticipated seasonally took place in lumber production last week and the adjusted index has eased to 56.6 from 56.9. The figure for the week ended Feb. 6, 1937, was 59.1.
Fortynine men and one woman, indicted on Federal lottery charges, appeared before Judge Frank Cooper in the Federal court today in one of the largest mass arraignments in the history of the district.
Starting the practice of issuing semi-annual fiscal reports for the State, Governor Wilbur L. Cross announced today a surplus of $224,300 for the six months beginning July 1, 1937.

Mayor La Guardia assured the Hotel Men's Association of New York at its fifty-ninth annual dinner last night in the Biltmore Hotel that during the World's Fair he would protect the city's hotels against inroads by shipping companies' use of their vessels as floating hotels.

Purchases in odd lots continued to exceed sales on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 5, with 275,805 shares bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

At his foreign press conference today Rear Admiral Moda made it clear that the answer to the three naval powers will not comply with their requests. The navy's policy, he explained, remains exactly as stated at London in 1936 and again last year, when the question of gun caliber arose.
Large attendances marked the dinner dance tonight at the Everglades Club preceding the program by Ted Shawn and his dancers, and the Garden of Allah party at the Palm Reach Biltmore Hotel.

While business continued slow, sentiment in wool goods markets turned more cheerful this week, as the belief spread that prices had touched bottom and would gradually rebound, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

A number of leases for locations a on Fifth Avenue were reported yesterday by brokers. The Oriental Craft Shoppe, Inc., importers of antiques and Far Eastern products, took two stores in 565 Fifth Avenue, through Mark Groskin, broker.

The Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate for the textile industry, with offices at 44 East Twenty-third Street, announced yesterday the suspension of seven local unions constituting the New Bedford Textile Council as well as of the New Bedford Textile Council
Kathleen Kennedy, 18 years old, second daughter of Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, will be her father's hostess at the American Embassy in London for several weeks this season.
The State Employment Service has withdrawn all its placement interviewers from district relief offices of the city Department of Welfare, it was learned yesterday.

A suit to restrain further showing of a "March of Time" newsreel dealing with conditions in the American merchant marine was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by the district committee of the National Maritime Union and three members of the crew of the steamship Algic who are under indictment in Brooklyn Federal Court for mutiny.

Rear Admiral Louis R. de Steiguer, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. de Steiguer have left the Vanderbilt to pass the remainder of the Winter in Miami. Miss Alma Clayburgh of the Berkshire has gone to Washington to pass the week-end with Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and the latter's husband and daughter, Paul C. Wilson and Miss Susanna W. P. Wilson.
Broadway, 339, 27.8x178.7; William Hamilton Swan, Tucson, Ariz, to Chase National Bank. as trustee. Sheriff St, 56, 25x100; Manuel Greenbaum to Nathan Julien,. 3,110 Bainbridge Ave, Bronx ($1.50).

The secret trial in Berlit of Pastor Martin Niemoeller, accused of inciting the populace to civil disobedience and of other seditious acts, is arousing renewed protests from Christian leaders in many countries against the National Socialist anti-religious campaign.

With a fiftymile-an-hour gale aiding him, Squadron Leader J. W. Gillan, in the dark tonight, flew one of the Royal Air Force's new, secret Hawker Hurricane fight planes the 327 miles from Edinburgh to Northolt, west of London, in fortyeight minutes, or at an average of 408.75 miles an hour.

The government has sold to AndersonClayton Company, -cotton brokers, of Dallas, Texas, the 1937 crop raised in the La Laguna region by government-financed community farmers for $4,000,000 to be used in reducing a government overdraft of more than a hundred million pesos with the Bank of Mexico.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries, excluding the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, reported yesterday for 1937 a net income of $623,746 before depreciation and a net income of $193,165 after depreciation, compared with $400,664 and $107,756, respectively, a year ago.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar delivered to American markets for domestic consumption in 1937 under sugar control laws amounted to 6,674,690 short tons, raw value, compared with 6,706,218 in 1936.

Mrs. Henry Warren Beebe of Montclair, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rosamond Beebe, to Thomas Childs Cochran of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cochran of Flemington, N. J.

Shipments of oil burners in 1937 totaled 193,180 units, a decrease of 1.9 per cent from the total of 196,877 burners in 1936, according to figures just issued by the Bureau of the Census. Shipments for December amounted to 8,239, compared with 10,546 in November and 11,300 in December 1936.
The yawl Stormy Weathey, owned by Robert W. Johnson of New York and sailed by Ducky Endt, wellknown ocean racer, today was dedared the winner of the 184-mile yacht race from Miami to Nassau.

Favorable trends which have characterized Latin-American credit and collection conditions for more than two years were reversed in the final quarter of 1937, William Swingle of the foreign department of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men reported yesterday.

High-speed daylight passenger train service between Chicago and Kansas City will be inaugurated about April 1 by the Santa Fe Railway, according to an announcement by Samuel T. Bledsoe, president of the road.

Viewing the plight of unemployed, discouraged and disillusioned youth as "one of the major problems of our times," the New York State Youth Administration advisory committee recommended today approval of a bill, introduced by Senator Joseph, Bronx Democrat, to create a "State youth service" designed to build programs for youth throughout the State.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 10.Bankers are skeptical of the 90 per cent mortgage loans authorized by the recent amendment to the Federal Housing Act, Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank, Brooklyn, N. Y., said today.

The thousands of Winter sports devotees in this part of the country, who have been looking forward to enjoying good slope and trail skiing over the Lincoln holiday week-end are doomed to disappointment unless the weather man takes a more favorable attitude and sends sufficient snow to cover the "Northlands" tomorrow and Sunday.

The Mexico City bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES transmitted on Jan. 6 a report of a widespread revolt in Northerm Guatemala against the regime of President Jorge Ubico. Careful investigation has revealed that the report was incorrect. There has been no disturbance of any consequence in Guatemala nor is any expected.

Captain Carl E. Berg, Thirty-fifth Field Artillery, died today at Fort Bragg, N. C., the War Department was advised. His age was 40. He was born at Eau Claire, Wis., and he entered the army as a private on July 15, 1917.

G. W. Kunze, national director of public relations for the GermanAmerican Bund, led a delegation of half a dozen gray-uniformed Nazis into Syracuse tonight and was met by a belligerent band of American Legion men.

The offices of the Federal Housing Administration in New Jersey are busier than they have been for many months answering inquiries which have been pouring in from buyers, builders, developers and lenders as a direct result of the passage of the amendments to the National Housing Act.
Charles Eli Green, former president of the American Can Company,. died here tonight at. his home, 216 Prospect Street, after a prolonged illness. He was 64 years old.

The Cohoes Savings Bank of Cohoes, N. Y., sold to the Better Construction Corporation of Brooklyn the taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Ditmars Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, Astoria, L. I. The deal was arranged by King King, Inc., for cash over the first mortgage.

The total of awards for engineering construction this week has taken a sharp jump over the 1937 total for the same week, with contracts of $54,831,000, or 66 per cent more than last year, when a volume of $33,010,000 was contracted for, according to The Engineering News-Record.

With all counting in yesterday's general election completed today, with the exception of the four-member constituency of Queens University, Viscount Craigavon's Unionist Government was returned stronger than before. It did not lose a seat while gaining two.

A large part of the infant mortality in New York State is due to syphilis infection, Dr. William Bayard Long, chief of dermatology at St. Luke's Hospital, declared yesterday at a luncheon of members of the Junior League and the women's committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

George F. Clark, for twenty-five years a pressman with THE NEW YORK TIMES, died here yesterday at Meadow Brook Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old. Mr. Clark, who lived at 310 Schuster Avenue, Mineola, was formerly a member of the Mineola Fire Deapartment, Company 2.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a modification of its rules for short selling for the benefit of small exchanges.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

HILPOLTSTEINER, SAMUEL (Oct. 26, 1936). Gross assets, $54,947; net, $51, 510. To Harry D. Hiller and Victor Hiller, sons, one-half residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $46,173. Manfred Nathan, attorney, 47 W. 34th St.

Stanley H. Howe, executive secretary to Mayor La Guardia, was elected chairman of the Mitchel Commissioners and Associates at an informal dinner of about twenty members of that organization at the Advertising Club last night.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday reduced the price of lead 25 points to 4.50 cents a pound at New York. The St. Joseph Lead Company made a similar reduction to 4.35 cents at St. Louis. This is the second price cut this week, a reduction of 15 points having been made on Tuesday.

Collapsible railroads, designed for scale-model locomotive fans who live in small apartments, will be featured at the First National Model Show, arranged by the Association of Model Railroad Manufacturers, which will open at 114 West Fortysecond Street tonight and will continue through Feb. 26.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a performance of the Verdi "Requiem" Friday evening, March 4, at Carnegie Hall, the receipts to be directed, at the conductor's own request, toward the reconstruction of the Festspielhaus in Salzburg, Austria.

Wilmer Hines of Hollywood, Calif., made a delayed entry into the Everglades tennis tournament quarter-finals today by defeating Lewis Faquin of Miami, 6-3, 10-8. In doubles, Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., advanced with a 6-1, 5-7, 6-1 victory over Charles Mattmann and Lewis Duff of Miami.

Mrs. Rose Alcorn, 38 years old, formerly of 78-18 Ninety-fifth Street, Ozone Park, Queens, was convicted yesterday by a jury in General Sessions of the theft of $3,700 from her employers, Burns Brothers, coal dealers, at 500 Fifth Avenue.
Anglo-Italian reconciliation took another stride forward today when Foreign Minister Anthony Eden and Count Dino Grandi, the Italian Ambassador, had a friendly talk of almost two hours.

A collection of hitherto unpublished stories by Washington Irving is to be issued in a limited edition by the Countryman Press of Weston Vt. The manuscripts of the stories were acquired some time ago by George S. Hellman, a New York bibliophile.

For the fifth consecutive week The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices has declined, and on Wednesday its index was 82.9, compared with 83.2 a week before and 92.5 a year ago. The low mark in 1936 was 79.6, on May 12. In December, 1934, the index was 78.5.

The threatened lockout in the fur industry, long the field of many industrial conflicts, will be effective this afternoon, George Greenberg, manager of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A Thompson gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Lord and Lady Sackville. The other guests included Lady Decies, Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, Mrs. Walter B. Sullivan, Mrs. John E. Lancaster, Mrs. Sheridan Norton, Mrs. Howard B. Sherman, Captain Walter Roper, Irving Harris, Louis Rossini, John Halmagyi, Henry T. Blair, Vuk Vuchnick and John Curtis.

Seven young-men who, according to Patrolman Wartel, refused- to take their hand-trucks off the side-walk and demanded that he give them summonses, were fined $10, each or three days in jail by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

Average shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation last month were 19,935 tons a day, compared to 18,810 tons daily in December, the first upturn after nine consecutive months of decline.

Some 250 friends and associates of Dr. Abraham L. Greenfield, member of the faculty of the New York University College of Dentis-. try since 1919, will honor him at a dinner at the Hotel Ambassador tonight to mark his promotion to Professor of Roentgenology.

Townsend Martin of New York and Mrs. Elizabeth Peet of Greenwhich, Conn., were honor guests at the cocktail party given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reynolds Jr. of Sapeloe Island and Winston-Salem, N. C., aboard their yacht, Zapala, which is tied up at the Sea Island Yacht Club dock here.

The Midston House Squash Club team scored its eighth victory of the season in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association last night. Midston won by 4 to. 1 from the Jackson Heights aggregation at the latter's courts, James Eder, M. A. Van Nostrand, C. R. Van Nostrand and E. S. Oppenheimer annexing the winner's points.

The conference report on the proposed amendment to the Federal Trade Act broadening the power of the Federal Trade Commission over advertising so as to provide protection for consumers as well as competitors will be submitted to both houses within a day or two, it was learned today.

Acting after a conference with Governor Lehman, Joseph D. Nunan Jr. and- Abbot Low Moffat, the Democratic and Republican sponsors of the resolution which endorsed the Wheeler-Johnson bill on child labor, agreed today to broaden their resolution to include all child labor bills pending in Washington which embody the restrictions in the Wheeler-Johnson bill.

Octavian Goga, harassed by internal and external political difficulties and by the growing disastrous economic situation produced by its anti-Semitic measures, resigned yesterday on King Carol's demand.

Evidence was presented today in Federal District Court here to show that more than 73 per cent of the holders of notes and more than 59 per cent of the holders of common stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company have assented to a plan of reorganization which is before the court for approval.

In "Frozen Glory," presented at the Gate Theatre tonight, the brother dramatists Leslie and Sewell Stokes have chosen a theme in reactions to the prospect of death by slow starvation of six Arctio explorers marooned in a log cabin.
Guns of Japan's campaign to choke off China's Lung-Hal Railway artery and dominate 100,000 square miles of Central China thundered today on the northwestern edge of the Lung-Hai corridor.

An easier undertone prevailed in the wheat market today despite firmness in securities. Weakness in Liverpool, where futures were to 1 cent a bushel lower combined with a lack of export demand and a let up in dust-storm reports from the Southwest, led to sufficient selling to carry prices on the Board of Trade here off 1 cent with the close at the low point of the day.

Desperately ill in a Saskatoon hospital with blood poisoning, "Miss K. M. Phipps," a social service worker, who is said to have been employed in Toronto, Montreal and Peace River, Alberta, was revealed today to be Lady Katharine Phipps, daughter of the widowed Lady Normanby and sister of the 25-year-old Marquess of Normanby.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, which lists a membership of nearly 400,000, characterized Henry Ford as "America's outstanding lawbreaker" in an address last night before more than 1,000 members of Local 22 of the International Ladies Garment Workers at the Hotel Center, 108 West Fortythird Street.

The Bituminous Coal Commission denied today the requests of New York and Cleveland for suspension of minimum coal prices pending "adequate" hearings, but it extended relief to gas-producing companies in New York and New Jersey, by setting minimum prices on four grades of low-volatile coal from West Virginia fields to New York ports, via tidewater Virginia.

Frank E. Cuffe, 27 years old, a chiropractor on relief, was busy yesterday planning for the return of his wife, Maude, 24, from Kings County Hospital, where triplets were born to her last Friday. Cuffe lives at 97-13 Eighty-sixth Street, Ozone Park, Queens.

A decline of $5,000,000 in the total of loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city for the week ended on Wednesday was revealed in their statement of condition, issued yesterday. The loans of the banks were down $41,000,000 to $3,244,000, while investments increased $36,000,000.
Capturing five of the six first places, the Savage school women's swimming team defeated the Hunter College naiads, 36 to 17, in the pool of the American Woman's Association last night.

Marking the official opening of the Greater New York Campaign of the United Palestine Appeal, the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the Appeal's executive committee, announced yesterday the appointment of Harold Jacobi as chairman here. Nationally, the appeal seeks $4,500,000 for the settlement in Palestine of Jews of Poland, Rumania, Germany and other lands.
The Senate began consideration of the crop control conference report today and immediately became involved in discussion of a point of order upon which hinges the fate of the legislation.

Mrs. Leonora H. Warner gave a dinner last night at the home of her mother, Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh, 10 East Sixty-Second Street, for Lady Decies, the house guest of Mr. and Mrs. Kavanaugh. Later the party went to the El Morocco. Guests included Mrs. Philip Kip Rhinelander, Mr. and Mrs. John L., Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Maguire, Howard A. Plummer and Richard von Strothman.

As the result of concessions offered by proponents of the disputed proposal to put special surtaxes on closely held or "family" corporations, the deadlock among Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee appeared today to be nearing an end.

A North-South final was assured for the annual Palm Beach women's championship today when Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., and Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., won their semi-final matches at the Palm Beach Golf Club.

Further trimming of expenditures was forecast by officials of the United Automobile Workers Union today as Walter N. Wells, vice president, became manager of the union's international headquarters office.

Mrs. Joanna Bright Potter, daughter of Mrs. Osborn Wyckoff Bright of 27 East Sixty-second Street and the late Mr. Bright, was married yesterday at the Colony Club to Charles Huntington Erhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Erhart of 1 Sutton Place South. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The Five Corners Building and Loan Association sold to Frank Miele the three-story flat at 49 Logan Avenue, Jersey City. The Eleventh Ward Building and Loan Association of Newark sold to Evart Yarvote, Austin Fitzgerald and George T. Green the two two-story dwellings on a plot 50 by 116 feet at 252-54 Belgrove Drive, Kearny.

Robert H. Jackson, named by President Roosevelt to follow Justice Stanley Reed as Solicitor General, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that he believed the Supreme Court should express the will of the people in its decisions.
The House Immigration Committee debated a bill today to permit Miss Suye Narita, a Japanese, of Mount McGregor, N. Y., to apply for citizenship.

IT is easily understood why the Chinese, at the moment, are against any Japanese movement, including the preparations for the Olympic Games scheduled for Tokyo in 1940. There was issued recently a Chinese plea for the cancellation, transfer or boycott of the Tokyo athletic festivities.

With one of the most notable casts ever assembled for a flat-floor meet, the Seventh Regiment A. A. reenters the picture as a track and field promoter tonight after a lapse of thirteen years with a sixteenevent program starting at 8 o'clock at the armory.

The idea of a "breathing spell" for business at this time really isn't as funny as it seemed to many newspaper men at the White House the other day when one of their number asked the President about a report he was preparing to grant one.

Mrs. Cyrus L. Sulzberger died yesterday afternoon at her home, 271 Central Park West. She was 77 years old. Mrs. Sulzberger (Rachel Peixotto Hays), born on Jan. 26, 1861, in New York City, was one of several children of David Hays and Judith (Peixotto) Hays.

When it comes to spelling, New York City school children, on the whole, rate rather low, a study disclosed yesterday. It was found that 32 per cent of the pupils examined were one year or more retarded in spelling.

Seigo Nakano; member of the Japanese Parliament, said on his arrival on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday that while the strength of the military faction of Japan was growing in influence and strength he could see no possibility of a radical military clique gaining excessive power and leading the nation into trouble with her international friends.
John A. Warren, a former Assemblyman from Brooklyn and at one time Mayor of Fredonia, N. Y., his home town, died yesterday in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, where he resided since last December.
Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation introduced its new line of electric ranges at a sales meeting attended by 2,500 dealers and salesmen from this area at the Auditorium Theatre today.

With Senator Herring of Iowa now preparing a bill on stricter control of radio broadcasts, a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion shows that government censorship of programs is opposed by a majority of radio owners.

Mrs. Ruth Alley, 40 years old, of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel and formerly of San Antonio, Texas, was found dead at 7:45 o'clock last night in the kitchenette of the basement apartment of Clarence Frye, a paint salesman, at 36 West Ninth Street.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today statistical data relating to the underwriting and distribution in 1937 of securities registered under the Securities Act of 1933 covering a total of $1,754,128,000. Most of the data was based on issues where the amount offered was $1,000,000 or more.

Colby defeated Williams, 37 to 36, tonight in an exciting game in which the score see-sawed during the last ten minutes of play after the losers had come from behind to tie the score at 30--all. Durrell's timely shots featured the Colby attack.

10:00--Ring 1, Airedale terriers. Judge, Joseph P. Sims. Stewards, William L. Barclay, H. Alvin McAleenan. 10:00--Ring 2, Doberman Pinschers. Judge, Hamilton smith Newsom. Stewards, Dr. Harold A. Benson, William W. Brainard Jr. 10:00--Ring 3, Cairns terriers. Judge W. Edgar Baker. Stewards. Eugene V. Connett, C. M. Greer Jr.

The latest footwear vogue for cattle in Czechoslovakia is a galosh type of rubber overshoe to be used for protection against hoof and mouth disease, says a report to the Department of Commerce from Prague, made public today. The new style cattle shoes are to be manufactured by the Bata concern, the report said.
If Federal relief of unemployment is to be administered exclusively through WPA, and exclusively on the basis of work-relief, there can be no question of the present need for greater funds.
An initial quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share was declared on the 5 per cent preferred stock of the Gatineau Power Company, which became a cumulative stock on Jan 1.
