Gus Jordahn, one of Palm Beach's most colorful figures and known nationally for his life-saving record, died this morning at a hospital here. Mr. Jordahn was the organizer of "Cowboys of the Sea," with membership limited to those who had saved a life.
After advancing steadily for several days, cotton prices yesterday proved more attractive to holders in the South and the list was set back 8 to 12 points.
EVENING

For the first time since repeal New Jersey taxes on alcoholic beverages reached the million dollar mark last month. The total collected was $1,049,035, an increase of more than $60,000 over January, 1937.

Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, until recently chief of army engineers, took over his post as Commissioner of the new Department of Public Works yesterday without any, predetermined policies or notions except to give an efficient administration and to let politics alone.

The development of public recognition of the need for proper balance among the "three basic divisions of American life-the farmer, the business man and the worker"-is one of the jobs that should be done by the advertising man, Roy S. Durstine, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., said today before the Advertising Club of Chicago.

Ceremonies honoring the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Peter Cooper will be held tomorrow morning at New York University's Hall of Fame on the uptown campus on University Heights, it was announced yesterday at the university.

With the end of the stevedores' strike after six weeks, Puerto Rico today ceased to be an island surrounded by freight ships unable to discharge cargo and for the first time since Jan. 3 resumed normal commerce with the rest of the world.

A chemical agent that has cured distemper in dogs, ferrets and cats, the first drug in medicine to cure, as well as to prevent a disease due to a virus, is announced in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Goalie Dave Kerr scored his eighth shut-out of the season as the New York Rangers blanked Detroit's reviving Red Wings, 4 to 0, before 10,623 spectators in a National Hockey League game tonight.

A substantial reduction in bituminous coal production and a fairly large drop in industrial electric power sales were responsible for a moderate decrease in business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Thomas Rome, who as chairman of the Mersey Docks and Harbor board was largely responsible for construction of the world-famous Gladstone dock, died today at the age of 85.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today, Dorothy C. Bennett and John Joseph McDermott, of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Joachim von Ribbentrop was formally inducted into the office of Foreign Minister today by his predecessor, Baron Constantin von Neurath, the -initiation being made the occasion for a ceremony that also afforded the retiring Minister an opportunity for taking leave of his more intimate colleagues after a collaboration of more than five and a half years.

One unsatisfactory moment in "The Island" staged at the Comedy Theatre tonight, spoils what critics consider might otherwise be a satisfactory play of life in an isolated garrison. For some unknown reason the heroine withholds from her husband a simple explanation of how she came to be kissed by a drunken officer.

The two five-story flats at 148-150 W 17th St were sold by the Emigrant Bank to the Sonjay Building Corp, Jacob Feder. president, at a price indicated as $50,500, the bank taking back a mortgage for $50,323 and making an additional loan of $17,000 under a building loan agreement.

Confronted by something entirely new in the history of the oldest Winter carnival in the country, the members of the Dartmouth Outing Club were accomplishing the impossible today. They were setting the stage for a Winter carnival With only the smallest help from Winter.

The dollar declined moderately yesterday in terms of the principal foreign currencies, but the volume of trading was again reported as light. The pound sterling advanced 5-16 cent to $5.01 1/2 while the French franc gained 3/4 point to close at 3.29 cents.

During the week ended Feb. 9 member bank reserve balances decreased $44,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $2,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold, $13,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $50,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by an increase of $4,000,000 in Treasury currency and a decrease of $17,000,000 in money in circulation.

The City Commissioners today adopted an ordinance which forces the taxicabs here to charge at least 50 cents for two passengers and 10 cents for each additional rider, or more than double the present minimum of 25 cents for five persons.

The Democratic leadership moved ahead of Mayor La Guardia in the New York City transit situation today as John J. Dunnigan, majority leader in the Senate, announced that he had called for a joint public hearing by the Public Service Committees of both houses on all New York City transit legislation.

New Jersey employers who apply age-discrimination against those employed or seeking employment would be liable to a fine or imprisonment or both under a bill introduced in the State Assembly last night by Assemblyman John M. Kerner, a lawyer, of this city. The object is to aid the middle-aged in finding and keeping jobs, although no age limits are mentioned.

Daniel F. Gordon, former executive vice president of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters and former Deputy State Superintendent of Insurance, died last night at his home here. He was 64 years old.

Whatever the future of Brazil, so far as governmental form and policy are concerned, a continued emphasis on nationalism is to be expected. This means that Brazilians led or supported by their government will doubtless continue to strive for and demand a greater share in the fruits of the development of the country, whether that development comes through their own initiative or from the outside.

Mrs. George Bethune Adams, resident director of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, received the 1937 Chappel Award "for distinguished service to American dogdom," at exercises yesterday in the hospital, 350 Lafayette Street.
Trading was uneven, good to slow. Prices on traefa meats were mostly unchanged. Kosher business was confined mostly to lamb at lower prices as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Appointment of a special committee to recommend candidates for Bishop Coadjutor in the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York has been announced by the Right Rev. Edward H. Coley, Bishop.

Giving up their fight, J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, the disbarred lawyer and reputed heir to the underworld machine of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, and George Weinberg, a henchman, decided today to waive extradition and return to New York, where they face prosecution by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Viewing the Democratio move to investigate the qualifications of Councilmen Joseph Clark Baldwin and Michael J. Quill as retaliation for the current inquiry on Councilman Hugh Quinn, members of the Mayor's bloc voted with their opponents in the Council yesterday, to name a committee of live to investigate the two coalition members.

Fritz Lang's next picture, which will follow "You and Me," now before the Paramount cameras, will be "Return Not Again," by Annette Heard, which is concerned with the poor whites of the cotton and tobacco belts. Whether he will make it for Paramount has not been determined, but if studio approval is not given he has indicated he will take it elsewhere.

Dr. W. F. Roberts, Minister of Health and Labor for New Brunswick and the first Minister of Health in the British Empire, died at his home here tonight. He had been ill for months after an operation and suffered a relapse recently. He was 68 years old.

Protective committees for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific's general mortgage 4 per cent bonds and first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent and secured 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an adjournment until. June 30 of the hearings on the railroad's plan of reorganization that are scheduled to be resumed on Feb. 28.

Secretary Morgenthau this afternoon gave notice of the sale of approximately $50,000,000 in ninety-one-day bills, bids to be received up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday, at the Federal Reserve Banks or their branches.

An evening gown solidly beaded with crystal, weighing fifty-two pounds, was one of the more striking of the costumes shown yesterday before an audience of 1,000 notion buyers at I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company's second annual parade of American fashions.

Mrs. Gussie Firstenberg, member of a ring of smugglers alleged to have brought $10,000,000 worth of diamonds into this port in the last ten years, was sentenced yesterday to prison for two months and fined $20,000 by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

Aggregate bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities of the United States in the week ended on Wednesday were $4,322,816,000, the lowest for any full week in more than four years, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Bankers dollar acceptance outstanding in the country as of Jan. 31, 1938, amounted to $325,804,395, a decrease of $17,261,552 from Dec. 31 and $61,422,885 under Jan. 31, 1937, according to the monthly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank.

James M. Kurn, former president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, admitted yesterday in Supreme Court that he had once denounced as "lies" charges similar to those that he and his co-trustee of the road are now making against Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the board; Speyer Co., and J. W. Seligman Co.

Organization of the National Mortgage Association of Washington, with a paid-in capital stock of $10,000,000 and a paid-in surplus of $1,000,000, to aid in the Administration's housing campaign was announced today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

President - Anastasio Somoza in a signed statement given to the foreign press today said: "I regret that some North American newspapers, undoubtedly misled by the propaganda of Nicaraguan enemies of my government, have published false reports that I have fascistic tendencies and that I might enter into agreements of a political nature with nations which are not on this continent.

Thomas Ross, Fort Monmouth United States Army pigeon expert, died suddenly today at his home on Wolf Hill Avenue. His age was 62. He had been in charge of the pigeon lofts at the Signal Corps army port for the last thirteen years and during that time had under his care the famous World War pigeons President Wilson, Spike and Mocker.
Kevin Butler, 33 years old, son of Supreme Court Justice Pierce Butler, died at 1 o'clock this morning of injuries suffered in a fall from a speeding passenger train's washroom.
Appointment of a committee td study plans for reducing the membership of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Vere-Smith entertained with a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Virginia Randolph, daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Hillas of Greenwich, Conn., and Herman Henry Ridder, whose marriage will take place this afternoon.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation disbursed in January $42,817,809 for loans and investments and $21,187,303,-was repaid, according to a report made public today.

Miss Georgia Inez Kauffman. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kauffman of this place, has selected Feb. 19 as the date of her marriage to Dr. Frederick E. Mowry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Mowry of Johnstown, Pa. The ceremony will be performed in the New Providence Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Carroll H. Yorkes.
John Hay Whitney's Francesco was something of a surprise as the winner of the Okeechobee purse today at Hialeah Park, where another candidate for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup failed to impress.

Calling a convicted prisoner "a potential murderer," Assistant District Attorney William Smith asked yesterday a limit sentence for Anthony Pappleo, 29 years old, of 222 First Avenue, before Bronx County Judge Harry Stackell. Judge Stackell sentenced Pappleo to Sing Sing for from fifteen to thirty years.

H. A. Melgard of Lake Mahopac, N. Y., chalked up an expected victory in the second round of the annual Ormond Beach championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today. He vanquished Alden L. Painter of Pittsburgh, runnerup last year, by 2 and 1. The latter upset Isaac L. Merrill Jr. of Camden, Me., the medalist, yesterday.
Action on the resolution of Senator Burke, proposing an investigation of the National Labor Relations Board, was indefinitely postponed today by a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Captain J. E. Lewis, commander of the American tanker Nantucket Chief, has been released from prison at Palma, Majorca, and has flown to Malaga, via Cadiz, to resume command of his ship, the State Department announced today.

" THE HIDDEN LINCOLN"* is an extraordiary book. It is a collection of the letters and papers of William H. Herndon, Lincoln's garrulous and Boswellian law partner, who spent years in spading out original material for a biography that was never published in the form he wanted. And he himself saw reason enough for that.

Mike Jacobs cabled Max Schmeling in Germany yesterday, requesting the ex-heavyweight champion of the world to come to this country as soon as convenient. The promoter also asked Schmeling to abandon whatever plans he may have for any more tune-up fights before his meeting here in June with Joe Louis for the latter's heavyweight championship of the world.
The Browns, who have had Catcher Rollie Hemsley on the trading block for several years, sent him to the Indians tonight for Catcher Billy Sullivan, Infielder Roy Hughes and Pitcher Ed Cole.
In the carmies of the world, the older men are on their way out. The bigger and better armaments are apparently for young men to
The Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., tender, Castle Harbor, has reached the disabled Greek freighter Mountaetna and is towing her to Bermuda.

Students at the University of Rochester were warned today by Dr. Alan Valentine, president, against working toward economic security rather than "the great intellectual goals of life." Speaking on "The Price of Security," at the university's annual convocation exercises, Dr. Valentine said:

Ironing out difficulties which have arisen under the section of the New York Stock Exchange's constitution that refers to the minimum commission chargeable, the committee on quotations and commissions issued an interpretation yesterday defining "one transaction."

Following a day of rumors of military troubles in Germany, and of official denials, admission in National Socialist party circles of "difficulties" with the army came from Berlin tonight in a telephoned dispatch from the correspondent of The Times of London.

At least fifteen persons were killed and extensive property damage was caused as the worst storm in twenty years struck here last night and raged on into today. Scores of homes were wrecked, phone and light services were disrupted and streets were flooded by bursting sewers.

The Hamburg - American liner Hansa will arrive today from Bremen, Hamburg and Channel ports. Passengers are the Earl and Countess of Meath, Dr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Sondern, Christian F. Ahrenkiel, Joseph H. Saville, Mr. and Mrs. Erhardt M. Oehmichen, Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Luettmann, Heinrich Henkel, the Right Rev. Richard R. W right Jr. and Mrs. Wright, Henry W. Hoch, Gert Keller and Dr. Guenther Leopold.

The performance of "A Doll's House" was called off at the Broadhurst Theatre last evening at the end of the first act due to the illness of Miss Ruth Gordon with laryngitis. Money was refunded to those present, or if they wished they received tickets for another performance. About 50 per cent took tickets.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. denied yesterday the application of a group of petitioners, including BoroughPresident George U. Harvey of, Queens, for the right to incorporate under the name "We Americans, Inc."

John M. Barber, former vice president and treasurer of Ward Baking Company, has been elected. executive vice president. Daniel P. Adams has been appointed assistant treasurer of the Marine Midland Trust Company.

Extension of the broad advance among railroad loans was the feature of more active trading yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The carrier group, scored the widest advance in some time, gains of 1 to 3 points being registered throughout the list.

INSPECTOR OF FIRE PREVENTION, GRADE 3-Amended Notice-Persons who filed application for this position between Jan. 10 and Jan. 24, 1938, need not again file application. The list resulting from this examination will also be certified for C Grade 2 positions and for all inspectorial positions of a similar character in the Emergency Relief Bureau or its successor, the annual salary of which is less than $3,000 per annum.

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following reserve officers, released to headquarters, First Military Area, are assigned to units as indicated: 513th Coast Artillery (AA) 2d Lt. Clarence E. Johnson, CA-Rer., 59 Schiller St., Apt. 4, Binghamton, N. Y. 2d Lt. John G. Skidmore, CA-Res., 1,931 Holland Ave., Utica, N. Y.

The trustees of Vassar College have appointed for the next college year Dr. Lyle H. Lanier of Vanderbilt University as Professor of Psychology to succeed Margaret Floy Washburn, Professor Emeritus, who retired in June; Dr. Ada M.

Mrs. Helen Baker Krakeur, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Baker of Chicago, was married to Harold Spear, son of Mrs. Samuel H. Spear of this city and the late Mr. Spear, here yesterday afternoon in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black, who performed the ceremony.
The Rev Martin Niemoeller not only has abandoned any attempt to defend himself before the Emergency Court.trying him here in secret, but also has openly challenged the court. it was reported today.

During the past year the permanent funds of the philanthropic foundations, which have given at least $680,000,000 for the support of American higher education since they were established, have been swelled by gifts amounting to about $480,000,000, a sum never previously approached, according to a survey conducted in the Advanced School of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, made public yesterday.

Joseph V. Curran of New York, head of the C. I. O. National Maritime Union, was absolved of charges of communism today by the Senate Joint Commerce and Labor Committee, which is considering the pending bill to amend the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, urged by Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman of the Maritime Commission, for an expanded merchant marine.

The third annual Eastern badminton title tournament opened yesterday on the courts of the Old 69th Badminton Club. William Markham, representing the Old 69th club, and winner of the District of Columbia championship last week, seeded No. 1;

As a step in preparation for the opening of the metropolitan racing season on April 16 at Jamaica, the stewards of the Jockey Club and the license committee cooperated yesterday to issue permits to sixtythree trainers and twelve jockeys.

It will be Boston against Philadelphia in the semi-finals of the Women's National Squash Racquets singles championship tomorrow morning at the Harvard Club, for Mrs. William F. Howe and Miss Eleonora Sears of this city today earned the right to meet Miss Anne Page and Miss Cecile Bowes, favored entrants from the Quaker city.
At the instance of the Nicaraguan Government the reciprocal tariff concessions under the existing trade agreement will be no longer effective after March 10, the State Department announced today.
Police have arrested two American stowaways in the past two days. They are Francis Murphy, 17 years old, of Kearney, N. J., and Miss Gloria Reyes of 108 West Fortyninth Street, New York.

Mrs. Pauline Pitt of 204-18 111th Avenue, Hollis, received permission yesterday from Surrogate John Hetherington in Jamaica to accept a settlement of $12,000 in a claim which arose from the death of her son, William Harold Pitt, 30 years old, who was killed in a plane crash in Utah last October.

Dartmouth gained undisputed possession of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League lead tonight by overcoming Yale, 38 to 29, in a game marked by three stirring rallies. Dartmouth registered ten points before Yale tallied, and finished the first half leading, 21-10.

A twenty-three game varsity baseball schedule, featuring contests with six metropolitan rivals and the return of Holy Cross and Manhattan, was announced for the Fordham nine yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics.

Six members of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, who have spent fifty years in the industry, were presented with engrossed certificates by D. Hayes Murphy, president of the association at its annual dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The Chicago Board of Trade posted today on its bulletin board a notice informing members that the directors had ordered a paragraph stricken from the published annual report of the committee on securities and stock listings. The paragraph read:

Experimental fascimile tests, during which more than ten feet of printed matter and photographs arranged on a four-inch strip of paper were transmitted over WOR's wave from New York to Newark in two and a half hours, were carried out early yesterday morning and pronounced successful by station representatives.

For a fortnight a committee of the New Jersey Assembly has been trying to get at the records of the November election in Hudson County. The Republican Commissioner of Registration is ill. Without his permission his clerk refused to unlock the vault in which the books of registry and election are shut up.

A funeral service for George Daley, sports editor of The NewYork Herald Tribune, was held yesterday at 393 St. Paul's Avenue, Stapleton, S. I., the home of Charles S. Daley, Mr. Daley's brother. Mr. Daley died early Tuesday.
T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation and president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said today that there were signs of further gains in industry.

Joseph Unger, president of the Pawnbrokers Association of New York, presented yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine two checks, totaling $1,800, for the families of two policemen who frustrated a hold-up Jan. 28 in the Goodman-Edelstein pawnshop at 2,629 Third Avenue.
A suggestion that Air Minister Hermann Goering of Germany be asked to visit Britain threw the House of Commons into an uproar today that was quelled only by insistent efforts by the Speaker.

A sevenpoint program for installment banking to follow as a means of avoiding a serious credit crisis was proposed by O. C. Cameron, president of the Bankers Commercial Corporation, installment bankers, of Chicago and New York, in an address before the National Retail Hardware Association at its annual meeting here today. The program was as follows:

The State Department of Banking and Insurance reported today that State-chartered banking institutions had total resources of $1,455,800,189 on Dec. 31 last, compared with $1,489,613,327 on Dec. 31, 1936, and $1,452,810,210 on June 30, 1937.

Soviet officials imposed a heavy censorship today on the efforts of United States diplomats to obtain from Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens the full details of the American woman's arrest and detention as a suspected spy.

Information received by the Danish Greenland board from the Russian ice floe expedition placed its position at 10:30 A. M. today at Lat. 71 degrees, 56 minutes North; Long. 20 degrees, 53 minutes West on a southwesterly course between Cane Wardlaw and Cane Topham.

Failure to provide adequate service on its subway and elevated lines, especially during rush hour periods, was charged against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday by Transit Commission experts and spokesmen for civic and labor groups at a public hearing before Transit Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig.

The Metropolitan undoubtedly has found a strong new drawing card in Jan Kiepura, Polish tenor, who scored a sensational triumph in his debut as Rodolfo at the season's fourth performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" at that house last night.

The Grace Line announced yesterday that emergency speaker systems had been installed in all of the company's passenger vessels at a cost of about $100,000 to bring the vessels up to the rigid standard set by American maritime law.

Negotiations of the National Maritime Union, an affiliate of the C. I. O., with the American Steamship Owners Association for a blanket labor contract for all American-flag ship lines, terminated abruptly yesterday afternoon when committees for both sides were unable to arrive at an agreement on the union's demand for a closed shop.

A quick response to the easier financing terms provided under the amended FHA regulations is reported by the builders of Independence Homes, at Utopia Parkway and Twenty-eighth Avenue, Bayside, L. I., who announced yesterday that sales in this community set a new high mark during January.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/2c; sales, 20 barrels; receipts, 20 barrels; shipments, 999 barrels; stock, 26,691 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 162 barrels; receipts, 415 barrels; shipments, 2,069 barrels; stock, 75,527 barrels.

Opposition to the proposed legislation which would abolish "blue ribbon" juries was expressed yesterday in a report of the committee on criminal courts, law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. The report was made public by Timothy N. Pfeiffer, chairman of the committee.

It is understood here that Premier Benito Mussolini's eldest son, Bruno, as soon as he returns from his flight to South America will organize a round the world flight which he intends to carry out during the Spring or Summer.

If the steel business had continued as prosperous as it was a year ago, the C. I. O. might have gained some further concessions from the United States Steel Corporation. At the very least it would have renewed its contract for another year.

The hope that the United States' policy of keeping out of foreign entanglements may "somehow eventually entangle the world in peace" was expressed by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, at the annual dinner of the Bronx County Bar Association last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Gold or silver crown tokens have been awarded to 108 Columbia College students for achievement in extracurricular activities, Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of King's Crown, the supervising body of activities at Columbia, announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Maxine Rose-Marie Harding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Harding of London, to Eric Arthur Cleugh of 277 Park Avenue, British Consul in New York, will take place this afternoon at 903 Park Avenue, the home of Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, and Lady Campbell. The Rev. Dr. John Haynes Holmes will perform the ceremony.

The unsolved mystery of the disappearance of Feodor Butenko, Soviet charge d'affaires at Bucharest, developed a serious international aspect today with the presentation of a sharply-worded note from the Soviet to the Rumanian Foreign Office.

Declining 0.8 per cent during January, retail prices for the first time since October, 1935, have fallen under those of the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. The composite index now stands at 92.4, compared with 93 on Feb. 1, 1937.

Samuel L. Joseph of 740 West End Avenue, agents' counselor of the New York Life Insurance Company, died suddenly of a heart attack on Wednesday in a street car at Vanderbilt Avenue and Fortysecond Street. He was 82 years old.
The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization and Federal income taxes, of $3,325,769.

The Appellate Division heard arguments and reserved decision yesterday on the city's appeal from Justice John E. McGeehan's order upholding the Democratic budget which Mayor La Guardia vetoed and invalidating his substitute budget.
Cambridge University's rugby team will make another visit to the United States this year for a tour of the East which will keep the visitors in this country for about three weeks.

Followers of realty market trends who have been hearing so much of late about slums, abandoned buildings and the unfavorable position of many property investments on the lower East Side of Manhattan may be surprised to learn that in some respects at least the situation in that neighborhood is brighter today than it was four or five years ago.

Notables from numerous walks of life mingled as thousands visited Madison Square Garden yesterday for the opening of the sixty-second annual Westminster Kennel Club show. Veteran observers regarded the attendance as the largest for an opening day in the show's history.

Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, Jesse H. Holmes, Emeritus Professor of Philosophy at Swarthmore College, and William G. Simpson, former minister and author of "Toward the Rising Sun," will speak at Antioch College Feb. 19 and 20

A chart has recently been circulated from Washington showing how the most sensitive fourth of all the prices included in the Bureau of Labor statistics index fell 65 per cent from 1926 to 1933, while the least sensitive fourth fell only 10 per cent. The chart has been cited by Administration sources as evidence or proof of several contentions:

The dispute between the British Medical Association and the London newspapers over the publication of a series of advertisements warning the public against the use of unpasteurized milk has been ended by a

Attributing her brief criminal career to addiction to marijuana cigarettes, which "made wrong things seem right," Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl gave her version today of the fatal shooting of William Barhorst, bus driver, in a Belleville hold-up. Mrs. Sohl, 20-year-old daughter of a Newark policeman, and Miss Genevieve Owens, 18, are on trial in Common Pleas Court for the murder of the bus driver.

A declaration by Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller that the last word had been said and the final opposing argument refuted, wound up the proponents' case for the Equal Rights Amendment before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon, on the fourth day of the hearing.

Reports here yesterday indicated that Representative Patman has lined up eighty Congressmen for support of the new bill taxing the, chains which he plans to introduce. On the other hand, it was also reported that there has been much criticism of the proposed measure reaching Congress from consumer groups, trade boards and others.
Dr. John N. Ryan, Passaic Health Officer for twenty-six years, died today in St. Mary's Hospital after a month's illness of a stomach ailment.

Governor Lehman tonight signed the Mitchell-Nunan bill incorporating the New York City Police Cooperative Uniform Purchasing Association. The plan, which was asked for by the force itself, marks another step in the long fight of the police to obtain cheaper uniforms.

Lawrence A. Coleman, executive vice president of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company and former president of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, died early yesterday at his home, 301 Loring Avenue, Pelham, of a sudden heart attack.

After calling one witness, former Magistrate Albert Vitale, chief defense counsel for George De Renna, who is on trial for the murder of Police Sergeant David Kilpatrick on Jan. 28 during a holdup of a Bronx pawnshop, rested his case yesterday afternoon.

In line with the liberalized National Housing Act, the gas industry through the American Gas Association yesterday announced a national program to stimulate the construction and modernization of homes throughout the country to be inaugurated next month.

TODAY--New England: Clear and colder, with zero temperatures prevailing over the central and northern portions; hardfreezing temperatures over the south. New York State-Clear and continued cold, with zero temperatures over the north and moderate to hard-freezing temperatures over the central and southern portions. Pennsylvania:

Walter Kinsella, 52, of New York, lost to the youthful Jimmy Dunn of Philadelphia in the second round of the national professional squash racquets championships today. The score was 15-6, 15-10, 11-15, 15-11.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today John P. Ohl and Max Weitz of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 8: CAPTAIN McMullin, J. J. A., Med. Corps, Portsmouth, Va., to duty as Medical Officer in command of Naval Hospital, Canacao, P. I., about April 1.

Miss Jessie Wachenheim, daughter of Mr..and Mrs. Edgar Wachenheim of New Rochelle, N. Y., was married to Dr. Philip I. Burack of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Burach of Hartford, Conn., yesterday afternoon at the Society for Ethical Culture. Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott performed the ceremony.
Wholesale prices, on the average, registered a further decline in the week ended on Feb. 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. All commodities, except farm products, were lower.

I dread Winter. I shut my door Against the wind when the cold was sore, Gathered my precious things together Into one room against the weather, And bought a jewel to spend the night Turning its facets in the light.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 1,000 directs. Light hogs were fully steady with Wednesday's average; others mostly strong to 10 cents higher: spots 15 cents up.

George C. Van Tuyl Jr., former State Superintendent of Banks, died at his home, 194 Riverside Drive, Wednesday night following a brief illness. He was 65 years old. Appointed in 1911, he held the State bank post until 1914, when he entered the banking business here.

Three persons were killed and three wounded in a hold-up by fifty bandits of the cashier of the Britishowned Dos Estrellas Mining Company in the vicinity of El Oro, in the State of Mexico, this afternoon.
Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Ecker gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the ten-year development program of the institution.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted here tonight that, although Abraham Lincoln took the first step toward the abolition of slavery in

A group of "little business" men organized yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker, elected every member an officer or to the executive committee and held an exhaustive post mortem on the recent "small business" council in Washington, which cleared up some suspicions that the government had attempted to "tone down" their demands to President Roosevelt.

Moderate activity in calfskins has marked -an otherwise quiet hide market in the last week, and easier prices have developed on some other lines. Bids for calfskins at 1/2 cent below previous selling levels have been refused, with packers holding for 12 cents on 8 to 10 pound Chicago skins against bids at 11 1/2 cents.

Carrying information of international significance for President Roosevelt, High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt left for the United States today aboard the Hawaii Clipper from an air terminal heavily guarded by armed United States marines. To minimize chances of sabotage or other untoward occurrence, the naval authorities had placed a guard about the clipper a week ago. Guards will also be provided at Guam and Honolulu.

Indiana University's wrestlers proved too strong for the New York A. C. last night, sweeping all eight bouts to win by 26-0 in the Winged Foot gymnasium. The unbeaten Hoosiers, for whom this was the fourth victory, are on a trip that will take them to Navy tomorrow and V. M. I. on Monday.

Miss Theresa A. Quilty, for twenty years, connected with the Bronx District Attorney's office and a member of the general advisory committee on women's participation in the New York World's Fair, died yesterday after a brief illness at St. Clare Hospital at- the age of 48.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on admissions will ballot on Feb. 24 on a proposal to transfer for $59,000 the membership of H. Duncan Wood of Johnson Wood, which will continue as a member firm, to J. Burr Bartram.

A new fivemember State Milk Control Board was named by Governor Moore today, with four of the appointees being producers and the other a consumer representative. Two of the five replaced were producers, two were distributors and the fifth a consumer representative.

A luncheon will be given on Monday at the Junior League under the auspices of the organization's Arts and Interests Committee. Jay Allen, foreign correspondent, will speak. He will be introduced by Mrs. Morgan Wing Jr., chairman of the sponsoring committee.

Easter Island, Chile's only distant territory in the Southern Pacific, became an object of renewed interest this afternoon when radio reports reached naval headquarters here indicating the discovery of oil indications there.

Justice Auguste Tessier, former Provincial Treasurer and Agriculture Minister in the Sir Lomer Gouin Cabinet, died at his home today at the age of 84. Judge Tessier, who retired from the Superior Court bench in 1922, sat in Provincial Legislature for eighteen years as Liberal Representative of Rimouski County.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with great interest the letter "Handicaps in Civil Service" by Jerome Greenblatt. Unfortunately, Mr. Greenblatt speaks only of clerical help.

Benjamin Levine, 43-year-old garment manufacturer, charged by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey with having been second only to Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro in the operation of a garment racket that took in millions of dollars a year.

The Spanish Embassy at Washington has abused its diplomatic franking privileges by sending out Spanish Loyalist propaganda material postage free, Captain John E. Kelly, consulting engineer, charged last night at a meeting at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation totaled 518,322 tons in January, compared with 489,070 in December, a gain of 29,252 tons, and with 1,149,918 tons, a decline of 631,596, in January, 1937.

THE HIDDEN LINCOLN, edited by Emanuel Hertz. (Viking, $5.) The letters and papers of Wil-liam H. Herndon, Lincoln's friend and law partner. NOBODY'S IN TOWN, by Edna Ferber. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.) Two short novels.

The Interstate Commerce Commission extended today to motor carriers its rule requiring railroads to employ competitive bidding in dealing in securities or in supplies or other materials of commerce to the amount of more than $50,000 in any one year where there is an interlocking directorate relationship between the railroad and the selling or purchasing corporation.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "World-wide Current Events," Mrs. Henry R. Caraway. Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Music as a Social Force," Olga Samaroff-Stokowski.

The waterfront property of the Lynn Gas and Electric Company, totaling $1,000,000 in wharves, fuel-lifting Gerricks and coal, was destroyed by a fire which still was burning tonight after firemen from six cities and four towns had brought it under control in a six-hour battle.

More than 3,000,000,000 francs of gold has been transferred from the gold reserve of the Bank of France to the Exchange Equalization Fund, according to the Bank's weekly statement published today, in fulfillment of his intentions as announced two days ago by Minister of Finance Paul Marchandeau.

Senator Arthur F. Foran of Hunterdon County, a Republican, and Senator James I. Bowers of Somerset County, Democrat, were appointed today by Governor Moore to be members of his military staff with the rank of lieutenant colonel.
The Westminster Kennel Clut opened its sixty-second annual allbreed dog show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. The exhibition will continue through tomorrow evening.

The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church closed its three-day meeting yesterday by balancing the 1938 budget of the church with a cut of $47,554 in proposed expenditures. The budget is for missionary, social service and educational work, and as adopted yesterday calls for the expenditure of $2,345,080.

The Manhattan College debating team lost to a touring University of Detroit team yesterday afternoon in Smith Auditoriums A large audience heard the discussion on the topic, "Resolved, That the National Labor Relations Board Should Be Empowered to Enforce Arbitration in All Industrial Disputes."

he Administration's foreign policy and the $800,000,000 naval construction program were under fire again today in the Senate and before the House Naval Affairs Committee, which is considering the Vinson Bill to put President Roosevelt's proposals into effect.
Colonel Leonard P. Ayres told the Traffic Club of Cleveland tonight that 1938 may bring a fundamental change in American transportation "if real depression conditions prevail" throughout the year.

Death Annonnced Retired Fireman Richard J. McNamee, formerly a member of Engine Co. 54, residing at 3,115 Sedgwick Ave., Bronx, died Feb. 8. Special Notice The annual memorial mass for the deceased members of the Fire Department Holy Name Society, Brooklyn and Queens, will be celebrated on Saturday, Feb. 12, at 10:30 A. M., at the Holy Family Church, 13th St., between 4th and 5th Aves., Brooklyn.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks reached a new high or low point for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

William Allen White tried his best to take his seventieth birthday in stride today, but the home town would not let him. He arrived late at The Gazette office, blamed it on a Rotary Club's surprise gathering at his home last night and apologized.
A summary judgment awarding $9,000 in back pay to Kings County Register Peter J. McGuinness was granted yesterday by Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Plans for converting the Star Casino at 101 to 115 East 107th Street, northeast corner of Park Avenue, into a roller-skating rink and sports arena were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of the building by the Peter A. H. Jackson Estate, Inc., to sports arena operators.

Benjamin Franklin High School's quintet scored its fifth victory in six starts in the lower Manhattan Division of the P. S. A. L. and tightened its hold on second place by beating Stuyvesant, 47-24, at the DeWitt Clinton gymnasium yesterday.

Stocks closed steady and generally higher, with rail, chemical and farm equipment shares leading; turnover, 631,670 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, rail issues strong; transactions, $6,722,325.

Miss Laila Schou Nilsen of Norway today won her second individual title of the women's world speed-skating championship. The Norwegian girl, who captured the 500-meter crown yesterday, defeated Miss Madeline (Maddy) Horn of Beaver Dam, Wis., by 3.1 seconds in the 1,000-meter event.

Although Kenneth Hayes Miller's last previous one-man show was held-in 1935, his present exhibition at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, contains but fourteen canvases. In this three-year period Mr. Miller may have painted a little more than the current report reveals. But, unlike many artists, he does not fabricate pictures.

The birth in a log cabin near Hodgenville, Ky., Feb. 12, 1809, of Abraham Lincoln, the man who has been called "the first American," will be celebrated again today, tomorrow and Sunday by New York City and-the nation.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange will ballot within two weeks on an amendment to that institution's constitution changing the method of voting constitutional amendments.

Nathan Lieberman of 246 West End Avenue, a lawyer, and two stock corporations of which he was treasurer-Group Equities Corporation, an investment trust, and Naylib Realty Corporation-were enjoined permanently yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Sheintag from further dealing in securities in this State.

A first mortgage of $200,000 has been placed by the Haggstrom-Callen-Davis Co., Inc., on the recently completed six-story apartment on the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 187th Street, for the Shakbro Realty Corporation. Henry Waltemade, Inc., has arranged the extension of the first mortgage of $36,500 on the five-story apartment at 797 Crotona Park North for Caperton Estates, Inc., with the Joseph Wechsler Estate.

The 1938 municipal budget adopted by the Yonkers Common Council is legal and the veto by Mayor Joseph F. Loehr is without effect even though funds may not have been provided for general operating expenses, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis ruled today in a 2,500-word decision.

Business confidence will not be restored by the modifications in the undistributed profits tax proposed by the Vinson subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, the Merchants Association of New York declared. in a report adopted yesterday at a meeting of its board of directors.

Miss Harriet Taylor, world traver and for many years a local and national Y. W. C. A. executive, died early yesterday of pneumonia at the home of her niece, Miss Maude Goodman, 181 Claremont Avenue. She was 70 years old.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate an additional $250,000,000 to provide "a reasonable measure of relief" for an estimated 3,000,000 workers who had lost their jobs in the last three months, and to help give continued employment to the 1,950,000 persons now on the rolls of the Works Progress Administration.
Wesley C. Dudley, former State Supreme Court justice and District Attorney of Erie County, died at his home here today after an illness of ten years. He was 70 years old.

President Roosevelt sent to Speaker Bankhead a letter asking Congress to appropriate an additional $250,000,000 to care for increasing relief needs and later discussed the relief situation with David Lasser and Herbert Benjamin, representatives of the Workers Alliance.

Fred (Red) Lucas, 35-year-old right-hander, sent his signed contract to the Pittsburgh club today and with it enclosed a request for a starter's role this season. Lucas, who starred for many years with Cincinnati before going to Pittsburgh a few years ago, said he was "well pleased with the salary offered."

Canadian athletes rode the crest of a recordbreaking wave in track and field at the British Empire Games today. Of the six track and field titles at stake, Maple Leaf stars took the broad jump, hammer throw, 440-yard relay and the women's javelin and cracked meet marks in all four events.

The Guild of American Artists, Lawrence Tibbett president, will hold a benefit concert Sunday evening, Feb. 20, at Carnegie Hall to launch a program, the principal object of which is the establishment. of a national department of fine arts "that will give American artists the same recognition and encouragement enjoyed by artists in Europe."

Net sales of Best Co. for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 increased 8.3 per cent to $16,192,549 from sales of $14,945,251 in the preceding fiscal year, according to the preliminary annual report issued today by Philip LeBoutillier, president and general manager.

In the absence of any large new issues, municipal bond dealers turned their attention yesterday to the sale by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $5,616,100 of bonds of various municipalities. Interest centered upon the issue of $1,203,000 of New York City 4 per cent rapid transit subway serial bonds,

The League of Nations committee on the status of refugees from Germany finished its work today with seven of the fourteen countries represented signing the convention adopted yesterday. Several others are expected to sign later after their governments have had time to study the convention.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Edison Company, controlled by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, for 1937, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges, of $11,643,218.

Mrs. Loring Griswold Robbins of Pittsfield gave a dinner dance at Proctor House tonight in compliment to the bridal party of her daughter, Miss Cornelia Durant Robbins, and Russ Van Vleck Bradley, who are to be married tomorrow. Mr. Bradley's mother; Mrs. Van Vleck Bradley of Greenwich, Conn., is at Proctor House.

The trustee of t he will of Adolphus Ottenberg sold to the Vividon Realty Corp, Michael Lichtman, president, the flats at 36 W 116th St for $14,000, taking back a p m mortgage for $13,500, due ten years hence at 4 1/2 per cent, with monthly and quarterly amortization of $100 to $125.

In biting, zero cold, the short, stocky figure of Dick Durrance started the Dartmouth ski team off with avictory today as the twenty-eighth annual carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club opened on the skiing trail of Moose Mountain.

Effective yesterday, the firm of Daly Craib was dissolved. Frank J. Ouellette retired from Harriman Keech, effective Feb. 1; Jules C. Lazard from Marks, Laser Co., effective Feb. 1, and Everett E. Mellinger from Winthrop, Mitchell Co., effective Feb. 9.
The minimum-price structure set up by the government for the soft-coal industry suffered a serious blow today when the Federal Court of Appeals here suspended the prices for railroad fuel.

Plani for a five-year study of teacher education, financed by a grant of $200,000 from the General Education Board and directed by Professor Karl F. Bigelow of Teachers College, Columbia University, were announced today by Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council of Education.

The New York World's Fair is involved in its first strike. The labor trouble began two weeks ago when four employes in the fair's cafeteria for employes in the Administration Building were discharged and ten of the cafeteria's twenty-six employes walked out.
As their third production of the season, the Artef Players last night presented Ossip Dymow's venture into science called "The East Side Professor."

French wives will no longer be obliged to promise to obey, it is provided in a bill passed by the Chamber of Deputies without debate early this morning. The bill, originating in the Senate, contains many other reforms in the status of married women which go further, some feminists believe, in their emancipation than if it gave French women the vote.
Alexander, Philip G. Amole, Amelia Benson, Sarah W. Boylan, Mary Burke, Daniel L. Camman, Gertrude Center, Edward C. Coleman, Lawrence Conlin, Helen S. Corrigan, Helen A.

The annual meeting of Cord Corporation stockholders here today changed the name of the concern to Aviation and Transportation Company. The stockholders also reduced the authorized capital from $10,000,000 to $3,000,000 and the par value of the stock from $5 to $1 a share.

Don Lash of Indiana tonight won the Penn A. C. mile, feature event of Philadelphia's first indoor track meet in six years. Lash covered the distance in 4:22.3, with Gerald Tarant of the University of Pennsylvania second.

Tommy Smith, 19-year-old Utica (N. Y.) speedster, and the veteran Eddie Schroeder of Chicago, defending champion, today paced a large field in the opening of the North American speed skating championships.

The first Marconi Memorial Gold Medal for Valor established by the Veteran Wireless Operators. Association in memory of the Italian inventor, who was honorary president of the organization, was awarded here last night at the association's annual dinner to Lieutenant Carl O. Petersen, U. S. N. R., for outstanding radio work as a member of the Byrd. Antarctic Expeditions.

In the first eleven months of 1937 there were 4,018 accidents at railroad grade crossings, in which 1,686 persons were killed and 4,610 injured, as compared with 3,742 accidents, with 1,561 deaths and 4,340 injured, in the same period of 1936, the Interstate Commerce Commission-revealed today.
With Ruth Gordon still ill there was no performance of "A Doll's House" last evening at the Broadhurst and both showings have been canceled for today. Miss Gordon is expected back on Monday.

Dr. Walter S. Terhune, who had practiced - in Brooklyn for more than sixty years, died on Thursday at his home, 307 Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, in his eighty-fifth year. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, he studied medicine at Long Island College Hospital and the New York Homeopathic Medical College.

C. I. O. organizers or sympathizers stole a march on the Jersey City police today by distributing union handbills at a local manufacturing plant and disappearing before the police arrived to stop the distribution, which is a violation of the law under a city ordinance.

A little more than seventy years has passed since the great American whose birthday we celebrate today fashioned a phrase which his countrymen will long remember. The war which "both parties deprecated" was drawing to its end. The greater task of reconstruction lay ahead.

While thousands of Columbia University graduates throughout the world hark back to campus life in local alumni day celebrations, 3,000 alumni will visit Morningside Heights today to participate in a reunion program dedicated to the School of Architecture.

Loy W. Loy W. Henderson, American charge d'affaires in Moscow, was told yesterday by Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens, an American citizen, in an interview in Butyrskaya Prison, that she did not need any assistance, the State Department announced today.

Amos F. Morrison, 50 years old, of Village View, Media, Pa., was reported to be doing well yesterday at the Institute of Ophthalmology, Presbyterian Hospital, following a rare operation Thursday upon his eyes.

Complaints about poorly prepared and insufficient food served to employes in city hospitals were made at City Hall yesterday to Nathan Frankel, Mayor La Guardia's labor adviser, by six members of the State and Municipal Hospital Employes Union.

Payson Ave, s e cor Beak St, 31.4x100.8; Jewish Memorial Hospital, Inc, to Augusta Polpack, 95 Division Ave, Brooklyn; mtg, $8,250 ($3). Same property; Augusta Poplack to Carmine Rocco, 205 W 34th St; consideration, 3,750 .

Jamaica High and Brooklyn Technical High maintained their unbeaten pace in the city P. S. A. L. ice hockey championship tournament by scoring victories at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The triumph was the second straight for each school.

Recent attacks by the Nazi leader, Deputy Jorge Gonzalez von Maree, in Congress against the commander-in-chief of the army, General Oscar Novoa, which were taken up by the Leftist press in an unconcealed desire to turn them into a political issue are energetically denied by the Rightist Dress.
Henry H. Martyn, one of the few men who heard the din of Custer's massacre at the Little Big Horn in 1876 and lived to tell the story, died last night at his home at the age of 84.

It is impossible to think of the Middle West, or the American small city, or the homely virtues, or independent journalism, without thinking of William Allen White. Mr. White is the great unbossed American.
Great Britain, Switzerland and Lithuania scored 1-0 victories in the world amateur hockey championship, which got under way today. Latvia was forced into overtime to win, 3-1, from Norway.

Three prizes were awarded yesterday at the annual exhibition of oil paintings and sculpture by members of the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue. The Lay Members Prize of $700 went to Harry Leith-Ross for the painting "First Presbyterian."

All African governments south of the Equator are combining to fight a rinderpest cattle plague that is sweeping southward and threatening to destroy millions of cattle and to leave a trail of famine in its wake, as a similar plague did in the Nineties.

The New York State Athletic Commission, at its meeting yesterday, withdrew championship recognition from the bout in Cleveland on Feb. 19, in which Freddie Steele, world middleweight titleholder, is scheduled to defend his championship against Carmen Barth.

Production of hosiery during December totaled 6,097,553 dozen pairs, compared with 7,069,349 in November and 9,102,694 in December, 1936, according to figures just issued by the Bureau of the Census. Shipments during December amounted to 7,205,959 dozen pairs, against 8,156,766 in the preceding month and 9,311,040 in the same month last year.
Colonel William H. Linson, who served in the Spanish-American War with the Seventy-first Regiment, N. Y. N. G., died on Thursday at his home, 621 West 188th Street, after a long illness.

In announcing the declaration of a 37 1/2-cent dividend on its common stock the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company said yesterday that no preliminary earnings figures for 1937 would be given out this year.

The Mexican Army will have the largest single representation of any group in the "constituent assembly" scheduled to be held in Mexico City on March 31, to form a new State within a State by the formation of a new ingle official party to replace the National Revolutionary party.
The Rev. Z. F. Griffin, oldest trustee of Keuka College and one of the oldest college trustees in the country, died at his home here today at the age of 93.

Complaints that the Spanish Empbassy here hasp been sending- out propaganda matter postage free under its franking privilege, similar to those voiced at the Catholic Press Exhibit in New York last night, have been sent to the -State Department by various Catholic organizations and individuals from time to time.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 5 amounted to 564,740 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,564 cars, or 2.1

1st Lt. Austin W. Smith, CA-Res.; 412 Raines Park, Rochester, N. Y., 2d Coast Artillery District, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective Feb. 14, at CCC Co. 1268, Camp SP-5, High Bridge, N. J., for CCC duty.

Imports of gold into the United States in the week ended on Feb. 4 were valued at $1,565,761, while exports were $64,064, according to the weekly statement of the Department of Commerce, made public today. In the previous week Imports were $2,380,582 and exports $8,341.

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., climaxed a week of brilliant play by winning the annual Palm Beach championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. She defeated Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, former New Jersey State champion, in a thrilling final that ended on the nineteenth hole.

The Supreme Court expressed regret today over the death of Kevin Butler, 31-year-old son of Associate Justice Pierce Butler. At the opening of the court session Chief Justice Hughes, speaking in a low voice, explained the absence from court of the justice.

Mussolini seems to have II Duce's been the victim of poor Faulty timing. He took over the Timing German goose-step only a few days ago, when Hitler must have already made up his mind to throw the goose-step overboard.

The index of machine tool orders for January declined to 118.4, compared with 142.7 for the preceding month, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association announced here today. The figure compares with 200.3 for January, 1937. The index is based on 1926 shipments as 100.

Joe Gordon, Portland, Ore., infielder who is to be prepared as the successor to Tony Lazzeri at second base for the Yankees this year, yesterday joined the ranks of athletes under contract to Colonel Jacob Ruppert.

Cuba's sugar stabilization plan, launched in 1930 to save her sugar industry by segregation of surplus bought with a $42,000,000 government bond issue, has been successful under the direction of a commission of three, according to figures of the National Sugar Export Corporation made public here yesterday by the Cuban Chamber of Commerce in the United States.
Before departing on a Caribbean cruise of two months Commodore and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt were hosts today at a farewell luncheon aboard their yacht Alva on which the cruise will be made.

Tomorrow will be observed as the sixteenth annual Race Relations Sunday, the custom being sponsored by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. This observance always comes the Sunday nearest to the birthday of Aam Lincoln,, which is today.

Elwood G. Feldstein, 35-year-old attorney, with offices at 47 West Thirty-fourth Street, Manhattan, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning at 7:30 this morning in the garage of his home at 114 Prospect Street, here.
The New York University women's basketball team easily triumphed over Upsala yesterday at the Evangeline Gymnasium, 30 to 3. Miss Virginia Blum of the winners was high scorer with 14 points.

A fire of undetermined origin yesterday drove twenty families in an apartment house at 1,317 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, to the street. A fireman and a 66-year-old woman tenant were overcome by smoke, while a truck driver, who turned in the alarm and brought an unidentified woman to the street, received slight burns and abrasions of the legs.
Superior Judge Ingall W. Bull told the jury trying Paul A. Wright today for killing his wife and best friend that if it found he "was unconscious at the time of the act, you must acquit him."

Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $240,000 of city of Amsterdam, N. Y., relief and various purpose bonds on a bid of 100.37 for 1.90s. The bonds are dated Feb. 1, 1938, and mature Feb. 1, 1939 to 1948.

For the third straight year the same finalists came through as the Misses Anne Page and Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia eliminated Mrs. William F. Howe Jr. and Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston, respectively, in the semifinals of the women's national squash racquets championship today at the Harvard Club.

The Railway Express Agency, Inc., sold to S. B. Penick Co. of 132 Nassau Street, New York City, the five-story brick stable building and two garages on a plot 255 by 100 feet on the southeast corner of Tenth and Brunswick Streets, Jersey City.

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reversed yesterday a decision made by Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler which held that mortgage certificates held by title companies were subordinate in interest to certificates held by others.
Employers throughout the State were reminded today that information returns on wages and salaries paid to employes during 1937 must be filed with the Income Tax Bureau by Tuesday.

With the exception of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, the Boston Wool Exchange and certain livestock markets, all security and commodity Exchanges in the United States will be closed today in commemoration of Lincoln's Birthday.

Edward .E. (Doc) Ebling, trainer of the Philadelphia Athletics for twenty-three years, died today after an illness of several months.. His age was 63. Mr. Ebling, a native of Tyrone, Pa., joined the Athletics in 1915. Scores of players on other teams came to him for advice.

A 10-point spurt early in the second half proved the deciding factor as Long Island University's basketball team defeated Fordham last night at the loser's gym, 47--30, in the first meeting between the two universities on the court.
Rumania's new dictatorsnlp-now openly avowed-lost no time in getting into its stride with measures of absolutism.

New "frontiers" to conquer in this country have not disappeared, they have merely changed their form, Dr. James Shelby Thomas, president of the Chrysler Institute of Engineering, told the Advertising and Marketing Forum at the Advertising Club yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia dedicated a new $5,000 ambulance yesterday to Knickerbocker. Hospital in a ceremony at City Hall. Funds for the new vehicle were provided by am anonymous donor.

College newspapers as members of the Metropolitan College Newspaper Association will feature a joint editorial and questionnaire on the subject of social hygiene in their initial issues for the new Spring semester. next week,. it was announced yesterday by Bernard Rothenberg, executive secretary of the association.

Bonds continued to move forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange but the trading pace was quieter. The market, too, lacked the buoyancy of the preceding day, and this was particularly apparent among the railroad issues.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold to the Vilou Realty Corporation the four-story apartment house at 951-3 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, Westchester, through Eugene J. Busher Co., Inc., broker. There are two stores and seventeen apartments of three and four rooms in the building, which stands on a plot 50 by 100 feet.
All leading foreign currencies rose sharply yesterday in relation to the dollar in fairly active-trading here in the foreign exchange market. The spirited advance,

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division canceled yesterday a ten-day jail sentence. and a $250 fine imposed on Miss Lucile Pugh, woman attorney, for alleged contempt of court by Municipal Court Justice Keyes Winter.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls to defeated the New York Rovers, 4 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League battle tonight. Babe Tapin, Bill Cairns, Bill Davies and Gordie Wait tallied for the winners. Rimstad scored for the New Yorkers.
Cotton - mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 88.7 from 86.7. The figure was 138.4 for the week ended Feb. 6, 1937.

Princeton's mermen took every first place against Dartmouth today to defeat the Green, 49-26, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet. The victors broke four Dartmouth pool records as well as a Princeton mark.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente denied yesterday defense motions made to dismiss a $10,506,090 suit brought by the trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) against Edward N. Brown, former chairman of its board of directors, Speyer Co. and J. W. Seligman Co., investment bankers.

Borrowing 12,500,000 Chinese dollars from three Japanese banks, the provisional government of North China today paid for its half of the shares of the new Federal Reserve Bank. The bank's capital was fixed at 50,000,000 dollars, half being subscribed by the government and half by Chinese banks.

90th St. 171 E, 4-story stone tenement, 27.6x100, parcel 1; also 90th St, 173 E, 4-story stone tenement. 27. 6x100, parcel 2, Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against James F. Fay, dus, on parcel 1, $24,447, taxes, etc, $82; on parcel 2, $25,771. taxes, etc, $82; to plaintiff for $1,000 each.

Freddie Bartholomew, the 14-year-old film actor, sent his attorneys to Superior Judge E. Clement Nye's court today to plead for exemption from payment of 10 per cent of his $100,000 yearly salary to his father, Cecil Llewellyn Bartholomew.
President Roosevelt held his semi-weekly press conference today, but during the half hour of interrogation he was unusually reticent and refused to discuss business trends or foreign affairs.

Yale's varsity polo team, preparing for next month's intercollegiate tournament, will make its first appearance of the season in New York tonight when the Elis face Winston Guest's Optimists in one of the games at Squadron A Armory.

LUIS QUINTANILLA, the illustrious Spanish artist, once said that El Greco obviously copied Cezanne when he painted the sky over his famous -view of Toledo. It's up at the Metropolitan. Look at it, and you'll see that Quintanilla is right. In a fine new book of pictures called "Art Without Epoch"* you can see the same timeless resemblances between the men of the past and the men of the present.
Miss Catherine De St. Phalle, daughter of Mrs. Francois De St. Phalle of this city, was married to E. Eldridge Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erskine M. Smith of Old Orchard, Haverford, this afternoon.

The Edison Tower.at.Menlo Park, N. J., was dedicated at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor yesterday, the ninety-first anniversary of the 'inventor's birth. At 12:30 P. M. the donor of the $100,000 structure closed a switch that lighted the giant bulb atop the memorial thirty miles away.

J. Richard Davis, who was counsel to the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gang, appeared in Supreme Court before Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday in behalf of the only client his disbarment last November left him-himself.

Both the Foreign Office and the Propaganda Ministry today took formal notice of yesterday's rumors abroad regarding the internal situation in Germany. It was categorically denied in both quarters that there had been disorders or disturbances of a civilian or military nature anywhere in Germany.

James A. Ten Eyck, Syracuse University rowing coach, died today after a three-week illness following a heart attack. He was 86 years old. Mrs. Ten Eyck was at the hospital bedside when the veteran coach died at about 6 A. M.

Unsettling rumors of dissension in Germany kept business down to small proportions at the opening of the stock markets here today, but a little more interest was taken in several sections toward the close. Giltedge issues were slightly stimulated by the success of another municipal corporation .loan, but the foreign market was idle, with German bonds lower.

Charles Fletcher Ayers, one of New Jersey's oldest police chiefs and president of the Sussex County Octogenarian Club, died last night at his home here after a brief illness. He was 86 years old, but remained active in his police duties until a few days ago.

Constantine V. Riccardi, 50 years old, who was disbarred as a lawyer in California in 1921 on conviction and sentence to one to ten years in State prison as an embezzler, was sentenced by General Sessions Judge Streit yesterday to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing.

The crew of the Orizaba, passenger aid freight-ship operated by the New York Cuba Mail Steamship Company, staged a sit-down strike yesterday afternoon, an hour before the vessel was scheduled to sail for Cuba and Mexico.

The proposed increase of rates by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was opposed yesterday at a public hearing before Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee. Several witnesses declared that the higher rates would be beyond the means of many consumers, including a large number now on relief.

Liquidation of the affairs of the Manufacturers Credit Union, New York City, has been completed and the corporate existence of the union terminated, the State Banking Department's weekly bulletin announced today.

Indictments charging income-tax evasion were returned today against Don A. Jones, formerly assistant deputy governor of the Federal- Reserve Bank of Chicago, and John H. Rumbaugh, formerly second vice president of the Continental Illinois t National Bank and Trust Company and now a resident of New York.

This Winter's weather, so far, has been rankly unfair and would not be tolerated for a moment in a truly civilized country. Parts of the Central and Lower Mississippi Valley have had as much as four times the normal amount of rain and snow, according to Mr. J. B. Kincer, official recorder for the Weather Bureau.

The House of Commons was told today that the judicial housecleaning amongGreat Britain's justices of the peace had begun to bear fruit. The Attorney General reported 365 resignations had been turned in by aged, infirm or absentee justices.
O. Max Gardner, friend of President Roosevelt and former Governor of North Carolina, has requested the New York Stock Exchange not to consider him for its office of paid president.

Security and commodity markets were subdued yesterday on the eve of the holiday. The stock market moved narrowly and closed irregularly lower. The turnover on the Stock Exchange of 387,000 shares was the smallest for a full day since Feb. 13, 1935, and compared with Thursday's total of 631,000.

Leaflets calling- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek a "beaten wolf" and declaring that he is "at the end of his rope" were dropped from about twenty Japanese planes which .raided Wuchang, across the Yangtze River from Hankow, this afternoon.

The British Amateur Athletic Association today launched a boycott against holding the 1940 Olympic Games in Tokyo, but there was no indication the movement would draw much support from other European countries.
George P. Beatty, clerk in local office of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, notified the Nassau County police this evening that the office had been robbed of $312 by a lone bandit at closing time.

The arrival of the German training vessel Schlesien in the Bay of Valparaiso on a courtesy visit marked the start today of a series of public ceremonies. Commander Eleischer of the Schlesien issued a statement today that said:

John Lowry, Inc., has been awarded the contract for the construction of two additional stories on the building at 28-30 Waverly Place by New York University, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. William S. Gregory, architect, prepared the plans for the work, which is estimated to cost about $200,000.

Sheldon M. Stewart of Montclair, N. J., yesterday received one of the greatest thrills that can come to a breeder of dogs. At the second day of the sixty-second annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden his home-bred airedale terrier dog champion Shelterock Modest Smasher was named best of breed.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted a request by counsel for W. E. Hutton Co. and others, charged with manipulation of stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation on the New York Stock Exchange, to reopen the hearing in order to provide an opportunity "to adduce evidence correcting testimony heretofore given."
In honor of the memory of Maurice Ravel the program offered by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, in Carnegie Hall last night was largely devoted to selections by that composer.

Fireman 1st grade Martin H. Kerins of H. L. Co. 49 died Feb. 11. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 1.370 Merriam Ave., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, Feb. 14. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Announcement that the first national mortgage association had been organized under the terms of the amended FHA program provided at least a partial answer to the question, often heard within the past few weeks, of where the money would come from to finance residential building under the easy mortgage terms of the new FHA regulations.

Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee formally ratified today two mitigating amendments to the "third basket" section of the new tax bill, but still lacked one vote of a majority necessary to insure adoption of the provision by the full committee.
Although arbitrators to settle the final details of the waterfront strike settlement have not been appointed, work has resumed on all docks today and a half-doen ships were discharging cargo.
Three creditors petitioned in the Federal court today to reorganize the Grand National Films, Inc., and its subsidiary, brand National Studios, Inc., under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today the award to the highest bidders of forty-six of fiftyfour bond issues of municipalities, counties and districts, including an issue of $1,203,000 of rapid transit subway serial bonds of New. York City, on which bids were received yesterday. A list of the securities and the highest bids was published in THE NEW YORK TIMEs this morning.

The Cunard White Star liner Samaria will sail today for Cobh and Liverpool, carrying Mr. and Mrs. Frank-G. O'Connor, R. G. Blackie, Mr. and Mrs. P. Obregon, Lieutenant Desmond-Vincent-Jones, Mr.. and Mrs. E. F. Osler, Albert P.

Flood waters spread steadily across California lowlands tonight as streams began pouring over their banks the excess run-off from a record-breaking sixteen-day rain, while the storm continued with renewed vigor.
George F. Getz, Chicago coal operator and former treasurer of the Republican National Committee, died of a sudden heart attack today. His age was 72.

In an effort to correct the frequent misplacing of volunteer workers in social service the Brooklyn Junior League has organized a Central Volunteer Bureau to place volunteers according to their special abilities and interests.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt were the honor guests tonight of Vice President and Mrs. Garner, who gave a dinner for them at the Washington Hotel, followed by a program of entertainment presented 'by Gene Buck.

A resolution which would order the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the relations between automobile manufacturers and dealers in relation to the anti-trust laws was approved today by the House Interstate Commerce Committee, which voted to report the resolution favorably on Monday.

Captan J. E. Lewis, skipper of the American tanker Nantucket Chief, said tonight he was beaten with a rubber hose every day of the sixteen days he and his crew were held prisoners by Spanish Insurgents at Palma, Majorca.

New bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to taxexempt securities. An offering of $33,688,000 of State of Mississippi highway bonds lifted the total to 10 $49,248,000, as compared with $70,257,262 last week.

Northern Ireland has been blessed with Lord Craigavon's Government for seventeen years. Wednesday's blareand-scare election of members of the House of Commons, returns from which are complete except in the case of the four members for Queen's University, insures the continuance of those blessings for five years.

An important life-size French Renaissance statue, believed to be of Diane de Poitiers, has been acquired by the Worcester Art Museum, Worcester, Mass., from Jacques Seligmann Co., Inc., 3 East Fifty-first Street.

Elementary school children classified as slow learners made "astonishing" gains in their school work through the use of an activity project which substituted motion pictures, original dances, cooking and excursions for the conventional textbook and class room, the Board of Education disclosed yesterday.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs and fresh pork cuts was fair to good, other classes only fair to slow. Steer beef and fresh pork cuts were steady to slightly higher, veal weak to lover, other classes mostly unchanged.

The four-story garage at 349 Canal Street and 6 to 10 Wooster Street has been sold byIsaac Cohen, trustee, to the Inter-City Garage, Inc. It fronts 25 feet on Canal Street and 75 feet on the east side of Wooster Street and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $132,500. Walter J. Dickerson was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $170,000.

The sixth annual Charity Ball of the Junior Auxiliary of the Paterson General Hospital was held tonight at the Swiss Chalet in Rochelle Park. Proceeds from the benefit will be used to continue the work of the auxiliary in the hospital.
