Specific 1939 budget estimates calling for the expenditures of $16,880,000 for the army on the basis of President Roosevelt's national defense message were made public at the White House today.

Major Gen. William C. Rivers, retired, who commanded the Philippine Constabulary for eleven years, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that the Filipinos would revolt if Presidents Manuel Quezon "persuades the United States to hold the Philippines."
Increased earnings last year over 1936 were reported yesterday in the annual report of the American Can Company and its subsidiaries, submitted by Dr. H. A. Baker, president.

Stocks drifted listlessly and closed irregularly lower in dullest trading in three years; turnover, 387,210 shares. All groups of bonds continued steadier and generally higher; transactions, $6,340,125.

Henry Holt, who published the American edition of Romain Rolland's "Jean Christophe," will bring out in March another monumental work by a French author. The book is "The Pasquier Chronicles," written by George Duhamel E and translated by Beatrice de Holteur.

Walter S. Cate, United States Court Commissioner at Ashland for twenty-five years and widely known attorney, died last night at his home after a brief illness. He had been a member of the Wisconsin bar since 1899 and served as Ashland City Attorney and President of the City Council.

A four-day festival of American music, presenting native compositions from "the time of. George Washington to the present" will be held by the Federal Music Project at the Federal Music Theatre in the evenings of next Friday, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.
Robert Grant 3d of New York, national and Canadian amateur racquets champion and recent winner of the open tournament for the Clarence Pell Cup, began the defense of the Tuxedo Gold Racquet tonight.

Miss Ruth Mead Tompkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Tompkins of Hastings, was married this evening'to Ralph Albert Bankes of Riverhead, L. I., son of Mrs. James Prentice Bankes of Philadelphia, in the Dobbs Ferry Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. David 0. Kendall, the rector, officiated. The ceremony was followed by a reception at Abbey Inn, Yonkers.-,'.

Newly married King Farouk and Queen Farida spent the monarch's eighteenth birthday today. meeting thousands of persons from morning to night. Farouk started his day by receiving 2,000 guests at a levee.

Miss Betty Zeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Zeller of this place, has chosen the evening of April 8 for her wedding to John Hunter Gage of Glen Ridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Raymond Gage of Winchester, Mass. The ceremony will be followed by a reception at the Glen Ridge Country Club.
The marriage of Miss Leonie M. Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. 'Samuel Parmelee Williams Jr. of this city, to John Ogden White, also of Waterbury, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sage White,

The marriage of Miss d Ruth Bedlow Wilmerding of Dansville, N. Y., and Plainfield, to Harold Joseph Berlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Berlin of North Plainfield, took place this afternoon at St. Joseph's Church, here. The Rev. Michael Lease, assistant pastor, performed the ceremony.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

J. Montgomery Strong died yesterday at the Post-Graduate Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old. Mr. Strong, who figured in New York society in the early years of the century, was the son of Joseph

Edmonds Co. announced yesterday that they had moved their office to 120 Broadway with Josepthal Co. James J. Crawford, State Senator from Brooklyn, and John L. Smith, vice president and manager of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., have been elected to the board of trustees of the Bushwick Savings Bank, Brooklyn.

Ten young New Yorkers received medals last night that marked them the most courteous of the 90,000 children who belong to the Junior, Inspectors Club. The medals were presented by William F. Carey, Commissioner of the Department of Sanitation, which fosters the club.

Miss Reata King Kimball, daughter of Mrs. Donald R. Cragin of this city and the late Frederick Strong Kimball, was married here this afternoon in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church to Jerrems Chamberlain Hart,

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the six months from Aug. 1 to Jan. 31 was 4,322,085 tons, compared with 3,364,155 in the same period a year before. Cottonseed at mills on Jan. 31 was 1,439,194 tons, compared with 880,640.

An unusual conference of government financial authorities, lasting for about two and one-half hours this morning in the office of Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury Department, gave rise to varied speculation as to its purpose. However, at the close, none of those present would discuss what took place.
Mrs. H. Young's Saxopal won his first race in his 1938 campaign today, when he took the feature race for 4-year-olds and up, ever the mile and one-sixteenth distance today, at the Fair Grounds.

President Roosevelt received "the sincere thanks and deep appreciation" today of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York for the contribution he made as its first president, when a Scout representative from each of New York's five boroughs called on him at the White House.

Concern over the effects of the Maloney bill for regulation of the over-the-counter security trading on the market for State and municipal securities is not confined to municipal bond men and municipal officers, but includes the large institutional investors in municipal securities, it was disclosed yesterday.

Minister of Labor Waldemar Falcao explains that the provision in the new Constitution that insurance companies may operate here only if their shareholders are Brazilians refers only to new companies wishing to establish themselves in Brazil.
Mrs. Margaret M. Farmer, In 125 E 63d St; Matthew Darcy, in. 249 E 56th St; Edward Ahern, in 440 W 34th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc. broker.

A delegation from the Workers Alliance received assurance yesterday that $50,000 from other sections of the City Department of Welfare budget would be made available this month to meet the clothing needs of home relief recipients.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

In an expansion move, Oldtyme Distillers Corporation has renewed its lease for the entire forty-fifth floor of the Chanin Building, at 128 I East Forty-second Street, and has taken in addition nearly three-quarters of the forty-third floor, Chanin Management, Inc., announced yesterday.

Substitution of Margaret Sullavan for Irene Dunne in "A Letter of Introduction" at Universal, a vehicle designed for Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, has left Miss Dunne free to go to Columbia for one picture.

The field of 200 players that started play in the third annual Eastern badminton tournament was cut considerably as the men's and women's singles and doubles reached the quarter-final round last night on the courts of the Old 69th Regiment Armory.

Frederick C. Gilimore, City Treasurer of Utica and holder of offices in Oneida County for more than-forty years, died today of coronary embolism at the age of 64. He had been Mayor of the city three times and Sheriff of Oneida County. He was born here Feb.

Ferdinand Lundberg, author of the book "America's Sixty Families," insisted yesterday that the heirs of Mark Hanna are proprietors of The Cleveland Plain Dealer in a letter to Editor and Publisher, the newspaper trade journal, replying to the second letter of Carr V. Van Anda, former managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES,

A bill to amend the labor provisions- of the Merchant Marine Act to provide for mediation of disputes by a Presidential board and put safeguards around employer-employe relationships in the interests of safety at sea,
A brilliant English quartet tonight closed the 1938 British Empire Games swimming championships, claiming for Great Britain two more titles to add to four won earlier in the games.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended the scope of its study of investment trusts to cover the question of the investment counsel. At a public hearing,
Four of Harvey S. Firestone's favorite songs, several prayers and two psalms comprised a thirty-minute funeral service today for the man who molded a world-wide tire empire.

THE AFFAIRS OF MAUPASSANT, suggested by the diary of Marie Bashkirtseff; scenario by Felix Joachimson; music by Offenbach; additional music and lyrics by Paul Abraham and Fritz Rotter; directed by Henry Koster; produced by Panta Films of Vienna; distributed by Gallic Films,. Inc.. At- the Fifty-fifth Street. Playhouse.

Elmer E. Johnson, 78-year-old retired educator, of Middletown, N. Y., was arrested at his home at 2 o'clock this morning on a charge of attempting to blackmail Arthur W. Eames, headmaster and owner of the Suffern Academy for Boys at Suffern.

The opening gun in what is expected to be one of the stormiest debates of the present session of the Canadian Parliament was fired by Prime Minister Kin today when he introduced a bill to provide for the transfer from his government to Parliament as a whole of control over the issue of licenses for the export of Canadian electric power to the United States.

Mrs. Marion T. Cluett, divorced in Reno for a second time from George B. Cluett 2d, official of Cluett, Peabody Co., of Troy, N. Y., was married shortly after noon today to Cadwallader W. Kelsey of Troy, who is engaged in the farm machinery business there.

President Roosevelt displayed an unusual reluctance to answer questions at his press conference. He received a delegation of Boy Scouts, who thanked him for his services as head of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.
A dispatch from Rio de Janeiro to THE TIEMS last Thursday incorrectly reported that the French liner Normandie would visit Rio de. Janeiro from France.

J. Howard -Cowperthwait, who was for more than fifty years senior partner in Cowperthwait Sons, furniture firm, died yesterday at his home at 975 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was in his ninetieth year.

Cases involving police killings moved with unusual speed through the courts here yesterday. Exactly two weeks after Police Sergeant David Kilpatrick was killed in a Bronx pawnshop, a jury of seven women and five men in the Bronx County Court returned last night a verdict of guilty of first-degree murder against George De Renna.

In response to complaints from trade unions that thousands of workers in this State were suffering through the failure of employers to observe the State Unemployment Insurance Law, two State departments announced yesterday their determination to stamp out such abuses.

" Continued opposition" of county welfare bureaus, Lester W. Herzog, upState New York WPA Administrator; charged today, has hampered the WPA in reducing its rolls, "loaded with person's who in no sense could be termed employable."

William Joseph Halleran, uncle of Borough Works Commissioner John s J. Halleran, died yesterday at the home of his niece, Miss Mary Campbell Curran, 153-38 Forty-first Avenue, Flushing, less than a week after-the death of his brother, Cornelius. His age was 89.

Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progress Administrator, told a Ways and Means Subcommittee today that the 250,000,000 added relief appropriaion requested by President Roosevelt meant a difference in relief benefits affecting some 950,000 of he unemployed.
Lower cables from Liverpool and preholiday evening-up resulted in a lower level of wheat prices today. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

Operations on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday were of a pre-holiday character and reflected a disposition on the part of most traders to even up obligations rather than embark upon new ventures. As a result. the market held within a narrow range and ended with gains of 2 to 6 points.

A radio message received here today from Scoresby Sound stresses the necessity of beginning immediateroperations for the rescue of the Russian Arctic expedition. Members of the Greenland Board sent the message to the Soviet Charge d'Affaires, Frederic Linde, who, however, requested them to await Moscow's approval.

It is understood that Bruno Mussolini, eldest son of Premier Benito Mussolini, shortly after his return from South America will announce his ,, engagement. The wedding will likely be held in May. His fiancee is Gina Ruberti, whose father is an engineer.
A community of small homes constructed of steel will rise on the farmlands near the giant Irvin works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation at Clairton, Pa., under plans disclosed today.

Interest in color reproductions seems steadily to increase and prints now available cover a very wide range. Quality is not of uniform excellence, but when a reproduction seems not altogether satisfactory it is often possible to trace the cause back to the original painting.

The Senate voted down, 48 to 31, an attempt today to send the Crop Control Bill back to conference, and later consented to vote on the measure not later than 3:30 P. M. Monday. With this limitation on debate, the Senate recessed until noon Monday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Secretary of State Hull's denial that an agreement exists or is contemplated with Great Britain relating to war, or the possibility of war, or that there is any understanding, expressed or implied, for the use of the American Navy in conjunction with the fleet of any other nation, could not have been intended to cover this hemisphere.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Renwick Kerr, who had been visiting Mrs. Orin B. Mitcham at the Beekman, sailed yesterday on the Saturnia for Rome, where they will be joined by their daughter, Miss Ida Kerr, who has been staying with friends in Austria.

After holding sessions each Sunday at 9:30 A. M. for more than forty years, the Men's Bible Class of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which John D. Rockefeller Jr. is honorary president, will hold its weekly meeting on Tuesday evenings at 7:30 o'clock, beginning next week.

A definite plan, designed to meet the inroads of Fascist propaganda in South America and at the same time to increase generally the goodwill among those nations toward the United States, is expected to grow out of negotiations now in progress between private and civic interests and the government.

Recommendations made to Governor Lehman by the corporation counsels of six cities in the State that in future appeals for the reduction of assessments taxpayers be required to prove inequalities in assessments as well as overvaluation, are attacked in a letter sent to the Governor by the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease for December of 3.4 per cent from the same month of 1936 and a decrease of 3.6 per cent from November, 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today.
John L. Lewis, chairman of the commit

The marriage of Miss Janet Gordon Keidel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Keidel, to John Henry Lewin, son of Mrs. Frank Park Lewin of Parkton' and the late' Mr. Lewin, took place at the home of her parents at Greenway, Guilford, this afternoon.

The St. Francis College baseketball team turned back Lincoln University, 44 to 23, at the St. Peter Claver Auditorium in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 2,000 attended the contest, which was played for the benefit of the Colored Orphan Children's Fund.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,184,000 bales, against 1,146,000 a week ago, 1,127,000 two weeks ago, 1,141,000 three weeks ago and 906,000 a year ago; of which American 787,000 bales, against 139,000 a week ago, 722,000 two weeks ago, 726,000 three weeks ago and 399,000 a year ago.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, "reluctantly" resigned today from the United Mine Workers of America, terminating his membership of more than forty-five years.

Following the unanimous ratification by manufacturers of the new labor pact in the millinery industry, two settlement committees will begin work on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union.

The parents of Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, on trial here with Genevieve Owens on a charge of slaying William Barhorst in a Belleville hold-up, testified today that they asked Joseph Cocozza, acting captain of Essex County detectives, a few weeks before the slaying to have their daughter examined for her sanity.

The country will call on the Republican party "in the near future to solve the same problems that faced Abraham Lincoln,- the founder of the party, to unite it and lead it to a more abundant life;" Representative Bruce Barton declared last night in an address at the annual Lincoln's Birthday ball of the Fifth Assembly District Kings County Republican Club at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. About 4,200 persons attended.
The day after tomorrow is St. Valentine's Day and anything is liable to happen. A sweet-voiced stranger may call you up, for instance, and without preliminaries start singing to you:

The Empire Housing Corporation, of which Reuben Horowitz is president, has resold the four-story apartment building at 446 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, which it recently purchased from the Belmont Engineering Corporation, to Marl-Roy Associates, Inc, The house is on the corner of Caton Avenue, and the buyer paid cash above a. mortgage of $263,500 held by the Bowery Savings Bank.

The closed shop issue reached the Supreme Court today when six New Yorkers filed a petition demanding review of a New York Court of Appeals decision upholding a contract whereby employes of the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and three subsidiaries must join the Transport Workers of America within thrty. days or quit work.

Retail sales this week, hindered by spreading unemployment, payroll shrinkage and unseasonable weather, dropped to from even to 3 per cent under volume of the same week last year, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The newspaper Telegrafo says the United States State Department has informed the Ecuadorean Minister, Colon Eloy Allaro, that it has no intention of intervening in the controversy with the Americanowned South American Development Company over this government's demand for revision of the company's concession.
Defeat of the medalist, long-distance battles and rousing upsets marked the first and second rounds of match play in the $5,000 San Francisco open golf tournament today.

The Rev. Gerard A. Donovan, Catholic missionary, who was kidnapped by bandits from his mission in Hopel, Manchukuo, Oct. 5, is dead, according to a cablegram received today by the Most Rev. James E. Walsh, Superior General of Maryknoll Seminary of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America here.

The Federal court jury sitting in the Graham-McKay swindling case, after deliberating for nine hours and forty-five minutes without reaching a verdict, was ordered locked up in a hotel for the night at 10 o'clock last night by Justice Willis Van Devanter, presiding at the trial.

A shadowy "Mr. Stevens of Moscow" was described today by "Miss X," Britain's counter-espionage heroine, as the link between an undisclosed foreign power and four Britons accused of stealing their nation's arms secrets.

Stewart McGuire, manufacturers of vending machines, have leased the three-story factory building covering the north side of Thirty-fifth Avenue from Thirty-sixth to Thirty-seventh Street, Astoria, Queens.

The painfully slow process of discovering what happened behind the wall of secrecy surrounding the first two days of the Rev. Martin Niemoeler's trial now reveals that the judge accepted three letters from distinguished citizens defending the pastor.

The Fordham swimming team triumphed over New York University at the Park Central -pool yesterday by 39 to 31 in a match that was decided by the relay race. Bill Schirmer of Fordham finished inches in front of his rival in the 400-yard relay after he had won the 220 and 440 free-style events.

ADAIR, RATE (Aug. 13, 1936). Gross assets, $2,199; net, $1,582. To Rose T. Offerman, sister, insurance and mortgage; William Bannon, brother, residue; three specific bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $2,190. George H. Meehan, attorney, 56-50 68th St.. Maspeth. L. I.

Two armed hold-up men lastnight accosted James H. Gilvarry, prominent Brooklyn real estate broker, as he was waiting for his daughter, Peggy, 14 years old, outside the home of James J. Heffernan, Democratic leader of the Twelfth Assembly District, at 65 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

The Cuba Company, a New Jersey Corporation, which controls a railway system with 1,083 miles of line that serves almost exclusively the eastern half of Cuba, filed here yesterday in Federal court a petition for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Questions on whether he subscribed to the Communist anti-religious policy of Russia were addressed yesterday by the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, to Simon W. Gerson, Communist, whose appointment as assistant to the Manhattan Borough President is being fought.

Conservation of wild life was the dominating theme of the first North American Sports, Garden and Outdoor Life Show which opened this afternoon in the Fifth Regiment Armory, converted. into a veritable game refuge.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Due chiefly to the uncertainty created by the proposed British trade treaty, the wool market has slumped further this week. Were it not for this uncertainty, it is believed buying would ensue at present low prices for wool.

Dr. Shirley Carter Fisk entertained at dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Lady Mary Acheson. The other guests were Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Parsons, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Reynolds jr., Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Fisk Jr., Miss Eunice Herrick and Thomas Trowbridge Jr.

The Society of Virginia Women gave a large reception and tea yesterday in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. Louise C. Ball, president of the society, presided and welcomed the guests who included officers and other members of the organization and their friends,

With dramatic suddenness King Carol yesterday resolved Rumania's political crisis by proclaiming himself virtual dictator for a transitional period. The unlamented Goga regime, forced by the King to give way, is succeeded by a Government "of national concentration."

For the third time in thirty years and the first in nine, Wall Street telegraph operators went on strike yesterday. Seventeen telegraph and teletype employes of Harris, Upham Co., brokerage house, were called out by the Eastern brokers' division of the Commercial Telegiraphers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, in protest against a 20 per cent salary cut instituted on Feb. 1.

Witnesses before the City Council committee investigating the residence of Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens testified yesterday that Mr. Quinn leased an apartment in Astoria last December, moved in on Dec. 22 and transferred his milk deliveries there from a previous residence in Brentwood, L. I.

Interests opposing approval of the present plan for reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy. Act occupied most of today's session of the Federal District Court here trying to convince Judge John P. Nields that the plan should not be adopted as filed.

The War Deoartment released the following orders today, dated Feb. 10: COLONELS Keller, F., Cav.., three months and twentyone days' leave, Feb. 10. Miller, T., Cav., Presidio of Monterey, Calif., detailed in the Inspector General's Dept., at headquarters, Governors Island, N. Y., to sail from San Francisco about May 14.

The Newtown High tossers extended their winning streak in the Queens P. S. A. L. race to eleven games and entrenched themselves more firmly in the lead by downing Grover Cleveland High, 32 to 25, on the losers' court yesterday.

Personal Stationery Corporation, 103 East Thirty-second Street, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue representing its work as engraving when such is not the fact, the commission announced today.
One of the painters and sculptors who will present their work to New York's critical public next week is a recent recruit from the ranks of industry, Clark H. Minor.

Abnormally high tides halted four passenger trains on the SydneyHalifax run tonight at the Strait of Canso, where the car ferry Scotia was unable to dock at Point Tupper, on the Cape Breton Island side of the mile-wide channel.

Fur coats were slashed by a party of raiding vandals yesterday morning in advance of the lockout of some 4,000 fur workers, voted by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., as their answer to what the manufacturers described as excessive demands of the Fur Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate.

Hundreds of specific charges by industrial life insurance agents, including "brow-beating" by their managers into "overselling" poor families and paying the premiums on "dead" policies out of their own pockets to avoid discharge, were told at the hearing yesterday of the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law in the State Office Building.

Glenn Cunningham flashed the fastest mile ever run on a local flat board track when he strode majestically to a 4:15.2 victory in the featured event on the program of the Seventh Regiment meet at the old Park Avenue drill shed last night.

The New York University fencing team scored its third straight victory of the season yesterday at the Washington Square gymnasium when it triumphed over Cornell by 161/2 to 101/2. The Violet had previously defeated Purdue and Yale. It was the second defeat for Cornell. which had bowed to Yale.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Randolph, daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Hillas of Byewater, Greenwich, Conn., and of the late Wilson G. Hunt Randolph, to Herman Henry Ridder of St. Paul, son of Mrs. Hilda M. Ridder of this city and Bronxville and of Bernard H. Ridder of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Second annual convention of the American Law Students Association begins at Harkness Theatre, Columbia University, this morning at 10 o'clock and continues tomorrow. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

Residents of the Saugatuck Valley above the site of the proposed Bridgeport Hydraulic Company reservoir dam sued in Superior Court today for an injunction to halt the project and asked $150,000 damages.

With thirty-eight fraternities staging elaborate house parties, more than 2,000 students and their guests from forty States and several foreign countries danced tonight at the fifty-sixth junior prom--the climax of Cornell University's traditional Junior Week.

Stubborn resistance by the Chinese forces yesterday continued to hold up Japanese efforts to advance toward Suchow from the Hwai River along the southern Tientsin-Pukow Railway front in North China, according to reports received here.
Pennsyivania and New York lake shipping interests joined today in protest against the Parsons bill, which would permit increased water diversion from the Great Lakes.

SERGEANTS-John E. Flynn, from 47th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Bronx, for 5 days, from 4 P. M., Feb. 7. William E. Lightcap, from 80th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Kings, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., Feb. 7.

In a joint statement issued yesterday the International Silk Guild, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, the American Federaticn of Hosiery Workers and the Ourene Association denied "that these organizations or any of them are cooperating with the Japanese Chamber of Commerce of New I York in a campaign- to combat a boycott of Japanese goods."

A disturbance started by 600 inmates of the State reformatory in protest against food served at the institution and recent Parole Board rulings was quelled tonight by reformatory guards and State troopers.
The last two sections of the 19.7acre recreation center on the site of the old Williamsbridge Reservoir, 208th Street and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, will be opened today.

To commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of constitutional government Emperor Hirohito granted today a wide amnesty, by which scores of thousands of prisoners, including young officers implicated in the 1936 mutiny, benefited through a reduction of their sentences, but Communists did not share in the amnesty.
Despite the threat of the first snowless Dartmouth Winter-carnival in the twenty-eight years of its existence a record gathering of 1,300 young women were in Hanover today as guests of students.

William Green warned both labor and capital against the "fettering of freedom" in a vigorous speech here tonight. They have "a common cause to protect against autocratic usurpation of power over their destiny by governmental agency," he declared at the Founders Day banquet of the University of Wisconsin Alumni Association.

Although the Legislature has handled its comparatively light program with little difficulty to date, it has become apparent that several of the major items on Governor Lehman's program are to undergo serious scrutiny and face a barrage of amendments, before the session comes to an end.

The second in a series of dinners which J. Frederick Talcott is giving this season at the National Arts Club was held last night. The guests were members of various committees of the club, who are active in the expansion of the permanent art interests of the organization.

The simple kitchen of the German Evangelical Lutheran Church, 53 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, was the scene yesterday morning of an exciting experiment as two blind women made use of the first Braille cook book 'transcribed by volunteers of the Brooklyn Red Cross.

United Air Lines announced today through Harold Crary, vice president in charge of traffic, plans for expansion of sales and advertising departments and appointment of several men to newly created executive positions.

Not so long ago Kip Farrington, in a radio talk, expressed the belief that giant tuna increased in weight the farther north they went on their Summer migration. He expressed the belief that the 500-pounders caught in the Gulf Stream off Bimini in June were the 700-pounders taken off Nova Scotia in August.
An unidentified burglar, about 30 years old, was shot and killed tonight by a policeman as he fled from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Whitman of 184 William Street here.
Pelham Bay Park, n w cor Park Lane, 175x 170 x irreg; Connecticut Mutual Life Ins Co against Evelyn Randall; due, $34,871; taxes, etc, $50; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Affiliation of Maison Lew, large European buying and export organization, with the resident buying Office of Irving Yahr Co., Inc., 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, which specializes in the ready-to-wear and accessory buying fields, was announced yesterday.

After three days of secrecy the Junkers works announced today the crash of the Great Dessau plane, the pride of Germany's new commercial aviation fleet. The company admitted that Edward Harnemann, testing engineer, was killed. The others in the plane escaped with their parachutes.

Grand Central Terminal for a period last night was overrun with gayly clad Winter sports enthusiasts as an estimated throng of 1,400 skiers, intent upon spending the holiday week-end running where snow could be found in the North country, departed on snow trains.

The Soviet Union has refused to increase its aid to China, according to reliable information, because of fear of becoming involved directly in the war with Japan. Wellinformed foreign sources said Moscow had taken the stand that it was not in a position to take the risk alone.

Jim McGovern's long field goal with twenty seconds left to play enabled Fordham Prep to gain a 23-to-21 decision over St. Peter's Prep tonight to capture the fourth annual Metropolitan Jesuit School basketball tournament before a capacity crowd of 1,000 fans.

Eighty-seven plans for industrial buildings in the State outside New York City representing an investment of $786,085 were submitted last month to the State Department of Labor. The total was 60 per cent

Responsive to demands for a statement in language so plain as to be impossible of misconstruction, Chairman Carl Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee announced today that the $800,000,000 naval bill would state exactly the "fundamental naval policy of the United States."

THE drop in temperature found Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, secretary of the Giants, taking a musical tip from Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. He was whistlingat his work. He was opening the mail, slitting envelopes out of which fell no signed contracts of Giant ball players.
Six more persons indicted in connection with what the government terms "the biggest organized lottery syndicate in the- East" pleaded guilty in Federal court today.

Mr. and Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes, who leave tomorrow for Puerto Rico and Venezuela after several weeks at Brazilian Court, gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Myron C. Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. Newell W. Tilton, Colonel and Mrs. Latham R. Reed. Mrs. Benjaminn Rogers,
Four months have passed since President Roosevelt discussed large questions of foreign policy in his Chicago speech, and some of the phrases he then used resound today in the debates in Congress.

Dr. Bruce M. Bigelow, director of admissions of Brown University, said today that boys usually show greater intelligence than their parents in arranging for admission to college and in planning their program of study.

The people of this country are in default to Lake Placid for one-half of an international entertainment debt of $350,000. The taxpayers of this little community carry the burden, amounting to $28,000 a year.

Formation of a "Wine and Spirits Academy," at which salesmen and others in the liquor industry will be given a thorough grounding in the fine points of both domestic and imported wines and liquors, was announced here yesterday by Jack H. Truehaft, managing editor of Beverage Retailer Weekly, trade publication. Domestic distillers and importers are backing the project, he said.

The fight for enactment of Federal anti-lynching legislation will continue regardless of what happens to the Wagner-Van Nuys bill now before the Senate, Charles H. Houston, special counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told an audience of -2,500 persons -last night at the Mother. African Methodist Zion Church, 152 West 137th Street.

Eighty-six employes of the International Nickel Company, Inc., who have served for twenty-five years or more, were made members of the company's Quarter Century Club at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.
Dan Martella, the favorite, from Wilmington, Del., and Lester Cummings of New York today advanced to the semi-finals in the national professional squash racquets championships.

The Ford Motor Company filed with the Regional \Labor Relations Board here today a denial that it had been guilty of unfair labor practices, and contended that the National Labor Relations Act was "void, unconstitutional and without force."

Eighty-seven plans for industrial buildings in the State outside New York City representing an investment of $786,085 were submitted last month to the State Department of Labor. The total was 60 per cent

Responsive to demands for a statement in language so plain as to be impossible of misconstruction, Chairman Carl Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee announced today that the $800,000,000 naval bill would state exactly the "fundamental naval policy of the United States."
