Houston, special counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told an audience of -2,500 persons -last night at the Mother. African Methodist Zion Church, 152 West 137th Street.

Eighty-six employes of the International Nickel Company, Inc., who have served for twenty-five years or more, were made members of the company's Quarter Century Club at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.
Dan Martella, the favorite, from Wilmington, Del., and Lester Cummings of New York today advanced to the semi-finals in the national professional squash racquets championships.

The Ford Motor Company filed with the Regional \Labor Relations Board here today a denial that it had been guilty of unfair labor practices, and contended that the National Labor Relations Act was "void, unconstitutional and without force."
Following are the texts of the letter of Secretary of State Cordell Hul to Representative Louis Ludlow and of Mr. Ludlow's letter, to which it is a reply:

The United States Department of Agriculture reported today that the slight increase in demand for wool on the market here last week showed some further expansion this week, but activity, on the whole, continued on an exceedingly moderate scale.
Last survivor of a group of famous friends, Henry Ford paid tribute today to the late Harvey S. Firestone, "his honesty, his industry and his insistence on quality."

More than 30,000 experiments conducted for two years have convinced Dr. Eugene Adams, Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Colgate University, that extra-sensory perception cannot be established and that telepathy and clairvoyance are not scientific facts.

Rallying in the second half, the Yale basketball team defeated Harvard tonight, 35-33, in an exciting Eastern Intercollegiate League game before 2,300 spectators. The visitors from Cambridge took the lead soon after the' start and maintained it at the end of the first half, when the score was 15-14.

As a result of the revival of Title I of the National Housing Act, permitting FHA insurance of modernization loans, the Long Island National Home show will display the latest types of equipment and materials that may be used in the modernization of old houses and
THE Fifth International Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Pictorial Photographers of America, will be held at the American Museum of Natural History from April 13 to April 28.
Vic Ronchetti, Chicago's blond streak on the ice, won three first plates today virtually to assure himself of the North American speed skating title.
STUDENTS of the life of Abraham Lincoln have long been troubled by the knowledge that there existed a large collection of source

The Long Island University basketball team gained its second victory in two nights when it crushed Earlham College from Richmond, Ind., at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night, 72 to 38.

THE man President Roosevelt bas chosen to be Uncle Sam's chief advocate is a lawyer without a degree. But at 46 Robert Houghwout Jackson ranks high in his profession. Circumstances forced him to get most of his education in the school of hard knocks. but what he failed to get in formal schooling has been more than made up by selfeducation.

IN a season as active as this one, it is perhaps inevitable that an occasional event of genuine significance should be overlooked, especially if it happens to take place somewhere off the beaten track of the Broadway recitalists.

Japan has been asked to give a simple promise that she will not, without disclosing her intention, build battleships over 35,000 tons during the next five years. Her refusal means not only another rise in income tax of the Japanese but evervbody else.

What, it may be asked, is Russia doing to protect her own interests in China at a time when the Japanese have joined Chancellor Hitler's anti-Communist pact and appear to be deliberately trampling upon all foreign interests indiscriminately?
Finland's new rearmament program, which is seen as a necessity here because of Russia's growing military preparations, is ready for submission to the Diet.
The Russians have shown that they have a flair for the dramatic in polar exploration as well as the courage to attempt the unusual.

Announcement of a gift of $50,000 to the College of William and Mary has been made by John Stewart Bryan, president of the college. The name of the donor has been kept secret and the gift was made through Admiral Cary T. Grayson of Washington.

Florida's proposed 200-mile cross-State canal, dormant and not even discussed since three Federal allocations totaling $5,400,000 were spent on it, is back in the public mind because Senator Claude Pepper, seeking re-election against former Governor Dave Sholtz and Representative Mark Wilcox, has announced that he is in favor of completing the project, which would cost about $200,000,000.
Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, forecast today that 'the international gold standard would return some day in the form of a gold bullion standard.

The Socialist party disclosed yesterday that Dr. Harry W. Laidler, State chairman, had sent a letter to the board of directors of the World's Fair Corporation protesting against the projected military display at the exposition opening.
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today that foreign countries had experienced indifferent success with restrictive farm-production measures.
The Realty Board of New York has just added twenty-one new members. These included the Continental Realty Investing Company, which has joined the owners' division.
ALL that Sheldon Garrett asks of Scotland Yard is that it shall find out who isplotting to commit what crime against whom and to see to it that the plot comes to naught.

THE spectacular success of the Japanese Army, aided by naval bombing planes, in capturing Nanking, China's former national capital, and seven provincial capitals within a period of five months has started many conjectures that Japan will soon be able to overrun and finally absorb China into the Japanese Empire.
ALWAYS the dutiful mouth piece for the opinions of our constituents (they numbered three at the last count), we see that the time has come for another huff and puff against the double feature.

Molecular distillation, a new and powerful process by which perishable substances of high boiling points are separated, has made possible the large-scale production of Vitamin A concentrates, Dr. K. C. D. Hickman of the Eastman Kodak Company told chemical engineers today.

ROOSTY--Tomorrow evening at the Lyceum Theatre. A play by Martin Berkeley, with William Harrigan, Katherine Emery, Russell Hardie, Mary Morris, James McCallion, Tucker McGuire, Zamah Cunningham, Harold Johnsrud, William Fay, Abner Biberman and Ernest Woodward in the cast.

Three days after the chronological "first day of Spring" an elaborate and seasonal fashion show will be staged in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Generosity Thrift Shop.

Al Davis, Brooklyn lightweight, scored his fourteenth consecutive knockout victory last night when he stopped Georgie Karkella, also of Brooklyn, in 1 minute 14 seconds of the fourth round in the scheduled eight-round feature at Ridgewood Grove before a capacity crowd of 4,500.

Government intervention, like a plant, an animal or an institution, passes through a series of definite stages and acquires a life and momentum of its own. A form of Government control imposed in an emergency, and designed solel to meet that emergency,

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, describing himself as a "conservative," defended yesterday his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, to the post of Assistant to the Borough President as "based on sound Democratic traditions."

Elizabeth Smith Friedman has done it again. Headlines in last week's papers announcing that she had "cracked" a case in Vancouver, B. C., that had been worrying the Canadian police for fifteen years brought into deserved prominence-not for the first time-the first and only woman who is serving her country as an expert cryptanalyst in the Treasury DeDartment at Washington.

A well-equipped work shop designed to provide the opportunity for students to pursue hobbies in which they find pleasure and relaxation has been opened recently at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The shop is sponsored by the institute but virtually managed by the students themselves.

The United States Field Hockey Association, at its annual meeting recently in New York, announced plans for a three-month tour of Australia to return the visit the Australian players made to this country for the 1936 International Federation tournament.

When it comes to a matter of "light tackle," Miss Frances Weir of Steubenville, Ohio, certainly showed up the husky "heavy tackle" boys recently when-she boated a 450-pound marlin on a 16-ounce rod and a 24-thread line.

Miss Cornelia Durant Robbins wore a gown of the style popular among brides in 1871 at her marriage here this afternoon to Russ Van Vleck Bradley. The ceremony, which took place in the First Congregational Church, was performed by the Rev. Dr. Horace Dutton Taft, headmastter of the -Taft School in. Watertown, Conn., and the Rev. John Gratton, pastor of the church.
A CRITICAL audience is the best assurance of continuously improving radio programs, Commander T. A. M. Craven, member of the FCC, asserted in a recent broadcast over the CBS network.

LONDON. SIX of the biggest Spring fairs in Central and Western Europe are being held this year at about the same time, the first beginning in London on Feb. 21. It is unusual for all six to fall so close together that buyers and tourists can attend them all in less than two weeks' time.

Charges against Kotzen, Mann Siegel, a lawyers, of New York, cited to appear before the National Labor Renations Board to show cause why they should not be barred from furtheir practice before it, were denied and dismissed today by J. Warren Madden, chairman, after an all-day hearing.

The completion last week of eleven more homes in the Munsey Park development at Manhasset, L. I., brought to 364 the total number of homes erected on the former estate of the late Frank A. Munsey since it was taken over by Munsey Park, Inc., developers, ten years ago. Twelve additional houses are under construction.

Diana, one of the world's two captive pandas, arrived today from the Orient. Her captor, Mrs. W. H. Harkness Jr. of New York, said she would take the 3-month-old animal to Chicago to join Su Lin, the other member of the species in the Chicago Zoo.

Evergreen Farms, leader in the Metropolitan Senior Indoor Polo League, ran its winning streak to five straight games last night with a 14-to-10 victory over the First Division team at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

Arrangements have been made by forty-two manufacturers to participate in exhibitions of American industrial arts and crafts in the capitals of Sweden, Norway and Denmark in the Spring and early Fall, according to Louis Bonnard, commissioner of. the exhibits organization, whose office is at 17 East Forty-second Street.

CHURCHVILLE, N. Y. (the toy village on the third floor of 152 West Forty-second Street), Feb. 12.--Traffic on the main rail line running through this tiny town was tied up for a short time today when the crack Churchville Flier, toy train, leaped from the rails while crossing a split switch and crashed head on with a diminutive freight train.

More than 200 photographs seelected from 1,000 taken by amateur camera men in nineteen countries will be placed on exhibition next Saturday in the Kodak International Exhibit for 1938 in the Mezzanine Gallery of the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

A new method of boring tunnels beneath rivers, which is intended to eliminate many of the hazards now involved in such operations and also cut down the time and expense, is the invention for which a patent has just been granted to Miles I. Killmer of New York.

The low cost housing space to be available in the projects in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn and the.Queens Bridge neighborhood of Queens will be only one-third of that originally estimated, Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, disclosed yesterday.

A committee of economic experts was announced yesterday by Walter W. Van Kirk, director of the National Peace Conference, to draft a program of practical steps toward greater economic cooperation, to be undertaken nationally and internationally, to further world peace.

Giving the most brilliant exhibition in the recent history of the Dartmouth Outing Club carnivals, Dartmouth's superb array of skiers made a sweep today to triumph for the fourth straight year, this time with a perfect score of 500 points.

With the Misses Jane Walsh and Kathleen McVeigh each scoring 10 points, the St. Joseph's College for Women basketball team routed the Mount St. Vincent combination, 20 to 4, yesterday on the loser's court. The contest was played according to three-zone rules and Miss Walsh and Miss McVeigh each tallied five field goals.

Japan, in a note to the United States, Britain and France, refused yesterday to give any information on her naval plans. She held that questions of "qualitative building," or the size of ships and guns, cannot be discussed until "quantitative building,"

Elizabeth Walker, 2 1/2 years old, of 251 East 236th Street, the Bronx, died in Fordham Hospital last night after the amputation of her left leg, which was crushed under a bus in front of her home a few hours before.

GARDNER READ'S First symphony, which won the New York Philharmonic-Symphony prize last year, will be played this Thursday and Friday by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dr. Frederick Stock, in Chicago.

Chicago's injury-riddled Black Hawks strengthened their hold on third place in the American section of the National Hockey League by defeating the Maple Leafs, 2-1, tonight. Only two minor penalties were meted out.

With the cooperation of several religious groups and many civic and philanthropic organizations, the Brooklyn Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will hold a forum on world affairs on Tuesday at the Academy of Music.

WOMEN," said Hazlitt a century ago, "are an eye-Judging sex." They still are, so Hollywood has found out, -for only a tiny fraction of men trouble much over the looks of stars in films, what, they wear,
Arsenal and Middles brought, famous cup-fighting teams will not be among the eight team that go into the sixth round of th English Cup soccer competition.
The Yale freshmen tonight defeated Exeter Academy at basketball, 48 to 32. The visitors overtook their rivals for a brief period in the first half.

Cities of the Pacific Coast are watching developments in the campaign to obtain the deportation of Harry Bridges to Australia with intense interest but with little or nothing of the active participation reported from certain public officials in Oregon and Washington and from American Legion posts in the interior valleys of California.

New students at Pennsylvania State College this week began active reorganization of their "political" parties in preparation for the class elections in April. Under the supervision of the student council and its elections committee, they will wage campaigns for all undergraduate class offices.

Efforts to raise the average sale in those departments where it has fallen below levels consistent with efficient merchandising offer one solution to the problem of meeting increases in costs, retailers agreed yesterday.

Propaganda for mass withdrawals from the Christian churches is beginning to show real results. At certain Berlin municipal bureaus where resignations can be made, lines have appeared. Signs have been posted saying "Church Withdrawals Here."

As the United States recession continues and British unemployment figures creep back toward the 2,000,000 mark, the ever-present undercurrent of British criticism of President Roosevelt and his policies is becoming more vocal and more generally accepted.

The directors of the Merchants Association of New York have endorsed the Desmond-Parsons bill for the creation of a permanent legislative council to develop a legislative program between sessions of the State Legislature, it was announced yesterday.
A nation, like a man or woman, must be aware of a purpose in life if it is to be happy. It must conceive of itself, in its collective consciousness, as meaning something and going somewhere.

THE highest "personality" in Chinese art, writes Lin Yu tang, author of "My Country and My People," in discussing the contributions of East to West in art in the February number of the Magazine of Art, is always "a soul which shows calm, peace and a sense of detachment from life.
THE "most important individual in American history who has not had a biography" is now amply clothed in his habit as he lived.

Witchhazels are in bloom and the first Spring snowdrops have opened their white and green pendent bells, but it is still too soon to predict, with any certainty that this is going to be an unusually early Spring. The probability that it will be, however. daily grows stronger.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Alison Jr. of Bridgeport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Smith Alison, to Walter Earle Witsil, also of Bridgeport, formerly of Wilmington, Del.
A $250,000 monument will be constructed on a rugged hill east of here to commemorate the four most famous words in the history of Utah and the Latter Day Saints' Church.

Dissensions in the British Cabinet over foreign policy set London buzzing last night. The majority, headed by Prime Minister Chamberlain, wants to push rapidly for an agreement with Germany and Italy. Foreign Secretary Eden and a minority would go more slowly and preserve "principles." The Secretary's political career is believed to be imperiled. [Page 1.]

Percentage leases, based on the gross volume of sales, are becoming increasingly popular, according to Herbert Jacques Morris, chairman of the stores committee of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New YorkH.

Border collies furnished a tinge of country atmosphere to the final day of the Westminster show in Madison Square Garden yesterday, participating in special sheep-herding exhibitions before thousands of city dwellers at both the afternoon and evening sessions.

WASHINGTON STEREOSCOPIC television--sending and receiving television images in relief or in three dimensions--is revealed in a patent (No. 2,107,464) granted to Vladimir K. Zworykin of the RCA Victor Company, noted television researcher and inventor of the iconoscope, or radio "eye."

One of the earliest reactions to the Japanese note on naval building today was an announcement by Senator William H. King of Utah that he planned to introduce on Monday a resolution authorizing President Roosevelt to convoke a world conference on limitation of armaments.

The signal failure of this week's efforts to smoke out President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and other officials engaged with foreign affairs on some supposed new foreign policy for the United States sprang primarily from the attempt of the interlocutors to visualize foreign policy as something as definite as a mathematical formula.

ANY doubts as to the prevailing taste of the Roman opera public were dispelled by the frenetic ovation that greeted the revival of Francesco Cilea's three-act lyric drama; "Gloria," at the Teatro Reale some days ago.

The Kentucky Democratic Senatoral primary next August may be the Gettysburg of the party's internecine strife over national control in 1940. Every prospective element in the impending contest between Senator Alben W. Barkley and Governor Albert B. Chandler unites to provide an unmistakable test of the President's political leadership.

William Green, president of the American. Federation of Labor, told the Chicago Federation of Labor today that the difference between the A. F. of L. and the Committee for Industrial Organization was the difference between majority rule and minority dictatorship.

Dartmouth increased its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating Princeton, 44 to 38, for its sixth victory in seven circuit starts. It was the Tigers' fourth defeat in five league games.
More than 15 per cent of Pennsylvania's population received State or Federal relief in January. During the month 150,000 persons were added to relief rolls, bringing the State's total to 1,454,000.
CUSTOM prescribes that when a "lost" book turns up it should make its appearance in an odd and unexpected quarter.
AFTER a series of books about China which have placed her firmly in the ranks of our foremost writers, Pearl Buck turns for the first time to
In the week following Chancellor Hitler's purge of the army and diplomacy in the Third Reich two events have taken place that in France and Britain are regarded as indirect consequences.

Associate Professor Ann Anthony, acting dean in charge of the Bronx buildings of Hunter College, has been promoted to Professor and assistant-dean, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college.

The principle of State intervention and control of business and industry, as against workers' control of them in the guise of collectivization, is gradually being established in Loyalist Spain by a series of decrees now appearing.

A resolution calling for the formation of an organization of lower West Side organizations to work for better living conditions was adopted yesterday at the Village Conference on the High Cost of Living, attended by about fifty men and women interested in bettering conditions in the Greenwich Village neighborhood.

AN astonishing picture of the confusion which exists in this country as to motor vehicle traffic conditions and regulation, a fact which has been held accountable by many authorities for a large proportion of highway accidents, is contained in a report now made public from the Secretary of Agriculture to the Congress,

That the Papanin expedition may be rescued tomorrow was indicated by tonight's 11:30 broadcast. At 6:45 the icebreaker Taimir radioed to Moscow that she was only forty miles from the ice floe polar station, with which she had exchanged messages at 12:30.

English and American furniture, a collection of Meissen eighteenthcentury porcelain figures, Georgian silver and English porcelain table services will be sold at auction on Thursday and Friday afternoons at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, by order of the owners, who include Mrs. William Platt and Elizabeth Lady Fielding.
MUCH has already been written about that penal settlement which, with geographical inaccuracy and spiritual truth, is generally known as Devil's Island. About two years ago we had the

Objections to the plan of Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner, to convert the right-of-way of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway into a highway for trucks and buses were expressed here today by residents, public officials and real estate brokers.

Miss Mary Watkinson Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. ward Smith Cole of Upper Montclair, was married this afternoon in Union Congregational Church here to William Edward Jordan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Edward Jordan of Fairlawn, Cobourg, Ont. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. George Clarke Vincent.
The intercollegiate debating season of Lehigh University opened today with a radio debate with the University of Detroit debaters.

Gertrude Pitzinger, Czechoslovak mezzo-soprano, whose recent recital at Town Hall was such a pronounced success, will give a second one on Tuesday afternoon, Feb. 22, in Carnegie Hall, before her return to Europe.
For twenty-six days Sweden has now been without service in hotels, restaurants and cafes, while small boarding houses and hotels unlicensed for the sale of liquor struggle to take their place.
ERNEST KRENEK, Austrian composer, will be guest of honor at a musical to be given by the League of Composers Feb. 27 at the Cosmopolitan Club.

The State Fair at Syracuse will be extended to two weeks this year, with the dates set from Aug. 29 to Sept. 10, it was announced today after a conference between Holton V. Noyes, Commissioer of Agriculture and Markets, and Dr. Albert L. Brown, the fair director.

Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Dickinson of Chestnut Hill and Palm Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Dickinson, to George Evelyn Harrison, son of William Gordon Harrison and. of Mrs. Sarah King Harrison of Richmond. Va.

Japan promised again today that her forces in China would respect the United States flag and Americans and their property. The promise was made in a note replying to the United States protest of Jan. 17 against attacks on Americans.
The Muhlenberg basketball team tonight defeated Lafayette by a score of 48 to 39, squaring their series for the season at one game each.
Degrees in course will be awarded to about 275 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania at the midyear convocation at Irvine Auditorium next Saturday morning. Dr.

Anticipating an active home-buying market during 1938, Ray Craerin, president of the realty corporation owning the Fort Hills Estates development in the Greenville section of Greenburgh, Westchester County, announced yesterday that plans have been made for the erection this year of forty additional houses.
MENTION of Australia means, to most people, kangaroos. If such mention is not followed by lore, serious or frivolous, about kangaroos, their attention wanders.
Ivan Brown, Keene Valley, N. Y., machinist, cracked all records for two-man bobsleds on Mount Van Hoevenberg today as he triumphed in the fifth national A. A. U. senior championships.

Georgia's chain gangs became a thing of the past today under legislative action which will convert them into "public works camps" for "honor" prisowners, with a policy of "no more shackles, whipping or sweat boxes."

The United Automobile Workers of America said the Ford Brotherhood of America, Inc., an independent union, voted today to disband and join the U. A. W. A., but an F. B. A. official declared the action was illegal.

The Walter Hines Page Chapter of the D. A. R. elected the following officers at its annual meeting: Mrs. Royden Rothermel, State regent; Mrs. Volney Brundage of Washington, vice State regent; Mrs. James Lee, recording secretary; Mrs. William R. Comings,

How the Federal Savings and Loan System, now consisting of 1,328 members with assets of more than $1,000,000,000, is tending to unify and strengthen the entire savings and loan field was described yesterday by Dr. W. H. Husband, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which supervises the system.

When the colorful clouds surrounding the new collections have ceased to dazzle, one realizes that the combinations of navy blue and white or black and white predominate at leading houses, such as Mainbocher, Lanvin, Molyneux, Alix, Paquin, etc.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Sporti, card parties, supper dances and convention sessions will engage' the attention of Atlantic City's-visitors this week.

The International Flower Show, which celebrates its Silver Jubilee this year, will be held March 14 through 19 in Grand Central Palace, with private and educational commercial displays occupying four floors.

The North China adventure conceivably can bring Japan three kinds of profits: strategic, industrial and commercial. The chances are that only the first and last will be realized until such time as hostilities have given place to peaceful trade conditions.

THE VOYAGES OF JACQUES CARTIER. Retold by Esther Averill. Illustrated by Feodor Rojankovsky. 94 pp. New York: The Domino Press. $3. THIS is an outstanding book for young people in the field of history.

This Friday will mark the opening of the third National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace, and thousands of anglers and hunters will travel hundreds of miles to look over the exhibits gathered from all over the world in the name of sport.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 11, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Somers, Feb. 12; Potomac, Acushnet. At Guantanamo Bay, Feb. 12: S-20, Vega. Chester, Mare Island Yard to San Pedro. Cormorant, at Key West, Feb. 12. Craven, at Bostcn Yard.

Swarthmore College scored its ninth victory in eleven starts tonight against Lehigh, winning by 42-31. Ed Jakle, Garnet four-letter man, took high scoring honors with 10 tallies. Jake Hankins scored 9 for the visitors.

Selling and sales-promotion work in the hotel industry will be major subjects of discussion at the eleventh annual meeting of the Hotel Sales Managers Association, which will be held in Atlantic City from March 31 to April 2.
The complexion of the local municipal administration was changed yesterday w h e n Commissioner Francis M. Seaman resigned as head of the Department of Public Works, effective March 15.
Reports are current here that, with the early arrival of Stanley Hiller, president of the Santa Cruz Oil Company, and another American financier,

THE concourse of the railroad terminal is a lively place on any pleasant Saturday morning. Sportive week-enders besiege the track gates, clad in outing togs of wonderful and often fearful hue, and lugging skis, toboggans and other athletic paraphernalia proper to the time of year.

OINTING out that the number of motor vehicle accidents to children is decreasing in his State, Ernest W. Butterfield, Commissioner of Education of Connecticut, has issued a bulletin under the title "Children Protect Your Parents!" which goes on to reverse the usual admonitions in a striking way.

By forcing his breath into her lungs, Patrolman George Scharnikow saved the life of Alice Rantella, 2 1/2-month-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rantella, -541 West 124th Street, who had swallowed her tongue while coughing before daybreak yesterday morning.

To the Drama Editor: As all Equity members must know by now, $1,500 or more of their money is being expended by the socalled liberal regime on a survey which is expected to bring to-light some startling conclusions.
OBVIOUS but pertinent and inevitable questions come at once to the mind when the matter of subway art is broached-as it is broached, with samples attached, at the Museum of Modern Art.

Justice W. E. Middleton of the Ontario Supreme Court today accepted the claims of four mothers to shares of the $500,000 stork derby prize bequeathed by Charles V. Millar to the Toronto woman giving birth to the largest number of children in the ten years following his death.
The Pawtucket Chamber of Commerce launched an extensive industrial expansion program today to attract American business to one of the most highly developed manufacturning centers in the East.

While some lending agencies have been hesitant in accepting the 90 per cent mortgage plan of the FHA on small new residences, they are preparing to cooperate on a broad scale in making modernization loans, according to officials of the Federal agency who are preparing to put the new program into operation immediately.
Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire outlined a ten-point Republican program tonight to end what he termed "the depression of 1937."

With the active interest and cooperation of many women of prominance in society, the.Alliance for Guidance of Rural Youth (formerly the Southern Women's Educational Alliance), has taken over the mat inee performance of "Parsifal" on March 18 at the Metropolitan Opera House to raise funds for continuing the provision of a national vocational guidance service for boys and girls of rural districts.

Books are still the leading topic of Wheaton students, although the midyear exams are over. But now it is exteriors rather than interiors which claim attention. The reason is the annual campus book show, now in preparation, to be held for thirteen days beginning Monday.

LIONEL BARRYMORE has the distinction of being the first player chosen for the film edition of "You Can't Take It With You." He will appear in the role of Grandpa Vanderhof, a character to be known on the screen as Grandpa Sycamore.

The psychological ravages of unemployment visible in the disintegration of stable family life and the warped personalities of children and young people were recounted in a study made public yesterday by the University of Newark.

Thomas Miller, who was connected with the Lawyers Title Corporation for more than twenty-five years, has joined the Colonial Realty Company of Brooklyn as manager of the business department, specializing in mortgage servicing, property management and appraisals.

The elimination of the No. 1 seeded player, Donald Hawley, by Henry Daniels, former national junior doubles champion with Robert Low, featured the first round of the fourth annual metropolitan indoor tennis championships conducted by the Hamilton Indoor Tennis Club at the 102d Regiment Armory last night.

A rise in diphtheria deaths from thirty-five in 1936 to fifty-eight in 1937 is attributed to the failure of immunizations to keep pace with births in a statement issued yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

The total cost of a new propeller and a new motor for the airplane used in the search for the six Russian aviators who disappeared during a transpolar flight last August will be about $10,000, Sir Hubert Wilkins said here today.
State police late today arrested two brothers who Corporal George Westefeld said confessed attempting a hold-up in New York State in which their father was killed.

The need for continuing the work of Abraham Lincoln in the United States of the present was a general theme of rabbis here in their sermons yesterday. They extolled him as the personification of the spirit of democracy.

The Federation of French Veterans of the Great War will hold their annual dinner and Bal des Fleurs on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania. Under the patronage of Doynel de Saint-Quentin, recently appointed French Ambassador to the United States.

Exeter defeated Andover, 4-1, in a stirring hockey battle played at the Boston arena tonight. The New Hampshire lads had too much man-power for their rivals, and this, coupled with an effective scoring punch, enabled Perry Rogers's boys to come through with flying colors.

Builders in Bergen County, N. J., who experienced the best home construction and selling year in 1937 that had been seen in that section of the State for many years, despite. some curtailment due to the business recession in the closing months, are predicting that a much higher record will be established this year.
Freeholder Frederick E. Koester, chairman of the Police Committee, is tired of hearing the question: "What do the county police do for their money?"

The New York Rangers, taking advantage of Maroon penalties, defeated the Montrealers, 5 to 3, tonight in a wide open National Hockey League encounter. The triumph lifted the Rangers to within a point of the Boston Bruins, leaders in the league's American group.

One of the few remaining mementoes of the mid-nineteenth century, when the Chelsea-Bloomingdale sector of New York was a fashionable residence suburb, is the Victorian Gothic auditorium of Public School 33, 418 West Twenty-eighth Street.
The foreign exchange market here was steadier today after yesterday's erratic movements. Apart from small clearing-up operations, little business was done.

The Junior League of New York is now engaged in preliminary plans for one of its most ambitious undertakings in recent years-the prssentation on April 29 of a "Ball of Tomorrow" at the grounds of the New York World's Fair.

Miss Carol Smith Allen will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 280 Riverside Drive, for committee members of the New York County Chapter of the National Republican Builders, who are now arranging their annual dance, a Washington's Birthday Ball, for the night of Feb. 21 at Sherry's.

ADVENTUROUS souls who mourn the demise of the speakeasy and the crafty devices which often distinguished its existence might refresh their memories by a visit to the cellar and second-floor joints up Yorkville way.

REGULARLY all Winter a New York restaurant serves stone crabs caught in Florida the same day. According to the demand and the season, fish from subtropical waters, tree-ripened fruit from sunny South and West,

National mortgage associations, which have been authorized by one of the amendments to the Federal Housing Act, possess possibilities of great importance in providing new financing facilities for the housing progress of the nation, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

LITHUANIA, one of the republics carved out of the land which was the Russian Empire before the World War, will celebrate this week the twentieth anniversary of its political freedom and will commemorate the occasion by issuing special stamps in values of 15, 30, 35 and 60 cents, together with a two-stamp souvenir sheet.
MIAMI, Fla.--Ice skating and skiing, for the first time Min the history of Miami, have been added to the entertainment program, and it is expected that spectators from the greater Miami area,

Almost one-third ot the undergraauates of Wellesley College will devote their "leisure hours" of the coming month to intensive preparations for the most ambitious theatrical enterprise which students and faculty have ever undertaken to produce.

In the more than ninety countries covered by a world survey of motion-picture developments made public today by the Department of Commerce, American motion pictures were shown during 1937 to the extent of

Statistics recently released by the Municipal Rose Garden in Tulsa, Okla., largest test garden in the mid-South, show that most of its hybrid tea casualties over a threeyear period (March, 1935 to 1938) were due to the unusual low temperatures of February; 1936, and not to the three-month drought of that same year.

There is no little indignation in The Netherlands over an incident in Berlin yesterday when A. J. Berndt of the German Press Department at a press conference was asked by a Dutch correspondent whether correct information could be given concerning recent German events instead of denials.
Pope Pius XI observed today the sixteenth anniversary of his coronation by attending mass in the Sistine Chapel.

The visit to Poland of Regem Nicholas Horthy and Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya went unnoticed even in Hungary in the greater excitement caused by the army and Cabinet shake-up in Berlin. To that was added even greater excitement about the change in Rumania.

The United States Lines has rejected the proposal of the National Maritime Union for recognition of ships' committees as an item of the new wage contract that is under negotiation, it was announced yesterday by A. J. McCarthy, vice president in charge of operations.

An "indictment" of the bar, and especially the American Bar Association, as a barrier to social progress and a protector of predatory privilege was handed up last night by Paul J. Kern, Commissioner of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and one of the founders of the National Lawyers Guild, at a dinner session of the second annual convention of the American Law Students Association.

The sale of the late Mrs. Thomas Fortune Ryan's furnishings and decorations by the Plaza Art Galleries was completed yesterday. Her goods were sold in two parts. Part one, which was auctioned the week before last, realized $37,023.

Miss Elizabeth De Angelis Bogart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril De A. Bogart of this place, was married here today in St. Paul's Church to Philip Hirst Milner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfrid W. Milner of Hastingson-Hudson. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wilbur L. Caswell, the rector.

" University training which achieves specialization at the expense of mature professional judgment and mellow scholarship will not help the American liberal arts college to meet the challenge of present-day democracy," said Dr. Paul Klapper, head of Queens College,
To the Art Editor: THE fair may not have the right answer to the problem of adequately exhibiting contemporary American art. But neither, I think, have the protesting coordinating artists.
Brown University looks forward toward the time when its extensive McLellan Collection on Abraham Lincoln will contain virtually every item ever published concerning the Civil War President.

WASHINGTON BACKED by favorable expressions from every one of the forty-eight States, the House Roads Committee will soon report a bill proposing to continue the Federal road aid appropriations through 1942, in direct opposition to the recommendation President Roosevelt made in December to trim such authorizations by $113,000,000 a year.
The regular monthly meeting of the Kindergarten - 6B Association will be held at the Hotel McAlpin Tuesday at 4 P. M. A report on school legislation will be made.

Foreboding--an anxious awaiting of developments--still pervades Central Europe as a result of the installation of the "new order" in Germany last week. In the views of Prague, Vienna and Budapest there appears general agreement that "no good will come out of it."

Japan's peremptory reply to the treaty powers peremptory question concerning her naval program is regarded here as the starting gun of a naval race in which Britain must join no matter how reluctantly.

A double-headed recommendation for submission to the State Constitutional Convention-including elec tion of Assemblymen by proportional representation and a single-cham ber Legislature-is embodied in a report approved this week by the city affairs committee of the Women's City Club. Miss Juliet M.

Miss Dorothy Kenyon, newly appointed to the committee on legal status of women of the League of Nations, will speak at a meeting tomorrow of the Greenwich College Club at the Edgewood School. Miss Kenyon will discuss the proposed equal rights amendment and the women's charter.

New York and Philadelphia fives split a basketball double-header tonight as St. Johns' of Brooklyn rallied in the second half to defeat St. Joseph's after Temple had subdued. N. Y.. U. In the opening game at Convention Hall before a crowd of 9,000. Temple won, 42-34, while St. John's triumphed by the same margin, outcoring. St. Joseph's, 38-30.
In the highestscoring game ever played between the two countries, England defeated Ireland, 36-14, in a weird international Rugby match today.

Following is the address of Senator Vandenberg before the Middlesex Club tonight: I acknowledge my sense of obligation for the privilege of addressing this famous old Republican organization which is rich in the traditions of party loyalty and party valor.

Miss Louise Livlngston Rich, a descendant of Robert Rich, Earl of Warwick, and a great-granddaughter of James Vander Kamp Rich of New York, a founder of the East River Savings Bank, was married here this afternoon to Chandler Knapp Garland of New York, formerlv of Milton, Mass.

Battling enormous snow drifts, State Highway Department crews with snowplows struggled today to take aid to five families made homeless by -an avalanche which killed two men and crushed a. tiny community of homes on the south shore of June Lake in this high Sierra country.
TWO of the new exhibitions testify to the unusually good harvest of water-colors this season. One of these attractions is the show of recent work by Georges Schreiber at the A. C. A. Gallery;

A few new bright and shining decorative accessories go a long way toward dispelling the dull sameness that settles over the appearance of living quarters in the late Winter. Some shops are showing china, glassware, linens, objets d'art that will give any domestic interior the fillip of change.

When President Roosevelt affixes his signature to the Omnibus Farm Bill next week (the Senate has given evidence of its intention to pass the bill without delay) he will launch the most ambitious farm-relief experiment this nation has yet attempted.

WARRENTON, Va.-The Warrenton Horse Show, which has been held in October for the last two years, has been set for Sept. 9 and 10 this year. This is nearer to its accustomed time, and lessens the probability of cold weather, such as hampered the 1937 show.
