Frank Strafaci of the Lakeville Country Club, Great Neck, L. I., shooting sub-par golf, went into the lead for low gross honors at the end of the first half of the 36-hole medal play competition on the St. Augustine Links today.

NEWS that Hitler is to build skyscrapers in Hamburg--they are to be 800 feet high--revives a question which every first-tripper to Europe has asked at some time or other, Why have the old countries never taken to skyscrapers?

Not for the first time, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg has taken his countrymen completely by surprise, and one of the originators of the surprise was the ingenious and resourceful Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador who was recently recalled.
Meeting of the Board of Governors of the New York State Council of Polish Democratic Clubs, George Washington Hotel, 1:30 P. M. Address by Attorney General John J. Bennett.

HOW about another extra-curricular examination, more or less mathematical-a test in subtracting of old togs and adding on new ones? It ought to be easy to rate an A in that one, especially when there are such attractive new things to be had.

Pennsylvania's fast-improving basketball team pulled another surprise today by defeating Cornell, 51-45, in an Eastern League game before a junior week crowd of more than 3,000 persons. Penn fought its way out of a 42-42 tie in the last six minutes to win.

A supper fashion show to be known as "A Trip to Bermuda" will take place Feb. 23 at La Conga for the benefit of the Music Education League; Inc. Costumes for cruise and Bermuda wear will be shown by a group of young,women headed by Miss Eileen Herrick.

The long awaited weights for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, which were announced today at Hialeah Park, show that handicapper Charles McLennan has established War Admiral at the head of the list, with 130 pounds.

Retail trade in most districts was below that of a year ago, but gains were reported in some districts and in others the losses were smaller than in the previous week. The volume at wholesale showed sharp declines in most districts, although a few, notably Texas and the Northwest, found better business going to jobbers.

The Stevens Tech quintet vanquished Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in a fast game at Castle Point tonight, 33--27. Stevens led throughout the game, but was challenged near the end of the second half when the score stood at 29--27.

After a preliminary survey had indicated that nearly half the money paid in the State Unemployment Insurance Fund by employers would be required to finance a relatively modest plan of benefits for partial unemployment,
TELEVISION program producers in London recently turned the cameras on the second act of "Tristan and Isolde," presented as a masque with a double cast of invisible singers and eyeworthy actors.

The first showing of "Parabola," an abstract motion picture by John Rutherford Boyd, will be the feature of the annual reception of the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts at the Chanin Theatre, Wednesday, Dean Raymond Bossange announced yesterday.

A larger amount of money was spent for building construction in the town of Bedford last year than in any previous year since the business depression. George F. Rogers, Building Inspector, reports that his office issued 110 permits in 1937.

Continuing its study of finance for the family, the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, under the direction of Mrs. Kathryn Ford, chairman, will hold a meeting on Wednesday at 2 P. M. in a broadcasting studio of WNYC.

Japan's refusal to disclose its own naval building intentions or to enter into any discussion of limitations agreements, on a basis which this country could accept, was interpreted in official circles here as a direct challenge to a "blue-sky" naval building race.

The La Guardia Administration, acting through Senator Desmond, will sponsor in the Legislature Monday night a transit measure far broader in scope than a mere bill for the abolition of the State Transit Commission.

Stormy weather still prevails over the North Atlantic and ships arriving from Europe are being delayed. The President Harding of the United States Lines, incoming from the Channel ports, will arrive tomorrow morning, two days late.
FOR a while in Rome I lived among archaeologists, and ever since I find myself occasionally looking at the things about me as an archaeologist will look at them a thousand years hence.

Twenty student craftsmen of the College of New Rochelle began work this week on the construction of a setting for the annual mid-year play, "Cradle Song" to be presented at the college on Thursday, Feb. 24, and Sunday, Feb. 27.

Indications are that the race for the Democratic nomination for Senator in Kentucky in August will be the most bitterly contested in years, as It will be a contest between the national and State administrations, according to Senator Barkley, the Democratic leader in the Senate.
ANTIQUE pewter tankards, platters and other ware are pleasant reminders of a flourishing American craft which lasted from early Pilgrim days through the first years of the nineteenth century.

There are 1,500,000 people trying to kill one another in the Spanish peninsula, but behind the front of Nationalist Spain the war might be a legend. I have just come from 2,000 miles of traveling in Spain.
A strong Princeton wrestling team, pressed hard by Washington and Lee in the lighter classes, came back in the heavy divisions tonight to gain a 23-11 victory.

Kenneth Ridgway of the Garden City B. C., former metropolitan champion and seeded No. 2, came from behind to defeat Wayne Sykes of Old Sixty-ninth, seeded No. 3, in the semi-finals of the third annual Eastern badminton tournament on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
The Optimists defeated Yale's good polo team, 20 to 17, at the Squadron A Armory last night in a match that had some, but not all, the earmarks of an alumni-varsity game.
A freight-car load of supplies for the men on five gunboats of the United States Yangtze River patrol had hundreds of bullet holes when it arrived here today on the Canton-Hankow Railway.

A 155-foot carillon tower will be a feature of the exhibit of the Belgian Government at the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was disclosed yesterday when the completed plans arrived on the French liner Normandie. Belgium is the first nation to have her plans approved by the fair's board of design.

IN the February issue of The Winged Foot, the monthly publication of the New York A. C., there is a story that modern track and field fans would do well to read. The title is "Track and Field Story of the New York Athletic Club" and the author is Thomas T. Reilly, chairman of the athletic committee of the club.
Miss Louise A. Boyd of San Francisco, the only woman explorer of the Arctic, will be the principal speaker at the annual dinner on Wednesday of the New York unit of the Society of Women Geographers.

Several advantages would be gained through the adoption of a uniform mortgage foreclosure law in all States, declares Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia, who also defends the practice of life insurance companies of foreclosing on mortgaged homes.
Settlement of a 27-month-old labor dispute in a factory operated by the Brown Shoe Company at Vincennes, Ind., was announced today by the National Labor Relations Board.

Winter sailors of the Larchmont Yacht Club made a sweep today in Class B one-design team dinghy racing. They ran up 186 points to 103 for Indian Harbor of Greenwich and 102 1/4 for Manhasset Bay. The second session of the match will be held tomorrow.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-One of the season's major offerings, the climax of months of arduous rehearsing, will be the annual concert by the Romany Chorus and Orchestra on Wednesday night at the Paramount Theatre, with Richard Crooks, Metropolitan Opera tenor, as guest artist. Proceeds will go to the Romany fund for the musical education of members.

Paced by its sharpshooting center; Ed Sadowski, the Seton Hall College quintet defeated the Columbus Council K. of C. five, 46 to 31, last night on the loser's court. Sadowski was the high scorer with seven field goals and five free shots for 19 points. Seton Hall led at the half, 26 to 11.

The American freighter Fluor Spar stood by for several hours last night, according to radio messages, as the British freighter Eastpool, which had lost her propeller and was drifting sixteen miles off Tuskar Rock,
SIX-PFENNIG green and 12pf red stamps have been received from Germany, commemoraing the fifth anniversary of Adolf Hitler's being called to the chancellorship in 1933.

Playing on its home court, the Brooklyn College basketball team last night defeated the Montclair Teachers, 45 to 35. Led by Abe Gerchik, left forward, who scored 7 of his 12 points. in one minute of th opening period.

Jim Howell, 205 1/4, Harlem, substituting for Joe Walcott, scored an upset last night when he took the decision from Yustin Sirutis, 221, Brooklyn, in the ten-round feature bout at the Rockland Palace before a crowd of 2,000.

St. Francis College of Brooklyn won its second game in two days by defeating Newark University last night, 48-38, at the Butler Street gym. St. Francis completely dominated the play in the entire second half.

THIS Fall, my novel "On Borrowed Time," so lately dramatized by Paul Osborn, appeared with a jacket blurb which violated the conventional reticence an author ordinarily preserves regarding the background of his story.
Reports from Venezuela today said that seven missing schoolboys from Port-of-Spain had drifted ashore at Macuro yesterday. A rescue boat left here a short time later to bring the boys home.
Staging a third-period rally, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the Bronx Tigers tonight, 4 to 2, and moved into a second-place tie in the Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League.

A profusion of scarlet and magenta bougainvillea, coconut palms and yellow flowering alamanda will .transform the terraces and ballroom of the Miami Biltmore Country Club into a tropical garden on Friday for'the Helen Lee Doherty Lace Ball.

Notable episodes in English history will be portrayed in a pageant entitled "England's Hourglass," which will be presented at the Lyceum Theatre on the night of Feb. 27 to raise additional endowment for the maintenance of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossining.
Dr. Henry Rushton Fairclough, Emeri tus Professor of Classic Literature at Stanford University, died suddenly today in Palo Alto of a heart attack. His age was 75.

AFTER a short setback, retail trade regained higher levels in various sections of the country last week. Increases were reported over the previous period, although volume was still running, as a rule, below a year ago.

Gifts totaling more than $10,000 have been received by Barnard College recently for scholarship funds and for continuation of the expansion program of the college, the office of the dean announced yesterday.
The Smith College Alumnae Council will hold its midwinter meeting here next week, assembling 150 delegates from fifty-nine classes and sixty-three Smith Clubs.

The members of the National Puzzlers League went into a huddle over charts, maps and blocks here today, but the convention was soon stymied by Cipriano Farraris, the champion number juggler of them all.

For the first time since the World War a full-dress debate on American foreign policy got under way last week. President Roosevelt's request for a bigger navy loosed the discussion. That request gave rise to the questions: Why do we need a larger navy? What is American foreign policy? The questions stirred Congress and public to heated discussion.

A larger Summer colony at Candlewood Lake, near Danbury, Conn., is anticipated this coming season, in view of the unexpected demand at this time of the year for small homes and building sites, reports the Homeland Company, developers of Candlewood Knolls and Knollcrest on the West shore of the lake.

Members of the New York Society, Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence. will give their annual banquet next Saturday night at the Pierre. The speaker will be Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York.
The girls' basketball team of Savage School remained undefeated yesterday by scoring its seventh straight victory of the season over the East Stroudsburg (Pa.) sextet, 19 to 14, on the Savage court.

" Why Christianity?" is the theme for the annual Forum of Modern Religious Thought which opens tomorrow at Bowdoin College. Twelve clergymen from several denominations and from many sections of New England, will serve as leaders for the discussion periods to be held each evening at the fraternity houses.
Ending of the "proxy racket" whereby a small minority of stockholders are able to control the operations of large corporations was urged yesterday by Mortimer Fishel, attorney.

Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia today won the women's national squash racquets title by defeating her sister townswoman, Miss Anne Page, defending champion, in a five-game final by 15--5, 15--12, 11--15, 10--15, 15--12.

Labor men here say that John L. Lewis appears to be developing a new formula for making wage and hour agreements for his unions. The new formula they say, seems to call for these things: An unheralded trip to New York City.

University of Washington crews, which swept all three races on the Hudson River at the Poughkeepsie regatta the last two years, will defend their titles in the 1938 classic, Athletic Director Ray Eckmann said today.

ALONG two new fronts the attack on television is being widened to simplify and make telepictures practical for reception in the home. First, research experts here and abroad have turned their attention to the development of a television attachment for standard broadcast allwave sets to convert them into receivers of ethereal cinema.

In an editorial titled "Democracy Must Be Protected," El Mercurio, South America's oldest daily newspaper, urges citizens to abandon their apathetic attitude in the face of conflicting political tendencies.

The airplane of J. W. Cannon 3d, member of a North Carolina cotton textile family, crashed near Snellings, five miles from here, late today and he suffered an acute brain concussion, leg, arm and kneecap fractures, lacerations and severe bruises.
MR. ARNOLD'S volume has caused a tremendous fluttering among the reviewers. The usually shrewd Clifton Fadiman, finds in it "one on the funniest examples of social satire since Voltaire."
In his address before the Bar Association of the City of New York, Under Secretary of the Treasury Roswell Magill expressed himself as favorably disposed to the undistributed-profits tax.
LIKE the New York Philharmonic the Philharmonic of Vienna will be a hundred years old in 1942. Yet it has not waited for the emergency of that jubilee to publish its official biography.

The historic Union League Club of Chicago this week abandoned the restraints of its traditional dignity. It burst upon public attention with an eight-page folder which shouted in red letters "America, Wake Up!" Above this waved the Stars and Stripes in color.

The American Chemical Society will hold its ninety-fifth meeting in Dallas, Texas, with Dr. Henry Winston Harper as honorary chairman and Dr. N. C. Hamner as general chairman, it was announced yesterday. About fifteen hundred chemists from scientific, industrial, educational and other fields are expected to attend. The meeting will open on April 18 and close on April 22.
THE complete schedule of events is now available for the coming Eastern championships, which will begin at the Park Central Hotel Monday afternoon Feb. 28, and end Sunday night. March 6.

THE influence of William A. Dunning on the teaching and the writing of American history was profound and lasting. From his study on Morningside Heights came his own masterly contributions to the history of the American Civil War and reconstruction and to political theory:
Building progress in the South, points out George H. Spohn of Miami, and a member of the South Florida Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, awaits the return of prosperity in the North.

The Bureau of Fisheries today gave a number of explanations why mackerel should have been present off the Southern coast of New England after the first of the year, but it remained a certainty that, when the mackerel returned to the coast in large numbers following the usual close of the season they ordinarily would not have been molested by fishermen.

ADAMS--Frances, beloved mother of Ethel A. Vogel, on Feb. 12, 1938, at her late residence, 67 Hilton Ave., Garden City, N. Y. Services to be announced. AFFELD-On Feb. 12, 1938. Jane, beloved wife of Oscar Affeld, devoted mother of Casse Lehmann. Services Monday, Feb. 14, 1 o'clock, Campbell's Funeral Church. Kindly omit flowers.

Daro of Maridor, an orange belton heavily-ticked English setter, last night captured the best-inshow title of the sixty-second annual all-breed exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden.

It is unfortunate that the Japanese Government has not seen fit to reply directly to the question asked by the Governments of the United States, Great Britain and France: namely, whether Japan is now building battleships or cruisers which exceed in tonnage or in gun-caliber the qualitative limitations to which these three Western Powers subscribed in their Naval Treaty of 1936.
Miss Evelyn Ruth Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Thompson of this city, was married this afternoon to Irving Pell Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis I. Scott.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: From the top rail of my corral fence I have been an interested observer of the many political poultices that have been applied to the ache under the Corn Belt. Naturally, I have acquired a few ideas, but, having resided personally on the seat of the pain,

The Irving School quintet rallied in the last period to defeat Blair School, 29-28, in an Eastern Private Schools League game today. The setback was the first in the league for Blair and the victory advanced Irving to second place.

The St. Paul's School quintet of Garden City scored its thirteenth straight victory on its home court yesterday by defeating Poly Prep, 45 to 15. Oscar Petersen, center, led the attack with thirteen points.

Miss Marion McDougall of Portland, Ore., won the medal in the qualifying round of the Everglades women's invitation golf tournament today with a card of 37, 3673, three under par. In second place was Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco, runner-up for the national championship in 1934, with 35, 40-75.

The Architectural League of New York issued yesterday an invitation to members of the architectural profession and the allied arts throughout the country to participate in the league's fifty-second annual exhibition, which will be held in the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-second Street, April 18 to May 12.

THE scarcity of army airplane pilots was emphasized again last week when the Air Corps announced that it will pay a bonus of $500 to cadets who qualify for a Reserve commission and stay in the army three or more years after completion of their training.
The gown worn by Miss Sonia Elinor Mogensen for her marriage here this evening to L. Paul Ahlers suggested the color scheme for the costumes and flowers of her three attendants.

The Roosevelt administration, Representative Hamilton Fish said here tonight, was plunging the Southern textile and cotton States into a crisis "more serious than the Civil War" for the sake of temporary profit to the cotton growers.

College dramatics this season are undergoing a drastic change, approaching more closely to the professional stage than ever before. Colleges are beginning to swing away from the Victorian tradition of sweetness and light, from drama which is merely-literary and highbrow, toward plays which mirror more closely the life of our own times.

ALFRED HITCHCOCK is frankly a writer of melodramas--on film. That is his genre and he intends to stick with it, leaving to others tales of high society, epics of empire building and stories with social significance.

There are more deer in the State today than when the Indians roamed through the forests, according to Clayton Seager, State supervisor of game distribution. In a jalk before the Leatherstocking Club banquet, Mr. Seager placed the present number of deer in the Adirondacks at 205,000.

NEW opportunities for goodwill broadcasts to the Latin Americas have been opened by the FCC in allocating four Pan-American channels equally to the General Electric Company and the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation of Boston.

The United States today opened its bid for the world amateur ice hockey championship by defeating Latvia, 1-0. Hugh Young of New Haven, Conn., scored the goal in the ninth minute of the second period.

The opening performance of the return engagement of the Salzburg Opera Company the night of March 8 has been taken over as the annual benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association. The name of the opera has not as yet been announced.

THE new naval radio communications million-dollar station under construction about fifteen miles outside Washington at Camp Springs, Md., will be ready for operation this Summer, accordding to Commander W. J. Ruble of Naval Communications Division.
Most senior officers of the army and navy in Washington laid aside

Dr. Cornelius J. Carr, one of Buffalo's most prominent physicians for many years, died today after an illness of three weeks. His age was 70. Since 1896 Dr. Carr practiced medicine in Buffalo as a general practitioner, but other physicians said he was considered a specialist anc expert in diagnosis.

Executives of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, in committee meeting here, determined yesterday upon inclusion of all theatrical workers, especially film and stage actors. The alliance is an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Fighting an uphill battle after being held without a score from the floor during the first nineteen minutes of play, Andover's basketball team gained a 20-16 decision over the Harvard freshman five today.

TO a large part of the English-speaking race Daniel Defoe is the man who wrote "Robinson Crusoe" and stood in the pillory. Far fewer people know anything else he wrote, and very few at all could tell what he stood in the pillory for.

An important conference of Belgian diplomats, including the Ambassadors and Ministers to Paris, London, The Hague, Berne, Barcelona and Angora was held at the Foreign Ministry today. The Belgian Ambassador to Moscow was the only leading Belgian diplomat who was unable to attend.
NICE. THE sixtieth of a line of carnival kings will gain accession to the throne of merri ment on Thursday in the carnival capital of Nice.

Visible for fifteen miles, a spectacular fire razed a West New Brighton (S. I.) warehouse, in which was stored furniture and upholstery valued by the owner at from $10,000 to $15,000, yesterday afternoon, causing a total damage estimated by Fire and Police Department officials at between $60,000 and $70,000. No one was hurt.

America, so long the "safe home of representative government," is approaching what may prove to be the "ultimate test" of democracy, Dr. Francis P. Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University, said today.

Miss Mary Marguerite Larkin, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Francis Larkin of this city and the late Mr. Larkin, was married yesterday morning in the church of St. John the Evangelist to Daniel Joseph McCartan, son of Mrs. Hugh McCartan, also of New York, and the late Mr. McCartan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles J. Quinn, a friend of the family.

STROUDBBURG, Pa.--Skating is Sthe principal Winter sport in the Pooonoa. 'In addition, there has also been some excellent tobogganing, the slides having been flooded with water each night to assure a smooth coasting surface for the following day.

About 170 prominent men in business and professional fields are assisting the Beekman Street Hospital in its campaign for $150,000 to meet its operating costs and maintenance for the current year, it was announced yesterday.

JULES ROMAINS publishes Volumes XIII and XIV of "Les Hommes de Bonne Volonte" (Flammarion). It brings that imposing history of manners in the twentieth century to the year 1914, on the eve of the war.

Mrs. Franklin C. Watkins and David T. Fleisher, both of this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances M. Fleisher, to Dr. David A. Dolowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Dolowitz of Brooklyn and Cold Spring-onHudson. N. Y.

Patrolman Joseph J. McGarry, 35 years old, of 69 Pinehurst Avenue, attached to the West 100th Street station, was arrested yesterday morning on charges of driving while intoxicated and third-degree assault after his car had struck and injured James Morris, 48, of 2,406 University Avenue, the Bronx.

The marriage of Miss Jean Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Boris Miller of Kingsbridge, to Dr. Jesse B. Wildenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wildenberg of Woodlawn, took place here last evening at the Hotel Riverside-Plaza, West Seventy-third Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Putterman of the Park Avenue Temple.
THE National Association of Broadcasters meets tomorrow in Washington for what is expected to be the most important convention in its sixteen years of history.
Business in the wholesale market last week was fairly satisfactory in most lines, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Brown University's basketball team, with Harry Platt of Yonkers and Leonard M. (Soupy) Campbell of Woodbridge, N. J., setting the pace, outscored the Colgate sextet, 84 to 66, at the Westchester County Center tonight. Brown now has won four victories in a row and seven in twelve games this season.
The National Bituminous Coal Commission considered today whether to suspend all miinimum prices it has set for the sale of soft coal.

The Scottish breed in Canada has improved, says John James Dalrymple, Earl Stair, who was here today with the touring Scottish curlers. The Earl, who stands 6 feet 2 inches, spoke with feeling of Canadian hospitality.

The solar-observing station maintained for nearly five years by the Smithsonian Institution on Mount St. Katherine in the Sinai Peninsula, Egypt, has been closed. The decision to abandon the observatory was based in part on the difficulty of living conditions during the Winter.

BROOKS TOO BROAD FOR LEAPING. By Flannery Lewis. 274 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.50. LAST year Flannery Lewis wrote the vivid and charming pioneer story of his Grandmother Flannery and her stormy days in Virginia City. Nev., when bandits, the Ophir saloon and "impulsive" citizens.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of William J. Wilgus suggesting a "way out for the railroads" comes as a breath of fresh air to one in the throes of suffocation.

John Goggin Jr., 30 years old, of 235 Vanderbilt Avenue, Stapleton, S. I., and Joseph Murphy, 30, of 540 Metropolitan Avenue, West New Brighton, were arrested in West New Brighton last night on the complaint of a 16-year-old girl that they had attempted to assault her.

Endowment participation certificates totaling $1,250 in value were awarded to twenty-one freshmen at Stevens Institute of Technology this week. The certificates were given on the basis. of scholastic standing and participation in extracurricular activities. The value will be deducted from the students' tuition charge.

The British public received today Leftist suggestions as to how to deal with Japan. A two-day international conference to which nearly twenty Leftist and Socialist organizations sent 850 delegates from nineteen countries heard speakers urge official and unofficial boycotts of Japan by other nations.

A committee of more than 100 faculty members and alumni of New York University's Washington Square College has been named to plan a silver jubilee dinner in April and an anniversary conference in the Fall to celebrate the school's twenty-fifth year of existence, it was announced yesterday.

A junior committee has been enlisted to aid with the plans for the annual opera benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., which will take place on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The 101st annual report of the Colored Orphan Asylum and Association for the Benefit of Colored Children in the City of New Ybrk, Palisade Avenue and 261st Street, Riverdale, disclosed yesterday that 702 boys and girls were under its care on Oct. 31, 1937.

IF Mr. Middleton's title were followed by an exclamation point it might get him into trouble with Postmaster General Farley. Followed by an unpretentious period, it is far from being an incitement to violence.

A voice crying in the wilderness of the interior of China to the accompaniment of a traveling motion picture is carrying a gospel of thrift, devised by a young Hungarian woman now a visitor in New York City.

A proposed State bill giving towns of more than 10,000 population and $40,000,000 assessed valuation the right to -install town managers somewhat similar to city and village managers was being considered today by the legislative committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

The Columbia fencing team defeated Cornell, 15-12, yesterday for its third consecutive victory. The Lions dropped the foils and the epee matches to the Ithacans, but were considerably stronger with the saber.
Motion pictures contrasting the old and new in life at Rutgers University will feature the annual Alumni Day program on Feb. 22. More than 500 graduates are expected back on the campus.

In a speech describing the Japanese "invasion" of American fishing waters off the Alaskan coast, Senator Lewis B. Schwellenbach of Washington, said tonight that the situation "involves potentialities threatening the peace of the nation."

ACTION has long been recognized as the vitalizing element in pictures, and in an effort to capture exciting action and produce strongly dramatic pictures the most enterprising of the city's amateur photographers are turning to boxing and wrestling bouts as subject matter.

In Washington, in Albany, in the City of New York and in thirty or more States which have enacted housing authority laws, the problem of better homes for the American people is receiving increasing attention.

A FIRST-RATE production of Chekhov's "Three Sisters" and a new light comedy, "The Innocent Party," in which H. M. Harwood has collaborated with Laurence Kirk, have given variety and interest to the past week.
New York milk production went up in January and continues to rise, while farm prices went down, a joint report of the Federal and State Agricultural Departments showed today.

CAIRO.--With the expansion of modern scientific archaeological research, many of the mysteries which have for centuries enshrouded biblical history and. the story of ancient civilization are now gradually being solved.

A plan for leveling peaks and valleys of plant activity, by penalizing machine tool buyers who order during active business periods and regarding those buying when business is slack, has been advanced to customers by a large machine tool building plant.

PINEHURST, N. C.--Weather typical of the northern late Spring prevails. Adding to the outdoor charm and beauty of the Sandhills section, a number of shrubs are already blooming. The Washington Birthday period is receiving attention from cottage residents and hotel representatives at this Midsouth resort.

" The Constitution in Wartime" is the topic which Dr. John A. Krout will discuss at a meeting of the history section of the Scarsdale Woman's Club on Tuesday at 2 P. M. The literature section will hear Constance Murray Greene of Larchmont on Wednesday at 3 P. M., and the Italian section, Miss Electa McKay at 10 A. M., on "The Saints in Art."

The annual junior promenade of Vassar College was held tonight in the Students' Building, where 200 members of the class and their guests danced in a hall decorated in a grape motif with clusters of purple balloons and gold leaves.
All available ships of the fleet will put to sea Monday for three days of manoeuvres, with Admiral Claude C. Bloch commanding from the flagship New Mexico, it was announced today.
A little after 2 o'clock yesterday morning, Patrolmen Griffith Williams and Charles Trainor, passing a diner at 255 Tenth Avenue, heard some one inside shout: "I've been held up."

When William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, reached the fork in the road which turned his face away from the United Mine Workers of America, after a companionship of forty-eight years,
The Borough of Roselle, Union County, N. J., has purchased a tract of eight acres as a site for a new. public school. The property is near the four corners of St. George

A remarkable comeback in the closing minutes of a fiercely waged contest brought the Army basketball team a 46-40 victory over Columbia last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. About 2,500 persons witnessed the struggle, which featured the athletic program of Columbia's Alumni Day.

IN his delightful "Romantic Exiles," published about five years ago and devoted to a portrayal of the Russian revolutionary Herzen and his circle, Mr. Carr (who, incidentally, has written the best critical biography of Dostoevsky available in English) apologized for having done scant justice "to that amazing energumen of revolutionary

Johnny Mize, Cardinal first baseman and one of the club's "big five," signed his 1938 contract today after a conference with Branch Rickey, Cardinal vice president and general manager. Rickey- said "everybody is satisfied" but declined to announce the terms of the agreement.

Travel courses for the study of art, literature and sociology in England, Scotland and Wales, and for the study of modern life and industry in Norway, Sweden and Denmark, have been announced by State Teachers College in Newark.

Jim Marshall, American magazine correspondent injured in the Japanese bombing of the United States gunboat Panay two months ago, said the Japanese celebrated on the night of the attack "with the army boasting of the incident."

Representatives of community chests and councils in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will attend the second of three all-day conferences on Friday at the Hotel Roosevelt on the general subject "Community Planning."

Seven hosiery mills closed for long periods are getting under way again, with the result that more than 2,500 hosiery workers will be back at their jobs here within the next three weeks, it was announced tonight.

It is no trick at all to photograph lightning during a thunderstorm. The camera is simply left open. As a rule the trick works only at night--works, that is, to the satisfaction of the physicist who wants to avoid fogging of the photograph.

MONTREAL. WITH ground radio equipment established and in operation at Winnipeg, Regina, Lethbridge, Cranbrook and Oliver, and to be ready shortly at Vancouver, the main setup of the Trans-Canada Air Lines, providing two-way voice communication between planes and airports, is now practically completed on the western section.

The twentyeighth annual conference of State and local health officers will be held at the State House next Friday in morning, afternoon and evening sessions, and the following day the New Jersey Health Officers Association will meet.
Grain prices a in foreign markets were on the c, down grade today, with trading extremely slow because of the holiday in this country.
A survey of the college baseball situation, centering around possible "alliances" between college coaches and professional clubs relative to the signing of players, was in the making today.

More buildings artistically decorated and properly equipped might be seen in this country, points out Ely Jacques Kahn of the American Institute of Architects, if architects were permitted to supervise the decoration of the buildings which they design.

Moral and spiritual education of modern youth is being neglected by the schools and colleges, Dr. William W. Comfort, president of Haverford College, Haverford, Pa., said at the annual dinner of the Head Masters Association at ChalfonteHaddon Hall Hotel here tonight.
Occasionally the garret of an old Maine farmhouse will yield a copy of the strange Indian Bible translated by Eugene Vetromile for the Penobscot and Micmac tribes of the Abnakis.
W. Nightingall's Silver Bow, a prominent candidate for the Grand National, collapsed and died after falling at the last fence in the Troytown Handicap Steeplechase today.
Lester Cummings of New York and Al Ramsey of Cleveland advanced to the final of the national professional squash racquets championship today in hard-fought matches.

A prediction that Nassau County, L. I., because of its low land costs, will benefit more than any other New York suburban county as a result of passage of the Housing Act Amendment, permitting insurance of 90 per cent mortgages on low-cost houses, was voiced yesterday by Frank J. Fellows, East Hempstead builder.

Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald J. T. Hildyard, Governor of Bermuda, and Lady Hildyard attended a tea dance given today at the Princess Hotel by the United States Consul, Harold L. Williamson, in honor of Lincoln's birthday. About 350 Bermudians, and. resident and visiting Americans, were present.
Coast Guard divisional headquarters reported late today that the freighter Castilla had struck the Sun Oil Tanker Pennsylvania off the North Carolina coast.

Dynamite is opening a path to fortunes in gold on the bottom of the "River of No Return." The river, the Salmon River of Central Idaho, is paved with goldbearing sand washed down from rich veins in neighboring mountains, but only a hardy prospector can shoot its swift rapids by boat.

Miss Elizabeth Haviland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Haviland, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Charles Augustus Whitney Jr. of New York, formerly of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney of Watertown, Mass.

Miss Virginia Caroline Pearson, granddaughter of Mrs. Oscar Pearson of Plainfield, N. J., was marrled yesterday morning to Herbert Daniel Ryan, son of Mrs. Daniel F. Ryan of West Roxbury; Mass., and the late Mr. Ryan, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Alphonsus, West Broadway.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH Snow White and Charlie McCarthy the most engaging characters on the screen today, the industry is looking for further novelties which will prove more popular than the flesh-and-blood glamour children of the cinema.

A testimonial fund in honor of Arturo Toscanini's donation of his services to the Palestine Symphony Orchestra is being raised for the general welfare of the orchestra. About $10,000 has been collected. The Toscanini Testimonial Fund Committee desires to present the full amount to the conductor before he leaves for -Palestine -early in March. Donations to the fund may be sent to Mrs. Morris Loeb, chairman of the committee, 927 Fifth Avenue.
What is said to be the oldest house in Bellport, L. I., has been sold by Osborn Shaw, antiquarian and town historian of Brookhaven. The name of the new owner was not revealed.

The Apawamis Club here held a dinner dance tonight in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The hosts included Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O'Day, Mr. and Mrs. Parker Newhall, Mrs. Morton C. Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Horton, Mr. and Mrs. John Depew, Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Fuller Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pilat and Mr. and Mrs. K. E. Danforth.
The Italian Government today expelled a Hungarian journalist, Imre Barcs, for five years the Rome correspondent of Az Est and other Hungarian papers.

The Yale and Lehigh wrestling teams, undefeated heretofore this season, met in Taylor gymnasium tonight before more than 2,000 spectators, Yale emerging with its first triumph over the Engineers since 1927 by 131/2 to 121/2.
Indifference of women themselves--and not masculine opposition-is chiefly responsible for the slow progress the woman candidate is making the world over in capturing public office.

NASSAU, Bahamas.--An art exhibition will be held in Nassau shortly. The show will be opened by the Governor. The committee responsible for arranging the exhibition is composed mostly of American and Canadian visitors, who are lending valuable paintings from their private collections.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone said today that he would hear arguments March 28 on the motions of sixteen oil companies and thirty executives to vacate the jury verdict which convicted them of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Miss Evelyn Comstock. was married here this afternoon to Francis Watkinson Cole Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Cole, at the home of her mother, Mrs. Elliott M. Comstock. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. B. C. Chandler of St. John's Church, Essex. A reception followed.

To the Art Editor: I READ with interest your article In the Sunday TIMES on the exhibitions in Philadelphia and Worcester. I thought you would be interested to know our policy in relation to prizes. We have no purchase prizes.

In its third attack on a $2,500,000 Reno, Nev., swindling syndicate that had been linked to the principal crime rings west of the Mississippi, the government won from a jury in Federal court yesterday the conviction of William J. Graham and James C. McKay, politically powerful gamblers, and two coJefendants. A fifth man was acquitted.

The ninth annual dance a entertainment of the Press Photo raphers Association of New Yo will be held Friday night at Commodore. New York debutante photographed in various activity. throughout the year by members the association, are reciprocatir through the formation of a cor mittee to promote the event.

A squadron of sixty army planes commanded by Brig. Gen. George H. Brett completed a successful training flight to Guatemala and return today. A cordial reception by officials and residents of Guatemala was reported to have been extended the fliers.

An aggressive Clarkson Tech hockey team rolled back the Orange and Black of Princeton, 8-3. tonight on the Hobey Baker ice before a capacity gathering of some 2,000 persons. Cliff Allen tallied five times for the winning side.

Reflecting concern over how they may rehabilitate dress departments, department store executives are collecting all the information they can on how to correct mistakes, according to veteran road' salesmen.

Fourteen out of thirty-seven de partments of New York and Brook lyn department stores had gains in advertising linage during January, according to the breakdown figures issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc.

Since the name of the first dog was entered in the stud book in 1878, the American Kennel Club has registered 1,215,801 pure-bred dogs, according to an announcement made yesterday by the governing body of the sport in the United States.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Tanenbaum of New Rochelle, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Edna Tanenbaum, to Murray C. Fuerst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Fuerst, also of New Rochelle.

The Haverford College debating team, undertaking a much longer schedule than usual, has participated in two contests already and ten debates are listed during the next two months, including meetings with Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania Thursday.

" Do We Not Bleed?" described by the author, Lance Lanyon, as an ironic melodrama, is opening tomorrow at the Aldwych Theatre. The play tells of two hours of crowded life in an imaginary but recognizable totalitarian State whose Governor is the proprietor of a notorious Jew-baiting journal.
Reaping, brilliant sprinter owned by Mrs. A. M. Creech, ran six furlongs under 122 pounds in 1:11 3-5 today to win the $2,000 added Baton Rouge Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

A joint committee representing the federations of women's clubs in New York has launched, in connection with the forthcoming Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, the first concerted effort to provide the equivalent of a community chest for club use.

Assailing the anen phllosohies of the Roosevelt Administration and charging that "fear is supplanting freedom in the American political mind," John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, called upon Republicans and Democrats alike to resist surrender to governmental domination.

Daniel J. Doherty, National Commander of the American Legion, asserted today that "tidal waves of un-American beliefs and doctrines" were endangering the balance between governmental authority and individual liberty in America.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the dinner dance in aid of the Barat Settlement which has been arranged by members of the junior auxiliary of the organization for next Saturday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's.

I. J. Harvey Jr., president of the Flintkote Company of this city, has submitted two plans to President Roosevelt designed to stimulate housing construction. One plan dealt with the promotion of home repairs.

Builders in Queens and other sections of Long Island are responding promptly to the more liberalized provisions for home buying in the amended housing act and in many of the active development centers enlarged building programs have been planned.

PREENING and singing so that the world may see and hear, the lyrebird has come to the screen in a sound film recently completed for the Australian Government. A decade ago his name was scarcely known to most Australians and certainly the species had not achieved any reputation overseas.

The profits system "is the only economic engine which works successfully," and if it could be released from restrictions imposed by the Administration "the present depression would be over tomorrow," General Hugh S. Johnson declared tonight in a speech before 600 railroad and transportation executives.
Three armed men tonight forced a jewelry store owner, his girl clerk and a salesman to disrobe, robbed the store safe of $10,000 in old gold and jewelry and fled in the owner's automobile.
Mrs. Edna Harrison assumed the lead in the women's tournament for the Hazel Allen Trophy yesterday when she defeated Miss Mildred Peters in the fifth round at the Marshall Chess Club.

Of the 183 social welfare projects of the Junior Leagues of America, 110 are serving children directly and seven through the family, it will be reported to the officers and regional directors of the association, meeting here tomorrow.

One-sixth of the city's population is dependent on some form of relief, a survey indicated yesterday. The public assistance rolls, which now embrace 1,255,000 of New York's 7,470,000 men, women and children, are rising at the rate of 5,000 persons a week, but the total is still 300,000 below the peak of March, 1936.

The Board of Education, continuing its critical attitude toward pending school legislation, has disapproved of twenty-three bills and approved of only six of those affecting the New York City school system, James Marshall,

The academic routine at Princeton University will give ground to extracurricular proceedings for the next ten days on the campus as nearly 1,000 juniors and seniors, representing seventeen private upper class clubs, set about electing "sections" from the sophomore class.

Another step in the Administration's campaign to convince doubters that the United States intends to play a lone hand in the confused world situation was taken today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull made public an exchange of letters between himself and Representative Louis Ludlow of Indiana.

GREAT geysers of soil, smoke and flame rose from the target range at Barksdale Field here the other day as the General Headquarters Air Force demonstrated bombing and machine gun tactics before the Air Corps Tactical School.

Executives of hospital service plans established in sixty key cities of the United States will open their first national convention on Thursday at the headquarters of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the 3-cents-a-day plan operated by the New York organization.

The old Queen City Hotel, long a landmark at the corner of Park Avenue and East Second Street, Plainfield, N. J., has been sold and will be demolished to make way for a one-story taxpayer, it was announced yesterday.

When several hundred Hamilton graduates and former students returned to the campus for this week-end to witness the induction of about seventy-five pledges into ten fraternities, they witnessed also the passing of one of the age-old traditions of the college.

The Milbrook Country Club, Greenwich, was the scene of a "Hawaiian night" this evening, the ballroom being transformed into a tropical setting. Miss Renie Roberts was in charge of the supper dance and appeared in native Hawaiian dances.
Wellesley College alumnae of this city and the metropolitan area will meet in the Grand Ballroom of the Biltmore on Feb. 26 for the annual luncheon of the New York Wellesley Club. Befor the luncheon.
Valuable time has been saved and many educational failures have been avoided at Boston University the past six years by means of counseling of students.

Jacob Boyko, former president of the Russian Orthodox Society of New York, was found dead last night in his apartment at 403 East Forty-eighth Street. Police said death was due to natural causes. His age was 65.

Four new marks were added to the Empire's record pages today as track and field stars wound up the third British Empire games, greatest recordshattering -meet since the competition was originated eight years ago.

Sportsmen and conservationists from all parts of the country are arriving for the opening here Monday morning of the third North American Wild Life Conference. All sessions of the four-day conference will be open to the public and an average attendance of about 3,000 is expected.

A new method of controlling exchange without disturbing the international monetary situation is believed by exporters here to have been uncovered by Mexico in imposing high, temporary tariff rates on imported products on Jan. 19.

Chile will not export wheat even if there is a surplus in the forthcoming harvest, it was announced today. This action was taken by Minister of Agriculture Maximo Valdes because hastily granted export permits issued last year created a scarcity in the country and it was necessary to import cereals when they were most expensive.

IN 1872 Fantin-Latour executed one of his characteristic can vases; "Coin de Table," in which he portrayed artists and poets of his acquaintance. Verlaine, then about 28, is shown seated at the head of a table. On his left Arthur Rimbaud, a boy of 18 with wonderful eyes and a disdainful mouth, turns his back upon the rest of the company with small regard for manners or composition.

" Ten Commandments of Good-Will" have been issued by the National Conference of Jews and Christians in connection with its fifth annual "Brotherhood Day," to be celebrated during the week of Washington's Birthday.

As far as the New Deal is concerned, President Roosevelt's conference of small business men was a "major blunder," DeWitt McKinley Emery, founder and president of the National Small Business Men's Association, declared yesterday.

State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee reported yesterday that 5,876 drivers' licenses were revoked in 1937, an increase of 42 per cent over 1936 and the largest number for any year in the department's history.
Sports circles intimated today that financial difficulties resulting from the Chinese incident may force Japan to default from the 1938 Davis Cup tennis competition.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Trenchard Wood of New Brighton, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Wood, to Vincent H. Callahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry V. CallIahan of BrooklYn.
O. G. Christgau, convention manager of the Anti-Saloon League from Washington, D. C., told reporters today that he expected a decided swing against the legalized liquor traffic in the next two years.

Recording instruments here were at variance on whether the trembling felt in the far South Side and sections of Northern Indiana at about 12:30 A. M. today was caused by a slight earthquake. The seismograph at Loyola University registered a quake; that at the University of Chicago did not.
Directed immigration controlled by a special commission is among the suggestions advanced in a legal project regulating immigration entry into Brazil drawn up by a special committee.

Two Brooklyn youths, who stowed away on the Queen of Bermuda and were not discovered until a few hours before the ship docked this morning, were returned to the United States on the same ship this afternoon and their hopes of finding work in Bermuda dashed.

Six-year-old Ronald Savelet, of 1,641 Taylor Avenue, the Bronx, learned a new trick on his bicycle early last night, By using it as a stepladder, he found he was tall enough to pull the handle on a fire alarm box at Garfield and Mead Streets, the Bronx..
The observations in the article that jorlows are based on a recent visit to Hitler's Reich. The author studied in Germany in the years immediately preceding the advent of the Nazi regime.

The Ralph L. Spotts Memorial Trophy, which for a number of years has featured the Lincoln's Birthday shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club, was taken by Frank A. Scola with a perfect score of 100 straight targets yesterday.

The annual sale under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital will take. place Wednesday and Thursday at 2,000 Broadway, at Sixty-eighth Street, for the benefit of the philanthropic activities of the organization.

Five components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity were lower for the week ended Feb. 5, and the adjusted index has declined to 81.4 from 82.2, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Feb. 6, 1937, the index stood at 101.2.
Some kinds of lily seed can be sown successfully any month of the year. February and March are two of the best months for sowing many of the reliable, easy-to-raise lilies.
The Propaganda Ministry today ordered the German film industry to make a major effort to conquer the Spanish market and also South America as far as iS possible.

Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that Continental Shares, Inc., was "flourishing" when he and W. R. Burwell lost control of it to a group of banks in Cleveland in 1931. He was chairman and Mr. Burwell was president.
The defense in the trial of eleven Nationalists for the slaying of a provincial policeman in a riot last Palm Sunday was completed when pleadings were made today.

The Unemployment Compensation Commission of New Jersey has on deposit $33,317,471.74 in the Federal unemployment compensation trust fund, it was announced this week by Harold G. Hoffman, executive director. This includes a deposit of $1,900,000 forwarded last week to the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia.

Seven members of the graduating class of February, 1938, at City College have won major and minor insignia from the Student Council for prominence in student life, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men.

In asking Japan to state her intentions regarding the size of future battleships and in warning General Francisco Franco of reprisals in case of further attacks on British shipping, the British Government seemed to adopt a somewhat stiffer attitude, which brought cheers in Parliament.

Sam Snead, the West Virginian who has developed into the home-run slugger of golf, and Jimmy Dremaret of Houston, Texas, will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of he $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

William Willett, who served two terms as a Democratic member of the House of Representatives, 1906 10, was found dead yesterday morning of a heart attack in his room in the Hotel McAlpin. He had returned on Friday from a trip to Washington in the interests of a realty organization, with which he had been associated since 1918. He was 68 years old.
Headmaster Boyd Edwards of Mercersburg Academy announced today Commencement Day honors as follows: Valedictorian-William E. Hense Jr. of Summit, N. J.

There are many splendid cut flowers; but in a few days they are gone. Not so with the everlasting or immortelles. They give cheer and color and comfort, and last. They have been improved in recent years, keeping pace with the marigolds, cosmos and others.

The seventeenth annual theatre party of the Tiny Tim Society of the House of St. Giles the Cripple will be held the night of Feb. 28. The play chosen for the event is Ibien's "A Doll's House" 'at the Broadhurat Theatre, with Ruth Gordon and Dennis' King in the leading roles.

The decrease, shown by Thursday's weekly Bank of France statement, of t 3,127,000,000 francs in its gold reserve attracted attention. It was explained by the Minister of Finance as due to transfer of that amount (about $102,000,000 at present exchange rates) from the bank's reserve to the Government's Exchange Equalization Fund.

The French liner Ile de France sailed yesterday with 311 passengers, including several notables in the world of music and entertainment. Cliff Reid, producer for RKO Pictures, sailed with his wife in search of film talent in Paris and London.
Staging an 8-point rally in the last three minutes of play, Amherst defeated the Tufts five, 40-35, tonight.

RED jerseys and white flash back and forth across the gleaming hardwood floor in an ever-changing pattern of color. An inflated leather ball flicks to And fro with stabbing rapidity. It whirls to one man and he passes it to another.

The Fine Arts Federation of New York, composed of delegates of seventeen representative art organizations, issued an attack last week on four bills which have been inproduced at Washington, all of which, in one form or another, would set up either a permanent department of art or a permanent bureau of fine arts as a part of the United States Government.

The "Big Apple," a dance fad which combines most of the modern dancing eccentricities from the "Jazz and Gin Era" to the present, was linked by police yesterday with the theft of fifty automobiles in Brooklyn in the last year.
WALTER DAMROSCH'S "The Man Without a Country" will be heard Thursday night for the first time in the Metropolitan's Winter season. Complete opera and concert programs for the current week follow:

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Western won Reserve scored an upset victory by over the Syracuse five tonight, win- last ning 34-32, before 2,000 fans.

Fifteen student "apprentices," members of the two upper classes, have been chosen from 123 nominees by the University of Pennsylvania to study State and local government through first-hand contact with agencies in this and other communities.

Erected at a cost of $500,000 with Federal aid, this city's newThomas A. Edison Vocational School, in Summer Street, was dedicated this week at a ceremony in which the Board of Education, city officials and representatives of the State Department of Public Instruction participated. The school was opened last Fall.

The text of the Japanese reply to the notes from the United States, Britain and France requesting information on future naval construction follows: It may be recalled that at the last London Naval Conference the Japanese Government proposed in earnest their desire to bring about a drastic reduction in naval armament,

THE author of the Federal Theatre's fifth edition of the Living Newspaper, ". . . one third of a nation...." Arthur Arent, is more of a direct product of Broadway than are most who lay claim to this distinction.

Former Mayor John P. O'Brien sailed yesterday with Mrs. O'Brien on the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia for Nassau in the Bahamas. He said he had been too busy with his law practice to attend a session of the new City Council.
There has evidently been a big clean-up in the Foreign Trade Commissariat, whose chief, A. P. Rosengoltz, early last Summer was appointed head of the government Reserves Department.
General Waldomiro de Castilho Lima died at Petropolis today at the age of 65. Born in Sao Borja, Rio Grande do Sul, the home town of President Getulio Vargas, he was an uncle of Mme. Vargas.
As the first step in the "increased dynamics" of German foreign policy following Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "second revolution" and the appointment

Air conditioning demand in the last six years has increased so rapidly that power consumption estimates based on the trend before 1932 must be revised to keep pace with the industry's growth, pointed out Dr. Willis H. Carrier, chairman of the board of the Carrier Corportion.

BADEN BADEN, the picturesque watering place twenty miles south of Vienna, which was one of Beethoven's favorite country resorts and where he wrote part of the Ninth symphony and a quantity of his other later works,

Descendants of neighbors of the Thomas Lincoln family, who lived in a crude cabin here a century and a quarter ago, gathered today on Lincoln City's highest hilltop to honor the memory of the mother whom Abraham Lincoln, as a boy of 9, helped to bury.

Leading Republicans at Lincoln Day dinners throughout the country joined last night in inviting Democrats dissatisfied with the Roosevelt New Deal policies to vote with them in the Congressional elections of this year and the Presidential election of 1940.

Forty years from now, despite our declining birth rate, our colleges will have twice as many students as they have today, and junior colleges will quadruple their attendance, according to a forecast, based on present education trends, presented in The Journal of Higher Education, by Dr. R. M. Hughes, president emeritus of Iowa State College.

Manhattan's swimmers defeated Lafayette today, 38-37. Trailing by six points going into the final event, the 400yard relay, the visitors gained seven points in one of the most exciting finishes ever seen in the local pool.

Yale's 58-to-17 victory over the Army swimming team today was featured by the creation of two new Yale records, both by Joe Burns of the Eli squad. In the 100-yard back-stroke leg of the 300-yard medley race, Burns covered the distance In 60.1 seconds.

THERE is a quality in this story which raises it above the level of the average of light fiction. George, the English pacifist preacher, with the hair and eyelashes of an actor and the burning fanaticism of his Cornish ancestry, is pitiful despite his cruelty. His child wife, half French, wholly infatuated with George's magnetism, is only a trifle less credible.

The marriage of Miss Sarah. Alice Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Price Patterson, to George Anderson Pagels of Albany, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Pagels of Chicago, took place here this evening at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Dr. Robert M. Russell of the Larchmont Avenue Church performed the ceremony.

The faculty of Skidmore College struck a note of revelry when, dressed in costumes of the early 1900's, they gave a benefit performance this week for twentyeight freshmen whose dormitory, South Hall, was burned during the Christmas recess.
The Insurgent army north of Teruel dugin today on both banks of the Alfambra River and sent hardriding cavalry patrols east from their newly conquered territory in preparation for a new drive.

The state Department is asking American business to make tariff consessions on British imports as an importantt preliminary to negotiation of the proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Great Britain.
Twenty years ago a British ship foundered in the Mediterranean Sea, hit by a German torpedo. Aboard the S. S. Garonhead were Captain J. Hanna and his brother, Lieutenant J. Hanna, of the Royal Navy.

The plight of the four Russian scientists and their dog on an ice floe off the coast of Greenland, after having drifted from the North Pole ever since May 21, has diverted attention from the icebreakers Sadko, Sedov and Malygin.

Borrowers from the Home Owners Loan Corporation have paid back more than $350,000,000 in principal on their loans and more than $400,000,000 in interest, according to a report just drawn up by the official staff.

Miss Anne Harriet G. Peck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Peck of 527 Morris Avenue, was married to John W. Herdegen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herdegen, also of this city, at the home of the bride's parents this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Stewart M. Robinson. pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church.
The Thames River, swollen by an eighty-mile-an-hour gale, began to overflow its banks in the heart of London today. Scores of families living along the waterfront were warned to be ready to evacuate.

Hugh Quinn, whose right to represent Queens as a Councilman is being investigated by a committee of the City Council, will call his wife as a witness when the inquiry is resumed tomorrow at City Hall.

THE HUMAN SITUATION. The Gifford Lectures in the University of Glasgow 1935-37. By W. Macneile Dixon. New York: Longmans Green d Co. $5. THIS volume attempts to arrive at a true knowledge of man and the universe of which man is a part.

A national committee against the use of Japanese goods was announced yesterday by the Committee for a Boycott Against Japanese Aggression, with offices at 5 Maiden Lane, and an appeal was made for donations.
The, average college youth spends much less money today than his predecessor spent in the prosperous years of 1923-29, according to Dr. T. T. Jones, dean of men at the University of Kentucky.

So many unexpected things turn up in Christopher Morley's ancient Troy that a reader is not surprised when in one of the later chapters of "The Trojan Horse" he comes across an ancient Trojan militaro-economic expert with his charts.
HUNGARY is to revolt against the Treaty of Trianon, which deprived her of more than twothirds of her pre-war territory and three-fifths of her population.
Concentrated flood waters kept numerous Central California lowland areas inundated tonight and intensified their threat to the agriculturally rich Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta.

A jury that sat through the monthlong trial of Paul A. Wright for the slaying of his wife and friend, tearfully convicted him today on two manslaughter counts that could send him to prison for twenty years.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Frank M. Townley of 1,227 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Frances Louise Townley, to Dr. Donald R. Keller of 899 Park Avenue, New York, and West Hampton Beach, L. I.
Miss Irene M. Lapsley, a supervisor for the Richmond Social Service Bureau lived for a week on food which cost $1.50--an average of seven cents a meal and today was "glad it's over."

No pupil has been injured by automobile accidents in Mount Kisco for eight years since the organization of a squad of older boys as special traffic policemen, according to a check-up by H. M. Jennings, Superintendent of Education. These young policemen, equipped with badges, police caps and black rain coats, go on duty four times a day to protect children going to and from school.

The mining share market, especially the medium-price gold issues, advanced in the short session of the Toronto Exchange today, while the industrials weakened about a half point in the index. As the market in New York was closed in. observance of Lincoln's birthday, action in the industrial section here 'lacked leadership. The turnover was 599,000 shares.

THE subject of the Irish in America is an interesting albeit a neglected one. Certainly the most familiar fact of Irish immigration is that, following the Black Hunger of the Eighteen Forties, the Catholic South Irish poured into the States in hordes to build our railroads and provide us with the Pat-and-Mike stories now happily out of fashion and forgotten. Less familiar, perhaps,

An increased demand by employers for college trained women with a knowledge of foreign languages has lifted that study to high place among the subjects favored by students of woman's colleges, according to a faculty survey at Georgian Court College here.

Mayor La Guardia urged the adoption of the Child Labor Amendment, which is due to come to a vote in the Legislature shortly, as the "only way to meet the problem," in a statement issued yesterday at City Hall.
ATURO TOSCANINI, whose directorship of the NBC Sym phony concerts was scheduled to conclude with the tenth in the series on Feb. 26, will lead an additional Wagnerian broadcast on March 5.
Mexican Contemporaries-Fifteen contemporary Mexican painters are represented in an exhibition that will remain at the Valentine Gallery until the end of the week.

Led by Captain Bob Benn, who threw in 18 points, Hofstra College downed the New York. Aggies tonight, 39-27, after gaining a 28-11 advantage during the first twenty minute's of play. Aaren Proct was tops for the Aggies with 12 markers.

LAKE PLACID. --The coming week Wi11 see some of the most important events of the Winter sports calendar at this Adirondack center. Carrying over to the Washington's Birthday holiday, the skiing and skating events planned are expected to draw caDacitv crowds.

A dinner dance will be given by members of the St. Agatha Alumnae Association in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, on Tuesday. Proceeds will be used for the association's memorial scholarship fund.
Harry V. Keep, president of the Keep Shirt Company, 5 East Forty-fourth Street, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home here. He was a native of Mississippi.

HARRlBURG, Pa. IT is only coincidence that beaver trapping begins Tuesday of this week in Pennsylvania while the third annual Wild Life Conference meets scarcely 100 miles away in Baltimore. Conservation will be the order of the day in Baltimore;
William Richard Tompkins of Gallatin, Tenn., shot himself fatally, the police said today, after ending a telephone call to Miss Dora Nunsell in Los Angeles with the words: "I'm going to kill myself."

An attack on the legality of the indictment on which he is held in bail of $200,000 appeared yesterday as the next move by J. Richard Davis, disbarred lawyer and reputed heir to the policy racket Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer once headed.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., with Mrs. Rockefeller and their son Winthrop, was the guest tonight of the employes of the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at the annual show given by the employes at the Masonic Temple here.

The six-story walk-up apartment building containing twenty- four three-room suites at 126 East Second Street has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investor. It is on a lot 26 by 102 by 122 feet in the rear of First Houses,
