With the pressure lifted from his shoulders, Glenn Cunningham put the pressure on his flying feet tonight and matched the fourth fastest indoor mile ever run.
The Department of Commerce announced today that imports into the United States from tradeagreement countries increased 18 per cent in 1937.

Increased interest in debating is evidenced at Wells College by the widened program of activities of the Wells Debating Club this year. Under the leadership of the president, Marion Kamin, and the debate coach, Professor Eleanor Luse, the Wells group is participating in the program formulated by New York State college debating coaches at a fall conference.

The following is the text of the note addressed to United States Ambassador- Joseph C. Grew today by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota replying to a protest regarding infringements on American interests in China:

No more Cain's warehouse: no more mournful gags at dismal first-nights. For Patsy Cain's red-brick mausoleum in Forty-first Street has gone out of the stage burial business. When the last curtain dropped on a theatrical production,

Sweet Briar students have spent 9,062 more hours of study in the library thus far this year than at the corresponding time last year. Sixty-one thousand three hundred and seventy-eight hours of work have been done in the library since the opening of college by the 450 students.

The government of Costa Rica has engaged a Chilean expert to direct reorganization of the taxation and revenue system so as to provide a modern, equitable system and additional revenue following reduction of the export tax on coffee.
The McCormick Steamship Company is resuming its regular coastwise schedule of two sailings per week between California and the Columbia River.

Dealers and traders in securities over the counter, from the large underwriters and municipal bond men to the small operator, have fought in the last two weeks what to them was the most important battle in the history of their business.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Otis Luscombe Jr. of this place, and Woods Hole, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsey Tobey Luscombe, to James Fletcher Chace, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Freeborn Chace of New York.

John L. Lewis left Philadelphia today without the prize for which he came here yesterday to bid-a plcge that Democtatic leaders would give Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers of America, a major place on the party ticket in Pennsylvania.

WHO would have thoughtthat is, until "Snow White and the Secen Dwarfs" came alongthat the film industry would suddenly find itself regarding the lowly animated cartoon not only as a medium possessing vast artistic potentialities but (much more importent!) as a mine of
HONOLULU is staging its ninth annual Malihini golf tournament next Tuesday. Malihini is the Hawaiian word for newcomer. Play in the tournament is restricted to vacationists in the Pacific playground.

Familiar phrases and enduring arguments resounded this week in the big caucus chamber of the Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill. That exclusively feminine dispute on the blessing or catastrophe of an equal rights amendment to the Constitution had flared again, in prospect of Monday's vote in the Senate Judiciary Committee.
A collection of valentines of the nineteenth century is being exhibited here by the Newark Museum and will be on view Monday, St. Valentine's Day.
Charles Fisher's "letter to the editor" in this column last Sunday seems to have aroused the cruising skippers and small boat adventurers to the certain fact that another Summer can't be far off.

Mr. and Mrs. William Burr Chapman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Lathrop Chapman, to John Hollister of Beverley, Mass., son of Raymond A. Hollister of Oshkosh, Wis., and the late Mrs. Hollister. The wedding will take place the latter part of April.
Once again a filly shows as best of the Hialeah Park juveniles, for Charlotte Girl maintained an unbeaten record in her decisive capture of Nursery Stakes No. 2 before 15,000 persons today.
Two criminally insane patients, one of them Paul Harrison, described as a "dangerous hammer killer," escaped tonight from the Illinois Security Hospital.
After having been held by the same family for more than two centuries, a 450-acre farm estate near Warwick, N. Y., has just changed ownership.

ROCKEFELLER CENTER nears completion; the last three of the fourteen buildings called for in the plan are to rise within the next few months. "The largest building project ever undertaken by private capital" will then be accomplished, and John D. Rockefeller Jr., its author and backer, can dust off his hands and say. "That's that."

John Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Legendre and Mr. and Mrs. Mario Pansa gave a cocktail party today at Villa Marina. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Stone, Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Tower, Baron A. Nunziante, Morris Legendre, Lord and Lady Stanley,

For the .fourth straight year and the ninth time in the last ten years, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School athletes, coached by George Eastment, won the -senior team championship at the eleventh annual city Cathofic Iigh Schools Athletic Association track and field games at the Thirteenth, Regient Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

Public officials and others prominent in the Democratic party are taking an active part in the completing of arrangements for the annual supper dance of the Democratic Junior League which will be held on Saturday in the Madison Room of Biltmore.

Downsbury Manor, well -known estate at Ridgefield, Conn., which was developed by the late Colonel E. M. Knox, hat manufacturer, has been acquired by Downsbury Manor, Inc., a group of New York and Connecticut business men, for use as a sports club.

THE Metropolitan's "surprise party," which is still under serious consideration, will take place, if at all, on the last Sunday of the regular season. This would be March 20. Most of the major singers have said that they can and will be ready to join in the festivities, and the only factor holding up a definite decision is arrangement for some rehearsal time.

BRUSSELS.-The increase of the number of cubs in litters among lions and the growing boldness of elephants in the Congo have led the Belgian Government to appoint two or three "hunting lieutenants" or super-gamekeepers, who are paid officials, while a corps of honorary hunting lieutenants will be formed among the long-time Belgian residents of the Congo to help them.

Operating behind heavy artillery barrages, Japanese troops succeeded yesterday in crossing and establishing themselves on the north bank of the Hwai River opposite Linhwaikwan and Pengpu at a cost of heavy casualties, according to reports from Suchow.

" State approval of deception, fraud and piracy" will be the result of enactment of the TradeMark Bill now before the New Jersey Legislature, according to a letter sent to Governor A. Harry Moore and members of the Legislature by Johnson Johnson, New Brunswick manufacturers of surgical dressings, the text of which was made public here yesterday.

Count Alfred Monteverde, 35, Portuguese nobleman who planned a non-stop New York-Lisbon flight last year, and Miss Betty Flugel were injured in an auto accident today in which their companion John Wesley Mackelfresh, 32, Cincinnati, was killed.

Combat experiences of the field forces fighting over the world's battle grounds of the past three or four years have had a strong, but as yet indeterminate, effect on the reasoning of the general staff of the United States Army.

The Confectionery and Tobacco Fair Trade Commission opened a campaign yesterday to encourage candy manufacturers to establish definite resale prices in the metropo'itan area under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law.

Representative Teigan of Minne sota asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to "make .a fair investigation" into the qualifications of Joseph Chapman to serve as a trustee of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Saulte Ste. Marie Railway Company.
A bronze tablet at a busy corner in downtown Indianapolis draws attention to the place where the rail-splitter President once split an infinitive on the way to the White House.

Two important items on the housewife's list-butter and eggsare showing a steady reduction in price and last week tub butter dropped to the unprecedented seasonal low of 35 cents a pound. Packaged butter, always about 3 cents higher than the tub variety, has also gone down in price.

A schedule of debates on the topic: "Resolved, that the National Labor Relations Board should be empowered to enforce arbitration in all industrial disputes," will occupy the debating team of Upsala College until April 24, according to an announcement today by college officials..

Following its custom of the last five years, the Chamber of Commerce and Civics of the Oranges and Maplewood is receiving nominations for the "citizen who has rendered outstanding service" during 1937 in those communities.

The possibility of a second payless pay day next Tuesday dawned today for 19,000 city and county employes as a result of the Council's failure to unravel the 1938 budget snarl. Meanwhile, it was disclosed that more than 2,500 persons on pensions have been without income for two months.

Ingersoll Bowditch, trustee and treasurer of the Faulkner Hospital and a member of the Boston Hospital Council, died yesterday after illness of two weeks at the age of 62. He lived at 32 Woodlawn Road, Jamaica Plain.

Further testimony intended to show that Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl's criminal acts were the result of temporary insanity induced by the smoking of marijuana cigarettes was introduced today, completing the defense of the 20-year-old girl on trial in Common Pleas Court for the hold-up murder of William Barhorst, bus driver, in Belleville on Dec. 21.

Miss Eliza Morton, daughter of Mrs. J. E. Cope Morton of Devon and of the late Mr. Morton, was married this afternoon to Dr. Willis Cadwalader Gerhart, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Milton Gerhart Jr. of Bala-Cynwyd. The Rev. Richard H. Gurley, rector,

As long as the majority of teachers view their profession as a "joy" and not a "trade," the future of our ancient and our most recent foundations is secure, President James B. Conant of Harvard University asserted this morning in a convocation address before-nearly a thousand Williams College students,
CZECHOSLOVAKIA has released two stamps, 50-haleru green and 1-korona light red, commemorating -the nation's Winter sports of the national Sokols, held at Tatra from Feb. 6 through 13.
Wesleyan easily defeated Connecticut State College in a swimming meet today, 48 to 27, the Cardinals winning first place in six of the nine events.

Catekill community is looking forward to celebrating Washington's Birthday in gala fashion with the mid-Hudson hockey championship tourney. Entered in the tournament in addition to Woodstoek there will be the Newburgh teams,, Falcons, St. Nick's and Twin Oaks. Kingston and Poughkeepsie will-send aggregations, also Tannersville, Saugerties and Hudson.
NEW YORKER, author, magazine editor and officer in the World War, Kendall Banning was well qualified to turn out an informative, compact and readable book about the United States Military Academy.
The recent conference of "little Business" men, fair from being handpicked, represented a fair crosssection of the business men of the nation,

Ten veterans of the Grand Army of the Republic, "Boys in Blue," whose ages average 92, last night attended the annual Lincoln dinner of the G. A. R. Allied Organizations at the Masonic Club, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Bad boys come from bad homes. So runs the popular mind. But is the dictum true? Dr. Nathaniel D. M. Hirsch, formerly director of Wayne County Clinic for Juvenile Delinquency and now State director of the United Public Health Survey, examines the question in a recently published monograph,

Mounting evidence supports the view that the Administration is seriously considering a revival of pump-priming, but this time on a self-liquidating basis instead of spending through the Works Progress Administration or some other method of relief from which funds are unrecoverable.
The St. Paul's School hockey team gained custody of the coveted Hobey Baker perpetual trophy for a year by defeating the Princeton freshman sextet at the school rink today, 4 to 3.
WITH two shows on Broadway, others in the offing, Jed Harris is in the picture again, which means that some of the old excitement fills the air once more.

" The thing that distinguishes the traditional college from the experimental institution is an adherence to purely academic interests," said President Mildred H. McAfee of Wellesley College in an address Friday night on "the educational policies of Wellesley." She was speaking before 200 graduates attending the annual business session of the alumnae council.

AT a meeting of the Greater New York chapter of the National Aeronautic Association, to. be held at 8 P. M. Tuesday at the Hotel Roosevelt, the Airhoppers Gliding and Soaring Club of New York will offer the first of a series of lectures on soaring, in an effort to stimulate this sport in the metropolitan area.
General John Macauley Palmer of Kansas City conceded today that Abraham Lincoln did interfere with his Civil War generals, but said that the only criticism should be that it did not come soon enough.
General Alberto Pariani, Under-Secretary of War, today directed the army to adopt the "Roman step," or "goose step, which has been taken up by the Blackshirts.
The Federal Government received up to January 31 $723,542,251 in taxes under the Social Security and Railroad Retirement Acts, according to the Treasury's monthly report.

Describing the New Deal era as "the five lost years," Representative Charles A. Halleck of Rensselaer, N. Y., called here tonight for a national crusade to re-establish "the fundamental principles of American government under the Constitution.
Delayed buying of Spring wash goods by both wholesalers and retailers will produce a delivery jam of important dimensions next month, according to market opinion yesterday.

Deep in Manhattan, within sound of the rumble of the Third Avenue elevated and the roar of midtown traffic, 'stands an unpretentious, aging, gray-red building which houses the most advanced unit of New York City's school system, the Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades.

Further industrialization of the Whippany Junior High School by the introduction of a modified platoon plan on a "half workshop and half academic" program, has been authorized by the Hanover Township Board of Education.
The stock market closed the fiveday business week with a small net gain, but any satisfaction over the recovery was dulled by the fact that trading was extremely light.
After reacting from an initial advance, cotton rallied again later today and the final prices -were steady 5 to 8 points net higher.

The five-story commercial building at 20 Fulton Street, southeast corner of Front Street, covering a plot 53.9 by 56 feet, will be sold in foreclosure proceedings tomorrow in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady.
ACCORDING to Miss Brande, her correspondent is an 18year-old goddaughter at tending Blank College, who has involved her English teacher, a Miss Greer, in a singular heresy:

Miss Eleanor Lydecker, a grandniece of the late New York State Senator Clarence Lexow of the Lexow Investigating Committee, was married here tonight in the Second Reformed Church to Winchester Dorr Smith, son of Arthur Valleau Smith, also of Hackensack, and the late Mrs. Smith.

Mercersburg Academy will celebrate the annual midwinter, weekend, beginning next Thursday and running through Sunday. The high spot of the celebration will be reached on Saturday night with the annual intersociety debate between Washington Irving and John Marshall Literary Societies.

The earthquake that has just shaken the National Socialist regime and the last tremors of which are still reverberating through the lower levels of the affected organizations as well as the German populace generally, has now quieted sufficiently to permit clearer and more confident appraisal of the new political contours of the Third Reich.

Declaring that Abraham Lincoln, if alive today, would be ashamed of the leadership of the Republican party, Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont asserted last night that, if this leadership continued to fail the people, there would be a permanent third party.

Cornell swimmers defeated Penn State, 55-20, today in the first meet ever held in the old Armory pool. Penn State won only one event, the diving contest. Cornell was paced by Bob Cloyes, who contributed first places in the 50 and 100 yard free style races.
New staffs for the Wesleyan University newspaper and literary magazine were recently chosen by the publications board. The Argus, bi-weekly newspaper, is ending its seventieth year of publication.
Frank Collins, executive vice president of the National Supply Company, died today in his home after a lingering illness at the age of 67. He also was president of the Toledo Pipe Threading Company.

The first semi-public demonstration of newly developed facsimile equipment designed by engineers of the R. C. A. Manufacturing Company, Camden, N. J., is scheduled to be given tomorrow at the annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters at the Willard Hotel, Washington, it was announced yesterday.
Scholastic honors have been accorded to 244 students at Manhattan College, it was announced yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar, upon the completion of the dean's list for the Fall term.
The thirteenth annual ball of the New York City Panhellenic will be held on March 5-in the grand ballroom of the -Ritz-Carlton under the chairmanship of Mrs. Cecil C. Briggs.

Rear Admiral David Potter, U.S.N., of Philadelphia and Mrs. Potter are at the Vanderbilt. Mildred, Countess of Gosford; Lady Mary Acheson, J. Ridgely Carter and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Carter, who have been at the St. Regis, have departed for Richmond, Va., and Charleston, S. C.

THE League of American Writers is offering $1,000 in prizes for student compositions on the subject: "The anti-Fascist struggle in Spain today in its relation to the general welfare of the American citizen of tomorrow."

The 148th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers will begin here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street and will continue through Friday.

STOCKHOLM. A SHIP with bulging sails stands on a quay in a Stockholm waterfront, ready to embark for America. King Gustav V of Sweden has been one of the first to come down to see it, and all through this wintry, sunless day visiting delegations and the city populace have passed by to take a look.
McGill University advanced into a tie with Queens for the lead in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League race by defeating the University of Toronto, 4-2, in a rugged game today.

ALTHOUGH Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" is set in Southern New Hampshire near Mount Monadnock, the New England aspect of his play goes deeper than that. His detached and speculative point of view conveys the New England rhythm.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Howland of 419 East Fifty-seventh Street, daughter of Mrs. Clarence Lincoln Howland of Fleetwood, N. Y., and the late Mr. Howland, to James Thrall Soby of Farmington, Conn., son of Mrs. Charles Soby of Hartford, took place here yesterday at noon in the chapel of Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal.

Cornell swimmers defeated Penn State, 55-20, today in the first meet ever held in the old Armory pool. Penn State won only one event, the diving contest. Cornell was paced by Bob Cloyes, who contributed first places in the 50 and 100 yard free style races.
New staffs for the Wesleyan University newspaper and literary magazine were recently chosen by the publications board. The Argus, bi-weekly newspaper, is ending its seventieth year of publication.

A FORMER newsboy will soon take up his residence in London as American Ambassador to the Court of St. James. Poets, historians, publishers, statesmen and editors heretofore have been named to head our most important diplomatic mission, and family lineage often has played a part in their selection. Joseph P. Kennedy is very different from all his predecessors and perhaps his appointment means a new type of diplomacy.

The Government Reorganization Bill introduced by Senator Byrnes of South Carolina Jan. 27 was ordered favorably reported with amendments today by the Senate Select Committee on Government Organization, of which Mr. Byrnes is chairman.

LOS ANGELES. TRANS-CANADA AIR LINES recently ordered six additional Lockheed planes, making a total of fifteen scheduled for delivery to the Canadian Government's new aircraft-operating organization, Carl B. Squier, sales manager of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, announced. The TransCanada fleet will include five Electras and ten of the Lockheed type known as Model 14.
PERSONS IN HIDING. By J. Edgar Hoover. 318 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $2.50. IT is time that Mr. Hoover gave his ghost some fresh material. This book is washed over and dimmed by banalities.
ON Good Friday last, the Boston Symphony Orchestra gave a special pension fund concert. The "Passion According to St. Matthew" of Bach was chosen for the occasion. Serge Koussevitzky directed.

Official feeling at Yale Is that the nine colleges, established in the last decade and completed four years ago, have surpassed the highest hopes of their founders. Views expressed informally today by alumni, undergraduates, and faculty members affirmed that in every way the colleges have become so essentially a part of Yale that the undergraduates would now feel lost without them.
Miss Fancy Benedict Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jones Harrison, was married here today to Eugene Franklin O'Connor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. E. F. O'Connor of Garden City, L. I.

SUCCESSFUL LIVING. By W. Beran Wolfe. 180 pp. New York: Farrar Rinehart. $2. IN his first paragraph Dr. Wolfe, drawing on his knowledge and experience as psychiatrist and author, says succinctly: "I have attempted to provide a plan for successful living."

North China should be developed by joint participation by Chinese, Japanese and Americans, and, far-fetched as this may sound at present, it is a possibility for the not-distant future, according to Baron Kishichiro Okura, head of the vast Okura industrial and financial empire of Japan.

More than 1,000,000 persons have enrolled in hospital insurance systems throughout the nation in five years. When executives of these services assemble in New York on Thursday for a three-day conference at the offices of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, they hope to chart a course of expansion which will bring the number of subscribers to 10,000,000 by 1942.

A record total of 32,536 aliens seeking advice on citizenship through the naturalization aid service offices of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education was helped last year, Gustav A. Stumpf, project administrator, announced yesterday in making public his annual report.
A panorama of New Jersey life, reflected in folklore as dramatically as in industry, is being unfolded at the State exposition now in progress at Newark.
William N. McNair, the one-time steer riding Mayor of Pittsburgh, today announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Close to 3,000 Columbia University graduates gathered yesterday on Morningside Heights for a reunion dedicated to the School of Architecture. Many of them, attending the alumni federation luncheon in John Jay Hall, heard a greeting from Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,

Judge Robert V. Kinkead of Jersey City, judge of the Court of Common Pleas. in Hudson County, will serve for the second consecutive season as chairman of the National Committee for the Passion play, "Veronica's Veil," it was announced here today by the Rev. Conrad Eiben, founder and producer of the play.

The little motor ship Romanica, formerly the Vergana, has sailed away to pursue her strange trade of killing sea lions off Asuncion Island, 600 miles south, and bring them here to be made into dog and cat food.
Labor organizations here will oppose any move to establish a camp of the Amerika-Deutschen Volksbund in this district, union leaders indicated today.
This purely residential community took steps yesterday to discourage itinerant merchants, traveling shows, circuses and gypsies from coming into town.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Hannan of Weehawken, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Hannan, to James P. McMahon, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McMahon of North Bergen, N. J. The announcement was made at a dinner given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Hannan at their home in Weehawken.

Paced by its star, Miss Mary Cohalan, who scored 24 points, the Manhattanville College basketball team recorded its fifty-first straight victory over a five-year period when it defeated the Mount St. Joseph College team from Philadelphia, 44 to 15, yesterday on the winner's floor. Miss Cohalan tallied a dozen field goals.

HARVEST COMEDY. By Frank Swinnerton. 561 pp. New York: Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc. $2.50. THREE old men at Brighton daily at the same hour taking their walk by the sea, not one of them ever bowing to another,

GUY de Maupassant, the great French short story writer, was notoriously a woman's man. He embodied in his own person all and more of the passions he so penetratingly scrutinized in his risque short stories.
With the aid of a recordograph just installed, Eastman School of Music students at the University of Rochester are bringing to light ancient music of high quality.
The annual session of the Lafayette Engineering Conference for Boys will be held for two weeks from June 19 to July 2, according to Professor William B. Plank, who is in charge of the conference.

Michael L. Igoe, United States District Attorney, entered the race for United States Senator today when he directed that a nominating petition to put his name on the Democratic ballot in the primary of April 12 be filed at Springfield Monday.

The Westchester Rangers gained a one-point victory over the Crescent A. C. in a Metropolitan Ice Hockey League game at the Imperial ice rink tonight, 4 to 3. Both squads staged three-goal rallies in the final stanza.
The last word on the Equal Rights Amendment proved today to be a written word, ending the four days of public hearings before the subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

In a clash between Agrarians and armed police near the town of Tlalhualilpan, in the State of Hidalgo, north of Mexico City, thirteen Agrarians, including a woman and a child in arms, were killed, according to authentic reports reaching the capital today.

The newly constituted government issued a manifesto to the country today in which it declared that there must be an end to the quarrels and hatreds that have infected Rumanian public life and have reached dangerous intensity in recent weeks. The manifesto adds that political strife must cease in order to restore peace and order.

" OF HUMAN HEARTS," which is a film about the Civil War, had its world premiere last Tuesday night in Greenville, S. C., which is the home town of Roy Harris, the youth who suggested the picture's title in a $5,000 contest sponsored by those indomitable Southern patriots, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer.

Mrs. John Pirie, English barrister, will speak on one of the oldest clubs in England--the Honorable Society of the Middle Temple--at the presidents' day luncheon of the Phalo Club on Saturday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
Staving off a desperate lastperiod rally, Wesleyan gained a 29-to-28 victory over Williams today in the Lasell gymnasium before a capacity crowd of alumni and students.
YESTERDAY was Abraham Lincoln's Birthday and the nation, including its Boy Scouts, paid tribute to the Great Emancipator.

Contracts will be put into effect on Tuesday by the Eastman Kodak Company fixing the maximum retail discounts allowable for the principal items of Eastman amateur photographic goods, following the mailing of such contracts within the last two weeks to dealers in the forty-two States where fair-trade acts are in effect.
Birger Ruud, Norway's world champion ski jumper, achieved two near-perfeet efforts under adverse conditions today at Soldier Field to capture the Central United States championship.

Navy opened its Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League season today with a 44-to-31 victory over the University of Pennsylvania. It was Penn's fourth straight circuit defeat, sinking the Red and Blue deeper into the cellar.

Even before Dr. Alexis Carrel startled the world by announcing that he and Colonel Lindbergh had been experimenting with a "heart pump" of the colonel's invention, biologists had succeeded in keeping organs alive in glass for a few hours.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 10: CAPTAINS Bernhard, A. D., Chief of Staff, commander, Aircraft, Scouting Force, to command the Langley, In June. Giles, W. J., Chief of Staff, commandant, 13th Naval Dist., to home, relieved from all active duty. about June 29.
Representative Disney, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today that he still was a "potential candidate" for the Senate despite President Roosevelt's action in urging him to remain in the House.
What is the President's attitude toward business and how does he react to its suggestions? The question has been intensified in the minds of business men, big and little,

The British public this week has been shocked and enthralled by a genuine spy drama, complete even to the tall, blonde "Miss X," who tirelessly, and finally successfully, labored to save the precious secrets of Woolwich Arsenal.

IN his latest book. "Ends and Means." Aldous Huxley described acting as one of the most dangerous trades and added that it was the rarest thing to find a player whose character had not been affected for the worse by the practice of his profession.

A COUNTRY GARDEN. Written by Ethel Armitage. Engraved by John Farleigh. 226 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $3. "A COUNTRY GARDEN" is a year book, the record of day-by-day happenings in a garden in the south of England, and in the orchard, woods, downs and village that lie beyond.

Once Mr. Toscanini said that the constant study and re-study of his scores kept him young and unfailingly renewed his spirit. The program he gave last night in Radio City with the NBC Symphony Orchestra testified to the fact.

AFTER several sojourns in New York, spread over a number of years, I still think that we have, in France, dramatists, like Bernstein, Sacha Guitry, Bourdet, Giraudoux, Cromelynck, Achard, Passeur and others, who have a talent and a knowledge of the theatre difficult to equal.

HE importance of the automoTbile industry as a customer for other industries is indicated by the fact that parts and materials used in making a steering gear alone sometimes pass through as many as fifteen different types of industrial establishments before reaching the assembly line of an automobile factory, according to a recent report of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

Proposed rules which would re quire identification of fiber content on all types of hosiery were submitted to the Federal Trade Commission last week by a committee of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, and now await a public hearing on a date to be set by the commission.
Harvard's indoor polo trio administered the first defeat of the season to Army today, 11 to 8. A crowded gallery watched the Crimson ride down the Cadets in six fast chukkers.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, in an address before the Lincoln Republican Club tonight, charged that the New Deal Administration had built up a political monopoly which threatened to expand into the domination of all industry and agriculture in the TTnited States.
Germain S. Glidden of New York, the defending champion, and two former titleholders stroked their way into the quarter-finals of the national singles squash racquets tournament today.

VALENTINES of long ago are being shown by collectors. Some like to bring forth their holdings on the day of the amiable saint for the private delectation of their friends; others lend them for public exhibition.

DESIGNED for a community where French and English architecture prevails, a modern, simplified version of the French provincial style was decided upon for the New Rochelle residence recently completed for Walter J. Dockerill.
The text of the address delivered last night by Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont at the dinner of the National Republican Club in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria:

To give American teachers a practical understanding of foreign education and culture, six field courses providing study in Europe next Summer have been planned by the International Institute of Teachers College, Columbia University, in cooperation with educational authorities in eleven countries, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Milton C. Del Manzo, associate director of the institute and provost of Teachers College.

A marked increase in women speakers is shown in those who will address students at New Jersey College for Women during the current semester in regular chapel services. Women in education, law and letters are scheduled to speak. Judge Florence E. Allen and Mrs. Elizabeth C. Morrow are among those chosen to present contemporary feminine thought to the undergraduates.

A three-day initiation period--perhaps milder than any here in recent years--ended today and 125 Rutgers University undergraduates, most of them freshmen, will be inducted into membership in thirteen national fraternities and two local clubs this week-end.

The dramatic story of four men on an Ice floe drifting away from the North Pole toward dangerously warm waters below the Arctic Circle probably has aroused more interest in Washington than in any place in the world outside of Russia. the home of these ice-dwellers.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Seymour ca Hutt today announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Lucille Hutt, to the Rev. Robert Sloan Beecher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Allen Beecher, also .of this city.

THIS closely packed book in belles-lettres follows hard on the heels of "Discovering Poetry," by the same author. For it is the conviction of Elizabeth Drew that just as reading poetry is adventure, is a voyage of discovery, so is watching and hearing or reading drama voyage of discovery and an adventure.

THE United States has 691 broadcasting stations with construc tion of twenty-five additional transmitters authorized by the FCC, according to the 1938 yearbook of the trade journal Broadcasting. Eighty-one stations are listed for Canada.

CONTRACTS have been placed for a foreign-language broad casting station with two highpower transmitters to be built by the British Broadcasting Corporation at Daventry. The aim is to permit a full-time program service to Asia and South America, as well as to Europe.
There are two dangers that the general educational system of today

STRANGE as it may seem, Mayor Frank Hague, Democratic boss of Jersey City, now the target of wide-spread attack as the conductor of a dictatorship for personal profit, once passed as a reformer in politics.

Henry Nathan, for nearly a half century active in Democratic affairs in the lower East Side, died on Friday, after a short illness, at his home, 214 Young Avenue, Pelham. He was 75 years old. Born at 54 Lung Catharine Street, he was for many years a neighbor and close friend of former Governor Alfred Smith.
A goal by Clifton Dance, substitute wing midway in the final period gave the Poly Prep hockey team a 2-1 triumph over St. Francis Prep on the Brooklyn Ice Palace rink yesterday.

Dolls representing twenty-five countries including sections of the Orient and the nations of Middle and Eastern Europe will be used to illustrate a fascinating hobby by Miss Anna E. Lipman at the meeting of the West Side Division of Ivriah, the women's section of the Jewish Education Association Wednesday at 2:30 P. M. at the Rutgers Club, 314 West Ninety-first Street.

Extra police details were posted throughout the fur district yesterday to prevent a recurrence of the vandalism that marked the lockout started Friday afternoon by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers. Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Martin of Greenwhich and Ormond Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Margaret June Martin, to John Morrill Lashar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Lashar of Fairfield, Conn.

IN the Puritan Boston of 200 years ago, or thereabout, a boy was born to all Irish mother. The father, as clearly as can be seen through the mists of time, "lay dying somewhere in the West Indies." This mother and father had been a brave pair.

The British public this week has been shocked and enthralled by a genuine spy drama, complete even to the tall, blonde "Miss X," who tirelessly, and finally successfully, labored to save the precious secrets of Woolwich Arsenal.

IN his latest book. "Ends and Means." Aldous Huxley described acting as one of the most dangerous trades and added that it was the rarest thing to find a player whose character had not been affected for the worse by the practice of his profession.

A COUNTRY GARDEN. Written by Ethel Armitage. Engraved by John Farleigh. 226 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $3. "A COUNTRY GARDEN" is a year book, the record of day-by-day happenings in a garden in the south of England, and in the orchard, woods, downs and village that lie beyond.

Once Mr. Toscanini said that the constant study and re-study of his scores kept him young and unfailingly renewed his spirit. The program he gave last night in Radio City with the NBC Symphony Orchestra testified to the fact.

AFTER several sojourns in New York, spread over a number of years, I still think that we have, in France, dramatists, like Bernstein, Sacha Guitry, Bourdet, Giraudoux, Cromelynck, Achard, Passeur and others, who have a talent and a knowledge of the theatre difficult to equal.
A MONG the achievements of the Composers Forum-Laboratory, which takes place at the Federal Music Theatre, are a critical audience and a composer with a tough hide and a sense of humor.

Funds for the creation of a collection of choral music that eventually will include a copy of every important choral work published either in this country or abroad have been given to Princeton University by David H. McAlpin 3d, '20, of New York City, according to an announcement by President Harold W. Dodds. The amount was not disclosed.

In defense of the National Labor Relations Board, the Upholsterers', Furniture, Carpet, Linoleum and Awning Workers' International Union of North America, A. F. of L. affiliate, wrote yesterday to Senator Edward M. Burke of Nebraska, that it was opposed to any curtailment of the appropriation for the board and also to the proposed investigation of that body.

Henry Nathan, for nearly a half century active in Democratic affairs in the lower East Side, died on Friday, after a short illness, at his home, 214 Young Avenue, Pelham. He was 75 years old. Born at 54 Lung Catharine Street, he was for many years a neighbor and close friend of former Governor Alfred Smith.
A goal by Clifton Dance, substitute wing midway in the final period gave the Poly Prep hockey team a 2-1 triumph over St. Francis Prep on the Brooklyn Ice Palace rink yesterday.

Dolls representing twenty-five countries including sections of the Orient and the nations of Middle and Eastern Europe will be used to illustrate a fascinating hobby by Miss Anna E. Lipman at the meeting of the West Side Division of Ivriah, the women's section of the Jewish Education Association Wednesday at 2:30 P. M. at the Rutgers Club, 314 West Ninety-first Street.

Extra police details were posted throughout the fur district yesterday to prevent a recurrence of the vandalism that marked the lockout started Friday afternoon by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers. Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Martin of Greenwhich and Ormond Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Margaret June Martin, to John Morrill Lashar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Lashar of Fairfield, Conn.

IN the Puritan Boston of 200 years ago, or thereabout, a boy was born to all Irish mother. The father, as clearly as can be seen through the mists of time, "lay dying somewhere in the West Indies." This mother and father had been a brave pair.

New York University's victory over St. John's, its fourth straight in intracity competition, at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, gave the Violet undisputed possession of first place in the race for metropolitan basketball laurels. During the busy week in intercollegiate circles every major team in the metropolitan district was in action at least once. Previously, the Violet and the Redmen had been tied with three victories apiece.
The United States' picked hockey team made it two straight and remained undefeated in the world amateur championship today by routing Norway, 7 to 1.

Seven months after the outbreak of hostilities, and nine weeks after the fall of Nanking, a major battle for the control of the vitally important LungHai Railway, which gives access to five of China's richest provinces, is in progress. The Japanese forces,

Mrs. Mabel Hollister Houghton, widow of Arthur Amory Houghton, former president of the Corning Glass Works, died yesterday morning at her residence, 2 East Sixtyseventh Street, after a brief illness. Her age was 71.

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep.) It is unfortunate that the Japanese have refused to announce their building plans. Their decision adds the miasma of secrecy to an already poisonous international atmosphere, makes Japan responsible for needlessly notching naval construction to a somewhat higher level of expense and serves to enfeeble critical examination in this country of the Administration's naval policies.

Vincent W. Howard and William B. Robbins have been elected vice presidents of D. M. S. Hegarty Co., Inc., underwriters and distributors of general market securities. The firm of Howard Robbins, Inc., with which both were connected, is being terminated.

A series of lectures on "The Meaning of the Humanities" will be given at Princeton University late this month and in early March by scholars in five different humanistic fields, it was announced today by Professor Hoyt H. Hudson, chairman of the University Committee on Public Lectures.
The United States cruisers Milwaukee, Memphis and Trenton steamed into Singapore from Sydney today as the last. preparations were. completed for the formal opening of the huge graving dock tomorrow.

A young dancer from California who calls herself simply Waldeen made her New York debut at the Guild Theatre last night in a brief program of her own compositions. The impression was a distinctly favorable one.

William Green's appeal for a fair profit and unfettered course for industry and for team-work by all groups points the way for capital and labor to work together for mutual prosperity, if the American Federation of Labor acts as its president talked, Chicago business leaders said today.

Celebration of a solemn mass of thanksgiving in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, marked the golden jubilee of the Rev. Mother J. G. Biegen as a member of the Society of the Sacred Heart yesterday. The mass was celebrated by the Rev. John O'Connor.

Netting the tying goal late in the third period and manufacturing two more in overtime, the New York Rovers made a thrilling comeback to down the Hershey Bears, 4 to 2, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League struggle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The annual report of the Woodward Iron Company for 1937 shows gross sales of $9,237,618, an increase of $1,706,162 over 1936. Net income was $1,177,512, after all deductions, against $633,927. Of the total net income, $777,346 was accumulated

A revival of the Socratic method of teaching by questioning was advocated by the Rev. Frank M. Murfeldt, assistant pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle Church, at Fifty-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Life possession of the pulpit of Brooklyn Jewish Center was the fiftieth birthday gift presented to Rabbi Israel Herbert Levinthal by his congregation at a dinner celebration attended by more than 500 of his friends and followers in the Center Auditorium, 667 Eastern Parkway, last night.

A "waiting policy" continues to rule the steel market with consumers limiting their purchases to current requirements, the magazine Steel said today. The national operating rate dropped 1 point last week to 30 per cent.

Sections of the Winter Wheat Belt which need moisture the least received fairly heavy rains last week, but the large area- west of the 100th meridian, which has approximately 33 per cent of the 57,500,000 acres seeded last Fall, had little or no precipitation, and official and private reports indicate irreparable damage in the latter area.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn made public yesterday a report from Assistant District Attorney Ralph K. Jacobs, who headed for two years the Rackets Bureau established with a special appropriation of $50,000.
New York City League of Women Voters, 151 East Fiftieth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Collective BargainingThe Employer," Clarence M. Updegraff, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Sensible Scandinavia," James Sawders.

The Philadelphia German-Americans defeated the Irish-Americans of Kearny, N. J., 2 to 1, in an American Soccer League game today. George Nemchek tallied first, but Johnny Pettigrew tied the score for the Irish-Americans before half time.

American and allied aviators who served in the World War will celebrate a memorable anniversary on Friday night at the annual aviators ball, to be given at the Roosevelt under the auspices of Aviators Post, 743, of the American Legion.

Jimmy Demaret, a bad-weather golfer if this section ever saw one, captured the $5,000 San Francisco match-play open tournament today with a 4-and-3 victory over Sam Snead of West Virginia in the thirtysix-hole final.

Despite record metals sales and a new production record, the net earnings of the Falconbridge Nickel Mines dropped from $1,873,607, or 56.1 cents a share, for 1936 to $1,471,495, equal to 44.1 cents a share, for 1937. There are 3,337,507 shares outstanding.

The Almoners will give their annual supper dance for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital April 23 at Sherry's. Plans for the benefit will be discussed at a meeting of the organization this afternoon at Sherry's. Mrs. F. F. Gannon, Deputy Commissioner Consumer's Service Division, will speak. A luncheon for members of the organization will be given by Mrs. Thomas J. Farrell, president, in advance of the meeting.

Louis Hirsch, president of Louis Hirsch Textile Machines, Inc., 47 West Thirty-fourth Street, died Saturday night in the Fifth Avenue Hospital, where he had been a U patient for seven weeks. He was 65 years old and lived at 41 Clifton Terrace, Weehawken, N. J.

The American trustees of the Charles and Julia Henry Fund today awarded Henry Fellowships of [Pound]500 each to seven students, four from Harvard University, two from Yale and one from Princeton, for study at Oxford and Cambridge Universities next year.

Alf Engen, who astonished Eastern skiing enthusiasts four years ago with his dazzling performances in professional competition, picked up today where he had left off then by winning the invitation amateur jump on the towering Norfolk Winter Sports Association hill in the foothills of the Berkshires.

Senator Ashurst revealed today that he never reads a telegram-unless it is from Arizona. The Judiciary Committee chairman said he had received about 3,600 telegrams about the proposed "equal- rights" amendment to the Constitution, which the committee is studying.

Orville Terjesen's field goal with thirty-five seconds of the second overtime period remaining gave the Crescent A. C. a 51-50 victory over the Union Temple five on the losers' court in Brooklyn last night. The score was tied at 42-all at the end of regulation playing time and at 47-all after the first five-minute overtime session.
Major events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, opening twelfth week of season; Beethoven Association, Enesco program, Town Hall; Irving Becker, violinist, Carnegie Hall.
Al Ramsey of Cleveland won the national professional squash racquets championship today by defeating Lester Cummings of New York in a three-game final match, 15-12,-15-12, 17-15.

Roger Fawcett broke 100 straight targets for the fourth time this season at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, but yielded the high-over-all cup to 0. Agathon after two shoot-offs.

There was moderately active trading in the cotton market here last week, with business increased because of the passage of the Farm Control Bill by the House of Representatives and the probability of early passage of the measure in the Senate.

International politics again is having an unsettling influence on the financial markets in Great Britain. Into the more hopeful situation which appears to have developed on the Spanish issue there has been thrust the disquieting disturbance in Germany which, because of the mystery surrounding it, is viewed in an unfavorable light.
Nava ships stationed at Culebra Island for Winter manoeuvres will have their last intensive training this week before they attempt to capture Puerto Rico.

" Arm-chair Catholics," who permit their pious practices to sink to the level of routine, are living in spiritual danger, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge warned 1,800 worshipers at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The protests of four judges of the Court of General Sessions against pending legislative bills that would do away with the special trial jury panels were sent yesterday to As semblyman Harry A. Reoux, chairman of the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

WAR IN CHINA, by Varian Fry. (Foreign Policy Association, 95 cents.) An account of America's role in the Far East. MUTINY AT SEA, .by Robert L. Hadfield. (Dutton, $3.) Thirteen tales of mutinies at sea.

H. Frank Pierson died last night at his home, 34 William Street, East Orange, at the age of 82. One of the oldest residents of the Oranges, he was for forty years associated with the A. M. Baldwin retail shoe stores. He retired in 1923.
Japan's refusal to reveal her future battleship plans, as requested by the United States, Great Britain and France, will receive attention tomorrow in both branches of Congress.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in On the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Following a sitting of five hours, Frank J. Marshall, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, and David S. Polland, champion of the New York State and American Chess Federations, adjourned their game in the final round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club after 45 moves last night.
Bobbie, said by officials of the Philadelphia Zoological Gardens to be the oldest gibbon in captivity, was found dead in his cage at the zoo this morning when Fred Huber, a keeper, made his rounds.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, opponent of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan, warned yesterday that future attempts to pass "emergency laws" like the Cour plan might pave the way in this country, as in Germany, to a dictatorship.

John Jackson, a tailor, and John Hecker, L a carpenter, both 42 years\old, died in Meadowbrook Hospital at East d Hempstead today of burns received early this morning in Jackson's home at 207 Oakley Avenue here. c Jackson threw kerosene on a coal stove, mistaking it for water, when a kerosene lamp he had placed on the stove exploded.

WHILE he hasn't made any direct move yet, it is known that Judge Landis is casting a scrutinizing eye over all these baseball schools that are blossoming in the land. . Unless there is some supervision, there may result a blot on the scutcheonn of organized baseball.

The foreign exchange market here was extremely quiet all this week, the stabilization fund having, at mid-week, shown its ability to check easily the tendency of foreign currencies to harden. At the week-end, the trend of the franc had improved considerably because of bear covering.

Industry is reported to be more active, and if normal weather conditions prevail, the Spring seasonal recovery will come earlier than usual. The number of unemployed rose 57,000 to 1,052,000 in January, against 1,853,000 in January, 1937.

The Hispanos defeated Brookhattan, 5-3, in an American League soccer game at Starlight Park before 3,500 fans yesterday. The victors led at half-time, 2-1. Salcedo tallied three goals and Aja two for the Hispanos. McIntyre accounted for a pair of Brookhattan's markers, the third being registered by Brown.

In the Federal Reserve Bulletin for February there is published a highly interesting series of tables, mostly compiled from present and past annual reports of the Controller of the Currency, and giving, for nearly fifty years, the annual earnings, expenses and profits of our national banks.

Confronted with surplus orange crops in California, Florida and Texas, which are 28 per cent larger this year than the three-year average, some 153,000 independent grocers of the country will stage weekly nation-wide sales of oranges, starting Feb. 24, March 24 and April 21.

The Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York will open a campaign for $275,000 this afternoon at a meeting of members of the drive's commerce and industry division in the office of Postmaster Albert Goldman in the general post office building at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-first Street. Peter Grimm.

The Merchants Association of New York warned in a statement yesterday that there was an element of danger to general recovery in any attempt at universal application of President Roosevelt's recently announced policy of keeping we ges up and prices down.
The Sleepy Hollow Country Club triumphed over the Apawamis Country Club, 4-3, in a Westchester Division Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association match on the victor's court today.
The National Maritime Union started yesterday a campaign which it described as an effort "to counteract the anti-union propaganda of Senator Royal S. Copeland and the shipowners."

While it may be too much to hope that the greater steadiness now reflected in commodity prices, after six months of uninterrupted decline, indicates an end of the downward movement, there certainly is evidence of more stability in the staples' markets.

The secret about what really happened at Berchtesgaden, Germany, yesterday was as well preserved today as was that of the meeting itself between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria until several hours after it had begun.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 82.4, which compares with 82.6 a week ago, 83.1 two weeks ago, 83.4 three weeks age and 83.9 four weeks ago.

China's flour king, Yung Ttsungching, a refugee from the ChineseJapanese war, died today of a paper stroke. He was the owner of twelve flour mills and sixteen cotton mills under the name of Soong-sing at Shanghai, Wusih, Tsinan and Hankow.

International Peace Campaign meeting, attended by representatives of the United States, the British dominions and eight European nations, adjourned tonight after demanding that their governments withhold war supplies, loans and all other help from Japan.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Patricia de Fabeck Burgoyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lennox S. Burgoyne of London and Surrey, England, to Elliott A. Dingee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Amerman Dingee of Old Greenwich, Conn., which will take place here on March 4 in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.
The New York Office Appliance Managers Association will hold its regular monthly luncheon meeting today at the George Washington Hotel.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in December, 1937, totaled 9,090,271 dozen pairs, a decline of 7.5 per cent from November and of 17.8 per cent from December, 1936, according to figures published in the current issue of the statistical bulletin of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

The grand ball room of the Hotel Astor will be the setting Friday for the annual military ball and pageant of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, Department of New York. The net-proceeds will be used for the organization's relief work among disabled and needy war veterans and their Dependents.

J. W. Cannon 3d, co-owner of an airport at Orlando, Fla., and member of the North Carolina textile family, died in a hospital here tonight from injuries received in a plane crash twenty-four hours earlier.

Miss Dorothea Maxine Kaesche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Baldwin Kaesche of this place, has chosen the afternoon of Feb. 26 as the date of her marriage to John Forster Abeel, non of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Abeel of Hackensack. The ceremony will take place in the t Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, New York.

Glenn Cunningham can break the world indoor mile record whenever he so desires. This was the impression that the transplanted Kansan gave last night at the Boston A. A. meet when he moved through a 4:10 Hunter Mile.

The Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Commitee made public yesterday its annual report based on statistics issued by the United States Department of Foreign Commerce, and said the figures illustrated the effectiveness of the anttNazi boycott carried on in the United States.

Chancellor Hitler's meeting with Chancellor Schuschnigg of Austria Saturday now shapes up, according to the Berlin view, as a first move toward a general European settlement based on a four-power pact to include Britain, France, Italy and Germany.

Engineering construction awards for the first six weeks of this year amounted to $315,825,000, or 28 per cent more than the total of $247,538,000 for the corresponding period last year, according to Engineering News-Record.

The New York A. C. conquered the Brooklyn Bruins, 7-0, and the Columbia Lions defeated the Long Island Falcons, 2-1, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The administration's rearmament program is a "deliberately calculated attempt" to lead this country into war as a way out of the "baffling" economic situation at home, John Haynes Holmes said yesterday in his sermon at the Community Church in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

For the first time in the history of organized commodity exchanges, a concerted effort is being undertaken to embark on an educational program designed to familiarize Wall Street in particular, and the public in general, with a fundamental working knowledge of commodities and commodity futures trading.

A district court jury today acquitted elevent Nationalists accused of killing a policeman, Ceferino Loyola, in a riot last Palm Sunday. A previous trial lasting three months ended in a non-trial because of illness among the jurors.
Absent from the Broadway wars these ten years, Albert Lewis returns tonight in the dual capacity of producer and director of "Roosty," opening at the Lyceum Theatre.

Except for three large issues of public utility companies, bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in comparatively small volume. Most of them were small amounts of municipal, real estate and institutional liens.
Vio Ronchetti, an unheralded Chicago youth, and 18-year-old Miss Janet Milne of Saranac Lake captured the senior North American amateur speed skating championships today.
Francis Charles McMath, retired engineer who also was known as an amateur astronomer, died today in a hospital which he entered three weeks ago because of a heart allment. His age was 71.
Senator Norris of Nebraska said today that he was going to press for consideration of his proposed amendment to simplify and facilitate the adoption of amendments to the Constitution.

Officials of the United States and Cuba are expected to commemorate on Tuesday the sinking of the battleship Maine, which forty years after it occurred is still an unsolved mystery. It was the surface cause of the Spanish-American War, and in the popular Wind its only cause.
The thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Polish National Alliance was celebrated yesterday afternoon when more than 2,000 members met in the Polish National Home, 19 St. Mark's Place.

Federal supply contracts awarded in the week ended on Feb. 10 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act amounted to $6,531,840, with eleven agencies reporting eighty contracts, the Department of Labor announced today.

GOLD IS WHERE YOU FIND IT, from the magazine story by Clements Ripley: screen Play by Warren Duff and Robert Buckner: music by Max Steiner: directed by Michael Curtiz: a Warner Brothers Production. At the Strand.

The national revenue of Canada for the first ten months of the current fiscal year totaled $438,065,893, an increase of $66,304,779 compared with the same period last year, the monthly statement of the Controller of the Treasury revealed today.
A nationwide investigation of the status of all foreign immigrants living in Mexico has been ordered by the Secretary of the Interior, according to an official statement of the President today.

There is uneasiness in France, but there is as yet no feeling of alarm over the events of the past ten days in Germany and what connection they may have with the diplomatic and other activities of the two partners of the Reich in the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo triangle.

Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Americans who fought on the Loyalist side in Spain's civil war, endorsed today President Roosevelt's Chicago speech in which he advocated "quarantining" aggressor nations.

After an uneventful four days, foreign exchanges turned to tremendous activity and wide price swings on Friday of last week during which a number of the currencies established new highs for the year and beyond. This sudden reversal in activity and trend sprang from several incidents, one of which was the Administration's request for additional relief funds, and the other the German internal situation.
The 148th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers opened for a five-day session here yesterday with a discussion of vocational guidance.

The problems of business recovery and the State's vast dairy industry loom as the main theme for the forum of the annual New York State Farm and Home Week opening tomorrow at the New York State College of Agriculture.

For two periods last night the Montreal Maroons gave as much as they took in their National Hockey League game with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden. In the third session, however, the blue-jerseyed sharp-shooters got the range on their rivals' cage and slapped four shots past Billy Beveridge.

Although no mention was made of the effect of buyers' strikes in the United States against purchases of Japanese silk products, a report from Yokohama made public yesterday by the Department of Commerce said that exports of raw silk from Yokohama to the United States in 1937 were 48,040 bales less than in 1936.

Kate Smith's Celtics turned back the Brooklyn Visitations, 39 to 31, and the New York Jewels vanquished the Jersey Reds, 52 to 35, in an American Basketball League double-header at the Hippodrome last night before a crowd of 4,500.

Last Christmas it became known that H. L. Redman, general director of Saks Thirty-fourth Street, occasionally designed costumes in his spare time. During the holidays photographs were released of a manikin wearing one of his creations, a spun-glass and cellophane dress, with neon lights for buttons, designed for "Mrs. Santa Claus."

Probably the stock market gives a fairly accurate picture of the present financial state of mind. It reflects suspended judgment, not increasing discouragement. Last week the averages rose slowly; on Thursday they reached a figure 3 3/8 points above the previous week's closing and 7 points above February's lowest, but 6 1/4 under the highest of January.

Revised rates for manufacturers' and contractors' public liability and property damage insurance will become effective today, increasing the public liability rate level slightly for all parts of the country with the exception of New York State, according to the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

Alexander Harris of East Orange, N. J., has purchased from Thomas H. Long the sixty-acre estate known as Long Lane Farm at Scobeyville, in Atlantio Township, N. J. He intends to build a residence for himself and remodel the old house on the property for a superintendent. The place was held at $15,000 and was sold through Ray Stillman, broker.

Smashing through the Chinese lines south of Changteh, the Japanese at tasckers on Saturday and yesterday advanced 90 miles, bringing them within only 40 miles of Chengchow, the important junction of the Lung-Hai and Peiping-Hankow Railways in Northern Honan.

Stacy DeWitt Arrowood, president of the S. D. Arrowood Company, hosiery mills representatives of New York, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home in Charlotte, N. C. His age was 52. A native of Albemarle. N. C.. Mr.
The annual one-day conference of the New Jersey Gas Association will be held here tomorrow. Home service directors and staff members of gas utilities in all parts of the State will be present.
An eleven-?? night went to the top of all contenders in the thirtieth annual specialty exhibition of the Boston Terrier Club of New York, at the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The neediest unemployed, who should be the chief beneficiaries of unemployment insurance, receive the least protection under the unemployment insurance laws of this and other States, Abraham Epstein, veteran executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security and an expert on social legislation, charged yesterday in an address over Station WNYC.

Declaring that there is-no public demand or need for such regulation of State and municipal securities as is proposed in the Maloney bill for regulation of over-the-counter issues, now in Senate committee, John S. Linen of the Chase National Bank, chairman of the municipal securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association, has urged that State and municipal securities be exempted from the bill.

Arthur Knapp scored by a single point over sixteen other Class B dinghy sailors today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He secured two seconds and a third place in his Four Deuces to roll up 56 points in three races to 55 for Frank Campbell in the Felix.

Cotton prices continued their general upward trend last week, reaching new high levels since last September. For the first time since the week ended on Sept. 18, last, the staple sold at more than 9 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Miss Ella Dunlevy Milbank, whose marriage to William Ward Foshay takes place the afternoon of Feb. 24 in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, will have Miss Carolyn Saltus for her maid of honor.

The celebration on Saturday of "Alumni Day" of Columbia University would have extended (in Samuel Johnson's phrase) "from China to Peru" if the people of that China had not been in such troubled state. As it was,
The wholesale price index for Feb. 2 was 105.6, against 105.5 the week before. On Jan. 5 the German wholesale price index stood at 105.6; it was unchanged at 105.5 in all other weeks of January.

Bernard' Yungbluth, president of the International Railway Company, owner of the destroyed Falls View - Bridge, announced today that the company would erect a new, single-deck span oxi the .site of the old structure, which collapsed two weeks ago under pressure of a gigantic icejam. He said the new bridge would cost $1,500,000.

The financial markets here have not derived much stimulus, if any, from the extremely easy condition of the credit situation, but considerable credence was attached this week to a persistent report that the tendency of industry to lag was to be met by a further reduction in the bank rate.
New York's Americans and Detroit's Red Wings played a listless 2-2 overtime tie tonight in a National Hockey League game before 7,500 spectators.

Traffic congestion due to parking in midtown Manhattan would be greatly decreased if motorists living in outlying sections of the city would park their cars in garages or lots near rapid -transit stations and use the transit lines to reach the midtown area, the Police Department declared in the report of a survey made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.
Atkins, driven by Walter Blair of this village, set today what horsemen claimed as an unofficial world competitive record for harness racing overt a halfmile ice track.
Two new Productions were announced by Warners over the weekend. The first will be "Up She Goes," by H. W. Haneman, in which Frank McHugh will be starred.

William Markham, 20-year-old representative of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club, who last week won the District of Columbia championship, yesterday added the Eastern title to his list of accomplishments when he defeated Kenneth Ridgway of the Garden City B.C. 15-2 14.

Corn exports from the United States in the first four months of the marketing season, with heavy shipments moving through New York for the first time in ten years, have been the most extensive since the season of 1928-29 and for the whole season may exceed exports of any year since 1922-23, Secretary of Agriculture Wallace announced today.
Business regards the reorganized Ministry of Economics as virtually militarized, seeing almost all important competences delegated to army men who have been tried already in the four years' plan.

Playing with sixteen on a side for the first time in the annual championship series of the Metropolitan Chess League, the Manhattan Chess Club defeated the visiting team of the Bronx Chess Club, 91/2 to 61/2, yesterday.

The third destructive gale to sweep the British Isles in a month moderated today, but North Sea waters rolled five miles inland near Horsey, on the Norfolk coast, inundating thousands of acres and forcing the evacuation of a village.

A tea will be given Wednesday at the home of Mrs. Davenport West, 943 Lexington Avenue, in the interest of the benefit matinee on Feb. 22 of "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance has been taken over by the New York Diet Kitchen Association to aid the support of its five health stations in the crowded districts of Manhattan.

A precedent-creating English setter puppy was the talk of the dog world yesterday while hundreds of tired exhibitors and weary kennel attendants departed from Madison Square Garden, heavily-laden with valuable canine cargo.

" Rest on the Flight to Egypt," an altar-piece painting by the Flemish artist, Bernard van Orley, has been presented to the Art Gallery of Toronto, it was announced yesterday by- Wiidenstein Co., 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, through which the picture was .acquired.

Martha Fullam Blair, wife of Frank W. Blair, died at the Prince George Hotel yesterday afternoon. She was a native of West Brookfield, Mass., and the daughter of the late Lemuel Fullam and Susan Adams Fullam. She was a member of the New York Wellesley Club and of the College Club of Boston.

Owing to the continued suppression of information about the political crisis here, foreign opinion last week predominantly influenced the markets here, and stocks recovered in conse- men quence of the belief abroad that a settlement had been reached.

An old holding in the Chelsea seation that came into the hands of the seller after various amalgamations over a long period of years has been purchased by an investor, it was learned yesterday. The property is a four-story building on a plot 84.8 by 100 feet at 244-250 West Twenty-sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

Houghton Mifflin will publish this Spring a third volume in Rafael Sabatini's "Historical Nights Entertainment Series." Mr. Sabatini is now at work on a novel which he calls "Swords of Islam," a story of Genoa in the sixteenth century.

The British steel output in January was 1,081,400 tons, a new high record for the month. It compared with 1,103,800 tons in December, 998,900 in January, 1937, and a high monthly record of 1,178,300 in November, 1937.
Moderate action in the wholesale apparel market last week favored women's coats. and suits, and men's and boys' apparel and furnishings. Women's accessories of all types moved well.

Speculative interest in the grain markets last week was the smallest so far this year, average sales' for the five days being slightly less than 15,000,000 bushels daily, against 19,00,000 in the preceding week and 41,000,000 a year ago.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago pulled-his favorite stunt of playing just hard enough to win as he defeated Charles Harris of West Palm Beach today in the Everglades Club tennis tournament final, 6-0, 6-3, 3-6, 4--6, 6-1.
New regulations for privatelyconducted institutions for the care of old people at the city's expense were announced yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater.

America's military airplanes, in the event of war, will not bomb civilians. Strategists of the general-staff and the air corps have so decided, not for humanitarian reasons but because their. study of. tactics and results in China, in Spain and in Ethiopia indicates the game is not worth the candle.

Charles Frederick Whigham, a director of Morgan, Grenfell Co., London associate house of J. P. Morgan Co., was killed yesterday in a hunting accident near his home, Purston Manor in Northamptonshire. He was 65.

With the third North American Wild Life Conference opening here tomorrow morning, speakers and observers from all parts of the country spent today informally discussing problems of conservation and management. As the men exchanged ideas and swapped stories of hunting and fishing, the drawl of Texans mingled with the accents of those from such States as Ohio and Oregon.

About 250 persons attended a memorial service in Mutual Benefit Auditorium here today in honor of the 266 sailors and Marines who lost their lives when the battleship Maine was blown up in Havana harbor at the start of the SpanishAmerican War.

The polar rescue ship Taimyr planned a desperate effort today to blast a channel through the last twenty miles of ice-packed Greenland sea to the floe on which four Russian scientists have been drifting through Arctic seas since last May 31.

The French money market shows little activity, and the tendency is firm due to the scarcity of funds. Call money remains at 2 3/4 per cent. Trade bills are quoted 3 to 3 3/4 per cent and Treasury bills are at 3 per cent, compared with 3 3/4 and 2 7/8 per cent, respectively, a week ago.

James J. Manusos of Chicago and of Mason City, Iowa, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Katharyn June Manusos, to Douglas Beck Tyler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Beck Tyler of Riverton, N. J.

Today's economic ills are only symptoms of the most serious problem this country faces, "a character shortage," which cannot be cured by "economic blueprints" but only by a renewed faith in God, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, said yesterday at the annual religious service of the Protestant Teachers Association of New York City in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
The consolidated net income of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1937 amounted to $7,105,015, compared with $5,828,582 in 1936.

The committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of'New York made publie yesterday a report in which it approved only -three' out of the nineteen pending bills that it considered last week.

The task of evangelizing a world beset by materialism, immorality and crime lies before Christians today, the Rev. Alfred W. Trinklein declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Messiah Lutheran Church, 202 Sherman Avenue near 207th Street.

Continuing its fight for drastic revision of the existing pension systems of the Police and Fire Departments, the Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday results of a survey of pension provisions for police and firemen in 293 American cities.

Funeral services for Mrs. Hannah Meyers Lissman, wife of the Rev. Edward Lissman, Rabbi of Riverside Synagogue, in West 103d Street, and Jewish chaplain of the Fire Department, were held yesterday morning at the synagogue. Mrs.

Miss Ishbel MacDonald who, while her father, Ramsay MacDonald, was Prime Minister, acted as official hostess at 10 Downing Street, today announced her engagement to Norman Ridgley, builder's decorator and handyman.

The combination lockout and strike in the fur industry, which normally employes 15,000 workers, will go into effect this morning. Approximately 700 shops, affiliated with the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.,...
Fred Davis, veteran Washington correspondent for The Sioux City Journal and other Iowa newspapers, died at his home here last night. His age was 68.
Again Health Commissioner Rice asks the cooperation of parents in protecting their children against diphtheria and in stamping out this dread disease. The Health Department is ready to do its part.

William Lyttleton Barclay, dog fancier, died at his home in Chestnut Hill yesterday at the age of 70. He was president of the Wissahickon Kennel Club, which he helped found in 1902 and of which he served as vied president until 1935.

Delegates at the quarterly session of the New Jersey Division, American Jewish Congress, adopted a resolution here today pledging moral support to the Jewish garment workers in the Jersey Homesteads, $4,000,000 Federal Resettlement project at Hightstown, N. J.

Competing in a field worthy of a national senior tournament, Miguel de Capriles, Professor of Economics at New York University, turned in a brilliant performance yesterday to carry off the metropolitan open individual saber crown on the strips of the Fencers Club.

The two-story frame storage building of the Harwein Feed and Fuel Company on John Street here was destroyed by fire of undetermined origin early today with a loss estimated at nearly $100,000. The flames scorched several unoccupied Long Island Railroad passenger the coaches and ignited two telegraph poles, causing a temporary disruption of the railroad's telegraph service.

Tributes were paid to the memory of Abraham Lincoln in pulpits throughout the city yesterday. Preachers not only emphasized the essentially religious character of the Emancipator but pointed out that his Gettysburg appeal for a united nation was never more urgent than now.
