The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Closing his local police career in a burst of glory, Patrolman William (Cowboy) Orman of the North Castle town force chased and captured two men in a car here early this morning and obtained a confession from one that he had just killed a man on a lonely road north of here.

Influenced by the decline in the franc, commodity prices in France rose noticeably in January. At the month-end the wholesale index was 612, compared with 601 for December and with 513 on Jan. 31, 1937.

Announcement was made. here last night of the death yesterday in Hollywood Beach, Fla., of George E. Greene of 277 Park Avenue, former president of the Niagara Paper Mills of Lockport, N.-Y. Mr. Greene, who was 70 years old, died of heart disease after several weeks of failing health.

In the court where Clarence C. Pell launched a career that carried him to fifteen Gold Racquets and twelve national crowns, Robert Grant 3d gave further evidence today of a mastery that stamps him as possibly the greatest of all American amateur racquets players.
A series of fist fights broke up a meeting being addressed here tonight by G. Wilhelm Kunze, German-American Bund leader.
Red Bank overwhelmed Squadron A of New York, 25 to 12, and the Rangers defeated the Pelicans, 19 to 13, in indoor polo matches at the Red Rank Armorv today.

Americans are eating more "protective foods" today than ever before, Miss Anna May Tracy, president-elect of the American Dietetic Association, asserted yesterday at a tea given in her honor by the Florida State College Alumnae Association of New York and New Jersey at the home of Miss Katherine Blood at 434 West 120th Street.

The recent approach by the United States, Britain and France to Japan regarding naval construction was inspired by a desire to weaken Japan financially and inveigle her into another disarmament conference, according to an elaborate analysis of the situation in today's issue of the newspaper Nichi Nichi.

The campaign to force the ouster of Simon W. Gerson, Communist, as an assistant to Stanley Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, continued yesterday, Jeremiah F. Cross, State Commander of the American Legion, calling upon all citizens to send "telegrams, letters and calls to our Governor, our Mayor and Borough President Isaacs, informing them that the patience of the people is exhausted and that Communists, Fascists or Anarchists must be summarily dealt with."
Dr. William Roy Smith, historian and educator, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital at the age of 61. Associated with Bryn Mawr College since 1902, he had been Professor of History since 1914.

The Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "the Protestant Church in New York should support through the Federation of Churches a program designed to bring Christ to 1,200,000 children who know him not."

Miss Marion McDougall of Portland, Ore., winner of the qualifying medal, scored an easy victory in the first round of match play in the Everglades women's invitation golf tournament today. She beat Miss Laddie Irwin. of Montclair, N. J., by 5 and 3.

" Panic of 1938," a musical revue, will be presented at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, on the evening of Feb. 25, by men and women active in the support of the Bay Ridge Day Nursery of Brooklyn. Some of the children cared for at the nursery, so their parents may continue in gainful work, will participate in the program.
Miss Elizabeth Watson, genealogist and one of the founders of the /Dartmouth (Mass,) Historical Society, died in her home here today at the age of 78. She had been ill nearly two years.
Germain G. Glidden, New York, national squash racquets champion, advanced to the final of the U. S. tournament today and will meet Leroy Weir, Detroit, tomorrow for the title.

The Financial News's index for thirty industrial shares, based on July 1, 1936, as 100, stood at 90.7 on Feb. 10, which was the lowest since early May, 1935, compared with 94 a week ago, 97 a month ago, 122.8 a year ago, a high record of 124.9 on Nov. 18, 1937, and a low of 41.6 in June, 1932.
Reported by American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel Brothers, R. H. Macy, Charles Scribner's- Sons, John Wanamaker, Womrath Book Shops and Libraries:

Recalling the trend of government during his period of public life, former Senator Steiwer of Oregon, who retired recently to practice law here, said today that the States had lost their power and that the doctrine of laissez-faire had been destroyed forever.

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in January, based on 1930 as 100, was 108.7, which represents the first rise since the decline which began in August. It compares with 107.6 in December and 102.9 in January, 1937.

Expressing the belief that the next naval war would be won in the air and under the sea,, Rear,Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., retired, advocated yesterday the development of all-around sea power in this country at an estimated cost of two and a half billion dollars.

In an editorial, La Carcajada of Guayaquil, Ecuador, attacking the charge d'affaires of the American legation and praising President Alberto Enriques in connection with the controversy over the South American Development Company, says:

Establishment of a law center at Columbia University on the scale of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical, Center was urged yesterday by Dean Young B. Smith of the School of Law in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. The projected buildings and equipment were estimated at $4.000.000.

The Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning that "what we need above all else now is a spiritual front." He added:
James Snell of the Mount Greylock Ski Club, North Adams, Mass., today won the New York State downhill skiing championship, held on the Ridge Trail of Gore Mountain.

H. C. Brill Company, Inc., Newark, N. J., manufacturer of liquid and powder preparations for making homemade ice cream, has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease violating the RobinsonPatman Act by granting alleged illegal discounts to chain-store organizations and food wholesalers, the commission announced today.

From thirty-five to fifty square feet of plaster fell from the ceiling of the underground level of the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation, 175th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, twenty minutes after the regular 10:30 o'clock masshad started yesterday morning, with almost 1,000 parishioners in the pews.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Today American Dock pf. Central Arkansas Public Service Corp. pf.

In the first British newspaper comment on the Japanese refusal to disclose naval building plans, The Times of London declared that as a result "all limits on the size of ships and their guns are likely to be abrogated."

The reputation of the great schools of America rests upon general acceptance by the students of high standards in the classroom, Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, declared here today at exercises celebrating the seventysecond anniversary of Peddie School.

Aubrey (Bucky) Wells continued his record-breaking series of dashes down the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today to win the national A. A. U. senior four-man bobsled title after one entry had crashed in a trial heat, injuring three riders.

The issue of complete colledtivization of land and industry, as against the "nationalization" of industry and the "industrialization" of all lands-which do not necessarily imply extensive collectivizationwas raised today by the National Confederation of Labor (C. N. T.), one of Spain's two great labor unions.
Count and Countess Jean de Polignac, Major Corniglion Molinier, Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. Hallock W. Beals, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park S; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

Isaac Nadler, general merchandise, store at 399 E 78th St; Gensup Stationery Co. store at 1 Union Sq W; M. MorgenthauSeixas Co, broker. Ultra Modern Textile Printers, in 598 Broadway; James Felt Co, brokers.

Virtually no interest was taken last week in the oat market on the Board of Trade. Prices held within a range of 1/4 cent a bushel, closing on Friday with gains of 1/3 to 1/4 cent. May was 313/4 cents; July, 291/4, cents, and September, 291/2 cents.

Opposite viewpoints on the Administration's proposal to reorganize and consolidate government agencies and bureaus were expressed tonight over the radio on the WOR Forum Hour, by Senator Brynes of South Carolina and Representative Taber of New York.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Weekes of Red Spring, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Louise Weekes, to Edwin F. Hendrickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard F. Hendrickson of Bridge Hampton. L. I.

Selfishness, either on the part of the husband or wife, is the cause of more unhappy marriages than any other reason, the Right Rev. Rocksborough R. Smith, Lord Bishop of Algoma, Canada, declared yesterday morning. He spoke from the pulpit of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, where he celebrated a high mass.

An innovation in bowling circles, a transatlantic match between the United Swedish Bowling League of Greater New York and the Stockholm Bowling Forbund, was staged yesterday, with the American team winning, 6,956--6,917. Twelve men bowled on each team.

Fairbanks, Morse Co. has been awarded a $1,750,000 United States Navy contract for ship-service equipment on two battleships, according to announcement here by A. E. Ashcraft, vice president in charge of manufacturing.

A new sensation was provided in Austria this afternoon by a report that Joachim von Ribbentrop, the new German Foreign Minister, had passed unexpectedly and with great secrecy through Tyrol on his way to Rome.

The National Labor Relations Board has ordered an election within fifteen days among employes of the Novelty Slipper Company, Inc., of New York to determine whether the collective bargaining representative shall be the Boot and Shoe Workers Union of the American Federation of Labor or the United Shoe Workers of America of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Two persons-were Killed here today in two grade crossing crashes about three-quarters of a mile apart involving the same train. Herbert Rosanbalm, 25, was killed when a Missouri Pacific train struck his machine at the outskirts of the town.

The German upheaval, occurring concurrently with the trial of Pastor Martin Niemoeller, and the suppression of minorities in other countries were cited-- from the pulpit here yesterday as evidences of possibly far-reaching changes.

The beginning of the Saturday evening Wagner "Ring" cycle and the first appearance of the season of Helen Jepson, young American soprano, will mark the thirteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season beginning next Monday. The bills for the week follow:

Cardinal von Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich, preaching before 20,000 Catholics today at a celebration of the sixteenth anniversary of the coronation of Pope Pius XI, challenged the National Socialists' denials that religious persecutions were going on in Germany.

The program for the annual benefit ball, to be held by the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt on the eve of Washington's Birthday, in aid of its emergency relief fund, was announced yesterday at the February meeting of the society at the Hotel Astor.
Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here on a nation-wide basis to be at 30 per cent of theoretical capacity of the mills.

Today the Senate is set to vote on the new Farm Bill. It will almost certainly be passed. Though as it emerged from conference it is 121 pages long, and practically a new measure compared with the widely differing bills originally passed by the Senate and the House, it will have been debated by the Senate for only a few days and by the House for just four hours.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that Mrs. David M. Levy had been named chairman of the women's division in the committee's 1938 Greater New York campaign. The division has a quota of $400,000 in the drive.

With the recent recession in business, efforts have been renewed to get Congressional action on a bill backed by the Department of Commerce, and in line with recommendations of the National Resources Committee as approved by President Roosevelt, which would stimulate the development of new industries through Federal aid to scientific research.

The list of the steamship President Harding of the United States Lines, due today from the Channel ports, includes Homer S. Fox Huldy Sarhan, B. L. H. Cosby Miss Enid V. Norwood, J. Tarn McGrew and Mrs. Wilfred Dunderdale.
The week's movements on the stock market have resulted in a general rise, with the principal bull activities centered in the equities which had been most sold during the preceding week.

The decrease of 3,127,000,000 francs in the gold reserves of the Bank of France that Dis was shown in its report for Feb. 3 resulted from the transfer of metal from the bank to the stabilization fund. This was foreseen, as it was known that the fund's gold resources had been weakened by the DO recent franc crisis.

Wives and daughters of physiclans on the staff of the Lutheran Hospital, Brooklyn, and wives of members of the executive board of the hospital are making plans for a dinner dance, which will be given for the benefit of the institution on Feb. 21 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Iir Norman Angell, Nobel Peace Prize winner, today urged an "Aid China Week" to marshal world-wide opinion against Japan's campaign in China.

Frederick Munz, horticulturist, died Saturday morning at his home at Sutphin and Rockaway Boulevards, Jamaica, at the age of 60. He was the originator of the terraniums the novelty glass containers in which plants are grown.

Former associates in the boating world, members of crews he coached and followers of the sport from all parts of the United States will join in paying final tribute to James A. Ten Eyck, Syracuse's "grand old man of rowing," at

The biblical narrative of Jonah and the whale was described as a "parable" designed to emphasize the aloofness of Jonah, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

The marked increases in industrial wages and prices of manufactured goods, "to which the current recession in business is commonly attributed," began in November, 1936, according to the results of a study issued today by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Harry A: Taylor, East Orange real estate'man and State- chairman of the Realty Factors of America, an, organization formed in Chicago recently to promote moderate-cost housing, announced yesterday that a State-wide conference of the Realty Factors would be held Wednesday at the Robert Treat Hotel in Newark to discuss plans for spending $20,000,000 in 1938 in the development of 5,000 dwelling units throughout the State.

Christ's life challenges us to answer the most important question ever asked--"Whom say ye I am?"--the Rev. Charles A. W. Brocklebank declared yesterday in his first sermon as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue.
Members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important legislation last week as follows:

The Oliver Farm Equipment Company has reported for 1937 increases of 39 per cent in sales and 80 per cent in net profit, compared with 1936. Its net profit was $2,182,763, or $6.44 each on 399,196 common shares, compared with $1,153,640, or $4.24 each, on 272,074 shares in 1936.

Excluding commuter traffic, travel on the New York Central Railroad increased 21.8 per cent in 1937, compared with 1936, the company reported yesterday. For December the increase was 9.2 per cent, compared with December. 1936.

Gregor Piatigorsky's skill as a program-maker and his art as a 'cellist were well met in his appearance at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The result was a concert in which a brilliant technique, first-rate musicianship and profound understanding were at the service of music worthy of these attainments.

A man identified by a passport as Oscar L. Van Den Bosseh, a Canadian journalist, 57 years old, was found dead shortly after 2:30 A. M. today when investigation of a supposed gas leak led searchers to a third-floor studio apartment at 116 West Forty-eighth Street.

Conflict between a prim white school teacher and the Eskimos of remote island settlements between Alaska and Siberia was disclosed today by Commander F. A. Zeusler of the Coast Guard cutter Northland.

This city experienced last week a fog such as the oldest inhabitant vowed he had never seen before. A real London "pea souper" blotted out the turreted hills of Buda and shrouded bridges over the Danube and reduced traffic to a standstill.

The announcement that. Presi dent-elect Roberto M. Ortiz had appointed Jose Maria Cantilo, now Ambassador to Rome, to be his Minister of Foreign Affairs has been greeted With unanimous satisfaction. He is perhaps Argentina's

William G. Cave, former owner of The Midland Argus, weekly newspaper, died yesterday at the age of 67. Death came at the time The Midland Free Press, Limited, took over the printing and publishing business that Mr. Cave

Charges that supervisors in the WPA Federal Theatre Project had discharged relief workers for failure to join a union, usually the Workers Alliance, were found warranted by the joint appeals board of the five Federal Arts Projects in thirty-six cases, according to the board's annual report, made public last night. The board directed that

Mr. Jennie Winter Katz, wife of Jacob Katz, president of the board of trustees of the Nathan and Miriam Barnert Hospital, died suddenly here tonight at their home, 215 Derron Avenue, of a heart attack. She was 48 years old.

Warning that in its next war, if one should come, the United States could not expect to have as much time to prepare as it did in 1917, Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the Sixth Corps Area, formally took part today in National Defense Week, sponsored by the Reserve Officers Association of the United States.

Fighting against involuntary retirement, at least 250 army officers are in general hospitals undergoing physical tests and examinations which probably will disqualify them from field service in the future, it was learned today.

Nearly a dozen group shows on the calendar make the present week a novel period in the season's progress. Several annual exhibitions figure in the list. The presence of four new sculpture shows also serves to lend the week distinction.

The sixty-eighth birthday of Hunter College today will be marked throughout this week by a series of events, including a radio broadcast, a tea, an operetta and the first formal chapel of the Spring semester.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lewis Terry of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Elizabeth Terry, to Francis Gaynor Evans of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. Ross Evans of Iowa City, Iowa.

Toronto's Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks battled through an overtime period to a 1-to-1 tie tonight in their second National Hockey League battle in two nights-a presentation which included fistic entertainment for 11,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.
It is an unfortunate coincidence that the Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, who rushed in where Archbishops feared to tread
Appointment of twelve members of local school boards in Manhattan was announced yesterday by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs. Four other vacancies will he filled soon. Mr Tsaacs said:

Mobile's mysterious "monster of Fisher's Alley," identified as an otter of about thirty pounds, and about four feet from head to tip of tail, was killed today, ending terror that had existed among Negroes since the "monster" stalked a near-by swamp and began foraging expeditions several weeks ago.

The Cuban Senate overrode President Federico Laredo Bru's veto of a bill providing for a settlement of public works obligations by a vote of twenty-eight to four, early this morning following an all-night session.

The sunspots that caused so much trouble in telegraphic and radio communications on Jan. 25 may reasonably be expected to repeat their performance about Feb. 21, according to Dr. Ralph H. De Lury, who is in charge of solar physics work at the Dominion Observatory here.

Since the United States Embassy and State Department' have said very little about the interview that Loy W. Henderson, American Charge d'Affaires here, had last Thursday with Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens, the writer proposes to do something unusual and unorthodox for a newspaper correspondent by giving a fictional account of what he imagines took place.

A new disturbance from the recordbrought gales, torrential rain and snow to the Coast. intensifying flood hazards in Northern California and carrying the recordbreaking storm through its eight?? consecutive day.

Colonel Albert E. Peirce of Warrenton, Va., owner of Sonny, which came in second in the Miami-Nassau yacht race, had the crew as his dinner guests last evening at the British Colonial. In the party were Albert E. Peirce Jr., James Peirce, George Pynchon and Henry Shufeldt of New York, Frank Bissell of Hyannisport, Mass., and Richard Maxwell of Greenwich, Conn.
The Legislature will reconvene tomorrow night for the seventh, and the busiest week thus far, of the current session.

Undeterred by gray skies and a threat of rain, the Allied Organizations of the Grand Army of the Republic marked the birthday of Abraham Lincoln yesterday in a ceremony at the statue of the Civil War President in Union Square.

The American Law Students Association, organized a year ago in an informal way, completed yesterday its first formal convention by adopting a constitution and bylaws, adopting resolutions of a liberal social character and electing William Cox of the Columbia Law School as president.

The only way to get men and women to live as becomes saints is to give them instruction that will teach them that they are saints, the Rev. George Douglas declared yesterday in a sermon in the Gospel Tabernacle, Eighth Avenue near Forty-fourth Street.

Walter Howard, State policeman, said today that Charles L. Templin, 18, of Richmond, freshman at Indiana University, had confessed that he stole nearly $1,000 worth of merchandise from the university book store here to get money to pay for his second semester's schooling.

Five persons were drowned and seventeen are missing of more than 100 sight-seeing passengers of the ferry launch Rodney, who were thrown into the water when the boat capsized during the departure of the United States cruiser Louisville from Sydney Harbor.

Mr. and Mrs. Wainwright Abbott, who are at Mayfair House, will sail this week for Hamburg, Germany, where Mr. Abbott is the United States Consul. Mrs. Robert B. Noyes of the Savoy-Plaza has gone to Puerto Rico for the remainder of the Winter.

Baltimore defeated the Passon club of Philadelphia, 3 to 2, in an American League soccer game at O'Donnell Park today. Baltimore held a 3-0 lead at halftime, but the visitors rallied and all but evened the count in the final session. Ernst got two of the victors' goals.

At the annual appearance of the Cadet Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy at West Point in impressive services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, the 1,800 seats in the church were filled, scores of persons were standing and hundreds were turned away.

An unlucky break nullified Wilf Cude's sensational goal-tending and enabled the Boston Bruins to top the crippled Canadiens, 1 to 0, tonight in an overtime National Hockey League game before 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

Maintaining his lead over the second eighteen-hole round today, R. U. Knox defeated 0. E. Carlson, 3 and 1, in the final of the Siwanoy Country Club's twenty-ninth annual Sno Bird golf tournament. Knox, runner-up last year to his brother, William F. Knox, was 4 up at the end of the first eighteen holes played last Sunday.
The prize of $500 offered by the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico, conductor, in a contest for a new composition has been awarded to a man.
The Baltimore Orioles found the range in the second period tonight and slammed in five goals to defeat the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 6 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League game.

A MYSTERIOUS performance was recently wit nessed in this department. During the fortnight just passed a series of amiable individualsfor the most part strangers-wrote, telephoned or paid personal calls on behalf of a novel published today: "Grass on the Mountain,"* by Henry and Sylvia Lieferant. One and all declared the novel extraordinary and something not to be missed.
Prince Paul Troubetzkoy, sculptor and descendant of a princely Russian family, died here today at the age of 72. He was well known in and the United States where he had the visited several times.
Howard Tuxbury Sands, retired public utility executive, whose home was at Saco, Me., died early today at the Orange Memorial Hospital following an illness of six weeks. He was 70 years old.

The world today is dominated by leaders who are experts in the psychology of the crowd and who have mobilized great multitudes of people by an appeal to the most primitive qualities of the mob, the Rev. Elmore M. McKee, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, said in a talk yesterday morning at a Bible breakfast conference in the William Sloan House of the Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirtyfourth Street.
Firmness in cottonseed oil prices enabled the lard market last week to resist hedging pressure. Packing interests generally were sellers of laird against the current market.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,055,219,900. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Plans for a vast celebration on April 30 to mark the progress of the New York World's Fair to date and to serve as a preview of the attractions to be provided when the exposition opens-on the same date in 1939 were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

A lot of people have cats who don't want cats, and the natural tendency is to take the unwanted feline for a ride in the country and drop it off in a likely patch of woods near some farmhouse. A lot of people salve their consciences by convincing themselves that if the cat isn't adopted by the nearest farmer it will manage to find enough to eat, anyway.
Apparently well on the way to recovery from the effects of twentytwo days of absolute fast, the Rev. Israel Harding Noe was planning tonight to leave the hospital he entered three weeks ago.

Mr. Somerset Maugham is dissatisfied with the Bible on literary grounds. He thinks that "King James's Bible has been a very harmful influence on English prose." For centuries this work has been "the daily, and with many the only, reading of our people."

Members of the New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service have launched an extensive ticket-selling campaign for the performance of "Once Is Enough" on the night of Feb. 23 at Henry Miller's Theatre. The benefit will advance the health program conducted by the nursing service in the Kentucky mountains.

In order to relieve congestion and also to enable residents of Brooklyn who are employed in other boroughs to pay parking and first-offender fines before reporting for work, the Brooklyn Traffic Court, commencing Feb. 21, will be open at 8:30 A. M., instead of 9 A. M., every Monday and Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman.
The suit of the Soviet Government to recover $1,000,000 from the National City Bank was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook. Dismissal of the suit, instituted last March,
Wheat prices fluctuated slowly within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel today, with continued dry weather in the Southwest offsetting the effect of weakness in Liverpool and a lack of export demand.

Champion Harry Jeffra and his challenger, Sixto Escobar, today began putting the finishing touches on their training for their bantamweight title bout, as officials predicted the island's record crowd for the 15-round fight next Sunday.

Applications by trustees and attorneys for $226,529 for fees and expenses in connection with the reorganization of the Prudence Company, Inc., under Section 77-B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act were filed yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn.

The American Rolling Mill Company acquired 227,600 common D shares of Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation by purchase from stockholders during 1937, in addition to 178,700 shares previously held, and owned 47.05 per cent of the common stock outstanding at the year end, with three representatives on the board of seven.

Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. gave a dinner tonight at Casa Del Pastor for Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Shepard, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hill, Sir George and Lady Prescott, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred
The increasing extent to which the United States has a business stake in the British rearmament program was shown today in the Board of Trade figures on British imports and exports for January.

Rumors that the Treasitry Department would make an announcement on its gold policy caused Uneasiness in foreign exchange circles early yesterday, but while this uneasiness brought about a Weakening in the dollar in relation to the principal foreign currencies, the decline was not sufficiently marked to draw undue attention. Secretary Morgenthau's announcement came after the close of the market.

Collections of current and delinquent taxes by the city of Camden, N. J., for 1937 amounted to $6,400,139, the largest for any year ever reported by the city, according to the year-end statement issued yesterday by Sidney P. McCord, City Controller. This is $457,945 above collections of $5,942,194 in 1936.

Strengthened by the acquisition of Johnny Sorrell, a forward, from the Red Wings, the New York Americans will face the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The Senate adopted and sent to the White House today the crop control bill asked by President Roosevelt as one of the four major pieces of legislation needed to complete his New Deal program.

Builders and realty men will watch with interest the result of the plan to build a large group of all-steel homes to house workers of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's new Irvin works nearing completion at Clairton, Pa.

Councilman Hugh Quinn, fighting attempts to remove him from the City Council on the ground of improper residence, produced a witness yesterday who told the investigating committee that he had seen the Councilman sleeping in his underwear in an arm chair at 24-29 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, during the Winter of 1937.

One of the most important criticisms that hay been made of the proposed Federal Wage and Hour Bill is that, if it attempted to establish a flat minimum wage for the whole country, it would in effect act as a tariff wall in the North against Southern goods.

Remington Rand, Inc., which emerged a victor last November in a test of the Byrnes act, which forbids the transportation of strikebreakers across State lines, suffered a defeat yesterday in its dispute with the American Federation of Labor.

Net assets of -Aldred Investment Trust at Dec. 31 amounted to $4,391,642, equivalent to $712 for each $1,000 of debentures outstanding, as compared to $6,593,253, or $1,045.80 for each $1,000 of debentures and $1.64 per common share, at the close of 1936.

Germain G. Glidden of New York, former Harvard star, won his third consecutive national squash - racquets crown today by overpowering Leroy Weir of. Detroit, 15-13, 18--15,13--15,15--9. Weir's stubborn fight won the third game but Glidden easily ran out the match in the fourth.

Following the improvement in the flow of midtown vehicular traffic as a result of the parking restrictions on ten crosstown streets, Police Commissioner Valentine announced similar restrictions yesterday on ten streets in the financial district.

Governor Lehman's $386,000,000 budget was ad vanced to third reading in the Senate tonight. Final action there on the budget, which was returned from the printers on Saturday, is expected to be taken Wednesday, and it will then be sent to the Assembly for passage.

The Associated Actors and Artists of America, the governing body of all actor unions, are "astonished and disturbed", by the "reiterated claims" of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes to jurisdiction in the associated's field, Frank Gillmore, president of the latter group, said yesterday afternoon.
The United States hockey team clinched its place in the semi-finals of the world amateur hockey championship today by defeating Germany, 1 to 0. It was the third straight

Parke, Davis Co. and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended Dec. 31, 1937, a net profit of $9,068,304 after depreciation, Federal normal and foreign income taxes and provision for surtax on undistributed income.

A city-wide high -school symphony orchestra, a band and a chorus are being selected from the musical organiiations in the five boroughs and will be trained for a festival concert in May, after which the Municipal Art Committee will award medals to individual members of the three groups.
A bill with the names of seventy-five Representatives attached as co-sponsors and co-authors to place a graduated excise tax on chain stores was introduced in the House today byRepresentative Patman.

The last of the Winter series of the Coffee Dances took place last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. The committee is planning a Spring dance after Easter. Prior to last night's .event several dinners were given, the hosts and hostesses later taking their guests to the dance.

Pondering the future of the Philippines, President Manuel Quezon has evolved what appears to be a new concept of government which is neither capitalistic nor communistic, nor corporate as envisaged by dictators.

As a peace loving nation in no danger of becoming an aggressive one, the United States not only cannot disarms but needs more and better equipment for its defense forces, especially at sea and in the air, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today..
To avert "an unprecedented catastrophe," help for millions of suffering Chinese must be given promptly, according to an American Red Cross bulletin made public yesterday by the New York Chapter.

Charles Denby, formerly Consul General at Shanghai and Vienna and a brother of the late Secretary of the Navy Edwin Denby, died in Emergency Hospital here late today after a brief illness. His age was 76.

The marriage of Mrs. Frederica Frelinghuysen Carleton of 2 East Sixty-seventh Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen of this city and Palm Beach, to Huntington D. Sheldon, also of New York, which was to have taken place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frelinghuysen in Palm Beach, has been postponed indefinitely because of the illness of Mr. Sheldon.
Charles Capehart, president and general manager of a New York City advertising firm, died at his home here yesterday following a heart attack. His age was 69. He had been ill for several months.

Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee said today that Senator Vandenberg's advocacy of a coalition of Republicans and Jeffersonian Democrats was inspired by the Senator's Presidental ambitions.

Mrs.' Nevil Monroe Hopkins will give a reception and tea today at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, for members of various committees active in preparations for the "Wild West Dinner Dance" to be given on Feb. 24 in La Salle Tropicale of Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.
The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors, by resolution, asked the Legislature to repeal a 1930 law making it a misdemeanor to print "false information" about a cooperative association.

The weight of French imports in 1937 amounted to 57,388,391 metric tons, compared with 47,960,280 metric tons in the preceding year, a gain of about 20 per cent, said a consular report from Paris made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Tonight's new event at Henry Miller's Theatre brings together some names not unknown to Broadway, this being the Frederick Lonsdale comedy called "Once Is Enough," starring Ina Claire under the management of Gilbert Miller.
A plan for the reorganization of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler by Referee James A. Martin with his approval.

Visitors of all ages passed through the sixth-floor exhibition hall in the L. Bamberger Co. store here today to examine the exhibits of Cultural Week, the third of four week-long expositions on "New Jersey--One of America's Great States."

The engagement is announced of Miss Elise Valerie Gettier, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Wise Gettier of Baltimore, to James Thomas Watkins 4th, son of Mrs. Eleanor Preston Watkins of San Francisco and the late Dr. Watkins.
The work of constructing the new Brooklyn Central Library at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway began yesterday morning without ceremony.

A total of 3,207 families, or 13,537 individuals, was aided last year by the Jewish Family Welfare Society, sole family agency affiliated with the Brooklyn Federation-of Jewish Charities, according to a report submitted last night at the twentyseventh annual meeting of the society at the Unity Club, Bedford Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn.

Jim.McMillen, 228, Illinois, threw Sammy Stein, 215, New York, in 35:17 of the feature finish wrestling match before 1,500 persons at the Hippodrome last night. McMillen triumphed with a crotch hold and half-nelson.

It may be coincidence, Dul waIl Marse Joe McCarthy in town over the week-end, the Yankees were able yesterday to announce the signing of- three players, two of them hold-outs until a short time ago. And there may be further

Smoke from a burning mattress factory yesterday seeped into the wards and corridors of Gouverneur Hospital, forced the postponement of several operations and temporarily stopped emergency treatments in the outpatient department.

The Greyhound Corporation of Delaware applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to buy the Old Colony Coach Lines, Inc., for $200,000, of which $25,000 will be paid in cash and the balance in 3 per cent negotiable promissory notes maturing in twenty-four months.

Oscar Odd McIntyre, whose column glorifying a New York that only he had ever seen reached 7,000,000 readers every day, died of a heart attack at 2 A. M. yesterday at his apartment, 290 Park Avenue. He would have been 54 years old Friday, his thirtieth wedding anniversary.

Trading in the slaughter houses was only fair to slow and in the wholesale markets fair to slow. The veal market was steady and other classes somewhat stronger. Early trading in kosher meats indicated calf and lamb prices to be slightly stronger, beef and veal steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The tax for the Melville Shoe m Corporation under the proposal of Representative Patman would amount to $19,000,000, on a total volume of business of $38,000,000, Ward Melville, president of the corporation, said last night. The concern operates 690 John Ward, Thom McAn and Frank Tod shoe stores.
President Roosevelt discussed domestic business conditions separately with Thomas W. Lamont and Paul V. Shields and foreign affairs with Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Tucked quietly away on the back page of the newspaper Izvestia today is an announcement of considerable importance. It simply mentions

Another fugitive in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's 1936 rackets investigation was captured in Chicago yesterday. He was Samuel Furstenburg, a disbarred lawyer, indicted on charges of extortion and conspiracy and alleged to have been a chief adviser and one of the organizers of the now defunct Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association, dominated by the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

Operations of the American steel industry are scheduled at 31 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 30.7 per cent last th week, a gain of 0.3 point, or 1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

" THE UNVANQUISHED,"* William Faulk ner's thirteenth book unless my count is wrong, is a collection of seven stories about a Miississippi family during and immediately after the Civil War. Six of the stories have already appeared in magazines, but they are here so reworked as to form a continuous and impressive whole.

Miss Emma T. Adler, co-founder of the old Lafayette Private School here, died Saturday at her home at Th the age of 84. She and her late sister, Miss Marie Adler, directed the school for thirty years. The building on Church Street now is occupied by the Y. W. C. A.

Out of a total of 2,040 mortgage loans amounting to $13,857,217 arranged during 1937 by the firm of J. Halperin Co., Jamaica brokers, 664 were for the construction of new small dwellings in various sections of Queens and Nassau Counties, Brooklyn and Westchester County. These loans totaled $3,166,945.

A Ford assembly plant employee testified at a National Labor Relations Board hearing today that he joined the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers of America under threats and later was active in distributing loyalty pledges given to him by an official of the Liberty Legion of America.
Contracts for exhibition space at the New York World's Fair have been signed by thirteen additional companies, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Feb. 10 rose to 306 from the total of 256 in the week preceding and 172 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Operations last year of the National Distillers Products Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $7,861,968 after all charges including provision for Federal income, capital stock taxes and $153,814 surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the fourteenth annual report issued today by Seton Porter, president.

Joseph Schenck 3d of New York matched par to win the medal in the qualifying round for the annual South Florida golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club with 35, 34--69, today. He led nearly seventy-five players.

George Gordon, who said he was in the automobile renting business, testified as a State witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of two men in the hold-up murder of Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor and related how his signal to the patrolman brought him to his death.

A 17-point scoring spurt in the last five minutes enabled Temple to come from behind tonight-and beat Carnegie Tech, 48-39. Thus the Owls scored their seventh straight victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference. They can win the title Friday by beating Pitt.

The typhoid fever epidemic that last Autumn swept through the London Borough of Croydon resulting in 297 cases and forty-three deaths was -caused by a germ-carrying laborer employed on one of the municipal wells, the commission of inquiry reported today.
Captain Jose Pino Suarez, a retired army officer, and twelve convicts today sailed aboard the cruiser Abdon Calderon to exile on Galapagos Island. Captain Pino is a political prisoner.

Master Holding Company sold to the Karot Management Company, Inc., of New York City, the sixteen family flat at 726-728 Polk Street, West New York. The building occupies a site 50 by 100. The seller acquired the parcel from Sam Frank last Jan. 28.
An Insurgent dispatch said today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco was massing approximately 1,000,000 men for a drive to end the Spanish civil war within six months.
A funeralservice will be held in Trinity Episcopal Chapel here tomorrow afternoon for Mrs. Susie Cruikshank Snyder, widow of the founder of the' Snyder Catsup Company,
The Transit Commission announced yesterday in its annual report that it had obtained the "virtual consent" of the private interests to a plan to unify the city's subway and elevated lines.

Widespread discrimination against Negro residents of the State is charged in the report of the New York State Temporary Commission on the condition of the urban colored population, submitted to the Legislature tonight.

Theodore Schorske, executive vice president of the Central Savings Bank, will retire today, just two to, days after completing fifty wears ro of continuous service. Starting as a clerk on Feb. 13, 1888, Mr. Schorske has actively helped the bank grow from 58,686 depositors and $22,646,857 deposits to its present-day position of two offices serving 206,910 so depositors, whose savings total ve $189,622,820.

With machinery in operation today to fix acreage allotments under the new Crop Control Bill,. representatives of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration said a revision of the 1938 conservation program would probably be issued to make it dovetail with the act.

Mrs. G. Iraci, in 5 W 86th St; Phillip Schwarz, in 320 W 90th St: Leonard Drachman, in 504 W 110th St; Belle Gorin, in 233 W 99th St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker. Mary V. Kingsbury, in 22 Grove St: Nathan Jones, Mary F. Hayes, John Brinley, in 2 Horatio St; Vera Dangerfield,

Stocks advanced moderately and closed slightly higher in second slowest trading in three years; turnover, 400,870 shares. Cuban Public Works issue up sharply, United States Government and other bonds irregularly hither: transactions, $6,339,600.

Ever since the days of Chaucer the English inn has had a fond place in the hearts of all who love English literature and the English tongue. It was charming news two years ago that Miss Iphbel MacDonald, once hostess for her father at 10 Downing Street, had transferred her talents for gracious hospitality to the old Plow Inn, at Speen, in Buckinghamshire.

Mrs. Evelyn Fahnestock Steele of 1,185 Park Avenue, New York City, who arrived in Reno about ten days ago, has retained counsel to represent her in divorce proceedings against her husband, George S. Steele.

Hearings of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee investigating railroad financing will be resumed this week with one of the first matters to be placed on the record involving the alleged illegality of the purchase of the Erie by the Chesapeake Ohio, it was learned today.

About 800 Sanitation Department employes were barred yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan from promotion to foremen because they had answered three questions in a civil service examination when the directions called for an answer to only one of the-three.

On the stage, at least, of the Metropolitan Opera House there was given last night an extremely interesting and spirited performance of Bizet's "Carmen." The new element in the cast was Jan Kiepura, the young Polish tenor, who is making his second appearance with the Metropolitan Opera Association this season.
The preliminary annual report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937, issued today, shows a consolidated net income of $13,573,490, after all expenses and charges.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has taken adequate steps to handle the extra business resulting from the closing Of. the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, Harold W. Davis, chairman of a special transit committee of- the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, declared here today in answer to complaints from commuters.
The newspaper Excelsior today charged General Tirso Hernandez, head of the Mexican Government Physical Education Department, with beating its sports editor, Manuel Seyde.
The Eastern Racing Association, operator of Suffolk Downs, today declined to change its racing dates to make room for a June meeting at Narragansett Park.
Professor Leo Wolman, Columbia University economist, in an address on "labor and capital" before the 148th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers,

February, already half gone, has shattered its tradition as a Winter month, appearing more as a harbinger of Spring. Temperatures remaining far above freezing yesterday rose to a high of 57 at 11 A. M.,

THE UNVANQUISHED, by William Faulkner. (Random House, $2.50.) A novel about the Civil War period. THE BIG FIRM, by Amabel Williams-Ellis. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) A novel about a young scientist in love.

An order, signed by Federal Judge William Clark, which permanently enjoins the Benjamin Franklin Foundation, Inc., of Philadelphia from continuing the sale of trust certificates in interstate commerce, was filed here today in the Federal district clerk's office.

Mrs. Christian R. Holmes of Port Washington, L. I., received a gold medal last night from the New York Florists Club for a group of potted lady-slipper orchids that she exhibited at the club's monthly meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Allen Hastings Rogers, senior partner in the consulting mining engineering firm of Rogers, Mayer Ball, 26 Beaver Street, and a former president of the Mining and Metallurgical Society of America, died yesterday at the Medical Arts Center Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Rogers, whose home was in Brookline, Mass., and who came here weekly on business, was 66 years old.

The House today approved a conference report on an amendment to the Federal Trade Act/ which broadens the powers of the Federal Trade Commission over advertising, infilets severe penalties for fraudulent advertising and permits action by the commission on consumer complaints without awaiting proof of unfair competition.
In anticipation of immediate Senate action on the farm bill, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward again yesterday and ended with a net advance of 7 to 12 points.

Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the Board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was called yesterday as a defense witness in a suit entered by trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway to recover $10,506,090 from Speyer Co., J. W. Seligman Co. and Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the 'Frisco board.

The annual report of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $7,257,287 after depreciation, charges, underlying dividends, Federal taxes and deduction of $10,342,743 to adjust inventories and commitments to the lower cost or market values.

Miss Nancy Krementz, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Richard Krementz of 755 Salem Avenue, has chosen April 23 as the date of her marriage to John M. S. Hutchinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Edwin Hutchinson of Detroit. The wedding will take place in Trinity Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Robert Lee Bull Jr., the rector, Will perform the ceremony.

The all-star basketball team sent here by the United States Amateur Athletic Union trounced the local Riachuelo quintet, 42 to 19, today in the first game of its tour. A crowd of 4,000 in the Stadium Brazil saw the Americans pile up a 21-6 lead in the first half.
Stockholders of the Greenfield Tap and Die Company will be asked at their annual meeting on March 2 to vote on a proposal to increase the authorized common stock from 200,000 to 250,000 shares.

THE first rush for hockey information was checked at the blue line. Red Dutton hadn't yet arrived back home. He was still on the road from Detroit, herding his star-spangled outfit in this direction to meet the Canadiens at the Garden this evening.

Payments of $1,405,491 were made last year to about 11,500 employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation or their beneficiaries, it was announced-at the annual meeting of the board of trustees of the Bethlehem Relief Plan, hed yesterday in Bethlehem, Pa.

An "Exhibition of City Gardens and Penthouse Terraces in Winter," arranged by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to advance its work in increasing the tidiness of the city streets, will be inaugurated today with the display of several landscaped places on the East Side.

The series of conferences covering the past few days between Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, which have kept both Washington and Wall Street wondering what all the talking was about, has finally produced an answer.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Joseph William Burns of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 378--Susie Maty, administratrix of the estate of George Maty, also known as George Matey, petr., v. Grasselli Chemical Co. On writ of cert.

In a celebration of St. Valentines Day marked by a revival of the old-fashioned sentimental type of Valentine (at $3 each) and the appearance of super de luxe tokens costing as high as $30, the two telegraph companies vied yesterday for public attention by inventing (a) the "kiss" and (b) the "singing" valentines.
The Rev. Edward M. O'Malley died tonight of a heart attack suffered in the rectory of St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church of which he was pastor for fifteen years. His age was 63.

The stock market here was generally quiet today and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues were weak but among the foreign loans, gains were shown by German and some Japanese bonds. Transatlantic stocks improved, with United States Steel and International Nickel in demand.

Jacob Powell, 29-year-old homeless Negro, accused by Newark officials of committing twenty robberies here and in near-by municipalities, was shot and killed this afternoon when he tried to escape from two policemen and a detective who tried to arrest him.

An indication that the Commonwealth may try to send Mary Keenan O'Connor, 19-year-old college athlete, to the electric chair for the death of Nancy Glenn, 5, was given today as a jury of nine men and three women was selected. The defendant pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and man slaughter.
The crisis always produces the man, and by unanimous conviction General Francisco Franco is the man of men for Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain.
Janet Gaynor's first film since "A Star Is Born" will be "The Young in Heart," adapted from I. A. R. Wylie's forthcoming magazine serial, "The Gay Banditti," SelznickInternational announced today.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
All favorites advanced as the first round of the eighth annual New York Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament was played yesterday on the Junior League courts.

The weekly analysis of traffic accidents showed another decline last week as compared with the corresponding week last year, the safety bureau of the traffic division at Police Headquarters announced yesterday.
The Regis H. S. basketball team beat New York Cathedral Prep, 35-22, on the loser's court yesterday. Jim McKay, Regis left forward, was high scorer with 12 Points.
Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe, lanky pitcher for the Tigers, broke into a smile nearly as wide as he is long where. a doctor pronounced his arm in shape today.

Larger assets and an increase in insurance in force to the highest point in the company's history were reported today at the seventy-fifth annual meeting of policy holders of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company here.
Dr. Angus Stewart Woodburne, a professor at Crozer Theological Seminary, Chester, Pa., died in Madura today after a brief illness. His age was 56.

Morris Bernhard has been elected vice president of the Hudson County National Bank, Jersey City, N. J. Formation of the firm of J. B. Boucher Co. to trade in unlisted securities is announced by John B. Boucher of 72 Wall Street.

Domestic business conditions and foreign affairs continued to occupy the attention of President Roosevelt today. He canvassed the business situation in separate discussions with Thomas W. Lamont, partner of J. P. Morgan Co., and Paul V. Shields, New York investment banker.

Although voicing little hope for favorable action in the near future, Senator Ring of Utah and Representative Maverick of Texas, Democrats, introduced their joint resolution today asking President Roosevelt to call an arms limitation conference in Washington, the results of which, if any, would be accepted as a guide to Congress in future arms appropriations.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14, Anthony Pelleteri's Reminding took the Valentine Purse, feature race at the Fair Grounds today.

Tax, warrants totaling $64,291 against eight individuals and one corporation were vacated yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora on the ground that a taxpayer's property could not be seized to satisfy a deficiency assessment without notice and an opportunity to pay the amount requested.

In a plea for adequate military preparedness, Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, accused churchmen yesterday of attempting to thwart the national administration's defense plans.
Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels's organ, the Angriff, today urged the Nazi regime to speed up the tempo of "liquidating" Jews in Germany's economic life.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Near Eastern Art," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; European decorative arts (general tour) noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M. "Design in American Furniture," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Buddhism in the Wei Dynasty," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P.M.

Great Britain's gigantic $55,000,000 naval base in the Far East was officially opened today when the yacht Seabelle II cut a tape across the entrance to the drydock, capable of handling the largest battleships afloat.

The $275,000 drive of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York started yesterday at a meeting of the campaign advisory council at the offices of Postmaster Albert Goldman at the General Postoffice Building, Eighth-Avenue and Thirty-first Street.

Consumption of apparel-class wool during 1937 amounted to 248,700,000 scoured pounds, a drop of 11 per cent from 1936, but an increase of 5 per cent over the average for the ten years 1927-1936, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

An unusually extensive program of festivities is being prepared here to welcome the highest military authority in Brazil, General Pedro Aurelio Goes Monteiro, who will arrive in a few days following an official invitation recently extended to him by the Chilean Government.

Austria's stock suffered a sharp setback tonight when it became known through a series of interviews granted to foreign diplomats here that Germany's attitude had hardened in the course of the negotiations that have followed the original interview of the Chancellors at Berchtesgaden.

Stars of the stage, screen and radio will participate in the annual show for the benefit of Israel Orphan Asylum, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on March Hall 19. Mrs. Gustave Hartman is president of the beneficiary.

The sixty-fourth annual report of the Council of the Corporation of Foreign Bondholders, London, just made available here, emphasizes the progress made last year in developing the fullest possible measure of cooperation with the bondholders' association of other countries.

Norman Ridgley, whose elbows planted on the counter of Ishbel MacDonald's Old Plow Inn long have been a familiar sight to the little village of Speen, Buckinghamshire, shortly will move behind the counter as the husband of the proprietress.

Endorsed by such veteran handlers of boxers as Billy McCarney, Lou Brix, Jack Hurley and Frank (Doc) Bagley, Jimmy Adamick, Michigan heavyweight, today will conclude serious training for his bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden against Harry Thomas of Minnesota.
Mrs. Jeanette Furnival, 23-year-old salesgirl, was shot and fatally wounded by an unknown assailant here tonight as she stepped off a bus 150 feet from her home at 211 Twentythird Avenue.

Announcement that the Belair Stables' Fighting Fox, Milky Way Farm's Tiger and Willis Sharp Kilmer's Nedayr have been nominated for the Kentucky Derby, May 7, was made by Matt J. Winn, president of Churchill Downs, today.

Differences within the Cabinet gave rise this morning to reports that the government of Patriarch Miron Cristea had resigned and that George Tatarescu, Minister Without Portfolio, had replaced him as Premier. In the afternoon an official denial was issued.

The American naval policy declaration which Chairman Vinson of the House Committee on Naval Affairs announced, on Friday, would be written into the pending $800,000,000 Naval Construction Bill is "camouflage," the purpose of which is to "alibi a super-navy," Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, of New York, declared before the committee today.

A bill setting up a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to construct a system of ten Federal trunk highways was introduced today by Chairman Steagall qf the House Banking and Currency Committee.

Play in the women's Class B invitation squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Country Club got under way today, with many of the matches closely contested. Among the firstround victors were Miss Eleanor Best and Mrs. Tudor Simpkins.

American curlers gained four victories and suffered three defeats in first-round play of the Ontario Bonspiel 'today. In the 'main event for the Royal York Trophy, two Detroit fours and one from Brookline, Mass., emerged unbeaten and two Detroit 'rinks were defeated.

Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday dismissed three patrolmen from the force, two of them on charges of accepting fees from attorneys and the third accused of improperly patrolling his post and being absent without leave.

A slight drop in its construction cost index for February as compared with January was reported yesterday by The Engineering News-Record. February's cost index is 243.9, or .2 per cent below that of January. It is the second successive month showing a decrease.

The New York Rovers and the Atlantic City Sea Gulls went into a triple deadlock with the Hershey Bears for first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by winning at Madison Square Garden last night. A gathering of 7,043 fans saw the games.

The Henry Hudson Bridge at 230th Street, Manhattan, was closed to traffic for twenty minutes shortly after last midnight when about 400 feet of wire netting, which had been stretched beneath the upper level that is in process of construction, dropped to the roadway.

Representative Rayburn, majority leader, announced today that the measure providing a deficiency relief appropriation of $250,000,000, as requested Feb. 10 by President Roosevelt, would be called up in the House for action Wednesday.

Major H. S. Heywood, Sirdar Kumar Jag-Jit Singh, Lieut. Comdr. L. S. Holland, Major and Mrs. J. C. Denton Carlisle and Captain and Mrs. H. W. Lance are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
Rivers and creeks rose today in the wake of light rains which fell yesterday over wide areas of up-State New York, but the threat of floods was tempered by forecasts of colder weather.

Secretary Hull's latest statement probably will not satisfy the more extreme isolationists. In it he says specifically that the United States seeks no alliances abroad and intends to reserve "the fullest freedom of judgment and right of independence of action" in matters of foreign policy.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Missions Sisters of the Church Army of the Protestant Episcopal Church will be celebrated at noon today at the chapel of the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 9: A decrease of $48,000,000

The marriage of Mrs. Elsa Cover to Gerard B. Lambert Jr. took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Rockwell S. Brank of Summit, N. J., in the presence of the immediate families.

The Governor signed two bills, one amending the real property law in relation to dower rights and the second extending the life of the commission to study the treatment of cancer cases. He also designated tomorrow as "Susan B. Anthony Day."

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hartwig Paulsen gave a dinner at their home here tonight at which they announced the engagement of Mrs. Paulsen's sister, Miss Ruth-Mairie Heitmann, to Gustav Birger Nelson, son of Mrs. Gustav Nelson of Teaneck, N. J., and the late Mr. Nelson.

Five Oriental priests will sing, at the invitation of the Capuchin Fathers, a mass-of concelebration, as it is called, next Tuesday, at 9:15 A. M. in the Capuchin Church of St. John the Baptist, 209 West Thirtieth Street. Seldom if ever has such a service been held in this country.

The proved crude oil reserves of the United States on Jan. 1 were estimated at a new high record of 15,507,268,000 barrels, according to a compilation by a committee of the American Petroleum Institute made public yesterday.

Japan's unsatisfactory reply to notes from the United States, Britain and France, asking the tonnages and gun calibers of ships she is building or planning to build, is thought here to mean intensive naval consultations which may amount for all practical purposes to an informal naval conference.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today the resignation of S. E. Hackett as president, director and member of the executive committee, effective on Feb. 14, 1938.
Nat Holman of City College despises the zone defense, but as it is allowed by the rules, his Beavers employ it.

Motor carrier organizations in the MiddleAtlantic States and Midwest protested today to the Interstate Commerce Commission on what they allege to be rate-cutting moves by certain operators who have filed tariffs lower than those agreed upon by the organized operators.

Governor Lehman has expressed approval of the participation of the women's wear industry in the New York World's Fair in a letter to Joseph Love, chairman of the Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., it was revealed yesterday. The organization is in charge of the industry's officially approved exhibit at the fair. Governor Lehman's letter read in part:
The protective committee for Vicksburg Bridge and Terminal Company first mortgage 6 per cent bonds is asking bondholders who have not yet assented to the reorganization plan to do so,

Grave anxiety was evident in official circles here today over the military situation in the PeipingHankow Railway sector in Honan Province, where the Japanese have succeeded in battering their way fifty miles in two columns, striking for Kaifeng and Chengchow, during the last few days.

Plans a for a three-day festival of Amer'ican music, Feb. 21-23, the first ever held on a nation-wide scale in this country, were announced today and will be carried out by the Works Progress Administration.

Board of Trade figures, issued today for January, as follows: Total imports, [Pound]84,950,000; exports of British products, ?41,180,000; re-exports, ?4,800,000; total exports, [Pound]45,980,000; excess of imports, [Pound]38,970,000.
The board of directors of the Bank for International Settlements indicated today that it favored the Van Zeeland plan to make the bank the world's sole international clearing house.
Twenty-five battery candidates reported for Fordham's baseball team in the Ram gymnasium yesterday. This marked the beginning of Jack Coffey's seventeenth season as coach.

For two hours this afternoon the Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Business heard speakers assail the bill introduced by Senator Arthur F. Foran of Hunterdon County to make compulsory the registration of trade-marks at a fee of $10.
Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Riedel, Americans occupying a cottage in Smith's Parish, were besiegedfrom midnight to 9 A. M. by a bull that broke loose and wrought havoo around the cottage.
The La Guardia Transit Bill, introduced tonight in the Senate by Thomas C. Desmond, contains what amounts to an offer of a bargain between the Mayor and the Democratic leaders.
Miss Jean Fraley Hallowell, at one time an associate literary critic of The Public Ledger, died at her home in Germantown on Saturday at the age of 81.

More than 500 members of the National Association of Broadcasters, in a three-day session that began today, took steps to "clean house" to meet threatened demands of the Federal Communications Commission. The first move was to adopt a new set of by-laws.

The Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938, which will become law with President Roosevelt's signature following its passage today by the Senate, represents the most ambitious experiment in farm relief ever attempted in this or any other demacracy.

James A. Farrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation, will receive this year's gold medal of the American Irish Historical Society, according to an announcement last night by James McGurrin, president-general of the society.

A C. I. O. affiliate, in a resolution made public today, thanks Mayor Hague's Jersey City administration and the police of the city for "the courteous and cordial treatment accorded our pickets and our union during the recent strike."

From a study of the birth dates of famous men the attempt has been made to derive a theory about the months most favorable to genius. In the total poll February does not come out very high, if memory serves.

Government planning has served to shorten the business cycles, rather than produce prosperity, and has made the cycles more severe, George A. Renard of New York, secretary of the National Association of Purchasing Agents declared here tonight before the New England Purchasing Agents Association at a dinner at Schrafft's, 16 West Street.

Balked in every prior attempt to get possession of Hudson County poll books and registry lists, the Assembly committee created to investigate the balloting there in last November's Gubernatorial election adopted today a resolution ordering Colonel Mark O. Kimberling,

With passage by the House of Representatives yesterday of the compromise Wheeler-Lea bill, increasing the power of the Federal Trade Commission over false advertising, only Senate approval and Presidential signature remain to make the act law.
ROOSTY, a play in a prologue and two acts, by Martin Berkeley. Staged by Lee Strasberg and Albert Lewis; settings by Nat Karson; produced by Mr. Lewis. At the Lyceum Theatre.

Fred E. Beal, former Communist and leader of the Gastonia textile strike of 1929, has decided not to a fight extradition and will surrender to the authorities of North Carolina, where he is under sentence of from seventeen to twenty years for the killing of Chief of Police O. F. Aderholt of Gastonia in a disturbance during the strike.

Employers who contribute to the State unemployment insurance fund obtained today an extension from Feb. 15 to March 1 of the date on which the January contributions are due. The action was taken because of the amendment to the Unemployment Insurance Law to include in its provisions persons warning more than $3,000 year.

John J. Munholland, chairman of the executive board of the Central Trades and Labor Council since 1920 and labor's representative on the new Queens Industrial Commission, died Sunday in the Medical Center after a short illness. His age was 56.

The Treasury today revised its gold sterilization program, retroactive to Jan. 1, to the extent that only gold which enters this country over and above $100,000,000 in any one quarter will be sterilized in the future.

The annual Silver Sailfish Derby, which ended its three-week run on Sunday and established a new derby record of 547 sailfish, brought the Rea Trophy to Samuel Sprott of Stockbridge, Mass., for an 8-foot 5 1/4 -inch fish.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 14 unless specified: At Mare Island: Pompano, Feb. 12; Wright, Feb. 13; Aylwin, Dallas. At Singapore, Feb. 13: Memphis, Milwaukee, Pecos, Trenton. At Culebra: Nitro, Feb. 13; Schenck, Jan. 29.

The Municipal Bond Club of New York, at a special meeting held yesterday to consider the effect of the Maloney bill on State and municipal bonds, adopted a resolution endorsing the testimony of several municipal bond men in opposition to the bill at hearings before a Senate committee last week.

Consoliated net earnings of $460,441 for the year 1937, covering fiftytwo weeks, were reported in the annual statement of Union Premier Food Stores, Inc., made public yesterday by Samuel Friedland, president. The result is after all charges,

The extensive educational, recrenational and health program conducted among children of the lower West Side by the Greenwich House Nursery School and Children's Health Service will be furthered by a performance of "Casey Jones" at the Fulton Theatre on the evening of Feb. 24.
The strain of hard work and long hours as a trial judge in Federal court had their effect yesterday on Justice Willis Van Devanter, who will be 79 years old next April.

Joseph Stalin, leader of the Communist party, urged today that the Soviet Union bolster its defense program by organizing the working classes of other countries to give Russia political aid "in case of military attack."

Scoring the change of United States Senator Millard E. Tydings that anti-loss leader measures lead to price-fixing, J. Frank Grimes, chairman of the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee yesterday defended laws of that type as ideal for meeting price-cutting evils in the grocery industry.

The Mengel Company and subsiddiaries, manufacturers of corrugated containers and lumber products, reported yesterday January bookings of $946,538, compared with $836,205 in January, 1936, a gain of 13.2 per cent.
The international stock market indices for Feb. 12, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Richard Browning Kent, an editorial writer for the last twelve years for The Jersey Journal of Jersey City, died suddenly this morning of a heart attack in his home here at 17 Union Street. He was 63 years old. Mr. Kent, under the name Cavendish, had conducted a daily column, "Pipe Smoke," in The Journal. He had also edited a part of the feature page.

Appointment of Ludlow Wray, former head coach of football at the University of Pennsylvania, and William (Biff) Glassford, former All-America guard at the University of Pittsburgh, to the football staff of Manhattan College was announced yesterday. by Herbert M. Kopf, head gridiron mentor and director of athletics.

Justice Black was at variance with his colleagues of the Supreme court twice today in opinions handed down. In one case, although he concurred in the result, he expressed opinions into which the majority did not go. In the other he was the lone dissenter.

William James Hume, president and general manager of Hiram. Walker . Sons, Limited, died here early today of uraemia at the age of 46. His body will be taken to New York on the liner Conte di Savoia for burial at Belleville, Ont., Mrs. Hume announced tonight. The liner is due to leave Naples next Monday.

The Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock of New York, an Episcopal Bishop was the first contributor to the Presbyterians' $10,000,000 sesquicentennial fund for Christian education, it was announced here today by the Presbyterian Board of Christian Education.

The vanity of a truckman who wore a stole1 full-dress suit resulted yesterday in the arrest of five men, all members, according to Reed Vetterli, head of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation, of a ring of waterfront thieves that has stolen $200,000 wouth of goods at piers and terminal stations in the city.

Charles Guy Folke Greville, seventh Earl of Warwick, today received a conditional decree of divorce from the Countess of Warwick, daughter of the late David Cecil Bingham of the Coldstream Guards, whom he married in 1933.

Decision on reporting to the Senate the proposed constitutional amendment granting Congress the power to enact "equal rights" legislation for women, was postponed today by the Senate Judiciary Committee, after a tie vote had been taken.

Gross assets, $19,840; net, $18,035. To Society of St. Vincent de Paul and Home for Blind, Crippled and Defective Children, $250 each; Society for the Propagation of the Faith, $100; brother, George A. White. $4,000 and one-third of residuary estate; nieces, Anna I. Kissner,

The possibility that the State Department in Washington may intervene again in the case of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Arnold Rubens, now under arrest in Moscow, where they arrived last November with passports bearing the names of "Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson," .was seen yesterday when it was learned that government officials were continuing their investigation into the nationality of Rubens.

Former Judge George Weston Anderson, who was born on a New Hampshire farm and became a member of the United States' Circuit Court of Appeals- in New England, died today at his Winter home in Deland, Fla., at the age of 76. He retired in 1932.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday that Dr. John W. Withers, dean of the. School of Education for seventeen years, would retire in September upon reaching the age of 70.

Water, air and land have had or are to have their honorable share in bringing a large American back to his adoring country. Paul Vories McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, is to speak of high matters with Mr. Roosevelt.

Announcement has just been made of the marriage here last Saturday of Miss Kathlyn Byers, daughter of Judge Daniel Richmond Byers of Fort William, Ont., and the late Mrs. Byers, to Dr. David Wallace MacKenzie Jr. of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. MacKenzie of Montreal.

Representative Sirovich of New York urged in the House today that the Neutrality Act be revised to permit Loyalist Spain to buy arms and ammunition in the United States to "defend itself against traitors and invaders.

Blame for the slaying of William Barhorst, bus driver, in a Belleville hold-up on Dec. 21 was placed today by Genevieve Owens on her companion, Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl. Both young women are on trial here for murder.
