The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday the decision of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan, setting aside the La Guardia city budget and reinstating the old budget of $589,980,576 adopted by the Board of Aldermen before it went out of existence at the end of last year.

Fred J. Catania, 34 years old, assistant cashier of the Bensonhurst National Bank in Brooklyn, and Attilio Galardi, 31, an employee of a brokerage house, who pleaded guilty to evolving a fantastic scheme whereby they stole $25,000 from the bank's vault on Jan. 3, were sentenced to Sing Sing Prison yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato.

Following a protracted dispute between cocoa farmers and buyers, the burning of cocoa already has started on the Gold Coast. The Division of Ashanti has undertaken to destroy 23,000 tons as her share.

The annual capacity of the steel industry in the United States for producing pig iron and ferro-alloys was increased 1,100,000 gross tons in 1937 to a total of 50,698,400 tons, while annual steel productive capacity was increased nearly 1,900,000 tons to 71,065,540 gross tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
The Treasury's announcement of partial abandonment of its gold sterilization policy gave a mild lift to Western securities in late trading today.

President-elect Roberto M. Ortiz announced today that the new Cabinet would consist of: Interior-Diogenes Taboada. Foreign Affairs-Jose Maria Cantilo. Finance--Pedro Roppo. Public Instruction--Jorge E. Coll. Agriculture--Jose Padilla. Public Works--Manuel P. Alvarado.

Gordon Drillon failed to drive past the National Hockey League goalies last week, but he stayed well out in front in the ing race. The young Toronto Maple Leaf wingman collected a brace of assists and they were enough to leave him 5 points up on the opposition.
The author, the hero and the plot of the Rumanian drama is the King. In some quarters he is credited with Machiavellian cleverness and daring in manoeuvring in the present crisis.
Mrs. Sadie Montelbano, 23 years old, mother of two small children, was found shot dead at 9.30 A. M. yesterday in her two-room apartment at 1,432 Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.
The Erie Railroad's president, Charles E. Denney, and a Cleveland lawyer, John A. Hadden, took today the task of piloting the railroad out of "the red."
Andrew J. Eken was elected president of Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday, succeeding Paul Starrett, who became chairman of the board.

The sale of the fourth and final portion of the famous Clumber library began at Sotheby's today and will end Wednesday. Thus far this rare collection of literary treasures has realized [Pound]60,000, and it is expected that the group of fourteenth and eighteenth century manuscripts now being sold will bring the total considerably above that figure.

Henry Wenzelberger, philatelist, died yesterday at his home, 21 High Street, Malden, after an illness of several months. He was 63 years old. Born in Philadelphia, he came to Boston in 1920. He was connected with the Lowell Hall Company, and in 1928 became manager of the Hub Postage Stamp Company, Inc.
Fliers aboard the icebreaker Taimyr were forced by an Arctic storm tonight to abandon an aerial attempt to In rescue the four Russian scientists on a drifting ice floe off Greenland.

The combination lockout and strike in the fur industry went into effect yesterday morning and a few hours later Mayor La. Guardia intervened in an effort to end the dispute arising from failure of the International Fur Workers Union and the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers to agree upon terms for a renewal of their agreement, which expired Jan. 31.
In the heaviest voting by members in the history of the New York Curb Exchange a new board of thirteen governors was selected yesterday at the annual election.

Accused of accepting $1,000 to obtain a job for Jacob Gross, 70 years old, of 1,002 Garrison Avenue, the Bronx, Charles Cohen, former executive chairman of the Retail Kosher Meat Trade Code Authority, was held in bail of $5,000 yesterday on a charge of grand larceny by Magistrate Cooper in Bronx Magistrate's Court. At the request of the District Attorney hearing was set for tomorrow.

Estate, more than $10,000. Will names as sole legatee decedent's husband, John Francis Dezell; lists four children as heirs, John F. Dezell Jr., 28 North Broadway, White Plains, Edmund J. Dezell, Rosemary C. Dezell and Paul Dezell, all of 344 W. St. Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co.. 70 Broadway, executor.
Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission and appointed Ambassador to Great Britain, dined privately with President Roosevelt at the White House tonight.
Steve Vasilakos, celebrated peanut vendor at the White House gate, has applied for American citizenship twenty-eight years one month and two weeks after arriving in this country from Greece.

Sheriff James V. Mangano of Kings County called at City Hall yesterday to inform Mayor La Guardia that he and his subordinates were willing to take a 7 per cent salary cut in the interest of economy, but the Mayor was too busy to see him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposal that the Legislature of New York State petition Congress to pass the Wheeler-Johnson bill raises important questions not as to the intent of the bill but its administrative provisions. New York has recently adopted

The credentials that J. B. Hubrecht will present as Minister to the Italian court within a fortnight will be addressed to "His Majesty, King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia," the Foreign Ministry announced today.
Yesterday's commercial leasing report was featured by a number of contracts for space in which restaurant enterprises will be installed.

W. K. Rice of the Harvard Club, No. 2 in the seeded list and topranking man left in the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club, was eliminated yesterday in an upset as E. L. Kemble of Montclair turned him back, 915, 15-12, 18--16.

Jean Kathleen Demers, 3-year-old prodigy of Tracadie, N. S., arrived in New York last night with her mother, Mrs. Albert Demers, with the full intention of seeking fame through the stage, radio or any other medium where she would have an opportunity of astounding her listeners with her profound knowledge of world events.

Virginio Gayda, commenting on the United States naval program in the Giornale d'Italia, says it has not the purpose attributed to it by American statesmen of guaranteeing the safety of the United States, but rather that of preparing America to play a more decided role in international politics.

The monthly administrative cost of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects here has been cut from $48,288 to $25,895 since last July and the proportion of non-relief employes has dropped from 20 per cent of the total personnel to 5 per cent, Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the VPA arts program in this city, reported yesterday.

An aftermath of the Drukman murder case came yesterday when William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, announced that he had dropped Harry S. Sullivan as an assistant on his staff. Mr. Sullivan, who received $10,000 annually, presented the evidence to the grand jury against the three defendants charged with the murder of Samuel Drukman but no indictment was returned.

Representatives of this country, Canada and Mexico participated in the first general session of the North American Wild Life Conference, which opened here this morning and will continue through Thursday.

The power of South Carolina to limit motor trucks on the State highways to a loaded weight of 20,000 pounds and a width of ninety inches was upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion regarded by some as likely to exert considerable influence on the future of the trucking industry and the railroads.
Princeton University's freshman hockey forces climbed back into the winning column today by shutting out the Morristown School, 3-0, on the Hobey Baker Memorial rink.

For the third time in the competition for the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy, medal honors were taken today by Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando, Fla., in the qualifying round of the eleventh annual national championship of gold club champions, on St. Augustine Links.

Jose Ramon Gutierrez, Minister of Foreign Relations, said in the newspaper the Nacion today that no international problem exists over the ownership of three small islands in Beagle channel near the Straits of Magellan. There have been several reports that Chile and Argentina were in dispute over the ownership of the islands.
The police questioned some crew members of the American Export liner Exochorda tonight in connection with the murder of a woman janitor. The woman, 47 years old

Governor Moore submitted to the Legislature tonight a budget calling for appropriations totaling $40,158,172 for operation of the State Government, exclusive of the Highway Department, in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

Four men who have beaten 9:06 for two miles, time no American ever had bettered two short years ago, will match strides in the invitation two-mile run at the New York A. C. seventieth anniversary indoor track games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

A meeting of holders of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company's 5 per cent Se ries A mortgage bonds due in 1975 has been called for 10:30 A. M., Feb. 28, at the Hotel Commodore to consider a proposed reorganization plan filed in proceedings before the Interstate Commerce Commission and to determine what, if any, steps should be taken by the bondholders at this time.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, went on trial yesterday in Kings County Court on a charge of grand larceny while acting as a receiver appointed to handle a trust fund belonging to John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

A meeting of holders of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company's 5 per cent Se ries A mortgage bonds due in 1975 has been called for 10:30 A. M., Feb. 28, at the Hotel Commodore to consider a proposed reorganization plan filed in proceedings before the Interstate Commerce Commission and to determine what, if any, steps should be taken by the bondholders at this time.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, went on trial yesterday in Kings County Court on a charge of grand larceny while acting as a receiver appointed to handle a trust fund belonging to John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

Reporting that a survey of retail outlets has convinced them that consumers are willing to buy Japanese goods despite the attempt to organize a boycott against such products, A. L. Tuska Son Co., Inc., importers of Japanese goods, 152 Fifth Avenue, has offered to guarantee stores against loss on purchases of their merchandise.

The Legislature was asked tonight to appoint a special legislative joint committee to make a "thorough and comprehensive" investigation of the milk industry in the State, in a resolution submitted by Assemblyman Peterson. Schuyler County Republican.

News that the Treasury had importantly modified its gold "sterilization" program came yesterday after the close of the business day. Rumors that something of this sort would occur were floating about the financial district throughout the day, but there was little anticipatory action.

Irving Wight Metcalf, a Congregational minister, formerly pastor of the Hough Avenue Church, Cleveland, who had been in business here since 1902, died Saturday at the age of 82. He was a trustee of Oberlin College, 1900-26, and a trustee of the Thessalonica Agricultural and Industrial Institute at Salonica, Greece, since 1904.

Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, died here early today. The 59-year-old naval physician, close friend of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the late President Wilson, had been ill of anemia.

The Board of Estimate announced today the appointment of the Rev. Thomas Plassman, president of St. Bonaventure College, Allegany, as a member of the college council, the board's advisory body on college matters. He succeeds the Rev.

Judge and Mrs. David H. Kincheloe gave a dinner last night at their home, 115 East Eighty-sixth Street, for their daughter, Mrs. James H. Davis, wife of Lieutenant Davis, U.S.N. Mrs. Davis arrived here yesterday from Panama.
A study by the National Bank of Costa Rica shows the cost of living increased 6.28 per cent during 1937. This is attributed largely to the lower price of one of Costa Rica's chief products, coffee.

The bond market worked irregularly higher in listless trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Developments of the day tended to restrict activity rather than to stimulate speculative or investment interest as the financial community awaited an announcement from Secretary Morgenthau.
A schedule of twenty games, including twelve Eastern intercollegiate league contests, for the University of Pennsylvania baseball team was announced today by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics.

Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York State Racing Commission will head a committee to make a thorough investigation of starting systems, it was said yesterday at Miami. He was named to the post by Edwin J. Brown, president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners.

Mary Schwimbersky conveyed the parcel at 226 E 111th St. 30x101, to Charles Schwimbersky, subject to a first mortgage for $26,000, she owning a 60 per cent interest in this property. Alfred Abeles owns a 40 per cent interest, and he and Charles Schwimbersky gave a mortgage to Libbie P. Motak thereon for $10,000, due in three years at 5 per cent.
Fritz Crisler, full of good humor but short on predictions, began the informal preliminaries, of trying to rebuild the University of Michigan's football fortunes today.

APPEL--Betty, beloved mother of Max and Jean, sister of Esther Goldsmith and Fanny Wallerstein, and devoted aunt of A. Harry Wallerstein. Services from her late residence, 227 Beach 80th St., Rockaway Beach, Wednesday, Feb. 16, at 1:30 P. M. Please omit flowers.

A Kuomintang (Nationalist party) effort to counteract the growing tendency of Chinese youth to follow the leadership of the Communist party is seen in the formation here of the Chinese Youths National Salvation Association.

The annual Mi-Careme luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit Houses of Study will take place March 14 at the Ambassador. The benefit is under the auspices of the Loyola School, of which the Rev. Coleman Nevils is rector and the Rev. Francis E. Garner is headmaster.

A bill has been introduced in the Legislature providing for the purchase of Lindenwald, the home of Martin Van Buren-New York's first President of the United States and the first President "born as an American citizen * * * after the Declaration of Independence," all his predecessors having been born as British subjects.
Tomorrow evening at 7 o'clock the Casiho in the Air at the Belmont-Plaza Hotel will be the scene of the annual gathering of the Booksellers League of New York.
With some 3,000 visitors on the campus, including 2,500 up-State high school pupils, Cornell's annual farm and home week opened with a record first day registration today.

Attilio F. Lipari, civil engineer, died suddenly Sunday of a heart attack at his residence, 568 West261st Street. Born in Italy fortyeight years ago, he had lived in this country since boyhood. In the World War he held the rank of Lieutenant in the United States Army while acting as liaison officer with the Italian Commission here.
Plans to build a nine-story $3,000,000 tuberculosis hospital with accommodations for 530 patients in Jamaica, Queens, were announced yesterday by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.
Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of State Police, lauded tonight newspaper treatment of crime news, and reported - conviction of 95 per cent of 63,431 persons arrested by State troopers in 1937.
The Beethoven Association had planned to honor a distinguished contemporary composer, Georges Enesco, with a program of his works at its concert at the Town Hall last night.

An application for an injunction to prevent construction of two apartment houses in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Brooklyn.

The operators of thirty American ship lines received requests yesterday from the National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, to start negotiations for wage contracts under the terms of the Wagner Act.
The Earl and Countess of Meath, of Killruddery, Bray, Ireland, are at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Moncrieffe Livingston, now at the Plaza, will leave Thursday for their place at Quitman, Ga.

Production of gold in the Union of South Africa in 1937 amounted to 11,740,891 fine ounces, setting a new high record, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Pretoria, made public today.

The Assembly tonight passed, without debate, the New York City Omnibus Bill, codifying into the law provisions relating to New York City which had been purposely omitted from the New York City new charter.

With tonnage sales running on a par with a year ago, retail grocery dollar volume is approximately a per cent below February, 1937, levels and wholesale billings are off 7 to 8 per cent, according to the weekly survey made by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc. According to this report,

New York City sold yesterday $25,000,000 of revenue bills to twenty-six banks, it was announced by Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller. This marks the third such sale of tax-anticipation securities since the first of the year, which formerly were handled by the revolving fund provided in the bankers agreement.

The Legislature was asked tonight to memorialize Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Stanley Isaacs of Manhattan to remove Simon W. Gerson, a member of the Communist party, who is confidential examiner in the Borough President's office.

Eight members of the handicap division, including four nominees for the McLennan Memorial and the Widener Challenge Cup, clashed in the Palatka Purse at Hialeah Park today, with Miss Mary Hirsch's No Sir, long a disappointment, finally coming through with a top performance for his first victory in eight Florida starts.

Mike Belloise, Bronx featherweight, triumphantly returned to boxing last night after a long absence. In the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace he carried off the decision over husky Frankie Terranova of Harlem, while about 3,000 fans looked on.
The cause of the death of the Rev. Father Gerard Donovan, Maryknoll missionary from Pittsburgh, who was abducted Oct. 5, has not been ascertained. It is believed he died about a week ago.

A most unwonted stir in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Pifty-seventh Street, is oceasioned this week by the arrival of three exhibitions, which fill the galleries usually occupied by but ohe large group show.

Amri Galli-Campi, American coloratura soprano, has been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson. She will make her first appearance as a member of the company in Cleveland on Thursday evening, April 7, when the Metropolitan will be on tour. She will sing the role of Gilda in "Rigoletto."
Liquidation developed in North American wheat markets today as the result of highly beneficial rains in the central and eastern sections of Kansas and Oklahoma.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
Total construction contracts for both public and private work awarded during January in thirtyseven Eastern States amounted to $195,472,000, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

For his "bravery and fortitude" while a newspaper man with the Italian Army in Ethiopia, a bronze medal was awarded yesterday to the late Edward J. Neil Jr., for the march on Addis Ababa. The campaign cross also was presented by the Italian Government.

Several properties in Brooklyn were reported by brokers yesterday as having changed hands. Among them was the three-story dwelling on a plot 18 by 100 feet, at 520 Second Street, which was sold by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank to Philip Vinticinque, who will alter it into two-room suites. L. L.

Today's major events: "Salome," evening, and "Rigoletto," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; John Charles Thomas, baritone, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Harold Bauer, Albert Spalding, Gaspar Cassado, trio concert; Town Hall, evening; Josef Martin, pianist, Town Hall, afternoon; Madrigal Singers, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

The Court of Appeals will return to Albany for a special session Monday to hear arguments in the appeal of New York City from the decision of the Appellate Division, which set aside Mayor La Guardia's budget in favor of the city budget adopted by the old Board of Aldermen last Fall.

The enforced retirement of several army officers, reported from Washington last week, has already affected local army posts, it was indicated yesterday. Brig. Gen. Lawrence Halstead, who took command of the First Brigade of the First Division, with headquarters in Fort Hamilton,

Turpentine firm 25c; sales 2 barrels; receipts 331 barrels; shipments 158 barrels; stock 26,881 barrels. Resin firm; sales 155; receipts 697; shipments 897; stock 76,302. Quote: B. D, $3.90; E, 54: F. $4.90: G, $5.15; H, I, $5.20; K, $5.35; M, $5.45; N, $5.80; WG, $7; WW, X, $7.40.
A play-off berth is virtually assured for the New York Americans as the result of developments along the National Hockey League front last night. The Spangled skaters
Another step toward normal coverage of foreign exchange for imports was undertaken today by the government, and officials of the Bank of Brazil predict that normality will be reached in May.

The first New York showing of the WPA Federal Art Project outside the New York region was opened yesterday in the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, in an exhibition of work by artists of the Illinois Project.

The news from Vienna of Cabinet changes to make room for pro-Nazi representatives caused no particular surprise here, for such a development had been foreseen ever since the meeting between Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg at Venice In April, 1937.

R. Remero, an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommended to it today that the Minneapolis, Red Lake Manitoba Railway Company be permitted to abandon its thirty-two-mile line from Bemidji to Redby, Beltrami County, Minn., and also its trackage rights over the Great Northern at Bemidji.

The $1,316,527,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will take action looking to the issuance of an additional 2,000,000 shares of common stock in order to permit future financing in view of expected capital requirements, according to a notice sent to shareholders yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the utility.

Michael David Mirsky, retired manufacturer of women's wrappers, died on Monday of a heart ailment in Beth Israel Hospital after a twomonth illness. Mr. Mirsky, who lived at 1 West Sixty-eighth Street, was 79 years old.

Radio as a means of strengthening further the spirit of solidarity and harmony among the nations of the Western Hemisphere was extolled last night during the first broadcast on a short-wave channel recently assigned by the Federal Communications Commission, for cultural purposes between the Americas, to the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation.

IT seems to be widely believed in this country that Nazi Germany is run by a group of gangsters. The Nazis have not blown up our gunboats or slapped our 'diplomats in the face, but they would, be little more hated and reviled had they done so.

A bill carrying out President Roosevelt's request for an additional $250,000,000 to finance the increased relief load of the Works Progress Administration for the rest of the fiscal year was reported favorably to the House today by its Appropriations Committee.

The marriage of Miss Helen Hicks, woman golfer and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jarvis H. Hicks of Woodmere, to Whitney Harb of Little Rock, Ark., took place this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here. The Right Rev.
The Assembly passed today the bill codifying in the State law the section of the old New York City charter and the existing State law, dealing with county offices.

Undismayed by the discouraging conditions that prevail in the upper stretches of the "North" country in general, the vast army of skiers in the metropolitan area is making extensive preparations to flee the city to wherever snowy slopes may be found the coming holiday weekend.
Winners of four prizes which will be presented at the Naval Academy during the next June Week ceremonies were announced today. They, are:

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 14: Colorado, San Pedro to Puget Sound Yard. G. D. Ford, Yokohama to Shanghai. Gannet, at Coco Solo. Nitro, Culebra to Norfolk. Ralph Talbot at Guantanamo.

South Kent defeated Kent at hockey today, .4 to 3. Each team made one goal in the first and third periods, but South Kent tallied two to Kent's one in the second. The high light was a solo score by Captain Waller of South Kent in the second period.

An extensive program, which will this open in May and continue into late October, has been arranged by the In Long Island Golf Association and brace the Long Island Professional Golf the. Association.

About 30,000 northern steel workers confronted Premier Camille Chautemps's Government with a virtual ultimatum tonight to persuade employers to grant pay increases within thirtysix hours or face a strike.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition today in its rooms of recent accessions five paintings of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries willed by Ogden Mills. Although the paintings were bequeathed in 1929, they have just come into possession of the museum, having been left to Mr. Mills's son, Ogden L. Mills, during his lifetime.
Meeting, Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Community House. 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, Mrs. Isaac Kubie.

President Roosevelt gave enthusiastic endorsement today of the method of excess condemnation as a means of making possible large-scale selfliquidating public works projects, such as transcontinental highways, which he has recently discussed with members of the Senate andHouse and Mayors of Midwestern cities.

Paul Williams, star sprinter on the University of Pennsylvania's swimming team, is well ahead of the field of point scorers, according to the statistics released yesterday by the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League. Williams has accounted for 37 points.

All favorites triumphed in the first round of match play for the annual South Florida golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. Among those who advanced to the quarter-finals were Tommy Goodwin of Mamaroneck, N. Y., defending champion; Joseph Schenck 3d

The Princeton varsity wrestling E team ran its string of victories to nineteen straight by defeating Columbia, 24-6, tonight. Fred Capers, Charley Powers and Charley Toll scored falls for the Tigers, while Bob Taylor and Joe Bartolf tallied the Columbia points on the referee's decision.

ALBERTI-Suddenly, in his sixty-sixth year, Frank Albertt Sr. Reposing at his residence, 74 Washington Place, New York City. Announcement of funeral later. APPEL--Betty, beloved mother of Max and Jean, sister of Esther Goldsmith and Fanny Wallerstein, and devoted aunt of A. Harry Wallerstein. Services from her
Hockey teams of nine nations, headed by the tournament's "big three"-the United States, Canada and Great Britainadvanced to the second round of the world amateur hockey championships tonight.

James M. Golding, former Kings County Commander of the American Legion, was appointed yesterday as a member of the staff of William F. X. Geoghan, District Attorney in Brooklyn. Mr. Golding, who will take office on March 1, is expected to receive an annual salary of about $7,000.

A decided upset marked the second round of the New York Junior League's eighth annual invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday when Miss Helen Stone of the home club defeated Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, seeded No. 2, in five games, 15-6, 15-13, 11-15, 10-15, 15-11, on the courts of the Junior League.
An exhibition called "The Tragic Painters" has just opened at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fiftyseventh Street, to remain current until March 12. The term "tragic"

Upon intervention of Mayor La Guardia, representatives of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers and the Furriers Joint Council of the International FurWorkers Union yesterday agreed to submit to the State Mediation Board the dispute which has given rise to the combination lockout and strike in the industry.

KNOWLEDGE comes, even if wisdom doesn't linger, as the late Alfred Lord Tennyson, speaking in hollow accents from Locksley Hall, said that it would-or should. But the Poet Laureate of the Victorian era was half in the right anyway. Knowledge does come and "quo minime reris," or from the most unexpected places.

The indications are for cloudy weather followed by light snow today and for snow tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at, the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

Technical studies made in Germany and German capital will contribute to the establishment of a cellulose manufacturing plant at Valdivia, in Southern Chile, where 20,000 hectares [roughly 8,000 acres]
World consumption of petroleum and related products for military purposes last year is estimated at 57,945,600 barrels by V. R. Garfias of the Cities Service Company. Mr.

Gilbert Miller's second offering in two days-this one is in association with Ashley Dukes-will go on tonight at the Ritz Theatre. It is the production of T. S. Eliot's poetic play, "Murder in the Cathedral," which was shown here two years ago by the Federal Theatre Project. Robert Speaight,
The American Federation of Labor rejected yesterday Joseph Stalin's appeal to organized labor in all countries to aid the Soviet regime in the event of war.

George Clarke Moore of White Plains, manager of the branch of the Corn Exchange Bank at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street, died here yesterday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital of a tumor after an illness of four months. He was born in Astoria, Queens, fifty-one years ago.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. was re-elected chairman of the board of the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York yesterday morning at the annual meeting of the board in the federation's headquarters at 670 Lexington Avenue.

Eleven students have been elected to membership in Pi Mu Epsilon, the Hunter College chapter of the national honor mathematics fraternity. The following were chosen on the basis of character as well as scholarship: Thelma Barish,
Archie San Romani was named yesterday as one of the four starters in the Baxter Mile, the feature of the New York Athletic Club meet at Madison Square Garden .on Saturday night.

Earnings of the Monsanto Chemical Company and its subsidiaries last year were $4,898,309 after all charges, including taxes, minority interest and preferred dividend requirements, according to the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday. This was equal to $4.4C a share on the outstanding common stock.
Without opinion, the Appellate Term of the Supreme. Court reversed yesterday a judgment for $19.47 given by a Municipal Court

Oscar Odd McIntyre's "neighbors" agreed tonight that he would have wanted a simple, unpretentious burial, but his home town Chamber of Commerce laid plans for one of its biggest civic observances to honor him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposed revision of the capital gains tax has been submitted in the subcommittee report to the Ways and Means Committee, dated Jan. 14. It shows some slight concession to the pleading of business men for a drastic reduction of this tax. However,
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor are "not contemplating a visit to the United States in the near future," the Duke's equerry has advised-the Sir William Johnson Bicentennial Committee.
The British Broadcasting Corporation's news broadcasts to Central and South America in Spanish and Portuguese will begin on March 15, it was announced tonight.
Air corps officers flying from Langley' Field, Va., landed here today in six "flying fortresses." They will take off tomorrow on a 3,132-mile nonstop flight to Lima, Peru.

The marriage of Miss Jane Lewis Mason, daughter of Mrs. Allen Mason of Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Mason, to James Gordon Campbell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Campbell of South Orange, N. J., took Place here at noon today in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.
Among 200 cabin passengers arriving yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania were seventy-five fashion experts returning from the opening of the Spring fashion shows in Paris.

A new method for producing iron and steel, that promises an annual saving of $35,000,000 to $70,000,000 to the industry in the United States, was described yesterday before the 148th meeting of American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty- ninth Street.

BRIESEN, ANNA VON (Feb. 9). Estate, about $25,000. To Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken, Hotel Ambassador; Fritz von Briesen and Hans von Briesen, executor, both of 850 Park Ave., children, residue equally. BUCHWALD. JENNIE (Jan. 29). Estate, not more than $1,000.

Scheduling an earlier production than was first intended, Selznick International today placed "The Young in Heart," with Janet Gaynor, on the studio's immediate program and assigned Douglas Fairbanks Jr. to the co-starring role, tl one in which Ronald Colman had been tentatively cast.

Operations last year of the United Carbon Company resulted in record earnings. The net profit of the company and its subsidiaries amounted to $2,350,486, after interest, depreciation, depletion, minority interest, Federal and State income taxes and $22,000 provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

Mrs. Ethel Gerlach Brown, widow of Charles H. Brown and daughter of Mrs. Charles A. Gerlach of Yonkers and the late Mr. Gerlach, was married to John Scudder Carroll this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 497 North Broadway.

Sonja Henie said today she would accompany Dick Merrill on a flight to her native Norway in June. The ice-skating star came from New York last week in a special plane piloted by Merrill, veteran of transatlantic flying.

Monday's announcement by the Treasury, modifying the "gold sterilization" process, can hardly be regarded as a highly important contribution to financial recovery. It is, however, rather obviously the lifting of part of a heavy burden from the Treasury.

The F. L. Jacobs Company of Detroit announced yesterday the acquisition of the W. I. T. Manufacturing Corporation, including its subsidiary, the Air-Track Manufacturing Corporation of College Park, Md. The transaction consisted
Jim Herbert of New York University tonight scored his eighth consecutive indoor victory in winning the invitation 600 at the Knights of Columbus games in Rhode Island Auditorium in 1:15.1.

A return of 31/2 per cent as the maximum to be expected from properly invested trust funds for some time to come was set at the mid-Winter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, opening a three-day session yesterday in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Rumania's "new era" begins with curious jolts and contradictions. Without a real coup d'etat it is not easy to abolish politics in a country that for months has thought and talked nothing else.

The British Embassy declared today that Russia's insistence that Britain close her Consulate General at Leningrad was unjustified, discourteous and detrimental to the good relations of the two countries.

A1though the 1938 Yonkers City budget is still a matter of controversy, with the tax rate depending on future court decisions, Controller James Hushion met today a $125,000 payroll and $150,000 in interest charges on municipal bonds with funds borrowed from Yonkers banks.
Sefton Tranter of the New York A. C. gained the final round of the Whitehall Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday by downing one of the favorites.

Contracts made on a when as ana if issued basis up to and including Feb. 21 in Peoples Light and Power Company securities must be settled on Feb. 25 by delivery of said securities, according to a ruling issued yesterday by the Uniform Practice Committee of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc.

A higher pay scale was in effect today for the musicians of the world-famous French Republican Guard Band. Under- a decree signed by War Minister Edouard Daladier the best performers will get a topsergeant's pay of 80 francs a day, as compared with the old stipend of 40 francs.

Three Canadian athletes equaled or bettered British Empire games marks in a Canada-Australia invitation carnival tonight. Bill Fritz, Toronto, won the 440yard dash in 0:47.5, two-fifths of a second better than the games record of 0:47.9 set by Denis Shore, South Africa, Feb. 10 and equaled by Bill Roberts, England, in winning the final Saturday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 12: CAPTAINS Haines, G. W., orders of Jan. 26 revoked, to continue duty, Naval War College, Newport. R. I, Scanland, F. W., staff commander Supmariple Force, U. S. Fleet, to duty as commander Submarine Squadron 4 and additional duty as commanding office Submarine Base, Pearl Harbor, T. H, May 9.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., former New York State champion, won her first Winter competition today by defeating Miss Sally Guth of Webster Grove, Mo., in the 18-hole final round of the Everglades invitation golf tournament, by 1 up.

The Independent Association of Chrysler Employes filed with the Chrysler Corporation today a demand for recognition as the collective bargaining agent of its members in the company's plants. E. L. Liddell,

Mr. and Mrs. Peter Jay have joined Mrs. Jay's mother, Mrs. Holden McGinley of Milton, Mass., at the Ambassador. Miss Martha Clarke of Boston also is visiting Mrs. McGinley. Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Lindabury have come from Princeton to the Savov-Plaza.

The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation has purchased from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation an issue of $1,400,000 of People of Puerto Rico 4 per cent electric power revenue bonds maturing from July 1, 1938, to 1956.

The Board of Education's bureau of attendance, whose corps of truant officers deals with boys and girls who play hookeyy," is becoming increasingly social-minded. Emphasis is now to be placed on the child's welfare, on the "behind-thescenes" situation that has made the pupil a problem case.

The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Maurice Milligan for another four-year term as District Attorney at Kansas City. The action was taken despite an attack by Senator Truman on the District Attorney's record.
Captain John L. Young, founder of the Young Million Dollar Pier Company of Atlantic City, died in his home here today. He was 84 years old.
The United States Marines made it clear today that they felt capable of patroling the American defense sector of the International Settlement without assistance from the Japanese.

Randolfo Pacciardi, who founded and commanded the Garibaldi AntiFascist Brigade for the Loyalists in Spain, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by his wife, to make a lecture tour.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $9,351,627 for 1937, including $1,055,972 cash received for patent rights and licenses and after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and $100,057 provision for surtax on undistributed profits.
A drive to sell $1,000,000 in "baby bonds" to meet an expected deficit in the city treasury passed its quota today.
A new high in useless thefts was reached yesterday with the disclosure that some one had pilfered an indictment from the files of the Brooklyn Federal Court.

Max Schmeling's third warm-up bout before meeting Champion Joe Louis for the heavyweight title in the United States this Summer will be with Steve Dudas at Hamburg April 19, Max Machon, Schmeling's trainer, told The Associated Press today.
Abolition of the 18-year-old New York State Athletic Commission was proposed in the Legislature today by Democratic Assemblyman Crawford W. Hawkins, Brooklyn.

The early use of "admiral" as a byform of "admirable" ceases to be obsolete in the person and career of Rear Admiral Grayson. He took his title of the sea, but his service was largely on the land and altogether "admirable."
William H. Raab of Bronxville fell dead on the street here today. He was stricken with heart disease while on his way to the office of the Todd Shipyards Corporation at 1 Broadway. New York.

Maurice Deiches, a member of the Board of Higher Education and a leading lawyer of the city, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, where he had undergone an operation a week ago. He was 56 years old.

Stagehand, chalking up his third straight victory here, won the featured $1,500 Grade A Derby Trial Handicap today and lived up to the expectations of the Maxwell Howard Stable as a formidable threat in the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby' next Tuesday.

In an effort to induce the Yale athletic management to allow the baseball nine to take a Southern trip at Easter, The Yale Daily News today asserted it had polled the players and found they were 100 per cent for the journey.

Two basketball games which only a couple of weeks ago shaped up as being decidedly one-sided now appear as two interesting affairs, with the results very much in doubt. They are the contests listed for Madison Square Garden tonight between Fordham and N. Y. U. and St. John's and Manhattan.

Plans for establishing a Holland house in or near Rockefeller Center, as a commercial, educational and cultural link between The Netherlands and the United States, were revealed yesterday at a reception given by the Netherland-America Foundation at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.
The Harvard Club and the Downtown A. C. advanced to the final in the play-offs for the Class B Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association championship yesterday.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Feb. 10 were higher in all five trade groups, compared with the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Lawrence Finnerty, 41 years old, a newspaper mechanical department employee, was found dead of burns and illuminating gas, early yesterday morning, in the kitchen of his apartment at 1,439 University Avenue, the Bronx. The body was discovered by police and firemen, who responded to a gas explosion alarm.
Faced with what it knows to be the surrender of Austria to the might of Nazi Germany, the British Government publicly stuck its head deep into the sand today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading the article in The Saturday Evening Post by Ralph F. Armstrong on the $4,000,000 village. I visited Jersey Homesteads and talked to the people. They would be happy in their new homes if they could be employed in the factory at least nine or ten months of the year.

After a White House conference between President Roosevelt and Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, it was revealed today that the Administration desires the simultaneous development of power sources held mutually by the United States and Canada through joint control of border waterways.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Livingston Gross have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gross's sister, Miss Carolyn Williams Callanan, daughter of the late Mr. -and Mrs. James Henry Callanan, to Andrew Pierce Kellogg, son of Mrs. James Warner Kellogg of this city and the late Mr. Kellogg.

President Roosevelt, in further explanation of his national defense policy, said today that in its naval construction program the United States must keep in mind the necessity of a fleet capable of defending both its coasts, regardless of the ratio that the number of its ships might have to those of other nations.
The fortieth anniversary of the sinking of the battleship Maine in Havana Harbor was observed this morning at the Maine monument on Malecon Drive.

Name Change The name of Fireman 4th grade John Czmor, Engine Co. 92, has been changed to read "John Cymore." Trial Decisions The following members of the department having been tried before Francis X. Giacone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, for violation of Rules and Regulations, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

At the annual meeting of .shareholders of the American Gas and Electric Company yesterday, George N. Tidd, president, told stockholders that the company was not particularly apprehensive as to what would result should the company lose its joint suit with the Electric Bond and Share Company testing the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.
The La Guardia administration sent to the Legislature today a bill for the extension of the emergency taxing powers of the city and a wave of protest immediately started on Capitol Hill.

The problem of mosquito control stirred a vigorous debate today at a general session of the North American wildlife conference. Every one agreed there should be mosquito control, but how the control should be carried out was a moot point.

Is there not breath and spirit in this tree That stoically weathers heat and storm And gives no sign? Beneath this shaggy form, Does secret force not stream invisibly? Are there not hints no flesh-bound eye can see
Chinese troops are fighting desperately to stem the Japanese drive toward Chengchow and Kaifeng on the Lung-Hai Railway. The Japanese were said to have been checked north and northeast of Sinsiang.

Dr. Leslie A. Burns, 35 years old, of Westminster, Mass., physician of the Grace liner Santa Rita, died at sea on Saturday of an overdose of a sleeping potion. He was making his first voyage as the ship's doctor, according to police who investigated after the liner docked from South America.

Six internationalists are on the squad of the Cambridge rugby team which arrives here March 21 for a five-game tour which includes contests with Yale, Harvard, Princeton, an all-New-York team and an aggregation selected from the pick of the East. Three played with England and the same number with Scotland.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I add another chapter to the already long record of insanities and absurdities in the State Unemployment Insurance Law? A mercantile firm of this city recently made an assignment to me for the benefit of creditors and its assets were liquidated as well as its employes.

Luxury styles in sheer washable fabrics were presented yesterday in the first style show of the Swiss Fabric Group, an organization of thirteen Swiss manufacturers of textiles, before an audience of 300 merchandising executives and fashion writers at the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center.

Princeton University's varsity and freshman crew squads, seventy-two men in all, took to the cold waters of Lake Carnegie late today. Coach Fred Spuhn, entering upon his first season as Gordon Sikes's successor, sent the Tiger oarsmen off to their earliest outdoor practice in- the twenty-seven-year history of intercollegiate rowing at Princeton.

Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs entertained this afternoon with a luncheon at the Alibi. Her guests were Lord and Lady Stanley, Sir George and Lady Prescott, Baron and Baroness Guy de Rothschild, Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan,
Representatives Ryo Iwase and Takeo Miki, backbenchers, have called- a public meeting for Saturday to form a society to be called the Allied Comrades on American Policy.

We publish on this page today an impressive letter from Elisha M. Friedman on the capital gains tax. Mr. Friedman demonstrates rather conclusively that the tax in its present form, wholly apart from its other defects, does not even produce revenue.

Congressional critics of the Roosevelt Administration are less than fair when they lay at its door responsibility for the fact that naval limitation has broken down and that nothing is being done to revive it. The Administration has a consistent record of trying to the best of its ability to make some kind of limitation a reality.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under the title: "Sweep Out the Yankees, Paper in Ecuador Urges," THE NEW YORK TIMES of today publishes an information taken from La Carcajada, newspaper of Guayaquil, by your correspondent at Panama.

Because it is based very largely on American standards, Danish advertising is on a high plane, according to a special report prepared by W. A. Schaffner of H. N. Elterich, Inc., export advertising agency here.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,324,500 oarrels, compared with 3,316,450 in the preceding week, an increase of 8,050, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The average was 113,700 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,438,200 daily by the Bureau of Mines for Februarv.

Daily average sales in chain grocery stores in January were about 1 per cent lower in value than in January, 1937, the Commerce Department announced today. Sales declined less than seasonally in -January from December, however, and the adjusted index rose to 97 from 94.

Although economic liquidation has about run its course, business operations are being held at a low level by "the psychological factor of fear and distrust of government policy," A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., New York, told the Purchasing Agents Association of Pittsburgh tonight.

Miss Katharine A. Wells, associate director of the Church Army, addressed a thanksgiving and consecration service yesterday that celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Mission Sisters of the Church Army.

The hardworking House of Commons relaxed to roars of laughter today when Oliver Stanley, president of the Board of Trade, was asked to produce figures on the number of corsets imported by Great Britain from the United States in the last five years.

Trading in steer hinds and' ribs was fair and prices were higher. Other classes were generally slow. The cow market was stronger, veal weak to lower, ether classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to slightly lower, other classes mostly unchanged from Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
John Ringling North, executive head of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus, was bitten on the arm by Gargantu the Great, giant gorilla, at the circus Winter quarters today

The Rev. Fred C. Fink, pastor of the College Street Christian Temple for nearly forty-eight years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 76 years old.

A frenzied mob of 800 men and women demolished a jail, set fire to a Federal building, threatened jailers with hanging and exchanged bullets with soldiers today in a futile attempt to lynch the man who ravished and killed an 8-year-old girl.

A five-day hearing on the reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company ended today in the United States District Court here. Judge John P. Nields adjourned the hearing after granting to a group of stockholders who opposed the plan two weeks in which to file briefs in support of their stand.

Police Captain Joseph (Square Deal Joe) N. Gassman of 84-12 Eighty-sixth Road, Woodhaven, for the last six years assigned to the Bergen Street Station, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Brooklyn Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

William H. Muench of Cincinnati, a member of the Ohio Society in New York and of the Queen .City Club of his home city, and Miss Phyllis Belle Engelbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton S. Engelbeck of POort Clinton, Ohio, his former secretary, were married here this afternoon in the parsonage of the First Christian Church by the Rev. Everett S. Smith.

How a senior supervising account ant falsified earnings and assets statements, of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., for 1934, 1935 and 1936 without profit to himself on "impulses", he could not explain was Judge divulged yesterday in a. report to the company's shareholders.

Author and former newspaper man, Howard Angus Kennedy died in a hospital today at the age of 76. He was correspondent for The Montreal Daily Witness and The New York Herald covering the Riel rebellion in 1885.

New Yorkers sailing today for the Channel ports on the steamship President Harding of the United States Lines are Mr. and Mrs. Walter Widmann, Mrs. W. E. Andrews, Miss Elizabeth O'Neill, Jorge Soto del Corral, Colombian Minister to France; Mr. and Mrs. Sydney J. Williams and George Gohmann.

Anschluss, the post-war German ideal of a union-with Austria, came appreciably nearer yesterday when Vienna yielded to a Berlin ultimatum and appointed pro-Nazi Ministers to control the police, foreign affairs and the administration of justice in a shake-up of the Cabinet.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

The elimination of the defending titleholder and medal winner, as well as several other favorites, featured the first match round in the eleventh annual national championship of golf club champions on St. Augustine links today.

Net additions of $104,477 to surplus in 1937 were reported yesterday by the New York Curb Exchange. This result surprised the financial community, which had expected an operating deficit in view of the salary cuts enforced recently by the institution.

Stockholders of the Carib Syndicate, Ltd., approved yesterday the granting of options to four members of the company's executive committee to buy up to 10,000 shares each of the Carib stock at $1.50 a share, exercisable in equal yearly installments over a three-year period.

Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, who died early this morning, will be buried on Thursday. Services will be held at 11 A. M. in St. John's Church, of which he had been a vestryman since 1926. President Roosevelt and many other distinguished persons are expected to attend.

Irving Barr, 21-year-old sign painter of 1,551 Park Place, Brooklyn, was found guilty of felony murder in the first degree by a jury of six men and six women before County Judge James M. Barrett in the Bronx last night.

Mr. and Mrs. S. Sloan Colt gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History. The occasion was the latest in the series of "natural science evenings" in the interests of the ten-year development program of the museum.

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following reserve officers, released to headquarters First Military Area, are as signed to units as indicated: 367th Field Artillery-2d Lieut. George ? Downing Jr., FA-Res., 102 Jay St. Schenectady, N. Y.

The semi-final bracket in the metropolitan indoor tennis championship was filled yesterday at the Hamilton Tennis Club in the 102d Engineers Armory. Joseph Fishbach, defending titleholder, advanced by defeating Morris Adelsberg in straight sets. 8-6. 6-2.

Receivers of the Wabash Railroad filed today a new plan of reorganization in Federal Judge Charles B. Davis's court, reporting at the same time that approval had not been given to the road by any of the various groups of security holders because of many controversial matters that had arisen.

For the first time the American Federation of Labor has a counsel, retained on a permanent basis. William Green, president of the federation, announced today the appointment of Joseph A. Padway of Milwaukee, a recognized authority on labor law.
General John J. Pershing, World War commander of the American Expeditionary Forces, was confined to his hotel today with a "rather severe" attack of rheumatism. He is 77 years old.

The scheduled appearance last night of C. T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, on a radio program presenting Lowell Thomas, radio commentator, was canceled yesterday by officials of the National Broadcasting Company when it was learned he had been invited to take part in the broadcast.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. William J. Ferris of Field Point Park of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lydia S. Ferris, to Granville K. Lester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward 0. Lester of Stamford.

The new liner Pasteur of 30,000 tons was launched this afternoon at the Penhoet shipyards. The Pasteur, replacing the Atlantique, which burned at sea, will be placed in the Buenos Aires service next year. She will develop between twenty-five and twenty-eight knots for the hypothetical blue ribbon of this run.

Members of the City Council astonished themselves yesterday by holding the first peaceful meeting of the Council's short career. To the great disappointment of the galleries the Councilmen transacted routine business with a complete absence of the verbal fireworks that have illuminated earlier sessions.
Charles J. Margiotti, State Attorney General, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor to succeed George H. Earle.

In New Jersey Municipalities for February are many useful suggestions for the student of municipal affairs, but the simple layman's heart finds its best nourishment-in a reprint from The Trenton State Gazette.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income for the year after all expenses and charges of $1,913,604. This was equal to $2.57 a share on the outstanding capital stock and compares with a net of $2,250,812, or $3.02 a capital share, earned in 1936.

John F. Berrigan, 72 years old, an assistant deputy clerk assigned to Special Term, Part I, of the New York Supreme Court, celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of his appointment as a court employe. He was first appointed,...
Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, offered today what he termed a "soft" answer to Postmaster General Farley's criticism of his Lincoln Day speech in Boston.

Langendorf, United Bakeries, Inc., has called a special meeting of Class A and B stockholders for March 1 to vote on a plan of recapitalization intended to eliminate arrears of $7 a share on the Class A stock.
Bondholders of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company and the company itself lost today in an attempt to prevent the Seaford Power and Light Company from continuing operation in Seaford.

President Alberto Enriquez, according to the newspaper Telegrafo, has rejected the plea of the South American Development Company to submit its controversy with the government to an arbitration tribunal or the Supreme Court.

The Transit Commission's unification plan for which the commissioners said Monday that they had obtained the "virtual consent" of the private interests is based on the cash payment of $336,000,000 for the lines, one of the city's transit advisers disclosed yesterday.

Passage of the Crop Control Bill by the Senate caused considerable activity on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices rose to the highest levels reached since the market broke under pressure of the largest crop ever raised in the South last Fall.

Great Britain is ready to take any steps necessary to counter any harmful effect on its business because of the decision of the United States to relax its gold sterilization program, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today in reply to questions.
Reports from Western Union and Postal Telegraph revealed yesterday that the greatest volume of Saint Valentine's Day business in the history of telegraphy was handled on Monday.

The marriage of Miss Eugenie Louise Beaupre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Beaupre of New York and Los Angeles to Philip Constantine Sellars, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Sellars of this city, has been announced. The ceremony took place on Feb. 2 in Harrison.

The four seeded players in the Class B women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Country Club came through in their second-round matches today. Miss Ethel Miller, the top-seeded star, advanced easily by defeating Miss Zelia Peet. 15-9. 15-12, 15-8.

The army, putting into effect a shakeup of the football coaching staff at West Point, today ordered Captain Garrison H. Davidson, head coach, to duty in Hawaii. Captain William H. Wood will succeed Davidson at the military academy.

Little disposition to ? business was shown in another declining stock market here today. Gilt-edge issues fell and the uncertain international political situation affected the foreign bond section, in which Austrian and German loans were lower.

After being bombarded again for four hours today with questions from two Senators, Robert H. Jackson was approved by a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee as Solicitor General. The subcommittee, which voted 5 to 2 for confirming President Roosevelt's nomination, will make its report to the full committee within a few days.

Two remarkable works made the program of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. They were the delicious "Haffner" symphony of Mozart and the modern, introspective "Lied von der Erde" of Gustave Mahler.

Holder of the Davis Cup for the first time since 1927, the United States Lawn Tennis Association finds itself with a battle on its hands to forestall a formidable attempt to make the international competition biennial instead of annual.

Emile Pierre Branchard, a onetime truck driver who became noted as an artist of originality and charm, died yesterday morning in his home, 61 Washington Square South. He was 56 years old. He had been ill for six weeks.

The Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company of Illinois has established voluntary reserves sufficient to absorb a decline in the market value of stocks to the lowest point reached in 1932, according to the annual report, published yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Chairman Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority stated on Feb. 9 that, so far as his group is concerned, the matter of the site for the Red Hook slum-clearance project is a closed issue; that he has definitely adopted the site south of Hamilton Avenue adjacent to the new athletic field.

With the House Labor Committee now preparing a new Wage and Hour Bill, a nation-wide study by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates that if the fixing of minimum wages were left up to the people there would be a greater differential between North and South than Congressional leaders have yet suggested.

The House voted today to wipe off the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's books $2,500,000,000 of unrecoverable notes and expenditures for relief and recovery and approved, another measure to maintain the Commodity Credit Corporation's capital at $100,000,000 and giving it a borrowing power up to $500,000,000.
The United States Navy clamped a lid of secrecy upon Its warship building progress tonight, reversing a publicity policy of thirteen years' standing.

Miss Diana Fishwick, 1930 British women's champion, teamed with Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley of London to win the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Everglades mixed foursome golf tournathe 36, 40-76.

Two steps to meet the possibility of concerted effort to amend or repeal the State fair trade laws were cited yesterday by speakers at the midwiner meeting of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association, being held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Essex County budget for 1938, which totals $11,580,049, was adopted here today by the Board of Freeholders. The 1938 total is $135,393 less than last year. The amount to be raised by taxation, however, will be $9,082,601 this year, which is $384,764 more than was raised by taxation last year.

Ranking among the events of the season was the beach party given today at the Surf Club by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Sweet and Mr. and Mrs. William H. Danforth of Boston. The eighty-five guests gathered on the beach before the cabanas for cocktails, and then partook of a Swedish luncheon.

Bryan Untiedt, the boy hero of a Colorado school bus disaster seven years ago, walked out of the Jefferson County jail today because an aged Denver lawyer believed it was "too bad that a fine boy like that should be a prisoner for a petty offense."

The preliminary report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for 1937 showed a net income of $27,278,638 after taxes and charges, equal to $2.07 each on the 13,167,696 capital shares of $50 par value outstanding. This compares with $38,742,092, or $2.94 a share, in 1936.

Upponents of the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill marshaled their strength today for a test, to be held by unanimous consent at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, on a petition to invoke closure and force a final vote in the Senate, on the bill.
If you were to stop off at a rambling old house at the foot of Mount Mitchell in North Carolina and question the bear-killing Wilsons as to the modern youth, they'd tell you he was a "softie."

Public opinion has grown increasingly strong against new labor methods, including mass picketing and sit-down strikes, and at the same time labor itself is regarding the sit-down as a liability rather than an asset,

Amendment to the Neutrality Act to render it inapplicable to Spain was urged upon President Roosevelt and the Foreign Affairs Committees of Congress in a letter made public yesterday by the Right Rev. Robert L. Paddock, chairman of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy.

The only newspaper commenting today on Joseph Stalin's letters is the army mouthpiece, Red Star--a fact that seems to confirm what the writer suspected yesterday, that the letter primarily concerns national defense and is not unconnected with the twentieth anniversary of the foundation of the Red Army, which will be celebrated Feb. 23. Red Star says:

A warning that unless the radio industry "policed itself" the government, through the Federal Communications Commission, would take a hand in making programs acceptable to radio listeners was voiced today by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the commission, who spoke to more than 500 members of the National Association of Broadcasters.

Invitations to serve on the advisory board for the national intercollegiate invitation basketball tournament, sponsored by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association, have been accepted by two prominent intercollegiate athletic figures, according to an announcement made yesterday at a luncheon held by the organization at the Hotel Lincoln.

The Board of Education of the city of Philadelphia will consider on March 15 tenders for a new issue of $8,350,000 of school bonds. Of the issue, to be dated April 1, $2,350,000 will mature on Oct. 1, 1938, and $1,000,000 on each April 1 and Oct. 1 from 1939 to 1941.

Extensive parliamentary opposition is developing against the National Mobilization Bill that the government is preparing to introduce. The bill has been drafted by the planning board in collaboration with the army.

David Holland, pianist, last night gave his first Town Hall recital. His wholly traditional program included four Scarlatti sonatas, the Bach-Liszt organ prelude and fugue in A minor and the Beethoven sonata, Op. 31, No. 2, in D minor.
Persons prominent in the fields of sport and business attended simple funeral services today for James A. Ten Eyck, Syracuse University's "Grand Old Man of Rowing."

Two stunning upsets marked the play in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League over the week-end, and again McGill and Queens find themselves deadlocked at the top of the standings with 14 points apiece.

Domestic stocks of refined copper in the United States increased 39,782 tons in January to 299,133, the largest amount since February, 1935, according to the Copper Institute. Blister copper stocks declined 11,680 tons, so that the net increase last month was 28,102 tons.

A total of 7,916,000 metric tons of pig iron was produced in France in 1937, an increase of 1,686,000 tons over 1936, according to a report received by the Commerce Department from the office of the American commercial attach in Paris.

Heavy rainfall following a severe electrical storm last night stopped telephone service in Rio de Janeiro, clogged traffic and endangered small craft at sea. The storm, which came up suddenly, followed a similar disturbance on Feb. 10.

Many parties were given last night at the midwinter entertainment in the Iridium Room of the St.. Regis. Platt Hubbard gave a dinner there for Mr. and Mrs. R. Beverley Corbin, Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, Mrs. Morris de Peyster and Walter Magee.

Major and Mrs. James Hunter Patrick of Montclair, N. J., and Cornwall, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Patrick's sister, Miss Miriam R. Booth of Cornwall, to Watkin Williams Kneath of Rochester, N. Y., and Swansea, Wales.

Major crimes, in the State last year increased 14.2 per cent over 1936, with New York City recording 56.8 per cent of all criminal offenses, according to a report submitted today to the Legislature by Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney of the Department of Correction. Violations of the motor
Government forces launched a new flanking movement in the Teruel sector today. A Government communique announced several positions were taken in a drive over a two-and-onehalf-mile front.
The Vesey Street realty auction salesroom was busy yesterday. Nine Manhattan properties were sold at auction. Details of the sales follow:

The American Chemical Society announced yesterday that its Chilcago section has awarded the Willard Gibbs Medal to Dr. Robert R. Williams of New York for "outstanding work in connection with the study and isolation of the beriberi vitamin."

President Roosevelt said today that he thought present price levels were too low, as was true in 1933, and that they should go up. He failed to mention what prices he had in mind, but it was assumed from a remark he made that he referred to commodity and raw material prices.
The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had granted a non-exclusive license to Heintz Kaufman, Ltd., of California. The license extends

Dr. Manuel Cordero Reyes, Foreign Minister, and' Dr. Carlos Cuadra Pasos, former Foreign Minister, have been named by President Anastasio Somoza to represent Nicaragua- before the mediation board that will reconvene at San Jose, Costa Rica, to settle definitely the boundary dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras.
Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winner and emigre from Nazi Germany, will arrive in New York on Feb. 21 for a lecture tour. Dr. Mann's newest novel, "Joseph in Egypt," will be published by Knopf on Feb. 28.
Resident Commissioner Santiago Iglesias of Puerto Rico asked President Roosevelt today to provide an army transport to bring the island's victorious athletes back from the Panama Olympics.

A Times Square crowd that yelled encouragement, but at the same time impeded both the law and its quarry impartially, saw two detectives stage an eight-minute chase along the sidewalks of Broadway and West Forty-third Street shortly after 10 o'clock last night.

The Alleghany Corporation's executive committee today authorized the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as trustee, to apply $100,000 of deposited cash to purchase and retirement of Alleghany's collateral-trust 5 per cent bonds due in 1950.

When the Assembly committee, created to investigate Hudson County balloting in the Gubernatorial election last November, reconvenes in Newark tomorrow morning it will have before it a letter from Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, Superintendent of the State Police Department, stating that the law will not permit him to carry out an order to obtain poll books and registry lists locked in a Jersey City vault.

A revised elementary school curriculum, to include courses in science, was recommended by Dr. Morris Meister, director of science in the junior high schools of the New York City school system, in a report made public yesterday. Although "we are living in a scientific age," pupils go through the grades without a touch of science in the classroom be said.

An attempt to boycott the Olympic Games in Japan was made at the annual meeting of the British Olympic Association today. The committee, however, decided to take no action until the meeting of the International Olympic Committee at Cairo, Egypt, next month.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Harper of 1 Fifth Avenue and Munsey Park, Manhasset, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Ashley Harper, to George Loewer Wilson, son of Mrs. Harry Higbee Wilson of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Wilson.
St. Paul's School upset the favored Dartmouth freshman hockey team, 5 to 3, with a great last period rally today. Captain Toland led the spirited attack with three goals.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, who retired from the United States Supreme Court but who has been sitting in the Federal court here, was reported yesterday to be much better by his sister, Mrs. F. L. Rairden, at Essex House. The justice is 78 years old.

Joseph W. Knapik, president of the Federation of Dyers, C. I. O. affiliate, said today that "thousands of New Jersey textile workers and hundreds of thousands in the United States are jobless and starving while the House Committees on Labor and Rules are playing politics with the Wage-Hour Bill."

The Senate Commerce Committee today invited Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, to make a third appearance tomorrow to discuss labor and other problems involved in the Copeland bill to amend the Maritime Act of 1936.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES today is an article headed "Motorists Urged to Use the Subway." It tells us that there is plenty of parking space along the subway lines, which motorists could use instead of bringing their cars to crowded Manhattan.
Edgar J. Williams, a boyhood companion of James Whitcomb Riley, the poet, died here today. He was 79 years old.

The steamship Jianicolo was feared lost today with all her crew of thirty men in a-Mediterranean storm that apparently already had cost the lives of fourteen persons aboard an airliner, ten of whom were believed to have been Italian army officers returning from Spain.

Copenhagen Telephone Company twenty-five-year sinking fund external 5 per cent gold bonds due in 1954, which have been called for redemption, have been suspended from dealings by the New York Stock Exchange.

A jury of twelve married men convicted tonight Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, 20 years old, and her reformatory school companion, Miss Genevieve Owens, 18, of murder in the first degree, with a recommendation for life imprisonment at hard labor.

Magistrate Charles Solomon in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn, apologized yesterday to a defendant for having to hold him for the Court of Special Sessions and declared that if the Magistrate's Court and the Special Sessions Court were consolidated, much inconvenience would be avoided for all concerned.

The Boston Bruins missed a dozen easy scoring chances while topping the lowly Montreal Maroons, 5 to 2, in a wide-open interdivisional National Hockey League game tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

Paul Bilcik of 317 East Seventyfourth Street, testifying yesterday at the General Sessions trial of ten corporations and twelve individuals, including two women, in the alleged fraudulent sale of lots in their so-called Slovak Manor development, near Deer Park, L. I., told Judge Collins and the jury of the sale of the same lots to different purchasers.

Fifty-three gifts totaling $108,503 were presented to Columbia University last month, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. The money will be applied chiefly to scientific research.

The problem of steel prices has not yet been solved, according to indications in steel circles, but there is information to the effect that there is some regret over the reduction of $4 a ton made last week in the price of cold rolled oiled sheets.
A $300,000,000 revolving fund for State aid for housing and slum clearance, in place of the $100,000,000 advocated by Governor Lehman, was suggested today by the Republicans from New York City.
Steel ingot output was unchanged last week in face of a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index eased to 41.0 from 42.6. The figure for the week ended Feb. 13, 1937, was 113.8.
Smith, Malone Frizzelle, Inc., has been formed to transact a general investment business, with offices at 60 Wall Tower, New York, and branches at Newburgh and Glens Falls.

Agnew C. Blanchard, service superintendent of the Frederick Loeser Co. department store at 484 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, died of heart disease on Sunday at his home, 55 Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn. His age was 47.
Harry Christensen is in the service department of Poor's Publishing Company in New York. Elisha Riggs Jones has become a general partner in Stein Bros. Boyce.

PARADISE FOR THREE. based on the book, "Three Men in the Snow," by Erich Kastner; screen play by George Oppenheimer and Harry Ruskin: directed by Edward Buzzell; produced by Sam Zimbalist for Metro-Golawyn-Mayer. At the Rialto.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, bestowed the medal "Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice" upon Mrs. Thomas J. O'Neill of Yonkers at a mass celebrated by him yesterday at 9 A. M. in the Lady Chapel of the cathedral.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in homemaking in day secondary schools other than junior high schools be issued, as of Feb. 11, 1938, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.

With all thirteen players scoring, Hofstra College of N. Y. U. overcame Queens College today, 75-14. Dick Peterman and John Reilly led the winners, scoring 12 and 11 points, respectively. Hofstra led all the way, holding a 21-point advantage at half-time.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Suprsne Court Justice Leander B. Faber, won a directed verdict of acquittal yesterday in Kings County Court, where he had been on trial on a charge of committing grand larceny while acting as a receiver of a trust fund belonging to John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

Opening of oil fields in Oklahoma in 1926 increased receipts of the Choctaw Line, a subsidiary of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway, from $7,000 to $1,000,000 a month for this type of traffic, Marcus Bell, general counsel for the Rock Island, testified yesterday in Supreme Court.
