A worker who goes on strike is still an employee and cannot be regarded as having been dismissed by his employer for that act, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday, holding that the Wagner Labor Act guaranteed a protection of his status.

Agnew C. Blanchard, service superintendent of the Frederick Loeser Co. department store at 484 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, died of heart disease on Sunday at his home, 55 Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn. His age was 47.

With all thirteen players scoring, Hofstra College of N. Y. U. overcame Queens College today, 75-14. Dick Peterman and John Reilly led the winners, scoring 12 and 11 points, respectively. Hofstra led all the way, holding a 21-point advantage at half-time.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Suprsne Court Justice Leander B. Faber, won a directed verdict of acquittal yesterday in Kings County Court, where he had been on trial on a charge of committing grand larceny while acting as a receiver of a trust fund belonging to John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Henry Maidment of this community and West Palm Beach, Fla., celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding today with a remarriage ceremony at the home of their son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs.

For the third time in four years the Assembly today defeated a resolution providing for ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment. The vote was 40 for and 107 against, which was a loss of two votes for the advocates of ratification from the strength they mustered in the 1937 session.
The Maemere Farm's Go Home, not entered for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, soundly defeated half a dozen eligibles for Hialeah Park's biggest stake in today's Marianna Purse at a mile.

Movement of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 21,000, including 3,000 direct. The market was mostly 10-20c lower than Monday's average, spots 25c lower than the bes time and active the decline.
A Long Island City restaurant landmark, which seemed to suffer instead of benefiting from the vast growth of that section of Queens in recent years, has passed into the hands of wreckers.

A bill recently introduced at Albany by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, it was disclosed yesterday by the League for Less Noise, proposes that on and after July 1, 1938, the automobile "horn or other device for signaling shall be approved by the Motor Vehicle Commissioner."
A large number of leases in the Broadway district were included in the commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Many of the contracts involved retail store space.

The number of visiting buyers reported in town during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week, but was again substantially above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the list- Published in THE TIMES.

Miss Elsie M. Hallock has a robin and a cat that are pals. They eat out of the same dish and go behind the kitchen stove together to get dry when they are wet. The robin, now almost grown, was raised from a week-old fledgling. The cat and the bird both like hamburger and bread and milk.

More than 1,000 friends of Joseph Goodman, Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, gave him a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night in observance of his thirty-seventh year as a city employe.

Thomas E. Wilson, chairman of Wilson Co., packers, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that after unprofitable operations in the first two months of the current fiscal year operations in January were "in the black."
Wesley Ramey, Grand Rapids boxer, won the decision over Eddie McGeever of Scranton, Pa., in the feature eight-round bout before a crowd of 3,970 at the New York Coliseum last night.

It does not appear at a first glance why Joseph Stalin should have chosen the present moment to announce his firm adherence to the Leninist aim of world revolution. If his appeal to the working classes of the bourgeois countries over the head of their Governments means anything, it means an end of the United Front policy to which the Moscow regime has so ardently dedicated itself.
The first rescue flight attempting to locate the camp of four Russian scientists adrift on an ice floe off Greenland failed late today because of poor visibility.
Violation of the meat inspection act was charged against Wilson Co., Inc., meat wholesalers, of Paterson, in an indictment presented to Judge Philip Forman today by the Federal grand jury.

The resignation of two Congress party Provincial Ministers that took office last Summer under the new Constitution, tonight precipitated a struggle between the Right and Left wings of India's dominant Nationalist party.
Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was dull yesterday, with prices drifting within narrow limits on a sharply reduced turnover. Considerable profit-taking
Stafing that it has reason to believe that the application by the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company for the registration of securities on the New York Stock Exchange, and annual
Undisguised elation prevailed in German Government quarters today over the new agreement with Austria and the consequent reorganization of the Austrian Government.

Newton Wylie, a director of many Canadian and American corporations, president of Capital Interests, Ltd., a mining concern, and an ardent prohibitionist in Canada and in England during the World War, died of pneumonia early yesterday in the French Hospital. He was 45 years old.

The General Investors Trust, Boston, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 2,000,000 shares of beneficial interest to be offered at the market for estimated cash proceeds of $9,460,000 to be used for investment.
Several hundred members and patrons of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association braved the wintry chill yesterday to visit outstanding private gardens on the upper East Side.

Mervyn Rathborne, president of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. O. affiliate, today defied the order issued yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board calling for an election on less than a nation-wide basis to determine whether the employes of the Postal Telegraph land lines system desire

Joseph J. Mullan, a former chief engineer of the C. H. Wheeler Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia, and a former member of the Roselle Borough Council and the Roselle Tax Adjustment Commission, died last night at the Elizabeth General Hospital after a short illness. Born in Glasgow, Scotland, Sept. 16, 1876, he came to this country with his parents as a child.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the remarriage of Mrs. Julia Evans Hess of 1,192 Park Avenue, formerly of St. Louis, to her former husband, Otto Theodore Hess, also of New York, which took place last Friday in Alexandria, Va., at the home of Justice of the Peace Herman Friedlander, who performed the ceremony.

Finance Minister Paul Marchandeau, seeking a way out of the government's financial difficulties, announced tonight a new issue of Treasury bonds limited to 3,000,000,000 francs ($98,700,000) of new money with an interest rate of 51/2 per cent.

Yale's varsity hockey team will make its first appearance in Brooklyn tonight where it will oppose the .St. Nicholas Hockey Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. It will be the second, meeting of the season between the teams, the St. Nicks having scored a 4-2 decision at New Haven earlier in the campaign.

The international friendship which the Diplomatic Service can foster is a nation's first and strongest outpost of defense, said Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, former Minister to Denmark, in an address today at the mid-year commencement exercises of Temple University.

The Federal Communications Commission barred today from its hearings on the application of major telegraph companies for a 15 per cent increase in their rates any discussion of a possible merger between Postal and Western Union.

Two aspirants to Barney Ross's world welterweight title are to furnish the action tonight in the weekly fistic carnival at the Hippodrome. Milt Aron, Chicago's candidate for the championship, and Vittorio Venturi, Italian star, will be rivals in the feature bout of ten rounds.

Representatives of the American Legion from the nine judicial districts in the State are scheduled to meet tonight at Legion headquarters in the Hall of Records to pass on the plan of Jeremiah F. Cross, State Commander, to force the ouster of Simon W. Gerson, Communist, as assistant to the Borough President of Manhattan.

Hawaii's hopes for Statehood were negatived in a report presented today in the Senate and House by a joint Congressional committee which made a study of the problem last Fall at the Hawaiian Government's expense.

Presley W. Edwards of St. Louis, a broker, was elected today president of the Hamilton-Brown Shoe Company, succeeding Luke E. Hart, an attorney, who has been president and counsel since October. 1934.

Governor Blanton Winship, addressing the opening of the Legislature today referred to the recent six weeks' dock strike in asserting that legislative steps must be taken to prevent recurrences of disagreements between employers and employes that would menace the island's economic welfare.

The Senate passed a series of bills recommended by the State Judicial Council, including one giving the State the right to appeal in criminal cases a court decision which it feels is in conflict with the law.
The War D apartment released the following orders to day, dated Feb. 14: COLONELS Curry, J. F., Air Corp. General Sta Corps, two days leave, Feb. 14.

Edwin S. Whit, attorney, died today of a heart attack at his home, 8 Forest Court, here, at the age of 43. He was a member of the New York law firm of Carpenter, Whit Landau, 70 Pine Street, and for many years had been active in the Knickerbocker Bull Terriers Club, of which he was vice president, and the New York Bull Terrier Club.

Newtown High School's strong basketball team scored its twelfth straight league victory by gaining an 83-9 triumph over Bayside yesterday on the Newtown floor. The Queens P. S. A. L. leaders were paced by Jerry Dorich, who got twelve field goals and three fouls for 27 points.

Proceedings in Federal court in the reorganization of Roxy Theatres, Inc., which resulted in-the acquisition of the Roxy Theatre by and the Twentieth: Century-Fox Film Corporation, were completed yesterday when Judge Francis G. Caffey made final allowances to attorneys and others for services in the case.

The shift from public belief in "business leadership of business to political leadership of business," which has taken place during the last few years, must be reversed if complete bureaucratic control of business is to be averted, Paul G. Hoffman, president of StudebakerCorporation, declared last night at a dinner meeting. of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
After a slightly higher opening, stocks closed around the low levels of the day in slightly heavier trading; turnover, 523,310 shares. All bonds generally higher; transactions, $5,622,700.

Public Service Coordinated Transport, a subsidiary of Public Service Corporation, announced here today it had placed with General Motors Truck and Coach an order for 294 new buses, of which 125 are of the fuel oil-electric type and 169 of the lightweight transit type.

Business confidence has suffered a more rapid decline since last Spring than in any previous period of similar duration, according to Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, writing in the current business bulletin of that bank.

The proposal in the now completed text of the new tax bill to put a special surtax on the undistributed profits of closely held or "family" corporations was vigorously opposed today by the Merchants Association of New York, which called it sharply and unreasonably discriminatory.

The annual benefit for the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre will be the performance of "Save Me the Waltz," a new comedy by Katharine Dayton, to be given on March 1 at the Martin Beck Theatre.
City realty figuring in the dealsannounced yesterday by brokers consisted principally of tenements, several of which were acquired by purchasers who plan to remodel the buildings.

The cost of living for wage-earners in the United States in January declined 1.2 per cent from December, but was 0.7 per cent higher than for January, 1937, according to the monthly survey issued yes-' terday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

A representative of Mayor La Guardia of New York and spokesmen for two New York utility regulating commissions were in conflict today before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, considering a revision of the Bankruptcy Laws which the New Yorkers thought might affect New York's five-cent subway fare.
Howard Bell, 21 years old, and his wife, Josephine, 19, of 55 Russell Place, Freeport, were indicted by the Nassau County grand jury this afternoon on charges of second degree forgery.

Greater realty activity. in the Fifth Avenue district this year than in 1937 was forecast yesterday at the annual meeting of the Fifth Avenue Association by Captain William J. Pedrick, who was reelected for the eighth consecutive terM as president of the organization. The meeting was held at the Hotel Biltmore.

Sir William Arbuthnot Lane, noted British surgeon, was guest of honor last night at a dinner of the International Medical Club of America at the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. He arrived Monday on the cruise ship Milwaukee and will sail for home today.

DEATH IN THE MAKING, by Robert Capa. (Covici, Friede, $2.50.) A photographic history of the Spanish war. POLITICAL HANDBOOK OF THE WORLD: 1938, edited by Walter H. Mallory. (Harper, $2.50..) A survey.
Councilman Hugh Quinn's own witness testified that he saw the Councilman sleep of nights on an easy chair opened out flat with another

Judge Bohan in General Sessions yesterday sentenced Mrs. Anna Donnelly, 27 years old, of 137 West Sixty-third Street, mother of two children, to an indeterminate term in the State Prison for Women at Bedford Hills.
Lester A. Strasser of the City A. C., second in the seeding, was among the victors yesterday in the opening round of the veterans' national squash tennis championship at the Princeton Club courts.
At the invitation of the British Broadcasting Company, Secretary Ickes will make a radio address to Great Britain by short waves on Wsshington's Birthday.

President Roosevelt at his press conference said that the United States must have a fleet adequate to defend both coasts regardless of the effect of ratios with other countries, and endorsed the excess condemnation plan in connection with the construction of highways and other public works projects.

Soldiers of the Eighteenth Infantry from Fort Hamilton, cooperating today with a fleet and a marine brigade, made an "attack" from battleships on this island as the first phase in strenuous Winter war games in which the army and navy are jointly participating under the direction of Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, commanding the training force.

New York City pay checks are not likely to be held up by budgetary difficulties at the beginning of 1939 as they were last month, it was suggested yesterday by Lawrence A. Tanzer, associate counsel of the Charter Revision Commission.
Directors of I. Miller Sons, Inc., voted yesterday to pay the remaining arrears on the preferred stock with the declaration of $2.25 a share on the new preferred and $2.50 on the old preferred.

Interpretation abroad that the Roosevelt Administration's partial abandonment of its gold sterilization program is a further step toward inflation, even though slight, caused further weakness in the dollar yesterday in relation to all major foreign currencies except the French franc. Sterling rose 3/4 cent to

" Man on the Dock," which expected to open a Broadway run next Tuesday at the Mansfield Theatre, has decided to cease activity after Saturday evening in Baltimore. It may be done later this season, or next. the time depending on the speed of revisions. Henry Ephron and Sam Rosenberg are the authors; Felix Jacoves and Eliot Cabot are producing.

Stockholders of the Jacob Dold Packing Company, Buffalo, N. Y., today unanimously approved a proposal to sell the assets of the Dold Packing Company, a subsidiary operating plant in Omaha, Neb., to Wilson Co. of Chicago.

McGowan Garage Corporation, operator of a garage in the building on the southeast corner of Bridge Plaza and Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, has leased from Cora Cook Rowan a plot 25 by 100 feet known as 42-11 Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, through Lehr Benes,. brokers.
Chairman Jesse H. Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, urged the Treasury today to do what it could to hasten action in Congress on the pending tax revision bill.

A net loss of $140,377 was reported yesterday for 1937 operations by the New York Stock Exchange, contrasted with a profit of $172,768 in 1936. The former result did not include initiation fees of $332,000 and the 1936 figure was reached without including $260,000 from the same source.
Shots by Horace Keesey and Kydd with 25 seconds left of an overtime period, gave Amherst a 47-43 victory over Massachusetts State tonight before a capacity crowd of 4,000.
After forging into the lead early in the second half, the Providence College quintet defeated Yale, 41-32, tonight. Crowley and Kwasniowski paced the visitors with 13 and 11 points, respectively.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday of Sergeant Kendall, artist and former dean of the Yale School of Fine Arts, at his home, Garth Newell, Hot Springs, Va., at the age of 69. A heart attack proved fatal after four months of failing health.
Plans calling for the establishment of free neighborhood workshops under a city-wide community art program were announced yesterday by the WPA adult education division of the Board of Education.

Today's major events: "Man Without a Country," evening, and "Walkuere," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Blair Fairchild Memorial Concert 4.30 P. M.

With Europearr financial centers exhibiting marked apprehension over the "inflationary" character of the United States Treasury's latest move in its gold de-sterilization program, the dollar underwent yesterday a pronounced spell of weakness as all the major foreign currencies except the French franc bounded to the highest levels of the last year and a half.

The preliminary report of the Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, shows net income of $1,689,154, after all expenses and charges, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $2.71 a share on the common stock and compares with $1,634,139, or $2.61 a share, earned in 1936.

Honoring her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. L. E. Pritchard of Great Neck, L. I., on the eleventh anniversary of their wedding here, Mrs. Mercer P. Moseley of New York gave a ball at the Surf Club tonight for more than two hundred.

Richard Chapman of the Greenwich, Conn., Country Club defeated Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., former Yale star, in one of the featured second-round matches of the national championship of club champions today.

An unemployed bus boy who set himself up as a mountain climber came to grief yesterday afternoon when he tried to scale a seventyfive-foot cliff that rises from the Hudson River Parkway at 175th Street. Not only did he fail to scale the cliff, but he tied up traffic on the parkway for a half hour and had to be assisted by policemen and fireman.

Trains of coal and ore may consist of as many as 140 cars. They are operated with economy and safety. Despite their record, the railway brotherhoods introduced in the Senate a bill which would permit no railway to consolidate more than seventy cars into a train.

The Maritime Commission recommended to Congress today that no effort be made at present to develop a tramp fleet under the American flag. The report, required under the terms of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, said that American tramp operations were practically impossible without large subsidies and "no justification appears to warrant the payment of such subsidies."

Increases last year of 2.4 per cent in the passenger receipts and 6.1 per cent in the freight revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad were disclosed in the annual report issued by M. W. Clement, president. Last year was the second in which reductions in Eastern passenger fares ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission were in effect.

A new realty firm to be known as Schwarzkopf Lukach has opened offices at 6 East Forty-fifth Street to engage in management, alteration and construction of buildings and to general Investment in real estate.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company has been called for March 25 to consider the sale of the three ships of the Panama Pacific Line, the company's intercoastal subsidiary, to the Federal Government, it was announced yesterday.

Following his unanimous re-election yesterday as president of the New York Curb Exchange, Fred C. Moffatt made an inaugural address to the institution's board of governors in which he made three recommendations.

Creation of a consumer bureau in the Federal Government will be one feature of a program which will be put before President Roosevelt on Feb. 24 by a delegation of representatives of consumer organizations, headed by Miss Helen Hall, president of the Consumers National Federation and director of the Henry Street Settlement here.

The weeding-out process of older army officers to make way for younger and more aggressive leadership in the "top rank" was not ordered by President Roosevelt, it was learned today, but it was not denied that Mr. Roosevelt approved of the plan put into effect by General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff.

Milt Aron, Chicago welterweight, last night advanced a peg toward his championship goal by pounding out a decision over Vittorio Venturi, rugged Italian, in ten bitterlyfought rounds at the Hippodrome. A scant 1,397 saw Aron rally twice from staggering blows on the jaw and win a two-to-one decision.

Joseph Giordano, vice president of Ralph Giordano, Inc., funeral directors, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital of pneumonia after a three-day illness. He lived at 2,242 First Avenue, where is located the main office of his firm, which has branches in the Bronx and Pleasantville, N. Y. His age was 47.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Preparing to leave for my plant tomorrow morning, I assorted my papers in my dispatch case. No matter what letterhead they bear, they are all in one tone: threats of action in case of nonpayment of the debts they represent.

As a result of President Roosevelt's remarks on Tuesday afternoon to the effect that present price levels were too low, as in 1933, and that they should rise, prices of most commodity futures advanced briskly in active dealings on the local markets yesterday.
The Peekskill Military Academy scored its eleventh victory this season by defeating the Columbia freshmen, 32 to 27, in an overtime game in the Columbia gym yesterday.
Medalist Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., defeated Mrs. F. W. Thomas of Columbus, Ohio, 8 and 7, today in the first round of the women's Mid-Florida golf tournament.

Either the schools are becoming more attractive or the truant officers are more diligent in their duties, because fewer pupils are staying away from their classes now than ever before, the report of George H. Chatfield, director or the bureau of attendance, indicated yesterday.

John C. Huntington, president of More Game Birds Foundation, sounded a note at the North American Wild Life Conference which was a delayed echo of a song many hunters sang last Fall. He pointed out that the "disregard for recommendations of State game officials and the secret drafting of Federal migratory game laws threaten to bring a serious breakdown of enforcement."

Miss Anna Barbara Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Martin Johnson of Flushing, Queens, and Boston, was married in the First Congregational Church here this morning to Captain Ernst Fitzwilliam Carter of Sands Point, L. I. The Rev. Alden Smith

Without giving figures or definite details, Air Minister Guy la Chambre informed the Aviation Commission of the Chamber of Deputies today that a new program was in preparation calling for an important appropriation for "a large number of airplanes."

The State Chamber of Commerce was warned here today in a report based on a comparative study of corporate taxes in this and fourteen other industrial States that Pennsylvania faced "an alarming and increasing migration of industry."

Extension of the existing boycott of German merchandise to Austria will be undertaken immediately if the Austrian capitulation to Chancellor Hitler's ultimatum reaches the point of complete Anschluss or if the pro-Nazis, who have been named to key positions in the Austrian Cabinet, force measures similar to those in effect in Germany, it was stated yesterday at the offices of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, 20 West Forty-seventh Street.

Emn C. Miller, who rose from office boy to partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Fahnestock Co., died today at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N. J. Mr. Miller, who was 62 years old, was a civic and fraternal leader in Nutley. where he made his home.

The ashes of James A. Ten Eyck, the "grand old man of rowing," whose funeral was held here yesterday, will be spread at his request over the waters of the Hudson River not far from where for almost thirty-five years his crews raced in the Poughkeepsie regatta. His body, now in a cemetery vault here, will be taken to Rochester for cremation.

More than 150 members of the New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild adopted a ressolution last night upholding Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, in his refusal to discharge his assistant, Simon W. Gerson. The meeting was held at S the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The New York Rovers jumped into an early lead and staved off a late rally tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 4, in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League game.

The second of the season's performances of Richard Strauss's "Salome" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, and the eloquent interpretation of the work, bore witness again to the fact that it is the most spontaneous, the most concise, lyrical and admirably proportioned of all the Strauss scores for the theatre.

The sticking-point in any plan for slum clearance in any large city will be the cost of the land, which tends to be high in proportion to its actual use value for rehousing purposes. This problem cannot be solved with the statement that landlords are greedy people and lacking in public spirit.

Arturo Toscanini, basing his action on recent developments in Austria, announced last night that he had withdrawn from this year's Salzburg music festival and had changed the beneficiary of a New York concert planned originally to aid the Salzburg Festspielhaus.

The Polish police; at the request of the New York authorities, are endeavoring to locate Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, who were said to be implicated in threats to kidnap Mme. Jeanette Suchestow, the filancee of Prince Michael Radziwill of Poland.

Conflicting price movements characterized somewhat more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Profittaking and nervous selling in some groups, notably the railroad liens, was offset in part by brisk advances in a few selected issues. The volume was $6,024,000, against $5,622,700 on Tuesday.

Hankness Edwards of Lexington, Ky., who sailed his ketch Winsome Too for a number of years and then converted her into a yawl, has ordered a 70-foot over-all-length yawl from designs by Sparkman Stephens which he expects to enter in the Bermuda race, other offshore contests and the cruises of the American and New York Yacht Clubs next Summer.

The Federal advisory council of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System has re-elected as president and vice president, respectively, Walter W. Smith of St. Louis and Howard A. Loeb of Philadelphia.

The Bronxville Field Club gained the right to face the Cornell Club in the Class C championship final of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association by defeating the Essex Club in a playoff last night, 4 to 1, at the University Club.

John Marshall College of Jersey City climaxed its home schedule tonight by overwhelming Catholic University's five of Washington, D. C., 65 to 43, for its fourteenth victory of the season. Marshall held a lead of 28-14 at half time. Johnny Killat featured with fourteen points.

The consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in January is estimated at 29,429 long tons, as compared with 29,160 in December and 50,818 in January last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Imports of crude rubber in January were placed at 42,135 tons, as compared with 68,305 in December and 32,820 in January, 1937.

A daughter was born to Lieutenant Robert La Tourrette Cavenaugh, Medical Corps, United States Army, and Mrs. Cavenaugh of Fort Myer, Va., on Feb. 13 at the Walter Reed General Hospital in Wahsington, D. C. Mrs. Cavenaugh is the former Miss Hertha von Siemens Wilson.

Twelve charitable institutions that received the residuary estate of Mrs. Emma W. Schoonmaker in her will share equally in $1,952,196, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Schoonmaker, who died Feb. 25, 1987, left a net estate of $2,754,907.

The Legislature adopted the Moffat-Nunan resolution today memoralizing Congress to enact the Wheeler-Johnson Child Labor Bill, or any other now pending or introduced later, which incorporates its principles.

" Rigoletto," in a special performance for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., was given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. A cast that included Jan Kiepura as the Duke (his third role at the Metropolitan), Lily Pons as Gilda and Lawrence'

The outstanding stick-swinging soiree of the season will be staged on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight when the Rangers and the Boston Bruins meet in what well may be a preview of the Stanley Cup play-offs for the world hockey championship.

A first mortgage of $400,000, with interest at 4 per cent for 5 years, has been arranged for Hearst Magazines, Inc., with Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America by Qulnland Leland, brokers, on the 13-story building at 572-6 Madison Ave.

Mrs. William Carter Dickerman gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 6 East Seventy-ninth Street, for a group of women interested in the performance of "Cosi Fan Tutti" by the Salzburg Opera Guild on March 11 at Carnegie Hall, for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association.

Despite its failure to get the highly important poll books and registration binders, the Young Assembly committee prepared today to start the actual inquiry into alleged ballot frauds in Hudson County Friday morning at the Essex County Court House.

Hopes aroused by enthusiasts that the extraction of oil from coal would make the British Navy, Army and Air Force independent of overseas supplies and bring salvation to the British coal industry have been dashed by a report of the Committee on Imperial Defense.

Alan Ramsey Hawley, whose record balloon flight with Augustus Post in 1910 won them the James Gordon Bennett trophy and the acclaim of a nation which had given them up for lost, died of coronary thrombosis yesterday afternoon at his home, 400 Park Avenue, in his sixty-ninth year.

Miss Caroline Bull, daughter of William Perkins Bull, K. C., of Toronto and this city, and the late Mrs. Bull, was married here today to Hilary Glyn, son of the late Maurice Glyn of Much Hadham, Hertfordshire, and the Hon. Mrs. Glyn of London. The ceremony in St. Peter's, Eaton Square, was performed by the Rev. Austin Thompson.
Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, sailed for international meetings abroad last night, departing on the Hansa of the Hamburg-American line.
The National Labor Relations Board was both defended and condemned by speakers today before the personnel conferenoe of the American Management Association at the Palmer House.
A preview audience last night having voiced approval of "Romance in the Park," Gladys Swarthout's most recent epic for Paramount, the studio today ordered preparation of three stories for the singer.

Mrs. Stephen Hurlbut of this city and Lenox, Mass., gave a tea yesterday at her home here, 10 Gracie Square, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diana Kissel, to J. Lawrence Barnard. son of Mr. and Mrs. J.

Defendants in criminal cases in Federal court have only one chance in 24.09 of winning acquit- , tals, it is indicated in a report of the activities of the United States Attorney's office, made public yesterday by Lamar Hardy, its head.

The 2 5-story flats with stores at 823-25 Amsterdam Ave, adjoining the n e cor of 100th St. were sold by the East River Savings Bank to Beatrice Goldstein for a stated consideration of $60,000, the bank taking back a p m mortgage for S54,000 payable Feb. 1, 1943, at 3 per cent, $135 to be pad off quarterly during the last 3 years.
GENERAL WASHINGTON'S DILEMMA, by Katherine Mayo. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) An account of an episode of the American Revolution, by the author of "Mother India."

Twenty-two per cent of the 8,834 home relief recipients referred to the Works Progress Administration here in the last fortnight for place ment in the WPA jobs have been rejected, more than half for physical disability, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, administrator of the B Federal relief agency in this city, disclosed last night.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
Reports current abroad to the effect that Col. Gen. Werner von Fritsch, who recently surrendered the upper army command, had "mysteriously" disappeared were denied today by the Propaganda Ministry.

Home St (10-2753), s s, 50 ft w of Bryant Ave, 50x100; Abe Singer to Practical Realty Corp. 4,840 Bway. 137th St (10-2549), s s, 950 ft w of Home Ave., 50x100 ft; Stephen H Jackson to Bank of New York Trust Co; mtg $44,250.

W. Scott Pyle, American artist, died in The Hague, The Netherlands, on Sunday after an operation, according to word received here yesterday. He had gone abroad in June, taking some of his paintings with him for exhibitions in Switzerland and The Hague.

Inability to read in the lower school grades is one of the underlying causes of juvenile delinquency, Dr. Robert E. Bell, principal of the Chappaqua public schools, said yesterday in making known the results of a recent survey.

Members of the Alumnae Assiciation of the Hartridge School in Plainfield, N. J., held a luncheon here yesterday at the Weylin. Among those who attended were Miss Emelyn B. Hartridge, principal of the school; Mrs. Donald McClure, president of the Alumnae; Mrs. Read Ryan,

Reports that Ohio and Missouri may follow Michigan in banning entry of Indiana beer were received here today as Governor M. Clifford Townsend said a new retaliation fight is being considered against Michigan's embargo.
The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges. of $9,426,324.

Terms of a new contract being signed with its distributors, which will affect the relations of the corporation with 14,000 automobile dealers, were outlined here yesterday by B. E. Hutchinson, vice president and chairman of the finance committee of the Chrysler Corporation.

At the annual meeting of James Talcott, Inc., textile and general factors, yesterday, Amos H. C. Brown, president of James Talcott, Boston, Inc., and Ludwig K. Moorehead, assistant vice president of James Talcott, Inc., were elected directors, in addition to members or the present board, who were reelected for the ensuing year.

Lawrenceville defeated the Peddle quintet by 36-23 today. The Laurentians were never threatened after the first quarter and led by 23-12 at half time. Captain Bartlett and Tutwiler led the Red and Black with 11 points each, while Bleicher scored 8 points to lead Peddie.

Wheat made an easy start and a strong finish today on the Board of Trade here. Reports of further beneficial rains in Central and-Eastern Kansas and Nebraska and light precipitation in Western Kansas led to scattered selling and a decline of around 1/2 cent a bushel early.

New York University sprinted strongly in the home stretch to nail Fordham right at the tape in their traditional basketball engagement at Madison Square Garden last night as the Violet vanquished the Rams, 31 to 24, and thus remained unbeaten in the race for the metropolitan intercollegiate crown.

Richard Hough, powerful Princeton breast-stroke star, shaved threetenths of a second off the Eastern intercollegiate record in the 200yard event in Brokaw Pool tonight as the Nassau swimming squad remained undefeated this season by conquering Rutgers, 41-34.

Trailing, 17 to 14, at the half, the New York University freshman basketball team rallied in the second period to defeat the Fordham yearlings, 43 to 30, yesterday at the University Heights gymnasium.
Cardinal Hayes has set the period of March 27 to April 4 for the 1938 appeal of Catholic Charities, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the New York Archdiocese announced yesterday.

A blazing workout by the champion, War Admiral, this morning, and the news that he would make his 1938 debut in the McLennan Memorial Handicap on Saturday quite overshadowed all other events at Hialeah Park today.
Paul A. Wright, former airport executive who killed his wife and his best friend, was technically freed today by the same jury which convicted him last week on two. counts of manslaughter.

Once more--for the third time in four years--the New York Assembly has defeated a resolution providing for ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment. The vote--40 for and 107 against--was actually more unfavorable by two votes than that in the 1937 session.
A cyclotron atom-smasher designed to permit the most precise calculation ever made of the forces released by atomic disintegration is under construction at Harvard University.

Roy B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, urged the Federal Communications Commission today to approve promptly the application of the principal telegraph companies for a 15 per cent increase in virtually all domestic rates.

The scene of the joint United States Navy and Army Winter manoeuvres shifted today to Viequez Island. Viequez is only a short distance from Culebra Island, where the Eighteenth Infantry led an attack yesterday after landing from the battleship Arkansas.

The Rev. RaYmond Adams Heron, archdeacon of Boston and for twelve years rector of Grace Church, Lawrence, was me consecrated Suffragan Bishop of Massachusetts in Trinity Church today as nine Bishops laid their hands upon his head.

Senators and Representatives from the States in the Tennessee Valley Authority area received letters today from Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, TVA chairman, expressing support for the stand of J. P. Ross, administrator of the Bonneville power project, as to a policy for public acquisitions of private power systems.
The Kings Highway Board of Trade will hold a dinner dance Washington's Birthday Eve in the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island. A number of prominent real estate men are expected to attend.
The United States' picked basketball team, making its second South American appearance, conquered the local Carioca combination, 31 to 22. tonight.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday of Roland Spencer Condit of 268 Oakwood Avenue, Orange, N. J., in Lakeland, Fla., where he had arrived a few days ago, having gone South in the hope of recuperating after a long illness.

Two witnesses told the City Council committee investigating Councilman Hugh Quinn yesterday that they had been intimidated and threatened by members of the Department of Investigation who put them through preliminary interviews.
The Chamber of Commerce of the United States told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that a pending bill to limit freight trains to seventy cars was "a most undesirable measure.
The towering team of Temple tottered but did not tumble today before Navy, thanks to the 5 points scored by Meyer Bloom, center, in the final minute of the game. Temple led at the end, 61 to 58.

American Hosiery Elects Coale S. Chase Coale, president of American Hosiery Company since 1934, has been elected to the new position of chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday. Roger W. Whitman, who has been vice president in charge of plant and operations, has been elected to succeed Mr..Coale as president.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has acquired nearly 100 more paintings since the formation and endowment of the foundation was announced last June by Solomon R. Guggenheim. The foundation's collection of non-objectlve paintings, it was learned yesterday, now ranks as the largest of its kind in the world.

The American Fidelity and Casualty Company reported yesterday for 1937 earned premiums of $2,983,027, compared with $2,661,039 in 1936. The company stated that net earned operating profit amounted to $138,266, equal to about $1.38 a share on the average number of shares outstanding during the year.
Operators were active yesterday in deals involving properties in Harlem and on the upper West Side. Most of the parcels were bought by investors.

Commander Delavan B. Downer, U.8.N., through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., in 320 E 72d St; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker. Fred I. Archibald, in 105 E 53d St; Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, through Byrne Bowman, Inc, in 15 E 48th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker.

Seven partners in Marks, Laser Co., a brokerage house with offices at 231 La Salle Street, and eleven of its salesmen were arrested today on charges of violating the State Blue Sky Law. Warrants were issued for arrest of four other partners and four more salesmen.

Boy Scouts who gathered at City Hall yesterday to celebrate the twenty-eighth birthday of their organization added a strange touch to the ceremony by climbing on a table which promptly gave way under their weight and slid them to the floor.

The maritime industry either is "ripe" for conciliation and mediation of its labor disputes or it is "overripe for ruin," Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, told the joint meeting of the Senate Commerce and Labor Committees today.

Brooklyn Poly lost a hard-fought basketball game to Drexel Tech at Curtis gymnasium tonight, 39-34, mainly due to the all-round playing of Harry Wolf, substitute forward, who scored 15 points for the Drexel quintet.

It was reported here today that Great Britain and France would act jointly in requesting the German Government to explain its part in the Austrian Cabinet revision and its attitude toward Austrian independence. But it was officially denied in London that joint action was contemplated.

Charges that the Administration's proposed $800,000,000 naval construction program is part of a plan to police the Pacific while Great Britain engages in a like venture in the Atlantic, and that what the United States did in Mexico in 1914 and in Panama during the Theodore Roosevelt Administration are "exactly analogous" to what Japan is now doing in China enlivened the House hearing today on the bill.
Recruits to be called for compulsory military service next October will include all young men in France born during the 'sixteen: months from July 1, 1917, to Oct. 31, 1918.

Senator Buckley, Democratic chairman of the Committee on- Taxation, and Assemblyman Moffat, Republican chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, presented to the Legislature today a bill to extend for a year the powers of the city to impose emergency taxes for relief.

Acting Foreign Minister Georges Tatarescu gave the press a statement today on Rumania's foreign policy, which he described as loyal to Rumania's treaties, alliances and allies. He particularly stressed the loyalty felt toward members of the Little and Balkan Ententes, France and Great Britain, traditional friends of the country.

Although a continuation of trade and commission-house buying sustained prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, fluctuations became somewhat irregular and the list ended unchanged to 4 points lower on the .day.

The Italian Government today gave formal assurances that the rights of Jews would be respected when Informazione Diplomatica, official' Foreign Ministry organ, gave out a statement saying among other things that the "Fascist government never thought and is not thinking of adopting political, economic or moral measures against Jews except, of course, in the case of elements contrary to the Fascist regime."
Six of the army's newest and biggest bombers soared away from the Municipal Airport at 12:55 A. M. (Eastern standard time) today on a 3,132-mile non-stop good-will flight to Lima, Peru.
Mrs. Dorothy Garthwaite, only daughter of Lord and Lady Duveen, was married today to Dr. Bryan Hartop Burns at the Marylebone Registry Office. The bridegroom is a London surgeon.
The Lafayette five swept to a 53-41 victory over Moravian tonight. A 31-22 lead at half time enabled the Maroon to coast. Coach Michalske used ten players.

After eight years or agitation for a dual swimming meet between Yale and Michigan, the teams finally got together tonight to determine, orace and for all, intersectional supremacy between these outstanding college aquatic squads.

" Fool's Hill," by Robert Wetzel, which won a $500 prize in the first competition of the Bureau of New Plays, arranged by film companies, has been bought by the Theatre Guild and is scheduled for production next season under the standard contract of the Dramatists Guild, it was announced yesterday.
Henry L. Doherty, president of the Cities Service Company, holding company for nearly 200 public utility and petroleum companies, received last night the Anthony F. Lucas Medal,

The House of Commons today unanimously passed a motion that, in view of foreign propaganda against Great Britain by press, radio and motion picture, the government should give every "moral and financial encouragement'' to "wider and more effective presentation of British news, views and culture abroad."

Despite the widespread disturbance of market conditions caused by the recent reduction of $4 a ton in prices of cold rolled sheets, the Iron Aage states that there is no indication of a downward revision of steel prices generally.

Apparent adjustment of differences between Arnold D. Kates and the management of the Crocker-Wheeler Company was effected at the annual meeting of stockholders at the company's plant here today. Three new directors, including one representing Mr. Kates, were elected.

The baseball population of Hot Springs, Ark., will be increased by the arrival of twelve Brooklyn Dodgers Monday, according to an announcement made yesterday by Larry MacPhail, executive vice president. ManagerBurleigh Grimes will assemble eight pitchers and four other members of his 1938 machine at the resort for two weeks of preliminary training before proceeding to the club's Clearwater, Fla., camp.

Thirty-five women met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Max Baller, 1 Sickles Street, in Washington Heights, to further the campaign of the Bronx Women's Division of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for $400,000 as its share of the metropolitan quota of $2,040,000 for 1938.

A full maximum claim allowed by the Workmen's Compensation Law was recommended yesterday by Bertram Nye, referee for the State Labor Department, for Mrs. Helen Nolan Neil, widow of 'Edward J. Neil, correspondent of The Associated Press who was fatally wounded by shrapnel in Spain last Dec. 31,

While the league-leading Montclair A. C. team was inactive, the Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis players gained their thirteenth triumph of the season last night in the metropolitan interclub series.

Dr. Charles H. Gluck, general physician and surgeon who did much work in diseases of the eye, ear, nose and throat, died on Tuesday night in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a week's illness. Death was due to septicaemia believed to have been caused when, while operating, he cut his finger.

BARSHAY-Lena Sarah, Feb. 16, 1938. Services Thursday, 12 o'clock, at her late residence, 1,569 Ocean Ave., Brooklyn. Interment Montefiore Cemetery, Sprlngfield, L. I. BEAM-On Feb. 16, Lulu James. Funeral and services from Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 1 West 190th St., Friday, 2 P. M.

The sixteen-story Belvedere apartment hotel building, at 319-35 West Forty-eighth Street, was sold at auction yesterday. The structure is on a plot 162 by 110.5 feet, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

Wesleyan defeated a strong Brown basketball quintet tonight, 45 to 30. With the score 12-all after about seven minutes of play, the Cardinals forged ahead and at half time were leading, 19 to 16. Wesleyan held the lead throughout the last half.

The new American Ambassador to Germany, Hugh R. Wilson, arrived here this morning. He was greeted at the station by V. von Buelow-Schwante, chief of the protocol division, and Councilor Freytag, chief of the American section of the Foreign Office. The embassy staff and representatives of the consulate were also present.

A list of forty-six probable starters for the Grand National, the classic Aintree steeplechase handicap, on March 25, was issued tonight, together with the riders. The list was reduced from the seventy-eight named Jan. 27 as acceptors.

The elimination of the medalists, Miss Diana Fishwick, 1930 British women's champion, and her partner, Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley of London, England, featured the first round of match play in the Everglades mixed foursome golf tournament today. They bowed to Mrs. H. D. Sterrett of Hutchinson, Kan., and P. B. Lucas of London, by 5 and 4.

The Attorney General in a formal motion yesterday asked the Mexican Supreme Court to uphold the Federal Labor Board's decision in the oil wage controversy and deny the United States and British companies' petition for an injunction on the grounds that the Labor Board has no jurisdiction.

Senator Truman of Missouri rose Monday to an unexpected and solitary height of independence and moral grandeur. He has been a docile supporter of Mr. Roosevelt. Renomination of the District Attorney who has prosecuted and jugged so many too zealous "workers" in Tom Pendergast's Kansas City, set one loyalty against another.
The text of the letter-of Joseph P. Kennedy, sent as chairman of the Maritime Commission to Senator Copeland, chairman of the Committee on Commerce, was as follows:
Frank J. Marshall, former national chess champion, retained his Marshall Chess Club title yesterday as the result of a draw in his adjourned game with David S. Polland of Brooklyn.

Vienna today, when the news of last night's fundamental changes in the country's situation was made known through the morning newspapers, resembled a great beleaguered capital whose forces had suffered a crushing defeat before its gates and which was awaiting only the triumphant entry of the victors.
The capitulation of Austria threatened today to develop into the greatest German victory since Tannenberg.

Last year's finalists won their second-round matches in the annual South Florida golf championship tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. Tommy Goodwin of Mamaroneck, N. Y., the champion, eliminated John Barry Ryan of New York, 3 and 2, and Joseph Schenck 3d of New York, runner-up to Goodwin in 1937 and winner of the qualifying medal last Monday, triumphed over the veteran William B. Langford of Chicago, 1 up.
The United States hockey team suffered its first defeat in the world amateur championships today, dropping a-to-O decision to the lightly-regarded Czechoslovak squad.

The government-owned freighter Algic, which became the center of a Federal inquiry because of the refusal of her crew to work with longshoremen in Montevido, Uruguay, last September, precipitated another Federal investigation yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation at 45 Broadway.

Manager Mickey Cochrane of the Detroit Baseball Club announced today he was hanging up his big mitt for good after thirteen years as a major league catcher. At the same time he predicted the Tigers would knock off the Yankees "if we get the pitching."
The AviationCorporation announced today the election of Victor Emanuel as president, succeeding L. B. Manning, who held the titles of president and chairman Mr. Manning will continue as chairman.

Robert T. Swaine testified yesterday in Supreme Court that James M. Kurn, former president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, and Edward N. Brown, former chairman of its board, discussed a consolidation of the Frisco with the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway in 1925 and that on Jan. 19, 1926,
The general real estate business of Frank O'Hara, Inc., real estate firm of Jackson Heights, Queens, reached a total volume of $1,705,473 during 1937, it was announced yesterday.
The mystery of the disappearance of Feodor Butenko, charge d'affaires of the Soviet Legation in Bucharest, was solved today when he turned up in Rome, where he had arrived a few days ago.

A world's record sailfish, weighing 190 pounds, was caught by Captain E. K. Tremayne, a guest of T. O. M. Sopwith, noted yachtsman, whose motor yacht Philante returned last night from the Galapagos. The Philante, with Mr.

William M. Ward, superintendent of the city mortuaries, has been suspended' and William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, is making an investigation of the Mortuary Division of the Department of Hospitals, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.

Sir Prabashanker Pattani, who in addition to many years as head of the Administration of the State of Bhavnagar played a conspicuous part in the roundtable conferences and other Indian affairs, died of a heart attack today at the age of 75.

The marriage of Miss Cornelia Macy Walker, daughter of Mrs. L. Swan Walker, and of I.- Henry Walker of Putney, Vt., to John Galt Piper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Piper of Pasadena, Calif., took place last night at the home of the bride's mother, 570 First Street, Brooklyn.
President Roosevelt today signed the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938, embodying the most ambitious farm relief experiment the nation has ever attempted.

The Commerce Department learned today that executions or judgments in bankruptcy in foreign countries against Brazilian banks or firms, based on the gold clause in contracts, cannot be enforced, and no appeal will be allowed.
A net profit of $407,376 from last year's operations was reported today by the Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiaries, including the Midvale Company.

THE BUCCANEER, based on an adaptation by Jeanle Macpherson of "Lafitte the Pirate," by Lyle Saxon; screen play by Edwin Justus Mayer, Harold Lamb and C. Gardner Sullivan; musical score by George Antheil; directed and produced for Paramount by Cecil B. DeMille. At the Paramount.

Trading was fair to slow. The cow market was higher and fresh pork cuts strong to higher, the lamb market was uneven, and other classes traefa meats mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be weak to lower, other classes steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Conference of hospital service plan executives called by the committee on hospital service and the advisory group of the American Hospital Association, 370 Lexington Avenue, 10 A. M. Afternoon session, 1:30 P. M. Dinner at St. Moritz Hotel, 7 P. M. Speakers: Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Mgr. Maurice F. Griffin. Meeting will convene at Hotel Commodore tomorrow at 9 A. M.

Bullock Fund, Ltd.-Net assets at close of last year equal to $12.69 a share on the 141,525 shares of capital stock, compared with $22.60 a share on Dec. 31, 1936. On Dec. 31 investments costing $2,152,169 had a market value of $1,574,012.

A decrease of 12.1 per cent in new ife insurance in January from the same month of 1937 was reported yesterday by the Association of Life insurance Presidents. The summary sent to the United States Deapartment of Commerce,

Former President Herbert Hoover arrived at Havre this morning on the liner Washington on a visit to Belgium, Finland, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland and France. He was met by Robert D. Murphy, first secretary of the embassy, and Military and Naval Attaches Colonel Horace H. Fuller and Commander Francis Cogswell.
" Profiteering" in unemployment insurance was laid to the Federal Government tonight by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner of New York.
After remaining for sixty years in one ownership, the property known as 9 South Broadway, White Plains, Westchester, has been purchased by Carleton Carter, a client of Fred A. Moehlenbrock, broker.
Free cheese was served in the Senate restaurant today, with the compliments of Senators Wagner and Copeland, who took this means of attempting to demonstrate the superiority of New York's product.

The State Mediation Board, headed by William H. Davis, yesterday began efforts to end the combination lockout and strike in the fur industry. Mr. Davis and members of the board conferred yesterday afternoon with representatives of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers and the Furriers Joint Council of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

The committee on the criminal courts of the New York County Lawyers Association joined yesterday the growing opposition to the bills now before the State Legislature seeking the abolition of the blue ribbon jury system.
At Capone is suffering from "intermittent mental disturbances" but most of the time his mind is lucid, the Justice Department stated today.

The Ten Eyck tradition will be carried on at Syracuse University. Edward H. (Ned) Ten Eyck, son of the beloved "Old Jim," whose death ended a thirty-five-year career as the university's rowing coach, will take up the task.
The Senate refused today for the second time in three weeks to invoke closure and force a vote no the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.

Little more than ordinary second-hand prices were obtained today in Dorchester when the furniture from Thomas Hardy's old home was auctioned. The settee on which he received many of his famous visitors at "Max Gate" brought [pound]5.

Nathan Straus, Housing Administrator, striving to get the low-cost construction program started, authorized municipalities today to shelve slum clearance programs and concentrate on building new homes.

William W. Kleinman, former assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, was acquitted early today in Brooklyn Supreme Court, following trial on a charge of perjury. The blue-ribbon jury returned its verdict at 3:20 A. M.

The Bentley Construction Company, Morris Meltzer, president, sold to Harry Turkish, Ben Miller and George Feder the three twostory dwellings, each on a plot 30 by 117 feet, at 119-123' Bentley Avenue, Jersey City. The sale was subject to three mortgages of $10,000 each.

Eastern District's basketball team, playing on its home court, defeated Brooklyn Tech, 20-17, yesterday in a Brooklyn, Section 1, P. S. A. L. contest. In the same division Boys High won its sixth league game from Bushwick, 31-23, on the winner's court.
Although outscored, 24 to 17, in the second half, the Rutgers basketball team defeated Lehigh tonight, 44 to 34, for its ninth victory in ten starts.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission certified yesterday its list of 4,200 eligibles for the position of social investigator. Paul J. Kern, president of the commission, said he expected all the list would be absorbed in the Department of Welfare and in other bureaus in three months. The Department of Welfare, which will take 3,500, absorbed the Emergency Relie Bureau under the new charter.

The "average driver," not the drunken or defective driver, is responsible for the majority of automobile accidents and therefore adequate policing of highways and strict traffic courts are the most important accident preventive,

Led by Captain Willie Thomas, who scored 16 points, the Dartmouth basketball team beat Syracuse, 51--41, before more than 2,000 spectators at the Alumni Gymnasium tonight. At half-time the Indians led, 18 to 15.

Announcement was made today of the engagement of Miss Katherine Parkhurst Hall, daughter of Mrs. William H. Hall of Hartford to Deane Keller, son of Professor and Mrs. Albert G. Keller of this city. Miss Hall is a graduate of the Oxford School, Hartford, and the Yale School of Fine Arts.

A New York division of the National Anti-Syphilis Committee will be formed today at a luncheon at 12:30 P. M. in the Biltmore Hotel. The anti-syphilis committee is campaigning for $500,000 in national contributions to pay for the educational work in this branch of the American Social Hygiene Association's health Drozram.

Since the more liberal financing terms which the Federal Housing Administration is now putting into effect to promote residential building and buying generally will apply only to new construction, builders and lending institutions are seeking to guage the possible effect of the new program on existing houses and old mortgages.

The need to arouse public opinion to keep the United States from being dragged into another foreign war was stressed last night by Attorney General. John J. Bennett Jr. and by Major Charles Spencer Hart, Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, at a dinner in the Hotel Astor commemorating the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the organization.

The Twenty-third Street Association went on record yesterday as opposing passage of the Williamson bill, which would make it incumbent on taxpayers seeking review by the courts of assessments of real estate to show inequality or illegality.

The complete fields for ten relay races were announced yesterday by the New York Athletio Club for its annual track carnival on Saturday at Madison Square Garden, the finest relay card that the Winged Footers ever have arranged.
United States marines turned back today for the fourth time an armed Japanese patrol of thirteen men attempting to enter the American defense sector of the International Settlement.

The events of the last few days have brought the Trojan horse of German Nazism into the capital of Austria. Through three key posts Hitler has gained control of the Austrian police, of the administration of justice and, to a large extent, of the direction of Austrian foreign policy.
Two robbers held up four employes of the Philmont National Bank in this Columbia County village today, locked them in the vault and escaped with cash estimated by bank officials at $10,000.

Announcement nas been made Dy Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Jarrett of this city and Shepherdstown, W. Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Olivia Heather Jarrett, to Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler Jr., son of Dr. Edmund P. Fowler and the late Mrs. Mabel Denman Fowler.

An increasing trend among men of wealth to dispose of their holdings before they die was reported yesterday at the midwinter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, in its second day at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A chase of several blocks, which a ended in West Twenty-sixth Street near Ninth Avenue after a detective had fired a warning shot into the air, resulted yesterday in the arrest of Edward Brady, 20 years old, of 282 Tenth Avenue, on a charge of grand larceny.

Spring advertising campaigns of local men's wear stores and chains will be launched about the middle of March, with budgets slightly higher and with more definite themes planned, according to store executives yesterday.

Cincinnati Street Railway Company--For January: Net income after taxes and charges, $6,232, comparing with a net of $12,865 in January, 1937, which included $72,160 transferred from contingent reserves to cover flood losses.

The Earl and Countess of Moray, who have been at the Pierre since their arrival recently from London with the Earl of Cawdor, are leaving soon for Florida. Mr. and Mrs. Sosthenes Behn will give a dinner tomorrow in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
Miss Ethel Miller and Mrs. A. F. King, both members of the Apawamis Club, will meet tomorrow in the final of the club's Class B women's invitation squash racquets tournament.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. O'Donoghue of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Williams O'Donoghue, to Joseph John Ryan Jr.,

Randolfo Pacciardi, Italian author and founder and commander of the Garibaldi Anti-Fascist Brigades fighting for the Loyalists in Spain, appeared yesterday before a special board of inquiry at Ellis Island and was permitted to enter the country for a sixty-day visit with his wife under $500 bond each.

A horse that finished fifth in his only start last year after a successful 1936 campaign returned to the races in winning form today when the Southland Stable's Ceiling accounted for the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

A "grave situation" in regard to New York City's water supply was pictured tonight by Ellwood J. Turner, vice chairman of the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin, at a dinner given the commission by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

A discussion of the new bill introduced this week by Representative Patman featured the closed meetings yesterday of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association, which concluded the midwinter convention of the association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Approval of a $20,000,000 low-cost housing program in New Jersey for the coming year was given here today by about seventy real estate operators, who are members of the recently organized Realty Factors of America, a cooperative buying organization.
A strong hint that the German Government may tear up the concordat that Chancellor Hitler signed with the Vatican in 1933 is contained in the Elite Guards' official organ, the Schwarze Korps.

The Union Pacific Railroad announced today resumption of work at Portland, Ore.; Grand Island, Neb., and Omaha on its $9,000,000 car-building program affecting 400 employes, temporarily suspended thirty days ago.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses clashed yesterday with angry residents of the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn over his plans for an elevated highway there, which were up for a hearing before the City Planning Commission in City Hall.
Miss Virginia Wagner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Wagner of Baltimore, and Juan Paul Zamboni of Buenos Aires, Argentina, were martried quietly in Washington on Monday, it was announced today.

President Juan D. Arosemena announced that he intended to submit a plan to reform the Constitution at the next session of the National Assembly, at a dinner given in his honor last night by the justices of the Supreme Court.

The thirteen-family apartment at 1,328 West Seventh Street, Brooklyn, on a plot 80 by 57.6 by irregular feet, has been sold by the Home Life Insurance Company to Fannie Greenberg for investment. Rosenblum Rosenblum were attorneys for the buyer and Tanner, Sillcocks Friend acted for the seller.
Rescuers finally reached the four Russian polar campers today when two airplanes from Soviet ice breakers landed near their drifting ice floe off Greenland.

Shortly after he held up and robbed a Great Atlantic and Pacific store at 780 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx. of $274 early yesterday morning, Carl Meyer, 42 years old, of 136 Edgewater Park, the Bronx, was captured with all the loot by a patrolman in a hallway near the scene of the robbery, according to the police.
The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net loss of $694,408, including a loss of $399,003 on sale of securities.
Organization of a committee to provide a memorial for the Right Rev. Herbert Shipman, late Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, was announced yesterday.

The five-story building at 65 East Fifty-seventh Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, has been leased by Edward Wells, Inc., dealers in Chinese and oriental works of art, which will occupy the structure after completion of extensive alterations.

The report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges of $18,761,294.

Antoine de Saint-Exupery, French aviator and author of "Night Flight," crashed today while taking off from Guatemala, Republic of Guatemala, in a flight from Montreal to Buenos Aires, Argentina, it is announced by Pan American Airways.

Contracts were awarded at the local quartermaster depot today as follows: Invitation 159, for 200,000 pillow cases for the Civilian Conservation Corps, went to the S. B. Marks Company, whose bid was submitted in two 100,000 lots; Lot A, f. o. b.

Revealing pictures of war-time Chinese life far behind the lines of fire are seen by travelers along the Canton-Hankow Railway which winds for 600 miles through Hupeh, Hunan and Kwangtung Provinces across some of the richest, most picturesque territory in China.

As Austria took the first firm steps on the road to Anschluss with Germany yesterday, Berlin began looking ahead to a reorganization of Central Europe. German objectives in Austria are to be a Berlin-Vienna customs union, coordination of the two countries' military forces and a crushing of monarchistic agitation.

LONG, long ago an Italian named Marco Polo went into the Far East where the howitzers and field guns are -roaring today. He was a trader and something of a diplomat, and he saw sights that no other European-except perhaps his father and his uncle, with whom he traveledhad seen before or would, in some cases, see again for centuries.
Goodhue Livingston Jr. was inducted into office as secretary of the city Department of Health yesterday afternoon in the office of Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Following closely on the complaint made by small business men of the nation in.Washington that one of the contributing factors in the present business recession was their inability to obtain loans, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York called the attention of banks and other financial institutions yesterday to its power and desire to assist business and industry wherever possible in the field of credit.
Floods rolling through Oklahoma and subzero weather advancing across the broad Missouri River Valley today brought death and hardship to the West.
The annual report of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company for 1937, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $3,759,527 after all expenses and charges. This compared with $1,711,185 in 1936.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $67,000, up $2,000 from the last price, on Feb. 14, was reported yesterday. Marks, Laser Co. plan to retire as Exchange members on Feb. 28. Norman Mesirow, the Exchange member of the firm, will leave it on that date.
Spanish Insurgents rushed reinforcements tonight into the Montalban sector, about forty miles north of Teruel, to stop a new Government offensive involving 15,000 men.

Top Row's comeback failed today and the silks of Maxwell Howard flashed first for the second straight day as Sceneshifter won the $1,500 Concepcion Handicap, projecting himself as a worthy candidate for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on March 5.

Judge Frederick W. Fosdick of the Superior Court found today in a decision in a civil suit that former Governor Curley "corruptly accepted" $30,000 in the settlement of a damage suit against the city of Boston while he was Mavor in 1933.

A 1938 budget of $878,700 for the Children's Aid Society was voted yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the trustees in the board room of the Bank of New York and Trust Company, 48 Wall Street.

The resisting powers of the Chinese troops on the Peiping-Hankow front, displayed after the initial striking advances by the Japanese forces in their latest big drive down this railway has resulted here in a feeling of greater confidence in the ability of the Chinese Armies to make the invaders' offensive a slow, costly process.

Jimmy Adamick, Michigan heavyweight, will find himself paired with Champion Joe Louis in Detroit in April if he conquers Harry Thomas, Minnesotan, in their battle tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

A trade practices conference for the silk industry, to which- all persons, firms or corporations engaged in the importation and sale or manufacture and distribution of silk products have been invited, will be held under the auspices of the Federal Trade Commission on March 4.
The formation and incorporation of the Chemist Advisory Council, Inc., an outgrowth of the Chemists Unemployment Committee, whose work it will take over, was announced yesterday.

Appropriation of $250,000,000 to pay costs of adding an average of 750,000 unemployed persons to relief rolls during the last four months of this fiscal year, was approved today by the House by a vote of 353 to 23. The measure was sent to the Senate, where action is expected Friday.

The seventieth annual dinner of the Brown University Alumni in New York was held last night at the Hotel Roosevelt, with an attendance of 500 persons. John H. Williams, an alumnus of 1912, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and dean of the new Harvard School of Public Administration, was the guest speaker.

Three dress manufacturers have bee- fined $250 each by the grievance board of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group for violating the group's regulations on dress returns, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive director. The action was taken after hearings on complaints made by the Dress Returns Control Bureau.

A sharp decline in operating revenue for January was shown today by ninety-one class I railroads representing 83.6 per cent of the total. The report was made public by the Association of American Railroads.

Raymond Marien of 50-14 Fortyfirst Street, Long Island City, Queens, pleasant-mannered aocountant with a record of a previous conviction, who puffed up the books of the' Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., to an inflation exceeding $1,000,000, was held without bail yesterday on a forgery charge for examination on Feb. 23 in Felony Court.

Premier Eamon de Jalera of Elre [Ireland] is returning to London Saturday to resume Anglo-Irish negotiations, although the British Government has given him no satisfaction whatever on what he has called the "essential" problem of Ulster.
Divergent opinions on "the hows and whys of making annual water fowl shooting regulations" were expressed today at the session of the North American Wild Life Conference.

Electric power production declined last week, running counter to seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index dropped to 93.2 from 95.1. The figure for the week ended Feb. 13, 1937, was 105.5.
Luigi Cardinal Capotosti died today after a long illness. He would have been 75 years old next week. He formerly was secretary of the Congregation of Sacraments.

Mayor La Guardia denounced the Building Division of the Board of Education yesterday as an "incompetent, indolent and indifferent" agency, when he included a school building program in his message to the Board of Estimate on the capital outlay budget for 1938.

Nathan Klau, co-founder and president of Weiss Klau Company, one of the largest oilcloth and window-shade firms, and an honorary trustee of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 1,175 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old.
It now turns out that when Secretary Ickes addresses the people of Great Britain by radio on Washington's Birthday he will have
Leon Sedoff Trotsky, son of the exiled former Soviet War Commissar, died in a Paris hospital today after an illness of several weeks.

WHEN Jakie Forbes was the goalie for the star-spangled Americans of old and unlamented days, he had a volunteer valet who helped him into his defensive armor for the hockey wars. One of his famous orders before battle was:

Houghton Mifflin is actively preparing for its Fall publications, which will number new novels by Margaret Ayer Barnes, Dorothy Aldis and Lloyd C. Douglas. The nonLfiction list will include books by Irving Stone, Gertrude Atherton and Valentine Williams and the second volume of the "Letters of Henry Adams."

The Ludlum Steel Company of this city has started production on a new stainless steel sheet, it was announced today by Hiland G. Batcheller, president. The new product is backed by a non-metallic material which is waterproof and flexible, and will be made available for new homes, home modernization,. stores, hotels, institutions and manufacturers.

Labor gained its most outstanding victory at the Parliamentary polls since the general election of 1935 at Ipswich tonight when R. R. Stokes, local Laborite business man, defeated H. U. Willink, Conservative, King's Counsel, for the seat in Commons left vacant by Sir John Ganzoni's elevation to the peerage.

R. P.. Burnet, curator of the Carl bad Museum, announced today dis cover of another great cave, which may prove even larger than th famed Carlsbad Cavern,. the second biggest previously known in th world.

A sharp drop in passenger traffic and consequent declines in revenue that make it impossible to meet obligations in the face of rising costs were emphasized yesterday as showing the necessity for increasing the fare on the downtown line of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from 6 cents to 10 cents.

Convicted last night of slaying William Barhorst, bus driver, in a Belleville hold-up, Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, 20 years old. and Genevieve Owens, 18, were sentenced here today by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan to life imprisonment at hard labor.

The list of the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines, due today from the Channel ports, includes H. A. Blomquist, Monnett B. Davis, United States Consul General at Singapore, who is being transferred to Buenos Aires;

Mr. Stalin seems to have got a prompter reply than he expected to his letter to young Ivan Phillipovitch. "It is necessary," he told young Ivan, so that everybody else might overhear, "to organize political aid by the working class of bourgeois countries for the working class of our country in case of military attack on our country."
