A stockholders' suit seeking to recover for the Guaranty Trust Company upward of $12,000,000 from forty-three present or former directors of the Guaranty Company directors, twenty partners in J. P. Morgan Co., sixteen former directors of the Gauranty Company and the- Bankers Trust Company has been started in New York Supreme Court, it was disclosed yesterday.
The trial of the Rev. Martin Nieinoller, Protestant pastor accused of sedition, will be resumed Friday. It is reported on good authority that Herr Niemoller's attorneys will again appear.

Norfolk St, e a, 125 ft s of Broome St, 25x 100; Dantel W. Blumenthal to Emigrant Bank; consideration, $1,000, foreclosure. Lewis St, n w cor 5th St, 48.9x113.11: Meyer Levy to Garwin Realty Corp, 819 E 5th St: consideratIon $400, foreclosure. Broadway,_ se cor 104th St, 70.9%x69:
A brilliant Lawrenceville School polo team rallied in the final period today to defeat the Princeton junior varsity, 15-13, for its eleventh victory in twelve starts this Winter.
Edward C. Cordes, real estate man, died in Bethesda Hospital today. For thirty-five years he was a partner of former Governor Meyers Y. Cooper in the Hyde Park Lumber Company.

A strike of 300 more workers engaged in skilled mechanical trades in Rockefeller Center will be called at 8 o'clock this morning by Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.
Manager Frankie Frisch predieted today that his St. Louis Cardinals would be in the thick of the National League pennant race this year.

George J. Chapman of 50 Pine Street, securities broker, was enjoined permanently yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron Levy from further dealings in securities in this State on the complaint of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

By capturing six of the nine saber matches, Yale tonight defeated the Columbia varsity fencing team, .1413. The visitors took the epee and foils bouts by 5-4 margins. Maurice Grasson won all three of his foils matches. Kellerman and Seltzer starred for the visitors.
The stock market here was depressed today by political developments on the European continent and most issues lost ground.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee for a ;23,000,000 issue of prior-lien gold bonds of the National Railroad Company of Mexico instituted suit yesterday in Supreme Court to recover for bondholders about

The city will issue $43,000,000 in serial bonds on or about March 1 Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday. The money will be used for capital improvements already under construction, including schools and subways.

Leading by two points early in the second half, Columbia's basketball team put on the pressure midway through the period to gain a 39-33 triumph over Penn at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.
French Foreign Office quarters tonight disclosed details of a plan for international action to "humanize" war, which has been submitted to twenty-seven governments and the Vatican.

Applications for fees and expense allowances aggregating. $417,715 were filed today before Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson on behalf of the trustee of Insull's Utility Investments, Inc., and fourteen individuals, law firms and security holders' committees active in the case.
President Roosevelt signed the farm bill and issued a statement warning that additional revenues would be required to finance the program it provides.

The Senate passed today without a record vote a House bill canceling $2,500,000,000 of debts owed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Treasury on account of advances to relief agencies and other government bureaus.

On the eve of the first national convention of representatives of hospital service plans, to be held here today and tomorrow, Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York,

At the meeting of the board of directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday, the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on the capital stock was declared, thus continuing the regular $9 rate which has been in effect since July 15, 1921.

The importance of maintaining an adequate reserve corps was stressed yesterday by Colonel Bernard Lentz, executive officer of the Second Military Area, which takes in reserves in New York City, Long Island and counties north to the vicinity of Poughkeepsie.

Official circles here profess that the Austrian development neither surprises nor disturbs them. Closer contact between Austria and Germany was judged to be inevitable and it is considered preferable that it was arranged by mutual agreement.

A large gathering of notables in society attended the Romany concert tonight at the Paramount Theatre, at which Richard Crooks, Metropolitan Opera tenor, was guest artist. Clegg Monroe directed the chorus and Mary Miller Trownsell the orchestration.
Anxiously awaited official figures tonight showed that Britain had lived on her. capital abroad to the tune of more than [Pound]50,000,000 in 1937.

As the site for a one-story store building, the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Seventhy-ninth Street, known as 1,522 to 1,526 Second Avenue and 301% East Seventyninth Street, has been leased for twenty-one years by Mary S. Keveney to Municipal Properties, Inc., represented by Isidore Ehrman, attorney.

Mr. and Mrs. John Slack Keith of 1,060 Fifth Avenue and Brightwaters, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fay Devereux Keith, to Donald Francis Haggerty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joheph Francis Haggerty of Larchmont, N. Y.
Charles Joseph, clothier here for more than sixty years, died at his Winter home in Sarasota, Fla., today, according to word received by his son, Harold K. Joseph. Mr. Joseph was 82 years old.
Columbia's crews moved from the gym to the Gould boathouse at Baker Field yesterday and two boats went out for their first spin of the season on the icy Harlem River.

MURDER IN THE CATHEDRAL, a play in two acts, by T. S. Eliot. Staged by E. Martin Browne; scenery by Andre Bicat; costumes by Stelia Mary Pearce; Presented by Gilbert Miller and Ashley Dukes. At the Ritz Theatre.
Several thrilling matches were played as the third round of the women's New York Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament was completed on the court of the Junior League yesterday.

Developments in Austria are being observed with deep interest by officials here who are convinced of the seriousness of the potentialities, but every indication is that the United States Government intends to maintain a hands-off policy.

The committee representing holders of the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Mountain states Power Company, headed by David Soliday of Hopper, Soliday Co., investment firm of Philadelphia, announced yesterday that to late it has received assents from more than 1,300 shareholders,

The City Commission passed on first reading today a 1938 budget, which will effect a decrease of $6.02 from the 1937 tax rate. The reduction is made possible by the appropriation of a cash surplus revenue from 1937, the result of improved collections last year in current and delinquent taxes.

Henry St, 221; to 5-story tenement; Ernest Callipari, 15-47 76th St, Brooklyn, owner; M. M. Elkind, architect; cost, $10,000. Worth St, 65-67-69, to 5-story offices: Nathaniel S. Wheat, trustee, et al, Keyser Building, Baltimore, Md., owner; Delano Aldrich, architects; cost, $25,000.
Dr. Paul J. Pontius, an eye specialist who formerly headed the staff of the Wills Eye Hospital, died at his home here today after a month's illness. He was 70 years old.

Sales last week of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 3.4 per cent under those for the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure compares with a decline of 1.9 per cent for the week ended Feb. 5.
A group of Democratic Senators, all opponents of last year's court reorganization bill, stood ready tonight to help Senator Van Nuys, Democrat of Indiana, in an indeDendent battle for re-election.

Oral argument requested by a committee of holders of West Ohio Gas Company 6 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds in regard to an amended plan of reorganization of that company under the Public Utility Holding Company of 1935 will be held before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Feb. 24.

Arthur Besse was re-elected president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at its annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. Other officers chosen included Franklin W. Hobbs, Thurmond Chatham, Lewis A. Hird and Millard Brown, vice presidents, and Walter Humphreys, secretarytreasurer.
Continuing its series of one-picture exhibitions, which began on Nov. 15, the Town Hall Club, in its brief survey of nineteenth century French art, has reached the Impressionist painters.

Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, and Michael Francis Doyle, Philadelphia attorney, were appointed by President Roosevelt today as members of the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague.

W. H. Beal, chairman of the board of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, has been elected president of the Aviation Manufacturing Corporation. Albert I. Lodwick, formerly of the CurtissWright Corporation, was elected executive vice president.

Coming from behind on three occasions, Harvard played a 4-4 hockey tie with Princeton at the Boston Garden tonight. It was the best Tiger showing against Harvard since 1935, the Crimson sextet having won five straight previously.
The Legislature passed Governor Lehman's $386,364,615 budget today, with only five dissenting votes in the Senate and four in the Assembly.
Here lie the seeded furrows under snow, Sparkling and white as scarves that Sheba wore And yet more frail, for when the wild geese soar Toward the north star, their brittle thread shall go.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, appointed a committee yesterday at a special meeting of the board to act on Mayor La Guardia's plan for a two-year training course in the city colleges designed to prepare high school youths to enter the Police,
A two-goal splurge in as many minutes late in the last period gave Yale University's sextet a 4-to-S triumph over the St. Nicholas Hockey Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.
A good demand for office space in midtown buildings was indicated yesterday, when this type of lease comprised the bulk of the contracts for new quarters in the city.

Samuel Furstenburg, 57 years old, the disbarred lawyer who says he now is a chemical- salesman, pleaded not guilty before Supreme Court Justice McCook yesterday on embezzlement and extortion indictments growing out of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's 1936
Movements of livestock in tne Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

A three-paragraph will bequeathing the entire estate of Harvey S. Firestone to the Cleveland Trust Company as executor was filed in Probate Court here today by E. B. Roberts, trust officer for the Cleveland institution.

The Byrnes bill, now under consideration in the Senate, which it is said proposes to reorganize the executive branch of the Federal Government, is opposed by the legislation and taxation committee of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.
Levi S. Hulse, for more than a half century a practicing lawyer in New York, died at his home here tonight at the age of 76.

Piling up an early first-half lead, the Montclair State Teachers College five turned back the New York Savage School of Physical Education by 42-33 tonight. It was Montclair's fourteenth victory in eighteen starts.

President Roosevelt is understood to have suggested to a group of administrative and Congressional advisers with whom he conferred at a secret White House conference early today a new formula for solution of the troublesome war debt question.

Although the stock markets here generally were quiet today, a steadier tendency was evident in most sections. Giltedge issues were among the most active, with prices mostly higher. Foreign bonds remained dull; Czechoslovakian bonds were weak.

Ignoring demands of labor spokesmen, Democratic leaders of Pennsylvania have tentatively agreed upon a primary campaign ticket on which Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers of America, has no place.
John Grimshaw, retired silk manufacturer, died last night at his home here at the age of 90.

Forecast: OHIO-Rain, colder in central and west Friday. Saturday cloudy and colder, possibly preceded by rain in east. KENTUCKY AND TENNESSEE-Rain, colder in central and west Friday. Saturday cloudy and colder, preceded by rain in east.

A client of Mrs. Clifford A. Wolf has purchased for occupancy from the Highridge Realty Company an eight-room Colonial dwelling now under construction on Eton Road, Larchmont Ridge, Larchmont, Westchester.
Delachance, giant chestnut jumper owned by the American, J. B. Snow, stood alone tonight as favorite for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, March 25.

A 20-year-old musician who admitted, the police said, that for months he had been going to various hotels and night clubs stealing musical instruments and pawning his loot for a fraction of its value was locked up last night on a charge of grand larceny at the West Forty-seventh Street Station. He said he was Carl Nappi, a pianist, of 111 Roebling Street, Brooklyn.

John A. Carlson, formerly secretary, has been elected vice president of the fire companies of the American Fire Insurance and Indemnity Group, and Arthur A. Nelson, formerly assistant secretary, has been elected secretary.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 15: COMMANDERS Alvis, J. D., the Perkins, to duty as recruiting inspector, Southern Division, New Orleans, La., about June 11. Kilduff, W. D., Boston, Mass., about April 30. to home, relieved of all active duty.

Five countries are to be represented in the international racing among thirty-square-meter yachts which will start in Buzzards Bay off the Beverly Yacht Club of Marion, Mass., on Aug. 20, it was learned yesterday. They will be England, Germany, Sweden, Bermuda and the United States.

" When environment no longer, tolerates and produces fish in the waters and game on the uplands, man may look forward to an early reduction of his own diet," said Jay N. Darling, president of the General Wild Life Federation, today as he painted a word picture of the need for public education in conservation.

Officials of the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, have decided to hold an exhibition at the museum of 104 drawings of the Spanish war by Luis Quintanilla, Spanish artist and one of Loyalist Spain's war heroes.

By 6 o'clock tonight the transformation of the interior of Grand Central Palace will have been completed and the doors of the Lexington Avenue exhibition hall will swing open to admit the thousands of outdoor enthusiasts who welcome the National Sportsmen's Show.

North American Investment Corporation and Subsidiary-As of Dec. 31: Net assets, based on market value of securities at the close of 1937, $3,012,973, equal to $48.7, a share on preferred stock, against $6,160,525, or $150.17 a preferred share in 1936;

Ever since the first subways were scooped out under Manhattan it has been evident that the public interest would be best served by the unified control and operation of the rapid transit systems of Greater New York. Accordingly, this was one of the jobs entrusted to the Transit Commission, a State agency, in 1921.
The Scottish Office today announced the King had approved the appointment of Sir John Gilmour, former Home Secretary, as Lord High Commissioner of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland.

Kenji Hinoki, Japanese dancer, gave a recital last night at the Palm Garden in West Fifty-second Street, assisted by a company of seven, of whom four were also Japanese. The program consisted almost entirely of solo dances, ranging in style from the ancient classic dance of Japan to a free creative treatment of the same essential material.

Shoppers along Fifth Avenue during the noon hour yesterday saw a new shoe salon "unwrapped" in opening its doors to the public. The store, the newest addition to the Florsheim Shoe Shops, is at the southeast corner of Forty-first Street.

A GREAT LORD, by Paul Frischaur. (Random House, $2.50.) A historical novel about Poland in the time of Napoleon. ONE MINUS Two, by Henri Croyat. (Ives Washburn, $2.) A novel translated from the French by James Whitall.

The four-story apartment and store building at 898 New York Avenue, on the corner of Fortyfifth Street, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Lexington-Jersey Holding Company to the Beacon Realty Company for investment through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, announced yesterday total life insurance of $6,734,531,661 in force on Dec. 31, 1937, an increase of $323,068,774 for last year.

Spanish Government forces reported tonight they had trapped 1,000 Insurgents in fierce fighting in the village of Villanueva del Rebollar, about forty miles north of Teruel, in the center of an active sector.
A mortgage for $25,000 on 123 E 88th St, held by the Metropolitan Savings Bank from the 123 East 88th St Corp, Henry Slefke, president, was extended to March 1, 1943, 4 per cent. .

William J. Graham and James C. McKay, politically powerful gamblers of Reno, Nev., convicted here last week as key men in a syndicate of swindlers that defrauded victims of $2,500,000, received prison sentences of nine years each and were fined $11,000 each yesterday by Justice Willis Van Devanter.

The action of Arturo Toscanini in withdrawing from this Summer's music festival at Salzburg because of political changes in Austria will be followed by other artists who oppose political and racial discrimination in music, it was disclosed yesterday.

The increased tension in Europe growing out of the "nazification" of Austria was reflected in the foreign exchange market yesterday and brought about a slight recovery in the dollar, which had been under pressure several days.

Manhattan Alterations Mott St, 20; to 3-story club and restaurant; Leo J. Alexander, 1,819 Broadway, owner; Bruno W. Berger Son, architects; cost, $4,000. Grove St, 57; to 3-story dwelling and restaurant; Arthur J. Raganati, premises, owner; F. L. Liebmann, architect; cost, $4,000.

Turpentine firm, 25 1/2c; sales, 43 barrels; receipts, 54 barrels: shipments, 10 barrels: stock, 26,850 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 164; receipts, 872; shipments, 473; stock, 77.067. Quote: B. D,. E. $3.75: F. $4.70; G, $4.90; H. I, $5.00; A, $5.10; M, $5.30; N, $5.45; WG, $6.65; WW, X, $7.10.

After an existence of nearly thirty years the Arthur Sunshine Home and Nursery School for Blind Babies will close its doors here March 1, according to official announcement by the home's treasurer, Pearce Rogers.
Fifteen of the small business men of New York who went to Washington recently, assembled at the Hotel New Yorker last night where they set up the Association of Smaller Business, New York district.

General revision of the National Labor Relations Act and adoption of "a consistent industrial relations policy" were urged upon President Roosevelt today by Secretary Roper's Business Advisory Council.

Organized labor will oppose the plan for compulsory arbitration being urged on the Legislature by Governor Blanton Winship, according to Fred N. Meyers who directed the C. I. 0. stevedores' strike here and who sailed for New York today.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of industrial arts (elementary woodworking) in junior high schools, as of Feb. 15, 1938, the names of the following applicants who have been granted said license:

Johnny Gottselig's goal eleven seconds before the finish of regulation time gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 3-to-3 tie tonight with their National Hockey League jinx, the New York Americans, before 7,500 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.
The British Government at last showed faint signs today of diplomatic activity in connection with Germany's triumph over Austria, with all that it implies for the rest of Central Europe.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland will arrive today from Germany and Channel ports. On board are Paul Hindemith, Princess Elizabeth of Thurn and Taxis, Count and Countess Hubert Deym, Mrs. William R. Shepherd, Oscar Traun, Mrs. C. E. N. Sobey, William McKay, John Edward Kinnaird, Edward Voss, Miss Mary K. Drescher, Mrs. Rosel Mela and Mr. and Mrs. Fritz Akkermann.
Charles Haubiel and Robert L. Sanders will divide the $500 prize offered to native-born composers by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society for a short symphonic work, it was announced yesterday.

A decidedly-better undertone ruled in most sections of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace, too, was stepped up. Domestic corporation issues, as a whole, gave the best performance in more than a week, with the combined price average rising 0.23 to 71.71.

The new French National Railway Company, which took over the various railroad companies in France, announced yesterday through La Maison Frangaise, Rockefeller Center, statistics covering its operation during the first week of 1938.

A supplementary summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in December, made public today by the SEC, showed that Sewell L. Avery, officer of Montgomery Ward Co., sold 9,200 common shares of that company and made a gift of 811 shares, retaining holdings of 100,112 shares.

If a jubilant Nazi press is right in its predictions, Hitler's success in Austria is only a prelude to further triumphs in Central Europe. Already there is talk in Berlin of confronting Austria's neighbor Czechoslovakia with demands for concessions which would constitute, according to our dispatches, "a first step toward detaching that country from its French and Russian alliances and bringing it within the German orbit."
A tornado that smashed across Rodessa, small North Louisiana oil town tonight, was believed to have killed a score of persons and seriously injured many more.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts. 14.000 including 3,000 directs.
Several hundred singing followers were at the train tonight as Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension leader, left here for Washington, D. C., to serve a jail term for contempt.

Donna Fox and two members of his United States crew of bobsled contestants, Clifford Gray and William Dupree, arrived last night on the United States liner Manhattan. They are en route to Lake Placid for the North American bobsled championships.

The. Long Island University basketball team, making its last appearance of the season on its home court, routed the Catholic University quintet at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night, 84-28.

Resident Commissioner Santiago Iglesias of Puerto Rico said a bill reported favorably by the House Judiciary Committee today would extend a two-year moratorium for repayment of agricultural loans by Puerto Ricans.
Cotton prices improved $1 a bale yesterday, advancing more than any day since the upward movement started, and the list ended at the top with net gains of 17 to 20 points.

A resolution asking a constitutional amendment to give the Legislature the power to transfer the Governor's power of commutations in death sentences and pardons to the Board of Parole or to "some similar body or commission" was introduced in the Senate today by Lazarus Joseph Democrat, of the Bronx.

When the Duke of Rutland entertained a family party at Belvoir Castle, near Grantham, at Christmas none of his fifteen guests knew he was keeping secret the death of his mother, Violet, Dowager Duchess of Rutland, three days before.

Even though Sinclair Lewis may not have reconciled himself to all his major objections to the literary traditions of his native country, apparently he has reconciled himself to associating with the ghost of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st grade Hugo J. Klempersch of Engine Co. 22, died Feb. 16. Funeral will take place from 1,451 First Ave., Manhattan at 9:30 A. M. Saturday, Feb. 19. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

Grain and provision prices advanced sharply today after an early sinking spell. A rush of general commission house buying and short covering based on inflation talk, strength in securities and commodities and a belief that the farm bill program would inaugurate a higher loan level on wheat and corn swept aside all resistance.
An army firing squad dealt swift death to a sex killer today to beat a relatively lenient Mexican civil law and ease mob tension which had gripped Tijuana for seventytwo hours.
Surrounded by twenty of his players and a band of baseball reporters, Colonel Bill Terry surveyed the marvels of this famed spa today as the Giants officially launched their 1938 training campaign.
Harper announces that the John Gunther novel, "Ring Round Vienna," has been postponed until early in September. Mr. Gunther is now in Asia collecting material for his new book, "Inside Asia."

Miss Herta Kremer, daughter of Gustave Kremer of Paterson, N. J., and the late Mrs. Kremer, was married last night at 5 East Sixty-sixth Street to Frederick Kring Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kring of Bristol, Pa., by the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Moldenke.

The institution of a system of minimum prices on liquor served by bars through cooperative efforts of the distillers, the jobbers and the tavern keepers was proposed last night by Frank J. Gannon, president of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of Manhattan, at the organization's annual dinner at the Hotel Astor.
The Harlem Savings Bank sold to a client of Emanuel Schoenzeit the five-story building containing ten apartments at 643 East 169th Street, the Bronx, through Suslow Co., brokers.

Trading in veal slow, other classes fair to good. Lamb and some fresh pork cuts strong to higher, veal weak to lower; calf and other classes strong. Thursday being an off-kosher day, the slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher was light and excepting lamb which was heavy in some sections and light in others, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

An honorary committee for participation by The Netherlands in the New York World's Fair has been named by royal decree. The long list of committee members published today incrudes the American Minister, George A. Gordon; Jonkheer H. M.

Boston's battering Bruins strengthened their hold on first place in the American group of the National Hockey League by defeating the New York Rangers in a stirring overtime struggle at Madison Square Garden last night, 3 to 2.

Colonel David E. Sherlock, retired commander of the Fifty-fifth West Lancashire Division of the Royal Artillery, stationed at Liverpool, died early this morning Burnham, Buckinghamshire, England, after a short illness, according to word received here.

Expenditures of 232 public utility companies of this State for legal services, fees and attorney's expenses between Jan. 1,. 1931, and Dec. 31, 1936, totaled $14,500,000, according to an analysis made publio yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

The trustees of Tufts College elected as the seventh president today Dr. Leonard Carmichael, 39, dean of the faculty of arts and science at the University of Rochester. He is a graduate of the college, class of 1921.

The "freeway," the super-highway of the future, was advocated as the ultimate answer to the motorists' safety problem at the fourteenth annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States at the Hotel Ambassador today.

The advantages of trading in commodity futures compared with trading in stocks were discussed yesterday afternoon by Richard T. Harriss, former president of the New York Cotton Exchange, at a meeting of more than 600 commodity commission men in the Chamber of Commerce Building of the State of New York.
An insurgent stockholders' committee of the Apex Electrical Manufacturing Company sought today to establish R. H. Clarke, former chairman of the board, as head of the management he left in 1936.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Evelyn Osborne Squire, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Amos O. Squire of this place, to Harvey Willard Culp of New York, son of Mrs. Frances D. Culp of Baltimore and the late Harvey Melvin Culp.

A "flying torpedo boat," new and formidable air weapon developed during the last two years, has been turned over to the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics and is undergoing final testing in connection with what is described as "the most modern armament available."

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Leonard C. Loman, Inf.-Res., Sept. 10, 1938; Capt. Alfred P. Barnard, Fin.Res.. Sent. 23. 1938.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation for the five-day week ended on Wednesday amounted to $4,297,187,000, as compared with $5,578,656,000 for the corresponding five days of 1937, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Demand for wool piece goods this week started to show signs of expansion, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Tonight's major events: Guila Bustabo, violinist, Carnegie Hall; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House; Ernesto Berumen, pianist, Town Hall; Composers' ForumLaboratory, Federal Music Theatre; Ruth Klug, pianist, Steinway Hall.

John P. Buzzell, a watertender employed on the government-owned freighter Algic, charged yesterday before a committee of inquiry of the Federal Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation that an officer of the ship ?? attempted to foment trouble among the crew when the ship visited Montevideo, Uruguay, in December, in the hope of inciting action which would be called mutiny.

Caleb C. Peirce administrator of the Peirce School, died at his home here today at the age of 52. He was the son of the late Dr. Thomas M. Peirce, founder of the business school, and attended Pennsylvania Military Academy and the Lawrenceville School before enrolling at Princeton, from which he was graduated in 1900.

A plan of reorganization of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company under Section 77B of the National Bankruptcy Act was presented today to Judge Oliver B. Dickinson in Federal District Court here.

The thousands of Winter sports enthusiasts in the East, who for weeks have been anticipating good running conditions on snow-covered slopes and trails this holiday week-end and who, accordingly, made reservations at popular resorts, are confronted with a discouraging outlook.
Several Manhattan tenements and Bronx apartment houses passed into new hands as the result of realty deals reported yesterday. Some of the buildings will be modIernized.

Municipal TELEPHONE OPERATOR. GRADE 1 (MEN)-Salary: $1,200 to $1,800 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: Two. eight men appointed from last list-all men on list appointed. Ages: No restrictions; no one will be appointed who is over the minimum retirement age of 55 on date of appointment.

Japanese reports showed evidence of doubt yesterday as to a previous announcement of the fall of Weihwei and important Chinese positions on the Peiping-Hankow Railway sector, northward of the Yellow River.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by Middle West Corporation, successor to Middle West Utilities, the old Insull holding company, to acquire legal title to 280,269 common shares of the Central and Southwest Utilities Company and 36,077 common shares of the North American Light and Power Company.

A proposal for an inter-American military and naval alliance among all American nations for mutual protection against possible European or Asiatic aggression against any country in the Western Hemisphere either already

Skating on soft ice in a light rain, Williams gained a 1-0 victory over the Colgate hockey team tonight. Dud Head scored unassisted early in the first period. The final period had to be cut short because of the condition of the rink.
Percival Frederick Spencer, balloonist and last man of his family in the pioneer balloon firm established more than a century ago, died today at the age of 29.

Continuing presentation of its case yesterday before Interstate Commerce Commissioner Claude R. Porter at a hearing in the Hotel Belmont Plaza, the Hudson Manhattan Railroad offered expert testimony intended to show that nothing less than an increase from a six-cent to a ten-cent fare on its downtown lines would solve its financial difficulties.

Two significant events were reported yesterday which may mark the crisis in the fitful fever which has beset our sick merchant marine. One of them, a sort of valedictory by Joseph P. Kennedy, the retiring chairman of the Maritime Commission, was also unfortunately too much in the nature of a "morituri te salutamus" in behalf of our bluewater industry. In effect Mr.

Representative Fred Vinson, chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation, stated today that the "third basket" section of the Tax Revision Bill would be in the measure when it was reported to the House.

A system used in 1933, during the depression, to reduce the number of telephone operators without dismissing any one, is to be revived by the New York Telephone Company in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

The United States hockey team was eliminated from the world amateur championships today by losing its second straight game, a 1-to-0 defeat at the hands of the high-scoring Switzerland skaters. The Swiss outfit tallied in the last period.

Taking advantage of a momentary interlude while a broker's messenger rested a brief case containing securities with a market value of about $61,000 on a table, although he remained standing beside it, a daring sneak thief got away with the securities yesterday from the receiving room of a brokerage office on the thirteenth floor of 40 Wall Street.

Further evidence of the effect of the general business recession upon Manhattan real estate activity, the Real Estate Board of New York points out, can be found in its regular monthly report of new mortgage loans issued yesterday.

John Revolta, top money winner of the Winter circuit, carried his bag of birdies right into the $5,000 Crescent City open tournament today. His batch of booming drives and iron shots into a stiff wind gave him a 67, five below par 37, 35-72, and a new record for the City Park course.

Mayor La Guardia's sponsorship of the pending bill to abolish the Transit Commission and transfer its powers over rapid transit unification to the Board of Estimate is only one phase of a broad program designed to give to the city virtually exclusive control of its own transit affairs, it was disclosed yesterday.
A deluge of water today trapped eight men in a coal mine at Jeanesville, five miles from here, and washed two others unhurt to safety.

The Senate Military Affairs Committee approved a bill today which would relieve General John J. Pershing of the necessity of returning to the government about $19,000 of salary paid him as chairman of the World War Battle Monuments Commission.

The Theatre Guild and the Actors Repertory Company now have agreed definitely on a joint production of "Simply Henry Hogg," the plan being that the first performances shall be private ones for, Guild subscribers only.

Frank Reed, a former president of the New Brunswick Board of Education and associated for forty years with the National City Bank of New York, died at his home here today after an illness of six weeks. He was 59 years old.
The good luck Townsend B. Martin has experienced in Florida racing continued at Hialeah Park today when his Sir Gallahad III colt Galapas captured the featured Marco Polo Purse.

ON BOARD THE SOVIET ICEBREAKER TAIMYR, off the Greenland coast, Feb. 17.-A fortnight's effort against gale and ice in an attempt to reach Ivan Papanin and his three comrades was finally crowned with success yesterday when Pilot Genady Vlasov established -the first personal contact with the scientists since they-landed at the North Pole last May 29.

Arthur Mareus King, a former assistant United States district attorney and for many years a New York lawyer, died yesterday morning at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

Formation of a national association of electrical household appliance dealers, the first in this field, will be acted upon at a meeting to be held on March 21 at the Hotel Commodore, it was learned here yesterday. Russell Atkinson, former president of the Brooklyn Electrical Appliance Dealers Association, is temporary chairman of the organizing committee.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation and largest steel company in the world, resumed yesterday price leadership in the domestic steel industry by reaffirming current prices for all its products for the second quarter of 1938.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Martime Union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, denied today before a Senate committee the charge made a week ago by Joseph P. Ryan,
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets from New York City:

Warners today named Claire Trevor as the moll opposite Edward G. Robinson in "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse." Miss Trevor attracted attention in a similar part in "Dead End" and is one of the nominees for the Academy Award.

Millions have been spent by the WPA to aid penniless painters, actors and musicians, with the result that art has flourished under the WPA. Science has been neglected. At the President's suggestion the Science Advisory Board explored the possibilities of research as an aid in overcoming the depression.
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index declined to 53.1 from 56.6. The figure for the week ended Feb. 13, 1937, was 69.3.

Sharp declines in prices of farm products and foods caused a further recession in the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Feb. 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Other commodities groups fell off less markedly.

The "key man" in the Nazified Austrian Cabinet, Interior Minister Seyss-Inquart, conferred with Chancellor Hitler yesterday, reportedly on the creation of a secret police for Austria, the lifting of curbs on Nazi activities and measures to combat the "Communist menace."

Large shipbuilders' prices for cargo vessels intended as naval auxiliaries are so high they threaten to balk the rehabilitation of the merchant marine, Joseph P. Kennedy told President Roosevelt today in his final report as chairman of the commission.

Members of the "Pins and Needles" companies (the local one and the forthcoming road troupe) will be at the Hotel Mayflower, Washington, on March 3 to help celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Department of Labor.

Representative Cochran of Missouri criticized the Federal Surplus Commodity Corporation today for dumping into a slough near Poplar Bluff, Mo., about 6,000 pounds of potatoes which had been condemned, "through an error of judgment," as unfit for consumption by persons on relief.

Lee Bradley, a salesman, testified today that the General Motors Corporation contributed $25,000 to the 1934 campaign fund of Martin L. Davey, elected Governor of Ohio that year. In return, he said, General Motors was to receive half the State's motor business.
The Annalist reported yesterday that its monthly index of business activity continued to decline in January, but at a much slower rate than in the preceding four months.

The total of loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City advanced $19,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the statement of condition of the banks made public yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

The Midston House team completed its schedule in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association last night, vanquishing the City A. C., 4 to 1. Midston finished the season at the top with nine victories in ten matches.

But trailing clouds of glory do we come From God, who is our Home. But to what a home on this earth are children being invited, though promised by the poet that Heaven would lie about them at least in their infancy?

A new method for saving money that at the same time involves a new way of coining money, in the literal sense of the word, was outlined yesterday before the 148th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Workers in this State have filed more than one-quarter of all the applications for unemployment insurance received in the nation since Jan. 1, a survey by the State Labor Department disclosed last night.

Protests against any cut in present tariffs on linoleum and felt-base floor coverings in negotiating a reciprocal trade treaty with the United Kingdom, have been made in a brief filed by the Linoleum Workers Protective Union, composed of employes of the linoleum plant of the Armstrong Cork Company at Lancaster, Pa.
The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the cumulative convertible preferred and common Class A stocks of the Peoples Light and Power Company.

Cast in bronze, a bust of John Russell Young, journalist, minister to China and first librarian of the new Library of Congress, was presented to City College by Fred W. Ruckstull, sculptor, at exercises in the freshman chapel in the Great Hall of the college yesterday.

A decree was issued today forbidding all persons mustered into compulsory Reich labor camps to reveal the "secrets" made known to them there. Any one who talks about such secrets even after his discharge likewise will be punished.
Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen gave a large dinner tonight at Southways for her guests, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Leonard of New York.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Feb. 16 were announced today: Imlay, Lieut. M. H., the Nemesis, to Academy, about July 1. Jones, Lieut. M. C., the Cayuga, to Academy, about June 15.
In the Westchester schools they have found that young children who are backward in their reading fall most easily

Competent circles in Angora consider premature and exaggerated the report published in the Turkish newspaper Aksham that as a result of the visit of Turkish bankers to London a credit of [Pound]50,000,000 would be opened by British firms in favor of Turkey to be used for the Turkish second five-year industrial plan.
The Soviet Government today branded as an impostor a man who turned up in Rome and identified himself as Fedor Butenko, missing charge d'affaires of the Soviet Legation at Bucharest, Rumania.

Rear Admiral William G. DuBose, chief of the Naval Bureau of Construction and Repair, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that on the basis of present costs of materials, labor and equipment, the combatant and auxiliary ships provided for in the Administration's construction program will cost $977,546,000.

The Mexican Government announces that it has signed a contract with James Stewart Co. of New York by which the company is to act as the government's purchasing agent for machinery for railroad development and petroleum machinery, and materials for other undertakings.

Court review t of real estate assessments which are held to be overvaluations are causing an increase in the cost of government to small taxpayers who do not protest their assessments, according to a report today by a committee of corporation counsels ,of the State conference of Mayors and other municipal offiicals.
Caspar Wistar Hodgson, conservationist, publisher and editor, died yesterday morning of pneumococcus septicemia in New York Hospital. He was 69 years old.

A jury of three women and nine men was called into night session this evening to receive a charge from Judge Joseph Sloane in Quarter Sessions Court and at 10:22 P. M. began deciding the fate of Mary K. O'Connor, 19-year-old college girl on trial for the death last Labor Day of Nancy Glenn, 5, a neighbor's child. Late tonight they were locked up.

Douglas Raymond of Boston University, who chased Jim Herbert, New York University's undefeated Negro flier, all the way to the tape in Boston last Saturday, accepted an invitation yesterday to be the fifth starter in the twenty-second running of the classic Buermeyer 500 in the New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Republican criticism of special assistants to the Attorney General marked general debate today in the House upon the "Four-Department" Bill, carrying a total of $131,909,651 in appropriations for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments for the next fiscal year.

John H. Kimball, 52 years old, a banker, of Manor Inn, Larchmont, N. Y., who was arrested on the night of Feb. 9 charged with driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident, was discharged in traffic court on Wednesday evening by Magistrate Peter A. Abeles.

Five of the six United States Army B 17 bombers which arrived here from Miami, Fla., at 4:25 this afternoon, Eastern standard time, took off at 10:35 tonight on the next stage of their good-will flight to Buenos Aires, Argentina, with a possible stop at Santiago, Chile.

The Treasury will conduct an "experiment" on the West Coast beginning March 1 to bring the means of income tax appeal to the taxpayer. Secretary Morgenthau called it today "one of the most constructive moves from the point of view of tax collections since I have been in the Treasury."

Extension of the present hospital service insurance plans to cover the necessary medical care incidental to hospitalization was urged last night by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of New York City Hospitals, before a dinner meeting of the first national conference of hospital service plan executives.
Lord Beaverbrook will be among the hosts at Roddey Burdine Memorial Stadium tomorrow night for opening of the Winter sports revue. Lord and Lady Stanley are among those coming down from Palm Beach.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday for an investigation of charges of irregularities in the award of printing contracts by the Board of Elections after Kenneth. M. Dayton, Budget Director, had complained that there was wholesale waste in that field.
Miss Bernice Lapp and Miss Constance Hanf won two events each to help the New York University girls' swimming team to a 37-18 victory over Hunter College in the losers' pool yesterday.

Miss Marjorie Yvonne Bywater, daughter of Selwyn Bywater of New York and Greenwich, and the late Mrs. Bywater, was married here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Mary's Church to James Benjamin Adams Jr., son of James B. Adams of Omaha and the late Mrs. Adams.

Senator Wheeler of Montana suggested today that the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad's right to participate in the affairs of-the Erie might be jeopardized if the Virginia. Transportation Company's purchases of stock of the Erie 'were invalidated under a New York law.

With the Baltimore Orioles acquiring four of the disbanded Bronx Tigers and the Atlantic City Sea Gulls gaining two, the third and final round of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League's split schedule will be among four teams, it was announced yesterday.
The strike begun by fifty electricians, members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, on Tuesday at Rockefeller Center spread yesterday when about seventy-five maintenance men joined the walkout.

Discovery of a magnificent limestone cavern, with one vaulted chamber more than three miles long, was reported here today. The great cave, said R. P. Burnet, curator of the Carlsbad Museum, rivals in beauty the famed Carlsbad Cavern near by and may be the largest in the world.

Greater emphasis on safety and not so much on speed in designing airplanes was urged yesterday by Captain Frank Hawks, aviator, who spoke before a gathering of leading airmen and representatives of other fields at a luncheon in the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
Roman Biske, a Russian, who has been employed as the legal adviser of the United States Embassy, has been missing for several days, it was learned today.

President Federico Laredo Bru announced after today's Cabinet meeting that he would return to Congress with recommendations for modification the bill requiring that all physicians become members of the newly created National Medical College.

President Roosevelt will restate at his press conference tomorrow the attitude of his Administration toward current price trends, suggest the correction of some maladjustments in the price structure and the extent to which recovery efforts are being hindered by disparities between "fluid" and inflexible prices.

The Greenlands Trading Company's annual fur auction, which usually attracts customers from all over the world, has just been held, with even greater numbers in attendance from the United States, Great Britain, Germany, France and South America than in the past.

Isidore Einstein, whom Supreme Court Justice William Howard Taft once called "the only prohibition agent of prudence and caution," died yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan General Hospital following the amputation of his right legten days ago.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar delivered to markets in the United States in January under the Sugar Control Act totaled 362,186 short tons, raw value, compared with 379,124 in January, 1937.

The new plan of reorganization for The Oliver Cromwell first-mortgage 6 per cent serial bond certificates of the 14 West 72d Street Corporation, approved on March 6, 1937, in the Supreme Court, has been substantially consummated, according to a letter to holders of the certificates of deposit from the bondholders' committee headed by Lewis H. Pounds.

The Shanghai Paper Importers Association has taken steps to minimize the losses occasioned by difficulties arising from financial restrictions, said a consular report from Shanghai to the Department of Commerce, made public today.
Michael J. Cannon, retired fire captain, died Wednesday at his home, 21-57 Forty-fourth Drive, Long Island City, at the age of 74.

Former President Herbert Hoover, accompanied by Ambassador Hugh Gibson, today went to Laeken to lay a wreath on the tomb of King Albert of the Belgians, who was killed by a fall just four years ago today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.
KINGS DILG, EMMA K. (Oct. 22, 1937). Gross assets, $13,366; net, $12,033. To husband, Philip Dilg. Chief assets, real and personal property, $13,366. William F. Litter, attorney, 315 Wyckoff Ave.

The concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall had two exceptional features. One was an adorable symphony composed in his youth by a great master, too little known here, and delightfully performed.

Slum clearance and low-cost building to provide homes for slum dwellers are indivisible factors essential to the development of the program designed by the United States Housing Authority to carry out the provisions of the Wagner-Steagall act, Nathan Straus, administrator, said today.

The recession is the result of the deliberate adoption of deflationary policies by the Roosevelt Administration with the object of reducing commodity prices to a point where Congress could be induced to pass a farm bill giving the Administration permanent control over agricultural production, in the opinion of Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Margaret Cantrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Cantrell of Benton, Ill., and Chicago, to W. Meredith Behrens of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Behrens of Brooklyn, took place here yesterday afternoon in St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

Governor Lehman today signed the O'Brien bill permitting life insurance corporations within the State to invest in real property for low-rental housing in cities of 300,000 or more until Dec. 1, 1943.
The Japanese naval spokesman said today that the fact that United States naval defense problems embrace two oceans to Japan's one did not alter Janan's stand on naval parity.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals granted a temporary injunction today to seven coal companies staying the National Bituminous Coal Commission's orders relating to minimum prices on railroad coal. Similar injunctions have been granted in New York and Washington.
The desires of mice and men are being put today under the scrutiny of science to test a theory that it is natural to try hardest for what is impossible.

The New York A. C. basketball team triumphed on its home court last night, defeating the New York Stock Exchange quintet, 44 to 34. The victors led at half time, 24 to 12. Bob Reinacher, former Fordham ace, starred for the Winged Foot squad, tallying seventeen points.

The world's largest bearing, designed to carry the 1,000,000-pound load of the giant telescope on Mount Palomar, Calif., is being completed in the East Pittsburgh plant of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
The inspired organs of Soviet opinion, the newspapers Izvestia and Pravda, today deplored German influence in Austrian affairs as a further complication of Europe's unsettled politics.

Miss Eileen Mae Smith, daughter of Mrs. J. Denver Smith of Riverdale and the late Mr. Smith, was married to Stewart- M. Muller, son of Henry T. Muller of this city and the late Mrs. Muller, yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. E. J. Kellenberg.

Canal St, 34, and 156 East Broadway, 25 ft on each; Emil Goodman and wife to Seamen's Bank for Savings; mtg $22,000 held by bank. Suffolk St, 104, 25.3x100: Louis Susman to Dry Dock Savings Institution; consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

Rear snip, sympathy and understanding Admiral Cary T. Grayson, physician and friend of three Presidents and chairman of the American Red Cross, was buried today with military honors in the National Cemetery at Arlington. Funeral services

The release of a presentation, "The Road Ahead for Newspapers," yesterday marked the beginning of an intensive drive by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, to enlist every newspaper in the country in a cooperative effort to sell more national newspaper advertising.
The Hunter College fencing team, intercollegiate champion, opened its season yesterday by defeating the Wagner girls, 8 to 1, in the winner's gymnasium in the Bronx.

Cliff Battles, one of the great running backs of modern football, has been selected as Columbia's varsity backfield coach and assistant to Head Coach Lou Little for next Fall, it was announced last night by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics at Columbia.

Angelo Trulio, defending champion, led the field into the semifinal round of the New York State four-wall handball championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night. Trulio defeated Tom Ginty, Pastime A. C., 21-7, 21-6.

No practical program has been found to date which will provide decent housing for the lowest income groups, Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, said yesterday.

Dr. Lyman J. Briggs, director of the Bureau of Standards, wants to shorten the inch. It is too long, he says, and, furthermore, the difference between the length of the inch in this country and in Great Britain is "intolerable."

A national survey by the American Society for the Hard of Hearing revealed that 3,000,000 of the nation's 30,000,000 school children, on the basis of school tests, had defective hearing, according to a society announcement yesterday.

The Commodity Exchange Administration issued today an order designed to prevent grain market "squeezes" by forbidding trading in grain futures contracts in the last seven days of the delivery month. Present regulations prohibit such trading in the last three days.

" We have lost a battle, but not a war," was the predominant mood here today as the Austrians began to realize a little of what had happened at Berchtesgaden last Saturday and to recover from their first panic.

The national affairs committee of the National Republican Club made public yesterday a program calling for drastic revision of the New Deal policies which will be acted upon by the club in the near future. William S. Bennet is chairman of the committee.
The Hitler Youth Organization has undertaken to make sharpshooters of the whole generation of boys now growing up in Germany.

Testifying in his own defense yesterday, Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens told an investigating committee that he was qualified to sit in the City Council because his actual residence was in Long Island City, rather than in Brentwood, L. I., as his opponents charged.

Patrick Whalen, recently elected president of the Baltimore Industrial Union Council, central C. I. O. body, and four other members of the National Maritime Union at the Port of Baltimore were sentenced to ninety days in the Hudson County penitentiary tonight after they had been found guilty of being disorderly persons.

During the week ended Feb. 16 member bank reserve balances increased $11,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $4,000,000 in money in circulation and $24,000,000 in Treasury cash and increases of $6,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $25,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by increases of $31,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $19,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
William Clarkson Van Antwerp, financier, author and bibliophile, died today at his Hillsborough home on San Francisco peninsula. His age was 70.
The Treasury awarded today a $696,131 contract to O'Driscoll Grove, Inc., New York City, for remodeling of the New York City Postoffice. Work is to be completed in 300 days after an order to proceed.

This is Illinois week at the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fiftyseventh Street, where, in fact, the WPA artists of that Midwestern State will continue to show oils, water-colors, prints and mural sketches through March 12.

Trial of a $10,506,090 rescission suit brought by John G. Lonsdale and James M. Kurn, as trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, against Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the road's board; Speyer Co., J. W. Seligman Co. and individual partners in the two firms ended yesterday in the Supreme Court.

Decreases in Dominion Government deposits and in notes in circulation was shown today in the report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. The bank's holdings of United States dollars and sterling were decreased.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

An original political demonstration compared by its participants to a combination of Mussolini's march on Rome and American sit-down strikes caused a flurry in Tokyo last evening, but ended ignominiously.

France today took a hand in the Austrian situation both in Berlin and Vienna. Ambassador Andre Frangois-Poncet in a conference with Foreign Minister Joachim Von Ribbentrop in Berlin expressed the "painful surprise" of the French Government at the manner in which the Berchtesgaden negotiations with Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg were carried out.

Miss Lucille Marie Streat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hearn Waters Streat of 1,165 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue, to James Francis Bartoccini, son-of Mr..and Mrs. Astolfo Bartoccini of New Rochelle, N. Y.

Now that Wall Street has had more than a week to study the Securities and Exchange Commission's short-selling rule, which took effect on Feb. 8, the original favorable reaction is being altered. Brokers find that it has had a tendency to restrict the volume of trading, to make the market even thinner than it had been.

Buddy Hassett, leading Dodger holdout, held what the first baseman described as a "pleasant conference" with Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail in the Brooklyn offices yesterday afternoon and came away with his 1938 contract still unsigned.

Top executives, to deal successfully with employes must have a sense of humor and be able to "take it on the chin and smile," John H. Goss, vice president of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, Waterbury, Conn., told the American Management Association personnel conference today.

An investigation into the New York financial affairs of Marks,. Laser Co. of Chicago was begun yesterday by Attorney General Bennett after seven partners had been arrested in the Illinois city on charges of violating the "blue sky" securities law of that State.

Legislative leaders, after conferences with representatives of savings banks, now seem fairly confident that a compromise plan for savings-bank life insurance can be worked out and passed at the present session of the Legislature.

In an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday headed "Morgan Partners Sued in Rail Deals" it was erroneously stated that the Bankers Trust Company was being sued in a stockholders action instituted by a stockholder in Guaranty Trust Company.

One hundred mothers whose babies were born at Gouverneur Hospital, Gouverneur Slip, and their children joined yesterday afternoon in celebrating the second anniversary of the hospital's Well Baby Clinic.

The first exhibit of one, two and three-sheet posters will be held in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, from March 30 to April 12, under the sponsorship of Transit Advertisers, Inc. Separate contests will be held for travel, hotel, theatrical and general product posters, and the winner of each of these classifications will be eligible for the grand award for the best poster in the show.

Mr. and Mrs. John E. Rousmaniere of 115 East Sixty-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Hall Rousmaniere, to Richard Salter Storrs Jr., son of Richard S. Storrs of Orange, N. J., and the late Mrs. Storrs.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Priscilla Alden Badger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kingsbury Badger of this place, to Edward S. Gilson of Brooklyn and Amityville, L. I., formerly of Summit.

A pledge to sustain as far as possible the equity of the stockholders in the Chicago North Western Railway, in bankruptcy, was contained in the annual report of Fred W. Sargent, president, which was issued yesterday.

A religious service supplemented by the rituals of three fraternal orders marked the funeral at the Riverside Memorial Chapel yesterday of Maurice Deiches, lawyer and member of the Board of Higher Education, who died on Tuesday in Polyclinic Hospital.
The annual convention of the American Institute of Steel ConIstruction will be held in French Lick Springs, Ind., Oct. 10 to 14, V. G. Iden, secretary of the institute, announced yesterday.

An industrial "putsch" in which armed guards hired by the Bush Terminal Company are said to have taken possession of the Forty-first Street power house, operated by the Bush Terminal Building Company, and since New Year's Eve have prevented employes and officials of the latter company from entering and operating the plant, was described in papers filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

The statement of the Sun Oil Company for 1937, released for publication today, shows a net income of $9,544,085 after depreciation, amortization, depletion, interest and taxes, including the undistributed profits tax, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.17 each on the 2,328,380 common shares outstanding on Dec. 31.

Designed to result in savings to the public of from $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 annually in the cost of distribution, a renewed effort to simplify and standardize the boxes and bags used for wrapping dustomer purchases will be undertaken this year, it was announced yesterday.

A retirement income plan for all employes of the Merchants Fire Assurance Corporation of New York and associated companies, Washington Assurance Corporation and Merchants Indemnity Corporation, was announced yesterday and will be carried by the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which has carried the Merchants group life insurance for twenty years.

A stocky little WPA carpenter of Montclair, N. J., who studied ballistics and fingerprinting in a correspondence course during his spare time, admitted yesterday, according to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that he had written three threatening letters to Gerald M. Livingston, New York broker, who has an estate at Lloyd's Harbor, L. I.

The final of the Riddells Bay Golf and Country Club's fourth annual mixed foursomes golf tournament tomorrow will be practically an allAmerican affair, with Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, New York State champion in 1937, and Major Chidlaw-Roberts of the British Army, meeting Mr. and Mrs. K. H. Sheldon of Nassau, L. I.

Supreme Court Justice Newton H. Porter upheld today the dismissal of ten persons as workers in a city recall election tomorrow. The ten were dismissed by the Cape May County Board of Elections on a complaint by George W. Krogman and Benjamin Ingersoll, recall nominees, who asserted the ten were in the city employ and therefore ineligible to serve. Mayor Doris W.
A new method for the longer preservation of fresh fish has been developed in Germany, according to a report from Berlin made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The midwinter conference of the Trust Division of the American, Bankers Association concluded yesterday a three-day session in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with an examination of the practical difficulties as well as the advantages of the common investment fund for small trusts, authorized in December by Regulation F of the Federal Reserve Board.
With Spring only a few weeks away, many New Yorkers are turning their thoughts to Summer homes and resort properties close to the ocean or in mountain communities.
Securities registered with -the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933, becoming effective in January, remained at a low level, gross proceeds aggregating $79,909,000.

Political developments in Central Europe cast gloom in export circles here yesterday as many foreign traders conceded the loss of all markets which come under German dominance in the near future. So far as Austria is concerned, some exporters announced they have already changed their conditions of sale to accounts there to strict terms of cash in New York.

The Beauharnois Power Corporation is now delivering 125,000 horsepower to the Ontario Hydroelectric Commission on the modified basis of the new contract which ultimately calls for 250,000 horsepower, John S. Norris, president of Beauharnois, told shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Montreal.

Retail ALBANY-Berkley Dress Shop; H. Richman, coats; 225 W. 34th (Retail Specialty Shops). AMSTERDAM, N. Y.-M. Lurie Co.; M. Mayne, house furnishings, novelties, dollar, premium items; 128 W. 31st (S. Hoffman). BOSTON-Chandler Co.; Miss H. Howry, women's better dresses; 50 W. 35th (Syndicate-Alliance).
After allowance for the usual seasonal changes, business in the Pittsburgh district declined a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Clarence J. Huff, for many years general sales manager of Procter Gamble, has been elected vice president in charge of sales, according to announcement yesterday by Richard R. Deupree, president.

The wou desterilization of $30,000,000 of gold received since Jan. 1, in accordance with the Treasury's new policy announced by Secretary Morgenthau on Monday, caused certain changes to appear on the Treasury daily statement for Feb. 15, which resuited in inquiries to the Treasury which were answered today.

Four trainmen were killed and seven other persons, including five passengers, were injured when a Colorado Southern freight train and a passenger train crashed sixtyeight miles south of here, railroad officials reported today.

From British Guiana's inland jungles came word today of the death of Dr. Frederick John Fox, New York scientist, and the safety of other members of an exedition searching for Paul Redfern, long-missing American aviator.

Six educational and humane institutions receive large interests in the estate of Edward Bayard Halsted, retired stock broker, who died in Ventura, Calif., on Feb. 5, last, in his seventy-sixth year. His will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Michigan conservation authorities have just completed a three-year creel census of the lakes and streams of that State, and one of the conclusions they have reached is going to bring out an argument. This conclusion is "that women are not as good at trout fishing as are men."
Uncle Sam at the end of 1987 owned 71,733 homes through, foreclosures, or about 50,500 more than a year before, records of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation showed today.

There was a brief but sharp flurry of excitement among the patrons in the main building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art late yesterday afternoon when a 51year-old man climbed up on the guard rail of the second floor balcony and jumped thirty feet to the marble floor of the building.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 16: COLONELS Hayne, P. T., Adjutant General's Department, 3 days' leave, Feb. 23.

The Millsdale Stable's Winning Chance annexed the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today. The son of Chance Play-Mary Jane took command at the top of the stretch and under steady handling scored going away.
President Getulio Vargas's insistence that his new regime is not linked with European Fascist movements has just been supported by several events.

Walter Damrosch's "The Man Without a Country" made its entrance in the Winter season of the Metropolitan Opera last night. Although the cast listed three debutantes, two had been heard in the same opera last Spring.
An angry crowd of 2,000 burned an effigy of Premier Mussolini of Italy today as a result of a complaint by a taxi driver that he had been attacked aboard the Italian cruiser Raimondo Montecuccoli.

Realty interests throughout the city were urged yesterday by Oscar S. Cox, Assistant Corporation Counsel, to cooperate with the city administration in its efforts under the new charter and administrative code to make New York a "better place in which to work and live."
With Bob Peters setting the pace, the Hun School basketball team defeated the Rutgers Prep quintet today, 37-15. Peters contributed eight field goals.

Ageneral Midwest beer blockade against Indiana appeared possible tonight in the wake of Ohio's virtual ban of Indiana beer. The Ohio Tax Commission, retaliating against Indiana's political port of entry system, placed a $1,500 additional annual fee on Ohio wholesalers handling Indiana beer.
Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the Anthracite Institute, denied today that there was any "semblance of monopoly" in the Pennsylvania anthracite industry.

Clifford B. Harmon today announced award of the annual International Harmon Trophies for general aviation promotion to Dick Merrill, American transatlantic flier, and Jean Batten, New Zealand woman pilot who holds the Australia-England air record.

Playing up to the form that gave her top seeding in the Class B women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Apawamis Club, Miss Ethel Miller, star player of the host club, today won the event by defeating her clubmate, Mrs. Alfred King, in straight games.

A reporter who simulated lunacy symptoms, had himself committed to the Rockland State Hospital for the Insane and later found it difficult to obtain his release described his experiences yesterday at a resumed public hearing of the legislative committee investigating law enforcement.
The supplementary war budget has been fixed by the Treasury at about 4,800,000,000 yen. This covers only the combined demands of the army and navy for the campaign in China.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: F. Parker Lewis taking issue with Dr. Charles A. Beard foresees that it would easily be possible for a foreign power to land an army of 500,000 on our shores and exact tribute from our great cities provided we had not sufficient battleship protection.
The one-story building at 415-23 West Twenty-fifth Street, on a plot 125 by 100 feet, will be altered for use as a combination freight and passenger bus terminal.
President Roosevelt conferred secretly with a group of administrative and Congressional advisers, and was understood to have suggested a new formula for solution of the war debts problem.

Advisory Master Dougal Herr in Chancery Court today granted a divorce to Edmund S. Baird of 411 Fourth Avenue, Westwood, on the ground that Mrs. Elizabeth M. S. Baird of 136 West Clinton Avenue, Bergenfield, had deserted him on Feb. 19, 1935.

The official Italian attitude toward developments in Austria is fully set forth today by the Informazione Diplomatica, the Foreign Ministry organ, which states that closer understanding and collaboration between Germany and Austria are regarded with nothing but favor by the Italian Government.

Frank Sieverman Jr. of the New York A. C. captured a secondround match in the veterans' national squash tennis championship at the Princeton Club yesterday. leverman eliminated L. H. Sonneorn of the Yale Club, 15-9, 15-3.

When the command came this afternoon ending the two-day attack on Vieques, the first half of the fleet landing exercises, which constitute this Winter's Caribbean manoeuvres, closed and soldiers, sailors and marines called it a day.
Andre Lebon, one of France's leading shipping men and vice president of the Suez Canal Company, died today of grippe. He was 79 years old.
The Annalist reports that for the sixth consecutive week its index of wholesale commodity prices declined and that on Wednesday the index was 82.2, against 82.8 a week before and 92.6 a year before.
The St. Joseph's School for the Deaf quintet defeated St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School, 39 to 23, on the winners' floor yesterday. Dan Corrella led the attack for St. Joseph's with 13 points.

Dr. Charles Paul, city of Paris medical examiner, today performed an autopsy on the body of Leon Sedoff, son of the exiled former Soviet War Commissar, who died here Wednesday after a three-week illness, which had led his lawyers, Gerard Rosenthal and Jean Rous, to suspect a poison plot by the NKVD [Soviet political police.

Bancamerica - Blair Corporation will offer today-an issue of $1,400,000 of The People of Puerto Rico 4 per cent Electric Power Revenue bonds of 1936 Ponce Electric Plant, maturing in varying amounts from July 1, 1938 to 1956.

The temperature was 23 below zero on the ground here yesterday, but 46,260 feet up in the air it was 74 degrees above. Radio robot revelations were told by W. B. Drawbaugh and L. A. Coffin, sent from Washington to conduct a high altitude survey.
Edward Olszewski, 28, machine operator, was arrested early today on a charge of participation in the robbery Wednesday of the Philmont National Bank.
The German Government has approved the extension of the permit for the use of Haavaramarks (Jewish emigrant marks) for another year, it was announced yesterday by Intria, Ltd.

Purchases of securities in odd lots continued to exceed sales on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 12, with 60,339 shares bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

John F. Bottomley. Inc., has arranged first mortgages as follows: With an insurance institution. $75,000 at 4 1/2c on the six-story apartment at 1,224 St Nicholas Ave for Edward Brandt; $150,000 at 4%
Representative Mary Norton, chairman of the House Labor Committee, said today that the committee would start the consideration, one week from today of a new Wages and Hours Bill.
Aubrey Williams, Acting Relief Administrator, urged a Senate appropriations subcommittee today to approve a $250,000,000 supplementary relief outlay to provide WPA jobs.
Recent dramatic changes in Central and Southeastern Europe have caused the postponement until Feb. 25 of the conference of the Balkan Entente, originally scheduled to open here tomorrow.

Frank J. Taylor, former City Controller, was elected president of the American Steamship Owners' Association yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the directors at the association's offices, 11 Broadway. He succeeds R. J. Baker, who was elected secretary and treasurer.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis, defending champion, who was seeded No. 1, and Miss Margaret Bostwick, former metropolitan and New York State champion, fought their way into the final of the eighth annual New York Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament on the courts of the Junior League yesterday.

To help bring the school libraries of this city up to the State requirement of two books per pupil, the Board of Education has voted a special appropriation of $100,000 to purchase books for the city's forty-eight academic high schools, it was learned yesterday. About 75,000 volumes will be purchased, it was estimated.

Leading school-building authorities throughout the country are taking issue with the recent recommendations of the Illuminating Engineering Society increasing minimum classroom lighting standards by 200 per cent, it was learned yesterday.
By DANIEL GREENWALD Division St, 129, 3-story tenement and store, 25x62.5; Ida Weisglass against Lillian W. Maybaum; due, $3,104; taxes, etc, $877; to plaintiff for $1,000.
The A. A. Button Works, Inc., buttons and findings, leased from the Wendel Foundation the fourstory store and loft building at 825 Sixth Avenue through the Cross Brown Company, brokers.

Jimmy Adamick, the Midland (Mich.) heavyweight who has built up quite a record in the Middle West, will make his first appearance in a New York ring when he tackles Harry Thomas in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Building Trades Employers Association of New IYork City has elected officers for this year as follows: President, Walter S. Faddis; vice president, Robert C. Whiting; second vice president, Alexander H. Burgess; third vice president, Fred Brutschy, and treasurer, J. George Costello.
