Thomas J. Carroll has been appointed manager of the New York office of Marshall Field Co. and Frederick Nelson, succeeding Charles D. Bunker, who has been named merchandise manager of the Marshall Field retail store in Chicago.
Engineering construction awards for this week are 6 per cent above the total for the same week last year, with $45,001,000, as compared with $42,558,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.

IF you enjoyed George Santayana's brilliant novel, "The Last Puritan," you should enjoy reading his new book, "The Realm of Truth."* For though it is a book of philosophy, not a novel, it is a continuation of the reflections of the mind that made the novel-sparkling, ironic and profound.

Hearings in the Securities and Exchange Commission proceedings against W. E. Hutton Co. for dealings in the stock of the Atlas Tack Company were reopened here yesterday at the request of the company, so that Herbert S. Hall might alter his testimony.

Consolidation of the Grace Line Steamship Company and the Colombian Steamship Company to improve and expand American shipping service in Caribbean and South American ports was announced today by Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.

Charging that a hearing called by the Federal Trade Commission for establishment of trade practice rules for the wool industry was instituted on the request of "exactly two members of the wool textile industry and certain wool growers," Arthur Besse, president of the National Asociation of Wool Manufacturers, wired the FTC yesterday declining to participate in the conference.
Luncheon, City Club of New York, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, 12:30 P. M. "New Phases in the Health Department Program," Dr. Shirley W. Wynne.
By GEORGE J. KEARNS Grand Ave, 1,696, 2-story dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Isaac Kafka. due, $13,891; to plaintiff for $500.
Leland Harrison, United States Minister to Switzerland, returned yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan to report to the State Department in Washington.

BECK. OTTO (Jan. 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Theresa Jerabek, 3,006 Midvale Ave., Philadelphia, Pa., $2,000; Rhomas Elwood Schenk, 4,825 Palethorpe St. Philadelphia, Pa., $2,000; New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital, 354 W. 50th St., remainder in $5,000;

Ted Gold, Salle Santelli fencer and former N. Y. U. star, annexed the national junior foils fencing championship at the Greco Academy last night. Gold, intercollegiate epee champion, made a splendid showing, as he won six of his seven bouts for the laurels.

The unusual feature of the fine performance of Wagner's "Walkuere" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was the appearance of an excellent new Fricka-Enid Szantho, who then made her first appearance on this stage in the part of Wotan's unobliging spouse.
In preparation for the Silvermine (Conn.) Music Festival in August, improvement of the grounds on which the orchestral shell stands has already been begun, it was announced yesterday.

-"Operette," Noel Coward's latest musical play for which he has written the book, lyrics and music opened before an enthusiastic audience tonight in the Manchester Opera House where it will stay until its London premiere in March.

SOME entrancing light literature on heavy topics comes off the mimeograph machines of the fight managers and promoters. The advance output on Jimmy Adamick, a young heavyweight from Michigan making his Garden debut this evening against Harry Thomas, includes the following due notice and general warning:

United States marine headquarters announced today that Japanese Army authorities have forbidden Japanese patrols to encroach upon the United States defense sector of Shanghai's International Settlement.

Mace Ave (16-4455), s s, 235 ft e of Hering Ave. 40x100; Eugene Blitz to Mary Schmitt, 1,244 Clay Ave. Seton Ave, 3,909 (17-4960); Anna Kratzer to Teachers Building and Loan Assn, 103 Park Row. St. Raymond's Ave (15-4080), n a, 144 ft e of Williamsbridge Rd, 50x100; James L. Hammill to Vincenza Santinello, 1,885 3d Ave.

The Administration's announced policy designed to raise commodity prices gave further strength to these markets yesterday, although traders were in the dark as to just how Washington proposes to accomplish such a task.
Miss Diana Battye, whose disappearance last June aroused fears that she had been kidnapped, today married Michael Henry Asquith, grandson of Britain's wartime Prime Minister.

Five witnesses called by the Bethlehem Steel Company-two local business men and three non-union workerstestified at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that the Johnstown Citizens Committee, organized during the "Little Steel" strike here in June, was not a vigilante body or a company "stooge," and that the company did not discriminate against union members after the strike.

The Long Island Falcons and the Columbia Lions battled to a 2-all overtime deadlock in a first-round game in the play-offs for the New York Amateur Hockey Association championship at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The teams will replay the game Saturday night.
Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the RitzCarlton for Mrs. J. Peter Hoguet, Mrs. Charles C. Auchincloss and Mrs. Grant Norden.

Miss Madeline Mason-Manheim has returned to 77 Park Avenue after passing the Autumn and early Winter in Portugal, where she was a guest of Herbert Claiborne Pell, the United States Minister, and Mrs. Pell, in Lisbon.
Mrs. Carrie K. Medalie, wife of George Z. Medalie, former United States Attorney, was appointed a member of the Board of Higher Education yesterday by Mayor F. H. La Guardia.
Police were called out today to disperse rioting Czechoslovak Nazis at Karlovy Vary, only fifteen miles from the German border.

To Sports Bditor of The New York Times: It is not too early to consider the question of the 1940 Olympic Games in Japan and John Kieran's recent column is a valuable contribution, although I differ with his conclusions.

Lester P. Barlow, inventor of aerial bombs, asserted today that a deadly new weapon, the "aerial mine," which would compel revolutionary changes in methods of warfare, would be announced in the "immediate future."

Business leases reported yesterday included several contracts for space in buildings in the downtown area. The entire twenty-fifth floor in 30 Broad Street was leased to F. S. Smithers Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange.

Estate, $42,736; net, $41,296. To Elsie Cohnstaedt, widow, two-thirds residue; Elsie Cohnstaedt, daughter, one-third residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $38,203. Raphael L. Elias, attorney, 70 Pine St.

Commander Frank Slinguff, U. S. N., and Mrs. Slinguff are at the New Weston. Mrs. George Horace Lorimer has come from Wyncote, Pa., to the Ritz-Carlton. The Misses Lucy and Hilda Hutchinson left yesterday' for Greenfield, Mass., where they will be joined by their sister, Miss Harriet Hutchinson, a student at Milton Academy, for the Winter sports over the holiday.

Rough Diamond, 6-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Ed. Haughton and trained by her husband, finally came through with a victory today in accounting for the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds.
Homer S. Campbell, controller of the. Crane Company since 1933, was found dead in the basement' of his home in River Forest this' morning.

A group headed by Stanley Heller and Joseph Steiner have leased for ten years part of the Coburg Hotel, at 219 West Thirty-fourth Street, and a plot fronting seventy-five feet to the rear, on West Thirtyfifth Street, and will shortly erect thereon a motion picture theatre for the showing of newsreels and short subjects.
A single coast defense gun develops as much power in firing one shell as do all of the engines propelling the Navy's battle fleet, a Navy scientist said today.

The season's fifth "La Boheme" was seen last night at the Metropolitan Opera House by a capacity house. Jan Kiepura appeared again in the role of Rodolfo, in which he made his debut, and was again enthusiastically received. Grace Moore, as Mimi, was also heartily applauded.

The injustice inherent in some of our common uses of words is illustrated by a bit of scientific information which trickled into this office the other day. When we want to be mean about a person who obviously enjoys his leisure we call him slothful.
Sales of copper were made in the export market yesterday at 10.125 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the best level for the current movement.
Mr. and Mrs. John T. Scheepers of 173 Riverside Drive gave a dinner last night at their home for Dr. J. W. Th. van Erp,

Tom Kennedy, Secretary-Treasurer of the United Mine Workers and Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania, is Mr. John L. Lewis's candidate for Governor. Has Mr. Lewis's word ceased to be law? Is Senator Guffey a bigger boss than he?

Eight four-year scholarships for high school seniors in Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey have been established by Muhlenberg College. The scholarships will be awarded each year on the basis of a competitive examination, the first to be held this year at the college on April 30. Each scholarship is valued at $1,200.

Another exceedingly dull period in respect to new State and municipal financing is indicated for next week, when a total of only $2,429,900 in new issues is scheduled for award. They will consist of obligations of thirty-three municipalities.
The Rev. William Thomas Flood, an assistant pastor at St. Monica's Catholic Church, 413 East Seventyninth Street, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital following an operation. He was 42 years old.
Howard L. Ross has resigned as president and general sales manager of the Sparklets Corporation. His future plans have not yet been announced.

All the major winners of the season, now at the height of their racing effectiveness, will compete in the New York A. C. games at Madison Square Garden tonight in the seventieth anniversary of America's first indoor track games.

The practical elimination of inflation or further devaluation of the dollar as a market influence as a result of the President's press conference today resulted in fairly general liquidation by recent buyers of grain futures on the Board of Trade here.
The International Tin Committee fixed today the tin-production quota for the second quarter of 1938 at 55 per cent of standard tonnages, compared to 70 per cent for the present quarter.

Paul Waner dickered for two hours and a half today about terms in his 1938 contract with the Pirates, then scrawled his signature on his thirteenth major league agreement. The three-time National League batting champion, looking lean and bronzed, said the new pact was entirely satifactory.

George Fred Pelham Jr., architect, announced yesterday plans for a six-story apartment house on the block front on the south side of West 238th Street, from Fieldston Road to Greystone Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
Garner Rieck Weed, a vocalist, died on Wednesday in Waterville, Me., after an illness of a few days at the age of 36, according to word received here by his mother, Mrs. Lewis M. Weed of Binghamton.

The marriage of Miss Gretchen Cressler Heasley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Heasley of this city, to Douglas Franchot Hickok, son of Mrs. Neil Macdonald Wilder of Goshen, N. Y., and of Lieut. Col.

The visiting United States AmateurAthletic Union basketball team defeated a picked. Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo squad, 32 to 27, in its third game here tonight. At half time the North Americans led, 20 to 6.

Scoring its tenth success in twelve tournament games, St. Francis Prep assured itself of at least a deadlock for the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. championship as a result of a 36-to-26 triumph over St. Augustine's High on the losers' floor last night.
Ernesto Berumen, Mexican pianist, long resident in this city, gave a recital in Town Hall last night which was received cordially by a sizable audience.

Taking the lead after getting away to a slow start, Princeton's quintet avenged an early season setback by defeating an invading Rutgers five, 49--41, in the university gymnasium tonight. It was the second loss in eleven starts for the New Brunswick team, which beat Princeton 34-33 last December.

John F. Dewey, commissioner of the conciliation division of the United States Department of Labor, visited this city yesterday to investigate the strike of the telegraph and teletype operators of Harris, Upham Co., Wall Street brokerage house.
Squadron Leader R. E. Alderson of the Royal Air Force, stationed at Ramleh, was killed instantly today when a taxi in which he was riding was fired on by a gang of Arabs on the Haifa-Jaffa road.

Representative Plumley of Vermont charged today that the Federal Power Commission had discriminated against the Boulder project in fixing low interest rates on amortization charges at the Bonneville project in the Pacific Northwest.

Thirteen persons recorded as having voted in one Jersey City district in the November Gubernatorial election did not vote, William E. Sewell, chief counsel for the Hudson County Superintendent of Elections, John Ferguson, testified today before the Young Assembly Committee in Essex County Court House here.
Harry Hyams, an auctioneer in Brooklyn for forty-five years, died on Thursday night at his home, 1 Sidney Place, Brooklyn, at the age of 67.
Raymond Trotter, 9 years old, delivered his newspapers in the Monmouth County Court House today in spite of a prohibition by Fred Davidson, custodian of the building.

Ciro Terranova, the one-time "artichoke king" and a major gang leader who was exiled from New York City by Mayor La Guardia, has been living in the city for about a year under a kind of guarded amnesty from the Police Department, it was revealed yesterday.
The Kodak international exhibit for 1938 was opened with a private preview last night in the mezzanine galleries of the International Building, Rockefeller Center. From today through Feb. 27
The Brooklyn Tech and Jamaica High sextets maintained their unbeaten pace in the P. S. A. L. ice hockey championship tournament by winning at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.
Frederick W. Ford, for fifty-one years telegraph and news editor of The Boston Transcript until his retirement two years ago, died today in his home in Medford at the age of 74.

Miss Suzanne Cort, daughter of Mrs. Harry Lindsley Cort of 102 East Twenty-second Street and the late Mr. Cort, has chosen March 1 for her marriage to John Walter Wood, son of Mrs. J. Walter Wood of this city and the late Mr. Wood.

Only one candidate, a private school teacher, passed the recent written and. oral tests for the coveted $11,000 post of examiner in the Board of Education. This was disclosed yesterday -when the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced that Joseph Jablonower, teacher of mathematics at the Ethical Culture School, was the one to receive a passing grade.

Miss Gwen Bader Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seward -Bader Jackson of Chatham, N. J., was married in Christ Church here yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Ackley Rowe, son of Mrs. Benjamin Ackley Rowe of New Rochelle, N. y., and the late Mr. Rowe.

Today's major events: National Orchestral Association, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; "Lohengrin," afternoon,, "Faust," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; "La Boheme," New York Hippodrome Opera, evening; Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Town Hall, afternoon; Mailaam concert, Town Hall,. evening.
A marble tomb in Westminster Abbey containing the bodies of an infant prince and princess has been opened 700 years after their burial, abbey officials disclosed today.
Staging a drive in the last five minutes, the Tufts quintet overpowered Williams College, 37-38, on the Cousens court tonight.
Jack Kearns came back to New York boxing last night with a heavyweight who looks as if he will go places. His name is Jimmy Adamick and he is from Detroit via Midland, Mich.

The vagaries of the elements weighed heavily in Manager Bill Terry's favor today as he tackled the second day of his manifold duties as high commander, trainer and physician to the Giants' expeditionary forces.

Conrad Morris Braker, retired importer and a brother of the late Henry J. Braker, importer and philanthropist, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home, 136-05 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, after a five-day illness. He was 79 years old.
Federal Judge Knox dismissed yesterday a petition filed last December by the J. Edward Jones Petroleum Corporation for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Captain N. H. Goss, commanding Destroyer Squadron Ten- based at Culebra Island for manoeuvres the last month, brought his little fleet in today in time for officers and men to witness the opening of the Ponce de Leon carnival.

Announcement was made at a tea at Wells College this afternoon of the engagement of Miss Winifred Kellogg Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stearns of Mount Vernon, N. H., to Professor Lewis H. Niven of Hobart College.

Maurice W. Metzler of the City A. C., who was the fourth ranking player last season, came through with seven others in the opening round of the Eastern Association Group I squash racquets championship at the City A. C. yesterday. Metzler defeated W. O'Reilly of the New York A. C. in a match that went five games.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 12 amounted to 542,991 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that the 1938 program for construction of arterial parkways in the metropolitan area contemplated the expenditure of $3,575,000 and that two bills to appropriate the necessary funds already are pending before the Legislature.

A plea for greater cooperation and effort in bringing peace to the State's milk industry was made by Governor Lehman in an address to a capacity Farm and Home Week audience in Bailey Hall, the largest auditorium on the Cornell campus.

Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange; Ernest Angell, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Frank R. Hope, former president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, will attend the annual dinner of the Cashiers'

Mrs. Theodore W. Griggs gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Lidie Lane Sloan and Andrew M. McBurney Jr., whose marriage will take place next Saturday in the Church of the- Heavenly Rest.

Common Pleas Judge Samuel E. Kramer approved the reorganization plan for the liquidating Union Trust Company today and cleared the way for establishment of the new Union Bank of Commerce and payment of $38,000,000 in dividends to depositors of the Union Trust.

Seven steamship lines carrying freight between the Atlantic seaboard and the southwestern part of the United States asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a complaint filed against Eastern and Southwestern railroads to require the rail carriers to grant to them a more equitable share of joint rates.

Only one match was played yesterday in the University Club invitation doubles squash racquets tournament for the Arthur H. Lockett trophy. The winners were W. S. Wonham of the Greenwich Field Club and D. Lee Norris of Rockaway Hunting Club.
Almost all classes of listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were lower yesterday as the result of a moderate reaction, but the trading pace was somewhat slower.
The French composer-teacher Mile. Nadia Boulanger today became the first woman ever to conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a public performance.

Documentary evidence that Councilman Michael J. Quill listed his permanent residence address as 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, Manhattan, a few weeks after his election from the Bronx was introduced yesterday at the opening session of the Council committee investigating Mr. Quill's residence qualifications.
Victor F. Ridder, Chalmers Wood, Mrs. Yorke Allen and Frank M. McCurdy have been elected trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., 51 East Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday.

The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation has issued a certificate of insurance to the Jackson Heights Savings and Loan Association of 83-20 Roosevelt Avenue, Queens County, L. I., according to an announcement today.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

It would be hard to imagine a more dramatic demonstration of how close in point of time the peoples of the Americas have been drawn by the magic of wings than the flight completed yesterday at Buenos Aires by six giant B-17 planes of the Army Air Corps.
The American Airlines flagship Texas, on its way from Memphis to California with twelve passengers, was forced down in a field two and a half miles south of here at 11:30 A. M.
Queens University defeated Harvard, 6--2, tonight in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game to complete its schedule with the loss of only two games.

Charlotte Kirk bought from the 11 West Fordham Road Corp the dwelling at 116 W 71st St and gave back a purchase money mortgage for $5,250, due in 5 years at 5 per cent, subject to a first for $10,000, the price being shown as $6,500 over this 1st mortgage.

Doddrick Olson has been named president of James McCreery Co., succeeding Neil Petree, who resigned recently to become head of Barker Brothers, Los Angeles. Mr. Olson has dropped his former title of chairman of the board of the organization.
Dr. Charles Gott, dean of Tufts Graduate School since 1935, died tonight at the Baker Memorial Hospital after an illness of several weeks. His age was 50.
Miss Louise Josephine Schiele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Schiele of this city, was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Edmund Laskin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Laskin

The Harbor Towboatmen's Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, abandoned yesterday a strike against the Oil Transport Corporation, which had been effective since Jan. 4. The company agreed to re-employ fourteen of the twenty-two men involved in the strike and to employ the others when business conditions warranted.
Movements of livestock In the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Many leading agencies took advantage of the rise in building costs during 1937, and the consequent buyer resistance to higher prices on new homes, to dispose of many of the houses which they had acquired through foreclosure.

Union labor suggested yesterday that President Lazaro Cardenas be re-elected President of Mexico when his term expires in 1940. The suggestion, made at the convention of the Federation of Electrical Unions, received prominent attention in the newspaper Universal today.

Mayor La Guardia, who has been ailing with a touch of grippe for the last two days, plans to make a speech on transit unification before the City Affairs Committee in the Hotel Commodore at 1 P. M. today.

The text of the statement of administrative price policy read by President Roosevelt to his press conference today was as follows: This administration has from the beginning pursued a policy designed to promote full employment of our human and material resources.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Helene Anne Marie Charlotte De Suzannett, widow, 20 Rue Greuze XVI, Paris, France, household, personal effects and one-fourth residue; Jaqueline M., Roland L. E.. Sybille J. P., Alain L. G., Robert A. C. V. and Lionel J. R. De Suzannett, children, same address, one-eighth residue each. Frederic R.
J. F. T. O'Connor, United States Controller of the Currency, today formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor of California.

The refusal of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers to participate in the trade practice conference for the wool industry which the Federal Trade Commission has scheduled for March 8 will not interfere with the commission's plans to hold it, an official spokesman said today.

A downpour today caused a one-day postponement of the $5,000 Crescent City open golf tournament. Twenty-three threesomes were wading through the driving rain when tournament officials announced the postponement.

A contra-seasonal increase in cotton-mill activity last week sent the adjusted index forward to 90.6 from 87.2, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Feb. 13, 1937. it stood at 140.4.
Pennsylvania suggested today that the Federal Government share the $50,000,000 cost of its mountainpiercing highway, the first link in what may become a transcontinental speedway.

Possible rule changes will-be discussed at the two-day annual meeting of the National Professional Football League which opens tomorrow. Among changes suggested are putting the ball in play on the 45-yard line when a kick-off goes out of bounds instead of the 35-yard line;
The marriage of.Miss Doris Lane Laidlaw, daughter of Alexander Laidlaw of 270 Park Avehue and the late Mrs. Laidlaw, to William Edward Dillmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Dillmeier
Colonel Jeremiah Beall, retired textile executive who served overseas in the Ordnance Department during the World War, died yesterday after a long illness at New York Hospital at the age of 67.

Breaking a tie with only three minutes remaining in the second half, the George Washington University five turned back St. John's University, 44 to 41, in a thrilling game in the De Gray gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.
Governor Olin Johnston signed the Forty-Hour Textile Bill today, declaring it was "blazing the trail for national legislation to eliminate slave-driving forever from industrial life."

Guila Bustabo, 18-year-old violinist, gave her first local recital in three years last night at Carnegie Hall. Her recent appearance with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra had evidently been an alluring foretaste of her gifts, for the hall held a large audience that honored the artist with its profound attention and ardent response.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,192,000 bales, against 1,184,000 a week ago, 1,146,000 two weeks ago, 1,127,000 three weeks ago and 920,000 a year ago; of which American 794,000 bales, against 787,000 a week ago, 739,000 two weeks ago, 722,000 three weeks ago and 415,000 a year ago.

Colonel and Mrs. E. Cuthbert Binns of Istanbul have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Binns, to William 0. Baxter of Princeton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Baxter of Knightstown, Ind.

The Boy Scouts of Managua will become part of the city's fire department and will be trained for special work. The department, which was organized two years ago by an expert from Panama, has as active members some of Managua's most distinguished citizens, who, regardless of the times of fires, are always present.

A reduction in the rates of the voluntary non-profit hospital insurance plans lest the government enter the field in competition and set up its own system of hospitalization was recommended yesterday at the convention of hospital service plan executives in the Hotel Commodore.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Harry Cohen in THE TIMES for Feb. 10 is a plausible statement of a complaint often heard: why do not banks extend credit freely to the small man? Mr. Cohen says he needs more goods wherewith to stock his Troy store; why doesn't his local bank grant him sufficient credit with which to buy the goods?

Properties on the upper West Side representing an investment of more than $2,200,000 were involved in. a deal announced yesterday when Frederick Brown, the operator, sold a large apartment house on Central Park West to the James Butler estate, which gave several parcels in part payment.

Paul Mellon's American-owned Drinmore Lad, unplaced his last four times out, today won the twoand-a-half-mile optional selling steeplechase and gained further support for the Grand National at Aintree, March 25.

Of the nine parcels of Manhattan realty sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms, seven were sold to satisfy tax liens. All of the latter properties are on East 127th and 128th Streets between First and Second Avenues, just north of the Triborough Bridge.

President Roosevelt today withdrew the restrictions put on activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation last October, and directed the corporation to resume the extension of loans to "all deserving borrowers" with emphasis, in this connection, on loans that would maintain or increase employment.

Nelson T. Rathbun, second cousin of the late Nelson H. Tunicliff, must keep the grass green over Tunicliff's grave if he would share in his $48,400 estate. Mr. Tunicliff's will provides that a trust fund becomes void if the grass turns brown.

The Treasury's usual weekly issue of ninety-one-day bills, which ordinarily would have been sold on Monday, but which this week was sold today owing to the holiday on Tuesday, brought an average price of 0.092 per cent, compared with 0.078 per cent for the preceding issue, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

CHILDREN OF LIGHT, edited by Howard H. Brinton. (Macmillan, $3.50). Fifteen essays written by students of Quaker history in honor of the seventy-fifth birthday of Rufus Jones. "Children of Light" was an early name for the Quakers.

A defense bill increasing the national defense expenditures, compared with last year, from nearly 30,000,000 florins to 110,000,000, was adopted in the upper house today with only four Socialists voting against it.

Police today released 270 of the 400 members of the Defense Against Communism who on Thursday evening converged on Tokyo by truck from Hachioji, twenty miles away, and established themselves with household equipment in the headquarters of the two major political parties, which they sought to reform.

An exhaustive study of the adequacy of the machinery for underwriting securities, with particular emphasis upon the advisability of commercial banks being readmitted to the function of corporate underwriting,

The Administration of Jersey City, through Acting Mayor Arthur W. Potterton, threatened yesterday afternoon to frustrate the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company's proposal for a fare rise from 6 to 10 cents on its Cortlandt Street line by rerouting bus lines to carry thousands of passengers to competing railroad ferryboats instead of to the tube system they now feed.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 5 totaled 304,494,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Neither the Interborough Rapid Transit Company nor the Manhattan Railway Company has agreed with any representative of the Transit Commission to accept any price base for these properties less than the one fixed in the transit unification plan proposed by Samuel.Seabury and City Chamberlain

GOVERNORS ISLAND Leave of absence for 20 days, effective on or about March 7, is granted Lt. Matthew F. Stiling, D.-F. U.S.N.R. Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. Alfred F. Bolger,
The ninth annual dance and entertainment of the Press Photographers Association of New York was held last night at the Commodore Hotel. Thirty-five hundred or more persons attended the gathering.

Inland Investors, Inc.--As of Dec. 31 market prices, the value of securities represented by each share of stock, stood at $18.71 a share, compared with $27.11 a share a year earlier. Profit for 1937 was $143,942 after expenses and Federal taxes,

The following members having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

A graphic demonstration of the part that chemicals may play in the next war was given here today as thirty-six officer-students from the army, navy and marine corps, attending the current class at the Chemical Warfare Service School, were put through tests that blurred eyes and caused irritation to heads and hands.
The resignation of Chet Wynne as athletic director and head football coach at the University of Kentucky was announced today by President Frank L. McVey.
After another sharp advance which lifted all months above 9 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $1 a bale following President Roosevelt's statement of policy on price relationships.

Sermons will be preached today in synagogues and tomorrow in churches in observance of the fifth annual Brotherhood Week which will begin today. Sermons will also be delivered in commemoration of the birthday of George Washington.
William Nutley, home on Hatfield PI., Port Richmond, S. I., and August Heerlein, on Hartford St., West New Brighton, both from Staten Island Savings Bank through Cornelius G. Kolff, Inc., broker.
A radio message from a Japanese station at Nagasaki today said the steamer Vogesen was in imminent danger of sinking after a collision at Moji harbor, Japan.
Now it is the average driver who is responsible for most of our automobile accidents.

The tenants and former residents of Rosalind Gardens Apartments, in Dobbs Ferry, ill give their tenth annual party tonight in the ballroom of the building to honor Harry Z. Suchin as "the best landlord in the State."
President Roosevelt arrived here tonight for a four-day rest, his special train making the trip from Washington in less than seven hours.

A last-minute spurt carried Miss Peggy Wattles, former New York State champion, and Major Childlaw-Roberts of the British Army to victory over Mr. and Mrs. K. H. Sheldon of Nassau, L. I., in the thirty-six-hole final of the Riddells Bay Golf and Country Club's fourth annual mixed foursomes tournament today. The score was 1 up.

Louis M. Loeb, 10 rooms and 4 baths, in 1,120 Park Ave; Mrs. Sarah A. Murphy, in 22 E 62d St; Mrs. Fredric K. Trask, through Bertha Stockwell, in 4 E 95th St; Mrs. W. J. Tappan, Maxwell M. Klien, in the Buchanan, 160 E 48th St; Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.

Newton's high-scoring quintet ran its league winning streak to thirteen and assured itself of at least a tie for the Queens P. S. A. L. title by crushing Jamaica, 43 to 26, at Jamaica last night. Johnny Carroll led the attack for the Newowners with 17 markers.

Judge Joseph Bradley David, veteran of the Cook County Superior Court bench, died of a heart attack late last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Milton R. Jonas. He was 74 years old and had served as a judge for twenty-one years.

The National Labor Relations Board today certified the American Newspaper Guild as sole representative for bargaining purposes of all the employes of The New York Daily Mirror except those in the mechanical departments.

Louis O. Van Doren, for nearly fifty years a New York lawyer, died here today at his home at the age of 75. He was graduated from the College of the City of New York in 1883 and was admitted to the bar in 1885.

A gain of 22,000 members by the Communist party in the United States was reported by William Z. Foster, national chairman, at the opening yesterday of a four-day convention at the Manhattan Odd Fellows Temple, 105 East 106th Street.
Several apartment buildings were among the properties figuring in New Jersey realty transactions announced yesterday.

The Fordham freshmen basketball team bowed to the Bridgeton (Me.) Academy quintct, 32 to 29, at the Fordham gymnasium yesterday. Bridgeton, coached by Jack Fisher, former Maroon football and baseball star, trailed the Fordham yearlings, 19-16, at the half, but rallied in the late stages to win.

The stockholders of Ulen Co. have approved a plan to expand the management and personnel for the purpose of increasing the activity of the company to include domestic engineering, advisory and appraisal work, with compensation of executives to be partly in cash and partly in stock.

Indiana Associated Telephone Corporation, Lafayette, Ind., has filed a registration statement under provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 to cover the sale of $400,000 of Series B, 4 1/2 per cent, first-mortgage bonds, due in 1965.
Paul Hindemith, German composer, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland on his second trip to the United States.

A Winter tornado cut a path of death and destruction through this little northwest Louisiana oil town of 2,000 people last night, leaving twentyfive dead and scores of splintered homes and business houses.

Washington provided the financial community with a double-barreled discharge yesterday when the President revealed that the administration seeks to achieve a balance of prices and then, through Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced that that agency is ready to resume lending to business.
Five of the six United States Army good-will planes from Miami, Fla., reached here early this afternoon after the longest and fastest flight ever made by the bombing craft of any nation.

Establishment of a fast luxury-liner service from New York to the east coast of South America, designed as much to improve trade and diplomatic relations as to make money, is being considered by the Maritime Commission, it was announced today by Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy.

A polite and insincere little comedy, the Roxy's "The Baroness and the Butler," is a feeble exercise for William Powell's drollery, none at all for Annabella's volatile charm. Mr. Powell will survive it, for his exertions in the film's behalf were so slight that he has probably forgotten all about it by now.
City College's swimmers last night defeated New York University, 46 to 29, taking six of the nine events in the Lavender pool. The Beavers' seconds and thirds helped in the commanding lead.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 17: MAJOR GENERAL Moses, A., Hawaiian Dep't, to duty headquarters, Governors Island, N. Y., pending retirement.
Fourteen names trickled through the entry box today, with Seabiscuit and Pompoon topping the field in tomorrow's "Little Santa Anita Handicap," the $5,000 San Carlos Handicap.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the international Longshoremen's Association, was again charged yesterday with diverting union funds to his own uses. The new charge was made in a suit instituted in the Supreme Court. Accused with him were the officers of Local 791 of the I. L. A., of which Mr. Ryan is financial secretary.

The four-story apartment house at 2,500 Arthur Avenue, in the Bronx, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, has been purchased by Louis Cooper from the East River Savings Bank for cash above a $20,000 five-year mortgage.
Abbot Low Moffat, Republican chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, introduced his bill today for the establishment of a capital budgeting system.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.
The reviving courage and the will to resist of the non-Nazi population will probably receive a shock from tomorrow's newspapers, which will contain three communiques.

The strange coincidence of a visit by a fleet of German warships to Lisbon at the same time that a strong British fleet was here has set the public to speculating why the Salazar government consented to the German call or rather did not arrange the visits separately.

More motor vehicles were registered in the Bronx during January than during any other month in the last two years, according to figures compiled by the Bronx Board of Trade and made public yesterday by William E. Matthews, executive secretary.

A "balance" of commodity prices which would promote a "balanced" expansion of production and thus increase income and employment was declared by President Roosevelt today to be the immediate goal of the Administration's economic policies.

A prohibitive favorite to retain its laurels, the powerful Dartmouth unit appeared to be well on its way to another Intercollegiate Ski Union championship when the Indians from Hanover dominated the first two events held under wretched conditions today.

For the second year in succession Tommy Goodwin of Mamaroneck, N. Y., annexed the annual South Florida golf championship tournament by defeating Joseph Schenck 3d of New York, 10 and 8, in the thirty-six hole final round at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.
Secretary Wallace proclaimed marketing quotas today on the 1938 crops of cotton and flue-cured

President Roosevelt today named Rear Admiral Emory S. Land a member of the Maritime Commission to succeed Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman of that agency, and let it be known that the new chairman was expected to continue the "two-fisted, hard-hitting" policies of his predecessor.
A film depicting the work of the American Mission to Lepers in a typical colony at Chandkuri, India, will be shown by Raymond P. Currier of the mission at a meeting tomorrow night at the Madison
Mrs. Laura Reardon, one of Port Washington'smost active civic and church workers, died today in the Nassau Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 55.
Benjamin L. Van Schaick, executive secretary of the Long Island State Park Commission, died today at his home at 41 Wellington Road here of a heart ailment at the age of 60.

Colorful Confederate flags decorated the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the annual Dixie Dinner Dance of the New York Southern Society, which was attended by more than 600 members of the Southern colony in this city and their friends.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Demand for wool continues light on Summer Street and prices are easier for the week, .both with respect to worsted and woolen wools.
Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., Feb. 19: SECOND GRADE DETECTIVE-John J. McMahon, from 18th Division, O. D. D. to 34th Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked.
The College of the City of New York outclassed La Salle in the second part of a basketball double-header at Convention Hall tonight, winning by 40-23 without extending itself.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller's trial, surrounded by the utmost secrecy, was resumed today before the emergency court which is trying him for sedition. His three attorneys again represented him, since the two observers for the Confessional Church were permitted to sit in the court room,
The hacienda of Santa Barbara outside Mexico City, owned by former President Plutarco Elias Calles, now an exile in California, today was ordered distributed among peasants of La Magdalena.

The City Planning Commission, holding a-special meeting yesterday in its offices in the Municipal Building, referred back to Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn the plans for the section of the proposed circumferential parkway around Brooklyn and Queens that passes Sheepshead Bay.
Miss Dorothy Weber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis F. Weber of this place, was married to Richard H. Ludeman, son of Mrs. Edwin H. Ludeman of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Ludeman,

Frederick Phinney of 2,515 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, retired bandmaster and a descendant of Captain Miles Standish, died yesterday in Midland Park, N. J., after an illness of two months. He was 88 years old.

A study of the ratio of wage disbursements to the total value of products in fifty leading manufacturing industries revealed percentages ranging from 2.2 per cent to 48.3 per cent, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Members of the Veterans Corps Artillery of New York and the Military Society of the War of 1812, with many of their friends, will observe Washington's Birthday Tuesday with a luncheon and dance in the grand ballroom of the Pierre.
Harry Jeffra, bantamweight champion of the world, finished heavy training today for his title fight against Challenger Sixto Escobar on Sunday night with a pound or two to lose before weighing in.

As guests of the WPA Composers' Forum-Laboratory, the Ballet Caravan last night gave its first Broadway evening at the Federal Theatre of Music, presenting three ballets with scores by American musicians. It was a distinctly agreeable evening and revealed a first-rate little ballet company in the making. The audience packed the theatre and expressed its approval cordially.

Six sergeants and twelve patrolmen of the Fort Hamilton police station will face police departmental trial Feb. 23 at Brooklyn Police Headquarters for failing to report the parked automobile in which Mrs. Christine Oliveri and Nino Columbo were found murdered alongside of 9,260 Shore Road, Brooklyn, at 11 o'clock in the morning of Feb. 6.

The Daily Princetonian, becoming editorially articulate on the subject for the first time since Herbert Orrin (Fritz) Crisler resigned as football coach, today came out strongly for the appointment of a successor from among his three assistantsTad Weiman, Campbell Dixon and Earl Martineau.

An employer cannot get a judicial review of a State Labor Board order certifying a particular union as collective bargaining agent for all or part of his employes, the Appellate Division held yesterday in a threeto-two decision dismissing proceedings brought by Wallach's, Inc., the clothing store chain, against the members of the board.
The House passed and sent to the White House today a Senate bill extending lending authorizations of the Disaster Loan Corporation through 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Hume gave a supper party last night for their daughter, Miss Priscilla Alden Hume, in the Persian Room of the Plaza, which was preceded by a dinner given for her by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Blum at their residence, 106 Willow Street, Brooklyn.

The German Automobile Show, which opened here today, exhibits a model of the projected plant for the manufacture of the "people's auto-the world's cheapest car; which will be the world's largest automobile plant, allegedly exceeding in size even the Ford plant.

The value of a three-year-old child's smile was put at $5,250 today in a damage suit settlement in District Court. The settlement was made in a $30,000 action brought by Mrs. E. M. Shafer against C. G. Hilligoss following an automobile accident.

The net income of nil reported by the Clinchfield Railroad for 1937 resulted from bookkeeping methods, it was explained yesterday by Eugene S. Taliaferro of Joseph Walker Sons. Mr. Taliaferro said the company actually had a substantial net balance after expenses, taxes and interest charges in 1937.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Ganzenmuller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ganzenmuller of this place, to Frederick Everett Evans Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Larchmont, took place this afternoon in the Huguenot Memorial Church here. The Rev. Dr. William P.

The first mortgage loan of $156.000 on the seven-story apartment at 230 W. 101st St: has been extended for five years by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank with Joseph Nassoit. Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., was the broker.

Rather definite indications that the-House Ways and Means Committee would report the new Tax Bill in substantially the form as previously reported were given late today after that committee had considered the bill all day.

More than 100 members of the junior class of Barnard College and their' escorts attended the Junior Promenade last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests of honor included Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, Miss Mary F.

The Sportsmen's Show is attracting thousands of anglers and hunters to its crowded booths and you can't help being impressed when you recognize the great interest evidenced by the sportsmen, many of whom have traveled hundreds of miles to see the exhibits.

The Harvard Club yesterday captured the title in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by scoring a decisive victory over the New York A. C. team in the final of the tournament, 4 to 1. Harvard closed with thirteen victories and one defeat.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 17, unless specified: At San Pedro: Arctic, Lexington, Saratoga. Acushnet, Indianhead to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Feb. 18. Cassin, Boston Yard to Philadelphia, Feb. 18.

The General William E. Mitchell Memorial Plaque, an annual award for achievements in aeronautics, was presented last night to Miss Jacqueline Cochrane at the nineteenth annual aviators' ball, held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The "whole world today is under the shadow, the possibility and the threat of another World War," the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared last night in a sermon at the Salvation Army Temple.
President Roosevelt's announcement yesterday concerning prices of commodities and monetary values stimulated the dollar in the foreign exchange market.

The Union College Alumni Association of New York last night celebrated its fiftieth anniversary with a concert by the college glee club followed by a dance at the Hotel Astor. According to F. M. Bishop.
Rising Star Credit Union of New York City has been dissolved after completion of liquidation, it was announced today in the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department.

Publication yesterday of the refusal of Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, to attend a trade practice conference on the wool industry precipitated statements by three groups, with no change indicated in the attitude of any. F.

Harry Cook, 58 years old, a disbarred lawyer who roomed at 61-13 Thirty-seventh. Avenue, Woodside, Queens, was sentenced by Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court yesterday to serve from five to ten years in Sing Sing.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $273,000 of feneral improvement, sewer improvement and emergency relief bonds of the city of Trenton, N. J., on a bid of 100.3099 for 21/4s. The bonds are dated Jan. 15, 1938, and will mature serially from Jan. 15, 1939, to 1954.
Reports that Austria was to be drawn into the German Four-Year Plan through a customs union caused Vienna Stock Exchange prices to drop today as much as 10 Der cent.

Twelve properties in the Bronx were sold yesterday at auction in the rooms at 3,208 Third Avenue. Eight of these were bought in by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff, and two by the Mortgage Commission of New York. The list follows:

Stockholders of the Valspar Corporation approved yesterday at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., a recapitalization plan providing for funding of bank indebtedness and discharge of accumulated dividends on the present preferred stock through exchange for new preferred and additional common shares.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court held yesterday that the personal property law did not apply to the sale of mortgage Participation certificates and dismissed a test suit seeking to hold the Title Guarantee and Trust Company liable for certificates guaranteed by the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Corporation, a subsidiary.
Chartering of a new A. F. of L. local to organize hotel and club workers in this city was announced yesterday.

The National Biscuit Company reported yesterday that net income in 1937 was $11,895,111, compared to $12,640,077 in the previous year. Roy E. Tomlinson, president, in a statement to stockholders, said that the decrease was due largely to the expense of old-age benefit and unemployment compensation taxes and increased costs of raw materials.
Judge Thomas. Downs yesterday sentenced William H. Tubbs, 37 years old, in Queens County Court, Long Island City, to twenty years to life for the murder of his 6-yearold son, William Guerin Tubbs.
Mary K. O'Connor, young college athlete, was acquitted today of causing the death of Nancy Glenn, a neighbor's 5-year-old child, last Labor Day.

In and out of Wall Street, disappointment and discouragement have been created by the continued absence of definite business revival. The Reserve Board's monthly index of industrial production, which had fallen from 118 per cent of the 1923-25 average,
New York's Mortgage Commission renewed today its appeal for legislation authorizing privately owned, State-regulated mortgage banks to solve the State's mortgage investment problem.
Seven coal miners who spent a night "praying and waiting" were rescued today from a flood-blocked tunnel 500 feet underground. An eighth was found dead-buried in mud.
Congressional leaders have advised President Roosevelt against accepting a proposal by Hungary for settlement of its debt to the United States.

Sculpture has been considerably in evidence since the first of the year, and four new one-man shows became current this week. About thirty pieces by the famous German sculptor Georg Kolbe are on view at the Buchholz Gallery,

For the fourth month in succession British automobile production in December was less than in the corresponding month of 1936. The output of private cars was 31,552, which, while showing an improvement of 4,518 over November, represents a decline of 2,797, compared with December, 1936.

Dr. Bayard Dodge, native New Yorker, who for the last twenty-five years has been a member of the faculty and for the last fifteen years president of the American University of Beirut, Syria, will return there in a fortnight.
Ernst Baier and Fraeulein Maxi Herber of Germany successfully defended their world championship in pair figure skating today before 12,000 fans in Berlin's sportpalast.

Bertram S. Beir has sold the apartment and store building at 245-02 Jamaica Avenue, Bellerose, to Barnet Moskin. The structure occupies an irregular corner plot about 99.53 by 200.2 feet, and contains two apartments and two stores.

Trading by members in round lots for their own account rose to 23.16 per cent of the total volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 22, compared with 21.60 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
A willingness to arbitrate their tax dispute with Indiana authorities was expressed today by Ohio Tax Commission officials.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College will leave today on a trip to New Mexico for a rest. Later she will go to Canada to participate in local meetings of the International Federation of University Women, .of which she is president. Miss Gildersleeve expects to be absent from the college for a month.
A moderate increase in prices of hogs within two or three months as the slaughter supply declines seasonally was forecast today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

The proposal that the Federal Government build a series of transcontinental super-highways was endorsed today by the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States, with a recommendation that the first work be done between Washington and Boston.

Through the use of a modified curriculum slow pupils were able to "acquire wi h enjoyment" elements of French, German, Spanish, and Italian, according to a report made public yesterday by Dr. Theodore Huebener, assistant director of the foreign language department, New York Public Schools.

Frank Strafaci of the Lakeville Country Club, Great Neck, L. I., and 18-year-old Burleigh E. Jacobs of Wauwatosa, Wis., won their semi-final matches today in the eleventh annual national championship of golf club champions on St. Augustine links.

Mrs. Henry R. Rea entertained with a luncheon today at Lagomar for Mrs. Oliver G. Jennings, the guest of Mrs. E. H. G. Slater. Mrs. Gilbert Lee gave a dinner at Reef cottage for Mrs. Frederick Samuel Fish. Colonel and Mrs.
Two plots aggregating about an acre of land on Swathmore Avenue in Scarsdale Meadows, Westchester, have been purchased by Dorothy L. Dresser through the Raymond R. Beatty Organization.

BELIEVE it or not, "we have better maps of some parts of the moon than we have of certain 'blank' portions of the polar regions," Charles Key remarks in his illuminating book, "The Story of Twentieth-Century Exploration."* And, on reflection, that seems reasonable enough to me. I know there are parts of Manhattan that are practically terra incognita to some one trying to get somewhere in a hurry.

Dismissing $18,000,000 of Federal funds as "chicken feed" compared to the sums necessary to cope adequately with New York's municipal housing ills, Harold Riegelman told yesterday what he Lopes would be accomplished on the problem during his service as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention.
The Rev. Dr. J. Sumner Stone, Methodist Episcopal clergyman, missionary, lecturer, writer and physician, died today in his sleep of a heart ailment at his home, 5 Circuit Road. He was 82 years old.

Renewed opposition to the bills now before the State Legislature, which would stipulate that overvaluation alone could not be a basis for an action to reduce realty tax assessment valuations, was expressed by the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday in the form of a statement by Jones W. Mercereau, executive vice president.

Broken in health, Dr. Anton Rintelen, former Cabinet member and Austrian Minister to Italy, who was sentenced to life imprisonment in connection with the 1934 Nazi putsch in which Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was murdered, was released today under Austria's new amnesty for political prisoners.

Four captains, George Cookman, Yale; Leroy Lewis, Pennsylvania; Al Sulloway, Harvard, and Bernard Ridder, Princeton, today reached the semi-finals of the intercollegiate squash racquets tournament which began this morning in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium.

The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to report the $250,000, 000 Deficiency Relief Bill to the Senate on Monday. The committee eliminated a House provision which would deny relief payments to aliens who had entered the United States since 1928 and had not applied for citizenship.

Dr. William E. Dodd, former United States Ambassador to Germany, will be the speaker at a luncheon on Tuesday which will close the annual meeting of the Church League for Industrial Democracy. The session will open on Monday at 2 P. M.

Six Yale junior fraternities of the academic department announced tonight the election of seventy-one members from the sophomore class, closing the annual week of revised preliminaries,, which included the calcium light parade and visiting of the candidates and fraternity members.

Soon after Walter Bossert, a Liberty attorney, had announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination as United States Senator, James E. Watson, former Senator, telegraphed friends today that he, too, would seek the nomination. Mr. Watson is in Texas on a business trip.
British diplomacy today finally shook itself out of the apparent paralysis that had gripped it ever since Austria's capitulation to Germany.

Opening of Kodak International Exhibit of amateur photos, Mezzanine Gallery of International Building, Rockefeller Center, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. Continues to Feb. 27. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Greek Art: The Mycenaean Period," Stuart M. Shaw, 11 A. M.;
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 16: CAPTAIN Allen, A. H., Med. Corps, San Diego, Calif., to Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa.

The remarks of the President at his press conference yesterday and the statement prepared for him by the committee of Cabinet members and departmental advisers clarify the Administration's price policy in at least a few respects.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, defended yesterday the estimates submitted to the Maritime Commission by American builders for the construction of new tonnage, which were criticized by Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring chairman of the commission, in his final report to President Roosevelt.

George R. Cathers, a non-union water tender in the boiler house of the Cambria works of the Bethlehem Steel Company, testified at a National Labor Relations Board hearing today that he was the one who put a poster issued by the Johnstown Citizens Committee on the boiler house door after last June's unsuccessful strike of the C. I. O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

An engagement of international interest that has just been announced here and in London is that of Lady Henrietta Diana Juanita Finch-Hatton, younger daughter of the Earl and Countess of Winchilsea and Nottingham,

M. L. Wilson, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, defended tonight the policy of reciprocal trade pacts, praising it particularly as an aid to the farmer, and L. J. Taber, master of the National Grange, criticized it, asserting that it failed to protect the American market for the American farmer.

Stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation will be asked at the annual meeting on April 4 to approve changes in capital structure which will permit the writing down to $1 of intangible assets

Contrary to general foreign expectations that the main Japanese drive would be made in the Tientsin-Pukow Railway sector, the principal battle front apparently has shifted to the Peiping-Hankow Railway and southern Shansi Province.

How good a 4-year-old War Admiral, America's champion thoroughbred, has become will be known tomorrow when the famous son of Man o' War makes his 1938 debut at Hialeah Park in either the Heather Purse or the McLennan Memorial Handicap.

The annual report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for 1937, forwarded to shareholders yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $24,531,606. This was equal after full preferred dividend charges to $2.67
Gendarmes raided today the famous Monastery of Neamtsu, where they discovered another Iron Guard [Fascist] headquarters.

Decatur Ave, 3,105 (12-3332): Gray Apartment Co to Frances K. Teplitz, 808 West End Ave; installments, 6 per cent; $15,600. Fulton Ave (11-2930), w s, 92 ft s of 175th St, 41x100; Gabriel Gabrielson to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtg to Feb. 16, 1943, at 5 per cent: $20.000.

Assurances have been received of the unanimous willingness of members of the Eastern Women's Headwear Group to sign the new millinery agreement, it was reported yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the joint board of the Millinery Workers Union.

In an interview that Ambassador Charles Corbin of France had with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in London today he made a strong bid for joint FrancoBritish action to prevent Anschluss of Austria and Germany.

For the first time in many years, F. W. Woolworth Company will use all New York newspapers to advertise the opening of its new sixstory store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street on Thursday, J. E. Vollmer, merchandise manager in charge made known yesterday.

Three printings, totaling 102,500 copies, have been. ordered of Hervey Allen's "Action at Acquila" which will be published on March 7. Meanwhile "Anthony Adverse" has passed the 900,000 mark in America.

Moderate trading in spot hides has developed in the last few days, following a rise of more than 100 points in prices on the futures market, but it was reported yesterday that tanners generally were "sitting on the sidelines" and the buying was largely done by brokers for resale.

The marriage of Miss Betsy Lee Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Adams of Spring Glen, to Nelson H. Dodge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland W. Dodge of Pasadena, took place in the Church of the Redeemer this afternoon.

Although sales of retailers this week increased on some items and were ahead of the week previous by 1 to 5 per cent, estimated volume fell 3 to 6 per cent below the corresponding period a year ago, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

The United Light and Power Company of Chicago and two of its subsidiaries, the United Light and Railways Company and the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, have registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Victories by John Nemeth and Sid Emmer in the last two bouts tonight gave the C. C. N. Y. boxers a 4-4 tie in a match with Villanova. Nemeth beat Bill Piscione in the 175-pound division and Emmer won the decision over Ed Killian in the heavyweight class.

Thin and ill, William Astor Chanler of New York, a-member of the Waldeck Expedition that went into British Guiana in December to search for Paul Redfern, lost American flier, was brought back to Georgetown today and rushed to a hospital.

The provisional commercial agreement between the United States and Chile, which was entered into on Jan. i6, has come into force provisionally as of Feb. 1 and will come into force definitely thirty days after its ratification by the Chilean Congress.
Edward C. Ohl, formerly associated with Slawson Hobbs and with Pease Elliman, Inc., has beer appointed manager of the apartment house division of Spear - Co., Inc.

Miss Charlotte Sharpe Bray; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Genung Bray, was married this afternoon in the home of her parents here to Layton Hall James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther James of Scranton, Pa.

In most respects only 1929 levels surpassed the foreign trade of the Philippine Islands in 1937, and in some particulars even the records of that year were exceeded, according to a consular report from Manila made public today by the Department of Commerce.

For the second consecutive period new bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt securities. The sharp falling off in activity from the preceding week in that field dropped the total new offerings to only $6,361,000, as compared with $40,248,000 in new loans placed on the market last week.

Harvard's superb shooting frown the foul line enabled it to defeat Cornell, 39-37, in a rousing battle for second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight. The Crimson is now tied with Columbia for runner-up honors to Dartmouth.

State Senator Joseph D. Nunan explained the recommendation of the legislative committee on the mortgage moratorium situation, and Mar. Daly, general secretary of the Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., urged the support of a proposal that the constitutional convention create a Department of Commerce for the State of New York, at a luncheon meeting of members of the Queens Chamber of Commerce held yesterday at the Chamber in Bridge Plaza, Long Island City.
Adolf Hitler, in his speech before the Reichstag tomorrow, was expected by Berlin to proclaim a "Monroe Doctrine" for pan-Germany.

Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, German Ambassador to the United States, declared today that extension of Nazi influence in Austria was inspired by the Austrian people themselves and not by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Franz von Papen, retiring Nazi Ambassador to Austria, said today that the farreaching Austro-German accord was but the first step toward a "commonwealth of nations in Middle Europe" under Germany's leadership.

Harry L. Glucksman, for the last nineteen years executive director of the Jewish Welfare Board, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had gone two days previously for observation. He was 48 years old.

Sales Here Off 4 to 5% On the average retail trade here this week maintained about the same pace of activity as featured last week, although the decreases in sales noted by some stores were somewhat sharper.

Substantial progress toward settlement of the strike of maintenance workers at Rockefeller Center was reported by the State Labor Relations Board last night at the close of a four-hour conference with representatives of the Center management and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate.
Conferees representing several civic groups and city departments agreed yesterday to support a local bill standardizing the weight and price of bread sold at retail in the city.

Captained by Stanley McCabe, a team composed principally of cricketers who will represent Australia in England this year, started a match today against an eleven headed by K. E. Rigg, Victoria. Don Bradman, Australian captain, W. A. Brown and C. L. Badcock are not playing.

In an interpretation of its "daylight trading" rule, the committee on business conduct of the New York Stock Exchange has instructed members- that the requirement that forces them to be fully margined at all times applies to each account which they hold, not to their combined accounts.

Testimony of officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad that they had given financial aid to shippers in order to obtain traffic led Senator Wheeler of Montana today to demand stricter regulations of railroad subsidiaries.

Mayor Doris W. Bradway, New Jersey's first woman Mayor, was defeated today in a special recall election in this resort city. Ousted with her was City Commissioner Frederick McMurray, also a Republican.

Fresh from a series of easy victories over the American International Intercollegiate Hockey League teams, Clarkson Tech was tonight held to a 3-to-2 victory by Yale, the winning goal coming well toward the end of the final period.

Like the rest of the State, New York City pays gasoline taxes and license plate fees. Park Commissioner Moses, who makes public today a statement on two pending bills for arterial parkway construction in the metropolitan area, thinks we ought to get some of that money back.

Frank Marinko, 52 years old, of 47-35 Forty-fourth Street, Long Island City, a chef, who turned real estate salesman in 1928 for the Slovak Manor Corporation in its alleged $2,000,000 fraudulent sale of lots at Slovak Manor, L. I., was the principal State witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of ten men, two women and ten corporations for conspiracy.

President Roosevelt, before entraining late in the day for Hyde Park, held a long press conference at which he declared as his goal of economic policies a balanced system of production and therefore increased income and employment.
Out of the mind the waiting warriors come To build the battles of the past again. Who waked upon the hill that frightened drum? Who sounds the horn there in the lonely plain?
Mr. and Mrs. Sargent F. Eaton of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Cook Eaton, to Cuyler H. Shaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Cuyler Shaw,

" God Save the King" will never be accepted by the Afrikaans-speaking people of the Union of South Africa as their national anthem, Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog told a questioner in Parliament today.

Leon Trotsky, exiled former Soviet leader, issued a statement tonight saying he was dubious as to whether his son, Leon Sedoff, had died a natural death in Paris, although he asserted, "I don't have direct data that the death of L. Sedoff is the handiwork of the GPU [meaning the Soviet secret police]."

Headed by Robert Grant 3d, the defending titleholder, and including Robert Lumb of England, a field of fifteen players started in the national amateur racquets championship. yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Baron Bouthon, president of the Salzburg Festival Committee, refused today to credit reports that Arturo Toscanini would not come to Salzburg next Summer.

Jerry Cardi-Nale, 23-year-old ditchdigger of 530 Ninth Avenue, employed as a WPA relief worker, will make his operatic debut Friday evening with the New York Hippodrome Opera Company in the leading tenor role of Alfredo in "Traviata."
The Labor Relations Board ordered the American Manufacturing Company of Brooklyn today to re-employ, with back pay, sixteen employes the board held were discharged for union activity.

More than 100,000 jobless in this State have received more than $1,000,000 in unemployment insurance benefits since the first check was issued on Feb. 1, the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

Bernard Rothenberg of 1,260 East Eighth Street, Brooklyn, was reelected editor-in-chief of Campus, undergraduate student newspaper at City College, and began the new Spring semester with a reorganized staff. The new staff for the Spring semester includes Solomon Kunis,

Finding that the dislodging of a stone from a building was due to a motor car collision which occurred twenty minutes before, the Appellate Division in a three-to-two decision, granted yesterday to Aaron Kuttler of the Bronx claims for $5,000 and $2,500 against the Guardian Casualty Company and the Consolidated Indemnity and Insurance Company, respectively.

The Downtown Athletic Club's Class B squash racquets team scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Harvard Club last night in the play-off match between the winners in Groups I and II of the New York division of the Metropolitan League.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt has sent a letter to the National Conference of Jews and Christians expressing his approval of its aims and ideals in connetcion with the annual Brotherhood Week, which will begin today in synagogues and tomorrow in churches. The President, who is chairman of the anniversory committee. wrote:...

Mr. and Mrs. Olney Blanchard Mairs of the Pierre have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Constance Mairs, to Charles McGhee Baxter Jr. of Cleveland, which took place secretly in Elkton, Md., on Jan. 17. The couple will make their home in Cleveland.
The American Iron and Steel Institute announced that it had filed a brief yesterday with the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington, urging that no tariff concessions be granted on iron

Manhattan College swimmers easily defeated St. Joseph's at the Broadwood pool today, 47-28. Paul Shea of the Jaspers finished first in the 50 and 100 yard freestyle races, beating his team-mate, Cohalan, in the former.

Attorney St, 164, 24.91/2x100; excr will of Angelina de Champlin to John T. Javasile, 1,120 Theriot Ave, Bronx; consideration $1,750. Prince St, n w cor Mulberry St, 25x100; same to same; vacant; consideration $3,250.
Testimony of an asphalt salesman before the State Senate Graft Investigating Committee brought sharp retorts today from Governor Martin L. Davey and the Democratic State Chairman, Francis W. Poulson.
Former President Herbert Hoover today had a long audience with King Leopold. Before visiting the King Mr. Hoover made a short tour of the city and visited a hospital for children in Brussels.
Edouard Anseele, one of the founders of the Belgian Socialist party, died in Ghent this morning at the age of 82. He was Minister of Public Works, 1918-21, and Minister of Railroads, 1925-27.

The citizens of Melbourne will present a collection of Australian books to the United States cruiser Louisville in recognition of the crew's bravery in the recent Sydney disaster. Included in the collection is a rare facsimile of Abel Tasman's Journal.

The bridge Progress was launched with colors flying yesterday morning in Erie Basin, Brooklyn. The structure slid sidewise down the ways at 11:17 o'clock as harbor craft whistled in salute and several hundred spectators sighed with relief.

The practice of gathering of friends and relatives to sing hymns at the homes of dead persons night before burial would be banned in Georgetown under a new municipal law intended to curb night noises.

The tentative Democratic slate for the primary election in Pennsylvania, framed yesterday at Harrisburg, with Charles A. Jones of Pittsburgh designated for Governor and George H. Earle for the Senate, was apparently wrecked today when John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, gave notice that his labor votes would not support such a ticket.
New College of Columbia University scored a 32-to-14 basketball victory over the N. Y. U. girls' team in Thompson gymnasium last night. The winners led, 17 to 8, at half time.

Bronx Park E (16-4424), e s, 100 ft n of Waring Ave. 125x134: Manufacturers Trust Co to Randolph Associates, Inc, 500 5th Ave; mtg $212,500. 221st St, 927 E (16-4692); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Giuseppa C. Frazio, 907 E 221st St.
Three of a group of thirty-four tenements bought recently by the Lewine Realty Corporation have been resold to investors who intend to modernize the properties.
James E. Meyers, won a divorce yesterday from Bernice Meyers after testifying that she neglected him to follow her career as a softball pitcher.
Thousands of city dwellers who like to hunt and fish were present last night at Grand Central Palace for the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show.

The Osservatore Romano, official Vatican organ, today reveals that the Holy See on Feb. 15 sent a memorandum to the Yugoslav Government formally protesting its decision not to submit the concordat to the Senate for ratification.

Canada, Great Britain, Czechoslovakia and Germany tonight entered the final pool of the world amateur hockey championship which an Ontario team known as the Sudbury Wolves is defending for the Dominion.

WITH the New York A. C. Games coming up, the Baxter Mile looks like "one more for the overtaker," the "overtaker being Galloping Glenn Cunningham, who has a habit of giving the other fellows a bit of a headstart and passing them en route. Apparently he has more fun that way.
The House unanimously passed today the four-department appropriation bill which grants $130,099,052 for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments for the next fiscal year.

Following the action taken on Thursday by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation in continuing its quotations for steel for the second quarter of the year, the American Steel and Wire Company announced yesterday in Cleveland, Ohio, that its current prices on rods, wires, wire products and cold rolled strip steel also would be in effect throughout the quarter, with the exception of commodity cold rolled strip. which is reduced $2 a ton.

The Schoonmaker dairy farm, a 100-acre tract near Walkill, N. Y., has been purchased by a client of Stewart Franklin Co., Inc. There is a main dwelling of twelve rooms on the property and a second dwelling of eighteen rooms which will be remodeled by the new owner for the accommodation of boarders.
The Holland-America liner Volendam, sailing today for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam, will have as passengers Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Miss Virginia French, Miss Auriol Lee, Dr. Walter K.
Leroy A. Van Bomel, president of Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., said tonight that the recent State audit of milk dealers' books showed that prices paid to farmers had been "fair."

A report that Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro had been arrested in Warsaw was erroneously credited, in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Thursday, to a Jewish Telegraphic Agency dispatch to the Jewish Morning Journal.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis, three times metropolitan champion, successfully defended her New York Junior League laurels when she defeated Miss Margaret Bostwick, former New York State and metropolitan titleholder,

Miss Marion Miley, medalist from Fort Pierce, Fla., and Lexington, Ky., gained the final of the women's mid-Florida golf tournament today by defeating Miss Frances Owen of Jacksonville, Faa., 6 and 5.
Dr. Irving L. Walker, a psychiatrist, died at his home in suburban Cold Water yesterday at the age of 65. He had been confined to his bed for the last three years.
