Three young "Mayfair men," all of them with rich relations, received heavy sentences and wo of them were ordered flogged by Lord Hewart, Cord- Chief Justice, after they had been found guilty in Old Bailey today of robbery with violence.

The Appellate Division vacated yesterday an order signed by Supreme Court Justice Black restraining the State Liquor Authority from interfering with the business of Gifts By Wire, Inc., or proceeding against any lice??ee because it used the services of the company.

Mrs. Rose Alcorn, 38 years old, of 101-21 Sevrenty-eighth Street, Ozone Park, Queens, who was convicted on Feb. 11 of stealing $500 from Burns Brothers, Inc., at 500 Fifth Avenue, when she was employed as a cashier, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessinns.
Daniel A. Dugan, former judge of this city's Municipal Court, died today at the age of 60. Mr. Dugan had practiced law in Beacon for thirty years.

To understand today's developments in Europe it is necessary to travel down the Danube. A very hurried trip across the Balkans reveals why the internal conflict in Germany turns upon the question of Austria and Czechoslovakia,

Angelo Trulio, the defending champion, advanced to the final round of the New York State fourwall singles handball championship last night at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. by defeating William Phelan of the West Side Y. M. C. A., 21-19, 21-13. Eddie Linz of the New York A. C. kept pace. He subdued Vladimir Kotal of West Side, 21-10, 21-13. Trulio and Linz will meet this afternoon.

The Group Theatre's second production of the season--also Robert Ardrey's second play of same-opens this evening at the Fulton Theatre. It is "Casey Jones," and while its hero is a railroad engineer only his name comes from that great legend of the tracks.
In a brief psychopathic court arraignment before Superior Judge Ben B. Lindsey in. General Hospital, Paul A. Wright was ordered today to appear for a sanitary hearing Monday afternooon.
It cost Chancellor Adolf Hitler's guests at a musical last evening in the Reich chancellery here 1,050,000 marks to attend.

The prospect that several Latin-American countries would soon propose an inter-American military and naval alliance among the American nations for mutual protection against possible European or Asiatic aggression against any country in the western hemisphere was regarded with reserve here today.

With the industry convinced that "Snow White" will be a box-office success, there is a wild search by producers for comparable fantasies. Within the last ten days Samuel Goldwyn has received five offers for L. Frank Baum's "Wizard of Oz," the highest bid being $75,000.
Insurgents reported today a surprise counter-offensive had forced 40,000 government troops to fall back from the mountain positions northeast of Teruel, where they had been massed for an attack.

New picturesque details were added to the American Legion's drive to oust Simon W. Gerson as assistant to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan because he is a Communist when Maurice Stember, State adjutant of the legion, made allegations yesterday of wire tapping and reprisals against city employes who as legion members have protested the appointment.

A powerful Army gymnastic team overwhelmed the Princeton Tigers, 42-12, today in the university gymnasium for its fourth consecutive triumph of the Winter and its first victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

The Appellate Division dismissed yesterday two suits for $250,000 each instituted by Charles Locke, a radio script writer, on the basis of interpolations made by Floyd Gibbons, radio commentator, in the script of an Ohio River flood broadcast.

Joseph Polstein, a retired builder, a former president of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, Manhattan and a director of Yeshiva College, died today of pneumonia in his home at 623 Central Avenue here. He was 73 years old.
Today marked the close of the largest silver fox sale ever held anywhere in the world, conducted by Fromm Brothers. Prices obtained were substantially above those of New York.

Declaring that the front pages of newspapers today are loaded with untruths, William F. O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, yesterday urged advertising men to "use your influence to put across the real story of business."
More than 600 tonight attended the fifth annual Helen Lee Doherty Lace Ball in the Miami Biltmore Country Club to aid the milk fund for undernourished children.

The gross crude oil production of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, last year amounted to 63,563,000 barrels of which its net interest was 50,611,000, or a daily average of 138,660, H. C. Weiss, president, disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting at Houston, Texas, it was reported here.

IT isn't that she is particularly nervous or anything. It is just that she fears she is going to miss those old familiar faces; that Hollywood is probably so different from what it was so manywell, five or six-years ago, and that she herself is almost twice as old as she was then which causes Mitzi Green (aged 17, going on 18) to anticipate her imminent return to a motion-picture career with some misgiving.

Warmth generally speeds up physiological processes. But everybody knows that we are hungrier in cold than in warm weather. Drs. C. Sleeth and E. Van Liere study this anomaly in The American Journal of Physiology.
JUST about a generation ago on a Summer day in 1905-the Belmont family brought with them on board a Fall River Line steamship an automobile with a chauffeur.

Students in Brothers College of Drew University have been contemplating marriage this week, merely from an objective point of view, however, in connection with a student-sponsored course of lectures limited to upperclassmen.

Mayor La Guardia pledged his second administration yesterday to the establishment of a municipal government clothed with a maximum of home-rule power and hampered by a minimum of political judicial interference.

Industrial purchasing executives who expected that President Roosevelt's statement on prices would touch off a buying movement, overdue since Jan. 1, conceded yesterday that the statement will not have an immediate effect upon buying activity. They added, however, that its ultimate effect will be to encourage commitments.

The Manila Tribune said today that an agreement had been reached on the main points of a contract between the Philippine Commonwealth and the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company for development of Philippine oil resources. The paper said the matter would be submitted shortly to the National Assembly.

A large group of patronesses has been enlisted in behalf of a card party to be held the afternoon of March 5 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.
Eight years of pleading the cause of the unemployed middle-aged woman has at last produced some encouraging results for Miss Ollie A. Randall.

WASHINGTON.-About two million persons are engaged in the graphic arts industry throughout the world, producing products valued at $5,000,000,000 annually, the Department of Commerce estimates in a survey of world markets for printing machinery, equipment and supplies.

With signs of rebellion growing against the primary ticket agreed upon by Pennsylvania Democratic leaders Thursday night at Harrisburg, Governor Earle announced his candidacy for the party's nomination for Senator today without waiting for the outcome of further conferences.
Coast Guard headquarters reported today that the cutter Tahoe had reached the disabled American freighter Azalea City about 1,200 miles northeast of Boston and that the vessel was riding easily.

IT was felt by motor truck interests last week that while the decision of the Supreme Court upholding the State of South Carolina in limiting the loaded weight of trucks using its highways to 20,000 pounds and their width to ninety inches would result in hampering certain types of heavy interstate trucking in the Southeast it would eventually bring about a clarification of the whole problem of load and size limits.

Miss Virginia A. Dougherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dougherty of this city, was married to Peter H. Shannon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Shannon of Newark, this afternoon in Blessed Sacrament Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Mahoney.

The verbal battle between Mayor Verman Kimbrough and C. C. McKnight, royal chief of the Tin Can Tourists of the World, Inc., resulted today in the Mayor's challenging Mr. McKnight to a game of marbles.
AUSTRALIA has issued for the first time in her history a crown (five-shilling) coin. It is of silver and on the obverse is shown a profile of King George VI facing left, and on the reverse the crown.

A mysterious person who asked for thirty-five passport application blanks and left a devious trail for their delivery, plunged agents of the State Department and detectives of the Police Department's criminal alien squad into an investigation of a suspected spy ring, it was learned yesterday.

A philosopher, a sculptor and three college students chose the most beautiful Empire Lady at the Beaux Arts Ball at Skidmore College last night. The judges were Dr. Jesse V. Mauzey, Professor of Philosophy; Robert Davidson,

IN the wake of the American Water-color Society annual, the Downtown Gallery is putting on (through March 5) an interesting and in some ways a supplementary exhibition: "American Water-colors and Pastels: 18001938."
Michael Hare, architect, has bought from Arthur Weisenberger the four-story dwelling at 212 East Forty-ninth Street, in the Turtle Bay section, for altering. into a residence and office.

The Ohio Senate investigating committee's ace witness, Lee Bradley, whose testimony linked alleged contributions of utilities and the General Motors Corporation to Governor Martin L. Davey's 1934 campaign, was arrested tonight on a perjury warrant.

THE first part of this puzzling and amusing tale of murder is told by Henry B. Simmons, a rural Connecticut Shylock who owns the first and second mortgages on Jed Ashmead's Surrey Inn, which is the scene of two seemingly irrational killings.

Disapproval of the legislative bill introduced by Senator John J. McNaboe for the establishment of a State Lunacy Authority and local lunacy boards in each of the nine judicial districts is expressed in a memorandum by the committee on criminal courts, law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Sharply delinated lines dividing the forces of the American Federation of Labor from the Committee for Industrial Organization and both from the general public mark Seattle's municipal primary campaign which will end at the polls on Monday.

The marriage of Miss Marie Lesure Arnold of this place and New York, daughter of Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Arnold, to Gerald Davis, son of Mrs. J. Edward Davis of New York and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., took place here at noon today in St. John's Church.

Hope for the re-establishment of business confidence converges more and more upon the prospect of eliminating the undistributed profits tax and the tax upon capital gains from the revenue legislation now being formuated.

SLACKENING a trifle in the week, retail trade for the country probably ran about 6 per cent under a year ago. Lay-offs in industry and adverse weather conditions were given as reasons for the easing. In the New England area, however, volume was reported as running slightly above last year.

The Columbia Lions defeated the Long Island Falcons, 3 to 1, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace in the first round of the New York Amateur Hockey Association playoffs. Kenneth Button tallied for the Lions in 5:35 of the first period.
FORGOTTEN HERO: A blizzard trapped a Colorado school bus one day in March, 1931, and before rescuers arrived the driver and five children
Engineers completed today their 184th inspection "tour" of the nation's power systems-without leaving their laboratory.

There is an "overabundance" of youth in many industries from the standpoint of labor's relations with management because youth has "none of the wisdom and practical common sense" of older persons in their dealings with industry, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared yesterday.

ASTOR-In Old Chicago: Alice Faye, Tyrone Power.* BELMONT-Dawn Over Ireland. CAPITOL-Of Human Hearts: Walter Huston. CENTRAL-Sez O'Reilly to MacNab and Wild Horse Rodeo. CINEMA DE PARIS-Sara Lar Sig Folkvett, Swedish comedy. CONTINENTAL-The Dybbuk, Yiddish drama.* CRITERION-The Girl Was Young: Nova Pilbeam; also The River.*

IT is a century now since Henry Adams was born-"the First Church, Boston State House, Beacon Hill, John Han cock and John Adams, Mount Vernon Street and Quincy, all crowding on ten pounds of unconscious babyhood"-and it is well-nigh a generation since he died. but there is a curious contemporaneity about him.
"The best landlords in the State," Mr. and Mrs. Harry Z. Suchin, were feted tonight by tenants arid former tenants of their apartment house, the Rosalind Gardens, at 1,000 Broadway, here.

The Springfield College basketball team, playing its next-to-last home game of the season, found little difficulty in defeating Williams, 61-31, today. Outstanding players for the Maroon were Nels Phillips and Bruce Munro, both with six field goals.

Named head football coach at Rutgers University to succeed J. Wilder Tasker, Harvey Harman, former Penn coach, came to his new stamping ground today and explained some of his hopes and plans for Scarlet elevens.

The varsity debating team of the College of New Rochelle will uphold the affirmative of the resolution "That a system of socialized medicine should be adopted, making available to all complete medical service at public expense," in an encounter with Manhattan College Monday night on the campus here.

Charles W. Murdock has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Birdella Virginia Murdock, to Dr. David Scott Boyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Boyer of Nashville, N. C. Miss Murdock was graduated from the Weylister School in Milford.
Harvard University today placed on exhibition in Widener Library the first Irish New Testament and many other rare volumes of the Celtic literature of Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

Canada produced 4,090,621 ounces of gold worth $143,171,735 in 1937, an advance of 342,593 ounces valued at $11,990,755 over the 1936 figure, the official compilation by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics shows.

Freddie Steele of Tacoma, Wash., retained his middleweight championship tonight by stopping Carmen Barth after 2:19 of the seventh round of their scheduled fifteenround bout. Barth's followers tossed in the towel after he had been knocked down four times. James J. Braddock, former heavyweight champion, was the referee.
A police recruiting of blood donors among bystanders in Coolidge Square gave a 38-year-old Watertown wife a chance for life today at a Boston hospital.

Another Jewish banking combination, passed into the control of a non-Jewish competitor today when a fusion was announced of the Bleichroeder, Arnhold and Hardy banks. All three operated in the same field but the Hardy bank is non-Jewish.
Yale's swimming team won six of the nine events to beat Cornell, 45-30, in the first meet ever held between the two teams.

John J. Breslin Jr., Prosecutor of Bergen County, asserted today on the first anniversary of the slaying of R. Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader, in front of his home in Teaneck, that the investigation still was alive.

The marriage of Miss Paula Elizabeth Farrelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Valentine Farrelly of this city, to William Wilson Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allston J. Morris of Upper Montclair, N. J., took place here this morning at the home of the bride's parents.
THE B. B. C. and the Royal Philharmonic Society have sponsored the most impor tant novelties produced here since the beginning of the new year.

Senator La Follette criticized the government's relief policy today as "an attempt to bail out this ocean with a tin dipper." He advocated the establishment of an agency for centralized administration of public employment, not as an emergency office, but as a regular arm of the government.

WITH its arresting title, "Tragic Painters," the current exhibition at the Bignou Gallery opens up wide interrogative vistas and uncovers wells of a prodigious depth, full of echoes that answer back: "Enigma."

Richard Whiting, a writer of popular songs for a quarter of a century, died in his home here today after an illness of nearly a year. He was 46 years old. Born in Peoria, Ill., he came to Los Angeles as a boy and began his career as a piano player in Nat Goodwin's Cafe in Santa Monica. Later he was in vaudeville with Marshall Neilan, who became a film director.

The engagement of Miss Mary Ann Evans, daughter of Mrs. J. T. Evans of Kingston and the late Mr. Evans, to Alan Bruce Cutting, also of Kingston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Cutting of Westfield, N. Y., has been announced. The wedding will take place in the early Summer.

Miss Elizabeth Frances Maddox, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustavus Maddox, was married to Brian Miller Benson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carville D. Benson, this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here by the Rev. S. Thorne Sparkman, the rector.

A fear that Switzerland, along with other small nations of Central Europe, will be drawn under German influence in the political manoeuvres now going on on the Continent, was expressed here yesterday by exporters who specialize in Swiss trade.

The address of the Mayor before the City Affairs Committee yesterday follows: After that very forceful introduction, it is rather difficult for a timid person like myself to speak. Dr. Holmes has very graphically divided the period of good governments. He says he looks forward to the future.

MARKED deference is shown to denizens of the bird world by the great ocean greyhounds that slow down off Gaspe Peninsula, Quebec, to give passengers a view of the seabird sanctuary crowning Perce Rock.

Six children tumbled happily over each other on the worn linoleum floor in the kitchen of their coldwater flat near Bellevue Hospital yesterday, unaware that they were exhibit A of the housekeeper service, a welfare activity recently taken over by the Children's Aid Society from the New York City. Junior League.

Belief that the Mexican Government failed to better its financial position and its exchange balance by prohibitive tariffs is supported by the weekly statement of the Bank of Mexico, which shows metallic reserves are unchanged.

When Mayor Rossi of San Francisco decided to send a walnut tree to Mayor La Guardia of New York to replace a walnut tree which grew a century ago on Manhattan Island he sought the oldest walnut orchard in California.

THE UNVANQUISHED" presents Mr. Faulkner in his most communicative mood. He tells. fairly simply and directly. a story of the Sartoris family during the latter days of the Civil War and early days of Reconstruction;
"Fraternity Trends Today" is the topic for a panel discussion arranged for the monthly supper meeting of the New York City Panhellenic at the Beekman Tower Hotel tomorrow. Mrs. Ralph L.

TILIO, very small, very black, was a native of the deep woods in the north of New Guinea, and, when the story opens, was happily engaged in being as much like his father as a 3-year-old can imitate the man who, because of his strength and cunning, was chief of the Savia.

Columbia University graduate students from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut do not fare as well in their studies as those who come to Columbia from greater distances, according to Dr. George B. Pegram, dean of the Faculties of Political Science, Philosophy and Pure Science, in his annual report to President Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

Non-instructional staff members of the municipal colleges will petition the Board of Higher Education tomorrow for establishment of a five-day work week. The petitions, which have been circulated in Brooklyn, Hunter and City College, are to be presented to Dr. Mark Eisner, chairman of the board.

The quest of government officials and bankers for some avenue through which permanent capital may be supplied to the small business man and minor industries must proceed despite the resumption of lending by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was said in Wall Street yesterday.
The Most Rev. Paul Yu-pin, first Roman Catholic Bishop of Nanking, China, today declared his country "has enough men to resist Japan for twenty years."

Miss Helen A. Turrell, daughter of John C. Turrell of 10 Gracie Square and the late Mrs. Turrell, was married yesterday afternoon in a-private suite of the Vanderbilt to Richard M. Denne, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Denne, also of this city.

Miss Jean Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Martin of Crestwood, was married to Joseph T. West Jr., tonight in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, Crestwood, by the pastor, the Rev. Walter J. Benedict.

Floor coverings buyers who departed from the wholesale market here the first week in January announcing that they would place commitments for Spring goods early in February are still out of the market, mill sales executives complained yesterday.

BARON-Professor and Mrs. Salo W., announce birth of a daughter, Feb. 13, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospltal. BERNSTEIN-Dr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Bernstein (Carol Silverman) announce the birth of a son. Sunday. Feb. 13.

Acting Chairman Jeremiah D. Maguire of the Interstate Sanitation Commission has requested New York's new City Planning Commission to put the $150,000,000 pollution elimination program in New York Harbor on its "must" program.

Today Argentina inaugurates Roberto M. Ortiz as President for a sixyear term. Though pledged only, in the pre-electoral campaign, to carry on the policies of his predecessor-General Agustin P. Justo-Dr. Ortiz commands the respect and confidence of his countrymen on his own record.
Mrs. Max Kops of 440 Park Avenue and Riverdale-on-Hudson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Kops, to Rudolph Wisbrun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Wisbrun of El Paso, Texas.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lipman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Lipman, to Harry David Haber, son of Municipal Court Justice and Mrs. Isidore I. Haber of this city.

The Davis Library of the Phillips Exeter Academy has just received the manuscript materials of two more modern novels, Booth Tarkington's "Harlequin, and Columbine" and Robert Nathan's "The Enchanted Voyage." The gifts were added to its collection of original materials for teaching.

The P. M. C. polo team downed Princeton, 13-8, in a game that was deadlocked seven times at the 103d Cavalry- Armory tonight. Bob Eisner, Princeton No. 3 player, starred for the Tigers. He not only scored seven of their eight goals, but frustrated many P. M. C. threats.

State sovereignty is dead, but its diminished ghost is raised occasionally in Washington. Which is sovereign in the potato field, Maine or Idaho? In the Senate or the House restaurant, juries of Congressmen sit with full mouths on this great question.

Fritzl Scheff, musical comedy star at the turn of the century, will give her reminiscences of the stage and sing a brief program of songs at a dinner tonight of the Drama League of New York, to be held at the Hotel Pierre.

Fliers and mountain climbers who ascend to great heights find it hard to focus their attention and to make decisions. At 12,250 feet the efficienoy of concentration is reduced by only 10 per etnt, at 20,000 feet by 40 per cent.

A lapse of twenty-four years apparently has increased and not dimmed interest in varsity show production at Rutgers University, tryouts for roles this week indicated. More than three hundred students applied for parts for "Free, White and 21,"

Ellsworth Vines, the tennis professional who would skip two meals for a game of golf, has his heart set on a United States Walker Cup golf team berth. Vines, an entrant in the $5,000 Crescent City open golf tournament, confessed he would "give almost anything to be on that Walker Cup team some day."

The zoning of some areas in the city strictly for private, singlefamily dwellings will be considered by the City Planning Commission at a special public hearing at 10:30 A. M. Wednesday in City Hall, A. A. Berle Jr., chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.
The national amateur baseball federation re-elected O. L. Fawley of Fort Wayne, Ind., president today and awarded the 1938 championship tournament to Pittsburgh.

This Spring there will be a new answer to the old question of how to have a wealth of continuous bloom in the perennial borders after the big early Summer display ol delphinium, Madonna lilies, foxgloves and many other colorful plants die down.

In the final round of the women's competition in the Princess Hotel's thirty-fourth annual tennis tournament today Miss Gladys Hutchings, Bermuda champion, easily defeated Miss Mary Butterfield of Bermuda, 6--1, 6--4, before a gallery of local and American spectators.
A plea for America to take the leadership in revitalizing the democracies of the world by taking a firm stand against Fascist,

EVERY one wants to know what every one else is thinking these days. "Finger on the public pulse"-surveys, fact-finding commissions, forums of every kind and inquiring reporters and "vox pop"-it is the newest science.

The Holland-America Line announced yesterday the appointment of Captain Jan Pieter Wepster as master of the passenger liner Volendam. Captain Wepster was in command of the ship when she sailed yesterday for Rotterdam, it being his second visit to New York in eighteen years.

ELEBRATIONS of the centenary of Henry Irving's birth have greatly occupied us during the present week, and on the day itself, Feb. 6, everyone of importance in the theatre will spend a part of their Sunday morning in church, attending a memorial service. The power of his legend is extraordinary.

Succumbing to injuries received last night as he started across Oil City's busiest intersection in a heavy rain, William Kennedy Borland, 68, Republican leader in Venango County politics for many years, died today in Oil City Hospital.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George A. Walton of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Pusey Walton, to Dr. C. Douglas Darling, son of Mrs. C. D. Darling of Philadelphia.

Earl Robertson handed the Toronto Maple Leafs their first shutout of the National Hockey League season tenight, leading the New York Americans to a 4-0 victory over the International group leaders. Robertson was brilliant.
The Interstate Commerce Commission fixed valuations today for three pipe line companies. The appraisals, for property owned and used for common carrier purposes as of Dec. 31, 1934, are:
ONE hundred years ago, in 1838, New York City celebrated the arrival of the Sirius, the first steamship (British) to cross the Atlantic from east to west.

Alumni of the New York University College of Medicine will pay tribute to the late Dean John Wyckoff on Tuesday With the largest reunion in the history of the institution and at the same time start a campaign for a John Wyckoff Memorial Fellowship Fund.

The first annual North Carolina Garden Club tour will be held April 9 to 23 under the sponsorship of the Garden Club of North Carolina and various local garden clubs.* * * In the following week, April 25 to 30, Virginia will hold its annual Garden Week and ninth annual tour, proceeds from which are to be used for the restoration of some publicly owned garden or historic grounds in Virginia.

Three facts have emerged from the negotiations that for about a week have been under way between the Anarcho-Syndicalists' labor union, the C. N. T., and the Socialists' labor union, the U. G. T., for a common working basis that will in a sense mean unity between these two ancient enemies.

THE study and care of animals play a large part in the pro gram of the Boy Scouts. As a result Scouts have become pet owners and conservers of wild life. And some of them, in later life, have turned from a boyish interest to the scientific pursuit of animal study as a life work.

Two girls and a boy were killed near Mooresburg today when they were thrown out of a car that overturned after hitting a telegraph pole. They were Bessie Ruth, aged 12; Dorothy Jane, 10, and Walter Lloyd Jr., 8, children of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lloyd Bomboy of 207 South Front Street, Milton, Pa.

The possibility of constructing parking spaces under City Fall Park are being studied by the City Hall Park Association in connection with new police restrictions against parking on ten downtown streets.
Tuesday will have dual significance on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College here, being both Washington's Birthday and Parents Day for the girl students.

Mortimer Rubenstein of 246 Harrison Street, Paterson, has won the A. Harry Moore Scholarship given by the John Marshall College of Law, it was announced this week by the dean, Dr. Alexander F. Ormsby.

Before the Duke and Duchess chose the Chateau de la Maye, a modern structure of indifferent Louis XIII style surrounded by a mag?? been expected they would settle down in one of the fine historical chateaux that abound in the vicinity of Paris.
The St. Joseph's women's basketball team easily defeated the New York University quintet 14 to 9 on the courts of the Brooklyn College yesterday.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 16, which included only five business days in many of the reporting centers, aggregated $7,066,000,000 or 10 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 20 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days in many of the reporting centers.

Pouring it on in the last lap, the peerless Glenn Cunningham unfurled man's second fastest indoor mile last night. The master workman from the Corn Belt won the Baxter Mile at the New York A. C. games in Madison Square Garden in the sensational time of 4:08.6.

The marriage of Miss Mary Gene Larson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand C. Larson of Glen Ridge, to C. Ellison Harkrader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Harkrader of Maplewood, took place this evening in Glen Ridge Congregational Church.

TOREADOR: Mr. Ernest C. Riedel, an American wintering in Bermuda, found himself cast last week in the unfamiliar role of a bull-fighter. At midnight he discovered that his bungalow was being charged by a bull. Both Mr. and Mrs. Riedel sallied forth with brooms instead of espadas, only soon to retreat.
A complete change in the wheat situation in the United States has taken place within the last year, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

The Stuyvesant High basket team captured its first league gas yesterday when it defeated Haar 33 to 26, on the Stuyvesant court a Lower Manhattan Division P. A. L. contest. The winners we ahead at the half, 16 to 15.

Two groups of "little fellows," both springing from President Roosevelt's recent conference with small business men, were organizing forces today with a view to greater expression of their opinions on business and government.

Tribute will be paid to one of the leaders of the Negro race Feb. 23, when Atlanta University and the affiliated colleges, Morehouse and Spelman, will join with friends and associates throughout the nation in celebrating the seventieth birthday of Dr.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Aided by the Chemical Foundation and the Department of Agriculture, Dr. E. F. Hopkins, assistant professor in the New York State College of Agriculture, has developed at Laurel, Miss., a process which will make it possible to dry fleshy vegetables more effectively than ever before and to store them indefinitely.

Plans for the expansion of passenger service between New York and Irish ports were announced yesterday by the Cunard White Star and French lines. Officials of both lines said that the volume of travel developed by ships already operating to Ireland warranted the addition of tonnage.

Noting a considerable difference of opinion between buyers and "figure executives" as to the most efficient purchasing policy at this time, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.,

Jose and Amparo Iturbi, pianists, and Fritz Reiner and Dr. Walter Damrosch, both conducting the NBC Symphony Orchestra, will participate in a concert to be given Thursday evening at the Center Theatre, in connection with a meeting in which health and welfare work in New York will be discussed.
The Carnival de Venise, fourth in the series of dinner dances at the Surf Club, was held tonight. Decorations depicted a carnival on the Grand Canal.

A Constabulary patrol shot to death one of eight fugitive convicts today but failed to prevent the flight of the other seven. The patrol, part of 400 Philippine soldiers ordered into the hunt when ten men escaped

Rutgers crushed Springfield's swimmers, 57 to 13, before a junior prom week-end crowd of 1,000 today, taking eight of the nine events. Jimmy Rawstrom was the only winner for Springfield. He took the 440-yard free style race in 5:14.3.
Longer and longer, blacker and blacker grows the shadow that the fascist dictatorships are throwing on the green English countryside.

James A. Farrell, retired president of the United States Steel Corporation, received the gold medal of the American Irish Historical Society last night at the forty-first annual dinner of the organization in the Hotel Astor.

WITH several warnings ringing in their ears, broadcasters from all parts of the country have returned home from the National Association of Broadcasters' sixteenth annual convention held during the past week in Washington.

Several suggestions for improving the' East Bronx area are presented in a letter sent recently by the United Civic Associations of the Bronx to Lawrence Orton, a member of the City Planning Commission.
On Tuesday George and Martha will celebrate their fiftieth wedding anniversary. The George and Martha will not, however, be George Washington and Martha Dandridge Custis, but George and Martha Sohl.
In a greenhouse in Washington Dr. Earl S. Johnston of the Smithsonian Institution experiments with colored light to find out whether one color is any better for growth than another.
Donald R. Richberg, former NRA administrator, told Washington and Lee students today that the lawyer of tomorrow must help to solve "two outstanding problems," of national welfare.

A series of vocational talks to be given on Wednesdays at 1 P. M. at the 2 Park Avenue Building of Hunter College will be started by the Bureau of Occupations this week. For ten years the bureau at Hunter has been actively developing fields of employment other than teaching for college women.
Wondering whether coffee has any influence on skin affections, Dr. W. Fahlbusch began a series of interesting experiments which he describes in the Dermatologische Wochenschrift.

Where are good places to fish and hunt? What accommodations can one find for vacations, near streams or lakes? The attempt by resorts, camps and States to supply information of special use to the angler and hunter resulted last year in the distribution of more than a million pieces of reading matter at the National Sportsmen's Show.

The names of those who will receive the sportsmanship awards of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association is being kept a deep secret until tomorrow, and the actual awards will not be given out until Wednesday night, when the association will hold its annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore.
The assets of two closed national banks will.be sold at auction next month by Joseph P. Day, William A. White Sons and Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., auctioneers and agents.
The C. C. N. Y. basketball team defeated St. John's tonight, 26 to 18, the visitors making one of their lowest scores of the season.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Gertrude Alexander, widow, 115 Central Park West, residue. S. R. Weltz, 75 Central Park West, executor. BRADFORD, WILLIAM HENRY (Dec. 31). Estate, more than $10,000. To George D. Bradford, son, executor, Darien, Conn., three-fourths residue; Gerald Bradford, son, Jersey, England, life estate in one-fourth residue; Beatrice Wadleigh Rolfe, Cannes, France, life estate in S15.000 trust.

An- English, half-timbered residence, with twenty-six acres on the Duck Pond Road, Mattinecock, L. I., part of what is known as one of the "show" places of the North Shore, .has been purchased by William Simpson of Syosset.

WINE OF CHOICE-Tomorrow evening at the Guild Theatre. S. N. Behrman's new play, which has been out practicing through a couple of versions and a couple of months. Leslie Banks, Claudia Morgan, Alexander Woollcott, Donald Cook, Theodore Newton, Herbert Yost, John Maroney and Paul Stewart are in .the acting company.

New Yorkers are going back to the farm in increased numbers. Statistics published today by the State Agricultural Department revealed 782,000 persons on New York farms Feb. 1, an increase of 2,000 over a year ago.

The track season will hit a climax on Saturday when the pick of America's athletic army gathers at Madison Square Garden for the fiftieth national championships of the Amateur Athletic Union. Every star performer of the season to date will compete along with a few choice newcomers to the local scene.

This city is watching with intense interest a new experiment in industrial relations-a series of public meetings between a committee representing the city's wealthiest employers and committees from the Labor Council of the American Federation of Labor and the Industrial Council of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The first break among the leaders in the women's championship tournament for the Hazel Allen Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club occurred yesterday when Mrs. Edna Harrison won a difficult and closely fought game from Mrs. Mathilda Harmath, previously undefeated.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 18: MAJOR GENERAL Conley, E. T.. the adjutant general, three days leave, Feb. 23.

Increased business in the building materials field during 1938 is expected by more than two-thirds of the 835 dealers in such products who recently' filled in questioniaires on the subject at thirteen housing clinics conducted by the Johns-Manville concern in as many cities.

Members of Mary Murray Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, gave their annual reception yesterday afternoon in the Mary Murray Room of the Hotel White. Mrs. Clarence N. Titterington is Regent of the chapter.

Mr. and Mrs. John Clark Sims of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary R. Sims, to James Browning Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Browning Miles of Brookline, Mass.
FROM Los Angeles, where there are said to be more dancers employed (or trying to be) and in more different lines of activity than any place else in the country,

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Indians, Puritans, French voyageurs Spanish and English settlers, belles and beaux of the Revolutionary and Civil War periods, Gibson girls and other picturesque folk of the past in America will dance in the Orange Gardens on Wednesday night at the All-American Ball of the Everglades Club.

Evidence of heightened undergraduate interest in public affairs was brought to light on the Princeton University campus this week with the announcement by the American Whig and Cliosophic Societies of the most ambitious debating program undertaken at old Nassau in recent years.
A camera for photographing licenses of speeding automobiles at night was brought forward today by the Pennsylvania motor police as a new weapon in he war on highway accidents.
RICHARD W. PALMER, designer of the plane in which Howard Hughes set a world speed record, has recently been appointed chief engineer of the Vultee Aircraft Company of Downey, Calif.
This chief center of European Winter sports was newly linked with the outside world today when a non-stop air flight brought the Engadine Valley within four hours of London.

Blair Academy entrenched itself deeper in first place in the Eastern Private Schools League by defeating the Trinity five today, 33 to 25. Bob Beck, right forward, led the winners with 12 points as Jim Kelleher tallied 7. Young, with 7 points, led Trinity, which trailed 15 to 10 at half time.

Women who occupy unique positions In government will furnish a substantial part of the program which the International Federation of Business and Professional Women will sponsor on Friday in a world-wide observance of "International Night."

In a fast and thrilling game Army beat Colgate on the basketball court today, 45 to 42. The upstaters flashed a speedy and hard-fighting aggregation which more than once threatened disaster to the Cadets and left the capacity crowd of 2,500 spectators breathless.
A "blood bank," which has been in operation at the Philadelphia General Hospital less than four months, has been used in more than 400 blood-transfusion cases,
Against a background of diplomatic disaster abroad and dissension at home, the spotlight has turned again this week upon the elegantly tailored figure of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary.

The Edward M. Morgan Foundation of the New York Postoffice, Inc., an organization supported by contributions of postal employes and conducted for the benefit of postal employes who need hospital service, expended $35,808 last year in providing 10,652 days of hospital care for 640 patients, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman, president of the foundation.

The making of final revision of the oldage provisions of the Social Security Act was postponed at the close of a two-day meeting today by the Social Security Advisory Council in favor of a more extended study, but the "expectation" was that "substantial recommendations" would be made before the end of this year.

Frank R. Curda, cashier of the City National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, will be chief guest at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking on next Saturday.

It is a sign that the Winter fruit season is in full swing when strawberries from Florida begin to sell for as little as two pints for 25 cents. During the past week baskets of them have flooded the market, and although they require a little more sugar for flavoring than Summer berries demand, their quality is good.
Continuing undefeated, the girls' basketball team of Savage School yesterday defeated the St. John's girls of Brooklyn, 48 to 11, in the winners' gymnasium.

A telegram protesting the declaration by Commissioner William Hodson of an extra holiday tomorrow for employes of the Department of Public Welfare was sent to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by the Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars.

ABRAMS--Ada, wife of the late Abraham Abrams, beloved mother of William, Max, Nettie E. Wiley, Sue Shafer, Ray Brookov, Celia Ruppert, Fannie Goldstein, Minerva Burrows, Louis, Leo and Martha. Funeral from home, 175 West 93d St., Sunday, 1 P. M. Interment Mount Neboh Cemetery, Cypress Hills, L. I., N. Y Kindly omit flowers.

Opposition to the pending bills for creation of a Department of Fine Arts has been announced by the National Federation of Music Clubs following a conference of the president, Mrs. Vincent H. Ober, with Mrs. Edgar Stillman Kelley, chairman of legislation.

Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's American-owned Kellsboro Jack, winner of the Grand National Steeplechase in 1933, today ran second to Sir Warden Chilcott's Dunhill Castle in the Newbury Handicap Steeplechase.

WASHINGTON-Lowell J. Chaw ner, senior economic analyst of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, estimates that 5,000,000 more families of moderate income could buy minimum-priced houses if the financing were put on a 41/2 per cent interest basis, with amortization over thirty years.

Last November Boston elected Maurice J. Tobin, young, able and ambitious, to a four-year term as Mayor at a salary of $20,000. He ran on an economy platform. He declared the Boston tax, rate to be "the highest of any metropolitan city in the United States," with heavy overvaluations and thousands of abatement cases pending.
A slight easing-off in wholesale market activity was noted last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.
Manhattan College gained its second victory in two days by defeating Temple University at the Owls' pool, 38-36, today. The Jaspers triumphed over St. Joseph's yesterday.
A special exhibition of the art work prepared by pupils of the High School of Music and Art will be shown at the Raymond Raymond Galleries, 40 East Fifty-second Street, starting Thursday morning.

War Admiral, greatest son of Man o'War, ran and won like the champion he is before 25,000 persons, Hialeah Park's greatest crowd, today. At the end of seven furlongs the brown colt was being eased by Charley Kurtsinger as he finished

The girls' basketball teams of New College and Rhode Island State played a 26-26 tie in Thomp son Gymnasium yesterday. Under girls' rules no overtime periods are allowed, so no attempt was made to break the deadlock.

Syracuse University's circulating library plan for living centers, modeled after commercial circulating libraries and intended to stimulate recreational reading, received added impetus this week with completion of plans for placing circulating libraries ih cottages for freshman women.

Dr. Francis C. Edgerton, a surgeon who had been a member of the staff of St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx, since 1908, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital following a brief illness from pneumonia. He was 64 years old.

How old is the earth? There are about forty ways of arriving at the answer. For the most part the answers do not agree. The best method of estimating the earth's age seems to be that of measuring the radioactivity of rocks.

Applications for family relief at New York Catholic Charities have increased steadily since 1933, despite governmental relief, social insurance and other forms of taxsupported social work, according to a preliminary report for 1937 made public yesterday by the Rev. John J. Donovan, director of the division of families.

The Dramatic Association of the College of Saint Elizabeth, here, will present "Joan of Arc" in Xavier Auditorium Friday evening and Saturday afternoon. The title role will be taken by Miss Mary Hinderer of Philadelphia, a sophomore, who made her dramatic debut at Saint Elizabeth's as Charlotte Lucas in last year's production of "Pride and Prejudice."

The rape of Austria, as Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg has privately described last Saturday's Berchtesgaden meeting, according to a diplomatic representative here, must be unique in the world's history.

The Stevens Tech quintet overpowered a strong Hamilton team in an overtime game at Castle Point by 39-35 tonight. Stevens led, 13-12, at the half and Stevens held the lead until Carmer's basket tied the score at 30-30 with eighteen seconds to play.

ONE reason, possibly, for this book's extraordinary lack of the kind of bias which blinds judgment, warps thought and shrouds in misleading fog the true implications of events is the fact that its author hails from Australia.

The inauguration of Roberto M. Ortiz as the twenty-first constitutional President of the Argentine Republic tomorrow afternoon will be accompanied by the greatest demonstration of United States progress in military aviation that has ever been staged in any foreign country.

Extending informal faculty efforts to give individual instruction to freshmen, Harvard has now extended the tutorial system to include some of the first-year men who desire this work in the second half of the academic year.
The annual entertainment for the benefit of the Authors' League Fund will be held next Sunday afternoon in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center.
Bentford's 15-week hold on the top rung of the English Football League ladder ended today when the Griffin Park squad bowed, 3-2, to Derby County before a home crowd.

One and two family dwellings and multi-family buildings with total accommodations for 211,265 families were erected last year in the urban areas of the United States, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and announced yesterday by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

Political observers on the side lines are watching with keen interest the Democratic situation which has developed in Indiana, along with the home-comingthis week of Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines.

Each of the following Reserve Officers is ordered to active duty, effective Feb. 27, at Ft. Hamilton, N. Y., for training: Capt. Pierre Lomet Jr., Inf.-Res. (311 Infantry), 555 West Lincoln Ave., Oakhurst, N. J. 2d Lt. Jesse B. Halprin, Inf.-Res. (37th Infantry) (R.A.I.), 809 Murray St., Elizabeth. N. J.

A benefit luncheon and a fashion show to be known as "Fashions for the Dance Style Revue" will be held on March 8 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. A percentage of the proceeds will be donated to the Stage Relief Fund.

The following results are from a nation-wide sampling referendum conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion for leading United States newspapers on the issue, if the question of national prohibition should come up again, would you vote to make the country dry?
Representative O'Connell of Montana asked President Roosevelt today to relieve Dr. Francis E. Townsend from serving a thirty-day jail term for contempt of the House.

More than 300 couples will attend the annual senior ball of Hunter College tomorrow night at the RitzCarlton Hotel. Among the guests of honor will be Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, and Mrs. Colligan; Dean Hannah M.

THE annual dollar turn-over in the used-car business in the United States is greater than that of food and clothing or the combined jewelry and furniture business, W. E. Holler, general sales manager of Chevrolet Motor Division of General Motors, declared last week.

Statistics just compiled by the National Resources Committee indicate that, as a result of the population trend from country districts to the cities, the urban population in 1960 will approximate 82,400,000. In 1930 the urban population was estimated to be slightly less than 70,000,000.

Hooked Rugs. Handicraft Center, 369 East 62d Street. Antique and modem hand-made examples. Also modem Swedish hand-made rugs. Old Wallpapers. American Woman's Association, 353 West 57th Street, until Feb. 28. Work of leading French designers of the early nineteenth century.

The Foreign Office tonight announced the conclusion of a new trade agreement with Japan. The agreement, supplementing the last accord signed in 1911, was accomplished by an exchange of letters between the Japanese Ambassador and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos.

Commissionhouse buying of wheat futures developed today on the Board of Trade on an early decline of 3/4 cent a bushel and absorbed the surplus in the pit and finally brought about a rally of 1 1/2 cents from the inside figures, with the close at net gains of 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel.
STROUDSBURG, Pa.-Lack of snow has caused the postpone ment of the seventh annual Pocono Mountain sled-dog derby, which was scheduled for Feb. 15, 16 and 17.

A jury of .ten men and two women condemned Harry and Henry Dingledine, father and son, and Harry Chapman to tne electric chair today for the slaying, September a 3, of Patrolman Martin Randolph C and Deputy Sheriff Edward Furry.

SOUTH AMERICA on the radio map is like a bullseye on a target. Short-waved projec tiles propelled by words embellished by music are being shot across the South Atlantic as propaganda and as entertainment to woo listeners in lands south of the Equator.

It is at the end of a momentous week which has witnessed a thrust of Nazi power into Central Europe that Hitler delivers today his long-advertised address to the German Reichstag. It is predicted in Berlin that "pan-Germanism," or "German racialism," will form the keynote of his speech.

Summarizing the attitude of other national organizations of women toward the spending program adopted by the General Federation of Women's Clubs at a board meeting a month ago, Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson, president, described it yesterday as "sympathetic."
Following Friday's setback of $1 a bale under active profit-taking operations, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied again yesterday to end with gains of 10 to 13 points.

AS has been noted, Columbia is everready to introduce a fresh name to its lists. Between regular issues of Petris and Giesekings, lesser known and younger pianists are frequently given a chance. So also it is with violinists who come and go the while Joseph Szigeti sails serenely on.

Ciro Terranova, police character who achieved notoriety as the "artichoke king" and as a "big-shot" racketeer during the period preceding the various investigations conducted by Samuel Seabury, died at 12:30 o'clock this morning in Columbus Hospital.

The Agricultural Adjustment Act, the third important bill to be enacted by the Roosevelt Administration in its effort to aid agriculture generally, which became a law on Wednesday when it was signed by the President,

Effective city planning must have the cooperation of all civic Iand neighborhood associations inIterested in such work, declares b Arthur C. Holden of the New York i chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

In the exhibition hall of Mechanics Building in Boston tomorrow and Tuesday there will be benched 1,306 of the country's canine stars, who will comprise the competitors In the twenty-sixth annual all-breed show of the Eastern Dog Club.

To augment its scholarship fund, the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre has taken over the performance of "Save Me the Waltz" for the night of March 1 at the Martin Beck Theatre. It will be the annual benefit for the school, and Mrs. Reginald de Koven is serving as honorary chairman of the committee.

Leroy Lewis of the University of Pennsylvania today won the intercollegiate squash racquets tournament by defeating Vernon Ridder of Princeton in a hard-fought fivegame final, 13-15, 11-15, 15-10, 15-11, 17-16. Ridder lost the final match in the intercollegiates last year to Dawson of Harvard by exactly the same score.
Mrs. E. Davies's search for her daughter was ended today after twenty years of hoping and worry. The London mother learned that the girl for whom she sought had been dead nineteen years.

Miss Sarah Norwood Ross, daughter of Mrs. John Henley Ross of Termon Rook, Madison, and the late Mr. Ross, was married here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church to Herbert St. John Webb Jr., son of Mrs. Herbert St. John Webb of Montclair, and the late Mr. Webb.
Miss Mabel Anne Maesing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Maesing of this city, was married this afternoon to Joseph H. Fikentscher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fikentscher, also of Nutley.
Theree German Army planes landed on Netherland territory today, the pilots pleading they had lost their direction in the fog.

BAUMBLATT-ROSENTHAL-Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rosenthal, Burlington, Vt., announce the marriage of their daughter, Bette Evelyn, on Sunday, Feb. 13, to Mr. Mortimer Baumblatt son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Baumblatt, Larchmont, N. Y.

Joe Louis will write another unique chapter in boxing history in the ring of Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. The Detroit Bomber will make his second defense of the world heavyweight crown in a fifteen-round bout against Nathan Mann, New Haven's young contender.

Another gala ice carnival is in prospect for ice-skating enthusiasts. On the nights of March 23, 25, 26 and 28 the annual International Skating Carnival will run its course at Madison Square Garden as a benefit for the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, the Carroll Club and the Carroll Vacation Camp--beneficiaries of the ice show last year.

Edward Rogers, the defending champion, lost his first match to Sol Traeger of Brooklyn, 125 to 112, as the national amateur pocket billiard title tournament got under way yesterday at the Strand Academy. Traeger won in twenty-three innings and had a high run of 35, while Rogers, who hails from Glen Cove, L. I., turned in a string of 34.
Six workmen, on the job only a week, put finishing touches today on an experimental all-steel, prefabricated house in suburban Clairton.

With the squad augmented by the presence of Hank Leiber and spurred into action by a wintry blast, the Giants' expeditionary forces received their first taste of air-conditioning in the Ozarks today as Colonel Bill Terry led his squad on a five-mile hire through the mountains.

A Catholic mass, attended by General Chu Teh, commander of the Communist Eighth Route Army, and many other famous Eighth Route Army leaders, whose kidnapping of foreign Christian missionaries was a matter of Chinese Communist party policy to get funds for many years, was described as one of the highlights of a visit to Shansi Province by three Americans upon their return here this week.

A dance was given by Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees, headmistress of Rosemary. Hall School, Greenwich, for Rosemary students over 16 years old in the school tonight. Several students from Yale, Princeton, Dartmouth, Williams and other colleges were invited guests.

Witn the statement that "wages and hours legislation is the only immediate possible salvation of the (silk and rayon) industry from bankruptcy," the New Jersey joint board of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. has appealed to President Roosevelt for "drastic action to wake Congress from its sound sleep."

Miss Anna Lomauro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Lomauro of this city, was married this afternoon to Leonard Buys, also of Passaic, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Buys.
THE people of this city on the hilly shores of Puget Sound will go to the polls tomorrow to decide a Mayoralty election of national significance.

Ten women and a man, who told the police they had been playing poker, were held up by three unmasked bandits yesterday afternoon in the apartment of Mrs. Anna Berg at 3,031 Brighton Fourteenth Street, in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, and robbed of $400 in cash and jewelry valued at $3,000.
Dr. and Mrs. William E. Ladd of Milton, Mass., their daughters, Miss Katharine Ladd and Mrs. Alvah Crocker 3d of Fitchburg, Mass., are at the Ritz-Carlton.
Prince Serge Obolensky was slightly injured in an automobile accident shortly before noon yesterday when his car and another collided on the Seventy - ninth Street transverse road in Central Park.

Professor H. B. Walker, head of the agricultural engineering division of the University of California, sees the labor problem as the greatest cause for a growing interest of farmers in machinery to do their work.
Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming gave an explanation today of the bill sponsored by himself and Senator Borah of Idaho for Federal licensing and regulation of corporations.

At home all day alone" was what George Washington, a gentleman farmer, traced in his diary on the night of Feb. 22, 1773. Not until the last year of his Presidency did his diary mention a celebration of his birthday.
The glee clubs of the Katharine Gibbs School and Princeton University will give their annual joint concert on Friday on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A faint glimmer has appeared on the Arctic horizon. It is the first sign of the sun. A generation ago the four Soviet scientists on their floe would have given it the symbolic meaning of a rainbow in the sky. Dawn and hope. In these more materialistic days that pearly glow marks only the coming of day after long months of dreary night.
Lawrenceville's interscholastic polo champions overwhelmed a highly touted Essex Troop team tday, 21-10.
New courses added to the curriculum at Massachusetts State College included the study of the elements of photography in the Physics Department and three courses in political science.

THE Savoy Ballroom is no place for those who wear long underwear. If it's for mal cheek-to-cheekin' and a dainty little dip on the downbeat which is one's idea of paying tribute to Terpsichore, Harlem's unique institution at 140th Street and Lenox Avenue may very well seem beyond the pale.
The Spring conference of the savings division of the American Bankers Association will be held on March 3 and 4 in the Hotel Roosevelt, Henry S. Sherman, president, announced yesterday.

A novel rushing plan, adopted this year at Jackson College, the department for Women at Tufts, weathered its first major test with the completion of the rushing period and the issuance yesterday of about eighty bids to undergraduates.
Mrs. Pearl Duke Bachman, widow of Senator Nathan Lynn Bachman of Tennessee, died at a hospital here today after a long illness. Her age was 60.

LONDON. - Fogs over London have always had a romantic implication for fiction purposes, but never for the every-day life of Londoners. The dark pall which falls over the city has been a scourge to be borne patiently.

The Williams College hockey team downed the R. P. I. varsity, 2-0, tonight in a game that had to be shortened in the last period because of soft ice. George Oldham scored early in the game and the other goal was made by Bill Spurrier on Johnny Jay's pass.

THAT "planned economy" which is more or less forcibly fed to whole nations by politicians today is, of course, nothing new. It was accepted doctrine and approved procedurein the domestic sphere-with the eighteenth-century worthies who set this country up in business and, without neglecting public affairs, made their private fortunes a personal and studied concern.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Oakes of Bloomfield, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Juliet Guion Oakes, to John S. Eells Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Eells of Ross, Calif.

Miss Carolyn Louise Hunt, daughter of Mrs. Stanley B. Hunt of Flemington, and Thomas R. Disbrow, son of Councilman and Mrs. William L. Disbrow of Caldwell, were married this afternoon at the bride's home.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Howson of Wayne have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Howson, to Charles D. McKendrick of Baltimore.

ANOTHER deluge of postal paper has arrived from Spain, with both the Loyalists and the Rebels contributing. Which items will eventually be recognized for chronicling in the American standard catalogue remains to be determined.

Community Youth Service, New York State Federation of Young Folks Temple League, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, 11 A. M. "Charting Our Course With Religion," Dr. Nathan Stern. Luncheon at 12:30 P. M. Afternoon session, 2:30 P. M. "Our Security-Is It Threatened?" Rabbi J. X. Cohen, Dr. Ludwig Lore, Professor James V. Thompson.

Completing plans for Spring sales promotion drives last week, most manufacturers of nationally advertised products aimed at keeping volume within 10 per cent of their Spring, 1937, total, although a number confidently predicted increases, according to a survey of important companies.
The National Bureau of Standards has started -perhaps the most sporting scientific research of its history, the Department of Commerce announced today.
AT the beginning of the Victorian era in London people walked. One's own foot power offered the "most usual method of locomotion."

In a wide open game which produced ten goals and many thrills for the crowd of 1,500, the University of Toronto defeated the Harvard hockey team by 7-3 today, in an International Intercollegiate League game.

Among the thousands who are thronging the floors of the Palace this week are many who are seriously preparing for the opening of the season on trout and salmon, only two months off. These anglers are not interested in the guns or salt water tackle displays, but concentrate their attention on the exhibits of flies and trout and salmon rods.

Members of the children's theatre department of the Newark Junior League will give a benefit performance of "Sleeping Beauty" Friday afternoon at Elliot Street School here. Special guests will be children from the Newark Orphanage, Home for the Friendless and Protestant Foster Home.
WITH the proper apologies and within reasonable limits, it is suggested that Alexander Pope's famous line should be temporarily amended to read: "The proper study of Mankind is Mann."

What is regarded as the first comprehensive effort for direct consumer representation in the Federal Government since the days of the Consumers Advisory Board of the NRA will get under way this week when a plan for such representation will be urged upon President Roosevelt and members of Congress by a delegation of twenty-five representatives of consumer organizations, acting under the auspices of the National Consumers Federation.
At 11 years of age Harry Heckman weighs 263 pounds, is 5 feet 2 and does a full man's work on his father's farm. The Heckman boy lives on nearby Heckman Island.
Hi-Bey, owned by Crispin Oglebay of Gates Mills, Ohio, was adjudged the best horse of the fourth annual Virginians' Horse Show, conducted under sunny skies at the J. North Fletcher stables today.

New York University's basketball team finally met defeat on its home court when Villanova stopped the Violets, 30 to 27, at the University Heights gymnasium last night. It marked the first defeat ever suffered by N. Y. U. at the uptown gymnasium after the Violets had run up a string of forty-seven straight home victories.

Mrs. Marion Berford Allen Ludin, a daughter of the late Rear Admiral Louis J. Allen, U.S.N., was found dead of a heart attack today in her home here when her sister, Mrs. Duncan B. Harrison, came to visit her. Mrs. Ludin was 70 years old.

W. D. Hoag of the Yale Club yesterday advanced to the semi-final round of the national veterans' squash tennis championship when he defeated G. W. Cobb Jr., a Harvard Club rival, 15-1, 15-10, on the Princeton Club courts. The Harvard Club. City Athletic Club and Columbia University Club also put players into the semi-final brackets. 0. C. Stanton,' Harvard Club, defeated P. C. Markman,

PLANS for a national superhighway system, reaching into every part of the coun try and connecting with the proposed Pan-American Highway penetrating the Latin-American countries, have received such impetus in recent weeks that national planners are now focusing their attention on the project.

RUTLAND, Vt.-Ski enthusiasts who are looking for new slopes to conquer will try atleast one week-end this Winter at Rutland, Vt., New England's latest skiing center, where they may run the new Sunset Schuss Trail laid out on Pico Peak by Charles N. Proctor.

Recovering from a staggering right-hand punch to the jaw, Ossie Stewart, Pittsburgh middleweight, last night stopped Eddie Maguire of Johannesburg, South Africa, in the first round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at Rockland Palace.

A benefit luncheon and fashion show will be held on March 24 at the Park Lane under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary of Stony Wold Sanatorium. Mrs. Irving Smith will give a tea on Thursday at the same hotel for members of her committee to discuss plans for the event.

Youth problems, "good neighbor" relationships in the Americas and educational goals for the Federal Government are among the topics to be considered at the sixty-eighth annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators here from next Saturday through March 3, according to an announcement today by Charles B. Glenn, president of the association. More than 12,000 educators are expected to attend.

Paintings from the collections of Mrs. William Platt, James Lynde and other owners, as well as from the estate of Eben J. Knowlton will be sold at auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries on Thursday evening.

Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Biological Survey, has issued a warning to waterfowl shooters that great care must be exercised in regulation of shooting now and in the future in order that sportsmen may be assured of game.

Both Chilean and Argentine commissions of engineers will simultaneously plan to build highways up the sides of the Andes going up to Uspallata Pass, it was decided today at a meeting confirming the conclusions of a recent conference here between the chiefs of departments of both countries.
Clyde Troutt's 3-year-old filly, Novelette, won serious consideration as a contender for the Louisiana Derby by taking the mile and a sixteenth New Orleans Handicap today at the Fair Grounds.
The fourteenth annual supper dance of the Alumnae Association of Georgian Court College, Lakewood, N. J., will be held here in the Garden Terrace of the Hotel Ambassador next Friday evening.
PINEHURST, N. C.-A large field of golfers is expected to participate in the thirty-fourth annual anniversary, tournament of the Tin Whistle Club to be held on Wednesday.
A tract of twenty-eight acres adjoining the Somerset Hills Country Club at Bernardsville, N. J., has been purchased for home development by Robert W. Gutleber from Dudley Olcott.

Champion Blakeen Jung Frau, striking white standard poodle owned by the Blakecn Kennels of Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N. Y., tonight was awarded the title of best in show at the nineteenth annual all-breed fixture of the Elm City Kennel Club.

The operation of the Social Security Act and proposed modifications of the measure will be considered at a conference on Wednesday at 8:30 P. M. called by the public affairs committee of the American Woman's Association at the clubhouse.

Director of Public Safety William S. Cuthbert announced this week that a mounted patrolman would be assigned to the beach because of complaints that attendants at horse rental stands were abusing balky steeds.

Financial collapse of the Chiang Kai-shek regime in China is now a matter of time, according to a private cablegram received in New York from the head office of the South Manchuria Railway Company in Dairen, Manchukuo.

The Mexican Government has signed a contract with D. A. Thomas of Vancouver by which he has sold a tanker load of crude oil to Harrison, Ltd., of London, coal and oil brokers, at a price said to be 92 to 95 cents a barrel, according to reliable quarters.

Dismissal of the injunction suit brought by the C. I. O., several affiliated groups and the American Civil Liberties Union against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, the Board of City Commissioners and Police Chief Harry Walsh was asked today in Federal Court here.

The change in operatic taste is in no way more surely indicated than by the fact that the Metropolitan Opera House, once dubbed the "Faustspielhaus," just got around last night to Gounod's masterpiece at the tail-end of its season's twelfth week.

C. B. Van Dusen will retire as president of the S. S. Kresge Company at the annual meeting of stockholders on April 22, but may continue as a director, it was learned yesterday. R. R. Williams, vice president in charge of merchandising, is expected to succeed to the presidency.

John Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. Mario Pansa and Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Legendre entertained with a dinner tonight at Villa Marina. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Burden, Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Gates, Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Pond Ordway, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Barry, Mrs. Jean Cochran Atwell, Milton Holden, Robert Sweeny Jr. and Lytle Hull.

Several persons have called and written us concerning the highpressure magazine salesmen at the Sportsmen's Show last year, and a number of them seem to have been taken in by the same salesman. Before we go into this matter let it be understood that we have no fault to find with the exposition management on this score, and we believe they are doing everything possible to prevent such salesmen from operating.

Fully conscious of the fact that all eyes are riveted on Germany today as at no time since the fateful days of 1914, Chancellor Hitler tonight is putting the finishing touches on the speech he will deliver before the Reichstag and an anxious world tomorrow afternoon.

Forty-six hundred trade unionists and members of the Workers Alliance marched through the raindrenched streets in the City Hall and financial districts yesterday, demanding 100,000 new WPA jobs here and a 40 per cent increase in home relief allowances.

THE forty-fifth annual May festival of the University of Michigan will be held May 11-14 at Ann Arbor. Six concerts are scheduled, at each of which the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, will perform.

The trustees of Town Hall and a special dinner committee are arranging a dinner to be given atthe Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 28 for Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist and a director of the Bank of England, and Lady Stamp, who are expected to arrive here Saturday en route to England from a visit to Australia. A "major mystery" of Union College will be cleared up during the Founders Day Convocation next Friday when alumni, joined by radio over the world, will learn who Dirck Romeyn was and what he did.

Dartmouth's athletes gave another remarkable demonstration of allaround skiing technique in successfully defending their Intercollegiate Ski Union team championship as the annual two-day competition ended today in ideal weather.

Squadron A and the New York A. C. recorded triumphs at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night to remain tied for third place in the senior division of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League. Each is credited with four victories and three reversals.

THIS week will be a busy one for the "King's English." The National Puzzlers League, meeting in Cincinnati for its semi-annual convention and bee, will labor to make sense out of the scrambled-word riddles its members have been originating during periods of heavy concentration.

Yale came close to upsetting Cornell's favored track team in their fourteenth annual indoor meet tonight, but lost the final event, the onemile relay, after pulling up to a 54-54 tie. Cornell took the meet by 59-54.

In order that the vulnerability of battleships to aerial attack may be presented by experts of the navy as well as by experts from civil life, the House Committee on Naval Affairs decided today to postpone final action on the Administration's $1,000,000,000 naval construction program until Friday of next week.
The first chapter of Phi Beta Kappa to be established here will be installed at the George Washington University on Tuesday, during the Winter convocation of the university.
RECENT reductions in prices of steel have given rise to rumors that new passenger car prices soon will be lowered to pass these savings on to the buyer.

In a raid on what the police described as the biggest policy game since the days of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, the racketeer, plainclothes men arrested seven men and seven women, all Negroes, shortly after 7 o'clock last night in a five-room flat at 42 West 138th Street, in the heart of Harlem, and seized 500,000 policy slips.

Mooney, Mrs. Joseph B. Long, Mrs. Henry Colwell Beadleston, Mrs. Charles Blount, Mrs. Theodore Lucas and Mrs. Bradish Johnson Carroll.

Passenger revenues of 141 Class railroads amounted to $442,809,306 in 1937, against $412,365,686 in 1936, an increase of 7.4 per cent, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday. Freight revenues were $3,377,908,423,

NEW YORK, as the saying goes, is not what it once was. A perusal of this nostalgic book, a large part of which pictures the lurid life of the city during the middle years of the nineteenth century, will make the reader thank his lucky stars.

The West Point officers encountered little difficulty tonight in defeating the Essex Troop trio, 15 to 9. Captain H. W. Johnson scored seven goals to pace the officers, while Charles Hodge tallied four times for the Essex Troop.

American and other foreign missionaries here are "up in arms" owing to the refusal of Japanese military authorities to grant them permission to return to their homes, stations, schools and hospitals in the area between Shanghai and Nanking.
Secretary Perkins appointed a committee representing industry, labor and the public today to confer here Wednesday and Thursday on ways to discourage discrimination against older workers.

Thomas H. Reed, director of the Consultant Service of the National Municipal League, is the author of "Twenty Years of Government in Essex County, New Jersey," just published in New York by the D. Appleton-Century Company.

With many of the guests attending in Western costumes, a Wild West Dinner Dance will be given on Thursday in La Salle Tropicale of Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.

Again acting without financial asdistance from the Westchester County Recreation Commission, choral singers and music patrons in Westchester and Southern Connecticut perfected arrangements today for the fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival, to be presented at the County Center here on the evenings of May 13, 20 and 21.

Joseph W. Catharine of Brooklyn, president of. the National Association of Real Estate Boards, and Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president, left New York yesterday for Florida and other points in the South on a tour in the interest of the association.

King Boris ordered today the retirement of nine generals, including the commandant of the Sofia district, and of twelve colonels and two other officers. This latest clean-up of what are termed political elements in the army gives the King a freer hand in personally controlling the army and the Dolice.
TS. ELIOT'S "Murder in the Cathedral" has a history so unlike that of any other play of our time that it must be worth recording.
The background of the Spanish situation will be discussed tomorrow at 10 A. M. at a meeting of the Contemporary Club of White Plains by Albert C. F. Westphal.

Playing an impressive brand of basketball throughout the entire game, the Manhattan five last night defeated spirited Seton Hall, 46-34, in the Jasper gymnasium. A crowd of 1,000 witnessed this annual contest between the interstate rivals.
Spring costumes will be displayed in conjunction with a luncheon for the benefit of the -Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which will take place March 1 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.
