In the early days of water gardening in this country pools were unduly artificial in appearance. They were usually perfectly round or perfectly rectangular in shape, and the curbs around the edges projected above ground to accent their outlines. All this has charged In recent years.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rollin Brewster Sanford of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Sanford, to Arthur Clements Twitchell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Twitchell of New York and Westhampton, L. I., formerly of Scranton, Pa.

Mr. and Mrs. Shelby T. Harbison of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Harbison's daughter, Miss Nancy Dyer, to William Don?on Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Perry Edwards of San Jose, Calif.

"The Passion Play," produced by Holy Family Roman Catholic Church here, will be presented Sunday afternoon, March 13, as a benefit for the Philippine missions of the Jesuits. It will be held in the church auditorium.

GOLF in America is celebrating a golden anniversary this month. It is just fifty years since a little group of Yonkers men tried out John Reid's gift clubs from Scotland in a cow pasture across the street from Reid's home and launched what was to become the "Old Apple Tree Gang" and St. Andrew's Golf Club.

The New Jersey FHA has just arranged to insure its first 90 per cent twenty-five year mortgage under the amended and liberalized program sanctioning 10 per cent down paymentson homes, Thomas E. Colleton, director of the FHA in- that. State, announced yesterday.
Union Temple's basketball team scored its fifteenth victory last night, defeating Brooklyn College, 47 to 38, at Union Temple, Brooklyn. Taking a lead of 11--0 early, the home team led throughout.

An effort to attract' $1,000,000,000 of private funds into home construction and financing got under way today when Stewart McDonald, the Federal Housing Administrator signed a charter authorizing creation of a National Mortgage Association.

THE complete string quartets of Beethoven will be performed in a series of five concerts by the Budapest String Quartet, March 26, 27 and 31, and April 2 and 3,-at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A. Each program will contain a quartet from each of the three periods into which the composer's output generally is divided. The series already is more than half subscribed.

President Roosevelt is planning a White House conference next week on what he regards as one of the major problems confronting his administration-the plight of the nation's railroads. This is in anticipation of an early decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the railroads' application for a horizontal freight rate increase.

Started as a promotion of advertised food products by super-markets of the country, "National Brands Week," which opens Thursday and continues to Mar. 5, has expanded into the largest joint promotion ever attempted on behalf of nationally known food products, officials of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., reported yesterday.

The liberalizing provisions of the National Housing Act will result in the construction of many lowcost homes throughout Long Island, states Cadman H. Frederick, president of the Suffolk County Federal Savings and Loan Association and Mayor of Babylon. He points out that developers throughout the island are making plans for expansion of their building programs.

Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, gave an informal address last night to a group of Amherst College undergraduates and faculty members of Amherst and Massachusetts State Colleges on "Science and the Journalist."
The Steel Workers Organizing Committee announced tonight negotiations for a new collective bargaining contract with the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation probably would begin Monday.
The dollar continued yesterday its upward climb in terms of the principal foreign currencies, but trading was light. The pound sterling again fell, declining 7-16 cent to $5.0113-16.

Harry Cooper, golf's mechanical man, bored a four-under-par 68 through high winds today to lead his field by three shots in the opening round of the $5,000 Crescent City Open tournament.
Albert F. Eckel, Syracuse attorney, died last night following a stroke suffered while trying a case at the court house Thursday. His age was 62.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the executive committee of the 1938 Citizens' Appeal for the Salvation Army, announced yesterday that Mrs. Douglas L. Elliman had accepted the chairmanship of the women's committee of the drive. The appeal will be for $600,000 to carry on the Army's work in New York during the next year.
Seated in his dental chair, Dr. Peter Segal, 60 years old, was found dead of gas poisoning at 9 o'clock last night in his office on the twelfth floor at 33 West Forty-second Street.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.--Up to the beginning of the new year, nearly 20,000 visitors to St. Petersburg had taken the trouble to register in the books of the Chamber of Commerce kept for that purpose.
HAMILTON, Bermuda. -The week will see play start in the island's principal golfing tournament of the year, the Fifth Annual Mid-Ocean Tournament on the Mid-Ocean Golf Club course.

Trailing the Columbia five by a score of 25-22 at the end of the first half, the Harvard varsity basketball team came back refreshed in the second session to hold the New York sharpshooters in check and win an Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight by a score of 36-31. Harvard's victory enabled it to break a second-place tie with the Lions.

Amherst tightened its grip on the Little Three basketball series honors tonight by defeating Wesleyan, 44 to 35. It was the second victory of the year over the Cardinals. Amherst led throughout. At halftime the score was 25 to 18.

The Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra, a unit of the Federal Music Project, will give a concert at the County Center here on Monday evening. Presented under the auspices of the WPA, the concert will be free to the public.

MOTOR cars on country roads, hikers passing through woods of oak, beech and ash, have been converging in crowds on the tiny village of Speen in Buckinghamshire, one of England's loveliest counties, ever since Miss Ishbel MacDonald, daughter of the late Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald, bought and renovated the picturesque Plough Inn, built in 1621.

The Board of Tax Appeals entered into a stipulation with Jack Benny, radio comedian, today for payment of $4,500 out of $7,756 originally claimed by the government as deficiency income. taxes for 1934.

George W. Bermas, for twenty years superintendent of Postoffice Station K, Brooklyn, and in the postal service for forty-six years, died on Friday night at his home, 1,114 Fifty-eighth Street, at the age of 64.

In a race marred by a spill on the last turn. Jerome H. Louchheim's odds-on Favorite, Pompoon, won the $5,000 added San Carlos Handicap today in a select field of candidates for the coming Santa Anita Handicap.

A positive statement on the government's foreign policy is being sought by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedorn in advance of the State meeting to be held Friday at New York headquarters, 150 Fifth Avenue. All branches of the league have responded to the request from the executivee officers that Congress been be urged to obtain definite information on what course the Federal Government will take in pending matters of international concern.

There is a real "kick" to be had from growing one's own vegetable plants for extra early crops. But that is by no means the only advantage to be derived. Just the varieties that are wanted can be produced; and that is seldom the case when ready-grown plants are purchased.

HENRY OF NAVARRE, in sculptured effigy on his own "New Bridge" in Paris. held the mob's respect through the revolution. although the statue of every other King of France was toppled wrathfully from its pedestal.

The Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, announces that Professor Emil Brunner of the University of Zurich, Switzerland, a noted theologian, has accepted an invitation to come here as guest Professor of Systematic Theology for the academic year 1938-39.

DURING 1937 the British Broadcasting Corporation's stations sent out 1,213 S O S messages, which means that on an average of more than three times daily it was urgently necessary to get in touch with one person or a little group of persons, out of the 40,000,000 inhabitants of the British Isles.

"Waiting for Lefty" long has been firmly established as the most considerable work in the repertory of British workers' drama groups, whose growth, indeed, it has helped promote, but not until now has a full length play by Clifford Odets been given professionally here.
Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were without marked price trend yesterday as trading interest was small and the volume fell to the smallest amount since Sept. 4, 1937.

Yic Ronchetti, husky young Chicagoan, led the point standing for the men's senior title in the na'tional ice skating tournament today with a victory in the feature mile race and two second places. Ranchetti, who recently won the North American men's title at Saranac Lake, N. Y.,

Harvard's swimming team continued its undefeated pace today by defeating Dartmouth, 53-22, and lowering four Spaulding pool records. By winning, the Crimson remained in a tie with Princeton for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
Appointment of nineteen new policemen, bringing this city's entire force to 293 men. was announced here today by Denis Morrissey, Safety Commissioner.

A collection of children's schoolbooks published before 1900, whose contents, with few exceptions, are as subtle as an evangelist hitting the sawdust trail, are now on view at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. "From the latter part of the seventeenth century throughout the ?ighteenth," said a museum official, "literature of this sort was with few exceptions of an extremely re?igious nature.

Maurie M. Milligan's confirmation by the Senate as United States District Attorney at Kansas City ends for the moment a lively political episode in Missouri which, however, may have far-reaching effect in forthcoming elections.

Buermeyer 500--Won by James B. Herbert, N. Y. U.; Douglas Raymond, Boston University, second; Richard M. Gill, Boston College, third: Howard Borck, Manhattan College, fourth. Time-0:58.1. Matt Halpin Half Mile-Won by Charles Beetham, New York Curb Exchange A. A.; Ross Bush, University of Southern California, second: Louis P. Burns, Manhattan College, third. Time--:54.6.

The Adirondack outdoor speed skating championships were post poned late today after workers had struggled for two hours to clear off slush and water covering the Mirror Lake rink. With the temperature dropping tonight and colder weather forecast, officials said they hoped to stage the meet Sunday

Miss Madeline W. Smith, president of the Woman's Advisory Board of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, has assembled a large group of patronesses for the ninth annual Spring bridge party for the benefit of the blind under the care of the association.
Measures to promote highway safety will be inproduced next week by Assemblyman Middleton of New York and Senator Desmond of Newburgh, Republicans.

The United States Power Squadrons are attempting to settle by a mail canvass of their several thousand members the old argument whether the squadrons' ensign should be flown from the stern staff or from a halyard to the starboard arm of the military mast on cruisers.

Seeing New York from Harlem to Chinatown and from the night courts to the police academy will constitute the field work of a new course "designed to acquaint New Yorkers with the vital social forces molding the destiny of their cidty."
Joseph Krock, father of Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YoRK TIMES, died here last night after an illness of six months. He had lived in San Diego since 1930.

FOR the centenary of Cosima Wagner this past Christmas one might reasonably have expected a real unvarnished, un-Bowderlized biography of the mistress of Bayreuth. Such a labor ought to be a tempting job for an alert and unbiased historian.

A ground-breaking ceremony held indoors will start the General State Authority's $5,000,000 building program at the Pennsylvania State College next Saturday. The exercises will be held in Recreation Hall, which seats more than 6,000 persons, instead of at the sites of the ten major buildings to be added to the fifty structures on the campus.

IT begins to look as if the season of 1938-39 will be a tenor years That is to say, it will be a year in which new tenors and perhaps an old hero will return to the local scene, thus creating fresh interest in a type of voice that has languished relatively in recent seasons.
The President's signature on the new farm bill was a signal to the Corn Belt to suspend argument for the time being and submit the presumptions on which it was based to the test of experience.
Mrs. Thomas Adrian Fransioll Jr. of Edgehill, The Plains, Va., has announced to friends here the engagement of her niece, Miss Anne Vans-Agnew of London, to Robert Nigel Carew Hunt, also of London.

Before city school systems expend large sums in increasing artificial light in classrooms, the whole matter of the desirable amount of light to conserve children's eyesight should be investigated by a committee including ophthalmologists, physicians, physicists and educators, rather than lighting engineers alone, national school building experts agreed yesterday.
Growing dissatisfaction among conservative peasants in rebel territory, coupled with passive resistance and industrial sabotage by townfolk and workers,

Stocks improved and closed generally higher in smallest two-hour session since Oct. 2; turnover, 295,950 shares. All groups of bonds steady, and mixed in dullest Saturday trading since Sept. 4; transactions, $2,554,500.
A READER whose mind is full of bright imaginings and whose leisure permits rare speculations will be delighted with "The Crescent and the Rose."

Sportsmen and outdoor enthusiasts will go hunting tomorrow at the National Sportsmen's Showwith cameras. The popularity of the candid camera has made itself felt once more and tomorrow the Grand Central Palace is expected to take on a different atmosphere

Picturing the "school of tomorrow" as no longer centered around the 3 R's but as a definite part of the community life, leading city educators attending the annual conference of the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association yesterday outlined the teachers' function in the future school system.

A description of improvements provided for communities throughout the nation by the Works Progress Administration is given in a report issued today by Aubrey Williams, Acting Administrator, covering the two years of its operation.

Reporting many inquiries from foreign traders on the effect of the action of marine underwriters in modifying war risk insurance clauses, the Merchants Association of New York, in a statement issued yesterday, declared the consensus of underwriters, shippers and banks "appears to be that,

THE election of Joseph M. Schenk, chairman of the board of Twentieth Century-Fox, to the presidency of the Association of Motion Picture Producers (the Hays office) is interpreted by many of the informed citizenry as an attempt to solidify the industry in some attitude concerning the artists' agents.

The organization meeting to revive the American Fair Trade League by proponents of resale price maintenance, originally scheduled for Feb. 28 at the Hotel Astor, has been postponed until April 4, William H. Ingersoll of Ingersoll Norvell, and one of the sponsors of the movement, said yesterday.
Secretary Wallace created today a Federal crop insurance corporation to offer wheat growers insurance of $100,000,000 against losses from droughts, floods, hailstorms and insects.

WITH the awarding of two contracts, totaling $759,472, on Feb. 10, rapid progress is being made on the construction of the westerly, or Bronx, approach td the Triborough Bridge. Following the building of numerous bridges and underpasses, as well as the grading of land, the concrete pavement will be laid and landscaping done.

Comfortably lodged in third place in the International Group of the National Hockey League, the New York Americans will seek to strengthen their position tonight when they oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.

Low back pains caused by a hypertrophy or general increase in the size of ligaments connecting the vertebrae of the spinal column are much more prevalent than is commonly believed by members of the medical profession, according to Dr. H. A. Brown, assistant clinical professor of surgery at the University of California Medical School.

General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter American Red Cross, reported that $16,140 in contributions had been received for relief of suffering civilians in China. More than $2,000 was received following President Roosevelt's recent appeal.

Flood waters and freak winds continued to harass the Central South today, leaving more than a score dead and thousands homeless. In Arkansas, a major flood threatened as rampaging rivers and their tributaries rose swiftly in the wake of torrential rains.
Dr. John Edgar Coover, Emeritus Professor of Psychology of Stanford University, died today after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

The controversy surrounding the National Labor Relations Board is reflected in several bills before the New Jersey Legislature, three of which would create a State Labor Relations Commission similar to the Federal board, while a fourth,

What this country needs, four well-known men. decided yesterday, is an intelligent, energetic, dignified, and above all singable new national anthem. No bombs bursting in air, they decided, and no sectionalism (and no high C's) are wanted.

China's hopes for an ultimate victory in her life-and-death struggle with Japan are based on the weaknesses of Japan's economic and financial structure, which may not be able to withstand the strain of war for any length of time.

Mrs. Myron C. Wick Jr. is chairman of a committee arranging for a children's fashion show to be held Wednesday afternoon at the Saks Fifth Avenue Greenwich (Conn.) shop. A percentage of the sales during the day will be donated to the Mothers Milk Station of the Greenwich Committee for Maternal Health, Inc.

Trading on the Stock Exchange last week produced the smallest total for a full week since the week ended on June 26. The turnover was only 3,317,000 shares. As a matter of fact, there have been ten million-share days thus far this year,

Class 1, Jumpers (juniors 17 and under)First, Mrs. Gordon Wright's ch. g. Tupelo; second, Mrs. Helen Kees' ch. g. Comador; third, Archie Dean's Kitt; fourth, Saxon Woods Hunt Club's gr. g. Little. Flight.

THE name of Gustav Stresemann stands for'the shortlived "golden age" of the German Republic. As the Reich's Minister of Foreign Affairs from the end of 1923 until his death, in October, 1929, he saw his country reclaim its place as a world power.

Colonel Stephen O. Fuqua, former Chief of Infantry of the army and now United States military attache in Spain, who has been ordered to duty at Governors Island, effective July 29, is well known in New York, where he served in command of the Sixteenth Infantry.

Every kind of sophistry is being used by the French press to disguise the fact, which is admitted privately, that Chancellor Hitler's imposition of a Nazi Ministry on the Austrian Government is due, in the first instance, to the weakness of the French Government on March 7, 1936, when it permitted Reich troops to reoccupy the Rhineland.

In one of the season's finest displays of sustained hitting and exemplary racquet work, J. Richard Leonard of Tuxedo defeated Reginald Fincke Jr. of New York yesterday to gain the semi-finals of the national amateur racquets championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Frederick McQ. Falck of Chestnut Hill has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Catherine Falck, to J. Nevin Schroder Jr., son of Mrs. J. Nevin Schroder of Old Top Farm near Lancaster,
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Cutler-Hammer, Inc.

ALMOUR--BASEL-Rabbi and Mrs. Alexander Basel of 260 East 197th St., New York, announce the engagement of their daughter, Naomi Judith. to Dr. Henry Almour of 27 West 72d St., son of Mrs. Julia Almour.

LTIGHT, open-web joists may be economically utilized in apartment construction under the new Building Code now in effect here. The steel members are light enough to be installed without the aid of hoisting machinery.
The volume of trading on the New York Wool Top Exchange last week was the heaviest for such a period snice the market was opened in 1931, and prices made broad advances.

Biweekly faculty-student roundtable-discussion conferences were Started this week at Williams College under the auspices of the Williams Liberal Club and the undergraduate chapter of the American Student Union.
Forty independent labor union delegates met in a national convention today to perfect an organization opposed to the A. F. of L., the C. I. 0. and the National Labor Relations Board.

Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will talk at a meeting on Friday to which representatives of local women's organizations have been invited by the New York Women's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference.
More than thirty prominent women, headed by Mrs. Roosevelt, will be guests of the Women's National Press Club at its annual Stunt Party Dinner March 5 at the Willard Hotel.
The La Guardia Transit Bill, introduced in the Legislature this week, brought once more to Capitol Hill the vexatious problem of what to do, if anything, about New York City's transportation picture.

Burleigh E. Jacobs, 18-year-old high school graduate of Wauwatosa, Wis., won the eleventh renewal of the national championship of golf club champions by defeating Frank Strafaci of Great Neck, L. I., in a thrilling extra-hole final on St. Augustine links today, 1 up.

In an effort to resolve the tangle of conflicting bills before Congress for the regulation of civil aeronautics, Chairman Lea of the House Interstate Commerce Committee announced today that he would precent a composite draft of various bills to a subcommittee in a few days.

The marriage of Miss Maxwell Phillips Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dudley, formerly of Richmond, Va., to Jesse Thornhill Davidson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davidson of Bedford, Va., took place here this evening in Wilson Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church.

A report on the education of the Dionne quintuplets and its implications for child care and education will feature the twentieth national conference of the Progressive Education Association which opens at the Hotel Pennsylvania Wednesday morning.

W. H. Tilman, leader of the 1938 British Mount Everest Expedition, has arrived in India with E. E. Shipton. Other members are en route, and the party will assemble shortly at Kalimpong, preparatory to marching up through Sikkim to the site of their base camp, which will probably be established toward the middle of April.

THE sixteenth annual exhibition of the "Fifty Books of the Year," sponsored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, attests the outstanding fact that the day of revolutionary typographic experimentation is over for the time being.

Although they are convinced that prices named for Fall lines of dry goods are low, both in relation to mill costs and as compared with those of a year ago, wholesalers generally have determined upon a cautious buying policy and there is little hope of aggressive forward covering, buying office executives said yesterday.

JANET GAYNOR'S next will be "The Young in Heart." I. A. R. Wylie is the author and the story is due to be serialized soon in a national magazine under the title "The Gay Banditti." When the story was purchased two weeks ago it was rumored as a likely item for Fredric March.

State Reservation police reported that Niagara Falls and the fallen Honeymoon Bridge were bringing thousands of tourists here tonight for one of the busiest weekends this resort city has had in several years.

THE subject-matter of books Printed in the fifteenth century is being explored to such an extent that long before the monumental Gesamtkatalog will have finished with the 40,000 editions awaiting recognition the interested public should have a fairly comprehensive idea of their nature.

To the Drama editor: Time is kind to our memories, particularly of things long past; and while it does not necessarily tric us into remembering what never existed, it undeniably tends to drape all irritating commonplaces in a rosy veil of illusion.

Earnings of the Midland Steel Products Company increased 7.4 per cent in 1937, according to a report issued yesterday, despite a sharp decline in plant operations in the last two months of the year due to the falling off in general business.

Thirty members of Teachers Union, Local 5, headed by Charles J. Hendley, president, left a letter at City Hall yesterday urging Mayor La Guardia to stop the Board of Education's "wave of retrenchments," which they said was continuing the evil of overcrowding.

A group of fire and casualty insurance companies are organizing to protect their interests in the Erie Railroad's bankruptcy, C. Shelby Carter of 52 Broadway, adviser in corporate reorganizations, announced yesterday.

Under the supervision of Dr. Wallace W. Atwood Jr., Professor in the Clark University Graduate School of Geography, work has been resumed on the construction of the world's largest relief map of the United States, which will be housed in a special building on the campus of Babson Institute.
Professor Claudius H. de Goeje, Dutch ethnologist from The Hague, sailed yesterday on the Holland-America liner Volendam, accompanied by his 24-year-old daughter, Maria.

Building activity in Queens this year, judging from home construction programs by the leading developers, will be centered chiefly in the large residential area extending from Flushing and the World's Fair grounds on the north, Jamaica on the south, easterly through Forest Hills and Kew Gardens and thence northerly to Elmhurst and Jackson Heights.
THERE is at least one dissentient from the general lamentation over the alleged excessive number of new novels. Writing in The Publishers' Circular.

Though opposed to public ownership of railroads as a general policy, State Senator Pliny W. Williamson suggested today that communities formerly served by the New York, Westchester Boston Railway purchase the trackage of the bankrupt company and operate the line themselves or by lease to a private corporation.

The Society of Georgia Women in New York will celebrate Washington's Birthday on Tuesday with a historical meeting and tea at the home of the vice president, Mrs. Walter B. Radcliffe, 400 Rugby Road, Brooklyn. Historical readings by Mrs. E. D. Hopkins and a program of minuets and waltzes will be presented with Mrs. George B. Turpin presiding.
Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were again in light volume. Except for several individual calls of foreign and Land Bank issues,
Dr. Weston Krupp of Woodstock, Ont., is the new national open singles lawn bowling champion. He defeated Stanley Hayes of Buffalo in the finals yesterday by a score of 21-16.

The Morgan Fraternity will hold a bridge party at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Monday night, Feb. 28, to raise funds to aid needy students of Cathedral College, according to an announcement yesterday. Bishop Stephen J. Donahue,
Mrs. Charles D. Hubbard of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Edna Linton Hubbard, to Karl H. Weber, son of Mrs. Harry O. Weber of Boston.

The Uhiversity of Rochester Basketball team staged a second-half rally to beat Hobart College tonight, 42 to 30, and run its streak to five straight. Bob Ulreck, sophomore guard, bore the brunt of the Rochester scoring burden with 16 points. Dobbin and Bootay led the losers with 8 points each.
A government "trial balloon" suggestion of an anti-war pact to link Japan and the United States was cheered at a mass meeting here today.
The Navy made its No. 1 aviator, Captain John Henry Towers, assistant chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics today.

Massachusetts State College and Amherst College, town rivals on the athletic field for sixty years, will compete Monday in debating for the first time. They will argue the merits of the consumer's coeperative system.
Mrs. L. Kinney Packard of Stelton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane J. Packard, to Dr. Rene G. Schirber of New York.

Awaiting Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech tomorrow and the decision of the British Cabinet the French Foreign Office continued active today. Its position remains that joint action should be taken by France and Britain in Berlin and Vienna, opposing recognition of any arrangements threatening Austria's independence.
Boston University defeated the Army sextet from West Point, 6 to 5, at the Arena tonight. Boston University got away to a fast start, scoring four goals in the first period to one for Army.
The executive committee of the Wesleyan University alumni council has nominated four alumni as candidates for the trustee election to be held this Spring: C. Everett Bacon, '13, of Montclair, N. J.;

TEN of what are expected to be the world's largest commercial land planes and six of the most gigantic flying boats ever built for passenger service are under construction at the plant of the Boeing Aircraft Company here.

Supply contracts valued at $4,478,205 were awarded in the week ended on Thursday by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced. Eighty-one orders were placed, of which twenty-nine, valued at $2,824,041, went to New York bidders; one, for $125,355, to New Jersey, and one, for $16,198, to Connecticut.
SEARCH for new decorative motifs takes the designer into many fields. Industry with its factories and complicated machinery; architecture with its skyscrapers;
FICTION "AN INFAMOUS ARMY." Georgette Heyer. (Doubleday, Doran.) April. "WINGED PHARAOH." Joan Grant. (Harper.) March. "THE GREAT AMERICAN NOVEL-"' Clyde Brion Davis. (Farrar Rinehart.) April.

One of the well known charities in Paris, the American Aid Society, the principal task of which is to find means of sending home worthy citizens who become stranded in France, has reelected Mrs. Henry S. Downe as president.

Manhattanville college suffered its first basketball defeat in five years when Rosemont College came through with a hard-fought 24-23 victory on the Rosemont floor today. The New York girls had won fifty-one straight games. It was Rosemont's fifth in a row this season.

A popular song of a short time ago-"The Music Goes 'Round and Around"--would seem to provide a rather accurate description of the mental gyrations and verbal circumlocution that have marked the House and Senate investigation of the President's recommendation to increase greatly the strength of our navy.

Two Yellow River "gospel boats," operated by Miss Elsie Daddow, an Australian, and Miss Helen Bailey, an American, from North Carolina, will not leave despite the attack by Japanese planes ten days ago and the increasing war dangers as the Chinese and Japanese battle on opposite banks of the river.

Except for some sensational squash racquets on the part of H. S. Tenney and R. V. Wakeman, Philadelphia teams would have been left in complete command of the situation at the University Club, where the ninth annual invitation doubles tournament for the Lockett Trophy is in progress.

Miss Hope Sturtevant, daughter of Mrs. F. Raymond Sturtevant and the late Rev. Dr. Sturtevant, was married to Dr. Richard Nelson Tillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Henry Tillman of Riderwood, this evening in the First Unitarian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Omer H. Mott.

Miss Ethel Louise Klimback, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Charles Klimback of Montclair, was married this evening to Donald W. Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude T. Johnson of East Orange in Grace Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Frank A. Hunger.
Arturo Toscanini mounted the podium of the NBC Symphony Orchestra at Radio City for the ninth time last night. Nine was the number symbolizing the ideally perfect to Dante and other great mystics,

It was officially announced by Insurgent officials here today that Mansueto had been captured and that Teruel was now untenable for Government forces. The Mansueto heights are a few miles northwest of Teruel.

Led by Danny Lynch and Joe Dzienkewicz, who tallied 11 and 10 pointss respectively, the St. Francis college basketball team conquered the Hudson College five of Jersey City, 46--40, on the winner's court ?? Brooklyn last night.

Japan is making a new threat to sea trade by the construction of a number of "pocket battle cruisers," that, according to the naval correspondent of The Sunday Times, have great speed and bigger guns than the vessels that the Washington powers thought adequate for convoy work.

To the Art Editor: WHEN the possibility of installing murals and other forms of art in New York subway stations was first recognized, those who conceived and elaborated the idea were aware of the risk of derision from a public accustomed to thinking of subway pictures as inevitably either advertisements or the gratuitous embellishments of anonymous pencils.

The marriage of Miss Sallie Ann Williams, daughter of Mrs. Harrison Williams of Washington and Harry A. Williams Jr. of Norfolk, Va., to William Michael Connors of Troy, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Connors, took place at noon today.

Retail trade in nearly all Federal Reserve districts showed losses as compared with a year ago, last week, and even in the South, which had resisted the downward trend more consistently than other areas, the declines were fairly sharp.

IT being customary for winners in bridge tournaments to defend their titles the following year, most of those who won the various events in the 1937 Eastern tournament will be on hand for the twelfth. annual tournament which begins at the Park Central Hotel on Monday, Feb. 28.

Women active in furthering the work of the Family Thrift Shop, a permanent organization maintained for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association, have arranged a bundle tea in its behalf for March 18 at the administration building of the association, 524 West Forty-second Street.

A house plan at the School of Business and Civic Administration of. City College will become operative next week when the student groups will lease their own house, for social activities, according to an announcement by James S. Peace, director of the house plan at the Main Center of the college.

WINDMILLS, now picturesque reminders of a bygone day when they were a familiar part of every English pastoral, have attracted the attention of a group interested in preserving the atmosphere of old England.

The evolution of women's costumes from simple Grecian tunics through the centuries to the latest in Spring silhouettes is the topic of a series of lectures with which the Museum of Costume Art will open its second season.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Schneider of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Schneider, to Lyman M. Stowe, son of Mrs. Elmert C. Stowe of Hartford, Conn.

Elaborate precautions were taken by the police to guard Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland from the enthusiasm of his admirers as he arrived here today with his leading Ministers and Maurice Moynihan, Secretary of the Irish Government, for the resumption of Anglo-Irish treaty talks.

Stocks closed generally higher yesterday in the slowest trading since Oct. 2. Gains in the half-day session ranged from fractions to 2 points, with a few issues doing slightly better. The volume on the Stock Exchange was only 295,000 shares.

When Miss Maribell Vinson, nine times United States figure skating champion, abandoned the amateur ranks last year to lead her own professional troupe on a tour of the country she left the field open to others.

Jackie Kid Berg, 146, England, stopped Silvio Zangrillo, 145 1/4, South Brooklyn, in 1:35 of the fourth chapter of the feature eight-round engagement at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a crowd of 4,000. Referee Jack Goodman halted the contest to save Zangrillo from further pounding.

Attention, crow lovers everywhere: a worthy successor has at last been found at the Trailside Museum of the American Museum of Natural History at Bear Mountain Park to Joe the Crow, the 9year-old pet of the museum's staff, which met sudden death in August, 1936, in a valiant but short-lived skirmish with Napoleon, a weasel.

A MABEL WILLIAMS - EL LIS'S first considerable novel to be published here (there were two slight ones in 1926 and 1927) is too distinguished as a work of literary art to be classified as propaganda, but it is no less passionate a plea for "peace in our time" because of the quietness of its intensity.

FEW public men in modern times have evoked such passionate polemics as Chiang Kai-shek. No man of his generation has been so bitterly reviled by his own people; and yet just now he is more nearly a national hero than any Chinese has been for generations.

The motion of the Progressive Miners of America for rehearing of a suit in which the United Electric Coal Company obtained a $117,000 judgment for business losses during a strike was overruled today by Judge Fred L. Wham of the Federal court.
"Just another cave," said Floyd Rigdon, Carlsbad publisher, today after emerging from a newly discovered limestone cavern.

Private collectors are expecting to find the last will and testament of Don Carlos II, son of King Charles IV of Spain and Carlist pretender to the throne, in a safety deposit box of a now deceased American woman in Monte Carlo.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert V. Kieslich of Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Elsie Kieslich, to Cadet Lawrence Chandler Baldwin of the First Class of the United States Military Academy at West Point, son of Colonel Karl F. Baldwin, U. S. A., and Mrs. Baldwin, who are now in Kansas.

The marriage of Miss Anna Mary Carhart, daughter of Arthur Carhart of Newark and the late Mrs. Carhart, to Charles Robert Barth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Barth, also of Newark, took place this evening in Forest Hill Presbyterian Church here.
NATCHEZ will again open to the public its ante-bellum mansions and formal gardens on March 11, when the program of the Mississippi Pilgrimage Garden Clubs opens.

Portugal, which has displayed marked sympathy for General Francisco Franco since the beginning of the Spanish civil war and has shown considerable friendliness toward Germany and Italy, recently signed a contract for the purchase of fifteen British fighting planes, it was learned yesterday.

Led by Captain Daniel Bukantz, the C. C. N. Y. fencing team defeated St. John's, 13 1/2 to 12 1/2, at the Twenty-third Street Branch of City College yesterday. Bukantz was the outstanding figure on the strips, losing only once on his seven turns to the strips.
The Columbia varsity wrestling team defeated Cornell, 15 1/2 to 14 1/2, yesterday at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

The most stunning upset of the indoor polo season came last night at the Squadron A Armory when the Green-shirted riders of Boulder Brook galloped roughshod over Evergreen Farms, 20 to 9, to subject the New Jersey trio to its first defeat in the Metropolitan League and to leave not the slightest doubt which was the better team for the night.

The government today suppressed the Nationalist party in Vilna and sent three of its leaders to a concentration camp. Criminal proceedings were instituted against the editor of a local party organ, Alexander Zwierzymnski, and also against a lecturer in the university, Dr. Cywinski, author of an article "insulting to Pilsudski's memory."

President Roosevelt's long-awaited statement on price policies for his Administration was made at a White House press conference Friday morning. The meeting was one of the longest held by him with the press since that day in 1935 when the President raked the Supreme Court over the coals for its "horse-and-buggy" treatment of the National Industriall Recovery Act.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, created as an emergency lending institution by President Hoover's Administration, threatened with extinction with the advent of the New Deal, revived and "streamlined" by the New Deal, and now revitalized by President Roosevelt after he ordered it liquidated last Fall, has proved a Federal agency difficult to abolish.

HERE on this page are gleanings from the English press which present an unusual picture of England and the Englishman. The selections were made by V. S. Pritchett and the drawings are by Low, the cartoonist.

Miss Marie Reynolds McGeorge, a descendant of the Reynolds family of Rhode Island. of the family of Gardiners that owned Gardiners Island and of the Percy family of England, was married here this evening to Blaine A. Davis of Brooklyn.

The proposal now before the New Jersey Supreme Court to make a college degree necessary for admission to the bar in that State and to withhold recognition from part-time law schools appears to have slight chance of immediate adoption, Dean Spaulding Frazer of the Newark University Law School, its originator said yesterday.

An English summary of Chancellor Hitler's address today before the German Reichstag is scheduled to be relayed from Berlin and rebroadcast by the WJZ network from 11:30 to 11:45 A. M. Roderich Dietze, National Broadcasting Company observer in Berlin, will read th summary shortly after Chancellor Hitler has ended his address.

Harry Jeffra rules the favorite in tomorrow night's fifteen-round bantamweight championship fight despite the fact that Challenger Sixto Escobar is a home boy, highly popular and is striving to get the title back. However, there is little or no betting reported.
Members of the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union will celebrate Washington's Birthday with a dance on Monday night at their headquarters, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Harold R.

A new literary magazine, the Portfolio, has passed the experimental stage to take its place alongside of Swarthmore College's two chief publications, The Phoenix, a weekly newspaper, and The Halcyon, a year-book put out by the junior class.

Six hundred teachers of science in the city's high schools at their annual luncheon in the Hotel Astor yesterday heard a talk on "Celestial Science" by Dr. F. R. Moulton, permanent secretary of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and a discussion of the manufacture of synthetic rubber

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with much interest the plan of Colonel W. J. Wilgus for creating a national transport authority and the reply of Charles J. Nasmyth, both in letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Mrs. Gail Hazelette, 47 years old, of 1,855 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was rescued at 9 o'clock yesterday morning when she attempted to commit suicide by walking, fully dressed, into the surf off Coney Island. Eric Montelione, 42, of 8,222 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn,

Dr. Luther Weigle, dean of Yale Divinity School and nationally known educator, will be the speaker at the first annual dinner of Wagner College, Staten Island, to be held tomorrow evening at Beekman Tower, Manhattan. Dean Weigle will speak on "The Place of the Small College in Education."

A second-half rally led by Dick Peterman and Don Lay gave Hofstra College a 38-26 victory over Lowell Textile tonight in Calkings gym. Lowell held the edge throughout the first period, leading, 18-16, at half-time.
Louisiana State's football team will play Holy Cross here on Oct. 7, 1939, it was announced today by Athletic Director Tom McCabe. Arrangements for the intersectional game were completed this week.

Delegates to the tenth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Young Folks Temple Leagues met yesterday afternoon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street. Their conference preceded sessions today open to all members of the federation.

Near where the original settlers of Newark landed in 1666 there now stands an institution that is the newest of urban universities. Its main purpose is announced to be that of extending "democracy's frontiers."
Senator Norris proposed today that the moribund wage and hour bill be revived, minus its minimum day provisions, to solve the pressing problem of unemployment.
Pennsylvania defeated Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game at the Palestra tonight, 35-32, before a crowd of 5,500 fans.
Wesleyan University debaters will open their season Friday, meeting Colgate here and Bowdoin away. The subject is "Resolved: That the Several States Should Adopt a Unicameral System of Legislature."
Long Island University's basketball team scored its nineteenth victory in twenty-two starts tonight, defeating Canisius College, 50 to 41.

The Colorado Southern Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $1,072,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to meet the maturity on March 1 of $1,072,000 of first-mortgage 6

Thirteen seniors in the Business Education Teacher-Training course at Russell Sage College are receiving their first baptism of fire as teachers under the actual conditions which they will be called upon to meet when they graduate in June and obtain the positions for which they have been four years in training.

Mrs. Sarah M. Wilsey of White Plains, N. Y., has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Mae Traver, to Frank Christian Klode, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil R. Klode of Milwaukee, Wis. The marriage will take place on Feb. 28 in Miami Beach, Fla.

Patriotic, civil and religious groups will pay their annual tribute to the memory of George Washington today, tomorrow and Tuesday. Tuesday will be the 206th anniversary of the birth of the nation's first President.

WITH two more broadcasts by the NBC Symphony Orchestra on Saturday nights at 10 o'clock remaining in the 1937-38 series of eleven concerts under the direction of Arturo Toscanini, plans are afoot for another series to begin late in the year.
PARIS.-Nationalization of the French armament industry, authorized by the law toted in August, 1936, has now been carried out to the full extent that this law allows.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What is disturbing to many citizens in the new naval proposals is not merely that they increase the fleet but that they seem to herald a broad revision of our foreign policy. A few points in the change that is taking place stand out.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Washington's Birthday and the opening of the national conventions of twenty-four groups of educators will bring thousands of visitors to Atlantic City this week.

Preliminary conversations will be held soon with the British delegation of experts due here next week to assist in the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement with the United States, but no definite decisions will be reached nor will tariff rates be considered until after hearings have been concluded by the United States Government for American business men, according to Secretary Hull.

ALTHOUGH the tracking down of real or imaginary "traitors, Trotzkyists and wreckers" has inflicted no heavy casualties on the ranks of Moscow literati, it has continued to affect Soviet literature as much as it has been disorganizing Soviet industry;

Revisions sought by the Board of Trustees in the proposed city charter for this village have been withdrawn, following a private conference with members of the drafting committee. The charter is now before the Legislature for consideration as originally presented.

The importance of giving emoyers the right to seek elections under the Labor Relations Act has been exaggerated, if the experience the New York State Labor Retions Board is a criterion, Burton Zorn, counsel to the board, said yesterday.

Archie Dean Jr. of Larchmont, N. Y., 14 years old and one of the cleverest of the younger riders of the ring, held the spotlight at the annual Horse Show of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club at the Riding and Polo Club last night, when he retained the Horsemanship Challenge Trophy by winning it for the third successive time.

THE death of Ravel made a deep impression here. The composer had a weakness for Vienna, he was several times in this city and it was to Vienna that he owed the inspiration for "La Valse." For their part, the Viennese esteemed him like few other modernists.
We now have a new AAA and the alphabetical atmosphere of the country is by that much enriched.
Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee proposed a ten-point legislative program today, including abolition of the surplus profits tax, to rehabilitate the nation's railroads.

To the Music Editor: It seems to me that the concertgoing public is entitled to some explanation of the fact that at 10 A. M. of Feb. 11, the day on which the second Toscanini concert at Carnegie Hall was announced, only the most expensive seats for this concert were still available at the box office.

A Pennsylvania Railroad accountant testified yesterday before Claude R. Porter, Interstate' Commerce Commissioner, that it costs his company about 84 cents to carry a single passenger to Thirty-third Street from local New Jersey stations, although it pays the Hudson Manhattan Railroad only 8.64 cents

Federal savings and loan associations of the Philadelphia district reported yesterday a record of growth "believed unparalled in the history of financial institutions," one organization showing an inorease in assets of 1,100 per cent in the last two years, and of about 140 per cent for 1937.
MR. BOLITHO is an able journalist who has obtained an interesting as signment. He is the inside man at the British court.

It is regrettable that so many good plants, when first introduced to horticulture, have so long to labor under the handicap of ungainly botanical names. Veltheimia glauca, from South Africa, is a case in point. A fairly accurate translation of the common or first name would be "Home-onthe-Range."

New Jersey College for Women will present three one-day conferences to acquaint high school girls with the possibilities of a college course, in place of the former threeday pre-college guidance conference, through which more than 1,100 girls have received a foretaste of actual college life.

Rear Admiral Emory S. ("Jerry") Land, retired chief of the Navy's Bureau of Construction and Repair, assumed the chairmanship of the Maritime Commission today and announced that there would be no change of policy.

Entrants for the championship lined up in the Stockholm Ice Palace just before going into action. From left to right, they are: Hedy Stenuf, Austrian born but now living in the United States, who placed third; Annemari Saeter of Norway; Daphne Walker of England; Cecilia Colledge of England, who ranked second; Britta Rahlen of Sweden;

The John Marshall College basketball team yesterday invaded the Savage School court to score a 59-to-44 triumph over the local team. Paced by Weber and Killat, the two forwards, who accounted for 25 points between them, the visitors led throughout.

The Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia indicated in a ruling today that it would act favorably upon a petition filed by New York interests for a temporary stay of coal prices fixed by the National Bituminous Coal Commission last Dec. 16.

The. New York Stock Exchange is applying to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to remove from listing and registration the $7 preferred stock and the $6 preferred stock of the New York Steam Corporation, because the amounts outstanding are too small.

Current movements in this country for the extension of marriage health laws gain interest in the light of the recent passage in Ecuador of a bill requiring medical certificates from couples contemplating matrimony.

AT the memorial services for Thomas G. Masaryk, President of Czechoslovakia, on March 7 in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the United American Czechoslovak Societies of New York, Victor Kolar, conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, will direct a program of Czechoslovak orchestral compositions.
An overtime goal by Johnny Gagnon gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-to3 victory over their local rivals, the Maroons, in a National Hockey League clash before 10,000 fans tonight.

The government has arranged a settlement of the controversy with the American-owned South American Development Company, operator of the Zaruma gold mines at Porto Bello, over the government's demand for a larger share in the production of the mines, the newspaper Telegrafo declared today.

Eight second-round matches in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group I championship at the City Athletic Club were played yesterday, with no upsets recorded. Maurice W. Metzler Jr., City A. C., again was a winner, turning back his club-mate, Newton Kutner, in straight games, 15-5, 15-11, 15-8.

THE Treasury Department's regulations governing the printing of black-and-white illustrations of United States postage stamps, under the law recently enacted by Congress, were made public last Thursday and became effective on that date.
Rome took the news of the Hitler-Schuschnigg meeting last Saturday, and of the Cabinet changes in Austria to which it gave rise, more calmly probably than any other European capital.

Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women will hold their annual reunion on Washington's Birthday. Since more than 70 per cent of the alumnae of the college live within the State, and so find it possible to return to the campus frequently during the year,
Officials of Manhattan College have made available four scholarships for young men who are to be graduated from high school next June, it was announced yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar.

Extension of British Empire preferential tariff rates to United States products is one of the main concessions sought by exporters here in the reciprocal trade agreement to be negotiated with Great Britain, it. was revealed yesterday when the National Foreign Trade Council,

All those who attended the current National Sportsmen's show at the Grand Central Palace yesterday were not spectators. Some forty-five anglers took part in a novel obstacle fly-casting contest and this morning the doors will open before the actual show time to permit another band of casters to start a competition.

Continental rates moved against the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market today, support for the dollar being particularly noticeable. The dollar's further recovery to 5.02 1-16 to the pound was largely owing to the
Forty-four homes have been completed in Fort Hill Estates, residential community in the Scarsdale section of Westchester County, according to Ray Craerin, president of Fort:.Hill Estates, Inc.
DIFFICULT as it may be now to realize it, Asiatic cholera was the most terrible scourge that ever afflicted this country.

THE "ten days that shook the world" had ended; Trotsky's "Red Guards" patrolled the streets of Petrograd and in words that were to make history-"We have shown that we can take the power; we must show that we are able to keep it; I summon you to ruthless fight"-Trotsky, founder of the Red Army. had proclaimed "the approaching Civil War."
A threeday music festival built around the works of American composers will be held on a nation-wide scale under the sponsorship of the Works Progress Administration on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

Mr. and Mrs. August H. Haucke of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lenore Audrey Haucke, to Allen Hazen, also of Dobbs Ferry, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allen Hazen.

Miss Catherine Marie Meaney, daughter of Mrs. Timothy J. Meaney i of this city and the late Mr. Meaney, was married to Joseph W. Sheelen, son of Mrs. Fred J. Sheelen of North Plainfield, and the late Mr. Sheelen, this morning in St. Mary's Church, Plainfield. Rev. James C.

Under the auspices of Fordham University, a Danubian congress, to be attended by representatives of nine European nations with interests in the Danubian section of Central Europe, will be held here from March 31 to April 3. Preliminary plans for the congress have been disclosed by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.

A warning against possible frauds on- the part of swindlers or impostors seeking to take advantage of the fact that the Federal Housing Administration again is insuring loans for repairing or modernizing homes was issued yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the FHA.

Swarthmore increased its string of consecutive victories to nine by defeating Lafayette at basketball tonight, 46 to 34, principally through the work of Ed Jakle, guard, who not only stopped the Lafayette attack, but who shot with uncanny accuracy for 21 points.

Seven civic and trade associations have joined the rapidly growing opposition to the bills to abolish the blue ribbon jury system now before the State Assembly by directing an appeal to the Assembly Judiciary Committee to disapprove the bills as "unneeded" and dangerous to the speedy, fair and impartial administration of justice in the County of New York.
Addison Warner Co., investment bankers at 39 South La Salle Street, will discontinue operations on Feb. 28, Addison Warner announced today. The company has been in business since 1930.
Sheridan's comedy, "The Rivals," will be presented by the Marymount College Dramatic Club here on Thursday, according to an announcement today by Miss Dorothy Gregory, president of the group.
Japanese forces hold 260,000 square miles of territory in North China and 2,700 square miles in Central China, according to a statement made today by Imperial Headquarters.

Three sisters of King Zog of Albania, who will soon have a sister-in-law of American descent, arrived in Naples today on their way to the United States for their first tour of the country. They will sail for New York tomorrow aboard the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

Approved by stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation at their annual meeting on April 4 of two simple changes in the company's certificate of incorporation will permit the board of directors to engage, at any time in the future,

AN all-Strauss program will be Liven by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra Thurs Jay evening and Friday afternoon, with Rose Pauly as soloist. Complete opera and concert programs for the current week follow;

Albert Morris Bagby gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Among his guests were Mrs. James Roosevelt, Mrs. John Dyneley Prince, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford N. Carver, Lady Boileau of London, Mrs. D. D. Forbes, Mrs. Chamberlain Chanler, Charles Edward Sampson and Carlton Smith.

OSTENSIBLY a very brittle. very bitter modern comedy. a comedy of wry smiles and laughter which jars most on him, or her, who laughs, Elinor Rice's first novel is at bottom a story of that tragedy, stripped of all dignity, which is the saddest of all.
BURGESS MEREDITH, chairman of the Federal Arts Committee, asks this department what it is willing to do to help pass the Coffee bill.
RADIO'S newest singing discovery, John Carter, 26-year-old tenor, began his professional career as a dancer in vaudeville back in 1931.

T. Kirby Davidson of St. Louis has been named general chairman for the annual Junior Promenade of Columbia College, to be held next Friday evening at the Essex House, it was announced yesterday by Gerhard E. Seidel, president of the junior class. Three hundred couples are expected to attend.

Anundefeated Princeton swimming team hung up its ninth victory of the season with a 45-30 triumph over the University of Pennsylvania in Brokaw tank today. It was the fifth Eastern Intercollegiate League loss for the Quaker City mermen.

Germany's foreign trade, which rose to record heights under the National Socialist regime last year, suffered a serious reverse during the first month of the year. Exports dropped to 445,900,000 marks, a decrease of more than 100,000,000 or approximately 19 per cent compared with December.

Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, said today he would begin closing about 300 camps on March 1, in compliance with President Roosevelt's budget recommendation of $226,000,000 for the corps during the next fiscal year.

The week's events involving Germany and Austria must in a certain sense be viewed from the perspective of the Rome-Berlin axis. The final showdown between Berlin and Vienna, it is postulated here, no longer could be deferred if Chancellor Hitler's foreign political plans in other directions were to be tackled.
Declaring that "twin horns and similar diabolical devices for splitting the ears of human beings are the worst noise nuisance still prevalent,"

A dinner dance under the auspices of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas will be held March 11 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. Mrs. A. Harris Gaines is executive chairman of the benefit committee.

An anonymous donor has given $5,000 to Vassar College for the endowment fund of its Summer Institute of Euthenics, and the trustees of the college have renewed for five years, beginning with 1939, their annual grant of $10,000.

Newspapers here publish reports from the Russian border that the Soviet is about to begin construction -of fortifications along the Russo-Rumanian frontier on the left bank of the Dniester River, similar to the French Maginot line.

Continued Japanese declarations of intention to adhere to their open-door pledges are being received here with growing skepticism in view of the new measures being instituted in the territories under Japanese military control.
A capacity audience is expected at Henry Miller's Theatre on Wednesday night for the performance of "Once Is Enough," which has been taken over as a benefit for the Frontier Nursing Service.

Speaking at a luncheon of the American Association of University Women yesterday on "Why Women?" Mrs. William P. Earle, only woman member of the New York City Council, said she frequently wondered if her twenty-five male colleagues, "looking longingly on a seat that might be occupied by a politician, don't sometimes wonder 'Why women?' too."
Miss Josephine Simpson Logan, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Simpson Logan of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to John L. Merrill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Merrill of Greenwich, Conn.

Extension of the program of a week end exchange of Professors of English between Cornell and the University of Toronto will be marked by the visit here early in March of Professor James H. Hanford of Western Reserve University.

With an appeal to universities to refuse to permit themselves to be used as propagandist agencies, Dr. J. Duncan Spaeth, president of the University of Kansas City, pictured academic freedom today as the bulwark upon which the preservation of western institutions and civilization depends.
Isaao Gordon, a clothing manufacturer for forty years, died yesterday at the Park West Hospital. Mr. Gordon, who made his home at 250 West Ninety-fourth Street, was 64 years old.
Columbia's fencers easily defeated Pennsylvania in their annual meet today, scoring 18 1/2 to 81/2. Leo Kellerman starred in the foils, Bob Else made a clean sweep of three matches in the epee,

Research conducted at Indiana University by Dr. Roland C. Davis, Associate Professor of Psychology, and Dr. William Shaw, now of Columbia, shows that we think not only with our minds but with our bodies.

Buffalo's Civil Service Commission, which has been under fire in the city affairs investigation, today canceled examinations taken by 277 Fire Department applicants last Fall and prepared to investigate all examinations taken in recent years.

Miss Jewel Marie Markham, daughter of General and Mrs. Baird H. Markham of New York and Oklahoma City, was married here yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 40 East Sixty-sixth Street, to Joseph Farrington Connolly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Connolly of Oklahoma City.

Envisaging ultimately an organization of national scope, leaders of the newly organized Association of Smaller Business for the New York district outlined yesterday their plans for founding a group that will function, free from the oratorical chaos and fanfare that disrupted the recent Washington conference, in the best interests of small-scale business men.
If Dr. N. A. Iljin of the Wool Laboratory, Moscow, is right it will soon be unnecessary to clip sheep for their wool. He simply doses the sheep once with thallium compounds, whereupon they moult.

HIRAM SHERMAN, like most of the Mercury troupe, is not just an actor. Earlier in the season he was the buffer between 1,000 hopeful actors and Orson Welles, and even in the face of that ordeal he maintained a golden disposition and a continuous grin. But he is better known as the slouch-hatted Cassius in "Julius Caesar," and Firk, the shoemaker apprentice of the trembling tenor, in "The Shoemakers' Holiday."

This year, probably because of a relatively mild Winter, women seem to be Spring-clothes conscious earlier than usual. Winter ??ment and particularly the accessories one bought last October are beginning to pall. Vernal equinox is four weeks away. Anticipating it, the first Spring handbags are already in the shops.
The National Football League voted today to prohibit post-season tours such as the one conducted recently by the Chicago Bears and the Champion Washington Redskins.
The Scarsdale Junior Service League will sponsor "A Cherry and Hatchet" dinner dance Monday night at the Scarsdale Golf Club to aid the ?? fund.

The staggering problem of providing food and medical attention for the tens of millions of war victims in the areas of North and Central China occupied by Japanese forces is already claiming the serious attention of Tokyo's Parliament.

A COMPREHENSIVE picture of what this country needs in the way of traffic reform and what steps must be taken before permanent improvement can be expected are presented in the report made public by the United States Bureau of Public Roads, of which Part 1, dealing with lack of uniformity, was discussed in these columns last week.

In a long Saturday session the British Cabinet almost split wide open over policy in dealing with the Italian-Austrian-German situation. Disputes, however, were put over until today, when another extraordinary session will be held following Hitler's speech. Widening differences between Foreign Secretary Eden and the majority brought indications that he and two other members might resign. [Page 1.]
Georgetown beat Pittsburgh in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference game today. 34 to 22.

More than 300 used textbooks have been sold and $500 has been given to undergraduates for them in the last scholastic year by the student-managed book exchange at Barnard College, Judith Lenert, chairman of the exchange, announced yesterday.
'Frederick A. Wyckoff, president of the Wood Dolson Company, sat! at his desk yesterday and lookedi back twenty-five years to the day he took a job with this West Side realty firm.

St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street, near Ninth Avenue, will hold a special service Tuesday evening in celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the consecration of its edifice.

RICCARDO ZANDONAI was the latest conductor in the symphonic season of the Academy of Santa Cecilia at the Teatro Adriano. His program brought no less than three local novelties-an example worth imitating.
THE sidewalks of New York may be only the words of a song to many people, but to a large majority of the city's 1,500,000 camera men they are one of the richest picture sources at hand.
Britain's strongest farthermost East bulwark of empire, the powerful new Singapore naval base, was formally opened this week with simple but impressive ceremonies.

The National Labor Relations Board was criticized today in citizens' resolutions protesting the board's recognition of the C. I. O. union as bargaining agency for employes of the closed Maidwell Garment Company.
A fifteen-day truce in the strike of 1,500 Toronto coal handlers was signed today and deliveries to homes and buildings, cut off since yesterday, were resumed.

N EWS of the recent crash of the dirigible USSR V-6 in a little known Far North territory, en route to the diminishing ice floe where four polar scientists awaited rescue, was the first intimation to many abroad that serious lighter-than-air building and operation work is carried on in the Soviet Union.
Winning both the medley and free-style relays and taking first honors in five of the seven individual races, Columbia University swimmers defeated the Navy today 45 to 30.
Robert Buck, 24-year-old airline copilot, came down on a snow-covered airport here today and sighed "its's sure tough"-having to spend his wedding night more than 1,000 miles away from his fiancee.

Rear Admiral Harris Laning, U. S. N., retired, governor of the United States Naval Home here, and Mrs. Laning have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hester Marie Laning, to Dr. Dickinson Sergeant Pepper, also of Philadelphia.

The click of the dice and roulette ball continues and the stolid faces of the dealers are unchanged at the Bank Club, big gambling hall conducted by James C. McKay and William J. Graham, who were sentenced in New York Federal court this week to nine years in Federal prison and to pay fines of $11,000 each on charges of using the mails to defraud.

Demands for expansion of Federal relief and the anticipated appropriation of $250,000,000 by Congress to meet these demands have focused attention again on the nation-wide organization of the Works Progress Administration and its methods for measuring the need for relief.

The marriage of Miss Frances Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Perry of Westerly, R. I., to John C. Schroeter, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Schroeter of Marion, Ohio, took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes, 141 East, Forty-third Street.

The American Legion will apply for an order in Supreme Court tomorrow directing Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, to show cause why Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, should not be removed as assistant to the Borough President and why Gerson's salary should not be withheld pending the outcome of the ouster move.

Robert L. Ferguson Jr., a tall youth of 22, who faces a jail sentence for having entered this country, from Canada ilegally, did not know last night whether he would be able to aid his ill sister after all.

GERHART HAUPTMANN has another jubilee. The literary celebrity from the Silesian mountains has rounded out three quarters of a century and bids fair to vie in age with that of his great confrere, Goethe, who lived to be fourscore and two.

Felix Justice, one of the State's principal witnesses in the Nicholas (Nick Montana vice case and the object of a nation-wide police search when he disappeared last November as Montana was about to be placed on trial,

RED caps at Union Station are carrying more bags and brief cases than usual at this time of year. The added travelers are not tourists; they bear familiar names, most of which can be found in the Directory of Directors, and they are Washingtonbound to one of the most protracted mind-reading sessions on record.
Mr. and Mrs. Maximillian Courtland Meyer of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Maxine Meyer, to Dr. Joseph M. Krimsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Krimsky of Brooklyn.

Seven hundred guests, in merry mood, gathered in this Western New York village tonight for a yellow alley cat's birthday party. It was the twenty-third anniversary of Tommy Clark, who, besides being a cat, is an Elk.

How and why the Constitution of Canada should be amended to make it more modern and efficient has been the subject of a royal commission inquiry in different parts of this country for the past three months.
Penn State's powerful wrestling team defeated Syracuse today, 29 to 3, the visitors being limited to a decision in the heavyweight bout.

Young Americans, millions of them, are becoming "joiners," according to a study completed by Dr. M. M. Chambers for the American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education. From groups interested in missionary work to those sponsoring communism, bird study or aviation, there are organizations today for every type of youngster.

The national ski jumping championships got off to a flying start today on a "home-made" course with Crosby Perry-Smith of Lake Placid, N. Y., capturing the opening event-the Class C competition for skiers under 17.

At least six Smith College girls may justly be found guilty of having their heads in the clouds during the remaining months of the college year, according to reports from the Smith College Flying Club, which states that half a dozen of its members are licensed pilots.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marz L. Fashena of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Gladys Jeannette Fashena, to Dr. Floyd Alvin Norman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Alvin Norman of Dallas, Texas.
THAT the modern age makes new and urgent demands on leadership is almost a platitude. How those demands are to be met is a question not so easy to answer.

Accused of stealing a wallet said to have been a gift from President Roosevelt, Arthur Russell, 40, of 4,197 Third Avenue, the Bronx, pleaded not guilty to charges of assault and robbery in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday before Magistrate Matthew Troy.

Ralph Flanagan of Miami, national free-style champion, has quit the University of Texas. Registrar E. J. Matthews said today the swimmer, a freshman, formally withdrew from his course early this week.

The final registration date for soloists in the Music Education League contest is Wednesday, with district auditions beginning at Steinway Hall March 10 and continuing throughout the month, it was announced by the league.

Yarn mills of the nation representing 1,163,000 spindles have agreed to abide by the new proposed cotton yarn rules, according to announcement today by Owen Fitzsimons, secretary of the carded yarn group. Just off the press in booklet form, they are being mailed from Charlotte to yarn producers.

Former President Herbert Hoover's visit to Belgium reached its high spot today when he dedicated a memorial tablet placed on the wall of the room where the American Committee for Belgian Relief held its meetings during the World War.

LONDON.-The Aberdeen branch of the Kilt Society, which seeks to promote the correct wearing of Highland costume, has decided that to admit women members would be "not only humorous but ridiculous." In doing so, however, it departs from tradition, for until fairly recently Scottish national costume has been identical for both sexes.

The marriage of Miss Frances Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Perry of Westerly, R. I., to John C. Schroeter, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Schroeter of Marion, Ohio, took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes, 141 East, Forty-third Street.

Gerson, a Communist, should not be removed as assistant to the Borough President and why Gerson's salary should not be withheld pending the outcome of the ouster move.

More than 1,000 music educators and administrators are expected to attend the second annual music conference, sponsored by New York UnilVersity's School of Education, next Saturday in the Auditorium, 41 West Fourth Street, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ernest G. Hesser, chairman of the University's Department of Music Education.

At least six Smith College girls may justly be found guilty of having their heads in the clouds during the remaining months of the college year, according to reports from the Smith College Flying Club, which states that half a dozen of its members are licensed pilots.

Alfredo Salmaggi, impresario of popular-price opera and director of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, suffered an injury to his left knee, a bruised forehead and deep scalp laceration in an automobile accident at 1 A. M. yesterday near his home, 1 Quentin Road, Brooklyn.

With five of its components lower, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has dropped to 79.7 for the week ended Feb. 12. This compares with 81.3 (revised) for the previous week and 102.4 for the corresponding week a year ago.

PROPOSALS for a superhighway system direct attention to - America's pre-eminent position in road construction. Half of the world's 7,000,000 miles of all-weather highways, it is estimated, are in the United States, with new ones coming at the rate of .5,000 miles a year.
