IT was certainly a fortunate idea that led Julius E. Lips to the preparation and compilation of this volume. "The Savage Hits Back." The "Savage" is the native of Africa, of aboriginal America,

"Educational orders" to train industrial plants in making war materials are receiving close study at the War Department. Assistant Secretary Louis Johnson said the program could be put into effect if Congress approved a pending bill.
The Lehigh University quintet handed Haverford a 45-to-33 defeat tonight. At the half the Engineers, by their flashy, sharp-shooting attack, had earned a 25-to-12 lead. In a wild second period.
Opposition to the SchwartzwaldBrenner bill providing for an annual license tax of from $10 to $550 each on chain stores was expressed yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union.

Official circles here decline to make any statement on the new Austro-German agreement until after Chancellor Hitler's Reichstag speech tomorrow, but the consensus is that cooperation between the National Socialists in Germany and Austria will be intensified, and in particular there are fears of military coordination.

Brooklyn Technical High School has received a gift of two Diesel engines, valued at $100,000, from the New London (Conn.) Naval Base. These engines are being installed. A course on the subject of Diesels will be offered this Fall.

Chinese foreign loan and Boxer indemnity bonds, together totaling nearly $500,000,000, will continue to be serviced through February, 1938, it is believed here by American and European financial experts who have made extensive year-end surveys of China's financial status.

Dr. Lewis Hanke, fellow of the Social Research Council, left last week to lecture at universities in Brazil under the auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, it was announced yesterday. He will spend five months in South America studying conditions there for the council.

Progress is being made in the preparation of the proposed "dictionary" of merchandise terms, which would afford a common terminology for consumers, retailers and manufacturers, but the work will be a "continuous process" that will require considerable time for its completion, according to H. M. Lawrence of the American Standards Association.
South Americans are watching plans for the enlargement of the United States Navy with much keener interest than they would care to admit.

The potential rise in small home construction on Long Island is indicated by a survey of the Building Department in Queens for January. Partly in anticipation of more liberal mortgage policies on the part of the FHA, and partly to gain the benefit of the old building code regulations, one architect alone filed plans last month for 818 private homes with an aggregate estimated cost of $4,908,000, exclusive of the value of the land.
Syracuse University, scored an easy 63-to-29 victory over the University of Buffalo quintet at Elmwood Music Hall tonight before 1,500 spectators.
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue.

The Rovers downed Hershey, 6 to 5, in an Eastern Hockey League game at the Sports Arena tonight. As a result, the New York skaters figure in a triple tie at the top with the Bears and Sea Gulls, the Atlantic City six scoring in its encounter with Baltimore this evening.

A special feature of the concert given by Emanuel Feuermann, the Austrian 'cellist, and the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was the SchoenbergMonn 'cello concerto, which received what is believed to be its New York premiere.
IT would take a novelist of Miss Young's extraordinary deftness to interest one, as she so surely does, in this quiet, delicate, uneventful story of a woman in early middle age.

Capturing during the 220-yard free style evok and 150-yard back-stroke race, addition to swimming the secc-leg in a winning relay, Gil Wrig led Amherst to a 42-33 victory of the Wesleyan mermen in Pro pool today.

Duncan C. McCrea,. Wayne County Prosecutor, recommended warrants today charging the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, the Citron-Kolb Oil Company of Detroit, the Gulf Refining Company and the B. F. Goodrich Company with criminal violation of Michigan statutes.
A FOREIGNER in New York, after a trip to the Metropolitan, where he had gone to see the work of American painters, asked about Ryder-Albert Pinkham Ryder.
CHARLIE McCARTHY, Edgar Bergen's saucy little dummy, continues to run far ahead of all contenders in broadcasts of sixty minutes duration, according to February popularity polls.

The two Astor half-brothers sailed yesterday in opposite directions from opposite sides of the Hudson River. Vincent left on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania for Panama, where he will board his yacht, the Nourmahal, and cruise in the South Seas, going first to Honolulu and then to Tahiti and the Fiji Islands.

Burgess Whitehead, second baseman of the Giants, was operated on today for acute appendicitis. Dr. L. W. Kornegay said that Whitehead apparently was rallying satisfactorily and that his condition appeared "good," adding it would require at least three days- to ascertain Whitehead's "reaction."

EARNEST young men in the State Department pore over reports from American diplomatic missions throughout the world, weighing every word, intent on missing no possible shade of meaning. Word comes from Secretary Hull's office, asking how the Berlin Embassy interprets the "purge" of the German Army. What does Ambassador Phillips in Rome gather concerning the effect of the changes on relations between Mussolini and Hitler?

A positive statement on the government's foreign policy is being sought by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom in advance of the State meeting to be held Friday at New York headquarters. 150 Fifth Avenue.
WHAT a coincidence that Doris, that wonderful new palmist at the Versailles, should have told Joy Hodges that it looks as if she is going to be a commuter between here and the West Coast.

Child training experts were warned today that unless handicapped children were taught to be self-sustaining "civilization will be submerged." Major Frank L. Beals, assistant superintendent of Chicago schools, addressing the International Council for Exceptional Children, said:

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg reassured Jews tonight that they had nothing to fear from Nazi influence in his government, while his German-approved Minister of the Interior, Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, said that Austria would undergo no further changes.
The Lehigh wrestling team lost to Michigan, 27 to 3, before 1,800 spectators tonight. Captain Dick Bishop, Engineers' 155-pounder, did not wrestle because of illness.
Striking electricians, mechanics and maintenance men continued picketing Rockefeller Center yesterday in protest against the alleged failure of the management to bargain collectively.

John J. M. O'Shea, national director of the America'Spanish Relief Fund, the Roman Catholic group formed to aid sick, injured and needy noncombatant victims of the Spanish civil war, announced yesterday the Diocese of Springfield, Ill., was the first in the country to report results of "Spain Sunday" collections in the churches.

A double engagement in the family of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Engel of 465 West End Avenue has been announced. Their daughter, Miss Marjorie Edith Engel, is betrothed to Fred H. Diamant, and their son, Henry William Engel, will marry Miss Edith J. Schick.

The army is to have canned cheese on its already substantial menu, it was revealed yesterday. Canned cheese is not new to the nation-it was first sold about four years ago-but the army's naturally conservative "mess sergeants" hesitated to deviate from the tried and tested "corn willy" and "slumgullion."

Henri Marquis de Madaillan, descendant of a companion-in-arms of Richard Coeur-de-leon in the crusade of the twelfth century, is staying at the Hotel Shelton under the name of Henry Mercadier, it was learned yesterday.
Topics of national and international interest will be discussed at the annual luncheon of the Woman's Press Club of which Mrs. Harriet Bishop Waters Christie is president.
The Syracuse boxing team remained undefeated tonight by turning back a rugged Navy team, 5 to 3, before 3,000 spectators.

Reversal of a trend to centralization of power in the Federal Government lest it lead in the end to "some form of totalitarian government" is urged in a report by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States made public today.
Sales of competitive chocolate and confectionery products in January by 282 manufacturers reporting to the foodstuffs division of the Department of Commerce amounted to $19,301,317,

The hotel lockout may be settled in the near future. The government mediator stated today that the confli?t would be submitted to arbitration as it is now beginning to make its effect felt on other sections of the community.

General John J. Pershing suffered increased rheumatic pains tonight, but his physician insisted he was "in good general condition." The General was forced to miss seeing Tucson's annual Winter rodeo, which he had planned to attend,
ONE day recently on the streets of Rio de Janeiro a visitor from the United States had lost his way. He stopped a passer-by, obviously a Brazilian, to ask directions.

A group of Columbia University students will live for six weeks next Summer with Italian families in, Perugia, while others visit Rome to study teaching methods and Faenza for a course in the history and technique of ceramics, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Howard R. Marraro, director of the Italian Interuniversity Bureau on Morningside Heights.

WINTER fruits are flowing daily to the city, and old-timers who gather at the markets to survey the harvest are apt to remark that times have changed vastly since the day-not far distant--when New York saw no

Colonel Frederick William Phisterer died today at his home near Boonville after a brief illness at the age of 64. Born Oct. 5, 1873, in Columbus, Ohio, he was a son of General Frederick Phisterer. He was graduated from the Military Academy at Albany in 1891, from Cornell University in 1895 and received his doctor's degree there in 1897.

A German pharmaceutical company is now prepared to send at any time a privately owned airplane to any point in the country bearing serums and trained personnel to meet epidemics or other emergencies, according to a consular report to the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

"Why is his chariot so long in coming?" said the mother of Sisera, looking anxiously through the lattice, awaiting his return from the Battle of Megiddo. Her "wise ladies" answered, but she herself knew and "returned the answer to herself":
Mrs. Albert Fishburn will be hostess at a bridge party to be given in Dorchester Hotel on March 23 by the Walter Hines Page Chapter, D. A. R., for the benefit of the Woodlarks Camp.

Mr. and Mrs. Martyn S. Cole of Kew Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roderick Cole, to Richard E. Gooch, son of Mr. and Mrs. 'Claiborne W. Gooch of Lynchburg, Va.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara A. Steinert, daughter of Mrs. Elliot Tucker Sayward of this place, to Robert K. Massey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Silas T. Massey of Worcester.

The announcement by the Treasury Monday that it would henceforth "sterilize" only such of its gold imports as exceeded $100,000,000 in any quarter year was not very illuminating to the average lay reader. Its implications were somewhat obscured by the mystery that seems too often to cloud matters concerning banking, credit, the currency and international exchange.

A default judgment for $2,512,435 against the 565 Fifth Avenue Corporation was entered yesterday in the office of the New York County Clerk in a foreclosure action brought by the Continental Bank and Trust Company. Bonds secured by a $3,000,000 mortgage were sold to investors throughout the country by S. W. Straus Co., Inc.

Former Senator and Mrs. James S. Frelinghuysen of Far Hills, N. J., entertained this evening in the Flamingo Grill of the British Colonial at dinner for Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Eagle of New York. The occasion was the Tennis Night party.

When leading Anti-Saloon Leagueers meet for a 1938 convention in St. Petersburg, Fla., today there will be one less dry State on their rolls than last year, for the Georgia General Assembly has voted this month to allow "county option" on the sale and manufacture of alcoholic beverages.

YOU can't win. Well, hardly ever. The contests which have broken out all over this country are, in their overwhelming majority, "absolutely honest, as far as their mechanics are concerned," and fairly judged;
The Parke-Bernet Galleries' twoday sale of English and American furniture, which was completed yesterday afternoon, realized $32,706, the amount for the final session being $22,277.

Miss Marjorie Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of this place, was married to William Drought Cox, son of Mrs. William D. Cox of New York and the late Mr. Cox, this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Andrew Flynn of this city, was married to Martin Warren Davenport this morning in the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Clarence A. Heavey of St. Bernard's Church performed the ceremony.

Nearly five years ago General Hugh S. Johnson, newly appointed NRA Administrator, stood before an improvised blackboard in the Commerce Department and with the aid of a few chalk marks tried to explain to a group of incredulous newspaper men the Administration's program for industry.

A YOUNG, aspiring lawyer who had just returned from the World War to his home in Fort Wayne, Ind., was mentioned as a possible candidate for Congress. He journeyed to Indianapolis to ask the advice of a friend who was one of the leaders of the bar of the State.

Seniors at Brown University are to take special "comprehensive inventory" tests, designed to show each student just what he has retained from his four years on the campus and to point out what intellectual resources each senior has when he faces the world outside college gates.

A German pharmaceutical company is now prepared to send at any time a privately owned airplane to any point in the country bearing serums and trained personnel to meet epidemics or other emergencies, according to a consular report to the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

"Why is his chariot so long in coming?" said the mother of Sisera, looking anxiously through the lattice, awaiting his return from the Battle of Megiddo. Her "wise ladies" answered, but she herself knew and "returned the answer to herself":

Miss Marjorie Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of this place, was married to William Drought Cox, son of Mrs. William D. Cox of New York and the late Mr. Cox, this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Andrew Flynn of this city, was married to Martin Warren Davenport this morning in the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Clarence A. Heavey of St. Bernard's Church performed the ceremony.

Nearly five years ago General Hugh S. Johnson, newly appointed NRA Administrator, stood before an improvised blackboard in the Commerce Department and with the aid of a few chalk marks tried to explain to a group of incredulous newspaper men the Administration's program for industry.

A YOUNG, aspiring lawyer who had just returned from the World War to his home in Fort Wayne, Ind., was mentioned as a possible candidate for Congress. He journeyed to Indianapolis to ask the advice of a friend who was one of the leaders of the bar of the State.

Seniors at Brown University are to take special "comprehensive inventory" tests, designed to show each student just what he has retained from his four years on the campus and to point out what intellectual resources each senior has when he faces the world outside college gates.

Colonel and Mrs. David Walker Wear of the Hotel Astor and Binghamton, N. Y., have dent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Hotchkiss Wear, to John Sutherland Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Keene Mitchell of Wilkes-Barre,

After being questioned for nearly twenty-four hours, two men held as suspects in the hold-up of a "poker flat" in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Saturday afternoon, were booked at 3 P. M. yesterday on charges of assault and robbery to await action by the grand jury.
Senator Wheeler of Montana revealed today that he had written President Roosevelt requesting a pardon for Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension campaigner.

Sir Cedric Hardwicke, noted English actor, will succeed Sir Barry Jackson as director of the Malvern Summer Festivals in England, from which he recently said he planned to retire, it was announced last night at a dinner of the Drama League of New York, at which Sir Cedric was a guest of honor.

Canada tonight won the world amateur hockey championship by defeating a strong British team, 3-1, in the final match. 'Czechoslovakia defeated Germany, 3-0, to take third place in the tournament, behind the two Empire teams. Germany was fourth,

Ben Harrison established a record today in the Winter sailing regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club by capsizing in his Class B one-design craft Blubber. He had turned over once before in each of the other dinghy classes-the old Al, X and D.

The fate of Teruel hung tonight on a fierce battle raging on its outskirts, where Spanish Government defenders fought desperately against advancing Insurgent troops attempting to recapture the city that they lost two months ago.

The Richard Trading Corporation, 637 Broadway, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to cease representing that its leather saddle soap conforms to United States Government specifications, since no general specifications for saddle soap are prescribed by the government, the commission announced yesterday.

Striking electricians and maintenance men at Rockefeller Center rejected yesterday a proposal from the management and voted to continue picketing until the demands of Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union for recognition and wage increases are granted.

The loan issued this week by the French Treasury was intended primarily to consolidate the Treasury's three-year bonds issued in 1935, which are to mature on March 10, next, as well as the one-year Treasury bonds isued in August, 1937.

The settlement of fifty strikes involving more than 20,000 workers, and the averting of 300 threatened strikes were among the achievements of the State Labor Relations Board during the first six months of its existence, it is declared in a report submitted yesterday to Governor Lehman by the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the board.

The American Foundation for the Blind announced yesterday that William Nelson Cromwell, attorney, had been chosen as the first recipient of the group's annual gold medal for outstanding services to the blind. The medal is being given by M. C. Migel, president of the foundation.

Dr. Norman Bethune, a Canadian doctor; Charles Parsons, an American, and Miss Jean Ewen, a Canadian, who came to China recently for war medical work financed by Canadian and American peace organizations, have left here for Yenan, administrative headquarters of the former Soviet districts.

Edward F. McGrady, former Assistant Secretary of Labor, will step back into the labor-picture tomorrow as final arbiter in a dispute between the American Federation of Hosiery Workers and the Apex Hosiery Mill.
J. H. Holmes Jr. and W. B. Adsit, Ardsley entrants, recorded firstround victories in the Westchester Class A squash racquets singles championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

A capacity gathering watched Joe Louis go through his training paces at Dr. Bier's gymnasium today, for his fight with Nathan Mann. The onlookers, among whom were Major General John J. Phelan, Harry Thomas and Ralph Metcalfe, were impressed by the heavyweight champion's sharpness and hitting power.
Stocks irregularly higher in quiet trading; turnover, 3,317,940 shares. All groups of bonds irregular, with trading dull; transactions, $33,609,400.

Any weakening of the American wool growing or wool manufacturing industries through international trade agreements that increase imports of wool products is a "serious threat to our national security," Julius Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, of Passaic, N. J., declares in a brief to be filed tomorrow with the Committee on Reciprocity Information of the Tariff Commission.

The twenty-two members of the Brewers' Board of Trade will officially announce the opening of the Bock Beer season on March 14 with extensive advertising campaigns on an individual basis, according to the board.

While inventories "generally are still a little I gher than may be desirable, in many lines they have been reduced to normal stocks," Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declares in his monthly business review issued today.

The prospect of a "free-for-all" Democratic primary in Pennsylvania increased today as John L. Lewis refused to recede from his demand that Lieutenant Governor Thomas Kennedy be endorsed for a major place on the ticket.

The world has changed its accent are from the good, to the useful and from the eternal to the temporal, declared the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer in his sermon yesterday morning at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.
Members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important legislation last week as follows:
The spiritual annexation of Austria by Germany, proclaimed in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's blunt speech, concerns Italy more vitally than any outside country.

Prison terms of fifty to seventyfive years face Henry Lorenz, 22, and Harry Dwyer, 27, who pleaded guilty to second-degree murder of W. L. Smith of El Paso, Texas, a switchman, in their attempted "Wild West" train robbery near Hachita, N. M., on Thanksgiving Day.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse S. Phillips of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Phillips, to John H. Galloway Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Galloway, also of Bronxville.
Mrs. Eugene Livingston Delafield of 995 Madison Avenue and Riverdale-on-Hudson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margarett Woodhull Delafield, to William Vincent Gellately Barrett.
Adolf Hitler's speech to the German Reichstag was received today with disfavor in official circles of Czechoslovakia, which contains about 3,000,000 Germans within her borders.

The largest crowd to attend the 1938 National Sportsmen's Show thus far passed through the portals of Grand Central Palace yesterday. Many visitors from out of town, unable to view the show during the week, took advantage of the holiday to journey to the show.
Frank W. Regan won the medal today in the eighth annual mid-winter golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club played on the No. 1 golf course at the Belleview Biltmore.

The extent to which the recession has hit industrial and agricultural districts up-State was indicated yesterday in a disclosure that homerelief rolls in the State, outside of New York City, had increased by 76 per cent since last August. In the same period the rolls here rose only 12-per cent.

New York City, which has solved its own problem of the older municipal worker by retaining him on his job, should not be expected to permit its payrolls to be "converted into a house of refuge for those whom private industry has mistreated in middle age," Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, said yesterday.

The reaffirming of current steel prices for the second quarter has removed one cause of uncertainty from the situation, according to the magazine Steel, which says that "in recent weeks it has been apparent that some consumers have held back buying as far as possible until the announcement had been made.

John Osborne Sumner, historian and retired Professor of History at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died today at his home, 409 Marlboro Street, at the age of 74. He was a full professor at M. I. T. from 1907 to 1933 in the field of history of civilization and art.

Industrially, things were again last week pretty much at a standstill. For the third successive week, steel production remained at 31 per cent of capacity, the only new development being the trade's announced decision not to reduce prices for other products than the one on which they had been already lowered. On the whole,

An important step to show the effect of lower electric rates on the revenues of utility companies, which may offer strong support for the administration's thesis that utilities benefit from the increased use of electricity resulting from reduced charges, has been taken by the Federal Power Commission.

" The Farm Woman," who writes editorially for William Allen White's Emporia Gazette, tells of the "urge" (such as made Chaucer's folk long to go on pilgrimages) impelling Kansas farm men and women to make the annual pilgrimage to Manhattan (Kansas), the seats of the State Agricultural College, and exchange their reminiscences and experiences.

The projected $19,000,000 low-cost housing development in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn will be composed of six-story buildings of steel and masonry construction, equipped with automatic elevators, it was disclosed yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

The partition of Ireland was denounced as an "international crime foreign to the American idea of democracy" at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Chatham Hotel of Irish-American organizations, which pledged their support to the people of Ireland in their efforts to restore their country to its original integrity.
The Vinson Naval Bill was critioized today by Norman Thomas, who spoke at Rutgers University's chapel service.
A second-round play-off match in the New York Amateur Hockey League championship between the Brooklyn Bruins and the Columbia Lions resulted in a 1-1 deadlock yesterday at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

The generation now past 30 years of age was identified as "the hope for freedom in the world" in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. C. Everett Wagner, pastor of the Union R Methodist Episcopal Church, Fortyeighth Street, west of Broadway.

Maurice Podoloff, president of the Eastern Division of the International-American Hockey League, announced after a meeting of the circuit officials today that Hershey, Pa., would be represented by a professional team in this league next season.

A gorgeous work, unjustly neglected, was performed by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall: Rimsky - Korsakoff's symphonic suite. "Antar."

William Alves Boys, former Conservative Whip in the House of Commons, died today in Augusta, Ga., according to word received here. Mr. Boys, who represented Simcoe South and Simcoe North in Canada's Parliament from 1912 to 1930, was 69.
HEARKEN UNTO THE VOICE, by Franz Werfel. (Viking, $3.) A novel by the author of "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh."
There were 2,229 airports and landing fields in the United States on Jan. 1, 1938, the Bureau of Air Commerce has reported. Of this total, 720 were partly or fully lighted for night use.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Patricia Wallace, niece of Mrs. Nathaniel Francis of this city, to Robert H. Hillis, son of Mrs. Lucy Hillis of South Pasadena, Calif., which took place in Norwalk, Conn., on Jan. 31.
Miss Blanche Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris A. Harris of this place, was married this afternoon to Irving Streit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Streit, also of Passaic.

In Spanish Government circles the negotiations now under way in London for the withdrawal of Italians fighting for the Rebels are regarded with the greatest suspicion. Julio Alvarez del Vayo, the Government's representative at Geneva and until recently Foreign Minister, characterizes the negotiations as "a dangerous manoeuvre on the part of Italy to further her mischievous designs in Spain."

A letter from President Roosevelt, congratulating the rector and the congregation, was made public yesterday in connection with the forthcoming celebration of the 100th anniversary of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, 344 Twentieth Street.

Mrs. Hollis T. Gleason of Cohasset, Mass., president of the Smith College Alumnae Association; Anne Coburn of Philadelphia, a director of the association, and Mira Wilson, principal of Northfield Seminary, were chosen as alumnae trustee nominees at the closing session of the Smith Alumnae Council this morning.

A college-club basketball doubleheader will be held at the Fordham University gymnasium tonight under the auspices of the North American Martyrs Shrine Committee as a "Sportsmen's Tribute" to the Rev. Isaac Jogues. Father Jogues, one of America's pioneer missionaries and explorers, was slain by Indians in the seventeenth century.
Returning to the pulpit for the first time since he was taken ill last Dec. 26, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street,

The third fire since June, 1936, in adjoining three-story buildings at 761-63 East 165th Street, between Forest and Tinton Avenues, the Bronx, killed three persons early yesterday morning and caused injuries to nine others, including an infant orphaned by the blaze.

A bomb exploded early today on the doorstep of the Liedertafel Saengerbund Hall, scene of many pro-Nazi gatherings, in North Philadelphia. The neighborhood was aroused and windows were broken in a squareblock area, but the building was damaged only slightly.

The drama of Anthony Eden's departure from the Foreign Office today was played out before hundreds of plain men and women, who had stood hour after hour in the tiny lane that is Downing Street, waiting for what all felt somehow was inevitable.

The New York Rovers battled to a 3-all deadlock with the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in a bruising Eastern Hockey League game, the feature of an amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Paris Bourse received with great sangfroid the news of the changes in the Austrian Government to place it directly under the domination of Germany, although it realized that this event can have grave consequences for the future of Europe and the maintenance of peace, because the move cannot but encourage the Reich to formulate fresh claims, either concerning colonies or other Central European countries.

Under instructions from President Roosevelt, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has announced that it is prepared to resume its lending activities and to extend credit to "all deserving borrowers."

Prominent representatives of public life and the judiciary, among them Governor Herbert H. Lehman and his brother, Supreme Court Justice Irving Lehman, were among the 350 persons who attended funeral services for Harry L. Glucksman, for nineteen years executive director of the Jewish Welfare Board, yesterday morning at the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

Wholesale prices in France have turned weaker. For the week which ended on Feb. 12 the index number was 607, compared with 610 and 612 for the two previous weeks. The decline is particularly noticeable in imported products, and native products also were off.

A two weeks' observance or the 150th anniversary of the American Constitution by Masonic organizations was brought to a close yesterday afternoon at a service attended by 1,500 Masons and their wives in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

That Brazil's removal of her limitation on the export of coffee caused the suspension of service on foreign loans by El Salvador is indicated in an address by President Maximillano Martinez to the present Congress.

IT'S the notion in this corner that the textbooks offered in many foreign language courses in even our best universities are not attractive or enticing to the students. The professors could do better. If they offered textbooks in sports editions the students probably would learn faster and also have more fun.

As the shadow of totalitarianism lengthens over Japan, conservative Japanese industrialists and financiers must be asking themselves whether the price of military conquest is not excessive. This question,

Special ferry service between the Christopher Street and Hoboken terminals of the D. L. W. Railroad for trucks bearing inflammables, explosives and other dangerous articles now barred from passenger-carrying ferries is expected to start about- March 1, it was announced yesterday.

Tribute was paid to the democratic principles of Roger Williams, founder of Rhode Island in 1636, by Oswald Ryan, general counsel of the Federal Power Commission, in an address this afternoon in Statuary Hall at the Capitol.

Drivers of Flint Trolley Coach, Inc., the main means of transportation in this city of 165,000 population, struck at 1 o'clock this morning in behalf of demands of the C. I. O. Transport Workers Union for a restoration of a wage cut.

Western hospitals today took their first concerted step toward providing care for expectant fathers. The Western Hospital Association allotted time for discussion of the subject during its convention here next week and opened its exhibit space to articles designed to help the worrying male through hours of anxiety.

The marriage of Robert Nietzel Buck, airline co-pilot, and Miss Jean Pearsall, daughter of Mrs. Ferris Randolph Pearsall of Westfield and the late Mr. Pearsall, will take place at the First Methodist Episcopal Church here tomorrow evening.
Charles Mathisen of Norway won the 1,500 and 3,000-meter speedskating races today in the international competition. Mathisen was timed in 2:22.5 for the 1,500 and 5:02.1 for the 3,000-meter event.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. joined yesterday the opposition to abolition of special or blue ribbon trial juries. In a letter written to Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux, chairman of the Assembly Committee on Judiciary, Mr. Bennett expressed the hope the committee would not report favorably on bills to end selected panels.
Japanese officials today expressed profound appreciation of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech, which, they felt, greatly strengthens Japan's international position.
Howard L. Barlow, fingerprint expert and retired police inspector, died tonight of heart disease at the age of 47. He was a native of Holyoke, Mass.
Representatives of thirty-nine artists' and allied organizations adopted a resolution yesterday afternoon favoring the establishment of a Federal bureau of fine art,
Throughout Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech Vienna's streets were like those or a dead city.
About 1,000 men, a third of the working force, have been laid off in the last few days at the Ford Motor Company's export assembly plant here, it was reported today by Nell Brown, the superintendent.

In a superlative demonstration of team play the combination of Neil J. Sullivan and Roy R. Coffin of Philadelphia scored a straight-game victory over David McMullen and W. M. Large, also of Philadelphia, in the final squash racquets match yesterday at the University Club, where the ninth annual invitation doubles tournament for the Lockett Trophy was completed.
Steel-trade publications in Germany believe that the new agreement with producers in the United States increases the prospect that the international cartel may be prolonged.
German industry, viewed broadly, is active. The January foreign trade report, although seasonably adjusted, must be considered unsatisfactory.

Still dressed for their wedding, which took place in New York last night, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Porter of 1,215 Olmstead Avenue, the Bronx, spent the early hours today at police headquarters after their automobile had struck a man at Broad Street and Branford Place here.

The Maryland Realty Company bought from Donbert Estates, Inc., J. P. Finneran, president, the fivestory altered apartment house at 347 East Fifty-eighth Street. The property was sold for cash over a mortgage of $15,000 through William A. White Sons, brokers.
CASEY JONES, a play in three acts and ten scenes, by Robert Ardrey. Staged by Elia Kazan: settings by Mordecal Gorelik: produced by the Group Theatre. At the Fulton Theatre.

The Manhattan C. C. strengthened its lead in the annual championship competition of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday when its team of sixteen defeated the West Side Y. M. C. A. at the Hotel Alamac by 10 to 6.

The Franklin Square National Bank, Franklin Square, L. I., has arranged with a life insurance company a mortgage of $80,000 on the southwest corner of Stewart and Franklin Avenues, Garden City, for Stephen Proper??es, Inc.

Dr. Frederic Warren Smith, a laryngologist and teacher, died at Hahnemann Hospital today after an operation. His age was 56. He was Professor of Laryngology at Hahnemann Medical College and was consultant laryngologist for a number of hospitals in this area.

Reino Luoma, young Chicago pianist of Finnish descent, made his local debut in a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His firstoffering was the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, which was followed by Bach's partita in C minor.

Bill Shannon, Troy (N. Y.) speedster and Dick Werner of Haledon, N. J., today streaked to the lead in the opening of the Adirondack speed skating championships. Shannon annexed the 220-yard final, while Werner, who represents the New York Curb Exchange, sped to victory in the mile.
A large audience of Greenwich society folk attended the concert in the Greenwich Library series in the library art gallery this afternoon.
John L. Lewis won't break bread with William Green at the Labor Department's twenty-fifth anniversary dinner March 3.

Banking reports on the state of home trade make light of signs of a recession. Certainly there has been some setback since Fall, but it is moderate and partial, several important industries maintaining their previous activity. In January,

European politics again is looming large in the City's vision, causing hesitation and depression, from which, however, the markets now are inclined to shake themselves free in the belief that, after all, the Austro-German situation may develop along less threatening lines than appeared likely at first sight.

Jennie R. Suydam assigned to Michael Fedorko a mortgage for $13,500 given to her on June 1, 1929, covering 639 6th St. The New York Savings Bank sold to Lillian Schauben the southeast corner of St. Nicholas Ave. and 113th St, for $40,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for S34.000.

For the third successive week, cotton prices rose last week, thus continuing the moderate advance which had been under way since last October. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active future deliveries registered net advances of 27 to 29 points.
The house in which Theodore Roosevelt was inaugurated as President of the United States is being made into a restaurant here.

C. T. W. Worrell, the acting Solicitor General of Trinidad, and thirteen other persons were taken to a hospital, critically injured, today after a head-on collision between Mr. Worrell's automobile and a bus.
Charles Evans Hughes, who has presided over the Supreme Court during one of the most turbulent periods in its history, will observe next Thursday his eighth anniversary as Chief Justice.

Orders booked by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in 1937 amounted to $229,540,061, compared with $182,521,304 in 1936, a gain of 25 per cent, and. the best for any year except 1929, when bookings were $240,220.555.

This city was gayly beflagged today with Austrian and some swastika banners as local newspapers urged the inhabitants to beflag their houses in honor of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech and to do the same Thursday when Chancellor Kurt von Schuschnigg delivered his answer.

Legislation for forced consolidations of railroads is being considered seriously in at least three of the government offices now preparing plans to be laid before President Roosevelt at his rail conference scheduled for the coming week.

A serious attempt to meet the exactions of a comprehensive program of works ranging from the classic to the modernistic was made at Town Hall last night by James Sykes, a New York pianist now active in Denver and Colorado Springs, Col. Mr. Sykes was more successful with the latter-day selections scheduled than with such compositions as Mozart's sonata in A minor or Schumann's "Faschingsschwank," the most important of his contributions.

Packages of clothing suitable for resale later at Thrift House in East Fifty-seventh Street have been requested in lieu of the usual admission fee at -the annual Thrift House dance to be held the night of May 3 at the Commodore.

Washington's Birthday will be observed at the Surf Club with a fashion show and water-sports program. Mr. and Mrs. John Humphrey Crawford of Orange, N. J., entertained Mr. and Mrs. William Y. Dear of Montclair, N. J.;

The police broadcast last night an eight-State alarm for Thomas Minichiello, 29-year-old former prize fighter, who escaped recently while being transferred from Kings County Hospital to the Brooklyn State Hospital for the Insane.
Appointment of Dr. Edwin Sharp Burdell, Dean of Humanities at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as director of Cooper Union was announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the Union.

A Spring fashion show and luncheon will be held on March 22 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop. Each guest has been requested to bring a bundle of used articles suitable for resale later at the shop.
Those who ask "What is the matter with the Christian churches today?" were invited to listen to an answer yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany, has been asked to call a meeting of its executive committee to select an advisory committee to make suggestions for the rehabilitation of the organization for the coming State campaign, it was learned yesterday.

With a wintry gale still holding the hardiest of health addicts indoors most of the day, and not even Colonel Bill Terry on the premises to provide food for comment, affairs in the local baseball colony appeared enveloped in a vast silence today when in from the West swept Harry Danning, slated to be the Giants' first-string catcher this year.

Having conferred with several officials, trustees and leaders of Indiana University here today and yesterday, Paul V. McNutt, United States Commissioner to the Philippines, will go to Bloomington tomorrow to visit the university.
Imports of gold in January were [pound]12,728,252 and exports [Pound]7,279,047.

John S. Martin of New York will receive the trophy of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association for the "outstanding angling exploit of 1937" at the dinner of the association Wednesday night in the Hotel Commodore.

The world can be brought into order by our making a deliberate choice of fundamental principles, particularly in Germany, declared the Rev. Dr. Albert Dieffenbach, religious editor of The Boston Evening Transcript, in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Little Harry Cooper rolled along in front of the Crescent City open golf tournament today, but a sunscorched baseball player who used to understudy for Babe Ruth had the gallery stampeding at his heels.

The Hygrade Food Products Company leased from Albert Vischia the two-story building at 51-3 Central Avenue, Passaic, N. J., through Leo Flaster, broker. It is altering the property for the sale and distribution of meat products.

Mrs. Joseph Miele of this place gave a tea this afternoon at the Crestmont Golf Club, West Orange, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Theresa Ciluzzi, to Dr. James H. De Girolamo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. De Girolamo of West Orange.
The Old Westbury polo team defeated a stubborn Southern California four today, 8 to 7, at the Midwick Country Club. It was the first of a threegame series and attracted 5,000 fans.
A dictatorial Constitution was given to Rumania tonight by a proclamation signed by King Carol. It was not countersigned by any of his Ministers.
Of Hitler's long-advertised address yesterday to the German Reichstag it must be said that while it made no open threats it brought no real assurances.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 82.4, which compares with 82.4 a week ago, 82.6 two weeks ago, 83.1 three weeks ago and 83.4 four weeks ago.

Gilbert Julien, sports editor of the Ottawa French-language newspaper Le Droit for a quarter century and a university professor since 1916, collapsed on the street early today and died soon after of heart disease. He was 45 years old.

Chinese troops slowly gave ground along the Peiping-Hankow Railway north of Chengchof yesterday. The Japanese late in the day were reported to have occupied Kangchung, only forty-five miles north of Chengchow and twenty miles from the Yellow River.

Mr. and Mrs. Claiborne Randolph Watkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roddy Watkins, to George Gilmer Minor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Minor. Miss Watkins attended St. Timothy's School in Catonsville,
Mayor La Guardia may be, as he said in his talk before the City Affairs Committee on Saturday, a "timid person." He may be, as he also said, a "quiet, calm person." If so,

One hundred prominent citizens, among them three members of Congress, literary men, educators and economists, have joined the Nonpartisan Committee for the Defense of Fred E. Beal, it was announced yesterday by Hugo Pollock, secretary of the committee.

Zinka Milanov, soprano; Bruna Castagna, contralto; Charles Kullman, tenor, and Ezio Pinza, basso, all members of the Metropolitan Opera, will be the soloists in the Verdi "Requiem" which Arturo Toscanini will direct at Carnegie Hall on March 4, it was announced yesterday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Delegates to a new labor union which is opposed to the C. I. 0. and A. F. of L. ended a national convention late today by adopting a constitution and issuing charters to thirty-eight independent unions.

Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, in a speech today before C. I. O. unionists, told what he said was the inside story of recent successful contract negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation in which "S. W. O. C. rejected a yardstick formula for computing wages which had the blessing of the Federal Administration."
